feedback: From the perspective of an EU citizen as well as an open-source developer and maintainer for the last 23 years, I highly appreciate this call for evidence. It shows both appreciation of the work and dedication of open-source developers as well as the willingness to listen to and support open-source developers. Answering the questions from the call for evidence, I wish to refer to the attached document.

feedback: I have over 20 years of involvement in Open Source, contributing significant time and effort to widely used projects and well-known organizations. One thing that will not help in its current form is the Cyber Resilience Act. As so often with EU initiatives: good intentions, poor legislation. A better starting point would be to formally recognize Open Source contributions as tax-free voluntary service. Regulation should put consumers -not companies- first (PSD2 is a clear example of a good idea with a flawed implementation that disproportionately harms OSS). Finally, companies must not be allowed to restrict hardware in ways that prevent users from running Open Source Software.

Madame, Monsieur, Je vous transmets ma contribution dans le cadre de la consultation sur la souveraineté numérique européenne. Le message central est simple : il est urgent de passer dun constat (dépendance) à une stratégie dinvestissement et dexécution, structurée et ambitieuse. Aujourdhui, on voit enfin des décideurs prendre conscience quil faut réduire une dépendance devenue systémique à certains acteurs non-européens (notamment dans les suites bureautiques, lidentité, la collaboration et le cloud). Cest une prise de conscience nécessaire, mais elle ne suffit pas : si lon se contente de corriger lexistant, on traite surtout un terrain déjà verrouillé depuis des décennies. À mon sens, la priorité est déviter de reproduire exactement le même scénario sur la prochaine dépendance majeure : lintelligence artificielle. En Belgique, par exemple, il est préoccupant de voir des administrations sorienter très rapidement vers des solutions packagées (ex. assistants IA intégrés à des suites existantes) principalement pour des raisons de contrats globaux et de coûts apparents, sans une analyse suffisamment exigeante sur : la localisation et la maîtrise des données (sensibles ou non), la traçabilité, lauditabilité et la gouvernance des modèles, la réversibilité (risque denfermement technologique), la performance réelle et ladéquation aux besoins, la dépendance long terme à un écosystème unique. Si lEurope ne se donne pas les moyens maintenant, lIA deviendra la prochaine couche de subordination numérique : non plus seulement sur les outils, mais sur la connaissance, lautomatisation, la productivité et, demain, des pans entiers de la décision. Je recommande donc une stratégie offensive et concrète, articulée autour de quatre axes. Créer une capacité européenne de calcul et dhébergement à léchelle Investir massivement dans des capacités de calcul (GPU/accélérateurs), data centers, interconnexions et énergie, avec une vision de souveraineté (capacité disponible, résilience, coûts maîtrisés). Développer des offres cloud/IA européennes compétitives et réellement adoptables, pour le public comme pour le privé, avec des garanties fortes sur les données et la gouvernance. Financer et industrialiser des modèles et solutions IA européens Accélérer le soutien aux acteurs européens capables doffrir une alternative crédible aux géants américains (ex. Mistral et autres), non pas uniquement via des subventions, mais via des programmes dindustrialisation, de mise à léchelle et de commandes structurantes. Favoriser des solutions ouvertes et interopérables (standards, APIs, portabilité), pour éviter un verrouillage rapide du marché par intégration suite et effets de réseau. Utiliser la commande publique comme levier stratégique Introduire des critères obligatoires dans les marchés publics : hébergement UE quand pertinent, contrôle des données, exigences daudit, clauses de réversibilité, transparence sur la chaîne de sous-traitance, garanties contractuelles sur lusage des données. Mettre en place des cadres de référence communs et simples à appliquer, afin déviter que chaque administration refasse seule lanalyse des risques, avec des conclusions hétérogènes. Ne pas limiter la souveraineté au logiciel : réindustrialisation matériel et chaîne de valeur La souveraineté numérique est indissociable du matériel. LEurope dispose datouts majeurs (savoir-faire, R&D, champions industriels comme ASML), mais reste vulnérable si elle ne maîtrise pas davantage la production et la capacité industrielle sur son sol. Il faut une politique industrielle assumée, avec des investissements importants et une vision long terme, pour consolider la chaîne de valeur (semi-conducteurs, packaging, infrastructures, équipements critiques). Lobjectif est clair : réduire la dépendance stratég

feedback: I am glad to see the EU is formulating a strategy for an open digital ecosystem. I wholeheartedly agree with the critical nature of such a strategy for the EU technological sovereignty, security and competitiveness, especially considering all the current geopolitical events. In my opinion, it's important that digital services like web search, the cloud and AI are considered public infrastructure just like roads. And while I think the most important aspect is that the EU invests in developing their own infrastructure to reduce dependence on big tech and foreign nations and that this could also technically be accomplished with closed source software, I still strongly believe that open source would be the best choice and best fit for European values. In an open democracy there should be no reason to keep the source code closed, especially for such critical software as that used in digital infrastructure. Moreover, the choice for open source would allow the infrastructure to be built on top of already existing robust open source projects so that we don't have to "reinvent the wheel" for everything. This also means that people outside the EU could benefit from any investments made in open source projects, something which has also been very beneficial in the Open Science movement, for which open source research software is essential (in my work as a researcher I am user and co-developer of open source research software projects). Likewise we can also benefit from further contributions from outside the EU to the open source projects.

This contribution highlights how open source, evidence-based digital infrastructures can strengthen public-interest AI systems, particularly in regulated and civic contexts. Open source governance layers are critical for auditability and institutional trust. Evidence traceability and provenance should be first-class design requirements. Modular, replaceable AI components reduce vendor lock-in and systemic risk. Education and curriculum-based open-source systems deserve explicit recognition alongside industrial use cases. The Commission should explicitly support open, inspectable architectures that separate decision authority, evidence, and execution. Further technical detail and a worked architectural example are provided in the attached document.

Je témoigne en tant que citoyenne européenne, actuellement enseignante-chercheuse et contributrice dans le libre, et précédemment employée dans le privé après un passage dans une administration publique. Voici mes constats de ces différents points de vues. Concernant les déploiement de solutions libres en administration et entreprise : - Des solutions collaboratives libres (messagerie Partage Zimbra, visioconférence Jitsi, etc) ont été déployées avec succès sur le réseau public national (Renater), à profit des établissements d'enseignement et de recherche français. - Il en est de même à l'échelle locale de mon Université, avec l'intégration du partage de fichier NextCloud et de la plateforme d'enseignement Moodle, sur des serveurs locaux. L'adaptabilité propre au libre de cette dernière est activement exploitée par les équipes enseignantes par le développement de modules intéractifs spécifiques. - Ces solutions co-existent avec des logiciels propriétaires en doublon (Citadel Team au CNRS, Zoom au CNRS et à l'Université). Les solutions libres ont la préférence des collaborateurs, quand ils en ont connaissance. - Dans une autre administration publique française, j'ai pu assister à des échecs répétés d'intégration de logiciels propriétaires et de logiciels libres (pour une messagerie, un intranet Drupal, et un réseau social d'entreprise), menés par des prestataires de consulting et d'intégration par marché public. J'ai pu observé leur manque évident de compréhension des besoins, de compétence décisionnelle et technique de ces prestataires externes, en opposition aux équipes internes dans le milieu académique. - Dans le public et dans le privé, je constate que les appels d'offres sont quasi systématiquement remportés par des sociétés de consulting et d'intégration n'ayant pas de rapport avec les développeurs des solutions libres qu'elles déploient, au détriment de ces derniers. - Il en est de même avec des hébergeurs cloud (PaaS et SaaS), qui tendent à exploiter des solutions libres en les revendant comme services, souvent avec l'ajout de verrouillage technologique (par exemple, Citadel Team est basé sur le protocol ouvert Matrix, mais sans fédération ouverte). - Les logiciels propriétaires ont tendance à dépendre des uns des autres. Par exemple, l'utilisation de SAP pour la gestion administrative force les collaborateurs empêche la migration de système d'exploitation de Windows vers Linux pour les agents. Concernant l'utilisation personnelle de logiciels libres : - La vente liée de logiciel et de matériel subsiste et s'aggrave : il est devient de plus en plus difficile, voire impossible, d'installer un système d'exploitation libre sur des smartphones et tablettes, à cause de la présence de verrous technologiques. - À cela s'ajoute maintenant la dépendance obligatioires à des services liés aux logiciels présents : des comptes Apple, Google, Microsoft sont obligatoires pour utiliser de appareils Apple, téléphones Android, ou ordinateur équipés de Windows. - Les applications tierces, parfois publiques, participent aussi à ce verrouillage : l'application France Identité refuse de fonctionner si elle n'est pas téléchargée depuis le Google Play Store, demandant ainsi un compte Google, même sur un téléphone GrapheneOS. Il en est de même avec les applications bancaires, qui utilisent Google Play Integrity ou Google Wallet, et qui sont essentielles depuis la mise en place de la Directive européenne sur des services de paiement 2. D'autres applications, telles que pour les transports publics, dépendent aussi d'APIs et de services propriétaires tels que Google Maps. En tant que développeuse : - Je déplore la dépendance de projets libres principalement européens (NixOS) aux ressources offertes par des plateformes américaines (Github, CDNs). Forge publique équiv

feedback:
Il software è libero (o "open source") se qualunque utente è libero di utilizzarlo, modificarlo e distribuirne copie. Ciò presuppone la disponibilità del codice sorgente sotto una licenza libera. l'Unione Europea ospita alcuni dei principali progetti di software libero, tra i quali Blender, Godot, KDE, Krita, VLC, Parrot OS, Mastodon, LibreOffice e Codeberg. L'uso di software "proprietario" (non libero) pone restrizioni tecniche e legali alle attività dell'utente, che si tratti di un individuo, di un'organizzazione o di una pubblica amministrazione. Le pubbliche amministrazioni dovrebbero agire in base alla legge, non alle condizioni d'uso di programmi informatici, e non dipendere da servizi remoti privati o formati file proprietari. I cittadini dovrebbero poter esercitare i loro diritti, inclusa l'istruzione, senza accettare i vincoli di software proprietari. Risposte: 1. Il principale punto di forza del settore del software libero dell'UE è la presenza di una comunità di progetti di grande rilievo e di volontari disposti a contribuire. La principale debolezza è la mancanza di determinazione da parte del settore pubblico nel sostituire il software proprietario impiegato con software libero. I principali ostacoli sono i rischi legali causati da leggi scritte con, in mente, principalmente "l'industria" e non le comunità di sviluppatori indipendenti. 2. Il software libero è economico (quasi sempre gratuito), flessibile, trasparente, più sicuro, utile alla cooperazione, migliore per la privacy (dà più controllo all'utente), più affidabile, più versatile e più adatto all'interoperabilità. Mentre molti programmi proprietari richiedono di connettersi a servizi privati, programmi liberi come Blender e Godot sono offline di default (se non lo fossero potrebbero essere modificati), riducendo la superficie d'attacco e migliorando privacy e sicurezza. Prezzo e funzionalità dei programmi proprietari, molti dei quali su abbonamento, possono cambiare. Possono anche cessare di essere disponibili (Adobe Animate), di funzionare correttamente (si veda la campagna "Stop Killing Games") o cambiare licenza (l'edizione Community di Visual Studio sostituisce la Express, ma ha clausole più restrittive). Con software liberi si può continuare ad usare versioni vecchie oppure i "fork" (versioni modificate indipendenti). Potendo essere usato e studiato da chiunque, il software libero consente di ricevere supporto e assistenza da qualunque azienda o professionista, agevolando una maggiore e libera competizione. 3. L'UE dovrebbe ascoltare le organizzazioni di software libero e per i diritti digitali (come EDRi) prima di approvare leggi nel campo digitale. Nel settore pubblico è fondamentale per la sovranità, la sicurezza e l'innovazione che il software libero sostituisca quello proprietario. Le autorità dovrebbero fornire indicazioni su come fornire servizi web (come Mastodon) o decentralizzati (come Tor e Nostr) nel rispetto della legge, cooperando con la comunità. 4. I settori dell'hardware, dei firmware e dell'istruzione dovrebbero essere considerati prioritari. Il settore dell'hardware e dei firmware perché molto trascurato. La computazione, su CPU e su GPU, obbliga quasi sempre all'uso di hardware, firmware e driver proprietari, rendendo l'intero sistema dipendente da essi. Perfino Debian ora accetta firmware proprietari, perché necessari. Il settore dell'istruzione perché di grande utilità per gli studenti e per le sue ripercussioni sugli altri settori. Le software house donano licenze a scuole e università per abituare gli studenti all'uso dei loro programmi, perché anche le aziende che li assumono si trovino a doverli usare. L'uso di software libero nelle scuole risolve questo problema. 5. Un maggiore ricorso al software libero porterebbe ad un aumento della competitività e della ciberresilienza in praticamente tutti i settori eccet

The Innovation Council public health e.V. (Innovationsverbund Öffentliche Gesundheit e.V. - InÖG) is an independent charitable German NGO, advocating for public digital infrastructures and gov-tech solutions that empower the communities they are built to serve. In the fall of 2020 the InÖG emerged out of several winning teams of the #wirvsvirus hackathon of the German government. Supported by the Björn Steiger Stiftung, the team coordinated the development of IRIS-Connect, a modular open source, security & privacy by design platform. It connected 70 contact tracing apps with the enlisted health centers in North Rhine-Westphalia, Hesse, Saxony and Thuringia serving 30 million citizens for a year. Its members serve in various international (IETF, ENISA, etc.) and German expert groups, are invited to parliamentary hearings, e.g. the Bundestag, and are speakers at various conferences. 1. What are the strengths and weaknesses of the EU open-source sector? A strength of the EU open-source sector is that it is highly innovative and deeply integrated into academia. Its biggest weakness is the absence of EU open-source institutions, due to neglect of policymakers in the EU. In our own experience we could not form a charitable entity that is legally binding beholden to serving the public interest in the field of civic-tech but had to narrow the scope to the public health space, the maintenance of fundamental general-purpose technologies, e.g. privacy-preserving technologies was not legally possible. What are the main barriers that hamper (i) adoption and maintenance of high-quality and secure open-source; and Whilst open source software projects make their code freely available, most of their governing bodies lack accountability, reliability, sustainability and transparency towards those not actively involved. Thus organisations that want to use FOSS software not only have to build expertise to use open source software but also to ramp up staff to engage with the projects. (ii) sustainable contributions to open-source communities? Most open source projects are either governed by 501 (c) 3s in the US or private entities or consortia thereof (e.g. 501 (c) 6s). Thus establishing other forms of contributions outside of code like engagement in the project or collaboration agreements suffer from severe friction due to different legal systems and recent geopolitical developments. 2. What is the added value of open source for the public and private sectors? Please provide concrete examples, including the factors (such as cost, risk, lock-in, security, innovation, among others) that are most important to assess the added value. Modern democracies are accountable as laws and administrative instructions are either public or can be accessed by freedom of information requests. This is not the case for the used software, with advancing digitization of the public administration additional transparency is needed as well-documented in the toeslagenaffaire. 3. What concrete measures and actions may be taken at EU level to support the development and growth of the EU open-source sector and contribute to the EUs technological sovereignty and cybersecurity agenda? Create a legal landscape that allows the formation of organisations that maintain open source code and are legally binding beholden to the public intrest in an accountable, reliable, sustainable and transparent manner. 4. What technology areas should be prioritised and why? Election software and should be prioritized. The trust in elections and the institutions is paramount to their legitimacy and persistence in a time of disinformation. During the pandemic the transparency of the German Corona-Warn-App allowed for a wide-ranging adoption of contact tracing solutions in one of the EU's most privacy-minded member states. 5. In what sectors could an increased use of open source lead to increased competitiveness and cybe

feedback:
Question 1: The EU IT industry primarily consists of smaller players with SAP being the notable exception. This applies also to the OSS sector. The IT industry is full of network effects creating "winner-takes-it-all" markets where only one or a very small number of players can succeed. We see that situation with cloud infrastructure providers. Likewise, OSS players are relatively small in Europe. Thanks to the ability to collaborate on open standards and open source code, they can fight above their weight class, but still fail to bolster real competition in the larger platform markets. Meanwhile, big tech companies in the US have understood how to leverage Open Source technology to their advantage, using the rights that non-reciprocal (permissive) OSS licenses give to enhance software without contributing back. That said, they actually do strategic investments into OSS where it suits them and this way contribute more than large companies in Europe do. The latter have largely failed to understand the lever Open Source gives to them. Barriers in Europe is a highly fragmented market with fragmented regulation. And too many companies with traditional business culture (in risk-averse society) avoiding the risks of a fast moving software industry. There is no capital market that understands and supports startups in this space to a sufficient degree. Later stage funding for successful IT startups in Europe required for scaling more often than not comes from the US. Question 2: A success story is the Sovereign Cloud Stack (SCS) where cloud providers have agreed on common standards for user-facing APIs and also collaborated on open source engineering work to deliver a resilient platform together. This avoids customers to become locked-in to a single provider, as switching inside (or combining) a network of coopeting providers is technically very easy. The ByCS.de (Bavarian School Cloud) is a successful workload on top of an SCS cloud, serving more than a million pupils, teachers and parents. Question 3: The funding projects need to ensure not to be too fragmented, creating too disconnected pockets of innovation which may not fit together. That said, funding is a great way to provide the initial open source investments to build successful business models. Funding may also be a requirement for infrastructure project maintenance, where the common access is so beneficial that value extraction with a commercial model may not be desirable. For most areas, open source should be created and maintained by a network of collaborating companies. These should fund the development from customers that buy their services such as support, maintenance, trainings, consulting. The EU should thus have procurement policies in place that prefer EU open source companies. The contribution to the (global!) open source projects needs to be an important criterium for the selection of the vendor, this way ensuring that the digital public good does benefit from its use. Procurement needs to measure & prioritize true sovereignty, The EU has strict regulation on data protection (GDPR) as well as DSA and DMA. However the adequacy decision subverts GDPR. The regulation is only marginally enforced causing a moral hazard for those that want to follow the laws and creates little incentives to work with smaller (and initially less capable) European vendors that do comply. Question 4: The foundations of our IT infrastructure are what most other projects depend upon and are thus the most important. - The ability to design and manufacture computer chips needs to be built. Takes decade and needs heavy investments. - We need good open source cloud and container platform technologies and a network of operators that provide services. Much easier. - The situation in Operating Systems is better with Linux. - The collaboration space would benefit from escaping the M365 monopoly with public sector initiat

feedback: Since 2025, reliance on American digital tools has become a geopolitical risk for French publichealth services. Administrative decisions abroad can suspend proprietary software, threatening care continuity. Opensource solutions now offer a strategic path to digital sovereignty, keeping data and services under national control and immune to external unplugging. Martinique Hospital feedback : 20Year Operational Experience - Maturity & reliability: Linux, Samba, Docker have run for 20years with no major incidents, matching commercial stability. - Resilience: Hardware failures trigger a degraded mode that preserves data; the whole infrastructure is rebuilt every three years on standard hardware, faster and cheaper than vendordriven refreshes. - Cost savings: License fees eliminated amount to hundreds of thousands of euros, freeing budget for training, innovation and patient care. - Autonomy: No licensing lockin eliminates the risk of forced disconnection by foreign governments. - AIdriven innovation: Generative AI enables rapid, inhouse creation of tools (contactmanagement, DPI fallback, automated mailserver deployment), reducing development cycles from months to days. ARS Feedback - Cybersecurity: Open code is auditable, allowing quicker detection and remediation of vulnerabilities than opaque proprietary products. - Transparency & trust: Public scrutiny of source code strengthens patient confidence in data handling. - Economic impact: While licence costs disappear, ARS note that training and technical support become new expense lines that must be budgeted. - Sovereignty support: French and EU policies increasingly back opensource initiatives, but sustained political commitment is needed to scale benefits. Key Challenges 1. Skill shortage & inadequate training Curricula still focus on proprietary stacks; remote territories lack exposure to tools such as Proxmox or Samba AD, requiring high upfront upskilling costs. 2. Concentration of expertise Small teams often rely on a single opensource champion, creating organizational risk if that person leaves. 3. Lack of contribution framework Internal projects frequently stay in private repositories, depriving the community of feedback and preventing collaborative improvement. 4. Pressure toward uniformity Procurement trends favor commercial suites perceived as cheaper to maintain, forcing institutions into onesizefitsall solutions that ignore specific needs. 5. Incompatible publicprocurement models Centralised purchasing bodies prioritize largevendor hardware, sidelining equipment better suited to opensource stacks. 6. Certification bias Certification schemes are tailored to proprietary vendors, raising entry barriers for smaller opensource projects. 7. Supplychain security Managing dependencies and patches across a diverse opensource portfolio is complex in a regulated health environment, demanding dedicated governance. Recommendations 1. Make opensource a pillar of European digital sovereignty Fund EUscale forks of critical services via public procurement and R&D grants; mandate data portability and interoperability for all publicsector software. 2. Scale education and awareness Develop EUrecognised curricula and certifications for freesoftware technologies and launch campaigns for publicsector leaders highlighting strategic, economic and security benefits. 3. Incentivise sustainable contributions Create longterm funding mechanisms that reward hospitals and agencies for maintaining and sharing opensource projects; establish publicprivate partnership models that allow staff to allocate time to community development. 4.Reform Public Procurement and Centralised Purchasing Expand the catalogue of hardware compatible with opensource stacks within national and EU procurement. 5.Protect Proven OpenSource Infrastructures Recognise existing, battletested opensource deployments.

Hi, I appreciate that the European Comission is taking action on this important issue. I am an engineer in the IT industry, and I specialize in Cloud Technologies, Developer Platforms, and Open-Source. As an IT consultant, I have built cloud infrastructure for many public sector and private sector organizations, and I have deep insight into the technical decisions made as a consumer of cloud services. I believe EU vendors and open source software are well-positioned to compete with non-EU tech vendors and that supporting and enabling these projects and actors are the best way to reduce digital sovereignty risks for EU citizens and organizations. I would like to contribute my professional and personal experience with developing EU cloud and using open source software as the European Commission investigates these areas. I also have a somewhat unique geopolitical perspective, having been born and raised in the US and having worked in the IT industry in both the US and Sweden. My full comments can be found in the attached document, where I detail the current practical issues with EU IT systems and open source, and I point out some possible policy solutions to improve digital sovereignty and promote open source software. Thank you!

feedback:
Propositions de l'Association TOSIT https://tosit.fr TOSIT, "The Open Source I Trust", est une association loi 1901 à but non lucratif, sans employé, qui fédère 25 grandes organisations utilisatrices dOpen Source en France.\ TOSIT vise à soutenir lémergence de codes, logiciels et solutions informatiques sous licence Open Source et/ou licence libre, notamment en matière de cybersécurité via un partage entre pairs. Plus de détails dans le PDF en PJ avec les constats face aux actions. Ce que nous devons collectivement faire (approche "grands utilisateurs") 1.Créer un radar technologique souverain (alternative à Gartner/Forrester) Action : Co-construire un catalogue commun basé sur la réalité de la productio&x6E;. Un Radar / Cadran pragmatique de l'open source&x20;&x63;onstruit à partir de l'état de l'art dans les grandes organisations : c'est ce que nous faisons chez TOSIT. Par ailleurs, nous partageons une grille commune d'évaluation des caractéristiques Open Source des logiciels : communauté, licence, sécurité, ecosystème de support (MCO, MCS) et de développement... 2.Industrialiser le co-financement de roadmaps" (crowdfunding B2B) Actions : TOSIT Fr a réussi à mener la démarche besoins communs > roadmap > chiffrage > cofinancement. Cette démarche pourrait être démultipliée à l'échelle Européeene. L'UE doit nous aider à promouvoir l'émergence d'autres TOSIT dans les états membres. l'UE doit nous aider à financer en abondant nos co-financements. 3.Renverser le modèle de formation (limiter le vendor lock-in) Actions : Dans toutes les disciplines qui utilisent un logiciel propriétaire dans leur formation, l'UE peut elle imposer d'avoir systématiquement une formation sur une alternative Open Source (exemple : Suite Adobe <=> Gimp, Scribus, Inkscape, Blender , PostgreSQL/MariaDB <=> Oracle/SQL Server) L'UE peut promouvoir formations complètes spécialisées sur l'Open Source (développement, business plan, conformité juridique des liences...) et des options à ajouter aux mastères numériques existants. Ce que l'UE doit faire pour aider (leviers politiques et réglementaires) 4.Adapter le Code des Marchés Publics Action : Assouplir les règles du Marché Public lorsqu'il s'agit d'acheter des "features" qui seront libérées dans une licence Open Source. 5.Structurer la représentation des grands utilisateurs" (Corporate Users groups / passage à l'échelle du modèle TOSIT) Actions : Aider au développement d'équivalents européens de groupes comme le TOSIT pour créer un interlocuteur représentatif du Corporate User capable de peser sur les directives (comme le Cyber Resilience Act). 6.Créer un statut fiscal "Investisseur en Communs Numériques" Actions : Favoriser l'émergence d'entités de type "Fondation de Bien Commun" éligibles au mécénat ou à la défiscalisation. Une entreprise qui détache des développeurs sur un projet d'intérêt général devrait pouvoir déduire cet effort, à l'instar du Crédit Impôt Recherche (CIR), mais ciblé Open Source. 7.Garantir un "droit au fork" et la continuité de service Actions : Créer un fonds de garantie européen pour soutenir la maintenance des "Forks de survie" lorsque des briques critiques pour les services publics européens deviennent soudainement propriétaires 8.Financer la sécurité et la supplychain logicielle (en lien avec le cyber resilience act) Actions : Financer des audits de sécurité et des programmes de bug bounty sur les infrastructures critiques de l'UE, pour décharger les mainteneurs bénévoles de cette responsabilité juridique et financière. 9.Mutualiser les infrastructures de forge Actions : Soutenir une infrastructure souveraine européeen pour l'hébergement du code et des modèles d'IA (alternative publique et commune à Github et Huggingface), pour éviter que le code source européen ne soit soumis aux condit

language: I'd like to report on this often ignored but important topic. PC firmware
country: is used in many devices from small network appliances over laptops to huge servers. Important about this firmware: 1. PC firmware is the most privileged software running on a vast amount of devices in our digital ecosystem

PC firmware operates as the trust anchor to verify digital signatures of our OSs (i.e. secure boot). It is the key element that ensures we actually run the untampered software that we intend to run. Most proprietary PC firmware is developed by a small oligopoly of three non-EU companies

feedback: The European parliament report on the 28th Regime rightfully addresses the broader ownership situation of European businesses today: - an unprecedented change of ownership putting the European economy up for sale, with a silver tsunami of European baby boomer business owners retiring in the coming decade. - the need for autonomy in tech, energy and the like innovations - and theres plenty of engineers and founders willing to start up and scale up - US private equity giants persuading European entrepreneurs to sell off their valuable businesses for irresistible amounts of money - and (often American) venture capital funds cleverly poaching EU startups and scale-ups with the most innovative potential, - causing a loss of assets, taxes, jobs, autonomy and intellectual property to Wall Street and Silicon Valley. European businesses run the risk of effectively falling into the hands of owners driven solely by short-term financial profits. This short-termism is fundamentally incompatible with the EUs longterm competitiveness agenda, which calls for patient capital and future orientation. This is even more important in the context of digital sovereignty. This is why we were very very happy with the multi partisan(!) support in the European Parliament, including the Presidents own EPP, last Tuesday for a 28th regime INI report that asks for - a harmonized limited liability company form, anchored in the Member States, implemented by maximum harmonisation and ensuring full free movement rights and automatic recognition across the Internal Market - fully inclusive i.e. available for all businesses - fully digitalised and simplified company registration - minimum capital requirement of 1 - and optional enabling elements such as: * an equity-like debt instrument enabling investors to invest without acquiring rights of control over a company, such as profit participation rights, silent partnerships or profit-linked loans; * employee ownership forms (Employee Stock Ownership Plans, ESOPs), not to be confused with stock options (ESOs) * purpose and mission-driven corporate forms through optional elements such as asset locks and steward ownership, ensuring that companies that do not seek an exit can attract investment and protect themselves against killer acquisitions if they choose to do so. European sovereignty - digital, economic, and institutional - cannot rest on branding, good intentions, or abstract commitments to innovation. It requires durable structures: open-source infrastructure that remains genuinely open over time, and ownership models such as steward ownership that align control with long-term stewardship rather than short-term extraction. The question is not whether Europe will innovate. The question is whether European innovation will remain European - or whether it will continue to be enclosed, acquired, and subordinated inside US-controlled capital and cloud empires.
organization: University of Amsterdam, School of Business and Economics

feedback: # Position on EU Open Digital Ecosystems Initiative Open source has been foundational to my IT career providing learning opportunities that would be prohibitively expensive with proprietary products. Today, as an infrastructure engineer, open source underpins my daily work: Kubernetes, Terraform, observability tools. I welcome EU's support for open source. However, the devil is in the details. ## Corporate lobbying under the open source banner I observe large corporations co-opting open source to serve commercial interests. I witnessed a "community position" on softening CRA requirements effectively drafted by a major tech company's employees potentially enabling exemptions for their commercial mobile products. In another case, an Asian telecom manufacturer released their OS as "open source" with license violations; when controversy grew, they transferred it to a European foundation while retaining control. Even student mentorship programmes can serve as tools for building ecosystem dependency. Open source promotion by NGOs must be 100% transparent. Ideally through public benefit organisations whose funding is subject to scrutiny. ## Exemplary organisations Apache Software Foundation demonstrates independent governance without single-sponsor dominance. In Europe, NLnet Foundation excels funding projects from WireGuard and Jitsi to Nitrokey. NLnet's model (5k50k grants, streamlined procedures, openness to individuals) should template other EU initiatives. ## Open source in public administration Poland's mObywatel (eID app) source code "publication" exemplifies performative transparency: only mobile frontend released without the security-critical backend; code requires authentication despite MIT license; no guarantee it matches the running app; contains "Hello World" placeholders. Such façade openness undermines trust in eID systems. The EU must require genuine, not theatrical, transparency. ## Software supply chain Supply chain attacks (XZ Utils) expose infrastructure fragility. I propose: - Mandatory SBOM publication for all public sector vendors even closed-source - Mandatory sponsorship of SBOM-listed open source projects by these vendors - Higher requirements for closed-source products incentivising code opening This addresses single-maintainer vulnerabilities while shifting responsibility to benefiting commercial entities. ## Education Schools and universities should prioritise open source. This shapes citizens who understand technology rather than being held hostage by it. Promotion could be NGO-delivered with transparent funding. ## Licensing clarity Licenses like BSL (Business Source License) don't meet the open source definition and should be explicitly excluded. I propose defining openness levels: - **Highest:** Community building with external contributions accepted - **Minimum for public sector:** Code availability with reuse rights for interoperability
I am the maintainer and main developer of GIMP, a widely known Community-driven Free Software for high-end image creation and manipulation. You will find my feedback in the attached document.

The Interactions Research Group at the University of St. Gallen welcomes the Commissions initiative on Open-Source Digital Ecosystems and especially supports an open-source strategy that advances autonomy, strong privacy protection and open innovation without compromising global interoperability and connectivity. The group investigates technology-mediated interactions in complex socio-technical systems, with a particular focus on human-centered, autonomous, and pervasive computing environments. Our work spans open and adaptive systems, cyber-physical systems, multi-agent systems, and regulatory-aware computing, and regularly engages with the societal, economic, and governance implications of digital infrastructures. Based on our research and experience with deploying and governing open systems, we view open digital ecosystems as a foundational requirement for transparency, accountability, and long-term European technological sovereignty.

feedback: Thank you for funding so many wonderful OpenSource projects. I use Mastodon, Libreoffice, and Wireguard on a daily basis. Others - such as Phosh or CryptPad - I'm looking forward to use in the future. I'm glad that they're receiving the support needed to have a chance against competition from US megacorps. And I love that it's the EU that is supporting them. Keep up the good work!

Strengths of EU open-source sector: - the community is big and growing - new areas of exploration are emerging - NGI Zero sprouted so much innovation! Weakness of EU open source sector: - open source volunteering not recognized as volunteering in most EU countries - grant and fellowships do not offer enough life security - there is a gap between building open source projects and building full products that people can use in their daily lives - open source projects rarely know how to apply or secure funding or even set up a business development and sales pipeline Barriers that hamper sustainable contributions: - lack of a sustainable funding model means that most contributions come from students, young people or researchers - contributions as volunteering next in free time can lead to substantial burnout - leads to a lot of volunteering-based short term work, hard to deliver long-term work - leads to a lot of solutions which are partially implemented Barriers for high-quality and secure open source: - implementing something to a high quality and security requires a lot of long-term work - it is hard to motivate volunteers or underpaid people to do such work Added value for public and private sectors: - if an open source company goes away, the projects remain and they can be rebuilt - innovation can always easily be contributed Concrete measures and actions at EU level: - most of the proposals in the "From NGI to Open Internet Stack" report by Stuart J Mackintosh - users should be given the ability to replace the operating system for their own smartphone devices with software they choose - smartphone bootloaders shall be unlocked to allow users to run their software and prevent the phones from becoming landfill - device OEMs shall be forced to publish hardware interface specification documents for smartphones that they do not update anymore - the EU digital wallet should mandate that country implementation should not be allowed to use device attestation from Google or Apple, because this would prevent open source operating systems from running those apps (Lineage OS, Carbon OS, etc.) - support creation of integrated consortia of organizations from the EU to focus on building full open source products instead of a lose collection of projects.
Please see the attached file.

feedback: Sono un Research Software Engineer con esperienza in varie comunità di Software Libero. Sono nato e cresciuto in Italia, lavoro in Spagna e collaboro con organizzazioni basate in Francia. Ritengo il software open source una maniera efficiente di realizzare nuovi strumenti focalizzato sulla condivisione di conoscenze: ciò permette di studiare e/o riutilizzare parti di codice scritti da altri, non necessariamente per gli stessi obiettivi, risparmiando il tempo di dover arrivare alle stesse conclusioni di forma autonoma. Le varie comunità costituiscono una palestra molto importante nella formazione dei programmatori. Lì persone con una formazione scolastica possono apprendere come usare gli strumenti del mestiere più avanzati e le buone pratiche di lavoro, migliorando anche le proprie capacità di scrivere codice di qualità, assistito da programmatori esperti e spronato dal fatto che il codice sarà visibile a tutti mostrando chiaramente difetti e qualità. I problemi principali che il software open source, sia scientifico che non, si trova ad affrontare ritengo siano il finanziamento e la manutenzione costante. Ciò è particolarmente evidente nel mondo scientifico e della creazione dei componenti di base: spesso il peso della manutenzione ricade su una sola persona che svolge larga parte del lavoro in maniera volontaria. Il sistema attuale inoltre si basa principalmente su finanziamenti collegati a progetti di ricerca, con problemi aggiuntivi: l'impatto del software è spesso sottostimato dai ricercatori stessi, che ignorano le componenti fondamentali del software da loro usato e sovente non lo citano negli articoli di ricerca. Di conseguenza non tutti i ricercatori includono lo sviluppo software nelle loro domande e chi lo fa rischia di non ottenere abbastanza in quanto non abbastanza citato. I progetti finanziati in questa maniera alla fine devono focalizzarsi sulla creazione di nuove funzionalità nei tempi brevi dettati dalla borsa, quando la parte di codice già esistente richiederebbe manutenzione e migliorie. Una soluzione potrebbe essere la creazione e/o incentivazione di corridoi alternativi per l'accesso al finanziamento, indipendenti da progetti di ricerca specifici e con un occhio di riguardo alle piccole librerie dimenticate ma essenziali nello sviluppo. Tale azione migliorerebbe la stabilità finanziaria permettendo anche di abbassare il carico di lavoro. Un altro aspetto fondamentale, evidente quando ci si muove tra paesi, è il differente trattamento fiscale e normativo ancora presente. Essere riconosciuti in un paese dell'Unione come organizzazione non a scopo di lucro, che è solitamente il metodo utilizzato da chi prova a vivere di donazioni, spesso non è sufficiente per esserlo anche negli altri stati, con le ovvie conseguenze nel trattamento fiscale dei donatori. La differenza tra i paesi è notevole anche dal punto di vista dell'organizzazione: la vocazione è spesso internazionale e i contributi arrivano da remoto, ma la normativa ancora non prevede una forma agevole per assumere persone che vivono, e intendono continuare a vivere, in un altro paese membro.

feedback:
In line with the EESCs report on services of general interest (TEN/851-EESC-2025), which calls for reforming governmental digital infrastructures to reduce dependence on non-EU providers and to strengthen European sovereignty and securityparticularly in connectivity and public service deliverywe affirm that Open Source-based Digital Commons are a strategic necessity for the European Union. Today, EU values of democracy, fundamental rights, and the rule of law are increasingly challenged by proprietary tools of control and surveillance used by public authorities. Open Source, understood solely as a licensing or economic model, is insufficient. Openness must be treated as a political instrument, serving the EUs democratic objectives rather than as an end in itself. It only becomes a real strength when embedded in strong community governance models that ensure reciprocity, shared responsibility, and long-term stewardship. While open data and Open Source software are driving innovation, they have also enabled Big Tech actors to free-ride, reinforcing market concentration and strategic dependencies. The EU must therefore move beyond a purely technical approach and actively support community-driven digital commons that foster cooperation between public authorities, civil society, and economic actors. Digital Commons generate high public value for the public sector: they are resilient, protect fundamental rights, and can contribute to climate objectives. However, communities require care. Governance, maintenance, and community building must be recognised as essential public investments, especially in markets biased towards US proprietary solutions, where public intervention is both legitimate and necessary. Evidence from French public-sector initiativesincluding ANCT, ADEMEs Call for Commons, Panoramax with IGN, Suite Numérique by DINUM, Fabrique des Mobilités, Fabrique des Géocommuns, and FabLogdemonstrates the added value of Digital commons for public administrations. Digital Commons drive social innovation, support the modernisation of public services, and renew citizen participation in public policymaking. By mutualising tools, documentation, and maintenance efforts, they reduce costs and risks while strengthening strategic autonomy. Crucially, Digital Commons ensure continuity: projects and infrastructures endure beyond initial funding cycles. Yet significant barriers remain. Existing legal and financial frameworks are not fit for purpose: they are designed to fund projects, not to sustain communities. Public servants who play a key role in enabling people-first PPPs remain undervalued, weakening institutional capacity. Public actors struggle to position themselves in complex governance systems due to insufficient knowledge and support. Finally, the lack of stable and predictable funding threatens the emergence and sustainability of Digital Commons. Priority technology choices should be debated publicly with users, taking into account planetary boundaries, social justice, mental health, peace, and democracynot economic growth alone. Public administration tools, including office suites, email, and messaging, would particularly benefit from wider use of Digital Commons. We therefore call on the EU and Member States to: Recognise Digital Commons in public procurement as solutions aligned with EU values and strategic autonomy Maintain funding for grassroots innovation (e.g. NGI) while adding support for scaling and industrialisation Be an example, actively use and contribute to digital commons within EU institutions and public administrations Create an EU fund for the maintenance and improvement of strategic digital commons, covering both technical and community work Invest in education and capacity building for users and public institutions Establish an independent expert panel to identify key areas of general interestsuch as social data or digital twin

feedback:
L'Open Source se distingue par l'absence de positions monopolistiques, favorisant une pluralité d'acteurs économiques de taille modeste (PME et micro-entreprises) qui, ensemble, renforce l'autonomie stratégique des utilisateurs finaux. Si cette granularité garantit l'agilité et l'innovation, elle constitue un obstacle majeur face aux processus de marchés publics classiques : la taille de ces entreprises devient un facteur bloquant, les excluant de facto des grands appels à projets nationaux et européens au profit de structures généralistes. Cette exclusion force les institutions à s'appuyer sur des intermédiaires massifs qui ne sont pas impliqués dans les écosystèmes libres et Open Source. Au delà des enjeux économiques, cette situation crée un risque stratégique : - Conflits d'intérêts : ces acteurs peuvent avoir des intérêts contraires aux motivations ayant menées au choix de l'Open Source, veillant parfois à ce que les recommandations n'impactent pas leurs propres modèles propriétaires ou monopolistiques (reproduisant des logiques de captation de marché et lock-in) - Dilution de la valeur et affaiblissement des communautés : en captant la valeur sans reverser de contributions (code, documentation, financement) aux communautés -- ou en les reversant mal --, ces intermédiaires affaiblissent la durabilité des solutions qu'ils déploient et des communautés qu'ils exploitent. - Intérmédiation inutile génératrice d'un coût pour le bénéficiaire et les acteurs de l'Open Source (ces acteurs s'attribuent généralement les parts les plus rentables et les moins à risque des marchés, s'appuyant pour le reste sur un écosystème Open Source surexploité) Rejoingnat des structures de mutualisation telles que CSI Piemonte en Italie ou le TOSIT en France, la structure Open Source Experts (OSE) issue des travaux stratégiques menés par Numeum et le CNLL vise à corriger ces asymétries de marché. Elle a été conçue pour répondre précisément à ces défaillances de marché par deux leviers d'action : - Outiller l'appel aux expertises locales : OSE permet de rendre visible, accessible et outillé un réseau d'experts hautement qualifiés. Il s'agit de fournir aux donneurs d'ordre publics les mécanismes et outils (juridiques et techniques) nécessaires pour solliciter directement les acteurs qui maintiennent et développent les technologies, plutôt que des généralistes de l'intégration. - Consolider l'écosystème local : en structurant une filière de proximité, OSE garantit que la commande publique alimente un tissu économique souverain, pérenne et ancré dans les territoires. Pour que l'Open Source soit un réel outil de souveraineté, la commande publique européenne doit être repensée avec la filière industrielle de l'Open Source et notamment : - Diviser les marchés, notamment en favorisant l'allotissement technique et géographique pour permettre aux PME de l'Open Source de répondre sans passer par des intermédiaires dénaturant la mission. - Valoriser l'engagement communautaire, intégrer des critères de sélection reposant sur la contribution effective aux projets (historique de commits, maintenance des projets, etc.) afin de privilégier les acteurs réellement engagés dans la pérennité du numérique européen. - Soutenir les structures de mutualisation en reconnaissant et s'appuyant sur des réseaux comme Open Source Experts pour identifier les compétences critiques et éviter la concentration du marché entre les mains d'acteurs susceptibles d'exercer une influence négative sur l'ouverture des systèmes. - Préfigurer les grandes migrations vers l'Open Source (telle que les postes de travail, les mobiles, la bureautique, etc.) pour donner confiance et influencer aussi les pratiques du privé. Préserver l'écosystème Open Source nécessite une organisation en réseau qui allie expertise d

feedback: We, the Interest Group Digital Tools and their Development, including Artificial Intelligence and Machine Learning within the Alliance Focus Digitality in Science, encourage the EU commission to foster the attractivity of the open source market for providers in the EU with this envisioned initiative. The EU open source sector should now be considered in terms of its paramount importance for the digital security and digital sovereignty of EU and its Member States. Emphasis should be laid on the political necessity and political will to significantly reduce dependence on international technology giants. European money spent within the EU on open source software adds to a more stable internal European economy. Academic and research institutions are experienced in designing and implementing open source solutions. Open source software in research is highly accepted to support reproducibility of scientific findings and trustworthiness of research. Additionally, open source can enhance knowledge and technology transfer from academic research into commercial applications. The adoption of open source software corresponds to open science approaches, mitigates the risk of vendor lock-in and fosters competition in the development of optimal solutions for end-users, thereby benefiting society. Support for existing open source providers and networks and for research-related open software offerings for European higher education systems would be of great benefit. Another import context is open source for generative AI models and tools through the provision and development of open source AI. This is especially important for open training data, open model weights, and open AI algorithms. Universities and research institutions are exposed to an increased risk of cyber attacks, often with long-term consequences in reputation and financial expenses. The increased use of open source software can help to mitigate hazards and reduces the risk of significant internal organisational and economic damage to scientific organisations. A consistent combination of open source code and cybersecurity through increased use of open source-based, trustworthy solutions in software or hardware, such as RISC-V microcontrollers, could be effective. Open source trust anchors have to be promoted and used particularly in security-critical areas. Examples are technology-neutral 5G and 6G test environments (i.e., the Open RAN concept). It is also desirable to strive for the implementation of rules for publicly funded institutions and projects requiring them to use a certain amount of open source software, if possible. Strengthening these efforts by means of additional funding opportunities for open source software projects and their use in publicly funded projects and institutions would be beneficial for academia and society. It enhances digital sovereignty and in addition reduces the potential for state-guided coercion through the manipulation of software or disturbance of services.

feedback:
The Software Freedom Conservancy (SFC) is a US based charitable nonprofit. For nearly 20 years, we have supported Free and Open Source Software (FOSS) projects, enforced the license agreements underpinning FOSS, and educated the public and industry about the benefits of FOSS, among other things. Our mission mandates that we pursue the public good for the entire public of the world. Much of the feedback we would provide has been articulated by many of the organizations and individuals who have submitted their feedback to this Call for Evidence. Rather than repeat these same points, we refer you to the submission by Free Software Foundation Europe (FSFE) (based in Germany), which comprehensively covers these points. We additionally raise two issues of key importance in addition to the FSFE's comments: First, we would like the EU to consider that FOSS began in the US in the 1980s as a rejection of Big Tech and centralized control. US based FOSS initiatives made digital sovereignty possible by creating basic infrastructure and sets of principles upon which today's digital ecosystem is based. US FOSS (with help from around the world) proved that an alternative model of software development could be successful, free from the control of large companies. Many US based nonprofit charities continue that work today. FOSS communities (including volunteers, unaffiliated contributors, and small organizations and NGOs) together agree that the EU (and everyone) avoid procuring proprietary software from Silicon Valley Big Tech. We hope that the EU, while encouraging European based development and deployment of FOSS, continues to partner with US based orgs as well as FOSS communities around the world. Second, we wish to raise the issue that not all FOSS is created equal. Some FOSS is available under licensing structures called "copyleft", such as the GNU General Public License (GPL). Copyleft licenses include provisions that assure consumers' rights to software repair and the ability to modify and improve the software (or hire anyone they like to do so). Software developed under a strong copyleft license is "forever free." When companies use, improve and distribute copylefted software, they must do so under the same license. This not only enables more collaboration and prevents vendor lock in, but also disincentivizes market fragmentation. Copylefted code (and all new software derived from it) continues to remain FOSS, even as corporations take it their own way. In contrast, non-copyleft licenses are preferred by industry (especially Big Tech), which tend to prioritize their short-term profit motives. Those companies try to limit the adoption of copyleft licenses, as this would create a more competitive landscape. However, when software available under copyleft licenses is superior in quality, companies manage use it despite the drawbacks they cite. We already see around the world phones that use Android (the Android Open Source Linux-based operating system) enabling alternatives and right to repair for citizens who can repurpose mobile devices that no longer receive updates from the manufacturer into long lived devices that serve their needs and allow them to repair their own equipment. Security updates are managed and implemented by volunteers, who want this for their own devices and helpfully choose to share these changes with others so they can benefit too. This kind of repair and improvement is essential to decreasing e-waste from Europe and continue the use of fully functional devices over new devices that for-profit corporations would like to sell. Prioritizing copyleft will allow the best long term assurance of digital sovereignty and access to high quality, customizable solutions. We ask the Commission to seriously consider, should it implement any EU-wide Open Source Policy, a preference for copyleft FOSS licenses as opposed to non-copyleft ones (such as

feedback: As a leading global community for Free and Open Source Geospatial Software, OSGeo.org welcomes the European Commissions Communication "Towards European Open Digital Ecosystems" (Ares(2026)69111). For over two decades, the Open Source Geospatial Foundation (OSGeo) has served as an umbrella foundation for global open source geospatial software like QGIS, gvSIG, GeoServer, MapServer, GDAL, PostGIS, GeoTools, OpenLayers, GRASS, GeoNetwork, PygeoAPI, Rasdaman, Zoo and many others, providing key components to the European spatial data infrastructure. It provides public authorities, SMEs, and researchers with a sovereign, interoperable, and cost-effective alternative to proprietary software [0]. We endorse the Commissions focus on cementing digital autonomy and open collaboration. Hence, we submit this evidence to emphasise that a truly resilient European digital ecosystem requires sustained, systemic support for the underlying open source communities that maintain it. By prioritising "Open Source First" procurement and investing in the security and scalability of community-driven tools, the EU can ensure that its geospatial future is built on transparent, democratic, and truly sustainable foundations. While open-source software is already widely used across European public administrations, widespread usage alone does not guarantee its long-term sustainability. The reliability, security, and strategic value of Digital Public Goods depend on continuous investment in maintenance, governance, and community coordination. Without deliberate policy and procurement mechanisms that distinguish between merely using open source and actively sustaining it, Europe risks building critical digital services on infrastructures whose long-term resilience is underfunded. Despite hosting several large open source geospatial communities (e.g. QGIS, Leaflet, GeoServer, GeoNetwork), Europes institutional infrastructure is locked into a non-EU proprietary monopoly. ESRIs dominance, fueled by free academic licensing and restrictive public procurement, creates a "sovereignty gap" where critical national data is managed via proprietary software. This concentration hinders technological autonomy and captures economic value outside the Union. To meet the goals of Ares(2026)69111, Europe must ensure its digital roadmap is dictated by public interest, not global commercial providers. About the Open Source Geospatial Foundation OSGeo is the official legal entity and community-driven organisation that oversees the development and maintenance of the largest number of geospatial open source software products available today. It serves as the formal hub for a global ecosystem of developers, users, and organisations dedicated to democratising geospatial software in its broadest sense. The organisation is tasked with managing the foundation's infrastructure, securing financial sustainability through sponsorships and donations, and ensuring that the projects under its umbrella remain free and open. By fostering a transparent and meritocratic environment, OSGeo empowers individuals and public institutions alike to access professional-grade geospatial tools without the barriers of proprietary licensing and vendor lock-in, thereby playing a critical role in the global advancement of digital sovereignty and spatial science. While OSGeo boasts a global community of developers and users, the majority of its developers, users and founding members are located in Europe. (The members of the OSGeo board of directors currently include representatives from Switzerland, Greece, Romania, The Netherlands and Portugal.) Some of OSGeos projects are officially recognised as a Digital Public Good [1] by the Digital Public Goods Alliance (DPGA), a status that highlights its critical role in promoting sustainable development and providing equitable access to professional-grade geospatial technology worldwide.

feedback: L'écosystème numérique ouvert européen, il existe mais n'est pas promu. Il vit et se développe grâce à des citoyens et des associations, mais pas grâce à l'UE ni aux gouvernements qui la composent. L'UE et les gouvernements continuent jour après jour de préférer faire appel à des initiatives privées, fermées et souvent américaines, plutôt que de participer à lessor du numérique ouvert. Et ce alors même qu'une part importante de celui-ci est d'origine européenne. Linux est né d'un citoyen Finlandais, VLC d'une association française, le Web d'un citoyen britannique et d'un belge travaillant tous deux pour une institution européenne. Et pourtant l'UE préfère copier les américains plutôt que de développer ce qui fait son identité.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: The European open digital ecosystem exists but is not promoted. It lives and grows thanks to citizens and associations, but not thanks to the EU and its governments. The EU and governments continue to use private, closed and often American initiatives every day rather than engaging in open digital. This is despite the fact that a significant part of it is of European origin. Linux was born to a Finnish citizen, VLC from a French association, the web of a British citizen and a Belgian both working for a European institution. And yet the EU prefers to copy the Americans rather than develop what makes its identity.

feedback: As a senior IT Architect and IT Manager at a large German university and IT representative of a European University Alliance, I can report that open-source software is an essential component of modern IT service provision and the foundation of a sustainable and resilient IT portfolio. European open-source communities are strong and high-quality, particularly in academia, the public sector, and SMEs. This strength is closely linked to the high compatibility of open source with academic values such as openness, transparency, peer review, and reusability, as well as with core EU principles including data protection, interoperability, and fundamental rights. This makes open source particularly well-suited for public-interest infrastructures. At the same time, European open-source projects often face complex legal and financial frameworks for non-profit organisations and long-term sustainability compared to international or big-tech-vendor-bound counterparts. In public procurement, contracting authorities are required to formulate tenders in a vendor- and product-neutral manner. Even when there is a clear strategic intention to adopt open-source solutions, this requirement can make it difficult to express such preferences in a legally robust way. Product-neutral tenders tend to favour larger vendors or agencies offering established house products, while smaller providers supporting community-driven open-source solutions are harder to involve. This can result in solutions being selected based on market availability rather than scenario fitness, architectural openness and long-term sustainability. For the public sector, particularly higher education institutions, the added value of open source is most visible in the areas of standards, interoperability and sustainability. Open standards, data formats and application schemas are essential enablers of digital transformation in universities. In identity and access management, open-source technologies such as OpenLDAP and Shibboleth form the backbone of federated infrastructures, enabling secure, interoperable and privacy-preserving digital services across institutions and borders. University web platforms and content management systems are often the nucleus of digitalisation efforts. Open-source CMS solutions such as Plone provide a robust and security-oriented foundation for complex organisational structures, accessibility requirements and long-term operation, while enabling deep integration with identity management, research platforms and external services without vendor lock-in. Open-source tools for data science, including Python and ecosystems like Jupyter, enable innovation, reproducibility, and long-term reuse without structural dependencies. While targeted funding of critical components (e.g. Python, curl, Linux kernel) is important, it is not sufficient on its own. Sustainable impact requires long-term framework conditions, including recognition of community-driven open-source projects as serving the public interest, safeguarding the operational and security-critical infrastructure of open-source ecosystems (such as repositories and vulnerability databases), and creating viable incentives for companies to align their business models with open source through appropriate procurement and legal frameworks. Priority should be given to open technologies that form critical digital foundations, including identity and trust infrastructures, web and internet technologies, infrastructure projects and toolchains, cloud and data space middleware, and cybersecurity. Priority sectors include higher education and research, including university hospitals as critical infrastructure, as well as public administration, eGovernment, health, and public services. Strengthening open source in these areas represents a strategic investment in Europes digital sovereignty, resilience, and long-term societal stability.

EU institutions, including the EC, are currently spending significant amount of money to pay for American corporations, namely Amazon with AWS, Microsoft with Azure but also the Office Suite, SharePoint, Windows, and a lot more, for the last few years OpenAI, Oracle, etc. This is money that is then not available for supporting existing EU corporations and startups. The EU is directly funding competition while fueling the lock-in those corporations have been improving, both technically but also through lobbying, for decades now. This is an economical problem but even more deeply a problem of trust. It means that EU institutions trust American corporations more than EU equivalents and potentially worst it broadcast that message for the entire World to see, both EU entrepreneurs, EU citizens and everybody else. The EU might be funding EU "champions" and yet it does not rely on them. All EU civil servants are daily logging in to Windows, sharing their data on SharePoint, searching in Google and now ChatGPT, being literally trained on how to use Microsoft Excel, insuring that current and future civil servants are not familiar with alternatives. Until the EU institutions will keep on talking about digital sovereignty without actually doing the most basic step of not relying on such solutions they nobody will rational believe in the claim of genuinely wanting to fuel and support an "open digital ecosystem" while using as its own dependency, adversarial dependencies, the very tools it claims to want to free itself and its citizen from. The very act of change starts with the single step. Until EU institutions show the way and simply pay for open ecosystems it uses then it will remain the digital vassal of incumbents.

The GÉANT Association welcomes the European Commission initiative to set out a strategic approach to the open-source sector. A strengthened EU open-source sector can contribute significantly to Europes technological sovereignty and the cybersecurity agenda, and we call for the support of the European Union to create the framework conditions for this. Specifically, we would welcome the designation of key open-source components as critical to allow sustained funding and governance beyond the initial development. feedback:
In line with the EESCs report on services of general interest (TEN/851-EESC-2025), which calls for reforming governmental digital infrastructures to reduce dependence on non-EU providers and to strengthen European sovereignty and securityparticularly in connectivity and public service deliverywe affirm that open source-based digital commons and distributed manufacturing (DC DM) are a strategic necessity for the European Union. Today, EU values of democracy, fundamental rights, and the rule of law are increasingly challenged by proprietary tools of control and surveillance used by public authorities. Open source, understood solely as a licensing or economic model, is insufficient. Openness must be treated as a political instrument, serving the EUs democratic objectives and allow critical re-appropriation of technology by the public. It becomes a real strength when embedded in strong community governance models that ensure reciprocity, shared responsibility, and long-term stewardship. While open data and open-source software are driving innovation, they have not prevented Big Tech actors to reinforce the market concentration and strategic dependencies. The EU must therefore move beyond a purely technical approach and actively support community-driven digital commons that foster cooperation between public authorities, civil society, and economic actors. Digital commons generate high public value for the public sector: they are resilient, protect fundamental rights, and can contribute to climate objectives. However, communities require care. Governance, maintenance, and community building must be recognized as essential public investments, especially in markets structurally biased towards US proprietary solutions, where public intervention is both legitimate and necessary. Evidence from French public-sector initiativesincluding ANCT, ADEMEs Call for Commons, Panoramax with IGN, Suite Numérique by DINUM, Fabrique des Mobilités, Fabrique des Géocommuns, and FabLogdemonstrates the added value of digital commons for public administrations. Digital Commons drive social innovation, accelerate the modernisation of public services, and renew citizen participation in public policymaking. By mutualising tools, documentation, and maintenance efforts, they reduce costs and risks while strengthening strategic autonomy. Crucially, digital commons ensure continuity: projects and infrastructures endure beyond initial funding cycles. Yet significant barriers remain. Existing legal and financial frameworks are not fit for purpose: they are designed to fund projects, not to build and sustain communities. Public servants who play a key role in enabling publiccommons partnerships remain undervalued, weakening institutional capacity. The lack of stable and predictable funding threatens the emergence and sustainability of digital commons. Priority technology choices should be debated publicly with users, taking into account planetary boundaries, social justice, mental health, peace, and democracynot economic growth alone. Public administration tools, including office suites, email, and messaging, would particularly benefit from wider use of digital commons. We therefore call on the EU and Member States to: · Recognise digital commons in public procurement as solutions aligned with EU values and strategic autonomy · Maintain funding for grassroots innovation (e.g. NGI) while adding support for scaling and industrialisation · Actively use and contribute to digital commons within public administrations. · Create an EU fund for the maintenance and improvement of strategic digital commons, covering both technical and community work · Invest in education and capacity building for users and public institutions. · Establish an independent expert panel to identify key areas of general interest where a commons-based approach is most relevant. Be an example and systematically use
