feedback: Open Source should not be limited to source code or digital sovereignty alone. It should actively foster human collaboration, shared digital infrastructure, and algorithmic transparency across Europe. European citizens have the right to understand the software they are required or encouraged to use, particularly when it is funded by public resources. Transparency strengthens trust, accountability, and democratic legitimacy. By fostering open contribution models, Europe can create the foundation for faster development and innovation among smaller organisations, SMEs, and public-interest initiatives, ensuring fair access to high-quality digital tools. Open Source also strongly supports the "Secure by Design" principle in cybersecurity. Transparency enables independent auditing, shared responsibility, and faster vulnerability detection and mitigation. This approach should become the standard for publicly funded social and administrative software. Europe is already one of the world's leading public-sector actors in the open source ecosystem. By establishing clear contribution rules and a supportive policy environment, it can once again set a global example of how open source can serve the broader social good. Key barriers that should be addressed 1. Sustainability and maintenance funding A major barrier to open source adoption is the lack of long-term funding for maintenance, security updates, and project governance. Sustainable financing models are essential to ensure reliability and resilience. 2. Fragmentation across Member States Despite shared objectives, open source initiatives remain fragmented across Member States and EU institutions. A coordinated European framework for sharing, reusing, and co-maintaining open digital assets would significantly reduce duplication and increase efficiency. 3. Insufficient support in public funding and procurement EU-funded software should be open source by default. Public procurement rules should explicitly favour open standards, open licenses, and reuse, rather than reinforcing vendor lock-in and long-term dependency on proprietary solutions.

The Wikimedia Foundation is the nonprofit organization that hosts Wikipedia and other free knowledge projects. Our vision is a world in which every single human being can freely share in the sum of all knowledge. To this end, we support a vibrant community of 260,000+ volunteers worldwide, who contribute to the Wikimedia projects by adding, editing, and verifying content in over 63 million articles across 300+ languages. The Foundation is pleased to submit its response to this consultation in the attached PDF file.

Europe has an outstanding culture of transparency that aligns with EU digital rights and the clear support of end user and customer rights. It has also become clear, that the European IT infrastructure heavily depends on EU-external big tech companies with proprietary systems. That leaves the EU and its countries subject to political pressure and amplifies a brain-drain out of the EU. Many crucial Open Source projects have only a single maintainer behind them that are in dire need of financial and technical support. While initiatives like the NLNet, Sovereign Tech Fund, and the ECs OSPO have laid a vital foundation for the support of the Open Source ecosystem, it has not solved it. Free Software is for a digital society like roads and bridges: Expertise required for construction and long term funding for maintenance. Therefore, the ecosystem must have funding that isn't redirected to the current or next hype of technologies (e.g. AI). 90% of proprietary products contain Open Source, but the commercial value is solely captured by the vendor, many outside the EU. We like to see a mandatory label for software products so that buyers can make an informed decision. A EU wide Sovereign Tech Fund (EU-STF) could create secure and long-term funding. However, those who profit from Free and Open Source Software must be made accountable for its vendor-neutral support. Also, Open Source is developed on top of existing CI/CD and hosting infrastructure, most often non-EU based systems, leading to a resilience-gap. Preferring Open Source helps the EU to rapidly grow technical skills and build up European solutions, keeping R&D investment within the Union while benefiting from globally created innovations, rather than exporting it as license fees. Open Source code enables a competitive ecosystem of providers to deliver long-term maintenance and security patches well beyond standard industry timelines. The economic shift towards buy European (which is just the next vendor-lockin) as the only way to "sell" a solution in the EU would be dramatic for the Open Source ecosystem. As Free and Open Source Software is global, with maintaining and developers from all nations contributing. Therefore, we'd like to see: - Clearly prefered incentivize "buy Open Source" solutions backed by european vendors - Mandate a transparency label (like EU SEAL0-4) to leave the decisions about the choice of software by the individuals and / or the public rather than forcing it already upon the public by only promoting non free big-tech products, for example with the requirement to use those products in schools. - Promote the benefits of Free and Open Source software so that the general public can make an informed choice between a proprietary, a digitally sovereign and an Open Source and sovereign solution. - Lead by example via Public Money Public Code. EU institutions should mandate Open Source solutions backed by Open Source from the EU's own sector. - Establish a EU wide Sovereign Tech Fund to protect maintainers from the growing funding gap and bring secure and long-term funding to the Open Source projects. - Build a clear strategy that benefits Open Source maintainers and projects in the EU, for example by incentivizing via tax-reduction EU businesses to support Open Source for the public good. Reduce the burdens to contract Open Source developers across the EU member states. It is crucial to keep and strengthen expertise and knowledge in the EU to avoid being passengers in our own IT strategy. - Consult with Free and Open Source experts for existing and new regulations, to ensure their practicality and avoid to damage SMEs as well as the Free and Open Source ecosystem as has happened in the past. - Form a legal "safe-harbor" zone for EU-based open source contributors to lower the administrative burden.

feedback: The following feedback focuses on open-source silicon and its ecosystem. "Open silicon" denotes an integrated circuit whose complete design (from the abstract description to the layout) is publicly available and can be implemented using open-source EDA tools, enabling full auditability and technological sovereignty. The text is largely based on the following documents: Recommendations and roadmap for the development of open-source silicon in the EU (2023) https://wiki.f-si.org/images/1/19/Recommendations_and_roadmap_open_silicon_2023_11_03.pdf White paper for the EC, January 2020 https://wiki.f-si.org/index.php?title=White_paper_for_the_EC,_January_2020 Question 1: Strengths, Weaknesses, and Barriers Strengths: Europe has excellent chip design education and historically contributed core Electronic Design Automation (EDA) algorithms. Pioneering open-source EDA companies exist (YosysHQ, ChipFlow), and IHP Microelectronics released Germany's first open PDK, a replicable model. Weaknesses: The know-how for developing (not for using) EDA tools has nearly disappeared from EU universities. Academia lacks incentives for open-source contributions -publications count, open-source projects don't. Most professors are users, not developers, of proprietary EDA tools, creating cultural bias against open-source. Barriers to adoption: Mainstream EDA vendors prohibit publishing any outputs from their tools, killing open hardware at its root. Students face NDA burdens (e.g. restricted access or inability to study the EDA code) before lectures, discouraging careers in chip design. Mainstream tools are unfriendly and expensive. Barriers to sustainability: EU dependence on foreign EDA tools creates existential extraterritorial risk, as demonstrated when Cadence shut Moscow offices overnight. Permissive licenses allow publicly-funded innovations to be absorbed by proprietary vendors effectively undermining the economic sustainability of the open-source ecosystem. Patent threats loom over open-source EDA and hardware developers. References: Roadmap §3.3, §7, White Paper §3-4 Question 2: Added Value Cost: Open-source EDA tools eliminate license fees exceeding 1M/year per company. OpenROAD development cost ~$3M/year total -less than three commercial licenses. Lock-in: Open-source silicon enables foundry portability. Foundry PDKs written in proprietary formats lock entire ecosystems to foreign EDA vendors. Security: Open silicon (open all the way to layout) enables public verification that fabricated chips match published layouts (genuine auditability). See the ROCA vulnerability in Estonian ID cards for an example of the problem. Innovation: Open-source enables massive design synthesis parallelization impossible with costly proprietary licenses. OpenROAD achieved 24-hour RTL-to-layout synthesis and 12nm-node capability by 2023. Community-developed PDKs can arguably contain fewer errors through public scrutiny. Concrete examples: Prof. Pretl (JKU Linz) runs complete open-source chip design courses. TinyTapeout democratizes silicon access commercially. IHP's open PDK enabled the first fully-open European chip designs. References: Roadmap §3.2, §4.2, §4.3, §12.1, White Paper §2 For better formatting and for the full text, see attached .pdf

Per favorire l'adozione di tecnologie F/OSS in ambito europeo (e, in particolare, nelle Settore Pubblico) le Università possono svolgere un ruolo fondamentale. Adottando soluzioni F/OSS nei percorsi di studio, possono contribuire da un lato a generare una "consapevolezza di base" da parte degli studenti (risultati long-term), dall'altro a supportare il mercato stimolando lo sviluppo ed il supporto di tali soluzioni (risultati short-term). Nei Dipartimenti e nei percorsi di studio maggiormente orientati alle tecnologie informatiche, si potrebbero avviare delle campegne di "adozione" di almeno uno/due progetti "open-source" di alto profilo, contribuendo allo sviluppo di tali progetti coinvolgendo in modo coordinato tesisti, dottorandi, specializzandi che diverrebbero parte integrante dei team di sviluppo dei progetti selezionati. Tale azione risulterebbe win-win, con l'istituzione accademica (europea) che verrebbe riconosciuta come un vero e proprio contributore open-source, e con il mondo open-source che beneficerebbe delle nuove energie apportate. A livello statale, inoltre, gli Atenei potrebbero essere incentivati all'utilizzo delle soluzioni F/OSS (peraltro gia' previsto in diversi quadri normativi) mediante forme di premialità nei confronti di quei progetti (sia di ricerca che di gestione "operativa") basati, appunto, su tecnologie F/OSS. Le istituzioni Europee potrebbe favorire azioni tese alla costruzione di social-network alternativi, partendo proprio dal mondo accademico e dai relativi studenti. Emblematico è il caso di SURF (https://www.surf.nl/en/mastodon-pilot-for-research-and-education), il cui esperimento "mastodon" ha riscontrato un successo andato oltre le attese. Successo che potrebbe banalmente essere replicato altrove, con ricadute esponenziali circa il numero di utenti ed il numero di messaggi scambiati. Una larga adozione di tecnologie e piattaforme F/OSS nei contesti accademici genererebbe una domanda analoga negli ordinamenti scolastici di rango inferiore (Istruzione di secondo grado e Istruzione di primo grado). A tal riguardo, la dimensione operativa/tecnologica di un singolo Ateneo risulta tale da poter "supportare" un numero relativamente alto di scuole del proprio comprensorio, a cui l'Ateneo potrebbe offrire soluzioni F/OSS in modalità SAAS, continuando cosi' ad espandere la diffusione di tali piattaforme. Con una diffusione significativa nel contesto dell'istruzione (universita' + scuole), finalmente le soluzioni F/OSS entrerebbero nella vita quotidiana dei cittadini i quali inizierebbero a toccare con mano tali soluzioni. Parallelamente a tali iniziative --necessariamente articolate lungo un arco temporale particolarmente ampio-- si potrebbero finanziare progetti specifici volti a realizzare qualcosa di nuovo. Seppur apparentemente banale, lo sviluppo di una piattaforma hardware e software orientata al settore degli smartwatch rappresenta un obiettivo particolarmente importante: lo smartwatch, infatti, è sempre piu' un oggetto che acquisisce e tratta dati personali di particolare importanza. Ad oggi --con l'unica eccezione di AsteroidOS, compatibile con pochissimi smartwatch relativamente obsoleti-- non mi pare esistano smartwatch svincolati da piattaforme cloud USA/CINA. Di nuovo: un OS ed un ecosistema software adatto agli smartwatch potrebbe diventare una piattaforma adatta anche al variegato mondo delle smart-appliance e, a lungo termine, quando sara' risolto il problema dell'hardware, anche agli smartphone. L'esperienza di Huawei, post-ban USA, rappresenta certamente un caso cui ispirarsi (Harmony OS). Trasversalmente a tutte le azioni, la stimolazione di un comparto IT focalizzato su componenti infrastrutturali 100% open-source (OS, Hypervisor, Microservizi e relativi orchestratori, Software-Defined-Storage, Piattaforme di Automazione, Sviluppo Codice, Comunicazione, etc. etc.) favorirebbe ulteriorme

feedback: The Rust programming language project (the language, compiler, standard library, etc.) is increasingly an incredibly important part of many modern open source technology. The Rust project has over a hundred active members (maintainers) and many more contributors. Many of the maintainers and contributors live in the European Union, and the Rust project couldn't exist in its current form without these people. However, compared to those that live in places like the U.S.A., the maintainers and contributors in the EU more often do this work in their free (unpaid) time, rather than as part of their (paid) job. Those that are paid full time to work on Rust often work as contractor or as employee in a place with at-will employment, which has proven to be a big risk for stable continued maintenance of Rust. Stichiting Rust Nederland (aka RustNL) is currently in the process of collecting funds and hiring full time Rust maintainers and contributors in Europe. An issue we run into is the difficulty in paying maintainers across (EU) borders. Within the Netherlands, we can easily offer someone employment. But hiring a (remote) worker in another EU member state is trickier and comes with an unfortunate amount of overhead. A way to employ remote (open source) software engineers across the entire union would be incredibly helpful towards a sustainable future for open source that does not rely on volunteer time or unpredictable employment. Additionally, for those maintainers and contributors that are not seeking (full time) employment, platforms like GitHub Sponsors are a popular choice to provide and receive financial support. While that is in many cases easy for the sponsor, a recipient of the donations in a EU member state is nearly always put in an impossible position with respect to local tax laws. The situation around VAT and local income and gift tax rules w.r.t. such income is very unclear, which has already put some maintainers in trouble with their local tax authority. It would be very helpful if the EU could create a way to sponsor open source maintainers and contributors in the EU without causing them a financial and legal headache.

This contribution is submitted by RIOS, the Italian network of open source enterprises, which brings together companies actively developing, deploying, and maintaining open technologies, with the aim of strengthening high-quality, sustainable open source offerings within the European market. The contribution is intended to complement and support the submission by the Open Source Business Alliance, sharing its core objectives while offering additional perspectives on governance, organisational capacity, and aggregation models. It outlines how open source can act as a strategic enabler for European technological sovereignty when combined with organisational capacity and cooperative scale. The document argues that policy intent alone is insufficient without governance mechanisms capable of translating principles into practice, and highlights aggregation across enterprises, foundations, and institutional networks as a democratic alternative to capital-driven or state-directed approaches to scale, including in emerging domains such as artificial intelligence. Structured open source development modelswhere governance, contribution, and business coexistare identified as key to long-term sustainability and alignment with European values.

Below is a list of proposals, including some examples of financial mechanisms designed to ensure that every Member State (MS) and company contributing Open Source Software (OSS) receives quantifiable EUlevel recognition and compensation, thereby strengthening the overall strategy. [[1. Enhance Transparency & Trust]] Publish full source code so citizens and auditors can verify GDPR compliance. OSS governance makes decision making visible, building confidence in digital public services. Incentive: Transparency grants for repositories certified by an independent auditor. [[2. Avoid Vendor Lock In]] Use open licences (e.g., EUPL) that allow copying, modifying and redistributing software without a single suppliers permission. This enables migration to any cloud or onpremise infrastructure and protects budgets from price spikes or product discontinuations. Incentive: Migration Grant covering a percentage of the annual ICT budget for administrations adopting EUapproved licences. [[3. Reduce Risks]] Full code visibility lets security teams run analyses on the exact deployed version, enabling rapid patching of disclosed vulnerabilities (CVE). [[4. LongTerm Technology Independence]] Rely on open standards and publicly maintained repositories, ensuring the software runs on any platform and is archived on trusted EU mirrors. Incentive: Digital Sovereignty Bonus for States that become OSS development hubs at EU level. [[5. EU Wide Innovation & Shared Costs]] When a MS releases a reusable solution (e.g., digital identity verifier) in a central EU catalogue, other MS can adopt it, sharing expenses. Incentive: Shared code funds allocated based on the number of MS adopting the code. Establish EU wide digital commons foundations that host code, provide longterm stewardship and resolve disputes; mandate maintenance funding to avoid abandonment. [[6. Lower Total Cost of Ownership (TCO)]] Eliminate licence fees, redirect savings to software improvement with EU based contractors. Incentive: OSS Innovation Grant for projects adopted by at least N Member States. [[7. Accelerate Service Delivery]] Publicly shared reusable components (e.g., authentication widgets, dataviz libraries) let ministries build new services quickly, avoiding duplicate development. Incentive: PayPerAdoption Bonus for each new adoption by another MS. [[8. Strengthen EU Digital Sovereignty & Market]] Collaborative OSS projects create a shared digital ecosystem owned by the EU, enabling EU SMEs to develop and commercialise extensions, reducing reliance on non EU tech giants. [[9. Promote Interoperability Across MS]] OSS APIs and reference implementations of standards (e.g., einvoicing, FHIR on health) ensure seamless data exchange and multilingual support, with common authentication (e.g., eIDAS). [[10. Community Innovation]] Open contribution models invite academia, startups and citizen developers to add features. Featurebounty programmes let administrations fund targeted enhancements aligned with policy goals. Incentive: Funding&PPP instruments such as Horizon Europe grant schemes earmarked for OSS R&D and cofinancing models requiring opensource contribution clauses. [[11. AI Readiness]] Well documented repositories serve as context and/or training data for AI assistants, shortening innovation cycles. [[12. Regulatory & Policy Alignment]] Embed OSS compliance into EU legislation (Cloud and AI Development Act, Digital Services Act) and procurement directives (preferopensource clauses); create certification schemes for security, interoperability and sustainability. Incentive: Additional scoring points in publicprocurement tenders for solutions meeting EUlevel OSS compliance. [[13. OpenHardware for Robotics]] Opensource robotic frameworks enable EU manufacturers to build modular, interoperable robots without vendor lockin, fostering crossborder collaboration and security. Incentive: Dedicated Horizon Europ

feedback: AI strategy Theres the idea that Europe is falling behind (compared to the US and China) on AI development. But that narrows it down to generative LLMs (Large language models). Generative LLMs are good at generating text, speech, images, music, etc. But are also used to do math, solve problems. There are computer scientist who believe generative LLMs are a dead end technology and advocate reinforced learning. (see Richard Sutton; https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=21EYKqUsPfg). The human brain works much more efficiently than the current generation LLMs. (see https://www.mpi.nl/news/brains-over-bots-why-toddlers-still-beat-ai-learning-language) I think the best way to address the issue of failling behind, is to invest in a different kind of AI. Another way to address this issue is to adapt the current open source (not open weights) LLMs (Like for instance olmo-3) to areas where the EU has a leading edge. To not compete with general large language models, but to make them excel in certain areas (medical, pharmaceutical) where we excel. This will take less power (which is in Europe expensive) to train. It could also give the AI research back to the open source community and (like China is doing with Qwen and Deepseek) undermine the business case of US AI companies. Another strategy is to thwart the advancement of US AI research. By not allowing ASML to export to the US and at the same time not allowing US companies to provide AI services in the EU the AI bubble could pop. (see https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2025/dec/17/europe-donald-trump-ai-bubble-us-economy-eu) There is also the question whether how much the EU wants outside countries to influence its citizens, especially during elections. Already there are accounts that various generative LLMs are spreading propaganda. (deepseek - https://www.politico.eu/article/we-asked-deepseek-about-geopolitics-chinese-government-propaganda-artificial-intelligence/ . Chatgpt/grok/etc. - https://www.nytimes.com/2025/11/04/business/right-wing-chatbots-gab-arya-chatgpt-gemini.html) People tend to believe the output of generative LLMs. But they forget that these models can hallucinate and are not factchecked) The current European commision wants to simplify legislation to allow AI companies to more easily use data from its citizens. By doing this it could give US companies more access to data of EU citizens. Microsoft and Apple want to integrate AI more and more in its operating systems. Does the European commision fancy the idea that a more hostile US can read from (and even manipulate to some extend its) EU citizens? The US tech companies have close ties to the current US president. By creating a different kind of AI, Europe does not need to loosen its AI regulations.

An earlier anonymous contributor phrased it better than I ever could so I gratefully echo them with some changes: I welcome the initiative for European Open Digital Ecosystems. However, as a citizen concerned with public safety, infrastructure resilience, and the rule of law in an era of hybrid warfare and shifting geopolitical alliances, I urge the Commission to anchor this ecosystem in strict reciprocity and pragmatism. True digital sovereignty cannot exist if governments or giant commercial parties act as 'Free Riders' on the work of open-source communities, nor if we remain dependent on volatile external powers for our digital foundations. Therefore, I strongly suggest the following pillars for a robust strategy: 1. Mandatory Reciprocity & Upstream Obligation - The usage of Open Source Software by public institutions must come with a mandatory 'upstream obligation.' If public funds rely on existing open libraries, kernels, or frameworks, there must be a facilitating contribution in return, be it financial support, developer hours for maintenance, or infrastructure. 'Public Money, Public Code' should not just be about transparency, but about the active maintenance of the digital foundation that guarantees our collective security. This directly supports the EUs goal of Strategic Autonomy by securing the supply chain against neglect and external sabotage. A similar effort should also be induced from commercial entities that choose to use open source software. The EU should somehow help bring this into being. See: https://openssf.org/blog/2025/09/23/open-infrastructure-is-not-free-a-joint-statement-on-sustainable-stewardship/ "[..]a small number of organizations absorb the majority of infrastructure costs, while the overwhelming majority of large-scale users, including commercial entities that generate demand and extract economic value, consume these services without contributing to their sustainability." 2. Extended Right to Repair & Legalised Reverse Engineering - In alignment with the objectives of the Cyber Resilience Act (CRA), reverse engineering must be explicitly legalised in cases where manufacturers fail to provide a proper End-of-Life exit strategy for IoT or networking devices. Abandoned hardware is not just e-waste; it is a potential beachhead for hostile botnets and state-sponsored cyberattacks. If a vendor abandons the security of a device, the community must have the legal right to inspect the firmware and maintain the 'maintenance contract' themselves. Additionally, manufacturers who commercially free-ride on open-source software without honoring the license terms (e.g., GPL violations) must face active penalties. 3. A Decentralised, Scalable 'EuroStack' The Commission should facilitate the creation of a decentralised 'EuroStack': a software and infrastructure standard that is scalable from supranational institutions down to SMEs and the individual self-hosting citizen, prioritising 'local-first' principles and edge processing. This stack must ensure individual data sovereignty independent of hyperscalers, European or not. Lagging governments should be induced and helped to move to European platforms and tools. European countries that develop good platforms should provide English language versions of those platforms to make adoption by other countries attractive at all levels, including lower-level civil servants whose negative responses with regards to user-friendliness often keep alternative systems from being adopted.

feedback: This position paper, submitted by Open Knowledge Sweden, Open Knowledge Foundation, Open Knowledge Finland, and Open Knowledge Estonia, responds to the European Commission's 2026 Call for Evidence on "The European Open Digital Ecosystem Strategy." Drawing on two decades of experience in building and supporting open digital infrastructure, we provide observations and recommendations to advance the EU's strategic approach to open source, emphasizing its role in enhancing technological sovereignty, security, competitiveness, and the Commission's internal use of open digital assets, building on the 2020-2023 Open Source Software Strategy. The EU open-source sector boasts significant strengths, including one of the world's largest developer communities (nearly 25 million EU-based contributors generating over 155 million annual contributions), alignment with EU principles like transparency and GDPR compliance, and contributions to 70-90% of global software codebases. Successes such as FIWARE, RISC-V, and Simpl demonstrate innovation in AI, cloud, and data spaces, contributing 65-95 billion to EU GDP. However, weaknesses include uneven organizational maturity (only 34% have formal strategies; 22% have OSPOs), value exploitation by non-EU entities, and barriers like vendor lock-in, underfunding for maintenance, legal concerns, and skill gaps, which hinder adoption, contributions, and scaling. Open source adds substantial value to public and private sectors by enabling sovereignty, cost savings, reduced lock-in, enhanced security, and innovation. Public examples include France's Nextcloud deployments and Estonia's X-Road for efficient, resilient e-services; private benefits encompass productivity gains (63% of organizations) and competitiveness in telecom and automotive. Key factors: TCO reduction, transparency, and collaborative ecosystems. To support growth, we recommend dedicated funding (e.g., 1-2 billion via Digital Europe Programme), "open by default" procurement with EU-owned company preferences (EuroStack), sovereign infrastructure (e.g., expanding Codeberg/Gaia-X), public-private partnerships, cybersecurity mandates, and capacity building. Prioritize technology areas like open AI, cloud/edge, cybersecurity tools, RISC-V hardware, and IoT/industrial applications due to high dependencies and sovereignty risks. Amplify OSS in sectors such as public administration, healthcare, automotive, energy, and finance/telecom to boost competitiveness and resilience. These measures will unlock open source's potential, reducing external dependencies, fostering innovation, and positioning the EU as a global leader in resilient digital ecosystems. We urge swift implementation through pilots and monitoring to achieve quick wins.

feedback: Nivenly Foundation is a US-based non-profit migrating to the European Union; however, no established migration pathway exists for smaller foundations. Legal structures vary by country, guidance is fragmented, and qualified expertise is difficult to access. We are grateful for this opportunity to share our expertise and experiences on this matter.

From the perspective of an agency managing director who has been developing community-oriented open-source software for 30 years and offering services with it, I very much welcome the move toward digital sovereignty. For far too long we have talked about it and often met with deaf ears. It is very nice to see that governments are committing to digital sovereignty and making it clear in strategy papers that they want to position themselves more independently. Kudos. What I observe at the same time, however, is that the core of public tenders is not changing substantially. Too often, the really relevant tenders are crafted in such a way that they target the same players who previously sold closed-source instead of open-source. When tenders require annual revenues that even a bidding consortium of 10 community-oriented agencies together cannot reach, in the end, for those who develop the open-source software, only the status of a subcontractor remains. We know this already. Up front, the millions are pocketed and supposedly clever consultant days are sold, and when it finally comes to the actual implementation with FLOSS, the price is squeezed. There would only be leftover budget now anyway, and the community should just be happy about the reference. Sustainability and a worthwhile ecosystem work differently. Create opportunities right from the very start for bidders who contribute significantly to FLOSS to be considered. These are often rather small companies that, together with other small and larger companies and many freelancers worldwide, develop great software. Demand proof of contributions. Demand concepts on how reuse will be enabled. Use taxpayer money sensibly. Strengthen entrepreneurs, not corporations. Strengthen your local economy. They pay taxes where you are, too. Great FLOSS has relevant contributors in every country.
organization: Gesellschaft zur Entwicklung von Dingen mbH

feedback: Please find attached our feedback as the Matrix.org Foundation. To summarise, whilst the EU open source sector is very dynamic and, in aggregate across all countries, is at level with the US, it suffers from a different set of weaknesses. In particular the lack of recurring funding and revenue limits its evolution and scalability. Part of it is due to the belief that open source is free and overall lack of contribution back from organisations relying on open source. There are also logistical issues making it hard for some projects to set-up the right entity to actually receive financial contributions. Besides, the lack of interoperability and standardisation creates a very fragmented market which dilutes its energy competing locally rather than against the real threat. And eventually the lack of adoption by the private sector, due to lack of understanding of the added value and often subpar usability of the open source solution slows the growth of the ecosystem. Open source and open standards positively impact the world across the board: from the economy, to businesses and society at large. Our recommendations are split across two main themes. First the need for more recurring contributions to the projects, and second the need to unlock the collaboration within the open source ecosystem and with the rest of the industry to increase the use of open source and open standards, ultimately bringing more digital sovereignty and growth to the European economy. The former can be achieved by mandating upstream contribution within public sector procurement, promoting frameworks providing a sovereignty-check, mandating contributions for profitable organisations, setting up an EU-STF, and supporting open source projects in setting up legal structures and governance. The latter can be achieved by pushing for interoperability and open standards, supporting user-facing open source applications in their UX improvements, and providing tools for organisations to quantify their technological dependence to ease investment prioritisation.

feedback: Most open source applications lack good user interfaces, user excperience, and design. Less skilled users are either not aware of the existence of open source alternatives or are turned off by the inferior user experience. Sometimes it's hard to decide which ones to use because there are too many competing (often mediocre) products. Most open source applications do not integrate /interoperate well with each other. That is in contrast to the app suites (docs, calendar, mail, ...) of Google, Apple or Microsoft: one account only, applications share data, e.g. of contacts, events, settings, ... To foster trust in applications, privacy friendly solutions are crucial, especially through encryption.

Il superpotere dell'europa è la capacità di regolamentare. Non possiamo creare dal nulla realtà cloud come AWS, Azure, Oracle e amici, ma possiamo regolamentare un sistema di armonizzazione dei servizi cloud, che permetta ai clienti di usare servizi di cloud di diversi provider europei come se fossero un unico cloud; questo aumenterebbe la concorrenza e la trasparenza nell'utilizzo, effettivamente obbligando alla collaborazione diversi provider di servizi. Questo atteggiamento può essere conseguito con strumenti open source. Un altro punto interessante potrebbe essere la possibilità di invitare la pubblica amministrazione allo sviluppo di codice open source, per i propri progetti: in questo modo i progetti software che ora sono sviluppati ad-hoc per ogni realtà, possono diventare progetti di più ampio respito, nazionale o addirittura europeo. Per un piccolo comune questo può voler dire poter accedere ad un software che prima aveva un costo di licenza (e vendor lock-in) inarrivabile. Una svolta interessante sarebbe poter trovare un modo di retribuire gli sviluppatori opensource che ora sono volontari: grandi talenti possono trovare il modo di rendere l'opensource la loro fonte di guadagno primaria.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: Europe’s superpower is its ability to regulate. We cannot create cloud realities like AWS, Azure, Oracle and friends from scratch, but we can regulate a system of harmonisation of cloud services, allowing customers to use cloud services from different European providers as if they were one cloud; this would increase competition and transparency in usage, effectively obliging different service providers to collaborate. This can be achieved with open source tools. Another interesting point could be the possibility to invite the public administration to develop open source code for their projects: in this way, software projects that are now developed ad hoc for each reality can become larger, national or even European projects. For a small municipality, this may mean being able to access software that previously had an uncomfortable cost of licensing (and vendor lock-in). An interesting step would be to find a way to pay opensource developers who are now volunteers: great talent can find ways to make opensource their primary source of earnings.

feedback:
Very thanks for this open call and the opportunity for general public inquiry submissions. In this words will be tried to show how European union has an unique golden opportunity for at the same time, effort and cost, solve the open source setbacks and technology lockups while at same time show everyone, and future generations, that EU is a transparent construction of a functional society and not, as its publicly labeled, a bureaucratic dysfunctional regulator. 1) First, Open source as is, has a troubled flaw that needs to be understood: the source code. i)Technology diverged from classical human knowledge and science methods and any future innovation needs to be understood and used as a tool, knowledge or science like everything in the last centuries or general human survival is at risk. ii)EU needs to understood technology as a tool, knowledge or science and displace software as product, service or whatever business model the vendor decided to lock everyone in. 2) Software became essential to our daily lives and requirement for society functionality. Having this locked and controlled by a few third parties, even if open source where mandatory, having this in the form of source code that only the same few third parties can manage is a returning to a medieval society with its feudalism from the illiterates to the clergy. For the current technology not to overcame society its mandatory that only exists in the form of manageable parts and never as an complex single end product locked to a vendor. 3) European commission has an remarkable president today, Von der Leyen superior vision, wisdom and work capabilities makes her almost extraterrestrial by the current worldwide political landscape. Every person involved in this matter needs to be a Von der Leyen, our societies are at risk with the unbalanced power of technology on today society. EU needs a superior vision from the wisdom perspective to solve this. Not extensive regulation, neither one single euro wasted, just wisdom vision. Like bureaucratic processes or law, with fundamental foundation, before the final specific definition, software need to be broken and only considered as a sum of parts, like law, knowledge, science or human tools that made us today. EU needs to define in law the method to define software and technology. Not even compilers function from source code today, they use Intermediary Representations (IR), some programming vendors prefer a Virtual Machine (VM) approach, and there are universal runtimes like Web Assembly or compute language. i) In a very short way, a law approach like the Touring Machine, simple and short basic way that IRs, VMs and runtimes could be defined. And open source organization and individuals can build standard reusable exchange building blocks. ii) At acquisition time, like any bureaucratic process, options are evaluated from the evaluation of its parts. And with time, the most successful evaluated parts will archive success final evaluation. iii) The technology for archiving this is already exists, no need to throw more money in it. Decentralized Identifiers in the form of DID documents already prove claims in form of credentials, using DIDs to prove anything digital as a universal description for anything technological. Any technology can be made transitioned, archived and verified in the form of a DID document. DIDs and the existent decentralized systems (that can be referred from a DID) are enough for true digital sovereignty and security, with a true open public participation on manageable parts. 4) The most urgent needs are Digital Identity and network decentralization, for technological sovereignty and security of our societies. 5) Every sector urgently needs its associated technology to be broken in to manageable parts, for real concurrency at each part, otherwise resilience and competitiveness will never be archived. Only in a constant interchange

feedback: We welcome the opportunity to contribute to the European Open Digital Ecosystems Strategy. Open digital ecosystems are a prerequisite for scalable compliance, supply-chain security, and long-term competitiveness. The Open Regulatory Compliance WG advocates achieving digital sovereignty by retaining operational control over technology, rather than focusing on the geographic origin of code, in order to avoid isolating Europe from global open source innovation. We outline six key areas of action to support resilient and compliant open source supply chains: - Practical Portability and Interoperability: Support open, documented APIs and formats for project data (issues, CI, metadata) to reduce platform lock-in, improve business continuity, and increase resilience. - Resilient Digital Services: Ensure that critical infrastructure like package repositories and registries have resilience through contingency planning, federated services, EU-based mirrors, and archival layers like Software Heritage. This requires a shift to an 'Upstream First' development and security model. - Open Source Attestations: Standardise and support verifiable attestations to provide continuous trust and lightweight evidence of compliance with regulations like the Cyber Resilience Act (CRA). Open source Foundations should be enabled to act as neutral facilitators of this infrastructure. - Compliance Enablement through Open Source Tools: Promote and support open source compliance tooling (SBOM generation, vulnerability tracking, provenance) to lower implementation costs and enable efficient compliance for all manufacturers, especially SMEs. - Reliable Identification of Software Components: Endorse content-based, persistent identifiers such as Package-URL or SWHIDs as best practices for CRA-aligned SBOMs to strengthen traceability and long-term auditability. - Responsible Use of Open Source in AI Development: Promote traceability and accountability mechanisms that link AI-generated code back to archived origins, reducing legal uncertainty and maintaining trust in AI-assisted development. In conclusion, the most effective path forward is not additional regulation of open source, but targeted support for the infrastructure, practices, and tooling that enable regulation to be implemented efficiently The ORC WG recommends that the European Commission: - Recognise open source as a Global community asset and treat its infrastructure (forges, repositories, build systems) as a strategic asset. - Strengthen continuous trust through open source attestations and develop specific regulatory guidance to support non-commercial open source Foundations acting as neutral facilitators. - Promote interoperability and portability by design and Ensure Friction-Free Access to Open Standards. - Enable compliance through open source tooling. - Strengthen software traceability and supply-chain trust by endorsing persistent identifiers (Package-URL, SWHIDs). - Align AI, software, and cybersecurity policies to promote responsible use of open source code in AI training. - Promote Upstream First development and security models. Please check the attachment for further details.

feedback: The European Open Digital Ecosystem Strategy represents a critical opportunity to transform open source from a hidden dependency into a deliberate instrument of industrial policy, cybersecurity and technological sovereignty. In a future characterized by converging IoTEdgeCloud continua, AI-native 6G networks, Intelligent Internet of Intelligent Things, autonomous systems, quantum computing threats, pervasive zero-trust requirements, etc. the strategy must go beyond supporting isolated open-source projects. It requires building a comprehensive European ecosystem spanning: 1) Technology - Open reference stacks for continuum, 6G, edge intelligence, autonomous systems, quantum-safe cryptography and zero-trust security. 2) Governance - EU-centered foundations and transparent governance frameworks. 3) Business models - Sustainable pathways from research to industrial deployment and commercial viability. 4) Skills - Education and training for multi-disciplinary open-source development. 5) Policy - Procurement, regulatory and funding frameworks that systematically favour open, sovereign solutions. The measures proposed in this response - stable lifecycle funding, open reference architectures, domain-specific foundations, adapted procurement, shared infrastructure, quantum-safe roadmaps and zero-trust integration - provide a concrete pathway to realize this vision. Success will be measured not just by the volume of open-source code produced in Europe, but by: 1) The proportion of critical digital infrastructure running on trustable, auditable, European-anchored open platforms. 2) The number of viable European companies and foundations providing open-source-based solutions. 3) The degree of technological sovereignty in sectors from telecommunications and cloud to automotive, manufacturing and public services. 4) The resilience of European digital systems to supply-chain attacks, vendor failures and emerging quantum threats. This Call for Evidence provides a unique opportunity for stakeholders across the European open-source ecosystem - developers, companies, foundations, public administrations, research institutions and civil society - to shape a strategy that will define Europe's digital future for decades to come. The proposed answers directly address the initiative's key objectives by discussing the added value of open source across public and private sectors, proposing concrete measures for deployment infrastructure, software supply chain security and project sustainability through stable lifecycle funding and EU-centered governance frameworks, outlining viable business models and public-private partnership mechanisms, identifying best practices and procurement reforms to encourage contribution and adoption, and prioritizing technology areas and sectors where open source can achieve successful market integration alongside legacy systems through interoperable reference architectures and policy alignment.

feedback: Meiner Meinung nach spielt Freie Software eine entscheidende Rolle für die digitale Souveränität und Innovationskraft der Europäischen Union. Sie fördert diese, indem sie offene Standards und Wahlfreiheit bietet. Das ist besonders wichtig, da Abhängigkeiten von proprietären Lösungen die Selbstbestimmung und Innovationskraft europäischer Unternehmen einschränken. Eine Implementierung verbindlicher offener Standards ist notwendig, um die Optionen für öffentliche Institutionen und Unternehmen zu erweitern - Ähnliches ist nämlich auch bereits durch die OpenData-Intiative gezeigt worden. Ein klarer rechtlicher Rahmen zur Unterstützung von offenen und interoperablen Dateiformaten ist unerlässlich, um die Datensicherheit zu garantieren. Öffentliche Institutionen sollten verpflichtet werden, ausschließlich offene Formate zu verwenden. Durch diese Maßnahmen würde nicht nur die Zugänglichkeit von Daten erhöht werden, sondern auch die Marktbedingungen für Open-Source-Lösungen würden verbessert werden. Außerdem sind echte Wahlmöglichkeiten bei Betriebssystemen und Anwendungen entscheidend für die Schaffung eines vielfältigen digitalen Marktes. Die EU muss sicherstellen, dass öffentliche Ausschreibungen Open-Source-Lösungen bevorzugen, um eine größere Auswahl und Wettbewerb zu gewährleisten, was auch eine Anpassung der bestehenden Beschaffungsrichtlinien erfordert. Es wird Zeit für ein Memorandum zu Freier und Open Source Software in der Beschaffungspolitik. Es ist zu sagen, die gezielte Unterstützung europäischer Open-Source-Projekte reduziert die Abhängigkeit von ausländischen Technologien und fördert das eigene Know-How in diesem Bereich. Investitionen in die Entwicklung und Wartung von Open-Source-Infrastrukturen sowie in die Ausbildung von Experten sind entscheidend, um Innovationen innerhalb Europas zu erhalten. Ebenso sei erwähnt, vor dem Hintergrund der aktuellen globalen Spannungen ist die Unabhängigkeit in der digitalen Infrastruktur von äußerster Bedeutung. Lösungen, die auf offenen Standards basieren, können Resilienz und Sicherheit bieten. Ein Umstieg auf offene Schnittstellen und Dateiformate in kritischen Infrastrukturen ist notwendig, um zukünftige Risiken zu minimieren und die Handlungsfähigkeit der Europäischen Union zu sichern. Offene Standards und Freie Software sind essentielle Treiber für technologische Innovationen. Daher ist ein transparenter Prozess zur Integration von Freier Software wichtig, um das Vertrauen der Bürgerinnen und Bürger zu gewinnen. Durch gezielte politische Maßnahmen für offene Standards kann die EU ihre digitale Souveränität und Innovationskraft steigern. Ich bin überzeugt, es ist entscheidend, eine aktive Rolle in der Gestaltung der digitalen Zukunft zu übernehmen und die dazugehörigen Daten in Europa zu halten. Daher plädiere ich dazu, dass die EU ihren Weg in Sachen Software übedenken sollte - weg von proprietären Lösungen hin zu Freien Alternativen. Das wäre wichtig für die digitale Zukunft Europas.

A clear legal framework supporting open and interoperable file formats is essential to guarantee data security. Public institutions should be obliged to use only open formats. feedback: Symfony welcomes the opportunity to provide evidence for the European Commissions Open Digital Ecosystem Strategy. As a European-born open source PHP framework that now powers over 20% of the professional web and supports a global community of 600,000 developers, our contribution is attached and focuses on five key areas: 1) we advocate for open source as a foundational infrastructure for European digital autonomy. 2) we propose contribute-back procurement mandates and a permanent EU FOSSA program to ensure long-term maintenance. 3) we suggest investing in the mid-stack frameworks where European business logic lives to avoid vendor lock-in. 4) we address the risks that AI poses to the developer talent pipeline and the professional craft. 5) we call for direct financial and legal support for the developers who are the architects of Europe's digital autonomy.

Europe fuels the open-source fire. We are world-class, yet we consistently fumble the cash our developers crank out. If we want true tech sovereignty, we have to stop the charity vibe. It is time to treat Open Source Software like prime real estate, a killer asset class. Right now, the VC gap is choking us. European capital shies away from slick models like Open Core or Managed Services because they do not always get the playbook. The Commission needs to step up and spin a dedicated European OSS Fund. Co-invest with VCs, slash the risks, and fuel those long runs to global domination. Cash alone will not fix it. We need to ditch the fluffy innovation grants and go hard on commercialization. Standard hackathons are a yawn, low stakes and academic traps. We should fire up Industrial Grand Challenges instead with prizes over 1M Euro that are fat and fierce. We need to target open, interoperable rivals to those fat-cat foreign stacks, igniting real competition that shatters markets far beyond lab dreams. Our biggest bazooka is procurement muscle. Mandate that 10% of IT budgets go to local OSS SMEs for support and tweaks. This creates instant demand, allowing firms to scale without begging foreign VCs for scraps too soon. We also need three-year Sovereign Tech Bounties to lock in maintenance and security for critical gear. The success metric should not be the size of our code piles, but our ownership share and the sustained commerce within our own ecosystem. It is time to flip the script from technical brilliance to market rule by brewing capital havens tuned for the unique open-source lifecycle.

We welcome the opportunity to contribute to the European Open Digital Ecosystems Strategy. Free and open source software is a key enabler of Europes technological sovereignty, competitiveness and digital resilience. By reducing strategic dependencies, increasing transparency and strengthening security and interoperability, open source provides a practical foundation for resilient European digital value chains across critical sectors. The Eclipse Foundation is a Brussels-based, international non-profit association that provides a vendor-neutral and business-friendly environment for open source collaboration and innovation. PLEASE SEE ATTACHED DOCUMENT FOR OUR FEEDBACK

In this feedback I will be focusing mainly on the question of benefits of FOSS: The benefits of FOSS are numerous and interconnected. > Sovereignty >> Exploitation In the example of Microsoft vs IBM, Microsoft showed that software platforms dominate markets, and closed-source, for-profit platforms stifle competition. At some point, for-profit companies reach a plateau of new customers and simply need to charge existing customers more to achieve growth. For-profit companies also disregard possible long-lasting damage to society. For example, Meta (formerly Facebook) suppressed internal research showing that its platform leads to various mental health harms. >> Politics Technology cannot be separated from politics. This is evident in cases such as Microsoft suspending services for ICC judge Karim Khan. Foreign for-profit companies obey the actions of foreign leaders. For example, Trump threatened to pull the broadcasting license of CBS. Currently, with such high dependence on foreign software and services, the EU is indefensible against hostile foreign acts. It is important to note that possible hostile actions by foreign for-profit companies will be commanded by foreign leaders, not by CEOs. When assessing trust in a foreign company (for example, Microsoft), it is not enough to consider only its for-profit motives; we must also consider the foreign leader who might command hostile actions (for example, Trump). This means we should not ask ourselves if we trust Microsoft, but if we trust Trump. > Cost Effectiveness Open source is a long-term, cost-effective solution. The narrative of for-profit companies is that the total cost of ownership is lower with a subscription, but in the long term, these companies exploit users as the cost of switching becomes prohibitive. Using FOSS in corporate environments is not necessarily free, as there are maintenance and support costs, but software subscription costs are greatly reduced. For example, the mandatory upgrade from Windows 10 to Windows 11 rendered millions of PCs obsolete or a security risk due to a one-sided decision by a for-profit company. Such actions do not align with EU environmental goals or basic consumer protection. A clear example of cost effectiveness is the use of FOSS by large hyperscalers like Google and Amazon. These companies use Linux as the basis for their services because the costs of depending on for-profit OS manufacturers would be exorbitant. They also benefit from the ability to adapt the OS to their exact needs. > Personal Mental Freedom The digital tools we use become an extension of ourselves. Time invested in learning to use digital tools can be wasted if users lose access to them. Creative software now costs an exorbitant amount for starting artists or non-professionals. If an artist loses a job and thus access to such tools (usually paid for by their employer), they lose their main creative instrument. In contrast, if the education system relies on FOSS tools, artists always retain access to their learned skills. The years invested in personal education cannot be taken away by a company raising prices or changing the work environment. > Shared Infrastructure FOSS should be viewed as shared infrastructure. The EU should not be breeding future predators, but should instead develop efficient digital infrastructure that everyday citizens can use in their daily work and that companies can use to run their businesses efficiently and safely: without the risk of spiking costs or foreign interference. The EU should strive for interoperability and open formats, providing future innovative companies with a larger pool of users.

feedback: Open Source software is the surest way for the EU to gain tech sovereignty. Furthermore it protects customers from vendor lock-in.

Merci à la Commission européenne pour avoir lancé cette consultation sur les écosystèmes numériques ouverts européens. En tant que citoyen européen travaillant sur Internet, je suis particulièrement attentif aux enjeux des usages de l'internet et de son impact sur nos sociétés. Je suis promoteur du logiciel libre qui véhicule des valeurs de partage et de progrès équitable. Je me félicite que la commission d'y intéresse pour assurer lindépendance technologique de l'Europe et assurer son développement économique. J'espère qu'elle utilisera aussi le logiciel libre comme un levier pour réduire les inégalités, briser les monopoles et garantir une technologie au service du bien commun. Dans le document ci-joint, je réponds aux cinq questions de la consultation avec mes réflexions du moment. Les actions que je propose pour la prochaine stratégie européenne pour un écosystème numérique ouvert incluent, entre autres, la création dun fonds souverain européen pour financer des projets Open Source à fort impact, la réforme des marchés publics (principe « argent public = code public »), et la création dun cadre darbitrage sur les licences Open Source pour sécuriser l'écosystème libre et la création de logiciels ouvertement compatibles avec le RGPD ou le DSA.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: Thank you to the European Commission for launching this consultation on European open digital ecosystems. As a European citizen working on the Internet, I am particularly attentive to the issues surrounding the use of the Internet and its impact on our societies. I am a promoter of open source software that conveys values of sharing and equitable progress. I welcome the Committee’s interest in ensuring Europe’s technological dependence and economic development. I hope it will also use open source software as a lever to reduce inequalities, break monopolies and ensure technology for the common good. In the attached document, I answer the five questions of the consultation with my thoughts of the moment. The actions I propose for the next European strategy for an open digital ecosystem include, among others, the creation of a European sovereign fund to finance high-impact Open Source projects, the reform of public procurement (principle “public money = public code”), and the creation of an arbitration framework on Open Source licences to secure the free ecosystem and the creation of software openly compatible with the GDPR or the DSA.

feedback: Proxmox VE: European Excellence in Virtualization When discussing technological sovereignty and open-source innovation in Europe, Proxmox Virtual Environment deserves special recognition. This Austrian-developed virtualization platform perfectly embodies what the EU's digital strategy aims to achieve: independent, transparent, and high-quality technological solutions. At SOKOM SRL, we've been relying on Proxmox since 2008, and this long-term relationship speaks volumes about the platform's reliability and evolution. Over these years, we've witnessed Proxmox grow from a promising solution into a mature, enterprise-grade virtualization platform that consistently meets our evolving needs. What makes Proxmox truly special is its European DNA. Developed in Vienna by Proxmox Server Solutions GmbH, it represents a success story of how European companies can compete with global tech giants while maintaining values of transparency and user respect. In today's geopolitical landscape, having a trusted European alternative matters more than ever. The open-source nature of Proxmox is its greatest strength. Built on Debian Linux, KVM, and LXC, the platform offers complete code transparencyno hidden surprises, no vendor lock-in, just pure freedom to adapt and modify according to your needs. This transparency is crucial for security audits and regulatory compliance, particularly important for European organizations. From a practical standpoint, Proxmox is remarkably versatile. It handles both full virtualization and lightweight containers effortlessly, making it suitable for virtually any workload. The web-based interface is intuitive enough for quick deployment yet powerful enough for complex enterprise scenarios. Features like high-availability clustering, integrated backup systems, and live migration work seamlessly out of the box. Security-wise, Proxmox takes no shortcuts. Regular updates, robust access controls, and two-factor authentication ensure your infrastructure remains protected. Our experience since 2008 confirms this platform's stability and security credentials. Proxmox proves that European open-source projects can deliver world-class solutions, supporting the EU's vision of technological independence and digital sovereignty.

The EU is a major player in the global open-source sector, hosting many open-source software projects and contributors. The R project is one example of this: a third of the core development team are in the EU, the non-profit R Foundation that supports the project is seated in Austria, and R is one of the few OSS projects with a package repository hosted in the EU. Many open-source projects with a substantial footing in the EU - either via their development and governance or via their userbase - are critically underfunded and facing a sustainability crisis. R, being free software, gives its users the freedom to explore how computations are performed in every necessary detail. Access to this information is crucial for faster innovation (standing on the shoulders of giants and being able to learn from the best), quality assurance (ensuring correctness of results), and long-term reproducibility (assessing analyses done a long time ago). The large pool of add-on packages for specialised analyses (currently > 23'000 packages hosted on https://CRAN.R-project.org) with standardised installation procedures across all major platforms allows users to deliver high-quality data products and implement even very complex analyses quickly and reliably. Free software development crucially relies on a secure infrastructure for project communication, software deployment, unit testing, and hosting of dedicated services. Offering reliable, secure, and stable hosting and communication services, as well as access to computing environments for software testing and building, would help contributors to the R Project to concentrate more on software development and maintenance. As a beneficiary of investment from the Sovereign Tech Agency, we welcome the call for an EU Sovereign Tech Fund (https://eu-stf.openforumeurope.org/) that can secure and maintain critical open-source software. It is important that there are long-term sources of funding for open-source projects and that all states benefiting from open-source contribute to such funding. We would also like to see the development of mechanisms by which users of OSS, in both the public and private sectors, contribute back financially to open-source. As a software project rooted in academia, we welcome innovative approaches to academic institutions supporting OSS. There are many directions this could take including creation of national or European Research Software Institutes, creation of Open Source Program Offices within universities, funding for maintenance and development of existing research software (not only new research software), funding of academic positions focused on OSS development, and promoting good practices for recognising OSS as a research output. Creating a culture and environment in which free software projects can flourish and contributors can put their time to good use, seems more beneficial than a top-down list of projects, areas, or tasks to be prioritised. However, technology that would be of wide benefit to OSS projects (e.g. ForgeFed) should be strong candidates, alongside implementing high accessibility standards and supporting localisation of OSS, so that everyone can benefit. The primary, secondary, and tertiary education systems should exclusively use and provide free software for learning, training, and research. Allowing the next generation to take ownership and responsibility for the free software environment is the least expensive and most efficient way to increase competence, competitiveness, and resilience. Projects helping schools and universities to achieve this goal are candidates for prioritisation. We attach a full response that includes more detail on barriers that hamper maintenance of high-quality and secure OSS and concrete examples of the added value of open source.

With open standard it's possible to achieve interoperability, which can allow us more easily to replace one solution with another. The benefit of free and open source software is transparency, cooperation to not invent the wheel in other way. The last thing is, the open protocols and open source are nothing if we can't use it. I am Director of Strategic Partnerships for DataKind, a global nonprofit that develops open source digital products and data-powered tools for the social sector, including a Digital Public Goods Alliance-certified solution. DataKind views a healthy open source sector as essential public-good infrastructure, and so welcomes the European Open Digital Ecosystem Strategy and commends the EUs leadership in advancing an open and secure digital landscape. Open source makes a crucial contribution to a strategic framework for the EUs technological sovereignty, competitiveness, and cybersecurity, while enabling inclusive and resilient innovation ecosystems across sectors. As a global ecosystem, open source relies on maintainers and contributor communities who act as stewards of critical digital infrastructure. The reliable and thoughtful investment in the development, maintenance, and long-term sustainability of open source technologies can play a crucial role in enabling cross-border collaboration and innovation towards addressing urgent social, environmental, and humanitarian challenges. We strongly support the establishment of an EU Sovereign Tech Fund and encourage the creation of funding frameworks that minimize bureaucratic barriers and are accessible to maintainers, small teams, and community-led initiatives. We also advocate for actively involving the open source community in decision-making mechanisms. Supporting the open-source sectors ability to grow and develop further will produce lasting public value and cross-sector benefit.

Verda's response addresses Europe's open source software strategy through three interconnected pillars. The first, "Public-Sector Stewardship" advocate for "open by default" policies where government systematically publish code, contribute upstream, and establish OSPO capacity to professionalize engagement with open digital commons. The second pillar, "Sustainable & Secure Foundations" emphasizes funding the critical "middle" of the OSS lifecycle. The maintenance, security engineering, and supply-chain integrity, treating widely relied-upon components as strategic infrastructure requiring sustained investment rather than depending solely on voluntary effort. The third, "Market Integration & Scaling" calls for "earned preference" procurement that rewards quality and operational maturity, commercialization support beyond research funding, and cross-border operationalization through instruments like the Digital Commons EDIC. Throughout, we emphasize that Europe's sovereignty depends not only on open code, but on European capacity to maintain, secure, and deploy it at production scale. Our recommendations align with the Commission's full-lifecycle framing and the Draghi competitiveness priorities of focus, reduced friction, and measurable adoption outcomes. Please see our attachment for our full feedback.

feedback: Open source is a key in EUs tech sovereignty, as the code is public and not controlled by any state. It drives competitiveness, as collaboration allow to grow really fast comparing to closed source projects. Open source is also the only way to provide transparency for citizens privacy, who will know where their data go and where they are hosted. Open source and open data is a key that accessibility and usability of a service can be ensured in the long term. Barrier against open source adoption is often the lack of information, marketing and advertisement for open source solutions comparing to its challengers. Barrier to open source adoption comes also from the lack of commercial support. For example, it is difficult to find a Linux user ready laptop for desktop in stores, when it is very easy to find MacOS or Windows laptops. EU can help open source durability, investing in some key projects, avoiding critical components being sometimes maintained by small and under-resourced teams. EU can provide help to open source projects with governance and compliance, potentially helping to build non-profit organization/foundation to sustain some of those key projects and their community. This way, EU would avoid non EU jurisdictional control over key platforms. AI, big data, cloud, smartphone ecosystem and open hardware should be prioritized first, are they are crucial for sovereignty and everyday life of both citizens and industry.
