feedback: AI Chamber CEE provides comments on the European Open Digital Ecosystem Strategy, with particular attention to the implications for innovation and the competitiveness of SMEs. An open digital ecosystem (open source) should be treated as an instrument of the EUs strategic digital autonomy rather than merely a technical choice. While OSS underpins an estimated 7090% of code in the digital economy, a significant share of the economic value and scaling capacity generated by European communities is captured outside the EU. This results in technological dependencies (including on cloud services), reduced competition, and heightened risks to cybersecurity and the resilience of public services. From the perspective of SMEs, the key barriers are: (1) insufficient access to capital and support instruments for the scale-up phase and for long-term maintenance of critical components; (2) a shortage of shared infrastructure (secure build and distribution, signing, SBOM, compliance testing, registries); (3) vendor lock-in and data-format lock-in; (4) excessively high entry costs for public procurement and insufficient contracting authority capability to assess and implement OSS; and (5) uncertainty regarding the allocation of compliance obligations across the supply chainan issue that disproportionately burdens SMEs. Recommended EU-level measures: Lifecycle funding instead of R&D-only support: establish a Sovereign Tech Fundtype mechanism covering maintenance, audits, hardening, bug bounties, and support for maintainers of critical components, with streamlined access paths for SMEs and small teams. Digital Commons EDIC as durable, cross-border infrastructure: provide shared services (CI/CD, signing, SBOM, vulnerability scanning, mirroring) and deployment incubation so that SMEs can build products on common assets without prohibitive capital barriers. Public procurement: require criteria for open standards and interoperability, and assess TCO including switching/exit costs; provide template specifications and training for contracting authorities; ensure proportional requirements and genuine market access for SMEs. Establish an EU-level open by default policy for software developed with public funding, with strictly limited, proportionate derogations where required by public security, critical infrastructure protection, or other overriding public-interest considerations; ensure practical guidance on licensing and reuse. Consistency with the Cyber Resilience Act (CRA) and the AI Act: provide compliance toolkits and templates; support security by design (including memory safety), while ensuring proportional obligations to avoid a chilling effect on SMEs and non-commercial projects. Synergies with the forthcoming CADA and HPC/AI/edge initiatives: ensure SME access to compute capacity, testing and validation (e.g., through AI Factories), so that openness translates into competitive deployments in the EU. The strategy should include measurable KPIs (e.g., uptake of open standards in procurement, number of supported critical components, time-to-remediate vulnerabilities, SME participation in projects and procurement) as well as stable funding and clear implementation accountability.

Many business endeavours in the EU and the world are only possibly because they build upon OSS. The EU has an inherent advantage here, since many of these OSS projects are developed by EU citizens and thus often already tailor made for European needs. Should the rate of publication and development of OSS ever decline, the impact on the european economy could be significant and would likely be felt within at most 18 months Thus the EU should capitalize on its advantage, by promoting and supporting OSS development and usage wherever possible. An very easy and cost-neutral approach would be "public money public code", where software that governments are already paying for, can not just double but "tripple" as stepping-stone for the European economy and the European citizen. Governments could support OSS development, not just with grants and by stipulation in their tenders, but also by making it easer for companies and universities to donate to European open source developers. Currently this is often a problem of impractical bureaucracy. Recognizing OSS development (outside a business) as charitable non-profit work, would further help the foundation on which EU software companies build their fortunes. Using exclusively OSS in schools, would better prepare children for work, as OSS is usually better at teaching general principles that can be applied in any similar software. In contrast the goal of commercial software in education (e.g. office365, etc), is not to teach our youth but to exclusively bind our youth to their companies subscription models, thus ensuring that billions of euros will be extracted from the EU by providing the only software that future workers can use, since they actively ensure they were never taught general principles. Lastly, OSS is often far ahead of commercial software in terms of security, cyber resilience, since many different people can and do review the code. If fact, OSS is secure, preciously because it's code can be reviewed. The EU could greatly capitalize on this and save enormously by promoting OSS code reviews. In my opinion, we should establish an EU agency tasked with open-source software security reviews. This agency would proactively audit OSS projects, that can be found online, identify vulnerabilities, and submit security patches directly via pull requests. Thus streamlining the process compared to requiring individual projects to apply for funding. The agency would build credibility through competent contributions and thus als attract developer talent to itself, which European governments are currently in dire lack of. This model would significantly further strengthen OSS security, reduce cybercrime, and enhance local and global software infrastructure.

Open source is meer dan een licentievorm: het is noodzakelijke infrastructuur. Waag Futurelab pleit (net als Open Nederland bij wiens reactie we aansluiten) voor een strategie die transparantie, innovatie en democratische waarden borgt volgens het principe: publiek geld = publieke code. De Nederlandse situatie: beleid en uitvoering Nederland hanteert sinds 2020 het beleid "Open, tenzij". Wij waarschuwen de EC voor een stap terug. Termen als "Open where appropriate" of open source als "experimenteel" zien ondermijnd bestaande ontwikkelingen en infrastructuur. De strategie moet niet gaan over het opzetten van een ecosysteem, maar het versterken van het huidige, fragiele ecosysteem door professionalisering en infrastructuur-financiering. 1. Sterktes, Zwaktes & Barrières Strengths: Verankering van publieke waarden: waaronder transparantie, veiligheid, competitie (op diensten). Bewezen maatschappelijke en economische waarde: Bestaande Initiatieven als het EDIC en opensourcewerken.nl maken van de publieke sector een vliegwiel voor innovatie. Weaknesses: Kennishiaten: Economische waarde vloeit weg naar andere regio's door gebrek aan business-kennis. Afhankelijkheid: Europa mist soevereine open source infrastructuren. We leunen op Big Tech. Onderhoud: Geld gaat naar 'nieuwe features' (projectfinanciering), niet naar beheer (infrastructuur). AI-dreiging: AI-modellen, getraind op open code, ondermijnen het verdienmodel van dienstverleners en tasten de 'commons' aan. Barrières: Financieringskloof: Subsidies stoppen na de innovatiefase; er is geen geld voor structureel onderhoud. Aanbestedingen: Tenders stellen eisen aan organisaties die gemeenschappen uitsluiten. Er mist een eis voor 'upstream contribution', waardoor leveranciers wel nemen maar niet geven. Juridische onzekerheid: Wetgeving zoals de CRA creëert aansprakelijkheidsrisico's die individuele ontwikkelaars wegjagen. 2. Waardepropositie Publieke Sector: Soevereiniteit: Geen vendor lock-in, volledige controle over eigen infrastructuur. Vertrouwen: Controleerbare code en functionaliteit. baten: Onderzoek schat de maatschappelijke baten van Open Overheid op 4,4 miljard/jaar. Hergebruik voorkomt verspilling. Private Sector: Snelheid: Startups bouwen op bestaande fundamenten. Bewezen kracht: open source e-commerce wordt gebruikt door ca. 40% van de partijen. De waarde verschuift van licentieverkoop naar hoogwaardige dienstverlening. 3. EU-maatregelen Wij pleiten voor 4 structurele ingrepen: 1. Sovereign Tech Fund: Richt een fonds voor onderhoud en security van bewezen open source infrastructuur en veelgebruikte libraries (de digitale wegen en bruggen). 2. Veranker "Public Money, Public Code": Maak dit dwingend in wetgeving. Draai bij aanbestedingen de bewijslast om: comply or explain waarom er voor gesloten software & ontwikkeling wordt gekozen. 3. Verplicht Upstream Contributions: Gebruik inkoopmacht om het open ecosysteem te voeden. Eis in aanbestedingen dat leveranciers aantonen hoe zij bijdragen (tijd/geld) aan gebruikte open source projecten. 4. Bescherm de 'Commons' in AI/CRA Wetgeving: Juridisch: Creëer safe harbors voor non-profit ontwikkelaars. Financieel: Zorg dat AI-heffingen ook terugvloeien naar open source makers, niet alleen naar betaal-per-kopie rechthebbenden. 4. Prioriteiten & Sectoren Open source is geen sector, maar infrastructuur. Het is cruciaal voor alle sectoren, waaronder NIS2-vitale infrastructuur en infrastructurele concurrentiekracht tegenover Big Tech. Focus op de fundamentele infrastructuur (talen, libraries, encryptie) en publieke kernfuncties (digitale identiteit/wallets). Laat diensten over aan de markt. Conclusie Digitale soevereiniteit en een gezonde competatieve markt heeft een vitaal open source ecosysteem nodig. Dit ecosysteem is fragiel. Wij roepen de EC op: erken open source als publieke infrastructuur, financier het onderhoud structureel en bescherm de 'co

feedback: Linux Foundation Europe welcomes the opportunity to contribute to the public consultation on the European Open Digital Ecosystems Strategy. More detailed feedback is provided in the accompanying document, while the key points are summarised as follows: 1. Open source is a basis of successful business ventures and is widely used across industries, with most modern software built on open source components, whether proprietary or not. It is a diverse ecosystem spanning multiple governance, sustainability, and commercial models, and the Linux Foundation welcomes the Call for Evidences acknowledgment of this reality and its pursuit of pragmatic, evidence-based approaches to strengthen EU competitiveness and technological autonomy. 2. Europe should build on and influence the global open source commons rather than pursue isolated notions of European Open Source, as existing global projects already underpin cloud, AI, and emerging digital infrastructure. Strategic upstream investment and participation in these commons - alongside scaling local commercial open source companies through funding instruments, market-access initiatives, and updated procurement practices - offers the most realistic path to technological sovereignty, innovation, and talent retention. 3. Critical open source infrastructure should be hosted under neutral governance to ensure balanced decision-making, mitigate single-vendor and lock-in risks, and foster rapid de facto standardisation.

feedback: Centre for Net Zero welcomes the European Commissions initiative to develop a strategy for European Open Digital Ecosystems. We strongly support the Commissions ambition to strengthen Europes competitiveness, resilience and technological sovereignty through open, interoperable and trustworthy digital infrastructure. Centre for Net Zero is a non-profit, open energy research institute, established by the Octopus Energy Group. We operate autonomously and set our own research agenda. We are building a global evidence base on demand flexibility showing how and when energy can shift in response to system needs. Using insights from our trials and system modelling, we demonstrate how mobilising flexibility at scale can displace fossil fuels - and what happens when demand is an active part of the system. We share our work openly, supporting governments, policy-makers and grid operators. Energy is a flagship sector for European Open Digital Ecosystems. Europes energy system is already highly digitalised, yet progress in deploying AI and advanced digital tools remains constrained by fragmented data access, limited interoperability, and fragile digital foundations. Open-source software, open standards and open data approaches are therefore foundational infrastructure for Europes energy transition, and offer an opportunity for Europe to develop sovereign, domain-specific AI. To support open, collaborative and competitive digital ecosystems in energy, the Commissions strategy implement the four actions below, and outlined in further detail attached. The upcoming strategy should: 1. Establish dedicated, multi-year funding mechanisms for open-source communities and critical digital components. Open ecosystems tend to move faster and adapt more easily than consortia designed to satisfy funding calls. 2. Embed open data and open-source requirements in public procurement and funded projects. Procurement frameworks should enable system operators and public bodies to contract for long-term support and maintenance of open solutions. 3. Support the development and adoption of trust and assurance frameworks already emerging from open initiatives. Evaluation frameworks for open-source AI-generated and AI-ready grid data are being developed for the energy sector through collaborations such as OpenSynth. These provide technical assets and practical experience in aligning on interoperability, data quality and model evaluation which can directly inform EU-level standards, certification schemes and guidance. 4. Build on existing open-source and synthetic data initiatives when developing new data infrastructures. The Data Union Strategy and emerging work on synthetic data and data-sharing frameworks is particularly welcome. Rather than creating new structures for the proposed synthetic data factories announced in the Data Union Strategy, the EU should explicitly build on existing open initiatives. Supporting and scaling open ecosystems. For energy, openness is not a secondary design choice but a prerequisite for deploying AI and digital technologies safely, competitively and at scale. Europe already possesses many of the necessary foundations: a highly digitalised energy system, strong open research communities, emerging trust and assurance frameworks, and a growing policy focus on data accessibility through initiatives such as the Data Union Strategy. The priority now is to move decisively from strategy to implementation. By investing in the sustainability of open-source ecosystems, embedding openness in procurement and funding, scaling privacy-preserving data approaches, and building on existing open initiatives, the EU can turn data from a constraint into a strategic asset. In doing so, Europe can strengthen competitiveness, enhance cyber resilience and accelerate the delivery of an affordable, secure, decarbonised and digital energy system.

Full feedback attached. Most importantly, we discuss issues and possible solutions: - Supply chain blindness: disregarding software packages (as opposed to models, applications) and distribution pathways (e.g., python package index). - Governance blindness: disregarding who controls a package, community, or its assets - a truly open community or a US foundation under tight but covert control? - Sustainability blindness, track record blindness: prioritizing flashy claims and "research hype" over actual impact and long-term sustainability, often against publicly available track record (or lack thereof). - Misallocation of funds via academia, especially to institutions that lack actual AI competence, or operational competence in maintaining production-grade open-source infrastructure.
organization: German Center for Open Source AI

feedback: 1. Nextcloud is an example of a promising alternative to MS 365 suite, but it could benefit from more resources to make it a better drop-in replacement for an expensive MS subscription for the organization both with regard to functionality, stability, scaling and end-user experience. Cost savings will probably not be positive before almost all proprietary subscription services are replaced by open and free alternatives. 2. Europe (as well as the world!) consists of many smaller nations and many languages written and spoken. Many poorly served by proprietary software because of low financial rewards. Open source software were we can collaborate, not for profit, but for the common good allows also smaller communities to be served. Not doing software development for maximum profit, but for the greater good also enables improvements to be shared back to the community and further built and improved upon. 3. Funded by the public, the code should be free/libre and public. Open source projects that are deemed important should be supported financially and morally. Historically great things came from research parks like Xerox parc, Bell labs, perhaps bringing smart people together allowing freedom to do research they find interesting. 4. The reliance on Microsoft and Google especially for "Office productivity" is complicated because many products and services are bundled together and coupled together. It should be replaced with an all-open tech stack that allows you to freely change parts without replacing the whole thing. Like email used to be where server and client did not matter as long as they both adhered to the same procol (POP3, IMAP, SMTP etc). It is difficult to predict the future so making the parts user-replacable is a great feature. The open source software stack should support all major languages and be open so that other languages can easily be supported by anyone willing to contribute. The EU should also assist in curating quality datasets for AI training for the benefit of users of the language, and common good. 5. Moving away from proprietary software were possible it should be easier to keep software stacks up-to-date and more secure. Sharing security- and efficiency best-practices in the community freely and with access to the source code to verify, or if needed change or add functionality also greatly benefits learning.

All EU government required SW component capabilities must be implemented with EU money as open source reference implementation, which is free for all. Engineering english implementation first for good cooperation, and then could support internationalization, productization, packaging for the EU national languages and for major OSS packaging lines Fedora rpm and Debian dep packaging. Industry and society try to get more done with the less. Its productive to utilize existing available software stacks for production. Utilization of Open Source Software (OSS) as one ready made component is increased, which is good. Still there is lot to do to get vendors to maintain physical product included, embedded software components and then deliver those improvements back to community. EU could demand vendors to maintain embedded software as long as hardware stays relevant. They could outsource this work for third party. Or they could open they software fully, so peoples could to those things themselves. While EU or national offices demand fixes to these software components, which maybe used on communication devices etc. or be part of OSS releases, then EU should be ready to pay from working hours what is needed to bring outdated, still widely used, communication stack etc. software component up to date. In OSS world improvements come through participation and maintenance support actions. From major commercial digital business players there is trend to purchase competition away from market, especially when competitor offer solutions for OSS platforms. Other tactics they use are delayed support for the communication device or other needed peripheral component so that user cant get best user experience out from new purchased machine loaded with OSS. Especially 5G module you could use as pure modem is still treated different way depending which operating system you are using. I am kind of amazed how much radiation differs for same transmitted data through 5G modem with the different OS release on machine, even electric feed, physical environment and data is exactly same. They especially mention SAR (Specific Absorption Rate) as reason for the unnecessary FCC locking. It looks more like delayed market opening for the OSS platform, and cleverly its not fully stopped due fear from possible fine due abuse of significant market position. EU could and should demand removal of all unnecessary digital locking or limiting. Peoples purchase those machines and have right to use as they like. Yep, I know that peripheral implementation could be done to share code with the platform, good question is should we have these poor mans softmodems at all, because then controlled communication DSP software is spreading to customer controlled side. In this case vendor should do the testing for OSS stacks too before entering to EU market with softmodem. I would like to say that this delaying, braking, is purposeful commercial strategy. Similar habits there is with the better displays availability with OSS preinstalled, even if OSS stack is working well with HW. The other significant trend is the lifting software more up to stack from actual hardware, which makes possible to control, remote manage, what can be executed over the hardware platform. As we have seen there could be remote service denial for local EU officials. Therefore EU should have significant own commercial or open source hardware production to get OSS/OSHW stack which is solely in EU control.

I am submitting this feedback on behalf of Wikimedia Germany e.V., a nonprofit organization that supports the german-speaking Wikipedia community and Wikidata next to other projects of the global Wiki Movement that is dedicated to the common good. We support the people, technology, and policies that enable reliable information to be shared with the world. The purpose of Wikimedia e.V. is the promotion of the creation, collection, and dissemination of free content to promote equal opportunities in access to knowledge and education. Wikipedia is already the backbone of the internets knowledge. From students to chatbots, everyone is learning from it. Wikipedia has been officially recognized as a DPG by the Digital Public Goods Alliance in February 2025. Wikimedia e. V. has over 110.000 members and supports many more volunteers in Germany and internationally via collaborations. Wikimedia e. V. is representing civil society in the Board of the Internet Governance Forum Germany e. V. A free and Open Source Ecosystem at its core is a digital reflection of European values. It emphasizes transparency and collaboration, thrives on diversity and is grounded on fundamental human rights such as the protection of privacy. By combining collaborative innovation with a strong commitment to transparency and human rights, this approach offers a compelling model for the world and can help Europe emerge as a geopolitical and geo-economic powerhouse. We see some strenghts, such as a vibrant open source community, probed democratic pracices and established regulation including the protection of privacy. Concrete Actions: 1) Research, document, and showcase success stories. Such a research project would be a great start for the EDIC for Digital Commons. 2) Recognise open source as a participatory and collaborative practice. The number and diversity of contributors should be treated as key performance indicators. 3) Support and promote collaborative FOSS communities: Facilitate partnerships among public administrations, businesses, civil society organisations, and research institutions to enable innovation, resource sharing, and long-term sustainability across the open source landscape. 4) Increase public sector skills, literacy, and awareness: Empower civil servants to actively contribute to open source projects by hiring FOSS developers within public institutions and strengthening internal IT capacities. 5) Enable and encourage reuse of EU open data: Build a reuse strategy for example around Wikidata and use the worlds largest knowledge graph for the advancement of open data reuse. 6) Increase investment and reform procurement: Allocate substantial dedicated funding streams to support free and open source projects, including maintenance work, security audits, grant schemes or matching funds to incentivise community contributions and a thriving community network. Focusing on Free and Open Source Infrastructure will strengthen european values such as cooperation, equity and human rights. Democratic practices can be a strenght, also in digital.

feedback: Sehr geehrte Damen und Herren, sehr geehrte Frau Präsidentin, unabhängig der Hauptfragen zu einer öffentlichen Konsultation die zufällig 2 Tage nach der FOSDEM 2026 endet, stelle ich Ihre Begründung in den Vordergrund. Sie schrieben: "Mit der Konsultation sollen Beiträge und Fakten zum aktuellen Stand bei den Open-Source-Lösungen in der EU gesammelt werden. Dabei geht es unter anderem um Stärken, Schwächen, Hindernisse für die Einführung, tragfähige Geschäftsmodelle, den Wert von Open-Source-Lösungen für öffentliche und private Organisationen sowie mögliche Maßnahmen zur Förderung des europäischen Open-Source-Ökosystems." Und genau hier setzt das Problem an ohne eine entsprechende Rechtsgrundlage zur Gründung gemeinnütziger Stiftungen in Europa zum Wohle der Allgemeinheit in den Bereichen Freier Software ohne dedizierten Grund auf ein einzelnes Thema/Projekt in allen Mitgliedsstaaten, ist aus rein wirtschaftlichen Gründen Europa sowohl aktuell als auch zukünftig durchgehend im Nachteil zur Schaffung unabhängiger Hard- und Softwarelösungen unter Freier Lizenz. Eine Stärkung einer europäischen Resilienz wird die Untätigkeit der Kommission in Bezug auf alle Mitgliedsländer eindeutig verhindert. Es obliegt nicht mir, hier einen konkreten Umsetzungsvorschlag zu unterbreiten, gleichwohl es betont werden muss, dass nicht ohne Grund aus rein "wirtschaftlichen" Gründen als Modelle zur Steuerersparnis, grundsätzlich Stiftungen ausschließlich außerhalb Europas gegründet wurden und werden, sofern es um die Bereiche Freier Software geht. Die bisherigen Maßnahmen der EU-Kommission in Abstimmung mit Parlament und Rat sowie allen beteiligten Mitgliedsstaaten verweigern seit über 20 Jahren eine entsprechende Rechtsgrundlage, außer gemeinschaftlich generiertes Wissen aus Wissenschaft und Zivilgesellschaft so zu privatisieren, dass keine Souveränität gegenüber anderen Staaten weltweit im Bereich Freier Software möglich ist. Ein sehr schönes Beispiel ist exemplarisch der Aspekt, dass Deutschland finanziell oder begrifflich nicht Willens war zu erkennen, dass das Projekt "Sentence Transformers" eines weltweit renommierten Teams der Technischen Universität Darmstadt seit Jahren als Kernbaustein in den Bereichen von "KI" (hier irgendwas mit Stochastik andenken, wenn man weiß wovon man redet) aufgrund Ressourcenmangels nicht mehr steuerbar war. Das gesamte Projekt wird nunmehr (und dankenswerterweise bevor es verschwindet) durch ein US-Unternehmen betreut immerhin unter dem primären Maintainership eines Europäers. Es mag durchgehend schlauere Produktplatzierungen und Ansätze geben ich bitte Sie jedoch genau diesen Aspekt der mangelnden und aktuell niemals herstellbaren Souveränität in Bezug auch aus Streitvermeidung intern aufgrund "Steuervermeidungsgründen" und Hoheiten hin zu einem eindeutigen Schritt zu ziehen. Hochachtungsvoll und mit Dank für alle Dienste, die die EU-Kommission bislang unter Freier Lizenz veröffentlicht hat und anbietet mit besonderem Dank für eTranslate des DGT. Marc "Grumpy" Olejak.

feedback: Red Hat*, the worlds leading provider of open source solutions, uses a community-driven model to deliver high-performing Linux, cloud, automation, container, and Kubernetes technologies, as well as open source AI frameworks that power the full machine learning lifecycle. Though a wholly owned subsidiary of IBM since 2019, Red Hat operates as a distinct legal entity, maintaining neutrality to serve as a catalyst for open innovation across the global hybrid cloud. Our "upstream-first"** development model ensures that we do not merely consume open source code but actively harden, secure, and contribute back to the projects from around the world that power the modern digital economy. Instead of "forking" code into proprietary silos - which creates technical debt and incompatibility - we submit every bug fix, security patch, and feature enhancement to the community repository first. This model represents one of the largest R&D budgets in industry, as a percentage of revenue, and is widely recognised as key to sustain thriving communities as well as optimising a secure, stable and standardised public good for all. To complement various commercialisation/monetisation models, public intervention can sometimes be helpful for projects which have not attracted the same level of commercial support and thus need public and/or steward support for underfunded or potentially fringe projects. This EU call for evidence is a timely initiative to level-set about the success of open source and the importance of understanding core drivers which underpin this success as well as its critical role to realise many EU policy objectives such as European competitiveness and digital sovereignty. Doing so in a comprehensive way will also better position Europe to co-develop and unlock the next wave in open source innovation and break-through emerging technologies. Given our 30+ year role of developing open source software and defending open in the public policy field, we welcome this important EU consultation and would like to share some preliminary perspectives - attached - as a basis for further dialogue and collaboration. *https://transparency-register.europa.eu/search-register-or-update/organisation-detail_en?id=741186216712-07 **https://www.redhat.com/en/resources/open-source-participation-guidelines-overview#section-5

feedback:
Submitted on behalf of Social Web Foundation (https://socialwebfoundation.org/), Newsmast Foundation (https://newsmastfoundation.org/), Stichting Advies Bureau Ongevraagd Advies (SABOA) (https://www.saboa.eu/), Fedivariety (https://FediVariety.org/) and Save Social (https://savesocial.eu/) We are a coalition of civil society organisations operating in Europe and globally. We are encouraging the adoption of Open Source social networking platforms that connect to the Fediverse. Social networking is an especially vulnerable sector for digital sovereignty, security, and competitiveness. Worldwide, an increasing percentage of citizens get their news primarily or solely from social media. Centralised social platforms have been documented vectors for interference in the democratic process in Europe and elsewhere. Engagement-oriented algorithmic feeds have amplified inauthentic behaviour. From Brazil to Canada to Brussels, centralised social platforms have used their power in the market to push back on enforcement of local laws like the Digital Services Act and the Digital Markets Act. We believe the Fediverse provides a strong check on these vulnerabilities. The Fediverse is a network of interoperable social media platforms connected with the open standard protocol ActivityPub. Services on the Fediverse include Mastodon, Flipboard, WordPress, Peertube, Write As, Pixelfed, Meta Threads, Ghost.org, Mobilizon, WordPress, and others. The Fediverse offers users a choice of social media platforms without losing access to their friends, families, publishers, local communities or important thinkers. Because its possible to connect across platforms, different users can make different choices, and maintain their social ties, read others posts, and comment, like and share. Every day, millions of people share their life and career updates, engage in conversations, post silly memes, or stay in touch with loved ones on the Fediverse. Because ActivityPub is an open standard protocol, published at the World Wide Web Consortium (W3C) in 2018, it is available to any company or developer to implement, without patent encumbrance or fees. Fediverse software that is available under an Open Source license lets individuals, families, communities, businesses, universities, cities and other stakeholders in society establish social network servers of their own, which interact on an even playing field with commercial services. There are dozens of Open Source Fediverse social networking programs, such as made-in-Europe options like Mastodon, Peertube and Mobilizon, with thousands of installed servers across the continent and around the world. Connecting the Fediverse from the bottom up, person by person and community by community, is a resilient structure and one of the Fediverses core strengths. Heterogeneous Open Source software lets software decisions occur much closer to the user than with a single commercial platform. The choices that the Fediverse provides allow a competitive market in social platforms resistant to vendor lock-in. Local and national governments, the EU, universities, public broadcasters and media companies in Europe have adopted Fediverse technologies. The Fediverse is a solid foundation for European digital sovereignty in the social networking space. Europeans can use social platforms hosted and managed close to home, under the jurisdiction of their elected officials. And the Fediverse allows them to stay connected to people in Latin America, the US and Canada, Asia, Africa, and Oceania but rooted in Europe, on European terms. Our organisations strongly encourages the EU to consider the promise of the Fediverse for connecting European society with autonomy and independence, and the importance of Open Source software to the spread and adoption of the Fediverse. The EU can greatly aid digital sovereignty efforts by supporting the development and adoption of Open So

feedback: QGIS.org submits this contribution as the steward of QGIS, a widely deployed Digital Public Good forming a core component of public and private-sector geospatial infrastructure. Drawing on more than two decades of real-world use across administrations, SMEs, and critical sectors, we highlight that Europes digital sovereignty depends not only on adopting open source, but on sustainably maintaining and governing it. The submission provides concrete, experience-based recommendations on procurement, funding, cybersecurity, and ecosystem support to ensure that open source remains a secure, resilient, and competitive foundation for Europes digital future. See the attached PDF for the full submission

Aujourdhui, la plupart des modèles économiques de lopen source reposent sur lopen core : une part propriétaire (souvent une version entreprise) est nécessaire pour accéder à tout le potentiel de la technologie. Cette approche peut freiner la dynamique collective, car les incitations à contribuer se concentrent sur lacteur qui contrôle la partie différenciante. On se retrouve ainsi avec beaucoup de logiciels open source mais trop peu de communs numériques et un paysage fragmenté. Les communs numériques puissants et durables (Linux, Wikipedia, VLC, etc.) obéissent à une autre logique : lactif principal est la communauté, cest-à-dire la capacité à maintenir, sécuriser et faire évoluer dans la durée un socle partagé. Imaginons maintenant une garantie effective pour les citoyens et organisations européennes : pouvoir stocker, partager et collaborer sur des informations numériques de manière sûre et à un coût abordable. Cette garantie nest pas pleinement assurée aujourd'hui : les coûts augmentent avec les situations de dépendance, les risques sur les données et la continuité de service sont réels, et les possibilités de substitution limitées. Cette garantie pourrait être incarnée par une Open Internet Stack : une pile technologique de référence, accessible et réutilisable, permettant à lécosystème européen de proposer des services numériques compétitifs. Pour chaque dépendance critique, la pile offrirait au moins une alternative crédible, idéalement plusieurs pour la résilience. Une telle pile gagnerait à être gouvernée selon un modèle à but non lucratif, afin daligner durablement les incitations sur lintérêt des utilisateurs : sécurité, transparence, continuité, interopérabilité. À linverse, dans des modèles strictement guidés par la rentabilité, un désalignement structurel dintérêts peut apparaître : captation de valeur, verrouillage, hausse des coûts de sortie, et parfois dégradation progressive du service. Dans le contexte géopolitique actuel, ces dépendances peuvent aussi être instrumentalisées. But non lucratif ne signifie pas financement uniquement public. La pile porterait une image forte de confiance, elle peut tolérer des usages gratuits, tout en organisant un financement soutenable : par exemple, lEDIC des communs numériques pourrait mesurer les utilisateurs actifs, répartir une contribution équitable entre réutilisateurs et structurer des mécanismes simples (contribution mutualisée, accords dusage de marque, engagements de support). Lobjectif est de massifier linvestissement dans les briques communes, tout en laissant les acteurs se différencier (intégration, déploiement, services managés, fonctionnalités spécifiques). Les priorités doivent viser les zones où limpact est maximal et où les alternatives souveraines sont insuffisantes : espaces de travail collaboratif et infrastructures cloud, ainsi que les composants qui conditionnent la substituabilité (standards, annuaires, fédération didentité). La DINUM porte une logique de communs numériques et de mutualisation, incarnée notamment par FranceConnect et La Suite, avec une doctrine claire : renforcer la capacité autonome daction (substituabilité, interopérabilité, investissement durable dans la maintenance et la sécurité). La DINUM souhaite que la Commission européenne agisse en complément via un mécanisme dinvestissement orienté résultats : doter lEDIC et les structures à but non lucratif portant des communs critiques de moyens significatifs, et financer sur la base de lusage réel. Cette orientation est cohérente avec nos propositions sur la stratégie européenne FOSS : soutien aux écosystèmes de maintenance et commande publique comme levier dadoption.

feedback: ** Q1 Strengths / barriers We are a small Plone company with 6 years of publicsector experience; we observe that EU opensource platforms are mature but face structural barriers. Main barrier: procurement rules that favor market share and large references. ** Q2 Added value and examples Open source enables legal and technical reuse and reduces vendor lockin; it supports data sovereignty and long lifecycles. - Cost: lower longterm TCO through reuse and shared maintenance. Example: we provide Quaive, a Plone-based social intranet platform, to more than a dozen municipal authorities. The platform provides a rich feature set which is 90%+ standard and shared across all installs. Development and maintenance is shared not just between the participating municipalities, but also with other organisations using the same platform (universities, NGOs). Moreover, we participate in and benefit from development and maintenance of the underlying Plone application server, extending synergy to the whole Plone ecosystem. ** Q3 EUlevel measures (suggested positions) We support targeted EU measures that fund sustainability and level the playing field. Options: - Ecosystem diversity funding: support 35 platforms per use case to avoid winnertakesall. - Procurement reform: remove marketshare/reference thresholds disadvantageous to communities. ** Q4 Priority areas Priority: publicsector digital platforms (government, education, healthcare). ** Q5 Highimpact sectors Highest impact: public administration, education, healthcare where long lifecycles, data sovereignty and accessibility matter most.

Gentile Commissario, ricorda la Direttiva (UE) 2022/2380, quella che stabilisce lo standard di ricarica universale USB-C? Dal 2024, tutti devono usare lo stesso connettore USB-C: questo ha evitato che ogni marca producesse cavi diversi, migliorando la convenienza per i cittadini e riducendo gli sprechi di rifiuti elettronici (RAEE), con un risparmio concreto e verificabile. Immagini la stessa attenzione applicata ai dati dei cittadini: oggi i dati personali non solo messaggi generici, ma le ricette mediche scansionate, le immagini cliniche inviate a uno specialista (il neo sul seno), i piani educativi personalizzati dei ragazzi con disabilità, i dati in tempo reale prodotti da pacemaker, defibrillatori impiantabili o misuratori continui di glicemia informazioni da cui dipendono decisioni cliniche immediate e, in alcuni casi, la vita stessa delle persone non sono più realmente sotto il controllo di chi li produce o li riceve, ma sotto quello di chi fornisce il dispositivo o lapplicazione che li conserva. Non per un trasferimento formale di proprietà, ma perché laccesso, la portabilità e luso effettivo di quei dati dipendono da sistemi chiusi. Per i dati esiste già un vero cavo universale digitale: è il software libero (o più in generale FLOSS). Grazie a standard aperti e software condiviso, la cartella clinica completa, la storia vaccinale di un figlio, i referti di anni di visite restano del cittadino, visibili solo a chi egli autorizza, trasferibili facilmente da un sistema allaltro, senza dover ricominciare ogni volta da zero. Nel documento allegato mostriamo come le scuole che seguiamo siano tornate padrone dei loro dati grazie al software libero e a standard aperti. Il nostro approccio produce trasparenza, favorisce innovazione le startup europee possono sviluppare applicazioni compatibili senza dipendere da operatori dominanti e, soprattutto, rafforza la fiducia dei cittadini nelle istituzioni, perché i loro dati rimangono sotto controllo europeo. In allegato portiamo molti casi di successo tra i quali descriviamo il nostro rapporto con Loacker (sì, quello dei Wafer), cominciato con un piccolo progetto ma che si è presto espanso a tutta l'infrastruttura, la trasparenza e condivisione delle conoscenze producono la più grande ricchezza: la fiducia. Nell'allegato troverà i casi di successo dove usiamo molte soluzioni che utilizzano FLOSS e rispondono alle esigenze attuali di infrastruttura e compliance dimostrando che la realtà è molto diversa da come viene narrata: è possibile avere uno stack completamente autonomo Non è teoria: i caricabatterie standardizzati hanno dimostrato che uno standard aperto può ridurre sprechi, riequilibrare il mercato e restituire scelta ai cittadini senza frenare linnovazione. Applicare lo stesso principio ai dati personali sarebbe un passo decisivo verso una reale sovranità digitale europea. È una direzione che noi stiamo già percorrendo, con i nostri clienti e nelle scuole dei nostri figli.

feedback: Vorrei che ci fosse un finanziamento stabile a pioggia verso una moltitudine di progetti software libero o veri e propri contratti di lavori. Finanziamenti stabili cosicché i manutentori possono vivere tranquillamente sviluppando e mantenendo un progetto software libero (ma preferibilmente limitato ai soli cittadini EU). Inoltre vorrei che venissero considerati di più progetti che solitamente sono molto sotto i reflettori (come i famosi progetti del tipo di nebraska) quali librerie di sistema(tipo libxml o libz), protocolli (dbus, wayland, ...), applicazioni gui e cli di uso generale (non serve finanziare nginx e docker ma tipo openssl e gedit), software con un valore economico limitato tipo i videogiochi o troppo difficili da autofinanziare, linux(kernel), la pacchettizzazione e la manutenzione delle distribuzioni, progetti emergenti poco commercializzabili. Seppure sia possibile guadagnare soldi col software libero (es con contratti di sviluppo, supporto personalizzato, ecc), c'è una grande fetta di software che non riuscirebbe a autofinanziarsi in questo modo e perciò può sopravvivere solo di lavoro volontario Inoltre vorrei un piano per il raggiungimento del 100% software libero nelle pubbliche amministrazioni, con annessi strumenti realistici di enforcing di questa politica e sanzioni reali ai dirigenti/decisori che si rifiutano/rallentano eccessivamente la migrazione. Vorrei che venisse preso in considerazione il finanziamento a progetti coreboot/libreboot (e supporto legislativo/industriale) al fine di ampliare e mantenere la varietà di hardware supportato. Spero che nelle catene decisionali venisse coinvolto maggiormente la community del software libero o semplicemente degli esperti IT veri(e indipendenti, non mandati/in partenariato con le solite big tech). E come corollario, le catene decisionali capiscano come funziona il mondo IT, di internet e delle comunità del software libero, e come rapportavo-ci a essa. Vorrei che l'europa si coinvolgesse di più negli organismi di standardizzazione dei protocolli e che forzasse l'implementazione degli standard attraverso strumenti legislativi. Vorrei che venissero aggiustate tutte le leggi che, con un abuso di paternalismo, impedissero la modifica software dei dispositivi digitali. Sogno in cui in europa si possa vivere realisticamente usando solo software libero e senza essere costretti ad usare il software proprietario.

I would like to see stable funding rainy towards a multitude of free software projects or outright works contracts. Stable funding so that maintenance workers can live comfortably by developing and maintaining a free software project (but preferably limited to EU citizens only). I would also like to see more projects that are usually much underneath reflectors (such as the famous Nebraska type projects) such as system libraries (libxml or libz type), protocols (dbus, wayland,...), GUI applications and general-purpose cli (no need to finance nginx and Docker but OpenSSL and Gedit type), software with limited economic value such as video games or too difficult to self-finance, linux (kernel), pacchettisation and maintenance of distributions, emerging projects that are unmarketable. Although it is possible to earn money from free software (e.g. with development contracts, personalised support, etc.), there is a large proportion of software that would not be able to finance itself in this way and can therefore survive only on a voluntary basis. Furthermore, I would like to see a plan to achieve 100 % free software in public administrations, with realistic tools for enforcing this policy and real penalties for managers/decision-makers who refuse/excessively slow down migration. feedback:
The following feedback is provided by Herrmann Ultraschall, a global leading manufacturer of ultrasonic welding equipment for industrial manufacturing processes. 1. Q: What are the strengths and weaknesses of the EU open-source sector? 1. A: Strength: Software quality and interoperability. Weakness: non-EU dependencies in the supply chain, tooling and infrastructure: Most dependency trees end up in the US, while global trade is subject to conflicts, and embargoes are everywhere. As a machine building company with a global customer base we need to stay out of geopolitical trade wars, thus need a neutral providence of software. 1.Q What are the main barriers that hamper adoption and maintenance of high-quality and secure open source. 1. (i) A: Adoption in our family-based business is hampered by traditional misconception that commercial software would be of better quality, more feature rich or more widely available. This is what management still believes, not developers. Considering software as a main differentiating factor in machine building is an emerging insight, but not fully effective yet. 1. (ii) A: Contribution is hampered by the lack of private and public funding of open source projects. We have heavily invested in US based foundations to speed up the security evolution of our open source tech ecosystem. There simply weren't any meaningful EU based foundations, even though the techstack originated from Sweden and Poland. These investments have paying off better compared to an corresponding private contracting, while serving a much larger audience. 2. Q: What is the added value of OSS for the private sector? 2. A: Added value stems from the OSS transparency (quality, security) and the plurality (features, speed, longevity). Absence of license cost is comparatively irrelevant. Also an independent body such as an OSS foundation is trusted better in security matters compared to the marketing promises issued by companies. We have been able to build an industrial manufacturing automation system from cable to cloud exclusively on open source technology and will continue to do so. 3. Q: What concrete measures and actions may be taken at EU level to support the development and growth of the EU open-source sector and contribute to the EUs technological sovereignty and cybersecurity agenda? 3. A: In the context of CRA open source projects and foundations shall act as stewards, while their contributions are not challenged by legal liability claims. Instead, by providing subsidiaries, tax relieves and other funding endorsements, the projects shall be empowered to keep up with their mission. Certification frameworks for software security build trust. Suggest to establish such as Industrielle Gemeinschaftsforschung (IGF) in the OSS Domain to allow company collaboration, but respect anti-trust. Avoid mandatory third party certification, instead mimic the successful mechanisms established in the adoption of safety of machinery 4. Q: What technology areas should be prioritized and why? A: We are advocating for what we need: 1. industrial grade linux operating systems 2. soft-real-time applications on top of that, like provided by the Erlang Ecosystem 3. secure industrial communication 4. authentication and authorization of users using 3rd party identity providers 4. reliable web based UI frameworks for monitoring and controls 5. Sleek distributed Process Data Analysis frameworks including visualization tools of time series and logs 6. doc-as-code frameworks for consistency and efficiency. The target is to have an open source techstack suitable to create industrial manufacturing automation, basically using IoT devices: 1. to allow cost-effective hardware, 2. to seamlessly bridge the gap between IT and OT in connected factories. 5. Q: In what sectors could an increased use of open source lead to increased competitiveness and cyber resilience? 5. A: Machine Buildin

feedbackTextUserLanguage: Sascha
column29: Europe, like its Member States, has become highly dependent on American companies in particular. This situation is unacceptable, especially in view of the increasingly deteriorating relationship with the US. As the Member States – particularly in Germany – are not addressing this problem, the EU must lay down the following requirements: in the short term, an obligation for companies, organisations and authorities to store and keep up-to-date the data in an EU repository in parallel with non-EU repositories (avoid lock-outs), mandatory use of open interfaces and migration of existing applications. The corresponding cloud solutions must be developed by the EU in the short term – the know-how is available in Europe and the solutions can be offered cheaply by scaling them up (“all European data must be stored in the EU repositories”), taking into account the EU’s exemplary data protection rules. In the long term, the use of open source should be encouraged and made mandatory. The use of non-EU software/storage and storage is still possible, but only to the extent that access and use is possible without this non-EU software/storage. The use of open source software can create a market in the EU in the long term, with the possibility of selling the solutions to other countries. In parallel, the EU should take a hard line towards companies whose activities run counter to the interests of the EU and its citizens (social media influence).

feedback: Feedback attached PagoPA S.p.A., created as a result of the Italian Simplifications Law Decree no.135 of 14 December 2018, is the company wholly owned by the State through the Ministry of Economy and Finance (MEF) and subject to the supervision of the Prime Minister. The Company's mission is to design and build infrastructures and technological solutions aimed at promoting the widespread diffusion of digital public services accessible to citizens and businesses in the simplest possible way, via mobile devices ("mobile first" approach) and according to the once-only principle, with secure, scalable, highly reliable architectures based on clearly defined application interfaces (API). The company works in this direction in line with the evolution underway in the European Union, and pays great attention at international level to monitoring, to exchanging of good practices, as well as building synergies in the field of experimentation with new models and technologies.

feedback: The primary challenge of the EU open-source sector is the lack of funding for development, especially when it comes to community or individual-led projects. This is due to overly complex applications for large grants, or opaque and overburdened cascade-funding initiatives. Multiple surveys report that increased funding would directly impact the quality of open source products and start a virtuous cycle that goes beyond software development and maintenance. A concrete measure to improve this is to define the budget/scope of public funding of open source projects retroactively, based on applications submitted by the projects themselves. Offer open source communities the tools to apply for funding with minimal restrictions, and evaluate the business plans. Crucially, plans should be evaluated by public, expert-led, peer-nominated panels or advisory groups. Besides investing in open source for all infrastructure (from hardware, storage and networking technologies to desktop and mobile environments), greater competitiveness will come from investing in open source content creation and industrial design tools. Such tools are the modern pencil used to conceptualize, design and build the world around us. Having control over the tools, and most importantly the data formats, will increase interoperability, reduce friction in collaboration processes and achieve greater cost effectiveness in the long run. All industrial sectors can benefit from deep open source adoption, once the principles are applied correctly. This can be done by involving experienced practitioners with a track record of being aligned with open source principles and best practices. Such practitioners should be willing to work in public and take accountability for the work done.

Die Wiener Stadtwerke unterstützen nachdrücklich die geplante Strategie der EU und betonen die Notwendigkeit eines kohärenten, EU-weiten Ansatzes, um ihre wirksame Umsetzung sicherzustellen. Ein einheitlicher Rahmen mit klar definierten Rollen, Zuständigkeiten und Kooperationsmechanismen ist unerlässlich, um eine Fragmentierung zu vermeiden und eine skalierbare grenzüberschreitende Einführung zu ermöglichen. Durch die Offenheit des Quellcodes und auch den vermehrten Einsatz von Open Source im Cloud-, Data-Center und AI Bereich ist die internationale Open Source Community bereits jetzt ein essentieller Teil innovativer Lösungen. Die Open-Source-Strategie könnte dazu beitragen, die Wahrnehmung für die Verwendung von Open Source Produkten zu ändern. Open Source Komponenten werden bereits jedem genutzt, weil diese in vielen digitalen Produkten enthalten sind. Dies ist jedoch nicht bewusst bzw. bekannt. Die Kompatibilität von Open Source Anwendungen mit den bestehenden IT-Strukturen in einem großen Unternehmen stellt eine enorme Herausforderung dar. Der Einsatz von Open Source Lösungen wird durch ein teilweise fehlendes Supportnetzwerk für Unternehmen gehindert. Da IT-Lösungen immer komplexer werden, müssen sich Unternehmen darauf verlassen können, dass ausgelieferte Software weitestgehend fehlerfrei ist. Aktuell bieten vor allem große proprietäre Softwarehäuser die entsprechenden Wartungs- und Supportverträge an. Entsprechend den europäischen Zielen für Souveränität und Cybersicherheit sollten insbesondere die Bedürfnisse der kritischen Infrastruktur vorrangig berücksichtigt werden. Im Bereich der kritischen Infrastruktur müssen auf Open-Source basierende Softwareprodukte u.a. entsprechende Zuverlässigkeit und Cybersicherheit aufweisen. Dies geht mit einem hohen Entwicklungs- und Wartungsaufwand einher. Diesen können in der Regel nur externe Entwicklungspartner liefern. Eine Chance für den Open-Source Bereich in der EU kann die Förderung von Unternehmen sein, welche sich auf die Bereitstellung von Wartung und Support von bereits bestehenden Open Source Lösungen spezialisieren. Die europäische OpenSourceLandschaft braucht mehr Flexibilität, um qualifizierte Fachkräfte und innovative Start-ups in der EU zu halten. Dazu gehören erleichterte Unternehmensgründungen, frühe finanzielle Förderung und regulatorische Ausnahmen, die jungen Projekten ermöglichen, ihr Potenzial schneller zu entfalten. Um die Wiederverwendung bestehender EU-Lösungen zu beschleunigen, ist ein barrierearmer Zugang von entscheidender Bedeutung idealerweise über etablierte Rahmenverträge oder vergleichbare Abrufmechanismen. Spezielle themenspezifische Arbeitsgruppen (z. B. Cloud, Daten, KI, Arbeitsplatz, Zusammenarbeit) würden die Harmonisierung, den Wissensaustausch und die Interoperabilität zwischen den Mitgliedstaaten weiter fördern. Hinsichtlich der Definition von EU-Lösungen wäre zu hinterfragen, welche Kriterien dafür herangezogen werden (z. B. Firmensitz, Eigentumsverhältnisse oder Finanzierungsquellen). Die Stärkung öffentlich-privater Partnerschaften und Fachgemeinschaften ist der Schlüssel zur Förderung von Innovation. Referenzarchitekturen und transparente Erfolgsgeschichten sollten den Interessengruppen als Leitfaden von der Problemidentifizierung bis zur Bereitstellung operativer Lösungen dienen. Klare Zulassungs- und Qualitätskriterien für private Unternehmen, die zur Open-Source-Entwicklung beitragen, können dazu beitragen, Vertrauen, Nachhaltigkeit und langfristigen Wert innerhalb des EU-Ökosystems zu gewährleisten.

The Deutsche Blinden- und Sehbehindertenverband e.V. (DBSV), as the umbrella organisation, represents the interests of 1.2 million blind and visually impaired people in Germany. In our view, a European open source strategy must explicitly address how accessibility and usability of open source software can be ensured in the long term. In particular, it must be ensured that the assistive technologies necessary for persons with disabilities reach a level of development in the open source field that allows professional work in education, employment and everyday life. Assistive technologies include screen readers to read screen content and control software, and screen magnification programs. These technologies are essential for blind and visually impaired people to benefit from a digital workplace. However, the currently mature screen readers and magnification programs are not available in comparable quality for the open source

feedback: Working for a large IT service provider operating in Germany, Austria, and Switzerland in Data and AI, I experience several structural problems regarding European software adoption in businesses. First of all companies like Swish, Allegro, willhaben or iDEAL clearly demonstrate that Europe has the talent and innovation to build relevant technology companies but they often remain too locally and struggle with necessary scalability. Europe doesnt have a talent problem. It has a scale + coordination problem. First of all, implementing European software internally in a company (unless it operates at the scale of SAP) would often require financial support. Frequently, we include European alternatives in tenders, but they are technically just not yet as advanced as their American counterparts while often being similarly priced. We would however sometimes even go with them because they can still be adaptable to our processes however in the end, the priceperformance ratio decides. Without a clear price advantage, the safer and more mature U.S. solution usually wins. This creates a vicious cycle: without customers, European vendors cannot scale; without scale, they cannot improve their products. Therefore, the European Union should subsidize not only software companies themselves but also the companies that adopt European technology. Supporting demand is just as important as supporting supply. Second, European sovereignty does not lie in the isolated implementation of open-source tools like LibreOffice, selfhosted VMs or GPUservers. Running 500 self-hosted Linux boxes isnt sovereignty its just expensive chaos. Sovereignty comes from platforms, business standards and ecosystems, not from replacing one application at a time. Fragmentation weakens us and is not helpful in a companies IT architecture. German and Austrian companies often equate open source or sovereignty with running everything on their own locally hosted infrastructure, with their own it support, fully in-house. However, this approach simply reintroduces hidden costs: personnel, expertise, maintenance, security, and operational complexity. In many cases, these costs exceed those of commercial SaaS solutions. Open source and souverenity should not mean self-host everything, but rather maintaining control while leveraging professionally managed services or SASS platforms. What we actually need are scalable European SaaS solutions that are plug-and-play, enterprise-ready, and hosted in Europe as well as good open source IT service support. Create EU-certified managed service providers that host major open-source stacks professionally. Instead of thousands of individual Linux installations that nobody can effectively manage, we need standardized, centrally operated services that reduce complexity and deliver compliance, security, and reliability out of the box. European sovereignty does not mean moving everything back in-house. It means using software products that operate under European jurisdiction, comply with European laws, protect data, and reduce strategic dependencies. Ultimately, if Europe truly wants digital independence, it must think bigger: fewer fragmented initiatives, more coordinated investments, stronger publicprivate partnerships, and the deliberate creation of European champions that can compete globally on both quality and scale. Change all european agencies to similar platforms like SAP or Nextcloud - and financially support the private companies that follow. Officially Label European AI (Mistral), IT service providers or software that follow european rules and data protection with a european label so that companies can trustfully use them, without hosting everything themselves but still being sure about safety, european sovereignty and european innovation.

The EU's strategic direction for open source should fundamentally prioritize participation over creation. Rather than launching new initiatives in already-served domains, European funding should focus on encouraging meaningful European participation in existing, recognized open source projects. This participation must occur at both the technical level (code contributions, maintenance) and at the governance level (involvement in steering committees and decision-making bodies). Implementation should begin by identifying one or two strategic projects per technology domain that already demonstrate global traction and healthy communities. European funding would then support European developers and companies in contributing substantively to these projects, leveraging mature codebases refined through years of diverse use cases and testing. New projects built "from scratch" should be reserved exclusively for situations where a genuine technology gap exists with no mature alternatives. Even then, such projects must be designed from inception to appeal to the worldwide community, not exclusively to European participants. The goal should be globally relevant solutions with strong European leadership, not European alternatives to existing global solutions. When governance problems arise in mature projects, the appropriate response is supporting a fork of the existing codebase rather than creating an entirely new competing project. Forking preserves the maturity and quality of proven code while addressing governance concerns through a new organizational structure. A critical principle must guide all European open source funding: solutions imposing strong national restrictions on usage and governance must be actively discouraged. European funding must have a genuine pan-European dimension rather than serving to promote national platforms at the European level. When national champions are elevated to European status, the result is fragmentation and internal competition rather than the unified strength Europe needs to compete globally. Licensing frameworks must remain market-friendly and avoid creating barriers to commercial participation. The EU should resist the temptation toward over-regulation, introducing new requirements only where existing frameworks demonstrate clear gaps. Excessive regulation makes European projects less attractive compared to global alternatives operating under more flexible frameworks. Most importantly, European public administrations and the European Commission itself must become demonstrable users of the open source software they fund. This requirement should be non-negotiable: funding should be conditional on documented public sector usage commitments with transparency mechanisms showing actual deployment. Procurement policies must align with funding priorities. This usage requirement serves multiple critical functions: it ensures projects address real operational needs rather than theoretical requirements, creates a stable user base providing consistent requirements and validation, and demonstrates genuine commitment beyond rhetorical support. If the European public sector is unwilling to use the software it funds, why should private companies take the risk?

Llevo más de 30 años desarrollando software FLOSS. Algunos de esos proyectos han alcanzado una popularidad razonable y han sido utilizados durante años por empresas de primer nivel en todo el mundo, en ocasiones formando parte directa de sistemas críticos para su operativa diaria o incluso de sus fuentes de ingresos. Y, aun así, en todo ese tiempo no he visto ni un duro de vuelta. La sensación es inevitablemente agridulce. Por un lado, me siento profundamente orgulloso de haber contribuido a algo útil, duradero y ampliamente utilizado. Por otro, no puedo evitar pensar en todo el valor que he generado sin recibir absolutamente nada a cambio, más allá de la satisfacción personal y algún thanks en un README. Cuando se habla de Open Source, mucha gente piensa inmediatamente en Linux y en unos pocos proyectos emblemáticos más. Pero eso es solo la punta del iceberg. La verdadera magia del Open Source está en que casi cualquier cosa que necesites, alguien ya la ha creado antes. Algunas de esas piezas son grandes, generales y con un público masivo; otras son pequeñas, muy específicas y apenas visibles. Pero cuando las necesitas, están ahí. Y ese es precisamente el software que marca la diferencia: el que permite construir componentes mayores, sistemas más complejos y aplicaciones completas sobre una base ya existente. Ese ecosistema está formado por miles de módulos desarrollados por personas anónimas, en su tiempo libre, porque sí, porque les pica la curiosidad, porque les hace falta algo y deciden compartirlo, o simplemente porque les va la marcha. Y puedo hablar con conocimiento de causa de la vida de ese tipo de desarrollador Open Source: el que no trabaja en una empresa que le pague por hacer Open Source, sino el que lo hace casi de tapadillo. El que programa mientras su jefe hace la vista gorda (porque en el fondo también entiende el veneno), o en los ratos libres los fines de semana, mientras su pareja lo mira de reojo y suelta el clásico ¿otra vez pegado al ordenador?. El que se levanta temprano un sábado, cuando todo el mundo duerme, para avanzar un poco en ese módulo que solo iba a ser una tarde. Y, en el fondo, no me quejo de no haber sido compensado económicamente. Lo que realmente me frustra es pensar en todas las ideas que tengo y que no desarrollo, en todos los proyectos que podrían existir y no existen, simplemente porque para mí esto es y tiene que ser un hobby. Porque hay facturas que pagar, prioridades que atender y un mundo real que no se sostiene con commits. Ahí es donde, creo, está el verdadero coste oculto del Open Source. No en lo que no se ha pagado, sino en todo lo que podría haberse creado y no se creó.

I have been developing FLOSS software for more than 30 years. Some of these projects have become reasonably popular and have been used for years by top companies around the world, sometimes directly part of systems critical to their daily operations or even their sources of revenue. And yet, throughout that time, I have not seen a hard return. The sensation is inevitably sweet-sour. On the one hand, I am deeply proud to have contributed to something useful, long-lasting and widely used. On the other hand, I cannot avoid thinking about all the value I have created without receiving absolutely nothing in return, beyond personal satisfaction and some thanks in a README. When talking about Open Source, many people think immediately about Linux and a few more flagship projects. But that is just the tip of the iceberg. The real magic of Open Source is that almost anything you need, someone has already created it before. Some of these pieces are large, general and with a mass audience; others are small, very specific and barely visible. But when you need them, they are there. And that is precisely the software that makes the di

feedback: Se bifogad fil. Om Internetstiftelsen: Internetstiftelsen är en oberoende, allmännyttig organisation med uppdraget att verka för ett internet som bidrar positivt till både människa och samhälle. Vår vision är att alla i Sverige ska vilja, våga och kunna använda internet. Sammanfattning Öppen källkod erbjuder betydande samhällsnyttor och är en central drivkraft för digitalisering, innovation och teknologisk självständighet inom EU. Samtidigt kvarstår hinder i form av osäkerhet kring tillförlitlighet, krav på kommersiella supportmotparter samt bristande finansieringsmodeller för långsiktigt underhåll av projekt. För att stärka sektorn bör EU vidta åtgärder som möjliggör hållbar utveckling av strategiskt viktig öppen programvara, särskilt inom kritisk digital infrastruktur såsom backbone-internet och kommunikationsprotokoll. Riktat stöd och långsiktig finansiering kan bidra till ökad cyberresiliens, minskat leverantörsberoende och stärkt konkurrenskraft i hela unionen.

About the Internet Foundation: The Internet Foundation is an independent, public benefit organisation whose mission is to promote an Internet that makes a positive contribution to both people and society. Our vision is that everyone in Sweden should be willing, confident and able to use the internet. Summary Open Source Code offers significant societal benefits and is a key driver of digitalisation, innovation and technological autonomy in the EU. At the same time, barriers remain in the form of uncertainty about reliability, requirements for commercial support counterparts, and a lack of funding models for long-term maintenance of projects. To strengthen the sector, the EU should take measures enabling the sustainable development of strategically important open source software, particularly in critical digital infrastructure such as backbone internet and communication protocols. Targeted support and long-term financing can help increase cyber resilience, reduce vendor dependency and strengthen competitiveness across the Union.

feedback: Our foundation organizes cultural events for ~10 years at this point, primarily with volunteers. We have used Open Source solutions for years, allowing us to both lower costs and achieve things we could not otherwise afford (fully digitalized and centralized inventory, online invoicing and document signing), and customize those solutions to match what we do and make our events better than we otherwise could do with closed-source software (custom ticketing and event management software, metrics collection, one-off computer provisioning systems and more). Commercial software vendors would rarely even talk to us with the budget we have - rather low, and the vast majority of it goes into paying for the event location and attractions, not for the infra around it. Some of the solutions we used/created were shared with other organizations doing similar things in Poland, and as a result they could reuse them and spend the limited volunteer time we all have on more important things, without breaking their own budgets. Another big plus is that, as long as we host a given piece of software ourselves, all the data stays on our servers, instead of sharing it all with a company that might not support the same values regarding privacy as we do. Long story short - we love Open Source. Let's do more of it.

EU should strongly support not only in declaration but in action the development and widespread adoption of free software and copyleft licenses, like Affero GPL and EUPL. Public funding must contribute to increasing the common good in a way that makes it difficult for Big Tech to exploit it without contributing back. AGPL and EUPL licenses as opposed to non-copyleft licenses like MIT or BSD have been proven effective in that, as Googles AGPL policy shows. Such policy would realize the principles of the EU, such as the protection of human rights and sustainable development. Meanwhile the current model of operation, in which public money supports the development of Big Tech companies, contradicts this idea. We are facing the absurdity products from Big Tech are dominant even in public institutionsand as a result public employees are forced during work hours to create value (such as data) for private companies. Companies, lets notice, that are subordinate to the authorities of non-EU country, whose political stability and dedication to human rights (or even human life would be fair to say) and to democracy are today questionable. Unfortunately, as we can see, these political and commercial impact are intertwined in the US today, and the authorities do not hesitate to use all means of influence to maintain the oligopolies of their businesses. One would like to see the same determination in the EU authorities. The last decade has also shown how difficult it is to enforce European laws on non-European companies let us learn from this and draw conclusions for the future. Free software also allows for more efficient use of resources money, labor, talent, and time (which is at essence in a race against the growing power of digital oligopolies): effort that has already been done is not repeated, but rather the general intellect is developed and thanks to copyleft licenses, it becomes secured and equally accessible to everyone. The EU and MSs should implement the requirement for free software and copyleft, together with the principle of interoperability, in their public procurement. This will ensure the rational management of public funds. The same rules should apply to the requirements for granting programs from EU, member states, and associated countries funding opportunities. Public funds public ownership of the code. The EU should fund the infrastructure that is critical for Europe's digital sovereignty from data servers and clouds, through open APIs, to software for public institutions. Free source operating systems for mobile devices is particularly important for the security of data generated by children, who begin their digital lives with tablets and smartphones. Publicly funded, easily accessible range of services and products based on free software and copyleft should eventually replace proprietary systems. Finally, the issue of securing one of the key pillars of democracy, namely public debate. Since ancient times, the agora has been a place where discussions took place, different positions were presented, and it was only through their clash that the best decisions and ideas emerged. Today, unfortunately, it is terrorized by algorithms they dictate which voices are amplified and which cannot break through. Instead of the development of general intellect and the ability to think critically,from multiple perspectives, they reinforce extreme opinions. Democracy cannot exist without freedom of debate (which is more than just freedom of expression for individuals) it is the task of EU institutions to ensure this freedom by supporting alternative spaces for discussion, such as social media based on FOSS. The fight against disinformation cannot be won when all power is handed over to the owners of companies whose business model is based on spreading disinformation. Funding FOSS SM would be in line with the protection of minorities' rights to participate in d

It will be necessary to plan for the medium and long term and also to act in a more sustainable way. Investment in RISC-V is a start. We need to start investing in our future and independence. NOW!
