feedback: European open digital industry development requires enabling businesses and open digital ecosystems to interface effectively with procurement and funding mechanisms. This response proposes custodian organisations managing dual-fund mechanisms, four-way value chain separation in procurement, and immediate policy declarations making open source the default. Implementation pathway sequences 40+ concrete measures across four timeframes, from immediate Commission desktop migration through long-term industrial strategy development. We welcome further engagement to develop and implement an open Digital strategy for Europe. The detail of our response is contained in the attached file.

European DIGITAL SME Alliance supports the Commissions initiative to create a cohesive strategy for European Open Digital Ecosystems, at the condition that this does not become exclusive of portions of the existing market. DIGITAL SME supports the boost of made-in-Europe solutions in AI, digital public infrastructure and all the critical tech layers that are key to attain tech sovereignty, including via open-source solutions, to reduce vendor lock-in and foster better interoperability. DIGITAL SME particularly looks forward the publication of the Tech Sovereignty Package, and in particular the Cloud and AI Development Act, its core pillar, as a crucial opportunity to cut the dependency on extra-EU hyperscalers and boost European homegrown alternative solutions. Please find attached an initial response by the European DIGITAL SME Alliance on the European Open Digital Ecosystems Strategy. A full response will be published after further consultations with its members.

Associazione Italiana Internet Provider (AIIP) is the oldest and largest association of ICT operators in Italy and has been representing for 30 years more than 60 Italian SME operators, who have been and still are committed to create an open, distributed, and independent telecom network, including by setting up colocation data centres and offering and/or using them to provide housing, hosting, and cloud and edge services. AIIP welcomes the opportunity to submit its contribution to the European Open Digital Ecosystems initiative. Open-source and sovereign data management represent two fundamental pillars for building a more open, efficient, and independent Internet, enabling innovation, trust, and resilience across digital services and infrastructures. By promoting open digital infrastructure and reducing reliance on non-EU proprietary technologies, this initiative can help secure a more sovereign and secure, digital future for citizens, businesses and public administrations alike. Please find our contribution in the attached document.

feedback: (1) Strengths in general: highly educated, experienced and enthusiastic developer workforce Weaknesses in general: funding for open source projects. Barriers: (i) training for prospective users is severely lacking. It's difficult to retrain decades of muscle memory when switching to OSS. Also: support, support, support. No OSS operating system that is guaranteed to work out of the box. Training on-prem support personnel. Buying premium support from specialized European companies. Lack of enforceable contracts (see DORA). (ii) yet again, funding. Open source projects would need direct funding and investments from dedicated government agencies (see the GNOME project, not too long ago). Time spent on FOSS projects for the public good are not reciprocated by society. Open source should be better protected from pilfering by closed source parties. (2) Free availability of FOSS enables digital independence from foreign actors (governments, corporations), the ability to change and tailor existing software to specific needs at man-hour cost, and avoiding vendor lock-in. In terms of risk and security, it's a double edged sword: anyone can contribute anything to open source, so project maintainers have a greater responsibility in reviewing contributions before allowing them to get merged into the main code base. On the other hand, if anyone can see and read the source, that means more eyes looking out for existing issues. Mature open source projects tend to be more secure than proprietary ones. Last, but not least, the nature of open source software makes it virtually impossible to create and maintain backdoors to said software. (3) Allocating budget at the EU level to fund locally based (F)OSS projects by way of tenders/applications. Creating a dedicated EU institution to employ senior developers that regularly work on the security aspects of select projects, based on adoption. A new EU body to regularly draft EU recommendations (and even directives) for financing and coordinating open source projects within the Union. Creating a common legal framework (maybe under the umbrella of the 28th regime) to allow EU-based OSS companies to operate frictionless within all member states of the Union. Classifying unpaid work on FOSS projects or related support activities as non-profit work or work for the public good. (4) Operating systems development, because the dependence on American tech companies for the most basic layer of computer interactions is probably the greatest risk to digital sovereignty that currently exists. Cloud infrastructure and related projects, because right now, the largest cloud providers operating in the EU are all foreign in origin. Database and data storage projects, because governments and institutions should always care more about the data than the means to process it. (5) General purpose OSS projects (operating systems, database projects, webservers, etc.) can benefit all areas above. Specialized software, such as accounting, healthcare management, etc. might still be better off closed source.

Per rafforzare realmente lecosistema open source europeo non basta investire solo in grandi progetti industriali o programmi di ricerca: è fondamentale sostenere le comunità, le associazioni e le infrastrutture sociali che ogni giorno rendono lopen source vivo, accessibile e adottabile. Associazioni come Fedimedia Italia svolgono un ruolo chiave nella promozione e nella diffusione del Fediverso e delle tecnologie open source: accompagnano utenti, amministrazioni pubbliche e organizzazioni private nelladozione di piattaforme aperte; offrono competenze su governance, moderazione, interoperabilità e migrazione; e contribuiscono a creare fiducia e consapevolezza attorno a modelli digitali alternativi alle Big Tech. Uno dei principali ostacoli alladozione dellopen source è infatti la mancanza di risorse stabili per coprire i costi strutturali: hosting, sicurezza, manutenzione, supporto agli utenti, formazione, documentazione e attività di coordinamento delle comunità. Senza un sostegno economico continuativo, molte realtà open source rimangono fragili, nonostante producano un elevato valore pubblico. Per questo lUE dovrebbe: riconoscere formalmente il ruolo delle associazioni e fondazioni open source come infrastrutture civiche digitali; prevedere meccanismi di finanziamento strutturali e ricorrenti, non limitati a bandi sperimentali o a breve termine; facilitare laccesso di queste realtà agli appalti pubblici, anche attraverso criteri che valorizzino interoperabilità, assenza di lock-in e governance aperta; sostenere modelli imprenditoriali e associativi ibridi e sostenibili, che combinino servizi, supporto, donazioni, membership e partenariati pubblico-privati; investire in reti europee di supporto al Fediverso e ai beni comuni digitali, favorendo la cooperazione tra Stati membri. Il valore dellopen source per le organizzazioni pubbliche e private non è solo economico, ma anche strategico e democratico: riduzione delle dipendenze esterne, maggiore trasparenza, sicurezza verificabile, controllo sui dati, resilienza delle infrastrutture e capacità di adattamento nel tempo. Sostenere queste realtà significa quindi investire nella sovranità tecnologica europea, rafforzando un ecosistema digitale aperto che non sia dominato da pochi attori globali, ma costruito e governato collettivamente nellinteresse pubblico.

To truly strengthen the European open source ecosystem, it is not enough to invest only in major industrial projects or research programmes. it is crucial to support communities, associations and social infrastructure that make source lopen live, accessible and adoptable every day. Associations such as Fedimedia Italia play a key role in promoting and disseminating Fediverse and open source technologies: accompany users, public administrations and private organisations in the adoption of open platforms; offer expertise on governance, moderation, interoperability and migration; they help build trust and awareness around digital models that are alternative to Big Tech. One of the main obstacles to the adoption of open source is the lack of stable resources to cover structural costs: hosting, security, maintenance, user support, training, documentation and community coordination activities. Without continued economic support, many open source realities remain fragile, despite producing high public value. This is why the EU should: formally recognise the role of open source associations and foundations as digital civic infrastructures; provide for structural and recurrent funding mechanisms, not limited to experimental or short-term calls; facilitate their access to public procurement, including through criteria that enhance interoperability, lack of lock-in and open governance; support hybrid and sustainable business and associative models, combining serv

feedback: About eco: With approximately 1,000 member companies, eco (international.eco.de) is the leading Association of the Internet Industry in Europe. Since 1995, eco has been highly instrumental in shaping the Internet, fostering new technologies, forming framework conditions, and representing the interests of its members in politics and international forums. eco has offices based in Cologne, Berlin and Brussels. In its work, eco primarily advocates for a high-performance, reliable and trustworthy ecosystem of digital infrastructures and services.

feedback: Europes digital future increasingly depends on open digital ecosystems, yet current policies do not sufficiently address structural risks arising from underinvestment, fragmented governance and persistent external dependencies. Although open source software underpins a large share of Europes digital infrastructure, its long-term sustainability, security and integration into industrial value chains remain inadequately supported. This creates vulnerabilities affecting technological sovereignty, security of supply and competitiveness. A first structural challenge is the mismatch between Europes extensive reliance on open source and the lack of systematic, long-term investment in its maintenance, security auditing and governance. Many critical components depend on small, under-resourced communities, creating systemic risks for public administrations, critical infrastructure and European industry. A second challenge concerns security of supply. The EU increasingly depends on software, hardware and embedded systems that cannot be independently audited, maintained or adapted. These dependencies expose Europe to geopolitical, legal and supply-chain risks linked to non-EU jurisdictions and proprietary technologies, including the risk of unilateral service discontinuity. A third challenge is the disconnect between open digital assets and Europes industrial and manufacturing base. Open source software, open hardware designs and open standards are rarely embedded in regional innovation, industrial design and production ecosystems. As a result, Europe remains largely a user rather than a co-producer of the digital and industrial infrastructure it depends on. Open source is a foundational enabler of technological sovereignty and strategic autonomy, understood not as isolation but as the sustained capacity to control, adapt and evolve critical digital and industrial infrastructures without unilateral external constraints. By enabling transparency, auditability and the right to modify and redistribute, open source reduces vendor lock-in, mitigates systemic risk and enables sovereignty without isolation, while remaining compatible with global collaboration and interoperability. To translate these principles into durable capacity, the European Open Digital Ecosystem Strategy should position the European Commission as a strategic coordinator and steward of Europes open digital and industrial commons. Beyond software policy, the Strategy should promote the establishment of Open Industrial Design and Manufacturing Labs in every EU region. These labs would act as shared infrastructures where open source software, open hardware designs, open data and open standards converge in industrial contexts, enabling SMEs, startups, researchers, public administrations and citizens to co-design, prototype, test and locally manufacture interoperable and reusable products. They would serve as regional anchors for technological sovereignty and security of supply. Public procurement should recognise open source and open industrial design as strategic public assets. Software, hardware designs and specifications developed with public funding should be openly licensed and systematically reused, supported by open source and open design first assessments for mission-critical systems. Procurement can act as a demand-side driver for open digital and industrial ecosystems. Long-term sustainability requires moving beyond project-based funding towards structural investment. A European Sovereign Tech and Open Source Fund, combined with support for regional Open Industrial Design Labs, would strengthen EU digital and industrial resilience. These labs can be supported through coordinated use of ERDF, Horizon Europe and Digital Europe.

feedback: Wir als Interessengemeinschaft IT der Gewerkschaft GPA begrüßen die EU-Initiative zu europäischen offenen digitalen Ökosystemen. Das GPA-Bundesforum (Nov. 2025) beschloss mit großer Mehrheit den von der IG IT eingebrachten Antrag zu digitaler Souveränität. Die zentralen Forderungen sind auch für diese Stellungnahme relevant: verpflichtenden Einsatz von Open Source/Freier Software im öffentlichen Bereich mit kohärenter OSS-Roadmap (Migration, Interoperabilität, Sicherheit) sowie in kritischer Infrastruktur; steuerliche Begünstigung gemeinwohlorientierter Freier Software. Für KI fordern wir Open Source/Open Weights: Bei großen LLM-Systemen, die mit umfassenden Datenquellen (Menschheitswissen) trainiert wurden und teils unklar lizenziert sind, sollen Modelle/Weights verpflichtend veröffentlicht werden. Zudem braucht es einen entschiedenen Einsatz gegen (die Ausweitung von) Softwarepatenten. Querschnitt: Bildung/ForschungVerpflichtende Nutzung von OSS in Schule, Bildung und Forschung mit systematischen Schulungen für Lehrer:innen und IT-Verantwortliche. Ergänzend: Förderprogramme (Bildung, Gesundheit, Verwaltung), Kooperationen mit Hochschulen/Zivilgesellschaft (z.B. Open Source Program Offices) sowie Inkubatoren, damit Nutzung auch zu Beiträgen (Feedback, Doku, Peer-Support) und zu neuen Lösungen führt. Kritik am FramingOpen Source ist weniger ein eigener Sektor als kollaborative Infrastruktur zwischen Anwender:innen und Unternehmen (auch Wettbewerbern). Kernnutzen: weniger Abhängigkeit/Überwachung, mehr Anpassbarkeit und Innovation sowie volkswirtschaftliche Einsparungen; Support/Integration sollen in einem echten Wettbewerb verfügbar sein. 1. Stärken/Schwächen & HindernisseStärken: Unabhängigkeit von Monopolen, Anpassbarkeit, Transparenz/Prüfbarkeit, Innovation.Hindernisse: Lock-in durch proprietäre Ökosysteme (Kundenbindung), Unterfinanzierung von Maintenance/Security, Know-how-Defizite. Problematisch sind Rechtsrahmen, die Lock-in stützen können (z.B. rechtlicher DRM-Schutz); solche Effekte sollten reduziert werden. 2. Mehrwert für öffentlichen & privaten SektorMeist niedrigere Kosten und sinkende Total Cost of Ownership, wenn Migration, Skills und Support mitgeplant werden. Weniger Anbieterbindung, höhere Flexibilität. Sicherheit: nicht automatisch sicher, aber besser unabhängig überprüfbar; Backdoor-Risiken lassen sich durch Transparenz reduzieren. OSS kann Hardware länger nutzbar halten (z.B. alternative Firmware wie OpenWRT, wenn Hersteller-Updates enden). 3. EU-Maßnahmen zur UnterstützungOSS als strategische Infrastruktur behandeln: (a) Beschaffung konsequent OSS-freundlich und mit offenen Standards, (b) verbindliche OSS-Vorgaben schrittweise (Verwaltung, Bildung/Forschung, kritische Infrastruktur), (c) steuerliche Lenkung, (d) Finanzierung für dauerhafte Wartung, Core-Developer, Security-Audits und öffentliche Zertifizierung, (e) Förderung von Community-Austauschformaten (User Groups/Plattformen) und Aufbau europäischer Support-/Integrationsangebote. 4. Prioritäre TechnologiebereicheEU-gehostete, OSS-basierte Code-Plattform als Alternative zu GitHub (z.B. Forgejo/Codeberg) inkl. verlässlicher Authentisierung. Gatekeeper-Technologien am Smartphone: Unterstützung freier Android-Derivate (LineageOS/GrapheneOS). Backend: priorisierte Migration zu offenen Storage-Systemen. 5. Sektoren für Wettbewerbsfähigkeit & CyberresilienzÜberall mit starker Anbieterbindung (Verwaltung, Bildung, Gesundheit, Infrastruktur, Industrie/SMEs). OSS schafft Wettbewerbsvoraussetzungen; Kriterien müssen Open-Core-Scheinlösungen ausschließen. Für Resilienz sind längere und automatisierbare Update-Zyklen besonders für Firmware/IoT zentral.

feedback:
Fairphone welcomes the European Commissions initiative to develop a European Open Digital Ecosystem Strategy. We believe technological sovereignty and the circular economy are interconnected: truly sustainable hardware requires an open and long lasting software. Our vision about the key pillars for an Open Digital Ecosystem: 1. Open Source and Circular Economy Currently, the EU imports the vast majority of its smartphones. Open Source and alternative OSes help to extend the lifespan of devices, therefore it helps in boosting the European circular economy to shift consumer spending from product acquisition (where value flows to non-EU manufacturers) to maintenance and repair services (where value stays in the local EU economy). Every year a device stays in use is a year the user spends on European-based services and repairs rather than a new imported handset. This supports local SMEs in the repair and refurbishment sectors. Recommendation: The EU should recognize OSS as a prerequisite for the "Right to Repair" to ensure a 8-year device lifespan also supporting independent OS providers like postmarketOS, LineageOS, or /e/OS. 2. Addressing the "Black Box" barrier in Hardware Currently, European hardware innovators are often hindered by the proprietary nature of chipsets and components from non-EU vendors, and the lack of open documentation and upstreamed" drivers. The proprietary "black box" drivers are harder to audit and maintain. In an era where the Cyber Resilience Act (CRA) mandates lifetime security, being dependent on a third-party vendors secret code is a massive legal and financial liability for EU firms. Recommendations: The EU should incentivize or mandate that hardware components sold provide the necessary documentation to allow open-source communities to maintain them. Just as the EU is pushing for SBOMs in software, it should require a "Component support map" that guarantees the availability of documentation for the entire expected lifespan of the device (e.g., 8 years). This reduces "vendor lock-in" and empowers European SMEs to build long-lasting products. The EU should require that any hardware component vendor must "upstream" their drivers to the main Linux kernel to ensure that the hardware can be maintained by anyone, not just the original vendor. 3. Open Source as a guarantee for privacy and data sovereignty Proprietary operating systems and drivers often contain hard-coded, invisible telemetry for the end users that exports user metadata and are hosted to servers outside EU jurisdiction, undermining GDPR. Open Source provides a necessary method to verify a device's true function. Recommendations: The EU should require auditability through Open Sourcing, allowing independent European security researchers to check the code for "backdoors" or unauthorized data collection. EU public institutions should favor open-source and privacy-hardened software ecosystems. 4. Open Standards for Interoperability To foster a competitive European ecosystem, we need strict adherence to open standards. This prevents dominant platforms from creating "walled gardens" that exclude sustainable hardware alternatives. Open digital ecosystems ensure that a user can access all essential European digital services without being forced into a specific proprietary software stack Recommendation: The strategy should support open standards. While the Digital Markets Act (DMA) has started to address this, a few technical areas remain a "walled garden" problem. Support for open protocols like Matrix for messaging or Fediverse/ActivityPub (this includes Mastodon) for social media should be encouraged for all critical communication infrastructure in Europe. Conclusion Transitioning to a circular economy requires an open digital ecosystem. As long as software is a black box and drivers are proprietary, European electronics wont last. We must decouple har

feedback: The European Union faces a strategic crossroads regarding the adoption and development of open-source technologies for cloud services. While open source has become a global driver of innovation, competition, and technological independence, Europe currently plays a limited role in leading major open source projects. Most significant initiativesespecially those shaping cloud and digital infrastructure, such as Kubernetes or Linuxare governed by US based organisations like the Linux Foundation, whose European footprint remains minimal. This structural reliance weakens Europes capacity to shape standards, ensure technological sovereignty, and build secure, interoperable cloud infrastructures. Several barriers slow down both the adoption and the sustainable development of high quality open source solutions in Europe. Organisations often face vendor lock in from incumbent technology providers, making migration costly and risky. The proliferation of competing open source projects also complicates identifying stable and widely adopted options. In addition, many open source communities are effectively controlled by a single vendor, creating de facto proprietary models that reduce trust and hinder broad European participation. From a contribution standpoint, companies must allocate significant technical and promotional resourcesan investment that many struggle to justify without targeted support mechanisms. Despite these challenges, open source delivers substantial added value for both public and private sectors. It promotes standardisation, reduces operational complexity, accelerates time to market for technology providers, and lowers costs by stimulating competition. Equally important, open source ensures independence from proprietary vendors, giving organisations full control over the evolution of their digital solutionsan essential component of security and resilience. For instance, the widespread adoption of Kubernetes has enabled interoperability across cloud providers and reduced the risk of lock in, creating a more dynamic and competitive cloud ecosystem. To strengthen Europes open source ecosystem and reinforce technological sovereignty, coordinated action at EU level is required. Possible measures include identifying and promoting open source projects critical to Europes digital future, providing financial incentives to companies contributing to those projects, and incorporating open source requirements into public procurement processes when suitable solutions exist. Such actions would foster competition, accelerate innovation, and reduce dependency on non European vendors. Strategic prioritisation is essential. Europe should focus on technological domains where it currently lacks strong providerssuch as hardware, AI, and cybersecurityas well as emerging digital infrastructures where early leadership can be decisive. By doing so, Europe can ensure it retains control over core technologies underpinning its future competitiveness. Finally, increased use of open source has the potential to enhance competitiveness and cyber resilience across all sectors. Open ecosystems naturally promote transparency, rapid innovation cycles, shared security practices, and interoperabilitykey attributes for a robust and sovereign digital Europe. In this context, developing and adopting a European sovereign cloud, built on open standards and open source technologies, becomes a strategic necessity. Public institutions should lead this shift by integrating open source based solutions into their digital infrastructure and procurement policy, fostering buy European. This will not only strengthen Europes autonomy but also set a baseline for trust, security, and long term technological independence.

feedback: OVHcloud, the leading European cloud provider, welcomes the opportunity to contribute to the European Commissions initiative Towards European open digital ecosystems, in response to the questions suggested in the Call for Evidence. Together with the upcoming Cloud and AI Development Act, these initiatives can provide a coherent framework to strengthen Europes digital sovereignty and competitiveness. Open-source software is a strategic asset and a key enabler of this objective. OVHcloud considers open source to be a foundational layer of Europes digital infrastructure. It enables control over critical technologies, reduces dependency and vendor lock-in, supports security and transparency, and fosters innovation and competition aligned with European values. Europe already benefits from a large and widely adopted open-source ecosystem, yet it remains fragmented and structurally fragile. Insufficient long-term funding, weak incentives for upstream contribution, and reliance on non-European platforms limit its ability to scale and to sustain mission-critical software. This initiative presents an opportunity for the EU to strengthen its capacity to sustain and adopt open source through a horizontal and enabling approach. Complementing the Cloud and AI Development Act, such an approach should focus on shared foundations, ecosystem sustainability, and long-term resilience, ensuring that open source delivers lasting strategic and economic value for Europe.
Please see PDF file attached.

feedback: [Answer 5] In what sectors could an increased use of open source lead to increased competitiveness and cyber resilience? Targeted use of open source can measurably boost both cyberresilience and competitiveness lowering TCO, accelerating innovation cycles and giving European suppliers a credible path to win on trust and sovereignty. Public administration & egovernment: shared OSS building blocks (identity, document services, collaboration) cut duplication, lower TCO and enable interoperable crossborder services. Healthcare & life sciences: auditable software and SBOMs improve patient safety, speed vulnerability handling and enable trusted data sharing. Energy & critical infrastructure: transparent, audited control stacks and secure deployment pipelines reduce systemic risk and accelerate incident response. Finance & insurance: composable OSS platforms let SMEs innovate on secure foundations and reduce vendor lockin in core systems. Manufacturing / Industry 4.0 & Transport: reference stacks for edge compute and secure orchestration shorten timetomarket and enable local adaptation. Research & education: open tools accelerate innovation cycles and workforce skill transfer. An increased use in open source could also lead to cross-sectors-gains, like for example: Platform consolidation + EUhosted infrastructure => lowers entry barriers for European suppliers and SMEs, creating a competitive European supply chain. Federated digital identity + secure container baselines => consistent authentication and hardened runtimes for regulated sectors (health, finance, government). Confidential computing & key sovereignty => enables costefficient accredited hosting while preserving control over secrets. Efficient AI models + robust CI/CD & attestations => make AI adoption affordable, auditable and portable across sectors. Foundations already exist and Europe should build on them. First European initiatives and organisations (e.g. EuroStack efforts, the EU Cloud Sovereignty workstreams, GaiaX experiences as well as openCode and crossEU stewardship pilots) provide concrete building blocks and governance models that can be scaled. At national (German) level, agencies and programmes such as BSI, Cyberagentur and GovTech together with specialized private suppliers bring deep operational experience in secure infrastructure and public service delivery. Standards and regulatory frameworks (e.g. ISO 27001, NIS2, ISO 5230, GDPR) offer a common compliance language and testing baseline.

We support the Commissions initiative on European open digital ecosystems and the objective of reducing structural dependencies in the digital stack. Open source can be a decisive lever for technological sovereignty because it increases user agency, auditability and control of critical infrastructure, while enabling interoperability and reuse. However, the main barrier we observe is not technical maturity; it is market structure and procurement practice. In many public tenders, closed and proprietary stacks benefit from strong first-mover and scale effects: they bundle applications, data and operations, make switching costly, and often rely on tightly coupled, non-EU-controlled infrastructure and services. Without an explicit advantage for open and non-lock-in solutions, incumbents will keep these advantages and change will remain slow. From deployments in public administrations, we can confirm that sovereign-by-design platforms are feasible today. A modern public-service platform can be delivered as SaaS while still avoiding lock-in if it is built on enforceable properties: (1) source code published under an open licence; (2) modular architecture that allows incremental adoption; (3) complete, documented APIs (e.g., REST/OpenAPI) for all operational data in read/write; (4) portable deployment packaging (e.g., containers) so another supplier or the administration can operate the system; and (5) a tested reversibility process that exports data and configurations in machine-readable form. In practice, this enables multi-channel citizen services (web, mobile, conversational access), end-to-end digital procedures, and integration with enabling platforms for identity, payments, notifications and interoperable data exchange, applying the once-only principle and reducing administrative burden. For AI, the same principle applies: architectures should be model-agnostic and allow EU-based or on-prem deployment to avoid a new generation of lock-in. What is missing is a policy and procurement framework that consistently rewards these properties. We recommend EU-level measures and guidance to Member States: 1) Make open, interoperable, reversible a default evaluation axis in public procurement with measurable criteria and explicit scoring advantage (open licence; open standards and data models; documented APIs; reversibility-by-design exit plan). 2) Require a concise lock-in impact statement in tenders, covering data portability, dependency on proprietary PaaS services, and the practical ability for another supplier to run the system. 3) Treat maintenance and security as first-class procurement objects: fund and procure long-term upkeep, vulnerability management and software supply-chain transparency, not only initial delivery. 4) Incentivise contributions back to upstream communities (code, documentation, security fixes) so public investment compounds across administrations and reduces duplication. 5) Support EU-controlled foundation infrastructure (repositories, CI/CD, artifact registries, sovereign cloud/edge options) so the open ecosystem is not dependent on non-EU platforms. Priority technology areas should include interoperable digital public service platforms (web, forms, case handling, bookings, help desks), identity and access management, payment and notification rails, API/data-space middleware, cybersecurity tooling, and trustworthy AI components. The highest-leverage sectors are public administration (especially local government), health and social services, and any domain where continuity, transparency and resilience are critical. In short: if the EU wants open ecosystems to scale, procurement must act as the market-shaping instrument. Giving a clear advantage to open, non-lock-in solutions is the fastest way to align market incentives with the EUs sovereignty objectives.

[Answer 4] What technology areas should be prioritised and why? Priority technology areas should create a secure, scalable, and sovereign foundationthen enable higherlevel capabilities like AI and domain services. Cloudnative platform core (onprem + sovereign service model): Build a modular, standardsbased cloud stack that runs both onprem and via trusted European operators. A single, convergent approach (e.g. aligning DeutschlandStack, Sovereign Cloud Stack, GaiaXaligned efforts) avoids duplicated work and creates a common operational baseline for migration, federation and multivendor operation. This is the platform on which everything else depends. Confidential computing & key sovereignty: Confidential computing enables running workloads on thirdparty infrastructure while the customer retains key control. For public sector usecases this allows accredited European cloud offerings to be used without compromising data protection or operational sovereigntylowering cost and expanding hosting choices. Efficient, sustainable AI model families (beyond bruteforce transformers): Prioritise research and adoption of more resourceefficient ML architectures (sparse models, distillation, retrievalaugmented approaches) to reduce cost, energy use and enable realistic onprem or edge deployment at scale. Robust deployment & developer toolchain (secure containers, CI/CD, SBOMs): Simple, reproducible deployment patternssecure container baselines, curated CI/CD templates, automated SBOM generation and standardized test pipelinesare essential to move solutions from prototype to production across many administrations. AI as integrator & automation enabler: Use AI to automate code quality checks, dependency hygiene, test generation and deployment validationmaking secure, auditable delivery at scale feasible. Mature OSS frameworks & curated reference implementations: Consolidate and harden proven OSS building blocks rather than proliferating competing stacks. Fund stewardship and provide productiongrade reference architectures for databases, messaging, identity, observability and more. Unified, federated digital identity (open standards, multilevel authentication): Provide an interoperable, federationready digital identity layer based on open standards (e.g., OIDC/OAuth2, eIDAScompatible flows) that supports multiple assurance levels. A broadly accepted digital identity enables secure single signon, strong authentication for sensitive services, federated access across administrations and trustable user consent models it is the glue for interoperable, usercentric public services. Open Hardware & hardware sovereignty: Include open hardware (e.g., RISCV ecosystems, open designs for edge devices) as a firstclass priority. Hardware sovereignty reduces singlesupplier dependency, improves auditability down the stack, and is essential for resilient edge and highperformance deployments. Especially development of KI- and efficiency/energy-optimized hardware, software and models could create a huge value creation for Europe rather than becoming the next level of dependency. Skills, education & practical knowhow (OSS, licensing, operational practice): Invest in training and capacity building: practical curricula on OSS development, licensing (how to handle mixedlicense stacks, contribution agreements), secure build pipelines and operational best practices. Offer handson workshops, apprenticeships and project clinics that pair administrations with experienced maintainers to transfer knowhow and reduce legal/operational friction. Practical, small wins accelerate adoption: adopt secure container baselines (e.g., ZenDiS SGCI pilots), provide EUhosted CI runners and registries, deploy a federated identity pilot across a set of administrations, and fund a few crossborder reference implementations.

Decathlon welcomes the European Commissions endeavor to establish a roadmap to support Digital Sovereignty in the Union and appreciates the opportunity to provide feedback on the state of the European Open Source ecosystem. As a global leader in the sporting goods industry, with a deep commitment to digital innovation, we believe that a thriving, collaborative open source ecosystem is a key lever towards ensuring European businesss technological sovereignty and competitiveness. As such we welcome the Commissions initiatives to grow and sustain Open Source technological solutions as new alternatives on the software market. Please find our written answer in pdf attached.

feedback: We have tried to unpublish this feedback, as we have updated the attached document, but this has not been possible because of a repeated technical error. We have then replaced the attachment with the new document, which is also attached to the new feedback published on February 3. Both feedback are from The Document Foundation.

[Answer 3] What concrete measures and actions may be taken at EU level to support the development and growth of the EU open-source sector...? Europe can convert open source from a promise into a strategic pillar but it needs concrete, implementable EUlevel actions. Key measures are straightforward: define clear eligibility and sovereignty criteria; embed those criteria across funding programmes; provide public developer infrastructure; fund longterm maintenance; operationalise automated quality and security checks; and reform procurement to reward portability, governance and sustained contribution. Here are three concrete, practical examples: Public infrastructure + attestations: an EUhosted registry with CI runners and SBOM storage where projects publish machinereadable attestations (passing tests, dependency scans, license checks). Initiatives like openCode aim in this direction; security best practices and tooling can draw on work by the OpenSSF to operationalise supplychain hygiene. Procurement pilots with enforceable maintenance commitments: adopt OSB Alliancestyle procurement guidance and run pilot tenders that require explicit maintenance line items, contribution obligations, and scoring for community governance and portability. This makes public money = public code operational and financially sustainable. Stewardship + secure baselines: create a stewardship fund that pays core maintainers for critical libraries and commissions independent audits; pair this with secure baseline projects such as national secure container initiatives (examples exist at regional level) to provide readytodeploy, reviewed templates for government use. Legal & businessmodel clarity EUPL and practical safeguards: The EUPL 1.2 already provides a solid European licensing foundation that balances copyright protection and reuse. It should remain a central legal instrument, but it can be usefully complemented with practical guidance to protect viable monetisation paths for OSS maintainers. A key risk today is that mature components are commercialised by third parties as SaaS without upstream subscription or support agreements, which can starve maintainers and incentivise a drift back to proprietary models (examples in the ecosystem include licencechanges around major database and middleware projects). Additionally, legal constraints in some jurisdictions (for example, limits on formal transfer of copyright under national law) make constructs like public domain problematic in practice and can introduce unexpected liability or rights gaps. To reduce these risks, the EUPL framework could be extended with bestpractice guidance for mixedlicense stacks, recommended contractual patterns for SaaS provisioning, and clarity on mechanisms that preserve maintainers revenue while guaranteeing public reuse. Small wins matter: publiccode.yml is a case in point a simple, standardised format for software catalogue entries that is easy to implement and yields immediate discoverability and comparability benefits. Practical, interoperable standards, a minimal but trusted EU infrastructure, and a funding model that pays for maintenance will together reduce risk, lower total cost of ownership, and give European industry the footing to outcompete alternatives through superior, sovereign solutions.

[Answer 2] What is the added value of open source for the public and private sectors? Open source is not just a licensing model it is a strategic enabler for both public administrations and private organisations. When assessed against cost, risk, lockin, security and innovation, OSS delivers concrete, measurable advantages but only if policy and practice enable reuse, maintenance and trustworthy deployment. Why it matters Sovereignty & trust: Open code permits independent audit, transparent supplychain proofs (ISO/IEC 5230) and data portability (OpenData concepts). That reduces the strategic risk of opaque vendor stacks and gives public bodies control over critical functions. Cost & TCO: Upfront license savings are only part of the story. Reuse of common, wellmaintained components cuts duplicated development and longterm maintenance costs across administrations and industry. Nevertheless, Open Source products are not free, we need to make sure that vendors are able to continue with high quality solution development based on subscription and support agreements. Risk & security: Public visibility accelerates vulnerability discovery and remediation. Combined with automated tooling (SBOMs, dependency scanning, CI/CD tests), this lowers meantimetopatch and improves operational hygiene. Lockin & interoperability: Open interfaces and reference implementations reduce migration costs and enable multivendor ecosystems, fostering competition and SME participation. Innovation & scale: OSS is the ideal substrate for derivative innovation from bespoke government services to AI models trained on common, auditable foundations. Shared components let teams focus on unique, highervalue features instead of reinventing the wheel (see. doi: 10.2759/430161 "The impact of Open Source Software and Hardware on technological independence, competitiveness and innovation in the EU economy") Concrete examples and enablers Reusable building blocks (Linux, PostgreSQL, Keycloak...) form the backbone of many production clouds and national platforms. National secure container baselines and shared CI/CD templates accelerate secure deployments across agencies, e.g. ZenDiS' Secure Government Container Initiative (SGCI) Automated QA and attestation pipelines (license checks, security scans, SBOMs, e.g. openCode) make procurement decisions evidencebased and comparable. Two KPIs examples to evaluate added value (proposals) Total Cost of Ownership (TCO) over 35 years: compare cumulative costs (acquisition, integration, migration, maintenance, security and exit) between OSSbased and proprietary alternatives to capture lifecycle economics a practical metric to assess real value beyond license fees. See the Public Money, Public Code rationale for lifecycle valuation: https://publiccode.net/ Mean Time to Remediation (MTTR) for critical vulnerabilities (CVSS 9): measure how quickly critical CVEs are fixed and deployed in production across a project portfolio; faster MTTR indicates stronger community responsiveness and operational security posture. Guidance on supplychain hygiene and remediation metrics: https://openssf.org/ Prioritize invest in EUhosted registries and CI/CD, procurement templates that value maintainability and contribution, and durable funding for core maintainers. Combine these with standardized attestations so procurers can objectively compare options. For further reading on sustainability and security frameworks in open source, see Public Money, Public Code (publiccode.net) and the OpenSSF initiative (openssf.org).

The European Open Source Academy (EOSA) welcomes the European Commission's initiative to develop a strategic approach towards open digital ecosystems, particularly as it relates to recognition of and support for open source software (OSS) and open source hardware (OSH). As an institution dedicated to advancing understanding of the importance and impact of open source technologies across Europe, we offer our perspective across four critical dimensions: Excellence and Achievement, Business and Impact, Advocacy and Awareness, and Skills and Education.

feedback: Comments from The Document Foundation, providing an answer to the 5 questions, with a specific section about the opportunities for digital sovereignty represented by desktop software and open document standards, are in the attached file.

[Answer 1] What are the strengths and weaknesses of the EU open-source sector? Open source is a strategic instrument for Europe it delivers transparency, reuse and communitydriven innovation while reducing vendor lockin. But to turn potential into practice we must remove concrete barriers: fragmented discoverability, a chronic maintenance funding gap, limited EUhosted developer infrastructure, and procurement procedures that still privilege established vendors. Europe has a unique opportunity: by aligning policy, funding and tooling, we can pursue a stepwise path to greater digital independence and, through technological innovation, outcompete nonEuropean alternatives in performance and trustworthiness. This is not about protectionism; it is about building resilient, sovereign digital capacity that reflects European values and scales economically. The current dominance of US vendors is not a law of nature it is a market outcome shaped by historical scale and investment patterns. Europe can alter that outcome by pooling demand, funding maintenance, offering trusted public infrastructure, and certifying quality with automated attestations. Competing on trustworthiness, sovereignty, costefficiency and domain fit is a realistic pathway to displace established vendors in key public and enterprise markets. Policy and practice should act together and deliver measurable levers: Procurement: adopt openbydefault tender templates that reward demonstrable governance, portability and contribution back to projects. Practical groundwork already exists the Open Source Business Alliance (OSB Alliance) has developed procurement guidance that can be adopted by public buyers. Infrastructure: provide EUhosted registries, CI/CD resources and curated catalogues so procurers can find operable, maintained software and avoid integration surprises. Initiatives like openCode are already working on public infrastructure and automated compliance/quality checks to make reuse safe and scalable. Sustainability: fund maintenance and security (not just R&D maintenance pools, procurement line items, payments to core maintainers) so critical components are not left to volunteers. EU stakeholders consistently identify underfunding of maintenance as a central barrier to upscaling OSS. Trust & automation: roll out standardized, machineassisted testing and attestation for supplychain hygiene and operational readiness; publish attestations in a Europewide catalogue to create clear trust signals for procurers. Governance & metrics: establish multistakeholder stewardship, clear sovereignty/operability criteria and KPIs (e.g. funding levels, CI health, vulnerability response times) to measure progress. Stakeholders expect EUlevel coordination and longterm stewardship structures. Two measurable targets (proposed baselines to build on) Public investment share for OSS: Aim that, by 2030, at least 25% of public software procurement spend (by value) flows into OSS or publicly funded OSS projects (through direct procurement, maintenance contracts or public grants). This target builds on the call to convert public money into longterm, reusable digital assets and to fund maintenance beyond oneoff R&D. Initiative mapping & consolidation: By 2028, map and coordinate a portfolio of at least 10 EUlevel OSS initiatives and 16 national/regional initiatives (including existing efforts such as national stacks, GaiaXrelated activities, openCode pilots and stewardship experiments), and publish a consolidated catalogue as a working basis for coordination. This responds to repeated calls to reduce fragmentation and create EUlevel coordination. The European Public License (EUPL 1.2) already offers a robust European licensing instrument that supports copyright protection while allowing practical reuse and monetisation patterns for OSS; it can be a sound legal basis for public projects and commercial ecosystems. feedback: Open Source is the equivalent of roads and bridges. It's public infrastructure that enables everything else. Europe is especially good at public infrastructure when you compare with other continents. So let's make sure that the digital world is no exception. I'll keep it short. Two main points: 1. Public money, public code Whenever a company, a citizen, an organisation is receiving public money to develop a piece of software, they must release it in open source. If they want to keep it private, then they should use private money. 2. Universal basic income for open source maintainers. People in Europe have been "nominated" for life to work for our public infrastructure. Let's do the same for our digital infrastructure. Instead of having a huge bureaucracy to give money away to various open source projects, just give a universal basic income for open source projects that are dependencies for our governments and public services. Start small, start there. It's fairly easy to identify those projects and identify the EU citizens behind them, and make sure that they keep contributing. This would ensure a safe and reliable digital infrastructure on top of which many more projects will be able to be build on.

I think that the biggest things that the FOSS sector is in dire need of is more funding and government support and adoption over proprietary software. Most personal computers and smartphones in the EU run proprietary software (Windows 10/11, proprietary forks of Android that comes with every non-Apple smartphone, iOS, MacOS, etc.) and the latter is becoming ever-increasingly hostile towards installing truly open-source and user-respecting operating systems such as LineageOS and GrapheneOS due to anti-consumer decisions from both Google and smartphone manufacturers (Please refer to the "Bootloader Unlock: Wall of Shame" wiki on Github). The desktop side of things is relatively better due to the limitations of OS choice and monopolistic restrictions (such as Google's proprietary Play Integrity making most bank apps not work on "unofficial Android OSes" while the open-source Android Hardware Attestation API built into Android used by GrapheneOS is much more than enough for legitimate security needs. See GrapheneOS' Attestation Compatibility Guide for more details) being rather rare, but it's not perfect. Most computers come with proprietary BIOSes with no easy way to install great open-source options such as Libreboot or Coreboot (which I think is important for such low-level privileged code). GNU/Linux (the kernel itself, then also the tools and desktop environments such as GNOME and KDE) is also more popular and actively developed than ever before, in big part due to Microsoft making Windows 11 an increasingly worse and anti-consumer experience. And all of that makes Linux very viable and attractive for the average user these days, but issues regarding software support (for example Adobe software and online video games with anti-cheat not working and decreased performance on Linux compared to Windows) still exist, which is why all this increased popularity and adoption makes these open-source projects in more need of funding than ever before. All in all, I believe that aid from the EU both in terms of money and in terms of regulatory action (against corporate anti-consumer practices in different spaces) is necessary for the prosperity of Free and Open Source Software in the EU. That will in turn give the EU more digital sovereignty and consumers more choice, control, freedom and rights over the hardware they paid for and the software they use.
Please find in the attached file the feedback from Specific-Group Healthcare GmbH.

feedback: Statement in Support of Open Source Virtualization Infrastructure As an MSP team with over 25 years of combined experience in IT infrastructure management, we want to express strong support for open source digital ecosystems and highlight the critical role Proxmox VE plays in our operations. Over the past year, we have successfully migrated multiple client environments from VMware to Proxmox Virtual Environment. This transition was driven by concerns over vendor lock-in, unpredictable licensing costs following VMware's acquisition by Broadcom, and a desire to provide our clients with sustainable, transparent technology solutions. The results have been overwhelmingly positive: Cost savings have been substantial, allowing our clients to reinvest in other areas of their infrastructure Operational flexibility has improvedwe can scale environments without navigating complex licensing tiers. Technical capability matches or exceeds our previous proprietary solutions, with robust KVM virtualization, integrated Ceph storage, and comprehensive backup options. Long-term viability is assured through active community development and transparent governance Proxmox, developed by an Austrian company, represents exactly the type of European open source success story that deserves support. Strengthening open digital ecosystems reduces dependency on non-EU vendors and gives European businesses genuine choice in critical infrastructure decisions. We encourage the Commission to support policies that foster open source alternatives in virtualization, storage, and datacenter management. The MTC Team - https://www.mtcusa.com

I would like to address the questions as they were put forward by the Commission: 1) Strengths: Yearly FOSDEM conference in Brussels for fostering open source communities. Weaknesses: Lack of contributors with graphic design and user-experience (UX) skills. (i) Main barriers for adoption and maintenance: Competing companies should consider if they can collaborate on developing software for their business sector, because in the end, software needs to meet the shared needs of its users. (ii) Sustainable contributions to OSS communities: Ideally, OSS developers should be able to live from their work to ensure that they have enough time and energy to produce good software. 2) Processing of medical data in the public sector: We can understand much better what our systems do, because of the available source code and the open data formats. We have more freedoms to start new it-projects that integrate with open source software, because it is not obstructing interoperability. We can be more confident, that the software does not perform unwanted operations on this critical and sensitive medical data. We have more control over the software compared to closed source software. 3) The https://kde.org/ project provides a user-friendly interface for non-technical users. Follow the principles from https://publiccode.eu. Support https://eu-os.eu/. Drop the CSA-regulation (COM(2022) 209), because it undermines cybersecurity and is not compatible with open-source. 4) Prioritise sectors where cloud-based software is prevalent to ensure that Europe can run its own sovereign infrastructure. In the case of the software development sector, I like to suggest to support https://forgefed.org/, which will make it easier for OSS developers to transition away from github. The key idea behind ForgeFed is that open source code can be hosted and developed on many different decentralized servers. And with ForgeFed it is possible to reuse one's developer account across these many different servers. This greatly reduces friction for open source contributions on independent source code sharing websites. Reusing accounts is important, because accounts have reputation. Reputation gives trust and trust is important in open source development. In general: Decentralisation leads to more resilience and healthier ecosystems. 5) *sigh* In the military. Closed source can be an Achilles' heel in this sector, because devices can be turned against their owners.

Pragnę podziękować Komisji Unii Europejskiej za podjęcie inicjatywy na rzecz rozwoju ekosystemu otwarto źródłowego. Jest to temat drogi mojemu sercu, który niestety jest pomijany w polityce państwowej wielu krajów członkowskich Unii Europejskiej. Tym bardziej cieszy mnie, iż niniejszy temat jest poruszany na arenie międzynarodowej. Jednakże smuci mnie fakt, iż niniejszy temat jest poruszany jedynie w retoryce mechanizmów rynkowych. Zważywszy na sukces polityczny/legislacyjny jakim jest GDPR i EIDAS pragnę zwrócić uwagę, że należy też rozważyć daleko idące możliwości regulacji prawnej w obrębie ustawodawstwa na szczeblach krajowych. Sektor publiczny krajów członkowskich z mojej perspektywy stanowi największego potencjonalnego konsumenta rozwiązań otwarto-źródłowych. Jednakże ze względy na fragmentacje odpowiedzialności oraz brak inicjatywy ze strony politycznej sektor publiczny nie posiada odpowiednich zachęt do rozwoju oprogramowania otwarto-źródłowego. W celu ilustracji niniejszego problemu pragnę posłużyć się dwoma przykładami. Aktualnie na niemal wszystkich szczeblach administracji państwowej de facto standardem jest system operacyjny Microsoft Windows, który w ostatnich czasach zniesławił się pogorszeniem jakości swojego oprogramowania, działaniami anty-konsumenckimi oraz licznymi podatnościami bezpieczeństwa, które zostały wprowadzone w drodze integracji sztucznej inteligencji na poziomie systemu operacyjnego. Z perspektywy bezpieczeństwa i niezależności cyfrowej Unia Europejska winna rozwijać alternatywę dla systemów operacyjnych wykorzystywanych przez administracje publiczną. Niestety w aktualnym ekosystemie takie działania były by co najmniej marnotrawne. Poszczególne podmioty publiczne mogłyby wykorzystać istniejące dystrybucje Linuxa, jednakże na samym wstępie pojawiają się pytania o odpowiedzialność cywilno-prawną za wykorzystanie owych systemów do przetwarzania poufnych danych. Ponadto żadna z dystrybucji Linuxa (nawet RHEL) nie jest produktem, który mógłby być wdrożony "out-of-the-box" i wymaga dużej ilości konfiguracji, aby była zdatna do wykorzystania w organizacjach zatrudniających tysiące pracowników. Drugim przykładem jest sam system EIDAS, który pomimo sukcesu wciąż ma wiele bolączek. Między innymi samemu napotkałem na problem z owym systemem, kiedy próbowałem się zalogować na niniejszą stronę, aby sporządzić niniejszą opinię. Problem wystąpił na poziomie przekierowania do węzła krajowego. Samo oprogramowanie otwarto-źródłowe nie jest lekarstwem na wszystkie problemy teleinformatyczne, jednakże można się pokusić o tezę, iż owy system mógłby być bardziej stabilny, gdyby był rozwijany w modelu otwarto-źródłowym gdzie nie tylko kooperacja pomiędzy różnymi podmiotami państw członkowskich Unii Europejskiej mogłaby się przyczynić do podwyższenia jakości oprogramowania, ale również ekspertyza ludzi spoza sektora publicznego mogłaby wyłapać błędy i potencjalne podatności bezpieczeństwa. Owa sytuacja dobrze ilustruje, iż istnieje nietrywialna ilość pracy, która jest aktualnie i była by w przyszłości powielana pomiędzy różnymi podmiotami publicznymi. Rozwiązaniem zatem jest kooperacja podmiotów publicznych w celu ujednolicenia, standaryzowania i normalizacji rozwiązań w zakresie wielu projektów, a rozwijanie owych projektów w duchu open-source'a umożliwi większą transparentność i zwiększenie innowacyjności na wielu szczeblach gospodarczych. Dla tego zachęcam Unię Europejską do rozważenia ustawodawstwa, które za zadanie stawia sobie utworzenie ram kooperacji podmiotów publicznych poprzez, między innymi, tworzenie wspólnych międzynarodowych rozwiązań teleinformatycznych na licencji open-source na potrzeby wypełnienia ustawodawczych zobowiązań. Ponadto propon

feedback: Open Future welcomes the opportunity to contribute to this call for evidence, and welcomes the focus of the proposed strategy on open source software and technologies as a way to bolster digital sovereignty. A thriving open source ecosystem is the best path towards building not (just) European alternatives, but an ecosystem that supports alternative ways of developing technology that serves the needs of society. Open source should be understood not just in terms of products openly licensed software code but as digital commons. This shifts the focus from technological artefacts to the social and institutional conditions that sustain them. Please see the attached file for our full response.

feedback: Le CEA soutient pleinement linitiative de la Commission européenne visant à élaborer une stratégie européenne en faveur des écosystèmes numériques ouverts et des solutions open source. En tant quorganisme de recherche et de technologie, le CEA développe, utilise et valorise de nombreux logiciels, dont une part croissante est diffusée sous licence open source, et sappuie largement sur ces solutions dans ses activités de recherche, de développement technologique et dinnovation. À ce titre, le CEA est directement concerné par les enjeux de structuration, de soutenabilité et de gouvernance des écosystèmes open source, qui constituent des leviers clés de compétitivité, dinnovation, de standardisation et de souveraineté technologique. Le CEA partage lanalyse générale présentée dans le document de consultation, tout en soulignant que, malgré la vitalité des communautés open source européennes, lUnion européenne fait face à des faiblesses structurelles, notamment un déficit de structuration de lécosystème en matière dexploitation, de valorisation et de pérennisation des solutions open source quelle produit. En effet, lUnion européenne ne dispose pas encore dun cadre stratégique pleinement structuré pour lopen source, comparable à celui dautres grandes puissances technologiques. La reconnaissance du rôle stratégique du logiciel open source constitue dès lors un enjeu central de la future stratégie européenne.

feedbackTextUserLanguage: The CEA fully supports the European Commission’s initiative to develop a European strategy for open digital ecosystems and open source solutions. As a research and technology organisation, CEA develops, uses and valorises many software products, an increasing share of which is distributed under open source licences, and relies heavily on these solutions in its research, technological development and innovation activities. As such, the CEA is directly concerned by the challenges of the structuring, sustainability and governance of open source ecosystems, which are key levers for competitiveness, innovation, standardisation and technological sovereignty. The CEA agrees with the general analysis presented in the consultation document, while stressing that, despite the vitality of the European open source communities, the European Union is facing structural weaknesses, in particular a lack of structuring of the ecosystem in terms of exploitation, valorisation and sustainability of open source solutions, which product. The European Union does not yet have a fully structured strategic framework for the source network, comparable to that of other major technological powers. Recognition of the strategic role of open source software is therefore a key issue in the future European strategy.
organization: Commissariat à l'énergie atomique et aux énergies alternatives (CEA)

feedback: Very nice to see this initiative from the Commission. Open Source Software (OSS) is crucial to a large number of small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) across Europe, and represents a primary pathway for SMEs to enter the market of software solutions, in the world of web-based services and elsewhere. While OSS is widely used in high-end technical education, such as computer science and engineering, this is less pronounced in institutions aimed at training for roles in large enterprises and the business world at large - where future decision makers get their education. To help level the playing field for especially SMEs from the Open Source world, I propose three areas of intervention to strengthen the European sovereign technologies ecosystem in the mid- to long term: A) Provide funding for strategic education initiatives related to open technologies for business and societal services at all levels from vocational schools to high-end business schools, B) Provide grants for high-TRL R&D in large-scale orchestration and integration of open technologies into business-focused IT technology stacks, and C) provide financial and organisational support for the maintenance of OSS technologies that function as a part of the shared digital infrastructure of public and private sectors and originate in non-commercial projects.

Open-Xchange would like to thank the Commission for the opportunity to participate in its call for evidence on open digital ecosystems in Europe. We think the open-source paradigm naturally aligns with Europe's objectives of digital autonomy. As a European open SME, we face problems such as market entrenchment by global proprietary vendors and a lack of venture capital. The non-profit parts of our ecosystem often lack funding models and a path to industrialisation. An open digital ecosystem strategy should start from a clear objective: Europe should become the global leader in open digital technologies. Open licenses and standards should be the default model for the European public sector. These objectives should be pursued and monitored in terms of actual market uptake. Europe's digital strategy should adopt the Internet's open architecture as a reference, requiring modularity and interoperability and adopting open protocols and formats. Public code should be released under open licenses. The benefits of Europe's investments in open technologies should be directed to European citizens, entities, companies, and economies; while the rest of the world will still benefit from them, we should not be afraid to pursue our interests. The strategy should be based on two pillars. The first one should be a "buy European, buy open" industrial policy. Public purchases and funding should create jobs and fiscal revenue in Europe; sovereignty requirements should be added for services affecting national security or the basic functioning of society and economy. Priority should be given to open-source software and services, with a minimum quota increasing over time. Regulatory action should be part of this pillar. The Commission should also adopt European open-source applications for its own activities. The second pillar is a public investment fund for European sovereign technologies of various kinds, from foundational blocks to long-term moonshots. The fund should be managed proactively and focus on projects likely to produce mass-scale change in the digital services market, remaining independent of the dominant market players. A smaller portion of this fund should be used to strengthen the European open-source community, for example, by raising Europe's profile and influence within global organisations, and by sponsoring community meetings and education programs. While all stack levels need to be addressed, sectors with a large economic impact should be prioritised. Among our fields of expertise, messaging and productivity applications seem the most urgent. Finally, we address the issue of defining "European open source" for purposes of digital sovereignty. Sovereignty requirements should not focus on the origin of the code or nationality of the authors, but should be imposed on suppliers, following the model of the Cyber Resilience Act. Assessments should address two categories of sovereignty objectives, one related to security and lack of foreign interference, the other to economic returns to Europe. Both each service's sovereignty needs and each suppliers fitness to meet them should be assessed in these two categories, leading to graduated scales and different sovereignty requirements for different applications. We defer a more detailed discussion to the attached document. We thank you for your kind consideration and stand ready to provide additional technical expertise and comments on these proposals.

feedback: I'm a software storage engineer with 20+ years of experience in the field, dealing with and contributing open source software. One aspect where IT-related businesses and organizations may be hampered with promoting open source is with procurement rules, where the "cheapest" choice is often not the most future-proof, both in terms of being open-source and in terms of sovereignty of the solution. Granted that business initiatives should come "bottom up" for the market to be healthy, but a way to help the EU ecosystem to develop would be to regulate how software services at large are procured, where open source and sovereign solutions shall become a requirement, and exceptions shall be justifiable.

LHC welcomes the opportunity to participate and provide feedback to this call for evidence. LHC appreciates the European Commission's efforts to address the critical need for a better understanding of Open Source and its impact on both European public and private sectors in order to make critical decisions regarding the challenges, solutions and opportunities in this area. This will benefit the EUs technological independence and resilience in areas of Open Data, Open Training for Cybersecurity, Open AI models, Open Standards and support Open Source. LHC supports reinforcing investment on Open Community governance and Open Source as a mature operational model, as this will reinforce the EU decision making capability, similarly to economic controls, like the government created tax frameworks. Simply because for taxation mechanisms, both Open Source as well as propriety software need to be treated equally, considering taxation frameworks that are not designed around transactional values. Open Source costs are landing CapEx, while propriety software are mainly landing to OpEx. Also, Open Source costs are not determined from license fees to use the software, but by the costs of having in house skills to use and maintain the Open Source software. The economic model outlined above reflects the equal importance for Europe of creating open educational resources and keeping innovation and critical skills as cybersecurity, AI and PQC related in Europe. The critical mass of both individuals and companies is ensuring European digital transition for more open digital ecosystems in long term.For over a decade, NC3 has been supporting the GRC ecosystem in Luxembourg and globally through Open Source solutions. One of these is MONARC, an optimised risk analysis method and tool used worldwide, with more than 300 instances hosted free of charge. NC3 has also developed a Cybersecurity Observatory and a Testing Platform, which provide actionable threat intelligence information. These allow SMEs to assess the security of their applications and infrastructure in an accessible and practical way. LHC also developed a funding programme through the National Coordination Centre (NCC-LU), called the Luxembourg Cybersecurity Innovation & Development Funding Programme (LU-CID), aimed at supporting cybersecurity companies in accessing national and EU funding to develop cybersecurity solutions for SMEs. This initiative enabled 4 Open Source initiatives to strengthen the proposing SMEs resilience as well as the one of the broader ecosystem by delivering Open Source solutions.Feedback from the national ecosystem and the NCC network emphasis's the value of supporting actors in developing and maintaining Open Source solutions. Therefore, making the sharing of Open Source assets as a project delivery requirement on EU initiatives would be beneficial for the entire EU ecosystem resilience. From CIRCLs experience with applications like MISP (Open Source Threat Intelligence Platform), by providing openly specified data models, vocabularies, and exchange mechanisms for threat intelligence and incident-related information, the MISP standard enabled seamless interoperability across tools, organizations, sectors, and national boundaries. The open nature of the MISP standard has been a key factor in its wide adoption across the EU CSIRT Network, international organisations, and private sector communities. LHC considers essential for EU to ensure open access to the specification and reference implementations especially in the area of AI enabled cybersecurity developments as this allows participants to share actionable information while preserving autonomy over implementation choices and avoiding dependency on proprietary formats or platforms. Another major advantage of using Open Source relies on investing in in-house capabilities to use and maintain the software, which strengthens organizational s

feedback:
Sovereignty is about self determination and control. Currently, the EU is highly dependent on US-based mega-corporations like Microsoft, Alphabet (Google), and Amazon. Software written by these companies is used not only privately by EU citizens, but also by governments in all facets of their work. Unfortunately, these corporations only respect EU sovereignty when it is compatible with US interests. In 2025, Anton Carniaux, the General Counsel of Microsoft France, testified before the French Senate that Microsoft would provide data to the US government without consulting France. https://www.senat.fr/compte-rendu-commissions/20250609/ce_commande_publique.html https://www.heise.de/en/news/Not-sovereign-Microsoft-cannot-guarantee-the-security-of-EU-data-10494789.html In 2013, the Guardian reported that Microsoft worked with the US NSA to circumvent the company's encryption while publicly claiming their inability to perform wiretaps. https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/jul/11/microsoft-nsa-collaboration-user-data These are blatant violations of other countries' sovereignty. An apparent solution would be to reproduce the American model in the EU. We believe this approach is ill-advised. The EU should strive not for a handful of 100 billion Euro companies who are too large to fail, but thousands of 100 million Euro companies and many more small and medium businesses. Further, the EU must resist proprietary solutions. Companies chase profits, which motivates them to end support for unprofitable software. Historically it was possible to keep using unmaintained software, but as software increasingly moves to the cloud, when a company shuts down a service, users are stranded and may lose access to their data, which either can't be exported or only in a low-fidelity format. A recent example of this is Adobe discontinuing Animate. In their announcement they tell users to migrate soon as access to their data will not be available in a year. This is not sovereignty. https://www.techbuzz.ai/articles/adobe-kills-animate-in-major-ai-pivot-leaving-creators-stranded Open source software (OSS) is a key ingredient to solving these problems. OSS guarantees that users can audit the code they run either directly or by hiring an expert. This provides strong security guarantees. OSS gives control to users to add the features they need if the maintainers don't want to. And, OSS continues to be available after the maintainers abandon the software ensuring that users can continue to use, maintain and develop it. OSS reduces the trust individuals and organizations have to place in companies; OSS puts users in control. Switzerland has recognized this value proposition and passed the "Electronic Means for the Fulfilment of Governmental Tasks" in 2023. This law requires code developed by or for the government to be released under an open-source license. OSS is sovereignty. With OSS anyone can copy, modify or share software. This enables sovereignty. For companies focused on OSS development this results in a weak negotiating position: why pay for software that is free? This attitude that OSS is a commons suggests that it should be treated as one. In practice it is used as one. Black Duck, a security company, reported in their "2025 Open Source Security and Risk Analysis Report" that 97% of codebases include OSS. Yet, these companies rarely financially support the projects they depend on, and governments do not protect OSS as a commons. The EU must create programs to fund the long-term development and maintenance of OSS. Germany's Sovereign Tech Agency, which funds critical digital infrastructure like our project, Sequoia PGP, is a good start. A well-endowed EU Sovereign Tech Fund is essential. Also important is the creation of an IT support ecosystem for consumers. https://eu-stf.openforumeurope.org/ The best solution to ensuring the EU's sovereignty and security is OSS. To be
