feedback: Due to the restrictions of text length and the lack of formatting options in this text box, my feedback is provided in the attached PDF file. I would also attach the plaintext source, but it seems that attaching more than one file is not possible.

I would like to refer to point 3, concrete measures and actions that can be taken at EU level to support the development and growth of the EU open-source sector and contribute to the EUs technological sovereignty and cybersecurity agenda. Suggestion 1 The EU should require national public digital services, such as Austrias IDAustria app, to be usable on mobile operating systems beyond Googles Android and Apples iOS. Currently, access to essential public digital infrastructure is effectively limited to these two platforms, which prevents people from switching to alternative operating systems. Public digital services are essential for societal participation. EU member states should not reinforce US-based vendor lock-in by restricting access to Google and Apple. Supporting public digital services on platform-independent web-apps or alternative operating systems would strengthen digital sovereignty, allow people to choose their preferred mobile operating system, and support the emergence of alternative mobile operating systems (aligned with European values). Suggestion 2 Inspired by the gender equality requirements in EU funded Horizon research projects, the EU should also introduce a "open-source by default" principle for publicly funded projects that develop software or hardware. Public funding should generate public value beyond individual projects. Releasing publicly funded software and hardware under open-source licences would make project outcomes reusable and support the open-source sector. Moreover, open-source development improves transparency and security, as code can be independently audited and validated. As with gender equality policies, such a principle should not prescribe specific actions, but rather set a clear expectation and change default practices.

Interaktiv GmbH, an SME with 25 employees based in Germany submits this evidence based on 25 years of Plone CMS integration for educational institutions and public administration in the DACH region. We operate platforms serving 1.5+ million users in critical public sector contexts, providing concrete evidence of European open source delivering at scale with complete data sovereignty. THE FUNDAMENTAL PROBLEM: WINNER TAKES ALL DESTROYS ECOSYSTEM DIVERSITY EU open-source funding paradoxically creates concentration. Germany's Government Site Builder invested 108 million euros exclusively in TYPO3. European Commission operates hundreds of sites predominantly on Drupal. This marginalizes mature alternatives like Plone offering distinct advantages for specific contexts. Educational institutions need different capabilities than municipal websites. One-size-fits-all creates suboptimal outcomes. Our platform serves 1.5 million users for 15+ years on Plone, yet procurement gravitates toward established choices rather than evaluating fitness-for-purpose. Recommendation: Fund 3-5 mature platforms per category based on technical merit and use-case fit. FUNDING MODEL MISMATCH: INNOVATION VS OPERATIONAL SUSTAINABILITY NGI 2020-2024 excelled at innovation funding, supporting 1,200+ projects with 140 million euros. However, production systems require continuous investment over decades for security patches, compliance updates, and dependency maintenance. Innovation grants don't fund this unglamorous work keeping critical infrastructure operational. Recommendation: Establish EU Digital Infrastructure Fund with 500 million euros annually for 5-10 year operational contracts supporting 20-30 strategic platforms with proven scale over 100,000 users, public sector deployment, and EU-based maintenance. PROCUREMENT BARRIERS SYSTEMATICALLY EXCLUDE EU OPEN SOURCE Seemingly neutral requirements create barriers. Market share weighting rewards US vendors' dominance. Requirements for 3 reference implementations over 100,000 users exclude EU platforms. BSI certification costs of 50,000 euros are marginal for Microsoft but existential for 25-employee SMEs. Recommendation: Mandate Open Source First with written justification for proprietary choices. Subsidize EU cybersecurity certifications. SOVEREIGNTY THROUGH CONCRETE DEPLOYMENT Our platforms demonstrate measurable sovereignty through complete control over users' data without US dependency. Data stays in German jurisdiction, avoiding Schrems II and US CLOUD Act exposure. Costs run 60% below proprietary alternatives, employing DACH developers building German capabilities rather than enriching US shareholders. MULTI-NATIONAL SCALING: THE MISSING LINK Fragmented national procurement prevents economies of scale. Successful deployments don't replicate across Member States despite proven viability. Recommendation: Fund 3-5 Member State consortia for joint deployments with 50 million euros annually supporting 5-10 multi-national implementations and shared development costs. TECHNOLOGY PRIORITIES Focus where European regulatory requirements create advantage in public sector platforms for CMS and collaboration, plus compliance-first AI. Educational institutions cannot accept black box AI processing minors' data under GDPR Article 8. Europe should standardize compliance-by-design before US frameworks dominate. Shifting 25% of 20+ billion euros annual public sector platform spending to European open source injects 15 billion euros into EU ecosystems while achieving sovereignty.

Greetings, I have chosen to volunteer feedback as a US citizen currently entrenched in open source software. I am an Information Technology professional with the United States finance sector. I currently make my living supporting Microsoft operating systems and its surrounding ecosystem. However, my personal participation in Big Tech is limited. I took it upon myself to regain my agency, my right to be anonymous, to delete myself from social media, and de-monetize myself for others gains. My current cloud implementation involves Debian linux distributions on all endpoint devices. My file, contacts, calendar, instant messaging platforms are all contained within Nextclouds platform. My mail client is Mozillas Thunderbird. My collaboration suite is Only Office. My hypervisor is ProxMox and im currently planning an implementation of their Backup solution. My offsite backups are handled by a linux friendly provider as well. While im merely an enthusiast providing support for my immediate family, i can confidently argue that open source technologies are indeed ready for enterprise environments. My aim today was merely to support the open source communities that have given me my freedom for these past five years and have never asked for anything in return. Take back your right to opt in as opposed to the now normalized opt out dark patterns.

Digital sovereignty is more important than ever. The European Union should advocate for the use of open standards. However, it is not enough to simply use open source software. In order to use open systems, the devices that are connected to and interact with these systems must also be open. Free drivers and well-documented interfaces are therefore of great importance. If a device only has proprietary, closed drivers, it is often not possible to use it with a free operating system. The switch is made difficult or even completely prevented. Openness and longevity are particularly important in critical infrastructure. Proprietary drivers, which are only available for closed systems, make it difficult to use open operating systems with these devices. In addition, closed drivers prevent users from updating the operating system they are using. This forces them to either work with an old operating system that is no longer supported by the manufacturer or to discard the device in question. If the EU wants to promote open source, free operating systems and open standards, it must also ensure that devices work with these free operating systems. The demand for more open source must go hand in hand with the demand for open source drivers and open firmware. This should apply to all classes of devices, from printers, network and communication technology to medical technology.

By reducing spending on proprietary software licenses, open source allows organizations to allocate more resources to consulting services and specialized expertise, thereby creating high-quality jobs and supporting local technology sectors. However, inconsistent funding, fragmented support, and procurement biases towards proprietary software still limit wider adoption and sustainable contributions. Many organizations lack the expertise or incentives to participate, and cross-border collaboration is sometimes hampered by legal and language barriers. Open source offers real value to both public and private sectors: reduced costs, lower risk of vendor lock-in, enhanced transparency and security, and faster innovation. The EU should invest in long-term funding for key projects, harmonize procurement policies to favour open solutions, and support compliance and legal expertise. Priorities should include cybersecurity, public administration tools and cloud infrastructure. Sectors like government, healthcare, and education stand to gain most in competitiveness and resilience from broad open-source adoption. Supporting open source at the EU level will strengthen Europes technological sovereignty, security, and innovation capacity.

Cette contribution s'appuie sur une pratique de plus de 15 années au sein d'inno³, où chaque mission de conseil alimente une réflexion sur la soutenabilité des communautés (et projets associés) via une démarche de recherche-action structurée. Elle complète les réponses élaborées avec la Coop des Communs, Numeum, Open Source Experts et le CNLL. L'effort européen s'est trop longtemps focalisé sur la technologie et sa place sur le marché ("le comment") au détriment des finalités humaines et politiques ("le pourquoi"). L'enjeu fondamental n'est plus de produire plus de code, mais de restaurer la confiance des usagers, de garantir l'autonomie des entreprises et d'assurer la souveraineté des États. Pour ce faire, il est effectivement nécessaire de se tourner vers des modèles de développement alternatifs, plus vertueux et plus efficaces, et en premier lieu l'Open Source. Les domaines prioritaires sont naturellement ceux où sont les usagers, de manière à répondre à des besoins réels. Dans un contexte de tensions géopolitiques, l'Open Source est l'outil d'une indépendance stratégique. Pour qu'elle opère, l'Europe doit soutenir son tissu économique réel composé majoritairement de PME. La commande publique doit être repensée, a fortiori pour la Commission européenne (et à fortiori dans le cadre de marché d'étude, au risque sinon de teinter l'action publique d'une manière contraire à ses intérêts). La Commission doit affirmer son rôle de régulateur face à un marché qui se concentre. Notre économie libérale ne suffit plus à garantir le progrès ; il faut une Europe capable de réguler le marché tout en soutenant l'écosystème mobilisé. (et not. les structures intermédiaires nouvelles -- telles que le CSI Piemont en Italie, le TOSIT ou Open Source Experts en France -- destiné à outiller et structurer la filière Open Source locale). Dans une démarche de "communs numériques", l'acteur public doit cesser d'être un simple consommateur pour devenir un partenaire engagé d'une communauté hétérogène afin de garantir l'utilité sociale des projets. Cette vision, développée par la Coop des Communs et nos travaux sur la rentabilité des communs, converge avec l'émergence de l'EDIC européen. Le secteur public doit aussi transformer ses aides : financer les contributeurs et les entreprises qui les portent selon leur impact et leur durabilité (modèle des AAC, NGI, etc?) plutôt que sur leur seule capacité à lever des fonds. Les récents textes européens (IA Act, CRA) témoignent d'une volonté louable de protéger l'Open Source communautaire, mais cette intention reste fragile : - CRA : application d'un régime de "produits physiques" à des biens numériques "non-rivaux", faible accompagnement des acteurs (not. recherche) - IA Act : au delà des valeurs, la réussite de l'IA européenne dépendra de notre capacité à organiser la collaboration humaine derrière les infrastructures et les données ('"IA d'intérêt général", structures fiduciaires (Data Trusts), etc.). Nos recherches de terrain préconisent quatre axes majeurs : Exemplarité institutionnelle : adoption par les instances politiques de postes de travail libres pour créer un signal de marché fort Soutien à la maintenance critique : des études et méthodes existent (cf travaux FOSSEPS) pour identifier et soutenir les bibliothèques fondamentales invisibles et critiques Levée des barrières réglementaires : not. les certifications favorisant les modèles fermés face à des solutions ouvertes (comme la certification imposée en matière d'ERP qui remet en cause l'usage important de solutions telle que Dolibarr en Frannce). Souveraineté matérielle : lier l'Open Source à une politique globale, incluant l'organisation de l'accès à des Digital Public Infrastructures (DPI), dans une approche inclusive et ouverte. Conclus

IBM has been a long term advocate for open technologies and open infrastructures. This includes our long history and strong commitment to open source which was further strengthened with the acquisition of RedHat. IBM is an active and leading participant in open source projects. IBM contributed to the foundations and success of leading open source foundations like the Linux Foundation

feedback: As is described by the Commission, "European governments and companies are heavily dependent on non-EU digital technologies, hampering choice, competitiveness and creating challenges for cybersecurity" rather than using the open source technology developed in the EU. While I personally don't believe it is true to the fullest extend, I believe a significant reason is that open-source software in Europe is often not developed with particular fit for governments or companies in mind, but rather to serve the people, individuals, EU citizens. This I see happening much more in Europe, compared to other regions in the world, where open-source is used more as a tool of business and where software and technology is mostly made open-source if doing so is believed to increase profits for the company doing so rather than by principle. That we won't see "successful scaling of open source solutions" when supporting ideologically-driven open-source developers in Europe is only to be expected, as scaling to become a successful business with high ROI is simply not what these developers wanted to do in first place - instead they wanted to create a public good. As other public goods, from telephony, energy and water grids to public transportation, those may just not need to be profitable business, they may not need to scale into commercial offerings. It is such public goods which are immensely important to be supported by governments and public institutions without the expectation of profits or returns in the form of taxes paid or else they will simply not be possible to be created as a public good, for the people. When it comes to European governments, the use of technology provided under a license that is in the public interest - which is true for a copyleft license like the GPL or EUPL, but less so for "lax" licenses like Apache Software License or MIT License - should be *heavily* preferred or subsidized in public procurement ("public money, public code") to make it easy to run a business that builds on top of existing, open-source technology built by the people, for the people. Because what was built for the people, will still need adjustments to be a perfect fit for government use. Doing such adjustment in the open will come at a heavy cost for such business, because they must fear others taking their work when instead keeping it private usually means they can sell the same work repeatedly to different governments and institutions.

I am an experienced software developer with over 20 years of experience in creating and publishing open-source software. I see open-source software (recommended with reproducible builds to verify binaries) as the only way to achieve digital sovereignty and for running critical infrastructure. How else would you be sure what the software does and that there are no backdoors or timebombs included? It also helps avoid artificial end-of-life of devices when the hardware is still good and just the software stops being supported by a vendor. With open-source-software, it can be kept alive as long as needed. This helps the environment. Open-source also allows to add needed features that are missing in existing products. The answer to "can it be done?" is usually "yes". Just a question of effort. In my opinion, the EU should extend funding for open-source initiatives and developers (without overly complicated paperwork) to ensure communities stay healthy. The EU should also support the "Public Money => Public Code" initiative by the FSFE. This helps to become more independent from US software-vendors and strengthens EU's economy by redirecting funding to EU developers. Thanks for your consideration.

All produced code from public sector (so financed by the tax) should be free (https://publiccode.eu/) Shared toold and code between european states for lots of public services So investment, dev, support, documentation, shared standard => Factur-x Benefits for the contributor are unclear and uncertain. # Added value # Development resources saving By relying on open-source technologies you rely on a community of developpers/users that are more involved in the robustness, versability and resilience of said technologies. Thus you are not alone assuming the quality, compatibility and updates of a technology. # Mechanicaly incrementing innovation Having open-source technologies available speeds up the process of innovation instead of spending resources re-developing existing but proprietary technologies that are not often tunable to your use case. # Measures and actions What concrete measures and actions may be taken at EU level to support the development and growth of the EU open-source sector and contribute to the EUs technological sovereignty and cybersecurity agenda? # Priorities: what technology areas should be prioritized and why? # Information technologies People are loosing the ability to use, understand, create, adapt their day-to-day productivity tools. Softwares are more and more intertwined with our personnal and professional lives we should be able to own them as craftsmen use to own the content of their toolboxes. Subventions for open-source alternatives to proprietary monopols: CAD (ArchiCAD, Solidworks, CATIA Adobe & Dassault) Desktop suites (OS + Office suite + Cloud) # Hardware and infrastructures What good is software sovereignty without hardware sovereignty? We should focus on the whole Product Lifecycle Management, the hardware runing and producing the software as well as the infrastructures it relies on. # Sectors In what sectors could an increased use of open source lead to increased competitiveness and cyber resilience? # Education As students are the users/developers of the futur, they should be aware of the benefits of open-source development. # Public services Lead by exemple. Define open-source standards and enforce their use in the EU states public services. In public invitations to tender allow points for open-sourced use and contribution.

OpenForum Europe welcomes the opportunity to contribute to the European Commissions Call for Evidence on the forthcoming Communication Towards European open digital ecosystems. We welcome the growing recognition across EU institutions of the strategic importance of open source as a foundational component of Europes digital infrastructure, as well as the emerging convergence of policy initiatives that place software ecosystems at the centre of Europes digital and industrial strategy. The Communication is timely and well aligned with recent and forthcoming policy instruments, including in cloud, data and AI, and signals a more coherent approach to addressing Europes structural dependencies in critical technology domains. The Commissions acknowledgement that Europe combines strong developer communities with persistent barriers to scaling, sustainability and market integration reflects a shared understanding of the challenge. This submission seeks to build on this positive momentum by offering a structured analysis of open source as an under-leveraged policy tool and by setting out policy recommendations aimed at strengthening competitiveness, resilience, and long-term European capability. Please see the attached document for OpenForum Europe's detailed feedback.

feedback:
This submission is accompanied by a full-length analytical background paper (PDF). The text below summarises its core findings and policy implications. Why Open Source Fails to Scale: Structural Underprovision of Usability, Documentation and Governance Capacity This submission examines the structural underprovision of free and open-source software (FOSS) using the case of CiviCRM. CiviCRM is a constituent relationship management system that has been developed for and by non-governmental organisations (NGOs) worldwide for the past 20 years. It supports core organisational functions such as contact and relationship management, fundraising, membership administration, events and political or civic engagement workflows. Within the EU, CiviCRM has a high but still under-realised market potential and is already used by thousands of NGOs, associations and civic organisations. Despite this relevance, many mature open-source ecosystems including CiviCRM fail to scale beyond a comparatively small group of resource-rich users. This is not primarily a technical problem, but a structural one. Based on an in-depth empirical and analytical study of CiviCRM, the attached background paper shows that open-source ecosystems tend to stabilise at a functionally sufficient but socially inefficient equilibrium. The software is powerful and reliable, yet difficult to adopt, operate and scale without expert mediation. The main bottleneck lies in the systematic underprovision of usability, documentation, onboarding and long-term maintainability. Crucially, this underprovision is not the result of poor governance, lack of goodwill or insufficient competence. It is the predictable outcome of rational decision-making under collective-goods conditions. Investments in adoption-critical qualities generate high collective benefits but low private returns and are therefore structurally deprioritised in favour of project-specific features and fixes. Governance mechanisms can mitigate but not automatically resolve this imbalance. Without explicit mandates, resources and accountability for these underprovided qualities, governance risks stabilising the status quo rather than transforming it. The consequences are substantial. High adoption costs limit diffusion into civil society, public administration and SMEs. Usage remains dependent on scarce intermediaries, constraining scalability and competition. Empirical estimates for CiviCRM alone indicate millions of euros in sunk implementation costs and recurring productivity losses caused by deficits in usability and documentation. These patterns are representative for many mature open-source ecosystems. The European Union is uniquely positioned to address this structural imbalance. Targeted intervention can unlock significant welfare gains without undermining community autonomy or market dynamics. Key policy implications include: Treat usability, documentation and onboarding as core digital infrastructure, not optional add-ons. Align public funding and procurement criteria with reusability, maintainability and long-term adoption, not only feature delivery. Support decision-relevant quality benchmarks that make adoption-critical differences visible and comparable. Fund stewardship roles for documentation, UX and maintenance alongside technical development. Promote reference implementations and standard use cases to lower entry barriers while preserving flexibility. Evaluate governance by its measurable impact on adoption and usability, not merely by its formal existence. The attached background paper provides the full empirical evidence, theoretical grounding (drawing on Mancur Olson and Elinor Ostrom) and a detailed discussion of governance risks and realistic transformation paths. A European Open Source Digital Ecosystem Strategy that explicitly addresses these structural dynamics can transform FOSS into a widely accessible, scalable and soc

feedback: The city and Eurometropolis of Strasbourg are pursuing a proactive policy of replacing non-sovereign software with free and open-source alternatives. We are currently preparing to replace Microsoft office tools with free and sovereign alternatives: NextCloud, LibreOffice, Collabora Online, Element/Matrix, etc. We have also launched projects aimed at replacing ShareCan and Teams with free and open-source alternatives. We also take care to identify unsupervised uses (ShadowIT) in order to offer sovereign and, where possible, open-source replacement solutions. We would like the European Commission to promote and support the establishment of a European ecosystem conducive to the development and deployment of alternatives to non-sovereign software. One of our biggest concerns is the fair financing of contributors to free software, who are often torn between respecting the principles of digital commons and the need to financially support their activities.

1/ La principale faiblesse du secteur des solutions libres en UE est sa dépedance aux projets libres principalement US. Même l'écosystème open source n'est pas à l'abri de cette dépendance: en 2024, la communauté Linux a du se soumettre aux sanctions américaines en écartant l'ensemble des développeurs dont l'employeur figurait sur la liste U.S. OFAC SDN. Ce précédent démontre qu'open source ne signifie pas souverain dès lors que la gouvernance du projet est soumise à une juridiction extra-européenne. Un exemple d'opportunité récente nous vient de la création de la fondation Illumos en Suisse (pas UE...) qui nous permet de disposer des sources de Solaris, un des OS les plus robustes du marché depuis plus de 30 ans. Il faudrait peu pour que cette opportuné soit transformée en une réelle force. C'est pour ces raisons que c'est sur Illumos et sur OmniOS (fondation suisse elle aussi), sa distribution centrée sur la virtualisation, que nous avons conçu et développé OmniCube. OmniCube est un système de virtualisation qui permet en cas d'attaque ou simplement d'erreur humaine, de remonter le temps, heure par heure, et de retrouver le dernier état sain de n'importe quelle machine virtuelle. Pour contrôler l'ensemble, nous avons développé une interface graphique basée sur une blockchain. Le tout est bien sûr en source ouverte. À nos yeux, les deux principaux obstacles auxquels font face les solutions libres européennes sont l'absence de gouvernance et une industrialisation presque systématiquement chinoise. Sur ce dernier point, l'histoire du processeur libre RISC-V est emblématique: créé aux USA, dernièrement financé par des fonds européens et impossible à trouver autre part que via des fondeurs chinois. 2/ Question bien trop vaste que pour pouvoir être répondue dans le cadre de cette consultation. Nous restons toutefois à votre disposition pour partager les éléments à notre disposition. 3/ Le rapport du Parlement européen sur la souveraineté technologique et l'infrastructure numérique (juin 2025) souligne que 69% du marché cloud européen est détenu par des entreprises américaines. En tant que PME européenne disposant d'une solution de virtualisation opérationnelle et déployée avec succès depuis cinq ans, notre besoin est celui que cette consultation entend précisément adresser: l'accès au marché et la visibilité face aux acteurs dominants non européens. Loin des déclarations d'intention, nous proposons un Proof of Concept pour démontrer en conditions réelles la capacité d'OmniCube à offrir une alternative souveraine, résiliente et compétitive aux solutions non européennes. Quand vous voulez, où vous voulez... au sein de l'Union Européenne. 4/ La virtualisation constitue aujourd'hui la couche fondatrice de toute infrastructure informatique, qu'il s'agisse de cloud computing ou d'edge computing. Or, l'ensemble des solutions disponibles sur le marché VMware (Broadcom, USA), Microsoft Hyper-V, et les distributions dérivées de Linux/KVM telles que Nutanix ou Proxmox sont contrôlées par ou dépendantes d'acteurs américains. Plus généralement, il faut toujours viser l'entièreté de la chaîne de valeur, même ses éléments les plus insignifiants, la souveraineté étant à ce prix et c'est ce que la Commission ne fait malheureusement jamais. La Chine l'a bien compris il y a plusieurs décennies ce qui lui permet maintenant de nous concurrencer sur les technologies les plus avancées. 5/ Pour être compétitif, il faut être maître de ses prix et de sa production, donc indépendant. Pour être indépendant, il faut maîtriser un maximum de sa chaîne de valeur. Des solutions libres peuvent contribuer à cette maîtrise. De la même manière, la résilience est la capacité à absorber une perturbation. Toute dépendance est une source potentielle de perturbation ce qui nous ramè

feedback: Numeum welcomes the European Commissions Call for Evidence on Open Digital Ecosystems and supports the development of a renewed EU open-source strategy. Open-source technologies play a central role in strengthening Europes competitiveness, innovation capacity and technological sovereignty. Representing 2,500 digital companies in France, including many active in open source, Numeum is keen to share its practical experience to help identify obstacles and support policies that encourage the development and uptake of open-source solutions across Europe.

feedback: BSA supports the EUs ambition to review its approach to open source by releasing a new Strategy, updating the framework introduced by the EU Open Source Strategy 20202023. We strongly believe in the importance of boosting the development and competitiveness of the EU open source sector, as well as in encouraging open-source uptake by private and public users. We support the goals of strengthening the position of start-ups in the innovation ecosystem and of pushing organizations to contribute to open-source development. However, to meet these objectives, careful attention should be paid to the nature of open source, which heavily relies on global cooperation and on the portability and reusability of software, and appropriate consequences should be drawn. BSA calls for a balanced approach to the future strategy on EU open source, grounded in real-life examples and aiming for efficiency. In this context, BSA recommends the following: 1) Aim for collaborative and interoperable innovation, without geographic restrictions that conflict with open source principles, as well as global cooperation to adopt best practices for open source 2) Expand the scope of the 2020-2023 Open Source Strategy while maintaining a form of technological neutrality that does not prioritize open-source solutions over proprietary software, but instead focuses on organizations leveraging the best available solutions 3) Integrate the OSI definition of open source, and support the ecosystem through targeted funding of open-source infrastructure 4) Engage in structured dialogue with global open source foundations and other stakeholders while strengthening existing initiatives, including cooperation with ENISA 5) Promote open source in strategically important technologies and across the digital stack, without focusing on specific applications, as well as developing strong public-private partnerships. Please see the attached document for further information.

feedback: The geospatial sector within the European Union is largely shaped by open source software. This includes factors such as open standards, interoperability, and reuse. Public institutions and geodata-holding bodies of various administrative levels benefit from open source software and consider it indispensable for their daily work. The BKG welcomes the continuation of the European Commission's European Open Ecosystem Strategy for the realization of digital sovereignty for public administration and civic society alike.
organization: Federal Agency for Cartography and Geodesy (BKG)

feedback: Im using linux and wouldn't go back to windows. But I'm an advanced user. It should be easy to for non technical users to use linux. Therefor the EU should found projects like KDE which are more aimed at normal users. And computers shouldn't come preinstalled with windows. Many opensource products, that are necessary to run most of the digital infrastructure, are build by European citizen. For example most servers run Linux. Linux is also the basis of android, which is the operating system used by most users worldwide[1]. Linux was invented by Linus Torvald, which at the time was a finnish resident (now a european member state) Open source projects are often run by enthusiast with no funding. So if they use interest or they live situation changes projects could get abandoned. Therefor more funding of this projects are needed. Focus should also lay on critical infrastructure. It should not be possible for foreign governments (or companies) to disrupt our infrastructure (e.g. with the cloud act [2]). So software like windows should not be used and open source alternatives should get used and financially supported. [1] https://gs.statcounter.com/os-market-share/ [2] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cloud_Act

Dear European Commission, Europes ability to safeguard its digital freedom, security, and innovation hinges on regaining control over its software supply chain. To achieve true technological sovereignty, the EU must actively support a robust, resilient open-source ecosystem. In this regard, we strongly recommend increasing the investment in Nix/NixOS related technologies born in Europe, with Nix originating from the Netherlands in 2003. Our unique approach to declarative, reproducible system configurations makes it an ideal foundation for critical EU sovereignty initiatives, including sovereign cloud infrastructure, trustworthy artificial intelligence, and sovereign operating systems. By ensuring complete transparency and verifiability in software builds, Nix directly addresses security and dependency risks inherent in todays fragmented supply chains. Moreover, we encourage collaboration with well-established organizations such as NLnet, which have a proven track record of nurturing open-source development and digital sovereignty through long-term funding. Supporting homegrown technologies like Nix/NixOS and the ecosystems around it is not just a technical decision, its a strategic investment in Europes autonomy, resilience, and leadership in shaping the future of digital infrastructure. More information: https://nixos.org/ Sincerely, Sebastian Kraus NixOS Foundation Board member

Open source is vital to computing. Without open source software to manage our data, there can be no guarantees on access and management of our data. Proprietary software can't support the guarantees required with modern computing. For example, Adobe discontinuing cloud products, including the option to access proprietary formats associated with them, requiring users to export their files into a different format to keep ownership over the data. Open source does not have these limitations and allows to keep using software and open formats. Open source software doesn't only consist of shiny applications, but also of vital libraries and other components often left out of the spotlight. Maintenance of these libraries is vital, but looked over often and the burden remains on the maintainers free time to support the software.

a. Using public procurement as a lever to promote the adoption of European open-source solutions - According to the European Commission, 70% to 90% of the code used in the digital economy relies on open-source components, but the economic value generated by these developments largely benefits non European players (European Commission, 12/01/26). - This situation largely results from the network effects of major vendors, which create a structural barrier hindering European solutions from entering public procurement markets, both in terms of winning contracts and accessing talent. Proposal : Leverage the revision of the Public Procurement Directive to introduce a European preference in public procurement, and promote purchasing policies that are not license centric in order to support European open-source solutions. b. Ensuring sustainable funding for digital commons and European open-source actors - The Commission highlights the absence of longterm, scalable funding mechanisms capable of supporting European opensource projects beyond the research and prototyping phases, even though these digital commons constitute strategic infrastructure essential for European sovereignty, security, and competitiveness. - According to Numeum, open source underpins 96% of software and generates up to 95 billion in annual economic impact across the EU. Despite this, it remains structurally underfunded, weakening Europes capacity to maintain technological autonomy (Numeum, 18/07/2025). Proposal : Establish multi year funding mechanisms for digital commons, by contributing to the operation of existing structures, supporting the creation of European level foundations, and strengthening the ecosystem of European contributors. c. Mobilizing operational and regulatory levers to make open source a priority - The Commission describes Europes dependence on non European technologies as a strategic handicap, weakening its competitiveness, limiting its decision making autonomy, and creating strategic vulnerabilities in cybersecurity and resilience. - Therefore, operational and regulatory levers should be used to make open source a priority: setting up open data repositories to foster open-source solutions in critical fields (data on climate, health, energy), developing interoperable standards at the European level, training high school and university students on open source solutions, and more. Proposal : Adopt an open source first policy aimed at prioritizing projects or regulatory frameworks that favor the use of open source for strategic digital services when a European solution exists or could be developed. About MAIF and open source : As a mutual insurer committed to maintaining control over its critical components, MAIF relieswhen relevanton open-source solutions and contributes to their development by open sourcing components of its information system. MAIF adopts a pragmatic strategy combining in house development for critical activities, market solutions for other uses, and contributions to digital commons aligned with the European Commissions objectives for a more sovereign, transparent, interoperable, and sustainable digital landscape.

I consider that the work of the Next Generation Internet project has been excellent to date, and would hope to see it continued. I believe it necessary that the EU should continue to fund and help Free Software as an alternative to proprietary products. In this way the digital sovereignty of Europe may be achieved.

feedback: Towards European open digital Ecosystems: (Feedback by 1io Brandguardian GmbH) Please find the full feedback pdf attached. 1) While the EU open-source sector thrives on high-quality developer talent and ethical innovation, its full potential is stifled by a lack of cohesive organizational strategy, economic value leakage to non-EU entities, and a complex regulatory landscape thatdespite aiming for digital sovereigntyoften creates prohibitive compliance burdens and funding barriers for sustainable community contributions. 2) Open source provides the public sector with vital digital sovereignty and enhanced security through transparent, community-vetted code that eliminates dependency on non-EU tech giants, while enabling the private sector to drastically accelerate innovation by using reusable building blocks that shorten development cycles. The primary added value is measured by the elimination of restrictive vendor lock-in and licensing fees, though these benefits must be weighed against the initial costs of organizational training and the strategic shift toward resilient, local-first architectures. 3) To bolster the EU open-source sector and digital sovereignty, the EU should establish a "28th regime" legal framework for open-source foundations and create a European Open Source Trust Label to automate cybersecurity certification, alongside mandating sovereignty modules in university engineering curricula. Furthermore, public procurement must shift from license-centric to outcome-based criteria while securing multi-year funding for the maintenance of critical digital infrastructure and providing shared compliance tools to ease the regulatory burden on small developer teams. 4) Priority should be given to base-layer capabilities such as local-first collaboration primitives and interoperable data-sharing mechanisms, which ensure system resilience and sovereign deployments across European data spaces without central points of failure. Additionally, the EU must focus on open-source AI traceability and self-sovereign identity frameworks to provide verifiable data handling and granular access control, essential for maintaining accountability and user choice in high-risk digital domains. 5) In manufacturing, agriculture, and construction, the adoption of open-source architectures enables SMEs to optimize operational cycles through high-quality data ownership and technical interoperability, effectively ending the trade-off between convenience and control inherent in proprietary cloud platforms. Furthermore, in critical sectors such as energy, healthcare, and public administration, open source bolsters competitiveness and cyber resilience by dismantling data silos and ensuring long-term auditability and service continuity across complex, multi-stakeholder supply chains.

feedback: The main barrier to open source adoption and maintenance is the negative return on investment for those who develop open source solutions in an unfair competition with private solutions, which benefit from vendor lock-in. There's also attrition for those who want to use open source software due to lack of help desk support and long wait times for bug fixes and new feature development. To make open source sustainable, some form of economic return or tax incentive is needed, not only weighted by the work itself but also by its impact and future use of the solution, lasting like a patent. Open source should be considered less a consumable commodity and more something enduring, like laws and regulations, that benefits everyone now and in the future. Build in public prevents vendor lock-in in favor of a standardized way to solve problems and promotes transparency and interoperability, that is the main added value of open source. It also improves competitiveness by allowing contractors to study the code in advance and facilitate turnovers in workplaces that use open source solutions. The EU could make open source solutions mandatory for the public sector of member states. This would create a positive feedback loop, encouraging open source development and making it more convenient for the private sector to adopt it as well. Additional insights can be drawn from Italy's Codice dell'Amministrazione Digitale about prioritizing open source software (https://www.normattiva.it/eli/id/2005/05/16/005G0104/CONSOLIDATED @ art.68). Data governance and business intelligence should be prioritized first. No AI, nor human, can make good decisions with dirty data, imprecise metrics, or poorly presented information. Data-driven decisions are what we need most. The public sector moves a lot of taxpayer money and powers many critical infrastructures, so it should be a first good and feasible example of open source applications.

I've been running a small (< 10 employees) company that exclusively produces public domain (Unlicense) software for the last ~16 years or so. It's extremely hard as an open source company to find reliable sources of income as the main things you can ask from customers is money for support and feature development - but both of those are "temporary" in the sense that if you do things right, neither is needed long-term. That means that to guarantee long-term existence of these kind of projects, easy access to funding is critical - but preferably in a way that big companies (which generally don't need funding to survive) can't swoop in and take that funding for themselves. Why should we support open source projects? Because they provide a level of transparency that, especially for the things that everyone uses or is dependent on (government, digital infrastructure and communication services, etc), is absolutely necessary to guarantee basic human rights are being upheld in modern society. Even if they are not used (yet), the mere availability of open source alternatives to services and digital infrastructure keeps even the non-open ones honest: once these things devolve into something harmful or dangerous, literally anyone can quickly use open source to provide an alternative that is still "good". Not only that, but open source does the same thing that patents were originally created for: it makes technology available to all (potentially with some restrictions), in order to nurture human technological advancement. Beyond making funding easier to access for open source projects and companies, it could be interesting to introduce tax breaks for companies that work on open source (perhaps based on what percentage of their work is open and the type of licensing), to encourage them to release more code as open source rather than closed source.

Strengths and weaknesses: - strengths - open minded "engineer" approach vs. focus on profitability - weakness: existing solutions not taken into account even by EU functions (get the heck out of twitter etc and use oss solutions ONLY). Missing regulations for mandatory (!) inclusion of oss in public sourcing. Missing requirement of full disclosure of cost incurred through use of closed source solutions - why should we not know about the discounts that MS, AWS, Google etc grant public institutions?Missing requirement of public money - public code! Missing engagement of EU to confront DSGVO breaches - e.g. make it loud and clear that the US cloud act etc actually FORBIDS using US hyperscalers for personally identifiable data. Missing financial support: grant startup companies infrastructure usage. Use Mastodon. Use Pixelfed. Use Matrix. Provide grants to schools and kindergartens to start their infrastructure - and those of the families (kindergarten should offer a parents' Matrix chat instead of parents using Whatsapp...). Sponsor educational programs for open source for teachers - counter incentives from big commercial companies - or even forbid those. Establish the possibility to work 1 month on an oss project - public or private - instead of going on educational leave for one or two weeks for employees. Conduct industry fairs for OSS CeBIT 2.0). Define a yearly OSS prize scheme - newcomer, best rated, most installed etc... In the past services like post, railway etc. had been public institutions. They went private and what did happen? Service down, prices up. Oligopols forming. I do not see any reason why EU or other public institutions should not run Datacenters. Instead of burning billions in nuclear fusion (and I am a physicist!) - spent a few million in kick-starting a Competitive European Datacenters Network (CEDaN). What not to do: jump on the next hype... AI is no solution. Blockchain is no solution. Etc...

feedbackTextUserLanguage: H! I would like to highlight how enthusiastic I am about the EU’s support for open source software initiatives. I experience the result every day since I started to free myself from dependence on Microsoft. feedback: As a European technology leader headquartered in Sweden, Axis has long built its products on open source software, combining openness with strong governance, security by design, and sustained investment in research and development. As early as 1999, Axis launched one of the first commercial embedded Linux products, helping to validate open source as a viable foundation for specialized hardware. Today, the Axis Camera Application Platform (ACAP) enables a global ecosystem of developers and demonstrates how open platforms can drive innovation at scale while preserving operational control, accountability and security. Our experience shows that open source, when combined with professional industrial stewardship, is a strong foundation for resilient, competitive and trusted digital infrastructure. Open code alone is not sufficient, success at scale requires clear governance, defined responsibility, lifecycle management and long-term maintenance. 1. Strengths, weaknesses: The EU benefits from strong and highly skilled developer communities aligned with European values such as transparency, trust, and security. European companies have demonstrated the ability to build globally competitive and sustainable business models on open-source foundations, particularly in infrastructure, industrial, and safety-critical domains. Key challenges include integrating open source with legacy systems and fragmentation of standards, for example through evolving SBOM formats, which can impede seamless adoption. More fundamentally, open source requires dedicated industrial stewardship to succeed at scale. Responsibility for security, lifecycle management and long-term maintenance in distributed community projects is often unclear, creating significant risk. The Cyber Resilience Act highlights this gap. Many community-driven open-source projects lack the structured governance, long-term maintenance commitments, and clear accountability required under the regulation. This creates uncertainty for companies integrating such components into certified or safety-critical products and may hinder adoption of otherwise valuable open-source solutions. 2. Added value of open source When professionally managed, open source reduces vendor lock-in, strengthens digital resilience, and supports technological sovereignty. Transparency improves trust and supply-chain security, which is increasingly important for compliance with regulations such as the CRA. Open platforms also enable faster and more tailored innovation by allowing third-party development while preserving operational control and accountability. 3. Recommended EU-level measures To unlock these benefits, the EU should focus on enabling conditions rather than prescriptive technical requirements. This includes removing barriers to secure vulnerability discovery, promoting interoperability and alignment with international standards, supporting sustainable governance and maintenance of widely used components, focusing procurement on outcomes such as security and lifecycle management, ensuring practical and harmonized compliance requirements, and reconciling secure boot mechanisms with long-term device viability to avoid vendor lock-in and electronic waste. 4. Priority areas EU efforts should prioritize edge computing and IoT platforms, device and identity management, and cybersecurity tooling such as software composition analysis and vulnerability scanning to enable the secure, large-scale use of open source. 5. Priority sectors Open technologies can strengthen competitiveness and cyber resilience across public safety, smart cities, transport, energy, manufacturing, healthcare, and other critical infrastructure sectors. When combined with professional stewardship and security by design, open source delivers vendor independence, faster innovation, and stronger security through transparency.

feedback:
PMB Services est une SSLL (Société de Services en Logiciel Libre) de 42 salariés établie en France. Nous éditons le logiciel libre de gestion de bibliothèque PMB. Nous avons un modèle B2B de services autour du logiciel PMB ce qui favorise linvestissement dans le développement du logiciel. Nous ne vendons que du service, le logiciel doit donc être fiable et évolutif : la mise à jour ne rapporte rien. Nos clients, essentiellement du secteur public, financent parfois des évolutions du logiciel qui sont alors disponibles pour les autres, cela réduit la dépense publique. Ce modèle impose une qualité de service élevée : accompagner sur le meilleur usage du logiciel compte tenu du contexte et non linverse : adapter son contexte pour pouvoir utiliser le logiciel. Lentreprise a une politique constante dindépendance numérique. Nous sommes sous Linux, nous maitrisons notre infrastructure interne (matériel, et services essentiels). Pour les services externalisés, nous priorisons des entreprises européennes (libres si possible). Ce modèle est viable car nous ne supportons pas les couts de licences tels ceux de Microsoft ou autres éditeurs monopolistiques : faire travailler des salariés Européens nous coute moins cher. Du point de vue de la sécurité, la transparence des algorithmes permet le développement dun écosystème dévaluation de la qualité des logiciels. Cela encourage une information objective des risques au lieu de dépenser pour des antivirus, et autres « anti » pour protéger des systèmes intrinsèquement opaques et non sécurisés. Dun point de vue environnemental, cela prolonge nos matériels et incite à nutiliser que les services numériques nécessaires et adaptés à notre activité ce qui limite nos besoins en énergie. Enfin cette indépendance nous permet davoir une prévisibilité à long terme sur nos couts dinfrastructures logicielles et matérielles ainsi que sur les risques juridiques. Une politique favorisant le logiciel libre au sein de lUnion Européenne permettrait une innovation massive et rapide, adaptée aux besoins réels de nos économies avec une réflexion sur les usages, les besoins et le cout sociétal à priori plutôt quà postériori. La mutualisation des investissements pour des technologies communes efficaces, linteropérabilité des formats de données et des protocoles issus des logiciels libres favorise la concurrence loyale et évite les monopoles. Nous ne souhaitons pas de GAFAM Européens car cela conduira aux mêmes abus quactuellement. Pour soutenir ce modèle, lEurope doit investir massivement dans des infrastructures logicielles et matérielles afin de permettre laccès équitable à des ressources performantes pour des PME/TPE et stimuler leurs capacités dinnovation. Cela peut être financé par un impôt du numérique et un prix dutilisation bas, moins cher que des rentes artificielles abusives imposées par des sociétés Américaines. Laccès à ces ressources pourrait être gratuit pour les citoyens afin de stimuler la création dentreprises. Ladoption de normes communes (protocoles, données, certifications) favoriserait la décentralisation des fournisseurs, rendant nos infrastructures numériques plus résilientes. Enfin, la règlementation doit favoriser les logiciels libres dans tous les secteurs, dont ladministration. Publier un taux de dépendance à des technologies non libres ou non souveraines, favoriser les modèles de service du logiciel libre dans les règles dappel doffre, renforcer le droit dauteur pour pérenniser le code libre, rendre obligatoire linteropérabilité et la transparence des logiciels non libres. La majorité des projets libres sont hébergés sur GitHub de Microsoft qui peut en restreindre laccès à tout moment. Face à ce risque majeur, tout projet utilisé dans une administration ne doit plus être hébergé sur cette plateforme. Une alt

feedback: Wir sind ein Unternehmen, das u.a. virtuelle Infrastruktur für Kunden aller Branchen bereitstellt. In der Vergangenheit haben wir dazu dieselbe proprietäre Software aus den USA eingesetzt wie die meisten übrigen Unternehmen auf der Welt auch. Nachdem der Hersteller Ende 2023 übernommen wurde und die neuen Besitzer ab 2024 die Nutzungsbedingungen und Preise drastisch änderten, haben wir deutlich zu spüren bekommen, was mangelnde Souveränität bedeutet: ohne einen mutigen Strategie- und Technologiewechsel wären wir sicher untergegangen. Um nicht von einer in die nächste Abhängigkeit zu geraten, haben wir die Situation entschlossen genutzt, um unsere Virtualisierungsinfrastruktur samt sämtlichen Kundensystemen auf Proxmox VE, eine österreichische Open-Source-Software, umzuziehen. Das war uns innerhalb der knapp gesetzten Frist nur deshalb möglich, weil wir einerseits bereits viel Virtualisierungs-Know-How mitbrachten, andererseits gut vernetzt waren und uns schnell von einem Proxmox-zertifizierten Unternehmen schulen lassen konnten. Wir beobachten auch heute noch, dass viele Unternehmen vor ähnlichen Migrationsprojekten zurückschrecken. Was früher "No one ever got fired for buying IBM" war, gilt heute in ähnlicher Weise für Infrastruktursoftware. Als "Enterprise-tauglich" gilt nur, was von vielen großen Unternehmen eingesetzt wird. Wir würden uns daher wünschen, dass nicht nur die Open-Source-Softwareherstellung selbst, sondern auch ihre Einführung in Organisationen gefördert wird. Ein Ökosystem, das Unternehmen aller Größen und Branchen die Sicherheit gibt, dass die ihrer IT zugrundeliegende Virtualisierungssoftware ihnen immer zuverlässig und unbegrenzt zur Verfügung steht, ist m.E. die beste Voraussetzung, um europäische Unternehmen souveräner in Sachen IT-Betrieb zu machen.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: We are a company that, among other things, provides virtual infrastructure to customers in all sectors. In the past, we used the same proprietary software from the US as most other companies in the world. After the manufacturer was taken over at the end of 2023 and the new owners drastically changed the terms of use and prices as of 2024, we have clearly felt what lack of sovereignty means: without a bold change in strategy and technology, we would certainly have disappeared. To avoid falling into the next dependency, we have used the situation decisively to move our virtualisation infrastructure and all customer systems to Proxmox VE, an Austrian open source software. This was possible within the tight deadline only because, on the one hand, we already had a lot of virtualisation know-how, on the other hand, we were well connected and could quickly have ourselves trained by a proxmox-certified company. We are still seeing that many companies are reluctant to engage in similar migration projects. What used to be ‘No one ever got fired for buying IBM’ today applies in a similar way to infrastructure software. ‘Enterprise-ready’ refers only to what is used by many large companies. We would therefore like to see not only open-source software production itself but also its introduction into organisations promoted. An ecosystem that gives companies of all sizes and sectors the assurance that the virtualisation software underpinning their IT is always available to them in a reliable and unlimited manner is, in my view, the best way to make European companies more sovereign in IT operations.

feedback: Open Source Software is the backbone of computing. In contrast to proprietary software, it allows for direct participation of citizens/users and is the only sustainable way for digital sovereignty of Europe. The Open Source ethos is a facet of civil society that is often underestimated but crucial in the age of Big Tech trampling over right to privacy and ownership, and as such should be backed by the government wishing to empower its citizens. Open Source Software delivers security, independence and free flow of ideas and tools that are much needed for thriving society and prosperous economy. The shift to Open Source Software in the European Union will improve interoperability, reduce costs, increase competition and reduce foreign influence.

Schwarz Group supports the objectives of the European Open Digital Ecosystem Strategy. The AI breakthrough and the shift to cloud-native architectures represent a paradigm change. To ensure competitiveness and digital sovereignty, Europe must reduce dependencies by scaling three key levels: Applications: Boosting European CSPs which act as long-term maintainers and industrial integrators of critical components. Software: Developing interoperable, vendor-agnostic building blocks that allow software to run flexibly and securely across diverse, local infrastructures. Infrastructure: Expanding European data centers (AI Gigafactory). Open source is essential to avoid lockin, enable portability, and ensure long term digital sovereignty. By utilizing open standards to ease collaboration between diverse players, Europe can translate faster its innovation power into market-ready solutions. European industries and public sectors need an independent, marketoriented open source ecosystem delivering a vendoragnostic software stack between hardware and cloud/AI services. Today, the governance, funding and roadmaps of open-source-software development is often disproportionately influenced by non-European commercial interests and often ignore EU specific needs for enhanced security, data protection and manufacturing applications. Many components act as onboarding ramps by offering a standardized open-source core that requires the integration of proprietary cloud services for enterprise-grade security, scalability, and operational viability, effectively funneling users into a vendor-specific ecosystem to proprietary addons, creating vendor lockin and fragmenting the ecosystem with unpredictable long-term availability and affordability. The future strategy should prioritize the development of a validated, industrial-grade intermediate layer that integrates existing open-source standards into a European software stack. This stack should ensure true interoperability at the software layer, moving beyond "onboarding ramps" to eliminate vendor lock-in and enable portable, vendor-agnostic deployments. The strategy should bridge the investment gap and provide a sustainable alternative to the proprietary ecosystems of non-European hyperscalers. The objective should not be to reinvent existing basic standards, but to systemically integrate them into an validated, industrial-grade open-source layer, for Infrastructure and for cloud-native intermediate layers such as Platform (depending on the different use cases needs). Very significant investments, including several thousands developers would be required for Europe to reach the 2025 technological level of other regions by 2030, and even more to go beyond the state of the art. Furthermore, additional investments of a similar magnitude would be necessary for GPU software orchestration to enable vendor-agnostic hardware configurations for European data centers. Initiatives going in this direction should be supported.The strategy should therefore focus on the private sector and industrial use cases. In terms of governance, the future strategy should consider the creation of an Open Source Foundation acting as anchor for strategic open source projects at European level. Future actions should be implemented in a practicable way that takes into consideration the decentralized and flexible dimensions of open source communities, in particular when it comes to public funding requirements. Use cases should include the public sector and critical sectors (such as healthcare). In particular, the funding mechanisms should ensure that the developer community works hand in hand with actors involved in the rolling out of use cases. It should be ensured that public authorities act as anchor customers and support the offtake of European digital services.
I love open source. Stallman is my god.

feedback: The European Council of Engineers Chambers (ECEC) sees the initiative on European open digital ecosystems as a key lever for securing Europe's economic, legal, and technological capacity to act. Digital infrastructures have long been critical foundations for professional, economic, and public activity and must not be shaped exclusively by the short-term business interests of individual global providers. From the perspective of the planning (designing) and construction industry, permanent data sovereignty is of fundamental importance. Responsibility for buildings, infrastructure, and public safety extends over decades. Digital tools must therefore guarantee unlimited, reliable access to own project data. In addition, readability for the public sector must also be ensured; digitization of documents must not result in authorities and thus also the EU losing access to data on the building stock and thus an essential basis for future EU GWP calculations. Models in which access to essential data depends on active subscriptions, cloud availability, or external server structures are not compatible with this responsibility. The ECEC expressly warns against the progressive economization of digital dependencies through exclusively subscription-based licensing models. The withdrawal of permanently usable software licenses and the imposition of ongoing payment obligations shift business risks unilaterally to users and jeopardize the economic stability of small and medium-sized enterprises in particular. European digital ecosystems must therefore ensure predictable, sustainable, and non-exclusive usage models. The increasing shift of central functions to proprietary cloud infrastructures must be viewed just as critically. A de facto cloud requirement for core functions deprives users of control over the availability, confidentiality, and functionality of their work tools and creates systemic dependencies on non-European infrastructures. This contradicts the goals of European digital sovereignty. The ECEC also rejects closed BIM strategies and proprietary ecosystems that restrict interoperability and hinder collaboration in complex, division-of-labor value chains. Open standards are not a technical option, but a political necessity to ensure competition, innovation, and fair market conditions. These positions are in line with the fundamental principles advocated by the Free Software Foundation Europe (FSFE), among others: vendor independence, transparency through open source code, open standards, and control over software and data. However, experience in the planning industry shows that these principles are not only normatively desirable, but also practically indispensable. European open digital ecosystems should therefore be understood not as a voluntary addition, but as a strategic infrastructure policy. They must ensure the following: permanent usability and data access, economic planning security, independence from individual providers and infrastructures, interoperability through open standards, and protection of sensitive data within European jurisdictions. Only under these conditions can digital ecosystems make an effective contribution to securing Europe's planning, construction, and innovation culture and to Europe's long-term digital sovereignty.

On Building Capacity and Capability for Open Source and Civic Software Sustainability and Digital Sovereignty in Europe I would like to personally thank the Commission for this opportunity to provide feedback and evidence on the strategic open source strategy that is developed. I would like to focus on one very narrow aspect - that of capacity and capability building -- of ensuring that the Europe of Tomorrow has what it needs to maintain and further the digital infrastructure it so crucially relies on in general, and by extension its open digital ecosystem. And to make this practical - I would like to do this in the form of a very practical proposal (attached) -- the creation of the Jacquard Grant. That 1) exposes students to Open Source and Standards widely, 2) creates an European Open Source Excellence Centre (EOSEC) to work on OpenSource & Civic Software that 3) allows a smaller group of academic students to get hands-on experience in open source to prepare them in their career and 4) provides Europe with a strategic knowledge capture on the open source that is crucial to a modern, open and democratic, society.

**Towards a Human-Centric, Open and Sovereign European Digital Ecosystem This proposal presents a comprehensive framework for the regulation of the digital domain, grounded in the *European Declaration on Digital Rights and Principles* and aimed at strengthening *Digital Strategic Autonomy* within an open, democratic, and human-centric European Digital Ecosystem. The digital domain is recognized as a *European Digital Public Space* in which citizens, public administrations, and economic actors exercise fundamental rights, access essential services, and generate social and economic value. As such, it requires democratic governance under the rule of law, equivalent in relevance to territorial, maritime, and airspace domains. At the core of the proposal is the recognition of citizens enforceable rights over their *personal and collective digital assets*, including personal data, digital identities, software artifacts, and other immaterial resources. These rights encompass control, protection, portability, and fair use, in line with the GDPR, the Data Governance Act, and the Data Act. Digital assets are therefore treated as rights-based assets whose protection is a public responsibility. To ensure effective governance, the proposal establishes an *Independent Digital Public Authority for Regulation and Guarantee* (Servizio Informatico Nazionale - SIN). Operating in coordination with European institutions and national competent authorities, the SIN is responsible for regulating digital activities, coordinating public digital policies, and providing assistance to citizens within the European Digital Public Space. Its role is comparable to other essential public services, such as healthcare or civil protection, ensuring continuity, resilience, and rights protection. The proposal introduces legally defined professional roles of *Certified Digital Professionals* and *Certified Digital Support Practitioners*, whose activities directly impact fundamental rights, public services, or critical digital infrastructures. The exercise of these roles is subject to a mandatory *License to Code (Professional Digital Accountability License)*, which certifies technical competence, ethical responsibility, and legal accountability. The license is issued, supervised, suspended, or revoked by the SIN according to transparent and due-process-based procedures. Public and private organizations are required to employ licensed professionals for all digital functions affecting systems, data, security, and essential services. The use of unlicensed personnel in such roles is prohibited and subject to proportionate sanctions, reinforcing trust, safety, and accountability across the digital ecosystem. Finally, the proposal establishes that *Executable Digital Artifacts*, including software, platforms, and systems, must ensure traceable authorship and legal accountability. Such artifacts must be cryptographically signed by the valid professional licenses of all contributing certified professionals. In the event of license revocation, the artifact becomes legally invalid for execution until compliance is restored. This mechanism strengthens software supply-chain security while remaining fully compatible with *Free and Open Source Software* principles, as licensing requirements apply to professional responsibility and execution in regulated contexts, not to access, study, modification, or redistribution of source code. Overall, this proposal contributes to the development of a trusted, open, and rights-based European Digital Ecosystem, reinforcing democratic governance, professional accountability, and Digital Strategic Autonomy in full alignment with European values.

feedback: While it is a good sign, that the European Commission starts an initiative to strengthen the open source sector in the EU, it is unfortunately way too late. We as a society and its legislators have waited far too long to change the current situation. Big Tech has a virtually infinite amount of money and with this money comes unprecedented power to keep their monopolies and kill every competition, either by unfair practices or simply by buying other companies. If you think about funding certain projects, that's nice for some developers, but it will change nothing. It doesn't matter how much money you will throw at the problems, the Metas, Microsofts and Alphabets of this world will always spend more money for lobbyists, spin doctors and pressure campaigns. You will always loose the money game. The situation is so bad that you have to think beyond funds and the tweaking of some rules for open source projects. You have to be radical, you have to change the system that allowed Big Tech to grow like cancer cells and extract so much of our money. One radical solution that we propose is adversarial interoperability. Following the Digital Millenium Act (1998 ) the US enforced the adoption of so called "anti circumvention laws" worldwide. The EU gave into the pressure and issued 2001 the Directive on Copyright in the Digital Single Market (Directive (EU) 2019/790 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 17 April 2019 on copyright and related rights in the Digital Single Market and amending Directives 96/9/EC and 2001/29/EC). This legislation contains the infamous Article 6 which prohibits anti-circumvention technology. What does this mean? When you buy something and it contains software with an access control, you (the owner) are not allowed to make changes to the device. This is a fundamental new perspective on ownership. Ownership means, you can do with you property whatever you want. If you buy an iPhone, it is per definition not your property because you can not do with your iPhone what Apple doesn't want you to do. Let us stay with the Apple example. If some US president decides to cut the EU from all US Services, you have millions of citizens with completely useless iPhones the next minute. Because the Article 6 prohibits open source teams to develop an alternative, European operating system for smartphones. Apple takes 30 cent of every dollar for every digital sale on the iPhone. A European alternative app store could take only 5 percent and still earn billions each year. Lets take a look at some bigger hardware. After Russia stole some John Deere tractors from the Ukraine, the company pulled a kill switch to deactivate these machines. Sounds like a win, but this could happen to the whole of Europe tomorrow. European developers could free all these tractors from US control and could provide Europe with better products. Adversarial interoperability is without any doubt a radical move against the wishes of one former ally. But we are sure: radical moves are our only chance against a system which was build against free and open source projects and European alternatives. Let's fight the power or die trying.

Mobivia (Norauto, Midas, ATU) strongly supports the European Commissions initiative for an Open Source Software-Defined Vehicle (SDV) core stack. This is viewed as a vital move for EU technological sovereignty, ensuring that the automotive transition remains competitive, secure, and open, rather than restricted to closed proprietary ecosystems. Key Benefits of Open Source Innovation: Open standards allow a diverse range of stakeholders to develop services (predictive maintenance, energy management), preventing a monopoly by vehicle manufacturers (OEMs). Trust & Resilience: Moving away from "black box" systems toward transparent, audited security protocols increases cyber-resilience. Neutrality: Open source breaks the dependency on the restrictive "Extended Vehicle" model, promoting a level playing field. Critical Market Barriers Mobivia identifies three major obstacles that currently hinder independent players: Gatekeeping: The lack of open on-board platforms prevents third parties from running independent algorithms. Data Retention: Up to 99% of data remains in-vehicle. By labeling critical data (like Battery State of Health) as "proprietary inferred data," OEMs bypass the Data Act, depriving the aftermarket of essential information. Security Pretexts: Regulation UN R155 is frequently misused as a justification to block access to vehicle interfaces. Strategic Recommendations To ensure a fair digital ecosystem, Mobivia proposes: Functional Equivalence: Independent operators must have access to the same computing resources and predictive capabilities as official manufacturer networks. Standardized Open APIs: Mandating universal protocols (e.g., OAuth2) to lower entry costs for SMEs and ensure the portability of vehicle history. HMI Neutrality: Preventing OEMs from using dashboard screens to unfairly direct customers to their own networks, thereby protecting consumer choice. Strict Oversight: Creating a monitoring body to audit access costs and sanction anti-competitive behavior with GDPR-style deterrent penalties. Conclusion Transitioning to an open-source SDV stack is essential to guarantee the Right to Repair, fair competition, and the long-term viability of independent automotive operators in Europe.
