feedback: Open source is the best strategy the EU can adopt for digital sovereignty, to foster development and competitiveness for the network of small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), which constitute the Union's true economic strength, and to enhance our research and educational institutions. Open source and its full support, including at the political and regulatory levels, are the way out of the US oligopoly, the risks of which are now clear to all. Please support the full migration to open solutions and formats (formats are crucial!) for all European public administrations, of all sizes.

Feedback Response to Ares(2026)69111 from ElaadNL Strengths and weaknesses of the EU open-source sector The EU opensource sector benefits from strong collaboration, alignment with EU values, and a need for digital sovereignty. However, the ecosystem faces notable issues: Chronic underinvestment in open-source systems, leading to maintenance and sustainability risks Limited awareness and availability of open-source alternatives for critical systems Incompatible tendering favoring proprietary solutions, reinforcing vendor lock-in These issues increase dependency on proprietary solutions, hinder the modernization of digital grid systems, and slow down transitions toward open, interoperable alternatives. Added value of open source Open-source reduces cost, lowers vendor lock-in, and strengthens digital sovereignty. Its open and community-driven nature improve security through faster vulnerability detection and remediation, while shared R&D accelerates innovation. EU level measures to strengthen technological sovereignty and cybersecurity The EU must adopt a systemic, end-to-end view of digital dependencies. Open-source software alone does not guarantee digital sovereignty if critical layers, such as hosting, cloud, compute, and operational control, remain under non-EU influence. Digital sovereignty should not imply building internally but ensuring that organizations retain effective governance, oversight, and decision-making power over the digital systems on which society depends. EU level support should prioritize the following: 1. Open source first procurement. Align procurement frameworks to prefer open source solutions, ensure consistent regulatory guidance, and direct investment toward sovereign EU open source based services. 2. Reduce structural dependencies. Ensure credible substitution paths to open-source alternatives for essential systems, especially in critical sectors. 3. A risk-based roadmap for adoption of open-source. Prioritize open-source adoption in critical systems first, where resilience and security gains are highest. Scale capability across the EU through skills development, training, and organizational structures. Priority technology areas The EU should prioritize foundational technology domains where dependencies create systemic risk: Open-source cloud and edge infrastructure Open-source AI and shared data infrastructures Critical sectoral technologies (e.g. open-source grid and energy system and eMobility software) Sectors where OSS boosts competitiveness and cyber resilience Energy: Interoperable, vendor independent open-source tools strengthen the resilience and sovereignty of critical energy infrastructure. Cloud & edge: Open platforms reduce dependence on non EU cloud and edge providers and create growth opportunities for European alternatives. AI: Open, trustworthy open source AI models support compliance with EU regulatory and ethical standards.

ITI - the Information Technology Industry Council - is the global trade association of the technology industry, representing 80 of the worlds most innovative tech companies. Our membership spans across the entire spectrum of technology, including global leaders on software and AI, hardware, cloud, infrastructure, cybersecurity and semiconductors.

feedback: Open source has become one of the fundamental bricks on which today's society is built. It is essential, in particular, as an enabler of rapid innovation and economic growth. Furthermore, in the current geopolitical context, it is becoming all the more important for digital sovereignty and independence from (in particular) US-based mega-corporations. Fortunately, the EU commission and MEPs are well-aware of this. Past initiatives, such as NGI have supported open source development through grants distributed among others by the NLNet foundation. These grants have been very beneficial to the open source ecosystem, and they were well-targeted to help develop alternatives to the centralized US-based platforms we have become so dependent upon. One limit of these grants however, is that they were generally focused on new development, rather than boring maintenance. But maintenance of open source software is essential if we want to be able to rely on it, and this work is rarely funded as such. Even when there are sustainable businesses behind some open source projects (which is not always the case), maintenance work is often funded by selling other things such as services or development. This is why the EU should go beyond the current strategy and look into ways to support the on-going and long-term maintenance of essential open source projects. For this, a good source of inspiration could be the German Sovereign Tech Fund, which has a part of its mission dedicated to precisely this. That's why I call on the EU to implement a EU Sovereign Tech Fund, and build on past experiments on how to distribute the funding. In particular, it is important that funding targets maintainers of open source projects and be as unbureaucratic as possible: maintainers need to be able to focus on software maintenance and evolution. Open source is a global movement, which doesn't stop at the frontiers of the EU. We can benefit from open source projects being well-maintained, even when they are developed outside our borders. Therefore, it makes sense to support not just EU developers. However, for our independence, it is also useful to have EU-based developers, who can be hired in EU companies and help the EU economy switch to using open source solutions. Money distributed through an EU STF should strike the right balance between funding maintenance of important open source projects globally, and making sure that developers in the EU build competencies around this software. One solution could be through the funding of community events / organizations that help build a European presence and European expertise within communities of open source projects that may be lacking one (while also funding maintenance work carried out by open source developers who may be outside of the EU).

I am writing as a representative of an EU-based service company and a partner of the Proxmox ecosystem. Our business model involves developing strategic solutions for our clients, where our entire cloud infrastructure and value-added services are built upon Proxmox Virtual Environment (VE). We strongly support the "European Open Digital Ecosystems" initiative. We believe the EU must prioritize open-source infrastructure to prevent the risks. The global virtualization market is undergoing rapid transformation, driven by the need for real-time data access and cost-effective infrastructure solutions. In this scenario, Proxmox VE and the open source model offer the stability, predictability, and security that European companies need to plan for the long term. By leveraging Proxmox VE, we have built a sovereign cloud stack that rivals proprietary hyperscalers in stability and functionality, but without being tied to restrictive licensing models. This allows us to maintain full control over our data and infrastructure, a critical requirement for true European digital sovereignty. The open-source nature of our stack eliminates hidden licensing fees, significantly reducing TCO. This saving is reinvested into innovation and developing tailored, high-value implementations for our customers. A regulatory framework that supports this model would allow more European SMEs to compete globally. We urge the European Commission to view open-source not just as an alternative, but as a safety net for the European economy. Future regulations should explicitly support 100% open-source infrastructure solutions to protect EU businesses to ensure a resilient, competitive, and trustworthy digital market.

The EU open-source sector benefits from growing developer community, strong public/academic/industrial foundations, and close alignment with EU values. Open-source is a key lever for digital sovereignty. Open-source delivers strategic independence, security, efficiency and innovation for public/private sectors. It reduces vendor lock-in, enables deployment on European controlled infrastructure, ensure skills development and supports sovereign choices for AI, cloud and networks. Increased adoption brings massive business opportunities to EU companies and allows investments to remain within the EU. Code transparency improves auditability, vulnerability detection and supply chain assurance. It often lowers TCO, accelerates time to market. Concrete examples in telecom include carrier grade VoIP, routing/network OS (ex: SONiC), firewalls, telco cloud (ex: Sylva) and network services lifecycle management. EU telecom operators contribute to these components to build secure, high-performance networks, reducing dependency on proprietary vendors and enabling architectural optionality. Main weaknesses for open-source in Europe include: low open-source strategic maturity; lack of catalogue and visibility (open-source components/publishers) in a fragmented EU ecosystem; lack of EU-scale providers; low representation in large non-EU foundations; strong dependencies on non-EU critical tooling; short-term funding policy, with low lifecycle support; skills shortages in security, maintenance, and projects governance; lack of independent certification labs; lack of awareness of legal implications of open-source licences; persistent negative perceptions on supply chain and existing industrial ecosystem, robustness and security; insufficient awareness and operationalization of CRA/NIS2. Despite rising contributions, many organizations consume open-source without giving back, threatening its sustainability. Key actions at EU level include: 1.Policy: Clarify roles and responsibilities of open-source-based solutions stakeholders to remain compliant with CRA & NIS2 without impacting the development of the EU open-source ecosystem. Encourage open APIs in public procurement and recognize open-source contributions for R&D tax credit incentives. Set up incentive to finance securitization of open source. 2.Funding: Establish long-term funding mechanisms for critical projects with full lifecycle and European testing/certification structures. Continue Next Generation Internet initiatives. Ease and financially support / cofinance development of open-source software through associations like TOSIT in France. 3.Ecosystem: Structure an EU industrial ecosystem (incl. an EU manifesto), support EU-law based foundations, and actively support European representation in global open-source foundations. Reduce dependence on non-EU critical open-source tooling and infrastructure. Establish a specific status/label for maintainers and open-source specialized SMEs and encourage large software users associations like TOSIT in France. 4.Procurement: Explore Open-Source as a first option in the public sector leveraging standardized procurement frameworks and evaluation criteria specifically adapted to open-source-based and sovereign solutions. 5.Skills: Launch large-scale training programs and cultural transformation initiatives for enterprises. 6.Security: Develop European security frameworks including audits, SBOM standards, bug bounty programs, and trusted repositories aligned with CRA/NIS2. Priority technology areas should include cloud and edge infrastructure, operating systems, infrastructure virtualization, 5G/6G, network function virtualization, databases and data management platforms, AI ecosystem, cybersecurity tooling and open hardware. Open-source in the telecommunication sector would reinforce digital sovereignty and resilience. It is a unique opportunity for Europe to ensure control over

feedback: I would like to bring to the Commission's attention that with a concrete policy change the EU may currently be uniquely positioned to shape a long-term digital ecosystem structure that directly strengthens the European economy, encourages local innovation and reduces strategic dependence on non-EU platform providers. As journalist and digital rights activist Cory Doctorow has recently argued, there is a concrete policy lever in revising Article 6 of Directive 2001/29/EC that could have significant impact on European digital sovereignty, lowering barriers to market entry and enabling competitive European service ecosystems. In its current form, this article systematically disadvantages European SMEs and open source developers by restricting interoperability, alternative clients and lawful modification. In practice, this has repeatedly increased cost and technical effort in my own filmmaking business and has obstructed my colleagues' attempts to build alternative, domestic media platforms. I therefore encourage the Commission to consider a targeted revision and clarification of Article 6 in order to safeguard the future development of alternative, domestic and open source software. Additional information and more detailed reasoning can be found in Cory Doctorow's January 2026 Guardian article and his presentation at the CCC summit: https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2026/jan/10/trump-beginning-of-end-enshittification-make-tech-good-again https://media.ccc.de/v/39c3-a-post-american-enshittification-resistant-internet With kind regards

The EU has opportunities to develop the open source ecosystem and build it up as a sovereign alternative to the traditional "big tech" model used by many companies. An ideal scenario would see a continent working together in a non-zero sum economy, everyone contributing together to build a more secure, useful, and local technology environment. Ultimately, a functioning digital economy needs to treat software not as a source of rental income, but as a basis on which every other useful job and service is built, and this requires a more collaborative approach without gatekeepers. Open source forces this to be the case. The collaborative approach offered by open source allows people and organisations to share their own resources, and to collaborate on developing them as they need, without having to wait for investment from the company that owns the technology. This applies to everything from full operating system environments such as those offered by KDE, organised by a group in Germany, to smaller suites focused on specific tools such as LibreOffice, run by The Document Foundation, also based in Germany. A fully open source workspace offers better security as there is no central authority that can "retire" a tool, preventing workers from using it, and even if maintainers stop supporting it, another team can step in and take ownership. Many large tech companies such as google are noted for their propensity to stop offering products that people rely on (see killedbygoogle.com), or for companies such as adobe to take working products and force companies into an expensive cloud subscription model which takes control of their own work away from them. Open source can also refer to data - be this datasets in open access science, databases such as mapping and geo data (such as OpenStreetMap, developed initially in the UK), and resources such as educational material (often seen with open code education groups such as Code Your Future in the UK). There are some challenges to ensure that an open ecosystem can function better than closed source technologies: 1. Anti-circumvention laws prevent organisations in the EU from developing alternatives that can work with or compete with closed source technologies and if the EU is serious about supporting open source and a modern digital ecosystem, these laws should be repealed. 2. There needs to be much stricter requirements ensuring that closed systems adhere to interoperability, whether this is from a data aspect (such as allowing transfer of data between services) or a systems aspect (allowing users of different, even competing, services the ability to program them to talk to each other). 3. There needs to be an EU-wide approach to the concept of "public money for public code" - normalising the idea that code is a public good and that any investments should see the output shared with everyone. This should also extend to EU institutions only using open source solutions in their work and communications.

As a Proxmox partner, we work with many customers in sensitive environments such as critical infrastructure, public sector organizations, and industrial companies that require air-gapped systems with no permanent internet connectivity. In these scenarios, open source virtualization platforms like Proxmox VE provide clear advantages over many proprietary or hyperscaler-based solutions. Proxmox allows full local control, transparent software components, and predictable licensing without mandatory cloud dependencies. This is essential for customers who must meet strict security, data sovereignty, and compliance requirements. Compared to other market offerings, Proxmox VE enables us to deliver cost-effective, flexible, and secure virtualization solutions that are well suited for European regulatory and operational needs. A regulatory framework that actively supports open source software and interoperable, on-premises solutions would strengthen digital sovereignty, reduce vendor lock-in, and foster innovation across Europe.

Danke für diese Inititiave! Open-Source ist sehr entscheidend für Digitalisierung Europas. Ein Sektor, in dem Open-Source noch keine Rolle spielt ist der C-ITS-Bereich: Kooperative Intelligente Transportsysteme, also die Digitalisierung unser Mobilität und zugehöriger Verkehrssysteme (Ampelschaltungen, vernetztes Fahren, ÖPNV-Beschleunigung, uvm). Open-Source würde zahlreiche Vorteile bringen, um dieses Themenfeld in Richtung Zukunft zu beschleunigen. Es wäre aus unserer Sicht wichtig, die gesamte Branche (v.a. die Signalbaubranche) zu 100%-Open-Source zu verpflichten.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: Thank you for this initiative! Open source is key to digitising Europe. One sector that is not yet open source is C-ITS: Cooperative intelligent transport systems, i.e. the digitalisation of our mobility and related transport systems (traffic lights, connected driving, public transport acceleration, etc.). Open source would bring many benefits to speed up this topic in the future. In our view, it would be important to require the entire sector (especially the signalling sector) to be 100 % open-source.

feedback: This feedback is to express support for the creation of an EU level Sovereign Tech Fund, roughly modeled on its German namesake, and/or the current Next Generation Internet. Previous EU initiatives like the Next Generation Internet (of which we have been and still are recipients of funding) have made it possible for independent contributors of FLOSS (Free Libre Open Source Software) to conduct their work on otherwise neglected parts of the internet technical stack. Programs like this are incredibly valuable (my comment specifically refers to the NGI0 set of programs) because of their "low bureaucracy, low overhead" model. A simple application process means that small teams or even individuals are able to apply and obtain funding for work which is often critical. Such initiatives should be replicated, especially considering the very high value per euro they appear to produce. We would also like to stress that the Open source software ecosystem is global. Drawing lines along country borders is probably the wrong approach to assessing sovereignty of software. Instead it is more relevant to focus on open standards, open protocols and support those with code that is also open. Put another way, the sovereignty problem is not going to be solved by funding EU based privately held startups. Not only because investors will sooner or later come from beyond the EU, but because this is only replicating the current model which we are now seeing fail. It also follows that while a focus on EU based projects is relevant, it should probably not be a hard requirements as long as the software created is truly open and free, and allows actual data sovereignty. Another essential aspect of sovereignty is community involvement. By community, we mean all levels of contributors, from major corporations to individual developers, to users. This is essential to ensuring a broad perspective on how how software is built, used, reused and maintained. Corporate lobbyists alone cannot provide such diversity of perspectives. It would also be essential to think of long term maintenance of software. Whether it's low level bricks that support the internet, or end-user facing applications, software cannot be thought of as being built and then left to live its life alone. Maintenance, in the form of code updates, and related activities such as documentation and user support are also essential to the success of software over time. In that sense, one-off funding, while critical, is insufficient. Finally, besides funding free software through grants, it is also critical to make opensource, along with data sovereignty, a key criterion in public procurement. The "public money, public code" campaign summarises this much better than it can be done here. Many famous open-source projects are in fact corporate closed products with a layer of "opensource" gloss, where control over data and governance typically lies outside EU borders. Public procurement should instead focus on decentralised solutions based on open source software and open protocols.

Veuillez trouver ci-dessous une synthèse de la contribution de l'Institut national de l'information géographique et forestière (IGN France), ainsi que la contribution complète en pièce jointe. Besoin de communs numériques Lopen source ne suffira pas à créer une capacité technologique souveraine, il y a besoin de réaliser des communs numériques. Lopen source et les communs numériques sont des outils essentiels pour assurer la souveraineté et lautonomie de lUE pour certaines technologies et dans certains secteurs, notamment dans les suivants. Un engagement fort serait la mise en place dun fonds européen doté dun milliard deuros pour financer des briques technologiques de base, structurées en couches (selon une logique de stack), organisés sous forme de communs numériques. Cf. développement ci-joint : réponse à la question 3. Besoin de communs numériques dans le secteur géospatial Actuellement lUE nest pas souveraine en matière de données et services géospatiaux. Dans le contexte géopolitique actuel, il est important que lEurope assure sa souveraineté en matière de données géospatiales. En ce sens, il faudrait que la stratégie européenne pour un écosystème numérique de lUE inclue un volet géospatial. Pour cela, lUE a besoin de capacités autonomes dacquisition de données géographiques, de systèmes autonomes de production de données géographiques, et de systèmes autonomes de mise à disposition de données géographiques. Exemple dun socle technique pour les plateformes géospatiales : il serait utile de mettre en place un socle technique doutils et de ressources techniques génériques, qui aideront les plateformes de découverte, partage, diffusion, croisement et visualisation des données géospatiales, à mutualiser des outils opérationnels et à inter-opérer. Cf. développement ci-joint : réponse à la question 5. Besoin de communs numériques dans les services et applications cartographiques LUE devrait se rendre autonome en matière de services et applications de cartographie et de localisation (exemple : applications de cartographie pour smartphones), et en matière dinfrastructures sur lesquelles reposent les services de cartographie (plateformes et briques technologiques de stockage, de saisie collaborative, de représentation, de diffusion de données géographiques ; exemple : systèmes et plateformes dinformation géospatiale). Besoin de mesures législatives et normatives Instaurer une utilisation de commun numérique par défaut : imposer que tous les logiciels ou produits achetés par l'UE et les administrations sappuient sur des briques technologiques qui soient des communs numériques, dès lors quils existent. Réviser le droit européen afin que les communs numériques puissent être financés sans tomber dans le régime des aides dEtat. Cf. développement ci-joint : réponse à la question 3.

feedback: Ritengo che lopen source rappresenti un pilastro strategico per il futuro dellecosistema digitale europeo e che il suo ruolo debba essere ulteriormente rafforzato nelle politiche, nei finanziamenti e nelle implementazioni promosse dallUnione Europea. Ladozione di soluzioni open source favorisce trasparenza, interoperabilità e sovranità tecnologica, riducendo la dipendenza da fornitori extra-UE e da modelli proprietari chiusi. Questo è particolarmente rilevante in settori critici come la pubblica amministrazione, la sanità, listruzione, le infrastrutture digitali e lintelligenza artificiale. Il codice aperto consente verificabilità, audit indipendenti e un maggiore controllo sui dati, elementi fondamentali per la fiducia dei cittadini e per la sicurezza digitale. Lopen source non è solo una scelta tecnologica, ma anche economica e sociale. Supporta un ecosistema di PMI, startup e sviluppatori indipendenti, stimola linnovazione distribuita e riduce le barriere allingresso. A differenza di modelli centralizzati, permette allEuropa di valorizzare il proprio capitale umano e di costruire soluzioni condivise, riutilizzabili e sostenibili nel lungo periodo. Tuttavia, affinché lopen source possa esprimere pienamente il suo potenziale, è necessario un impegno più strutturato. In particolare, ritengo importante: riconoscere formalmente lopen source come infrastruttura digitale critica; garantire finanziamenti stabili non solo allo sviluppo iniziale, ma anche alla manutenzione, alla sicurezza e alla governance dei progetti; promuovere competenze open source allinterno delle istituzioni pubbliche; favorire ladozione di soluzioni open source nei bandi e negli appalti, evitando criteri che privilegino implicitamente il software proprietario. LUnione Europea ha lopportunità di diventare un riferimento globale per un modello digitale aperto, etico e collaborativo. Rafforzare lopen source significa investire in autonomia strategica, resilienza e innovazione condivisa. È una scelta coerente con i valori europei e con la necessità di costruire un futuro digitale più equo, sicuro e sostenibile.

I believe that lopen source is a strategic pillar for the future of the European digital ecosystem and that its role should be further strengthened in the policies, funding and implementations promoted by the European Union. The deployment of open source solutions fosters transparency, interoperability and technological sovereignty, reducing dependence on non-EU suppliers and closed proprietary models. This is particularly relevant in critical areas such as public administration, health, education, digital infrastructure and artificial lymphelligence. Open code allows for verifiability, independent audits and increased control over data, which are crucial for citizens’ trust and digital security. Open source is not only a technological choice, but also an economic and social one. It supports an ecosystem of SMEs, start-ups and independent developers, stimulates distributed novation and reduces entry barriers. Unlike centralised models, it enables Europe to capitalise on its human capital and build shared, reusable and long-term sustainable solutions. However, for lopen source to reach its full potential, more structured engagement is needed. In particular, I consider it important to: formally recognise lopen source as a critical digital infrastructure; ensure stable funding not only for the initial development but also for the maintenance, security and governance of projects; promote open source expertise within public institutions; encourage the use of open source solutions in calls for tender and procurement, avoiding criteria that implicitly favour proprietary software. The European Union has commended becoming a global reference for an open, ethical and collaborative digital mo

feedback: EU Open-Source Digital Ecosystems Global Forum for Media Development (GFMD) Submitted by: Bojana Kostić, Senior Digital Policy Advisor 1. Strengths, weaknesses, and barriers The EU open-source ecosystem benefits from strong, values-driven communities, mature technical expertise, and a growing political recognition of the risks associated with dependency on non-EU proprietary technologies. Europe has a unique opportunity to position itself as a global leader in public-interest, sovereign, and interoperable digital infrastructure. However, structural weaknesses persist. These include fragmented funding, limited pathways for scaling and long-term maintenance, talent retention challenges, and regulatory and administrative burdens that disproportionately affect small open-source projects and volunteer-driven communities. Fragmentation across languages and markets further complicates adoption, despite the existence of strong transnational networks. Key barriers include usability gaps compared to proprietary solutions, limited resources for security maintenance, licensing complexity, legal uncertainty, and the difficulty of demonstrating return on investment for open-source contributions. Without sustained institutional and financial support, open-source solutions struggle to move from experimentation to reliable, large-scale deployment. 2. Added value for the public and private sectors Open-source technologies provide significant added value through transparency, auditability, interoperability, and reduced vendor lock-in. These features are critical for cost control, cybersecurity, innovation, and technological sovereignty. Interoperability in particular is essential to ensuring competition, resilience, and user choice, and is often structurally resisted by proprietary systems. For the public sector, open-source enables accountability, democratic governance, and alignment with EU values. For the private sector, it fosters competitive markets, innovation, and flexibility. European examplessuch as public administrations migrating to open-source collaboration and cloud toolsdemonstrate tangible benefits in cost, security, and control. 3. EU-level measures to support open-source Priority actions at EU level should include: - Expanded and sustained funding for open-source R&D, maintenance, and security (including audits and bug bounties); - Streamlined, proportionate administrative requirements for open-source communities; - Public procurement rules that provide incentives for EU-based, open-source and interoperable solutions; - Legal and policy frameworks that embed public-interest principles in digital public infrastructure; - Support for sustainable business models, education, skills development, and community infrastructure. - Designating interoperability as a baseline requirement for public-sector digital technologies would significantly strengthen these efforts. 4. Priority technology areas and sectors Priorities should include cloud and collaboration tools, foundational digital infrastructure, cybersecurity, and digital public infrastructure that directly affect citizens and public services. In emerging areas such as AI, early support for open-source frameworks is essential to avoid future lock-in. In the media and public-interest sector, open-source cloud infrastructure is critical for resilience and competitiveness. The Journalism Cloud Alliance (JCA)a collaboration led by GFMD with investigative journalism partnersdemonstrates how shared, open, and secure cloud solutions can reduce costs, strengthen data protection, and enable innovation for journalism and accountability work. Supporting such initiatives aligns open-source policy with media freedom, democratic resilience, and cybersecurity objectives.

feedback: # Answer on behalf of the Plone Foundation ## Q1 Strengths/weaknesses and barriers The EU opensource ecosystem includes mature platforms used in critical public services. A core weakness is that longterm maintenance is undervalued versus new development (e.g., NGI programs fund innovation, not operational maintenance). Procurement often favors incumbents or marketshare thresholds rather than long lifecycles. Concrete barriers include market share requirements, 3 reference implementations >100k users, and certification costs such as BSI (~50k), which are hard for communitydriven platforms. Concentrated funding reduces diversity (e.g., Germanys Government Site Builder investing 108M into TYPO3 only; many EU public sites clustered on Drupal), marginalizing mature alternatives even when use cases differ. Maintaining a balanced competitive environment where multiple open source ecosystems flourish, avoids replacing single US vendor dependency with single EU platform dependency. ## Q2 Added value and examples Open source enables legal and technical reuse across administrations. In Italy, software reuse is a regulatory principle; reuse at scale depends on opensource solutions that can be adapted locally and shared. Open source supports continuous compliance with accessibility, interoperability, transparency and security, while reducing lockin and preserving control. Plone evidence: the BadenWürttemberg educational platform serves about 1.5M students with 15+ years on Plone, demonstrating reliability, GDPR compliance, and protection of sensitive data (minors under GDPR Article 8). Plones 20+ years of backward compatibility fits 2030 year publicsector lifecycles and datasovereign deployments. Its communitygoverned roadmap avoids vendordictated lockin. Plone is stewarded by an independent foundation with open, democratic decisionmaking, explicitly designed to prevent company control and preserve a level playing field for all contributors. This governance model reduces vendordriven roadmap risk and supports longterm publicsector trust. ## Q3 EUlevel measures EU support should go beyond innovation grants and fund sustainability of mature platforms: - Operational Infrastructure Fund modeled on Germanys Sovereign Tech Fund: 1025M per platform for 510 years to cover security patches, compliance updates and dependency maintenance. - Ecosystem diversity funding for 35 mature CMS platforms per use case (e.g., a mix of TYPO3, Plone, Drupal for government portals; Plone for research document management). - Procurement reform to remove marketshare and referencecount barriers. - Subsidize BSI/ANSSI certifications to level the playing field. - Crossborder scaling partnerships so Member States share development costs and deploy localized solutions. - Favor open, communitygoverned solutions and avoid duallicensing or defacto monopolistic models that recreate dependency. ## Q4 Priority technology areas Public digital platforms (government, education, healthcare) should be prioritized because they require stability, security, accessibility and the ability to evolve over decades. A second priority is compliancefirst AI integration for public services, where transparency and auditability are mandatory and opensource platforms can host accountable features. ## Q5 Highimpact sectors The highest impact sectors are public administration, education and healthcare. Education has high leverage: Plone supports educational platforms (1.5M+ users) with GDPR Article 8 compliance and 15+ years of stability. In government, longlifecycle requirements favor open source and reduce dependency on nonEU vendors. In healthcare, archival and documentmanagement needs align with opensource strengths and strict GDPR compliance. Increased opensource adoption in these sectors strengthens EU digital sovereignty and resilience.
The Open Cloud Coalition (OCC) welcomes the opportunity to respond to this call for feedback. You can find our full submission attached.

For the European Union's effort to build a sovereign digital ecosystem to succeed, the EU's digital strategy has to be based on the principles of open source. Thus, both Instrat and Centrum Cyfrowe share the view that expanding the current Open Source Software Strategy (2020-2023) to cover more areas of the Commission's activities (including those aimed at impacting the whole European economy, not just the operations of the Commission itself) is essential to reduce dependence on nonEU vendors, increase transparency, and strengthen European values such as privacy, collaboration, climate responsibility and competitiveness. Recent political developments reinforce this need. The European Parliament resolution of 22 January 2026 (2025/2007(INI)) defines technological sovereignty as the ability to build capacity, resilience and security by reducing dependencies, preventing reliance on foreign actors and single service providers. It highlights the concentration of power in non-EU companies as a barrier to innovation and democratic control. In line with the Tallinn Declaration (6 October 2017) and the EU's AI strategies, we propose concrete actions that will make open source the default choice for public procurement, research funding and digital services. Please find the detailed suggestions in the attached separate file. The document is submitted in the name of both Instrat and Centrum Cyfrowe.

El ordenador IBM fue la base del florecimiento de los ordenadores personales. Y lo fue porque su arquitectura fue abierta, múltiples fabricantes pudieron clonar el producto y fabricar variantes «compatibles IBM» y se convirtió en un estándar industrial. Lo mismo ocurrió con el kernel Linux, desarrollado por un estudiante europeo, y ahora ubicuo en nuestras vidas digitales, puesto que con él funcionan la mayoría de servidores de internet y teléfonos móviles, además de numerosas infraestructuras digitales públicas y privadas. La arquitectura de computadores RISC-V, las plataformas de computación compatibles con Arduino, los sistemas operativos basados en Linux o BSD, o las aplicaciones de usuario como Firefox, NextCloud, LibreOffice, VideoLAN, KiCAD, Inkscape o Gimp (entre otros) son CRUCIALES para la soberanía digital de la Unión Europea. Habilitan la transparencia de los procesos administrativos y laborales, así como la participación ciudadana y la libre elección de las herramientas, fomentan un mercado variado, competitivo y justo, y por tanto son la base fundamental para evitar los abusos de mercado y los riesgos estructurales de las grandes empresas monopolísticas. Además, en un contexto de crisis ecológica y climática, y del auge de infraestructuras de inteligencia artificial, que consumen recursos naturales como agua y energía y están reavivando la producción irresponsable de electricidad por cualquier medio, proyectos como postmarketOS para móviles obsoletos (comunidad fundamentalmente europea), o aquellos que ayudan a migrar ordenadores portátiles no compatibles con Windows 11 a sistemas Linux o a actualizar teléfonos Android sin más soporte como /e/OS de Murena (Francia), nos demuestran que gran volumen de la «basura electrónica» es responsabilidad directa y gravemente perniciosa de las decisiones inefables de una industria electrónica fuera de control. Podemos y debemos fomentar modelos de diseño de productos electrónicos ecosostenibles, reparables y reutilizables, como aquellos teléfonos de Fairphone (Países Bajos) o los ordenadores de Framework Computer, e iniciativas de reparación descentralizadas como iFixit (licenciadas con CreativeCommons). El software libre es una pieza fundamental en este entramado. Con respecto a la economía digital, los sistemas de pago tienen un rol crítico. Durante la última década hemos visto un auge de plataformas de pago instantáneo privadas de grandes multinacionales tecnológicas (Apple Pay, Google Pay), o integradas por las propias entidades bancarias nacionales (Bizum, en España), sin posibilidad de elección de los usuarios y con una cesión y tratamiento de datos masivos y desproporcionados. Mientras tanto, vemos cómo se cierran sucursales bancarias y se devalúa el dinero en efectivo, marginando a la población rural, aquella que tiene discapacidad, o la de edad avanzada. Por otra parte, las criptomonedas son un activo altamente volátil, no confiable para el uso de la ciudadanía general, y con un gran número de riesgos y efectos negativos. Sin embargo, en el seno del continente europeo nace una alternativa abierta, confiable, que respeta la privacidad, eficiente y compatible con la tasación de impuestos, y que se integra de manera descentralizada con la estructura bancaria existente: GNU Taler. Mientras hablamos del «euro digital» con pocos detalles técnicos, esta alternativa ya está madura y también funciona offline. Solo necesita un impulso institucional (NGI TALER) para instar a los bancos a que lo implanten como alternativa y que la población tenga una elección real y transnacional de micropagos seguros. En resumen, el diseño, la producción y el impulso de infraestructuras abiertas y software libre se alinea con los valores fundacionales de la Unión Europea, los Derechos Humanos y los Objetivos de Desarrollo Sostenible de la ONU, y con los re

Hello, my name is Luca Sighinolfi and I have been a free user of software for about 25 years. 1. Strengths: release itself from multinationals – software that can be adapted and modified by anyone with the skills – reduced demands in terms of hardware – that can be configured in every detail Obstacles to adoption: — some additional notions are needed for the management of the workstations, both by the system operators but also by the users – lack of specific 2D or 3D cad blowing and others. 2. Both public and private sectors benefit from: reduced licensing costs – improved security through appropriate configuration based on open and verifiable standards – possibility to adapt software to own needs – reduced and almost no planned obsolescence effects, also reducing HW 3 costs. Concrete EU measures and actions – create simple document with guidelines for individual states, with concrete choices and case studies – create an EU reference centre for free software – activate collaborations with EU free software development communities – including with regard to cloud, all data should be on EU territory. 4. Technology sectors: All strategic sectors for a nation – transport – energy management and primary resources – military – schools – health and public offices Ma primarily, in public offices, where the use of free software would lead to a significant long-term cost reduction and all those sectors that process citizens’ data. For public offices where e-mails, document management, browsers and little more are needed, free software already offers alternatives that are technically better than proprietary software. In these lines I used open source and free software as synonyms but it is not corre

COSS The Finnish Centre for Open Systems and Solutions (Open Source Finland) welcomes the chance to contribute evidence for the European Open Digital Ecosystem Strategy. COSS is a Finnish non-profit association representing around 50 companies and organisations that rely heavily on open source software, and it works to advance open source adoption and digital sovereignty in Finland and Europe. We see the EU open source ecosystem as strongbuilt on broad adoption, deep expertise, and mature communitiesyet still held back by slow decision-making and procurement and governance practices that favour proprietary models. We also note persistent gaps in productisation and market visibility (such as usability, documentation, packaging, and communication), and a lack of sustainable, well-aligned funding and mechanisms for long-term maintenance and community support. We emphasise that open source strengthens collaboration and reuse, reduces vendor lock-in, improves transparency and auditability, and enhances cybersecurity through independent scrutiny, while enabling more predictable spending focused on needed services. We therefore call for publicly funded software to be open source by default (with narrowly justified, independently verified exceptions), for EU support of shared European development infrastructure and services (e.g., repositories and CI/CD), and for procurement rules and Commission guidance that systematically prevent lock-in and guarantee operational freedom. The text field is too small for the full statement, and the complete statement is available in a separate PDF file.

feedback: En tant quintégrateur Proxmox et BlueMind, et éditeur de la solution libre dasset management OCS Inventory, FactorFX intervient à la fois au cœur des infrastructures (virtualisation, stockage, messagerie) et au niveau de la gestion de parc et de la sécurité des postes, ce qui lui donne un recul concret sur les conditions de succès des écosystèmes open source européens. Notre contribution est en attachement.

I have worked as a security auditor for many years, and I now have the chance to work on open source softwares funded with the EU NGI fund. Every system I have audited rely at different degrees on free and open source softwares (FOSS). We usually don't estimate correctly how much we rely on FOSS. It is understandable because many of them aren't exposed to users. They are hidden, parts of other softwares. Even end-user FOSS, aren't necessary known as being open source. FOSS and proprietary ones aren't perceived the same way. FOSS are often less visible to users, without the same advertising means. Ads for a proprietary competitor can give the impression, that the proprietary software is more common. Close to ads is lobbying, especially in school, universities and professional training. Some proprietary software lobby to train future employees on a single software, to push adoption on the future companies hiring them. Many of these FOSS are developed or heavily contributed in Europe. The EU is a fertile place for FOSS for many reasons, may it be the academic world, public funding, protective laws for user privacy, and a cultural awareness of common goods. The Europe is very productive in digital innovations, especially in FOSS. But too many critical services, for the users, the administrations or companies rely exclusively on a proprietary part, missing the advantage of the whole interoperable and open chain, making these services at risk. It is acceptable to use parts we don't control, if the dependence isn't exclusive. You can use Visa and MasterCard without risks if you have another 3rd option: if the first are inaccessible, you can still pay. FOSS are the more resilient dependencies: they are interoperable and not tight to a single provider. A few current blockers for the open source development I see are: - The technical or legal incapacity to replace the software on hardwares we own: smartphones, connected objects, etc. - Effective platform lock-in of the users due to critical services (public services, banks, etc) being distributed on proprietary platforms only: on Apple and Google stores - Incertitude regarding cyber security and data protection in the EU, due to law requiring to weaken encryption. Many users already avoid EU based solution because of the repetitive trial to weaken cyber security. They don't want their system and data to be at risk with an unpredictable new law. In addition, these laws are incompatible with FOSS: you can't effectively add a backdoor, to an open source project. The source code to build a backdoor-free encrypted communication is available for 35 years, it will always be possible to use this code again. - Public call markets are often inaccessible to FOSS because of the way they are written To help the development of FOSS in the EU: - OEM should be required to offer a simple solution to replace the original software on hardware they sell - Citizen rights of digital privacy should be included in the right of privacy, and the right to use encrypted communications should be explicitly protected by a EU law. - Software exclusivity should be forbidden in formations - Any critical service (public services, bank, etc.) application published on a proprietary platform must have at least a web based solution that offer the same features. The application must also be available from outside Apple and Google stores (eg. from a web server) and work without the platform proprietary services (Play Services). - Publishing code of public funded applications and open the projects to citizen contributions should help their adoption and improve these solutions. The open source ecosystem is very active, usually patches for free, and publishing code usually pushes to produce a better code in a first place. - Offer a free software based digital payment, like a GNU Taler based e-Euro
Digital Sovereignty and the Role of Free / Open Source Software see attached pdf

Nethesis Feedback Towards European open digital ecosystems If the EU truly wants to reduce digital dependence, it must stop treating open source as research and start treating it as critical infrastructure and an adoptable, market-ready product. Today Europe creates open-source value, but it is often scaled and monetised outside the EU, while public administrations and businesses remain locked into proprietary stacks due to procurement practices, inertia and lock-in. The problem is not the lack of open-source software. The problem is that the EU mainly funds the creation of projects, but invests far too little in: continuous maintenance and security (patching, hardening, QA, vulnerability management); productisation (packaging, documentation, reliable updates, migrations, UX); real-world adoption (legacy integration, training, support, SLAs). As a result, open source exists, but it does not become the default choice for public administrations and SMEs. What is needed (concrete EU measures) 1. Incentives for open-source adoption, not only innovation. 2. Vouchers or direct programmes for public administrations and SMEs to migrate to and integrate open-source solutions (with measurable goals: reduced lock-in, portability, resilience, operational continuity). 3. Grants for those who build EU open-source products that are ready to use. 4. Funding for EU companies that build and maintain open-source software aimed at the final product: release management, updates, documentation, roadmap, testing, support. Not one-off features: multi-year maintenance and clear accountability. 5. Procurement open source first where possible, and open source fair always. 6. EU tender templates and guidelines that remove criteria favouring incumbents (e.g., vendor size) and instead assess: interoperability, open standards, SBOM, artifact signing, governance, SLA/support, and exit strategy. 7. Mandatory software supply chain security in critical contexts. 8. SBOM, signing, provenance/attestation and vulnerability management policies must become minimum requirements for solutions adopted in public administration and regulated sectors. Open source without supply-chain security does not scale; with these requirements, it scales better than opaque proprietary stacks. Priorities: Cybersecurity, VoIP and Hybrid Cloud Cybersecurity: firewalls, network security, logging/monitoring and supply-chain tooling are essential for resilience. The EU needs verifiable and governable EU alternatives. VoIP/Unified Communications: communications are essential infrastructure for public services, healthcare and businesses. The EU should support reliable open-source solutions (PBX/UC, SBC, identity integration, compliance) with migration paths and professional support. Hybrid cloud: the foundation where workloads and data run; the EU needs reliable, supported EU/open-source stacks for virtualisation and hybrid-cloud management (orchestration, storage/networking, identity and policy) to avoid infrastructure lock-in and ensure portability between on-prem and cloud. Conclusion If the EU wants technological sovereignty, it must fund what actually changes the market: adoption + productisation + secure maintenance. It is not enough to have open source: it must become the easiest, safest and most convenient option for public administrations, ICT partners and SMEs.

E-Mobility Europe welcomes the European Commissions initiative Towards European Open Digital Ecosystems and supports the development of a coherent EU strategy to strengthen the open-source sector as a key pillar of Europes technological sovereignty, cybersecurity, competitiveness and green transition. E-Mobility Europe represents the full European electric mobility value chain, including vehicle manufacturers, charging infrastructure providers, software developers, energy companies, mobility service providers and research organisations. Across this ecosystem, digital technologies and increasingly open-source software and hardware play a central role. Open source already underpins critical layers of connected, electric and software-defined vehicles, charging infrastructure, energy and battery management systems, data platforms and mobility services. For the European e-mobility ecosystem, open source is therefore a strategic industrial enabler, not a niche choice. The European Union benefits from one of the worlds largest and most active open-source communities, well aligned with EU values such as openness, interoperability, transparency and respect for fundamental rights. In electric mobility and related sectors, collaborative development of non-differentiating software components is increasingly essential to manage complexity, improve interoperability and accelerate innovation. At the same time, important barriers remain. These include insufficient long-term support for maintenance and security, fragmented governance and reference architectures, limited integration of open source into regulatory and certification frameworks, and risk-averse procurement practices. In safety- and security-critical domains such as electric mobility, these challenges are further amplified by long product life cycles and emerging regulatory requirements. Open source delivers clear benefits for both public and private actors by reducing vendor lock-in, improving transparency and cybersecurity, supporting privacy-by-design approaches and enabling cross-border interoperability between vehicles, charging infrastructure, energy systems and digital services. E-Mobility Europe calls for an EU-level approach that focuses on strengthening open-source ecosystems rather than isolated projects. This should include lifecycle-based support, trusted governance structures, closer alignment with regulatory frameworks and better coordination across Member States. Priority should be given to software-intensive and safety-critical technology areas such as software-defined vehicles, battery and energy management, charging interoperability, connectivity, cloud and edge computing, artificial intelligence and cybersecurity. More detailed, question-by-question responses to the consultation are provided in the attached document. E-Mobility Europe stands ready to contribute to the implementation of a European open-source strategy and to collaborate with EU institutions, Member States and the broader open-source community.

feedback: I don't think there are great barriers to open source adoption. Almost all software on the server side is open after all. It is on the client side where Big Tech has a firm grasp on users, and having schools and public institutions adopt free and open source operating systems and office suites will have a huge impact on this in the long run. The added value of open source is monetary of course, but it also teaches users the value of cooperation and gives users agency. It also demystifies technology. Suggestions for concrete EU level measures to strengthen the ecosystem: Mandate that all public funding of software can only go to open code, make it illegal to use Microsoft and Google products. If there is missing functionality in open source software, fund the addition of those features once instead of paying yearly subscriptions to American companies. All public servants, students and researchers should only use free and open source software. Impose taxes on foreign cloud services. Support public institutions self hosting software. Build many public European clouds, not by giving money to european companies, instead hire staff at public institutions to run the software. That is true sovereignty. Have developers and operations close to the users, align the goals of the people running the software with those of the users. Don't make it a matter of making money for European companies to the detriment of the users, instead fund initiative that focuses on the users.

Le Comité Stratégique de Filière « Solutions Numériques de Confiance » salue l'initiative de la Commission européenne, qui acte une prise de conscience majeure : le logiciel libre n'est plus seulement un modèle de développement collaboratif, c'est désormais un pilier central de la souveraineté technologique et de la résilience géopolitique de l'Union. Si l'Europe dispose d'un vivier de talents exceptionnel et de communautés dynamiques, elle peine encore à transformer cette excellence scientifique en une puissance industrielle capable de rivaliser durablement avec les géants systémiques extra-européens. Cependant, le Comité tient à alerter les institutions européennes sur l'urgence de dépasser une certaine naïveté stratégique. L'ouverture du code est une condition nécessaire à la transparence, mais elle est insuffisante seule pour garantir la souveraineté. Comme l'ont démontré les récentes jurisprudences et les tensions géopolitiques, un logiciel Open Source opéré par des acteurs soumis à des lois extraterritoriales, telles que le Cloud Act, ne garantit pas l'immunité numérique de l'Europe. La nouvelle stratégie de l'Union doit donc impérativement coupler la promotion du code ouvert - dans le respect des dynamiques de développement collaboratif international - avec des critères stricts de localisation des données, de gouvernance et d'indépendance juridique. Pour réussir ce changement d'échelle, l'Europe doit opérer un changement de paradigme en réorientant ses financements de la seule R&D vers l'industrialisation et la maintenance. Le CSF plaide pour la mise en place de programmes ambitieux d'« usines logicielles » public-privé et dont l'objectif est de transformer des actifs technologiques prometteurs en produits industriels robustes, sécurisés et maintenables sur le long terme, capables de répondre aux besoins critiques de nos administrations et de nos opérateurs vitaux. Ce sursaut industriel ne pourra se concrétiser sans une mobilisation radicale de la commande publique. L'Union européenne doit avoir l'audace d'instaurer une préférence communautaire assumée pour les marchés numériques stratégiques. L'achat public ne doit plus être le vecteur de notre propre dépendance, mais le levier de notre autonomie, en s'appuyant sur des critères et des catalogues de solutions de confiance et sur une interopérabilité rendue opposable par la régulation, seule méthode efficace pour briser les verrous techniques imposés par les acteurs dominants du marché. Enfin, cette souveraineté restera théorique si nous ne remportons pas la bataille des compétences. L'Europe doit investir massivement dans la formation initiale et continue et intégrer la culture de la souveraineté numérique et la maîtrise industrielle de l'Open Source au cœur de l'enseignement. Le CSF se tient prêt à partager son expérience pour bâtir, avec la Commission, cette Europe numérique libre, compétitive et résiliente.
organization: Comité Stratégique de Filière "Numérique de Confiance"

feedback: VNG sees open-source software as a strategic enabler of digital autonomy, interoperability, and public values for local governments across Europe. Municipalities are committed to reducing vendor-lockins, enabling flexibility and reducing costs by facilitating re-use. This is in part organised via Common Ground. Common Ground is an information management vision and architecture paradigm that transforms municipal information provision from a closed, application-oriented landscape into an open, data-driven, and component based flexible system. From the viewpoint of Dutch municipalities, several EUlevel measures would strengthen the EU opensource ecosystem, reinforce technological sovereignty, and improve cybersecurity across local governments. Municipalities rely on interoperable, secure, and sustainable digital public infrastructure. The EU can play a crucial role in enabling this by: (1) Establishing long term, structural EU funding for open digital infrastructure and ensure municipalities can directly benefit from such funding streams; (2) Supporting crossborder municipal collaboration through shared opensource components and digital commons (for example via EDICs and NGI initiatives); (3) Invest in European led auditing and certification of open source software used in public administration; (4) Create an EUwide procurement and compliance framework that favors open source; (5) Strengthen the European open source skills and community ecosystem; (6) Proactively research the risk AI poses to the open-source sector and act accordingly in order to protect the use of open-source technologies within the public sector; (7) Contribute to researching different governance and management forms such a steward ownership or the beehive model, for the public sector. Please see the attached file with our answers to questions posed by the European Commission in this Call for Evidence.

feedback: Open source software is the basis of my career. As a Linux System Administrator I've seen the early days until now, where most servers in the world run Linux (also most cloud service providers). In the scientific computing world (EESSI) and HPC clusters and everythin gin between runs on Linux and is dependent on open source developments. I see innovation in the open source scene is the main driver for growth in a digital sovereign Europe, which is something we need to aim for, Europe should fund/develop/maintain European projects, not buy American products with questionable support, GDPR compliance et al. If taxes are spend on digital products, I would like to "own" my part; contribution to an open source code are common goods for all, while paying contracts for commercial products does not offer any advantage to the taxpayers, besides serving the initial requirement. Transparency of code is necessary for real security audits.

1. Living labs are already prototypes of open innovation ecosystems since 2006. Enoll has been the key actor in organizing and supporting this community. 2. Until now, living labs has been mainly focused on the "user of digital technologies" perspective more than in the generators of the digital technologies. 3. Now the times are changing. As Draghi report has highlighted and the geopolitical changes recommend we need a generation of open digital living labs focusing not only in the users but also in the actors that produces digital technologies and digital innovations in order to reinforce the digital sovereingty of the EU in a increasing complex and changing world. ENoLL is ready to give full support to this new EU initiative of building the best open digital innovation ecosystem in the world.

feedback:
ELIXIR coordinates sustainable, openly available and widely reused bioinformatics resources demonstrating that Europe can already scale trustworthy open digital technologies across borders. We connect developers and Open Source Software and Workflows (OSSWs) across our members (https://elixir-europe.org/platforms/tools) and coordinate EU-funded projects related to open software (https://elixir-europe.org/about-us/how-funded/eu-projects/steers). These publicly funded research infrastructures should be used more deliberately in the EUs approach to strengthening the open-source sector, competitiveness, technological sovereignty and cybersecurity, because they can turn open-source outputs into dependable, widely adopted services. However, barriers still limit OSSW adoption and sustainability in the EU. First, funding mechanisms tend to prioritise new features and short project cycles, while under-resourcing the work that keeps software and workflows secure and reliable over time (maintenance, testing, documentation, security patching, user support and community contributions). Second, individual contributions to open-source communities are not consistently recognised in evaluation, assessment and reporting, undermining sustained engagement (https://zenodo.org/records/17076988). Europe-wide efforts such as CoARA and work in the context of EOSC can support shift practice across research disciplines. Third, open source is still perceived as unsupported or less secure, with few clear signals for whether tools are well maintained and trustworthy. A healthy ecosystem also needs more European SMEs and industry actors developing open source platforms, supported by public infrastructures and EU projects that sustain the communities collectively maintaining OSSWs. Despite these challenges, open science already delivers value both for public and private sectors across the life-science innovation pipeline. ELIXIRs work with SMEs shows open data enables companies to build and commercialise new services and products, often by reusing and adapting public resources (https://elixir-europe.org/sites/default/files/documents/sme-report-2021.pdf). Similarly, SMEs and other industry players extensively use and contribute to OSSWs helping validate, enrich and sustain them (https://zenodo.org/records/17570133). As ML/AI becomes more ubiquitous in scientific discovery, robust tools and workflows are needed to access high-quality data. To strengthen Europes open-source ecosystem, we recommend EU-level action that makes OSSWs open by default under open-science obligations in the next EU Framework Programme, with exceptions only when clearly justified. The EU should also: (i) fund stewardship and maintenance (and not only initial development) through dedicated topics and evaluation criteria that reward long-term reliability work alongside innovation; (ii) fix incentives so contributions to research software, workflows and other research artefacts are consistently credited in research assessment and project reporting (https://zenodo.org/records/17076988); and (iii) continue supporting initiatives that build trust in open-source quality and security. Increased open-source uptake can most directly improve competitiveness in sectors where complex datasets and pipelines drive innovation (life sciences and health, biotechnology and agriculture), and, more broadly, any data-intensive public or industrial domain where reproducibility, interoperability and long-term sustainability determine both speed and innovation (https://zenodo.org/records/17570133). ELIXIR Nodes maintain registries of open source tools, containers and workflows, making it easier for scientists to access the open source solution they need (https://elixir-europe.org/platforms/tools). Another noteworthy example is the Galaxy community (https://elixir-europe.org/communities/galaxy), which creates reusable assets that accele

The Foundation for Public Code response focuses on a proven organizational modelthe Public Product Organization (PPO)that directly addresses many of the barriers identified by the Commission. PPOs provide a sustainable framework for public organizations and their vendors to collaboratively develop, maintain, and govern shared open-source solutions, transforming the economics of digital public infrastructure. We propose that the Commission consider issuing directives to Member States establishing the Public Product Organization as a new recognized nonprofit organizational forma dedicated legal vehicle purpose-built for the collaborative stewardship of digital public goods. This would provide the structural foundation needed for sustainable, cross-border collaboration on shared digital infrastructure. Based on our experience stewarding codebases for public organizations across Europe, we offer concrete recommendations for EU-level actions that would accelerate the adoption of collaborative open-source development models and strengthen the EU's open-source ecosystem.

Die Bundeskammer der Ziviltechniker:innen Österreichs sieht in der Initiative zu europäischen offenen digitalen Ökosystemen einen zentralen Hebel zur Sicherung der wirtschaftlichen, rechtlichen und technologischen Handlungsfähigkeit Europas. Digitale Infrastrukturen sind längst kritische Grundlagen beruflicher, wirtschaftlicher und öffentlicher Tätigkeit und dürfen nicht ausschließlich durch kurzfristige Geschäftsinteressen einzelner globaler Anbieter:innen geprägt werden. Aus Sicht der Planungs- und Bauwirtschaft ist insbesondere die dauerhafte Datenhoheit von fundamentaler Bedeutung. Die Verantwortung für Bauwerke, Infrastruktur und öffentliche Sicherheit erstreckt sich über Jahrzehnte. Digitale Werkzeuge müssen daher einen zeitlich unbegrenzten, verlässlichen Zugriff auf eigene Projektdaten gewährleisten. Zusätzlich muss auch die Lesbarkeit für die öffentliche Hand sichergestellt werden, eine Digitalisierung der Unterlagen darf nicht zur Folge haben, dass Behörden und damit auch die EU den Zugriff auf Daten des Gebäudebestandes und damit eine wesentliche Grundlage der zukünftigen GWP-Berechnungen der EU verliert. Modelle, bei denen der Zugang zu essenziellen Daten von aktiven Abonnements, Cloud-Verfügbarkeit oder externen Serverstrukturen abhängt, sind mit dieser Verantwortung nicht vereinbar. Die Bundeskammer der Ziviltechniker:innen warnt ausdrücklich vor einer fortschreitenden Ökonomisierung digitaler Abhängigkeiten durch ausschließlich abonnementbasierte Lizenzmodelle. Der Entzug dauerhaft nutzbarer Softwarelizenzen und der Zwang zu laufenden Zahlungsverpflichtungen verlagern unternehmerische Risiken einseitig auf Anwender:innen und gefährden die wirtschaftliche Stabilität insbesondere kleiner und mittlerer Betriebe. Europäische digitale Ökosysteme müssen daher planbare, nachhaltige und nicht-exklusive Nutzungsmodelle sicherstellen. Ebenso kritisch ist die zunehmende Verlagerung zentraler Funktionen in proprietäre Cloud-Infrastrukturen zu bewerten. Ein faktischer Cloud-Zwang für Kernfunktionen entzieht Nutzer:innen die Kontrolle über Verfügbarkeit, Vertraulichkeit und Funktionsfähigkeit ihrer Arbeitsmittel und schafft systemische Abhängigkeiten von außereuropäischen Infrastrukturen. Dies steht im Widerspruch zu den Zielen europäischer digitaler Souveränität. Die Kammer lehnt darüber hinaus Closed-BIM-Strategien und proprietäre Ökosysteme ab, die Interoperabilität einschränken und die Zusammenarbeit in komplexen, arbeitsteiligen Wertschöpfungsketten behindern. Offene Standards sind keine technische Option, sondern eine politische Notwendigkeit zur Sicherung von Wettbewerb, Innovation und fairen Marktbedingungen. Diese Positionen decken sich mit den grundlegenden Prinzipien, die unter anderem von der Free Software Foundation Europe (FSFE) vertreten werden: Herstellerunabhängigkeit, Transparenz durch offenen Quellcode, offene Standards und Kontrolle über Software und Daten. Die Erfahrungen der Planungswirtschaft zeigen jedoch, dass diese Prinzipien nicht nur normativ wünschenswert, sondern praktisch unverzichtbar sind. Europäische offene digitale Ökosysteme sind daher nicht als freiwillige Ergänzung, sondern als strategische Infrastrukturpolitik zu verstehen. Sie müssen verbindlich sicherstellen: dauerhafte Nutzbarkeit und Datenzugang, wirtschaftliche Planungssicherheit, Unabhängigkeit von einzelnen Anbietern und Infrastrukturen, Interoperabilität durch offene Standards, sowie Schutz sensibler Daten innerhalb europäischer Rechtsräume. Nur unter diesen Voraussetzungen können digitale Ökosysteme einen wirksamen Beitrag zur Sicherung der europäischen Planungs-, Bau- und Innovationskultur und zur langfristigen digitalen Souveränität Europas leisten.

feedback: To make an open-source strategy work in public administration, the focus should shift from principles to deployable, interoperable solutions and measurable outcomes. Early implementation should start with a joint assessment with public bodies to define expected benefits (e.g., efficiency, security, reduced lock-in) and track them with a small set of KPIs. Open Stack should be framed as a European one-stop shop - a curated set of trusted, interoperable components (including open protocols, libraries etc.) that can be adopted with minimal local adaptation. This approach requires EU instruments that fund real-world adoption incl. integration, migration, training, and maintenance and not only focused on the development. The main blockers of the open source use are practical: skills gaps, security concerns, procurement habits, and a talent pipeline shaped by proprietary tools. Addressing them requires targeted training, procurement guidance, and a narrative shift - open source should be seen as secure, supported, and sovereignty-enhancing. A key enabler for implementation can be DC-EDIC, acting as a platform for shared capacity-building, portfolio coordination, and cross-border reuse. Action points 1) Piloting: The most effective path is to begin with small, low-risk pilots where there is clear organizational support, scale what works and share best practices to promote the use of OS in the administration. 2) Open Stack as a European one-stop shop Publish a curated Open Stack catalogue with solutions already interoperable and deployable, open to local customization. Include not only software, but also open protocols, libraries etc. and implementation guidance. 3) Align EU funding with adoption and operations Structure EU support to cover deployment costs in the administration, incl. integration, migration, training, maintenance not only R&D. 4) Build skills and open source literacy Deliver role-based training tracks that should include: procurement, IT/security, legal/compliance, leadership etc. Add modules on open-source business models (support, managed services, dual licensing, foundations) to raise awareness. Support the establishment of a network of national-level OSPOs in countries that do not yet have them and facilitate their cooperation. 5) Modernize procurement and assurance Provide simple procurement guidance and baseline security assurance practices. 6) Use of DC-EDIC as an implementation tool coordinate the Open Stack portfolio, run shared training and competence centers, support cross-border reuse, enable common approaches to procurement and maintenance, run an awareness campaign directed towards the understanding of open source
organization: Ministry of Digital Affairs of Poland

feedback: In qualità di operatori del settore IT ed esperti nell'implementazione di soluzioni di virtualizzazione, in base alla nostra esperienza sul campo, segnaliamo l'adozione di piattaforme come Proxmox Virtual Environment (VE) la quale rappresenta una risposta concreta e immediata alla necessità di sovranità tecnologica e riduzione della dipendenza da fornitori dominanti non europei. Suggeriamo lintegrare Proxmox VE nelle strategie di adozione per i seguenti motivi chiave: 1. Eliminazione del Vendor Lock-in: Proxmox si basa su standard aperti (Debian GNU/Linux, KVM, QEMU). Questo garantisce che le infrastrutture critiche europee non siano ostaggio di cambiamenti unilaterali nelle politiche di licenza o nei costi di sottoscrizione da parte di entità extra-UE, assicurando la continuità operativa a costi prevedibili. 2. Trasparenza e Sicurezza: Essendo software open source (licenza AGPLv3), Proxmox permette un audit completo del codice. Per le pubbliche amministrazioni europee, questo è un requisito essenziale per garantire la protezione dei dati e la sicurezza nazionale, eliminando il rischio di "backdoor" o vulnerabilità non documentate. 3. Flessibilità e Interoperabilità: A differenza delle soluzioni proprietarie chiuse, Proxmox integra nativamente tecnologie di storage distribuito (Ceph) e networking (SDN) che permettono di costruire data center moderni e scalabili utilizzando hardware standard. Ciò favorisce la crescita di una catena del valore hardware tutta europea. 4. Sostenibilità dell'Ecosistema Locale: Scegliere Proxmox significa investire in competenze tecniche che rimangono sul territorio europeo. Raccomandazioni per l'azione dell'UE: Incentivare programmi di migrazione: Supportare economicamente le PA e le imprese nel passaggio da hypervisor proprietari a soluzioni open source europee. Certificazioni e Standard: Definire standard di interoperabilità che premino le soluzioni basate su kernel Linux e KVM, facilitando l'ingresso di Proxmox negli appalti pubblici (procurement). Formazione: Finanziare programmi di certificazione tecnica per amministratori di sistema su tecnologie open source per colmare il gap di competenze rispetto ai sistemi legacy. In conclusione, Proxmox non è solo un'alternativa, ma un pilastro per un'infrastruttura cloud europea resiliente, trasparente e autonoma.
feedbackTextUserLanguage:
As IT operators and experts in implementing virtualisation solutions, based on our experience on the ground, we note the adoption of platforms such as Proxmox Virtual Environment (VE), which is a concrete and immediate response to the need for technological sovereignty and a reduction in dependence on dominant non-European suppliers. We suggest Proxmox VE in adoption strategies for the following key reasons: 1. Removal of Vendor Lock-in: Proxmox is based on open standards (Debian GNU/Linux, KVM, QEMU). This ensures that European Critical Infrastructures are not held hostage to unilateral changes in licensing policies or subscription costs by non-EU entities, ensuring business continuity at predictable costs. 2. Transparency and Security: As open source software (licence AGPLv3), Proxmox allows for a full code audit. For European public administrations, this is an essential requirement to ensure data protection and national security, eliminating the risk of ‘backdoors’ or undocumented vulnerabilities. 3. Flexibility and Interoperability: Unlike closed proprietary solutions, Proxmox natively integrates distributed storage (CEPH) and networking (SDN) technologies that make it possible to build modern, scalable data centres using standard hardware. This fosters the growth of an entire European hardware value chain. 4. Sustainability of the local ecosystem: Choosing Proxmox means investing in technical skills that remain on European soil. Recommendations for EU action:
