feedback: Die Initiative der EU-Kommission bietet eine große Change, die digitale Souveränität Europas zu stärken und die Abhängigkeit von außereuropäischen Tech-Konzernen zu verringern. Jedoch ist die Souveränität ohne Inklusion unvollständig. Wenn auf Open Source gesetzt wird, darf niemand durch technische Barrieren exkludiert werden. D. h. die Souveränität darf nicht auf Kosten der Inklusion gehen. Damit dieser Wandel gelingt, müssen die spezifischen Hürden der digitalen Barrierefreiheit (EN 301 549 / ISO 14289-1) aktiv gelöst werden. Die Barrierefreiheit (Accessibility) muss von Beginn an als Kernkomponente verankert werden. Viele Community-Projekte priorisieren technische Features. Barrierefreiheit wird oft als Nischenanforderung behandelt und erst nachträglich oft unzureichend implementiert. In den Entwickler-Communities mangelt es häufig an tiefgehender Kenntnis über assistive Technologien (z. B. Screenreader) und die spezifischen rechtlichen Anforderungen der EU. Die Einbindung externer Bibliotheken (z. B. für komplexe Diagramme oder UI-Frameworks) führt oft dazu, dass Barrieren eingekauft werden, die auf Projektebene kaum behebbar sind. Ein zentrales Hindernis ist der Upstream-Prozess. Werden Barrierefreiheits-Fixes lokal implementiert, diese aber nicht in das Hauptprojekt übernommen, steigen die Wartungskosten bei Updates exponentiell. Durch häufige Pull-Requests in agilen Communities besteht die Gefahr, dass bereits barrierefreie Codeteile durch neue Beiträge unbewusst wieder beschädigt werden. Fehlerbehebungen im Bereich Barrierefreiheit dauern oft Monate, da die (oft ehrenamtlichen) Maintainer durch hohe Arbeitslast und langwierige Abstimmungsprozesse überfordert sind. Im Vergleich zu proprietären Anbietern (z. B. Microsoft) fehlen im OSS-Bereich die API-Stabilität als auch Marktanreize. Häufige Änderungen an Schnittstellen machen die Entwicklung professioneller Barrierefreiheits-Add-Ins (wie für LibreOffice) wirtschaftlich riskant. Für kommerzielle Anbieter von Accessibility-Tools ist der OSS-Markt aufgrund geringerer Marktanteile oft weniger attraktiv, was zu einem Mangel an professionellen Tools führt, insbesondere bei der Dokumentenerstellung. Proprietäre Anbieter (z. B. Microsoft oder Adobe) verfügen über jahrzehntelange Entwicklungsvorsprünge und Milliardenbudgets. Dies hat zur Folge, dass sie hochkomplexe, integrierte Tools geschaffen haben, die weit über die Grundfunktionen hinausgehen. D. h. es gibt mächtige Tools für Automatisierung, komplexe Layout-Strukturen und tiefgreifende Barrierefreiheits-Prüfungen (z.B. integrierte Accessibility Checker), die in dieser Tiefe im OSS-Bereich fehlen. In OSS fehlen oft essenzielle Funktionen für ein effektives und effizientes Arbeiten. Wenn Funktionen entweder gänzlich fehlen oder nur über komplizierte Workarounds erreichbar sind, gefährdet dies die Akzeptanz der digitalen Transformation. Während proprietäre Add-Ins (z. B. für die Erstellung von PDF/UA-konformen Dokumenten) hocheffiziente Workflows ermöglichen, müssen Nutzende in OSS-Umgebungen (wie LibreOffice) oft auf rudimentäre Funktionen zurückgreifen, die den gesetzlichen Anforderungen der EN 301 549 (ergänzend dazu ISO 14289-1) in der Praxis nicht standhalten. Es reicht nicht aus, OSS nur zu wollen. Die EU-Kommission muss erkennen, dass Nutzende, insbesondere die öffentliche Verwaltung und Unternehmen auf leistungsgleiche Tools angewiesen sind, um effizient Aufgaben erfüllen zu können.

feedback: # Answer on behalf of Syslab GmbH (syslab.com) SME Open Source Company ## Q1 Strengths / barriers - EU has many mature opensource platforms; main systemic barrier is procurement design that advantages large vendors and large references. - SMEs face costly certification and reference requirements (e.g., BSI/ANSSI fees, large "3×100k users" thresholds) that exclude community solutions - requirements that do not reflect publicsector needs for long lifecycles and adaptability. ## Q2 Added value - Open source enables legal/technical reuse across administrations, reduces lockin and supports data sovereignty (e.g., Plone used for publicsector CMS deployments across Europe in various EU-Agencies). - For SMEs: reuse lowers entry costs and enables local adaptation and shared maintenance, improving longterm TCO. - Open source enables practical crossborder reuse as public processes increasingly align across Europe. (See EU-OSHA - OiRA project and German Landers Education material sharing as example.) ## Q3 EU measures we support (SME perspective) - Reform procurement to be explicitly nondiscriminatory to SMEs and community projects. - Create targeted multiyear operational funding for mature platforms (security/maintenance), and subsidize certification costs for community projects. - Fund ecosystem diversity (support several mature platforms per use case) rather than singleplatform concentration. - Prevent tender intermediaries from cannibalising SME budgets: cap passthrough fees, require transparent subcontracting terms, and offer direct support/briefing for SMEs on administrative procedures. ## Q4 Priority areas - Prioritise publicsector digital platforms (government, education, healthcare) because of long lifecycles and sovereignty needs. - Support compliancefirst AI tooling as a secondary priority, with clear standards for auditability and explainability. ## Q5 Highimpact sectors - Highest leverage: education, public administration, healthcare where open source increases resilience and reduces vendor dependency. - Critical infrastructure must allow full control over all code and dependencies; reliance on external suppliers can become a critical risk to continuity and security.

Europes digital sovereignty depends on reducing structural dependencies on a small number of non-European proprietary vendors that dominate key infrastructure layers such as virtualization and cloud platforms. Today, many European organizations rely on technologies controlled by large US corporations, where licensing terms, pricing models, product roadmaps, and even strategic direction are decided entirely outside the EU. This creates long-term risks: cost escalation, vendor lock-in, reduced bargaining power, and limited alignment with European regulatory and strategic priorities. Open-source infrastructure platforms provide a realistic and proven alternative. Solutions such as Proxmox VE demonstrate that Europe can operate enterprise-grade virtualization and cloud infrastructure without dependency on proprietary hyperscalers or closed ecosystems like VMware and similar alternatives. Open-source software allows European companies, public administrations, and service providers to retain control over their infrastructure while fostering a competitive internal market. Promoting open-source at the infrastructure layer directly supports EU objectives: Technological sovereignty without sacrificing functionality or performance. Reduced exposure to unilateral commercial or political decisions by non-EU entities. A stronger European ecosystem of SMEs, integrators, and service providers. Long-term cost predictability for public and private organizations. To achieve meaningful digital independence, EU policy should actively prioritize open-source infrastructure solutions in procurement, standardization, and funding programs, and avoid regulatory frameworks that unintentionally reinforce the dominance of large proprietary vendors. A Europe built on open, auditable, and vendor-neutral digital foundations is more resilient, more competitive, and better aligned with its strategic autonomy goals.

Lopen source non è solo un modello di sviluppo software, ma una vera e propria visione: mette al centro la libertà, la condivisione e la responsabilità collettiva. È la dimostrazione concreta che la collaborazione aperta genera qualità, sicurezza e innovazione duratura. Scegliere lopen significa credere in un ecosistema più trasparente, sostenibile e libero, dove il valore cresce quando viene condiviso e non quando viene chiuso.

In qualità di Sicuro Tech Lab, accogliamo con estremo favore l'iniziativa della Commissione. La nostra esperienza quotidiana dimostra che l'adozione di soluzioni open source non è solo una scelta etica, ma una necessità strategica per garantire la resilienza e la sovranità tecnologica delle imprese europee. Sulla base della nostra attività operativa, desideriamo evidenziare i seguenti punti chiave: 1. Superamento del lock-in nei Sistemi Operativi Desktop e Gestionali Sosteniamo attivamente la transizione dal software proprietario a Linux anche in ambito aziendale. Tuttavia, riscontriamo che il principale ostacolo rimane lincompatibilità dei software gestionali (ERP/CRM) prodotti da software house locali. Proposta: Introdurre incentivi mirati per le aziende produttrici di software affinché rendano i loro prodotti compatibili con Linux, eliminando le barriere all'adozione per le PMI che desiderano affrancarsi da ecosistemi chiusi. 2. Sicurezza Infrastrutturale e Normative Utilizziamo e implementiamo soluzioni di sicurezza perimetrale basate su open source, come OPNsense. Riteniamo fondamentale che la Commissione assicuri che le future normative (come il Cyber Resilience Act o simili) non creino oneri sproporzionati che possano ostacolare o penalizzare le soluzioni open source rispetto a quelle proprietarie. L'apertura del codice è, di per sé, una garanzia di trasparenza e sicurezza della catena di approvvigionamento. 3. Virtualizzazione e Alternative ai Monopoli Il mercato della virtualizzazione ha subito scossoni significativi a causa delle politiche di licenza dei grandi player proprietari. In Sicuro Tech Lab promuoviamo con successo l'uso di Proxmox VE come alternativa solida e sovrana a VMware. Supportare lo sviluppo e la certificazione europea di questi hypervisor è essenziale per la gestione autonoma delle infrastrutture critiche. 4. Infrastrutture Web e Cloud-Native La nostra infrastruttura web è interamente basata su Kubernetes. Crediamo che l'UE debba investire massicciamente nella formazione e nella standardizzazione di queste tecnologie cloud-native. Un ecosistema basato su standard aperti garantisce che i dati e le applicazioni delle imprese europee rimangano portabili e non soggetti a ricatti commerciali da parte di attori extra-UE. Conclusioni Lopen source è il motore della competitività futura. Chiediamo che la strategia della Commissione si traduca in azioni concrete per abbattere le barriere all'ingresso e promuovere un mercato dove le soluzioni aperte siano la prima scelta, non l'alternativa.

feedback: GFOSS, a consortium of 37 Greek universities and research centres, welcomes this consultation as essential for European digital sovereignty. Our core argument is that technical capacity alone does not create sustainable open source ecosystems. Greece demonstrates this paradox in that we built sophisticated e-government platforms (gov.gr, Diavgeia, MITOS, opengov.gr) on open source, yet our public and private sectors barely contribute upstream. The difference between consuming countries and contributing countries is institutional architecture, not developer talent. We strongly endorse the EU Sovereign Tech Fund (EU-STF) as the centrepiece of this strategy. Chronic under-investment in critical open source infrastructure creates systemic risk for European governments, businesses, and citizens. Key recommendations: 1. Establish the EU-STF with 350M+ over seven years 2. Procurement reform requiring upstream contribution 3. Technical assistance for OSPOs in all Member States 4. Foundation membership support for European organisations 5. Harmonised 'comply or explain' legal frameworks 6. Mainstream open source in flagship EU programmes (EDICs, EDIHs, GAIA-X, GÉANT) 7. Prioritise open hardware (RISC-V) alongside open software Technology priorities: AI/LLMs with open training data, educational platforms, cloud infrastructure, cybersecurity tools, digital identity, and open processor architectures. France's 20-year institutional investment and Germany's recent initiatives (ZenDiS, Sovereign Tech Fund) prove that deliberate policy frameworks create thriving ecosystems. The Commission should ensure this strategy addresses both immediate funding and long-term institutional capacity building. Full response attached.

I am a daily user of free and open-source software, from LibreOffice and Thunderbird to Nextcloud and Linux distributions. I choose FOSS because it gives me control, privacy, and freedom, values I believe Europe should champion. As a citizen and professional based in Liège, Belgium, I rely on FOSS for work, communication, and data storage. Ive seen firsthand how open tools: - Respect my data: no tracking, no hidden telemetry, just software that works for me, not against me. - Save money: No licensing fees, no vendor lock-in, which are critical for individuals and small organizations. - Enable collaboration: I can share, modify, and improve tools with others easily. - Stay secure: Public code means public scrutiny. But FOSS needs support. Too often, open projects lack funding, maintenance, or visibility. Public institutions still default to proprietary tools, even when open alternatives exist and are better suited to European values. I urge the EU to mandate FOSS by default in public procurement and publicly funded software. EU should fund maintenance and security audits for critical open-source projects and create a European FOSS ecosystem, with training, support, and a unified marketplace for open tools. Investing in FOSS isnt just about technology, its about empowering citizens, protecting sovereignty, and building a digital future thats truly open, fair, and European.

Open source is essential to the success of the European Open Digital Ecosystem Strategy because it strengthens the EUs technological sovereignty, security, and competitiveness. By enabling full transparency and control over digital tools, open source reduces Europes dependence on proprietary technologies and external providers, supporting a more autonomous and resilient digital infrastructure. Open source also enhances security and trust. Since source code can be inspected, improved, and audited by a broad community, vulnerabilities can be identified and addressed more quickly. This collaborative model contributes to safer digital public services and reinforces confidence in EU digital systems. In this context, open source infrastructure technologies such as hypervisors are especially important. Platforms like Proxmox VE, an open source virtualization environment, allow public institutions and European organizations to run critical workloads without relying on closed, vendor-controlled systems. Open source hypervisors provide flexibility, interoperability, and cost efficiency while ensuring that Europe retains full control over the core layers of its digital infrastructure. They also support secure, sovereign cloud and data center initiatives by offering transparent and reusable alternatives to proprietary virtualization stacks. Open source also drives innovation and competitiveness by encouraging collaboration across borders, sectors, and institutions. It allows European companies, researchers, and administrations to build on existing solutions rather than duplicating efforts, accelerating the development of high-quality digital services. A key example is the openDesk project, which demonstrates how open digital workplace solutions can be developed and shared across European administrations. Such initiatives show the practical value of creating reusable open digital assets that support interoperability and reduce fragmentation within the public sector. This approach aligns with the principle of public money, public code: software developed with public funding should be openly available for reuse, improvement, and adaptation. This maximizes the value of taxpayer investment, prevents repeated spending on similar proprietary solutions, and fosters a shared European digital commons. Within the European Commission, a strategic and operational framework for open digital assets will strengthen the reuse and sharing of software and tools, improving efficiency and reducing costs. Building on the achievements of the 20202023 Open Source Software Strategy, this approach will help embed open source as a foundation for sustainable digital transformation across the EU. Ultimately, open source is not only a technical choice but a strategic investment in an open, secure, and competitive European digital future.

This contribution is submitted by a European open source e-learning and knowledge infrastructure provider with long-standing experience in the adoption, governance and sustainability of open source platforms across public administrations, universities, research organisations and defence-related contexts. From an operational perspective, European open source software demonstrates its greatest strategic value when it is treated not merely as a technical solution, but as a shared digital knowledge infrastructure. In practice, open source platforms are increasingly used not only for learning, but also for content and document management, institutional communication, governance, auditability and long-term preservation of organisational knowledge. Experience from large-scale public sector deployments and complex EU-funded projects shows that well-governed open source platforms can significantly reduce dependency on fragmented proprietary tools, improve continuity of knowledge beyond project lifecycles, and strengthen security, interoperability and regulatory compliance. These aspects are particularly relevant in domains such as education, research, public administration and defence, where institutional memory and long-term access to knowledge are critical. Despite these benefits, several structural challenges continue to limit the impact of European open source software. A persistent misconception equates open source with zero cost, leading to underinvestment in maintenance, security and governance. Public procurement frameworks often remain focused on short-term products rather than long-term infrastructures, disadvantaging open source solutions designed to evolve over time. In addition, European open source ecosystems face economic and regulatory asymmetries when competing with large non-European vendors. While policy discussions increasingly address data and cloud sovereignty, knowledge sovereigntythe ability to control, preserve and reuse institutional knowledge over timeremains insufficiently recognised. As a result, valuable knowledge generated within EU-funded projects is often fragmented or lost after project completion due to the absence of shared, sustainable knowledge infrastructures. To address these challenges, the European Union could consider: - supporting structural funding mechanisms for the long-term maintenance, security and evolution of strategic open source infrastructures; - adopting procurement policies that recognise lifecycle costs, governance models, interoperability and community-based development; - promoting guided adoption of open source solutions within public administrations where functionally equivalent; - investing in skills development and professionalisation related to open source software and governance; - strengthening institutional communication around mature European open source ecosystems and their role in digital sovereignty. European open source software is a key enabler of digital sovereignty, institutional resilience and democratic governance. Treating open source platforms as shared European knowledge infrastructuressustained by active communities and professional ecosystemscan reduce dependency on external vendors and contribute to a more sustainable and autonomous digital future for Europe. A more detailed contribution is provided in the attached document.

We are running Proxmox Virtual Environement software to manage our sovereign cloud infrastructure since 2010 (replacing vmware software for the vms && proprietary storage with opensource Ceph ). We also used Proxmox Backup Server to Manage our 1PB storage, replacing proprietary Veeam software. Proxmox company is a 100% european Company (based at Vienna - Austria) Our cloud infrastructure based on ProxmoxVE is in a process to pass the French Secnumcloud certification, the highest French Security certification, hosted on our own sovereign datacenters.

La Estrategia Europea de Ecosistemas Digitales Abiertos debería ir más allá de la contratación pública y la liberación puntual de software de código abierto. Si bien estas prácticas son necesarias, no son suficientes para garantizar la soberanía tecnológica, la seguridad y la competitividad de la Unión Europea a medio y largo plazo. Es fundamental que la UE apoye de forma directa y sostenida a los desarrolladores, comunidades y proyectos de software libre y de código abierto que nacen y se desarrollan en Europa. Esto incluye financiación estable, marcos claros para la sostenibilidad de los proyectos, apoyo a la gobernanza abierta, y el reconocimiento del trabajo de mantenimiento como una actividad crítica de interés público. Sin un ecosistema europeo fuerte de desarrolladores y proyectos abiertos, la reutilización de activos digitales y el uso de software libre por parte de las instituciones europeas seguirá dependiendo, en gran medida, de iniciativas impulsadas fuera de la UE. Apoyar a los proyectos europeos desde su origen es clave para reducir dependencias externas, reforzar la seguridad de la cadena de suministro de software y garantizar que los valores europeos apertura, transparencia y cooperación estén integrados en la infraestructura digital común.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: The European Open Digital Ecosystems Strategy should go beyond public procurement and the timely release of open source software. While these practices are necessary, they are not sufficient to ensure the European Union’s technological sovereignty, security and competitiveness in the medium and long term. It is crucial that the EU provides direct and sustained support to free and open-source software developers, communities and projects that are born and developed in Europe. This includes stable funding, clear frameworks for project sustainability, support for open governance, and recognition of maintenance work as a critical activity in the public interest. Without a strong European ecosystem of open developers and projects, the reuse of digital assets and the use of free software by the European institutions will continue to rely, to a large extent, on initiatives driven outside the EU. Supporting European projects from the outset is key to reducing external dependencies, strengthening the security of the software supply chain and ensuring that European values of openness, transparency and cooperation are embedded in the common digital infrastructure.

feedback: As the Conseil National du Logiciel Libre (CNLL), representing over 300 French SMEs and mid-caps, we affirm that Open Source software is not just a technical choice but the foundation of Europes digital sovereignty and industrial competitiveness. For too long, Europe has allowed its digital infrastructure to be dominated by non-European tech giants, draining value, innovation, and autonomy from our economy. This dependency is no longer sustainable. Our ecosystem excels in critical sectors like Industrial IoT, Edge Computing, and cloud infrastructure, offering a unique advantage: alignment with GDPR, legal immunity from extraterritorial laws such as the U.S. FISA and CLOUD Act, and localized value creation. However, it faces a systemic imbalance in value distribution. European industrial leadersparticularly in telecoms, defense, and aerospaceoften bypass local SMEs, opting instead for proprietary solutions from non-EU vendors or integrating Open Source components without financially supporting their creators. This creates a perverse dynamic where European companies subsidize foreign competitors while starving the local R&D ecosystem that is essential for their own digital sovereignty. Public procurement practices further exacerbate this issue. Risk-averse buyers default to proprietary solutions, ignoring the Total Cost of Ownership (TCO) and the long-term risks ans systemic costs of vendor lock-in. Meanwhile, some regulations like the Cyber Resilience Act, though well-intentioned, create uncertainty that stifles innovation rather than protecting it. Our proposal, backed by 28 concrete measures, calls for three urgent shifts: A Sovereignty Risk Assessment Framework must be implemented for all software used in critical infrastructure. This framework will ensure that technology choices meet strict criteria: legal immunity from foreign jurisdictions, full code auditability, genuine interoperability, and European maintenance capability. Without this, Europe remains vulnerable to external control and backdoors imposed by foreign laws. Public procurement must be reformed. The "Open Source First" principle should become a legal obligation, with public buyers required to justify any proprietary choice. Contracts must be structured to fund software creatorsnot just integratorsensuring that value flows to those who develop and maintain the technology. Publicly funded software must be open source by default, with narrowly defined exceptions. Structural funding for open-source maintenance is essential. We propose a European Sovereign Tech Fund, modeled on Germanys initiative, with a minimum budget of 350 million over seven years. This fund will support the maintenance of critical open-source technologieslibraries, protocols, and infrastructurethat are currently underfunded despite being vital to Europes digital economy. Additionally, we demand an end to "open washing." Interoperability standards must be legally binding, with real data portability rights. Public buyers and decision-makers need training to understand the strategic stakes, and Europe needs a European Open Source Envoy to advocate for our collective interests and cut through lobbying noise. The time for half-measures is over. Europe must act now to enforce sovereign criteria in procurement, fund maintenance, and redirect value to creatorsor accept permanent dependency on foreign powers. Our proposals are ready, realistic, and supported by partners across Europe. The CNLL and its members are prepared to lead, but we need the Commission to match our ambition with action. Digital sovereignty wont wait. Neither will we.

feedback: One barrier to the adoption of open source software that should be addressed in regulation is when access to critical/infrastructure services (such as telecommunication, postal service, energy supply, banking services, health services, public education (schools, universities, ...), public media, government services, ...) requires the access to proprietary software or hardware on the part of the user/customer/student/citizen (as the case may be). It should be enforced that such services be accessible without the need to use any proprietary systems on the part of the user/customer/student/citizen. Apart from removing a barrier to the adoption of open source software, this also helps with fixing what seems to be a blind spot in public procurement: When public institutions buy products or services, they are required to not buy unnecessarily expensive products. However, when they purchase digital products or services for public-facing functionality, that purchasing decision often has an externality in the form of costs to the public that needs to purchase additional products or services in order to make use of the public service implemented based on the procured systems or services, such as a license for a proprietary operating system that is required to run a provided piece of software that is required to be used to access government services, or a license for software that can process or generate data in a proprietary format that is required or provided by a public argency, where the procurement decision effectively locks citizens into a proprietary ecosystem if they want to have full access to government services, effectively making those government services a monopoly of a private vendor. In the worst case, this allows vendors to sort-of circumvent procurement rules, when they manage to sell to the government a solution that requires citizens to buy a product from that same vendor as a monopoly vendor in order to be able to use government services.

Como ciudadano europeo y emprendedor tecnológico español con más de 30 años de experiencia en internet con proyectos como Ferca Networks, Stackscale, Colorvivo, etc, quiero aportar mi perspectiva práctica sobre el código abierto. Dirijo una empresa de infraestructura cloud privada y gestiono más de 100 sitios web de contenidos. Todo nuestro stack es código abierto: Proxmox para virtualización, Docker para contenedores, MariaDB y Redis como bases de datos, OpenLiteSpeed como servidor web, WordPress como CMS, OnlyOffice como suite ofimática, Kopia y Restic para backups cifrados, y Linux como base de todo. Esta elección no es ideológica, es empresarial. El código abierto nos da tres ventajas competitivas reales: independencia tecnológica (no dependemos de decisiones de pricing de ningún proveedor), transparencia (podemos auditar y adaptar cada componente) y ahorro en licencias que reinvertimos en talento local europeo. El caso más ilustrativo es Proxmox frente a VMware. Cuando Broadcom adquirió VMware y multiplicó los precios de licencia, miles de empresas europeas descubrieron que dependían de una decisión corporativa estadounidense para operar su infraestructura crítica. Proxmox, desarrollado en Viena por una empresa austriaca, demostró que Europa ya tenía una alternativa madura, segura y competitiva. Este episodio debería ser un caso de estudio para la Comisión: la soberanía tecnológica no es un concepto abstracto, es la diferencia entre poder operar tu negocio o quedar a merced de un cambio de licencia. WordPress es otro ejemplo clave. Impulsa más del 40% de la web mundial y permite que editores, pymes y creadores europeos publiquen contenidos con total control sobre sus datos, sin cautividad tecnológica. OnlyOffice, por su parte, ofrece una alternativa europea real a Microsoft Office que permite a organizaciones mantener sus documentos en infraestructura propia. Sobre las medidas que propongo: Primero, la contratación pública debe adoptar un enfoque "open source first". Demasiados pliegos siguen especificando marcas comerciales en lugar de requisitos funcionales, lo que excluye de facto a las alternativas abiertas y perpetúa dependencias. Segundo, necesitamos un fondo europeo de sostenibilidad del código abierto. No basta con financiar innovación inicial; hay que mantener los proyectos críticos que sostienen la infraestructura digital europea. Un desarrollador que mantiene una librería usada por miles de empresas merece apoyo estructural, no solo donaciones voluntarias. Tercero, las contribuciones empresariales al código abierto deberían reconocerse fiscalmente como I+D. Esto incentivaría que más empresas europeas contribuyan activamente en lugar de solo consumir. Cuarto, Europa necesita infraestructura propia de desarrollo y repositorios. Actualmente dependemos de plataformas como GitHub (Microsoft) para alojar el código que se supone nos da independencia. Iniciativas como Codeberg merecen apoyo decidido. Quinto, todo proyecto financiado con dinero público debería liberarse obligatoriamente bajo licencias de código abierto. Si lo pagamos todos, debe estar disponible para todos. Esto no solo es una cuestión de transparencia y rendición de cuentas, sino que permite que cualquier ciudadano, empresa o administración pueda reutilizar, mejorar y adaptar esas soluciones. Hoy se duplican esfuerzos porque cada administración desarrolla desde cero soluciones a los mismos problemas. Liberar el código convierte cada inversión pública en un activo colectivo. Los ámbitos prioritarios son claros: virtualización y cloud (donde Proxmox ya lidera), IA abierta (para evitar depender de un puñado de empresas), ciberseguridad (donde la transparencia del código es ventaja intrínseca) y hardware abierto como RISC-V. El código abierto no es solo tecnología, es soberanía real. Cada euro invertido en fortalecer est

feedback: Open source is a naturally global collaboration. Persons in the EU benefit from non-EU contributions and vice versa. This leads to commoditisation of infrastructure which is desirable in principle (cheaper basis to build on + a level playing field) but may result in neglect. As with any global commons, it's often unclear how the burden of maintenance should be split. Much of the work is carried out by volunteers whose personal involvement makes them vulnerable to abuse and burnout. The EU should know its infrastructure, first of all. The use of audit tools (SBOMs etc.) should be encouraged, standardised and eventually mandated at EU institutions and in public and private sectors across member states. The CRA is a good step in this direction as it forces suppliers of open-source-based products to do the same. Second, the EU should help finance the unglamorous parts of running a project (hosting, compliance, documentation, ...). It can do this directly or it can help public and corporate users pool their money and channel it to maintainers. Steady flows rather than one-time grants should be preferred. Third: public money, public code. This is a no-brainer - any development paid for by taxes should result in software available to all (with exceptions in defence and intelligence). This would cut down on duplicate efforts across the Union, direct funds towards existing software as well as spur the creation of new projects. The EU should help member states (and regions) publicise their software development efforts and share their expertise. Fourth, participation in open source by EU citizens should be encouraged and any barriers eliminated. Experimentation, reverse engineering and security research must be free from legal risk (including frivolous copyright and patent litigation). Grants for new projects, features and improvements should be provided. Germany's Sovereign Tech Agency and NLnet are leading the way; this needs to be scaled up considerably. Finally, it would be nice if European companies (especially SMEs and startups) were supported when it comes to building competitive commercial products and services on top of all this infrastructure. Things like the 28th regime and a unified financial market would really help - but that's a discussion beyond the scope of the current initiative.

Dear Members of the European Commission, The Drupal Association welcomes the opportunity to respond to the call for evidence on the European Open Digital Ecosystem Strategy. As stewards of Drupal, one of the world's largest open-source digital experience platforms powering hundreds of thousands of websites globally, we bring 25 years of experience building and sustaining a thriving open-source community. We represent an ecosystem that already powers a significant portion of European public sector, NGO, and enterprise websites. The European digital landscape currently stands at a crossroads. While Europe boasts one of the worlds most active and talented open-source contributor bases, its digital infrastructure remains heavily dependent on proprietary technologies, creating digital sovereignty risks. The European Commission has increasingly recognised that open-source solutions often best serve the European digital landscape. However, there have been gaps in the European procurement strategy that must be closed to make the Open Source strategy fully sustainable and to enable true digital sovereignty. The key issue is that the current procurement process for most open source solutions (whether in Europe or elsewhere around the world) focuses only on the software, and not on the open source capabilities and credentials of the vendors competing for the procurement contract. Unfortunately, all too often, we see contracts given to vendors who can implement open source, but do not contribute back to the sustainability of the open source ecosystems they are exploiting. In some cases, these same organisations are simply subcontracting back to the true contributors in the ecosystem, at a reduced rate that drastically cuts the margins of the true contributors and makes it difficult for them to allocate resources to contribution. Open source is not just software; it is a body of practice that applies to both non-profit and for-profit entities, and their behaviour as open source citizens can be objectively measured and should be built into procurement criteria. In addition to requiring or giving a preferential option for open source software, we would propose that future procurement processes be updated to include: - Consultation with the independent stewards of these open source projects. In many cases, there are respected, independent non-profit organisations that certify vendors who use the software. For instance, the Drupal Association certifies agencies that meet contribution and quality standards under our Drupal Certified Partner program. - Minimum standards for past contribution - Standards requiring that relevant code developed during procurement projects be contributed back upstream. - Requirements for ongoing contribution back to upstream projects - We would also strongly recommend the inclusion of a pass-through provision that requires a portion of the contract value be passed back to any official governing entity for that open source project. For instance, the Drupal Association will only work with agencies or endorse products or services where there is a commitment to return 10% to the project. - Disclosure of any subcontractors that would be employed, and their contribution history. One way these specific mechanisms could be generalised to three principles in the procurement process could be as follows: 1. A Sovereign Score, which would require 20% of the scoring of bidding vendors to be allocated based on their contributions to the open source project. 2. Open Source Maintenance Billing, allocating a portion of the contract hours for the procurement project specifically to reviewing and submitting patches, documentation, and other elements of upstream contribution. 3.30-Day Upstream rule, requiring that the vendors submit their open source code upstream within 30 days of completion. We welcome the opportunity to consult on contribution and sustainab

feedback:
Como ingeniero informático y funcionario público comprometido con el código abierto y el software libre, considero que la iniciativa es bienvenida y más necesaria que nunca. A continuación respondo a las preguntas de la estrategia de consulta. 1. Situación del código abierto en la UE: a mi juicio, está a la vanguardia en número de proyectos, calidad y talento, pero su potencial ha estado limitado por la escasa adopción y falta de coordinación entre instituciones locales, nacionales y comunitarias. Sí, existen políticas aisladas que son positivas, pero se requiere un impulso decidido y coordinado por parte de los organismos públicos para fomentar este ecosistema. Los principales obstáculos que veo son: 1) la resistencia al cambio alimentada por la creencia de que los "walled gardens" de las grandes tecnológicas son inevitables y que cualquier alternativa es inferior. 2) Financiación insuficiente acentuada por la falta de profesionales dedicados a tiempo completo, que dificultan la contribución y sostenibilidad de los proyectos a largo plazo. 2. Valor añadido del código abierto: además de la soberanía digital, se da una reducción considerable de costes en licencias, que favorece mantenimientos a largo plazo y despliegues a gran escala. Los proyectos consolidados cuentan con comunidades activas de voluntarios o disponen de servicios de consultoría que proporcionan soporte de alto nivel y permiten atender mejor las necesidades de usuarios gubernamentales y corporativos tanto a nivel de funcionalidad como de compliance con la legislación actual. 3. Medidas y acciones concretas: propongo tres en particular: 1) Reforzar iniciativas internacionales ya existentes como la Sovereign Tech Agency (Alemania) y el NLnet (Países Bajos) bajo una entidad comunitaria europea. 2) Lanzar campañas de concienciación dirigidas a la ciudadanía, especialmente a niños y adolescentes, para promover el consumo de alternativas responsables, éticas y seguras. 3) Incentivar la contribución del sector público y privado a proyectos de software libre mediante financiación o recursos humanos, ya que muchos componentes críticos de infraestructura y negocio son soluciones desarrolladas voluntariamente y necesitan apoyo. 4. Ámbitos tecnológicos prioritarios: centraría la acción en cuatro áreas, en consonancia con el Digital Markets Act (DMA), que ya evidencia el exceso de poder de los "gatekeepers" y justifica el impulso de alternativas que refuercen esa independencia. Para cada una aporto soluciones creadas en Europa que pueden ser de interés: a) Gestión de la información y comunicaciones. Nextcloud como plataforma colaborativa que permite alojar datos en servidores propios sin depender de nubes de terceros; ProtonMail o Tuta, servicios de correo y calendario centrados en la privacidad. b) Sistemas operativos: migrar a distribuciones basadas en Linux es esencial. Especial atención a la iniciativa "EU OS", que busca crear un marco de referencia común y una prueba de concepto de sistema operativo orientado al sector público. c) Medios de pago digitales: apoyar iniciativas como GNU Taler, sistema de pago electrónico seguro basado en estándares abiertos que garantiza privacidad, auditabilidad, interoperabilidad y ausencia de tarifas de intermediación. d) Redes sociales: plataformas descentralizadas como Mastodon, sin opacidad algorítmica y con mejores mecanismos de moderación; la Comisión Europea ya participa en ella y debería extenderse su uso en más instituciones europeas y nacionales. 5. Impacto en competitividad y ciberresiliencia: reducir la dependencia de EE.UU. y China en sectores críticos como telecomunicaciones y defensa mediante soluciones de proveedores regionales basadas en principios abiertos tiene valor estratégico: refuerza la industria, la seguridad y la autonomía de la UE. Además, el código abierto facilitaría

scope: Ladies and gentlemen, on the subject of open-source software, I support the arguments and positions of Proxmox GmbH, see attached file. With more than 30 years of experience in managing (complex) IT systems, I personally conclude: Transparency, sustainability, sovereignty and security can only be ensured with open source software systems. This should encourage such initiatives and favour open source over proprietary solutions. Yours sincerely, Lünen Dietrich Dietz Dietz DATA GmbH

feedback: Every EU citizen should have the right to use free open source software that perfectly fulfills their basic needs without having to rely on tech companies from other regions of the world. It should have state of the art usability and functionality, which can be achieved by specifically targeted EU funding. Companies should have to pay for this same Software making them also independent. Open source should be the standard for solutions used by EU governments and a strong recommendation for EU companies.

Hello, I am a systems administrator since 2010. I will be succinct: 1 - Strengths: - One of the largest and most active open-source developer communities globally - Strong alignment with privacy, EU values, digital rights principles - Some of the best technical talent is present in the EU - Weaknesses: - Lack of technical support/documentation - Licensing concerns, complexity. I have seen legal teams shut down small business initiatives because they dont understand the "free and open source software" (FOSS from hereon) licensing complexity. - No initiatives or strategy to rally the developers that exist and already contribute their free time - Value generated in the EU by our developers many times gets captured overseas by tech giants. Impossible to fight once this happens. - Established vendors have deep budgets, FOSS developers do not, they can not compete, even though many times they provide a compelling solution 2 - Cost: No licensing fees. You can build the software stack of a small company for a fraction of the cost of proprietary tools. Can be scaled to large enterprise levels with decent support teams, this can offset the huge licensing fees that are paid overseas, instead of them being contributed locally, into our own economy. - Lock-in: You are not locked in save for some edge-cases, many times data and infrastructure can be migrated with low effort and lead times because of the interdependent compatibility. - Security: Code is available, auditable at any time without warning. - Speed: Open models and tools itarate faster because of the openness, everyone can contribute 3 - Tax incentives and grant programs for FOSS maintainers and contributors 4 - Infrastructure. Not AI, Infrastructure is what we rely on amazon, microsoft and so on. You can't have softare distribution without infra.

Als Cloud Infrastructure Engineer einer großen Forschungsinstitution möchte ich zu Ihrer Initiative für europäische offene digitale Ökosysteme Stellung nehmen. Aus meiner täglichen Praxis mit CloudInfrastruktur, Hochleistungsrechnen und sensiblen Forschungsdaten sehe ich Open Source und HackingKultur als zentrale Voraussetzung für technologische Souveränität, Cybersicherheit, aber auch für demokratische Resilienz in Europa. Erstens plädiere ich im Bereich öffentlicher Beschaffung für eine klare Public Money, Public Code-Strategie: Software, die mit öffentlichen Mitteln finanziert oder für öffentliche Aufgaben entwickelt wird, soll grundsätzlich unter einer anerkannten OpenSourceLizenz veröffentlicht werden. Ergänzend dazu sollte eine OpenSourceFirst-Beschaffungsregel gelten. Proprietäre Lösungen bleiben zwar möglich, ihre Auswahl muss jedoch im Einzelfall schriftlich und überprüfbar begründet werden. Dabei sollte Open Source explizit Vorrang vor maximaler Funktionalität erhalten, sofern die funktionalen Mindestanforderungen erfüllt sind. Ziel ist, VendorLockin systematisch zu reduzieren, Interoperabilität sicherzustellen und die in Europa geschaffene Wertschöpfung im OpenSourceÖkosystem zu halten und auszubauen. Zweitens sind robuste Rahmenbedingungen für Responsible Disclosure und WhistleblowerSchutz entscheidend. Sicherheitsforschung, Hacking im Sinne von SecurityResearch und das verantwortliche Melden von Schwachstellen sind ein öffentliches Gut, ohne das weder kritische Infrastrukturen noch demokratische Institutionen auf Dauer sicher betrieben werden können. Deshalb sollten EUweit harmonisierte Regeln geschaffen werden, die klar definieren, wie Sicherheitslücken verantwortungsvoll gemeldet werden können, und die Forscherinnen und Forscher vor strafrechtlicher und zivilrechtlicher Verfolgung schützen, wenn sie sich an diese Prozesse halten. Besonders wichtig erscheinen mir explizite Schutzprogramme für Whistleblower und Sicherheitsforscher, sowohl innerhalb der EU als auch für Menschen aus Drittstaaten, die Missstände, Überwachung oder Sicherheitsrisiken in autoritären oder problematischen Rechtsräumen offenlegen. Diese Programme sollten rechtliche, finanzielle und bei Bedarf aufenthaltsrechtliche Absicherung bieten und Europa zu einem sicheren Hafen für Hacker machen, die im Sinne des öffentlichen Interesses handeln. Drittens sollten offene Standards, Interoperabilität und die gezielte Förderung europäischer OpenSourceInfrastrukturen als strategische Prioritäten verankert werden. Hacking und Open Source gehören zusammen: die Fähigkeit, Systeme zu verstehen, zu auditieren, zu verändern und sicherer zu machen, setzt offene Protokolle, transparente Implementierungen und nachvollziehbaren Code voraus. Dazu gehören die Bevorzugung offener Protokolle und ReferenzImplementierungen in Open Source bei Regulierung und Standardisierung, die Kopplung von Fördermitteln an klar definierte Interoperabilitätsziele sowie ein langfristiger, nicht nur projektbasierter Finanzierungsrahmen für kritische OpenSourceKomponenten (z.B. Kernbibliotheken, Compiler, CloudStacks). Handels und Digitalabkommen sollten keine Klauseln enthalten dürfen, die Interoperabilität oder Reverse Engineering zum Zwecke der Sicherheit, Portabilität und des Wettbewerbs einschränken. Viertens sollte Europa ausdrücklich zum place to be für Hacker und OpenSourceCommunities werden, die freiheitlichdemokratische Werte vertreten. Das umfasst: attraktive Rahmenbedingungen für Sicherheitsforschung, klare rechtliche Leitplanken, die konstruktives Hacking erlauben statt kriminalisieren, Förderprogramme für offene Sicherheits und DatenschutzWerkzeuge sowie migrations und asylrechtliche Instrumente, die Menschen schützen, die Missstände und digitale Menschenrechtsverletzungen in anderen Staaten aufdecken. So kann Europa Talente anziehen,

feedback: 1. A strength of the EU open-source sector is the growing public interest and continuously increasing number of citizens with engineering backgrounds that are contributing to open-source. One of the key weakness is the limited adoption of open-source in the public sectors, partially because of procurement practices and the lack of political requirements that software funded by public money shall be open and verifiable to the public. Maintenance could be improved with more and specifically broader funding that is also applicable to smaller projects which are still critical when they are part of the supply-chain and consumer facing software SBOMs. Furthermore funding project-external contributors could increase resilience and help mitigate maintainer burnout. 2. Open source is a fundamental requirement to avoid indoctrinating future generations into vendor lock-in, particularly in schools, where dependence on a single proprietary vendor limits choice and reinforces the influence of specific lobbies. Freedom of choice promotes innovation, which remains a challenge in many institutions that only allow devices and software from one vendor. Open-source code can be audited, and the resulting software can be independently reproduced bit by bit, allowing verification that it has not been backdoored or tampered with by malicious actors. 3. Concrete EU-level measures should focus on structural rather than ad-hoc or punctual support. Software developed using public money must by default be released to the public as open source under permissive licenses. Public procurement rules should favor open and interoperable solutions to prevent vendor lock-in, especially in education and other critical sectors. Furthermore, there should be dedicated funding streams for the maintenance of small but crucial open-source projects that are part of software supply chains and SBOMs, including increased funding for and broader utilization of security audits. 4. Open source must be integrated as a cornerstone of the EU cybersecurity agenda by promoting and prioritizing auditable code and verifiable builds, and by requiring EU-based infrastructure and hosting to improve independence and resilience from outside the EU. EU-funded reproducible-builds infrastructure would be an excellent priority to verify distributed software in open-source app stores and Linux-based distributions, to oversee downloadable software and detect backdoor attempts by malicious actors throughout the supply chain, allowing swift reaction and minimizing potential fallout. 5. Competitiveness and cyber resilience can be greatly improved in education and public sectors where reliance on single-vendor platforms is very common. Open source promotes freedom of choice and prevents long-term dependence on proprietary products and software located outside the EU. The past years have specifically shown the importance of not taking reliance on partners, businesses, and infrastructure outside the EU as a given. Building platforms and infrastructure inside the EU and using independent open-source software is crucial for cyber resilience.

I strongly support the initiative to reduce dependency from (foreign) big tech companies by enhancing the usage and development of open source software. As a citizen, I see the following advantages of such an initiative: * More transparency of digital tools. Not being a computer scientist, I may not be able to understand the code myself, but if the code is open source and checked by a broad community, I do have more trust. Nowadays, software from the big tech companies tracks its users by default. It is completely intransparent, where such data is being stored and used. Even if there are privacy statements detailing the intended usage, I see a big risk that the huge dataset ends up in the wrong hands. As the software is proprietary I do not have any chance to verify the implemented security measures, or to check if there are any backdoors kept open for, e.g., state actors such as secret service or governments. Even if the involved state actors may be reliable and trustworthy in some cases, any backdoor can be misused by criminals as well, and must therefore be avoided. Looking at political tendencies suppressing democratic activity in several countries, I fear that tracking technology in software will be used to persecute citizens who are simply opposing certain opinions. * Easier availability of software without the need to register. This would greatly improve the current situation, in which, for example, when buying a smartphone I am obliged to register and share a lot of personal details, in order to keep the operating system up to date and to install apps. * In case of public funding, software might also become cheaper. * Better interoperability. Open source software can enhance the development of protocols that connect different tools. This would be a strong improvement compared to the current situation, in which every software vendor provides their own proprietary file formats and communication protocols, making it difficult to communicate and collaborate with others. What needs to be ensured in the strategy to support the independence and safety of European citizens: * New, free, open source tools in Europe should enable connection and exchange with people who are still using the broadly used commercial software. This is to support collaboration with people who are reluctant to switch to new tools, and to support collaboration with residents of countries outside Europe. It also supports the migration of data, thus makes it easier to switch. * There should be no need to register with personal data (or at the maximum very limited data fit for purpose), and no user tracking, both at app level and at operating system level. * Substantial financial support to create incentives for highly professional developers to work on such software projects. * Education: Integrate IT education in general school curricula to educate the developers and users of tomorrow. Education campaigns for both digital natives as well as older people to ensure they understand the relevance of open source software and digital independence. * Obligation for public actors to use open source, financial incentives for private companies.

We are lichess.org, a free and open source chess server and non-profit organization under French law. We started in 2010 as a hobby project and have developed into a professional charity with 100+ active volunteers due to the support of the community, which has provided feedback and contributions since our very start. We release every component we build under open source licenses ((A)GPL, MIT), and we make use of other open source tools, from the programming language Scala itself to the strong free and open source chess engine Stockfish. Our publicly available tools also enable companies like TakeTakeTake to build their businesses around them, and help international organizations like the International Chess Federation (FIDE) and the European Chess Union (ECU) to pursue their goals. To cover our existing costs, including 10 full time equivalent salaries, we almost completely rely on small user donations, many from the EU. In our opinion, having an EU-wide tax-deduction regulation for non-profits would help keep projects like ours sustainable and consequently strengthen the entire ecosystem that such projects foster.
See attached file

I believe that (free and) open-source software is crucial for achieving digital sovereignty of the EU and to fight back against "Big Tech" companies and corporations (and the countries that they reside in) having ever-increasing overreach into our (digital) lives. The whole world, including the EU, has too much reliance on proprietary software (think Windows, Google search, 99% of social media) mostly made and controlled by big US corporations who have abused their power and have shown their untrustworthiness countless times (think Microsoft, Google, Apple, but also Chinese companies like ByteDance). I could give a single specific example here, but that would only scratch the very surface of these deep-rooted issues, which is why I would like to direct towards the excellent ever-growing Consumer Rights Wiki founded by Louis Rossmann (consumerrights.wiki) which documents many of these consumer-abusive actions done by these megacoporations. Free and Open-Source Software is one of the main crucial ways to escape out of the palms of these corporations and as a bonus, due to the code being open-source, FOSS software is generally less prone to being controlled authoritarianly in a way that would be bad for the consumer [but don't be fooled by exceptions such as Google's Chromium and AOSP, which at it's core is open-source, but in the end what most consumers get (Chrome and Android that comes with their phone) are absolutely not. In big part due to Google being in charge, which is why having genuinely pro-consumer project leads is also important.]. FOSS software is always in need of funding, and aid from the EU to put Free and Open-Source software on the frontline of the IT world would be absolutely invaluable.

The Open Source ecosystem is essential for any cloud to function, or any digital society for that matter. For the EU to attain any level or competence and self-realiance the open source digital ecosystem must be maintained and continually developed. Open-source aceosystems also offer the instruments to leverage collaboration between countries, industries and institutions for a common good. Developed together and maintained together for the benefit of all. The results of the open source process are high-quality, offer better cybersecurity than closed source, more transparency, encourage the passing of knowledge between generations, support local public-private ecosystems while disencouraging monopolies. The current digital literacy programs in many countries in Europe favour a curriculum that is heavy on private and opaque software subject to commercial interests that do not align with European autonomy. Generations of people are now educated to be functional only in one specific set of digital skills that are hostile to their own sovereignty. In the Netherlands in particular we have seen a speedy transition during the pandemic to systems that have completely given up on our previous suppliers which used to be companies based in the Netherlands and instead have given that control of our education ICT infrastructure to multinationals. An open-ecosystem with abundant local expertise, that produces more useful systems for more people is desirable to progressively substitute the current picture. Primary obstacles at the moment are: - Access to funding - making the process light on bureacracy - incentivising organizations that mediate fundings processes - facilitating fiscal forms that expedite public-interest work - review processes that encounrage long term goals, sustainability and fairnesss - incentivise a pan-European network of funding organizations that act as mediators, evaluators and comisars of open-source ecosystems for public good - all scales matter, from large projects to small collectives to solo maintainers, open ecosystems a diversity of contributions - Fair participation of private businesses - Incentives for open tech ecosystems across private sectors that aid collaboration and lower costs for innovation - Incentives to participate meaningfully in the open source process. For example by: - facilitating donations and incentives to employ maintainers - supporting community efforts to extend product lifecycles - incentivise open-source deliverables in public tenders - Barriers to fair competition - relaxing intellectual property regulations where they clash with public interests, or the interests of fair competition, or where they favour monopolies or non-EU competitors instead - favour public-interest in the rare cases where innovation and intellectual property might clash - making user-level and supplier-level interoperability a requirement of the Digital Services Act - protect SMEs in the EU from abusive litigation of intellectual property - Over-reliance on work carried out on voluntary basis by individuals or small groups with no legal or fiscal form - fight precarity of the workers that contribute their labour to the public good - incentivise employers to shoulder in - facilitate flexible fiscal forms with transparent accountacy mechanisms that are acessible to individuals and small collectives - Underprioritization of cybersecurity, documentation, accesibility & user experience - Linking access to funding and/or tenders with requirements involving: - high standards of cybersecurity verified by audits - broad coverage of documentation so that products are more useful to more people - establish accessibility requirements, so that products are more useful to more people - high standards for user experience with emphasis in user centeredness, so that products can be more use

Please find enclosed our contribution to the European Open Digital Ecosystems initiative. This position paper aims to present a comprehensive perspective: it examines the drivers behind the rise of American digital dominance, analyses why migration strategies often fall short, and puts forward a concrete proposal for the establishment of a European Digital Commons Foundation.

feedback: This document presents the contribution of the IoT & Embedded Systems Working Group of the Digital Transformation Commission of the Catalan Engineering Association to the European Commissions Call for Evidence on Open-Source Digital Ecosystems. It reflects the collective perspective of professionals and experts working at the intersection of industrial digitalization, embedded systems, and connected infrastructures across Europe. A distinctive strength of the European Union is its long-standing tradition of publicly funded collaborative projects, which bring together companies, universities, research centers, public administrations, and innovation hubs across Member States. Such an approach can also help compensate for the lack of long-term continuity guarantees often associated with proprietary solutions, which may become obsolete, discontinued, or economically unsustainable if vendors change strategy or leave the market. Open, publicly supported ecosystems instead allow communities, companies, and public bodies to maintain, adapt, and evolve critical digital infrastructures over time, ensuring technological autonomy, resilience, and sustained value for European society and industry.
organization: IoT & Embedded Systems Working Group Digital Transformation Commission - Catalan Engineering Association

feedback: Jestem programistą i w czasie wolnym rozwijam oprogramowanie open-source. Dzięki grantowi uzyskanemu w ramach programu Next Generation Internet mój projekt ze szkicu zmienił się w wydajną, wykorzystywaną przez użytkowników aplikację. Jest jednak wiele użytecznych projektów, które nie otrzymały takiej szansy i zostały porzucone przez swoich autorów. Programy takie jak NGI lub EU-STF stanowią szansę dla społeczności Free and Open-Source Software (FOSS) aby dostarczyć narzędzia i usługi na poziomie niejednokrotnie dorównującym technologicznym gigantom. Rozpoczynając taki "cyfrowy renesans" możemy zastąpić wybór między zaledwie kilkoma gigantami różnorodnością, tak ważną dla nas Europejczyków. Jeśli Komisja Europejska wysłucha osób aktywnych w ruchu FOSS, wspólnie możemy znaleźć skuteczne i korzystne rozwiązania. Wśród nas jest wiele osób, które chętnie podejmą się takiej pracy.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: I am a developer and I am developing open-source software in my free time. Thanks to the Next Generation Internet grant, my project has evolved from a sketch to an efficient, user-driven application. However, there are many useful projects that have not been given such an opportunity and have been abandoned by their authors. Programmes such as NGI or the EU-STF represent an opportunity for the Free and Open-Source Software (FOSS) community to provide tools and services at levels that are often equivalent to those of tech giants. By embarking on such a ‘digital renaissance’, we can replace the choice between just a few giants with diversity that is so important to us Europeans. If the European Commission listens to those active in the FOSS movement, we can find effective and beneficial solutions together. There are many people among us who are willing to do so.

feedback: At Zataca Systems, we use Proxmox VE daily in production as the core of our virtualization infrastructure. We run multi-node clusters hosting critical business services, databases, monitoring, and internal platforms across production and testing environments. Proxmox provides us with flexibility, high availability, and full control over our infrastructure, while its open-source model helps us avoid vendor lock-in and align with European digital sovereignty goals. Our Proxmox environment is designed ensuring a stable, secure, and scalable deployment in real-world conditions.

Bardzo istotne jest, aby projekty finansowane ze środków UE nie były rozliczane wyłącznie na podstawie raportów i wskaźników. Takie podejście może prowadzić do sytuacji, w której wytwarzane rozwiązania nie znajdują realnych użytkowników, co skutkuje marnowaniem czasu i pieniędzy. Zamiast tego, projekty powinny być oceniane na podstawie rzeczywistego wpływu na użytkowników, liczby adopcji oraz opinii zwrotnych od osób korzystających z wdrożonych rozwiązań. W obecnym modelu, zbyt duży nacisk kładziony jest na raportowanie postępów projektów, podczas gdy kluczowe jest, aby końcowe produkty rzeczywiście znalazły zastosowanie i przynosiły wartość. Oznacza to, że projekty powinny być projektowane z myślą o konkretnych użytkownikach końcowych, na przykład urzędach, szpitalach czy instytucjach edukacyjnych, i nie ograniczać się do tworzenia innowacyjnych, ale bezużytecznych rozwiązań. W kontekście instytucji edukacyjnych, takich jak uczelnie, kluczowe jest zapewnienie, że projekty finansowane ze środków UE są wykorzystywane jako część ich infrastruktury i nie są wypierane przez inne, komercyjne rozwiązania, na przykład systemy Microsoft. Powinno istnieć powiązanie między produktami wytwarzanymi w ramach projektów a bieżącymi potrzebami uczelni, bez preferowania jednego lub drugiego systemu w wyniku polityki czy presji rynkowej.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: It is essential that EU-funded projects are not accounted for solely on the basis of reports and indicators. This approach can lead to a situation where the solutions produced do not find viable users, resulting in a waste of time and money. Instead, projects should be evaluated based on the actual impact on users, the number of adoptions and feedback from users of the implemented solutions. In the current model, too much emphasis is placed on reporting on the progress of projects, while it is crucial that the final outputs are truly applicable and of value. This means that projects should be designed for specific end-users, such as authorities, hospitals or educational institutions, and not be limited to creating innovative but useless solutions. In the context of educational institutions, such as universities, it is crucial to ensure that EU-funded projects are used as part of their infrastructure and are not crowded out by other commercial solutions, such as Microsoft systems. There should be a link between the products produced by the projects and the current needs of the universities, without favouring one or the other system as a result of policy or market pressure.

feedback:
# The American Hegemony on Mobile Phones In 2025, [Europeans used their mobile](https://gs.statcounter.com/platform-market-share/desktop-mobile-tablet/europe/2025) as much as their computer to access websites and online services.The mobile industry is dominated by two American behemoths: iOS (Apple), and Android (Google). Both iPhones and Android phones' system send information about all their users back to Apple and Google, respectively. Both require an Apple or a Google account to work. This gives Apple and Google, two American companies that have to comply with orders of the American administration, a lot of power over everyone using their phones. **If Europe depends on the US for end-user devices and their systems, it cannot be digitally sovereign.** If Europe builds a sovereign cloud and sovereign services, but Europeans still need to rely on American-made devices to access them, then Europe is not sovereign. Our recommendation: The EU must fund the open source ecosystem, so it can produce an operating system for smartphones that is completely independent of Android's Google and Apple's iOS. A pioneer in this space is the postmarketOS project, building on top of many well established open source components since 2017 to achieve this goal. Those efforts can be complementary with other projects that tackle a similar problem on end-user computers and server, like [EU OS](https://eu-os.eu/). # Open Source Is Not Enough Android is an open-source system for mobile devices. It means that Google releases the source code of Android regularly under [a software license approved by the Open Source Initiative](https://opensource.org/licenses). This means that in theory, everyone can take Android's code, modify it, adapt it, and potentially send those changes back to Google so everyone benefits from the improvements. In reality, [Google develops Android behind closed doors](https://arstechnica.com/gadgets/2025/03/google-makes-android-development-private-will-continue-open-source-releases/) and dumps a "finished" version of Android regularly. But other developers or manufacturers don't have access to the planning and development phase. They cannot contribute back to Google, nor bring changes that would make sense for them. In other words: Android's governance lies entirely within Google, and decisions are taken behind closed doors. In theory, it would possible to reuse Android's code and make a different system that doesn't depend on Google. But Android has become such a complex project that it would take astronomical resources to do so. In practice, manufacturers have to follow what Google decides to do. Our recommendation: When subsidizing the cross-country effort to develop an open-source system that runs on current and future phones, **the EU must also make sure that the governance of the project allows more parties to join the effort and contribute significantly.** # A Race To The Top postmarketOS takes a radically different approach than Google does with Android: postmarketOS is developed in the open, the project has an [open and documented governance](https://docs.postmarketos.org/policies-and-processes/governance.html). It is actively involved in the other open-source projects it relies on, to provide a consistent set of building blocks manufacturers can reuse when developing user-facing products. postmarketOS has a history of innovating to build a mobile phone operating system completely independent of Android, and reduce the differences between devices, by designing future-proof solutions that can be applied to multiple devices at once. postmarketOS is also embedded in an ecosystem of European enterprises, with employees from FairPhone or SHIFT contributing and looking forward to adoption in the long-term. **Our recommendation: The EU must ensure it contributes significantly to postmarketOS to bring it to a point where manufacturers also start inves

BOSSTEK (Business for Open Source Software and Technologies) est une ESN en logiciels libres depuis 2004 qi fourni des prestations pour le développement et lintégration de logiciels libres dans de domaine de linfrastructure et des réseaux. Lobjectif de permettre aux entreprises et aux administrations davoir une parfaite maîtrise et possession de leurs systèmes dinformation est lADN de Bosstek. 1. Les forces du secteur des solutions libres sont les fortes et importantes contributions, les bonnes initiatives non commercialement motivées, les bonnes pratiques, les fortes adoptions dans les administrations (malgré la loi Lemaire peu appliquée dans le cadre de léducation nationale). Les faiblesses sont le manque de crédit et linvisibilité des solutions libres (aucun marketing), la fuite de talents non mis en valeurs au sein de lUE (example dOpennebula, Docker, etc), pas dattractivité pour créer de nouveaux talents, pas de soutien à linnovation ou à laccompagnement par les fournisseurs ; et le plus important : accès difficile aux marchés publiques. Les obstacles sont : laccès aux marchés publiques, abus de pouvoir sur les petits fournisseurs qui se voient débaucher les meilleurs talents en dépit des clauses contractuelles censées protéger nos activités (pertes de 50 % de nos effectifs en 4 ans), par concurrences déloyales (facile de payer mieux quand ça coûte moins cher et quon investit pas dans linnovation). Les contributions durables sont les appels continuels à nos talents et le maintien de nos activités sur les projets innovants, tout en fournissant des prestations toujours plus efficaces qui permettent des économies. 2. Les valeurs ajoutées : échanges dexpériences et de bonnes en brassant les intervenants à travers de différents projets, maîtrise du système dinformation en remplaçant les solutions propriétaires par des solutions libres dont le coût de possession est inférieur aux licences dutilisation de logiciels propriétaires. Exemple de valeurs ajoutées lors des projets denvergure : projet Syracuse (portails 3 en 1) avec le remplacement des serveurs des portails usagers, professionnels et particuliers par une architecture centrale derrière un cluster Varnish et arrêt des services CDN = 200k déconomie par portail ; projet MCE : remplacement/renouvellement de la messagerie Lotus par des solutions libres cyrus/postfix/openldap/zpush/roundcube/php/nginx/linux/docker/kubernetes = généralisation de la messagerie à 100k utilisateurs + accès mobile, etc (projet denvergure, économie déchelle, efficacité et sécurité par le design de larchitecture basée sur des logiciels libres = souveraineté et maîtrise de la sécurité + résilience). 3. Les mesures concrètes qui pourraient aider sont : faciliter les accès aux marchés publiques en facilitant / limitant le nombre et les marges des intermédiaires pour rendre le marché plus équitable (limiter la markup à 10 % entre le fournisseur et le marché) ; protéger les activités des fournisseurs en interdisant le débauchage de ses salariés (ou par fortes compensations/pénalités lui permettant de se renouveler) car ils abusent de leurs positions. 4. Les domaines prioritaires sont : la mise en place dautorités de certification pour le chiffrement SSL au niveau de leurope (secteur aujourdhui dominé par les américains COMODO, Letsencrypt, etc) ; la compatibilité des matériels avec les logiciels libres (pilotes et firmware) car les adaptations sont longues et coûteuses (reverse engineering, développements, adaptation, etc). 5. les matériels pour les postes de travail et les serveurs ne sont pas livrés par les fournisseurs avec des systèmes dexploitation libres. Pour les utiliser, il faut « le faire soit-même » avant de pouvoir les utiliser en entreprise. Cest un coût important (en plus de lachat) avant de pouvoir lutiliser. Le secteur pour le
