feedback:
As a Technology Professional with decades of experienceincluding leading teams embedded in proprietary ecosystemsIve witnessed firsthand how closed platforms create dependency, unpredictability, and long-term risk. Open source software (OSS) is not just a technical choice; it is the foundation of true digital sovereignty for Europe. The EU must move beyond incremental replacements and fundamentally re-imagine how digital infrastructure is built, governed, and sustained. Below are the critical challenges and actionable recommendations to achieve this: Key Challenges in Enterprise Adoption Short-Term Thinking and Lack of Education Leaders default to proprietary solutions due to unfamiliarity with OSSs strategic benefits. Without education, OSS is perceived as risky rather than revolutionary. Scalability and Support Gaps Commercially backed OSS products often lack sustainable funding or disappear under investor pressure, leaving enterprises without reliable alternatives. Proprietary Monopolies Incumbents like Microsoft bundle services (e.g., Office 365 + Teams) into closed ecosystems, making open alternatives difficult to adopt. License and Model Instability Even well-intentioned OSS products shift toward proprietary layers under VC pressure, eroding trust and creating migration risks. Strategic Recommendations for the EU Address Short-Term Thinking and Education Launch EU-funded OSS education programs for C-level executives and procurement officers. Highlight case studies like Munichs LiMux project and Frances open source transition to demonstrate cost savings, security, and innovation. Bridge Scalability and Support Gaps Establish EU-backed "OSS Centers of Excellence" to provide enterprise-grade support, certification, and integration for critical OSS products. Fund Maintainers at Scale Expand initiatives like Germanys Sovereign Tech Fund to ensure stable, long-term funding for OSS project maintenance and development. Drive Demand Through Public Procurement Enforce "public money, public code" with deadlines for EU and national governments. Mandate OSS products in new public digital projects, starting with non-mission-critical systems. Introduce a Digital Sovereignty Label Create a mandatory AF rating system for software sold in the EU, evaluating: Openness (license, governance, community access) Interoperability (standards compliance, data portability) European Control (hosting, ownership, EU alignment) Tie the label to procurement advantages (e.g., prioritizing A-rated software). Break Proprietary Monopolies Use antitrust action to challenge bundling (e.g., Microsoft Teams + Office 365). Require incumbents to open interfaces or unbundle services where competition is stifled. Invest in Cross-European Champions Focus on 23 strategic areas (cloud, messaging, AI) and fund European OSS products like: Nextcloud (collaboration) Matrix/Element (decentralized communication) Sovereign AI models (e.g., Mistral, Aleph Alpha) Attach conditions for : permanent openness, ecosystem reinvestment, and no proprietary lock-in. Prioritize the Public Square Migrate EU official communications to open platforms (e.g., Mastodon) within 12 months. Mandate OSS products for EU-funded public services (education, healthcare). Urgency: Foreign-controlled algorithms influence millions of European minds dailythis is a democratic imperative. Lead by Example EU officials must stop using proprietary platforms (e.g., X/Twitter) for public communications. Launch a "Digital Sovereignty Pledge" for institutions. Why This Matters This is about more than softwareits about preserving European autonomy, economic resilience, and democratic integrity. The EU has a historic opportunity to lead by: Creating demand through procurement and education. Ensuring sustainability by funding maintainers Defending democracy by prioritizing open, decentralized platforms. Setting global standards with a

feedback: submitted by UwU-Space (uwu-space.ch) on behalf of 8 individuals As a group of individuals that are both privately and professionally involved in commercial and open source software projects in Europe, we are directly affected by EU activities and regulation around open source software. As an organization, we are working towards public accessibility of knowledge, where open source software, hardware and science plays a main role. We believe that to support the open source community as well as the European industry, the EU needs to clarify and improve the legal and regulatory framework that we work in, beyond basic financial support of open source projects: 1. (access) Broad, public access to computing hardware, including all hardware features, must be encouraged, legally protected and if necessary enforced by commercial regulation. 2. (compliance) Commercial, governmental and private entities must be able to use open source software without unnecessary regulatory risk and complications. 3. (circumvention) It must be possible for open-source as well as commercial projects to bypass artificial restrictions set by hardware and software vendors. --- The full comment with references is attached as a document.

FEEDBACK: European Open Digital Ecosystems Initiative From: RACKONE S.r.l. - Italy's Proxmox Gold Partner & Authorized Training Partner Q1. STRENGTHS & WEAKNESSES OF EU OPEN-SOURCE SECTOR Strengths: European innovation: Proxmox (Vienna, Austria) proves world-class open-source infrastructure can be EU-developed, with 1.6M+ installations globally Data sovereignty by design: Developed under EU jurisdiction, no exposure to US CLOUD Act. Genuine architectural guarantees, not just contractual promises 70% cost reduction vs proprietary solutions (VMware migrations) No vendor lock-in: run on any hardware, full infrastructure control Transparent, auditable code enables faster security remediation Weaknesses: Perception gap: open-source seen as "less enterprise-ready" despite evidence Training gap: insufficient certified professionals Procurement barriers favor established proprietary vendors Limited access to growth capital for EU open-source companies Q2. ADDED VALUE - CONCRETE EXAMPLES Our implementations demonstrate open-source value: Municipality of Padova: 12-node Proxmox cluster, migrated from legacy systems, full GDPR compliance, under support since 2022 ASST Bergamo Ovest (Healthcare): Multiple clusters replacing VMware, enhanced patient data protection RAI WAY S.p.A. (Broadcasting): Replicated clusters across Milan, Venice, Turin, Florence datacenters Value summary: No license fees | Auditable security | Hardware freedom | Faster innovation | True data sovereignty Q3. RECOMMENDED EU MEASURES 1. Maintenance grants for critical open-source infrastructure 2. Tax credits for companies contributing code 3. Standardized procurement guidelines recognizing open-source (Italy's MEPA model) 4. EU certification programme for open-source security 5. EU-funded training programmes with Authorized Training Partners 6. Prioritize open-source in public procurement 7. Proportionate regulation not discouraging small projects 8. EU Open-Source Infrastructure Fund Q4. PRIORITY TECHNOLOGY AREAS Infrastructure layer first (virtualization, cloud, storage). Proxmox VE demonstrates how open-source can replace proprietary hyperscalers. Controlling infrastructure controls data sovereignty foundation. Additional priorities: cloud middleware, cybersecurity, AI/ML infrastructure, edge computing, RISC-V. Q5. SECTORS FOR INCREASED ADOPTION Public Administration: vendor-neutral virtualization, full data control Healthcare: GDPR-compliant patient data, inter-institutional collaboration Broadcasting/Telecom: sovereign edge-cloud without lock-in Aviation/Critical Infrastructure: auditable systems meeting safety requirements Defense: sovereign stack, rapid vulnerability patching Energy/Utilities: resilient SCADA systems Financial Services: auditable infrastructure for cyber resilience Manufacturing: edge computing with ransomware recovery CONCLUSION The EU can achieve digital sovereignty by promoting European open-source infrastructure. Proxmox (Austria) and partners like RACKONE (Italy) prove enterprise-grade alternatives exist and serve critical EU infrastructure today. --- RACKONE S.r.l. | sales@rackone.it | www.rackone.it

Здравейте! Ще се опитам да дам своя отзив на база 10-годишния ми опит в ИТ и по-специално във виртуализацията на сървъри. Силата на отворения код е в свободата даден продукт да бъде развиван независимо от дадена корпорация и нейните интереси. Веднага пристъпвам към пример - съдбата на продуктите на VMware след вливането на компанията към Broadcom. Те са без спорно невероятен бизнес модел, който изкара пари на акционерите. Но за сметка на това тежко им на клиентите. Цените за лицензите бяха вдигнати многократно за кратък период от време. Малките клиенти бяха изхвърлени по свое желание или късмет, поради по-ниската зависимост. Големите обаче бяха толкова зависими от конкретния доставчик, че имаха избор или да си прекъснат бизнеса, или да плащат колкото им кажат. Това е добре дошло за бизнес модела на фирмата, но означава многократно увеличаване на разходите на клиентите, които рано или късно ще се прехвърлят на крайния потребител. За мен лично, след над 10г. работа с продуктите на VMware, беше удоволствие да се прехвърля на Proxmox, който е построен изцяло върху отворен код. Относно публичния сектор, държавата в която живея е известна с това, че администрацията излива страшно много пари в лицензи за софтуер, за който е много съмнително дали се изплаща. По-скоро се прави поради навика на работниците в сектора, по-голямата част от които са на възраст, на която нямат мотивация да се научат на нещо различно. В случая става дума за продуктите на Майкрософт, които безспорно са много добри, но не и незаменими в голяма част от задачите. Нещото, което би имало значение както за публичния, така и за частния сектор е възможността да се спре наливането на пари за поддръжка на фирми, които са събрали "сертифицирани" от съответния доставчик служители. По мое мнение, областите които се нуждаят от приоритет са на първо място държавните администрации. Както споменах по-горе, в България това иззглежда е най-закостенелият сектор. Мерките, които ЕС може да предприеме биха могли да бъдат стимули при преминаване към продукти с отворен код. Възможно е да са и във вид на регулации, но това по-скоро ще настрои част от засегнатите страни срещу инициативата, тъй като

column30: Economic potential and reinvestment: The elimination of royalties offers considerable financial leeway at national and supranational level. If only 1 % of the funds saved were to be reinvested directly in the OSS project used for this purpose, forecasts show that commercial alternatives could be technologically overhauled after one year. Resource allocation and Public Money, Public Code: In-house proprietary system specialists should be specifically retrained to develop OSS replacements. The principle is as follows: Publicly funded software must be available as open source to all other Member States and citizens. Collaboration rather than fragmentation: Instead of resource-distorting parallel developments, coordinated coordination within repositories should promote the overall public project. Where, for important reasons, the original project cannot be supported directly (financially or by further development) and a spin-off (Fork) is necessary, a supranational, joint development by the interested Member States provides for the development of optimised core software instead of different national project spin-offs in the form of sub-forks. An intra-EU inventory at Member State level showing the OSS projects used by (supra-) national administrations is useful for the joint allocation of resources and arrangements for further development. My conclusion: The consistent reinvestment of 1 % of savings ensures a superior, collaborative further development of the original software and maximises synergies for all, both Member States and individuals.

feedback:
1. strengths: large community animated by a desire for freedom and a multi-century history of tinkering and inventions; relative ease of traveling to meet other people. Weaknesses: sustainability (opensource doesn't put a steak on the table), language barrier compared to other very large countries (though progressively fading away with new generations). Development/maintenance are hampered by many factors: time/family (when done on spare time), job compatibility/salary (when done for a living), difficulty to legally receive funding, documentation (hardware schematics / specs hardly available), platform lock-in (secure boot/signed images, impossibility to modify/fix any relevant piece of software), technical means (e.g. difficulty to host one's own web/e-mail at home due to disappearing static IP addresses, forcing to resort to professional ISPs, rent external hardware and/or use non-EU hosted services), cost of domain names sometimes. Barriers to adoption by businesses are often the perception of absent liability in case of trouble, the lack of a clear project lifecycle with maintenance versions, the reliance on totally uncontrolled and unclear dependencies, often a poor documentation (initially), and often a difficult upgrade path between versions (full code rewrites, language changes, config format changes, completely different UI or interfacing with other tools etc). All of this is not exclusive to opensource but is very common in young projects due to the lack of experience of their authors (who often start them as students and stop 3 years later). 2. added value for EU: getting rid of forced commercial upgrades: maintenance can be continued internally or via contractors (no more lock-in). Ability to tweak to one's needs and contribute improvements back to avoid the cost of internal maintenance. Cost savings at scale (license and even hardware once better tuned). Portability to unplanned platforms (embedded, IoT, etc. see the success of Arduino). Ability to reuse and improve to serve other needs (e.g. Linux being the best example by initially targetting single-user 32-bit PC and powering phones, whole DCs and supercalculators now). 3. concrete measures needed: education: teach *used* programming languages, not just scripting languages nor those of the teacher. Teach software lifecycle at school (including versioning), basic principles of copyright and licenses, principles of dependencies and license contamination, compilation and cross-compilation, difference between development and maintenance, and orders of magnitude (size of a number, a string, how many ops per second on a modern CPU, power usage of a given program). Make it much harder/less affordable to sell products or components missing full schematics and specs, or locked systems (e.g. enforced secure boot and more generally systems that cannot be modified/maintained by anyone but the vendor). Make it easier to advertise one's project (e.g. revive an equivalent of "freshmeat.net"), with community evaluations/notes. 4. and 5. there's a huge danger right now with infrastructure code, that is critical everywhere on all network paths and every device we use, and increasingly overlooked. Few people are attracted by such plumber stuff when visible stuff brings fame quickly. We'll increasingly lack network, system and C developers due to permanent defamation of such skills, as well as people willing to spend a few decades of their lives participating to keeping the internet and public services healthy without any form of fame nor recognition. All those doing this right now have good jobs and found a good balance, but how long will this last ? Possibly that a task force should be created to sponsor such thankless efforts, a bit like the Civil Infrastructure Platform project in the US. Also, connected devices are currently being bought by everyone, placing their security at the mercy of foreign p

feedback: Jesteśmy społecznością inżynierów, programistów i entuzjastów technologii. Chcemy przedstawić perspektywę na temat znaczenia i podejścia do open source. # Dlaczego open source jest ważny: 1. Pozwala uniezależniać się od produktów dużych firm technologicznych. 2. Oferuje rozwiązania, które są transparentne w działaniu. 3. Jest bezpieczniejszy, ponieważ dzięki transparentności błędy są szybko wykrywane i naprawiane. 4. Pozwala edukować jak działa technologia poprzez jawność jej implementacji. 5. Daje możliwość modyfikacji, co sprzyja budowaniu własnych rozwiązań. # Dlaczego open source nie jest sektorem rynku w naszym rozumieniu: Open source nie jest częścią gospodarki w tym samym sensie, co duże korporacje technologiczne. Jest raczej infrastrukturą, która umożliwia funkcjonowanie tych sektorów, podobnie jak drogi umożliwiają ruch i logistykę. # Co możemy zaproponować w kwestii wzmacniania open source: 1. Mądre inwestowanie w open source. Poprzez finansowanie rozwiązań już istniejących, używanych przez instytucje europejskie i firmy, co zwiększy naszą niezależność od dużych monopoli. (m in Mastodon, matrix) 2. Audyt (SBOM). Sprawdzenie, jaka część oprogramowania używanego w instytucjach europejskich pochodzi z USA. 3. Inwestowanie w kompatybilność programów specjalistycznych z otwartymi systemami operacyjnymi lub regulacje wymuszające jej dostosowanie, np. Photoshop, narzędzia dla architektów, muzyków, grafików i programy medyczne. 4. Public Money Public code. Nałożenie wymogu open source na firmy i instytucje rządowe finansowane ze środków publicznych oraz sankcje finansowe i podatkowe dla tych, które się do nich nie stosują. 5. Uczelnie powinny uczyć o technologii, korzystając z narzędzi open source, a nie przygotowywać do roli konsumentów technologii poprzez korzystanie z zamkniętych rozwiązań. 6. Inwestowanie w podstawowe narzędzia do komunikacji i współpracy, takie jak czaty, maile, chmura czy SSO, dbanie o hosting tych usług. 7. Zachęcanie przez obniżenie podatków za wdrażanie open source i europejskich rozwiązań. 8. Zmiany w rozliczeniach europejskich projektów. Odejście od formy konkursowej w projektach unijnych na rzecz dotarcia do odbiorcy tych usług i wdrożenia w placówkach docelowych takich jak szpitale, szkoły czy urzędy. 9. Zapewnienie długofalowego wsparcia dla projektów open source, prowadzącego do ich utrzymania i rozwoju. Podsumowanie: Jako rynek europejski nie powinniśmy zaczynać od innowacji, tylko celować w zaufane, lokalne i użyteczne rozwiązania. Zabezpieczać się przed przejmowaniem europejskich firm przez amerykańskich gigantów.Naszą największą konkurencyjnością jako UE jest tworzenie rozwiązań, które dbają o prawa i prywatność użytkowników.

We are a community of engineers, developers and technology enthusiasts. We want to provide a perspective on the meaning and approach to open source. # Why open source matters: 1. It makes it possible to avoid being dependent on the products of big tech companies. 2. It offers solutions that are transparent in operation. 3. It is safer because, thanks to transparency, errors are quickly detected and corrected. 4. It educates how technology works by making its implementation public. 5. It gives you the opportunity to make changes, which helps you build your own solutions. # Why open source is not a market sector in our understanding: Open source is not part of the economy in the same sense as large tech corporations. Rather, it is the infrastructure that enables the functioning of these sectors, just as roads enable traffic and logistics. # What we can propose to strengthen open source: 1. Investing wisely in open source. By funding existing solutions used by the European institutions and compani

column39: 1. Promotion by the EU of the development/maintenance and use of more open-source software means giving more impact to the ‘Commons’ (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commons) in terms of public ownership and joint management and decentralisation of power. The ‘Commons’ need to be given more tools to counterbalance decades of abuse of power by Big Tech’s near-monopoly companies from which only the (super) rich shareholders benefit. 2. Promotion of open source by the EU provides opportunities for small businesses and for free organisations with a social purpose to attract and pay developers to develop, renew and maintain software (including software based on end-to-end encryption) that is cheaper for users (or even free based on donations), that gives users more choice, that lays the foundation for the functioning of decentralised networks that are not or less vulnerable to sabotage and blackmail by Big Tech companies, that adequately protects users’ privacy and that is more resilient to attacks by cybercriminals.

feedback: Vorrei che l'Unione Europea adottasse modalità e strumenti software Open Source nelle sue strutture amministrative e ne incoraggiasse e favorisse l'adozione negli stati membri anche richiedendo l'utilizzo di formati aperti, non proprietari, nella documentazione. Sarebbe importante per questioni di trasparenza ed indipendenza da soluzioni proprietarie sviluppate magari in stati extra europei, che non offrono garanzie adeguate.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: I would like the European Union to adopt open source software methods and tools in its administrative structures and to encourage and encourage their adoption in the Member States, including by requiring the use of open, non-proprietary formats in documentation. It would be important for issues of transparency and independence from proprietary solutions possibly developed in non-European states, which do not offer adequate safeguards.

feedback: Digital sovereignty is crucial for Europe to maintain control over its digital infrastructure, data, and decision-making tools. MovingLayers supports infrastructure and permitting workflows by building automated, transparent geospatial processes using tools such as QGIS, Apache Airflow, Jupyter Notebooks, Github and many more. In our daily work with infrastructure permitting and route planning, we rely on geospatial data from multiple authorities and formats. Proprietary software can create bottlenecks, prevent long-term access to project data, and lock authorities into single vendors. Open-source GIS tools and custom plugins allow us to harmonize, analyze, and visualize data in ways that remain fully auditable. We build workflows for corridor analysis, visibility studies, and permit submissions that require transparency and reproducibility. On-site data collection through our MoversSurvey app keeps sensitive information local, protecting privacy and compliance. Interoperable, open standards ensure that multiple stakeholdersconsultants, operators, and administrationscan collaborate efficiently. Without open ecosystems, multi-year permitting projects would face higher costs, slower timelines, and legal risk. Our experience shows that digital sovereignty is not abstract: it affects daily decisions, operational efficiency, and regulatory compliance. Strengthening Europes open-source capabilities directly enables resilient, trustworthy, and controllable geospatial and infrastructure workflows.

Software-ul liber asigură niveluri de eficiență a costurilor, independență și securitate pe care software-ul proprietar nu le poate oferi. Cu toate acestea, în prezent nu este utilizat pe scară largă în UE, nu în ultimul rând pentru că nu este bine cunoscut de către părțile interesate, dar și din cauza dependenței de furnizor (vendor lock-in), care împiedică adesea adoptarea sa chiar și atunci când este dorită, precum și a dificultății dezvoltatorilor voluntari de a-și îndeplini toate responsabilitățile. Adoptarea software-ului liber ar aduce beneficii semnificative, în special în ceea ce privește sistemele care gestionează informații sensibile (în special informații corporative), infrastructura critică sau volume mari de date cu caracter personal. Programele structurate de formare a utilizatorilor, obligațiile stricte de adoptare a software-ului liber, finanțarea direcționată și o entitate publică cu un rol de sprijin activ ar fi utile pentru a susține software-ul liber.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: Free software ensures levels of cost efficiency, independence and security that owner-software cannot offer. However, it is currently not widely used in the EU, not least because it is not well known by stakeholders, but also because of vendor lock-in, which often hinders its uptake even when desired, and the difficulty for voluntary developers to fulfil all their responsibilities. The adoption of free software would bring significant benefits, in particular in relation to systems handling sensitive information (especially corporate information), critical infrastructure or large amounts of personal data. Structured user training programmes, strict free software adoption obligations, targeted funding and a public entity with an active support role would be useful to support free software.

feedback:
1. What are the main barriers that hamper (i) adoption and maintenance of high-quality and secure open source; and (ii) sustainable contributions to open-source communities? Barriers to implementation and use: * Network effect. Including teaching in schools. * Often weak support ecosystem, e.g., commercial technical support. * Often missing software features. Barriers to development: * Behind-the-scenes work of commercial giants. * Insufficient entrepreneurial thinking of many programmers. 2. What is the added value of open source for the public and private sectors? * Easy and free transfer of outputs to the wider community. * Lower price (when the network effect is broken). * Easier support for multilingualism, including regional and cultural languages of the EU. * Support for user freedom. * Sovereignty. Including the ability to fork the source if the user disagrees with the developer's changes. 3. What concrete measures and actions may be taken at EU level to support the development and growth of the EU open-source sector and contribute to the EUs technological sovereignty and cybersecurity agenda? * [meta proposal] Assess the situation in a broader context, including those that do not immediately concern free software (e.g., "a rising tide that lifts all boats"). See the 4 quadrants / AQAL in Ken Wilber's Integral theory. * The EC itself will strongly prefer free software for its own use, including social networks (Fediverse). * Include social impact in the calculation for software selection in public procurement (e.g., paid improvements to free software will allow more Europeans to use the software for free, including people with fewer opportunities). * Support / introduce social conditions that provide more free time for volunteer free software developers: unconditional income, 4-day working week, tax breaks for volunteer programmers, etc. * Improve conditions for scaling European companies that develop free software: EU Inc, capital markets union. * Make EU more effective, e.g. create a European army, abolish veto for most decisions. That will release resources for open source and societal development. * Encourage member states to introduce free software into school curricula. * Support a culture of entrepreneurship, risk-taking, and social acceptance of failure (as an inevitable part of innovation). * Introduce an obligation for computer and mobile phone retailers to sell (at least on request) each model without an operating system, in which case the price will be reduced by the market price of the OS. * Exclude fees for non-free software from eligible costs for EU grants. * Strictly adhere to the principle of "Public Money, Public Code." * Create / support an educational platform for courses and similar educational materials on the creation and use of free software in all official EU languages for multiple levels of users. E.g., using Moodle. 4. What technology areas should be prioritised and why? * Areas with existential risk, especially AI (but in a way that reduces the risk!). * Critical infrastructure. To achieve EU sovereignty. * A combination of large cumulative expenditures and a small number of technically highly capable users. Especially the cloud. Because it will quickly free up large amounts of resources. * Large cumulative expenditure. E.g., office software, OS. Because it will free up large amounts of resources, even if it takes longer. * Many users. E.g., office software, OS. Because it will increase the freedom of many users. * Low levels of software, e.g. BIOS, operating system (including mobile). Because the freedom of everything else depends on it. * Software that necessarily requires use by multiple users. E.g. social networks, IM, document exchange. To break the network effect. 5. In what sectors could an increased use of open source lead to increased competitiveness and cyber resilience? * Public administration. * Com

feedback: Il contributo è nel documento allegato. Segue un estratto delle conclusioni. Il software libero assicura livelli di economicità, indipendenza e sicurezza che il software proprietario non può dare. Ciononostante, oggi all'interno dell'UE esso è poco diffuso, soprattutto perché poco noto ai portatori d'interesse, ma anche a causa del vendor lock-in, che spesso ne impedisce l'adozione anche quando essa sarebbe desiderata, e della difficoltà degli sviluppatori volontari a far fronte a tutte le responsabilità gravanti su di essi. L'adozione di software libero porterebbe notevoli vantaggi, soprattutto per quanto riguarda i sistemi che gestiscono informazioni sensibili (e in particolare quelli istituzionali), infrastrutture critiche o grandi quantità di dati personali. Per sostenere il software libero sarebbero utili programmi strutturati di formazione degli utenti, stringenti obblighi di adozione del software libero stesso, finanziamenti mirati e un soggetto pubblico con un ruolo di sostegno attivo.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: The contribution is in the attached document. An extract from the form of order sought is set out below. Free software ensures levels of cost-effectiveness, independence and security that proprietary software cannot provide. However, it is currently not widely used in the EU, not least because it is not widely known by stakeholders, but also because of vendor lock-in, which often prevents its adoption even when desired, and the difficulty for volunteer developers to meet all their responsibilities. The adoption of free software would bring significant benefits, especially as regards systems handling sensitive information (and in particular corporate information), critical infrastructure or large amounts of personal data. Structured user training programmes, strict obligations to adopt free software, targeted funding and a public entity with an active support role would be useful to support free software.

feedback: As the open-source committee chair of the Danish Data Science Community, I would like to make the following points: Trust and mutual contribution are the strengths of open source in the EU. We give back to each other across countries and public institutions. Not many private companies are able to contribute due to competition considerations and misunderstandings about what open source is and its quid pro quo nature. Even public owned companies have problems with releasing open-source due to legal restrictions. For organisations: Legal barriers are the greatest barrier, questions around liability of releasing open source and a missing legal foundation make them bigger. GDPR and the EU AI Act are important but also killing open source in especially AI ML data science due to the lack of released data from the private sector. The EU needs to help member states create a legal foundation for organisation to release open source including datasets for building AI and sharing knowledge. Furthermore, we and you need to share the good examples such as HuggingfaceHub, MistralAI and other companies who are open source first. And higlight companies who release and let there employees contribute to open source as good examples. We have found this is the best way in our community. Another good way is talking about digital soveriegnity, but we need to have a donate first approach and accept whatevers on the internet is up for grabs. Thats the different way we can do it in the EU, trusting each other and giving to each other, meeting in the process and not playing a zero sum game. This will also help center tech and smart minds around europe and our values of freedom and a rulebased society. Initiatives such as OS2 https://www.os2.eu/ and the Coral project https://huggingface.co/CoRal-project who has released great software and gold quality datasets can be used as good examples from the public sector in Denmark. The EU needs to teach how to do it safely, with risk, and a strong legal foundations that can not be used to punish contributors, but protect them. Side note: AI Generated code shows the main vulnerability with open source code. Dependcy injection can be done as a man in the middle attack on liberaries that are not accesible or do not seem to exist. EU can help manage opensource code and data for the use by all europeans if they can accept decentralisation. Some centralisation maybe accepted for increased security. The EU needs to help create a secure supply chair for open source, but it cannot lock down the internet. Organization website: ddsc.io

1. Welche Stärken und Schwächen hat der Open-Source-Sektor der EU? Die Beschaffung erfolgte in der Regel nach Wünschen der Verantwortlichen. Open Source spielte bei vielen eine keine oder eine untergeordnete Rolle. Open Source Alternativen sind oft nicht bekannt. Ich sehe auch Rahmenverträge mit den großen Herstellern und Systemhäusern als Problem an. Die Preise liegen bei mir bekannten Beispielen über dem Marktwert. Sie können sich gerne einmal beim ITDZ in Berlin die Preisliste besorgen und dann mit Marktpreisen, nicht dem Listenpreis vergleichen. Das Problem hier ist, dass hier die Beschaffung sehr bequem ist und so zu teuer i.d.R. bei US Herstellern gekauft wird. Bestandsoftware ist oft so speziell, dass es keine Alternativen gibt. Hier sollte die EU vielleicht einen Interessenpool schaffen, welcher solche Software als Open Source entwickelt oder gute Bestandprodukte aufkauft und als Open Source veröffentlicht und die Weiterentwicklung unterstützt. 2. Worin besteht der Mehrwert quelloffener Lösungen für den öffentlichen und den privaten Sektor? Herstellerunabhängigkeit. z.B. beim Storage sind sind Erweiterungen, Migrationen und Wartungsverlängerungen recht teuer. Wird z.B. Ceph eingesetzt gibt es mit Proxmox einen kompatiblen Hypervisor. Hardware kann im Markt unabhängiger beschafft werden. Es wird komplizierter die Ausschreibung zu einem Hersteller zu lenken. Wir haben bei (öffentlichen) Kunden seit vielen Jahren Ceph im Einsatz. Der Vorteil ist, dass Storage-Migrationen nicht notwendig sind. Die IT der Kunden ist in der Lage das in der Regel zu lernen damit umzugehen. Bei Neubeschaffung kann so ein Storage-System tatsächlich preiswerter sein, da die Speicherung effizienter als bei Ceph erfolgt. RAID vs. Replikation. Beim Hypervisor steht mit KVM (z.B. via Proxmox VE) eine gute Alternative zur Verfügung. Eine Migration ist in der Regel ohne übermäßigen Aufwand möglich. Der Support seitens von Softwareanbietern ist i.d.R. auch gegeben. Der Wechsel amortisiert sich innerhalb kurzer Zeit. Kleine 3 Sockel a 16 Cores Umgebungen z.B. 10.000/Jahr für Broadcom oder ca. 3.500/Jahr für Proxmox VE und das Backup wird in der Regel auch preiswerter. 3. Welche konkreten Maßnahmen und Aktionen können auf EU-Ebene durchgeführt werden, um die Entwicklung und das Wachstum des Open-Source-Sektors der EU zu unterstützen und zur technologischen Souveränität und Cybersicherheitsagenda der EU beizutragen? Die Finanzierung von Open Source Software wird aufgrund der KI in Zukunft schwerer werden. Die EU sollte zentrale via Linux Foundation und Apache Foundation... Infrastruktur Projekte unterstützen. Benötige Fachanwendungen müssen identifiziert und als Open Source entwickelt werden. ggf. gute Produkte als Basis aufkaufen. Blueprints pflegen die den gesamten Lifecycle abdecken. Ggf z.B. ansible-Module bereitstellen die sichere IT-Infrastruktur konfigurieren. Audit-Tools und Anleitungen bereitstellen. LLM mit den blueprints im Hintergrund bereitstellen. 4. Welche Technologiebereiche sollten vorrangig behandelt werden und warum? IT-Infrastruktu(Netzwerk, VMs, Container, Backup, SIEM, Monitoring, Authentifizierung, Storage): Wichtige Basis Web-Frameworks für Anwendungsentwicklung Browser von nicht US-Konzernen Ein guter Mail-/Kalender Client im Stil von Outlook. Mail selbst hosten klappt für kleine sowieso nicht mehr. Server ist daher nicht so wichtig. 5. In welchen Sektoren könnte eine verstärkte Nutzung quelloffener Software zu mehr Wettbewerbsfähigkeit und Cyberresilienz führen? Die Wettbewerbsfähigkeit wird durch sichere IT-Infrastruktur deutlich erhöht. Es ist mit steigender Menge an Ransomware zu rechnen. Daher die entsprechenden Lösungen s.o. bestmöglich finanziell und durch audits unterstützen. Die Abschaffung von Rahmenverträgen mit großen US-Herstellern fördert Beschaffung von Open Source.

Scrivo in quanto interessato a questi argomenti, ho lavorato prima come insegnante ed ora come informatico in un museo, sempre nella pubblica amministrazione (PA). Nel primo caso il servizio email era gestito da google, mi sono sempre chiesto quale fosse veramente il livello di privacy e che fine facessero i dati degli studenti che avevano problemi quando ci scrivevamo tra professori. Dove lavoro ora non siamo da meno, nella mia organizzazione hanno scelto di utilizzare il sistema office 365 di microsoft, dove andranno i dati delle nostre ricerche? É possibile che ogni singolo paese europeo o lEU stessa non abbia le risorse per offrire un servizio e gestire le mail della PA internamente? A proposito di scuola penso sia importantissimo dare lesempio e insegnare con strumenti open, il primo lock-in lo abbiamo nel software che si insegna agli studenti. LUE dovrebbe imporre alle PA luso di licenze (come lAGPL) e standard di comunicazione aperti come lXMPP, non per questo meno sicuri. Penso sia fondamentale avere un motore di ricerca che sia finanziato, gestito e mantenuto in UE, che utilizzi algoritmi indipendenti, europei e che non debba utilizzare dati provenienti da altri motori di ricerca (per es. google o bing) in modo che i risultati non vengano filtrati in base a interessi e che sia espressione dei valori europei. Un altro settore in cui lUE dovrebbe focalizzarsi e promuovere riguarda un sistema operativo per cellulari veramente open source che non dipenda esclusivamente da un fornitore per installare le app e garantirne la sicurezza (apple store o play-store di google). Attualmente uso un cellulare con lineageOS e appstore Fdroid, ma non posso installare lapplicazione IO e CIEID che servono in Italia per la PA in quanto non vengono considerate sicure. Il codice open è generalmente mantenuto e distribuito in piattaforme di versionamento. Le alternative open a github ci sono, ma devono comunque pagare i costi di funzionamento, perché lUE non contribuisce con incentivi? Infine per parlare di open-hardware. bisognerebbe promuovere unindustria che produca lhardware di cui abbiamo bisogno in europa per non arrivare a dover scegliere di comprare gli apparati americani o cinesi (sapendo benissimo che entrambi hanno delle backdoor) ma avere la nostra alternativa europea senza backdoor se veramente open-hardware.
feedbackTextUserLanguage:
I am writing as an interest in these topics, I worked first as a teacher and now as an IT teacher in a museum, also in the public administration (PA). In the first case, the email service was managed by Google, I always wondered what the level of privacy really was and what the purpose was to do with the data of the students who had problems when we wrote between professors. Where do we work now, have they chosen to use the office 365 microsoft system in my organisation, where will the data from our searches go? Is it possible that every single European country or leu itself does not have the resources to offer a service and manage PA emails internally? When it comes to schools, I think it is very important to lead by example and to teach with open tools, the first lock-in is in the software that students are taught. The EU should require public authorities to use licences (such as lAGPL) and open communication standards such as lXMPP, which is not less secure. I think it is crucial to have a search engine that is funded, managed and maintained in the EU, that uses independent, European algorithms and that must not use data from other search engines (e.g. google or bing) so that the results are not filtered by interests and that it is an expression of European values. Another area where the EU should focus on and promote is a truly open-source mobile operating system that does not depend exclusively on a provider to install apps and ensure their security (Go

feedback: 1. Digitale Souveränität durch offene Standards, Wahlfreiheit und Innovation: Auch nach der Open-Source-Software-Strategie 20202023 der EU-Kommission bleiben zentrale Herausforderungen, insbesondere bei der verbindlichen Umsetzung offener Standards, der Schaffung echter Wahlmöglichkeiten und der Förderung europäischer Innovationen. 2. Verbindliche rechtliche Rahmen für offene und interoperable Dateiformate und Schnittstellen: Die Strategie 20202023 hat die Bedeutung offener Standards betont, um Abhängigkeiten von proprietären Lösungen zu reduzieren. Um unsere digitale Souveränität zu verbessern, müssen nun verbindliche Vorgaben für den Einsatz ausschließlich (!) offener und interoperabler Dateiformate und Schnittstellen in allen (!) öffentlichen Prozessen eingeführt werden. Dieses Formular dürfte dann keine .doc, .docx, .xls und .xlsx Dokumente akzeptieren. Öffentliche Institutionen müssen hier als Vorbild agieren und den Einsatz offener Formate aktiv vorantreiben dadurch werden diese Dateiformate und Schnittstellen dann auch in allen anderen öffentlichen und privaten Bereichen verfügbar. 3. Wahlfreiheit für Verwaltungen, Unternehmen und Anwender: Wir benötigen rechtliche und politische Maßnahmen, die Verwaltungen, Unternehmen und Anwendern echte Wahlmöglichkeiten bei Betriebssystemen, Anwendungen, Dateiformaten und Schnittstellen garantieren. Öffentliche Ausschreibungen müssen a) Open-Source-Lösungen und/oder b) Lösungen bevorzugen, welche die festgelegten offenen Standards aktiv unterstützen. Dies erfordert explizit auch die Anpassung von Beschaffungsrichtlinien, die bisher oft proprietäre Lösungen inkl. Vendor-Lock-in begünstigen. 4. Förderung europäischer Open-Source-Ökosysteme: Die EU muss gezielt europäische Open-Source-Projekte und Unternehmen fördern, um Abhängigkeiten von nicht-europäischen und/oder proprietären Technologien zu verringern. Dazu gehören: - Finanzielle Unterstützung für die Entwicklung und Wartung kritischer Open-Source-Infrastrukturen. - Ausbildung und Rekrutierung von Open-Source-Experten, um Know-how in Europa aufzubauen und/oder zu halten. 5. Geopolitische Dringlichkeit und Sicherheit: Angesichts globaler Spannungen ist die digitale Infrastruktur Europas gefährdet. Lösungen auf Basis von offenen Standards bieten eine nachhaltige Grundlage, um Souveränität und Handlungsfähigkeit zu sichern und damit auch Resilienz zu erreichen. Die EU muss: - Kritische Infrastruktur auf Open-Source-Software und/oder offene Schnittstellen sowie Dateiformate umstellen. - Die verwendeten Open Source Komponenten aktiv weiterentwickeln, um Sicherheitsrisiken zu minimieren und den Nutzen stetig zu verbessern. 6. Innovation durch offene Ökosysteme: Offene Standards und Open Source sind Treiber für Innovation. Die EU muss: - Forschung und Entwicklung im Bereich Open Source fördern, insbesondere in strategischen Sektoren wie KI, Cloud, Cybersicherheit und Office-Anwendungen. 7. Bürgerbeteiligung und gesellschaftliche Akzeptanz: Die Strategie muss transparente Prozesse und Bürgerbeteiligung sicherstellen, um das Bewusstsein für und das Vertrauen in digitale Lösungen auf Basis von Open Source und/oder aus Europa zu stärken. Öffentliche Verwaltungen müssen Lösungen auf Basis von offenen Standards aktiv kommunizieren und deren Vorteile hervorheben, z.B. beim Datenschutz, der Kosteneffizienz, der Unabhängigkeit und bei der lokalen Wertschöpfung. 8. Fazit: Die EU hat die Chance, durch konsequente Politik für offene Standards ihre digitale Souveränität, Innovation, Wettbewerbsfähigkeit und Resilienz zu verbessern: Durch rechtliche Rahmen, gezielte Förderung und europaweite Zusammenarbeit. Die digitale Zukunft gehört denen, die sie selbst aktiv mitgestalten. Wir müssen unsere Daten und die damit verbundene Wertschöpfung in Europa halten, wenn wir in Zukunft wettbewerbsfähig sein wollen.

Please, find attached the full text. Below is an excerpt from the full text. A progressive and widespread adoption of open-source products and solutions, or even partially closed-source ones created by European players, within EU public administrations would establish a virtuous cycle for the development of a European digital economy. However, the road is uphill because of technological and organizational lock-ins difficult to break. In the public sector, at least in my country, I observe strong resistance to change when it does not take the form of a legal or regulatory obligation. Top management's failure to recognize the intrinsic value of adopting open source or local solutions creates a powerful disincentive to change and innovation and, conversely, fuels inertia, favoring the maintenance of the status quo and the adoption of solutions already adopted by other administrations as a form of de-accountability. To overcome this inertia, the "strategic approach" underlying this initiative is not enough. A regulatory approach is needed that should include mechanisms to incentivize the adoption and development of in-house technologies, starting with those that can be reused namely, open source technologies acting as a catalyst for bridging the gap that has developed in the digital economy, from basic components to the latest artificial intelligence technologies. Here are some ideas to preserve digital sovereignty, promote transparency in the operating logic of algorithms and, therefore, in data processing, develop a digital industry within the European Union, and consequently restore international competitiveness: 1 - Development of the internal market: when adopting or renewing software solutions, EU public administrations should compare market solutions, considering at least one solution developed in the European Union and justifying any potential adoption of a solution developed or provided by companies whose principal establishment is outside the European Union. 2 - Encourage the adoption of transparent software solutions: when adopting or renewing software solutions, EU public administrations should compare market solutions, considering at least one open-source solution and justifying any potential preference for closed-source solutions or those provided exclusively as cloud services whose source code cannot be inspected. 3- Foster competitiveness and discourage technological lock-in: Public administrations should only use open-source formats. Open formats that can be processed using software from various vendors. 4 - Open formats for public administration documentation: in particular, documents intended to be shared with other EU administrations or with businesses and citizens should be drafted and stored using exclusively Open Document Formats as defined by OASIS Open (Organization for the Advancement of Structured Information Standards). 5 - Adoption of special precautions when using non-EU cloud infrastructures to preserve information confidentiality: the adoption of IaaS or PaaS cloud infrastructures provided by entities whose primary establishment is in a country outside the European Union should only be done using end-to-end encryption (E2EE) whose cryptographic keys are not known to the service provider located in the non-EU country. Cryptographic techniques that, while providing for end-to-end encrypted data processing, implement intermediate cryptographic transformations during the process should not be considered suitable for adequately preserving the confidentiality of Community information. 6 - Impact assessment prior to the adoption of digital assistants based on artificial intelligence engines from companies whose principal establishment is in a non-EU country: when processing critical or otherwise sensitive data, an impact assessment should be carried on the risks arising from the use of IA digital assistants supplied or provided

feedback: Q1 Strengths / barriers I have worked at a university for 25 years in software development and have also contributed to open-source development for the Plone CMS. Based on that experience, I value open-source software very highly. At the university, it allows us to serve students and research with a very large user base and high transaction volumes without licence costs, for example on services built on Plone. Open source allows us to freely try and innovate new solutions based on open technologies without going through costly procurement processes. One barrier is that public opinion among decision makers is still in favor of closed-source, licence-based solutions, usually provided by the largest companies that win procurements. Procurement rules often favor big companies, even if in the end it is just a couple of junior developers who build the solution. The education of decision makers is lacking: they do not understand the value of open source, and open-source communities often lack the funds to properly promote solutions that are sometimes superior to their proprietary peers. Q2 Added value and examples As stated, we can run high-activity services for thousands of users. It would not be possible, at least in our countrys public sector, to do the same with licensed software. Another benefit is the possibility to innovate: we can freely try, combine, and develop new solutions. Third, we can trust the securityif we have access to the code, we can evaluate the quality of any codebase. Fourth, well-organized open-source communities like Plone maintain the codebase: we see active product updates as well as timely security patches when necessary. We do not have to suffer vendor lock-in. Finally, part of the university and public-sector mission is to give backif we contribute code upstream or organize a community event, it benefits everyone. Q3 EU-level measures I would support targeted EU measures that fund sustainability and level the playing field. For example, procurement reform: remove market-share and reference thresholds that disadvantage communities, and provide EU-level education for decision makers about the possibilities of open-source and free software to maintain sovereignty over services and data. Another idea is to provide multiyear maintenance grants for mature open-source platforms. Q4 Priority areas In my experience, the public sector (government, education, healthcare, etc.) would benefit the most from open-source digital platforms. That is where user bases are large, the benefits of local customization are significant, and data security and sovereignty are critical. Compliance-first AI integrations for public services could also be implemented transparently. Q5 High-impact sectors Again, public administration, education, and healthcarewhere long lifecycles, data sovereignty, and accessibility matter most. Open-source initiatives are very important in this time and age. I am happy to see this kind of initiative.

Most of the solutions that the EU and its Member states need already exist, beginning with Linux distributions and LibreOffice. First, essential steps for the EU should be (1) the recognition of open standards such as OpenDocument, (2) the identification of a Linux distribution to use as reference platform, and (3) the requirement that no solution shall rely only on US solutions with no local alternative. It's not only matter of software, but of procedures (e.g., login for e-banking, that today is universally implemented only on smartphones). Look at the examples of Russia and China and their national alternatives to software by US companies. It would be an instructive beginning.

feedback: Open source is critical for our sovereignty, so that we can decide on our own values without undue influence from the outside. It is also a huge driver for our economy here in Europe, since it provides the building blocks for a digital economy. As such any investment into open source will pay off not just with freedom and independence but also from an economic perspective. However this does not mean that open source should be seen through nationalists eyes. Open source has no borders but if Europe is at the forefront we can embed our values into open source software. Therefore it is imperative that the EU support the initiative for an EU sovereign tech fund. Care should be placed on making access to these funds unbureaucratic so that open source developers are not forced to open businesses and divert their time from development to work through red tape.

1.) Most governments in the EU are not invested in the use of open-source technologies, which is a political decision. The use of open-source technologies may require the build up of dedicated expertise to either use or further develop certain technologies. However, open-source communities often are a loose set of people, with a common interest in a certain technology or topic. Not all members may be interested in e.g. developing the technologies for pay. The requirements of a government or corporate customer may therefore not be met on a clear business offering level, but rather on a personal, case-by-case level. 2.) Open-source is public good, which can be used by anyone. This means infrastructure technologies can and should be auditable and transparent. Much of todays global infrastructure is run by a few mega corporations and is highly centralized. Community run Linux distributions provide the means of operating system autonomy to millions of users world-wide. However, usually they have a very low pace, if work on their adjacent technologies is not funded externally. Concretely, in Arch Linux we have recently been lucky to have received STF funding for work on a Rust-based package management framework (https://alpm.archlinux.page/), that allows us to develop a memory-safe and specification driven alternative to the existing ad-hoc technology. Separately, we are receiving external funding for work on a central signing solution (https://signstar.archlinux.page/), offering a generic system that supports several HSM backends for the signing of artifacts. These technologies can be externally audited at any time and allow anyone to use them for their needs (e.g. custom Linux distribution, custom digital signing of artifacts). 3.) The EU should increase the investment in dedicated non-AI expertise and learning facilities, as well as development of existing projects across the board. A program such as NGI Zero is useful. However, in many cases it did not further long-term investment and maintenance of existing technologies, but rather the development of new, often directly abandonded projects. Many projects would require long-term investments to e.g. stabilize existing technologies or develop new features. For this, a EU-level fund, similar to the German Sovereign Tech Fund should be created. On a corporate level, reliance on dedicated contracting companies for the open-source sector (e.g. Igalia) seems to have been beneficial in some areas (e.g. Linux kernel, graphics drivers). Funding, founding and supporting local initiatives such as https://coopcloud.tech/ would help for foundations, companies and individuals to migrate to decentralized solutions. 4.) Decentralized identity providers: To have autonomy from centralized systems, currently in use, which also impede on the core of open source itself (e.g. on programming language release platforms). Authentication technologies: To verify the authenticity of media in the age of large-scale machine generated disinformation media (photos, videos). Decentralized communication platforms: To disengage from highly centralized and vulnerable social media platforms, owned by oligarchs. Development of existing Linux distributions: As hubs of community-driven, auditable, decentralized operating system vendors, independent of centralized, corporation owned technology. 5.) Currently, the entire media sector is corporately owned (i.e. audio, documents, photo, video). Especially knowledge databases (e.g. wikis) and documents in corporations are exposed to vendor lock-in. Investing into decentralized alternatives would allow for more businesses to migrate also on the basis of a plain monetary decision.

This contribution presents the perspective of the EATRIS-CONNECT consortium on the European strategy for Open Digital Ecosystems, drawing on operational experience at the intersection of biomedical research, translational medicine, data, and AI. It strongly supports openness as a foundation for interoperability, auditability, and long-term resilience, particularly in regulated domains such as research and healthcare. At the same time, the document argues that openness alone does not ensure adoption, sustainability, or technological sovereignty. Across multiple EU-funded initiatives, a recurring gap is observed between the availability of open digital solutions and organisations capacity to implement, integrate, and sustain them in real-world settings. This ecosystem translation gap arises when abstract digital capabilities must be converted into concrete workflows, governance models, and compliance-ready data pipelines, and is further shaped by behavioural factors, institutional cultures, and persistent perceptions around open-source quality. The text emphasises that digital transformation is therefore not primarily a tooling problem, but a translation and capacity problem. Successful ecosystems require sustained expert support, continuous training, and proximity to users, rather than one-off technical delivery. It further notes that global digital ecosystems succeed through deep integration, long-term operational support, and ease of adoption, whereas fragmented collections of open components often fail to deliver comparable usability or sustainability. The document calls for a strategic shift in investment from code delivery towards "human infrastructure, including embedded expertise, knowledge transfer, and durable operational support models. It highlights the role of Research Infrastructures as long-term operational anchors capable of maintaining, governing, and evolving open digital tools beyond short project cycles. Finally, the contribution underscores the relevance of alignment with frameworks such as the European Open Science Cloud and concludes that Europes ability to achieve technological sovereignty will depend on its capacity to operationalise open solutions sustainably through people, institutions, and long-term funding models. The full document is attached.

Aluci welcomes the Commission's strategic push to reduce digital dependencies and bolster EU technological sovereignty. However, we contend that sovereignty cannot be achieved through the mere consumption of open source: it requires a fundamental mastery of the underlying engineering. Our contribution argues for a shift from "innovation-led" funding toward "maintenance-led" excellence. We advocate for the elimination of "vibe coding" (unstructured, AI-dependent development) in favor of a verifiable, memory-safe, and human-centric digital commons. By prioritizing technical rigour, AI transparency (via mandatory disclosure), and the public sector as an anchor customer, the EU can build an ecosystem that is not only independent but technically superior. For a comprehensive breakdown of our technical justifications and strategic recommendations, please refer to the detailed position paper attached below.

Als systeem-/netwerkbeheerder op een middelbare school hadden wij het mooi voor elkaar. Proxmox VM omgeving, PFsense firewall, PacketFance voor netwerk toegang, open source spamfilter, Zabbix monitoring omgeving en ga zo maar door. Allemaal mooie open source oplossingen. Toen kregen we een nieuwe manager en moest ineens alles naar Office365/Azure. Weg soevereiniteit en vast aan het Amerikaanse big tech infuus. Onze kinderen worden met handen en voeten gebonden aan deze tech-reuzen. Voor mij was bovenstaande een reden om verder te gaan kijken naar een werkplek die wel soeverein wil zijn. Nu driegt hetzelfde. Enterprise architecten die zich vasthouden aan beleid van jaren geleden, terwijl de wereld veranderd is. Toevalligerwijs zijn deze architecten afkomstig van een Amerikaans big tech bedrijf en geven zo een "gekleurd" advies. Ik vind het jammer dat er door onze overheden niet meer gepusht wordt naar het gebruik van Open Source en Open Standaarden door publieke organisaties, die (deels) bekostigd worden door deze overheden. Zodat ook managers en architecten zich niet kunnen verschuilen achter, vaak, onzinnige argumenten. Moties als pas-toe-of-leg-uit werken niet. Wij hebben laten zien dat het wel kan. Heb er zelfs tijdens het T-Dose evenement een keer een presentatie over gegeven. Kortom meer druk vanuit EU of landelijke overheden is zeer welkom
feedbackTextUserLanguage: As a system/network manager in a secondary school, we were beautiful for each other. Proxmox VM environment, PFsense firewall, PacketFance for network access, open source spam filter, Zabbix monitoring environment and continue. All beautiful open source solutions. Then we got a new manager and suddenly all had to go to Office365/Azure. Move away from sovereignty to the American big tech infusion. Our children are tied to these tech giants with their hands and feet. For me, the above was a reason to look further at a workplace that does want to be sovereign. Now the same is tripling. Enterprise architects who stick to policies of years ago, while the world has changed. By chance, these architects come from an American big tech company, giving a ‘coloured’ advice. I regret that there is no longer any reference by our authorities to the use of Open Source and Open Standards by public organisations, which are (partly) funded by these authorities. So managers and architects too cannot hide behind, often nonsensical arguments. Motions such as ‘comply or explain’ do not apply. We have shown that it can. Even during the T-Dose event, you made one presentation. In short, more pressure from EU or national authorities is very welcome

feedback: OPEN SOURCE IS THE ENGINE, BUT OPEN DATA IS THE FUEL: WHY EUROPE MUST FUND DIGITAL COMMONS As a European citizen (and the co-founder of Open Food Facts), I welcome this consultation on Digital Economy. I note a worrying gap: while "Open Source" is mentioned 48 times (and that's good), "Open Data" is absent. Focusing solely on code is like building a high-speed train network (the software) without laying down the tracks (the data). 1. DATA IS INFRASTRUCTURE, NOT JUST CONTENT We treat physical roads, tracks and bridges as public infrastructure funded by taxes because they enable commerce and movement. In the digital age, datasets like OpenStreetMap (transport), Open Food Facts (health and consumption) or Wikidata (structured knowledge) are the roads upon which the digital economy travels. Currently, for the Digital Commons, we maintain these critical European highways through citizen donations and sporadic project grants that are thinning. This is unsustainable. THE "MAINTENANCE PARADOX" It is somewhat easy to find EU/national funding to build a "new feature" on topics aligned with our broad mission. It is nearly impossible to find structural funding to pay for the servers, essential people, security, and database integrity required to keep a service running for 10 million users. Without structural "core funding" for maintenance, our digital commons are at risk of collapse or progressive capture by private interests. SOVEREIGNTY IN THE AGE OF AI If Europe wants Digital Sovereignty, we cannot rely on "Black Box" data faucets that can be turned off at any moment. We need open data to train EU models. Currently, global AI models and LLMs are absorbing European open data/code to build their intelligence, but without contributing back to the infrastructure costs or contributing on data gardening. **They are harvesting the crop without watering the soil.** If we do not fund the maintenance of the source data, the "intelligence" of these models might degrade over time, and Europe (and the rest of the world) might well lose its cultural and factual grounding in the AI era (or private data might just exist for the happy few owners of those models). Pathways to the digital commons need to be built in those new ways (Chatbots) to access information, or we risk a progressive destruction of the vital contributive energy which made them possible, jeopardizing the intelligence and progress they enable. BEYOND TECH: EDUCATION AND CIRCULAR ECONOMY Open digital commons are not just for developers. They empower citizens to take action. THEY ENABLE SCIENTISTS, CONSUMER ORGANIZATIONS AND CITIZENS TO DEMAND CHANGE, and HELP POLICY MAKERS RESPOND TO THIS (See https://world.openfoodfacts.org/open-food-facts-and-the-nutriscore) THEY ENABLE THE CIRCULAR ECONOMY: By allowing to map products, repairability, circular solutions across countries, product categories, lifecycle (as seen with Open Products Facts). They can act in conjunction and augment EU initiatives (like the Digital Product Passport for Open Products Facts) THEY FUEL EDUCATION: Like Wikidata or Wikipedia, they train future citizens to navigate the (digital) world with autonomy, to make better and more informed technology choices in their future jobs and lives, balancing convenience and autonomy. MY PROPOSAL: The EU must recognize non-profit digital commons as critical infrastructure. We need a funding mechanism that recognizes them by impact, and provides them stability to stay fertile, but also grow and thrive.

In the current geopolitical context, the EU and its citizens cannot afford to depend on foreign technology conglomerates for critical digital infrastructure. Such dependence undermines privacy, democratic governance, and strategic autonomy. The EU should therefore invest decisively in privacy-respecting, open-source digital alternatives. For most digital services used daily, mature open-source alternatives already exist. The challenge is not availability, but adoption. Open-source solutions face higher switching costs, weaker marketing and enterprise support, fewer network effects, and are often disadvantaged by de facto proprietary standards. Even EU institutions remain heavily dependent on proprietary ecosystems, reinforcing these dynamics. To address this, structural policy intervention is required. Defaults matter. Most users and organizations rely on default technological choices. The EU should leverage this by mandating open-source defaults. For example, Linux-based operating systems should be the default on devices sold in the EU, with proprietary systems available only as opt-in alternatives. Similarly, browser and search engine diversity should be protected by avoiding Google-controlled defaults and excessive reliance on Chromium-based browsers. Temporary friction is acceptable if it realigns incentives and stimulates investment in open ecosystems. Public options are needed for essential digital services. Certain servicessuch as internet search, AI chat systems, cloud infrastructure, and identity and access managementare now critical to democratic participation and cannot realistically be self-hosted by individuals. These should have publicly governed, auditable, open-source implementations. In particular, digital identity should be treated as public infrastructure; reliance on corporate identities (Google, Apple, Facebook, GitHub) for essential services should be restricted. Adoption barriers must be reduced. Many open-source projects assume self-hosting, which excludes most users. The EU should fund and operate hosted instances of key open-source services and incentivize European companies to provide managed hosting. In parallel, the EU should actively promote open alternatives to citizens and public administrations. Open standards must be mandatory. All public sector documents, datasets, and interfaces should use open, fully documented standards. Proprietary formats should not be accepted for official communication or data exchange, as they entrench vendor lock-in and undermine interoperability. Public procurement is a powerful lever. EU and national procurement rules should explicitly favor open-source solutions, require interoperability guarantees, and prohibit vendor lock-in. Software purchased with public funds should remain under public control. Usability and accessibility deserve direct funding. Many open-source projects fail not for technical reasons but due to poor UX, documentation, and accessibility. Funding programs should explicitly support designers, technical writers, and accessibility experts. Funding must prioritize sustainability. Grant mechanisms should be simplified, longer-term, and focused on maintenance and incremental improvement rather than constant novelty. Supporting stable communities and long-lived projects is more valuable than funding short-lived innovations. Finally, enforcement should move beyond fines. When digital services demonstrably harm citizens or democratic processes, the EU should be willing to suspend or ban them until compliance is achieved. Fines alone are insufficient deterrents for large platforms.

A well executed European Open Digital Ecosystem Strategy does not only benefit Europe and its small to mid-size businesses, but users world-wide who profit from a competitive software market where walled-gardens and quasi-monopolies are replaced with innovative solutions competing for business. ## I see the following key elements for the strategy: 1️ EU public offices move public communication from Twitter (X), Facebook, Instagram and the like to publicly run Fediverse servers, giving a clear sign that the EU no longer tolerates coercion of logins and data handover of its citizens to uncontrollable entities - politicians should do the same with their personal accounts. 2️ Change the law so that the right-to-repair includes the ability of businesses to offer replacement components and extensions to existing software and hardware products (as mentioned in other feedback comments, Cory Doctorow's recent speech "The Post-American Internet" at the 39c3 might serve as an inspiration) 3️ Essential productivity apps for public offices, educational institutions, small businesses and private citizen are available in publicly funded core open-source variants that are stable, secure, fast; they only have a minimal feature set, which is - crucially - extendable and interoperable; this creates a market where small and mid-sized businesses (SMB) compete with products building on core EU apps while staying compatible and with services to set up, host and support extended or bundled apps; a great example of such an app is https://github.com/suitenumerique/docs (lacking a bit in extensibility it seems); some of them already exist in good form, some would need a new start. 4️ For these efforts it is necessary to have an EU public office and corresponding national organizations that are capable of managing the infra-structure, managing open-source development - especially the handling of trusted releases - and operating a git forge (cant use Github) 5️ Going further it would be prudent to look at open-source software and formats for manufacturing: at the minimum vector and CAD drawing for 3d printing, cutting, milling; ️ Comments: (ad 2) these apps need to cover: word processing, slide decks, spreadsheets, email, password management, calendar, contacts, group chat, conferencing (audio, video), wiki, file sync, whiteboarding/diagramming, data sync and interoperable formats for calendar and contacts, photo management, photo editing (ad 3) these core apps need to be publicly funded and developed because there is low incentive for private people to engage in creating modern, fast open-source solutions in an area that is stalled and unmovable; this is in stark contrast to when and in what context the Linux kernel was initially developed and even later when Home Assistant was started, two lighthouse projects formed around charismatic personalities with strong opinions;

Dear Commission, I would like to share my thoughts on European Digital Ecosystems.The Austrian virtualization technology Proxmox delivers crucial value in business and residential areas. As a European, open-source virtualization and container platform, Proxmox empowers everyone to build and operate modern IT infrastructures without vendor lock-in. Its transparent philosophy, strong community governance, and self-hosted deployment model allow institutions and citizens to retain full ownership and control of their environments. In my point of view, aligning with European data protection standards and sovereignty goals is non negotiable.

I have started using and contributing to Free and Open Source Software in 1998, attracted by its strong social dimension and led by my willingness to contribute to society. Open source development does not forbid profit (quite the contrary), but allows wider participation from people who are motivated by just their aspirations, hobbies, or individual needs to contribute. And it is especially important to ensure support for minorities which often do not attract the attention of corporations due to their small market potential (such as linguistic minorities, persons with disabilities, etc.). Growing up while contributing to open source helped me on a very personal level. It provided me with a readily available library of code to learn from and improve, both during my studies and my work career. Computer science, like other sciences, is built on the shoulders of giants. I could not have gathered a good degree of my professional knowledge had I been unable to study and learn from source code written by others in the public. The Commission will also surely appreciate how most AI LLM models for coding are trained almost exclusively on open source code. Open Source allows that free exchange of ideas necessary to move the knowledge horizon always a bit further, and the motivations in support of such a model are similar to the arguments made about making publicly-funded academic publications freely accessible to all. During my professional life, I have been put multiple times in difficult positions due to the insolvency of smaller software providers, or by unplanned changes from bigger ones. This was particularly acute when acting as a consultant for several public sector governmental organisations in Italy (municipalities, region-wide, nation-wide, and schools). A provider ceasing operation without leaving behind any manuals, support for ageing systems, and source code meant wasted taxpayer money at regular intervals. Even when the original closed-software provider does not go bankrupt, if they are the only ones to own the source code, they can unilaterally decide to hike support prices or license costs, and once in a vendor lock-in, and past the initial adoption costs, it can be very expensive to get out of it. Open source allows free competition based on merit, where multiple suppliers can succeed one another if they meet the quality and budgetary requirements. Proprietary software often means being left with closed standards, undocumented binary formats and opaque APIs, and no code to continue development. It is also harder to figure out if it is leaking sensitive user data to third parties. This can happen either willingly (for the profit of corporate interests, or those of adversary countries), or unwillingly (by enabling attackers to access PII due to programming mistakes). Especially at a government level, full auditing capabilities from the public are essential to contain the risk under acceptable levels. There is also a fundamental right of inspection and transparency that citizens should be able to exercise over their own data and on how their taxes are spent. Citizens should own the products they pay for, and not just get them "under a loan"a time-limited software license which grants them very limited rights. Open source means I can still open files I created more than 30 years ago today. It means I don't need to fear the software going obsolete, stealing my data, or becoming inoperable in response to a kill-switch built in by another. And it means I can improve on it, remix it, change it, make it better, and redistribute it to others, even when I need to change it only for the one friend who is visually impaired. I do care about them, while the big corporation might not. It means I can compete on a level playing field with other companies and consultants based on our merits and capabilities. These are the reasons why I think Europe can only ben

feedback: Use of open source based products improves vendor diversity and can contribute to European digital sovereignty in multiple ways. For most public sector and sovereignty sensitive organisations this means commercially provided services based on open source. CIOs need a way to evaluate the sovereignty benefits of open source-based solutions. European sovereignty and European competitiveness will both benefit from a stronger European open-source sector. We support targeted incentives to grow this sector but grants etc. should be linked to products which offer greater sovereignty benefits (e.g. minimise proprietary interfaces). Above all we are cautious about introducing an open-source preference in public procurement which could push public sector organisation to use open source before the ecosystem (both users and vendors) is mature enough.

feedback: European Pirate Party Submission- Towards European Open Digital Ecosystems Executive Summary: The European Pirate Party welcomes the Commissions Towards European Open Digital Ecosystems initiative as a timely opportunity to place open source at the core of Europes technological sovereignty. Open source should be recognised as public infrastructure that is essential to transparency, cybersecurity, and democratic accountability. For this vision to move beyond principle, the EU must act on four fronts: reform public procurement to prioritise open standards, secure sustainable funding for maintenance and governance, reduce structural dependence on non-EU infrastructure, and put safeguards in place against open-washing and vendor capture. Without a coordinated EU-level approach, Europes strong developer ecosystem will remain fragmented, rich in talent, but poor in strategic autonomy and fair competition. Detailed Response: Our complete response addresses all five consultation questions with comprehensive evidence-based analysis and concrete policy recommendations. For our complete analysis and recommendations, please see the attached document.
