feedback: Being a user of open source for more than 3 decades I really appreciate the open source ecosystem. It provides great opportunities to exercise freedom of choice, the ability to dig deep into the internal of software solutions to learn and understand how things do actually work, and also allow to add features that one might wish for, or repair features that do not work (or not as needed or wanted). Here and there I have contributed in such a manner to a number of projects. In my view a very important aspect is the availability of clearly defined and published standards, formats and protocols. These allow for interoperability, e.g. when improving or replacing certain components of larger systems, to improve over time. From a political perspective demanding the use of openly defined interfaces wherever public money is involved is a prerequisite to strive in the digital realm, and helps to ensure a minimum level of (software) sovereignty.

I think that Call for Evidence correctly identifies some of the key challenges for Open Source adoption. In my opinion there is one major omission, which is thinking in terms of companies, industry, etc., while forgetting that open-source started as a bottom-up movement of people who believed in the core principle of freedom. I think this individual component of open-source is crucial. At the moment, majority of high-profile open source software is being developed by tech giants: companies such as Google, Facebook or Huawei are among the top contributors to Linux kernel. This has to be kept in check by ensuring that the maintainers have funding that does not come directly from tech giants. Otherwise, a conflict of interest arises. As someone who has worked on open-source, the biggest challenge is precisely that lack of funding for individual contributors. I have to balance full-time professional work and working on open-source in my free time. This is a major challenge and the amount of work open source work I am able to carry out is small. I would love to become a full-time open source developer, but that requires access to funding that is available either to individuals or to projects, not just to companies. The primary added value of open source is safety and security. Currently, we don't know what majority of our "intelligent" devices do. What exactly are the cars doing? Are they spying? Are they faking low NOx emissions in laboratory testing? The 2015 Volkswagen emission scandal would not have happened if car makers were obligated to publish all the code that runs their cars. There are documented cases of IoT devices having either poorly implemented security, exposing their users to cybersecurity threats, or outright actively spying on their users and sending data to producer (and also having killswitches that allow the producer to disable the device remotely). Requiring that all such devices have their code published (+ means of verifying that the published code is actually running on the device) would increase public safety end help enforce law compliance. Adoption of open-source varies by sector. One area where I think it is particularly bad is the public administration. This, in my opinion, results from the fact that people working administrative jobs are not trained IT specialists and are thus unaware that avoiding a vendor lock-in is possible. A common example are public tenders for software delivery that only require deploying the software, but not transfer of ownership of its source code. Another interesting case is the gaming industry and, more broadly, the digital art industry. Many programs used by artists for 2D and 3D art have no viable open-source alternatives. If EU funded creation of software that could replace closed-source programs, such as Adobe, that would help a whole branch of the EU industry.

Um Unabhängigkeit von US Firmen zu schaffen betreiben wir unsere Virtualisierung und die Sicherung mit Software der Proxmox Server Solutions GmbH mit Sitz in Österreich. Ausschlaggebend für die Wahl der Software, war dass der Quellcode als Open Source frei zur Verfügung steht und auch nach Änderungen im Firmenkonstrukt des Softwareherstellers weiterhin entwickelt und verwendet werden kann.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: In order to create independence from US companies, we operate our virtualisation and securing with software of Proxmox Server Solutions GmbH, based in Austria. The choice of software was based on the fact that the source code was freely available as an open source and could continue to be developed and used even after changes in the software manufacturer’s structure.

feedback: In my opinion, it is crucial to introduce European legislation that would require governments (both national and local) and other publicly funded entities to operate on opensource solutions instead of relying on Microsoft, Google, and other Big Tech companies not to mention the use of Palantir in healthcare systems, which is simply wrong. Basically, the use of opensource solutions should be the standard for every publicly funded entity and, if possible, a condition in public procurement and grant policies. It would create a framework that every European company or institution would need to follow if they want to receive public funding or contracts. For the last few months, I have been transitioning my company from Microsoft 365 to opensource solutions (Linux, selfowned servers, degoogled phones, Nextcloud), and I know its hard the process is difficult even in a small firm like mine but the decision was right, and the reward is worth the pain of the process. I believe it is crucial for European digital sovereignty and security to control our data and to provide thousands of Europeans involved in opensource development with a better environment for their work and support for their community. Open source is something we Europeans should be proud of, and the Commission should invest in it, keep it safe, and help it thrive for all of us.

We welcome the ambition to build European Open Digital Ecosystems and argue that Europe can advance digital sovereignty by making open-source adoption simpler, safer, and procurement-ready, especially for small and medium-sized enterprises, universities, and public administrations. We propose an EU-level certification mechanism that reduces practical GDPR and information-security barriers, is attainable for smaller actors, and remains valid for 35 years. This should be complemented by EU-endorsed compliance guidance, reference controls, transition checklists, and model documentation so adopters can move from intent to execution without disproportionate legal and administrative burden. We call for concrete migration roadmaps that address sequencing, risk management, skills and training, and reusable procurement templates. Interoperability must be treated as a non-negotiable foundation: public-sector systems should rely on open standards, publicly documented interfaces (open APIs), and enforceable portability requirements, particularly where software is publicly funded, to prevent lock-in and enable competitive, modular ecosystems. We recommend sustained investment across the full open-source lifecycle: R&D, piloting, scaling, deployment, long-term maintenance, and security. Funding instruments should be faster and lighter where possible, with dedicated tracks that recognise maintenance and security as core public value, building on mechanisms such as the Digital Commons EDIC and leveraging STEP when appropriate. On infrastructure, we support European cloud initiatives and open-source cloud software, but stress that success depends on real deployment capacity and operational support. We further propose an EU-wide, interoperable sovereign cloud for public services, governed and hosted under European jurisdiction, to ensure controllability, resilience, and trust. To underpin these ecosystems, Europe should also develop and sustain key digital public goods: Git-compatible code hosting, collaboration and storage capabilities for public institutions, and open-source cloud-native and serverless building blocks that can be operated by European providers. Finally, we advocate Open by Default procurement (with explicit justification when proprietary solutions are chosen), criteria that reward transparency and portability, and measurable public-sector targets for open operating systems and productivity tools. Similar openness expectations should extend to critical infrastructure, alongside support for open European AI and data commons. Member States should coordinate through national strategies, an EU policy network, and strengthened Open Source Programme Offices (OSPOs) to share practices, pool resources, and accelerate adoption at scale. We elaborate on the aforementioned points and provide more detailed feedback in the attached document.

feedback: I am an employee of a European application hoster for small- to medium-sized businesses and even government agencies. We recently had a vendor lock-in situation by a US business that we resolved by deliberately choosing an open source alternative and contributing to it. Unfortunately, we are still dependent on other US projects that we pay for and these projects are more mature for our business needs. We don't have the capacity without endangering our business to also strive for open source here. I have my fair share of changing jobs that's why I have additional insight. This is not only my company's problem, but other companies have a similar set of tools, consequently a similar problem. That's why we need to pinpoint this suite of essential tools for these companies und support their development to infallibly strengthen the European economy which is the basis of our livelihoods.

This document provides Rabobanks perspective on Cloud Foundry in Europe, highlighting our largescale adoption, the strengths and weaknesses of the European opensource ecosystem, and recommendations for strengthening EU opensource sovereignty. It supports the case for increased European involvement in strategic opensource governance.

I believe the open source ecosystem is the best carrier of the values of Europa in terms of software and digital services production. Its core concepts such as transparency and data portability offer an easy and fast way for Europe to emancipate itself from captive US-based solutions, which is essential to its survival in the current geopolitical situation.

Having worked with Proxmox VE for over half a decade, I've come to appreciate what European open source projects bring to the table, not just technically, but strategically. Virtualization sits at the heart of modern IT infrastructure. It's the layer everything else builds upon, cloud services, container platforms, disaster recovery, the lot. When that foundational technology comes from an open source project headquartered in Vienna, it matters. Not for ideological reasons, but for practical ones. European organizations increasingly need to consider where their critical infrastructure dependencies lie. Proxmox VE demonstrates that world-class virtualization doesn't require locking yourself into licensing models or ecosystems controlled from outside the EU. The code is open. The company Proxmox Server Solutions GmbH operates under European data protection frameworks. Support and development happen in our timezone, in languages we speak. This isn't about rejecting solutions from elsewhere, it's about having genuine alternatives. Technological sovereignty means the ability to choose, to audit, to adapt. Open source makes that possible. European open source makes it convenient. Projects like Proxmox VE, Proxmox Backup Server, and Proxmox Datacenter Manager aren't just tools. They're proof that Europe can build and maintain infrastructure software that competes globally while strengthening our own digital ecosystem. That's worth recognizing and supporting.

Számos területen alkalmazunk nyílt forráskódú megoldásokat saját belső rendszereinkben, valamint ügyfeleinknél is kiterjedten üzemeltetünk nyílt forráskódú szoftvereket. Néhány példa a használt technológiák közül: Proxmox, Xen, PuTTY, Nextcloud, Roundcube, LibreOffice, Debian, Postfix, Apache, Ente Auth, Thunderbird, OpenMediaVault, WireGuard, WordPress, Rspamd, OpenStreetMap, Bitwarden/Vaultwarden. Meggyőződésünk, hogy ezek a megoldások jelentősen hozzájárulnak ahhoz, hogy az európai magánszemélyek és vállalatok csökkenthessék függőségüket néhány nagy, globális informatikai szolgáltatótól. Véleményünk szerint a nyílt forráskódú szoftverek stratégiai jelentőségűek Európa számára, mivel lehetővé teszik olyan informatikai rendszerek kialakítását, amelyekkel mérsékelhető a nagy multinacionális vállalatokkal szembeni kitettség. A jelenlegi világgazdasági környezetben ez megítélésünk szerint az egyik legbiztonságosabb és legfenntarthatóbb megközelítés.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: We use open-source solutions in many areas in our own internal systems, and we also extensively operate open-source software in our customers. Examples of technologies used include: Proxmox, Xen, PuTTY, Nextcloud, Roundcube, LibreOffice, Debian, Postfix, Apache, Ente Auth, Thunderbird, OpenMediaVault, WireGuard, WordPress, Rspamd, OpenStreetMap, Bitwarden/Vaultwarden. We are convinced that these solutions contribute significantly to reducing the dependency of European individuals and companies on a few major global IT providers. In our view, open source software is of strategic importance for Europe, as it enables the development of IT systems to reduce exposure to large multinational companies. In the current global economic context, this is considered to be one of the safest and most sustainable approaches.

feedback: I am not (yet) a contributor to open source software, but I am a user. In my opinion open source is a (digital) embodiment of the values the EU was founded on. It allows for the creation of new technologies by anyone, it allows for sharing of said technologies, it encourages cooperation, and is one of the great forms of freedom in our vast digital world. It contributes to virtually everything virtual ever made because someone wanted it to exist and provide those tools for anyone, big and small. In the current context of digital sovereignty it will allow the EU to build it's own infrastructure, it's own services, and own it's dependencies. It will also allow us (either as the EU, a country, company, organisation, or individual) to pivot to new solutions if we keep open standards in mind without fear of being vendor locked. Open source is currently (possibly without specific intent) under attack as contributions from other parts of the world dwindle (and code generated through LLM chatbots steer people away from repositories) and will certainly benefit from sensible EU support. Just as the EU will benefit from open source.

Je ne reviendrai pas ici sur l'intérêt que représentent les logiciels open source pour une UE trop dépendante des logiciels américains. Je formulerai quelques idées pour que cette filière puisse prospérer au sein de l'UE. 1) Pour que la filière des logiciels open source prospère, il faut tout d'abord cesser de considérer qu'ils sont gratuits. Il y a quelques années encore, l'administration française (où j'ai exercé des responsabilités IT au sein de grands ministères) voyait dans ces logiciels une source d'économie puisque, très souvent, l'open source est gratuit à l'usage. Cette mentalité a heureusement changé, il y a 5 à 10 ans, et les grandes administrations demandent maintenant à leurs prestataires de contribuer à l'évolution des logiciels open source qu'ils proposent à l'administration d'utiliser. Il s'agit en quelque sorte, de payer, par ce retour, pour l'usage du logiciel. En effet, il ne faut pas simplement profiter de l'open source, mais il faut le faire vivre également au travers des organisations qui le font évoluer. Ceci rejoint une des recommandations de l'ANSSI (AGence Nationale de Sécutité des Systèmes d'Information) (https://messervices.cyber.gouv.fr/documents-guides/anssi_essentiels_selection_logiciel_libre_1.0.pdf) qui recommande de "souscrire un contrat de support (fonctionnel ou de sécurité) auprès dune communauté ou dune entité commerciale. Cette contractualisation peut permettre de soutenir le projet en lui assurant stabilité financière et pérennité, tout en rassurant lentité qui le déploie." 2) Pour favoriser ce changement de regard, il faudrait renommer en "biens communs numériques" ces logiciels open source. Ils appartiennent à la communauté, et chaque membre de la communauté doit en prendre soin. Ce changement de vocabulaire peut favoriser un changement d'attitude vis à vis de l'open source. 3) Il faut également être plus coercitif au niveau de la commande publique, et imposer à toutes les administrations et collectivités locales de reverser une contribution, basée sur le nombre d'utilisateurs ou la puissance du serveur utilisé, à une communauté ou ou à une entité commerciale qui entretient le logiciel open source. 4) Dans les écoles, l'usage des logiciels open source doit être la règle, et le recours aux logiciels commerciaux justifié par exception, afin d'acculturer la jeunesse à leur usage. 5) Les écoles spécialisées dans le numérique doivent illustrer leurs cours par des exemples tirés des logiciels open source et proposer à leurs étudiants de les faire évoluer au titre de leurs TP/TD, projets de fin d'année, mémoires,... afin de mieux faire connaître leur architecture et leurs conditions privilégiées d'usage. 6) Lors de l'achat d'un PC, la réglementation de l'UE doit imposer qu'il soit fourni avec ou sans système d'exploitation, au choix du client. La version sans système d'exploitation sera alors moins chère et l'utilisateur, acculturé à un OS open source durant sa scolarité, tel que Linux, pourra y installer LINUX et autres logiciels libres.

feedback: This submission focuses on open-weight AI, i.e. systems whose parameters are publicly available for download and adaptation, rather than open-source technologies broadly. We draw this distinction because open-weight AI presents governance challenges that traditional open-source software does not: once model weights are released, they cannot be recalled, safety guardrails can be removed with minimal effort, and thousands of safety-stripped variants already circulate freely. Simply transplanting broader open-source policy arguments to advance AI models could undermine the specialised governance these systems require. The geopolitical context makes this urgent. Today's open-weight landscape is dominated by Chinese models (DeepSeek, Qwen), while American frontier systems (OpenAI, Anthropic, Google) remain closed. While Europes Mistral also has open-weight general-purpose models, it does not compete at the frontier. Any strategy framing open source as a path to European sovereignty must reckon with the fact that uncritical adoption of Chinese open-weight models simply substitutes one dependency for another. Meanwhile, Europe's own position is precarious: it hosts only 56% of global AI compute versus roughly 75% in the US, faces acute shortages of advanced AI engineers, and captures just 6% of global AI startup funding. We argue that Europe needs a dual-track strategy. The first track builds societal resilience: the safety infrastructure, governance standards, and defensive capabilities needed to manage misuse risks from powerful AI models Europe does not control. The second track reduces strategic dependence: directing the EU's approximately 2 trillion in annual public procurement toward European open-weight developers to build a sustainable domestic ecosystem, without relying on direct subsidies. Neither track works alone. Resilience without alternatives means permanent dependency; alternatives without resilience risk a single misuse incident discrediting openness altogether. Concretely, this means developing tiered release standards where openness is granted in proportion to demonstrated safety, with AI Safety and Security Institutes (AISIs) leading risk threshold development. It means sustained investment in technical safeguards tamper-resistant architectures, machine unlearning, and restricted-access channels for frontier models. It means context-aware procurement that prioritises European open-weight solutions where they offer clear sovereignty benefits cybersecurity, public services, SME adoption, research without mandating openness where closed models remain materially superior. And it means societal preparedness: AI-specific incident monitoring, cross-border threat intelligence, and targeted support that raises the floor of resilience for businesses and critical infrastructure operators alike. The window for establishing governance frameworks that enable safe openness is narrowing as model capabilities advance. Openness and safety are not mutually exclusive, but pairing them requires deliberate investment in both tracks, starting now.

feedback: Subject: Feedback on the EC Open Source Software Strategy: Scaling Proven Grassroots Solutions for European Digital Sovereignty As the lead developer of the AGHOS project (based at AGH University of Science and Technology, https://aghos.agh.edu.pl), I am writing to provide feedback on the European Commission's Open Source Software Strategy. While the strategys "Think Open" approach is commendable, our experience in developing and deploying a functional ecosystem for public administration suggests several areas where the Commission can bridge the gap between policy and practical implementation. 1. From Strategy to Reality: AGHOS as a Proven Solution The EC strategy often focuses on future development. However, AGHOS serves as a testament that the tools for European digital sovereignty are already here. AGHOS is a fully functional, Arch Linux-based operating system currently in use by students, researchers, and administrative staff. It is not a prototype; it is a working environment that proves open-source can meet the rigorous demands of public institutions today. 2. Seamless Transition and Interoperability A major hurdle for open-source adoption is the perceived "learning curve." We have addressed this by ensuring that AGHOS requires no additional technical skills for users already familiar with modern computing. Furthermore, we prioritize full MS Office compatibility, ensuring that public administration can transition away from proprietary licenses without losing the ability to collaborate with the external world. Our architecture is also designed for effortless localization, making it easily portable to any European language to serve the diverse needs of the Union. 3. Strengthening Sovereignty through "Zero-Telemetry" Environments Digital sovereignty must be absolute. AGHOS is built on the principle that public data must remain entirely outside the reach of proprietary "telemetry" and automated scanners used by non-European providers (Google, Microsoft, Apple). By utilizing a high-performance stackspecifically Arch Linux and the Apache HTTP Serverwe provide a transparent, self-hosted infrastructure where data protection is not just a policy, but a technical certainty. 4. The Power of Grassroots Innovation and the Need for Scaling Perhaps most importantly, AGHOS was born out of pure passion for the open-source philosophy, developed with zero external funding. This demonstrates the incredible efficiency and dedication found within the European developer community. However, this also highlights a missed opportunity in the current EC strategy. If a small, passion-driven team can deliver a stable, privacy-focused operating system that rivals proprietary alternatives, the impact would be transformative if the Commission provided dedicated resources and funding to such grassroots projects. We encourage the EC to look beyond large-scale corporate partnerships and invest directly in existing, community-vetted European projects that have already proven their viability. Conclusion The AGHOS project is a practical example of how European interests can be protected through transparent, community-driven code. We have built the foundationa system that is secure, user-friendly, and ready for Europe-wide deployment. We invite the Commission to support such "ready-to-use" ecosystems to ensure that European digital autonomy is built on software that is truly open, independent, and free from corporate surveillance.

Today most open source business models are based on open core, meaning a proprietary share (enterprise version) is needed to access the full potential of the technology. This approach impedes growth, as no community but the company owning the software is eager to contribute. It leaves us with a lot of "open source software" but very few "digital commons", and a very fragmented landscape. Large and powerful digital commons (Linux, Wikipedia, VLC ..) obey a different rule. Using more permissive licence (MIT, cc-by, GPL), they affirm the asset is the community, not the software (which is more of a liability, brittle and decaying). Now imagine if "storing and sharing digital information without risk at an affordable cost" would be a new right for EU citizens? This right is not enforced right now in Europe: we pay far too much for digital monopolies, our data is at risk, our collective preferences are ignored and our choices are limited. This right could be embodied in an Open Internet Stack, a state of the art technology stack available to any of us for free, and, reused by the EU tech industry, it will guarantee the availability of state of the art EU digital services. For every digital dependancy, the stack contains at least one alternative, and generally several for resilience purpose. The stack should be managed under a non-profit scheme Every profit-driven technology company is a future adversary of its own users, since it will come under pressure to prioritize profits over users welfare. We can witness this **enshitifcation** everyday, while now comes the **weaponisation**: the tech industry allies with imperialisms to weaken our democracies. Not-for-profit does not mean public money only The stack will embody a strong image of **trust** (governments using it, EU backed, democratic, transparent), **quality** (lots of users), **community** (lots of contributors) and **affordability** (free). The stack allows free riders, but the reusers willing to benefit from the brand will contribute financially to the stack : for so, the Digital Commons EDIC could manage an effective count of the active users of the stack, and account for each reuser its share, inviting them to contribute in-kind or cash, through a brand licensing agreement for instance. This mechanism will help the industry share much more investments in the stack while differenciating and competing on top. Our priorities should be where there are a lot of active users and no sovereign alternatives. It notably includes collaborative workspaces and cloud infrastructures, but also consumer markets. Here the bottleneck is not only the technology, but the lack of federated alliances of service providers. Telcos should regain the SMS market through an universal messenging offering based on Matrix and/or Signal. Medias should regain the conversation they've lost by offering Arte.social, BBC.social or Rai.social federated micro-blogging platforms powered by Mastodon. This could be eased by a strong pressure of the DMA to force incumbents' interoperability, hence facilitating the value proposition "switch, but don't loose your community". Let's act bold. European citizens deserve digital rights. The digital commons EDIC community knows how to build the best digital products: we are the sons of bureaucracies, but we also have [the experience of seasoned tech entrepreneurs](https://beta.gouv.FR) with proven track record on large digital public services: FranceConnect SSO and secured data sharing platform, pass Culture, PIX, demarches.gouv, ProConnect, LaSuite ... We are connected with this maker community accross Europe, and led by member states representants. European Commission, be the change! do one thing: stop funding open source via bureaucratic subsidies, bring M of capital to the EDIC and to the many non-profit bodies holding bundles that really compete with tech oligopolies. Fund and refund

feedback: Open Source software is the backbone of our economy. It runs in billion devices, high end performace clusters run on open source. Business critical applications integrate open source. Open Source is everywhere. Open Source software drives innovation in different dimensions: 1. As innovation enabler - this is when all non differentiating software is realized with Open Source, and own developers concentrate on the differentiating features. 2. As innovation engine - this is when innovative Open Source implementations are applied to new fields 3. As innovation incubator - new technologies are driven in the Open Source ecosystem The IT infrastructure is critical to all parts of live, the EU shall invest in and move to an IT infrastructure implemented with Open Source. It is unacceptable that software which is part of the infrastructure is controlled by non EU companies. In order to achieve souverenity independence is a mandatory prerequisite. Since Open Source is vital for our economy and innovation capabilities, we need to safeguard Open Source in a sustainable fashion. Long term funding will ensure long term availability, development and maintainace. The EU shall setup an European Availability and Sovereign Tech Fund The EU shall exempt Open Source completely for all regulations. Open source projects do not have the reources to order legal advice. Open Source software is a public good which is donated to the public by its developers. This special circumstances shall exempt Open Source software from all regulations Open Source is the freely available representation and expression of knowlegde. Open Source with all its facetts shall be an integral part of all the different education paths. Open Source principles, development (because this is first class software development) and building and maintaining communities, etc.

At XWiki and CryptPad, based on more than two decades of experience building and sustaining open-source software in Europe, we observe that open source can play a decisive role in rebuilding Europes competitiveness in software and in achieving European digital strategic autonomy. By enabling all European actors from software builders to users, across both public and private sectors to align around the open-source software delivery model, Europe can regain control over the digital infrastructure used by organizations and individuals alike. The attached document presents the perspective of a 21-year-old open-source company, with extensive experience in building and sustaining open-source software businesses in Europe. It outlines our analysis and proposals to contribute to the shared European objective of regaining control over critical digital infrastructure and software ecosystems.

This contribution is made in the name of Vates. We have already participated in the answers and documents as part of other established industry groups. However, we thought it necessary to highlight some specific aspects of business models found and operated in the Open Source ecosystem. Therefore this contribution focuses on structural aspects of the European open source ecosystem that are critical for its long-term sustainability, competitiveness, and contribution to Europes digital sovereignty.

The following is a summary of the feedback we want to provide, as a duo of two experienced FOSS contributors from the Chaos Computer Club Berlin. There exists an initiative by many organizations that is popular in the Chaos Computer Club called "Digital Independence Day". https://di.day/ >"EU stakeholders generally struggle with high entry barriers and network effects of dominant players both in the public procurement market and in the private sector market" This issue should be tackled by restricting your financial support and the dependence of your infrastructure to open-source providers. Only by dogfeeding on open-source software you will be able to know what is still lacking, and thus needs further support. It would also strengthen transparency and thus cybersecurity. >"it has emerged that supporting open-source communities solely through research and innovation programmes is not sufficient for successful upscaling" This is due to the fact that a major part of the labor that goes into an open-source project can't easily be signed off as innovation but as maintenance. Often these projects then are at a risk of degrading in security over the years of being unmaintained, or even suffering a hostile takeover by state actors as it was with the compressing toolkit xz. We recommend to invest in shared build infrastructure and to also pay out developers for keeping critical open-source projects in a healthy state, as opposed to what NLnet and NGI achieve with their innovation funds. Another important factor is that educational institutions rarely cover critical infrastructure, or the necessary knowledge to provide and maintain such. We see a direct correlation in our mission for providing sustainable infrastructure, enabling the industry behind it to do so, and educating students about the challenges involved early on. We recommend there be an undertaking of educational programs in highschools and universities, where students learn to build the infrastructure they depend on. Bounties should be payed out for milestones such as keeping a working E-Mail server online for a few weeks. The key technologies here are IMAP, POP3 and SMTP, for which we recommend to invest in dovecot https://dovecot.org/ and postfix https://www.postfix.org/ respectively. This educational program could be supported by the idea of a contest among students. Excellent developers often are torn between realizing their dreams in open-source and making a living with their skills in companies that keep their achievements locked away.

Proxmox, OpenProject, Nextcloud, SNIPE-IT, OPNSense... and so many others. Europe is already a world leader in open source, but we struggle. We need more grants, investment and support. A good model could be Fraunhofer-like system in each EU country. The world already runs on open source, it is just that Github is US, and the US get all our code sent to their servers so they can incorporate into US products we then have to pay to use.

Cigref, representing major French companies and public administrations, shares the Commission's findings on the crucial role of Open Source Software (OSS) in digital resilience. For our members, digital resilience is the ability to realistically control their future in order to secure their growth and create sustainable value. Cigref members make extensive use of open source components, particularly at the heart of their infrastructures. However, these technologies are still under-represented in business software and productivity applications, even though they offer significant potential for strengthening the competitiveness of the European digital industry. In this regard, Cigref has high expectations: Greater visibility for industrial-grade open-source solutions that are secure, interoperable, compliant with European regulations and maintained over time (European strategic Magic quadrant-type presentation) A long-term European open source industrial and technological strategy must cover the entire software cycle, relying on active developer communities to maintain and evolve solutions according to market needs. It must also provide for the organisation of development and a hosting infrastructure for digital commons and open source solutions supported by the European Union or Member States. The EDIC Digital Common could provide a suitable framework at European level, provided that major public and private contractors are closely involved in its development. Acculturation to the mindset and use of open source The emergence of world-class European champions to enable companies to consume open source solutions as state-of-the-art, compliant and secure products. Question 1 Strengths, weaknesses and barriers to adoption and maintenance In terms of strengths, OSS benefits from proven technical maturity, dynamic developer ecosystems in Europe and a natural alignment with EU values (transparency, interoperability). It is the driving force behind disruptive innovations (cloud, AI, big data). In terms of weaknesses and barriers, there is a lack of visibility, which requires a catalogue of industrial-grade solutions, such as the European Strategic Magic Quadrant. Strategic maturity: Less than half of organisations have an OSS strategy or an OSPO, hindering compliance and supply chain management. Fragmentation: Lack of EU-wide suppliers, fragmented funding and critical dependencies on platforms such as GitHub. Perception: Persistent concerns about security, compliance and the legal complexity of licences. Question 2 Added value of open source solutions for the public and private sectors OSS guarantees control over dependencies and reversibility. Its transparency improves auditability and cybersecurity (SBOM, provenance). Beyond innovation, it allows for the pooling of development costs and promotes the creation of collaborative ecosystems rather than closed customer-supplier relationships. Finally, it is a major lever for CSR (extending the life of equipment) and a key factor in attracting talent for younger generations. Question 3 Concrete measures at EU level to support the sector Cigref recommends: 1. A clear European governance involving end users to prioritise strategic building blocks. 2. The industrialisation of the supply chain and support for the EDIC Digital Common as a framework for hosting digital commons. 3. Support for an ecosystem of publishers and maintainers capable of transforming code into finished and secure products. 4. The adaptation of public procurement practices to open source and the launch of large-scale training/acculturation programmes, starting in higher education. Question 4 Priority technology areas Efforts must focus on areas that are highly critical and generate dependencies: AI and software engineering: The agent-based AI revolution must benefit the European open source development industry. Alternatives to monopolies: Support

feedback: Successful enterprise migration in medium-sized businesses CIS GmbH Consulting & IT-Services, an experienced German IT system house focusing on high availability and virtualization, has successfully migrated a complex VMware environment to Proxmox VE in collaboration with a medium-sized customer. The infrastructure consisted of: - Two data centers Four ESX hosts (Gen10 & Gen11) - Approximately 60 business-critical virtual systems - Central IBM All-Flash SAN The migration was carried out step by step during ongoing operations. Immediately after installing the first Proxmox hosts, a highly available cluster could be set up and put into productive use. Existing network, SAN, and storage structures were fully reused. In addition, CEPH was integrated as distributed cluster storage to provide additional resilience and flexibility. Added value for the customer Future-proof virtualization based on open standards High availability without compromise Use of existing enterprise hardware Full control over architecture and operation CIS GmbH and Proxmox VE jointly demonstrate that modern open-source virtualization is also a powerful and stable platform in the enterprise environment. Why migrate to open source: - Elimination of critical licensing risks - More stable OpEx structure - Full utilization of existing hardware - Technologically open platform Management conclusion: The migration to Proxmox is not an isolated technical decision, but a strategic measure to secure economic and technological sovereignty. Why Open Source: 1. Initial situation Companies are increasingly facing structural change in their cost and investment logic. Whereas investments used to be made primarily in fixed assets (e.g., machinery, hardware, software licenses), the focus today is shifting more and more toward ongoing subscription models. This development is changing not only the cost structure, but also the balance sheet, liquidity, control, and strategic dependencies. ________________________________________ 2. Drivers of the subscription economy The increase in subscription models is mainly driven by the following factors: Technological change Cloud computing, software-as-a-service, and managed services are replacing traditional on-premises solutions. Flexibility requirements Rapid scalability during growth or restructuring is preferred over long-term capital commitment. Pressure to innovate Continuous updates, security patches, and new features are now only available through subscription. Shift from CapEx to OpEx Investments are being shifted from fixed assets to ongoing operating costs. 3. Advantages of subscription models Subscription models offer clear advantages from a business perspective: Low entry costs and reduced initial investment Predictable, regular costs (in theory) Faster time to market Reduced internal operating and maintenance costs Access to the latest technologies These advantages are particularly attractive for dynamic, project-driven, or growth-oriented companies. ________________________________________ 3. Increasing problems and risks At the same time, new challenges are emerging: 4.1 Cost explosion due to fragmentation Large number of individual subscriptions (software, cloud, security, collaboration) Lack of overall transparency regarding current obligations Subscription creep due to unused or duplicate services 4.2 Permanent cost commitment No amortization as with fixed assets Costs continue indefinitely, even with low usage Cancellation periods and price increases increase dependency 4.3 Balance sheet and strategic effects No capitalizable assets lower balance sheet value Dependence on providers (vendor lock-in) Limited bargaining power when renewing contracts Companies are required to critically examine their dependencies and strike a better balance between flexibility, cost control, and strategic sovereignty.

I am writing to contribute my evidence to the "Towards European open digital ecosystems" initiative. As a Senior System Engineer with 12 years of total experience in the IT industry and 8 years of intensive specialization in the Proxmox ecosystem, I have seen firsthand how opensource infrastructure directly impacts EU technological sovereignty and economic competitiveness. Currently based in Lithuania, I leverage these tools to provide highlevel solutions across the region. 1. Breaking Vendor Lock-in & Strategic Autonomy: Over the past 8 years, I have successfully implemented numerous projects where Proxmox enabled clients to break free from proprietary vendor lock-in. This directly supports the Commissions goal of reducing dependencies on nonEU entities and regaining control over digital infrastructure. 2. Cost-Efficiency & Migration from Public Cloud: I have managed several transitions where organizations migrated from expensive public clouds to Proxmox-based private clouds. This has significantly reduced their operational costs and redirected resources toward local innovation rather than extractive proprietary stacks. 3. Advanced Security & Resilience: My implementations focus on building resilient Private Cloud architectures with integrated Disaster Recovery (DR) and optimized opensource firewalls. This holistic approach ensures a high level of security, which is a core objective of this initiative. 4. Scalability from HomeLab to Enterprise: Proxmox has evolved into a mission critical solution capable of handling large scale environments. Its interoperability with other opensource projects makes it a cornerstone for a vibrant European developer community. Recommendations: I urge the EU to prioritize policies that facilitate easier market integration for open-source professionals and provide sustainable support for community-driven innovations like Proxmox.

CONTRIBUTION FROM OPEN FOOD FACTS: DO NOT FORGET DIGITAL COMMONS IN BUILDING OPEN DIGITAL ECOSYSTEMS This is a contribution from Open Food Facts, a major digital common, born in Europe. Our 2 million+ active contributors and many more millions of users prove that citizens want to actively build European digital sovereignty, not just consume it. We have a real-life impact on health and the environment, by computing Nutri-Score, ultra-processing score and an environmental score at a very large scale. This fosters systemic impact on reformulation and empowers scientists and policymakers to advance Public and Planetary Health. OUR KEY MESSAGE: dont focus only on open source, also focus on open digital commons! WHY / ADDED VALUE: 1. MASSIVE USAGE: digital commons are currently contributed and reused by hundreds of millions of European citizens and organizations: think about Wikipedia, OpenStreetMap, Open Food Facts, etc. 2. DATA AS INFRASTRUCTURE: Open Data has a massive impact on a lot of economic sectors, like transportation (Open Street Map), health (Open Food Facts), circular economy for citizens (Open Products Facts), education etc. Data commons should be funded by agencies because of their net positive impact on society. But the market and procurement logic, geared towards specific services, does not work. This is why specific funding rules should be found. 3. COST EFFICIENCY: It is cost efficient in a budget constraints era: Once data is open, it costs the public sector near-zero to reuse it indefinitely, while actively financing the commons. It also avoids investment dispersion by several agencies at different levels, collecting data aiming at similar purposes 4. FUELING SCIENCE: Open data fuels science and enables research at a European scale that would not be possible otherwise (the Nutri-Score success story, Environmental labelling at scale, ultra-processed foods, and more). 5. DATA-DRIVEN POLICYMAKING: Open Data allows data-driven policymaking, due to Open Food Facts being accessible and used by national entities like Santé Publique France, Belgium, EFSA. Because the data is open, the EU is not dependent on a black-box proprietary database from a foreign entity to assess food quality or environmental impact. 6. EUROPEAN SOFT POWER: Digital commons contributes at a high level to the European soft power: many of the digital commons were born in Europe and led by European teams: Open Food Facts, OpenStreetMap, Wikidata, Zenodo, GeoNames, Tela Botanica, #OpenLitterMap, Europeana, blitzortung.org, etc. 7. REPRESENTING EUROPEAN VALUES IN THE AGE OF AI: Fostering OpenData and Digital Commons on the continent is also of paramount importance because they are the digital representation of who we are. Data should reflect the cultural diversity of member states, diversity, multilinguism, European culture, heritage, languages to the rest of the world. Data we can use, on topics we care about is especially important in an era of Artificial intelligence and LLMs. Open Data is feeding Europe. To create it, a free and open multi-function shovel is cool, but it's missing the open land and free seeds, and the farmers in charge need subsistence. THE ISSUE: Open data is essential, but it needs structural funding to develop communities, maintain servers, ensure security, preserve database integrity and services benefitting the majority of Europeans. To create a digital common, a free Software shovel is nice, but it is useless without an open data land, free seeds, and subsistence for the farmers in charge. ONE POSSIBLE APPROACH: Implement structural core funding granted by each DG dedicated to Non-Profit Digital Commons that foster European values and policy objectives. Criterion should be devised to avoid capture by lobby or lobby adjacent organizations, and instead be funneled towards projects with tangible impact (actual usage by, criticality of data for the EU

feedback:
In Italy, the current legal framework mandates the adoption and reuse of OSS software, but it does not provide sufficient practical guidance to public administrations. As a result, we are exploring ways to offer more concrete support to help administrations implement these requirements effectively. Each public administration manages its own budget, and investing in community initiativeswhere savings are not immediately visible in individual budgetsoften discourages participation. Although the community is active, it currently includes only a limited number of people with an active role in public administration. To address this, we are planning a series of institutional initiatives aimed at engaging a broader base of contributors and strengthening participation across public administrations. Several public administrations have embraced a diverse set of OSS tools, motivated by considerations such as digital sovereignty, cost efficiency, transparency, and independence from vendor lock-in, even though no strict rules mandate this choice. Periodic conferences showcasing case studies and best practices. Each EU Member State has some interesting initiatives but often are not well communicated outside the country. Some initiatives are difficult to follow or replicate due to the high customization of the projects, even if the code is public; it is difficult to reuse. Involvement in consultations as early as possible. We should be aware that OSS is not enough for the public sector, there are projects like OpenStack that demands OSS but also open design, open development and open community, the four opens need to be adopted as well for an inclusive and non-discriminant society, this approach should guide the EU OSPO as well. Organize more unformal gatherings, where problems can be discussed openly. Some of the proposal we want to share, to be encouraged or regulated at the EU lever are: The public administration should have personnel dedicated full time to the promotion of OSS (as formal OSPO?) A citizen of the EU must be able to live a digital life by using only free/OSS software Public Administration must work to ensure digital inclusivity by supporting OSS tools and operating systems Increase the public recognition of the value of OSS. Code literacy should be a mandatory skill. The internet has changed profoundly our lives in a few years and we need education. Coding with OSS could be taught easily Promote open standards and interoperability and support software reuse and as the only software that guarantees the digital sovereignty Provide opportunities (i.e. funds) to strength the technical capacities and reskill of public administrations servant Promote the use of OSS for infrastructural services (SaaS for various services, such as social/video/audio publishing, document hosting, chat/video conferencing, webinars, community call, ...) to lead by example Align national regulations with the OSS first principle Have a dedicated team to share reusable software projects at the EU level Actively participate in OSS communities promoted by the EU Long-term, multi-year funding devoted to maintenance, security audits, and community support of strategic OSS projects Tax incentives for EU-Corporate OSS contributions and/or adoption Develop EU certification frameworks for quality, security, and compliance of OSS solutions (not just compliance with standards but trust marks) EU programs fostering professional OSS skills (secure coding, community governance, DevSecOps) EU-wide curated catalogue of OSS applications with additional metadata to include AI and new technologies. Software catalogues need to be more useful and provide guidance early in the software selection process; an AI-driven model could be envisioned Development of Community Support Programs Digital Infrastructure: Definition OSS stacks or platforms (drivers: Interoperability, Identity, Security, Cloud, Des

feedback:
Martel is an SME that is involved in Open Source Software at multiple levels: we use it in everyday business operations; we develop, contribute to, and offer platforms and solutions based on Open Source; we engage and participate in several Open Source communities in the context of our European R&I activities and beyond. From declarations and statements of the European Commission in the last years, it is now abundantly clear that Open Source has come to fill multiple strategic roles, not always in harmony and alignment with each other: on the one hand, there is the social, community, and talent nurturing value of Open Source; on the other hand, Open Source is now heralded as an irreplaceable critical enabler of both European industrial competitiveness and geopolitical sovereignty if not even safety. A very good case in point is the Open Internet Stack (OIS), managed by the EC unit E.3 in DG-CNECT (one of the two issuers of this Call for Evidence), within the larger strategy named 3C Networks (3CN). The 3CN strategy builds, among other things, on the Cloud-Edge-IoT convergence megatrend and the associated research funded in the last years but also acknowledges the continuing convergence with modern telecommunications in 5G and the upcoming 6G. The funding of two large research projects on Telco Cloud, one on 6G enablers and one on supply-side Large-scale Pilots (LSP), both with commitments to adoption and contribution to Open Source Software, sets the bar for Open Source and European industry. The OIS, on the other hand, targets the funding of Open Source projects and communities related to the 3CN vision in a much more widespread way, relying on financial support for third parties (FSTP) to fund a higher number of beneficiaries with much lower amounts of money. This approach builds on the past successes of the Next Generation Internet (NGI) programme, of which the OIS is in a sense the continuation. This combination of strong industry-led R&I with more inclusive community-friendly projects and assets will be key for the impact of the 3CN strategy, and it also represent a promising template for future initiatives in other areas (e.g., automotive industry) where Open Source can be leveraged for industrial goal but needs to be nurtured and engage industry contributors while keeping its identity and independence. As Martel, from our many engagement with R&I, Open Source, community building, and European Policy and Strategy matters, we have developed a few reflections regarding this key topic for European sovereignty, competitiveness, and social fairness. 1. There cannot be any scaling of Open Source impact without industrial engagement at multiple levels. Its almost tautological, and it is true for all industries that are experiencing ever-increasing softwarisation of their domain, not just for telco. 2. For the OIS, this means a strong engagement with the two Telco Cloud large projects, as well as a friendly and dynamic collaboration with the CSA supporting them. 3. Part of scaling-up support for Open Source and its impact on European industry and sovereignty must engage with the processes and expectations of relevant industry segments (in the OIS case, Telco and Cloud providers with their supply chains). 4. The very tool of the FSTP is getting under stress. Complaints of lack of transparency and hasty preliminary rejection of applications without due review are on the rise: FSTP administrators have economic incentives to reduce reviewing costs and need to cope with exploding numbers of submissions, further facilitated by generative AI tools and techniques. Some further safety measures should be put in place. As a closing statement, we would like to stress that for socio-economic, and ultimately even geopolitical impact, the Open Internet Stack needs emergent combinations of industry and community outcomes; these will require agility on all sides, and ca

feedback: Coming back from FOSDEM 2026, where I met EU Policy Makers, heard the EU's ambitions around the European Open Digital Ecosystems initiative, I was compelled to submit this feedback. Open Source is the building block of more than 90% of the world's digital footprint and functionality and has already proven to be one of Europes greatest enablers of digital sovereignty, innovation, and resilience. All volunteer-based projects like Joomla!, developed and maintained by a global community for 20+ years, show the real stability and value of collaborative software ecosystems that transcend borders and foster trust. It is critical that the EU continue its efforts and support cornerstone initiatives such as the EU Sovereign Tech Fund, building on earlier visionary programmes (the Next Generation Internet initiative) which strengthen the openness and interoperability that Europe needs to achieve its digital objectives and compete globally. Open Source thrives on collaboration, agility, and transparency. To unlock its potential for European digital autonomy, funding must remain simple and accessible to small and medium sized organizations and volunteer projects such as Joomla!. As initiatives like the Cyber Resilience Act start influencing how software is built and distributed across Europe, close consultation with the Open Source community is vital so compliance goals do not inadvertently harm the openness and diversity that make Europes digital landscape so strong. For any framework for European open digital ecosystems to succeed: it is crucial that you include Open Source actors in governance, strategy, and implementation so that decisions reflect real world development practices and those building such solutions. From the perspective of a long standing, volunteer driven project like ours, one key strength of the EU open source sector is its skilled, community minded contributors and organizations. Its main weaknesses lie in a lack of sustainable, predictable support and in regulatory uncertainty that can discourage smaller actors from engaging. Contributions are often hampered because critical infrastructure is maintained in volunteers spare time, with limited access to funding, legal expertise, and guidance on evolving legislation. Open Source brings undeniable added value to public and private sectors by reducing vendor lock in, enabling independent security scrutiny, and allowing local companies and administrations to adapt software to their needs. Concrete measures at EU level could include expanding unbureaucratic funding instruments for core open source infrastructure, integrating open source priority and preference and contribution clauses into public procurement, and investing in security review and maintenance programmes that work directly with upstream projects. Priority should be given to technology areas where Europe depends heavily on global open source stacks, such as web infrastructure, content management systems, security critical libraries, and key digital systems used by public services and SMEs. Europe must continue "to think global while acting local". Open Source software is an international effort. Its sustainability depends on cooperative governance models and on a recognition that just because something is free and open source does not mean the burden should rest on volunteers alone. There should be mechanisms by which funding and other resources are given back to the community through instruments such as the Open Source Pledge, the Open Source Employment Pledge, an Open Source Tax or yet to be imagined community-driven models. The EU has an opportunity to lead by example with the wider Open Source community as its partner, promoting open digital ecosystems that are inclusive, innovative, and grounded in fairness and trust: principles that have always been at the heart of Europe and communities like ours. Thank you for listening.

European sovereign IT solutions are key for europe to succeed. My personal believe is, that actually everything we need it terms of cloud solutions are available as open source, sometimes even from european providers like Proxmox or OpenStack. The EU should support these initiatives by supporting the development of such solutions financially but also by using these tools for the internal IT in all EU officies and departments as well as to ask all member states to act in such a way.

We are a group of software engineers and scientists working at the ISIS Neutron and Muon Source, UK. Many of us are EU citizens and we collaborate on open-source projects with many people across the world. We work particularly closely with the Institut Laue-Langevin in Grenoble and the European Spallation Source in Lund and Copenhagen. We participate in number of open science initiatives with European partners, such as the European Open Science Cloud. While we have an interest in open source software in general, we will focus our response on open-source scientific software. Like the majority of large-scale physics facilities (particle accelerators, large telescopes, large lasers) an open-source software model is central to how we operate. This is because we have a user-based operating model, where our role is to provide access to experimental techniques at operational scales beyond the reach of most institutions and businesses. Large scale facilities have both motivation and means to produce high quality open-source projects; gathering our data is expensive and we wish to see it have the highest impact on science and society. We have the resources to provide transparent and cost-free software for our users fields, primarily in materials science, which other scientific fields may not have. A big question, then, is how we can promote open-source software in scientific areas that lack the kind of support that teams like ours provide. This is becoming increasingly important as publicly funded research institutions adopt the FAIR data principles, by which scientific data should be Findable, Accessible, Interoperable and Reusable. Within the FAIR framework, publicly funded experiment results become available to everyone to view and interpret. However, access to scientific data is only going to be meaningful if equally open access is provided to the software tools that make it possible to view and analyse the data. FAIR data also requires open data formats. An open data format allows any interested party to develop their own software for reading and subsequently processing the data. We consider it a sign of a healthy software environment if multiple alternatives exist for performing a single task, using the same data format or the same protocol. In addition to the trend towards FAIR data, it is now standard practice that code used in research is made available on publication. This is important for the peer review process and for reproducing results. Code availability might sound positive from the perspective of open-source software, but in practice this rarely results in code that has a use beyond that publication. It does very little to help build an ecosystem of mature, community-supported, open-source software. We should encourage scientists to, where possible, collaborate with larger community projects, rather than on single-use, problem-specific code. The focus on novelty within scientific research means that it is much easier to find resources to prototype a novel computational approach to an esoteric problem than to provide reliable, user-friendly and maintainable codebases. This is one reason why the profession of Research Software Engineering (RSE) has emerged over the past decade. Support for careers within research software engineering and for institutions that home them is another important consideration. Finally, we have some further suggestions for possible ways of promoting open-source software and communities, which we have attached separately.
organization: Open Source Working Group, ISIS Neutron and Muon Source

feedback: Architecte/Ingénieur systèmes et réseaux au sein d'une collectivité territoriale, nous sommes en cours de migration de notre infrastructure virtuelle VMware vers Proxmox VE 9.1. En toute objectivité, Proxmox offre une agilité et une prise en main comparables à celles de VMware, tout en proposant une compatibilité quasi illimitée avec les standards ouverts. Performances et résilience du stockage : Le passage d'un datastore VMware sur baie RAID matérielle traditionnelle vers un stockage ZFS (RAID-Z) sur Proxmox a permis de réduire la durée des snapshots de plusieurs minutes à quelques secondes. Contrairement au RAID matériel propriétaire, le RAID-Z offre une détection et correction des erreurs silencieuses de données (bit rot) grâce aux checksums, une flexibilité dans la gestion des volumes sans contrainte de configuration fixe. Conteneurisation et souveraineté : L'intégration native des conteneurs LXC dans Proxmox nous permet douvrir la voie à lhébergement direct de nos workloads Docker et Podman de manière légère et sécurisée. Cette approche hybride offre plusieurs avantages stratégiques : - Démarrage quasi instantané des services applicatifs dès la mise sous tension de l'hyperviseur - Isolation optimisée entre les conteneurs applicatifs et l'hôte, renforçant la sécurité - Réduction de la complexité : plus besoin de VMs complètes pour chaque service conteneurisé - Maîtrise des ressources grâce à la gestion fine des quotas CPU/mémoire par conteneur provisionnable à chaud Cette architecture nous permet de concilier souveraineté numérique, performance et agilité opérationnelle, tout en réduisant significativement nos coûts de licensing propriétaire.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: As an architect/systems and networks engineer in a local authority, we are in the process of migrating from our VMware virtual infrastructure to Proxmox VE 9.1. In all objectivity, Proxmox offers agility and leadership comparable to that of VMware, while offering almost unlimited compatibility with open standards. Storage performance and resilience: The change from a VMware datastore on traditional hardware RAID bay to a ZFS storage (RAID-Z) on Proxmox has reduced the duration of snapshots from several minutes to a few seconds. Unlike the proprietary hardware RAID, RAID-Z offers detection and correction of silent data errors (bit rot) through checksums, flexibility in volume management without fixed configuration constraints. Containerisation and sovereignty: The native integration of the LXC containers into Proxmox allows us to doubt the way to directly host our Docker and Podman workloads in a light and secure manner. This hybrid approach offers several strategic advantages: — Almost instantaneous start of application services as soon as the hypervisor is energised – Optimised insulation between application containers and the host, enhancing security – Reducing complexity: no longer need full VMS for each containerised service – Manage resources thanks to the fine management of CPU quotas/hot provisionable container memory This architecture allows us to reconcile digital sovereignty, performance and operational agility, while significantly reducing our proprietary licensing costs.

feedback: Generally, the open-source community is averse to online advertising. This is understandable, as the history of online advertising is closely associated with surveillance and related practices that are antithetical to core open-source values. However, online advertising does not have to be surveillance-based. Transparent and fair online advertisingespecially when it is safe for end users and societycan provide a significant and scalable business model capable of monetising and sustaining critical open-source digital ecosystems. With this in mind, the European Commission should focus on regulating online advertising in a way that fosters an ecosystem that the open-source community, including end users of open-source technologies, can trust. By establishing such trust, the EU can also advance its broader competitiveness objectives and economic growth. Check My Ads Policy Platform provides a set of policy solutions that can lead to such a trustworthy online advertising ecosystem: https://checkmyads.org/policy/ We will continue to provide the European Commission innovative, creative solutions to reimagine online ecosystems in ways that serve the interests of small businesses (advertisers and publishers) and the general public.

I am a European IT infrastructure consultant and Proxmox partner, working mainly with SMEs and organisations linked to the public sector. I support organisations in modernising on-premise and hybrid infrastructures, often as an alternative to highly concentrated proprietary vendors. Open digital ecosystems, and in particular open-source virtualisation platforms such as Proxmox VE, play a strategic role for Europe in terms of digital sovereignty, resilience, and competitiveness. In practice, Proxmox VE enables European organisations to reduce dependency on a limited number of non-European vendors, avoid vendor lock-in, and regain control over costs, data, and infrastructure architecture. These solutions allow full control over data location and security policies, which is essential for regulatory compliance (GDPR) and sensitive workloads. From field experience, open-source solutions are often adopted following unilateral pricing or contractual changes imposed by proprietary vendors. They provide long-term stability, predictability, and sustainable IT investment planning, particularly for SMEs, local authorities, education, and healthcare. Open ecosystems also foster innovation and local employment by supporting networks of European partners, integrators, and skills across Member States, while ensuring interoperability and skills portability. However, the current regulatory framework can create indirect disadvantages for open-source ecosystems: compliance and certification processes designed primarily for large proprietary vendors, public procurement criteria favouring brand recognition over openness and interoperability, and a lack of clarity around support and liability models. To strengthen Open Digital Ecosystems in Europe, EU policies should: explicitly recognise open-source infrastructure software as a strategic asset for digital sovereignty, ensure proportionate and technology-neutral regulatory requirements, promote interoperability and open standards in public procurement, support European partner ecosystems, not only large centralised vendors. Open-source solutions such as Proxmox VE are mature, widely deployed, and essential to Europes digital autonomy. A balanced regulatory framework is key to enabling them to compete on fair and equal terms

As small business owner I can confirm that there are already multiple open source projects available that support internal and external business processes such as Mattermost (communication), Jitsi (video conferencing), Kimai (time tracking), Forgejo (issue tracking) and many others. One of the main challenges maintaining an on-premise installation of all of these is authentication and single-sign-on (SSO). While all of them provide multiple ways to do this, getting it to work is cumbersome and takes a lot of expertise not available to many on site. What I would find very helpful would be an EU-maintained distribution that provides a single-sign-on solution and has many business tools pre-configured to use it. Apart from enabling business owners to host it themselves, this would also allow small, local hosters to provide this kind of services for their regional customers with comparably little effort and a consistent quality.

Submission by Cloudera (Open Source Program Office) Cloudera provides critical data infrastructure for several European financial institutions and major public sector bodies. We welcome this initiative, and additionally warn that a focus solely on Open Source Software (OSS) overlooks a more pressing threat to digital sovereignty: Data Format Lock-in. Our evidence (attached) demonstrates that proprietary cloud providers frequently use open source code but store user data in opaque, proprietary formats. This creates "Data Gravity" that effectively forces European entities to "rent" access to their own data. Summary of Recommendations: Mandate Open Data Standards: Public procurement must require software to store data in open, vendor-neutral formats (e.g., Apache Iceberg, Parquet) by default, ensuring exit strategies are technically feasible. Recognize "True Hybrid" as Resilience: Sovereignty should be defined by the ability to move workloads between hyperscalers, sovereign clouds, and on-premise data centers without refactoring. Please refer to the attached PDF for detailed technical scenarios comparing Proprietary Cloud vs. Open Standards.
