feedback: As a strong advocate for EU-friendly and sovereign technology solutions, VMease is a private cloud management solution which is built on underlying open source technology from European companies such as Proxmox. As an EU-centric provider of private cloud solutions, VMease.com significantly lowers private-cloud costs, simplifies operations, and gives organisations far greater control and sovereignty as they modernise their infrastructure.

We are a small company that offers financial consulting and accounting services for businesses and private individuals. Personally, I have been using opensource software for more than 20years, deliberately purchasing hardware without a preinstalled operating system. The main reasons for the limited adoption of opensource solutions are: - Preinstalled operating systems that come with numerous oneclick ads for office suites and groupware packages. - Widespread use of closedsource systems by governments and public administrations. - Government administrations use proprietary formats when communicating with citizens. - Schools and universities heavily use and teach solutions from Big Tech companies. - Software vendors often release versions for a single operating system, knowing that a large share of orders comes from the public sector and government agencies. I have seen many comments describing the pros and cons of opensource solutions. To avoid some of the drawbacks, numerous companies now base their business models on open source: they charge fees for support and installation when the adopting company lacks qualified staff or simply wants to use the vendors services. This approach helps develop the software and encourages the community. We use opensource solutions in our daily work, hosting most of them ourselves on our own hardware. These include virtualization, backup, cloud technologies, and VPN solutions that help us: - avoid vendor lockin, - achieve significant flexibility for both us and our clients, - substantially reduce operational costs, - increase the technical competence of our staff. In my view, the most important areas that should be targeted right now are cloud technologies, local operating systems, groupware software, and office suites, with implementation beginning at the state and government level.

Igalia is an international open source consultancy with over 25 years of experience, based in Europe but with partners all over the world. We are significant contributors to key open source technologies like web engines, compilers, graphics drivers and multimedia systems, among others. We welcome these new steps to increase Europe's technological sovereignty based on open source solutions, and we are willing to contribute with our resources and knowledge to advance that goal. We would also like to make some high level comments about the existing situation: 1. Properly directed funding can have have a major impact on open source technologies and software sovereignty. * While we strongly welcome and encourage EU funding, the complexity of gaining access to it for funding open source projects has historically been very prohibitive for us. We believe that it is crucial to not only add funding, but to radically streamline these processes. The EU Sovereign Tech Fund, if scaled up, could provide a good blueprint. * Funding should not focus just on pure R&D, but also long-term maintenance and the production of industry-ready solutions. Up to 100% of direct costs should be available for projects producing open source output. * More than anything, reliable sources of financing should be created for European companies that want to invest in open source technologies for the European market. Public procurement or stable public-private partnerships, among others, could be key tools to tackling this problem. 2. However, we must also avoid basing this on a naive understanding of software sovereignty. We should not think we have to reimplement everything from the ground up, or insist that all decisions be made only by Europeans. We must be able to keep working with friends and allies all over the world, when possible. We believe that we must help to advance viable governance solutions for international open source ecosystems where Europeans are major players and feasibly able to fork if necessary. 3. We believe open source is strategically important for Europe, but that open source alone is not sufficent to sovereignty. * In the short-term, there are critical gaps to fill. In some cases, our basic digital infrastructure in Europe is 100% controlled from elsewhere and dependent on foreign companies. There cannot be "kill switches" for mission-critical software deployed in our institutions and companies. This has to be solved ASAP. Some compromises that iteratively improve the status quo might be necessary. * There are long-term problems which will not be solved immediately, but where Europe could be a leading actor for change, and where we should focus on getting the fundamentals right. Protocol-based solutions where the playing field is defined in a fair manner for everyone and where applications can be swapped in and out as long as they respect that common protocol are a very strong guarantee of sovereignty and freedom. We believe we should focus our energies, in terms of investment and development, on the "common protocol and diversity of applications" model: that of the internet, the web, and new developments like open social (atproto, activitypub and others). We should expand that model to as many places as possible. These are just some brief thoughts about some what we understand to be key issues, both urgent and long-term. Again, we are happy to be part of this process and we are happy to continue this conversation with the Commission and other members of the community.

Dobrý den, jako partner ekosystému Proxmox a dodavatel IT řešení pro organizace v EU vítáme iniciativu European Open Digital Ecosystems. Otevřené digitální ekosystémy jsou klíčové pro technologickou suverenitu Evropy, efektivní využití veřejných prostředků a dlouhodobou udržitelnost IT infrastruktury. Přínosy open-source virtualizace pro EU Open-source virtualizační platformy (např. Proxmox VE) přinášejí evropským firmám i veřejným institucím zásadní výhody: nižší celkové náklady (TCO) díky transparentní licenční politice a možnosti využít podporu dle potřeby, nezávislost na jednom dodavateli (vendor lock-in) a možnost volby partnera/provozního modelu, interoperabilita a otevřené standardy, které umožňují integraci do heterogenních prostředí, bezpečnost a auditovatelnost díky otevřenému kódu a komunitnímu i komerčnímu dohledu, lokální evropský ekosystém služeb podpora evropských dodavatelů, MSP a integrátorů. Tato řešení umožňují budovat moderní infrastrukturu pro cloudové služby i on-premise provoz (hybridní model), což je zásadní zejména pro organizace se zvýšenými požadavky na bezpečnost a ochranu dat. Výzvy v současném regulatorním a tržním prostředí V praxi se setkáváme s tím, že: veřejné zakázky často nepřímo preferují proprietární platformy (např. specifické licence, vendor-specifické požadavky), interoperabilita je deklarovaná, ale v reálném světě omezená nedostatečnou přenositelností workloadů a dat, administrativní a compliance požadavky bývají nepřiměřeně náročné pro malé a střední dodavatele open-source řešení, chybí jednotné a prakticky použitelné pokyny, jak hodnotit open-source řešení ve veřejném sektoru. Doporučení pro EU politiku Doporučujeme, aby iniciativa vedla k opatřením, která: 1. podpoří otevřené standardy a interoperabilitu jako povinný princip, zejména u veřejně financovaných digitálních řešení, 2. omezí vendor lock-in prostřednictvím požadavků na přenositelnost dat a workloadů, 3. zohlední open-source model v regulaci tak, aby compliance povinnosti byly proporcionální a neznevýhodňovaly evropské MSP, 4. podporovala férové podmínky ve veřejných zakázkách (např. možnost prokazovat funkčnost a bezpečnost i bez vendor-specifických certifikací), 5. uznala open-source jako strategickou součást evropské digitální infrastruktury. Otevřené digitální ekosystémy mohou významně posílit konkurenceschopnost EU, zvýšit bezpečnost a snížit náklady pro veřejný i soukromý sektor. Děkujeme za možnost se vyjádřit.
feedbackTextUserLanguage:
Hello, as a partner of the Proxmox ecosystem and supplier of IT solutions for organisations in the EU, we welcome the European Open Digital Ecosystems initiative. Open digital ecosystems are key for Europe’s technological sovereignty, the efficient use of public funds and the long-term sustainability of IT infrastructure. Benefits of open-source virtualisation for the EU Open-source virtualisation platforms (e.g.: Proxmox VE) bring major benefits to European companies and public institutions: lower total costs (TCO) thanks to a transparent licensing policy and the possibility to use support as needed, vendor lock-in and partner/operating model choice, interoperability and open standards that enable integration into heterogeneous environments, security and auditability thanks to open code and community and commercial oversight, a local European service ecosystem supporting European suppliers, SMEs and integrators. These solutions make it possible to build a modern infrastructure for both cloud services and on-premise operations (hybrid model), which is particularly crucial for organisations with increased security and data protecti

Afin d'être indépendant des technologies USA, j'utilise exclusivement des solutions opensource. Pour la virtualisation des serveurs, la solution Proxmox de l'entreprise Allemande du même nom est utilisé pour mes besoins et ceux de mes clients depuis plusieurs années avec un grand succès. Il faut absolument privilégier les solutions souveraines européennes.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: In order to be independent from US technologies, I use OpenSource solutions only. For server virtualisation, the Proxmox solution of the German company of the same name has been used for my needs and those of my clients for several years with great success. It is essential to focus on European sovereign solutions.

feedback:
LIncubateur des Territoires de l'ANCT a pour mission daccompagner les petites collectivités dans leur transition numérique notamment au travers du déploiement de La Suite territoriale (socle de services - identité numérique professionnelle, nom de domaine, messagerie, espace de stockage - et un écosystème dapplications open source déployées de manière décentralisée). Lopen source est un principe fondateur pour lANCT, car il garantit : - Souveraineté : maîtrise des données ; - Sécurité : réduction des vulnérabilités ; - Pérennité : maintenabilité. Cependant, les petites collectivités, qui représentent une part majeure du maillage administratif européen, font face à des freins et des défis structurels : - Financiers : les petites collectivités ne disposent pas des ressources nécessaires pour couvrir les coûts initiaux (migration, formation, maintenance), malgré des économies potentielles à long terme. - Dépendance aux solutions propriétaires : utilisation majoritaire de services fermés, coûteux et non souverains, exposant les territoires à des risques de dépendance technologique et de cyberattaques. - Manque de ressources : humains et technique rendant difficile ladoption et la maintenance de solutions open source. - Interopérabilité limitée : solutions pas toujours compatibles avec les outils existants ce qui complique leur intégration. - Absence de cadre réglementaire incitatif : les appels doffres publics favorisent encore trop souvent les solutions propriétaires. - Manque de tiers de confiance : les petites collectivités ont besoin dacteurs neutres et fiables pour les accompagner dans leur transition vers lopen source. - Méconnaissance des bénéfices : les élus et agents territoriaux ne mesurent pas toujours les avantages de lopen source. - Résistance au changement : la transition vers de nouveaux outils est perçue comme risquée (fiabilité, support). Propositions pour lever ces freins et renforcer laction de lANCT : 1. Créer un fonds européen dédié aux petites collectivités pour faciliter ladoption de lopen source : - Financer des programmes daccompagnement technique et financier, couvrant les coûts de migration, de formation et de maintenance. Ces programmes pourraient être portés par des acteurs comme lANCT, via des appels à projets simplifiés. - Soutenir des initiatives comme La Suite Territoriale, qui intègre des briques technologiques open source tout en garantissant leur souveraineté. 2. Adapter le cadre réglementaire pour favoriser lopen source : - Intégrer des critères open source dans les appels doffres publics, en privilégiant linteropérabilité et la souveraineté. - Simplifier les procédures pour permettre aux petites collectivités daccéder plus facilement à des solutions open source, sans être pénalisées par des processus administratifs complexes. 3. Renforcer la mutualisation et la coopération européenne : - Encourager les partenariats transfrontaliers entre collectivités pour mutualiser ressources, coûts et retours d'expérience - Soutenir les communs numériques comme La Suite (DINUM) et La Suite territoriale dans une logique de gouvernance partagée. 4. Sensibiliser et former les acteurs locaux : - Lancer des campagnes de sensibilisation destinées aux élus et agents des petites collectivités. - Proposer des formations pour monter en compétences sur les solutions open source. Conclusion : LIncubateur des Territoires de lANCT est convaincu que lopen source représente un levier essentiel pour renforcer la souveraineté numérique des petites collectivités. Pour cela il est nécessaire de : - cibler les petites collectivités avec des financements adaptés à leurs besoins ; - construire un cadre réglementaire ; - soutenir les acteurs mutualisant comme l'ANCT comme tiers de confiance. En agissant sur ces leviers, lEurope pourra accélérer la transi

feedback: * De open source strategie van onze organisaties staat beschreven in het rapport 'Opensourcewerken, de vrijblijvendheid voorbij' (2022). Dit rapport benoemt ook welke acties er nodig zijn om de eigen organisatie om te vormen. * In de 'kabinetsagenda Digitale Open Strategische Autonomie' (2023) staan zowel de afhankelijkheidsrisico's rond open source beschreven alsmede de kans om met open source problematische afhankelijkheden te doorbreken en strategisch nieuwe afhankelijkheden te kiezen. * Alle EU publieke organisaties hebben baat bij ondersteuning van kritieke digitale gemeenschapsgoederen, waaronder middels een European Sovereign Tech Fund, codebase stewardship, strategisch mee ontwikkelen en bug bounties. * Open source is een instrument dat vele aspecten van de strategie, beleid en uitvoering raakt. Maak sterke strategische keuzes en werk met organisatieonderdelen om een strategie te ontwikkelen die hen in staat stelt bij te dragen aan die doelen. Door het goede voorbeeld te geven kan de commissie implementatie voor alle publieke organisaties vergemakkelijken. Versterk hier voor het EC OSPO langs de lijnen: 1. kwaliteit- en beleidsbewaking, 2. ondersteunen en faciliteren, 3. aanjagen en opleiden. * De Europese Commissie heeft een unieke positie om publieke organisaties te verbinden, ondersteunen, faciliteren en opleiden. Dit kan bijvoorbeeld via het EU public administration en member states OSPO Netwerk, en andere bestaande structuren.

feedback: 5. Use of Open Source Within EU Institutions and Crisis Scenarios Beyond setting a strategic framework for the European digital ecosystem, the consultation should explicitly address how EU institutions themselves can and should adopt open-source solutions in their daily operations and crisis preparedness. EU institutions depend on secure, resilient, and controllable digital infrastructure for internal communication, coordination, and decision-making. Open-source solutions developed and operated by European providers offer clear advantages in this context, particularly with regard to data sovereignty, legal certainty, and operational resilience. Concrete application areas for EU institutions include: Secure internal and inter-institutional communication: Video conferencing, email, and collaboration tools for routine operations, cross-directorate coordination, and confidential exchanges. Crisis and contingency communication: Reliable communication platforms for emergency situations, including cyber incidents, geopolitical crises, or large-scale infrastructure disruptions. Hybrid and remote work: GDPR-compliant tools enabling secure remote collaboration for EU staff and external stakeholders. Interoperability with national administrations: Open standards facilitate seamless cooperation between EU institutions and member state authorities. Open-source solutions such as OpenTalk and OpenCloud are particularly well suited for these use cases. They can be operated as SaaS or on dedicated infrastructure, audited at code level, and adapted to specific security or compliance requirements of EU institutions. Resilience, business continuity and digital parachutes Recent geopolitical developments underline the importance of preparing for business continuity and own a digital parachute in case of emergency: situations in which services provided by non-European vendors become unavailable due to sanctions, political decisions, or legal conflicts. The EU has already experienced the real-world implications of sanctions regimes, including cases involving high-level political actors, such as the sanctioning of former EU Commissioner Thierry Breton. These developments highlight that access to critical digital services cannot be taken for granted when dependencies on non-European providers exist. Open-source solutions enable: Rapid migration or failover in crisis situations. Continued operation even if commercial contracts are suspended or providers withdraw. Full legal and technical control over mission-critical communication systems. By systematically adopting open-source solutions for its own operations, the European Commission can both strengthen its internal resilience and act as a credible role model for member states and public administrations across Europe. 6. Expectations for the EU Strategy The Heinlein Group expects the EU to: Provide clear political signals prioritizing open source in digital transformation. Ensure long-term funding for the development, maintenance, and scaling of open-source projects. Establish regulatory frameworks that promote open source as the standard without stifling innovation. Engage industry in strategy implementation, e.g., through pilot projects with companies like the Heinlein Group. 7. Conclusion The Heinlein Group welcomes the European Commissions initiative and stands ready to contribute its expertise and resources to its implementation. A strong open-source strategy is essential for securing Europes digital sovereignty and enhancing global competitiveness. We urge the EU to take concrete steps to establish open source as the standard for public and private IT infrastructure.

1. Position of the Heinlein Group Heinlein Group, based in Berlin, has been a pioneer in digital sovereignty, data protection, and open source in Europe for over 30 years. Through its brandsHeinlein Support, mailbox, OpenTalk, and OpenCloudthe company provides GDPR-compliant solutions for secure communication, hosting, and IT infrastructure. Our expertise lies in developing and promoting open standards and open-source technologies, enabling public institutions, businesses, and educational organizations to operate independently of non-European providers. Concrete Projects and Initiatives: OpenTalk: An open-source video conferencing solution already adopted by regional governments such as Thuringia, Schleswig-Holstein and the Federal Ministry of Defence of the Republic of Austria. OpenCloud: Strengthening the open-source ecosystem in Germany through innovative cloud services. mailbox: A secure digital workspace designed for privacy-compliant communication, widely used by public administrations and organizations with high data protection requirements. 2. Assessment of the EU Open-Source Landscape Strengths: Europe hosts an active open-source community and innovative companies developing high-quality solutions. Open source ensures transparency, security, and flexibilitycore values for digital sovereignty. The adaptation of OpenTalk by regional governments demonstrates that European alternatives are technically feasible and competitive. Weaknesses and Barriers: Lack of Funding and Scalability: Many open-source projects fail due to insufficient long-term support and market access. Dominance of Non-European Providers: Public procurement often favors proprietary solutions, even when open-source alternatives exist. Fragmentation: The absence of EU-wide standards and coordination hinders interoperability and broad adoption. 3. Value of Open Source for the EU Open source is a key enabler of digital sovereignty, offering: Cost Efficiency: Reducing licensing costs and dependencies. Security: Transparent codebases enable faster identification and resolution of vulnerabilities. Innovation: Open standards foster collaboration and accelerate technological advancements. Competitiveness: European companies can develop and market their own, controllable solutions. Example OpenTalk: The adoption of OpenTalk by regional governments illustrates how open source combines data protection, scalability, and independence without compromising functionality or user-friendliness. 4. Proposals for EU Action a) Targeted Funding and Financing: EU-wide funding programs for open-source projects, particularly in critical areas such as cloud, AI, and cybersecurity. Public procurement guidelines that prioritize open source (e.g., mandatory criteria in tenders). Support for open-source business models, such as public-private partnerships or tax incentives. b) Standardization and Interoperability: Development of EU-wide standards for open-source solutions to avoid fragmentation. Creation of a central platform for sharing best practices and coordinating projects. c) Strengthening Collaboration: Mandatory open-source clauses in publicly funded IT projects. Expansion of competence centers for training and knowledge exchange. d) Prioritized Technology Areas: Cloud Infrastructure Secure Communication (video conferencing, email, messaging) AI and Data Management (GDPR-compliant frameworks)

Feedback as one of 5 directors of a SME with focus on building semantic data processing applications. 1/ What hampers adoption? We believe that it is in the first place a matter of perception at the side of IT decision makers. Local IT-administrators believe they are more sure and unburdened by the choice for an American platform with a name and larger customer base. Nobody has been fired for choosing {ORACLE}, {AWS}, {AZURE},.... Clear policy advice that quality open source is the better choice is required to change that mindset. At a second level the quality standards for open source code should be made more known. Maybe by introducing a quality label or score for high-quality and community supported open source products. Level of reuse, Level of incorporated standards, structure and ease of maintenance should be criteria of evaluation. 2/ Added value? In the first place: the re-use of proven code. By reusing existing services according to guidelines and established practices, we make our open source applications more robust. It makes the ecosystem also more transparant and trustworthy for third parties that need to interface with it. https://www.vlaanderen.be/lokaal-bestuur/digitale-transformatie/lokale-besluiten-als-gelinkte-open-data. This reduces the operational and maintenance cost (significant less persondays). However we can not compare to a license/maintenance cost for a legacy platform.. In the second place, while open source components are independent of each other, an open source framework is more suitable to engage in agile project setups, i.e; progressive, software development. You dont need to subscribe to a legacy of software and practices to get started with first steps in a digital transformation. This reduces the risk. Cf. the significant % of failed IT transformation projects. Third, a well-understood and properly applied open source guideline implies that as much as possible, international approved and applied web standards are used. Applying these standards in the core of code implies that the application may run for decades. 3/ Actions to support? In the first place the EU itself should foster and use the EU open source stack. E.g. the alternative for social media network X should not be marginal, but mainstream for EU officials. Same for emailing and document editing (word processors, spreadsheets, presentation and video calls). Second: Make a European based and real open github, financed by the EU. It is a disgrace that the most widely used platform for sharing and managing open source is owned by a commercial, non-European company. Third: active policy and promotion of open source as being ours, better for our economy and for governance. Fourth: A Major Marshall plan Horizon and NextGenerationEU or Relance plan and budgets for programs building open source frameworks that matter. 4/ What technology first? Technology of functionality? There should be general trustworthy and well functional EU alternatives for gmail, outlook, github, etc. They are key to alter perception and keep ownership of crucial data and processes. An area that is also defence related, is investing in infrastructure for geo-location and telematics like LEO and GEO satellite internet; in EU owned smartphone and laptop platforms while a number of comfort services come from devices that are anchored in that infrastructure (e.g. GPS). 5/ What sector? Government and Industry. Health is already rather independent from American dominance.

The importance of Open Source working and thinking is far greater than many realize. It touches the very foundations of our culture and our ability to determine our own future. Western society and present-day Europe are built upon the intellectual heritage of the Scientific Revolution and the Enlightenment. Having been born and raised in a free Europe, I have discovered over the years that much is not as free as we think or wish. Autonomy shares a profound relationship with technology. In fact, it is a conditio sine qua non. Computer science played an important role in my education. It is the tool through which science is conducted, products are designed, and business operations are run. Alongside mainframes, the first PC networks emerged. We used software packages acquired by the university at heavily reduced rates. This is how I learned to work with the latest software for matrix calculus and system design. Many at the university admired these developments. The supplier capitalized on this, visiting frequently with the latest tools. After my studies, I joined a manufacturer of radar systems. There, I discovered that software which costs almost nothing for education is enormously expensive for companies. Because the young professionals entering the workforce had almost all learned to work with the same software, more licenses had to be purchased. With the new tools, programming became more about "scripting" individual commands. It became clear that education and the tools used within it ultimately determined the way of working within the company. Furthermore, suppliers manipulated the market; initially, simple versions for local use were available, but over time, only expensive floating network licenses remained. Total software procurement costs amounted to 10-20% of turnover, and these costs were a regular topic during the discussion of results. To the question of whether costs could be reduced, the answer was invariably: "No, that is not possible; otherwise, we cannot work." After ten years in radar technology, the corporate way of working began to stifle me. Eventually, I ended up at a small manufacturing company with a strong cost-conscious culture and no room for conventional software packages. Forced by these circumstances, we developed our own solutions based on Open Source. The learning curve was significant; everything I had worked with for years had to be relearned. Not everyone understood this: wasnt software supposed to be bought from a major supplier? Here, I encountered the "educational barrier" again: why are we doing it differently than we were taught? After an intensive start, the reward was great. With ease, software from development, production, and the product itself could be linked. It was all built from the same transparent foundation, thought through right down to the source. This method harked back to the Scientific Revolution, a mindset we summarized in the credo: only if you master the technology, you can control your destiny. Maintaining this strategy for years brought the small company great success. Market data showed that, due to lower costs, we achieved a higher margin than the competition. Currently, we find ourselves in a time similar to ancient Troy, where the statue of Athenathe embodiment of technique and strategyhad been stolen. After a long struggle, the Trojans found the magnificent horse on the beach, which, despite the warnings of Cassandra, was brought inside as the solution for their loss. Greek mythology told us long ago what happens when you are not a master of the substance. Software is embedded in almost every modern tool. An Open Source work and thinking culture, coupled with the ability to manufacture the corresponding hardware ourselves, is of vital importance to our future. In keeping with our tradition of enlightenment, Europe must mandate Open Source as the standard practice in both education

The Open Ecosystem Revolution: A road to true digital freedom Digital sovereignty is not a luxury, it is a fundamental need in our technological age. The European Union’s strategy for open source ecosystems represents a crucial step towards freeing up our dependence on big tech corporations that have monopolised knowledge and innovation for decades. Why Open Ecosystems Historically Essential, we have allowed a few tech multinationals to control our digital world. This dependency has meant: Loss of privacy Limitation of innovation Concentration of technological power in the hands of a few corporate giants The commitment to open source is a declaration of technological independence. It represents a model where: Transparency is the fundamental principle Collaboration goes beyond closed competition Knowledge democratises Technological Sovereignty: More than a Strategy, a Law The EU initiative demonstrates that it is possible and necessary to build independent digital ecosystems. By strengthening the development of open digital assets, we not only protect our privacy, but also: We encourage local innovation and reduce technological dependence. We create a safer and more transparent environment. We have taken this path a long time ago. Every year we allow Big Tech to control our data, communications and information is a lost year for true digital freedom. The Future is Open Digital sovereignty is not an option, it is an imperative. Open ecosystems are the only way to ensure: Truly collaborative innovation Real protection of privacy Independent technological development It is time to break the chains of technological dependence and embrace a future where knowledge, code and innovation are

feedback:
Open source is meer dan een licentievorm; het is noodzakelijke infrastructuur. Open Nederland pleit voor een strategie die transparantie, innovatie en democratische waarden borgt volgens het principe: publiek geld = publieke code. ### De Nederlandse situatie: beleid en uitvoering Nederland hanteert sinds 2020 het beleid "Open, tenzij". Wij waarschuwen de EC voor een stap terug. Termen als "Open where appropriate" of open source als "experimenteel" zien ondermijnd bestaande ontwikkelingen en infrastructuur. De strategie moet niet gaan over het *opzetten* van een ecosysteem, maar het *versterken* van het huidige, fragiele ecosysteem door professionalisering en infrastructuur-financiering. ### 1. Sterktes, Zwaktes & Barrières Strengths: * Verankering van publieke waarden: waaronder transparantie, veiligheid, competitie (op diensten). * 2. Bewezen maatschappelijke en economische waarde: Bestaande Initiatieven als het EDIC en *opensourcewerken.nl* maken van de publieke sector een vliegwiel voor innovatie. Weaknesses: * Kennishiaten: Economische waarde vloeit weg naar andere regio's door gebrek aan business-kennis. * Afhankelijkheid: Europa mist soevereine open source infrastructuren. We leunen op Big Tech. * Onderhoud: Geld gaat naar 'nieuwe features' (projectfinanciering), niet naar beheer (infrastructuur). * AI-dreiging: AI-modellen, getraind op open code, ondermijnen het verdienmodel van dienstverleners en tasten de 'commons' aan. Barrières voor adoptie & bijdragen: * Financieringskloof: Subsidies stoppen na de innovatiefase; er is geen geld voor structureel onderhoud. * Aanbestedingen: Tenders stellen eisen aan organisaties die gemeenschappen uitsluiten. * Er mist een eis voor 'upstream contribution', waardoor leveranciers wel nemen maar niet geven. * Juridische onzekerheid: Wetgeving zoals de CRA creëert aansprakelijkheidsrisico's die individuele ontwikkelaars wegjagen. ### 2. Waardepropositie Publieke Sector: * Soevereiniteit: Geen vendor lock-in, volledige controle over eigen infrastructuur. * Vertrouwen: Controleerbare code en functionaliteit. * baten: Onderzoek (BZK, 2025) schat de maatschappelijke baten van Open Overheid op 4,4 miljard/jaar. Hergebruik voorkomt verspilling. Private Sector: * Snelheid: Startups bouwen op bestaande fundamenten. * Bewezen kracht: open source e-commerce wordt gebruikt door ca. 40% van de partijen. De waarde verschuift van licentieverkoop naar hoogwaardige dienstverlening. ### 3. EU-maatregelen Wij pleiten voor 4 structurele ingrepen: 1. Sovereign Tech Fund: Richt een fonds voor onderhoud en security van bewezen open source infrastructuur en veelgebruikte libraries (de digitale wegen en bruggen). 2. Veranker "Public Money, Public Code": Maak dit dwingend in wetgeving. Draai bij aanbestedingen de bewijslast om: *comply or explain* waarom er voor gesloten software & ontwikkeling wordt gekozen. 3. Verplicht Upstream Contributions: Gebruik inkoopmacht om het open ecosysteem te voeden. Eis in aanbestedingen dat leveranciers aantonen hoe zij bijdragen (tijd/geld) aan gebruikte open source projecten. 4. Bescherm de 'Commons' in AI/CRA Wetgeving: * Juridisch: Creëer *safe harbors* voor non-profit ontwikkelaars. * Financieel: Zorg dat AI-heffingen ook terugvloeien naar open source makers, niet alleen naar betaal-per-kopie rechthebbenden. ### 4. Prioriteiten & Sectoren Open source is geen sector, maar infrastructuur. Het is cruciaal voor *alle* sectoren, waaronder NIS2-vitale infrastructuur en infrastructurele concurrentiekracht tegenover Big Tech. Focus op de fundamentele infrastructuur (talen, libraries, encryptie) en publieke kernfuncties (digitale identiteit/wallets). Laat diensten over aan de markt. ### Conclusie Digitale soevereiniteit en een gezonde competatieve markt heeft een vitaal open source ecosysteem nodig. Dit ecosysteem is fragiel. Wij roepen de EC op: erken open source als publieke infrastructuur, f

column38: The diagnosed problem of the EU’s technological dependence is relevant, but the proposed measures (soft strategy, lack of impact assessment) are disproportionately weak in relation to security and competitiveness risks. “Encouragement” is not enough to break the network effect of US giants. It might be preferable to introduce a hard ‘Public Money?’ principle instead of voluntary recommendations. Public Code!", obliging any publicly funded software to be open-source by default, which would create a guaranteed outlet for European companies? I think a more effective strategy would be to make support for open-source conditional on the solution being hosted on infrastructure under EU jurisdiction, in order to prevent European open code from creating value mainly for non-EU cloud providers. Since technological sovereignty and cybersecurity are at stake, would it not be reasonable to carry out a full Impact Assessment to base the strategy on hard data on ROI and not only on political declarations? Instead of successive R & D grants that do not guarantee implementation, it would be better to reallocate funds to subsidise the implementation of European open-source solutions in the SME sector, which would really stimulate market demand and not only code supply?

feedback: Contribution to Call for Evidence Reference: Ares(2026)69111 Towards European Open Digital Ecosystems Topic: Strengthening Digital Sovereignty through Citizen-Centric Open Source Operating Systems Date: February 2, 2026 Submitted by: Filipe Cidraes, Lead Developer of Luper OS 1. Introduction We welcome the Commission's initiative to foster European Open Digital Ecosystems. As the development team behind Luper OS (a European-based Linux distribution project), we submit this evidence to demonstrate that the technology required for full digital sovereignty already exists. The challenge is no longer technical, but rather centered on User Experience (UX) and accessibility for non-technical citizens. 2. The Problem: The "Last Mile" of Sovereignty While the EU has made strides in server-side sovereignty (cloud infrastructure, Gaia-X), the "endpoint" the personal computer of the average citizen remains dominated by non-EU proprietary operating systems. This creates a critical vulnerability in the privacy chain. Regardless of how secure European clouds become, if the citizen's access point (the OS) is compromised by external telemetry or surveillance capitalism, sovereignty is breached. 3. Evidence from the Field: The Luper OS Case Study Luper OS serves as a proof-of-concept that a sovereign, GDPR-native desktop ecosystem is viable today. Infrastructure: By utilizing European hosting (Codeberg e.V., Germany) and building upon established open-source technology (openSUSE Leap 16), we have created a supply chain that operates entirely within EU jurisdiction. Security by Design: Utilizing immutable file systems and strict sandboxing (Flatpak), we demonstrate that "consumer-grade" ease of use can coexist with "enterprise-grade" security, without relying on Big Tech ecosystems. Privacy Default: Our telemetry-free approach proves that an OS can function efficiently without harvesting user data, aligning perfectly with the Data Governance Act. 4. Barriers to Adoption The primary barrier to a European Open Digital Ecosystem is not the lack of software, but the "fragmentation of trust" and the steep learning curve for non-technical users. Current market solutions prioritize vendor lock-in over interoperability. 5. Recommendations for the Commission Based on our experience developing Luper OS, we propose three key actions for the upcoming strategy: A. Support for "Consumer-Facing" Open Source: Funding instruments (such as NGI or Horizon) should explicitly target projects that improve UX/UI for non-technical users. To achieve sovereignty, Open Source must be as easy to use as proprietary alternatives. B. Sovereign Defaults in Public Administration: We urge the Commission to recommend that member states pilot sovereign OS solutions in public facing kiosks, schools, and municipal offices to create a critical mass of adoption. C. Recognition of "Digital Commons": Projects hosted on European non-profit platforms (like Codeberg) should receive a specific "Trusted European Asset" designation to help citizens distinguish them from commercial, data-harvesting alternatives. 6. Conclusion Luper OS stands ready to collaborate with the Commission as a testbed for these policies. We believe that a true European Open Digital Ecosystem begins at the desktop of every citizen. Respectfully, Filipe Cidraes, Luper OS Project https://luper-os.eu

Proposition de contribution dAtol CD et Arawa. Tous les éléments mentionnés ici sont détaillés dans le document attaché en pièce jointe. LOpen Source constitue bien plus quun choix technologique : cest un levier stratégique majeur. Il renforce la souveraineté numérique en réduisant la dépendance aux solutions propriétaires, favorise linteropérabilité et la portabilité des systèmes, et stimule linnovation collaborative par la mutualisation des efforts de développement. 1/ Valeur ajoutée de lOpen Source. Nous soulignons que lOpen Source nest pas seulement un choix technologique, mais une philosophie et un levier stratégique pour : - Renforcer la souveraineté numérique, - Promouvoir linteropérabilité et la portabilité des solutions, - Stimuler linnovation collaborative, - Assurer une transparence accrue de la sécurité logicielle, - Permettre une meilleure maîtrise des coûts, - la résilience des systèmes, - la réversibilité, - la durabilité des systèmes numériques, - l'effet structurant sur les compétences locales, - la séparation claire entre édition logicielle et service, - la réduction des risques juridiques à long terme. 2/ Obstacles à ladoption de lOpen Source (barrières identifiées) Malgré les bénéfices mentionnés, plusieurs obstacles freinent encore son adoption. Le financement et la pérennité de certains projets reposent largement sur des contributions bénévoles. La gouvernance des communautés peut être fragmentée et complexe à appréhender. Le support et la maintenance sont parfois perçus comme insuffisants, bien que des acteurs spécialisés existent. Des enjeux de compétences et de formation persistent face aux solutions propriétaires dominantes, et le poids des grands éditeurs rend les changements plus difficiles à justifier... Aussi des enjeux et des défis doivent être pris en compte pour une adoption réussie : a) Modèle économique et Financement des projets, b) Gouvernance et Fragmentation, c) Support et Maintenance, d) Enjeux de compétences et de formation, e) Domination des "Grands Acteurs". 3/ Propositions de mesures concrètes au niveau de lUE. Pour répondre à ces enjeux à léchelle européenne et pour renforcer lécosystème Open Source en Europe, plusieurs pistes pouvent être explorées : a) Création dun fonds européen dédié à lOpen Source, b) Développement dinfrastructures partagées pour lOpen Source, c) Renforcement des synergies entre acteurs publics et communautés, d) Renforcement de l'utilisation de formats standards et protocoles ouverts, e) Harmonisation des pratiques de gouvernance et des cadres juridiques, f) Accompagnement des structures par la commande et lévolution des critères de sélection. 4/ Conclusion LOpen Source nest plus simplement une alternative, mais une option stratégique à part entière. Bien accompagné, il combine innovation, maîtrise des coûts, sécurité et flexibilité, tout en offrant aux organisations les moyens de construire des systèmes durables et évolutifs. Adopter lOpen Source, cest faire le choix dune transformation numérique maîtrisée et tournée vers lavenir.

feedbackTextUserLanguage: As an initiative that popularises free software in rural areas (Wendland, Northern Germany), together with data protection and sovereignty, in workshops and lectures, we consider it particularly important that 1. Free software must be a public good, 2) public institutions should be a model for use and 3) funding and dissemination. It does not matter where (geographically) free software comes from. It is important that it respects and embodies the four fundamental freedoms. Free software is solidarity in action.

INESC TEC is the largest Portuguese non-profit Research and Technology Organisation (RTO) dedicated to Engineering, Science and Technology, with over 40 years of activity. Software is a foundational asset across all our scientific domains including Artificial Intelligence, Computer Science, Communications, Robotics, and Power and Energy Systems and underpins applications in strategic sectors such as Energy, Industry, Health, Sea and Defence. INESC TEC is directly involved in European digital infrastructures and policies, notably through high-performance computing (Deucalion, integrated in EuroHPC), and actively participates in European fora to articulate the role of RTOs in the digital transition, competitiveness and technological sovereignty. From INESC TECs perspective, opensource software (OSS) is a strategic instrument to maximise scientific, technological and innovation impact. Beyond dissemination, OSS enables adoption, interoperability, trust and long-term reuse, and plays a key role in shaping de facto standards. In several technological areas, particularly in software-intensive systems, OSS is increasingly an effective pathway to standardisation, allowing European solutions to gain relevance, visibility and influence in global value chains. INESC TEC has actively contributed to European OSS ecosystems through multiple R&I projects (e.g., INTERCONNECT, AI4RealNet, TSP2Net) transforming research outputs into reusable open-source components supported by defined governance pathways. In INTERCONNECT and AI4RealNet, software was released under permissive licences and hosted within Linux Foundation Europe to ensure neutral governance, industry engagement, and alignment with international standards, while enabling broader community engagement, reduced fragmentation, and improved reuse. Our impact spans dual-licensing strategies (e.g., Predico, YAKE), integration into international OSS ecosystems, and measurable uptake through citations, reuse and community participation, confirming OSS as a powerful mechanism for European technology diffusion and interoperable standards. Our practice also reveals structural challenges. High-quality, secure OSS faces barriers that are not primarily technical, but organisational, legal and economic. These include managing OSSpatent interfaces, aligning OSS with intellectual property and standardisation strategies, ensuring compliance (e.g. licensing, SBOMs), sustaining software post-project, and reconciling openness with proprietary cultures. OSS is not the same as free software: it incurs real governance, maintenance, security and community costs, and must be treated as a deliberate strategic choice. In response, INESC TEC recently launched a coordinated institutional OSS initiative that brings together its Board, Technology Transfer Office and selected research centres within a common governance and decision-making framework. Rather than introducing isolated tools, the initiative establishes a structured OSS lifecycle: an institutional GitHub provides a controlled entry point for open releases; an OSS portal for visibility and engagement; and internal guidelines and onboarding processes to support compliance, risk mitigation and valorisation, embedding OSS as a strategic, institution-wide practice. From an RTO perspective, open source delivers clear added value to both public and private sectors by reducing lock-in, fostering interoperability, accelerating innovation and strengthening cybersecurity. Yet, supporting OSS only through research projects is insufficient. A European open digital ecosystems strategy should treat OSS as a key standardisation and technological vector, with RTOs as neutral, long-term bridges between research, industry, start-ups and public authorities. Dedicated funding instruments, OSS-aware procurement, shared European infrastructure, and impact-oriented KPIs are key to sustaining, scaling,

feedback: Q1 Strengths, Weaknesses, and Barriers The EU open-source ecosystem provides the foundation for critical public services, yet it faces a structural "Operational Maintenance Gap." While programs like NGI fund new features, long-term maintenance of "Digital Commons" remains chronically undervalued. Key Barriers to a Fair Market: Discriminatory Procurement: Tenders frequently mandate "market share" thresholds or "3 reference implementations >100k users." These are non-proportionate and discriminatory toward European SMEs who provide specialized services for community-governed platforms. The Certification "Pay-to-Play" Barrier: Costs for security certifications (e.g., BSI/ANSSI, ~50k+) act as a regressive tax, preventing smaller European players from competing even when their technology is technically superior. Monoculture Risk: Concentrated funding (e.g., investing solely in one platform) creates a new form of "Single-Platform Dependency." The Sovereignty Trap: True strategic autonomy requires a diverse ecosystem. The EU must avoid replacing dependency on a single US vendor with dependency on a single EU platform. Over-consolidation creates systemic risk and stifles the contestability of the European digital market. Q2 Added Value and Examples Open source is the engine of the Interoperable Europe Act, enabling legal and technical reuse across administrations. Case Study (Scale & Security): The Baden-Württemberg educational platform serves 1.5 million users and has relied on Plone for over 15 years. This proves community-governed open source handles sensitive data (GDPR Article 8) with greater longevity than proprietary alternatives. Governance as a Safeguard: Plone is stewarded by an independent, non-profit foundation. This democratic model prevents "capture" by a single company, ensuring software remains a pure public good. This is vital for 2030 year public-sector lifecycles where vendor-dictated roadmaps represent a risk to continuity. Q3 EU-Level Measures The EU should transition from "innovation grants" to "sustainability infrastructure": European Digital Commons Fund: Provide multi-year (510 year) funding for security, maintenance, and Cyber Resilience Act (CRA) compliance. Anti-Monopoly Funding Strategy: Explicitly fund 35 mature ecosystems per use case (e.g., TYPO3, Plone, Drupal) to maintain a competitive and resilient landscape. SME-Friendly Procurement: Mandate that tender criteria be based on open standards and functional outcomes rather than market-share metrics. Certification Subsidies: Provide centralized support for BSI/ANSSI/CRA certifications to level the playing field for community-driven projects. Preference for Foundation-Led Governance: Prioritize solutions governed by non-profits over "Open Core" models to avoid recreating vendor lock-in. Q4 Priority Technology Areas Public Sector Infrastructure (GovTech/EdTech/eHealth): Areas requiring high-security, long-lifecycle stability. Transparent AI: Open-source CMS platforms should "host" AI tools to ensure compliance with the EU AI Act and maintain public trust through auditability. Q5 High-Impact Sectors Public Administration & Education: Plones success in German education proves open source meets the highest standards of data sovereignty at scale. Healthcare: Permanent archival and strict GDPR compliance align perfectly with mature, document-centric open-source platforms offering full data control.

As a European software vendor serving large enterprises, we struggle to find European alternatives for many critical components (cloud platforms, developer tooling, libraries). This creates structural dependence on non-EU platforms, reduces choice for customers, and weakens Europes resilience and ability to control critical digital infrastructure. Open Source Software (OSS) is the pillar of modern digital ecosystems, yet many widely used OSS projects remain chronically underfunded. This is a market failure: the benefits (security, innovation, interoperability, vendor choice) accrue broadly, but maintenance costs fall on a small number of maintainers. **OSS should be treated like public infrastructure**. Evidence (Economic Policy Research, attached): The Software Complexity of Nations measures countries software economic complexity using open-source activity on GitHub. In their ECIsoftware ranking (2020), Germany ranks #1, and 7 of the top 10 countries are European (DEU, NLD, FRA, POL, GBR, ITA, SWE); the overall top 10 are DEU, AUS, CAN, NLD, FRA, USA, POL, GBR, ITA, SWE. Europe is already producing globally leading digital capabilities; policy should ensure the OSS foundations those capabilities rely on are sustainably maintained and governed. Recommendations for the European Open Digital Ecosystems initiative: 1. Create a dedicated, multi-year funding mechanism for "critical OSS dependencies" used across the public sector and key industries to fund maintenance, security response, audits, release engineering, and governance (not just new features). 2. Build an EU "critical OSS" register based on dependency mapping, so funding targets the highest security and sovereignty risks. 3. Update procurement guidance so public buyers reward upstream contributions, open standards, and funded maintenance plans to reduce lock-in and strengthen European suppliers. If the EU wants resilient, sovereign digital ecosystems, it must fund critical OSS directly and sustainably like other essential infrastructure. References "The software complexity of nations" (S´andor Juh´asz, Johannes Wachs, Jermain Kaminski, C´esar A. Hidalgo): - Text version: https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0048733326000132 - Details like the country ranking are available in the "Supplementary Information" download. - Raw research data: https://github.com/sandorjuhasz/eci_software

Open-source solutions reach their full potential when they are grounded in shared, interoperable standards such as those developed under the Digital Convergence Initiative (DCI - https://spdci.org). Common standards provide open-source projects with technical coherence, legal clarity, and institutional credibility, making them easier to trust, procure, and integrate across public and private systems. At the same time, open-source implementations transform these standards from abstract specifications into reusable, secure, and production-ready components that can be tested, audited, and improved collaboratively. This two-way reinforcement significantly reduces vendor lock-in by ensuring portability and interoperability by design, while lowering entry barriers for SMEs, startups, and public administrations. It enables cross-border and cross-sector digital services to be deployed in practice rather than remaining isolated pilots for example, DCI brings together different Digital Public Goods such as OpenIMIS, OpenSPP, OpenG2P, OpenCRVS, and MOSIP, aligning them around common standards to achieve seamless interoperability across social protection, civil registration, disability registries, farmers registries and identity systems. Aligning EU support for open source with open standards-based implementation is therefore essential to scaling sustainable European digital commons, strengthening digital sovereignty, and accelerating market adoption.

The international standards authorities create barriers to open source adoption, in multiple ways: - they charge high fees for their publications - they use proprietary licences - their processes fail to keep pace with technical advances - their guidance and recommendations (e.g. ISO 26262) expressly impede adoption of well-proven open source projects. We have created an Open Source initiative at the Eclipse Foundation (which is based in the EU), called The Trustable Software Framework (TSF), which aims to be an open source model for achieving high confidence in cybersecurity and functional safety across the whole software supply chain. This removes friction and cost by establishing an open source standard which can be implemented and improved rapidly in public. TSF is particularly applicable for critical software-intensive systems e.g. cloud infrastructure, vehicles, medical devices etc. Concretely we believe that the EU community would benefit by investing to raise awareness of the TSF and applying the TSF model widely as a basis for demonstration of compliance across a broad range of domains including CRA, GDPR etc.

Io lavoro in una società in house di delle maggiori PA italiane. Tale società gestisce tutta la parte IT: gare, sviluppo, gestione, sicurezza, ... L'uso del software opensource è ampiamente diffuso, anche se non per tutto. Secondo me, data la situazione degli ultimi periodi, è obbligo, per la sicurezza nazionale ed UE e per la sovranità tecnologica nazionale ed UE, diversificare e dotarsi internamente di tecnologie e software con forte basi locali, all'interno delle singole nazioni e all'interno dell'UE. La soluzione ottimale, secondo me, è l'uso di software opensource perché da un lato permette la piena collaborazione tra diverse nazioni UE, ma anche esterne, ma al contempo permette ad ogni attore di svincolarsi da uno o più partner se diventano avversi all'UE. Questo approccio dovrebbe essere seguito ovunque. Dove non è possibile diversificare deve essere scelto (imposto) l'uso di software opensource, poiché questo è l'unico che permette di evitare un lock-in o una situazione di sudditanza verso i propri fornitori. Alla peggio, partendo dai sorgenti, è possibile implementare in proprio o tramite fornitori l'evoluzione delle applicazioni; senza dimenticarsi che poter vedere i sorgenti permette di effettuare analisi dettagliate del software per capire se sono presenti backdoor, malware o altro (come dimostrato con prodotti commerciali i cui sorgenti sono stati rilasciati dopo che l'azienda li ha abbandonati). Per ogni settore/area occorre imporre l'uso di un'alternativa opensource, ove attualmente si utilizzano prodotti proprietari, soprattutto di nazioni extra-UE; tale alternativa deve essere reale e poter essere usata in ogni situazione nel caso di abbandono di quella proprietaria. Avendo un'alternativa, all'interno di ogni realtà, si potrà, in modo più agevole e veloce, riuscire a superare eventuali problematiche verso tali rifornimenti "problematici" (quello che è accaduto con il gas russo recentemente potrebbe accadere con un servizio software extra-UE: aumento dei costi per motivi "inventati" per poi arrivare a forniture a singhiozzo e minaccia di blocco). L'alternativa deve essere presente per ogni singolo componente: dal sistema operativo per desktop, al sistema operativo dei telefonini; dalle forme di storage usate al cloud; ... Inoltre è indispensabile che i formati dei dati e le loro esposizioni devono essere aperti, interoperabili e usabili liberamente da chiunque; pena l'esclusione da bandi pubblici. Chi crea un proprio formato proprietario e poi pubblica delle specifiche che non lo rispettano e le fa certificare, deve essere escluso. Un altro punto fondamentale è avere un repository UE per il software libero, con una piattaforma UE che ne permetta lo sviluppo e la distribuzione. Visto che questo deve essere un punto strategico, allora tale servizio deve essere gestito direttamente dall'UE, magari solo come gestione di più prodotti di più società UE. Ci deve essere una golden power su tutti i prodotti opensource dichiarati strategici, nel senso che le società che li gestiscono devono avere almeno il 51% del capitale diretto o indiretto basato in UE. La UE deve fortemente appoggiare/imporre tali comportamenti, iniziando dall'autenticazione (permessa da qualsiasi dispositivo, con qualsiasi software) all'uso dei formati di interscambio. Tutto il resto passa in secondo piano. Se vi è una forte spinta e una forte volontà tutto il resto è superabile. Il costo che si potrebbe avere per un problema in futuro potrebbe essere catastrofico per l'intera UE, mentre il costo per implementare una resilienza e delle alternative UE risulterebbe irrisorio rispetto al primo scenario. Infine, secondo me, occorre implementare la possibilità di usare servizi non digitali, in modo da essere resilienti anche per qualsiasi tipo di catastrofe o attacco. grazie per l'opportunità di poter esprimere la mia opinione, anche se 4000 caratt

column40: Contribution from U.Di.Con. In response to the European Commission’s consultation on open digital ecosystems, the Committee views the issue, from the point of view of consumers, as central to freedom of choice, safety, the quality of digital services and the protection of fundamental rights online. It also highlights the criticality of the EU’s dependence on non-EU technologies and providers and the need for a European strategy on open source. The document acknowledges the strengths of open source (dynamic ecosystem, transparency and interoperability), but points to structural weaknesses such as fragmentation, lack of governance and stable funding for maintenance and security, as well as still widespread perceptions of lower reliability compared to proprietary software. Proposed actions include: stable financial support to strategic projects, sustainable governance models, integration of open source in public procurement, investments in audit/certification and technical support, together with digital literacy and accessibility and security requirements for software for citizens. Cloud, operating systems and networks, cybersecurity, AI, digital identity and platforms for digital public services shall be identified as priorities; greater use of allopen source is considered useful for competitiveness and cyber resilience in digital public administration, health, education, smart cities and the data industry.
column42: U.Di.Con. APS UNIONE PER LA DIFESA DEI CONSUMATORI

feedback: Open Source software is fundamental to Europe's digital sovereignty and critical infrastructure. As a strategic pillar of technological autonomy and industrial competitiveness, Open Source enables European innovation through its meritocratic culture, which preserves democratic values, openness, and knowledge sharing across borders. The transparency of source code and development communities makes Open Source inherently resilient against ownership capture, with numerous historical examples of communities successfully preserving collaboration through forks and new projects when individual companies attempted takeovers. The Open Source ecosystem's technical governance and neutrality are essential for maintaining a globally relevant and resilient European digital infrastructure. Recent geopolitical developments, such as Beijing's directive against US and Israeli cybersecurity software, demonstrate the business risks of relying on proprietary products from specific countries. Open Source offers strategic advantages by being developed and maintained by global communities independent of any single nation's interests or policies, ensuring business continuity regardless of international tensions. Current and future EU regulations must explicitly recognize Open Source's unique characteristics its collaborative development model and free-of-charge nature. Regulations should either fully exempt Open Source projects or ensure no additional burdens fall on projects and maintainers, safeguarding the ecosystem's health and sustainability. The EU should support Open Source maintainers through direct funding for development work and infrastructure, expanding initiatives like the Sovereign Tech Fund to European scale. EU research and innovation programs must mandate Open Source development from the outset with clear objectives for building sustainable communities. Project reviews should prioritize Open Source progress and community strength, with funding continuation dependent on genuine community emergence. European companies should be encouraged to actively participate through fiscal incentives and recognition within sustainability frameworks. Networks shaping resilient digital infrastructure should be supported through dedicated initiatives like a "European Open Source Summit." The EU must refrain from creating new Open Source licenses, including AI-specific ones. Existing widely-accepted licenses provide solid legal frameworks and ensure compatibility. The European Union Public Licenses (EUPLs) have had minimal impact and should be avoided to prevent ecosystem fragmentation. Education is crucial for long-term European leadership in digital technologies. Open Source software and development should be integral to curricula at all educational levels, fostering digital competencies, innovation, collaboration, and technology independence from an early age. This includes dedicated mentoring programs led by experienced engineers, embedding Open Source participation in future generation training. Regarding hardware-software interdependence, many Free and Open Source Operating Systems rely on proprietary 'binary blob' drivers for WiFi and graphics cards. Without source code, communities cannot fully audit, maintain, or improve these drivers. Rapid hardware changes make reverse engineering challenging, causing Open Source drivers to lag. The EU should fund FOSS driver development and reverse-engineering efforts. Current dependence on Microsoft signing key Secure Boot components ('shim') creates a single point of failure. If withdrawn, Open Source operating systems could be excluded from secure booting. The EU should require hardware vendors to allow Secure Boot keys signed by independent, neutral certificate authorities and promote establishment of such authorities free from single commercial entity control.

I work for a university as a (mostly) lecturer. The added value of open-source in education is immense it allows us to practically show the workings of the software to the students, and experiment with its various properties. While this sounds insignificant, turns out that all of around two dozen courses given by our department to some few hundred students each year now rely almost exclusively on open-source technologies. The shift happened not only for the didactic reason, but also for accessibility for students, transparency, and the capability to use the open-source as a base material for student's further work, like theses. For the courses I teach, I am not aware of closed-source equivalents that would allow me to continue teaching without dire impact on the course quality. The concrete measures to support open-source vary; there are already great funding opportunities for open-source software development and the grant agencies generally recognize the importance of open-source software artifacts (especially within the framework of "open science"), thus aligning the funding with open-source development goals. On the other hand, what is most detrimental to the fate of the resulting open-source software is the common acceptance of vendor-backed closed-source solutions as a default, often without any discussion or evaluation of alternatives. This happens quite widely within all of industry, education, healthcare and administration; most notably by the use of the well-known office and groupware suites by a "big tech" software company. It does not seem realistic to me to improve this situation by economic incentives or additional funding. The sole benefits of open-source deployment already provide sufficient reason for the choice, and we have to assume that these benefits are ignored simply because of network effects, and general reluctance to change, supported by push from the already established industry. As a concrete action, placing simple restrictions on the applicability of vendor-locked closed-source solution to software deployments, ideally at least in state-funded or EU-funded administration and education sectors, would thus provide the much-needed kick towards a comprehensive migration to open solutions. Implications of the eventual migration to open solutions are quite natural: Given the removal of many artificial vendor lock-ins, both private and public institutions are benefited by vastly reduced costs of migration towards different solutions, and by much improved chances of successfully developing and maintaining customized or own solutions. This in turn increases many organizational flexibility metrics of the institutions, and creates an interesting job market for the local software maintainers perhaps partially averting the massive disappearance of skill into the globalized tech industry.

Die Open Source Business Alliance begrüßt die Initiative der EU-Kommission für eine European Open Digital Ecosystem Strategy. Die EU-Kommission trägt hiermit in entscheidendem Maße dazu bei, die digitale Souveränität der europäischen Verwaltung zu stärken. Denn der Einsatz von Open Source Software verringert Abhängigkeiten von außereuropäischen proprietären Anbietern und stärkt Wahlfreiheit, Interoperabilität und die Fähigkeit, digitale Systeme im öffentlichen Interesse dauerhaft zu betreiben und weiterzuentwickeln. Bereits heute steht eine leistungsfähige europäische Open-Source-Industrie bereit, die digital souveräne Softwarelösungen entwickelt und anbietet. Durch signifikante Investitionen in den europäischen Open-Source-Sektor kann die EU-Kommission Resilienz, Herstellerunabhängigkeit, Kontroll- und Gestaltungsfähigkeit der digitalen Infrastrukturen sowie Innovationsfähigkeit und Wettbewerb in Europa sichern. So kann der dauerhafte Aufbau von Wertschöpfung, Kompetenzen und Fachkräften in Europa gewährleistet werden. Dies sind in diesem Zusammenhang besonders zentrale Handlungsfelder für die EU-Kommission: Public Money, Public Code: Alle Software, die mit öffentlichen Geldern entwickelt wird, muss der Allgemeinheit als Open Source Software frei zur Verfügung gestellt werden. Im EU-Vergaberecht müssen im Rahmen der Public Procurement Revision die vorrangige Beschaffung von Open Source Software, eine Open Source by Default Regelung sowie nachhaltige Vergabekriterien für die Beschaffung von Open Source Software verankert werden. Es müssen konkrete und messbare Ziele für die Umstellung der Verwaltung auf Open Source festgesetzt werden. Es müssen Schulungsprogramme für Open Source Software für Beamtinnen und Beamte eingerichtet werden. Das EC Open Source Programme Office muss ausgebaut und gestärkt werden, der Austausch zwischen Wirtschaft und Verwaltung muss gefördert werden. Wo die langfristige Wartung und Pflege kritischer Open-Source-Basiskomponenten nicht gesichert ist, muss der Staat unterstützen. In der angehängten Stellungnahme gehen wir ausführlich auf die Leitfragen aus dem Call for Evidence ein.
feedbackTextUserLanguage:
The Open Source Business Alliance welcomes the European Commission’s initiative for a European Open Digital Ecosystem Strategy. The European Commission is therefore playing a crucial role in strengthening the digital sovereignty of the European administration. Indeed, the use of open source software reduces dependencies on non-European proprietary providers and strengthens freedom of choice, interoperability and the ability to operate and further develop digital systems in the public interest on a permanent basis. Already today, there is a powerful European open source industry that develops and offers digitally sovereign software solutions. By investing significantly in the European open-source sector, the European Commission can ensure the resilience, independence of manufacturers, control and design of digital infrastructures, and innovation capacity and competition in Europe. This will ensure the sustainable development of value creation, skills and talent in Europe. These are particularly key areas of action for the European Commission in this context: Public Money, Public Code: All software developed with public money must be made freely available to the general public as open source software. feedback: For building this strategy I'm suggesting this prototype model that I'm attaching. It is a European Open Digital Innovation Ecosystem based in a full open digital stack that includes open digital infrastructure (from open chips at the bottom to the open AI platforms at the top) but also it is including open innovation in the governance of the ecosystem and a layer of the open digital democratic values that inspire it. It is the result of the research project Digital Collaboratory, funded by the Generalitat Government of Catalonia. 2023-24.

feedback: Tors feedback: # How to secure cybersecurity in open source projects: Strong cybersecurity for open source is a combination of two things: (1) investment in maintenance of the stack, and (2) investment in innovation. To encourage both of these areas, the EU can: - Invest in addressing technical debt, maintenance of open source solutions, and in securing supply chain weaknesses: https://www.sovereign.tech/ and https://www.opentech.fund/funds/free-and-open-source-software-sustainability-fund/ are great examples of funds that prioritize these areas of investments. - Invest in academic research and transitioning that research to practice: -- Foster the interest of the academic community in researching the security of open source solutions by investing in this type of research work. -- Create funds that will support open source solutions to implement defence mechanisms proposed by this research (transitioning into practice). - Create specific incentives for open source solutions to adopt cutting-edge security such as post-quantum cryptography to future proof encryption. # Importance of supporting open source digital rights tools to further security of EU tech sovereignty initiatives with local business and public sector: Open source digital rights tools is a technology sector that doesnt receive the same type of investment as other sectors. However, innovation in areas of privacy and cybersecurity often comes from digital rights projects. Take Signal as an example, not only Signal is a tool used by millions in the private and public sectors, but its protocol has also been adopted by other private tools from the industry: WhatsApp, Messenger, Google Chat, Skype, and so on. Another example is Tor Browser, which is now the base for Mullvad Browser, a privacy browser offered by the Swedish company Mullvad. There is a proposal for a Europe Digital Rights Fund [https://miaan.org/the-european-union-needs-a-digital-rights-fund/], which would be a great mechanism to invest in innovative open source digital rights tech that chooses privacy and security by design. This will help create and maintain gold-standard software that protects the digital rights of its users, as well as create the privacy and security building blocks for other technology. # While thinking locally you must understand that open source is global: And therefore supporting community contributor engagement and management activities to improve the health of volunteer contributor communities and the quality of their contributions must also be a global effort that considers global context. The strength of open source maintenance and innovation is its diverse community. The nature of open source communities is borderless. And its important to include that in the strategy. Recognize that some projects might have contributors from other regions or some solutions might depend on open sources developed from other regions. While thinking of financial incentive for open source that can boost the development of local solutions for Europe, it is important to also have flexibility to embrace the spirit of open source collaboration that will expand to regions outside of Europe.
