feedback: I've been a user of open source software since the beginning of this century. I've also contributed to some open source software in the past. What struck, amazed and impressed me from the start was how much was possible with software that was freely available. Since then, I believe many open source has become even better, whereas various paid-for software has only gotten worse: price hikes, anti-features, being forced into paid subscriptions, getting "AI" shoved into every nook and cranny without having been asked, the list is quasi endless. And over the last months, it has become abundantly clear that the enormous dependency on (mostly US) tech companies, with our software and data running in their clouds is an enormous liability. So I fully support the move to open source. I think obliging any company that does any work for a government, EU body or whatever other public institution would be a very good idea. This will promote re-use of solutions, and contribute to making better software that we all benefit from. It will also foster innovation, because when all this software is publicly available, people will get ideas to combine them in unanticipated ways: this is going to stimulate creativity in an major way. It will also put the EU on the map as a hotbed of software development and creativity. In the same vein, the Eurostack is a very good initiative for us to get our digital autonomy back. Which we sorely need, by the way. The way things stand, the EU will have great difficulty taking decisions that the US doesn't agree with, i.e. our autonomy is whatever the US decides to grant us, which is no autonomy at all. But no matter how good the Eurostack is or becomes, people and organisations will find it hard to impossible to migrate without mass-migration tools. Tools that no hyperscaler will willingly provide, because lock-in is their business model. Therefore, it is imperative to repeal Article 6 of the EU's own Copyright Directive, because as long as that exists, it is illegal to create such tools. This article allows our legal system to be abused to do these large corporations' dirty work for them. Repealing it will open the door to these mass-migration tools. But not only that. People could develop their own app stores that don't rip off everybody with a 30% tax. We could develop alternative clients for Facebook, Threads, Instagram, streaming platforms, or anything else, that leave out the ads, the AI slop, and don't spy on their users. Repealing this article is going to be both a necessary condition to get to a viable EU alternative cloud stack, as well as a tremendous business opportunity for EU people and companies.

I'm an individual developing open-source software. My most popular product is raylib, a C graphics library intended to draw graphics in mostly any kind of screen, used for videogames development, tools, web applications, embedded devices, automotive displays, academia simulation/research software and more. raylib has become very popular in the last 12 years, thanks to its portability, wide range of applications supported and its free and open source license. For 12 years I've been working on raylib almost on a daily basis, while managing to live by getting some contract work and working as a University teacher. For some periods of time I've also been able to work full-time on this project, living from my savings. I'm sharing this feedback from my personal experience working as a solo-developer on a popular open-source project. I defined the main challenged I found as the THREE-Ms [MMM]: - Maintenance: Despite trying to keep the project as simple and small as possible, to date it has grown to support +20 platforms and has been adapted to +50 programming languages. Maintaining such a big project is not easy. Considering it is an open-source project, contributors are expected to help with its maintenance but many times contributions are limited to adding some new features or solving some issues. There is rarely a long-term commitment to the project or even code-ownership from many contributors. It implies work and burden for the maintainer of the project. - Motivation: Working on a project solo for so long has an impact on motivation. Even being very passionate about the project, the fact of solving issues for months with barely any retribution could feel like a full-time unpaid job. Additionally, working as a solo developer on a big project can be very isolating, generating an impact on motivation. - Money: I think this is the biggest problem with open-source. It's effectively very difficult to make money or even build a business around it, especially for a solo-developer. Even in the case of getting some money thanks to user-donations or some institutional fund like NGI0, there many other concerns: * Uncertainty: It's uncertain how long those donations could last or if there will be further funds. * Legal entity: Some countries could not have a legal regulation that considers donations/funds received for open-source development, specially operating as an individual. * Life stability: It is very difficult to plan for the future as an individual developing open source software. For all those reasons, I think many amazing open-source projects developed by individuals get abandoned after some years. Possible actions to improve that situation: 1. Create a Directory of Certified/Verified/European-supported/recommended open-source software. Projects included in the Directory can be directly supported by the European Union, with 5-year maintenance agreements to ensure stability and long-term commitment. So, institutions willing to use OSS can check available verified options and implement them with some guarantee that the software will be supported by a certain time with fixes and improvements. 2. Create an European OSS Association to work as an umbrella and support for small/individual OSS development groups, specially on legal multi-country matters. Also as a meeting point of open-source developers, to connect with others and share knowledge and opportunities. The association could also provide some physical space for small teams or individuals wanting to work in an office, even sharing equipment. 3. Connect with per-country governments to use already available resources. Many countries/cities have institutions to help startups/entrepreneurs but, in my experience, those institutions could not be aware of the impact and potential of open-source software. Consequently many of their services are not target to open-source developers. Thank you very much for this

feedback:
1.L'open source ha due grandi debolezze: La prima) soffre da sempre di pregiudizi e scorretta considerazione, lopen source è considerato non professionale, non sicuro, non manutenuto, in una parola non supportato. La seconda) open source è una coppia di parole che riporta al concetto di soluzione software gratuita, quindi intrinsecamente non considerata professionale. I punti di forza sono innumerevoli, noi ne sottolineiamo solo alcuni: protocolli aperti e migliorabili, community attive di sviluppatori, modelli di business basati non su pagamento di licenze ma di supporto, nessun lock-in tecnologico, nessun lock-in di fornitore, ecc.. Ostacolo principale alla diffusione di ciò che già esiste e alla realizzazione di nuove soluzioni open source nei settori in cui non ha ancora fatto breccia sono gli investimenti, non vengono messi soldi dagli stati su queste tecnologie, al contrario di quello che si fa con soluzioni commerciali ben note. 2. Qual è il valore aggiunto dell'open source per i settori pubblico e privato? Per chi lavora da sempre con tecnologie open source come ITServicenet, questa domanda risulta retorica. Non si parla di discutere del valore aggiunto per i settori pubblico o privato che sono scontati, ma di valore recuperato. Oggi molte realtà sono così legate alle soluzioni software che utilizzano da non potersi mantenere operative in caso di dismissione delle stesse, questo le rende facilmente ricattabili, aumenti di prezzi di qualunque tipo sono possibili da parte dei fornitori che hanno in pugno i loro clienti. Lopen source cambia paradigma, chiunque può usare queste soluzioni e decidere di pagare per un supporto in base a certificazioni, dimostrata affidabilità, autorevolezza e perché no, proposta economica del fornitore di turno, ma non è obbligato a farlo, il software continuerà a funzionare. Inoltre è naturalmente e intrinsecamente favorita la turnazione dei fornitori abilitati in caso si renda necessaria. 3. Vanno favorite e incentivate le realtà che studiano, usano, sviluppano, testano, implementano e soprattutto supportano lopen source. Devono essere favorite con incentivi economici diretti o indiretti, stimolando i possibili acquirenti di queste soluzioni a sceglierle. Lo stesso deve valere per la formazione su questi strumenti, che va erogata sia agli utilizzatori che ai decisori, senza consapevolezza su quello che possono ottenere resteranno sempre ancorati ai pregiudizi suddetti. Necessario investire anche nella formazione dei tecnici. Abbiamo un vuoto di competenza sui sistemisti che operano nelle PMI. Vanno sfavoriti invece tutti i bandi pubblici che ricadono sempre sui soliti servizi closed esterni il controllo EU. Va superato lalibi dei servizi erogati in Europa dai soliti noti, che non impedisce agli stessi di fare il bello e il cattivo tempo su tecnologie e dati che vengono ospitati. 4. Quali settori tecnologici dovrebbero essere considerati prioritari, e perché? Infrastruttura e cloud. È urgente e strategico liberarsi dalle dipendenza di stati terzi che agiscono sulle loro tecnologie e tramite le stesse in modo completamente diverso da quello che impongono le norme europee. 5. Non esiste un settore in cui lutilizzo di tecnologie open source non porterebbe ad un miglioramento generale di competitività, resilienza e sovranità digitale. Sia nel mondo pubblico che nel mondo privato piattaforme, protocolli, software e in genere soluzioni basate sullopen source supportato rappresentano ad oggi una delle principali vie per permettere ad ogni singola nazione europea e dunque a tutta lEuropa nel suo complesso di tornare competitiva e libera. Se si deve partire un settore in particolare quello pubblico è prioritario, ma è seguito a ruota da quello privato, dove diventa sempre più importante recuperare la sovranità del dato e lindipendenza digitale Oggi è possibile avere soluzioni open source su tutto lo

feedback: Parlo da sistemista italiano, ho trentanni e dieci anni passati a gestire virtualizzazione, rete e storage in ambienti tuttaltro che da laboratorio: ospedali, pubbliche amministrazioni grandi e piccole, PMI, realtà dove se qualcosa cade non è un test, è un problema vero. Quello che scrivo su Proxmox non nasce da entusiasmo da forum, ma da lavoro quotidiano. Proxmox è una piattaforma che funziona perché è pensata da tecnici per tecnici. Non cerca di nasconderti cosa succede sotto, non ti tratta da utente finale: ti dà controllo. KVM, LXC, ZFS, Ceph, rete, cluster, tutto è lì, leggibile, gestibile. Se cè un problema lo puoi capire, non devi pregare un vendor. Il fatto che sia sviluppato in Europa (Made in EU) per me conta davvero. Non per bandiera, ma perché oggi parlare di sovranità tecnologica, open source e riduzione del lock-in non è teoria: è esattamente la direzione indicata dallEuropa per uscire dalla dipendenza da piattaforme chiuse e attori extra-UE Proxmox in questo senso è perfettamente allineato. Una cosa va detta chiara: non è un gioco da homelabbers. Il fatto che si possa usare anche in homelab è un pregio, non un limite. In produzione, se progettato bene, Proxmox è resiliente, stabile e affidabile. Lho visto reggere carichi seri, aggiornamenti delicati, migrazioni live e situazioni poco simpatiche senza fare una piega. Altro punto spesso sottovalutato: supporto e community sono fortissimi. La community è tecnica, concreta, niente fuffa. Il supporto ufficiale, quando serve, risponde e sa di cosa parla. Non sei mai lasciato solo, ma non sei nemmeno ingabbiato. Io non parlo da fanboy. Parlo da lavoratore che deve dormire tranquillo la notte. E Proxmox, oggi, è una di quelle piattaforme che ti fanno dormire un po meglio.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: I am an Italian system engineer and have been managing virtualisation, network and storage in all-round environments for thirty-nine and ten years. hospitals, large and small public administrations, SMEs, where something goes wrong is not a test, is a real problem. What I write on Proxmox is not a forum enthusiasm, but a daily work. Proxmox is a platform that works because it is designed by technicians for technicians. Do not try to hide what happens below, do not treat you as an end user: it gives you control. KVM, LXC, ZFS, CEPH, network, clusters, everything is there, readable, manageable. If there is a problem you can understand, you don’t need to ask a vendor. It really matters to me that it is developed in Europe (Made in EU). Not by flag, but because nowadays talking about technological sovereignty, open source and reduced lock-in is not theoretical: it is precisely the direction that Europe has chosen to move out of dependence on closed platforms and non-EU actors Proxmox in this sense that is perfectly aligned. One thing is clear: it is not a homelabbers game. The fact that it can also be used in homelab is a value, not a limit. In production, if well designed, Proxmox is resilient, stable and reliable. LHO is faced with serious loads, delicate updates, live migrations and unfriendly situations without folding. Another point often underestimated: support and communities are very strong. The community is technical, concrete, nothing frivolous. The official support, when it is needed, answers and knows what it is talking about. You are never left alone, but you are not even caged. I don’t speak it from fanboy. I speak as a worker who has to sleep quiet at night. And Proxmox, today, is one of those platforms that make you sleep a bit better.

feedback: I welcome the Public Consultation on European Open Digital Ecosystems by the European Commission, but I do so with great concern and scepticism regarding the outcome of the final decisions. In 2008, the EU had its first real opportunity to initiate what is now the stated aim of European Open Digital Ecosystems and European digital sovereignty. Why 2008? That was the year of the infamous fast-track approval of ISO/IEC 29500, more precisely the OOXML file formata specification that, despite its status as an international standard, is controlled solely by a multinational corporation that has been prosecuted and found guilty of monopolistic behaviour. Searching for the keyword ODF in this public consultation, only seven contributions mention the Open Document Format, a standard that should have been mandated long ago for all public entities in the EU. Under the false argument of choice, and used by actors within the European Parliament to preserve the status quo, Europe has retained both a technological burden and a form of digital sovereign debt, not to mention the waste of public money. This technological burden exists because any softwareexcept that of the monopolistic incumbenthas had to allocate significant resources merely to be compatible, a situation from which the incumbent benefits immensely. Had ODF become the de facto file format, Europe would by now have almost two decades of a fair and competitive market. The key takeaways from the infamous fast-track of ISO/IEC 29500 are the following: -The ISO fast-track process for OOXML was complex and highly contentious. -The initial ballot failed in September 2007, triggering a -Ballot Resolution Meeting (BRM). -After BRM revisions and vote reconsiderations, the standard passed in April 2008. -Appeals delayed final resolution until mid-August 2008, with official publication occurring in November 2008. Throughout this process, ISO/IEC 29500 preserved legacy-compatibility constructs from the original ECMA specificationparticularly in the Transitional conformance classso that existing Office documents would not be broken by the new standard. These specific legacy constructs, however, continue to negatively affect interoperability across implementations. So, again, I welcome the initiative for a European Open Digital Ecosystems, but if the institutions failed us in a fundamental aspect of Digital Sovereignty, and are still proactively ignoring it, seems to me that these are constructs on top of pillars of sand.

**Jonas Sterr| ProxForge | Official Proxmox Partner | Passau** **1. Stärken/Schwächen & Barrieren:** **Stärken:** Europa hat hervorragende Open-Source-Projekte wie Proxmox VE, SUSE oder Nextcloud. Diese entsprechen europäischen Datenschutzstandards und die Communities arbeiten transparent. **Schwächen:** Viele gute Projekte bleiben klein und unbekannt. Es fehlt an Marketing und professionellem Support. **Adoptions-Barrieren:** Der größte Engpass ist fehlendes Know-how. Es gibt kaum Ausbildung zu Open-Source-Technologien in Schulen und Berufsschulen. Unternehmen finden keine qualifizierten Fachkräfte. Dazu kommen Bedenken wegen fehlendem Enterprise-Support und falsch eingeschätzte Gesamtkosten. Öffentliche Ausschreibungen bevorzugen bekannte proprietäre Produkte. **Contribution-Barrieren:** Die Pflege bestehender Software wird nicht finanziert - nur neue Features zählen. Viele Entwickler arbeiten unbezahlt und brennen aus. Unternehmen nutzen Open Source, geben aber nichts zurück. **2. Mehrwert:** **Öffentlicher Sektor:** Volle Kontrolle über die IT-Infrastruktur. Unabhängigkeit von Anbietern. Lizenzkosten entfallen. Transparenz und Datenschutz durch offenen Code. Regionale Wertschöpfung. **Privatwirtschaft:** Schnellere Entwicklung durch Wiederverwendung. Kein Risiko durch Preiserhöhungen. Anpassbarkeit an eigene Bedürfnisse. **Aus meiner Praxis als Trainer:** Bei Migrationen von VMware zu Proxmox VE entfallen die Lizenzkosten komplett. Langfristig sind die Gesamtkosten deutlich niedriger bei voller Kontrolle. Das größte Problem ist aber: Es fehlen Fachkräfte mit Open-Source-Know-how. Die Nachfrage nach Schulungen steigt stark, aber das Angebot in der Ausbildung ist viel zu gering. Wer heute in der Berufsschule lernt, kennt meist nur proprietäre Systeme. **3. EU-Maßnahmen:** **(A)** Bildungsoffensive: Open Source muss in Schulen, Berufsschulen und Universitäten Standard werden. Nicht als Randthema, sondern als Kernbestandteil der IT-Ausbildung. Lehrkräfte brauchen Fortbildungen. Nur so bekommen wir genug Fachkräfte. **(B)** Regionale Kompetenzzentren: In jedem EU-Land Anlaufstellen für Beratung, Schulung und Support. Eng verzahnt mit Schulen und Universitäten. **(C)** Öffentliche Beschaffung: Open Source bei Ausschreibungen bevorzugen. Verbot von Abhängigkeiten. **(D)** Nachhaltige Finanzierung: Auch Pflege und Wartung fördern, nicht nur Innovation. **(E)** EU-Infrastruktur: Hosting und Code-Verwaltung europäisch betreiben. **(F)** Unternehmens-Anreize: Open-Source-Beteiligung steuerlich fördern. **(G)** Sicherheits-Standards: Einheitliche Prüfverfahren. **(H)** Migrationsprogramme: Behörden beim Umstieg unterstützen. **4. Technologie-Prioritäten:** **(1)** Virtualisierung: Höchste Priorität. Die VMware-Situation zeigt die Risiken von Abhängigkeiten. Proxmox VE ist eine europäische Alternative. **(2)** Cloud und Edge Computing: Für europäische Datenhoheit essentiell. **(3)** Cybersecurity: Kritische Infrastrukturen brauchen prüfbare Software. **(4)** Künstliche Intelligenz: Offene KI-Modelle ermöglichen Transparenz. **(5)** Datenspeicherung: Unabhängigkeit von proprietären Systemen. **5. Sektoren:** **(A)** Öffentlicher Sektor: Kosteneinsparungen, digitale Souveränität, Datenschutz. **(B)** Gesundheitswesen: Datenschutzkonforme Systeme, Zusammenarbeit. **(C)** Finanzwesen: Innovation, Modernisierung, Sicherheit. **(D)** Telekommunikation: Kosten senken, Risiken reduzieren. **(E)** Energie: Prüfbare Systeme, Versorgungssicherheit. **(F)** Industrie: Interoperabilität, keine Abhängigkeiten. **Fazit:** Open Source ist der Schlüssel zu digitaler Souveränität. Die Technologie ist vorhanden. Was fehlt: Ausbildung, koordinierte Förderung und nachhaltige Finanzierung.

feedback: Dear Commission Reviewer, On behalf of OSI Europe Foundation and the Open Source Initiative, wed like to thank you for this opportunity to provide feedback on the European Open Digital Ecosystem Strategy. The Open Source Initiative (OSI) is a global charity at the heart of the Open Source Community for over 25 years, recognized globally as the authority defining Open Source. OSI Europe Foundation is its independent European chapter. The Open Digital Ecosystem Strategy comes at a pivotal time for Europe. As geopolitical instability intensifies, we concur with the Commissions view that digital sovereignty is a crucial goal. This involves Europe building and deploying competitors to the solutions on which it currently depends. We believe that Open Source Software (from herein FOSS) is the best way to achieve that goal. By embracing FOSS as a means to achieve this goal, Europe can compete with dominant technology players at a fraction of the cost, harnessing expertise from around the world to drive competitiveness, security and economic growth, while retaining digital sovereignty. With Europe contributing nearly 20% of global Open Source development, and EU developers being the largest group of contributors to Open Source on Github, the ecosystem represents Europes Silicon Valleya dynamic, decentralized hub of expertise and collaboration. This response contains a selection of proposals to achieve that goal. Including both non-legislative proposals the Commission can undertake to achieve that goal, as well as opportunistic changes that can be made to laws that are currently under revision. Please see the attached document for our full detailed response to all questions.

feedback:
Strengths & weaknesses of the EU open-source sector Strengths Low total cost of ownership open-source have no hidden licensing fees, allowing organisations to replace expensive proprietary stacks with a single, integrated solution. No vendor lock-in Customers can run the software on any hardware and can submit patches to add additional functionality that automatically benefits all others. High transparency code can be inspected, audited and improved by anyone. Large, active developer community that drives rapid innovation and bug-fixes. Concrete example Cost No licence fees, lower total cost of ownership. Reduces CAPEX and OPEX, especially for SMEs and public administrations. Enterprises pay only for support subscriptions while the software itself is provided through the open-source licences. Risk & security Source code is publicly auditable, enabling quicker vulnerability detection and remediation. Proxmoxs 100% open-source nature allows users to inspect security patches immediately. Vendor lock-in Freedom to move workloads between providers or on-premises without re-architecting. Innovation Community contributions add features faster than closed-source road-maps. Keeps the stack up-to-date with emerging technologies without waiting for a vendor roadmap. Interoperability Open Source simplifies integration with existing tools and software. Concrete EU-level measures & actions Dedicated maintenance grants for critical open-source infrastructure to ensure long-term security updates. Tax credits or subsidies for companies that contribute code or fund development of complementary modules. Standardised open-source procurement guidelines that recognize 100 % open-source solutions without hidden licensing fees. EU-wide certification programme for open-source security to build trust in sovereign-cloud stacks. Training & up-skilling programmes (EU-funded bootcamps) focused on important infrastructure software. Prioritise open-source alternatives whenever they are available and demonstrably fundable for long-term use this leverages the inherent cost-efficiency and vendor-independence of open-source solutions. Legislation and regulation must not discourage small or emerging open-source projects, overly restrictive rules push innovators toward non-EU investors, undermining the EUs strategic goal of technological sovereignty. The EU should therefore create a regulatory environment that lowers entry barriers for nascent projects while still ensuring security and compliance. What technology areas should be prioritised and why? The EUs most effective way to achieve digital sovereignty is to secure the underlying infrastructure first, rather than concentrating only on end-user-oriented services. If the EU were to fund and standardise similar open-source solutions across the infrastructure layer, it could build a sovereign cloud that matches the functionality of the large hyperscalers without being locked into vendors that have little incentive to support open-source alternatives. Focusing on this foundational layer also reduces the devil-on-the-wall narrative that proprietary players use to discourage open-source adoption. By promoting proven, open technologies, the EU can: Retain control over data and services No hidden licences or vendor-specific APIs. Lower total cost of ownership The software is free, only support contracts are optional, which keeps budgets predictable. Accelerate innovation The open code base allows rapid security patches and feature extensions, unlike the slower release cycles of many commercial stacks. In short, securing the infrastructure with open-source platforms is the pragmatic foundation for an EU-wide sovereign infrastructure, while end-user initiatives can build on top of that trusted base. Sectors that could an increased use of open source lead to increased competitiveness and cyber resilience FE Public administration Telecommunication

column72: OPA) to build enterprise-grade solutions. 1. The Paradox: Governance over Geography Open Source has no boundaries. A ""European"" approach must be defined by Strategic Autonomy and Governance
column73: not code origin. Sovereignty of Governance: A project is ""European"" if governed by transparent frameworks anchored in EU legal values
column74: preventing non-EU entities from unilaterally changing licenses. Economic Retention: ""Buying European"" means investing in the local ecosystem of SMEs and experts who provide maintenance
column75: keeping value within our borders. 2. Maintenance: The Bedrock of Cybersecurity A major blind spot is the focus on ""new"" features over the maintenance of existing foundations. Resilience as Investment: Cybersecurity is a continuous process. Many critical EU infrastructures rely on underfunded libraries. The EU must treat professionalized maintenance as a strategic investment in cybersecurity to reduce systemic vulnerabilities cost-effectively. 3. Living Hubs: Lowering Barriers via Coordination Technology alone is insufficient; we need the organizational ""glue."" Strategic CSAs: We advocate for ""Living Hubs"" to act as mobilizers
column76: growing awareness and providing legal/technical ""help desks"" for SMEs. These hubs bridge the gap between developers and industrial adopters. 4. Concrete Policy Levers Procurement Reform: Favor open source by default and separate software from service costs to empower local SMEs. Fiscal Incentives: Tax deductions for companies transitioning to or contributing to sovereign open-source stacks. Education: Integrate open-source governance into core digital training. 5. Realizing Autonomy: Beyond ""Bragging"" Regulation is defensive; Open Source is an offensive strategy. The only path to reducing dependency on Big Tech is to provide competitive
column77: sovereign alternatives. Treating open source as a strategic industrial asset builds an auditable foundation immune to vendor lock-in. 6. Critical View on EuroStack Martel views EuroStack as a necessary but high-risk ambition. To succeed
column78: it must avoid ""political protectionism."" A sovereign stack cannot be built by decree; it must be earned through technical excellence and developer experience. EuroStack should be a curator and guarantor of interoperability
column79: focusing on the vital work of ensuring best-of-breed European components (from Cloud-native to AI) work together seamlessly at an industrial grade
column80: rather than creating redundant tools. Conclusion Martel Innovate advocates for shifting from ""Open Source as a Research Topic"" to ""Open Source as an Industrial Policy."" By focusing on maintenance

feedback: L'opensource est aujourd'hui critique pour garantir la souveraineté, la transparence et la sécurité des systèmes d'information. C'est un écosystème riche, mais qui nécessite un support réglementaire et financier pour déployer toute sa valeur. Les principaux points sur lesquels l'UE peut faire une différence sont à mon sens les suivants : - "public money, public code" : une règlementation exigeant que l'argent public donne lieu à du code public ( licence libre OSI ) - une préférence aux solutions OpenSource dans les appels d'offres publics, avec un avantage systématique en terme de scoring, et une demande "opensource par défaut" systématique - le soutien aux PMEs : l'opensource est majoritairement développé par des PMEs, et l'expertise s'y situe. Ces dernières sont souvent exploitées par les ESN et autres grandes entreprises, sans qu'elles aient de retour financier. Le soutien actif aux PME de l'écosystème devrait être une priorité - éviter l'enshittification, le pull-rug : il faut favoriser explicitement les organisations qui n'ont pas de financements VC, qui sont des entreprises établies en europes, et particulièrement celles qui ont des engagements ( légaux, contractuels, de statuts ) permettant de garantir la pérennité de leur positionnement envers le bien commun pour tous et pour les utilisateurs. Et également favoriser les projets opensource qui ont un écosystème garantissant leur pérennité dans le temps ( qui ne dépendent pas d'une seule entité ) - financements directs simplifiés : les mécanismes de financement direct de l'opensource par l'UE sont efficaces si ils sont accessibles aux membres des communautés et aux contributeurs directs. Cela nécessite d'avoir des guichets de financement à l'accès simplifié d'un point de vue administratif. Les programmes NGI0 sont un très bon exemple de fonctionnement efficace, mais leur dotation devrait être démultipliée - Programmes de financement spécifiques pour les éléments difficilement finançables des projets opensource : maintenance, packaging, sécurité, organisation communautaire, communication, UX/UI - Mise en place d'équipes d'experts au sein de l'UE servant des services aux communautés de façon gratuite, pour tous les aspects qui peuvent manquer dans les communautés de développeurs : experts en design, sécurité, marketing, communication, packaging, legal - "eat your own dog's food" : les services de l'UE eux-mêmes devraient être opensource et de nature européenne : email, collaboratif, visio, réseaux sociaux Cette liste n'est pas exhaustive, et d'autres initiatives peuvent évidemment être particulièrement pertinentes.
feedbackTextUserLanguage:
OpenSource is now critical of ensuring the sovereignty, transparency and security of information systems. It is a rich ecosystem, but it requires regulatory and financial support to unlock its full value. The main points on which the EU can make a difference are, in my view, the following: — ‘public money, public code’: regulations requiring public money to give rise to public code (OSI Free Licence) – preference for OpenSource solutions in public tenders, with a systematic advantage in terms of scoring, and a systematic ‘OpenSource by default’ demand – support for SMEs: OpenSource is mainly developed by SMEs, and expertise is located there. The latter are often exploited by NSEs and other large companies, without any financial return. Active support for SMEs in the ecosystem should be a priority – avoid enshittification, pull-rug: organisations that do not have VC funding, which are companies established in Europe, should be explicitly favoured, especially those with commitments (legal, contractual, articles of association) to ensure their continued position towards the common good for all and for users. And also support O

feedback: Contributo alla consultazione pubblica sulliniziativa Ecosistemi digitali aperti europei Introduzione Il presente contributo risponde allinvito della Commissione Europea a definire una strategia che rafforzi la sovranità tecnologica e la cibersicurezza dellUnione. Si propone una transizione strutturale verso modelli Open Source, individuando nella Pubblica Amministrazione (PA) il motore di un cambiamento capace di generare un effetto sistemico sullintero mercato digitale europeo. feedbackTextUserLanguage: Contribution to the public consultation on the European Open Digital Ecosystems Initiative Introduction This contribution responds to the European Commission’s call for a strategy that strengthens the Union’s technological sovereignty and cybersecurity. We propose a structural transition to Open Source models, identifying public authorities as drivers of change that can have a systemic effect on the entire European digital market. [See attached document]

feedback: Stellungnahme der inett GmbH zur Open-Source-Initiative Als Geschäftsführer der inett GmbH begrüße ich diese Initiative als wesentlichen Schritt für die technologische Souveränität der EU. Open Source ist das Fundament eines sicheren digitalen Ökosystems. Kernpunkte unseres Feedbacks: - Souveränität & Sicherheit: Quelloffene Lösungen verringern Abhängigkeiten von Nicht-EU-Ländern und bieten durch Transparenz in der Lieferkette eine hohe Sicherheit für IT-Systeme sowie die einfache Möglichkeit zur Anpassung und Erweiterung. Innovation auf Basis existierender Lösungen ist schneller und kostengünstiger. - Wirtschaftlicher Hebel: Da Open Source bereits 7090% moderner Softwarelösungen ausmacht, muss die EU sicherstellen, dass die Wertschöpfung in Europa verbleibt und nicht primär globalen Technologiegiganten zugutekommt. - Wachstumsbarrieren abbauen: Ein verbesserter Zugang zu öffentlichen Aufträgen und Wachstumskapital für europäische Open-Source-Akteure stärkt innereuropäische Marktteilnehmer und führt letztlich zu Wertschöpfung innerhalb Europas. - Über Forschung hinaus: Die Förderung darf nicht bei Innovation enden. Wir benötigen Anschubfinanzierungen zur Entwicklung oder Weiterentwicklung offener Lösungen und nachhaltige Rahmenbedingungen für die industrielle Einführung und kommerzielle Tragfähigkeit. Wir unterstützen insbesondere den Fokus auf lokal, national oder europäisch betreibbaren KI-Initiativen, Open Source Software und offene Hardware. Diese Technologien müssen auf vertrauenswürdigen, interoperablen Fundamenten beruhen, um die langfristige Wettbewerbsfähigkeit und Sicherheit der EU zu gewährleisten. Marco Gabriel Geschäftsführung inett GmbH
feedbackTextUserLanguage: As the CEO of Inett GmbH, I welcome Inett GmbH’s comments on the open-source initiative as an essential step for the EU’s technological sovereignty. Open Source is the foundation of a secure digital ecosystem. Key points of our feedback: Sovereignty & Security: Open source solutions reduce dependencies on non-EU countries and provide a high level of security for IT systems through supply chain transparency, as well as an easy way to adapt and expand. Innovation based on existing solutions is faster and cheaper. Economic lever: As open source already accounts for 7 090 % of modern software solutions, the EU needs to ensure that value creation stays in Europe and does not primarily benefit global tech giants. Breaking down barriers to growth: Improved access to public procurement and growth capital for European open-source actors strengthens intra-European market players and ultimately creates value within Europe. — Beyond research: Support must not end with innovation. We need fast-start finance to develop or further develop open solutions and sustainable framework conditions for industrial deployment and commercial viability. We particularly support the focus on locally, nationally or Europeanly driven AI initiatives, open source software and open hardware. These technologies must be based on trusted, interoperable foundations to ensure the EU’s long-term competitiveness and security. Marco Gabriel Geschäftsführung inett GmbH

feedback: I strongly support the establishment of an EU Sovereign Tech Fund (EU-STF) as a dedicated funding mechanism for open source software maintenance and development. # Building on proven success The Next Generation Internet initiative demonstrates that EU investment in open source delivers results. NGI has funded over 1,400 projects since 2018, with approximately 80,000 individuals actively contributing to NGI-supported projects. Success stories include WireGuard (now in the Linux kernel), PeerTube, CryptPad, and components of Mastodon. The European Commission's own impact study confirms NGI has shaped "a sustainable, sovereign Open-Source tech landscape in Europe." This track record proves the model works. What is now needed is dedicated, long-term funding for maintenance, not just innovation. # Open source is inherently global The Commission's 2021 study found that open source contributes 65-95 billion annually to the European economy, a figure explicitly resulting from global collaboration. The study wisely warned against creating "European open source," noting benefits flow from international cooperation. GitHub reports 180+ million developers worldwide contributing to open source. Critical infrastructure projects are often maintained by small, globally distributed teams. Funding mechanisms must recognise this reality: to benefit EU citizens and businesses, software need not be "Made in the EU" as long as it is made open source. Any EU-STF should welcome applications from maintainers regardless of location, provided their work benefits European digital infrastructure. # Funding must be unbureaucratic The 2024 Tidelift report found 60% of open source maintainers remain unpaid. These are often individuals maintaining critical infrastructure in their spare time. Complex application processes exclude precisely the people most in need of support. Germany's Sovereign Tech Fund demonstrates that streamlined approaches work: 24.6 million invested in 60+ projects over two years, with applications accepted in multiple languages and minimum bureaucratic burden. This model operates within public procurement law, proving simplification is legally feasible. Research and innovation programmes alone are insufficient for maintenance work. As the Call for Evidence acknowledges, "supporting open source communities solely through research and innovation programmes is not sufficient for successful upscaling." # Community involvement is essential Effective open source funding requires community input in governance. The Apache Foundation's model of "community over code" and consensus-based decision-making offers a proven template. Germany's STF involves external community experts in project review. An EU-STF should establish advisory mechanisms with representation from open source foundations, maintainer communities, and end-users, not only corporate stakeholders. # Recommendations 1. Establish dedicated EU-STF funding in the 2028-2034 MFF, separate from R&I programmes 2. Design application processes accessible to individual maintainers, not only organisations 3. Accept applications regardless of maintainer location for projects benefiting EU infrastructure 4. Include community representatives in funding governance 5. Prioritise maintenance and security work alongside new development The European Parliament's January 2026 Resolution rightly endorsed "open-source first and public money, public code" policies. Now is the time to match those words with dedicated funding. Open source underpins Europe's digital economy. Sustainable investment in its maintenance is not charity, it is strategic infrastructure policy.

feedback: F6S is pleased to submit the following feedback on behalf of the NOUS consortium (HE project no.101135927) regarding the 'European Open Digital Ecosystems' initiative. Based on the consortiums extensive involvement in Horizon Europe, we have identified three critical operational points: Sustainability and Exploitation of R&I Results: One of the most significant challenges for EU projects is the "valley of death" that occurs after the funding period ends. Currently, closed ecosystems serve as market entry barriers, preventing high-potential R&D results from being integrated into real-world markets. Opening these ecosystems is not just a matter of fairness; it is a prerequisite for ensuring that innovative solutions born in European consortia become commercially viable and scalable. Interoperability by Design and Mandate: Our projects invest massive resources into creating modular, state-of-the-art architectures. However, when attempting to integrate these European innovations with dominant "gatekeeper" platforms, we consistently face closed APIs or predatory licensing terms. These practices effectively neutralize the competitiveness of European innovation. This initiative must enforce real interoperability based on open standards to level the playing field. Strategic Autonomy and Reducing Technological Dependency: To achieve true Digital Sovereignty, we must ensure that the intellectual and financial capital invested by the EU is not absorbed, sidelined, or blocked by third-country ecosystems that restrict portability. Preventing vendor lock-in is essential to ensure that European public funding translates into a resilient and independent digital economy. For these reasons, I urge the Commission to move beyond high-level principles and establish clear, technical, and enforceable requirements for openness. This will ensure that the next generation of European digital services can thrive in an ecosystem defined by merit and innovation, rather than by the control of existing digital gateways. For more information on the NOUS project contact us via info@nous-project.eu, and find out more here: https://nous-project.eu/

For more than 15 years, we have been developing and operating open-source tools for CSIRTs and the wider cybersecurity community in Europe and beyond. Through CIRCL, we have contributed to building a sustainable open-source ecosystem that directly supports detection, analysis, information sharing, incident response, and remediation. A prominent example is MISP, which has become a de facto standard for threat intelligence and information sharing. It is widely used across multiple trusted networks, including the EU CSIRT Network, NATO communities, private sector operators, and cross-border and sectoral information-sharing initiatives. Its success demonstrates how open-source solutions can scale across jurisdictions, foster trust, and enable interoperability while remaining aligned with European values. Open source is also a key driver for open and inclusive standardisation. We actively contribute to international standardisation efforts, notably within the IETF, where open-source implementations play a critical role in validating specifications and ensuring real-world deployability. In the threat intelligence domain, the MISP-STANDARD initiative provides openly governed data models and formats that are implemented consistently across communities, enabling effective information exchange without vendor lock-in. More recently, through the GCVE initiative, we have contributed Best Current Practice (BCP) documents that define open, decentralised approaches to vulnerability identification and publication, reinforcing resilience, transparency, and autonomy in vulnerability management. More broadly, as a CSIRT, open source has been one of our strongest enablers for collaboration and for improving the overall state of cybersecurity in Europe. Open-source tooling lowers barriers to entry, allows rapid adaptation to emerging threats, and enables security teams of all sizes to build and extend their capabilities. It also supports transparency, auditability, and shared responsibility in managing vulnerabilities across complex digital supply chains. In addition to MISP, we currently maintain and contribute to 17 other open-source projects serving the cybersecurity community. These projects demonstrate that open source is not limited to research or experimentation, but is a mature and proven operational model delivering measurable impact at European scale. We strongly recommend that the European Commission continues and strengthens its support for open source, particularly in the cybersecurity domain. Open source is essential to ensuring European technological autonomy, reducing external dependencies, enabling open standards, and increasing the effectiveness and resilience of information security teams. Sustained support for open-source development, maintenance, standardisation, and community governance should be considered a strategic investment in Europes cyber resilience and digital sovereignty.

feedback:
Dear European Commission / EU Policy Representatives, I would like to provide feedback on the importance of supporting open-source virtualization solutions in Europe, using Proxmox VE as a concrete example of how such technologies deliver clear advantages for European businesses, public institutions, and citizens. Open-source virtualization plays a strategic role in ensuring digital sovereignty, cost efficiency, innovation, and resilience across Europe. 1. Strengthening European Digital Sovereignty Proxmox VE is developed by a European company (Austria), offering a strong alternative to non-European proprietary vendors such as VMware or Hyper-V. By adopting open-source European virtualization platforms, European businesses and public services can: Reduce dependency on foreign technology providers Avoid vendor lock-in and unexpected licensing changes Keep critical infrastructure under European control Example: Municipal IT departments can host sensitive citizen data locally, instead of being forced into costly foreign cloud ecosystems. 2. Lower Costs and Better Use of Public Funds Licensing fees for proprietary virtualization platforms are often extremely high and rising. Open-source platforms such as Proxmox VE allow organizations to: Deploy virtualization at scale with no mandatory per-CPU license fees Allocate budgets toward staff, innovation, and better services Avoid sudden cost shocks caused by vendor pricing strategies Example: A regional hospital can virtualize dozens of servers without spending hundreds of thousands of euros on software licenses, freeing funds for healthcare needs. 3. Supporting SMEs and European Competitiveness European small and medium-sized enterprises need affordable and flexible IT solutions. Proxmox VE benefits SMEs by providing: Enterprise-grade virtualization without enterprise-level cost barriers A simple platform combining virtual machines and containers Access to a large community and European-based support providers Example: A small manufacturing company in Europe can consolidate its IT infrastructure using Proxmox VE instead of outsourcing everything to expensive cloud services. 4. Enabling Resilient Public Infrastructure Open-source virtualization is widely used to build robust and secure digital services for governments and essential services. Proxmox VE includes features such as: High availability clustering Backup and disaster recovery tools Secure role-based access control Example: A city administration can ensure its internal digital services remain operational even if one server fails, improving continuity of public services. 5. Transparency and Security Through Open Source Unlike closed systems, open-source virtualization allows independent review of code and security practices. This leads to: Higher transparency for critical infrastructure Faster identification and fixing of vulnerabilities Trustworthy systems for public sector deployment Example: Universities and public research institutes can audit and adapt virtualization systems to meet EU security requirements. 6. Driving Innovation and European Open-Source Ecosystems Investing in platforms such as Proxmox VE supports: European open-source developers and jobs A local ecosystem of IT service providers Innovation in cloud and edge computing technologies Example: Public-private partnerships could build sovereign European cloud infrastructures based on open virtualization rather than relying entirely on foreign hyperscalers. Conclusion and Recommendation Open-source virtualization solutions like Proxmox VE provide clear benefits for Europe in terms of: Digital independence Cost-effective IT modernization Stronger SME competitiveness Secure and resilient public infrastructure I strongly encourage the European Union to continue supporting open-source infrastructure technologies through funding, procurement frameworks, and strategic digital sovereignty init

feedback: Capacity: Open source contributor (25 years), Former board member of open source advocacy April and of the open source project Open edX, Founder of open source edtech company OpenCraft, French citizen SUMMARY Open source is inherently borderless and transparent. The EU's strategy should fund the maintenance of proven projects rather than creating new ones, and position open source as the federation point for all actors seeking digital independence. KEY RECOMMENDATIONS I) Fund Maintenance, Not Just Innovation EU funding has historically favored new project creation over maintenance. This is counterproductive: - Maintenance is where security happens: vulnerabilities are addressed and dependencies updated through ongoing work. - The open source ecosystem already innovates. The EU's highest-impact intervention is to sustainably fund and help to further develop existing projects that benefit to European interests. Current grant criteria often require "novelty," excluding maintenance of established critical infrastructure. In addition, it is easier for a public institution to identify established open source projects and provide them with maintenance & ongoing development funding for their roadmap, than to try to design new software or fund specific features. Recommendation: Create funding streams for long-term, recurring maintenance supportnot just one-off innovation grants. II) Embrace Open Source's Borderless Nature Open source licenses guarantee the EU's sovereignty over all open source software, regardless of the countries that contribute to it. It opens the possibility of international collaboration, where non-EU countries also contribute to EU sovereignty. - Transparency eliminates hidden risks. Code can be audited by anyone; security depends on the code itself, not on trusting foreign entities. - Free software freedoms legally guarantee rights to use, modify, and redistribute. No foreign actor can revoke access. Recommendation: Collaborate on international open source projects, whether they were created in Europe or not. Fund European developers on international projects, increasing the European influence in those open source projects. - Open Source as Federation Strategy To counter proprietary foreign platform dominance, position open source as the rallying point for digital independence. It allows any country, company, or individual to participate without ceding control. The EU can lead while welcoming global collaboration. III) Prioritise Education European schools depend on US platforms (Google Classroom, Microsoft Teams) with access to student data. Open source alternatives like Open edXserving 100 million learners globallyprovide auditable platforms hostable on European infrastructure. Recommendation: Make education technology a priority vertical for open source adoption. IV) Scale Proven Models Germany's Sovereign Tech Fund demonstrates an effective approach: fund existing critical infrastructure based on impact. It has supported 60+ projects with over 24 million since 2022. However, its scale remains insufficient. Recommendation: Create an EU-wide mechanism modeled on the Sovereign Tech Fund, significantly scaled up. V) Support Governance Capacity Healthy projects need sustainable governance. Models like the Apache Software Foundation demonstrate transparent community governance. Recommendation: Fund governance capacity-building: legal support, foundation establishment, certification programs. ---------- WHAT TO AVOID - Funding new projects that duplicate existing solutions - One-off grants without long-term commitment - Geographic restrictions on project nationality - the important bit is to be open source! - Opaque selection processes CONCLUSION The EU can become the global leader in sustainable open source infrastructurenot by building a walled garden, but by becoming the most reliable long-term supporter of the open source commons.

La virtualizzazione open-source offre benefici tangibili sia alle aziende private sia alle amministrazioni pubbliche, combinando riduzione dei costi, flessibilità operativa e indipendenza dai fornitori proprietari. Unazienda può utilizzare piattaforme basate su Linux e KVM tipo PROXMOX VE per consolidare decine di server fisici in pochi host virtualizzati. Questo approccio riduce i costi hardware e software, il consumo energetico e i tempi di distribuzione dei nuovi ambienti di test e produzione. Nel settore IT e dei servizi digitali, molte software house adottano soluzioni come Proxmox VE per gestire macchine virtuali e container in modo centralizzato. Grazie al codice aperto, le aziende possono personalizzare le funzionalità, integrare strumenti di backup esistenti e automatizzare le situazione di recupero dal disastro senza dover sostenere costi di licenza per ogni singolo server oppure con costi di sottoscrizione limitati. Praticamente: Basso costo totale di proprietà (TCO) Il software è 100% open-source e privo di costi di licenza nascosti. Questo consente alle organizzazioni di sostituire stack proprietari costosi con soluzioni integrate più sostenibili dal punto di vista economico. Assenza di blocchi I clienti possono eseguire il software su una vasta panoramica di hardware e contribuire direttamente allo sviluppo inviando patch o nuove funzionalità, che diventano immediatamente disponibili per lintera comunità. Programmi di formazione e riqualificazione professionale Iniziative di training mirate su software infrastrutturali strategici, come Proxmox Virtual Environment, rafforzano le competenze tecniche locali e favoriscono lautonomia tecnologica di aziende e pubbliche amministrazioni. Elevata trasparenza Il codice sorgente è accessibile, ispezionabile e verificabile da chiunque, favorendo audit indipendenti, maggiore sicurezza e miglioramento continuo. Comunità di sviluppo ampia e attiva Una vasta comunità di sviluppatori contribuisce a innovazione rapida, correzione dei difetti e aggiornamenti continui delle funzionalità. Ampio supporto di protocolli e standard aperti Le soluzioni open-source supportano un numero significativamente maggiore di protocolli e standard aperti rispetto alle alternative proprietarie, garantendo interoperabilità, integrazione con sistemi eterogenei e maggiore flessibilità nel lungo periodo.

feedback: Eine zentrale systemische Herausforderung von Open-Source-Ökosystemen liegt nicht im offenen Quellcode selbst, sondern in der strukturellen Entkopplung von Entwicklung, Nutzung und Wirkung. In offenen digitalen Systemen sind diese drei Ebenen organisatorisch, rechtlich und technisch häufig voneinander getrennt: Entwicklerinnen und Entwickler kennen die späteren Nutzungskontexte nicht, Nutzende kennen die Entstehungsbedingungen und Annahmen nicht, und die gesellschaftlichen oder sicherheitsrelevanten Wirkungen entstehen oft erst durch Skalierung, Aggregation und Zweckverschiebung. Diese Entkopplung ist kein Randphänomen, sondern eine strukturelle Eigenschaft offener, modularer und hochvernetzter Systeme. Sie führt dazu, dass Verantwortung, Risikoabschätzung und Kontrolle nicht entlang der realen Wirkungsketten organisiert sind. Dadurch entstehen systematische Angriffsflächen - nicht primär durch böswillige Akteure, sondern durch fehlende Governance-Architekturen, die Verantwortung, Schnittstellen und Rückkopplung explizit abbilden. Die Praxis zeigt, dass Missbrauch und unbeabsichtigte Folgen auf allen Ebenen auftreten: auf der Architektur-Ebene durch Dual-Use-Designs (z. B. Verschlüsselung, Anonymisierungsnetze); auf der Daten-Ebene durch Zweckänderung und Aggregation (z. B. politische Profilbildung); auf der Supply-Chain-Ebene durch kompromittierte Abhängigkeiten (z. B. manipulierte Open-Source-Pakete); auf der Infrastrukturebene durch kritische, aber schlecht governte Basiskomponenten (z. B. weit verbreitete Logging- oder Kryptobibliotheken). Diese Fälle sind historisch gut dokumentiert und zeigen, dass Offenheit allein keine Sicherheit, Resilienz oder Souveränität erzeugt. Im Gegenteil: Ohne explizite Mechanismen für Verantwortungsketten, Zonentrennung (kritische vs. experimentelle Komponenten), transparente Schnittstellen, systematische Risikoabschätzung und institutionalisierte Feedback-Prozesse wird Offenheit zwangsläufig zur strukturellen Angriffsfläche - technisch, politisch und ethisch. Für eine nachhaltige europäische Open-Source-Strategie bedeutet dies: Der Fokus sollte nicht nur auf Förderung, Adoption und Lizenzfragen liegen, sondern auf dem Aufbau von Governance-Strukturen, die Entwicklung, Nutzung und Wirkung wieder miteinander koppeln. Ziel ist nicht Einschränkung von Offenheit, sondern ihre Systemfähigkeit: Offenheit mit klaren Verantwortungsarchitekturen, nachvollziehbaren Wirkungsketten und lernfähigen Rückkopplungsmechanismen. Das ist keine Frage von Angst oder Misstrauen, sondern eine Konsequenz aus Systemtheorie, Komplexitätsforschung und den empirischen Erfahrungen der letzten zwei Jahrzehnte digitaler Infrastrukturentwicklung. ................... erstellt mit hilfe von ChatGPT

A key systemic challenge of open source ecosystems is not the open source code itself, but the structural decoupling of development, use and impact. In open digital systems, these three levels are often organisationally, legally and technically separate: Developers do not know the subsequent contexts of use, users do not know the conditions of creation and assumptions, and the societal or safety-related effects often only arise through scaling, aggregation and shift of purpose. This decoupling is not a peripheral phenomenon but a structural feature of open, modular and highly interconnected systems. It means that responsibility, risk assessment and control are not organised along real impact chains. This creates systematic attack surfaces – not primarily by malicious actors, but by a lack of governance architectures that explicitly reflect responsibility, interfaces and feedback. Practice shows that abuse and unintended consequences occur at all levels: at architecture level through dual-use designs (e.g. encryption, anonymisation networks); at the da

feedback: Strengths & weaknesses of the EU open-source sector? Strengths Low total cost of ownership Proxmox VE, Backup Server and Mail Gateway are 100 % open-source and have no hidden licensing fees, allowing organisations to replace expensive proprietary stacks with a single, integrated solution. No vendor lock-in Customers can run the software on any hardware and can submit patches to add additional functionality that automatically benefits all others. High transparency code can be inspected, audited and improved by anyone. Large, active developer community that drives rapid innovation and bug-fixes. Concrete EU-level measures & actions Dedicated maintenance grants for critical open-source infrastructure to ensure long-term security updates. Tax credits or subsidies for companies that contribute code or fund development of complementary modules. Standardised open-source procurement guidelines that recognize 100 % open-source solutions without hidden licensing fees. EU-wide certification programme for open-source security to build trust in sovereign-cloud stacks. Training & up-skilling programmes (EU-funded bootcamps) focused on important infrastructure software like Proxmox Virtual Environment. Prioritise open-source alternatives whenever they are available and demonstrably fundable for long-term use this leverages the inherent cost-efficiency and vendor-independence of open-source solutions. Legislation and regulation must not discourage small or emerging open-source projects, overly restrictive rules push innovators toward non-EU investors, undermining the EUs strategic goal of technological sovereignty. The EU should therefore create a regulatory environment that lowers entry barriers for nascent projects while still ensuring security and compliance. What technology areas should be prioritised and why? The EUs most effective way to achieve digital sovereignty is to secure the underlying infrastructure first, rather than concentrating only on end-user-oriented services. Proxmox Virtual Environment (VE) demonstrates how an open-source, software-defined stack can replace proprietary hyperscalers while delivering all the capabilities needed for a sovereign infrastructure. If the EU were to fund and standardise similar open-source solutions across the infrastructure layer, it could build a sovereign cloud that matches the functionality of the large hyperscalers without being locked into vendors that have little incentive to support open-source alternatives. Focusing on this foundational layer also reduces the devil-on-the-wall narrative that proprietary players use to discourage open-source adoption. By promoting proven, open technologies like Proxmox VE, the EU can: Retain control over data and services No hidden licences or vendor-specific APIs. Lower total cost of ownership The software is free, only support contracts are optional, which keeps budgets predictable. Accelerate innovation The open code base allows rapid security patches and feature extensions, unlike the slower release cycles of many commercial stacks. In short, securing the infrastructure with open-source platforms such as Proxmox VE is the pragmatic foundation for an EU-wide sovereign infrastructure, while end-user initiatives can build on top of that trusted base.

OW2, a EU-originated independent non-profit open source association based in France (note we contribute as "business association" but we are not just that, as open to individuals and public bodies: just, we are not an official "NGO"), would like to contribute by focusing on a few key points, placing emphasis on what can be done for:

- Public procurement, research, software and data produced by administrations, and mass market regulations.
- Open, free, public standards. - Edge to cloud (from smartphone to infrastructure) to be massively migrated to FOSS (Free / Open Source Software).
- Support to open digital commons by contributing to, using, backing and funding them.
- Support to the ecosystem, mostly small actors who develop 80%+ of FOSS dependencies, but also European FOSS foundations, by adequate grant schemes or tax exemptions.
- Generalizing FOSS in education.

Concerning FOSS itself, we insist on its importance for technical independence:
- Lots of successful European startups and technologies have been purchased by foreign actors: being a local company is not enough to secure anything, we need the technology to be open.
- FOSS protects against lock-in by a single actor, be it foreign or European then excessive price increases, customer roadmap control, monopolies, etc.
- Cybersecurity requires the code and design to be auditable, and the ability to fix critical breaches quickly. Only FOSS allows it.

Detailed contribution in the file attached to this submission (4 pages PDF).

feedback: Oprogramowanie open source Proxmox coraz częściej postrzegane jest jako realna i w pełni dojrzała alternatywa dla rozwiązań oferowanych przez globalne marki komercyjne. Szczególnie dobrze sprawdza się w sektorze MSP, administracji samorządowej oraz na uczelniach, gdzie liczą się stabilność, elastyczność i racjonalne podejście do kosztów. Wiele instytucji świadomie sięga dziś po rozwiązania open source, które nie tylko dorównują funkcjonalnie systemom klasy enterprise, ale również oferują wysoką jakość wsparcia technicznego często realizowanego przez lokalnych, europejskich partnerów. Ogromnym atutem jest także atrakcyjny model kosztowy, pozwalający efektywnie wykorzystywać budżet bez konieczności ponoszenia wysokich opłat licencyjnych. Dynamicznie rosnąca społeczność użytkowników oraz szerokie grono partnerów wdrożeniowych potwierdzają, że rozwiązania takie jak Proxmox zyskują przewagę nad zamkniętymi platformami komercyjnymi, które są często projektowane głównie z myślą o największych organizacjach dysponujących bardzo dużymi budżetami i zasobami do wdrażania złożonych technologii.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: Open source Proxmox is increasingly seen as a viable and fully mature alternative to solutions offered by global commercial brands. It works particularly well in the SME sector, local government and universities, where stability, flexibility and cost-effectiveness are important. Many institutions are now conscious of open source solutions that not only functionally match enterprise class systems, but also offer high-quality technical support that is often provided by local, European partners. An attractive cost model, allowing the budget to be used efficiently without incurring high royalties, is also a huge asset. A rapidly growing user community and a wide range of implementation partners confirm that solutions such as Proxmox are gaining advantage over closed commercial platforms, which are often designed mainly for the largest organisations with very large budgets and resources to deploy complex technologies.

feedback: --- modified: - 2026-02-02 --- Vorschlag: EU-Förderung für Open-Source-Software durch eine leistungsbasierte Plattform Ausgangssituation Als Softwareentwickler stehe ich vor einem grundlegenden Dilemma: Die Entwicklung qualitativ hochwertiger Open-Source-Software wie meiner Ende-zu-Ende-verschlüsselten Videokonferenzlösung https://brie.fi/ng erfordert erhebliche Zeit- und Kapitalinvestitionen. Ohne nachhaltige Finanzierung bleibt mir nur der Weg der kommerziellen Verwertung, obwohl ich die Software lieber vollständig frei zur Verfügung stellen und intensiv weiterentwickeln würde. Dieses Problem betrifft zahlreiche Entwickler in Europa. Kernidee Die EU sollte ein dauerhaftes Finanzierungssystem etablieren, das Open-Source-Entwicklung durch leistungsbasierte Vergütung fördert. Konkret schlage ich eine EU-betriebene Plattform vor (vergleichbar mit GitHub oder Codeberg.org), die Fördergelder anhand messbarer Erfolgskriterien verteilt. Funktionsweise Die Plattform würde den Nutzen und die Qualität von Projekten durch objektive Metriken bewerten: - Community-Engagement (Bewertungen, Sterne) - Technische Reichweite (Integration in andere Projekte, Downloads) - Wartungsqualität (Beantwortung von Issues, Behebung von Bugs) - Dokumentation und Support Fördergelder würden anteilig ausgeschüttet, wobei Obergrenzen pro Projekt / Person Missbrauch vorbeugen. Vorteile für alle Beteiligten Für Entwickler: Direkte Verbindung zwischen Leistung und Vergütung; Möglichkeit, sich vollständig auf quelloffene Entwicklung zu konzentrieren Für die EU: Aufbau digitaler Souveränität; Kontrolle über Qualitätsstandards (z.B. EUPL-Lizenzierung, Entwickler-Verifizierung); Förderung europäischer Innovation; Reduktion der Abhängigkeit von außereuropäischen Plattformen Für die Gesellschaft: Zugang zu sicherer, transparenter Software; Stärkung des europäischen Tech-Ökosystems Fazit Diese Initiative würde systematische Anreize für die Entwicklung hochwertiger Open-Source-Software schaffen und gleichzeitig europäische Werte wie Transparenz, Datenschutz und digitale Souveränität fördern.

Without sustainable funding, I will only be able to exploit the software commercially, although I would prefer to make it fully freely available and develop it intensively. This problem affects many developers in Europe. Core idea The EU should establish a permanent funding system that promotes open source development through performance-based remuneration. Functioning The Platform would assess the usefulness and quality of projects through objective metrics: — Community engagement (assessments, stars) – Technical outreach (integration into other projects, downloads) – Maintenance quality (answer to issues, correction of bugs) – Documentation and support funding would be distributed on a pro rata basis, with ceilings per project/person preventing abuse. Benefits for all stakeholders For developers: Dir

feedback: Higher education is a critical sector for EU tech sovereignty that requires dedicated attention in this strategy. Over 90% of European universities rely on Learning Management Systems (LMS) daily. A 2024 peer-reviewed study found that 98% of higher education institutions in Germany, Austria, and Switzerland use open-source LMS (Moodle, ILIAS, Stud.IP), with Moodle being the clear market leader. This infrastructure serves millions of students and educators, yet the Call for Evidence does not mention higher education among priority sectors. The Open Source Development Network (OSDN) is a cooperative initiative in Lower Saxony, Germany, where universities jointly develop and maintain open-source software for teaching and learning. We coordinate development across LMS platforms (Moodle, ILIAS, Stud.IP), video infrastructure (Opencast), and OER systems (OERSI). The European University Association has recognised this model as a successful example of universities achieving digital sovereignty through open-source collaboration. Responding to the Call's questions: 1. Strengths and weaknesses of the EU open-source sector: Strength: Vibrant communities, alignment with EU values (privacy, transparency), high adoption in public sector. Weakness: Project-based funding prevents sustainable maintenance; lack of coordination across Member States; insufficient understanding that continuous refactoring and security updates require ongoing investment, not just initial development. 2. Added value of open source: Open-source LMS in higher education delivers: vendor independence, GDPR-compliant data sovereignty, institutional control over AI integration, improved cybersecurity through transparent code review, and accessibility improvements benefiting all learners. Universities retain control over learning data, essential for trustworthy AI applications in education. 3. Concrete EU-level measures: Establish dedicated funding programmes for open-source education infrastructure, recognising higher education as critical sector. Provide seed funding for sustainable governance structures (e.g., cooperatives, foundations) that enable long-term maintenance beyond project cycles. Support cross-border coordination mechanisms for open-source communities serving public institutions. Consider extending DC-EDIC scope or creating complementary structures for education sector. 4. Priority technology areas: LMS and learning infrastructure, AI integration in education (requiring sovereign data), video/collaboration platforms, OER infrastructure, identity management, accessibility tools. 5. Sectors with competitiveness potential: Higher education and public sector education broadly. The EU's 2021 Fraunhofer/OFE study estimated OSS contributes 65-95 billion euros to EU GDP with a 1:4 cost-benefit ratio. Universities are ideal testbeds: large user bases, technical expertise, public mission alignment, and existing open-source adoption. Strengthening education infrastructure creates spillover effects for workforce digital skills. Conclusion: The OSDN demonstrates that cooperative, cross-institutional open-source development works. What is needed: recognition of education as critical infrastructure, sustainable funding models beyond project cycles, and EU-level coordination to scale successful regional initiatives. We welcome engagement with DC-EDIC and other EU frameworks.

Focusing on free and open software is absolutely crucial for any public entity fro two main reasons: Proprietary Software cannot be trusted. Even if a government body might get exclusive access to the source code to validate and audit it, the resulting binary might be from another source. Additionally, every audit covers just a point in time, so the next patch makes the audit pretty much useless. The second big point is sovereignty and resilience - even without considering the current state of affairs in large parts of the world, being subjected to vendor lock-in and being vulnerable to extortion and sabotage through vendors and foreign governments is not really acceptable. Besides those points, the possibility of collaboration and reuse of existing work offers a massive potential for cost savings and a potentially huge boost for efficiency in administrations in countless sectors. In my opinion, there has to be a strict FOSS only approach going forward - public money, public code!

Small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) operate under strict budgetary, operational and human-resource constraints. For them, open source is not an ideological preference, but a pragmatic and strategic tool to remain competitive, resilient and independent in an increasingly digital economy. Why Open Source Matters for SMEs Cost predictability and affordability Fully open-source solutions eliminate licence fees and hidden costs. SMEs can deploy enterprise-grade infrastructure while maintaining predictable budgets and healthy cash flow. Example: platforms like Proxmox Virtual Environment provide virtualisation, clustering and high availability without per-CPU or per-VM licensing. Freedom from vendor lock-in Open-source software runs on standard hardware and across different environments, allowing SMEs to avoid forced migrations, price increases or dependency on hyperscalers. Example: Proxmox can be deployed on-premise, at the edge or in hybrid setups, using standard Linux kernels and open formats. Operational simplicity for small IT teams Integrated open-source stacks reduce complexity by replacing multiple proprietary tools with a single, coherent platform. Example: Proxmox combines virtualisation, storage management, backup integration and clustering in one interface, reducing operational overhead for small teams. Transparency and trust Auditable source code increases confidence in security, compliance and long-term sustainability, especially when handling sensitive business or customer data. Tangible Benefits in Daily SME Operations Lower total cost of ownership (TCO) while retaining enterprise-level features such as snapshots, replication and high availability. Strong security posture through rapid, community-driven vulnerability detection and patching. Interoperability via open APIs and standards, enabling integration with existing ERP, CRM, monitoring or backup tools. Scalable adoption, allowing SMEs to start with a small setup and grow without re-architecting or renegotiating licences. What SMEs Need from EU Policy To unlock the full potential of open source for SMEs, EU action should focus on enablement rather than compliance burden: Sustainable funding for critical open-source infrastructure projects that SMEs rely on as foundational technologies. Tax incentives or financial support for SMEs adopting or contributing to open-source platforms (including testing, documentation and small patches). Procurement frameworks accessible to SMEs, explicitly recognising fully open-source solutions such as Proxmox-based stacks, without requirements tailored only to large vendors. Targeted training and up-skilling programmes focused on practical infrastructure software used by SMEs. Proportionate regulation that ensures security and compliance without discouraging small companies or early-stage open-source projects. Infrastructure First: A Pragmatic Path to Digital Sovereignty for SMEs For SMEs, digital sovereignty starts at the infrastructure layer, not at consumer-facing services. Open-source virtualisation and backup platforms enable SMEs to retain full control over data, meet EU data-residency requirements, and deploy resilient on-premise or hybrid systems at sustainable cost. By supporting and standardising proven open-source infrastructure solutionssuch as Proxmoxthe EU can ensure that SMEs access the same technological foundations as large enterprises, without the financial, legal or strategic constraints of proprietary ecosystems. High-Impact Sectors for SMEs Open-source infrastructure can significantly increase competitiveness and cyber resilience in SME-driven sectors such as public services, healthcare, manufacturing and Industry 4.0, telecommunications, energy and local utilities.

Gaining technological independence is vitally important for Europe. We must reduce our dependence on external technology companies and grow and promote our own technological fabric. We are currently reliant on solutions from other countries that have proven to be unreliable and have us technologically subjugated. Companies such as Proxmox are the foundation for growth and independence.

feedback: No vendor lock-in Customers can run the software on any hardware and can submit patches to add additional functionality that automatically benefits all others. High transparency code can be inspected, audited and improved by anyone. Source code is publicly auditable, enabling quicker vulnerability detection and remediation. A sovereign, fully auditable stack removes dependence on foreign vendors, supports classified workloads in isolated VMs, and allows rapid patching of vulnerabilities, critical for national defence cyber-resilience. In short, securing the infrastructure with open-source platforms such as Proxmox VE is the pragmatic foundation for an EU-wide sovereign infrastructure, while end-user initiatives can build on top of that trusted base.
