feedback:
Grenzen, Verantwortung und Innovation in offenen digitalen Ökosystemen der Europäischen Union ................... Die Europäische Union verfolgt mit ihrer Strategie für offene digitale Ökosysteme das Ziel, technologische Souveränität, Sicherheit, Innovationsfähigkeit und Wettbewerbsfähigkeit nachhaltig zu stärken. Die zahlreichen Rückmeldungen aus der aktuellen Konsultation zeigen ein hohes Maß an Praxisnähe und Innovationspotenzial. Gleichzeitig wird deutlich, dass viele Herausforderungen nicht primär technischer Natur sind, sondern auf strukturellen Spannungen beruhen. Diese Spannungen lassen sich als Konflikt zwischen zwei grundlegenden Rationalitäten beschreiben, die exemplarisch durch die philosophischen Positionen von Albert Camus und Jean-Paul Sartre repräsentiert werden. Die Camus-Perspektive steht für reale Grenzen, Vorsicht, Schutz, Stabilität und Verantwortung durch Begrenzung. Sie entspricht der Logik von Regulierung, Normen, Sicherheit, Compliance und Haftung. Die Sartre-Perspektive steht für Freiheit, Gestaltungsspielraum, Projektlogik, Innovation, Experiment und Verantwortung durch Entscheidung. Sie entspricht der Logik von Open Source, agiler Entwicklung, Prototyping und Community-getriebener Innovation. Beide Perspektiven sind in der europäischen Digitalpolitik gleichzeitig präsent, werden jedoch selten explizit unterschieden. Daraus entstehen systemische Konflikte: Sicherheit versus Innovation, Standardisierung versus Flexibilität, Haftung versus Offenheit sowie Prozessstabilität versus Projektlogik. Diese Konflikte sind nicht zufällig, sondern Ausdruck unterschiedlicher Weltbilder im Umgang mit Risiko, Verantwortung und technischer Gestaltung. Das Risiko für die EU besteht darin, diese Spannungen entweder einseitig aufzulösen oder implizit zu lassen. Eine Überbetonung regulatorischer Kontrolle kann Innovation hemmen, während eine Überbetonung von Offenheit Sicherheitsrisiken und Vertrauensverluste erzeugen kann. Beides würde die strategischen Ziele der EU untergraben. Vor diesem Hintergrund empfiehlt dieses Positionspapier eine strukturelle Zwei-Ebenen-Architektur für offene digitale Ökosysteme. Auf der ersten Ebene sollte ein nicht verhandelbarer Kern etabliert werden, der sicherheitskritische Funktionen, Datenschutz, Haftung, Normenkonformität und stabile Kerninfrastrukturen umfasst. Diese Ebene folgt der Camus-Logik und dient dem Schutz von Menschen, Systemen und öffentlichen Gütern. Auf der zweiten Ebene sollte ein expliziter Innovationsraum geschaffen werden, der Open-Source-Module, Plugins, Community-Projekte, Simulationen, Testumgebungen sowie Forschung und Prototyping ermöglicht. Diese Ebene folgt der Sartre-Logik und schafft gezielt Freiräume für technologische Gestaltung. Das zentrale Architekturprinzip lautet: ein stabiler, regulierter Kern mit einem freien, experimentellen Rand. Sicherheit und Innovation werden dadurch nicht gegeneinander ausgespielt, sondern strukturell entkoppelt und strategisch verbunden. Operativ sollte die EU künftig alle Open-Source-Initiativen durch zwei systematische Filter prüfen: einen Camus-Check (Sicherheit, Risiken, Nachhaltigkeit, Haftung) und einen Sartre-Check (Innovationspotenzial, Flexibilität, technologische Souveränität). Ergänzend sollten Pilotprojekte, klare Governance-Strukturen und transparente Verantwortlichkeiten etabliert werden. Die zentrale strategische Erkenntnis lautet: Open Source ist nicht nur eine technologische, sondern eine kulturelle und epistemische Frage. Die entscheidende Governance-Frage ist nicht, welche Software genutzt wird, sondern welche Form von Verantwortung organisiert wird. Innovation benötigt Freiheit. Sicherheit benötigt Grenzen. Nachhaltigkeit benötigt beides zugleich. Camus schützt das System. Sartre entwickelt das System. Europa braucht beide strukturell getrennt, strategisch vereint. ..................

feedback:
Feedback Iniciativa «Hacia unos ecosistemas digitales abiertos europeos» 1. Puntos fuertes y debilidades del sector del código abierto de la UE El sector europeo del código abierto presenta fortalezas claras: una base tecnológica madura, comunidades de desarrollo activas y una amplia adopción en capas críticas de la infraestructura digital (virtualización, redes, almacenamiento, ciberseguridad). Estas soluciones permiten un alto grado de transparencia, auditabilidad y control, aspectos esenciales para la soberanía tecnológica y la ciberresiliencia. No obstante, persisten debilidades estructurales. Entre ellas destacan las dificultades para escalar proyectos europeos frente a proveedores globales dominantes, el acceso limitado a la contratación pública debido a pliegos orientados a tecnologías propietarias y la ausencia de marcos homogéneos de certificación y referencia para soluciones open source. Asimismo, la carga regulatoria y de cumplimiento puede resultar desproporcionada para pymes y proyectos emergentes, afectando a su competitividad. 2. Valor añadido del código abierto para los sectores público y privado El código abierto aporta un valor diferencial tanto en el sector público como en el privado al reducir significativamente el coste total de propiedad, eliminar dependencias de proveedor (vendor lock-in) y permitir una mayor previsibilidad presupuestaria. La posibilidad de auditar el código fuente mejora la gestión del riesgo y la respuesta ante vulnerabilidades de ciberseguridad. En el ámbito de las administraciones públicas, las soluciones open source facilitan el despliegue de infraestructuras soberanas, tanto on-premise como híbridas, alineadas con los principios de protección de datos, continuidad del servicio y control de la cadena de suministro. En el sector privado, permiten a las pymes acceder a tecnologías avanzadas sin barreras económicas excesivas, fomentando la innovación y la competitividad. 3. Medidas y acciones que debería adoptar la UE La Unión Europea debería adoptar medidas concretas para fortalecer el ecosistema open source europeo, entre ellas: Incorporar criterios de neutralidad tecnológica en la contratación pública, priorizando soluciones de código abierto cuando sean técnicamente viables y sostenibles. Establecer programas europeos de certificación y referencia para soluciones open source, especialmente en infraestructuras críticas y ciberseguridad. Apoyar modelos de negocio sostenibles basados en servicios, soporte y ecosistemas de partners europeos. Reducir barreras regulatorias para pymes y proyectos emergentes, evitando requisitos de cumplimiento desproporcionados. Impulsar programas de formación y capacitación en tecnologías open source estratégicas para administraciones públicas y empresas. 4. Ámbitos tecnológicos que deberían priorizarse Para avanzar hacia la soberanía digital, la UE debería priorizar las capas fundamentales de la infraestructura digital, en particular: Virtualización y gestión de infraestructuras. Cloud y entornos híbridos soberanos. Copias de seguridad, recuperación ante desastres y alta disponibilidad. Edge computing y sistemas distribuidos. Ciberseguridad integrada en la infraestructura. El fortalecimiento de estas capas permite construir servicios digitales fiables sobre una base tecnológica controlada y transparente. 5. Sectores con mayor impacto en competitividad y ciberresiliencia Un mayor uso del código abierto puede incrementar de forma notable la competitividad y la ciberresiliencia en sectores estratégicos como: Administraciones públicas. Sanidad. Educación. Industria y fabricación avanzada. Energía e infraestructuras críticas. Telecomunicaciones. En estos ámbitos, disponer de infraestructuras abiertas, auditables y sin dependencias externas resulta clave para garantizar la continuidad operativa, la protección de datos y l

feedback: CONTEXT Europe faces critical dependence on non-European technology providers. The US CLOUD Act, trade tensions, and cloud market concentration in AWS/Azure/GCP represent real strategic risks to European technological sovereignty. Yet Europe has the open-source alternatives. France has proven they work: 40,000 users migrated to Visio (Jitsi-based), targeting 200,000 by 2027, saving 1M EUR/year. What's missing is coordination, information, and clear adoption frameworks. I propose four concrete actions: 1. CREATE AN OFFICIAL CATALOGUE OF EUROPEAN ALTERNATIVES Problem: No centralised, verified registry of European open-source solutions exists. Proposal: Fund a public catalogue that lists European alternatives by category (cloud, communication, productivity, AI), verifies origin, licensing and GDPR compliance, includes real use cases and maturity assessments, and maintains automatic availability checks. Precedent: France's SILL already provides a national model of recommended open-source software for public administration. 2. PUBLISH REAL MIGRATION GUIDES Problem: Organisations want to migrate but lack practical guidance. Proposal: Document and publish detailed case studies: France's CNRS migration of 120,000 users from Zoom to Visio, step-by-step methodology (assessment, pilot, rollout, training), real costs (development, training, support), and lessons learned. Make guides available in all EU official languages. 3. CREATE A FORMAL NETWORK OF EUROPEAN OPEN-SOURCE CHAMPIONS Problem: The ecosystem is fragmented. Nextcloud (Germany), Jitsi/Visio (France), Element (UK), Collabora (UK) operate independently without coordination. Proposal: Establish an official network connecting major European open-source projects to facilitate interoperability (standards, APIs, federation), share resources (infrastructure, testing, documentation), and represent the ecosystem before EU institutions. Similar to GAIA-X but focused on software, not just infrastructure. 4. MANDATE "OPEN SOURCE FIRST" FOR PUBLIC INSTITUTIONS Problem: Without legal obligation, institutions choose proprietary solutions by inertia. Proposal: Legislate an "Open Source First" principle requiring evaluation of open-source alternatives before contracting proprietary, documented justification if proprietary is chosen, minimum open-source spending percentages (e.g., 30% by 2028), and compliance dashboards by country/institution. Precedent: Schleswig-Holstein (Germany) is migrating 30,000 government PCs to Linux/LibreOffice, saving 15M EUR/year. The Interoperable Europe Act (2024) already mandates EU governments to prioritize open-source alternatives. CONCLUSION Europe needs: Coordination (a catalogue and network connecting the fragmented ecosystem), Information (migration guides and real cost data), and Obligation (legal mandates to overcome institutional inertia). The geopolitical pressure is real. The alternatives exist. Europe only needs to decide to use them.

En tant que dirigeant dune entreprise de services informatiques française, je souhaite souligner lurgence de renforcer les European Open Digital Ecosystems (EODE). Dans un contexte mondial marqué par des tensions géopolitiques croissantes et une dépendance accrue aux technologies, la confiance dans les infrastructures numériques est devenue un enjeu stratégique. 1. La souveraineté technologique comme impératif Les entreprises européennes, et particulièrement françaises, ne peuvent plus se permettre de dépendre exclusivement de solutions étrangères, souvent soumises à des réglementations extérieures ou à des risques de cyberespionnage. Les écosystèmes ouverts et européens offrent une alternative crédible, en garantissant : Transparence : des codes sources accessibles et audités, limitant les backdoors ou les dépendances cachées. Conformité RGPD : un respect strict des données personnelles, sans transfert vers des juridictions tierces. Résilience : une infrastructure moins vulnérable aux sanctions ou aux coupures géopolitiques. Exemple concret : Proxmox La solution de virtualisation Proxmox VE incarne parfaitement cette approche. Développée en Europe (Autriche), open source et sans licence propriétaire coercitive, elle permet aux entreprises de : Maîtriser leurs données : pas de cloud obligatoire, possibilité dhébergement on-premise ou chez des fournisseurs européens de confiance. Éviter le vendor lock-in : compatibilité avec les standards ouverts (KVM, LXC), facilitant les migrations. Bénéficier dun support local : une communauté active et des partenaires européens pour le support et la formation. Chez [Nom de votre entreprise], nous avons migré plusieurs clients vers Proxmox, réduisant ainsi leur exposition aux risques liés aux solutions américaines ou asiatiques. Les retours sont unanimes : performance, sécurité, et indépendance sont au rendez-vous. 2. Les défis à relever Malgré ces avantages, les EODE font face à plusieurs obstacles : Manque de visibilité : les solutions européennes sont souvent moins médiatisées que leurs concurrents américains. Écosystème fragmenté : il manque une coordination forte entre États membres pour promouvoir ces outils (ex. : interopérabilité entre solutions françaises, allemandes, etc.). Résistance au changement : certaines entreprises hésitent à quitter des solutions comme VMware ou AWS, par habitude ou méconnaissance des alternatives. 3. Propositions pour accélérer ladoption Pour renforcer les EODE, je propose : Un label "Souvereineté Numérique Européenne" : certifiant les solutions open source et européennes, avec des critères stricts de transparence et de sécurité. Des incitations fiscales : pour les PME adoptant des solutions européennes (ex. : crédits dimpôt pour la migration vers Proxmox, Nextcloud, etc.). Un fonds dinvestissement dédié : pour soutenir linnovation dans les infrastructures critiques (cloud, cybersécurité, IA). Des campagnes de sensibilisation : mettant en avant des success stories comme Proxmox, mais aussi Odoo, Matrix, ou OwnCloud, pour démontrer leur maturité. 4. Conclusion : un choix stratégique Les EODE ne sont pas une option, mais une nécessité pour lEurope. En tant quacteur du secteur IT, je suis convaincu que des solutions comme Proxmox doivent devenir la norme, et non lexception. La technologie doit être un levier de souveraineté, pas un outil de dépendance. Je reste à disposition pour échanger sur des cas concrets ou participer à des groupes de travail visant à promouvoir ces écosystèmes. Alexis Barnoux

feedback: Main reason for strenghtening the EU open-source sector is getting rid of vendor-lockins and achieve higher level of digital sovereignty. Even if this looks more expensive from the start, it is the olnly way to survive. EU should injvest in building its own IT technology stacks, starting form operating systems, databases and continuing to safe EU local and EU owned cloud offerings that EU companies and governments would not fe afraid to use.

I am responding to this Call for Evidence based on more than 25 years of leadership and participation in global open source communities, including sustained work with governments in Europe, Canada, and the United States. I am not submitting on behalf of my employer, although I work in the GovTech sector as CivicActions Open Standards and Practices Lead. My perspective is grounded in practical experience supporting open source adoption, public sector procurement, accessibility compliance, and the long-term sustainability of digital public goods. I regularly engage with government leaders internationally on the effective use of open source in the public sector. Strengths and weaknesses of the EU open-source sector The European Union has one of the worlds strongest open source ecosystems in terms of talent, community participation, and alignment with public values. Europe has demonstrated its ability to fund and nurture open, rights-respecting digital infrastructure. However, structural challenges remain, including limited pathways for projects to scale beyond pilots, barriers to procurement for small and medium-sized enterprises, overly bureaucratic funding mechanisms, and insufficient long-term support for maintenance, governance, and security of critical open source infrastructure. These challenges are policy and procurement issues rather than technical limitations. Added value of open source for the public sector Open source reduces vendor lock-in, increases transparency, strengthens security through peer review, and enables collaboration across institutions and borders. From an accessibility perspective, open source has been essential in supporting implementation of the Web Accessibility Directive and preparation for the European Accessibility Act. I am a Drupal Core Accessibility Maintainer, and much of my work over the past 15+ years has supported government accessibility obligations in Europe and North America through shared, open solutions rather than bespoke proprietary systems. Policy measures to strengthen European open digital ecosystems The EU Sovereign Tech Fund is a critical instrument for sustaining core open source infrastructure. Funding should prioritise maintenance, security, and governance of strategically important projects, building on experience from initiatives such as the German Sovereign Tech Agency. Keep funding mechanisms proportionate and accessible Canada provides a cautionary example. Despite early leadership in open source adoption, limited procurement reform constrained impact. In contrast, the Government of British Columbia has used targeted micro-procurements to build a diverse GovTech ecosystem contributing to shared open source solutions, including work on digital identity. EU funding instruments should adopt similarly targeted and agile approaches where appropriate. https://digital.gov.bc.ca/marketplace/ https://www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/governments/government-id/bc-wallet Embed open source in procurement policy The United States has indirectly strengthened global open source ecosystems through small business set-asides and federal contracting, enabling SMEs to collaborate on large public sector systems while contributing upstream. Europe can replicate this by favouring procurement models that support SME consortia, require upstream contributions, and avoid structural vendor lock-in. I recently presented on this topic at FOSDEM: https://github.com/usds/ditap-curriculum-update https://fosdem.org/2026/schedule/event/3YWKPG-lets_take_public_money_public_code_seriously/ https://ox.ca/presentations/procurement-fosdem26.html Related work: https://github.com/usds/ditap-curriculum-update Open source is global Open source ecosystems are inherently global. European technological sovereignty should be pursued through leadership and participation in global communities, combined with procurement policies that strengthen local

feedback: Government officials from many countries increasingly use Signal messaging app. No government or large centralized entity can be trusted to provide secure communications. Only an open-source app can be truly proven to be private. As recently expressed by experts, AI agents are being deployed in operating systems and this will compromise the security of those operating systems. This is a major security vulnerability that requires prompt action. Linux usage is growing and the EU should support that growth. Our operating systems and communication channels mentioned here are the modern equivalent to roads and ports. They need to be entirely supported by public funds to maintain objective delivery to all all citizens free from corruption by centralised controllers. Integrity of information and social dialogue are at risk. Centralized algorithms and user data are used to favour chosen narratives and nudge social preference. (Read Cambridge Analytica, Emerdata, Emic Consulting, Auspex International, Data Propria etc). Open-source solutions like the Fediverse and ActivityPub decentralize this power. It allows users to choose between apps to join the discussion. The EU can host it own fediverse applications where users can connect. By reducing dependency on non-EU countries in this way the EU will also overcome any dependency on any single state. Rather than changing from one single point of failure to another we can empower a larger community of EU stakeholders. The connections and strength of this network delivers a competitive edge to the EU. It will empower citizens to choose international connections and build on these relationships within the most robust secure framework. An establish well connected Fediverse provides the EU with tools and connections to quickly disseminate projects and initiatives. The new era of organization provides connections to the EU's various digital ecosystems embedded within social networks. Showing citizens embedded (from source) information will help combat misinformation currently overwhelming their social timelines. Using the Fediverse users and instances (their chosen connection point) can control their connections and data flow, maintaining privacy. It is these connections and data which deliver a competitive advantage to the EU while preserving privacy from non-EU countries. Open source and decentralization are crucial parts of maintaining data integrity. No government or large centralized entity can be trusted to maintain objectivity. Wikipedia and other decentralized attempts to provide the public with objective information should be supported by the EU. While pursuing these open-source solutions, the EU will empower smaller member states who are trying to regulate corporations larger than them. Open source delivers the fastest, most secure applications. The EU will benefit from the contributions of open-source developers from all nations while preserving our connections and data privacy from non-EU countries. It is the transparency that makes open source applications more secure. By accepting this new paradigm first and acting to reward all open-source developers, the EU further gains a first mover competitive edge. Priorities are; using available feasible open-source software within EU government(Linux, Libre office, etc), using EU in-house developers to work on them, paying external contributors for improvements on the software you use, funding initiatives for development of community-centred open-source software, funding initiatives to set up local instances of Fediverse apps, developing pathways for open-source developers to earn, funding education around algorithms and maintaining data security in schools to inspire the next generation of solutions.

We are a micro sized business, founded in 1988, providing software solutions to industrial clients. Much of our work already includes open source platforms and we are in strong support of initiatives to expand open source ecosystems in the EU. We suggest initiatives that provide low barriers to entry for individual developers, noting that many major open source projects, most prominently the Linux kernel, have started from such seeds. Please find our full statement in the attached document.

1i) The EU market in many industries is highly regulated (often for good reasons) but this can lead to unintended exclusion of OSS from procurement. This may be for a number of reasons: maintainers unable to afford necessary certifications, lacking the infrastructure for an EU representative (for GDPR and GPSR for example), lack of time to go through approval checklists are all reasons that come to mind. These are all issues that could be fixed through offering grants and sponsorships. Additionally, many projects only provide English language instructions which can be a barrier for many EU country citizens looking to get involved. EU could fund translation projects especially for underrepresented languages. 1ii) Many contributions originate from "corporate contributors"; that is, engineers developing and submitting code changes created in the process of their work on behalf of their employer. An example of this is Google engineers contributing to the Linux Kernel source code. To encourage this behaviour in the European sphere, funded "bounties" could be offered 2) One concrete benefit that is not discussed often is freedom from lock-in for support contracts. The open market for providing support for open source software, from both the authors and third parties, is significant. One can look at the healthy competitive environment for Wordpress hosting, tailored development and consulting. 3) The EU can act as a role model by adopting OSS internally, championing these projects and allotting time to employed software engineers to contribute to OSS on behalf of the EU. EU-organised "hackathons" and "bug bashes" (events where contributors are invited to build on a particular topic) could benefit the scene. 4) Cybersecurity 5) Agriculture could stand to benefit against industry wise issues of planned obsolescence. Thank you for your time

While lack of direct funding is a great concern, there are other important aspects where the EU can help and investments/legislature have a larger effect than giving one OSS org direct funds. 1) Help with Infrastructure: Today, github and npm dominate code hosting and publishing libraries. Both owned by microsoft. Independently run alternatives that cannot be controlled by a single entity help ensure that OSS developed and published on them stays available. See tangled.org or jsr.io for current efforts. Other important areas include chat and collaboration platforms. 2) Provide better funding options: Most popular donation platforms are currently operated in the US. Make it easier for OSS to register a foundation or set up a platform that serves as an umbrella foundation. Reduce legal overhead and associated risks. Make it easier for individuals to receive funds from an OSS organisation. 3) Communities don't just happen: People like Matias Capeletto (patak) are able to quickly rally people behind a project. (see how quickly npmx.dev grew from 0 to 100 contributors). Identifying community leaders and ensuring they can focus on what they do best pays off. Motivating more people to lead and help out OSS in non-technical positions would pay off even more. 4) Treat OSS as infrastructure: The goal of supporting an OSS org should not be that it is going to fund itself after a while. Their value isn't commercial success in itself, but to provide it to others so they can use, iterate, improve, build on it. So legislature and programs should be set up for long term perspective, not just a 6 month grant. 5) Encourage Self-Hosting and Decentralization: Centralized cloud providers create an extra layer, control over data and ownership can become a risk. Being able to run OSS on your own servers keeps you in control. Be it a government agency, a local business or individual citizens. Thank you for taking feedback on this! A european OSS maintainer edit: sorry for the missing newlines, this post was properly formatted but publish stripped them.

Open Source Software or better Free and Open Source Software is for me the possibility to change devices and what they do around me and provide services and software that benefits others on the other side. It is the freedom to be able to fix bugs and other problems, change it as i want to fit my personal needs and extend it without limitations of any original rights holder or corporation. By changing software it can be adopted easier and faster to multiple new use cases and ways never envisioned while initially developed; it gives me the freedom to change things even if the original author / corporation stopped supporting a device or service. By self hosting it gives me more freedom, defends my data privacy rights and allows me to control the things i use on a daily basis.

Feedback for the European Commission European Open Digital Ecosystems 1. Key Challenges for Open-Source Adoption in the EU Lack of Trust and Awareness: Private companies often hesitate to adopt European open-source solutions (e.g., Proxmox, Wazuh) due to concerns about long-term support, security, and compatibility, especially in an environment dominated by global players like Microsoft. The public sector could play a pivotal role as an early adopter, thereby increasing trust in these technologies. Dominance of Proprietary Solutions in Public Administration: The strong penetration of proprietary technologies (e.g., Microsoft) in public administration creates barriers for European open-source projects, preventing them from competing on equal termseven when they offer greater transparency, lower costs, and independence. Need for Standardization and Certification: There is a lack of EU-wide certification programs to validate the security and reliability of open-source solutions, which would facilitate their adoption in critical sectors such as healthcare, finance, and defense. 2. Added Value of Open Source for Public and Private Sectors Cost Efficiency and Independence: Open-source solutions like Proxmox VE and Wazuh reduce Total Cost of Ownership (TCO) and eliminate vendor lock-in, which is crucial for long-term sustainability and data control. Security and Transparency: The ability to audit source code and respond quickly to vulnerabilities enhances cyber resilience, particularly for critical infrastructure (energy, telecommunications, defense). Innovation and Flexibility: Community-driven development and open architecture enable faster innovation and customization to specific needs, providing an advantage over closed systems with lengthy release cycles. 3. Concrete EU-Level Measures Public Sector as a Catalyst: Public institutions should be encouraged (e.g., through legislation or funding) to prioritize open-source solutions where they are available and sustainable. This would create reference cases and boost confidence in the private sector. Financial and Educational Programs: EU-funded bootcamps and training for managing and deploying open-source infrastructure (e.g., Proxmox VE) would help address the skills gap. Standardization of Public Procurement: Open-source solutions should be considered on equal footing with proprietary products in public tenders, with clear criteria for evaluating their sustainability and security. Certification and Marketing Support: An EU-wide certification program for open-source security and promotion of successful European projects (e.g., Proxmox, Wazuh) as trustworthy alternatives would be beneficial. 4. Priority Sectors for Open-Source Support Public Administration: Deploying open-source virtualization and backup solutions (e.g., Proxmox) for critical services would demonstrate their reliability and reduce dependence on foreign vendors. Healthcare and Finance: Isolated and auditable open-source platforms can ensure better protection of sensitive data and compliance with GDPR. Industry 4.0 and Telecommunications: Open-source virtualization and edge computing (e.g., Proxmox VE) enable flexible and secure management of production lines and 5G networks without vendor lock-in. Energy and Defense: Open-source solutions for SCADA and classified systems would enhance cyber resilience and EU independence. 5. Conclusion Europe has the potential to become a leader in open digital ecosystems, but this requires coordinated support from the public sector, clear regulations, and investment in education and certification. Only then can the current dominance of foreign technologies be overcome, and EU technological sovereignty strengthened.

column31: We have been working and offering free, European or even French solutions as a priority for 25 years. We regret that these solutions are not always recognised and that, at the same time, our governments, too many administrations and companies of all sizes sign framework partnerships and agreements with the GAFAM or often American multinationals without considering alternatives and without taking into account our digital sovereignty. The current context reminds us if there is a need for this sovereignty to have no price and many European solutions should be promoted or promoted in Europe.

feedback: I'm very happy to see openness and especially free and open source software presented as core ideas for this strategy. Building on open standards and using free software enables our independence when we need it (and it seems like we do in these times), but it is not an isolationist solution to the problem. We take control, without denying control to anyone else. Deep down, I still believe an interdependent world is to be preferred over isolated blocks, though we have recently seen the drawbacks of taking globalization too far. At least in the digital realm, free and open source software enables collaboration without losing control. I do want to call out that this strategy comes with a requirement to build our expertise in house: to really benefit from using an open source solution, you need to be able to run it yourself. Ideally to maintain it yourself, if the need arises. And that might go beyond just relying on European companies (see e.g. the Solvinity situation in the Netherlands): critical government services should probably run on government infrastructure.

We believe that open source software and hardware, and the adoption of open standards, are essential for building a more open, transparent, and user-centric digital future for Europe. They protect us from risks like vendor lock-in, monopolies, geopolitical dependencies, privacy intrusions, security vulnerabilities, anti-consumer practices, and much more. To realize the full potential of open source in Europe, we need coordinated efforts from governments, the private sector, and civil society. This includes raising awareness about the benefits of open source, prioritizing open source solutions in public procurement processes, providing sustainable funding for open source projects, and enforcing antitrust regulations against the multinational tech corporations that currently dominate the IT landscape. With a strong focus on privacy and a collaborative spirit, the EU has the potential to become a global leader in open source innovation. For this to happen, we need a clear commitment to those principles at all levels, and the European Commission can play a guiding role in this endeavor. In the attached document, we elaborate on our view of the European open source ecosystem and concrete steps that can be taken to make Europe more digitally independent.
organization: Private.coffee – Verein zur Förderung von Privatsphäre und digitaler Souveränität

feedback: It is very important to promote opensource in Europe in order to be independent from other continents. It is also important that opensource is truly free and independent. The advantage of opensource is that identified vulnerabilities are fixed quickly, unlike in proprietary software, because the sourcecode is open and available to everyone. Another advantage is that the total cost of ownership is low. Many companies in the EU provide opensource software, such as Proxmox, and this must continue to be promoted. It must be possible for the community and associated companies that participate in this to further develop the software without major restrictions. This makes us independent in Europe. We use open source in Europe for our services to our customers.

Il me semble essentiel, pour ne pas dépendre de pays extérieurs à l'Europe, en particulier des États-Unis, de promouvoir et utiliser le logiciel libre. Leurs logiciels propriétaires peuvent servir de mouchard et l'affaire Snowden a dévoilé qu'ils l'ont fait (et pourquoi s'arrêteraient-ils là ?). Les États-Unis en particulier ne sont pas toujours amicaux, comme le montre l'actualité récente mais aussi plus ancienne (affaire GemPlus). Leur confier nos données, leur permettre de nous espionner, tout en leur payant une redevance (les licences de leurs logiciels propriétaires sont loin d'être gratuites) ce n'est pas raisonnable. Or les logiciels libres sont développés par de nombreux bénévoles (donc à moindre coût aussi), sont sécurisés (certains comme ssl ou ssh sont même des piliers de la sécurité des communications sur internet) et permettraient à un coût certainement bien moindre que les licences propriétaires, d'avoir pour les Européens des logiciels fiables et indépendants de puissances étrangères. En tant qu'enseignant, je trouve également important que les élèves sachent que les logiciels ne sont pas réalisés comme des tours de magie mais selon des processus bien réfléchis, et aussi que le code source ouvert permet à chacun de découvrir et d'apprendre (et d'avoir la possibilité d'apprendre à faire soi-même, ce qui est une réelle liberté très concrète).
feedbackTextUserLanguage: In order not to depend on countries outside Europe, in particular the United States, it seems to me essential to promote and use open source software. Their proprietary software can serve as a mouchard and the Snowden case revealed that they did so (and why would they stop there?). The US in particular is not always friendly, as recent events show, but also older (Gemplus case). Entrusting them with our data, allowing them to spy on us, while paying them a fee (licences for their proprietary software are far from being free) is not reasonable. However, open source software is developed by many volunteers (and therefore also at a lower cost), is secure (some such as ssl or ssh are even pillars of the security of internet communications) and would make it possible, at a much lower cost than proprietary licences, to have reliable software for Europeans that is independent of foreign powers. As a teacher, I also find it important that students know that software is not made like magic towers but through well-thought-out processes, and also that open source allows everyone to discover and learn (and have the opportunity to learn to do yourself, which is a very concrete real freedom).

Europe need 100% independency fro. any other country, starts by simple office suite up to hyperscale which have zero connection or under law enforcement of another country which could control or steal our data.

Jestem właścicielem małej, Polskiej firmy IT, która wspiera przedsiębiorstwa i organizacje w budowie, utrzymaniu i zabezpieczaniu ich infrastruktury cyfrowej. W codziennej pracy mocno stawiamy na rozwiązania opensource, ponieważ umożliwiają one rozwój małym i średnim przedsiębiorstwom bez nadmiernych kosztów licencyjnych i bez uzależniania się od w pełni komercyjnych, kontrolowanych przez dostawców ekosystemów. Technologie opensource dają firmom swobodę zrównoważonego skalowania infrastruktury. Pozwalają świadomie decydować, czy i w jakim zakresie inwestować w płatne wsparcie, czy też w trudniejszych okresach ograniczać koszty, jednocześnie zachowując bezpieczne i niezawodne środowisko IT. Ta elastyczność jest kluczowa dla MŚP i bezpośrednio wzmacnia ich odporność oraz konkurencyjność. Jest to szczególnie ważne w dzisiejszych, mniej stabilnych i szybko zmieniających się czasach, kiedy napięcia geopolityczne, zakłócenia łańcuchów dostaw czy nagłe zmiany w globalnym krajobrazie technologicznym mogą znacząco wpływać na dostęp do narzędzi i usług własnościowych. Rozwiązania opensource zapewniają niezależność technologiczną, redukują ryzyko strategiczne oraz oferują poziom przejrzystości i kontroli, który jest niezbędny w warunkach niepewności. Na co dzień obserwuję, jak ekosystem opensource pomaga lokalnym firmom być innowacyjnymi, podnosić dojrzałość cyfrową i utrzymywać konkurencyjność na szybko zmieniającym się rynku. Wiele projektów opensource rozwija się bardzo dynamicznie i staje się nie tylko tańszą alternatywą, ale także funkcjonalnie silną konkurencją dla globalnych, komercyjnych dostawców. Z tych powodów zdecydowanie popieram European Open Digital Ecosystem Strategy. Spójne podejście na poziomie UE, które wzmacnia rozwój, wykorzystanie i ponowne użycie otwartych zasobów cyfrowych oraz uznaje open source za kluczowy czynnik suwerenności technologicznej, bezpieczeństwa i konkurencyjności jest niezbędne. Dostępność wysokiej jakości narzędzi opensource bezpośrednio wzmacnia europejskie firmy, ogranicza zależność od zagranicznych rozwiązań własnościowych i buduje bardziej odporny i bezpieczny krajobraz cyfrowy. Zachęcam Komisję do dalszego wspierania otwartych ekosystemów, obniżania barier dla MŚP oraz promowania otwartych standardów, bezpieczeństwa opensource i zrównoważonego, społecznościowego rozwoju.

I own a small Polish IT company that supports companies and organisations to build, maintain and secure their digital infrastructure. In our daily work, we strongly focus on open-source solutions as they enable small and medium-sized enterprises to grow without excessive licensing costs and without relying on fully commercial, supplier-controlled ecosystems. Opensource technologies give companies the freedom to scale their infrastructure sustainably. They make informed decisions on whether and to what extent to invest in paid support or reduce costs in more difficult periods, while preserving a secure and reliable IT environment. This flexibility is crucial for SMEs and directly strengthens their resilience and competitiveness. This is particularly important in today’s less stable and rapidly changing times, when geopolitical tensions, disrupted supply chains or sudden changes in the global technological landscape can significantly affect access to ownership tools and services. Opensource solutions ensure technological independence, reduce strategic risks, and offer the level of transparency and control that is necessary in an environment of uncertainty. On a daily basis, I see how the opensource ecosystem helps local companies to be innovative, improve digital maturity and remain competitive in a fast-changing market. Many opensourc

A requirement of the tender should be that a percentage of the contract cost will go to a second set of organizations that can focus on hiring developers that can support the the open source projects. Following the European tender guidelines without expensive projects to move to other software. Meanwhile the development organizations can work with the community on enhancing the software. They can work on general project enhancements and enhancements requested by the government organizations. If setup correctly this will lead to stable development organizations across Europe which can after a few years start playing a bigger role in some projects. Becoming part of the teams that manage the commits to the master branch will allow Europe to better safeguard quality. feedback:
La résilience me semble un élément essentiel de la valeur ajoutée des solutions libres. En choisissant une solution libre, l'utilisateur ou l'organisation n'est plus bloqué par son fournisseur (vendor lock-in). Il est plus facile de migrer d'un fournisseur à l'autre, il est possible d'auditer le produit ou de le modifier soi-même pour son besoin spécifique. Il est aussi possible de faire appel à un tiers pour assurer le support, la maintenance et/ou les modifications. S'il est souvent possible pour des grands acteurs (états ou grandes entreprises) de négocier des solutions personnalisées auprès de fournisseurs, cela est souvent impossible pour les simples citoyens ou les petites et moyennes entreprises. Les solutions libres permettent également la maintenance de systèmes bien après que le fournisseur original ai arrêté. Un autre avantage des solutions libres est la vitesse. Que ce soit pour un processeur ( https://github.com/openhwgroup/cva6 ), un appareil médical ( https://www.theopenventilator.com/ ) ou un logiciel de calcul scientifique ( https://octave.org/) , n'importe qui peut immédiatement avoir accès au produit, gagnant du temps et de l'argent face à des solutions propriétaires qui nécessite négociations, contrats et souvent limitations d'utilisations. Les solutions libres évitent aussi la duplication d'efforts en permettant à des individus et entreprises de collaborer et partager des solutions plutôt que de devoir redévelopper des solutions en interne à chaque fois. Si la capacité d'audit est vitale pour les solutions liées à la sécurité (par exemple OpenTitan : https://opentitan.org/ ), elle l'est aussi pour la responsabilité des institutions envers les citoyens. Ainsi, l'algorithme de sélections des étudiants dans les établissements supérieurs en France est en code libre ( https://gitlab.mim-libre.fr/parcoursup/algorithmes-de-parcoursup ). Je pense que mettre un maximum de logiciels et algorithmes institutionnelles (et données) en accès libre pourrait donner une meilleure confiance dans les institutions à une époque où la compréhension de ces systèmes est de plus en plus difficiles par les citoyens. En terme de difficulté, je pense que le financement et la maintenance à long terme sont problématiques pour des solutions libres. De nombreux projets open-source ne sont maintenus que grâce à une petite communauté de volontaires, des individus seuls ou alors des sociétés de tailles réduites. Cela les rends vulnérables aux aléas économiques et de la vie. Par ailleurs, ces structures n'ont pas toujours les moyens humains et/ou les connaissances suffisantes pour faire les demandes de financement qui pourrait les aider. Je pense qu'un moyen d'aider au financement des solutions libres est de permettre aux individus et entreprises qui ferait des dons aux développeurs de solutions libres de défiscaliser ces dons, de la même manière qu'il est possible de défiscaliser des dons aux associations dintérêts publics. De même, un dédommagement pour les contributeurs aux solutions libres pourrait être trouvé (réduction dimpôts, priorité à des appels d'offres publics,...). Les solutions libres devraient avoir une évaluation différente des solutions propriétaires lors de mise en compétition public et être avantagées (public money - public code policy). Je pense que la migration des institutions publics européennes vers des solutions logiciels libres basés sur Linux serait très bénéfique. Lécosystème Linux est suffisamment mature pour ce changement. Je pense que les institutions de l'UE ont le poids suffisant pour obliger les vendeurs de solutions propriétaires à supporter Linux (que ce soit sur le plan matériel et logiciel). Cela réduirait fortement la prise des entreprises américaines sur le marché européen (en premier lieu Microsoft) tout en permettant aux entreprises

feedback: Sul piano politico e geopolitico, la dipendenza da software proprietario può diventare una vulnerabilità. Le sanzioni internazionali hanno mostrato come laccesso a servizi cloud, aggiornamenti di sicurezza o licenze possa essere revocato per decisioni politiche esterne. In questi casi, Stati e aziende si sono trovati improvvisamente privi di strumenti essenziali, senza alcun controllo sulla situazione. Lopen source offre una risposta concreta a questi problemi. La disponibilità del codice sorgente consente audit indipendenti, maggiore sicurezza, adattamento alle esigenze locali e continuità operativa. Inoltre, favorisce lo sviluppo di competenze interne e di un ecosistema economico locale, riducendo lesportazione di risorse verso pochi grandi fornitori globali. Adottare software open source non significa rifiutare linnovazione, ma governarla. Significa scegliere trasparenza, concorrenza reale e autonomia decisionale. In unepoca in cui il digitale influenza economia, democrazia e sicurezza, lopen source rappresenta uno strumento fondamentale per preservare indipendenza economica e sovranità politica. Alcuni casi di successo di software opensource che è bene ricordare. Elasticsearch Nato come progetto open source, Elasticsearch è diventato uno standard de facto per la ricerca distribuita e lanalisi dei log. È largamente utilizzato in SIEM e SOC per il monitoraggio di eventi di sicurezza, correlazione dei log e threat hunting. Grandi aziende e provider cloud lo impiegano per la sua scalabilità, velocità e flessibilità, dimostrando come un progetto open source possa competere e superare soluzioni proprietarie in ambiti mission-critical. PostgreSQL PostgreSQL è uno dei database relazionali open source più avanzati al mondo. Utilizzato da governi, banche, telecomunicazioni e grandi piattaforme digitali, offre affidabilità, conformità ACID e funzionalità avanzate (replica, estensioni, JSON, GIS). Molte organizzazioni lo hanno adottato come alternativa diretta a database proprietari, ottenendo riduzione dei costi, maggiore controllo sui dati e indipendenza dal fornitore. Linux Linux è forse lesempio più emblematico di successo dellopen source. Alimenta la maggioranza dei server Internet, supercomputer, dispositivi embedded e sistemi cloud. Tutti i principali provider (AWS, Google Cloud, Azure) basano le loro infrastrutture su Linux. La sua adozione dimostra che lopen source può diventare infrastruttura critica globale, garantendo sicurezza, trasparenza e resilienza. Kubernetes Kubernetes, progetto open source nato in Google, è oggi lo standard per lorchestrazione di container. È adottato massivamente in ambienti enterprise e governativi per gestire applicazioni distribuite e cloud-native. La sua natura aperta ha impedito la creazione di monopoli tecnologici, favorendo interoperabilità e portabilità tra cloud diversi. Apache HTTP Server e NGINX Apache e NGINX sono stati e continuano a essere tra i web server più usati al mondo. Hanno sostenuto la crescita del web moderno, dimostrando che software open source può essere più stabile e performante di molte soluzioni commerciali, diventando uno standard industriale. OpenSSL: OpenSSL è una libreria open source fondamentale per la crittografia e la sicurezza delle comunicazioni su Internet. È utilizzata in milioni di sistemi per HTTPS, VPN e servizi sicuri. Nonostante episodi critici come Heartbleed, la risposta aperta e collaborativa ha rafforzato il progetto, evidenziando come la trasparenza del codice sia un vantaggio, non un rischio. Questi casi di successo testimoniano come l'ecosistema open-source sia vincente, sempre

feedback: Open source software hraje důležitou roli v zachování rovnováhy na trhu. Pokud si uvědomíme například poslední dva roky vývoje software VMWare, které bylo dominantním hráčem na poli virtualizace infrastruktury IT, od akvizice firmou Broadcom došlo k naprosto zásadní změně cenotvorby. Pro menší podniky například vzrostly náklady na provoz tohoto software TÉMĚŘ NA STONÁSOBEK, nebýt open source alternativ, bylo by to pro chod těchto společností velmi problematické.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: Open source software plays an important role in maintaining market balance. Taking into account, for example, the last two years of the development of VMware, which was the dominant player in the field of IT infrastructure virtualisation, there has been a fundamental change in pricing since the acquisition by Broadcom. For smaller companies, for example, the cost of operating this software has increased by almost 100 times, without open source alternatives, which would be very problematic for smaller companies.

feedback: Premessa: è necessario creare un ecosistema tecnologico europeo certificato fatto di componenti software e hardware che punti a erogare servizi che utilizzano esclusivamente soluzioni europee indipendenti. Definizioni: lopen source e lopen hardware forniscono i mattoni di base sui quali anche i colossi del cloud, come AWS (Amazon) e Google Cloud, basano i loro servizi. Finanziare, direttamente o indirettamente, soltanto i progetti open source e open hardware non doterà lUE di un ecosistema di soluzioni indipendenti. Anzi questo potrebbe rafforzare le soluzioni cloud dei colossi del cloud. Inoltre come si fa a decidere quali progetti Open finanziare ? La soluzione proposta: prevedere una certificazione, basandosi su l'ottimo lavoro fatto ad esempio, dal team di PNT (Piattaforma Nazionale per la Telemedicina) in Italia, per avere una certificazione reale, sia del processo che del prodotto, per certificare le componenti dellecosistema tecnologico europeo. Questo ecosistema deve essere fatto di data center, che devono risiedere sul territorio di stati membri, devono usare sistemi operativi certificati ecosistema tecnologico europeo basati su Sistemi Operativi open source (si lavori ad una lista corta di sistemi operativi che può essere Debian, Ubuntu, ecc.), basato su hardware ecosistema tecnologico europeo. Questo ecosistema deve essere fatto di servizi base certificati ecosistema tecnologico europeo basati su DBMS open source (si lavori ad una lista corta di DBMS come PostgreSQL, MySQL), di WebServer (come Apache HTTP Server), di VPN (Wireguard) tutti obbligatoriamente self-hosted. Si certifichino i progetti open di iA e il self-hosting di questi. Si certifichino i progetti di integrazione open source (come Apache Camel) che devono usare protocolli aperti e condivisi (come HL7). Tutto questo ecosistema certificato deve avere come condizione tecnologica di base lindipendenza da servizi esterni rispetto allecosistema stesso. Tale certificazione avrà come target (chi la deve richiedere) le soluzioni software delle aziende pubbliche e private europee e con tale certificazione, la chiave di tutto, deve portare allottenimento di fondi stabili e continui di finanziamento e non costare al progetto richiedente la certificazione. Sarà lazienda richiedente la certificazione e quindi il finanziamento che dovrà documentare un supporto economico ad alcuni progetti open facenti parte della soluzione certificata. Questo è per buona parte un approccio regolatorio cosa che lUE sa fare bene. Così facendo si avranno una serie di data center certificati, non sottoposti al Cloud Act USA e una serie di servizi software di base certificati e solo le soluzioni hardware e software che girano su tali ecosistemi potranno beneficiare dei finanziamenti dellUE, solo le soluzioni che hanno questa certificazione potranno avere la compliance verso i servizi nazionali di IAM, di Privacy e interoperare con i servizi Sanitari e Statali dei paesi membri e con le Regioni (negli stati come in Italia dove la Sanità è demandata a queste). Come finanziare tutto questo: puntando alla costruzione di due ecosistemi così certificati, uno per i cittadini dellUE e uno per la difesa dellUE (clone del primo) e quindi usando i fondi previsti per il piano ReArm Europe. Questo perché la costruzione di un ecosistema tecnologico europeo per uso militare dovrebbe essere lobiettivo di ReArm Europe, prima che lacquisto di armamenti, ed Internet è nata proprio con questa bivalenza che potrebbe portare allottenimento della sovranità dellUE sulle comunicazioni e sulle infrastrutture tecnologiche che sono alla base di tutto.

Buonasera, I am writing as a designer of ambeinti cloud for a company with more than 500 employees and as a member of ILS (Italian Linux Society). The main strengths are undoubtedly some beautiful realities such as Nextcloud and Proxmox, which can build trust and a community in which to come together. It is clear that one of the obstacles is the empowerment of the wrong figures for the transition to open solutions (at least in Italy). System administrators should be relieved of responsibility for this choice, to avoid an office 365 effect, where nobody turned to open solutions because nobody wanted to take responsibility for exiting a de facto standard. The most virtuous projects should also be funded (perhaps by putting public metrics in place) and strategic projects such as Proxmox should certainly be protected. column65: I would like to urge the Commission, to the full extent of my rights, to define a strategy that: oblige public institutions to use open source solutions and if possible Free Software. Open and possibly free EU-wide standards for documents, protocols and databases for any software used in the EU should be defined and implemented. Because this strategy will avoid lock-in effects for organisations. Switching to open source and free software alternatives is often considered too risky, as the perceived cost of disposing of proprietary formats (such as the.docx) is too high. The application of open standards across the EU can significantly change this situation. If the EU applies open standards to all software companies operating on the EU market, it will incentivise non-EU companies to apply open standards in their private software, which in turn will maintain the compatibility of EU nations. It would also be a priority objective for the EU to promote these open standards globally.

feedback:
As a European IT service provider and certified partner deploying open-source infrastructure solutions for SMEs, public administrations and regulated sectors, we strongly support the European Open Digital Ecosystems initiative. From our operational experience, open-source infrastructure software is already a mature and reliable foundation for European digital sovereignty. Solutions such as Proxmox Virtual Environment enable organisations to build fully functional virtualisation, storage and backup environments without proprietary licensing constraints, while maintaining high security, interoperability and predictable costs. Open-source infrastructure provides several concrete advantages. First, it significantly reduces total cost of ownership. The absence of licence fees lowers both CAPEX and OPEX, which is critical for municipalities, associations and SMEs operating under strict budget constraints. Customers pay only for support and services rather than mandatory software licensing. Second, it eliminates vendor lock-in. Workloads run on standard hardware and Linux-based stacks, allowing organisations to change providers or internalise operations without re-architecting their systems. Third, it improves transparency and security. Publicly auditable source code enables faster vulnerability detection, independent security reviews, and quicker remediation, which is particularly important in regulated environments. These benefits are not theoretical. We observe them daily in production environments: In a French public-sector organisation, we replaced a legacy proprietary hypervisor with a three-node open-source cluster. The new platform provides high availability, distributed storage and integrated backup while running on standard servers. The migration reduced annual licensing costs by more than 60% and allowed the IT team to reinvest budget into cybersecurity and user services instead of software subscriptions. For a healthcare and social-care association hosting sensitive personal data, we deployed a fully on-premise virtualisation and backup stack. The solution provides isolated virtual machines, encrypted backups and fast disaster recovery while ensuring full control of patient data. Because the platform is open source and auditable, compliance and security reviews are simpler and more transparent than with black-box proprietary solutions. In an industrial SME, we consolidated multiple ageing physical servers into a small hyperconverged cluster. This reduced hardware footprint, energy consumption and maintenance overhead while improving resilience. Backup and replication are integrated, enabling rapid recovery from ransomware or hardware failure without additional proprietary software layers. For multi-site organisations, we regularly implement clusters that replicate between locations. This architecture ensures business continuity even if one site fails, without dependence on foreign hyperscale cloud providers. Customers retain full sovereignty over their infrastructure and data. Despite these successes, the current regulatory and procurement landscape still tends to favour large proprietary vendors. In practice, we observe that: procurement frameworks often assume per-licence commercial models and do not fairly evaluate 100% open-source solutions, certification and compliance processes are costly and complex for smaller European vendors and integrators, long-term maintenance of critical open-source infrastructure lacks dedicated public funding. To strengthen Europes digital sovereignty and competitiveness, we recommend: procurement guidelines that explicitly recognise open-source solutions as first-class options, financial incentives or tax credits for companies contributing to open-source infrastructure, dedicated EU maintenance grants for critical open-source components, simplified and affordable security certification schemes for SMEs, training

feedback: We are Sailboard. We support open. We are the Dutch open source company heading towards open ecosystems leading, enabling and engaging open ecosystems. At Sailboard we work together with our customers and partners to build open ecosystems, which focuses on (open) leadership for open source software, licenses and standards. As a member and consultancy partner of the OSPO Alliance, we use The Good Governance Handbook at our clients to build and maintain Open Source Program Offices. 1. What are the strengths and weaknesses of the EU open-source sector? What are the main barriers that hamper (i) adoption and maintenance of high-quality and secure open source; and (ii) sustainable contributions to open-source communities? First, let us acknowledge that open source itself should be borderless. As EU we can add value to existing and new open source projects, but we have to say Contributed in the EU, instead of making it political. Companies like Red Hat have their main engineering hub in the EU, so it is fair to say that we have plenty of open source talent in the EU. For example: every year we meet many talented people on events like FOSDEM. The problem we see every day is that most of the EU public sectors are relying on enterprise support instead of community support. Most (luckily this gets better every day) of the public sector doesnt engage with open source. They are mostly users of open source, instead of giving back to the open source software ecosystem. In our opinion this is a weakness of the EU public open-source sector. EU procurement rules also present challenges: many smaller SME companies cant even register for a tender, because for example they dont meet the stated requirements for minimum turnover, while enterprise companies arent always the best solution for open source software. 3. What concrete measures and actions may be taken at EU level to support the development and growth of the EU open-source sector and contribute to the EUs technological sovereignty and cybersecurity agenda? To address these barriers, we recommend concrete EU-level measures: * Take time to understand what an open source mindset means. * Build (public) Open Source Program Offices (consider realizing OSPOs by using the OSPO Alliance handbook; consider asking for help from the OSPO alliance partners) and publish information for both public and private sectors. * Work together with existing open source ecosystems and hubs.

Practical experience with open-source software (Proxmox, Zabbix). In our experience as an IT company providing technical support and consultancy to SMEs and organisations of different sizes, the use of infrastructure-level open-source software such as Proxmox and Zabbix has been essential to delivering reliable, sustainable, and secure services to our customers. Proxmox has enabled us to build complete virtualisation and backup infrastructures without hidden licensing costs or vendor lock-in. This is particularly important for SMEs, which often cannot afford the recurring costs of proprietary solutions but still require high availability, operational continuity, and fast recovery in the event of incidents or ransomware attacks. Thanks to the fully open-source nature of Proxmox, we can inspect system behaviour, integrate existing tools, and adapt solutions to the real needs of each customer, rather than forcing the infrastructure into vendor-defined models. This increases customer trust and reduces long-term operational risk. Similarly, Zabbix allows us to centrally and transparently monitor heterogeneous infrastructures, often composed of hardware and software from multiple vendors. The ability to customise monitoring and quickly integrate new systems is essential for providing proactive support services, especially in environments with limited IT resources. The combined use of these open-source solutions has enabled us to deliver high-quality technical consultancy while maintaining control over data, ensuring regulatory compliance (including GDPR), and reducing dependency on non-EU vendors. In this context, open source is not an ideological choice but a pragmatic one that improves competitiveness, security, and economic sustainability. We believe that supporting and promoting infrastructure-level open-source software at the European level represents a concrete foundation for strengthening EU digital sovereignty, particularly for SMEs and public administrations that require reliable, auditable, and long-term sustainable solutions.

I speak as a junior software engineer working in Belgium. European countries currently rely extensively on non-EU digital services, mainly from the USA and China. This raises numerous concerns for European citizens. First, these countries carry out mass surveillance programs on other countries including many in Europe. FISA warrants allow US intelligence agencies to monitor the usage of software applications and reshape them to monitor them even more. The USA has done so many times, for instance by tempering encryption keys generation algorithms and have access to users' secret messages [1] [2]. Besides privacy concerns, this allows them to analyze public opinion and influence it, for instance to alter elections. Reshaping the EU digital ecosystem by leveraging the existing open-source environment is absolutely doable, for it knows a extremely strong base of projects in all sectors, a solid community and widespread enthusiasm. We also have many brilliant minds in Europe, who are unfortunately often attracted by US salaries. Strengthening the European digital ecosystem would mitigate this effect and more people would participate in the manner of a virtuous circle. I know I would love to, either as a full-time activity or in my spare time. I believe that the overall impact of this initiative can be immense. The current digital world consists in various markets. It would probably take hundreds of pages just to explain how wide it is. Unlike other markets like industry or agriculture in which locality has a great influence in their evolution, the digital world communicates between its different parts across the globe in a matter of seconds, which make it a very unique sector. This lead to a world where a few companies hold the majority of market share in some areas, and the biggest companies can buy out emerging ones in other areas, which created an unprecedented and dangerous monopoly owned by a handful of corporations. I believe that the digital world does not have to be this way. We could rely on software produced by public institutions throughout Europe, indirectly funded by all citizen and benefiting everyone. This approach would solve user trust in digital systems, greatly reduce our costs (including individuals, institutions and businesses costs), strengthen European digital sovereignty and interaction between countries. The only issue I foresee is that some small European companies competing for a market share may go brankrupt when an open-source and publicly-funded alternative comes to play. However these very companies may join the effort and these positions could be fed back into the open-source environment. The systems which should be prioritized in my opinions are as follows: - 1. Services that negatively impact users' well-being - 2. Services in which user data flows are the highest - 3. Operating systems - 4. Hardware providers - 5. Services which are the most energy-consuming - 6.
