feedback: I believe open source is critical to both independence as well as an interdependent world. With Next Generation Internet to start projects and Sovereign Tech Fund to sustain them the structure is there to finance an open source world. However, i believe the size of the effort is still too small to really compete with Big Tech. I hope it can scale up, and maybe there can be other formats as well. For instance, why shouldnt the EU hire their own full-time open source engineers?

Open source software is essential for Europes digital sovereignty, competitiveness, and cyber resilience. Solutions like Proxmox VE show how a fully open-source infrastructure stack can replace costly proprietary platforms without hidden licensing fees, reducing total cost of ownership for SMEs and public administrations. Open source prevents vendor lock-in by allowing organisations to run workloads on any hardware or provider, ensuring long-term independence from foreign hyperscalers. Its transparency also improves security, since code can be audited publicly and vulnerabilities can be fixed faster. The EU should support open source infrastructure through maintenance funding, clear procurement guidelines, and regulations that encourage innovation rather than creating barriers for smaller projects. Open source is not only a technical option, but a strategic foundation for a secure and sovereign European digital ecosystem.

Qu'attends l'Europe pour privilégier l'open source !??! Principales motivations stratégiques en faveur de l'utilisation des logiciels libres en Europe : -Réduire la dépendance aux plateformes non-EU (Microsoft, GAFA, OpenAI,...) et privilégier le contrôle national des technologies critiques telles que les systèmes dexploitation. Cet objectif est non seulement ECONOMIQUE, mais aussi essentiel à notre SECURITE nationale, au CONTROLE de nos infrastructures critiques et à notre SOUVERAINETE technologique. -Gagner en FLEXIBILITE, REDUIRE LES COÛTS et limiter l'exposition aux contraintes externes. -Créer un cercle vertueux en stimulant l'INNOVATION rapide et de développement des compétences. S'appuyer sur de vastes communautés de développeurs en Europe (notamment dans les secteurs technologiques porteurs), renforcer leur communication et encourager une collaboration transparente, permettrait à l'Europe de se positionner pour accélérer les progrès dans des domaines de pointe comme l'IA, le blockchain, l'informatique quantique et la conception de semi-conducteurs (domaines essentiels à la compétitivité et à la résilience à long terme). Qu'attend l'Europe pour agir ?? (D'autres grandes puissances comme la Chine ont déjà compris depuis longtemps les avantages de l'open source !) PS : je ne comprends pas pourquoi je suis obligée d'acheter une licence Windows quand j'achète un nouveau PC (sous peine de me voir refuser l'achat). Je pensais que les ventes liées et forcées étaient interdites en Europe.

Open source Virtualisierung ist sehr wichtig weil die Vergangenheit gezeigt hat, welchen Stellenwert Unabhängigkeit in der Wahl der Software hat. Große Konzerne wollen Firmen in eine unabwendbare Abhängigkeit stürzen und ziehen dann die Preise an. Siehe z. B. Broadcom oder Microsoft. Proxmox ist als Virtualisierungslösung sehr leistungsstark, hat eine große Community und bietet jedem Kunden einen annehmbaren Preis, bei Bedarf mit Support.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: Open source virtualisation is very important because the past has shown the importance of independence in the choice of software. Large corporations want to plunge firms into inevitable dependency and then attract prices. See, for example, Broadcom or Microsoft. Proxmox, as a virtualisation solution, is very powerful, has a large community and offers an acceptable price to each customer, with support if needed.

feedback: Sehr geehrte Damen und Herren, Die Initiative "Auf dem Weg zu europäischen offenen digitalen Ökosystemen" beschreibt die aktuelle Situation der Open Source Software hauptsächlich hinsichtlich der wirtschaftlichen Bedeutung. Ich möchte anregen, dass ein weiterer Aspekte betrachtet wird. Open Source Software soll für die schulische und universitäre Bildung weiterhin uneingeschränkt zur Verfügung stehen. Diese Software ermöglicht die kostengünstige Ausbildung in Digitaltechniken, die für die EU notwendig sind. Die Einstiegsmöglichkeiten, insbesondere für finanzschwache oder jugendliche Leistungsträger werden durch Open Source Software vereinfacht. Mit freundlichen Grüßen Axel Rothe
feedbackTextUserLanguage: Ladies and Gentlemen, The initiative “Towards European Open Digital Ecosystems” describes the current situation of Open Source Software mainly in terms of its economic importance. I would like to suggest that we look at another aspect. Open source software should remain fully available for school and university education. This software enables cost-effective training in digital technologies necessary for the EU. Entry opportunities, especially for financially weak or young service providers, will be simplified through open source software. Yours sincerely, Axel Rothe

feedback: Ich bin seit über 30 Jahren im Bereich Software tätig und habe zuletzt auch ein international erfolgreiches Software Unternehmen mit Hauptsitz in Österreich geleitet. Ich unterstütze die Idee einer Promotion von Europäischer Software. Ein erstes, kurzes Feedback: Ich sehe hier aktuell kein durchdachtes, offenes Business Modell da sich in der Kommunikation und den Unterlagen eine Festlegung auf "Open Source only" feststellen lässt. Ich finde es strategisch falsch, hier grundsätzlich alle europäischen, proprietären Software Produkte von vornherein in der Initiative auszuschließen und ausschließlich in Richtung "Open Source" zu denken. Wir sehen ja anhand von vielen Beispielen, dass kommerzielle Software Produkte Innovation, Arbeitsplätze in Europa am Standort der Headquarters, Steuerleistungen, und viele andere Vorteile bieten, die Open Source basierte Business Modelle vergleichsweise nicht auf diesem Niveau bieten kann. Ich bin nicht grundsätzlich gegen Open Source, wir sollten in Europa aber auch kommerzielle Lösungen als wichtigen Wirtschaftsbereich wahrnehmen, und auch in unseren europäischen Technologieinitiativen abbilden. Ich stehe für weiterführende Informationen dazu auch sehr gerne zur Verfügung! Ich bin altersbedingt als CEO zurückgetreten, könnte mir aber vorstellen, hier mit meiner Erfahrung und Expertise zu unterstützen. Beste Grüße und weiterhin alles Gute!
feedbackTextUserLanguage: I have been working in the software sector for over 30 years and most recently also managed an internationally successful software company headquartered in Austria. I support the idea of promoting European software. A first, short feedback: I do not currently see a well-thought-out, open business model here, as the communication and documentation make it possible to establish that ‘open source only’ is used. I find it strategically wrong to exclude all European proprietary software products from the initiative from the outset and to think exclusively in the direction of open source. We can see from many examples that commercial software offers products of innovation, jobs in Europe at headquarters, tax benefits and many other advantages that open source business models cannot offer at this level in comparison. I am not fundamentally against open source, but we should also see commercial solutions as an important sector of the economy in Europe and also reflect them in our European Technology Initiatives. Please do not hesitate to contact me if you require any further information. I resigned as CEO due to my age, but could imagine supporting me here with my experience and expertise. Best regards, and best of luck!

feedback: Context: I work as a product manager for LaSuite Docs https://github.com/suitenumerique/docs/. It is a collaborative note taking and knowledge management product that was built by the French and German government. It's built on top of the following libraries: BlockNote(https://github.com/TypeCellOS/BlockNote/ by Yousef El Dardiry), Yjs (https://github.com/yjs/ by Kevin Jahns) and Prosemirror(https://github.com/prosemirror). For our roadmap(https://docs.numerique.gouv.fr/docs/d1d3788e-c619-41ff-abe8-2d079da2f084/) to unfold, we had the pleasure to collaborate directly with the maintainers of the libraries above. In the process we learnt a few things and decided to put forward a draft playbook to make the best of collaboration between IT buyers and oss library maintainers. We first presented this playbook at FOSDEM 2026(https://fosdem.org/2026/schedule/event/DC97FQ-building_digital_workplace_solutions_on_top_of_foundational_libraries_blocknote_/). Why this document? Libraries are rarely involved in the IT procurement processes and our products are as good as their underlying libaries. We believe that working directly with maintainers and ensure that maintainers get a piece of the IT contracting cake is the key to a better open source ecosystem. Bellow we propose a few ideas on how collaborating with oss maintainers should and could look. . Playbook :How to Collaborate with Open Source Libraries 1. Align with Existing Roadmaps Open source libraries thrive when contributions align with their long-term vision. Instead of requesting custom features, fund existing roadmap items. This ensures your investment benefits the entire ecosystem, not just your project. 2. Invest in Standardization Funding the development of standardized, reusable components creates value for everyone. Prioritize features that solve common problems and can be adopted across industries. Standardization reduces fragmentation and strengthens the librarys impact. 3. Support Ongoing Maintenance Building a feature is just the beginning. Maintenancebug fixes, security updates, and documentationis what keeps a library reliable. Allocate resources for sustained upkeep, not just initial development. (Ex: invest between 30 to 50% of you feature budget in maintenance work) 4. Provide Predictable, Long-Term Funding Open source maintainers need stability. Offer multi-year funding commitments or recurring sponsorships. Predictable support allows maintainers to plan, innovate, avoid [burnout](https://dev.to/opensauced/the-silent-crisis-in-open-source-when-maintainers-walk-away-1m81) and reduce [bus factor](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bus_factor). In short: **focus on quality rather than survival**. 5. Collaborate Transparently Engage directly on public code repositories (GitLab, Forgejo, GitHub etc.). Share your requirements, feedback, and progress openly. Transparency builds trust, attracts more contributors, and ensures alignment with the communitys needs. 6. Participate Actively in the Community Dont just fund contribute. Write issues, submit pull requests, and join discussions. Active participation strengthens the library and demonstrates your commitment to its success. 7. Understand and Support Dependencies Open source projects rely on other libraries. Audit your dependencies and, where possible, fund their maintenance too. A healthy ecosystem depends on the sustainability of its entire supply chain. This evidence is published on GitHub (https://github.com/virgile-dev/playbook-work-with-oss-libraries), it is open to contribution

Main points 1. The EU will have to lead by example 2. Improved procurement procedures 3. Advisable actions The EU will have to lead by example For open source to be a success, the European institutions will have to demonstrate the alternative is feasible. Currently, using open source is considered risky and complicated. At the same time, businesses don't feel pressured by European sovereignty laws (such as GDPR). There is a justified feeling that if the EU would enforce its own laws, its economy would crash. If the EU can show the alternative is feasible, it is both the carrot and the stick: it shows there is an alternative and that the EU would be capable of enforcing its own sovereignty laws. Improved procurement procedures When procuring software or related services a wider perspective on cost is required: - Cost of operating the service - Cost of migrating away at the end-of-life - Risk to continuity - Risk to sovereignty - Risk of monoculture - Good citizenship The current focus on the cost of operating a service, makes closed source strong, because they can more effectively hide their deficiencies. Risk to sovereignty When procuring software or related services, the supply chain risk and risk to sovereignty has to be taken into account. The knowledge, hardware, source code and data must be available to the EU and EU data protection has to be guaranteed. These requirements will favor European companies in general. Risk of monoculture A risk assessment has to be made at the tactical level (when a piece of software is procured) but also at the strategic level. If one local community chooses a particular email provider, this induces little risk. When every local community chooses the same, it is potentially very dangerous. By using a risk based approach, smaller vendors are more free to compete, as they inherently pose less of a risk, because they have a smaller userbase. Good citizenship. Companies that are not expected to pay taxes in the EU should be avoided. Open source companies not contributing back to the community should be similarly avoided. Companies repeatedly failing to deliver should be avoided, Concrete advice: - For government procurement, a wider view of risk is required: risks to sovereignty, continuity, . This assessment should not be left to the vendor, but should be executed by the government itself. By executing assessments on the buyer side, open source is naturally advantaged: all information is public, making it easy to audit, perform escrow, Large, foreign corporations will naturally be at a disadvantage, as they are complex, tied to many obligations and often not at liberty to comply with the required regulations. - Start a mandatory software registry for government agencies, to track software usage, vendors reputation and risk, to asses risk at the strategic level and to allow better information sharing. - Encourage local businesses, competence centers and services to be built around open source. Make the government itself take the first slice of risk. This will lead to a varied and localized business eco system that can be leveraged by businesses to go european.

Open source software is one of the foundations of todays digital world. Almost every modern digital systemused by governments, companies, universities, and individualsrelies on open-source components. Without them, technology teams would spend most of their time rebuilding basic tools instead of focusing on innovation and public value. For this reason, having a strong and sustainable open-source ecosystem is crucial for the EUs competitiveness, security, and technological sovereignty. 1. Strengths, Weaknesses, and Barriers The EU is already a global open source powerhouse: brand new data from GitHub's innovation Graph shows that there are now almost 25 million EU developers on GitHub, who made over 155 million contributions to public projects in the last year alone. However, funding for open source is often short-term and fragmented, while many critical libraries and tools require long-term maintenance and security work. In many cases, software used by millions depends on a very small number of maintainers with limited resources. Adoption is also limited by public procurement rules that still tend to favour proprietary solutions and well-known vendors, creating vendor lock-in and reducing the reuse of public code. In addition, not all public institutions have clear policies or expertise on how to adopt, contribute to, or publish open source. Finally, transparency alone does not guarantee security: without coordinated support for maintenance, vulnerability management, and secure development practices, risks remain. 2. Added value for the public and private sectors The main value of open source is that everyone can read, understand, improve, and reuse the code. This transparency increases trust and makes it easier to identify bugs, security issues, and inefficiencies. It also encourages collaboration: improvements made by one organisation can benefit many others. For the public sector, open source reduces dependency on single vendors, improves interoperability between systems, and allows publicly funded software to be reused instead of being rebuilt multiple times. For the private sector, it lowers entry barriers, supports innovation, and enables companies to build services on top of shared digital building blocks. 3. Measures the EU could take At the EU level, several practical actions could make a real difference: - Provide stable, long-term funding for critical open-source software, focusing on maintenance, security, and core infrastructure rather than only new features. - Invest in education and training to build open-source skills across public administrations, academia, and industry. - Improve public procurement rules so that open-source solutions are fairly evaluated, including their long-term benefits such as interoperability and reduced lock-in. - Create incentives for companies to contribute back to open-source projects they depend on, especially when those projects are strategically important. - Support common security practices for open source used in the public sector, such as vulnerability disclosure processes and software supply-chain transparency 4. Priority technology areas Open source innovation should largely remain driven by communities and real needs. However, the EU should prioritise support in areas that are clearly strategic, such as cloud and edge infrastructure, cybersecurity tools, and open tools for data and AI. This balanced approach respects freedom and innovation while ensuring that critical public infrastructure is reliable and secure. 5. Sectors with high impact Greater use of open source could strongly increase competitiveness and cyber resilience in public administration by improving transparency and long-term control over systems. Academia and research naturally benefit from open knowledge and reuse. Other important sectors include healthcare, energy, transport, and smart cities, where open solutions can reduce lock-i

feedback: Sehr geehrte Damen und Herren, ich möchte die aktuelle Initiative nutzen, um die Aufmerksamkeit auf notwendige Lösungen für die Verwaltung, Organisation und den sicheren Betrieb der IT zu lenken. Der stetig wachsende Sektor des Service Managements wird derzeit von großen außereuropäischen Anbietern dominiert, die ihre Kunden zunehmend zur Nutzung von Cloud-Modellen drängen. Die in diesen Systemen verwalteten Informationen sind für Organisationen unternehmenskritisch und in höchstem Maße schützenswert. Der Verlust, die Manipulation oder der unbefugte Zugriff durch Dritte stellen ein erhebliches Risiko dar nicht nur für den IT-Betrieb des betroffenen Unternehmens, sondern in einer vernetzten Wirtschaft auch für alle Partnerunternehmen. Innerhalb der EU entwickelte Lösungen, darunter hervorragende Open-Source-Angebote, sind funktional ausgereift und etablierten Produkten in vielen Punkten sogar überlegen. Da es sich hierbei jedoch meist um spezialisierte Einzellösungen handelt, scheuen viele Organisationen den Aufwand, diese zu einem Gesamtsystem zu integrieren oft auch aufgrund mangelnden Vertrauens oder fehlenden Verständnisses für Open Source. Hier könnte die Initiative ansetzen: Durch gezielte Förderung von Forschung und Pilotprojekten sowie durch regulatorische Unterstützung für kompatible Produkte könnten ausgereifte, vernetzte Lösungen geschaffen werden. Dies würde nicht nur die Verwaltung stärken, sondern auch den Weg für neue, wettbewerbsfähige Geschäftsmodelle europäischer Anbieter ebnen. Mit freundlichen Grüßen, Peter Resch-Edermayr, MSc vitamin-S.consulting
feedbackTextUserLanguage: Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to use the current initiative to draw attention to necessary solutions for the management, organisation and safe operation of IT. The ever-growing service management sector is currently dominated by large non-European providers, which are increasingly pushing their customers to use cloud models. The information managed in these systems is critical for organisations and deserves the highest level of protection. The loss, manipulation or unauthorised access by third parties poses a significant risk not only to the IT operations of the company concerned, but also to all partner companies in a networked economy. Solutions developed within the EU, including excellent open-source offers, are functionally mature and in many respects even superior to established products. However, as these are mostly specialised stand-alone solutions, many organisations are reluctant to integrate them into an overall system, often also due to a lack of trust or understanding of open source. The initiative could focus on: Mature, networked solutions could be created through targeted support for research and pilot projects, as well as regulatory support for compatible products. This would not only strengthen governance, but also pave the way for new, competitive business models of European providers. Yours sincerely, Peter Resch-Edermayr, MSc vitamin-S.consulting

feedback:
Practical experience from high-volume digital employment platforms Across several initiatives focused on employment, activation and lead-based matching, we operate digital platforms that process large volumes of registrations per day, handle continuous user inflow, and rely on automation, data-driven workflows and open technologies. These systems are not theoretical pilots: they are production platforms that must scale, comply with regulation, remain cost-efficient and function reliably under real-world pressure. In building and operating these platforms, we consistently observe that technology itself is rarely the limiting factor. The core challenges almost never stem from software maturity, scalability or performance. Instead, failures and inefficiencies arise from the system surrounding the technology. What is often missing from the public debate is the recognition that many digital failures are not technical in nature. The software is seldom the real problem. The root causes are structural and systemic: how projects are procured, how suppliers are selected, how decisions are taken (or avoided), and how innovation is structurally discouraged. Digital projects treated as construction projects Public-sector digitalisation is still frequently approached as if it were a traditional construction project: everything defined upfront, one large delivery moment, and the expectation that reality will adapt to the specification. In environments where technology, regulation and user behaviour evolve continuously, this model is fundamentally outdated. It prevents iteration, blocks learning, and transforms uncertainty into contractual risk instead of managed adaptation. Formal compliance over substantive quality Anyone with experience in public procurement recognises the pattern. Candidates can be excluded based on: a missing signature, a minor formal error, or an administrative detail unrelated to solution quality. At the same time, demonstrable real-world experiencebuilding, operating and maintaining systems actually used by hundreds of thousands or millions of usersoften weighs less than formal compliance or financial scale. This creates a perverse outcome: the system does not necessarily select the best solution, but the most procedurally compliant bidder. The illusion of competition Formally, tenders are open and competitive. In practice, they often convey the impression that: the winner is known in advance, the specification mirrors an existing model, alternative or more efficient approaches are structurally excluded. This is particularly visible in marketing, communication and digital production. Outdated operational models persist Many tenders still assume operational models where: large teams manually produce banners, visuals and variants, graphical output is central, human labour is the core production mechanism. In the private sector, this model has largely disappeared. Today, such processes are: highly automated, driven by templates, data and parameters, designed as systems rather than manual workflows. What previously required 2030 people can now be built by a single technically skilled specialist in monthsafter which the system operates autonomously for years, with fewer errors and lower cost. Yet public authorities continue to spend tens of millions annually on manual structures, simply because they fit existing contracts and procedures. The result is that public funds are used to preserve inefficiency. Artificial barriers that exclude innovation Selection criteria such as: minimum turnover thresholds of 2 million or more, team size requirements, reference demands only large incumbents can meet, are theoretically meant to ensure stability. In practice, they: exclude small, highly specialised teams with strong technical maturity, prevent innovative solutions from being considered, ensure the same actors are repeatedly selected. This produces a clos

feedback: It's really good that the EU is looking at open source as a way forward in its digital future. This is a good match with how the EU works, a collaboration with a sum bigger than its parts. To use open source as a strategy, you should both combine support for existing open source developers/projects to work on whatever they seem fit. Often this is a single person. They might not agree with the direction you want. Although you should be capable to take over the projects when they become stale, you should not be disruptive for the current teams/person. You need a solution built from bottom to top, where kernel, os, system libraries and end user software. Is being handled in such a way that you are completely independent. This includes every piece of cloud involved, like PPA servers. Practically, you'll need your own git host, build farm, and testing such that you can continue using it after you are cut off. For example, sing Microsofts GitHub will still keep you at a vulnerable spot. Finally, you need your users to become convinced of using it. Price, usability and legislation can help here. Although you'll have a governmental factor, it will be important to stay on the supporting side such that users don't see it as "controled by". If you want to go for this, it will require a significant investment of time, resources and money to get to a point where you can be considered fully independent. I definitely think it is the right direction, though be aware that you can't go back. If you betray the open source community by suddenly cutting costs/..., you'll become known as unreliable and they won't trust you any more.
Things people know are bad. Things people don't know are even worse. Things people do Open Source that are much better.

I strongly encourage a European Open Digital Ecosystems strategy and to scale-up funding for Free Open-Source Software (FOSS) accordingly. I think, by supporting FOSS in its entirety, the European Open Digital Ecosystems strategy can encourage more FOSS and attract projects under an European umbrella. FOSS can guarantee individual and social sovereignty and resilient democratic structures. Please find my detailed suggestions attached.

Apoyo firmemente que el Marco Financiero Plurianual impulse la soberanía digital europea a través de Ecosistemas Digitales Abiertos y el principio Dinero Público, Código Público. La inversión estratégica en Software Libre y estándares abiertos es esencial para mejorar la calidad de vida de la ciudadanía: garantiza infraestructuras públicas seguras y transparentes, protege nuestra privacidad frente a monopolios tecnológicos externos y fomenta un acceso plural y no discriminatorio a la vida digital. Esta política democratiza la tecnología, permitiendo que PYMEs, administraciones y la sociedad civil desarrollen soluciones adaptadas a nuestras necesidades y valores, evitando encierros en ecosistemas privativos. Es la base para una Europa digitalmente soberana, innovadora y socialmente justa.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: I strongly support that the Multiannual Financial Framework boosts European digital sovereignty through Open Digital Ecosystems and the principle of Public Money, Public Code. Strategic investment in Free Software and Open Standards is essential to improve citizens’ quality of life: it ensures secure and transparent public infrastructure, protects our privacy from external technological monopolies, and fosters pluralistic and non-discriminatory access to digital life. This policy democratises technology, enabling SMEs, administrations and civil society to develop solutions adapted to our needs and values, avoiding lock-in to private ecosystems. It is the basis for a digitally sovereign, innovative and socially fair Europe.

feedback:
- Ohne Kontrolle über die Entwicklungsplattformen, hat Europa keine Kontrolle über Open-Source, wodurch die Idee der Unabhängigkeit hinfällig wird. Microsoft kontrolliert GitHub, auf dem schätzungsweise 70 % aller Open-Source-Projekte entwickelt werden und kann im Zuge von Sanktionen feindliche Entwickler, auch europäische jederzeit ausschließen. - Europa hat keine Kontrolle über die Entwicklungswerkzeuge. Man kann keine Open-Source-Software entwickeln/warten wenn man durch Sanktionen den Zugang zu den Entwicklungswerkzeugen verliert. Ich sehe folgenden Mehrwert in der Verwendung von OpenSource: - Digitaler Unabhängigkeit: Schalten die USA zum jetzigen Zeitpunkt ihre Clouddienste oder mobilen Betriebssysteme für Europa ab, steht alles. - Kontrolle der eigenen Daten: Es ist schwierig einen Wettbewerbsvorteil zu erlangen, wenn die USA Einblick in alle Kommunikations-,Forschungs-, Verteidigungs-, Wirtschaftsdaten Europas haben. - Flexibilität: Die Verfügbarkeit des Sourcecodes ermöglicht es jeder Institution eine Software zu jedem Zeitpunkt, selbst oder von einem beliebigen Anbieter, an die eigenen Bedürfnisse anzupassen. - Sicherheit: Die Verfügbarkeit des Sourcecodes ermöglicht es kritische Sicherheitslücken schneller zu identifizieren und zu beheben. Ich würde folgende, konkrete Maßnahmen empfehlen: - Zunächst sollte man alle Schritte/Vorhaben stoppen die unsere digitale Abhängigkeit erhöhen. Hier benötigt es keinerlei Investitionen, lediglich den Willen und Mut entsprechende Gesetze zu verabschieden. Folgende Bereiche sind allgemein bekannt und würden sich sehr leicht lösen lassen: - Lobbying durch ausländische Technologiekonzerne in strategisch relevanten Bereichen wie der IT-Infrastruktur sollte strengstens untersagt werden. - Konkurrierenden Drittsaaten ist es zu verbieten Rechenzentren auf europäischem Boden zu errichten. Auch eine von Amazon in Europa errichtete Sovereign Cloud kann im Konfliktfall von den USA abgeschaltet werden und stellt somit keine souveräne Lösung dar. - Die Verwendung von Software wie auch Cloudlösungen aus Drittstaaten in strategisch relevanten Bereichen ist zu untersagen. - Solange Microsoft und Apple es schaffen, dass Kinder bereits in der Schule ausschließlich mit iPads oder Surface-Geräten arbeiten, ist es schwer, Akzeptanz für alternative Systeme zu schaffen. - Auf in Europa verkauften PCs, Notebooks und Mobilgeräten sollten keine Betriebssysteme konkurrierender Drittländer vorinstalliert sein. In Indien werden Systeme beispielsweise mit dem staatseigenen BOSS Linux vorinstalliert, in China kommen Geräte mit HarmonyOS auf den Markt. - Europa benötigt Sicherheit/Kontinuität in der Entwicklung strategisch wichtiger Software. Es gilt sicherzustellen, dass: genügend (europäische) Entwickler regelmäßig daran arbeiten, diese angemessen bezahlt werden, der Ausfall eines einzelnen Entwicklers ein strategisches Projekt nicht zum Erliegen bringt. der Quellcode kontinuierlich auf Sicherheitslücken überprüft wird. - Europa benötigt ein eigenes, unabhängiges, Betriebssystem für die Bereiche Regierung, Bildung, Industrie, Verteidigung sowie für Mobilgeräte. China und Indien haben hier bereits eigene Lösungen etabliert. - Das Verbot von Huawei-Komponenten im Mobilfunk ist wenig konsequent, solange die USA potenziell alle europäischen Endgeräte überwachen oder fernsteuern könnten. - Europa benötigt eigene Cloud-Systeme/Rechenzentren: Ein Großteil der auf european-alternatives.eu gelisteten Lösungen wird in Rechenzentren der US-amerikanischen Big-Tech-Konzerne gehostet. Auch eine von Amazon in Europa errichtete Sovereign Cloud kann im Konfliktfall von den USA abgeschaltet werden. - Solange Europa digital nicht unabhängig ist, ist es ein Fehler Technologien aus China/Indien usw. zu verbieten und sich in eine 100%ige Abhängigkeit der USA zu begeben. Bis zur digitalen Unabhäng

feedback:
Key challenges are correctly identified as dependency on non-EU digital infrastructure, underutilized EU developer communities, and barriers to scaling open source solutions. However, terminology matters; first recommendation is to consistently use "FLOSS" (Free and Libre Open Source Software) rather than the more generic adjective "open source", as it better captures the public good nature and freedom principles at stake. Strengths and barriers: the EU possesses substantial FLOSS resources and developer talent aligned with European values, yet we lack coordinated large-scale infrastructure, systematic integration frameworks, widespread education and understanding, proper organization, and crucially, the right investment incentives to gather, unite, and systematically elevate this ecosystem. Only systematic funding (both grants and VC/capital mobilization; EIB & beyond), intensive education efforts, and public-private community building will truly break down barriers and enable proper breakthrough and scaling. Legal and communal commitment frameworks are essential so organizations - especially larger ones - sustain continuous investment in both people and technology. The document rightly emphasizes "scaling up via sustainable support and governance frameworks aiming for community upscaling, industrial deployment, market integration and commercial viability" - this is the crux. Added value: FLOSS fundamentally combats massive big tech dependency and rampant vendor lock-in through flexibility benefiting all stakeholders. Cost and burden-sharing present major opportunities yet organizational challenges; finances, processes, and entire systems all require fundamental rethinking, e.g. for hosting, maintenance, and decentralization. FLOSS can unite entities and departments through systemic interoperability, facilitating collaboration that proprietary silos prevent. Customization becomes dramatically easier and cheaper than under proprietary lock-in, while openness creates lowest-possible thresholds for learning, experimentation, and continuous iteration. Concrete measures: IF "the EU can count on a very active and rich ecosystem of communities of open-source developers, among the largest worldwide, whose work is well aligned with EU digital rights and principles" THEN reward them! Help them be found and commercialize/scale, and facilitate synergies and integrations between them. Visibility and commercialization pathways are critical. A "joined-up EU approach" is essential, but must include SMEs and individuals like NGI Zero Commons does, not just large players. Mobilize existing organizations like SCS/Alasca and fairkom in all possible manners, e.g. support infrastructure. Promote open source AI throughout all initiatives to maximize EU independence. Integrate with efforts like EU Inc. to create maximize impact & speed. Priority technologies: cloud solutions generally and data storage particularly represent where largest dependency and value concentration exist - not only comprehensive platforms but also FLOSS replacements for everyday tools like Zoom and Slack e.g. Jitsi calls and Matrix IM. Sovereign data storage with local (cold?) storage creates interoperability dilemmas that FLOSS solutions could help resolve. Blockchain technology could connect minimally-exposed data with other nodes through secure, network-level encryption, enabling maximum collaboration while retaining data sovereignty, e.g. AI agents inferring value from datasets without privacy violations and trusted information exchange between organizations and citizens. These interconnected challenges demand collaborative solutions that proprietary models lack incentive to provide sustainably. Sectors: increased FLOSS use enhances competitiveness, autonomy and cyber resilience, particularly in public administration, healthcare, finance, and critical infrastructure where data sovereign

feedback: El software libre y de código abierto (entiéndase como FLOSS) es algo con lo que vivimos en el día a día todas las personas sin que lo sepamos. Ya no específicamente porque toda entidad que desarrolle software o despliegue servicio siempre esté usando algo que dependa del mismo, sino que hablo de la llamada cultura libre alrededor del movimiento del software libre. Y es que, la soberanía digital y la autodeterminación pasa por abrazar los valores comunitarios del mismo, reconociendo la necesidad de ayudarnos mutuamente para hacer algo mejor sin el afán competitivo propio del capitalismo. La campaña de la FSFE «Public Money, Public Code!» ya comentaba sobre esto. Las personas pueden avanzar de varias formas, y las predominantes son: * la cultura de la competitición donde entidades y personas desarrollan una idea y la mantienen de forma recelosa impidiendo que el resto la pueda implementar, aminorando esfuerzos que vaya en contra de los ideales de dicha entidad como ocurre con los grandes oligopolios digitales de las llamadas «Big Tech» que, adicionalmente, únicamente se han aprovechado de las herramientas libres desarrolladas por terceras partes para su propio beneficio en detrimento de las mismas y sin proveer verdadero soporte, creando una espiral de explotación de mano de obra gratuita. * la cultura del apoyo mutuo, que parte de la premisa de que cada persona o entidad tiene unos límites y puede aportar su granito de arena, y que cuando una no puede aportar, otra puede o puede hacerlo en otras partes, auto-organizarse, añadir modificaciones, poco a poco, adaptando las cosas a sus necesidades sin un impedimento ni recelo, sin una demanda más que la necesidad de la propia persona o entidad.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: Free and open-source software (understood as FLOSS) is something we all live with in everyday life without knowing it. No longer specifically because any entity developing software or deploying service is always using something that depends on it, but I talk about the so-called free culture around the free software movement. Digital sovereignty and self-determination mean embracing the EU’s values, recognising the need to help each other to do something better without the competitive desire of capitalism. The FSFE campaign “Public Money, Public Code!” already commented on this. People can move forward in several ways, the predominant ones being: * the competition culture in which entities and individuals develop an idea and maintain it in a reckless manner, preventing the rest from implementing it, reducing efforts that go against the ideals of that entity, as is the case with the large digital oligopolies of the so-called ‘Big Tech’, which, in addition, have only taken advantage of free tools developed by third parties for their own benefit, to the detriment of those tools and without providing any real support, creating a spiral of exploitation of free labour. * the culture of mutual support, which starts from the premise that each person or entity has limits and can contribute its granite of sand, and that when one cannot provide, another can or can do so elsewhere, self-organise, add modifications, gradually, adapting things to their needs without hindrance or suspicion, without demand other than the need of the person or entity itself.

feedback: Firmemente a favor del software de código abierto. Creo que las instituciones de la Unión Europea y países miembros deberían adoptar medidas para tender hacia ese modelo, así como eliminar la dependencia de las grandes corporaciones estadounidenses y apostar por software desarrollado por empresas europeas.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: Strongly in favour of open source software. I believe that the institutions of the European Union and the Member States should take steps to move towards this model, to eliminate dependence on major US corporations and to rely on software developed by European companies.

feedback: The ICC in the Hague was put under US sanctions for the second time in February 2025. A prosecutor and his team is banned from using services from US companies. This is not just the MS Exchange mail server! Since we're in a trade war with the US, we should have a look at every Euro we pay for services from the US. The LiMux Project in Munich started in 2009 and in 2012 they saved 10 million Euro compared to a Microsoft solution. It failed because the mail server and the spam protection couldn't handle a mail with an unusually long subject in 2014. Some lobbying by Microsoft might have helped. At the moment a comparable project is rolled out in Schleswig-Holstein. My third argument are opportunities. Especially government projects should use Universities for development. This helps students, governments and every user of Open Source Software. There are many opportunities waiting for Bachelor Master Thesises and Doctorates. Here in my hometown we have a company specialized in Linux for administration, they are right next to the University.
No debe apoyar interes privado o lucrativo. Debe ser para ayudar y mejorar al pueblo, accesibles a todos.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: It should not support private or profit-making interests. It must be to help and improve the people, accessible to all.

feedback:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of the EU open-source sector? A strong open source digital infrastructure exists in Europe, from system services like Linux and KDE, cloud services like NextCloud and Penpot, infrastructure services like bunny.net, and powerful AI solutions like Mistral. The biggest weakness is scale. Open alternatives to Google Workspace are a good example: they are up against a product funded by an organization with a yearly revenue rivaling the GDP of Finland. What is the added value of open source for the public and private sectors? Open source projects give the public a say in the shape of the tools they use. In education the tools themselves become a lesson, because students can take them apart and learn how they work. Integrating open source throughout the education system gives students a deeper understanding of the technology they use. The private sector is beholden to the owners of the closed source tools that they rent or buy. That means everything from unilaterally changed licenses to data exfiltration to corporations and governments. Open source helps ensure that the private sector owns its software instead. Open source also provides a chance for the private sector to participate in the commons while at the same time affecting the course of the development of the tools it uses. What can the EU do to support the development and growth of the EU open-source sector and contribute to the EUs technological sovereignty and cybersecurity? Support universities and embrace the U.S. brain drain The EU is already providing a safe haven for U.S. university researchers. It can extend that. Put them to work using and developing open source through research grants, software development infrastructure and extended education programs. Scale infrastructure Build out the open, sovereign digital cloud that Europeans deserve. Amazon recently announced the "AWS European sovereign cloud", not because they believe that they can deliver sovereignty to another polity but because they are afraid that Europe can do it without them. Europes digital infrastructure can come from within by leveraging what Europe already has and investing in interoperability between existing cloud providers. Support open information Google and Cloudflare offer free protection services like Project Galileo and Project Shield to at-risk enterprises like news-rooms and human rights organizations. They can also take those protections away at the whim of a CEO. Europe can subsidize the same thing through companies like bunny.net and back those protections up. Fund the bits that hold it all together There are hundreds of invisible open source libraries that we use every day, and most of us dont know it. They are the backbone of the worlds digital infrastructure and need social and financial support. It is a matter of security for EU to help fund and build communities for many of these isolated projects. Create truly open AI 1. Incentivize EU AI companies to release more open models by making deals to integrate them into European Commission projects 2. Tie AI expansion to sustainable energy sources. When building physical digital infrastructure keep AI front in center in thinking, especially in terms of environmental impact. 3. Use AI to fight AI. The same principles disinformation actors use to create discord can be used to detect and fight it. Integrating open AI tools into Europes battle against disinformation creates accountability and builds trust. What technology areas should be prioritised and why? 1. Open source libraries 2. AI 3. Collaboration suites 4. Interoperability 5. Open federated social tools In what sectors could an increased use of open source lead to increased competitiveness and cyber resilience? 1. Public sector 2. University research 3. Defense: Operations Security (OpSec), anti-disinformation, OS intelligence 4. Journalism and truth-telling 5. Soci

feedback: Enthusiastic support for the European Open Digital Ecosystem Strategy I welcome this fundamental initiative to consolidate free and open-source software as a pillar of European digital sovereignty. Free software is not just a technological issue, but a model that guarantees transparency, accountability and democratic control over the digital infrastructures that underpin our societies. This strategy is essential to reduce dependence on monopolistic suppliers and avoid vendor lock-in, which compromises both the security and autonomy of European public institutions. Technological independence from foreign powers: Europe's current dependence on American technological solutions poses a critical risk to our national security. Revelations about mass surveillance programmes such as PRISM have shown that proprietary software can contain backdoors or be subject to extraterritorial legislation that compromises the privacy of European citizens and institutions. Free software, by allowing full code auditing, is the only real guarantee against espionage and external manipulation. This strategy must be seen as an essential step for Europe to regain global technological leadership, developing robust European alternatives that not only protect our sensitive information, but also position the EU as a benchmark for ethical and secure innovation. Digital sovereignty is inseparable from political and economic sovereignty. Proposals for reinforcement: Sustained public investment: It is crucial to allocate significant funds to the maintenance of critical open source projects. Many fundamental components depend on voluntary or insufficiently funded work, creating systemic vulnerabilities. Open Source First priority: Public institutions should adopt open source solutions by default, requiring explicit justification for proprietary options. This would maximise reuse across administrations and foster interoperability. Education and training: Integrate free software into educational curricula and professional training programmes to create a critical mass of competent developers and users. Mandatory open standards: Link this strategy to open standards requirements in public procurement, ensuring that no proprietary solution can create artificial barriers. Communities and participatory governance: Support structures that enable citizen participation in the development and governance of public digital infrastructures. This strategy represents a historic opportunity for Europe to lead globally in a more ethical, secure and democratic digital model. Free software is the indispensable foundation for true technological sovereignty.

L'indépendance européenne au travers des logiciels libres est ce que nous défendons au quotidien. Et nous tenons à parler de nos difficultés via cette consultation. Nous représentons l'accessibilité, notamment du milieu culturel, aux personnes handicapées. Nous ne pouvons que constater que l'accessibilité et l'ergonomie des logiciels libres n'est pas au niveau, mis à part quelques exceptions. C'est un constat général et lié au fait que très peu de personnes connaissent et s'occupent de ces sujets-là au sein de la communauté des logiciels libres. Nous notons un manque global de ressources claires pour l'ensemble de la population et des équipes de développement. Nous constatons qu'aujourd'hui, la formation en informatique n'inclut que très peu de notions d'accessibilité logicielle, voire même des checklists contre-productives. Nous avons besoin que des cours soient donnés dans les écoles, que des formations continues atteignent l'ensemble des développeuses et développeurs, y compris les bénévoles. Il en va de même pour l'ergonomie qui nécessite des notions avancées de psychologie. Nous constatons également que le monde de l'ergonomie ne s'est globalement pas rapproché des communautés du logiciel libre, et cela est bien dommage. Globalement, il serait intéressant de sensibiliser l'ensemble de la population à l'éthique dans l'informatique et aux enjeux derrière la technologie. Nous craignons fortement l'idéologie TESCREAL aujourd'hui prônée par de grands acteurs du domaine, et de leur eugénisme affiché. Nous avons besoin des logiciels libres dans le milieu du handicap pour une multitude de raisons. Déjà, les données nous concernant deviennent rapidement des données médicales, car nos difficultés quotidiennes mêlent nos états de santé respectifs. Il est extrêmement frustrant de constater que des administrations publiques se permettent de nous réclamer des preuves médicales pour les stocker ensuite sur des clouds américains, via Teams par exemple, ou encore les passent à l'intelligence artificielle sans se questionner. C'est un échec global de l'application de la GDPR. Nous devons pouvoir connaître le traitement de nos données en toute transparence. Nous avons également besoin d'avoir accès à des protocoles ouverts, que des standards de l'industrie soient appliqués. Peu d'applications nous sont totalement accessibles, et nous devons trouver des moyens alternatifs. Pouvoir récupérer via une API des horaires de transport, par exemple, nous permet d'utiliser des systèmes plus accessibles que certains sites web de sociétés de transport en commun. Il en va de même pour nos équipements d'accessibilité, sur lesquels nous n'avons pas la main, et qui deviennent obsolètes bien trop vite. Qu'il serait agréable d'utiliser des firmwares alternatifs ! Nous aimerions aussi que les personnes handicapées puissent être plus accompagnées dans l'apprentissage de l'informatique, du développement logiciel, de l'autonomisation, de comment participer à des projets libres. Et surtout, nous avons besoin d'un changement global dans nos sociétés pour que l'on soit enfin acceptés dans des équipes de développement et dans des entreprises. Nous représentons une part non négligeable de la population, et beaucoup d'entre nous pourraient contribuer avec une meilleure formation et une meilleure acceptation. Nous pensons donc que les priorités absolues se résument à de la formation aux enjeux, à l'accessibilité et à l'ergonomie, à convaincre les utilisatrices et les utilisateurs et à les rendre actifs dans la communauté. Mais nous avons aussi besoin d'une application rigoureuse de la GDPR, et de régulations pour l'interopérabilité et l'open-hardware. L'implication de la population est nécessaire pour pouvoir réussir cette indépendance européenne et pour l'adoption des logiciels libres.

Ich unterstütze diese Initiative zutiefst. Aus meiner Sicht sollte die öffentliche Verwaltung hier mit gutem Beispiel voran gehen und wo immer möglich auf europäische und open source Software zurückgreifen. Europa muss unabhängiger werden um gegenüber Erpressung aus anderen Bereichen der Welt, sei es China, die USA weniger anfällig zu sein.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: I strongly support this initiative. In my view, the public administration should lead by example and use European and open source software wherever possible. Europe needs to become more independent in order to be less vulnerable to blackmail from other parts of the world, be it China or the US.

feedback: Europe's digital sovereignty requires several foundational puzzle pieces working together, two of them are described here, supporting documentation details architecture, roadmap, and partnerships for both systems are uploaded as part of this message ! Sovereign OSthe foundational operating system enabling a complete European digital ecosystem (cloud, AI, quantum, robotics, drones, military systems)is essential. But OS alone is insufficient. Without trust in digital content itself, even a secure OS cannot ensure citizens, governments, and military forces know what is real. That's why RVAD (Real Video Audio by Design) is another critical second cornerstone. While Sovereign OS secures infrastructure, RVAD proves digital images, videos, and audio represent what actually happenednot deepfakes. Together, they form the foundation for European digital independence. The Core Imperative Europe's digital future depends on three interconnected stakeholder groups: Citizens demanding privacy protection AND proof that digital media is authentic Governments requiring secure digital administration AND tamper-proof evidence (surveillance, medical records, forensics) Military forces needing sovereign weapons systems AND verified proof of real events for command-and-control Today, all depend on foreign technology, creating catastrophic vulnerability to both surveillance and information warfare. Why Now Matters Modern technology (Rust for Sovereign OS, cryptographic chip design for RVAD, AI- assisted development) has matured simultaneously. Within 3-5 years, this advantage closes. Europe has a narrow window. What This Enables Foundation Layer (Sovereign OS): European cloud, sovereign AI, post-quantum computing, independent robotics/drones, military systems Verification Layer (RVAD): Every image, video, audio from cameras/drones carries cryptographic proof of authenticity. Courts, media, governments verify instantly: real or fake. Core Capabilities Sovereign OS: Privacy by Design (GDPR/NIS2) | Military-Grade Security (60% fewer vulnerabilities, formally verified) | Zero Disruption | Open Source RVAD: Hardware-Rooted Authenticity (cryptographic signatures at capture) | Tamper- Proof (modifications detected instantly) | Decentralized Verification | Privacy- Preserving The Investment Sovereign OS: 4B over 3 years 22.3B value over 10 years RVAD: 1.5B (chip design, validation infrastructure) Combined: 5.5B for complete digital sovereignty architecture Geographic Hub: Approximately 230 engineers in Portugal; 60 PhD researchers across EU universities. Bottom Line Europe cannot defend its citizens or maintain military independence using foreign technology. Sovereign OS + RVAD form the dual foundation for European digital sovereignty: secure infrastructure + verified truth. The time to act is now ! I certainly hope to get feedback and can help that Europe becomes sovereign again - for Europes future, the future of my childs, grand childs and future generations - not only in Europe ! Markus

Puntos fuertes y débiles del sector FLOSS UE: La mayor Fortaleza es la meritocracia pura (los desarrolladores lideran según sus aportaciones al código, y si alguien no está de acuerdo, puede hacer un fork libremente). Además la innovación es muy rápida en las comunidades establecidas como Debian/GNOME, todo con una transparencia total. Se desarrolla, generalmente, por placer y por mejorar el código. En muchos casos es ALTRUISTA. Debilidades: existe voluntariado "AS IS" que puede llegar al "burnout", legislación estricta (CRA/GDPR) les expone a demandas, ciberseguridad frágil porque no se contratan pruebas. Los usuarios que NO aportan al código pero exigen mucho tampoco ayudan al desarrollo del Software Libre. Obstáculos i) Inercia de las personas para cambiar la tecnología hacia Software Libre porque están viciadas con programas privativos desde pequeños. El Software LIbre no invierte en campañas de Marketing para publicitarse como hacen empresas de sotfware privativo. ii) Contribuciones sostenibles: crear comunidad es complejo y se debe incentivar desde la Educación. Sin un mínimo de Comunidad es difícil que los proyectos se mantengan. Valor añadido: Reduce lock-in, acelera innovación vía revisiones colectivas y mejora seguridad por escrutinio global. - Nextcloud: Soberanía datos y privacidad. Universidades, Centros de Investigación, Empresas Privadas lo utilizan. - Debian Linux: Desarrollo comunitario de un software libre como Sistema Operativo. Decenas de miles de equipos informáticos en Galicia utilizan Debian como sistema operativo para la juventud. Empresas como Librebit utilizan y apoyan el Software Libre en eventos. Medidas UE concretas: * Vehiculizar fondos vía Asociaciones Empresariales o de Usuarios que tengan como Objeto Social la Promoción del Software Libre. Ejemplos como GALPon.org o AGASOL.gal (asociaciones con experiencia en código/eventos que ayudan a la Comunidad de Software Libre). * Patrocinio de eventos especializados en Software Libre, requisito explícito que los temas a exponer en el evento sean de Software Libre. Se deben excluir tanto el código privativo como soluciones no libres. * Creación de OSPO desde los Estados para que ayuden a los desarrolladores individuales o proyectos estratégicos a evitar problemas legales, mejorar en temas de ciberseguridad y en general a proveer de ayudas a los desarrolladores que son meramente técnicos y no son expertos en la parte legal. Ámbitos prioritarios: * Ciberseguridad: Comunidades FLOSS como OpenSSL han parcheado vulnerabilidades críticas (ej. Heartbleed) vía forks meritocráticos rápidos, algo imposible en propietario cerrado. Prioridad UE: CRA exige SBOM/auditorías; desarrolladores individuales necesitan escudo legal para codificar "AS IS" sin miedo a demandas, pero quieren que su código también sea seguro. * IA verificable: Modelos abiertos, cualquier aplicación de la IA sobre datos de un ciudadano que le afecte a sus derechos, debe ser contrastable por un tercero para que pueda replicar TODO el ecosistema de IA. * Obligar a fabricantes de hardware a que sea compatible con Software Libre (en especial sus drivers) para que puedan ser vendidos en Europa. Así se podrán explotar al máximo sin dependencia de los fabricantes de software. Permite una mayor resiliencia y evita la obsolescencia programada (al menos a nivel software), contribuyendo así a reducir residuos, al alargar la vida útil de los equipos informáticos.

feedback: Open-source software underpins the vast majority of the European technological sector, but its impact reaches beyond that. Software has "eaten the world" and now exists in every sector, from agriculture to retail. As a senior software engineer at Ingka, the largest IKEA franchisee, I see the impact first hand: relying on open-source technologies has directly enabled us to hire co-workers that speak the same technical language regardless of their background, to work faster, to deliver better experiences for customers and employees across the world, and all that a lower cost. Thousands of Europeans have jobs at Ingka thanks to, in part, open source software. Likewise, as an occasional contributor to open-source software, I continue to be amazed at the impact even a small contribution can make. A couple of hours of work on, for example, implementing a device driver, can result in tens of thousands of people being able to use products they were previously unable to. Other contributions can result in rescuing perfectly usable hardware, abandoned or unilaterally declared as "obsolete" by the manufacturer, thus significantly reducing e-waste and saving European citizens money. Open source work is driven by volunteers and enthusiasts, often in their spare time. Their work directly benefits everyone, from regular citizens to international corporations. But, they rarely get compensated. They are under pressure to build more, patch issues, resolve support requests. They are often passionate developers, but lack the skills and resources to promote their projects, conduct user research, build intuitive and attractive user interfaces, and achieve mass market adoption. As it stands, there are very few incentives for open source users to contribute back - either as individuals or through various organizations. Financial contributions (sponsorships, donations) require navigating the complexity of tax, labor and other regulations. For example, if I wish to pay someone to develop a feature for an open-source project, is this a labor agreement, a purchase, or something else? Do I have to pay VAT? Does the developer have to report this income, and how? Even if this was made clear, there would still not be any reason for a company to contribute. This is why companies using open-source components in their systems should be incentivized to do so, either financially or by hiring individuals to work on a project. This could take the form of tax credits for certain contributions. And there should be an additional incentive for companies to open-source their products under a copyleft or permissive license, either in form of a further tax benefit or a subsidy. We have plenty of foundational software; we need real products, built for non-technical users, that will be better in quality from their proprietary counterparts. We cannot expect the vast majority of users to use software that's worse or does not fit their use case simply out of ideological reasons. But through funding and protections for open-source software, we can build a future that is better than the one tech mega-corporations have in stock for us. I hope we get there.

One topic to consider within the digital sovereignty conversation is funding sources and sustainability. While many FOSS projects start out as volunteer groups, successful projects often reach a cross roads where they feel that growth and sustainability means becoming a company. While this is a model that works for many projects, it is not the only one. Maintaining an active volunteer network while continuing to grow and balance financial sustainability is vital because volunteers are not only passionate and willing to contribute, they also maintain a unique independence and sovereignty. Being volunteer driven is not a weakness, but a strength. The EC should consider volunteer driven groups in the same way as they consider FOSS companies, both are successful and play a vital role in the freedom and independence of the ecosystem.

Europe is lagging significantly behind in core digital technologies: Processors and Operating systems for example. I believe this gap is unbridgeable if we try to start from scratch in terms of intellectual property. Open-source solutions already exist that we should invest in (such as RISC-V and Linux, for example). However, I believe investment alone is not enough: European companies must also be encouraged to use these products in their daily operations (typically for office workstations). Large European corporations are currently saturated with proprietary U.S. technologies. Even though open-source solutions are highly mature, they will only be widely adopted if companies are pushed to do so.

Free and Open source software programs are key to businesses all around the world. Most innovation uses part of this software components, as they are easy to use and widely understood by developers. The world wide web (not that closed garden that US corporations want us to live on) thrives on free and open source. Even those US corporations that develop the most successful apps have their roots in hundreds or thousands of free and open source components. As a EU citizen, that wants to have digital sovereignty over my own assets, it is my opinion that we need to develop a EU policy for free software adoption in the public sector that helps companies to make the switch and stop being digital vassals to US companies. Our privacy and autonomy are in the stake.

There are already quite a few very interesting and exhaustive documents like the report from Linux Foundation and the white paper from Eclipse Foundation exploring many aspects of the questionnaire. We are in exceptional circumstances highlighting gaps and dependencies in many technological sectors accumulated over decades, which are not justified and should be mitigated and addressed thoroughly and rapidly. It will take quite some time to filling up some gaps and weaning Europe away from others in some sectors. Rather than creating new, larger and higher watertight compartments, we should promote and cultivate fair cooperation and collaboration on an equal footing, but ensuring no one can strangle or hold critical power or positions. Interoperability, Open standards and Open Source should be at the foundation of a fair procurement in all the public sector organisations, especially university, research and academia and the public administration: Open Source first should be the default rule with commercial & closed source allowed only as very strongly justified exception, when there are no viable alternatives. Specific long term and permanent funding should be made available to the public sector, especially in large and critical organizations and in consortia already focused on knowledge because of institutional mission (university, research and academia), to make possible contributions and build a solid and resilient ecosystem, distributed and diversified across Europe. Private support company could help with tackling bug and security fixes, when the internal and community support is not enough to adopt open source in the public sector. Some of them could be publicly funded, if the market size is initially insufficient to self sustain. Major public sector organisations should be funded long term and permanently to fulfil this role, in a leading position, and act as competence centre for themselves, consortia and smaller public sector organizations, making sure the geographical distribution and a strong collaboration is also fostered and taken in consideration at regional, national and European level. Dedicating time and effort to open source contributions should be recognized in rules and regulations for the public sector, as strategically critical and become the normality, with proper funding, rather then the unfunded voluntary based exception. In some years, this would change dramatically the European and international scenario making it more secure, transparent, resilient and sovereign and allowing Europe to lead the technology evolution instead of lagging behind while keeping the doors open to collaboration and cooperation.

Attached please find my position paper addressing Questions 1 to 3 of the consultation. Based on more than three decades of counseling U.S. and German software companies, IT providers, and IT customers, it analyzes structural challenges in public sector open source projects and proposes concrete recommendations based on my personal experience and international examples from other jurisdictions.

El software libre es la piedra angular de todo el desarrollo tecnológico de los últimos 30 años. Para alcanzar objetivos como la competitividad y la independencia tecnológica, invertir en el software de código abierto es la clave. Es un hecho que todo el mundo usa software libre, de una forma o de otra. Ahora, lo que falta, es potenciarlo e integrarlo, aún más, en nuestras instituciones, para poder avanzar en la dirección de una soberanía tecnológica real. Ojalá se aumente la financiación de proyectos de código abierto que puedan ser reutilizados tanto directamente por todos los ciudadanos de la UE, como por las instituciones que nos gobiernan.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: Free software is the cornerstone of all technological development in the last 30 years. To achieve goals such as competitiveness and technological independence, investing in open-source software is key. It is a fact that everyone uses free software, in one way or another. Now, what is missing is to boost it and integrate it even more into our institutions, in order to be able to move in the direction of real technological sovereignty. Hopefully, there will be an increase in funding for open-source projects that can be reused both directly by all EU citizens and by the institutions that govern us.

feedback: Our goverment have a big dependency on Microsoft Systems and almost all infrastructures are from EEUU supliers. It's mandatory to have an European technology in order to prevent future big troubles.

The EU should incentivize and strengthen usage of open source software for corporate environments, and explicitly fund the development of critical software infrastructure. Where such open infrastructure already exists, it is often maintained by single people in their spare time. Work on significant open source software should be safeguarded legally, and put on a similar standing as other volunteering work for the public good. Additionally, gatekeepers such as Microsoft or Apple or Google should not be allowed to hamper the distribution of open source software through means such as app stores or notarization. A large part of the software I use privately and professionally is Open Source Software. Particular standouts are Gitlab, the programming revision control system ubiquitous in German workplaces, Python, the most popular programming language in world, which I use at work, and Darktable/Digikam/GIMP, graphics editing programs I use at work and privately. I also maintain python-soundfile, an open source library that underpins most audio file interactions in Python worldwide. These technologies are not just provided free of charge, but crucially allow us users to read their implementations, learn from them, and provide improvements. This may seem far-fetched, but is actually commonplace both at work and privately. Much of my expertise as an image processing specialist was learned from taking part in the development of Open Source software. In contrast, the closed source software we use, mostly Microsoft's Teams, Visual Studio, Github, and Windows, as well as Apple's macOS and iOS, do not allow such insights and learning, and instead aim to lock in their users. Increasingly, this is becoming a liability. For instance, Microsoft services regularly have outages or errors, which at work have prevented people from logging in, and doing their work. Compiler errors break workflows at work, and require lengthy debugging and workarounds. Microsoft Teams did not implement multi-lingual spelling corrections for over a year, as it presumably is unimportant to Americans. Little recourse is possible in such cases, as we are dependent on Microsoft to fix these issues. In contrast, Open Source software can be inspected and fixed in situ by a skilled technician. It does not bare pondering what a malicious use of these powers by Microsoft, Apple, and Google might look like.

I'm an open source maintainer, for a project that has been funded by NLnet NGI 0 fund. The NLnet initiative has been incredible for us and let us get to the next level in our project. NLnet was very helpful to us and of course the grant money led us to actually create a non-profit for the project, ensuring that the project will keep going in the long term future. What I love about NLnet is that it is not bureaucratic at all and there is no artificial barrier to anything. Processes are open and state clearly, and if something is possible or not, you will learn very fast by asking. I also thing that the EU sovereign tech fund is a great opportunity and I hope the fund become a reality. More generally, I've advice to consider the public money public code initiative, as I would like the taxes I pay to go to open source instead of going to GAFAM. I also want to highlight that open source is global, in our project we have contributors from all over the world and this should be taken into account. Finally, please involve the open source communities to make sure anything that is put into place actually fit the needs of communitiies.

feedback: I am a software developer and IT consultant from Poland. For over 20 years, I have been trying to use open-source solutions and software in both my private life and work. Here are some observations regarding different areas where the EU could strengthen its support for open-source in attached file

Adopting the European Open Digital Ecosystem Strategy will solidify the EUs technological sovereignty, enhance security, and boost competitiveness by strategically leveraging open source, while providing a clear operational framework to maximize the use, development, and reuse of open digital assets across the Commission.

Strengthening EU digital sovereignty by ending discrimination against open source and enforcing existing law --- 1. General support for the initiative I strongly welcome the European Open Digital Ecosystem Strategy as a longoverdue step to secure EU technological sovereignty. As an entrepreneur active in IT since 1995 and in agriculture since 2003, I have consistently supported free/libre and open source software (FLOSS) as an alternative to proprietary solutions controlled by companies subject to the US Cloud Act. If the EU wants real digital sovereignty, it should begin by ending the structural discrimination that open source users and developers currently face in the EU market. --- 2. Stop tied sales of proprietary operating systems on PCs A first, obvious measure is to end the systematic tying of proprietary operating systems (mainly Microsoft Windows) to almost all PCs sold in the EU. - Today, around 99% of PCs offered to consumers in the EU are sold with a preinstalled proprietary OS, with no practical option to refuse the OS and no transparent price signal. - Consumers should always be able to: - Refuse the proposed OS licence, - Buy the same hardware without an OS licence, - See clearly separated prices for hardware and OS licence. This is not technically complicated: - Retailers could simply keep the OS unactivated and not provide a licence key when the OS is refused. - No uninstallation is needed; the consumer just does not pay for the licence and cannot activate it. - As with a 5kg bag of carrots where both total price and price per kilo must be displayed, the OS licence price and the hardware price should both be displayed. Linked sales of this kind are not tolerated in other markets in the EU internal market; it is difficult to find another example where such de facto forced bundling is accepted. Enforcing basic competition and consumer law here would be a costfree and powerful step towards digital sovereignty. --- 3. Enforce the software exclusion: eradicate software patents in Europe A second essential measure is to bring the European Patent Office (EPO) back in line with the European Patent Convention (EPC) and to give legal certainty that software as such is not patentable in Europe. - The EPC clearly provides that software, like literary works, is protected by copyright, not by patents. - The EPOs practice of granting computerimplemented invention patents is, in substance, an attempt to bypass this rule. If software implemented on a computer is patentable, then a novel text implemented in a book could also be treated as a patentable invention, which is absurd. The current drift towards software patents creates a permanent threat over open source developers: - A single court decision aligned with the EPOs practice could be used as a kill switch against open source projects using standard algorithms or interfaces. - The push by USbased closedsource lobbies (backed by some EU corporate allies) for a highly centralised patent court increases this risk: convincing a small number of judges in one central court is far easier than trying to convince many national courts that the EPC should be reinterpreted against its clear wording and intention. The EU should: state unambiguously that software as such is not patentable under EU law and that the EPO will cease its malpractice. It should then publicise that developing opensource software in the EU is safe, and that developers are protected from patent lawyers funded by GAFAM or by patent trolls, thereby attracting more major opensource players to Europe. --- 4. Going further These two measures require no funding and no complex implementation; they are simply a straightforward application of the relevant laws and conventions that safeguard free competition in a free market. In genuinely free markets. See in attachement some more ambitious measures. ---5. Ready to help See qualifcations and com
