feedback: Open source is at the root of the world's digital infrastructure. Maintaining it requires time and effort, and to ensure that this can continue on a sustainable way, we need to ensure that it stays funded. The only way we can make our digital infrastructure resilient and secure is to provide the necessary funds to maintain open source software on an ongoing basis. It's important that this is done on a non burocratic way, to enable that the money reaches the people doing the work rather than those that know how to fill up forms.
Digital sovereignty and civil cybersecurity will require restoring commodity software and ICT services See attached file.

# EU-ORG: a European Framework for cross-border non-profits ## The Paradox of Open-Source Governance in Europe Europe leads the world in open-source contributions, with studies consistently showing that European developers and organizations are among the most active globally. Yet, the governance of open-source remains overwhelmingly U.S.-centric: Major foundations - such as the Linux Foundation, Python Software Foundation (PSF), Apache Software Foundation, Mozilla Foundation, Open Source Initiative (OSI), and NumFOCUS - are incorporated in the United States. While some have established European chapters and present themselves as global organisations, their core governance, funding, and operational decisions remain tied to U.S. legal and cultural frameworks. This creates a striking imbalance: despite Europes outsized contributions, funding, priorities, and jobs are concentrated in the U.S., reinforcing a U.S.-centric bias that can misalign with European values like data sovereignty, privacy, and multilingualism. ## A Framework for European Open-Source Sovereignty To address this imbalance, Europe must foster the creation of independent governance structures incorporated on its own soil - not just as regional branches of U.S.-led organizations, but as fully autonomous entities. These organizations could better reflect European legal frameworks, cultural diversity, and strategic interests. A critical step toward achieving this would be the establishment of a dedicated European legal entity for cross-border non-profits. This new EU-ORG", inspired by initiatives like the EU-INC, would: - Simplify the process of creating and managing cross-border non-profits in Europe, which are not perceived as being associated with any specific member of the Union. - Provide a clear legal framework for funding, governance, and operations. By enabling such structures, Europe can provide a welcoming and stable framework to attract open-source governance organizations to Europe, and foster an ecosystem built with European values at its core.

Sehr geehrte Damen und Herren, ein zentraler Beitrag von Open Source zur digitalen Souveränität besteht darin, dass bei der Nutzung von Libraries und Frameworks keine ausschließliche Abhängigkeit von einzelnen Unternehmen oder deren Vertrauenswürdigkeit besteht. Stattdessen ist es zumindest theoretisch möglich, die Funktionsweise und Sicherheit der eingesetzten Software eigenständig zu überprüfen und bei Bedarf anzupassen. Diese Transparenz reduziert strukturelle Abhängigkeiten und stärkt die technologische Selbstbestimmung. Vor diesem Hintergrund halte ich es für essenziell, dass die Open-Source-Community gezielt mit öffentlichen Mitteln unterstützt wird, insbesondere dort, wo sicherheitskritische Projekte von einzelnen oder sehr wenigen Entwicklern getragen werden. Die Ereignisse rund um Log4j (https://www.cisa.gov/news-events/alerts/2024/03/29/reported-supply-chain-compromise-affecting-xz-utils-data-compression-library-cve-2024-3094) sowie die kürzlich bekannt gewordene Backdoor in XZ Utils (https://www.cisa.gov/news-events/alerts/2024/03/29/reported-supply-chain-compromise-affecting-xz-utils-data-compression-library-cve-2024-3094) zeigen eindrücklich, welche systemischen Risiken entstehen, wenn zentrale Open-Source-Komponenten unter hohem Druck und mit unzureichenden Ressourcen gepflegt werden. Ähnliche Vorfälle lassen sich zahlreich finden. Diese Beispiele verdeutlichen, dass die Förderung von Open Source nicht nur ein Community-Thema ist, sondern unmittelbar zur Cyber-Resilienz und IT-Sicherheit beiträgt. Da viele dieser Komponenten in Behörden, Unternehmen und kritischen digitalen Infrastrukturen eingesetzt werden, adressiert eine gezielte Unterstützung zugleich den Schutz eben dieser Infrastrukturen. Wichtig erscheint mir insbesondere, Entwicklerinnen und Entwickler, die mit der Wartung solcher Schlüsselprojekte überfordert sind, strukturell zu entlasten. Dies könnte beispielsweise durch unabhängige Organisationen erfolgen, die auf Anfrage Unterstützung leisten oder aktiv auf sicherheitsrelevante Projekte zugehen. Eine weitere Möglichkeit wären EU-Förderprogramme, die ohne hohen bürokratischen Aufwand direkt von Maintainerinnen und Maintainer sicherheitskritischer Open-Source-Projekte beantragt werden können. Ich hoffe dieses Feedback hilft Ihnen bei der Entscheidungsfindung. Mit freundlichen Grüßen Timotheus von Zitzewitz
feedbackTextUserLanguage:
Ladies and gentlemen, a key contribution of open source to digital sovereignty is that there is no exclusive dependency on or trustworthiness of individual companies when using libraries and frameworks. Instead, it is at least theoretically possible to independently review the functioning and security of the software used and adapt it if necessary. This transparency reduces structural dependencies and strengthens technological self-determination. Against this background, I consider it essential that the open-source community is targeted with public funding, especially where safety-critical projects are supported by individual or very few developers. The events around Log4j (https://www.cisa.gov/news-events/alerts/2024/03/29/reported-supply-chain-compromise-affecting-xz-utils-data-compression-library-cve-2024-3094), as well as the recently announced backdoor in XZ Utils (https://www.cisa.gov/news-events/alerts/2024/03/29/reported-supply-chain-compromise-affecting-xz-utils-data-compression-library-cve-2024-3094), clearly demonstrate the systemic risks of maintaining centralised open-source components under high pressure and insufficient resources. A large number of similar incidents can be found. These examples illustrate that promoting open source is not only a community issue, but directly contributes to cyber resilience and IT security. As many of these components are used by public authorities

feedback: As IT worker and software engineer I do believe that European Union should align itself with Open Source and its community. In my professional career I've experienced first hand the danger and issues connected with hegemony of proprietary software produced mainly in US. This, connected with current political climate and real examples of how US giants exploit the control over infrastructure used in EU makes a clear wake up call to increase sovereignty of EU states by rejecting proprietary solutions from external countries, which will use their power when politically needed for them. Open source solutions are already there, and while not perfect, they offer escape from this situation. EU has the unique opportunity to support this ecosystem, innovate it and secure the European infrastructure by building it together with many existing specialists. This will not only benefit the governmental institutions, but help every citizen.

In the Netherlands we have legislation that says "Open Source unless". Where unless is only in very specific cases. It would help the Open Source industry a lot when this rule would apply for the entire EU. Public money public code meaning that when a governmental organization spends public money is should try to spent it on Open Source and give it back to the public instead of buying licenses. As there is already a lot of experience in the Netherlands with "Open Source unless" this can be copied and lessons learned can be applied.

The European Commission correctly identifies the EUs dependency on non-European digital infrastructure as a major strategic, economic, and security vulnerability. Open-source software offers the strongest response, delivering transparency, security, and public value while supporting digital sovereignty. Europe already hosts one of the worlds largest open-source developer communities, forming the technological backbone of modern computing across critical sectors. In Artificial Intelligence, this open ecosystem is rapidly maturing. Contrary to the assumption that advanced AI depends on proprietary cloud services, open-weight large language models (LLMs) have reached near-parity with commercial alternatives. European actors such as Mistral, Apertus, and OpenEuroLLM provide capable, sovereignty-aligned options. Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) systems (combining LLMs with retrieval databases) are particularly suited for enterprise and government use. Thanks to open frameworks like RAGFlow, Open WebUI, vLLM, and llama.cpp, these systems can run efficiently on local or hybrid architectures, where all or most data remains on premise. A key misconception is that sophisticated AI requires massive hardware investments or exclusive cloud reliance. Modern open models run well on accessible hardware: a single RTX 6000 Pro (under 10,000) can serve hundreds of users, and compact models (7B14B) perform effectively on consumer GPUs or CPUs when optimized through quantization. For organizations avoiding on-premise management, European cloud providers now present viable, sovereignty-compatible alternatives. Hybrid RAG architectures allow sensitive data to stay local, using external LLMs only for inference. Targeted EU support, however, remains crucial. Many AI domains, especially healthcare and legal, still lack enterprise-grade, open-source applications. Healthcare offers the greatest potential and need: regulatory complexity (GDPR, EHDS, MDR), high data sensitivity, and specialized medical language demand trustworthy, auditable, open-source AI. Current healthcare-oriented LLMs lack clinical validation, production maturity, and integration with European health IT (e.g. electronic health record systems). As a result, proprietary providers process sensitive patient data, where on-premise, privacy-preserving alternatives should exist. EU-backed, open healthcare AI ecosystems could deliver immense public value by ensuring compliance with European law and supporting local deployment. EU initiatives such as GenAI4EU and OpenEuroLLM are positive steps and should be continued. Future funding programs should include concrete mandates to guarantee usability, transparency, and compliance: Open licensing: All EU-funded AI and infrastructure software must be released under permissive licenses (Apache 2.0 or MIT) with complete source code in open repositories. Comprehensive deployment documentation: Including installation guides, containerization files (Kubernetes, Docker Compose), and integration examples with common platforms like Nextcloud or Collabora. Governance frameworks: Templates for ISO 27000 (information security) and ISO 42000 (AI governance) systems. Regulatory documentation: Prepared materials demonstrating compliance with the AI Act, GDPR, and data protection principles (risk assessments, DPIAs, retention policies, user rights procedures). Operational guidance: Administrator and user manuals, API documentation, troubleshooting resources, and known limitations. Finally, public procurement policies should be revised to prioritize transparency and sovereignty. Open-source solutions and European providers, especially those minimally dependent on U.S. or Chinese markets, should be preferred in critical domains such as cloud, AI, and cybersecurity.

Europa hat starke Open-Source-Technologien doch Einführung, Betrieb und nachhaltige Finanzierung bremsen den echten Durchbruch. Wir fordern: Open Source muss in Vergabe, Förderung und Betrieb endlich als kritische digitale Infrastruktur behandelt werden für mehr Sicherheit, Unabhängigkeit und digitale Souveränität. Im Anhang benennen wir konkrete Praxisprojekte und formulieren klare, umsetzbare Forderungen an die EU, u. a. zu Vergabekriterien, Wartungsfinanzierung, Security, Betriebsmodellen und Skills.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: Europe has strong open-source technologies, but deployment, operation and sustainable financing are holding back real breakthroughs. We call for: Open source must finally be treated as a critical digital infrastructure in procurement, promotion and operation for greater security, independence and digital sovereignty. In the annex, we identify concrete practical projects and formulate clear, actionable demands on the EU, including award criteria, maintenance funding, security, operating models and skills.

feedback: I am writing in the name of LINBIT HA-Solutions GmbH. LINBIT is an Austrian company that writes and publishes open-source infrastructure software. The company was established in 2001, so it has been in existence for 25 Years. I adjusted the business multiple times. Today, we are about 35 FTEs (employees and freelancers) in Austria and about 10 FTEs in the USA. We mainly sell support services and access to software repositories containing pre-built packages of the open source software we produce. We create storage virtualization software (software-defined storage), primarily for data centers and corporations (B2B). In that sense, LINBIT is an open-source company, as our revenue stream depends on the adoption and success of our open-source software. A major boost to LINBITs success was (and is) the uncertainty and disruption created in the virtualization market following Broadcom's acquisition of VMware. That created a high number of organisations that decided to migrate away from VMWare (which was like the de facto industry standard). These VMware refugees turn in part to open-source hypervisors and, with that, to LINBIT for its storage virtualization solution. The EU cannot create such a global market disruption, but by setting rules for its own data-processing needs, it would send a strong signal to the European IT sector. Commercial software corporations (mainly from the US) influence policymakers at all levels through their lobbying efforts, leveraging deep pockets. The EU could help by implementing policies for its own data processing to comply with regulations mandating open source software in support of its digital sovereignty. A law beats a lobbying effort. I wish the EU would set up guidelines for education. Austria rolled out laptops for schoolchildren. Apart from being done hastily, it creates all sorts of challenges for parents who need to limit their children's digital media consumption. Information for parents and enforcement possibilities for limitations are coming years after as an afterthought. But the point I want to make is that it is a Microsoft monoculture that is presented to our children. Digital sovereignty starts in education. The EU should set policies requiring member states to teach their children about the existence of open-source software and its advantages, as well as the value of digital sovereignty. There are plenty of Laptops on the market with Linux pre-installed. The Linux Professional Institute has training material ready. Everything is ready, just ignored by the policy makers in my country. I guess it needs a clear signal from the EU to the member states to get movement in that direction. As bullet points: We'd love to see EU guidelines to prioritize open source for EU data processing solutions. We'd love to see clear signals to prioritize open source solutions in education. PS: I created this document on my Fedora Linux workstation, using LibreOffice. All open source software. Dipl.-Ing. Philipp Reisner Geschäftsführer LINBIT HA-Solutions GmbH

Open source follows the same principles as science: transparency, peer review and verifiability. Some domains, such as encryption, can only be trusted when the code is open. Closed-source alternatives are comparable to mathematics without proof. This also affects digital literacy. Many users appear technically skilled while remaining fully dependent on opaque systems. Open source is therefore not only a development model but a form of societal education. Without it, governments and organizations overpay due to structural knowledge gaps. Open source however, has a reputation problem. It is often perceived as amateur, despite the fact that most critical software building blocks in use today are open source. These components are among the most robust and most tested software in existence. Large technology companies actively contribute to such projects, because open collaboration accelerates bug discovery, security fixes, peer review and improvement. This does not threaten their business models, as commercial value is captured in closed implementation layers, market position, support networks and hosting platforms. Open source encompasses both foundational components and ready-to-use applications. While foundational components rarely need direct support, applications require integration, hosting, and maintenance to be useful at scale. The gap lies at this application layer, where companies often take open source components and open datasets, add minimal value, and resell the result within the EU. An example is the reuse of open satellite (climate) data, where trivial calculations are performed and sold back to governments and municipalities. This pattern is visible in the GEO/GIS domain. Open source alternatives such as QGIS and GeoServer are technically mature. But many municipalities independently purchase similar closed solutions with little improvement over time. If these resources were pooled, open applications could be developed once, reused broadly, and funded through the savings on licensing. The barriers to this open source adaptation is not software quality but learning curve, hosting, long-term management and support. Governments ask who keeps systems online and who provides support. Large vendors have built extensive partner and certification ecosystems around this expectation. Only a small number of projects, such as Nextcloud, have addressed hosting and support seriously and allow third parties to build sustainable service models around them. These remain exceptions. Because open source software is rarely offered in this way, it is often dismissed as an option. The EU objective should be to strengthen open source ready-to-use applications that are hosted and supported within the EU. Procurement rules reinforce this problem. Tendering often prioritizes short-term implementation cost over long-term operational cost, disadvantaging open source despite lower total cost of ownership. Limited technical knowledge within public institutions also leads to situations where solutions are labeled open source while critical components remain closed, recreating vendor lock-in. Education amplifies these effects. Closed-source vendors provide free or cheap student licenses, shaping long-term dependency. Examples include computer science programs using free cloud credits, teaching students that infrastructure is a one-click cloud service, and technical education relying on closed software solutions due to discounted licenses. Graduates later demand these tools, disadvantaging companies. Not using open source as the default in higher education limits student development and weakens the EU open source sector. The main weakness of the EU open source sector is therefore not technology, but education, support, hosting, long-term maintenance and synthesis of mature open source core components into usable applications.

Digital commons (collectively governed tech/AI systems and shared data infrastructures) represent a practical and proven alternative to corporate-controlled technology. Europe stands at a crossroads: we can continue depending on extractive, foreign platforms that concentrate power and profit, or we can cultivate an ecosystem of shared tools and organizations that serves the public interest. Code for Frances review rests on 3 pillars: 1) Bridging communities: Europe's digital commons communities remain fragmented. Although commons have for virtue to create lasting social bonds, the main actors in the field - technical developers, democratic/ethical governance actors, policymakers, and open source tech companies - still work in silos. This limits the power needed to challenge dominant platforms. Europe needs to play a role in bridging communities of practice that work on alternative models. Initiatives like NGI and Open Future have started this work, but Europe must scale these efforts. 2) Communication/campaigning: Europe's open-source communities still struggle from limited public awareness, keeping commons-based solutions marginal. While FSFE and national campaigns have advanced advocacy, Europe needs coordinated campaigns, developed with grassroots movements and citizens initiatives, demonstrating how these democratically-governed tools reflect European values and deliver concrete alternatives to techno-authoritarianism. 3) Scaling tech/data commons across Europe - meaning: scaling across (accelerating/funding commons projects at the European level to reach venture-backed levels of funding), scaling out (growing the user base of commons projects), scaling deep (increasing the impact of digital commons on the European tech culture, budget and policy-making), scaling in (making commons attractive to a broader variety of professions and onboard them to improve/maintain the quality of digital commons), and scaling up (having bigger European tech companies adopt commons principles). Europe has a key role in ensuring these scaling dimensions are addressed.

Sono un professionista del settore IT, ritengo doveroso che la Comunità Europea incentivi l'utilizzo e lo sviluppo di sistemi Open Source. L'utilizzo di questi sistemi permette di raggiungere obiettivi di indipendenza informativa, di sicurezza ed economica. Se si sviluppasse in Europa una forte comunità Open Source ci sarebbero anche benefici in termini di crescita economica e di posti di lavoro.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: I am a professional in the IT sector and I believe that the European Community should encourage the use and development of Open Source systems. The use of these systems makes it possible to achieve objectives of informational independence, security and economic independence. Developing a strong Open Source community in Europe would also bring benefits in terms of economic growth and jobs.

feedback: Proposals for Concrete Measures to Facilitate the Swift and Sustainable Implementation of This Significant European Union Initiative **1. Digital sovereignty must be classified as an essential component of the national security of all Member States as well as of the European Unions common security and defence policy.** Such a classification accords digital sovereignty the societal significance necessary to facilitate a swift transformation. This not only raises public awareness but also establishes the foundation for extraordinary measures, for instance in the area of public procurement or in cases where there is a risk that significant companies within this sector in the EU could be sold to foreign investors. **2. Retail Markets:** Introduction of an EU Digital Certificate (EU Digital Certified Year) for products and services. Manufacturers and service providers may obtain this certificate for their products from independent testing bodies - comparable to the German TÜV - with the associated costs to be borne by the manufacturers or service providers. The certification criteria encompass digital sovereignty, cybersecurity, and data protection. Retailers are obligated to offer certified products in each product category available (e.g., routers, PCs, smartphones, software). Initially, the certificate facilitates consumer purchasing decisions. Following a transitional period, only certified products may be distributed. The minimum requirements for certification may be progressively tightened. **3. Enterprises:** In a first step, enterprises should initially be permitted, on a voluntary basis, to procure products and services bearing the EU Digital Certificate (EU Digital Certified Certificate). In a second phase, such procurement should become mandatory. Already in the first phase, stricter requirements could apply to tenders exceeding a specified threshold. User-friendly solutions, free from unnecessary bureaucratic obstacles, promote sufficient acceptance. Enterprises should retain the autonomy to make their own procurement decisions. However, the review of such decisions should form an integral part of corporate audits. Specific regulations may apply to operators of critical infrastructures. **4. Simplification of the Cumbersome and Frequently Criticised Cookie Management:** Browsers holding the EU Digital Certificate must, by default, provide configurable settings for cookies and tracking. Some browsers already offer such options - for instance, for cookies or a Do-Not-Track feature. These individual browser settings, based on the EU regulations to be introduced, must be mandatorily complied with by all companies. This requirement applies to all tracking activities, including browser fingerprinting, which operates without cookies. In this manner, the previously mandatory management of cookies - required upon accessing numerous websites - is rendered entirely obsolete. In the event of non-compliance with user preferences by companies, appropriate sanctions shall be imposed. The protection of personal data constitutes a fundamental right. **Advertising Market:** Consumer habits may also be ascertained through surveys and studies. The collection of user data is not required for this purpose. **5. Involvement of IT and Network Experts:** In order to further develop this central issue, internationally recognised experts in the fields of information technology and network infrastructure should be invited to devise practical and user-friendly solutions that are free from unnecessary bureaucracy.

feedback: FOSS software is essential to our mission and our commitment to digital sovereignty. The public sector's subscriptions to the US giants have been diverting taxpayer money to fund a system that ruins the European tech sector. A comparatively small investment in funding secure European alternatives would have an disproportionate positive impact for Europe, and would be a much more appropriate use of public funds. 1. the main barriers are vendor lock-in to existing proprietary solutions that make it very expensive to integrate open standards. A lot of public institutions are already have expensive Microsoft subscriptions that make the introduction of any new FOSS software a costly integration problem. This vendor lock-in is subsidized by big companies that have a dominant position in the market (Microsoft but also Adobe for instance) in the education system, which maximize the cost of re-training. On the other side, FOSS projects tend to rely on free contributions, with most companies contributing as little as possible, as this does not benefit them directly. 2. FOSS is the only way to avoid vendor lock-in. Vendor lock-in occurs naturally without any effort; it has to be actively reduced by the developers. For a private company, this is a negative incentive unless the market highly fragmented and so most customers require guarantees from the provider. This is extremely rarely the case. Vendor lock-in means no leverage against the raise of subscription prices from foreign companies that decide they can extract more value from their captured market share. Security: it has been shown through the Snowden leaks that even companies that seemingly do not cooperate with the NSA may do covertly do so, e.g. by using compromised servers. It has also been shown that this had been used to give an advantage to Boeing over Airbus. There is no reason to believe this wouldn't happen again in cases where Europe might threaten the dominating positions of the US tech giants. Innovation: what is the point of developing anything if the gold standard is US developed? It's usually not possible to compete on price, as these companies can outprice competitors for as long as they need to dominate the market (e.g. Amazon). If sovereignty is a value, European alternatives can compete on a fairer basis, which will create more jobs in the economic zone, and improve the pool of job seekers, creating a virtuous cycle. 3. the most concrete measure would be to force open-standards and protocols for any company whose software manage essential information (accounting, payment, etc) 4. Communication, storage, essential services (banking, accounting, health) 5. All sectors would ultimately benefit, but of course all the IT sector would see a tremendous gain, followed by sectors that are the most reliant on their IT infrastructure. Except for some extremely small companies, software is required for tracking, payments, administrative and legal requirements. All are part of the market network that would gain from not being delocalized to foreign actors who have an interest in capturing the market.

Concrete measures to strengthen the EU open source sector: 1) Support efforts like codeberg.org to create a "european Github" support them financially and/or help create a network of such public free instances. Help making activity pub integration in git forges possible, such that these instances can communicate with each other This would build a more decentralized network. 2) Heavily support all governments, institutions of any kind and companies to ditch Microsoft and US-SaaS. Give incentives to companies and institutions to contriubte back to the open source projects they use: Professional developers could benefit from "open source time" in their work time, that is financially supported by the EU. 3) Students should be able to earn a little money by working on open source projects, it could be something like a paid "community service". Lots of young people are motivated to make a difference. This doesn't only include developers, but also design, marketing/PR, organization work. 4) Give regular free security audits to european open source projects. 5) Increase marketing efforts and make european projects more visible. In combination with 1. 6) Actively support open source meetups and communities. 7) Build a european youtube based on open source projects. Especially public institutions shouldn't post their videos on YT, but rather on a european platform.

Question 1 : 2 obstacles me frappent depuis plusieurs années. Le premier est en France l'utilisation dans le milieu scolaire principalement des outils des bigtechs pour offrir des outils numériques aux élèves. Primaire, collège, lycée, ... mon fils m'a pas échappé à l'hégémonie des outils microsoft ou google. Il est depuis le début de sa scolarité en école privée et je ne sais pas si la problématique est la même dans l'école publique. Quoi qu'il en soit, éduquer les élèves au numérique sur la base de logiciel libre serait bien plus bénéfique pour l'appropriation de ces technologies par les jeunes. Le second obstacle, qui saute au yeux lorsque l'on œuvre dans le monde des logiciels libres, est que c'est un monde très technico-technique. Ce monde manque de vision marketing pour enrober cette complexité et offrir ainsi une vision plus simple et donc plus vendeuse. Sous ce prisme technico-technique, le patrimoine du logiciel libre est constitué principalement de solutions techniques et de très peu de solutions métiers. On trouve entre-autre des logiciels ERP/CRM comme solutions métiers mais pas beaucoup plus. Question 2 : Il y aussi le verrouillage idéologique comme on l'a vécu avec X. L'avenir est aux réseaux sociaux libres, décentralisés et fédérés : Fédiverse. Question 3 : Éduquer les élèves au numérique sur la base de logiciels libres, développer le marketing du logiciel libre, développer des solutions métiers sous licence open source. Question 4 : l'infrastructure peut être ? C'est bien d'avoir des logiciels libres mais encore faut-il avoir le matériel pour les faire tourner. Qui fabrique encore des serveurs en Europe ? Bull. Qui d'autre ? Le marché est dominé aujourd'hui par les américains et les asiatiques. Question 4 : Le logiciel libre pour supporter la transition bas carbone et la résilience des territoires car c'est bien là le grand défi de ce siècle. Sinon à quoi tout cela va servir ? Les équipes d'opensustain.tech ont déjà fait un gros travail pour répertorier les outils. Il faut maintenant écrire la suite de l'histoire.

Primary, secondary, secondary, etc. my son has not escaped me from the hegemony of microsoft or google tools. He has been in private school since the beginning of his schooling and I do not know whether the issue is the same in public school. In any case, teaching students digitally based on open source software would be much more beneficial for young people’s ownership of these technologies. The second obstacle, which becomes apparent when working in the open source world, is that it is a highly technical and technical world. This world lacks a marketing vision to overcome this complexity and thus offer a simpler and therefore more saleable vision. Under this technical-technical lens, the heritage of open source software consists mainly of technical solutions and very few business solutions. feedback: Considering the amount of money spent in the EU for licenses to allow transferring huge amounts of data into non-EU cloud platforms, combined with license costs for other software, it is clear that there is money available to create open-source alternatives, or at least alternatives building on existing open-source with back-contributions to the project. Many government entities, at least in Sweden, build their systems on Sharepoint, which, apart from often being sub-standard in terms for functionality, also means money and data going out of the EU. By coordinating efforts, it should very much be possible to come up with better platforms with an open-source license (and/or, again, building on existing open-source platforms). Not only can more money be spent on developing the functionality, it is also possible to extend tools to meet the requirements (I often get the reply: "but Sharepoint does not support that"). With a special interest in electronics design automation, there is also the additional constraint of very high license costs, limiting the possibility for e.g. SMEs to produce ICs etc. As a general remedy, the EU should indicate a clear need to move away from non-EU cloud services and platform providers and encourage different entities to collaborate to develop alternatives. It should also indicate the need to pay back to open-source developers, either by backporting and/or financially supporting the development. It is strange that millions can be paid to American companies, but one cannot contribute a few hundred Euros to a tool that finds just as much use. Funds to support open-source development should also be made available. Not only as research funding, but for actually developing and maintaining open-source projects. This is critical as many high-value open-source projects are still ran on a volunteer basis on peoples spare time. Especially, universities are good arenas for open-source development, so it should be possible to have alternative tracks for academics, less research focused, more focused on developing and maintaining open-source projects.

VDMA represents 3500 German and European machinery companies. The industry stands for innovation, export orientation and SMEs. The companies employ a total of around 3 million people in the EU-27, more than 1.2 million of them in Germany alone. This makes the machinery sector the largest employer among the capital goods industries, both in the EU-27 and in Germany. Almost all machinery provided by our sector is digitalized, connected and innovation is increasingly driven by digital technologies and open digital ecosystems play an important role for our sector. 1. What are the strengths and weaknesses of the EU open-source sector? What are the main barriers that hamper (i) adoption and maintenance of high-quality and secure open source; and (ii) sustainable contributions to open-source communities? A: Maintaining Open Source (OS) Repositories is often a thank-less job, companies utilizing OS often do not contribute more management awareness is needed in this case. OS is often regarded as giving away development work for free, without seeing the benefits of collaborative approaches like in OS. 2. What is the added value of open source for the public and private sectors? Please provide concrete examples, including the factors (such as cost, risk, lock-in, security, innovation, among others) that are most important to assess the added value. A: Costs as licensing proprietary software can be reduced/avoided. A: Vendor-lock-in avoided, especially if OS interoperability solutions are utilized. A: Reduced financial and operational risk: risk is spread amongst multiple parties, which benefits all involved parties simultaneously. A: Security benefits: attacks like the mentioned one on the XZ utils repository are very difficult to conduct. Hiding backdoors or malware in code that can be audited by the public is difficult. Furthermore, using well-reviewed and proven OS code for things like encryption means that companies do not need to homebrew their own solution, which can introduce additional vulnerabilities. A: External impact: companies can greatly benefit from open sourcing their code: it creates transparency and enables potential employees/developers to engage with solutions before even picking up their work. OS is also often seen as a noble cause. A: Independence: as geopolitical tensions rise, the EU and European companies should seek independence from software vendors outside of the EU and establish sovereign alternatives to current hyperscalers, as heavy reliance on proprietary software solutions creates dependence. A flourishing European OS ecosystem could be the answer towards a sovereign digital Europe. Open source provides the technical, economic, and legal basis for Europe to shape its digital future independently and remain free from external interests. 3. What concrete measures and actions may be taken at EU level to support the development and growth of the EU open-source sector and contribute to the EUs technological sovereignty and cybersecurity agenda? A: Identify specific OS Software relevant for industries and subsidize contribution to those Open Source communities/projects. Labor of love only goes so far and resources of voluntary contributors are limited without adequate support. (Financial) Support could take many forms, for example designating certain relevant OS projects as industrial collective research, as industrial interoperability already relies heavily on OS today.

Open Source is the way forward for a sustainable, transparent, secure and sovereign future. There are many success stories for this (probably the most well known one: the Linux kernel). Please note that the definition of "open source" is very important to define. I would refer back to the original definition which means copy left. With that defintion code is still viewable, but future contributions must _also_ be that. This is very important for a sustainable and efficient future. In case you want some examples of why 'viewable code' (often referred to as "open source") is not sustainable enough, please have a look at the history. Old history: Apple was based on BSD, but due the license, did not _have_to_ contribute anything back. Recent history: Peerd ( https://github.com/Azure/peerd ) was forked from Spegel ( https://github.com/spegel-org/spegel ) leaving that community in the dust. This was only possible because of 'open source' permissive licenses, which do not enforce copy left. Let's build a better future together and embrace copyleft once again.
Please find the feedback from the Mercedes-Benz Group AG in the attached document.

feedback: Qui sommes-nous ? La transformation de Pôle emploi en France Travail consacre une mission essentielle : « faire système » avec l'ensemble des acteurs du réseau pour l'emploi (Missions Locales, Cap emploi, départements). Cette obligation d'intégration profonde et d'interopérabilité, issue de la loi pour le plein emploi, repose sur notre capacité à bâtir des communs numériques. L'objectif de la Direction SI Plateforme est de positionner France Travail comme une plateforme ouverte et un partenaire facile et efficace pour tout lécosystème. En s'appuyant sur des standards ouverts et des API documentées, nous avons vocation à devenir le pivot de la tech de l'emploi, organisant une interopérabilité fluide entre des dizaines de partenaires aux systèmes hétérogènes pour garantir la souveraineté et l'efficacité de l'action publique. 1. Forces, faiblesses et barrières de l'open source UE - Faiblesse (Volatilité des licences) : Le changement unilatéral de licence vers des modèles propriétaires (ou « faux open source ») menace la souveraineté numérique des services publics ayant investi dans ces technologies. - Barrière à la contribution : La frilosité d'une partie des acteurs privés à contribuer au code communautaire persiste, par manque d'intérêt économique immédiat ou crainte de perdre un avantage concurrentiel. 2. Valeur ajoutée pour les secteurs public et privé : Elle réside dans la construction d'infrastructures industrielles souveraines. Exemple : Pour le « Réseau pour le plein emploi », notre plateforme d'échange (FranceTravail.io) s'appuie sur des solutions open source robustes (Gravitee pour l'APIM/IAM). Cette stratégie « API-as-a-product » (standards REST/OpenAPI, sécurité OAuth2/FranceConnect) sur une stack « Cloud Native » garantit une observabilité et une indépendance technologique impossibles avec les solutions propriétaires américaines. 3. Mesures de soutien au niveau de l'UE - Filet de sécurité pour les Forks : L'UE doit financer (fonds dédié ou EDIC) la maintenance de briques critiques devenues propriétaires pour pérenniser la nature « commun » du code utilisé par le public. - Commande publique comme levier : À l'image de l'essor des éditeurs logiciels américains porté par la commande fédérale, l'UE doit utiliser la commande publique comme levier pour créer un intérêt économique incitant les éditeurs privés à rejoindre l'aventure open source. - Conditionnalité : Flécher les financements publics vers les acteurs qui reversent à la communauté. Il faut aider les partenaires privés à faire de l'open source un vecteur de rentabilité. 4. Domaines technologiques prioritaires : - Infrastructures de données et Middleware : Pour fluidifier l'Espace européen des données (compétences/emploi). - IA de confiance (Serving & Training) : Outils ouverts indispensables pour l'indépendance de l'automatisation des services publics. - Identité Numérique et API managers : Briques fondatrices des plateformes ouvertes. 5. Secteurs clés pour la compétitivité et la cyber-résilience : - Emploi et Protection Sociale : Secteur clé de la mobilité européenne. L'open source dans les Services Publics de l'Emploi permettrait un continuum de service (EURES) résilient et indépendant des cycles commerciaux des géants tech hors-UE. - Sécurité : La mutualisation des développements (ex: via l'association TOSIT) renforce concrètement la sécurité des chaînes d'approvisionnement logicielles (Software Supply Chain Security).

feedback: With competitiveness as the current political terms bread and butter, the absence of retention of ownership from the discourse misses a core point of the present EU economic and social reality. An unprecedented change of ownership is about to put the European economy up for sale, not only with startups and scaleups but also a silver tsunami of European baby boomer business owners retiring in the coming decade. With private equity giants persuading European entrepreneurs to sell off their valuable businesses for irresistible amounts of money, and venture capital funds cleverly poaching EU startups and scaleups with the most innovative potential, we continue to lose assets, taxes, jobs, autonomy and intellectual property to Wall Street and Silicon Valley. European businesses run the risk of effectively falling into the hands of owners driven solely by short-term financial profits. This short-termism is fundamentally incompatible with the EUs longterm competitiveness agenda, which calls for patient capital and future orientation. Ownership models play a pivotal role in reversing this trend. Steward-owned and employee-owned companies, such as Denmarks Novo Nordisk and the UKs John Lewis & Partners demonstrate every day that long-term business resilience is not only possible, but already achieved. If the EU is serious about creating global champions, it must look to the enterprises that have already excelled in their industries precisely because of their long-term ownership structures. The 28th regime represents a golden ticket to address the issue of ownership retention by including provisions for resilient and competitive ownership models. The EP INI report with multipartisan (!) support asks for · a harmonized limited liability company form, anchored in the Member States, implemented by maximum harmonisation and ensuring full free movement rights and automatic recognition across the Internal Market · fully inclusive i.e. available for all businesses · fully digitalised and simplified company registration · minimum capital requirement of 1 · and optional enabling elements such as o an equity-like debt instrument enabling investors to invest without acquiring rights of control over a company, such as profit participation rights, silent partnerships or profit-linked loans; o employee ownership forms (Employee Stock Ownership Plans, ESOPs), not to be confused with stock options (ESOs) o purpose and mission-driven corporate forms through optional elements such as asset locks and steward ownership, ensuring that companies that do not seek an exit can attract investment and protect themselves against killer acquisitions if they choose to do so. The multi partisan support in the European Parliament was achieved because of two crucial elements: - protection against killer acquisitions i.e. autonomy in Europe; - respect for subsidiarity through a harmonising directive We kindly urge you taking this broader view when thinking of support for open digital ecosystems. The 28th regime INI report has properly laid out a wider more sovereign based model for European business, and as such is a landmark report through the broad political support that was so carefully achieved in the EP.

IFTAS welcomes this initiative and strongly supports the Commissions recognition of open-source software as a strategic component of digital sovereignty, security, and innovation. The EU open-source sector benefits from a rich and diverse developer community, with strong alignment to European values - particularly data protection, human rights, and participatory governance. Decentralised European platforms such as Mastodon, PeerTube, and Mobilizon exemplify how open infrastructure can foster safer, rights-respecting online spaces. However, the ecosystem faces significant structural disadvantages. Community-run infrastructures and volunteer moderation teams often lack sustainable support, leaving them vulnerable to burnout, instability, or acquisition by external actors. EU institutions and Member States continue to rely heavily on proprietary platforms, excluding smaller, rights-based open-source projects from public procurement and local markets. Decentralised platforms also lack access to scalable moderation and governance infrastructure, limiting their ability to address online harms or comply with emerging legal obligations. Open-source platforms offer transparency, adaptability, and local control - critical foundations for democratic accountability and public trust. For example, communities using federated social platforms can implement content standards responsive to local needs, cultural contexts, and lived experience - something unattainable in centralised proprietary systems. Further, open-source alternatives reduce reliance on extractive or opaque platforms, mitigating risks such as algorithmic amplification of harmful content, surveillance tech, and political manipulation through non-transparent recommendation systems. To ensure open-source technologies fully contribute to EU technological sovereignty, the following measures are essential: 1. Targeted funding for social infrastructure, including community governance, trust and safety tooling, content moderation support, and ethical AI integration. 2. Dedicated support for federated ecosystems which enable pluralism, local governance, and interoperability through regulatory and infrastructural approaches distinct from those designed for centralised platforms. 3. Procurement reform to ensure public institutions are incentivised (or mandated) to adopt open-source alternatives wherever feasible, including those operated by small or non-profit entities. 4. Investment in the digital commons, recognising EU-hosted infrastructure for software repositories, interoperability tools, and moderation services as essential public goods. Increased support for federated platforms will decentralise control over public discourse and reduce dependence on non-EU technology monopolies. Open-source adoption within local government systems enhances transparency, auditability, and civic trust. In education, research, and innovation, open platforms reduce vendor lock-in and promote collaboration. Community-audited open tools enable faster vulnerability detection and remediation, contributing to greater cyber resilience. IFTAS urges the European Commission to view open digital ecosystems not merely as technical infrastructure but as a cornerstone of democratic resilience. The long-term health of this ecosystem depends on inclusive policies, sustainable investment, and deliberate support for decentralised infrastructure that prioritises the public interest, civil rights, and the needs of marginalised communities. We stand ready to contribute further to the Commissions strategy and support the development of a vibrant open-source future for Europe.

An economically effective way to stimulate the open source sector, would be to reform EU copyright and related laws that were established ~25 years ago, as a result of a treaty with the USA. This treaty stated that in return, the USA would reduce or cancel tariffs on European imports. It is clear that the USA does not hold itself to its side of the bargain, and that Europe is in the stranglehold of US tech companies. If the EU would make it legal to 'jailbreak' or 'reverse-engineer' technical products, and make the resulting software and hardware open source, this could lead to a whole new European tech industry. It would hugely improve the 'right to repair'. Recently, Cory Doctorow (of the Electronic Frontier Foundation) gave a speech to the 2026 Digital Government Leaders Summit in Ottawa, Canada about this subject. Here is a link: [ https://pluralistic.net/2026/01/29/post-american-canada/#ottawa ]. In Doctorow's view, allowing and stimulating open source solutions to the technical prisons that US tech firms have put us in, could make Canada the "disenshittification nation". If Europe wants to gain technological independence, the EU should consider the plan he outlines in his speech. We could probably co-operate with the Canadians, and strengthen the relationships with decent nations. Doctorow does acknowledge that becoming digitally independent will make the Trump regime very angry, because it will hurt his most important sponsors (and benefit his MAGA base, who do not understand that, and whom Trump doesn't care about). Until now, the EU has not really been capable of answering Trumps threats, and stimulating open source, in order to become digitally independent would finally show that the EU cares about its people, not just its billionaires. Having been a software engineer and contributor to open source software projects for more than 30 years, I would be delighted if the EU can turn the difficult position it is in, into its advantage, using open source software and hardware. (A transcript of Cory Doctorow's speech is attached.)

feedback: Im Rahmen von ILS Integrated Library Systems, also Softwaresystemen für Büchereien/Bibliotheken gibt es sehr grosse amerikanische Anbieter die meist nur noch Cloud Lösungen anbieten - somit landen alle Benutzerdaten auch im Zugriff der amerikanischen Behörden. Alternativ dazu gibt es einige europäische Anbieter, die unter anderem Open Source Software zb koha (https://koha-community.org/) unterstützen. Die Unterstützung von Open Source Software im Bibliotheksbereich steht also am idealen Schnittpunkt zwischen Kultur und Technologie.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: In the context of ILS Integrated Library Systems, i.e. software systems for libraries/libraries, there are very large American providers that mostly only offer cloud solutions – so all user data also end up in the hands of the American authorities. Alternatively, there are a number of European providers supporting, among others, Open Source Software zb Koha (https://koha-community.org/). Support for open source software in the library sector is therefore at the perfect crossroads between culture and technology.

feedback: Zum Monitoringplan und zur Strategie: Welche Ziele Sie sich auch immer setzen, investieren sie genug Zeit in eine klar formulierte Problemstellung (Problem Framing Methode). DAnn ist es wichtig, sich klare messbare Ziele zu setzen (OKRs). Diese Methode ermöglicht dann ein Monitoring was wirklich Fortschritt(oder halt auch nicht) aufzeigt. Eine gemeinsam abgestimmte Problemstellung und daraus abgeleitete Ziele mit entsprechenden Maßnahmen (die in ihrer Kontrolle liegen) stellt sicher, dass alle auf das gleiche Ziel hin arbeiten im Rahmen ihrer Möglichkeiten. Luftschlösser und waberige Ziele mögen einfacher zu formulieren sein aber Wirkungsorientierung geht damit nicht einher.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: On the monitoring plan and strategy: Whatever the objectives, they invest enough time in a clearly formulated problem (problem framing method). It is then important to set clear measurable targets (OCRs). This method then makes it possible to monitor what really shows progress (or does not show). A commonly agreed problem definition and derived objectives with corresponding measures (which are under their control) ensures that everyone works towards the same objective to the extent possible. Airlocks and adventurous targets may be simpler to formulate, but they do not have an impact-orientation.

feedback:
Quelloffene Software und Hardware sind wichtige Bestandteile für eine souveräne und unabhängige Technologiebasis. Nur mit offenem Quelltext können notwendige Veränderungen der Applikationen durchgeführt werden, wenn der Hersteller dies aus politischen oder sonstigen Gründen verweigert. Für eine gesunde Entwicklungsgemeinschaft reicht Quelloffenheit jedoch nicht aus. Eine besondere Stärke ist es, dass der Personaleinsatz zum Ausprobieren einer Idee sinkt, wenn bereits vorhandener Quelltext für gelöste Probleme wiederverwendet werden kann. Das geht allerdings nur, wenn der Quelltext unter einer freien Lizenz wie z.B. der EUPL, GPL oder MIT-Lizenz steht. Ansonsten sind derartige Veränderungen rechtlich nicht zulässig, obwohl sie zumindest faktisch möglich sind. Mit der EUPL hat die Europäische Union schon einen Standard für freie Software gesetzt. Dieser Standard muss die Grundlage für den Open-Source-Sektor der EU sein, um Innovation und Wettbewerb zu sichern. Ein frei einsehbarer Quelltext ist die Voraussetzung für eine vertrauenswürdige und sichere Applikation. Schon Kerckhoff hat 1883 hat Kerckhoff'sche Prinzip formuliert: Das [Verschlüsselungs-]System darf keine Geheimhaltung erfordern. Dafür gibt es viele Gründe, doch das bestechendste ist jenes, dass es jedermann möglich sein soll, Fehler in dem System zu finden. Angreifer können auf vielfältige Weise das System ausnutzen und mit genügend Aufwand werden sie die vorhandenen Schwachstellen finden, selbst wenn sie dem Hersteller selbst unbekannt sind. Durch Quelloffenheit ist es auch Forschern und Pentestern und all jenen, die ein Interesse an der Applikation haben, möglich, diese im besten Falle vor den Angreifern zu finden und zu schließen. Für Verschlüsselungsalgorithmen ist dies besonders wichtig, jedoch gilt dieses Prinzip für jegliche Anwendung. Das Prinzip bezieht sich nicht auf Daten und Fakten, sondern auf deren Verarbeitung. Die Daten selbst können und in aller Regel sollen geschützt bleiben. Um die Vertrauenswürdigkeit zu steigern ist es sinnvoll, wenn möglichst viele interessierte Menschen diese prüfen können. Der reine Quelltext ist dafür natürlich notwendig, kann jedoch um weitere Informationen ergänzt werden. Beispielsweise ist es in der Industrie der Standard, Versionskontrollsysteme zu verwenden, die einzelne Änderungen aufzeichnen und wiedergeben. Diese Änderungen enthalten typischerweise auch ergänzende Informationen zum Hintergrund und der Begründung, warum sie korrekt ist. Mithilfe dieser Metadaten wird es bedeutend einfacher, den Quelltext zu untersuchen, insbesondere in der Hinsicht, dass die Ursache für ein bestimmtes Verhalten der Anwendung ermittelt werden kann. Die Metadaten sind nicht notwendig, um die Anwendung zu kompilieren, erlauben aber einen deutlich niederschwelligeren Einstieg in die Bearbeitung des Quelltextes. Der letzte Punkt ist die Fortsetzung der bisherigen Errungenschaften: Von offenem Quelltext zu freier Software/Hardware zu öffentlicher Entwicklung. Danach kommt noch ein weiterer Schritt, hin zu nachhaltiger Entwicklung. Anwendungen sind keine festen Objekte, ihre Anforderungen ändern sich von Zeit zu Zeit. Die Funktionalität kann dabei unverändert bleiben, doch baut jede Applikation auf anderen Bibliotheken auf, die laufend verbessert werden. Dabei können Inkompatibilitäten entstehen. Man ist auf ältere Versionen beschränkt und profitiert nicht mehr von Verbesserungen. Daher ist es wichtig, nicht nur Anwendungen zu erstellen, sondern auch zu warten - eine Aufgabe, die für gemeinschaftlich entwickelte Open-Source-Projekte fundamental ist und oft durch kleine Änderungen von wechselnden Dritten durchgeführt wird. Für jedes einzelne Projekt reicht die Arbeit oft nicht für eine volle Stelle, in der Gesamtheit kommt aber viel zusammen. Hier ist eine übergreifende Instanz erforderlich. Die größte Stär

feedback: Deuxfleurs is the team behind "Garage", a cloud storage alternative to Amazon AWS S3, and "Aerogramme", an email service alternative to Microsoft Exchange. Both are open-source software projects. These solutions allow us and others to provide high-profile services such as hosting official websites for the french cities of Rennes and Marseille, using their own hardware and without requiring datacenter-grade infrastructure. Development of these projects has been supported by the EU through multiple grants under the Horizon 2020 and Horizon Europe projects for a total amount of ~400k euros, which have been crucial to their success. A key enabler for those projects is the NLnet foundation, which helps independant open-source software engineers to benefit from these grants. Garage has already been adopted by many european SMEs, including a French health-device manfucturer that was looking for in-house storage. Privacy, self-determination, moral values, business resilience, and access to EU experts are the main reasons actors adopt our software solutions. Open-source cloud foundation layers must be the EU's answer in the global competition over cloud computing, as open-source is key to retain EU talent and leveraging the vivid & recognized software ecosystem already present in the EU (eg. FOSDEM, CCC conferences). In a world where Microsoft has the power to shut down the International Court (ICC) email access, we believe it is critical for the EU to invest in foundation software key to our day to day life: while innovation is important, new advances can only be truly secured if they are backed by infrastructure based on a robust and independent software stack. Pilot programs with dedicated funds to accelerate adoption of these new EU open-source software solutions in EU institutions help promote EU-made open-source software from "interesting curiosities" to empowering "off-the-shelf solutions".

In helping your economy break free of domination, you help the whole world. It's somewhat understandable that the Frankenstein monsters of Big Tech have a lock on the USA, since they are the "home teams" there. But Europe? How incredibly shortsighted to invest in one's own bondage for decades, a process that continues. If only 10% of the licensing fees the EU (govt, business) sends to Microsoft each year had been invested in technology at home, we might be a decade ahead of where we are now in support of freedom, privacy, and informed consent. Another decade perhaps by skipping some Apple/Google purchases. Barriers: Government and business intransigence. "It doesn't support feature X." Again, direct a significant portion of current purchases to improving the features you need from Open hardware and FOSS, and then deploy it. Hire locals to do it! Demonstrate the value? The features you just bought above are much cheaper to maintain than licenses, especially with the whole world helping out! You've been renting very highly paid devs, managers, and stockholders in America, when your own workforce is less expensive. (Also, many are unemployed now if the job market is like other places.) Measures: Invest in European hardware and software and pay locals for features, bug fixing, integration, and maintenance. Conclusion: The EU is the *only organization* that can push us forward decisively and quickly. As they say, "the best time to do this was twenty years ago, the second best time is now." It's time to stand up. It may be surprising to hear, but those of us not in Europe are also counting on you and are our main hope. At least, one that has the means to make significant progress. Put that Trump aggression to good use, and make lemons from lemonade. When he's gone, we'll still enjoy a cold drink. ;-) We wrote our thoughts in further detail at the "Trustworthy Technology" site, soon to move to its own domain: https://aol.codeberg.page/eci/ p.s. You only mention "Open Source" software, but Open Hardware (FOSH), Free(dom) Software, and ethical cloud service hosting are just as important. Please, don't forget those as well.

i think its very important to gain some political independence from open source. Implement policies and funding that prioritize open source contributions, sustainable maintenance funding, and public procurement practices that advance interoperable, community-oriented digital infrastructure. Public availability of source code improves the ability to audit, detect vulnerabilities, and collaboratively fix security issues. This contributes directly to resilience and safety of digital systems across the EU. The Black Box of proprietary providers will always be untrusted. only open source is transparent.

Let's start with 'open', does not mean 'for free'. Not the code itself, but the application thereof should have a recognised market value. This means it can be sustainable, and marketable. This is often the reason why it ends up within a larger proprietary stack. Without working the market for both the fit, the value and the pursuit of making the code profitable in itself, it's just code. I believe in open source for exactly that, it is auditable by peers, which allows for improvements, reuse and alternative use by and through a community. This transparency is usually a guarantee no trap doors are included, reusing data for other means than intended of by other entities. In our case of going to full production of an open source application (fairsfair.io) leveraging and open standard as a utility service under the EU-label of Recognised Data Intermediary, were not just building very solid code. We filfill an important role in connecting ecosystems with daily high turnover operations (e.g. fare collection in public transport). This means we need to come out of the gate spotless. This requires a solid investment to go in full production, with a develop, test and acceptance environment. Such an investment is holding us back, as we speak, yet in the bigger scheme of things it's peanuts by what costs it can reduce, the reduction of dependencies (vendor lock-in, even releasing the payment -cEMV scheme- in PT (anywhere). Second to that, we need to set up a solid financial governance structure, that our customers can bank on. Continuity besides great tech is essential. Although we operate our infrastructure component as a utility service within the confines set out by the DGA, such guarantees are sought in a high volume/turnover market. The financial benefits and those related to personal privacy, overcoming commercial sensitivity and access to data to align transport networks at scale is massive. Besides the easy access to PT, reuse of home accounts (wallets), reducing transactional cost 'as is' and minimising transactional costs of payments through electronic money institutions or use of digital currencies would be extremely valuable for this domain, but can easily spread to any other (energy, data, etc.). Pleading for our own parish, we need a proper one off investment, to develop the application to be useable at scale in a secure fashion, in alignment with e.g. Simple components, building forth on other open source tooling. Then we would like to work with the authorities, operators and ticketing providers to link all the existing digital platforms into one, leveraging the networks in EMTA, POLIS, STA and UITP, to act as one for the EU citizen, representing MMTIS/NAPCORE (Transmodel) timetable, fare data and stop data. Then we would like to test out digital payments as EMI or CBDC to further reduce risks and costs (easy to pre authorise and reconcile), and deepen down into capping regimes. The individual can travel anonymously, yet its analogue interactions digitised in the process will flow back to them through their delegated agent, as they will to the transport operator and authority (legitimacy basis), triggering the data benefits to be retrieved as they see fit. No more lock-ins from an architectural (platform) or technology (card scheme, etc.) providers, Reduced cost and access to (valuable data). Serving a large population, even bigger including parking, would enhance the digital literacy and awareness rapidly, improving the respect for privacy and benefits of data governance. The 'trust' factor in data spaces is a short cycle of foresee-abliity, transparency and accountability of data usage in a specific context either legitimised or consented, being the minimally required scope. This will prove the EU concepts work at scale. The operational data -distributed to preserve competitiveness- will increase the value of the public resources in public tran

En pièce jointe j'explique pourquoi "écosystème" et "ouvert" sont contradictoires. Mais je propose surtout une solution... d'internet européen à 0 euros, les utilisateurs étant aussi des fournisseurs : qui n'apprécierait pas de NE PLUS payer d'abonnement réseaux numériques parce qu'étant fournisseur d'espace de stockage grâce à un NAS (Network Attached Storage), qui ? Nous aurions ainsi un méga-internet puisque capable de stocker 8 fois l'actuel internet à partir des Chalots (NAS) que chaque citoyen.ne européen.ne met en ligne. Mais cela suppose de changer bien plus résistant que l'infrastructure : les mentalités :) Vous laissant apprécier COMMENT le projet WeBs OAM4GW pourrait faire des chinois nos clients et des américains nos suiveurs, cordialement, Wilfried PFISTER
feedbackTextUserLanguage: As an attachment, I explain why ‘ecosystem’ and ‘open’ are contradictory. Above all, however, I am proposing a European internet solution of EUR 0, with users also being providers: who would not like to pay NON-PLUS for digital network subscriptions because they are a provider of storage space through a Network Attached Storage (NAS), who? We would thus have a mega-internet, since we would be able to store 8 times the current internet from the Chalots (NAS) that each European citizen places online. But this means a change that is much more resilient than infrastructure: mentalities:) You can let COMMENT appreciate the OAM4GW webs project make Chinese our customers and American followers, cordially Wilfried PFISTER

feedback: Public Services in the EU should switch from closed source to open source software. That is not to say that they should not pay for the creation of custom software. The contrary, EU should support European companies that produce software. What should change is that we should require that the deliverable artifact of any software contract should not only be a service/binary but also the source code of that artifact. That will enforce the open-source culture and EU can be the first customer. The benefit is that this open source software can now be used/improved by other entities in various sectors. The producing company can continue to grow by selling support contracts. Another benefits is the EU or any other organization will not be vendor locked.

Building a solid base for open source projects. The EU must have a controlling stake in this to ensure long term stability. This could be an EU majority owned company or foundation, that could still involve public-private partnerships and community based development. In my view this is a requirement for a successful open source transition. Current open source projects often suffer from issues where maintainers do work in their free time or as a secondary job, low salaries and unstable funding, often Silicon Valley corporations try to steer the development towards their selfish needs. These are causing uneven quality, fragmentation and tribalism, opportunities for bad actors. Areas that could be managed include an operating system, document editing, search engine, map, Wiki site, online storage, user verification with EU wide government ID. Access to these could be a basic EU citizen right. These are needed to gain information, search and apply for jobs, taking care of official business. Even if a citizen doesnt own a device, these can be done on a communal computer. Operating system Linux is not a good base in my view for an EU operating system. Its way too fragmented and full of tribal rifts. Just look at how many different distributions currently exist that try to achieve the same features just slightly differently. And we end up with dozens of half polished or poorly maintained products. Even the Linux kernel has areas that lack enough maintainers. I think a more focused effort would be better. BSD could be a good option, its already a stable server environment and the basis of multiple successful operating systems like MacOS and PlayStation Orbis OS. It would be likely more initial work to set it up for EU needs, but maintenance in the long term would be significantly easier. As its a smaller community with more system approach, EU involvement in the project would much more effective. Document editing There are already good suites like LibreOffice, that could benefit from increased funding and involvement. Focus of improvement should be on compatibility and collaboration that could benefit important for government and corporate environments. Search engine A search engine that is not based on Google data and provides objective search results, not trying to maximize ad revenue. Engines like these already exist in Europe. Map EU could get more involved in OpenStreetMap for example to provide reliable information. Government could provide street data, ESA with the Copernicus programme, industry giants like Airbus, OHB, ICEYE with satellite data and imaging. Online storage Small online storage where citizens can keep important documents and data. Something like Apple does currently where they offer free 5 Gb storage for each account. This is good place where commercial companies could offer extra services that extend the core features. Wiki site Either steer Wikipedia to revised contributor management by helping them with stable funding. Or build a new site where academia and verified experts are involved to ensure accurate information. EU Government ID This could be major step towards data protection. The gov is could tied to an id card, making identity theft more difficult, also users could avoid leaked passwords and the difficult management. The idea is similar to what Google and Apple is doing currently, but this could be elevated to government level. With features like Apple has with Hide my email, that could further protect user privacy. Websites and apps could be mandated to have this login option in the EU. For privacy reasons the EU not necessarily need to store user data its enough to route these request to member state government systems. This government verification could be also a tool to verify that the user is an existing person, not a bot spreading misinformation. User experience is key for adoption in all these systems. A clear vision
