feedback: Note: my feedback is structured with the help of AI, but all toughts are of my own. 1. Strengths and weaknesses: What is standing in the way of open source adoption? In the banking sector, the primary barrier to open source adoption is the lack of enterprise-grade support guarantees. Financial institutions cannot afford to take risks with critical infrastructure without dedicated support contracts, SLA guarantees, and liability coverage. We need "buy before build or use open source" because regulatory compliance and operational resilience requirements demand it. What's needed: EU-backed frameworks or certifications for open source support providers that give financial institutions confidence in long-term maintenance, security patching, and professional support availability. 2. Added value: How does open source benefit the public and private sectors? Open source in banking offers: Vendor independence: Reduced lock-in to proprietary systems (especially important to avoid over-reliance on single vendors like Microsoft) Transparency: Auditable code for security and compliance verification Cost efficiency: Lower licensing costs that can be redirected toward professional support services Innovation: Ability to customize solutions for specific regulatory requirements (EU-specific banking regulations) 3. Concrete actions: What should the EU do to support open source? Establish EU-certified support provider networks for critical open source projects used in regulated industries Create standardized procurement frameworks that allow banks to justify open source adoption to regulators Fund open source security audits and compliance certifications specific to financial services Support decentralized system architectures that reduce single-vendor dependencies Mandate interoperability standards that prevent vendor lock-in 4. Priority areas: Which technologies should be the focus? For banking: Cloud infrastructure (decentralized, multi-provider architectures) Cybersecurity tools (with enterprise support ecosystems) Data management (avoiding Microsoft/single-vendor dominance) API/integration platforms (open standards for financial services) Identity and access management (decentralized identity systems) 5. Sector impact: Banking sector specifics Open source can increase competitiveness and cybersecurity in banking by: Enabling smaller banks to compete with larger institutions using shared infrastructure Improving cybersecurity through transparent, community-reviewed code Reducing systemic risk by promoting decentralized architectures over centralized dependency on single backbone systems Accelerating innovation through shared development of regulatory compliance tools

Open source is often taken advantage of, which given how the internet and many other technologies started from open-source, is ridiculous. In recent years we have seen the impact of under-funded open-source projects, for example, with the vulnerabilities in SSL/TLS. Meanwhile large corporations use open-source projects with very little contributions back to the project, financially or otherwise. There are however example both the project and companies benefitting greatly from a symbiotic relationship. In the case of Valve, creators of the Steam Deck, they used a Linux based OS and used a fork of the Wine runtime to execute normally Windows-only software on Linux. In doing this, they vastly improved the stability of the OS, Drivers and Wine runtime, but also contributed fixes back to those projects for everyone to use, not just for Valve to use for profit. As a result, Linux is a viable and user-friendly alternative to Windows, and the Steam Deck is a well-loved device. At a time when companies are prioritising subscription models, or increasing prices without increasing value, these open-source projects offer a competitor. While possibly not as feature rich, it keeps companies from obtaining a monopoly where they can push prices as high as customers can afford. Many innovations such as the internet itself came from open-source projects. We need to ensure they are protected.

Лично аз смятам, че трябва да има финансиране за разработването на софтуер с отворен код, който е с голямо търсене и исползване. Трябва да има и финансиране за неговата поддръжка и анализ на заплахите. Това е от решаващо значение, тъй като много хора искат да разработват полезен, висококачествен софтуер, но им липсва време и енергия за това, защото целият им потенциал вече е изчерпан чрез изкарване на прехраната: това е капиталистически свят.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: Personally, I believe there should be funding for the development of high-demand and high-use open source software. There must also be funding for its maintenance and threat analysis. This is crucial because many people want to develop useful, high-quality software, but they lack the time and energy to do so because their full potential has already been exhausted by earning a living: this is a capitalist world.

feedback: Open-source technologies have strong potential to enhance the EUs control over its digital infrastructure, reduce dependencies on non-EU suppliers, improve supply chain transparency and support cybersecurity vulnerability management. By design, open-source software is based on transparency and auditability, allowing users to inspect, modify and share source code. This model contrasts with proprietary software, where control is concentrated, visibility is limited and trust depends largely on vendors. However, greater control over code does not automatically result in effective control over vulnerabilities. In practice, many critical open-source components are maintained by very small, often volunteer-based teams with limited time and resources, despite being widely reused across Europes digital ecosystem, including in proprietary products and services. As a result, vulnerabilities affecting open-source components can have systemic and far-reaching consequences. The European Commission has long recognised this challenge. The EU-FOSSA initiative, launched following the Heartbleed vulnerability discovered in 2014, was a key step in acknowledging that open-source security requires targeted public support. EU-FOSSA demonstrated that identifying vulnerabilities alone is insufficient: vulnerability researchers and developers must also be incentivised and supported to ensure timely remediation. Nevertheless, structural challenges remain. Some of the most widely deployed open-source components underpinning global digital infrastructure continue to be maintained by a very limited number of developers. When vulnerabilities go unnoticed, they can propagate rapidly across sectors. The Log4Shell vulnerability discovered in 2021 illustrates this risk: a critical flaw in a widely reused open-source logging library remained undetected for years while being embedded in software used by millions of organisations worldwide. This incident highlighted both the immense value of open-source innovation and the security risks associated with under-resourced maintenance. In response to such incidents, Member State level initiatives have emerged to address these gaps. Germanys Sovereign Tech Agency, created in 2022, demonstrates how targeted public investment in critical open-source components can improve security, stability and long-term sustainability across the digital ecosystem. While automated tools and artificial intelligence can assist in identifying potential vulnerabilities, they also generate large volumes of low-quality or non-exploitable findings. Ethical hackers, professional vulnerability management platforms and structured vulnerability reward programmes therefore play a crucial role in effective discovery, validation and prioritisation. Bug bounty programmes help compensate security researchers and developers for the significant effort required to identify, analyse and responsibly disclose vulnerabilities, and, where possible, contribute fixes. Reducing the societal cost of insecure software is a matter of public interest, as the economic and social impact of vulnerabilities is largely borne by users, businesses and public institutions even when vulnerabilities originate in open-source components embedded in commercial products. As the Commission develops its future European Open Digital Ecosystem Strategy, it should therefore address not only the role of open source in reducing strategic dependencies, but also the need to systematically strengthen the security and resilience of open-source digital infrastructure. Supporting ethical hacking, vulnerability reward mechanisms and maintainers can help ensure that Europes reliance on open source translates into lasting security, trust and sustainability.

There are too few incentives to invest in open-source software in EU, and in general, the ecosystem and communities are vastly underfunded. Due to the lack of funding, the sustainability is at risk, and it is likely that new larger players can dominate the market for IT services. Within the EU, many open-source projects and products have been fostered, including the Linux kernel, KDE, and MySQL/MariaDB. It shows that open source communities and companies thrive in EU. Open-source can provide a framework to ease collaboration of unrelated industries on shared solutions. Moreover, it can provide a deeper integration between academia and private sector. Public funded software projects should as such be released under an open-source license. This will encourage the reuse of existing software components, and the development of components to be reused in other projects. Open-source software is decentralized by nature, and without a big corporate entity controlling the technology, sovereignty is almost trivial to maintain. Generic technology stacks and infrastructure should be prioritized. This will enable companies to offer unique differentiators which will provide broader choices for the potential customers/users. Instead of building from ground up, companies can focus on innovating new concepts and products.

Sehr geehrte Damen und Herren, wir sind eine Steuerberatungskanzlei in Graz und stets darum bemüht, die Daten unserer Klient:innen sorgsam und sicher zu verarbeiten. Dabei stellen wir fest, dass die IT-Infrastruktur für den Betrieb einer Steuerberatungskanzlei stark von Microsoft-Produkten abhängig ist. Wir versuchen, diese Abhängigkeit schrittweise zu reduzieren, stoßen aber immer wieder an Grenzen, die wir nicht oder nur mit unverhältnismäßigem Aufwand überwinden können: So brauchen unsere Steuerberatungsprogramme beispielsweise Windows als Betriebssys-tem. In dieser Spezialsoftware gibt es sehr praktische Funktionen, die jedoch nur mit Microsoft-Programmen ausgeführt werden können. Meine mehrfache Bitte, Schnittstellen zu Open-Source-Programmen zu implementieren wurde leider abgelehnt, da einerseits aufgrund der Quasi-Monopolstellung von Microsoft der Bedarf (derzeit) überschaubar ist und andererseits (nachvollziehbarerweise) die dazu nötigen Kapazitäten nicht vorhanden sind. Meiner Meinung nach wäre es notwendig, die europäische Software-Industrie dazu anzuhal-ten oder gar zu verpflichten, neben einer kommerziellen Lösung auch mit Open-Source Lö-sungen zusammenarbeiten zu können. Eine Förderung auf diesem Gebiet wäre absolut vor-teilhaft und würde es den Software-Unternehmen die nötigen Ressourcen besser ermögli-chen.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: Ladies and gentlemen, we are a tax consultancy firm in Graz and always try to process our clients’ data carefully and securely. We note that the IT infrastructure for running a tax consultancy firm is highly dependent on Microsoft products. We are trying to gradually reduce this dependency, but we are constantly facing limits that we cannot overcome or can only overcome with disproportionate effort: For example, our tax advice programmes need Windows as a business system. There are very practical features in this specialised software, but they can only be performed with Microsoft programs. My repeated request to implement interfaces to open-source programmes was unfortunately rejected because, on the one hand, Microsoft’s quasi-monopoly makes the need (currently) manageable and, on the other hand, (meaningfully) the necessary capacity to do so is not available. In my view, it would be necessary to require or even require the European software industry to be able to cooperate with open-source solutions in addition to a commercial solution. Support in this area would be absolutely beneficial and would better equip software companies with the necessary resources.

feedback: Confartigianato Imprese è la più rappresentativa organizzazione italiana dell'artigianato e delle micro e PMI e una delle più importanti parti sociali in Italia. A livello nazionale, conta 104 associazioni locali, 21 federazioni regionali, 1.206 uffici e 10.700 dipendenti, che offrono diversi tipi di servizi a oltre 1,5 milioni di artigiani e piccoli imprenditori e a quasi 700.000 imprese. feedbackTextUserLanguage: Confartigianato Imprese is the most representative Italian organisation of crafts and micro and SMEs and one of the most important social partners in Italy. At national level, it has 104 local associations, 21 regional federations, 1.206 offices and 10.700 employees, offering different types of services to over 1.5 million craftsmen and small entrepreneurs and almost 700.000 businesses. In Europe, Confartigianato Imprese is a founding member of SMEunited and SBS (Small Business Standard) and has its own representative on the Economic and Social Committee. Confartigianato ICT represents thousands of Italian micro and small enterprises (MPIs) in the digital sector and is therefore interested in highlighting the point of view of those who operate on the market on a daily basis. Please see the attached document containing the answers to the questions in the Call for Evidence – Ares (2026) 476095.

feedback: We call on the European Union to establish a Digital Rights Fund (EDRF) in the next MFF as a strategic complement to existing initiatives on digital infrastructure and sovereignty, aiming to reduce Europes dependencies and strengthen its digital autonomy. The European Digital Rights Funds goal would be to invest in the open technologies, talent, and public-interest innovation necessary to uphold Europes core values and policies in its external action work, including upholding and promoting data protection, right to privacy, freedom of information, platform accountability, secure digital participation, and human rights abroad. The role of the EU is essential in order to make authoritarian regimes accountable and susceptible to democratisation. In order for this to happen, this fund will empower civil society by allowing them to communicate freely and to access the free Internet in countries with especially repressive regimes such as Iran, Russia, and China. While efforts such as the Sovereign Tech Fund address critical infrastructure needs, the proposed Digital Rights Fund would focus on strengthening the user-facing and rights-based layers of Europes digital strategy as part of its Joint Communication on an International Digital Strategy for the EU (as proposed in the page 10 of the Annex of the Strategy). The EDRF would support the technologies and services that safeguard privacy, strengthen democratic resilience, promote information integrity, and enable meaningful participation in digital spaces. Recipients could include: - Technologists and Software Developers: Support for building secure communication platforms, privacy tools, and anti-censorship software. - Digital Security Experts: Funding for developing defensive measures against state-sponsored attacks and providing secure infrastructure. - Human Rights Defenders and Activists: Financial aid for leveraging technology for advocacy and safe communication. - Researchers and Academics: Support for applied research informing practical tools and policies. - Legal Experts and Policy Advocates: Support for shaping legislation and advocating for robust digital rights laws. Services To complement financial support, the EDRF could establish a network of specialized services. These networks could offer critical, high-demand services to internet freedom projects lacking specialized expertise, enhancing their robustness and effectiveness. Services offered by these Labs could include: - Comprehensive Security Audits: Rigorous, independent security audits of software, hardware, and operational protocols, including penetration testing and vulnerability assessments. - Usability and User Experience (UX) Assessments: Enhancing the usability and accessibility of digital rights technologies through user research and simplified interfaces. - Localization: Translating the technologies to local languages. - Technical and Operational Training: Specialized training programs in secure coding, incident response, and digital hygiene. - Legal and Policy Advisory Services: Legal guidance on data protection and human rights law. Programme areas Information integrity: We believe in the importance of capacity building and media literacy work, that goes hand in hand with their Internet freedoms. This would mean supporting projects working on information integrity, disinformation, foreign interference, etc. which are top priorities for the current European Commission and the EU Member States. Secure anti-censorship technologies such as VPNs and other circumvention tools that allow them to access information freely without fear of repression; Encrypted communications and other privacy-enhancing technologies, and encrypted platforms and protocols that allow people in repressive environments to stay connected and protect their privacy and data protection rights; Applied research to identify threats to digital rights

### Strengths and weaknesses of the EU open-source sector The EU open source sector benefits from strong collaboration, alignment with EU values, and a need for digital sovereignty. These strengths are particularly relevant for grid operators like Enexis, Alliander and Stedin, which depend on resilient, interoperable, and secure digital infrastructure. Core open source technologies such as Linux, Kubernetes, and PostgreSQL form the backbone of digital landscape. Collaboration through foundations like LF Energy has enabled the co development of sector critical open-source systems (including Power Grid Model, OpenSTEF, and CoMPAS) reducing duplication, enhancing transparency, and accelerated innovation across the energy system. However, the ecosystem faces notable issues: Chronic underinvestment in open source systems, leading to maintenance and sustainability risks Limited awareness and availability of open source alternatives for critical systems Incompatible tendering favoring proprietary solutions, reinforcing vendor lock in These issues increase dependency on proprietary solutions, hinder the modernization of digital grid systems, and slow down transitions toward open, interoperable alternatives. ### Added value of open source Open-source reduces cost, lowers vendor lock-in, and strengthens digital sovereignty. Its open and community-driven nature improve security through faster vulnerability detection and remediation, while shared R&D accelerates innovation. CoMPAS, an opensource project for automated substation configuration, demonstrates these benefits in practice. It enables grid operators to create substation configurations independent of manufacturers. Proprietary tools lock operators into closed ecosystems, forcing them to maintain multiple incompatible systems. CoMPAS reduces these inefficiencies, supports collaboration, strengthens security oversight, and provides predictable, transparent requirements for manufacturers. ### EUlevel measures to strengthen technological sovereignty and cybersecurity The EU must adopt a systemic, end-to-end view of digital dependencies. Open-source software alone does not guarantee digital sovereignty if critical layers, such as hosting, cloud, compute, and operational control, remain under non-EU influence. Digital sovereignty should not imply building internally but ensuring that organizations retain effective governance, oversight, and decision-making power over the digital systems on which society depends. EUlevel support should prioritize the following: 1. Opensourcefirst procurement. Align procurement frameworks to prefer opensource solutions, ensure consistent regulatory guidance, and direct investment toward sovereign EU opensource based services. 2. Reduce structural dependencies. Ensure credible substitution paths to open-source alternatives for essential systems, especially in critical sectors. 3. A risk based roadmap for adoption of open-source. Prioritize open-source adoption in critical systems first, where resilience and security gains are highest. Scale capability across the EU through skills development, training, and organizational structures (e.g. OSPOs). ### Priority technology areas The EU should prioritize foundational technology domains where dependencies create systemic risk: Open source cloud and edge infrastructure Open source AI and shared data infrastructures Critical sectoral technologies (e.g. open source grid and energy system software) Sectors where OSS boosts competitiveness and cyber resilience Energy: Interoperable, vendorindependent open-source tools strengthen the resilience and sovereignty of critical energy infrastructure. Cloud & edge: Open platforms reduce dependence on nonEU cloud and edge providers and create growth opportunities for European alternatives. AI: Open, trustworthy opensource AI models support compliance with EU regulatory and ethical standards.

From the perspective of a European provider of enterprise-grade Linux and open-source lifecycle management solutions, strengthening Europes digital sovereignty requires a stronger focus on operational control and long-term sustainability of open-source infrastructure. Open-source software already forms the backbone of critical digital systems. However, real sovereignty is achieved not at the level of code availability, but through the ability to securely operate, update, audit, and manage systems throughout their entire lifecycle. Solutions such as centralized provisioning, patch management, compliance, and controlled automation are essential for making open source viable at scale in public administrations and regulated industries. EU initiatives should therefore place greater emphasis on production readiness and lifecycle responsibility, including maintenance, security updates, and governance. Funding and policy measures that stop at development or pilot stages risk leaving organisations dependent on external vendors for day-to-day operations. European SMEs play a key role in translating open-source components into reliable, supportable platforms. Fair procurement conditions, interoperability-focused requirements, and recognition of operational capabilities would enable these companies to scale and to provide sovereign alternatives to proprietary infrastructure stacks. Finally, open-source infrastructure management should be recognised as a strategic enabler of resilience and vendor independence, rather than primarily a cost-saving option. Aligning EU policy and procurement with these principles would significantly strengthen Europes ability to operate and control its digital infrastructure in a secure and sustainable manner.

L'open source è fondamentale per garantire l'indipendenza del nostro Paese (l'Europa) da Potenze straniere. Nella mia esperienza di System Specialist e Project Manager le soluzioni open source che ho proposto di utilizzare non sono mai state viste come valide perché percepite come "inferiori". Non è percepito il valore strategico del tenere i propri dati per sé. Inoltre, almeno in Italia mancano professionisti o aziende che si pongono come partner affidabili in questo settore, e si preferiscono le multinazionali americane. La stessa cosa tra privati: esistono software come Quicksy per la messaggistica, ma si preferisce usare Whatsapp perché "ce l'hanno tutti". Forse, alcune campagne pubblicitarie mirate in questo senso potrebbero aiutare. Questo approccio potrebbe essere valido anche per dispositivi europei come lo Jolla Phone oppure il FairPhone. Un'altra strategia che potrebbe portare risultati, potrebbe essere quella di stanziare dei fondi destinati alle aziende che decidono di creare prodotti open source, oppure forzature che obblighino la PA ad adottare una certa percentuale di software open source nell'immediato futuro, magari lasciando scegliere loro in quale settore utilizzare l'open source oppure no. (Ovviamente, se l'unica alternativa possibile è un software proprietario, questa strategia non dovrebbe essere applicata). Un grande problema è anche culturale: c'è ancora troppa poca consapevolezza di cosa sia l'open source, e soprattutto dei pericoli degli altri tipi di software.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: Open source is key to ensuring the independence of our country (Europe) from foreign powers. In my experience as System Specialist and Project Manager, the open source solutions I proposed to use were never seen as valid because they were perceived as ‘inferior’. The strategic value of keeping your data for itself is not perceived. In addition, at least in Italy, there is a lack of professionals or companies that act as reliable partners in this sector, and American multinationals are preferred. The same thing between private individuals: there are software such as Quicksy for messaging, but you prefer to use Whatsapp because ‘you all have it’. Perhaps some targeted advertising campaigns in this sense could help. This approach could also be valid for European devices such as Jolla Phone or Fairphone. Another strategy that could bring results could be to allocate funds to companies that decide to create open source products, or forcing the PA to adopt a certain percentage of open source software in the near future, perhaps leaving them to choose in which sector to use open source or not. (Of course, if the only possible alternative is proprietary software, this strategy should not be applied). A big problem is also cultural: there is still too little awareness of what open source is, and above all of the dangers of other types of software.

feedback: I wholeheartedly agree with GitHub's feedback. The EC should recognize that "open source" does not only mean free alternatives to Windows, Office, Whatsapp etc. The foundations of these projects are all open source components, libraries, sometimes very tiny ones, sometimes as huge as an entire programming language. Six of world's ten most adopted database systems are open source. 99% of Fortune 500 companies have open source software built into their own products. These building blocks of software are used by EVERY developer in the world, even at for-profit enterprise companies, who have no incentive to give back to the maintainers of these open source components. There are initiatives for companies to take part in a revenue sharing model with these open source contributors (which could be used as a blueprint for EU's model), but there is no widespread adoption of these. There have been countless times where open source libraries got discontinued because of lack of funding, which disrupted billion-euro industries that relied upon said library. A funding framework should be created by the EU, taking cues from existing, similar initiatives, consulting with the largest open source contributors and the largest companies, who all have a stake in maintaining an open source ecosystem, even if these companies make billions by selling for-profit software built upon millions of lines of open source code.

Jahrzehnte lang haben wir zugesehen, wie andere über unsere digitale Zukunft entscheiden. Jahrzehnte der Abhängigkeit, der Bequemlichkeit, der Naivität. Endlich endlich! regt sich Widerstand. Europa will sich digital befreien. Doch der Aufholbedarf ist gigantisch, und die Zeit drängt. Open Source soll unser Rettungsanker sein: Linux statt Windows, LibreOffice statt Microsoft, Blender statt Autodesk, Signal statt WhatsApp. Doch halt, wer glaubt, Open Source allein werde uns erlösen, irrt gewaltig. Die Realität ist ernüchternd: Linux kommt auf lächerliche 36 % Marktanteil, LibreOffice auf mickrige 2 %. Warum? Weil Open Source unsichtbar bleibt, weil kommerzielle Software schlicht bequemer ist, weil wir uns in alten Gewohnheiten suhlen. Doch das ist nicht das Schlimmste. Das wahre Skandalon: Open Source wird schamlos ausgebeutet! Kommerzielle Konzerne klauen den Code, lackieren ihn neu und verkaufen ihn als eigene Innovation während wir dankbar nicken. Auf GitHub trainieren Tech-Giganten ihre KI mit unserem Wissen, nur um uns dann ihre Premium-Lösungen anzudrehen. OpenGL und Vulkan? Jahrelang hinter Microsofts DirectX hergehinkt. In der Spielebranche sind zwei Jahre eine Ewigkeit und wir? Wir stehen am Rand und klatschen Beifall. Und dann die 3D-Engines: das Rückgrat unserer High-Tech-Zukunft: Militär, Medizin, Forschung, KI fast alles hängt davon ab. Doch was nutzen wir? Unity, Unreal und Unigine. Drei ausländische Monopole. Drei Un-Engines, die uns knechten. Godot? Ogre3D? Lächerliche Nischenprojekte, die an Performance und Features scheitern. Europa, die Heimstätte der Ingenieure, der Erfinder, der Pioniere und wir betteln um Krümel von amerikanischen und russischen Tisch! Doch es gibt Hoffnung: die Vektoria-Engine (https://www.hs-kempten.de/fakultaet-informatik/zentrale-einrichtungen/computerspiel-zentrum-games/vektoria). Ein europäisches Projekt, das die Un-Engines in Benchmarks alt aussehen lässt. Hybrid, klug, zukunftsfähig. Mit ein paar hundert Millionen Investitionen könnte sie in drei Jahren der weltweite Standard sein. Europa, es ist Zeit für klare Kante: Erstens: Wir müssen begreifen, dass Abhängigkeit kein Schicksal, sondern eine Entscheidung ist. Zweitens: Wir brauchen politischen Willen nicht leere Sonntagsreden, sondern Taten. Drittens: Open Source ist gut, aber nicht genug. Wir müssen selbst entwickeln, selbst gestalten, selbst bestimmen. Stellt euch vor: In zehn Jahren könnte Europa softwaretechnisch souverän sein. Zehntausende neue Jobs, blühende Start-ups, die besten Köpfe bleiben hier oder kehren zurück. Doch das gelingt nur, wenn wir aufhören, uns zu zersplittern. Nur ein vereintes, entschlossenes Europa kann sich gegen die digitalen Imperien behaupten dies würde diejenigen Werte und Eigenschaften stärken, die Europa zu einem liebenswerten Kontinent machen: Die sprachliche und kulturelle Vielfalt, die Subsidiarität, die Demokratie und der Schutz der individuellen Freiheit. Die Aufgabe ist gewaltig, aber sie ist machbar. Also: Worauf warten wir?

feedback: I think this initiative is a great idea. However, I have a couple of concerns. 1. Avoid US-based companies like GitHub (Microsoft) where possible. While large, established platforms are convenient, an EU-based open source platform would be preferable, as to not fund the American techno-oligarchy. This could also be a risk, if say the US government forces the platform to deny access from the EU. Using such platforms as a mirror would probably be a good idea, though, but I would certainly hesitate to rely on them for anything vital. 2. Support existing global open source projects where possible rather than only brand-new or EU-based projects. While yes, this may sometimes go against the prior point for projects using US-based platforms, I think it's important to not try to reinvent the wheel and end up with something worse, or to end up fracturing ecosystems by forking large projects. Instead, work with open source projects to ensure that the EU can use their software as-is, whether that be transitioning away from GitHub, license changes, or actual implementation details. 3. I feel a very important point was brought up by Andrew Nesbitt of the UK as a response here. He makes an excellent argument about how no matter where a Git instance is hosted, infrastructure surrounding dependencies (for example NPM [Node Package Manager]) would still be entirely owned by US-based companies. I urge the commission to heed his feedback on this topic.

The Commission's call for evidence rightly identifies European reliance on non-EU digital technologies, but focuses primarily on cloud infrastructure, AI, and end-user applications. There's a critical layer missing: the dependency intelligence infrastructure that sits between source code hosting and application deployment. Open source software underpins 70-90% of all code in the digital economy. But the infrastructure that tracks, analyses, and secures that software is almost entirely US-controlled: package registries, vulnerability databases, dependency graphs, software composition analysis tools, and automated update services. A European company can self-host Forgejo for code hosting and still depend entirely on US services for vulnerability scanning, dependency updates, license compliance, and SBOM generation. The M×N Problem Package management has an M×N problem. Every tool implements support for every ecosystem separately. When a new language ships a package manager, it goes to the back of every queue. No Dependabot support, no advisory database coverage, no PURL type for SBOMs. This is structural. Before the Language Server Protocol, every IDE implemented support for every language: M×N integrations. LSP changed that to M+N. Package management needs the same thing. The lack of a protocol creates lock-in by default. Not malicious, just gravitational. A protocol would make the dependency layer contestable. Run your own registry that federates with others. Stand up a regional vulnerability database that speaks the same language. Where Standards Exist and Where They Don't Some de facto standards have emerged. Git is universal. Semver is dominant. Some areas have formal specs: PURL for package references, OSV for advisories, CycloneDX and SPDX for SBOMs, SLSA for provenance. Other areas don't. Dependency graph APIs vary by platform. Vulnerability scanning integration is proprietary per forge. Dependabot and Renovate have their own config formats. Package metadata APIs differ across registries. Most standards work focuses on compliance artifacts. Less attention goes to the underlying tools developers actually use. The gap is where standardisation would reduce switching costs. Not building a European deps.dev, but defining a common dependency graph API. Not building a European Dependabot, but standardising how dependency updates get proposed. Concrete Measures First, treat dependency intelligence as infrastructure worth funding directly. The Sovereign Tech Fund model applies: direct funding to open source projects that serve as foundations. Ecosyste.ms, VulnerableCode, OSV, PURL implementations, CycloneDX tooling, Forgejo's dependency features. Second, fund protocol development. Someone needs to define common interfaces for dependency graphs, package metadata, vulnerability feeds, and update notifications. Third, use procurement to drive adoption. If an agency requires SBOMs, require that generation doesn't depend on proprietary services. Government procurement moves markets. Fourth, coordinate procurement language across member states. Shared interoperability requirements would move the market. The Cyber Resilience Act will require SBOMs and vulnerability handling. If that infrastructure remains US-controlled, European compliance with European regulations will depend on American services. The Commission has an opportunity to shape this market while it's still forming. Further reading: https://nesbitt.io/2026/01/28/the-dependency-layer-in-digital-sovereignty.html https://nesbitt.io/2026/01/29/zig-and-the-mxn-supply-chain-problem.html https://nesbitt.io/2026/01/22/a-protocol-for-package-management.html https://nesbitt.io/2025/12/21/federated-package-management-and-the-zooko-triangle.html Andrew Nesbitt, founder of Ecosyste.ms (11M packages, 22B dependencies tracked). Co-organizer, FOSDEM Package Management devroom and CHAOSS Package Metadata Working

feedback: Als IT-Leiter des Caritasverbandes für die Diözese Speyer e.V. positioniere ich mich wie folgt : - Wir wollen uns nicht abhängig von Unternehmen machen, die ihre Daten außerhalb der EU speichern. Aus diesem Grund betreiben wir unsere Server-Systeme in eigenen Rechenzentren und wenn möglich on premise. M365 ist uns ein Dorn im Auge, sowie die ganze Microsoft Cloud- Infrastruktur. Eine Lösung auf EU-Ebene wäre anzustreben. Mfg. Jendrik Gawrisch / IT-Leiter Caritasverband für die Diözese Speyer e.V.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: As IT director of the Caritasverband für die Diözese Speyer e.V. [Caritas Association for Diocese Speyer], I take the following position: We do not want to become dependent on companies that store their data outside the EU. This is why we operate our server systems in our own data centres and, where possible, on premises. M365 is a thorn in our eyes, as well as the whole Microsoft Cloud infrastructure. A solution at EU level should be sought. MFGs. Jendrik Gawrisch/IT Director Caritasverband für die Diözese Speyer e.V.
organization: Caritasverband für die Diözese Speyer e.V.

feedback: L'Europe présente le paradoxe d'avoir l'un des écosystème open source les plus développés au monde, et d'acheter majoritairement son logiciel aux États-Unis. Elle bénéficie de nombreuses PME extrêmement compétente, maîtrisant des solutions open source de grande qualité, mais ces entreprises sont sous-financées, souvent exclues de la commande publique et de l'achat des grands groupes et souvent en concurrence avec des entreprises étrangères bien plus financées. Ces concurrents internationaux profitent en outre souvent d'un effet de réseau propriétaire, favorisé par l'absence d'interopérabilité. Ces difficultés sont liées. Pour valoriser son expertise et renforcer sa souveraineté numérique, l'Union Européenne devrait mettre en cohérence tous ces axes, notamment à travers la commande publique : - Favoriser l'open source - Favoriser les PME - Favoriser les solutions interopérables et la mise en place de data spaces L'interopérabilité est une question clé pour le renforcement de l'open source. En effet, lorsque les solutions numériques sont proposées sous forme de plateforme, l'éditeur peut imposer un seul logiciel pour l'interface et l'algorithme, puisqu'il contrôle toutes les interactions des utilisateurs. A l'inverse, dans une logique de data space, chaque utilisateur et organisation peut choisir le logiciel lui convenant le mieux, réutiliser une solution, l'améliorer et la diffuser sous licence libre. Agir sur ces trois leviers dans la commande publique, imposer l'interopérabilité aux acteurs dominants et financer les PME européennes sont les meilleurs moyens de miser sur l'écosystème open source européen plutôt que de préférer les dépendances étrangères.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: Europe has the paradox of having one of the most developed open source ecosystems in the world, and buying most of its software from the US. It benefits from many highly competent SMEs, mastering high-quality open source solutions, but these companies are underfunded, often excluded from public procurement and the purchase of large groups and often in competition with much more funded foreign companies. These international competitors also often benefit from a proprietary network effect, facilitated by the lack of interoperability. These difficulties are interlinked. In order to valorise its expertise and strengthen its digital sovereignty, the European Union should bring all these areas into line, in particular through public procurement: — Fostering open source – Enabling SMEs – Enabling interoperable solutions and setting up data spaces Interoperability is a key issue for strengthening open source. Indeed, when digital solutions are offered as a platform, the publisher can impose a single software for the interface and the algorithm, as it controls all user interactions. Conversely, in a data space logic, each user and organisation can choose the software that suits them best, reuse a solution, improve it and distribute it under free licence. Acting on these three levers in public procurement, imposing interoperability on dominant players and financing European SMEs are the best means of relying on the European open source ecosystem rather than preferring foreign dependencies.

feedback: As a company with more than a decade of experience in open-source software and projects, we strongly believe that open source is not only a foundation for more transparent and open business in Europe, but also a key enabler of global, fair, and sustainable digital ecosystems. Open source allows communities worldwide to collaborate on software security in a reliable and verifiable way. It accelerates innovation by enabling faster development and the adoption of the right tools for real-world needs. Digital sovereignty over code and applications is essential. It empowers organisations across sectors such as finance, healthcare, education, and beyond to operate independently, without being locked into corporate-driven rules and proprietary constraints. This differentiation is critical for Europes competitiveness and resilience. Transparency, sovereignty, and security are core values that proprietary, profit-driven models cannot address with the same depth and neutrality as open-source approaches. Open source is driven by collaboration and shared responsibility rather than financial interests alone. For these reasons, open source must be actively supported through dedicated funding, clear policies, and long-term commitment to ensure its sustainability and impact across Europe.

Cloud Temple défend l'open source comme un pilier de la souveraineté numérique européenne. L'Europe dispose d'atouts réels : des instituts de recherche de classe mondiale, un tissu de PME et d'intégrateurs qui maintiennent des infrastructures essentielles, et une culture de transparence qui contraste avec les "boîtes noires" des hyperscalers américains. Mais ces forces se heurtent à des obstacles majeurs. L'écosystème reste fragmenté, sans la puissance de frappe nécessaire pour rivaliser. Surtout, il existe un déficit critique de financement pour transformer les prototypes de recherche en produits industriels matures. Cloud Temple pointe aussi le problème du verrouillage propriétaire qui piège les entreprises européennes dans des écosystèmes fermés, rendant difficile toute migration vers l'open source malgré ses avantages à long terme. La valeur de l'open source tient à trois dimensions complémentaires. L'auditabilité totale du code garantit la souveraineté et la sécurité, particulièrement pour les secteurs critiques comme la défense ou la santé. L'interopérabilité prévient le verrouillage technologique l'initiative SECA illustre cette possibilité avec des API cloud souveraines. L'innovation trouve également un terrain favorable : l'open source permet d'optimiser les ressources, que ce soit pour l'IA frugale ou le edge computing, comme le montre le secteur automobile où les constructeurs européens mutualisent des couches logicielles non différenciatrices. Cloud Temple propose plusieurs leviers d'action. L'interopérabilité doit devenir opposable, avec des standards contraignants qui empêchent les hyperscalers d'enfermer leurs clients. Les marchés publics doivent privilégier systématiquement les solutions open source pour créer un marché stable aux fournisseurs européens. Un financement spécifique doit accompagner la phase de maturation industrielle documentation, expérience utilisateur, audits de sécurité. Le soutien aux OSPO dans les administrations et grandes entreprises professionnaliserait l'usage de l'open source. Quatre domaines technologiques sont jugés prioritaires : le continuum cloud-to-edge face à l'explosion des données générées en périphérie, la virtualisation comme couche fondamentale du cloud, l'intelligence artificielle avec des modèles à poids ouverts et des outils transparents, et la cybersécurité incluant la cryptographie post-quantique. Les secteurs où l'impact serait le plus fort incluent l'industrie 4.0, les infrastructures énergétiques critiques, la défense qui exige un contrôle absolu de la pile logicielle, et l'automobile en pleine transition vers le software-defined vehicle.

Europe has real assets: world-class research institutes, a fabric of SMEs and integrators that maintain critical infrastructures, and a culture of transparency that contrasts with the black boxes of US hyperscalers. But these forces face major obstacles. The ecosystem remains fragmented, without the necessary firepower to compete. Most importantly, there is a critical funding gap to transform research prototypes into mature industrial products. Cloud Temple also points to the problem of proprietary lock-in that traps European companies in closed ecosystems, making it difficult to migrate to the open source despite its long-term benefits. feedback: I am a user, contributor, and developer of open source software. I am also a mother hoping to see my children growing up digitally literate, and not captured early into the strategic incompetence that proprietary software giants such as Microsoft, Apple, Meta, Alphabet, and others build into their platforms. It is my sincere hope that the political turmoil results in a more sovereign European digital ecosystem freed largely from US-based political influence. Cory Doctorow recently gave a talk at the Chaos Computer Club conference: https://media.ccc.de/v/39c3-a-post-american-enshittification-resistant-internet In it, he argues for the EU to repeal anti-circumvention law, which I find a worthwhile argument to repeat here. In practice, anti-circumvention laws grant US-based software vendors de facto control over interoperability, repair, modification, and competition. Dominant firms can use DRM to block rivals without relying on copyright infringement claims, reinforcing market concentration. Open source software values interoperability to build compatible, secure, and innovative alternatives, often requiring reverse engineering. Anti-circumvention laws criminalize these activities even when no copyright is violated, making it legally risky or impossible for European open source projects to compete with proprietary US platforms. By removing legal barriers to interoperability, the EU would enable homegrown open source alternatives in cloud computing, operating systems, productivity software, and infrastructure. This reduces dependency on US vendors, lowers public procurement costs, and improves long-term technological sovereignty. Anti-circumvention laws function as an industrial policy favoring incumbent US software firms. Repealing them would unlock competition, strengthen European open source ecosystems, and restore balance between copyright protection and the public interestwithout legalizing infringement. The EU should consider repeal as a strategic step toward digital sovereignty and a more competitive, innovative and open software market. At the same time, I want to urge political decision makers to keep education and digital literacy in their mind. While we need open source software, we also need a digitally literate population that uses them competently. Dominant software platforms often display what superficially looks like better user friendliness, but in practice often means forbidding the user to understand basic computing principles. This is a severe threat to digital competence that hinders adoption of open source alternatives, which often provide users with more technical freedom at the expense of appearing less user friendly in comparison. This can be remedied by educating students and adults alike in the marketing strategies behind market domination and user lock-in to proprietary platforms, early introduction of open source alternatives (e.g., mandating the use of FOSS operating systems and tools in schools, in public administration), and digital education that targets understanding computing principles instead of teaching use of specific proprietary tools.

feedback: When software runs hospitals, energy grids, public services and the devices we rely on every day, it should be treated like any other critical infrastructure. Open-source software is a strong foundation because it allows independent inspection, shared improvemen and real choice - but openness alone is not enough. We also need clear, enforceable standards that ensure security, accountability and fair access, so that no single company can quietly control systems we all depend on. Done right, open systems combined with strong standards reduce hidden risks, prevent lock-in and help keep Europes digital infrastructure trustworthy, resilient and under democratic control.

Greetings whomever reads this. I'm a non-EU citizen, but I live and work in the EU. I am a lowly individual contributor to OSS. Not to anything important, but maybe one day. I think that's fine, not everything gets popular. I worry that writing and sharing software has become dangerous. OSS is often made by motivated individuals in their spare time as a hobby for free. Sometimes a company, but not usually, and they have to retain the spare-time ethos anyway or they get unpopular. Sometimes they make money, but retain the spare-time ethos. Sometimes they transition to a tech company. I'll talk about projects with spare-time ethos, not ones that transition to a company. When someone made the Internet, Napster, Bitcoin, or Android, nobody knew what would happen. Just an experiment, no expectation of negative consequences. I think if you made one today you'd be arrested. In France, someone made an operating system for phones - GrapheneOS - focusing on privacy and security. That's good for European sovereignty. Less dependence on Apple or Google. But because of the priv/sec focus, very popular with criminals like drug dealers. Police came to the creator's apartment, said they support criminals and should be in jail. They fled the country. In Australia (outside EU) the same with the Session app. Like WhatsApp, with focus on privacy and security. Police said you support criminals, stop making this app. They fled the country. With Chat Control, this would be the law in the EU too. 2 Portugese people made a Bitcoin wallet program called Samourai. Because of its priv/sec features it was popular with criminals and the USA (not Europe!) said they support criminals, should be in jail. They're in USA jail now? If Europe wants OSS innovation, it needs to stop this! Greed balances fear. Maybe for enough money it's worth it, but there's no money in hobby OSS. When it's funded at all, only covers cost of living, not enough to take legal risks. The DSA is a great step, but only for certain things. Session might be covered, GrapheneOS isn't. And there's far too much paperwork, for a project that might only be online for 3 months. === One common thread: focus on privacy and security, so strong it kept law enforcement out. Should they just make it NOT private, and NOT secure, so LE can get in? I don't think this is reasonable in OSS, here's why: These are developers who find software exciting and make it as a hobby. That's great. Let a million flowers bloom, we'll see which are most beautiful. But beggars can't be choosers. Hobby projects and big companies have very different incentives. People excited by software just don't think sending private data to LE is very fun. Making ways to protect data, finding weaknesses, strengthening them, that's fun. So, hobby software often has strong innovative privacy and security. A computer can't tell the difference between a LEO, a thief, a hacker. Protection from thieves and hackers is legal, so LEOs are locked out too. Q: How do big tech companies do it? A: They don't protect data. The employees can access it all. They answer emails with human judgement. Sometimes they're tricked, and you get data leaks. When technology protects data, instead of employees, nobody can access it, they can't be tricked, and it can't leak. Q: Why can't the system tell between LEOs and hackers? A: It's been tried a few times. The only way we know, is with a secret password only LEOs know, and a law: every computer has to show its data if you have it. But the password ALWAYS gets leaked, then any hacker can use it to bypass any security anywhere. The idea just doesn't work. (Note: simplified explanation) There's another problem: hobby projects are often only provided as software, that you can download and install on your own server, not as a service running on the developer's servers, like Twitter or Facebook. They don't have your data, because it's on yo

feedback: Utilisateur de longue date des logiciels libres, je trouve primordial que l'Europe se dote d'une réelle politique de promotion incitative de ces logiciels et plateformes. Cela est d'autant plus vrai au vu de la situation géopolitique mondiale actuelle. Les pays européens sont bien trop dépendants des systèmes américains. Aujourd'hui, les USA peuvent très simplement mettre à genoux l'Europe, soit en coupant les accès à ces systèmes, soit en pratiquant une politique tarifaire ultra aggressive, pouvant mettre à mal la stabilité financière des entreprises ou organismes Européens. Devenir souverain sur ces points là (entre autres !) est non seulement urgent, mais aussi inévitable. Le comportement du président des USA aujourd'hui est peut être dû à une personnalité hors normes, provocatrice, avec un égo surdimensionné... Mais cela donne des idées et ouvre une voie que d'autres puissances mondiales ne se gêneront pas d'emprunter
feedbackTextUserLanguage: As a long-standing user of open source software, I find it vital for Europe to adopt a genuine policy of encouraging the promotion of such software and platforms. This is all the more true given the current global geopolitical situation. European countries are far too dependent on American systems. Today, the USA can simply knead Europe, either by cutting off access to these systems or by applying an ultra-aggressive pricing policy, which can undermine the financial stability of European companies or organisations. Becoming sovereign on these points (among others!) is not only urgent, but also inevitable. The behaviour of the President of the USA today may be due to a non-standard, provocative personality with an oversized ego... But it gives ideas and opens a path that other global powers will not be hampered in taking

feedback: To whom it may concern, I am writing to submit my recent analysis, "Digital sovereignty requires funding, not just adoption," as formal feedback for the "European Open Digital Ecosystems Strategy" call for evidence. While the EU has correctly identified open source as a "public good" essential for technological independence , adoption alone is insufficient. To achieve true digital sovereignty and mitigate the risks posed by reliance on non-EU hyperscalerssuch as supply chain vulnerabilities and data seizure under the US CLOUD Actthe EU must shift its focus from one-off innovation grants to sustainable, operational funding. Key Recommendations for the Strategy: 1. Fund Operations, Not Just Projects: Move beyond goal-oriented grants that end once a product is built. Open source infrastructure requires ongoing operational budgets to pay maintainers for "boring" but critical work like security patches and documentation. 2. Reform Procurement Policies: Leverage the billions currently spent on proprietary licenses to instead preference open-source solutions with European maintainers. 3. Plug the "Sovereignty Leak": Address the value extraction problem where international tech giants monetize European open-source contributions without reinvesting in the ecosystem. Infrastructure Support: Establish European equivalents to the Linux or Apache Foundations to provide hosting, CI/CD, and technical writing support for sovereign tools. Digital sovereignty is not merely a technology choice; it is a budget line item. Without a commitment to "write the cheques" for the people maintaining our digital foundations, Europe remains dependent on the labor of unpaid volunteers. I hope you consider the insights provided in the attached article to ensure a more resilient and independent European digital future. Kind regards, Will Hackett

feedback: I am the founder of Sensative AB, a Swedish technology company established in 2013. Since 2014, we have been developing Yggio, an IoT and data integration platform created to empower societies, cities, and organisations to become digitally sovereign, resilient, and effectively digitalised. From the outset, our ambition has been to enable long-term digital infrastructure without vendor lock-in, based on interoperability, open standards, and European values of transparency, security, and accountability. For this reason, I strongly welcome the European Commissions initiative on European Open Digital Ecosystems. Yggio is built extensively on well-established open source technologies, including MongoDB, Docker, RabbitMQ, Keycloak, and PyTorch. These components form the foundation of a production-grade platform used in real societal contexts, demonstrating that open source is a mature and reliable basis for critical digital systems. In addition to using open source, Sensative also contributes back by releasing selected internally developed components and tools as open source. This approach strengthens interoperability, enables collaboration, and supports innovation across organisational and sectoral boundaries. At the same time, Yggio is a commercially licensed platform, operated with clear responsibility for security, reliability, and long-term maintenance. We believe it is important to recognise that openness and commercial sustainability are not contradictory. Yggio is designed to be API-driven, standards-based, and interoperable with third-party systems, allowing customers to retain control over data and integrations while benefiting from a stable and accountable platform provider. From our experience, open digital ecosystems are essential to achieving digital sovereignty in practice, particularly in sectors such as smart cities, buildings, energy, and public infrastructure. These systems must remain operational over decades and therefore require openness, interoperability, and long-term governance rather than short-term proprietary solutions. We have identified several key challenges that limit the growth of open digital ecosystems in Europe: Fragmented and short-term funding for open source maintenance Unclear definitions of openness in public procurement Limited recognition of hybrid or open-core business models Barriers for SMEs to participate in large-scale European initiatives To address these challenges, I encourage the European Commission to: Explicitly support hybrid and open-core models alongside fully open source solutions Promote open APIs, open standards, and interoperability as procurement requirements Invest in the long-term maintenance and security of critical open source components Enable SMEs to act as long-term ecosystem providers, not only project partners Sensative and Yggio represent a practical example of how open technologies, open standards, and commercial platforms can coexist to build resilient, interoperable, and sovereign digital infrastructure in Europe. I strongly support this initiative and hope it will result in a strategy that is open in principle and viable in practice. Sincerely

Premetto che in qualità di docente di Informatica, ritengo che lopen source rappresenti non solo una metodologia di sviluppo software, ma una filosofia che incarna valori fondamentali dellEuropa stessa: libertà, trasparenza, collaborazione e inclusione. Ladozione dellopen source, soprattutto nel settore pubblico e nellistruzione, dovrebbe essere considerata una scelta strategica predefinita, in quanto strumento essenziale per la formazione di cittadini consapevoli, la riduzione delle disuguaglianze digitali e la promozione di una sovranità tecnologica europea autonoma e resiliente. Venendo alle domande indicate: 1. Punti di forza, debolezza e ostacoli del settore open source nellUE Punti di forza Libertà e trasparenza: Lopen source garantisce le libertà fondamentali di studio, modifica e condivisione del software, principi che si allineano con i valori democratici europei. Riduzione dei costi: Leliminazione delle licenze proprietarie consente un risparmio significativo per le amministrazioni pubbliche e le istituzioni educative, liberando risorse per investimenti in competenze e innovazione. Formazione e consapevolezza: Laccesso al codice sorgente permette agli studenti e ai professionisti di comprendere appieno il funzionamento dei sistemi informatici, riducendo il divario tra istruzione e mondo del lavoro. Innovazione collettiva: La collaborazione aperta accelera lo sviluppo di soluzioni tecnologiche, favorendo la competitività e la ciberresilienza. Punti di debolezza e ostacoli Frammentazione e sostenibilità: La mancanza di coordinamento tra progetti e comunità open source europea limita la scalabilità e la manutenzione a lungo termine. Sicurezza e qualità: La percezione di minore sicurezza rispetto ai software proprietari, spesso dovuta a una mancanza di risorse per audit e manutenzione, frena ladozione. Mancanza di competenze: La scarsa formazione specifica sullopen source nei percorsi educativi e la resistenza al cambiamento nelle organizzazioni pubbliche e private. Modelli economici insostenibili: La difficoltà di finanziare progetti open source in modo continuativo, soprattutto per le piccole comunità, ostacola la qualità e la sicurezza delle soluzioni. 2. Valore aggiunto dellopen source per pubblico e privato Settore pubblico Risparmio e indipendenza: Ladozione di software open source nelle scuole e nelle PA consente di ridurre la dipendenza da fornitori esterni, evitando il lock-in tecnologico e i costi ricorrenti di licenza. Esempi virtuosi sono la migrazione di molte amministrazioni locali europee a suite come LibreOffice o sistemi operativi Linux, che hanno permesso notevoli risparmi sui budget IT. Sicurezza e controllo: La trasparenza del codice permette una verifica indipendente della sicurezza, riducendo i rischi di backdoor o vulnerabilità non dichiarate. Partecipazione civica: Lopen source favorisce la collaborazione tra cittadini, sviluppatori e istituzioni, come dimostrato da progetti come Decidim per la democrazia partecipativa. Settore privato Innovazione e competitività: Molte aziende note nel settore high tech utilizzano lopen source per accelerare lo sviluppo di soluzioni IoT, AI e cloud, riducendo i tempi di mercato e i costi di ricerca e sviluppo. Resilienza e flessibilità: Ladozione di standard aperti consente alle imprese di adattarsi rapidamente ai cambiamenti tecnologici, evitando la dipendenza da singoli vendor. Attrazione di talenti: Le aziende che contribuiscono attivamente a comunità open source attraggono professionisti motivati e competenti, come dimostrato da casi come Red Hat o GitLab. Fattori chiave per la valutazione Costi: Riduzione delle spese per licenze e manutenzione, con reinvestimento in formazione e innovazione. Rischi: Minimizzazione del lock-in e maggiore controllo sulla sicurezza e sulla privacy dei dati. Innovazione: Accesso a un ecosistema gl

EC should prioratize not only open source software but, more specifically, free software, i.e. software with free (as in freedom) licenses, such as GPL, AGPL, and others. These licenses prevent enclosing free software in private hands and speculating on it, thus making the software less accessible. GPL software becomes undeniably a common good for all EU citizens to benefit from. Whilst there are a lot of free software out there, it exists mainly due to developers persistence and privilge to be able to work on itif something goes astray (for example financial stability), the software can be easily abandoned. There is an important opportunity for EC to create means of sustaining such software and developers working on itby creating a sovereign fund alike NLnet, for example.

I think that it's paramount for the EU to invest into a comprehensive framework of open-source alternatives to American Big Tech offerings to ensure the security of the Union, given the rampant authoritarianism and hostility coming from the United States. It is clear that we've been put at an enormous disadvantage within many sectors precisely because our infrastructures are so dependent on the whims of American corporate interests. Europe has already contributed beloved technologies like the Linux operating system to the world, so further developments in this area would be great, with actions like switching from Windows to Linux within governments and normalizing/popularizing open-source alternatives to popular services as the defaults for European citizens feeling more and more necessary given the current political situations. As a bonus, this would also be a great boon to citizen liberties and freedoms of speech. I feel like the most pressing issue right now is beginning to support and influence European alternatives for the usual software that's used in most European offices and organizations: this means breaking the (evident) monopoly that US corporations like Microsoft has in that space, with Windows, Office 360, and other similar tools, such as cloud storage providers. For most small businesses, American offerings are currently the simplest and cheapest possible way to get started: it's prime time to change that by developing affordable, intuitive, secure and useful tools that will help replace the US monopoly on these products within the EU, while simultaneously boosting the EU economy and helping technology businesses grow.

Well-maintained open source projects enable companies and developers to me more productive and efficient, and therefore benefit the economy. Additionally, they often avoid common security issues and increase portability to avoid vendor lock-in. The transparency increases trust, which is especially important in the public sector. To support and benefit from this, the EU should establish the principle "public money = public code". Contracts for software in the public sector should mandate to make the code available, preferably in the form of contributions to existing projects. Additionally, there should be continuous funding to secure the maintenance of important open source components. Applicable projects could be selected by usage and whether existing support is sufficient to ensure maintenance. A focus could be set on projects that support core European values like human rights (e.g. decentralized social networking solutions or secure and private messengers), but also on generic frameworks and general purpose libraries. Funding should be long-term and could be directed towards established open source foundations to ensure proper usage. While these measures contribute to security and resilience, it is as important that the EU refrains from legislation that would demand mass surveillance or backdoors, as this threatens security, resilience and civic rights.

1. & 2. Introduction & Context As a European SME (know.bi) specializing in data engineering, we submit this evidence based on our dual role as co-founders and core maintainers of the Apache Hop project and as developers of Putki, an enterprise-ready distribution designed for the European market. Our contribution highlights how the EU can bridge the industrial gap by supporting the SMEs that turn community innovation into production-grade, secure software. 3. Evidence of European Leadership: The Apache Hop Case Technological sovereignty is often misunderstood as needing a purely European foundation. We provide evidence that global governance frameworks (like the Apache Software Foundation) can host projects that are effectively "European-led": - Human Capital: 90% of the top 10 contributors and the project leadership of Apache Hop are based in the EU (Belgium, France, Italy, and Germany). - Strategic Autonomy: Because the core "brain power" is European, the projects roadmap is driven by European engineering values, emphasizing transparency and vendor-neutrality. - Recommendation: The EU should recognize projects as "European" based on the geographic location of the core maintainer base and user community, rather than the legal seat of the hosting foundation. - Market Adoption: Apache Hop is used by hundreds of organizations across Europe. Approximately 25% of all project website traffic originates from the EU, representing our most significant regional user base and proving the high demand for sovereign data tools within the Union. 4. The Role of Enterprise Distributions (Putki) A major barrier to EU digital sovereignty is the perceived lack of "mission-critical" stability in open source. Large EU organizations often choose non-EU proprietary vendors because they require professional support and lifecycle management. Our platform, Putki, demonstrates how European SMEs solve this: - Security & Resilience: We provide continuous security maintenance, including CVE backporting, which is a service community projects cannot sustain. - Regulatory Alignment: Our roadmap includes automated SBOM generation and PII masking to facilitate GDPR compliance, directly supporting the goals of the Cyber Resilience Act (CRA) and the EU Data Act. - Recommendation: EU policy should support the commercialization of these "Enterprise Distributions" to provide viable, supported alternatives to proprietary monopolies. 5. Key Policy Recommendations To strengthen the ecosystem, we propose four concrete actions for the European Open Source Sovereignty Fund: - Direct Maintenance Funding: Support European SMEs that drive the R&D and professionalization of critical open-source technologies. - CRA Compliance Support: Provide financial assistance for SMEs to handle the administrative and technical costs of security audits and SBOM management. - Procurement Reform: Modernize public tenders to prioritize "European Enterprise Distributions." Crucially, introduce simplified tendering procedures to prevent innovative SMEs from being disqualified by administrative burdens that only large multinationals can manage. - Testing Infrastructure: Support integration testing for European tools with global business systems (e.g., Odoo, SAP), ideally on-premise and on European cloud providers, to ensure our technology remains globally competitive. 6. Conclusion Digital sovereignty is achieved when EU organizations have a supported, secure, and locally-maintained alternative to global monopolies. We invite the Commission to review the attached Position Paper, which includes detailed Case Studies from Belgium, France, Germany and The Netherlands.

The EU has strong open-source software (OSS) communities and a long record of public support for open digital technologies through initiatives and programs such as Next Generation Internet, FIWARE and investments in open hardware ecosystems (e.g., RISC-V). The EUs goals for competitiveness, cybersecurity, and technological sovereignty align with OSS practices such as transparency, auditability, and shared development. A recurring issue is that value created by European OSS communities is often captured outside the EU, and market structures in public and private sectors can favor dominant incumbents through network effects and procurement patterns. Key barriers to adoption and long-term maintenance of high-quality and secure OSS include insufficient resourcing for maintenance and security hardening, limited capacity for coordinated vulnerability handling, and gaps in deployment and integration (documentation, usability, operations, and legacy system integration). Strategic dependencies can arise where core development, hosting, CI/CD, and package infrastructure are controlled outside the EU. Fragmentation across many projects and uneven sectoral maturity complicate convergence on widely reused components. Sustainable contributions are limited when organizations use OSS without incentives to contribute upstream. Common corporate barriers include missing internal KPIs for contribution, limited staff time allocated to upstream work, and legal or compliance uncertainty. This reduces the capacity of communities and maintainers to sustain critical components. In the public sector, OSS can support interoperability and reuse across administrations and cross-border services, and it can strengthen transparency and supply-chain visibility relevant to cybersecurity. In the private sector, OSS can reduce lock-in risks, enable switching and multi-vendor strategies, and improve innovation speed through shared building blocks. Assessing added value should include total cost of ownership (including operations and migration), exit options and lock-in risk, security and supply-chain risk management, and interoperability with open standards. A concrete measure to increase reuse and public value is Public Money Public Code: software developed with public funds should, by default, be released under an open-source license with public repositories and adequate documentation, with clearly defined exceptions (e.g., specific security constraints or data protection requirements). Procurement guidance and templates can standardize these requirements and support reuse across Member States. To increase sustainable corporate contributions, EU-level measures can include procurement evaluation criteria that recognize upstream contributions, security maintenance, participation in open governance, and long-term stewardship of dependencies. Complementary actions include targeted funding for maintenance and security work on widely used components and practical guidance that reduces legal and operational friction for companies contributing to OSS. To strengthen the contributor pipeline, EU-level programs can incentivize students and young professionals through paid fellowships or internships linked to priority areas (cybersecurity, cloud infrastructure, AI, edge/IoT). Priority areas for OSS support include cybersecurity tooling and secure-by-design as well as privacy-by-design components, cloud and digital infrastructure building blocks, AI frameworks and related tooling, edge/IoT platforms, core internet technologies, and open hardware ecosystems. Sectors where increased OSS uptake can improve competitiveness and cyber resilience include public administrations and digital government services, critical infrastructure domains with high security requirements, industrial stacks such as automotive and manufacturing, and EU cloud and data infrastructure.

Dans le contexte actuel de lenseignement supérieur européen, le passage vers des solutions Open Source répond à plusieurs enjeux stratégiques, économiques et réglementaires. Tout dabord, lOpen Source permet aux établissements de renforcer leur indépendance en évitant un assujettissement excessif à des fournisseurs, souvent extra-européens, tout en conservant la maîtrise des outils numériques et des choix stratégiques. Cette autonomie facilite également les évolutions futures et limite les risques liés à des changements de politique commerciale ou technologique imposés par des tiers. Par ailleurs, sur le plan financier, les solutions Open Source offrent une meilleure maîtrise des coûts. Labsence de licences propriétaires permet de réorienter les budgets vers des dépenses plus utiles, comme laccompagnement des utilisateurs, la maintenance ou lamélioration des compétences et des outils. Cette approche est particulièrement adaptée aux contraintes budgétaires des établissements publics et favorise une planification financière plus stable à long terme. En matière de protection des données, lOpen Source contribue aussi à une meilleure conformité au Règlement général sur la protection des données (RGPD). Les établissements disposent dune visibilité accrue sur la manière dont les données sont traitées et peuvent choisir des solutions hébergées en Europe, réduisant ainsi les risques juridiques et renforçant la confiance des usagers, quils soient étudiants, enseignants ou personnels administratifs. Concernant la sécurité numérique, les solutions Open Source facilitent le respect des exigences de la directive NIS2. Ces mêmes solutions permettent en outre une meilleure compréhension des systèmes utilisés et une plus grande réactivité en cas dincident, car les établissements ne dépendent pas exclusivement dun fournisseur pour corriger ou faire évoluer leurs outils. Cette transparence renforce la résilience globale des infrastructures numériques. LOpen Source favorise également la coopération entre établissements denseignement supérieur. Ceux-ci peuvent mutualiser leurs efforts, partager des développements et construire ensemble des solutions adaptées à leurs besoins communs. Cette dynamique collective renforce lécosystème académique européen. Enfin, le recours à lOpen Source est en cohérence avec les valeurs fondamentales de lenseignement supérieur, telles que le partage des connaissances, louverture, léthique et la responsabilité sociale. Il sinscrit pleinement dans les objectifs européens de souveraineté numérique et de développement durable.

In the current context of European higher education, the shift to Open Source solutions addresses several policy, economic and regulatory challenges. First of all, lopen Source enables institutions to strengthen their independence by avoiding excessive subjection to suppliers, often from outside Europe, while retaining control over digital tools and strategic choices. This autonomy also facilitates future developments and limits the risks associated with commercial or technological policy changes imposed by third parties. On the other hand, in financial terms, Open Source solutions offer better cost control. The lack of proprietary licences makes it possible to redirect budgets towards more useful expenditure, such as supporting users, maintaining or improving skills and tools. This approach is particularly adapted to the budgetary constraints of public institutions and promotes more stable long-term financial planning. As regards data protection, lopen Source also contributes to better compliance with the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR). Institutions have increased visibility on how data is processed and can choose solution
