feedback: It is more important than ever that social media and technology services created by EU users, communities and businesses are recognised and promoted by the EU. There needs to be a shift away from the "BigTech" US / Chinese companies such as Meta, X (fka. Twitter), Snapchat, WeChat in favour of EU based companies such as Mastodon, KDE, GoToSocial, ONLYOFFICE, Pixelfed, NextCloud that were previously funded under the #NextGenerationInternet programme.

Initiative Hin zu europäischen offenen digitalen Ökosystemen Beitrag der ayedo Cloud Solutions GmbH Die ayedo Cloud Solutions GmbH ist ein deutscher Cloud-Dienstleister mit Schwerpunkt auf souveräner, sicherer und skalierbarer Cloud-Native-Infrastruktur. Mit umfassender operativer Erfahrung im Aufbau und Betrieb von Kubernetes-Plattformen, Managed Cloud Services und Open-Source-Technologien unterstützt ayedo Organisationen dabei, resiliente digitale Infrastrukturen im Einklang mit europäischen Anforderungen an Transparenz, Interoperabilität und Sicherheit umzusetzen. Als europäisches KMU mit starker Verankerung im Open-Source-Ökosystem (www.ayedo.de) begrüßen wir diese EU-Initiative ausdrücklich. Europa steht unter wachsendem geopolitischem Druck, zunehmender Monopolisierung und struktureller Abhängigkeit von außereuropäischen Hyperscalern. Gleichzeitig geraten europäische Anforderungen an Souveränität, Datenschutz und demokratische Kontrolle durch extraterritoriale Regulierung und politische Entwicklungen, insbesondere in den USA, immer stärker unter Druck. 1. Stärken und Schwächen des EU-Open-Source-Sektors Die EU verfügt über eine der weltweit aktivsten Open-Source-Communities. Entwickler, KMU und Foundations leisten zentrale Beiträge zu digitalen Gemeingütern. Gleichzeitig wird der digitale Raum zunehmend von wenigen nicht-europäischen Konzernen dominiert. Dies schafft nicht nur wirtschaftliche Risiken, sondern auch demokratische Abhängigkeiten: kritische Infrastruktur, Cloud-Plattformen, KI-Grundlagen und staatliche Dienste werden durch externe Akteure geprägt. Open Source bietet Europa einen Weg zur digitalen Selbstbestimmung jedoch nur bei strategischer Unterstützung. 2. Barrieren für Adoption und Nachhaltigkeit Die zentralen Hemmnisse sind systemischer Natur: a) Vergabestrukturen bevorzugen proprietäre Hyperscaler-Ökosysteme, b)europäische KMU stehen im strukturellen Nachteil, c)Open Source wird oft als kostenlose Ressource behandelt, d) Europa fehlt eine souveräne Betriebsinfrastruktur (Repositories, CI/CD, Artifact-Distribution). Ohne diese Grundlagen droht digitale Abhängigkeit selbst innerhalb offener Ökosysteme fortzubestehen. 3. Mehrwert von Open Source Open Source ist ein demokratisches Infrastrukturprinzip und ermöglicht: - Transparenz und Überprüfbarkeit, - Resilienz gegenüber monopolistischer Kontrolle, - Reduktion von Vendor Lock-in, - öffentliche Rechenschaftspflicht, - langfristige strategische Autonomie. Gerade in Verwaltung, Gesundheitswesen und kritischer Infrastruktur ist Abhängigkeit von intransparenten proprietären Stacks ein ernstes Risiko. 4. Konkrete EU-Maßnahmen Eine glaubwürdige Strategie sollte umfassen: 1) Hyperscaler-Lock-in reduzieren als gesellschaftliches Risiko. 2) Europäische Betriebsinfrastruktur für Repositories, CI/CD und Governance. 3) Langfristige Finanzierung kritischer OSS-Komponenten. 4) Vergabereform, die Offenheit und EU-basierte Ökosysteme fördert. 5) Öffentlich-private Partnerschaften im Gemeinwohlinteresse. 5. Priorisierte Technologiefelder Priorität sollten haben: - souveräne Cloud-Native Infrastruktur (Kubernetes, Plattformen), - Cybersicherheit und Supply-Chain-Integrity, - offene KI-Frameworks, - Edge Computing, - digitale Commons für den europäischen öffentlichen Sektor. Schlussbemerkung Technologische Souveränität ist untrennbar mit demokratischer Souveränität verbunden.Wenn Europa strukturell abhängig bleibt verliert es nicht nur Wettbewerbsfähigkeit, sondern auch die Fähigkeit, seine digitale Gesellschaft selbst zu gestalten. Open Source ist das stärkste Instrument Europas, um digitale Infrastruktur auf Transparenz, Resilienz, öffentlicher Verantwortung und gemeinsamer Innovation aufzubauen. Wir bei ayedo Cloud Solutions GmbH stehen voll und ganz hinter dieser wichtigen und richtigen Initiative und sind gerne bereit, operative Ex

feedback:
HOP - Stop Planned Obsolescence is a French environment protection association. Since 2015, it advocates for long-lasting products. It is directly linked to the construction of circular economy tools such as the repairability and durability indexes as well as the French repair bonus. It represents a community of more than 60.000 people. HOP is also part of the Right to Repair campaign's steering group. HOP started in 2025 the "No Windows Tax" campaign which mobilized 22 organizations to denounce the end of free Windows 10 updates and raise awareness about software obsolescence. The end of Windows 10 free security updates Microsoft announced that the end of free security updates for Windows 10 will take place on October 14, 2025. This decision pushed users to upgrade to Windows 11. Due to the multinationals hardware requirements, 400 million computers worldwide were incompatible with Windows 11 as of summer 2025, some being only five years old. The estimated consequences were particularly alarming: Economic impacts: over 10.4 billion in additional costs for users to pay for extended updates over one year, not including the costs of replacing computers. Environmental impacts: the emission of over 70 million tons of CO², the extraction of nearly 32,000 Eiffel Towers worth of raw materials, and the production of at least 800,000 tons of electronic waste. This case also highlighted our collective dependence on non-European digital multinationals. In response to these challenges, the coalitions petition won strong public support, gathering 50,000 signatures in just one month. The campaign demonstrated a convergence of interests among public, private, and civil society actors in seriously considering the transition to free and open-source software. The citizen mobilization secured a concession from Microsoft: eased access to update extensions until October 2026 in Europe. However, this is an underwhelming victorythis extension is only a reprieve, and in one year, users will face the same problem again. Furthermore, Microsoft requires users to log in with an account and does not allow automatic activation. The company also communicated for nearly nine months about the end of updates, including messages encouraging the replacement of incompatible computers, and many people had already done so. Software obsolescence: a recurring problem to restrain Software obsolescence refers to all software techniques that push for the premature disposal of equipment. In the case of Windows 10, this encouragement to replace devices is due to the end of security updates, the lack of user information about alternatives to computer replacement, and the significant hardware requirements for upgrading to Windows 11. Many other forms of software obsolescence exist, such as mandatory updates that can cause malfunctions or overburden device memory, or part-pairing that digitally ties a part to the device (preventing its replacement or refurbishment), among others. Switching to free and open-source software: a viable alternative to promote Transitioning to free and open-source software like Linux allows users to: Free themselves from the unilateral decisions of Microsoft and other non-European software publishers, Significantly extend the lifespan of their devices, Do so securely and without license purchase costs. However, installation requires technical skills that are not yet widely accessible, and may involve adapting certain uses. This challenge has already been identified in the recommendations of French public authorities. GNU/Linux already equips the vast majority of the Gendarmerie nationale's devices. As already highlighted in a 2012 circular from the French Prime Minister, free and open-source software is driven by actual needs, minimizing unnecessary changes. It is high time these recommendations were put into practice. These points were echoed in a collective opinion c

feedback: 1. Wir setzen den Fokus auf Technologien, die für die weitere Digitalisierung der europäischen Wirtschaft elementar sind. 2. Wir etablieren Standards die sich nicht nur offen nennen sondern vollständig frei von Rechten und Ansprüchen dritter sind. 3. Wir bündeln unsere Ressourcen nur auf OSS die von unabhängigen Stiftungen getragen werden. 4. Wir erstellen auf der Basis von 2. und 3. Softwarekataloge/Softwarestacks, die für den Einsatz in steuerfinanzierten Projekten vorgeschrieben sind. 5. Wir validieren diese Softwarestacks periodisch und stellen einen langen Lebenszyklus sicher. 6. Wir nehmen wissentlich in Kauf, dass es am Markt immer auch bessere Lösungen geben wird.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: 1. We focus on technologies that are essential for the further digitalisation of the European economy. 2. We are establishing standards that are not just open-minded, but completely free from third-party rights and claims. 3. We pool our resources only on OSSs that are supported by independent foundations. 4. We produce on the basis of 2nd and 3 rd Software catalogues/stacks required for use in tax-funded projects. 5. We validate these software stacks periodically and ensure a long life cycle. 6. We knowingly accept that there will always be better solutions on the market.

feedback: We can become a lot less dependant on very short term. Most people are so used to us products that they think there are no alternatives. However open source operating systems like linux are very performant (often faster), safer and are these days very easy to use for an average windows user (e.g. linux mint). And this is the case for most of the american software (teams, office, sharepoint), they all have very performant and often better open source alternatives. This combined with a push for more European cloud centers in europe will be a good start in making europe less dependant regarding IT. This open source can be combined with a push to promote digital/tech/open source in schools to promote innovation in Europe. Also it is urgently required that europe promotes European social media as mastodon. For example, if you want to follow European policians you often have to use X which is used as political tool by promoting certain posts.

Zu uns: Wir sind Hersteller der Open-Source Wiki-Software BlueSpice. Wir bauen seit 2007 Kollaborationslösungen und Wissensdatenbanken (zunehmen auch KI-gestützt) für alle Branchen basierend auf der Software MediaWiki (=Wikipedia-Software). Aktuell sind wir vor allem als Alternative zum proprietären Marktführer Atlassian (Confluence) gefordert und haben eine stark steigende Nachfrage aus dem privaten aber auch aus dem öffentlichen Sektor. Das Unternehmen erwartet deshalb ein starkes Wachstum in den kommenden drei Jahren. 1. Die EU und nicht zuletzt Deutschland hat eine starke Open Source-Szene, die den meisten Verantwortlichen in der Politik unbekannt ist. Sie leidet unter mangelnder Finanzierungund unter dem Lobbyismus proprietärer Anbieter. Große Player wie SAP sind auch nicht bereit, ihr proprietäres Geschäftsmodell umzustellen. Eine Schwäche ist und bleibt der Ersatz der Microsoft Office-Welt. Stärken sind aber sowohl im Bereich des Cloud-Computings oder in Enterprise-Software zu sehen. Tatsache ist jedoch, dass die EU in kurzer Zeit die bestehenden Open Source Ansätze nutzen und hochfahren kann, um am Ende zu 90% bis 100% unabhängig von Anbietern außerhalb der EU zu sein. Um hochwertige und sichere Open-Source-Lösungen zu unterstützen, muss die EU mehr tun, als nur Sichtbarkeit herstellen. Im Wesentlichen müssen die EU-Staaten und die EU als gestaltende Akteure auftreten, Software Open Source und European first planen und beauftragen. Konsortien (ähnlich Airbus) können temporär helfen, aber nur mit Unternehmen, die mit Open Source vertraut sind. Hier sind viele kleine und mittlere Unternehmen gegenüber großen Konzernen zu bevorzugen. Die EU muss gleichzeitig sicherstellen, dass weiterhin ein Wettbewerb möglich ist. Der Auftraggeber sollte in jedem Segment mindestens zwischen drei Anbietern wählen können. Im Prinzip sind die Ansätze des Zentrums für Digitale Souveränität richtig: Der Aufbau von freien Repositories (Public Money, public Code) und Applikationen. 2. In Zeiten von KI gewinnt jedoch das Merkmal der Nachvollziehbarkeit an Bedeutung. Wie eine Software funktioniert, muss überprüfbar und veränderbar sein. Der zweite Mehrwert ist die Kostenkontrolle durch die Reduktion des Vendor Lock-ins. In Zeiten großer Ausgaben zur Bewältigung der Klimakathastrophe und der sozio-ökonomischen Herausforderung, können wir uns proprietäre Lösungen und Abhängigkeiten nicht mehr leisten. 3. Eine wichtige Unterstützung ist nicht nur die Formulierung von Cybersicherheitsstandards, sondern auch die konkrete Hilfe bei der Umsetzung: Best practices, Empfehlungen zur Umsetzung. Hier erfindet jedes Unternehmen das Rad neu und hat unnötige Kosten bei Beratungsunternehmen, die in den meisten Fällen auch keine Expertise haben. 4. Wir sind hier Partei und äußern uns dazu nicht weiter. Eine Fokussierung auf KI halten wir jedoch für einen Fehler. Die Kommunen in Europa brauchen nicht einfach irgendwas mit KI, sondern generell Infrastruktur und moderne Tools. Zumindest in Deutschland ;-) 5. Open Source fördert die Wettbewerbsfähigkeit und Cyberresilienz in allen Sektoren. Generell haben 10% der Unternehmen 90% des Marktes. Die Entscheidung wo man aufräumen möchte, ist eine politische.
feedbackTextUserLanguage:
As far as we are concerned: We are the manufacturer of the Open Source Wiki software BlueSpice. Since 2007, we have been building collaborative solutions and knowledge databases (including AI-based ones) for all sectors, based on the MediaWiki software (=Wikipedia software). feedback: The EU needs a trusted and easy to join ecosystem where OSS is the standard, where service providers compete having healthy business models to improve the software and help newcomers to get started. EU rules and incentives need to make sure the community is moving forward as a whole, while allowing forks that enable niche developments. In case of discontinued developments, new EU incentives need to make sure the "victims" get an affordable migration path into a better OSS solution. In case of OS owned by big tech, such as Java, owned by Oracle (not sure how good or bad that is), we might need more influence. Feedback per Question: Barriers (Question 1) and concrete measures (Question 3): 1. the absence of a marketing budget: EU could make existing OSS easier to discover, 2. the bits-and-pieces problem: EU could fund initiatives that save newcomers time getting to a total solution, 3. the who-is-servicing-what problem: EU could maintain a register for contacting available qualified developers if we need help. Added Value of OSS (Question 2): 1. digital sovereignty, 2. transparency, 3. cost. Needless to explain that we are first being made dependent on certain low cost closed-source solutions, only waiting for payback time or worse: unfreedom. Priorities (Question 4): work bottom-up, starting at security, identity providers, data storage, open digital formats, interoperability demands, fediverse demands. The sectors (Question 5) in my professional life use Cloud, database, Office, PDF, CAD and BIM solutions, e.g. Local Govt, Construction, Architecture and Engineering companies. They are all too dependent on a handful of closed software developers, like Amazon, Oracle, Microsoft, Adobe and Autodesk.

One of the reasons that large platforms dominate the internet today is that the internet's architecture demands that all services operate using a client-server model. This is because many internet service providers still use only the internet protocol version 4 and there are not enough IPv4 addresses to assign one to every device connected to the internet. ISPs work around this using a technology called Network Address Translation. This allows reuse of IP addresses on customer sites so that the number of IP addresses does not limit the number of devices connected to the internet, but it also prevents most customer devices from receiving incoming connections. For existing services using the client-server model, this is not a problem. Servers at Google or Meta or OpenAI have "real" public IPv4 addresses and can be contacted directly. This is quite convenient for Google and Meta and OpenAI because the only model possible is the client-server model, and they own the servers. If it was possible to connect to customer devices directly, there would be no need for those servers. Services such as social media could operate in a peer-to-peer fashion with no control by large corporations. This would prevent the dominance of such corporate gate-keepers, whether they are within EU sovereignty or not. People's data would live on their own devices and communicate with others directly, not mediated by a gate-keeper. But this model is technically not feasible currently because of the addressing limitations. The solution to this problem has been technologically available for decades: version 6 of the Internet Protocol (IPv6) massively expands the available address space, allowing the assignment of a unique address to every device ever connected to the internet. Universal adoption of this protocol would allow development of services which cut out the corporate gate-keepers and allowed citizens to interact directly without server mediation. Corporate interests have consistently dragged their feet in deploying IPv6 and the reason is clear: it is a direct threat to their own interests. It is time for governments everywhere, including the EU, to madate that ISPs provide IPv6 service and that existing services provide IPv6 service.

1. Main barriers - First we should say that it is FREE SOFTWARE and open; put the emphasis on the freedom of the user, which includes better maintaining and security. - Forcing hardware/software to provide a way to be used with free software. Too many cheap or expensive machines cannot be utilised without a particular system (medical utilities, fingerprint readers, card readers). - Lockin effect. - Closed by default. Hardware should be made available by default with free software (you buy a laptop, you don't have Windows by default). 2. Added value - Repairability, longterm management - Fairness and transparency: if the software is FOSS, then everyone (with a computer) can access and participate. - Independence - Control 3. Concrete measures - EU should enforce that every device provides an Free and Open Source solution (including your washing machine and toothbrush with WiFi). - FOSS should be possible by default, not just a possible option. - Universities and Public Services should be forbidden to use closed software and should realise Free Science / Free Services Europe - Support defence of rightsgivers: respect Open Licenses and, if necessary, take legal action against violations. - Do not use AWS to controle longin are you do on "https://ec.europa.eu" 4. Areas to prioritise - Smart Home and personal devices: this is where critical hardware can be easily compromised by bad actors / reused in attacks. - Communication and Social Networks: sovereignty.

As a professional registered engineer -with the commitment to advance and protect society- it is needed to testify the following: - After having been using Open Source Software for 30+ years, in economic sectors that matter to societal needs, it is completely clear that OSS is a solid step forward in any dimension and especially so when it comes to transparency and digital sovereignty. - Furthermore, it is needed to testify that OSS alone is not the endgame: standards that enforce a certain level of compliance, such as GDPR/CRA/DSA & DORA-like standards, will become increasingly important in order to enforce a regulatory regime which promotes accountability - especially when they are harmonized. - Open standards need to exist and evolve in order to create the best possible incentives in a competitive market This is a plea to treat software systems -when used for societally meaningful purposes- as engineering products, exactly as anything else that falls under engineering domains in order to account for: * Systemic risks * Public safety and well-being * Irreversibility & long time horizons * Information asymmetry in adequate assessment * Ethical duties beyond employment horizons * Trust in shared infrastructure It is imperative to make the best of Open Systems and in the right way.
Open access Internet is really important and what the Internet was intended for. I have particularly enjoyed joining the Mastodon community and hope to see it continue to grow and thrive.

Scrivo in quanto cittadino europeo informato (mi occupo di informatica da più di 30 anni). Il Codice Libero / Open Source, specialmente il codice sotto licenza AGPL, la migliore e più tutelante licenza per lo scopo, dovrebbero essere uno standard IMPOSTO per e alla Pubblica Amministrazione locale e globale Europea. Questo per molti motivi: perché l'uso esclusivo di codice libero è l'unico modo per garantire una indipendenza tecnologica libera da ricatti dalle aziende estere, non solo statunitensi perché la trasparenza nei processi di gestione dei dati dei cittadini europei è critica per la sicurezza europea e questa può essere garantita solo dal codice libero perché i soldi della pubblica amministrazione dovrebbero essere investiti con l'obiettivo di produrre anche una ricaduta locale e questo non lo si può fare spendendo i soldi dei cittadini europei per finanziare aziende che producono servizi opachi perché il codice libero è l'unico che garantisce l'interoperabilità necessaria a far funzionare la macchina pubblica perché il codice libero è l'unico che permette il livello di adattabilità e configurabilità necessario per un continuo miglioramento dei servizi, evoluzione ed adattamento tra diversi enti per l'interscambio efficace, in tempo reale e sicuro, dei dati dei cittadini Tutto questo considerato, cosa si può fare? Per ottenere ciò è necessario che la Comunità Europea non solo adotti al più presto il codice libero, ma che si faccia promotrice di questa innovazione. Purtroppo, visto il livello di penetrazione di tecnologie estere rapaci dei dati e dei soldi dei cittadini europei, oramai non è più sufficiente la mera promozione delle cosiddette "buone pratiche" di adozione del software libero nelle PA nazionali, è oramai necessario adottare misure più drastiche. Il mio personale convincimento è che sia indispensabile adottare una strategia a tappe forzate, imponendo e non solo promuovendo alle varie amministrazioni l'uso di tecnologie aperte e "made in EU". Sarà quindi necessario stabilire degli obiettivi e relative sanzioni per le PA che non si adeguano per tempo, investendo anche in incentivi ma i cui fondi potranno anche essere ricavati in parte dalle stesse sanzioni, ovvero: che le PA "virtuose" guadagnino e quelle "meno virtuose" paghino le conseguenze della loro inazione o cattiva azione in difesa degli interessi e diritti di cittadini europei.

feedback: Les sugiero que analicen la propuesta de Cory Doctorow https://pluralistic.net/2026/01/01/39c3/#the-new-coalition (en inglés). Resumiendo, la Unión Europea debería eliminar las leyes que prohíben que los compradores de un producto o los usuarios de un servicio lo usen a su conveniencia saltándose las restricciones fijadas por el fabricante. Estas leyes, incluidas por el gobierno de Estados Unidos en los tratados de comercio, favorecen mucho más a las empresas estadounidenses que a las europeas. Si las empresas y desarrolladores europeos no tuviesen que temer las leyes que permiten las restricciones del fabricante, podrían saltarse estas protecciones y aumentar la competencia en el mercado y la interoperatividad. También podrían ayudar a que los europeos se liberasen de la dependencia de empresas de fuera de la Unión. Anteriormente, legalizar el saltarse las protecciones acarrearía castigos a los exportadores europeos por parte del gobierno estadounidense, pero, en estos momentos, ese gobierno ya está aplicando aranceles contra Europa y amenaza con incrementarlos. Piensen si Europa se beneficiaría de software libre que sustituyese o interoperase con productos o servicios que nos mantienen en una dependencia peligrosa.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: I suggest that you analyse the proposal of Cory Doctorow https://pluralistic.net/2026/01/01/39c3/#the-new-coalition. To sum up, the European Union should remove laws that prohibit buyers of a product or users of a service from using it at their convenience while circumventing restrictions set by the manufacturer. These laws, included by the US government in trade treaties, favour US companies much more than European ones. If European companies and developers were not to fear laws that allow manufacturer restrictions, these protections could be lifted and market competition and interoperability increased. They could also help Europeans to free themselves from dependence on non-EU companies. Previously, legalising the abandonment of protections would result in punishments for European exporters by the US government, but the US government is already applying tariffs against Europe and is threatening to increase them. Think about whether Europe would benefit from free software that would replace or interoperate with products or services that keep us in a dangerous dependency.

feedback: Ich unterstütze die Initiative und würde es besonders begrüßen, wenn sich die Kommission stärker für Open-Source-Lösungen im Bereich mobiler Betriebssysteme und Apps einsetzen würde.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: I support the initiative and would particularly welcome a stronger commitment from the Commission to open source solutions in the area of mobile operating systems and apps.

feedback: From my day job in systems administration I know the importance of being able to look at the source code of a program to understand errors, and the empowering feeling to have the possibility to contribute fixes. To reach the goal of sovereignty in IT, we need Open Source software. Public money - public code should become the standard, not the exception. Fostering and supporting Open Source maintainers and communities will benefit the EU in the long run, because their projects last longer and do not have vendor lock-in effects like commercial solutions.

Open source is our strongest tool against planned obsolescence. I am a happy long time user of open source software for more than a decade now. Meanwhile my university just bought a completely new proprietary system to replace its old one and it doesn't work, but the developers can bill them for millions, because it's a new development. Public money should be spent on public code!

I would like to briefly outline my perspective. I work within the software development team of a Tier 1 supplier that serves major European brands and maintains a subsidiary in China, which primarily collaborates with Chinese OEMs. Among the numerous differences in approach, I am particularly struck by the excessive, and often unnecessary, level of customization demanded by European manufacturers. For instance, a product developed here in Italy for a Chinese OEM was deployed across multiple vehicle lines and subsequently resold, almost as an 'off-the-shelf' solution, to other manufacturers. These clients prioritized a proven, tested, and functional product, requesting only minimal configurability rather than a bespoke mechanical, hardware, and software redesign. In Europe, the trend is quite the opposite: even within the same organization, requirements are frequently overhauled for different models, forcing development to restart almost from inception and causing costs to escalate uncontrollably. Furthermore, this trend is exacerbated by a deep-seated cultural and structural resistance. In many European legacy organizations, proprietary specifications are still incorrectly perceived as a primary source of competitive advantage, leading to a 'not-invented-here' syndrome that stifles efficiency. In my view, the Open Source philosophy represents a powerful counter-trend to this mindset. By leveraging the collective expertise and know-how of a global community, it elevates the concept of reuse to a strategic level, offering a more sustainable and collaborative path forward for the industry

Accelerating the deployment and facilitation of access to such digital solutions among institutions and citizens seems to be a very good direction.

There is no reason to stay with proprietary software like Microsoft Windows or Office. This is true for all closed-source solutions: - No Transparency: The code is hidden. We cannot check for backdoors. Only Open Source allows real security audits. This is the 1st MAIN argument. - Money Stays in Europe: Instead of sending billions to US companies, Europe should spend this money here for development and support of open systems. This is the 2nd MAIN argument. - Open is not "Free": We should pay for the work, but the result must be a public asset. The code must be visible and usable for everyone in the future. - No Vendor Lock-in: Proprietary formats trap users. We need open standards so we can switch software without losing our data (such as .odt vs. .docx). - High Quality: Open Source is not "hobby software." It is professional, high-quality, and follows real standards for better interoperability. - No one defines which hardware to use as Microsoft is currently showing it with Windows 11. I just can hope that Europe is waking up finally, and starts to forget the "we are used to use Microsoft", and uses instead our own software solutions. Often I hear that there is no way without Microsoft - but this is indeed completely wrong.

Die EU muß sich unbedingt von amerikanischen Großkonzernen abkoppeln und eine unabhängige eigene Umgebung favorisieren. Durch eine Abhängigkeit von amerikanischen Umgebungen ist weder ein Datenschutz gewährleistet, noch ist eine durchgehende Verfügbarkeit sichergestellt, sollte es zu Unstimmigkeiten kommen. Genauso darf es nicht toleriert werden, dass Software von Banken für online Banking, Ausweisapps (auch der EU!) oder Versicherungen von z.B. Google Play Zertifizierungen abhängen. Sollte dies generell zurückgezogen werden, wären alle Bürger der EU handlungsunfähig. Dies käme einem globalen Blackout gleich! Somit muß digitale Souveranität das oberste Ziel aller Regularieren für EU Software sein!
feedbackTextUserLanguage: It is essential for the EU to disengage from American giants and to favour an independent environment of its own. Reliance on American environments does not ensure data protection, nor does it ensure end-to-end availability in case of inconsistencies. Similarly, it must not be tolerated that bank software for online banking, card apps (including from the EU!) or insurance depends on certifications from, for example, Google Play. If this were to be withdrawn in general, all EU citizens would be unable to act. This would be a global blackout! Digital sovereignty must therefore be the ultimate goal of all EU software regulation!

feedback: Strengths: - strong ties with public institutions + a value framework emphasizing transparency, equity, and democratic governance - legal harmonization to build & connect actors across the EU (e.g. non-profit law) - EU open source (OS) community has a globally competitive edge; even complex hardware (magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), ultrasound) has reached clinical performance and inform certified devices Weaknesses: - maintenance remains, particularly for hardware: physical constraints, higher compliance costs, longer development cycles - fragmented ecosystem + slow business uptake - large reliance on volunteers and people willing/able to allocate their work resources in the field (e.g. researchers) Barriers: - funding gap between proof-of-concept prototype and proven market solution, due to misalignments with public grants and investor expectations biased toward proprietary IP - lacking incentives for long-term community stewardship - lack of awareness about open source hardware (OSH) in procurement and development, especially in the public sector - Current institutions for technology standardization (e.g. CEN/CENELEC) fail to align with open source communities; on the other hand: absence of hardware-focussed OS umbrella organizations Added value: In highly monopolized markets (e.g. MRI), OS reference designs can push innovation toward affordable systems and diversified, fully transparent supplychains. Public sector benefits: lower lifecycle costs and risk, increased resilience, and stronger stakeholder representation in tech development. Private sector benefits: SMEs gain access to complex technologies, enabling diverse markets for manufacturing, add-ons, maintenance, certification, and application development, including data-driven business models built on standardized open technologies. OS reference designs provide fully characterized systems essential for replicable research, effective risk management, and downstream uses (e.g. AI training). Coupled with certification documentation, they can significantly reduce bureaucratic overhead and time-to-market for adopters within current regulaory frameworks particularly relevant under the MDR (increased compliance burden) EU measures: - Funding for organizations maintaining critical OSH; clear governance requirements (e.g. representative decision-making, strong community ties); integration of stakeholder feedback; management of shared assets (e.g. trademarks, prototyping facilities, legal support and compliance consultancy) under FRAND conditions within the EU - Establish funding schemes for selected OSH ecosystems (the Next Generation Internet (NGI) programme as an example). - Close the gap between de jure standardization and OS communities, enabling two-way contributions. - Issue clear guidelines for university transfer offices on when and how to publish results, hardware designs and code open source. - Adapt start-up and scale-up funding schemes to open IP business models. Priorities: - High societal impact technologies critical to welfare, security, and sovereignty, e.g. MedTech; areas that can benefit from transparency and standardization. - Public sector technology with substantial cost-saving potential across EU Member States and where OS communities are already active, e.g. ticket-vending machines and fire-pond monitoring hardware. - In both domains, Europe can gain a frontrow position by opening innovation pathways to specialized SMEs, community-rooted civic actors, and local public authorities. Supported by Europe's strong industrial and research infrastructure, this ecosystem would be globally unique (for hardware). Europe's diversity thus becomes a competitive advantage; genuine innovation emerges from the collaborative interplay of diverse perspectives rather than from "monocultural" hyperscalers.

feedback: Ich nutze täglich Mastodon. Vorher war ich jahrelang bei Twitter, habe aber Twitter verlassen, als Herr Musk Twitter übernommen hat. Ich wusste von Herrn Musks rechtsextremer Einstellung und so etwas unterstütze ich nicht. Ich bin froh, mit Mastodon eine gleichwertige Alternative gefunden zu haben.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: I use mastodone every day Before that, I was on Twitter for years, but left Twitter when Mr Musk took over Twitter. I knew of Mr Musk’s far-right attitude and I do not support this. I am glad to have found an equivalent alternative to Mastodon.

feedback: From the perspective of the Digital Humanities community, and concerning both research and teaching in this innovative and future-oriented field, I would like to highlight the critical role of ensuring digital sovereignty, best practices of Open Science, and multilingual data accessibility. Open-source tools enable transparent, reproducible scholarship and public engagement with cultural heritage, but their sustainability is threatened by precarious funding and fragmented infrastructure. To address this, the EU should invest in EU-based hosting for research data and code, support multilingual NLP tools such as LLMs and training data for European languages, incentivize open-source contributions in academia, and better support Diamon Open Access publishing, both on an infrastructure level and on the level of recognition and prestige. For teaching and research, open source fosters innovation and avoids vendor lock-in, but adoption is hampered by a lack of institutional recognition and interoperability. I'd recommend prioritizing open standards for cultural and research data, integrating open-source training into university curricula, and creating sustainable funding models for maintenance. Focusing on sectors like cultural heritage and education will strengthen the EUs technological but also cultural autonomy.

feedback: Onder andere door mijn studies informatica aan de universiteit ben ik overtuigd geraakt door het nut en belang van opensource software. Door de gemeenschappelijke belangen, leidt het vaker tot meer kwaliteitsvolle software (door test en audit) dan in een gesloten systeem. Als een project relevant is en op een transparante democratische manier gemanaged wordt, kan ook een grotere ontwikkel snelheid bereikt worden. Dit zowel op vlak van functionaliteit als onderhoud (inclusief beveiliging). Mijn advies zou zijn dat elke project binnen de overheid per definitie als opensource beschikbaar zou moeten zijn. Ook zou het gebruik reeds bestaande opensource oplossingen een gun factor moeten zijn. Waar enkele jaren geleden het gebruik van Linux als desktop omgeving nog een grote uitdaging was, zie ik hier vandaag meer kansen door de vele applicaties welke webbased zijn. Ook mag de focus niet eenzijdig liggen op nieuwe ontwikkelingen of gebruik, maar moet er ook aandacht besteed worden aan het leveren van bijdrages aan bestaande opensource projecten. Concrete en zichtbare bijdrages geven ook een signaal van appreciatie aan de mensen die reeds een bijdrage leverde. Ikzelf ben trots op software van Europese bodem en vind dat vanuit overheidswegen deze trots ook uitgedragen mag worden. Tot slot moet er niet enkel gekeken worden naar bedrijven die vandaag actief zijn op het vlak van opensource, maar ook naar spontane en organische groeperingen die vaak vrijwillig en belangenloos grote werkzaamheden verichten. Te denken valt dan aan NGO's, maker-communities, computer clubs, volunteer based conferences and camps, meet-ups, technologie georienteerde hobby clubs, ... Dit alles maakt ons meer onafhankelijk en draagt bij tot de ontwikkeling van kennis op diverse domeinen. Dit intelectueel kapitaal is meer waard, dan enkel de opgeleverde code.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: My studies in informatics at university, among other things, have convinced me of the usefulness and importance of open source software. Due to common interests, it results more often in higher quality software (through testing and audit) than in a closed system. If a project is relevant and managed in a transparent democratic way, greater speed of development can also be achieved. This includes functionality as well as maintenance (including security). My advice would be that every project within the public administration should by definition be available as an open source. The use of already existing open source solutions should also be a factor. While the use of Linux as a desktop environment was still a major challenge a few years ago, I see here today more opportunities due to the many applications that are web-based. There should also be no one-sided focus on new developments or uses, but attention should also be paid to contributing to existing open-source projects. Concrete and visible contributions also send a signal of appreciation to those who already contributed. I am proud of European soil software and believe that it can also be promoted by public authorities. Finally, attention should be paid not only to companies active today in the field of open source, but also to spontaneous and organic groups that often carry out major activities voluntarily and without interest. This could include NGOs, maker-communities, computer clubs, Volunteer based conferences and camps, meet-ups, technology-oriented hobby clubs, etc. All this makes us more independent and contributes to the development of knowledge in various fields. This intelligible capital is worth more than just the code provided.

feedback: Open Source and decentralized open source social networks have have been growing over the last years into a vivid civil ecosystem. While it is obvious to everyone that takes a look, that our technological world of today cannot exist without open source it might still not be as obvious for open social networks. Both suffer in the public eye due to the lack of advertisement - while advertisement shapes our public view. The fediverse is deeply rooted in European values, where privacy and communication counts more than optimization of reach for the ones willing to pay. Mastodon, Lemmy, Loops, Pixelfed, Peertube, Writefreely, Flohmarkt - to name a few are successful - enormously so compared to the investment into them in money and man hours. Same is true for OpenDesk, CryptPad, Libreoffice, Nextcloud - Blender, Godot, Krita, Gimp, Firefox, Linux. They are the foundation of our technological present and of Europe's digital sovereign future - if there there is any. Next to funding we need a secure economical basis for developing common good. What happened to Mastodon gGmbh in Germany must be a warning sign for how our economical infrastructure is vulnerable.
Love this! Keep the funding coming! Big hugs!

feedback: Ich unterstütze nachdrücklich die European Open Digital Ecosystem Strategy, insbesondere die Nutzung von quelloffener Software für Angebote der öffentlichen Verwaltung. Diese sollten weiter und verstärkt ausgebaut werden. Außerdem plädiere ich für eine umfangreiche Informationskampagne über die Notwendigkeit digitaler Souveränität - in allen Altersgruppen, aber vor allem bei Kindern und Jugendlichen. Dies halte ich für zielführender als pauschale Verbote bzw. Zugangsbeschränkungen.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: I strongly support the European Open Digital Ecosystem Strategy, in particular the use of open source software for public administration offers. These should be further developed and strengthened. I also call for an extensive information campaign on the need for digital sovereignty, in all age groups, but especially among children and young people. This seems to me to be more effective than blanket prohibitions or restrictions on access.

feedback: I would like to see that all EU Commission would stop using X, Bluesky, Facebook etc and consider wider use of Mastodon as an alternative avenue for communication with all of us. It's not only decentralised and open source, its underlying ActivityPub protocol allows sharing of information outside of walled gardens of that X, Facebook, Bluesky etc represent.

We need a strong and credible affirmation of free and open source software to be able to really establish and maintain digital sovereignty. Part of this is financial support for the fediverse as a really decentralized non-commercial universe of social-media plattforms. It's important to focus on the fediverse and e.g. not Bluesky, which is not really decentralized and has no protection from becoming enshittified like Facebook, or worse, Twitter/X. Also when it comes to operating systems we need more financial support for Linux systems that give us all the option to leave Microsoft Windows or iOS. It goes on to office and cloud programms, free smartphone OSs and so on. Only this way, we can ensure that technology really serves the people and not the other way around. Europe needs to do better here!

Ich begrüße die Initiative der Europäischen Kommission ausdrücklich. Aus meiner langjährigen Praxis im professionellen IT-Betrieb weiß ich, dass Open Source ein zentraler Baustein für digitale Souveränität, Resilienz und wirtschaftliche Planbarkeit ist. Das gilt insbesondere für die Infrastruktur-Ebene, die ich seit Jahren unter anderem mit Proxmox Virtual Environment, Proxmox Backup Server und Proxmox Datacenter Manager produktiv betreibe. 1) Stärken/Schwächen und Haupthindernisse Stärken: Europa verfügt über eine große Entwickler- und Unternehmenslandschaft. In meinem Alltag zeigt sich, dass europäische Open-Source-Anbieter auch im Enterprise-Betrieb erfolgreich eingesetzt werden können. Proxmox ist für mich ein gutes Beispiel dafür, weil sich Proxmox Virtual Environment als stabile Basis für Virtualisierung und Clusterbetrieb bewährt hat und Proxmox Backup Server die Wiederherstellbarkeit absolut zuverlässig unterstützt. Hindernisse (Einführung/Betrieb): Marktdominanz großer Software-Anbieter, Lock-in- und Netzwerkeffekte erschweren Alternativen. Das merke ich besonders dann, wenn Beschaffungs- oder Bewertungslogiken stark auf proprietäre Ökosysteme zugeschnitten sind. In der Praxis wäre es hilfreicher, wenn Kriterien wie Lifecycle, Interoperabilität, Update- und Security-Prozesse sowie Betriebsmodelle im Vordergrund stünden. Genau entsprechend dieser Kriterien habe ich Proxmox-Lösungen bewertet und eingeführt. Hindernisse (Beiträge): Nachhaltige Beiträge scheitern oft an Compliance-Prozessen, fehlenden Strukturen und zu wenig Finanzierung für Maintenance (Security Fixes, Tests, Dokumentation, Release Engineering). Für Lösungen wie Proxmox Virtual Environment oder Proxmox Backup Server ist diese unsichtbare Arbeit im Alltag entscheidend, weil sie verlässliche Updates, Tests und Betriebsstabilität ermöglicht. 2) Mehrwert quelloffener Lösungen Der Mehrwert quelloffener Lösungen liegt aus meiner Sicht in Planbarkeit (TCO), geringerer Anbieterbindung, Interoperabilität sowie Auditierbarkeit und Transparenz. Quelloffenheit erleichtert unabhängige Prüfung. In Kombination mit sauberen Update- und Vulnerability-Prozessen stärkt das Risikomanagement. Konkretes Beispiel: Ich setze Proxmox Virtual Environment als Virtualisierungsplattform ein, Proxmox Backup Server für Backup/Recovery und Proxmox Datacenter Manager für zentralen Überblick und Steuerung mehrerer Umgebungen. Dieser Stack erhöht im Betrieb hauptsächlich die Stabilität, Wiederherstellbarkeit und die langfristige Planbarkeit und reduziert gleichzeitig das Risiko, in ein einzelnes proprietäres Ökosystem gebunden zu sein. 3) Maßnahmen auf EU-Ebene Die EU sollte Open Source stärker als realistische Betriebsoption fördern. Beschaffung outcome-basiert gestalten (Lifecycle, Interoperabilität, Security-Prozesse, Betriebsmodelle) und Open Source fair bewerten. Maintenance und Security Engineering gezielt fördern (Tests, Dokumentation, Release-Prozesse). Supply-Chain-Sicherheit praktikabel unterstützen (Tooling, Audits, Schulungen) statt nur zusätzliche Pflichten aufzubauen. EU-basierte Infrastruktur (Repos/Artefakte/Signierung/Scanning) stärken, um Abhängigkeiten zu reduzieren. 4) Vorrangige Technologiebereiche Prioritär sind Cloud- und Edge-Infrastruktur (Virtualisierung/Management/Storage/Netzwerk), Backup/Recovery sowie Cybersicherheit und Software-Lieferketten. Aus meiner Sicht sind das die Grundlagen, auf denen Souveränität und Resilienz aufbauen. Proxmox Virtual Environment, Proxmox Datacenter Manager und Proxmox Backup Server zeigen dabei, dass es in Europa praxistaugliche Lösungen für genau diese Basisschichten gibt. 5) Relevante Sektoren Besonders profitieren öffentliche Verwaltung, kritische Infrastrukturen, Cloud- und IT-Dienstleister sowie Bildung/Forschung. In all diesen Bereichen sind langfristige Kostenkontrolle, Exit-Fä

feedback: En tant que citoyen, les solutions open-source sont difficiles d'accès sans connaissance en informatique. C'est d'ailleurs quasiment impossible aujourd'hui d'acheter un ordinateur ou un smartphone avec un OS open-source. En tant qu'ingénieur en génie civil, les logiciels professionnels même européens ne sont disponibles que sous Windows : RFEM de Dluba, IdeaStatic, SCIA et Allplan de Nemetschek, Solidworks de Dassault Systèmes, et les logiciels des administrations publiques CEREMA, CSTB ou du CTICM... Par ailleurs, nous utilisons beaucoup de feuilles de calculs Excel+VBA en interne développées depuis des dizaines d'années. Aujourd'hui, pour un bureau d'études, il n'est pas possible de migrer en dehors de Windows seul. Le préalable nécessaire est la migration vers des versions multiplateformes de tous les logiciels métiers de la part des éditeurs (notamment européens). L'autre frein est l'accoutumance à l'environnement Windows du personnel informatique (compétences mono-plateforme) : voir le REX de la Gendarmerie Nationale Française sur la migration vers Linux.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: As a citizen, open-source solutions are difficult to access without IT knowledge. It is almost impossible today to buy a computer or smartphone with an open-source OS. As a civil engineering engineer, even European professional software is only available on Windows: RFEM de Dluba, IdeaStatic, SCIA and Allplan de Nemetschek, SolidWorks de Dassault Systèmes, and the software of the public administrations CEREMA, CSTB or CTICM, etc. In addition, we use many Excel + VBA spreadsheets internally that have been developed for decades. Today, for a consultancy firm, it is not possible to migrate outside Windows alone. The necessary prerequisite is the migration to multi-platform versions of all business software by publishers (particularly European publishers). The other barrier is the accustoming of IT staff to the Windows environment (mono-platform skills): see the REX of the French National Gendarmerie on migration to Linux.

feedback: File attached ARES69111-BOUDICA.odt

1. STRENGTHS, WEAKNESSES, BARRIERS -Strengths: EU has historic strength in grassroots engineering/GDPR values. Technical superiority is evident in Drupal/Mautic powering the global web. -Weaknesses: Critical "productization gap." We lack the marketing muscle & "enterprise packaging" of US competitors (Adobe/Salesforce). Private sector often views OS as "hobbyist" vs polished suites. -Barriers: "Free Rider" problem (usage without contribution) starves maintainers. Procurement favors proprietary vendors/legal teams. Misconception that Enterprise OS lacks SLAs/security compared to proprietary options. 2. ADDED VALUE -Sovereignty/Lock-in: Proprietary platforms (Sitecore/Adobe) create lock-in. If US vendors change pricing/sunset products, EU is trapped. Open source guarantees code ownership. If vendors fail, code remains yours; any EU provider can take over. -Security/Transparency: Transparency makes bugs shallow. Global community fixes issues faster than "black box" vendors. Auditability is massive risk-mitigation for regulated sectors. -Economic Efficiency: Better TCO. Instead of paying license fees to non-EU hyperscalers ("dead money"), budget becomes "investment money" for local service/innovation (e.g. Dropsolid), fueling the EU economy. 3. EU MEASURES -Trust Label: Certify companies actively contributing to OS (code/finance). Grant preferential procurement status. -Redistribution: "Contribution Credit" system. Allocate % of digital procurement budgets to maintain OS projects. Contributors receive tax credits. -Mandates: Enforce "Open Source First" for critical infrastructure. Prefer sovereign solutions (Mautic) over foreign (HubSpot) to keep data in EU influence sphere. 4. PRIORITY TECH -DXP & CMS: Prioritize the layer where citizens interact with gov. Relying on US platforms creates dependency for communication channels. Strengthening Drupal/Mautic ensures we own the platform. -Sovereign AI: Prevent Cloud Act risks. Prioritize Open Source AI/RAG. Example: Dropsolid solutions allow using LLMs while keeping vector databases in sovereign EU clouds, avoiding sensitive context transfer to US models. 5. SECTORS & RESILIENCE -Regulated Sectors: Gov, Utilities, Finance, Health cannot afford foreign surveillance/leaks. Strong demand exists (e.g. Pidpa, EPSO) for absolute data control. -Resilience: Avoids "end-of-life" forced migrations. Infrastructure remains operational/secure for decades, not dictated by foreign vendor fiscal quarters.

Bonjour, Nous devrions avoir des forges souveraines étatiques fédérées en Europe. Un équivalent de GitHub ou GitLab mais sous forme de fédération. Et qui soient confiées aux États plutôt qu'à des associations comme codeberg ou autre. C'est un vrai service public de base pour les développeurs informatiques open source et ceux qui utilisent leur code source. Je parle bien de tous les codes sources et développeurs de code source libres, et pas seulement du logiciel directement utilisé par les administrations. Je parle d'un vrai service public. Pour préciser ce que serait une vraie forge logicielle souveraine de service public à mes yeux, si l'on part sur une variante européenne, ce serait une entité transnationale avec des fonctionnaires européens de chaque pays payés pour administrer et améliorer une forge aux URLs suivantes : forge.europa.eu pour l'URL européenne, forge.gouv.fr pour un miroir français, etc. C'est indispensable que les URLs soient "officielles" et "centralisatrices", et aussi qu'elles correspondent à des TLD administrés en Europe (pas .net, .org, etc.). Si les décideurs et intermédiaires arrêtent de pétocher sur un retour des "nazis", c'est possible. Sinon, la phobie des SI centralisés l'empêchera comme pour bien d'autres initiatives hors US. Là chaque forge devrait permettre de garantir une continuité de service nationale en cas de coupures d'Internet, les miroirs nationaux contenant tout le code source libre présent au niveau européen. Il est impératif que les miroirs ne soient pas des simples redirections HTTP, mais bien des instances auto-suffisantes fédérées autour de l'instance européenne. Ensuite sur le même modèle fédéré, il faudrait voir s'il n'y a pas possibilité d'avoir des miroirs des dépôts de paquets Python, JS, PHP, etc. (PyPI, NPMJS, Packagist). Voilà, ce serait un élément clé de notre souveraineté digitale, sinon ce sera toujours soit quasi centralisé aux USA, soit éclaté en associations dans les différents pays, sans aucune garantie de service public. Donc le travail de gestion et de développement des forges dans les associations des différents pays restera redondant, lent, et un critère de modes au sein de la communauté des développeurs au lieu de partir directement sur une solution pérenne. Prendre 300 ans pour bâtir une cathédrale on peut comprendre, mais si c'est juste pour construire des huttes ;) XD. Bien cordialement

Hello, we should have federated sovereign forges in Europe. An equivalent of GitHub or GitLab but in the form of a federation. And which are entrusted to States rather than to associations such as codeberg or others. It is a real basic public service for open source IT developers and those using their source code. I am talking about all free source codes and source code developers, not just the software directly used by administrations. I am talking about a real public service. If decision-makers and intermediaries stop picking up on a return of the “Nazis”, this is possible. Otherwise, centralised IS phobia will prevent it, as with many other non-US initiatives. Here each forge should make it possible to guarantee continuity of national service in the event of Internet shutdowns, since the national mirrors contain all the free source code

feedback: Verschiedene Ebenen sollten betrachtet werden *End-User und Betriebe* Viele Menschen sind abhängig von Produkten von Microsoft und/oder Google. Die Abschaltung der E-Mail-Konten von Mitgliedern des IGH sollte hier Warnung für alle sein. Für Betriebe entstehen schnell Lock-Ins durch Prozesse basierend auf Word und Excel. Man denke auch an das Scheitern des LiMux-Projekts in München Ende der 2010-Jahre. Mögliche Lösungen: - Stärkung von Geschäftsmodellen für offene Office-Lösungen (z.B. Libre-Office, NextCloud, OwnCloud) durch öffentliche Aufträge, Förderung von Maintainern - Stärkung des Rechts auf Portierung von Daten und Algorithmen (Makros) in alternative Lösungen - Kompromisslose Umstellung der öffentlichen Verwaltungen, nicht nur aus Kosten- sondern aus Sicherheitsgründen - Nutzung von OpenSource-Alternativen von Anfang an, z.B. beim Schulunterricht *Bereitstellung Digitaler Services* Die Erstellung digitaler Dienste ist außerhalb von AWS/Azure/GoogleCloud nur schwer möglich, bzw. unverhältnismäßig teurer zu erstellen und zu warten. Dadurch geraten standardmäßig nicht nur private Daten von EU-Bürger:innen in die Hände von Drittstaaten, sondern auch Geschäftsgeheimnisse und Informationen über kritische Infrastruktur und Militärgeheimnisse. Mögliche Lösungen: - Stärkung von Alternativen, z.B. auf der Basis von OpenStack durch die Schaffung zukunftssicherer Geschäftsmodelle - Klares Verbot der Nutzung von AWS, MS Cloud-Office und Co. für alle öffentlichen Verwaltungen - Verbot der Nutzung von Nicht-EU-Cloud-Lösungen für kritische Infrastruktur, Rüstungsbetriebe (inkl. Zulieferer) usw. - Kompromisslose Strafverfolgung für jede Form von Datenhandel, z.B. als Nebenprodukt von Webbanner-Bidding (RTB) - Harmonisierte Besteuerung von digitalen Dienstleistungen im EU-Raum.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: Different levels should be considered *end users and businesses* Many people depend on Microsoft and/or Google products. The closure of the e-mail accounts of members of the ICJ should be a warning for everyone. For farms, lock-ins are quickly created by processes based on Word and Excel. One might also think of the failure of the LiMux project in Munich at the end of the 2010s. Possible solutions: — Strengthening business models for open office solutions (e.g. Libre Office, NextCloud, OwnCloud) through public procurement, promoting Maintainers – strengthening the right to port data and algorithms (macros) into alternative solutions – uncompromising transformation of public administrations, not only for cost but also for security reasons – using open source alternatives from the outset, e.g. in school education *providing digital services* It is difficult to create and maintain digital services outside AWS/Azure/GoogleCloud, or disproportionately more expensive. By default, this brings not only private data of EU citizens into the hands of third countries, but also trade secrets and information about critical infrastructure and military secrets. Possible solutions: — Strengthening alternatives, e.g. based on OpenStack by creating future-proof business models – Clear ban on the use of AWS, MS Cloud Office and Co. for all public administrations – Prohibition on the use of non-EU cloud solutions for critical infrastructure, defence companies (including suppliers), etc. – Uncompromising law enforcement for any form of data trade, e.g. as a by-product of web banner bending (RTB) – Harmonised taxation of digital services in the EU.

Promouvoir les solution de stockage auto-hébergées. feedback: I wholeheartedly support digital sovereignty based on open source solutions for the EU.

Distinction fondamentale entre « logiciel libre » et « open source » : - Il est essentiel de bien différencier « logiciel libre » et « open source » qui sont souvent condondus, y compris dans le présent appel à contribution. Exigence de licence copyleft pour les productions financées par des fonds publics : - Les logiciels, données, contenus multimédias et autres œuvres numériques développés ou financés à laide de fonds publics devraient être publiés sous licence de type *copyleft*, telles que la GNU General Public License (GPL) ou Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike (CC BY-SA). Ces licences garantissent que toute œuvre dérivée doit être redistribuée sous les mêmes conditions, assurant ainsi une réciprocité et une pérennité du bien commun. - À défaut de telles licences, il existe un risque structurel de captation privée de la valeur publique : des entreprises peuvent sapproprier gratuitement des productions issues de leffort collectif sans retour à la société. Lexemple dApple illustre ce phénomène : son système dexploitation macOS repose en partie sur BSD, dont la licence permissive a permis une appropriation commerciale sans obligation de contribution en retour. Ce modèle, bien que légitime lorsquil sapplique à des productions privées, est inacceptable lorsquil concerne des ressources financées par les contribuables. Largent public doit servir à enrichir le patrimoine commun et à renforcer la souveraineté de lEurope. - À défaut de licence copyleft, une cession de droits rémunérée pourrait être envisagée pour les entités privées souhaitant exploiter commercialement des productions publiques, les revenus générés étant réinvestis dans de nouveaux projets dintérêt général. Souveraineté numérique et mutualisation des ressources publiques: - Pour des raisons de souveraineté et de cybersécurité, les administrations publiques des États membres de lUnion européenne doivent accélérer leur transition vers des solutions technologiques souveraines. Le partage obligatoire des codes sources et des données (notamment les jeux de données dentraînement pour lIA) entre ces administrations est indispensable pour favoriser linnovation collective et réduire la dépendance aux solutions non européennes. - Des task forces interétatiques devraient être créées afin de mutualiser, à grande échelle et en urgence, les ressources numériques publiques, permettant ainsi un sevrage progressif des administrations européennes des fournisseurs technologiques extra-européens. Dépendance matérielle et nécessité dune chaîne dapprovisionnement souveraine: - La souveraineté numérique ne peut se limiter au logiciel. La dépendance au matériel est tout aussi critique, voire plus complexe, car les composants électroniques sont souvent fermés.. De nombreux dispositifs "anodins" câbles USB-C, disques durs, clés USB, batteries rechargeables intègrent des microcontrôleurs et du firmware, dont le code peut être exécuté sans intervention du système dexploitation. - Ces composants, majoritairement fabriqués en Asie, posent des risques sévères de sécurité: un firmware malveillant pourrait exfiltrer des données, désactiver un périphérique à distance, ou compromettre lintégrité du système. Pour garantir une véritable souveraineté numérique, lEurope doit être capable de recréer lensemble de sa chaîne dapprovisionnement, y compris la conception et la fabrication de composants électroniques. Une approche collaborative, avec un partage contrôlé des connaissances, est incontournable face à lampleur du défi. Gouvernance et coordination : - Il convient de créer un organisme de coordination européen chargé de superviser, prioriser et diffuser les initiatives de souveraineté numérique, en alignement avec une stratégie globale de développement de lUnion. Cet organe assur
