feedback: Ich arbeite derzeit als Software-Architekt in einer großen deutschen Firma und habe Erfahrungen im Bereich der Unternehmensgründung (Jahr 2000) für Wissensmanagement Systeme und Social Media. Meinen Kommentar gebe ich eigenverantwortlich als Privatperson. Meiner Meinung nach ist die Umstellung auf OpenSource ist bei weitem nicht ausreichend. Es muss sichergestellt werden, dass die verwendeten OpenSorce Projekte in der EU verantwortet werden und rechtlich im produktiven Einsatz in Firmen verwendet werden dürfen, ohne IP Risiken. Des weiteren sollten europäische Startups massiv gefördert werden, welche Grundlagenprodukte (wie Betriebssysteme, Infrastruktur, Kommunikation, etc) entwickeln, obwohl diese einen sehr späten ROI aufweisen werden. Es muss die Abhängigkeit von ausländischen Investitionen für EU Startups gebrochen werden. Große europäische Firmen müssen Anreize erhalten, Eigenentwicklungen voranzutreiben, anstatt auf US Infrastruktur zu setzen. Es muss bewusst sein, dass europäische Wirtschaft extrem abhängig von US Infrastruktur ist und das wirtschaftliche Risiko für eine Umstellung der Infrastruktur mit zunehmender Verzahnung stetig steigt. In Europa gefertigte Endkundenprodukte (Haushaltsgeräte, Spielzeuge, KFZ) sollten darauf ausgelegt sein, Daten nur innerhalb der EU und nur auf eigenen DSGVO-Konformer Infrastruktur zu speichern. Datenschutz kann ein USP für Produkte der EU sein, aber nur, wenn wir die benötigte Infrastruktur selbst verantworten und diese auch wirtschaftlich betreiben können. Open Source ist meines Erachtens dazu ungeeignet.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: I am currently working as a software architect in a large German company and have experience in setting up a business (year 2000) for knowledge management systems and social media. I give my comment under my own responsibility as a private individual. In my view, the transition to open source is far from sufficient. It must be ensured that the OpenSorce projects used are accountable in the EU and can legally be used in productive use in companies without IP risks. Furthermore, European start-ups that develop basic products (such as operating systems, infrastructure, communications, etc.) should be massively supported, even though these will have a very late ROI. We need to break dependence on foreign investment for EU start-ups. Large European firms must be incentivised to develop themselves rather than relying on US infrastructure. It must be borne in mind that the European economy is extremely dependent on US infrastructure and that the economic risk of infrastructure conversion is constantly increasing with increasing interconnection. Retail products manufactured in Europe (household appliances, toys, motor vehicles) should be designed to store data only within the EU and only on their own GDPR-compliant infrastructure. Data protection can be a USP for EU products, but only if we can take responsibility for the infrastructure we need and also operate it economically. Open source is, in my view, unsuitable for that purpose.

feedback: I did not know about NGI but am very glad it exists. This was an important initiative ten years ago, but in the current climate, sovereignty over our data is absolutely critical. I cannot provide much expert opinion over strategies that might work going forward, but as an information worker, I am desperate to work for a company that is based in Europe and has our interests at heart. As a computer user, I'm crying out for alternatives to the US-based services upon which we've all become so dependent.

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY: This opinion paper addresses the European Commission's strategic objective of achieving digital sovereignty through open-source technologies. Drawing on 20 years of experience as an individual developer of critical cybersecurity infrastructure, I argue that the current EU funding and support frameworks suffer from an "institutional blind spot" that favors commercial entities and startups over the individual developers who maintain the worlds most critical Free and Open Source Software (FOSS). To achieve true strategic autonomy, the EU must shift its focus toward supporting the "unsexy" but foundational layers of the internetsuch as firewalls and SSL inspection toolsand dismantle the closed-source ecosystems that currently dictate the European cybersecurity landscape. PROPOSED STRATEGIC ACTIONS FOR THE EU: To improve the state of "Real FOSS" and secure the European digital stack, the Commission should: 1. Fund "Old Ideas" for New Sovereignty: Do not only chase "AI" or "Quantum." Fund the foundational technologies like UTM firewalls and Proxies that are currently dominated by proprietary monopolies. 2. Support Individuals Directly: Establish a "European FOSS Maintainer Fellowship" that provides livable stipends to individual developers maintaining critical security projects, regardless of their commercial status. 3. Mandate Transparency in Critical Tenders: Require that any security software used by EU public administrations for traffic inspection must be FOSS or at least provide a fully auditable, open-standard inspection layer. 4. Dismantle Proprietary Lock-in: Use the Interoperable Europe Act to ensure that cybersecurity training in schools and universities is vendor-neutral and emphasizes FOSS tools. CONCLUSION: If the EU continues to fund only commercial entities and "exit-driven" startups, it will remain a digital colony of non-EU proprietary tech. Digital sovereignty starts at the source code. It is time to support the individuals who keep that code open. [Please find the details of this submission in the opinion paper attached.]

I see two main barriers to broader open source adoption and contribution. One reason is human nature and individual habit. When schools already work with closed source software like Windows, Apple software, and especially Microsoft Office, children are implicitly taught that this is the standard. Similarly, children are taught that the closed source software distribution model is "normal" and due to a lack of legal means no intrinsic motivation to modify software and/or fix bugs is awakened. Since the licence terms of this software generally do not permit free use, European taxpayers' money also flows directly to American companies. This is annoying in itself, but becomes downright absurd when you consider that we Europeans are even paying ourselves to expand and strengthen our dependency. With the increasing compulsion for online storage and SaaS-only access to software, some public institutions are even violating the GDPR by storing personal data on servers of US companies. To place the responsibility for this in the hands of users especially in the case of schools is brazen and probably not legally tenable. To put it more briefly: Precisely in educational institutions, the foundation could be laid for greater open source use and contribution, and taxpayers' money could also be saved. By mandating that only open source may be used in all educational institutions and public bodies (both national and EU), orders would also come to the European software industry, triggering billions in growth. And if you add up all the expenditure on closed source software manufacturers by EU institutions and set it against these billion-euro investments, the EU budget would even be relieved. The weaknesses of the EU open source sector are in some cases the lack of equal functionality of software compared to closed source solutions. However, this could be compensated for within the next few years thanks to the investment strategy outlined above. Due to the large market for European software manufacturers, the economic situation of the participating companies would also be very sustainable, and for the EU as an institution it would be equally sustainable, as expenditure that would leave the EU area in the form of licence payments to US companies could be paid out within the EU, with even budget left over. Especially in a time of decline in the European automotive, steel, and chemical industries, it is of immense importance for Europeans to be able to build up a new industrial sector as a job engine and growth guarantee. And since no new debts need to be incurred, but only the money for software licences needs to be repurposed, building this job engine and growth guarantee is almost completely risk-free. The likelihood of backdoors decreases; supply chain disasters like that of SolarWinds would become less likely due to better maintainability (open source is verifiable in the source code); blackmailability by foreign nations outside the EU is eliminated. Archiving data and solutions is technically easier and more cost-effective with open source means. Especially in times of AI applications, it is also enormously important that data verifiably cannot fall into the hands of other nations to prevent industrial espionage. With open source AI applications, it can be more easily prevented that data can flow to other nations and (competing) companies.

First Off I would like to thank Europa for hosting an Open Call. With the digital landscape developing as rapidly as it is if you would do a call like this every year, it would be even more beneficial. My skills as a Cyber Security professional grow daily. The issues being faced by consumer and businesses is only going to grow, Database Engineering and the mass adoption of Ai problems are barely being touched, protection against this is at bare minimum. BlockChain Engineering and mass adoption of ISO20222 and the effect that it is having on trade and regulatory while as positive as it is still has not, nor will it resolve old issues yet to be address by regulatory and consumers and businesses that have been damaged in the past, caused by database engineers and pipelines directing fraud activity, but it is a step in the right direction. While I myself as a Cyber Security Analyst am doing everything I can daily in my studies to advance, the mountain is step. iapp.org/ai governance Comptia.com/ SecurityAi Microsoft Azure Az500 Security Engineer Microsoft Azure Ai102 Engineer Due to the fact Linux Open Source doesn't have a direct study such as Microsoft Learn on Azure, I presently am focused on my study within Microsoft system before moving to Open Source Linux. These focus on AI/ML skills running on Linux systems, not a cloud brand: - Linux Foundation (best match philosophically) LFAI / LF AI & Data certifications Covers: ML concepts Python Data pipelines - (A Whole lot of Fraud and Trouble going on) Model training & deployment Open-source tools (TensorFlow, PyTorch, Kubeflow) Very Linux-centric and cloud-agnostic Once again thank you for this Open Call and I do hope to have a chance to address this again next near after a year of advancement in my studies.

1. Exempt open source projects from digital regulations or make them optional. Whenever a private citizen or an enterprise wishes to use an open source tool, they are directly able to determine if those tools respect their preferred standard/certifications. This level of autonomous verification is not possible with proprietary tools (which should still be subject to regulation) 2. Impose EU-wide requirement to use non-proprietary format for modifiable documents when interfacing with public administrations (.odt for text files, .ods for spreadsheets, .odp for presentations, or other). Proprietary products (Microsoft and Google) are capable of handling these type of documents, while it is (intentionally) impossible to operate the other way around. Mandating open document file extensions in public facing offices, would allow users to choose open-source tools instead of having to rely on proprietary ones

Coming from a background in EU ICT RIA/IA collaborative projects for over 15 years, the way forward would include: - Support for software maintenance and playground infrastructure is needed after the lifetime of the project, for hosting and showcasing project outcome capabilities. - Software components and/or frameworks developed need to map to a common reference architecture that address - e.g. Cloud-Edge-IoT - at different layers. - Software components and/or frameworks developed need to align with standards for interoperability at all levels. - A catalogue is needed for adopters to browse and find open-source solutions, both at the component and framework level, with compatibility indicators to assist adopters to "mix-n-match". - Incentivisation for OSS sustainability needed for maintenance, quality assurance, conformance, TRL validation. - Incentivisation for industry to adopt EU open source outputs. Adoption has mainly been reliant on financial incentives. - Period of time within project timelines producing open source solutions need to be associated with OSS community.

Was verbessert werden kann: 1. Open Source Arbeit als Ehrenamt anerkennen (Petition: https://www.openpetition.de/petition/online/anerkennung-von-open-source-arbeit-als-ehrenamt-in-deutschland) 2. Open Source Entwickler finanziell unterstützen (sehr oft freiwillig und in der Freizeit) 3. Unternehmen incentivieren (Teil-)Software/Tools/Libraries von closed source zu open source ändern 4. "Klassische" Unternehmen (wenig fortschrittlich in der Automation von digitalen Prozessen) besser mit (OS) Entwicklern vernetzen, um Möglichkeiten für höhere Automation gegen finanzielle Unterstützung von verwendeter open source software ermöglichen 5. Gesetzlich verankern, dass Staaten OSS vor propritärer Software nutzen sollten und diese zusätzlich finanziell fördern sollten (siehe Open Source Strategie von Schleswig-Holstein https://www.schleswig-holstein.de/DE/landesregierung/themen/digitalisierung/linux-plus1/Projekt/open-source-strategie)
feedbackTextUserLanguage: What can be improved: 1. Recognise open source work as an honorary job (petition: https://www.openpetition.de/petition/online/anerkennung-von-open-source-arbeit-als-ehrenamt-in-deutschland) 2. Provide financial support to open source developers (very often on a voluntary basis and in their free time) 3. Incentivising (partial) software/tools/libraries from closed source to open source 4. Better connect ‘classic’ companies (lowly advanced in the automation of digital processes) with (OS) developers to enable higher automation opportunities against financial support for used open source software 5. Enshrine in law that states should use OSS before proprietary software and provide additional financial support for it (see Schleswig-Holstein’s Open Source Strategy https://www.schleswig-holstein.de/DE/landesregierung/themen/digitalisierung/linux-plus1/Projekt/open-source-strategie)

feedback:
1. I am an Infrastructure Engineer with 25 years experience of managing Windows Server & Linux operating systems. During this time, I have witnessed technological stagnation, which in turn created working cultures that inhibit change, and monopolistic abuse which restricts creativity and innovation. Today, the warning signs are present of an increasingly significant risk to Europe unless we act to embrace open source technology. 2. Microsoft Windows Server has barely changed over the last fourteen years, proven by Enterprises still running Windows Server 2012 or even older, with improved security, and availability of security updates, being the only business drivers to upgrading. Microsoft's core principal of forever backwards compatibility exacerbates this problem of complacency. 3. At the end of official Windows Server support, Enterprises scramble to mindlessly lift & shift existing applications onto new Windows servers. This is not innovation, it is a systemic re-platforming of potentially obsolete software, deriving limited business value and wasting significant amounts of European engineering effort. 4. Windows Server installation options include a rich desktop experience at the expense of a significant footprint, higher compute and storage, and a larger attack surface. Alternatively, a minimalist Windows Server Core installation is smaller, more secure, more efficient, and cheaper to run. However, due to a resistance to change, and the lack of training and acceptance, it is often rejected as being too difficult to manage. 5. If Microsoft was truly prioritising security, efficiency, and innovation, Windows Server Core would have evolved beyond its text interface limitations. As Microsoft Windows is propriety, there are no legal routes to removing this blocker. 6. Recent changes to the Windows 11 desktop is a critical indicator for future Windows Server stability, as they share a codebase. Windows 11 has been plagued with stability issues, ever invasive telemetry, user data harvesting to the Cloud, and insecure Artificial Intelligence services and agents. 7. The dominance of Windows 10, even after its scheduled end of support has passed, is an indication of how Windows 11 is not providing an improved user experience. 8. Enterprises rely on multiple 3rd party security tools on Windows, significantly adding to compute requirements. By reducing the attack surface & 'live off the land' built-in software for attackers to use, the number of these tools may be reduced. Every tool provides a supply chain that can become compromised. 9. Artificial Intelligence will further erode the quality of Microsoft software, especially during an economic downturn in the US. Microsoft will recuperate lost investment by laying off staff, relying heavily on AI agents, which is a severe security risk. If the quality of Windows Security Updates reduces, resulting in serious operational incidents, there is no secure workaround. 10. US Tech companies are leveraging their monopolies to aggressively extract value from everyone, with minimal reinvestment in quality or innovation. Enterprises traditionally have feature opt-outs, but economics or geopolitics may change this, allowing value extraction in the form of data exploitation. 11. AI companies are attacking the global memory & storage manufacturing capacity, reducing supply & raising prices, forcing critical data & compute onto US Cloud providers, vulnerable to surveillance and espionage through the US Cloud Act. 12. A strategic switch to open source is critical. Europe needs a Windows Server replacement strategy as a matter of security & defence. Open source has many disparate building blocks, but needs investment to fill sizeable gaps, improve user experience, raise awareness, and provide training. 13. Exposure of lone/underfunded developers, jurisdiction risk, forking projects for European sovereignty, and reverse engi

feedbackTextUserLanguage: EU_CITIZEN
column33: 1. The strengths of open source in the EU are the huge number of projects, their diversity and community support. However, for mass adoption, open source solutions should be mandatory in schools. This would make citizens accustomed and aware of open source from an early age. This will result in a full range of new projects that can evolve into future businesses. In my view, the monopoly of certain private solutions in schools prevents this mass adoption towards open source. As far as the mass contribution to open source projects is concerned, solutions will naturally be used and promoted as much as possible. 2. The added value of open source is cost, personalisation and sovereignty for the private and public sectors. 3. Impose open source in public sectors, subsidise promising open source projects and promote educational pathways that will form future contributors. 4. Artificial intelligence, renewable energy, the fight against cyber threats and cloud hosting, so that our data is hosted and processed by sovereign and open source solutions. 5. The public sector (administrations, healthcare, education, etc.), transport, energy and telecommunications.

feedback: Digital sovereignty cannot be achieved by focusing on isolated layers of the digital stack. Europes current debate often concentrates on cloud infrastructure, data spaces, or semiconductor supply chains. While these are undeniably important, they are only part of a much longer and more fragile digital chain. Open source software is vital because it is the only realistic way for Europe to maintain sovereignty across this entire chain, especially in foundational areas such as operating systems and core platforms. Rebuilding key digital components from scratch (such as operating systems, web browsers, or mobile platforms...) is neither economically nor technically realistic for Europe. These systems are the result of decades of accumulated development, global collaboration, and continuous iteration. Attempting to replicate them as closed, proprietary European alternatives would be prohibitively expensive, slow, and likely unsuccessful. Open source, by contrast, allows Europe to build upon existing, mature foundations while retaining the freedom to audit, modify, govern, and deploy them according to European values and legal frameworks. Operating systems deserve particular attention. They are the gateway to all digital activity, controlling access to hardware, applications, data, and networks. On smartphones and tablets - now the primary computing devices for many Europeans - this layer is almost entirely controlled by Apple and Google. This creates structural dependencies that affect competition, innovation, privacy, security, and long-term policy autonomy. Without open alternatives at the operating system level, sovereignty efforts elsewhere in the stack remain fragile and incomplete. European open source initiatives demonstrate that another path is possible. /e/OS is a concrete, working example of how Europe can reclaim control over critical digital infrastructure. Built on open source foundations and developed in Europe, /e/OS offers a privacy-respecting mobile operating system that reduces dependency on dominant ecosystems while remaining fully usable for citizens. Importantly, it proves that open source is not merely theoretical or experimental, but capable of delivering real-world alternatives at scale. Open source operating systems also generate important positive side effects. By enabling longer software support for existing devices, they significantly improve smartphone sustainability, reduce electronic waste, and support Europes environmental objectives. This aligns digital sovereignty with the Green Deal and circular economy goals, demonstrating that strategic autonomy and sustainability can reinforce each other. In conclusion, open source must be recognized as a cornerstone of Europes digital sovereignty strategy, not as a niche or complementary approach, but as an enabling framework across all major IT pillars. From operating systems to applications, from servers to end-user devices, open source is the only credible way for Europe to remain technologically independent, economically competitive, and aligned with its own democratic values in the digital age!

Dans un monde aux frontières changeantes, où la géopolitique vient toucher la vie de tout à chacun, ériger des règles fortes pour protéger les citoyens est un devoir de l'UE. Aujourd'hui les frontières numériques sont piétinées par des pays tiers dont les européens sont dépendants. Regagner une souveraineté numérique, c'est réduire le risque de dépendance, le risque de perte d'information, le risque de chantage, le risque de contrôle. Le choix des logiciels libres apparait comme un choix légitime et censé, mais il devra forcément être suivi d'une politique forte, avec financement, sensibilisation, formation et législation pour réduire voir annuler le risque d'ingérence extérieure que nous subissons actuellement. Le numérique de demain, c'est: - un Cloud souverain et compétitif, porté par des logiciels libres, dont les serveurs sont hébergé en Europe. - des systèmes d'opération libres non dépendants de serveurs en dehors de l'union européenne (Linux et Android sans Google) - Une maitrise de l'IOT pour ne plus dépendre de serveurs en chine ou aux états unis pour allumer sa lumière, ouvrir sa porte, régler son chauffage, regarder son système de vidéo-surveillance - Une police de cybersécurité formée et vigilante aux nouvelles menaces et ingérence numérique - Des financements pour la création d'une IA européenne, ouverte et libre, entrainée sur des sources connues, au raisonnement observable, et aux biais maitrisés. - Une politique énergétique forte et souveraine pour répondre aux besoins de demain des futurs data centers et IA. Merci à nos députés de prendre en considération que la vie de demain se prépare aujourd'hui.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: In a world with changing borders, where geopolitics affects everyone’s lives, building strong rules to protect citizens is a duty of the EU. Today, digital borders are trampled by third countries on which Europeans depend. Regaining digital sovereignty means reducing the risk of dependence, the risk of loss of information, the risk of blackmail and the risk of control. The choice of open source software appears to be a legitimate and intended choice, but it will necessarily have to be followed by a strong policy, with funding, awareness raising, training and legislation to reduce the risk of external interference that we are currently experiencing. Tomorrow’s digital world is: — a sovereign and competitive cloud, supported by open source software, whose servers are hosted in Europe. — free operating systems not dependent on servers outside the European Union (Linux and Android without Google) – A mastery of the IOT so that it no longer depends on chine servers or on the United States to light its light, open its door, regulate its heating, watch its video surveillance system – Cybersecurity police trained and vigilant to new threats and digital interference – Funding for the creation of an open and free European AI, driven by known sources, observable reasoning, and controlled biases. — A strong and sovereign energy policy to meet the future needs of future data centers and AI. Thank you to our Members for taking into account that tomorrow’s life is preparing today.

feedback: It is vital that Europe develops more digital sovereignty in all major IT areas and open source should be a major component of this strategy. I would like to draw attention specifically to the importance of doing this for all major IT pillars that are in use in Europe. For example, I hear people speak often about the importance of digital sovereignty in the areas of cloud and chipsets. However, there are many other important areas in both software and hardware that deserve equal attention. For example, a heavily under-discussed area is that of operating systems. Operating systems are truly the gateway to all other software that runs on smartphones, tablets, laptops, desktops and other devices. It is vital that European open source solutions such as /e/OS for smartphones and tablets (www.e.foundation) and European Linux distributions such as Linux Mint, Ubuntu, Kubuntu and Tuxedo OS for laptops and desktops are adopted and supported to a much greater degree. The same holds true for other software and hardware areas that have received less attention so far.

I am CTO at Meedio, a European company building a secure communication platform based on the Matrix open protocol. Our goal is to make Meedio one of the safest communication platforms in the EU, suitable for public sector and critical use cases. From our experience, the main problem is not a lack of open-source technology, but a lack of support for making it reliable at scale. Matrix is a strong and well-designed protocol, but maintaining it, conducting security reviews, improving encryption, and hardening federation are difficult to sustain without stable funding. Many open-source projects stop at the research or prototype level. Turning Matrix into a production-grade, highly secure communication system requires continuous work on: - end-to-end encryption - key management and recovery - federation security - abuse and denial-of-service protection - real-time media security Public procurement is another barrier. Even when open solutions are technically better, public institutions are pushed toward large proprietary vendors because of certification and support rules that small and medium open-source companies cannot easily meet. Matrix shows clear added value for the EU: - it is an open protocol that anyone can audit and implement - it avoids vendor lock-in - it supports federated and sovereign deployments - it allows long-term control over data and cryptography At EU level, the most useful actions would be: 1. Direct funding for the maintenance and security of core open protocols like Matrix. 2. Support for long-term encryption and federation security work, not only new features. 3. Procurement rules that allow public bodies to choose open protocols and multi-vendor solutions. 4. Help with certification and compliance for open-source security platforms. Priority areas should include secure messaging, real-time communications, end-to-end encryption infrastructure, and federated identity. Without long-term support for protocols like Matrix, Europe will continue to depend on foreign proprietary platforms even when open alternatives exist.

Call for Evidence: Towards European Open Digital Ecosystems January 2026 Submitted by: Seán Lynch Founder, OpenLitterMap (UN Digital Public Good) & LitterWeek Cork, Ireland sean@litterweek.org PURPOSE This submission provides empirical evidence of structural failure in European innovation policy: the absence of mechanisms to identify, evaluate, and sustain citizen-originated open-source projects with demonstrated public value. The evidence derives from 17 years R+D and operating a globally deployed, UN-validated open-source geospatial platform. FINDINGS Structural exclusion: EU funding architectures are institution-centric. Citizen (incl postgraduate) originated projects have no pathway for recognition, evaluation or support, regardless of outcomes. Evaluation misalignment: Contemporary structures lack competence to assess technical open-source geospatial systems. Allocation inefficiency: This produces funding decisions that are measurably wasteful by orders of magnitude. Democratic deficit: The absence of pathways for citizen-generated digital public goods contradicts EU commitments to participatory democracy and digital sovereignty. Member State failure: Ireland, ahead of its EU Council Presidency (July-December 2026), cannot identify a single citizen-originated digital public good. EVIDENCE: OPENLITTERMAP OpenLitterMap is an open-source geospatial platform enabling citizens to map environmental data. Research origins in 2008, operational since 2017. Outcomes: 500,000+ uploads, 850,000+ tags, 110+ countries, 101 peer-reviewed citations, UN Digital Public Good validation, open data (GPL/ODbL). Support received: Zero funding, Zero opportunities, 200+ applications rejected globally, 100,000 personal investment. COST-EFFICIENCY COMPARISON Plastic Pirates (EU-funded): 2.0m, 93,718 items, 21.34 per item. BluePointProject.eu 3.3m for 11 consortium partners, results not yet published. OpenLitterMap (self-funded): 0.1m, 850,000+ items, 0.12 per item. The unfunded project is at least 178x more cost-efficient. Current frameworks fail to identify high-efficiency alternatives already operating at scale. DEMOCRATIC IMPLICATIONS Six billion people carry data collection devices. European response: no training, no civic infrastructure, no pathways for citizen contribution. This is a public health, education, and security failure that contradicts commitments to digital sovereignty and falls within the Democracy Commissioner's mandate and constituency. REQUESTED ACTIONS 1. Direct funding pathways for citizen-originated projects without institutional consortiums. 2. Domain-competent evaluation for technical open-source applications. 3. Cost-per-outcome as explicit funding criteria. 4. Formal acknowledgment that current architectures structurally exclude citizen-originated innovation. IRELANDS EU PRESIDENCY OPPORTUNITY Ahead of Ireland's EU Presidency I have prepared a comprehensive policy dossier The Democracy Gap. A 1-page summary is attached. A request to view it has been sent to various officials across Ireland's institutions. Some have requested access to view it. Grma, Seán Lynch sean@litterweek.org

Mobile devices are central to todays digital life, yet the mobile ecosystem is still dominated by closed and proprietary platforms. I believe open source mobile solutions like /e/OS and Murena are strong, concrete examples of how software freedom, privacy, and user choice can be achieved on mobile. Supporting such initiatives is essential for building a truly open European digital ecosystem and strengthening technological sovereignty. FOSS plays a key role not only in Europe but globally, empowering users and communities on every continent.

I strongly support this initiative for European digital sovereignty. Mobile Ecosystems are Critical The mobile sector remains dominated by two proprietary systems, representing a major vulnerability. The Commission must prioritize mobile operating systems in this strategy. Support /e/OS and Murena Projects like /e/OS and Murena provide privacy-respecting, de-Googled Android alternatives with European-based development. They deserve recognition and support as they directly address the mobile ecosystem gap. Why Open Source Matters Digital sovereignty: Reducing dependency on non-European tech giants Security: Auditable, trustworthy code User rights: Citizens controlling their devices and data Innovation: Fostering competitive European tech Europe must translate this strategy into concrete support for projects advancing software freedom, especially in mobile.

Focus: Education, Higher Education, and Research Sector. The education and higher education sector remains underrepresented in European open digital ecosystems. Higher education institutions develop, operate, and disseminate digital technologies, thereby shaping competencies, usage patterns, and technological dependencies of future generations. Decisions taken in this sector have long-term strategic relevance for Europes digital sovereignty. Digital dependencies in education and research are not merely questions of efficiency or cost; they pose a strategic risk to the European Unions long-term capacity to act, innovation capacity, and security. Higher education institutions operate core digital infrastructures for knowledge production, qualification, and public discourse. Persistent reliance on non-European proprietary platforms creates structural dependencies that are costly and difficult to reverse. Digital sovereignty must therefore be treated as a security and structural policy priority in this domain. Higher education institutions and research organisations have long formed the backbone of Europes open-source landscape, combining development, operation, and knowledge transfer with deep experience in open standards and federated models. Yet structural weaknesses persist: the operation, maintenance, security, and governance of open-source solutions remain underfunded, as funding and procurement practices prioritise new development and short-term licence costs over long-term sustainability, Total Cost of Ownership (TCO), and lock-in risks. Dependencies in education often arise in subtle ways. Proprietary providers offer platforms at heavily reduced or nominal prices, including free-for-students-and-faculty models that conceal real migration, follow-up, and exit costs. These costs rise sharply after graduation or transition into administration, SMEs, or research roles, entrenching technological path dependencies. Cloud and AI platforms offering education discounts similarly create data, training, and operational lock-ins. Open source constitutes essential infrastructure for Open Science. Transparency, traceability, and reproducibility require open, verifiable, and sovereign digital infrastructures. The value of open-source solutions lies above all in transparency, controllability, interoperability, innovation capacity, and the reduction of strategic dependencies for public and private actors. EU action should therefore prioritise: open-source-by-default for publicly funded education and research infrastructures; funding eligibility for full lifecycle operation, maintenance, security, and governance; strengthening university computing centres as anchor institutions for open digital infrastructures; European reference architectures for campus IT and science; mandatory consideration of TCO, exit capability, and lock-in risks in public procurement. These measures should build on existing initiatives such as the European Open Science Cloud (EOSC), European data spaces, and the European Digital Education Area. Priority technology areas include identity and access management (IAM), cloud and container infrastructures, open AI platforms (including open models, training data spaces, and sovereign inference infrastructures), software supply chain security, interoperability middleware, and integrated collaboration platforms. These areas decisively shape systemic dependencies and long-term digital sovereignty. The education and higher education sector acts as a strategic multiplier: students trained predominantly on proprietary tools over several years are highly likely to reproduce the same technology choices later in public administration, research, and industry. A European open-source strategy that does not systematically integrate this sector therefore remains incomplete.
GitHub welcomes the opportunity to present evidence to the upcoming European Open Digital Ecosystem strategy. Please see the attached document for GitHub's recommendations.

feedback: Many EU administrations are confronting the real costs of technological dependence. Its goal is to build a coherent EUlevel approach to open source, recognising it as a foundation for technological sovereignty, security and longterm competitiveness. The strategy also aims to strengthen the Commissions own use, development and reuse of open digital assets, expanding on progress made under the 20202023 Open Source Software Strategy. Recent analyses, such as the Instrat Foundations report from Poland, illustrate why this shift is urgently needed. The study shows that 99% of Polish publicsector software procurement effectively excludes alternatives to Microsoft, creating a selfinflicted vendor lockin. Such dependence on a single foreign supplier exposes administrations to price increases, service disruptions and strategic vulnerabilities; and ultimately places unnecessary financial and operational risks on taxpayers. The EUs move toward an open digital ecosystem may directly address these concerns. Open source solutions reduce lockin, keep public money within the European economy, and allow governments to maintain control over critical digital infrastructure. As several European regions and ministries have already demonstrated, adopting open source is not only feasible but strategically beneficial. The new EU strategy aims to make this approach the norm rather than the exception, ensuring that public administrations can operate securely, transparently and independently. https://instrat.pl/zamowienia-na-pozor-otwarte/

feedback: Thank you for the possibility. 1. strengths and weaknesses Strength are well established and diverse communities as well as institutions that promote Open Source (OS). Difficulties arise with using specific licenses. Some can be changed by the license owners to proprietary licenses (they are semi-open). OS is in these cases a mechanism to gain attention and users/customers; when users are on board/semi-dependent, the license holder could change its license. The lack of trust can be enormous. Security is challenged by very skilled actors; individuals in important OS software project need the time and resources to themselves be able to fix bugs, check security, and maintain actuality. Another challenge is, how to fund/support a community. Often, there is no legal entity to give funds to. 2. added value OS are more open, thus more inclusive for users. Typically, they are more interoperable, so that many data formats can be used; there is no incentive (a lesser incentive) to bind a customer, but an incentive to provide a great tool. Innovation and implementation of new functionalities can be very rapid, depending on the software. The software is can be implementable by many different stakeholders, not just in one sector. 3. measures Use Linux operating systems in administration. Host pads and collaboration tools in EU. Fund OS projects and incentives to use copyleft licenses. Do *not* advocate for back doors, as they will be exploited by foreign and/or hostile actors as well. 4. technologies - Collaboration tools, democratic decision making (see Taiwanese digital Agenda); to fight the societal divide and allow for participation - Quantum computing software, as QC is being implemented more and more in research and industry environments; specialized software is needed to make use of the the computer - Earth system modelling, because having a thorough understanding of the functions of the planetary (and local) ecosystem is crucial for mitigating the ongoing climate change 5. sectors - small businesses: OS is cheaper and more inclusive; usage of OS software allows for abandonment of large player solutions - academia: OS as a means to enhance the knowledge in scientific domains; further results can be obtained much faster than if a code must be rewritten from a text description of a code 6. further comments: - Which licenses exactly? Open source is good, but does this then entail open software? - Steward ownership would be a possibility to ensure the long term license strategy and thus trust in a software product - there is a great deal of innovation in science; however, only few innovations transit/are being transferred from this sector - "Public money, public code"": commitment to certain open source licenses in certain sectors is conceivable - I recommend developing an understanding of the resilience of an ecosystem (analogous to the understanding in ecology), i.e. which elements are key elements, which flows are central, and which system designs promote resilience and which do not

As far as i have seen, the largest challenge is not the actual change in systems. There are more than enough open source systems, from operating system (linux) to hyperscalers (openstack) and software-defined storage (ceph) as well as many programs for end-users, libreoffice, etc., paperless office (paperless-ngx) and collaboration systems (nextcloud) and wiki's, and many many more ways, to be self-sufficient. The main issue is as usually, that all this needs more local knowledge, and the transition periods are sometimes challenging, mostly because the users need to focus on new systems, and learn to use them, as well as the higher management needs to understand what digital self-sufficience means for a company, or, at least on an european level. In my (humble, well, not really, but lets say so) opinion, the EU needs to focus on building, based on the existing open source systems, and by adapting and guiding their development, an open ecosystem, which will be able to boost eu-internal and world-wide development of open software components.

Most software, infrastructure and services is built upon open source (e.g. Linux, Docker, etc.). Service providers like AWS provide services above open source. There is abundance of expertise in European citizens today on how to build services open these open source systems and libraries. The main barrier is providing a vision. I would start with: 1. Build an office suite to every citizen which they can use as a result of paying their taxes 2. Develop a cloud infrastructure program to lower dependency from AWS, Google, etc 3. Encourage active European IT professionals and other required professionals (legal, marketing, etc) to participate on service build out programs, using tax breaks as an incentive to participate. 4. Reach out to leaders that have disrupted their industries with innovation, such as Stripe, to create a rapid service build out playbook I would love to participate in a program that would result in a world where my children have control over their digital data.

Hi, Mastodon, Libreoffice, Linux are all great examples of open technologies that should strategically be kept alive, nurtured but also funded and used by European institutions. The Open Source nature has all freedoms to modify base tech stacks into specialized alternatives, even with business models needing Operational Support, focus on stability etc. An example being Redhat. Also, the Open Source community develops specialized packages optimized for minimal footprints (ie for embedded devices), for performance or for graphical finess. Mastodon is a federated social media that mimics the positive, optimistic tone and community that was there when the Internet still held that idea. Had, because much of the Internet's centralized and dominating ownerships have polluted that ideal. No more "democratization of learning" but OneSpeak inc. I hope you forgive the analogy but also understand the meaning behind using it. I don't believe market thinking is completely useless, but when markets are dominated, they don't optimize towards "the best products for the best price" but become "suck them dry". I hate the pervasiveness of mass harvesting of data and the eventual damages. From data leaks (they shouldn't have collected that data in the first place) to supporting fascist regimes (Ring doorbells selling data to ICE to focus their razzias) to suddenly showing advertisments on your television screen based on viewing behaviour. And you cannot even be sure any more your products work when the seller just drops support. We've had examples of "vanMoof" bikes (not a fan, didn't buy) couldn't be unlocked any more after bankruptcy because the cloud service was disabled. Critical flaws are not patched. All this can be fixed - in consumer products as well - when more open technology stacks are embedded in all our ecosystems. Let the market prevail! Let's make sure noone wants to buy a "closed" product because the assurance is just worse. I have a more than 8 year old Pebble watch that is receiving new updates now that the OS has been made open source. Let's look at market and labor conditions as well. Europe seems to have a lack of skilled workers, especially with the enormous task at hand to get rid of the deep tentacles of bigtech, to create a European cloud. Open sourcing developments from government software to consumer devices firmware makes sure the core ecosystem can grow. Yes, there should be alternatives to find the best way to evolve, but what a waste if too much work is done in products and services that are closed source and that compete. That should just not be a viable business model for Europe if we want to scale and provide value. Yes, this would require some fresh economic thinking. I can see examples of this in for instance quantum developments, one of the strategic technologies as identified by the EU; let Germany focus on quantum computing and let the Netherlands focus on the optics - both doing that where they lead! A final suggestion would focus on Signal, it currently seems to be the best instant messaging alternative to Meta's WhatsApp. It has good features and some adoption though still not enough for full market adoption. The European Commission also prefers Signal over WhatsApp. However, the organisation, all servers are still based in the US. Sure, Signal's ambitions and actions seem more ethical than those of Meta, but we're still depending on a US company and US clouds. Either fund a Signal movement based in the US, building up a EU techstack or fund and adopt a EU based instant messaging service and let all governments use that. Similarly all governments should adopt and promote Mastodon, Peertube as channels to communicate with the people without instantly selling our personal information to 1000+ trackers based in the US. Did you know that all applicants for Dutch Intelligence (Secret Service) are tracked with Google Analytics

column30: I am a computer scientist working for a large German software company (SAP). I am aware of worrying developments that suggest that the current US administration does not shy away from restricting digital services based in the US for EU individuals acting against the perceived interests of the US. (E.g.: ICC judges are sanctioned). This is why we need a digitally sovereign Europe. This concerns mainly four topics: 1. Office software – open source software is available here. 2. AI – massive investment should be made in European suppliers, probably Mistral as the best candidate. 3. Cloud providers – an alternative European cloud should be established here. 4. Social networks – in addition to the mastodon, which is likely to be too cumbersome for ordinary citizens, I see the efforts for WSocial as positive. EU politicians should be instructed to end their presence on X. As an EU citizen interested in IT, I am really concerned about the dominance of US providers in these four areas. Thank you for your attention, Karlheinz Agsteiner

feedback: As a EU citizen and IT professional I am growing increasingly worried about the limited practical technology choices European citizens have. Cloud infrastructure and services are dominated by US companies, and in a growing digital world that leaves Europe at the mercy of foreign powers that don't have an incentive to protect European's citizens civil liberties. With recent developments in Greenland Europe should definitely start working towards a coherent and comprehensive set of infrastructure and services that allow Europe to be in control of its destiny

As an EU citizen, I am concerned with two aspects of open source: 1. The hardware lock-in of devices with open source software on it. 2. The intentional muddying of waters concerning the term "open source" and conflating it with open core and source available concepts. As for point 1, Google has recently announced that it will make side-loading of applications harder and all developers must be registered with Google [1]. This involves providing a great deal of personal details. It also requires that developers sign their compiled applications with their certificate and makes true open source distribution platforms like F-Droid (which I am personally using for the majority of my apps), harder to operate [2]. Google already offers a system called Google Play Services, which developers are heavily incentivized to use. These services perform, for example, verification of the installed Android version, making it impossible to install a custom Android distribution and, at the same time, use banking applications or even the government identity verification system (without severe "scare-screens" or entirely). The only halfway decent solution currently on the market is Graphene OS, as it sandboxes Google Play Services, but requires another Google product - a Pixel phone. This is - in part - Google's fault for their tactics, binding device manufacturers to their version of Android in order to even access the Play Store, but also in part the fault of large application manufacturers, such as banks, for only releasing on the Google Play Store and the iOS AppStore, failing to provide any viable alternative for online banking. (The offered hardware verification devices are often "not available" or outright don't work.) As for point 2, there are currently several products promoted as "open source", to which this term is not fitting or outright maliciously used. Companies use several strategies to accomplish this. These are, without being exhaustive: 1. the requirement to sign a Contributor License Agreement, where contributors sign over their rights to the source code to the owning company, allowing them to "dual license" or even outright change the license. 2. The usage of the term "open source" to describe a product, which is barely or not at all usable without the additional closed source components. (Often known as "open core".) See for example [3], promoting their membership of "openCode" [4] on their website, mentioning nowhere that the product contains closed source components. 3. The usage of the term "open source" for licenses that allow users to read the source code, but explicitly forbid a certain class of users or companies from using said source. In recent years several formerly open source projects have been relicensed (using the powers of the CLA) to source available licenses, such as Terraform. These changes are known as "rug pull" in the open source community. See [5] for a high profile example of such a switch. The EU should take two steps to foster a healthy open source community: 1. Regulate the term "open source" in marketing material, so it cannot be used to describe closed source or pseudo-open source products. Close source products should conspicuously marked as such. No particular list of licenses should be adopted, instead using a list of freedoms[6] to describe open source. 2. Unbundle mobile devices from their operating system similar to how the EU forced Microsoft to unbundle Windows from PCs. Developers should be free to distribute their projects and users should be free to install them easily without the approval of a non-EU entity and without hoops or scare screens. [1]: https://developer.android.com/developer-verification [2]: https://f-droid.org/en/2025/09/29/google-developer-registration-decree.html [3]: https://www.open-xchange.com/ [4]: https://opencode.de/en/home [5]: https://www.hashicorp.com/en/blog/hashic

feedback: Als Blogautor, der sich kritisch mit Medienmacht und lokaler Politik auseinandersetzt, erlebe ich täglich, wie Plattformmonopole wie Meta oder Twitter/X öffentliche Diskurse kontrollieren und verzerren. Das Fediverse mit seinen Diensten wie Mastodon, PeerTube, Lemmy und Loops bietet hier eine demokratische Alternative, die es uns ermöglicht, unabhängig von den Algorithmen und Geschäftsmodellen großer Tech-Konzerne zu kommunizieren. Mastodon ermöglicht zensurfreie Diskussionen ohne Manipulation durch Algorithmen, während PeerTube zeigt, dass dezentrale Videoplattformen ohne Tracking oder willkürliche Inhaltslöschungen funktionieren können. Lemmy und Loops fördern community-basierte Debatten, die nicht von Konzernen gesteuert werden, sondern von den Nutzerinnen und Nutzern selbst. Das Fediverse ist damit die digitale Antwort auf die Dominanz von Medienmonopolen wie der BILD-Zeitung: Es gibt lokalem Journalismus und zivilgesellschaftlichem Engagement eine Stimme, die nicht von den Interessen weniger Tech-Giganten abhängig ist. Für mich als Kommunalpolitiker ist klar: Öffentliche Verwaltung muss transparent, kontrollierbar und unabhängig sein. Deshalb setze ich auf Open-Source-Software wie Linux, Firefox und Matrix nicht aus technischer Begeisterung, sondern weil Transparenz und digitale Souveränität unverzichtbar sind. Die Europäische Union und die Kommunen müssen hier nachziehen und Open Source als Standard einführen. Matrix sollte als sicherer Messenger für Behörden genutzt werden, um öffentliche Kommunikation aus den Händen von Microsoft oder Meta zu nehmen. Firefox als Standard-Browser würde verhindern, dass Nutzerdaten an Google gesendet werden, und Linux auf Dienst-PCs würde nicht nur Kosten sparen, sondern auch die Abhängigkeit von proprietärer Software beenden. Steuergelder dürfen nicht länger für teure Lizenzen verschwendet werden das Prinzip Public Money, Public Code muss endlich Realität werden. Die Europäische Union hat jetzt die Chance, digitale Souveränität zu stärken und sich von Überwachung, Abhängigkeiten und Monopolen zu befreien. Dafür braucht es konkrete Schritte: Die EU sollte Fediverse-Dienste aktiv fördern, etwa durch Pilotprojekte in Kommunen wie Offenbach, und Open Source in Behörden verpflichtend einführen. Gleichzeitig müssen Mikrogrants für kritische Open-Source-Projekte bereitgestellt und eine EU-eigene Hosting-Infrastruktur aufgebaut werden, um nachhaltige Alternativen zu schaffen. Ich werde mich lokal und überregional dafür einsetzen, dass diese Forderungen umgesetzt werden denn Demokratie braucht Werkzeuge, die wir selbst kontrollieren, nicht Konzerne.

As a blog author critical of media power and local politics, I experience daily how platform monopolies such as Meta or Twitter/X control and distort public discourse. The Fediverse, with its services such as Mastodon, PeerTube, Lemmy and Loops, offers here a democratic alternative that allows us to communicate independently of the algorithms and business models of large tech companies. Mastodon allows for censorship-free discussions without manipulation by algorithms, while PeerTube shows that decentralised video-sharing platforms can work without tracking or arbitrary content deletions. Lemmy and Loops promote community-based debates that are not controlled by corporations, but by the users themselves. The Fediverse is therefore the digital response to the dominance of media monopolies such as the BILD newspaper: Local journalism and civil society engagement have a voice that does not depend on the interests of less tech giants. For me as a local politician, it is clear: Public administration needs to be transparent, accountable and independent. This is why I am not relying on open-source software such as Linux, Firefox and Matrix for

feedback: As an open-source developer myself, I very much welcome any EU initiative to support FOSS projects. From my personal experience I would like to draw your attention to one particular use case - existing open-source projects with little public exposure, such as FOSS libraries, which are critical for long-term maintenance of infrastructure. Such projects often receive little or no donations - due to little public exposure - and are maintained exclusively by literally a few dedicated developers who at some point are forced to abandon them due to change in life situation or simply burn out. What I would like to propose is a funding mechanism providing long-term stability for such projects by allowing them to apply for relatively small grants depending on the project complexity and activity. From my personal experience as someone managing a few dozens of open-source projects, one of them relatively popular, even 10-100 EUR per month makes a huge difference when the project is not yet a full-time job (and likely never will be) but starts to require time commitment that make it no longer a hobby. The definition of 'open-source' should be also quite broad in this aspect, because there's many useful initiatives that are technically not program code, but still have widespread use in critical infrastructure - from web design icons or templates, to information security lists of threats (IOC, malware domains etc). The largest issue for FOSS here is that it's not a problem to spend a week building a new list of e.g. malware domains, but it's certainly a huge challenge and commitment to continue maintaining it for months and years to come. This is precisely how many such FOSS projects burn out. The condition for such grants could be hosting the projects on EU Git instance where their activity would be measured e.g. by minimum time to respond to security issues. Open-source grants and public funding should leverage the EU Digital Cash mechanism, especially in its trial period, as its perfectly suited for such micro-payments with no costly third-party payment processors and would create synergy where EUDC would be immediately recognised in the FOSS community for its practical value.

The world relies heavily on physical infrastructure that makes everything work. For example, modern roads and rail lines would be unthinkable without the existence of bridges large and small. The principles of structural engineering keeping all these bridges safe are well known, taught at universities all around the globe, and constantly adopted to account for technological progress and changing societal needs. In a similar vein, ever since the digital revolution and the breakthrough of the internet, our world is increasingly dependent on software running its various electronic systems. Yet, to a large proportion, these software is completely opaque to its users, be it governmental agencies, businesses, or private individuals. Instead, it is tightly controlled by a relatively small number of gigantic for-profit corporations. Furthermore, the overwhelming majority of these companies is based outside the European Union. This situation might be acceptable in case of something comparatively trivial, such as a video game. In the case of fundamental digital infrastructure though, I consider it not merely problematic, but an outright threat to the very basis of our democracy. After all, fundamental rights such as freedom of speech and the press or the protection of personal information cannot be guaranteed if sensitive data is processed by closed-off systems, possibly even running on servers physically outside of EU jurisdiction. The alternative is at least in principle very straightforward though: a truly open digital ecosystem, based on well-documented standards and open-source software implementing these standards. With a population of over 450 million, the EU should not be afraid of taking the initiative in developing such an ecosystem. To facilitate the transition to that system, it also has to mandate the adoption of open-source software and the phasing out of currently implemented closed systems within each and every publicly run organization.

The Strategic Value of Open Source Open source software (OSS) is not merely a technical choice but a strategic imperative that addresses Europe's heavy reliance on non-EU digital technologies. Digital Sovereignty and Autonomy: Open source enables Europe to act independently in the digital realm, free from the control of a few global platforms or geopolitical pressures (e.g., the U.S. CLOUD Act). By providing full access to the source code, open source ensures that critical infrastructure can be audited, modified, and maintained within Europe, guaranteeing control over data and systems. Enhanced Security and Transparency: Unlike proprietary "black box" solutions, the transparency inherent in open source code allows for broad security scrutiny and independent auditing, making it easier to identify and fix vulnerabilities. This builds public trust, which is crucial for sensitive public sector applications. Innovation and Competitiveness: Open source acts as a catalyst for innovation by providing reusable "building blocks" (code bases) that allow European startups, SMEs, and researchers to build faster and experiment more without reinventing the wheel. This collaborative model can help Europe catch up in critical areas like AI and cloud computing, where it currently lags behind other global players. Economic Resilience: A 10% increase in open source contributions could raise the EU's GDP by 0.4% to 0.6% and generate over 600 startups. Supporting a robust local open source ecosystem prevents value (and talent) from flowing outside the EU to tech giants elsewhere. Interoperability and Avoiding Lock-in: The focus on open standards and interoperability in open source prevents vendor lock-in, ensuring flexibility and long-term sustainability for public and private organizations. Why KDE is a Prime Example KDE, a thriving, community-driven project that develops free and open source desktop environments and applications, perfectly embodies the principles of the European strategy: A Mature European Ecosystem: KDE is a well-established project with a strong European heritage and community, demonstrating that complex, high-quality software can be developed and sustained openly within Europe. Public Sector Suitability: Projects like the city of Munich's past use of KDE-based systems show a practical path for public administrations to migrate to sovereign, cost-effective, and customizable solutions, directly addressing the "comfort syndrome" and risk aversion often found in the public sector. Alignment with EU Values: KDE's focus on user control, privacy, and open collaboration aligns directly with European digital rights and principles, contrasting with the data-appropriation models of many non-EU tech giants. A Blueprint for Digital Commons: KDE is a concrete example of a "digital commons"a shared, reusable code base that is a public good, benefiting everyone from individual citizens to large institutions and fostering a collaborative, multi-vendor support ecosystem.

The European Open Digital Ecosystem Strategy should strengthen the use, development and reuse of open digital assets within the Commission. Furthermore, it should set actions to strengthen the broader EU open ecosystem of solutions and products not restricted to certain "critical sectors" which could be defined too narrowly. These actions should encourage greater adoption of open source by public and private users, and encourage organisations to contribute to open-source development. It is necessary to boost the development and competitiveness of the emerging EU open-source sector; and strengthen the position of start-ups in the innovation ecosystems - improving the EU open-source sectors ability to grow and develop further. One central point that should be emphasized towards companies and the public is the prevention of vendor lock-in: open source code should always enable people to create a fork of the original software in order to bolster competition and alternatives. Any attempts to prevent this should not be supported. As part of the strategy, it is important to support the development of EU-based platforms that bundle open-source projects into integrated, user-friendly solutions. Legal safety for users of open source software should be furthered, with EU-backed certification and audit programs for open-source projects, ensuring GDPR compliance and building trust. When it comes to procurement by EU and member states institutions, public money should result in public code.
As a think tank specialising in digitalisation in Poland, I am attaching our response to the Call for Evidence in PDF format.

feedback: As a software developer i'm all pro with sponsoring and pushing for open source. There pro outweigh the cons in the long run. Standardization of code would greatly improve, feature, security, compliance with law, deployment speed, interoperability, etc. at the cost of "freedom" which for critical software should not be taken in consideration. I would like to compare it to the USB-C ruling. Even without forcing people to use one specific "library", knowing that it has developer supported by public interest, audited by security searchers who can also fix bugs themself and apply them if needed (in case the code accept contribution) will create a normal preference for that library. There are so many open source example out there, first in foremost, linux. It powers so many things in our daily life and it does completely in the open. If eu started sponsoring project like linux the benefits would help EVERYONE not only us in the EU. Isn't that easy publicity? "Eu is building (supporting) the future of IT". If you want to also guarantee competitiveness europe must decide what it want from open source code via licensing. If we really want a level playing field it should enforce Copy-Left code as it the only way to monitor and check for correctness between the players. For example, if 'merica wants to rival EU digital euro it could just copy the stack, ripping the benefits without the cost. This is acceptable as long as they respect the licensing, as any new modification to apply said code to their end shall also be free and we could "re-implement" them back in our code. But this is another problem, one for the future. For now i can only ask to support Open Project, they will help us more trusting any other company.

I am a full-time software developer and regular participant in open source communities. Further, I am advising startups and individuals for their IT solutions. From my professional and private experience, I have observed that many EU companies default to single non-EU IT providers for convenience, as these offer integrated services. In contrast, open-source solutions are fragmented, requiring companies to select and integrate multiple projects. Specifically, a single IT provider offering operating system, software, email system and cloud solution is more convenient than choosing respective open-source solutions. Additionally, GDPR compliance is often accepted at face value when written in the contract regardless of the circumstances, while open-source solutions face greater skepticism. Further, non-EU vendors provide ready-made audit documents, creating an unchallenged impression of trust, whereas open-source projects rarely offer such documentation, making open-source solutions more challenging for system administrators to stand up for audits. Based on my observations, I propose the following concrete actions: Education and Training: Launch EU-wide programs to educate and train system administrators in open-source technologies. Integration Platforms: Support the development of EU-based platforms that bundle open-source projects into integrated, user-friendly solutions. Standardized Compliance: Create EU-backed certification and audit templates for open-source projects, ensuring GDPR compliance and building trust. Awareness Campaigns: Advise system administrator, auditors, and companies of the benefits and reliability of open-source solutions, challenging the default trust in proprietary solutions by non-EU providers. I believe that these steps will reduce dependency on non-EU digital solutions, strengthen EU technological sovereignty, and enhance cybersecurity.

Die Gefahr eines Vendor Lock-in in Bereichen wie Infrastruktur, Finanzwesen und öffentlicher Verwaltung ist signifikant, insbesondere wenn es um Entwicklungen im Cloud-Bereich geht. Diese Abhängigkeit kann ernsthafte Konsequenzen mit sich bringen, etwa wenn ein Anbieter den Zugriff auf Konten oder sogar gesamte Systeme einschränkt oder diese ganz schließt. Es ist entscheidend, dass staatliche Institutionen die Kontrolle über ihre Systeme behalten können. Open Source Software bietet hier eine vielversprechende Lösung, indem sie den Quellcode offenlegt und häufig auf Lizenzen basiert, die eine Weiterentwicklung der Software erlauben. Bei mit Steuergeldern finanzierten Projekten sollte der Quellcode ebenfalls zur Verfügung gestellt werden, selbstverständlich unter Berücksichtigung der notwendigen Geheimhaltung. Ein zentraler Vorteil von Open Source Software ist die Datenhoheit. Sie ermöglicht eine wesentlich einfachere Verifizierung der Hoheit über die Daten, was für alle beteiligten Akteure von hohem Interesse ist. Zudem bietet die Anpassbarkeit an spezifische Zielsysteme oder Umgebungen eine hervorragende Basis für den Einsatz von Open Source Lösungen. Neben den politischen Risiken eines Vendor Lock-in spielt auch die Verfügbarkeit eine entscheidende Rolle. Was geschieht, wenn ein Anbieter den Support einstellt, weil das Unternehmen nicht mehr existiert oder die Kunden zwingt, eine neue Version (bspw. eines Betriebssystem, welches einen bestimmten chip erfordert) kaufen? Dies führt nicht nur zu unerwarteten Kosten, sondern auch zu unnötigem Elektroschrott. Ein weiterer positiver Aspekt von Open Source Software ist die Möglichkeit für Bürger, Prozesse besser zu verstehen und sich aktiv daran zu beteiligen. Offene Standards und Interoperabilität fördern die Nutzung anderer offener Systeme. Ein Beispiel hierfür ist das europäische mobile Betriebssystem SailfishOS, das von mehreren Community-Mitgliedern und der Firma Jolla unterstützt wird. Durch die zunehmende Open Source-Implementierung wird die Integration erleichtert. Wenn offene Standards für Dienstleistungen verbindlich etabliert werden, wird es einfacher, APIs auf diesen offenen Systemen zu konsumieren. SailfishOS ermöglicht zudem die Ausführung von Android-Apps, solange keine spezifischen Google-APIs oder -Funktionalitäten aufgerufen werden, die von MicroG nicht bereitgestellt werden können. Ein häufiges Argument von Befürwortern geschlossener Software ist die angebliche Abwesenheit von Support. Dies ist jedoch nicht haltbar, da zahlreiche Unternehmen aktiv Open Source Software unterstützen und entsprechende Serviceverträge anbieten, wie beispielsweise SUSE, Red Hat und Canonical.
feedbackTextUserLanguage:
The risk of vendor lock-in in areas such as infrastructure, finance and public administration is significant, especially when it comes to cloud developments. This dependency can have serious consequences, for example when a provider restricts or closes access to accounts or even entire systems. It is crucial that state institutions remain in control of their systems. Open source software offers a promising solution here, by disclosing the source code and often based on licences that allow the software to evolve. For projects financed with taxpayers’ money, the source code should also be made available, of course taking into account the necessary confidentiality. A key advantage of open source software is data sovereignty. It makes it much easier to verify ownership of the data, which is of great interest to all actors involved. In addition, adaptability to specific target systems or environments provides an excellent basis for the use of open source solutions. In addition to the political risks of a vendor lock-in, availability also plays a crucial role. What happens if a supplier stops providing support beca
