column38: OpenSource is the central part of the Linux Community. I have been teaching in this direction for 25 years. Stable, safe, common, this is the Linux Community and the EU IMHO

feedback: Meiner Ansicht nach sollte Europa Open-Source-Technologien in den folgenden drei Bereichen stärken: (1) sicherer Datenspeicher in einer europäischen Cloud, die eine Zusammenarbeit von unterschiedlichen Geräten aus gut ermöglicht (z.B. Nextcloud und Collabora Office mit guter Nutzbarkeit auch am Smartphone). (2) in Schulen und Universitäten aller Art und auch in der Erwachsenenbildung sollten die Lehrkräfte mit Open-Source-Technologien vertraut sein und den Schüler:innen bzw. Studierenden die Arbeit mit Open-Source-Software und -Hardware gut ermöglichen und den Einsatz dieser fördern. Bildungseinrichtungen sind ein immens wichtiger Schlüsselbereich, denn dort lernen die Menschen, die später in Unternehmen arbeiten, die Technologien kennen, die sie dann auch in den Unternehmen einsetzen wollen. (3) Einsatz von Artificial Intelligence zur Simulation von Prozessen und Zusammenhängen, um Vorhersagen zu treffen, von denen Menschen Handlungsempfehlungen ableiten können. Die eingesetzten AI-Modelle sollten nach Möglichkeit transparent gestaltet, die Quellen der Trainingsdaten bekannt und öffentlich zugänglich und die Lösungswege erklärbar sein.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: In my view, Europe should strengthen open source technologies in the following three areas: (1) secure data storage in a European cloud that allows collaboration from different devices well (e.g. Nextcloud and Collabora Office with good usability also on smartphone). (2) in all types of schools and universities, including adult education, teachers should be familiar with open-source technologies, and students should be able to work well with and promote the use of open-source software and hardware. Educational institutions are a key area in which people who later work in companies learn about the technologies they then want to use in companies. (3) Use artificial intelligence to simulate processes and contexts to make predictions from which people can derive guidance for action. Wherever possible, the AI models used should be transparent, the sources of training data should be known and publicly available, and the solutions should be explained.

feedback: Buongiorno, sono uno studente universitario che si è da poco approcciato al mondo dell'open source e volevo fornire brevemente il mio punto di vista. Sono passato a un sistema operativo linux (così come il resto della mia famiglia) e ho iniziato a servirmi strumenti e/o servizi open source (o comunque alternative europee) anche per il mio studio, come Libreoffice per la scrittura di documenti e appunti; Tutamail come mail personale; Ecosia come motore di ricerca; LibreWolf come browser, Mastodon/Fediverse come social media; Element-Matrix come chat. Non è stato un cambiamento difficile né ho riscontrato grosse difficoltà durante il percorso. In caso di problemi, mi sono avvalso dell'ampia documentazione presente in rete tramite pagine wiki, forum o siti in cui ho trovato soluzione per la maggior parte dei miei problemi, gli stessi che avrei potuto - tra l'altro - riscontrare utilizzando closed software. Ho intrapreso questa strada perché ritengo fondamentale nel mondo di oggi non dipendere da singoli servizi il cui obiettivo principale è la massimizzazione del profitto a discapito della privacy dell'utente, del rispetto di fondantali valori etici e morali, e della libertà di internet. Rintengo, inoltre, necessario che l'Unione Europea, per rafforzare il suo carattere di entità sovranazionale indipendente, debba al più presto organizzarsi per sfruttare le enormi risorse dell'open source, investendo nelle capacità di tecnici, sviluppatori e brillanti menti presenti all'interno dell'Unione stessa, affinché si possa creare software che rispecchi i valori democratici dell'Unione Europea e rispetti e tuteli i suoi cittadini.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: Hello, I am a university student who has recently approached the open source world and wanted to give my point of view briefly. I moved to a linux operating system (like the rest of my family) and started to use open source tools and/or services (or other European alternatives) also for my study, such as LibreOffice for writing documents and notes; Tutamail as a personal email; Ecosia as a search engine; LibreWolf as a browser, Mastodon/Fediverse as a social media; Element-Matrix as a chat. It was not a difficult change nor did I experience any major difficulties on the way. In case of problems, I used extensive online documentation through wiki pages, forums or websites where I found solutions to most of my problems, the same as I could have found – among other things – using closed software. I have embarked on this path because I consider it essential in today’s world not to depend on individual services whose main objective is to maximise profit at the expense of user privacy, respect for fundamental ethical and moral values, and internet freedom. I also consider it necessary for the European Union, in order to strengthen its status as an independent supranational entity, to organise itself as soon as possible to exploit the enormous resources of open source, investing in the capacities of technicians, developers and brilliant minds present within the Union itself, so that software can be created that reflects the democratic values of the European Union and respects and protects its citizens.

feedback: 1. What are the strengths and weaknesses of the EU open-source sector? What are the main barriers that hamper (i) adoption and maintenance of high-quality and secure open source; and (ii) sustainable contributions to opensource communities? Strengths: Lots of open source developers in EU region and lots of open-source related foundation such as KDE e.v, the document foundation set up in EU region, and also lots of users in EU willing to donate to open-source foundation when correctly advertised(e.g. Thunderbird) so overall a good ecosystem for open source. Weakness: No clear law to view it as volunteer activity to reduce tax. This may stop some people from contributing to it and instead conduct other volunteer program. No so many talented developers compared with China or the USA. With not much work opportunity, lots of people will leave EU to seek for a better job. 2. What is the added value of open source for the public and private sectors? Please provide concrete examples, including the factors (such as cost, risk, lock-in, security, innovation, among others) that are most important to assess the added value. For example, transfer from Microsoft Office to open source office suite in government. This can reduce cost(only need to pay for maintenance, no need to purchase license), lower the risk to violate GDPR and easier to deal with vulnerability(with source available, you can audit them to ensure data was not sent outside the EU), avoid vendor lock-in(open standard means you can change software and no need to worry about losing access to data), faster response speed(maintainer can modify source code before upstream does), promote more work opportunity locally(not to pay oversea employee) and thus promote innovation locally since these developers are all local. 3. What concrete measures and actions may be taken at EU level to support the development and growth of the EU open-source sector and contribute to the EUs technological sovereignty and cybersecurity agenda? Cooperate with existing open source foundation and fund them. Enact a legislation to force EU countries to adopt open source product and also encourage those maintenance companies contribute back to upstream when possible(in short, upstream first). 4. What technology areas should be prioritised and why? Mobile phone operating system. It's a product where lots of people just use every day. And currently, the two big giants are all American companies, which is a threat to digital sovereignty. And now their move are concerning(lock side-loading, lock boot-loader, develop operating system behind wall which used to be open to public). With developing open technology, we can re-gain our control to these devices.

Towards Open Source 2.0., from open source software to open source resources? Research work is needed to understand the definition(s) of open source. (https://opensource2.cc) The meaning of « open source » remains confused and with the democratization of other openness movements (open science, open education, open hardware, open data, etc.) we may be near a paradigm shift in the very meaning of the concept leading to a change in its nature. Rather than « open source software », it may be key to move towards « open source resources » to develop open technologies in other sectors than software (research, education...). Apprehending this subtlety of « open source resources » may be critical to support the emergence of a robust open digital ecosystem in plenty of domains, where there is the need to develop specific environments to collaborate around various typologies of digital resources (text, research article, educational content, objects blueprints, datasets, images, video or audio resources or whatever). Dedicated infrastructures to build open resources at scale are still waiting to emerge. Rather than open source software, software with available source code, open source resource seems to be about digital (and "open") resources where source files are provided. Raw and editable elements that are needed to modify the final resource. Examples: docx/odt/pptx/LaTex of a pdf, markdown of a website, svg/psd file of an image, etc. With other types of open resources outside software, it's common to provide them under an open license granting the right to use/modify/share them but source files are regularly poorly handled preventing the ability to do so. Current digital solutions are not designed for these open practices contributing to a poor structure for the management of source files and related collaborative practices around open resources undermining the ability to develop them in depth. This stronger understanding of « open source » could increase consideration around source files of digital resources and therefore reduce obstacles to modification and collaboration such as in (open) science and (open) education. With orientations and policies evolving towards digital commons, with open source software, open science, open education and other open models more broadly, we lack an overall vision of the (public ?) infrastructure that needs to be developed to fully enable their existence. As long as we do not truly understand the meaning of « open source », we can't really know precisely what a related policy should be.

I give my honest feedback as an open source enthusiast, having studied cyber security at a masters level and having a Bachelors degree in Business and Economics. I think the EU should absolutely repeal its anti-circumvention laws (Copyright and Information Society Directive 2001, article 6, which obligates member states to pass and enforce laws criminalizing the reverse-engineering of certain technologies). These laws were written solely for the US benefit, under pressure, in order to maintain better trading agreements. As the US has proven itself to be an unreliable trading partner, it no longer makes sense to keep these laws on the books. They hinder European innovation. Without them, European open source enthusiasts like myself but even more importantly EU companies would be empowered and incentivized to find ways to mitigate against the monopolistic practices of American tech giants. This could even become a massive growth industry, in a trading and political bloc that sorely needs it. I will refer to Cory Doctorow in his great speech at the 39C3 conference held in Hamburg couple of weeks ago. It's hard to convey how much money is on the table here. Take just one example: Apple's App Store. Apple forces all app vendors into using its payment processor, and charges them a 30 percent commission on every euro spent inside of an app. 30 percent! That's such a profitable business that Apple makes $100 billion per year on it. If the EU repeals Article 6 of the Copyright Directive, some smart geeks in Finland could reverse-engineer Apple's bootloaders and make a hardware dongle that jailbreaks phones so that they can use alternative app stores, and sell the dongle along with the infrastructure to operate an app store to anyone in the world who wants to go into business competing with Apple for users and app vendors. Those competitors could offer a 90% discount to every crafter on Etsy, every performer on Patreon, every online news outlet, every game dev, every media store. Offer them a 90% discount on payments, and still make $10b/year. The same mechanism is used by coffee machine companies to restrict which coffee pods you can use up to parts for cars, tractors, trains or aeroplanes. In every case the only purpose of the software is to reduce consumer choice and create a monopoly. That being said, I'd also like to see more support for alternative app stores for mobile phones in Europe. There is for example a flourishing market of alternate app stores for Android, including F-Droid and the Accrescent. Apple does not currently allow third party app stores on its phones. Google and Apple have both taken measures to restrict which software can be installed on their phones. Right now, Google is taking measures to shut down the third party app stores available for Android. This monopolistic behaviour is justified as "user security" while in reality it is purely to maintain Apple and Google's positions as gatekeepers. The EU must robustly enforce the requirement that all phone operating systems must allow third-party app stores. This more than any other measure will ensure a large market of open source software free from control by two Big Tech gatekeepers. In terms of the coming EU Digital Identity Wallet, Im not able to use it in my home country if you dont enforce EU-countries sharing the official .apk files or having alternative app stores, as it seems that my country will most likely default to these two monopolistic, American-owned app stores and theres nothing I can do about it. Under the https://github.com/eu-digital-identity-wallet/eudi-doc-architecture-and-reference-framework spec you say that The EU Digital Identity Wallet will be: made available to anyone who wants to use it: Any EU citizen, resident, and business in the EU who would like to make use of the EU Digital Identity will be able to do so.

Für mich als EU-Bürger ist digitale Souveränität eine zentrale Voraussetzung für die langfristige Absicherung europäischer Werte, Rechtsstandards und wirtschaftlicher Stabilität. Aus der Perspektive eines Kleinunternehmers ist sie zugleich ein Instrument aktiver Risikominimierung. Vor dem Hintergrund der aktuellen geopolitischen Entwicklungen handelt es sich dabei nicht um ein theoretisches oder paranoides Szenario, sondern um eine nüchterne, strategische Notwendigkeit. Europa muss sich gegenüber den beiden dominierenden Machtblöcken USA und China technologisch und strukturell emanzipieren. Dazu gehört zwingend der Aufbau eigenständiger, kontrollierbarer IT-Infrastrukturen und digitaler Ökosysteme. Digitale Unabhängigkeit ist kein optionales Ziel, sondern eine Voraussetzung für Handlungsfähigkeit, Resilienz und Zukunftssicherheit. Sie ist alternativlos.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: For me as an EU citizen, digital sovereignty is a key condition for securing European values, legal standards and economic stability in the long term. From a small business perspective, it is also an active risk minimisation tool. In the context of current geopolitical developments, this is not a theoretical or paranoid scenario, but a sober, strategic necessity. Europe needs to be technologically and structurally emancipated vis-à-vis the two dominant blocs of power, the US and China. This must include the development of autonomous, controllable IT infrastructure and digital ecosystems. Digital independence is not an optional goal, but a prerequisite for action, resilience and future-proofing. It has no alternative.

feedback: Free software has many advantages over proprietary software. The advantage most people tend to name first is that it's free (as in beer) and so total cost of ownership must be lower. To me two other advantages far outweigh anything else though: 1. It doesn't lock your data and investment in: most systems build up a silo of data of some sort that the user of the system works with. Also processes adapt to the software and become dependent on it. The longer the system is in use, the harder and more expensive it is to switch to something else. Software vendors know this and make it extra hard to quit. Open source software usually does the opposite and even if one company turns "evil", there is always the chance of a fork of the project run by a different entity and everyone can continue like nothing happened. That is freedom! 2. Collaboration multiplies everyone's investment: one entity uses a system and invests in programmers to enhance the system. Another entity takes that work and further improves it. Each entity invests 50% and gets 100% functionality in return. That is why all public money should result in public code. Everyone wins and software gets better and better for everyone, from the school kid using LibreOffice for their assignments to the EU office with tens of thousands of work stations.

Hello, I'm using KDE, LibreOffice, Nextcloud and CryptPad privately and on my work notebook too and really like it, thanks for supporting it. I'm not a Microsoft hater, but I think choice and digital sovereignty is important. And in times where everything gets pumped up with AI based stuff that in the end requires backend SaaS solutions hosted on hyperscalers which are within US reach, we need independent and Open Source solutions like these. Best regards Arvid Requate

I am giving feedback as a "non IT-field" EU citizen that has in the past two years looked increasingly at open source options, due to general happenings in the world. Continuous investments in Open Source by the EU will be an important sign to citizens like me that might really wish to have some digital independence from other countries, right now primarily the US. If chief members of the legislative and judikative branches don't switch to open source options, I am quite afraid of them becoming blackmailed by their mail accounts, programs they use and other things. (The Microsoft/Karim Khan ICC situation triggered that fear initially.) Other fears are about apps that stored sensitive data like menstruation time being used for political reasons in possible abortion bans. Having investments in Open Source projects that deal with sensitive health data in a truly private and GDPR conform way would be also a big help for population health. Items like Smart watches/Heath trackers on your body have had historicaly many privacy/data protection problems, having an option Europeans can use would be a big step up. All in all I sense in other non techy people around me much desire to do something, if that something is using different applications/open source programs many are quite willing to make the switch.

Stärken in der EU: - Hohe Expertise in Nischenbereichen - Öffentliche Förderung - Datenschutz (DSGVO) Schwächen in der EU und FOSS (zB Linux): - Fragmentierung: Zu viele kleine Projekte, keine EU-weite Standardisierung - Fehlende Windows-Kompatibilität - Hardware-Abhängigkeit: Keine EU-Alternativen zu NVIDIA/Intel-Treibern oder US-Chips - Sicherheitslücken: Selbst Open-Source-Projekte wie Linux-Kernel werden von US-Firmen (IBM, Google) dominiert Backdoor-Risiko - Antivirus-Lücke: Keine europäischen Tools für Linux - Finanzierung: Viele EU-Projekte sind auf kurzfristige Fördergelder angewiesen - "Empty-Room-Effekt": Europäische Plattformen (z. B. Mastodon) scheitern, weil Nutzer zu US-Diensten (Twitter) zurückkehren "Es ist nichts los, also bleibe ich weg". - Fehlende Anreize für Unternehmen: Firmen nutzen Open-Source oft nur als Kostensenkung, nicht als strategische Investition. - Rechtliche Unsicherheit: Unklare Haftungsfragen bei Open-Source-Nutzung in kritischer Infrastruktur (z. B. Banken). Mehr Ansätze, Kritik, Lösungsvorschläge, etc. sind in der beiliegenden PDF zu lesen.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: Strengths in the EU: High level of expertise in niche areas – Public funding – Data protection (GDPR) Weaknesses in the EU and FOSS (e.g. Linux): Fragmentation: Too many small projects, no EU-wide standardisation – lack of Windows compatibility – hardware dependency: No EU alternatives to NVIDIA/Intel drivers or US chips – vulnerabilities: Even open-source projects such as Linux-Kernel are dominated by US firms (IBM, Google) backdoor risk – antivirus gap: No European tools for Linux – funding: Many EU projects rely on short-term funding – “Empty Room” effect: European platforms (e.g. Mastodon) fail because users return to US services (Twitter) “It’s nothing, so I’m left”. Lack of incentives for businesses: Firms often use open source only as a cost reduction, not as a strategic investment. Legal uncertainty: Unclear liability issues for open source use in critical infrastructure (e.g. banks). More approaches, criticism, proposed solutions, etc. can be found in the attached PDF.

feedback: I find FLOS software and practises essential for the EU and Europe for several reasons. - The EU is vulnerable to outside (hostile) actors controlling vital infrastructure. On a structural level we need to know that a foreign actor cannot simply surveil us or shut down our phones, computers or cars via code that we have no control over or knowledge of. - The inherent transparency of FLOSS can improve trust within society, since unwarranted fears can actually get checked. FLOSS thus strengthens civil society. - The participation from normal people in infrastructure also boosts a feeling of autonomy in people further helping civil society. People need to feel that they can control the things they use and own and FLOSS is key to this. - We need to reduce e-waste and FLOSS makes it significantly easier to keep electronics working, since the only necessary economic incentive is that of individual people believing it is worth it. - FLOSS fosters intra-European cooperation. We all benefit from advances made in one part of the continent and for example the KDE org works naturally across borders. - The world is presently experiencing a lot of turmoil and technology is linked to both the repression from governments and the resistance from the populace. When Chinese people used airdrop to share government-critical videos, Apple was pressured into basically removing that feature in China. FLOSS makes it harder to crack down on protesters, enables communication and doesn't let big companies decide what is acceptable. I hope the EU will fund and support both new FLOSS projects and the already existing projects that are working within our borders. This support could come in the form of directly hiring people to eg. translate software; in contributions to organisations that already work on FLOSS; in legislation forcing eg. phone companies to make alternative operating system possible to install; in making it easier for institutions to find FLOSS solutions for their needs or in simply finding locales for volunteer meet ups, so that it doesn't have to take up the resources of those developing.

Europe symbolizes democracy, peace, and collaborationnot only among its own citizens but also with the rest of the world. Or at least, that is the goal. Open-source technology and data embody these ideals in the digital sphere. Currently, the technology sector is dominated by powerful oligarchies with sufficient influence and capital to undermine democratic societies. We have witnessed this occur. These entities are a primary source of instability in today's world. To restore democracy, peace, and collaboration, we must fund open-source projects. We must require our public administrations to stop exporting public funds and instead invest in local engineers and programmers to lead these community-driven initiativeswithout barriers, without subscriptions, and without "enshittification." It has been proven repeatedly: open source leads to efficient, practical, and easily auditable software. Technology that is freely shared and adapted between communities ensures that benefits circulate back to the people, rather than being siphoned off to billionaires. The central challenge for open-source technology is initial funding. Precisely because libre software cannot generate billions in proprietary profita feature, not a bugit holds little interest for oligarchs, who only support it sporadically to burnish their reputations. Many flourishing open-source projects have been launched at virtually no cost. Now imagine if we could fund professionals to manage and lead them. Local professionals, who live within our communities. Patriots who serve our people and our democracy. Let us stop paying for "walled-garden subscriptions" to foreign entities outside our sovereign control. Let us start placing our own people in leadership roles within critical software infrastructure. We are not starting from zero. Operating systems, healthcare, social mediaLinux, GNU Health, Mastodon, ActivityPub... the list continues. There is even GNU Taler, a cleaner and more robust solution than the proposed "Digital Euro." Let's make it happen. Let's give open source the decisive push needed to challenge these oligarchies. The rest of the world will see these technologies flourish at a fraction of the cost. They will follow our lead, fund the same projects, and together we can restore democracy, collaboration, peace, and transparency worldwide. That is the European Union I want.

As a low-hanging fruit, public services should lead by example. They should adopt open source and interoperable solutions under the public money, public code principle, and use strategic public procurement to shape markets and reduce proprietary lock-in. Publicly funded code should be published under a permissive open source licence (e.g., Apache 2.0, MIT) or a standard interoperable licence (e.g., MPL, EUPL). This ensures the code can be audited, improved, and freely reused by both public administrations and private innovators. By choosing licences that facilitate commercial reuse, we allow European companies to build value-added services on top of public infrastructure without legal risk, fostering a diverse market rather than concealing defects behind a single vendor. Comprehensive, open documentation must be a mandatory deliverable for all public software projects. Code availability alone is insufficient if the architectural logic, API endpoints, and deployment procedures remain obscure or proprietary. Documentation should be published in standard, version-controlled formats (e.g., Markdown, OpenAPI) alongside the source code. This practice lowers the barrier to entry for European SMEs, prevents the loss of institutional memory when vendor contracts end, and enables faster, more effective security audits by independent experts. In citizen-facing interactions and system interoperability, public bodies should accept and produce open formats by defaultsuch as ODT for editable documents, PDF/A for archiving, open fonts (TTF/OTF), and standardized database protocols (e.g., SQL, ODBC). This ensures equal access regardless of software choice. Crucially, requirements that mandate only proprietary formats or vendor-specific database drivers must be explicitly forbidden, ensuring no citizen or business is compelled to purchase specific software to access public data or services. Where feasible, public institutions should prefer open source operating systems and applications (e.g., Linux-based desktops, servers, and kiosks) to enable competitive maintenance by multiple EU providers and to retain operational control. This also reduces the espionage risk associated with opaque components and external non-EU dependencies, because publicly reviewable code and diversified suppliers make covert access and single-vendor compromise harder to sustain. Examples of Usage: Public money, public code: A city council publishes the code for its new appointment booking system under an open license; other municipalities can reuse it freely, paying local developers only for customization rather than license fees. Permissive licensing (Apache/MIT): A national health agency releases its data-processing library under Apache 2.0. A private health-tech startup integrates this library into their commercial app to improve patient services without being forced to open-source their entire proprietary platform. Mandatory open documentation: A transport authority requires vendors to deliver OpenAPI specs and Markdown deployment guides for a new ticketing backend. When the original vendor contract ends, a new local IT firm takes over maintenance immediately without a costly reverse-engineering phase. Open formats & database standards: A business registry accepts annual reports in ODT and offers direct SQL/ODBC access to public records. This allows third-party accounting software to interface with the registry without purchasing expensive, vendor-specific API kits or proprietary Office licenses. Security & sovereignty (Linux/Open Source): A government ministry migrates its internal servers and sensitive workstations to a hardened Linux distribution. This allows security agencies to audit the code for backdoors independently and prevents data leakage to non-EU entities through opaque, proprietary telemetry.

Sehr geehrte Damen und Herren, den Einsatz von Open Source Software Lösungen kann einen zentralen Beitrag zur digitalen Souveränität die EU leisten. Natürlich ist einen derartige Umstellung oft mit Unbehagen und Vorurteilen besonders bei wenig versierten Nutzern verbunden. Deshalb ist es dringend notwendig bereits bei den jungen Nutzern (in den Schulen) entsprechende Kenntnisse aufzubauen. Deshalb einige Vorschläge zur Förderung von FOSS: - Umstellung der öffentlichen Verwaltung im Office-Bereich auf Open Source Lösungen, später auch OS - in der öffentlichen Beschaffung (Regierungen, Ämter, Schulen) Systeme mit Opens Source Betriebssystemen favorisieren - Förderung von IT-Unternehmen die spezielle Software für Open Source Betriebssysteme bereitstellen/portieren bzw. Support für diese anbieten - bisherige Software Lizenzgebühren für Support Anbieter im Open Source Bereich verwenden - Bedeutung der digitalen Souveränität, Open Source Software und Schulung der Nutzung von FOSS in den Schulen umsetzen - Nutzung von Server Infrastruktur von europäischen Unternehmen (Keine Europa Töchter von US-IT Konzernen)
feedbackTextUserLanguage: Ladies and Gentlemen, the use of open source software solutions can make a central contribution to the EU’s digital sovereignty. Of course, such a switch is often associated with discomfort and prejudice, especially among under-experienced users. There is therefore an urgent need to develop this knowledge among young users (in schools). Therefore, some proposals to promote FOSS: — Conversion of public administration in the office area to open-source solutions, later also OS – in public procurement (governments, offices, schools) favour systems with open-source operating systems – support for IT companies providing/porting or providing support for special software for open-source operating systems – use existing software licence fees for open-source support providers – implement the importance of digital sovereignty, open-source software and training on the use of FOSS in schools – use of servers infrastructure of European companies (No Europe subsidiaries of US IT groups)

feedback: Free and open-source software (FLOSS) is important, eg. Linux on the desktop has 5%+ user share now because big corporations keep abusing and preying on users with horrible privacy, ad-infested user interfaces, and abandoning support for older hardware that still perfectly works. However, the EU is kind of doing a bad job with open-source: - There seems software over-regulating with vagueness, favoring big tech. It seems like the Cyber Resilience Act and Product Liability Directive bend over with vague language to somehow still threaten open-source with uncertainty, instead of having extremely clear language of "projects with less than X of clearly related revenue are completely exempt" and "some lone maintainer isn't a manufacturer" and "shipping along some binary firmware blobs (e.g. like most Linux variants inevitably nees to) or other relatively minor closed parts won't suddenly turn the project as a whole not FLOSS and subject to this regulaton". This lack of clarity seems to result in regulatory friction that favors big tech. - Perhaps I'm wrong on this, but you might try to stop getting obsessed with detail regulation in general. Like regulating details of AI, supposedly dark patterns, and so on, until suddenly no small dev can navigate this anymore. More of these laws should probably be written to only apply to giant platforms, and perhaps the real problem might be that these big platforms by mega corps aren't broken up in the first place...? - There seems a tendency to break the free internet. FLOSS requires free discussion forums and collaboration. The EU wants to give us the UK Online Safety Act with strict age verification: https://digital-strategy.ec.europa.eu/en/library/commission-publishes-guidelines-protection-minors This seems like a horrible idea and might end badly, see here: https://www.aljazeera.com/opinions/2025/11/6/britain-calls-it-safety-it-is-censorship There are apparently privacy- and democracy-friendly approaches for this, which the EU seems to completely ignore, like this one: https://www.politico.com/news/2025/10/13/california-law-online-age-checks-00606115 - Rolling back the GDPR or copyright in favor of big tech AI slop seems scary. Copyright seems important for FLOSS, since if any AI can regurgitate pre-existing GPL code however it likes, does the GPL mean anything anymore? - Big tech seems to like to lobby for closed systems and lack of choice, typically the opposite of FLOSS. Way better lobbying transparency and income limits for politicians might help, I bet many of them are paid by big tech. That's all I can think of right now.

The benefit of open source (and, by extension, Open Specifications) is two-fold: not only can we all pool our resources into tackling a particular project, ensuring that our efforts can go further than they would were every participant to develop their own proprietary solution; we are also not beheld to the whims of companies or individuals, allowing users, both individuals and companies, to have the option to keep using a given project in the way that actually serves them. As a recent example: the non-open nature of Windows means that users, despite showing little interest, are having to put up with features that compromise our privacy. Were it to be truly open, alternative projects would have sprung up rather quickly*, providing a drop-in alternative to the operating system. We can see this in action with both Chrome and Firefox, where there is a diversity of forks serving niche interests; and with the web standards in that we have competing browsers (and more in development) that can be used effectively interchangeably. This ability to break free from a given provider (and our existing data portability efforts) would enable us, as a union and individual nations, to restore service were a hostile nation ever decide to force their private sector to not serve the European Union. We have seen what happens with this (see the sanctions on the judges that resulted in issues around banking), and we should take steps to shore up those weaknesses. If we want to grow this sector, there are, in my mind, two key areas we should focus on. First: users. We may want open competitors to existing standards or solutions, and while investment is great to drive projects forward, *users* with *real problems* and the resources to fix them is key. This might mean doing pilot programs moving away from proprietary solutions and investing in specific task forces to solve compatibility issues that inevitably crop up. But it can also mean something as simple as preferring vendors known for working in the open source space over those who might be "cheaper". The other area is a matter of bureaucracy. Not slashing it, or changing it, but in making it easier to navigate. For anyone looking to develop a product (open source or not), there should be *one* European Union website where they can sign up for any waste collection/treatment schemes that are necessary for selling electronic devices, instead of having to discover and visit each countries individual cases. We shouldn't weaken our regulations and protections, but we can certainly stand to make them easier to navigate from individuals and small business owners, as *these* are the lifeblood of innovation. Yes, Venture Capital is also part of the mix, even if I am frankly baffled operating at a loss for the sake of market is legal. Finally, when it comes to what we should be prioritizing on? Networking and communications. We need Open Source, European Networking solutions. Our networks should be ours. European communications should be European, and not be in the hands of third parties (and multinationals that are in a foreign stock market don't count as local, ever). Networking and communications underpin both civilian and military life, and given the state of the world, we should ensure that Europeans can communicate through European means, no matter where they are in the world. Securely. Privately. With assurances that no one but the intended recipients will ever see them (yes, this means no chat control). Perhaps European public workers could use something like the Fairphone for work? Otherwise, I think the best we could do is invest in strengthening our manufacturing sector. The more and cheaper we can prototype and develop within the Euroeapn Union, the more likely we are to remain competitive instead of providing the expertise and know-how to competitive nations (not that trade is bad, but given the raising tensions, it

feedback: I Have one feedback for nr. 2, 3 and 5. Assumption: In the future, autonomous systems will be widely deployed in urban environments, such as delivery robots, self-driving cars, and service robots, each with significant processing power and learning capabilities. Hazard: An actor with sufficient resources or influence could exploit these systems by redirecting delivery robots to block entrances, coordinating autonomous vehicles to disrupt traffic, or manipulating public service robots for surveillance, coercion, or intimidation. Or any combination of these. Mitigation: An open-source, verifiable boot and policy enforcement architecture should be mandated by EU, so that delivery robots, autonomous vehicles, and service robots can run only signed software, prove firmware integrity via TPM-based attestation, and produce transparent policy logs that enable rapid investigation of misbehavior.

Open source is the best way moving forward. It might be not the easiest, most fancy alternative but it allows the people to have a say, to be more in control of ther software/hardware. From Universities to local counsils the path forward is this. We are to stuck on american alternatives that for a while were great, but that now seem to charges us for the most mundane little thing. From Office 360, to Adobe products, to Games/Movies disappering from the consumers hands there must me a better way to do things. Its gonna be hard as we are used to a way of doing things with this products but essencial to our independence.

1. Strength is that it is seen as an enabler for digital sovereignty and innovation pillar. Barrier is that still for example, public sectors are procuring from the closed tech-bros like Microsoft, Teams. 2. We have concrete examples from public sector where we have saved millions on just reusing components and working together. IE economic positives, also of course sovereignty avoiding US techbro and US gov lockin. 3. An EU-wide initiative for long term like the German Sovereign Tech Fund. Set fees for member states that cant show that they dont procure open source (services first). 4. What technology areas should be prioritized and why? Boring as it may sound but - The desktop (linux-based EU), the office (reuse zendis/dinum initiatives and improve them), and standard protocols for chat, video, social media like matrix, mastodon etc. Also - Forbid hardware closed things like microsoft dependent "Secure boot", and put demands on on closed TPM and AMD-alikes (avoid backdoors).. Also, demand RIGHT TO REPAIR for consumers, ie The Framework Computer-model in instead of locked down The Apple Computer-model. 5. Public sector base tools. Healthcare. School. The foundations. Take the lead and polish and educate the good things that exist, but also regulate so it is harder to not not choose Open Source.

Our organisation tries to bridge the gap between the available open-source solutions and non-technical users that just need something that works reliably. We aim to do this in a fully transparent way with privacy and security in mind. While open-source software has in many cases become as good as or better than proprietary options, there is a barrier to adopting them for most citizens. What the EU can do to help: - promote open operating systems and tools starting in public schools and other public institutions - support initiatives, like ours, through funding - require public institutions to de-risk from proprietary American providers in their own IT infrastructure

Our entire business is based on open-source software. We provide alternative solutions and platforms to our partners that are more cost effective, more transparent, and more flexible than the well known big-tech solutions. The EU can become and open-source powerhouse by promoting open-source through legislation, funding, and collaboration with developers to meet legal requirements.

The main problem with proprietary platform providers is their tendency for *enshittification* (1) and anti-democratic behaviour (2), furthermore reducing consumer choice (3) and freedom (4), and contributing to e-waste with planned obsolescence (5) and disregard for old hardware (6). Open source software improves on all of these points being inherently transparent, easy to fork in case of ill-intentioned authors, inherently reistant to user lock-in, and can be made to work with old hardware longer without the consent of large corporations. It also generally promotes plurality and results in a more modular, open ecosystem. 1) examples of *enshittification* is found in most major "big-tech" providers, such as Google, Microsoft, Netflix, Meta, etc, and it is not found in open-source. Windows is now slow, buggy and packed with first-party spyware, Android is moving towards being as locked down as iOS, Google intentionally degrades search results to show more ads, Amazon charges towards sellers skyrocketed after it became impossible to circumvent for many, and Netflix (together with other streaming platforms) started showing ads while having less content because of a fragmented market. Social media platforms like X, Facebook and TikTok optimise for engagement, creating addiction in the users and contribute to worsening mental health globally. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Enshittification 2) Social media giants enable bad actors (eg. fascists) to spread misinformation and push a false narrative via their advertising platform (eg. Cambridge Analytica via Facebook et al) or directly via their content sorting algorithm that optimises for engagement via controversy and activating fear and anger (TikTok et al), or by directly trying to influence elections (X, formerly Twitter). This does not happen on open social media platforms. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Facebook%E2%80%93Cambridge_Analytica_data_scandal 3) Open source software often works through using open standards, for example any IMAP email client will work with any IMAP email provider, giving the user choice, meanwhile GMail and Outlook is becoming increasingly locked to their first party apps. Linux based OSes also come with a wide range of different desktop environments and hardware requirements, also applying to AOSP (Android) to some degree. Not the case with proprietary options. 4) Proprietary platforms often design their products to intentionally lock their userbase in, making it hard or impossible to migrate one's data, reducing our freedom to choose. In contrast, open-source tools tend to provide first-party tools that aid data migration, or inherently by virtue of open-source enable development of third-party tools. 5) While planned obsolescence effects hardware as well, too often perfectly capable hardware is rendered useless via a software update (Apple Batterygate et al). https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Batterygate 6) Hardware often becomes unsecure on account of dropped support by the manufacturer, or becomes too slow because of forced new features. Open-source enables community maintenance and plurality of chocie in the configuration and resulting hardware requirements. The EU must: - regulate platforms that benefit from a large userbase network effect as if they were some sort of public infrastructure (Facebook, iMessage, et al), - require transparency and a plurality of choice for algorithmic content discovery, eg. on social media, - ban the sale of personal computing devices and accompanying software that spy on users, take control and choice away from the user, and contribute to e-waste through proprietary only hardware support (eg Android smartphone drivers), - require member states' digital solutions to support secure open systems such as GNU/Linux, GrapheneOS, etc. to break the duopoly of Windows/Mac and iOS/Android.

Not knowing the exact track record of past funding, I identify several areas of interest, which concern and in parts worry me: 1) personal computing and information technology (including social media), 2) business and government and 3) hardware and chip dependencies. Current hardware and chip architectures rely on patented layouts. China on the other hand is heavily invested in the RISC-V ecosystem (no patents & open instruction set), thereby strategically dissolving dependence from western markets. The EU on the other hand is focusing on automotive chips or with project DARE on HPC/AI use cases, not addressing personal computing. European governments and institutions rely on digital cloud services. Aside from funneling tax money into overpriced licenses, recent events show (International Criminal Court) , that certain branches should operate more self reliant. Solutions like the (EU-funded) German OpenDesk promises, on the back of open source giants, to help out. Even though endorsed by the EU, only four EU governments are using Linux and OSS and that only in dedicated branches or in select federal states. Swapping long standing services to new providers is hard, especially if European cloud services are not yet competitive in pricing or performance. Still, there are plentiful open source solutions from operating systems, hosting and business applications, that would benefit from a coherent investment strategy to up the game. Daring to use more OSS in government, allows other companies to offer solutions on the grounds of support or individualization which might be a better fit, than the canned services of big players. By doing so, small to medium sized IT service firms could become enabler of an emerging market and also offer their services to businesses that choose differently today. With respect to personal computing, ambitions of operating systems to lock in users and to feed AI into each and every corner, worries me. The latest Windows updates, the removal of offline user accounts whilst introducing more bloatware, rightfully pushed many users, especially gamers, to embrace Linux. For some having a reliable OS without ads or AI-sprinkled browsers, is just enough for their day-to-day work. And if not, great projects like WINE, help to increase the availability of specialized applications. From my perspective, I would still love to see more native, well thought out applications for a faster adoption rate. Thinking mobile, there are to few well established options like grapheneOS, /e/OS or Jolla. Picking one and helping out with open source related issues, helps diversifying the market. When taking a look a digital services, there are plenty of problems in regard to, structural dependencies e.g. of the payment system or political influence on social media. Sanctions involving payment service, pose a personal risk, but could more importantly on a large-scale harm business and economy, too. Im wondering: how much of the European communication and banking system would be crippled, if certain cloud service would stop working over night. Broader funding of an alternative open source basis enable sectors to hopefully mitigate that risk. When it comes to social media and free speech, I see worrisome trends of certain countries trying to redefine, what open speech means. It happens to be, that all big social media platforms stem from said country and have intransparent algorithms that can feed tailored content to targeted users. Open source solutions, like the fediverse applications, circumvent such monopolies and algorithms in favor for transparency by also having a appropriate community-organized approach for moderation. Overall I close with the statement, that a European ecosystems and digital services could benefit from open source funding as well as branding initiatives similar to the OpenDesk. In my opinion, distributed social media is key, to a demo

feedback: The EU need for digital sovereignty is articulate and touches verticals and use cases that are pillars of governance and lifestyle in European area. From in-house payment processors, to proprietary AI models for our industries, from public knowledge bases for direct democracy, to bottom up social media and proprietary storage solutions. As open source and blockchain technology ambassadors, we would like to raise interest on the following use cases as scope for public funding within the EU area. 1) smart taxation: we believe that the rise of sympathy for extreme right ideals should not be countered with censorship, but with granular tools for citizens to express their financial participation to the state. A better, regional-first taxation and voting instrument based on Quadratic Voting and Quadratic Funding technology could help local communities put their priorities into practice and take the responsibility for them. Also, it would allow a better relationship between citizens and security forces when the latter's KPI are dictated locally and not by the centralized government. It would eventually also mitigate protests and riots if peace-supporting citizens had a way of making sure their taxes are not used for the war industry, by allowing them to hijack those taxes into funding local infrastructure. 2) AI and public knowledge bases. AI will soon devour the political field too. It has already started. Far from replacing human politicians, we might see the deployment of political AI twins in the next 5 yrs. The problem here relies on who owns the AI, and where that AI gather its consensus. It is then prioritary for EU to develop its own public LLMs as soon as possible, and foster the creation of public/decentralized knowledge bases like https://pensieve.ecf.network to guarantee the accountability of future AI administrators. 3) Public EU social media. We have procrastinated this too long. If it has to be echo-chambers, at least it must be our echo-chambers, open, verifiable and open source (if not decentralized) for better integration with new economic paradigms like visibility slots ownedby tge community. We have recently developed a PoC of a decentralized webradio - web3radio.it - that aims at being a tool for same-industry communities to organize their own palimpsest, playlists and ads via smart contracts.
Open Source ist essenziell für die digitale Unabhängigkeit.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: Open source is essential for digital independence.

feedback: I sincerely believe the EU needs to drastically increase funding for open-source projects. Not only that, it must start to adopt a "use open-source, unless absolutely not possible"-policy. It is the only way we European citizens can stay protected from big tech, and independent from countries like the USA, China and Russia.

**Masterplan 2035: A Strategy for European Digital Sovereignty** Here is the summary of the proposed industrial strategy to make Europe digitally independent by 2035: 1. **Goal: Full Digital Sovereignty by 2035** The primary objective is to eliminate Europes structural dependency on non-European tech (OS, cloud, hardware, and AI) to restore strategic autonomy and industrial competitiveness. 2. **Massive Financial Commitment** The EU will establish a permanent "European Open Digital Systems Program" with a structural budget of 50-100 billion per year, treating digital infrastructure as strategic critical infrastructure comparable to defense or energy. 3. **A European Open Operating System** Europe will develop a fully integrated, open-source operating system ecosystem for smartphones, laptops, and public sector workstations to break the reliance on foreign OS providers. 4. **Sovereign Cloud and AI Infrastructure** The plan calls for building a fully sovereign cloud stack and AI training infrastructure based on European providers (like OVHcloud, Scaleway, Hetzner) and European jurisdiction/encryption standards. 5. **"Made in Europe" Hardware Ecosystem** The EU will support the design and manufacturing of phones, tablets, and computers within Europe. These devices must be fully repairable, sustainable, and run European open systems by default (Key partners: Fairphone, Tuxedo). 6. **Open Alternatives to Big Tech Platforms** Europe will develop and deploy open alternatives for productivity suites, search engines, maps, and collaboration tools to replace dominant foreign platforms. 7. **Public Sector "Open by Default"** Open source systems will become the default in public procurement. Member States must migrate administrations, education, and healthcare to open systems; exceptions will require strict justification. 8. **Chip Autonomy (RISC-V)** Extending the Chips Act, the strategy aims for full-stack semiconductor sovereignty, emphasizing RISC-V open architectures and European manufacturing capacity. 9. **Support for SMEs and Open Source** Open source is recognized as a strategic asset. The EU will directly fund European open source maintainers, foundations, and startups to create a competitive innovation ecosystem. 10. **Mandatory Interoperability** New regulations will prevent vendor lock-in by mandating data portability and interoperability by law, ensuring that European systems can communicate seamlessly. **Timeline:** **2026-2028:** Foundation and funding deployment. **2028-2032:** Mass adoption in the public sector. **2032-2035:** Full-stack sovereignty.

In professional CAD workflows, the dominant DWG format is proprietary and non-ISO-standardised. This restricts interoperability between tools, limits reuse and development of European and open-source software, and creates long-term vendor lock-in. Addressing file format standardisation and interoperability aligns with the EUs strategic objectives for open digital ecosystems, technological sovereignty, and fair competition.

I am a university student and full-time system administrator. Keeping funding for open-source software is extremely important so that people have quality choices over the constantly-worsening services provided by large companies, like Microsoft and Google. Specifically, I am a huge advocate of KDE and its software please make sure they continue to have the funding they need to build awesome software.

I have a master's degree in software development and over two decades of experience in industry. I have worked as an individual contributor and as a manager and tech lead of small teams. To say that my entire career is built on open-source software would be an understatement. Almost all the software I used while studying and while working was either wholly open-source or built upon open-source components. As the Commission has noted, open-source is key and we have a large open-source community here in Europe. I think that while the current grant-based funding for open-source development in Europe has been successful, it misses two key elements of the problem, namely maintenance and infrastructure. To start with the praise, the grants have enabled many new features to be added to existing software. For example, I personally and professionally use Wireguard (developed partially with NLnet funding) daily on every computer I am responsible for. The first problem with the grant-system is maintenance. While grants are great way to provide funding for concentrated bursts of work, a lot of software development is just small amounts of work to keep the software running in the ever-evolving environment of a rapidly changing world. In other worlds, adding "the big new feature" is very important, but then somebody has to spend a little bit of time every year to ensure "the big new feature" still works on new versions of the operating system, has been updated to use secure versions of libraries, etc. This sort of maintenance work is not a full-time job, so one cannot realistically apply for a grant for it. Instead, a funding structure needs to be put in place to pay for such small continued contributions like this. The second problem the grants don't address is infrastructure. Software isn't developed in a vacuum. Instead, we need tools and some of the tools take the form of shared services. At the moment, effectively all open-source software is developed using the "forge" that is GitHub (owned my Microsoft and hosted in the US). The core reason for this is that there is no alternative that is offering as many features for free. The good news is that the open-source software to replace GitHub has been developed in Europe in the form of Forgejo, GitLab, and others. The bad news is that somebody needs to run these for free for the public good. Using these forges can't cost money because if it does, then people will just use GitHub which is free and so all code will be developed on a Microsoft platform. The solution is that there needs to a European public forge that open-source developers can use and trust. Since there are network and scale effects with shared systems like this, this forge would need to be run at the European level and not at the national level. It also needs to be open and not limited to official researchers at universities or something of the sort; after all, basically every open-source software starts as somebody's hobby. To summarise, while the grant system has been successful and should continue, there need to be additional systems in place to fund open-source maintenance and infrastructure. Having these will ensure a thriving open-source ecosystem in Europe which will in turn lead to cost savings and productivity improvements on anything done with computers, which in 2026 is basically everything.

Diese Initiative ist längst überfällig. Es ist absolut unverständlich, dass es Tonnen von Open-Source-Software (OSS) gibt, Europa über ein Heer von IT-Spezialisten verfügt, und trotzdem Milliarden an Lizenzgebühren ins außereuropäische Ausland abfließen. Europa sollte bei der Nutzung von OOS allerdings nicht nur als Konsument, sondern auch als Produzent auftreten. OSS wird oft als "kostenlos" wahrgenommen, eine Möglichkeit Kosten zu sparen, und wo kein eigenes Invest erforderlich ist. Das sollte nicht so sein. OSS-Projekte werden oft von einem winzigen Team von freiwilligen Software-Entwicklern getragen. Daher ist es nicht verwunderlich, wenn Bugs nicht gefixt, Features nicht implementiert und wenig Support geleistet wird. Eine Digitalstrategie sollte so aussehen, dass nicht nur konsumiert, sondern die Entwicklung von OSS aktiv unterstützt und mitgestaltet wird. Dazu sollte ein Katalog von relevanter Software erstellt werden, dann die "Painpoints" identifiziert und schließlich die Beseitigung dieser Hürden finanziell und logistisch unterstützt werden. Es müsste weiterhin auch eine Lösung für das Problem der Fragmentierung geschaffen werden. Es darf nicht sein, dass jede Institution, jede Behörde ihre eigene Software entwickelt obwohl es bereits vergleichbare Lösungen gibt. Dazu müsste es eine zentrale Stelle geben, die die Akteure beim Aufbau ihrer IT-Lösungen unterstützt. Diese zentrale Stelle sollte auch Änderungswünsche sammeln und die Implementierung koordinieren, sodass kein Grund besteht, OSS wegen fehlender Features nicht einzusetzen.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: This initiative is long overdue. It is absolutely incomprehensible that there are tons of Open Source Software (OSS), that Europe has a army of IT specialists, and yet billions of licence fees flow out of Europe. However, Europe should act not only as a consumer but also as a producer when using OOS. OSS is often perceived as ‘free’, a way to save costs and where no own investment is needed. This should not be the case. OSS projects are often supported by a tiny team of voluntary software developers. It is therefore not surprising that bugs are not fixed, features are not implemented and little support is provided. A digital strategy should not only be consuming, but actively supporting and shaping the development of OSS. To this end, a catalogue of relevant software should be drawn up, the ‘panpoints’ identified and the removal of these obstacles supported financially and logistically. A solution to the problem of fragmentation would still need to be found. It should not be the case that every institution or authority develops its own software, even though similar solutions already exist. This would require a central body to support stakeholders in building up their IT solutions. This central body should also collect requests for changes and coordinate the implementation, so there is no reason not to use OSS due to a lack of features.

feedback:
Based on 30 years of experience in software development, support, and collaboration with both private and public sector stakeholders, I propose a strategy for the EU to foster Open Source software that prioritizes data sovereignty, interoperability, and long-term sustainability. My recommendations aim to create a counterbalance to portal-type economic initiatives from outside the EU, ensuring that public administrations retain control over their data and software. 1. Data Sovereignty and Ownership - The data generated or managed by software developed for public administrations must belong to the administration, not the developer. This ensures transparency and prevents vendor lock-in. - Fully documented, open-source protocols for data export must be mandatory. This guarantees that administrations can migrate their data if needed, without dependency on a single provider. 2. Interoperability and Reusability - Actively raise awareness about the existing EU Open Source Software Catalogue. Encourage public administrations and software producers to contribute to and utilize this resource. - Incentivize Participation: Offer higher funding or grants for open-source projects (also for converting proprietary software into open-source solutions. - Community Engagement: Organize competitions, hackathons, and collaborative events to grow the developer community around the catalogue. Foster a culture of open-source innovation and collaboration, as mentioned in point 6. 3. Sustainability and Long-term Support - Multi-year Contracts: Development contracts should span multiple years to provide stability for developers and ensure continuous improvement of the software. - Maintenance and Security: All software requires ongoing maintenancefrom addressing security vulnerabilities to adding new functionalities. Funding must reflect this reality and not be limited to short-term projects. - Support Guarantees: Ensure that applications are supported throughout their lifecycle. This includes technical support, updates, and user training. 4. Collaboration and Synergies - Cross-border Development Hubs: Establish hubs where economic agents from the EU (and non-EU guests) collaborate to develop software for public administrations. These hubs should be sponsored and overseen by public administrations to align with their needs. - Neutral Expertise: Include neutral experts in these hubs to evaluate technological solutions, assess their long-term impact, and guide decision-making. - Avoid Transferring Development: Transferring an application from one developer to another is impractical for complex systems. Instead, focus on migrating to alternative solutions if a developer fails to meet requirements. 5. Economic Incentives - Balancing Public and Private Interests: Ensure that funding models allow private companies to grow while serving the public good. - Growth Opportunities: Economic agents should benefit from the expansion of their softwares use across administrations. For example, if an application is adopted by multiple administrations, developers should receive proportional rewards. 6. Education and Open Source Culture - Cultivate Open Source adoption through educationfrom schools to public sector training programs. Hackathons, workshops, and awareness campaigns can help build a culture of collaboration and transparency. - Community Engagement: Encourage public administrations to contribute to Open Source projects and share their developments with the broader community. 7. In-house Development Considerations - Collaborative Approach: In-house development can be effective if multiple administrations (even across EU countries) collaborate. This ensures that solutions are scalable, up-to-date, and aligned with real-world needs. - Avoid Isolation: Isolated in-house projects risk becoming outdated or irrelevant. Collaboration ensures that developments remain practical and beneficial fo
