1. What are the strengths and weaknesses of the EU open-source sector? What are the main barriers that hamper (i) adoption and maintenance of high-quality and secure open source; and (ii) sustainable contributions to open-source communities? The EU's diversity is a strength. The current dependence on US services and Taiwanese microchips is a choke point. The existence of tax havens like Ireland for US tech companies is a weakness, tis should be forbidden. (i) and (ii): a) Lack of legal certainty and protection from prosecution by US patent holders. In the US it is illegal to even try to reverse engineer or modify a proprietary protocol or proprietary software. b) Lack of funding. There are already many European open source and IT independence projects. 2. What is the added value of open source for the public and private sectors? Please provide concrete examples, including the factors (such as cost, risk, lock-in, security, innovation, among others) that are most important to assess the added value. Open source software is great for risk hedging. First, since the code is open for scrutiny, it is less likely to be faulty. But more important, as the user, you have always a way out if the original software maintainer/provider vanishes from the market or misbehaves, e.g., shuts you out, raises licensing fees or similar: you can always copy the code and pay some developers to maintain and enhance it for you, or do it yourself. Exhibit 1: Approx. 3 years ago: A first example is the simple-apps-suite (the orange symbols) for Android phones. The code is open source. The original developer sold his project to some advertisement platform, who started to clutter the apps. Since the code base is open source, other programmers simply maintained the uncluttered version (the green symbols). Exhibit 2: Approx. 10 year ago: Another example is Nextcloud: The project started as Owncloud, but became too commercial, so programmers forked the project and continued as Nextcloud. Now, Owncloud is basically dead, while Nextcloud is the cloud backbone of many European universities and civil administrations. Exhibit 3: Approx. 35 years ago: Linus Torvalds created an operating system kernel, and made it open source. Many smart people contributed. The result is Linux, and today the entire internet runs on Linux servers, basically for free. The Internet would not exist without open source software, but depend on those who are willing to pay for the server software. The list is endless, I stop here. 3. What concrete measures and actions may be taken at EU level to support the development and growth of the EU open-source sector and contribute to the EUs technological sovereignty and cybersecurity agenda? a) Give legal certainty and legal protection to programmers that reverse engineer proprietary protocols. This should not bee illegal. b) Fund existing projects. 4. What technology areas should be prioritised and why? - Europe needs to diversify microchip supply! It would be best to have european chip foundries. - A European cloud solution to eliminate dependence on shaky external providers. - At least in Germany, internet access is somewhat expensive and still very limited, especially in rural regions. 5. In what sectors could an increased use of open source lead to increased competitiveness and cyber resilience? As stated above, the use of open source software gives you independence. You can't be blackmailed, there is no lock in & licensing fee squeeze, and the software is generally of better quality as it is checked by many eyes. This is a universal truth. Therefore, in whatever sector you use more open source software, it becomes more resilient. The more important question is: which sectors are in most need for resilience?

I think the EU should priortize a public service alternative to X. One that politicians and public organisations should be obligated to use and media with public service obligations as well. This should be very well functioning and easy to use and integrate with for other media and journalists and of course the public.

Increasing Europe's prominence in the tech space through FOSS is a major step inte right direction. If European businesses and governments can escape the economic pressure that US tech giants put on them, while also improving cyber security and privacy, it will be a huge win. Increasing competition in a sector ruled by the US will only make things better.

While I strongly agree with the premise of European sovereignty, especially in the current political climate, I want to urge caution in focusing too much on *Europe* and too little on *Open*. European tech is not by definition in the benefit of European citizens. And an European company can easily be sold to a non-European company, see also the current state of Solvinity in the Netherlands (which runs the Dutch government sign-in system DigiD) being sold to an American investor. I believe the true answer to European sovereignty, especially in technology, lies in Open. Specifically, Open Source. European tech can be corrupted, European companies can be sold. But true Open Source can never be taken away from us. Even in the worst case scenario, which is the product no longer receiving maintenance or no longer being on our side, the ability to "fork" (which is the Open Source term to create a derivative version) in the interest of Europe exists. We can always continue development with a new team, without losing all previous investment (something impossible with Closed Source products). Therefore, even investing in foreign Open Source is more safe than investing in European Closed Source, because we keep a certain level of control and the ability to take things back. I would therefore like to urge to, above all, fund Open Source technology. If such Open Source technology is ran by an Europe-based non-profit: even better! But don't reduce funding in Open Source to fund Closed Source European tech. Everything Closed Source, European or not, is *one* foreign investor away from being taken away from us. Only Open Source technology can be saved from attempts of corrupting it into something that works against our needs. Only with Open Source, Europe can truly be sovereign.

Direct funding is very good and should be increased. In addition the software should gain wide adoption by the public sector. Start using the software in the public sector. Buy support from companies that manage the software for us. Pay for features we need or adapt workflows to fit the ideas of the people who knows the software best.

Good Day to whoever might read this feedback, I would love to share some great open source programs that I have already used and that I can recommend. 1) First of the biggest and most important one: Linux based machines! Linux distributions nowadays are just as intuitive and secure as Microsoft's windows solutions, with the big difference that they are free and configurable. It offers full transparency, less bloat, and full control over the system, thereby putting a big emphasis on independent software. 2) For access and identity management I would recommend "Keycloak", it is already widely used and built upon open standards like OAuth2 and OpenID Connect. 3) For data storage, "PostgreSQL" should be an obvious pick for handling data in rational schemes. A full, reliable, enterprise-grade database. 4) In a more and more growing microservice landscape, the use of OpenAPI is essential. It should be utilized as a standard for implementing micro services, aligning them all in a standard, pushing the "develop once, reuse everywhere principle. 5) For messaging, communication and collaboration "Matrix" and "Nextcloud" might be great open-source alternatives to Microsoft services like Teams or SharePoint. 6) For some more security regards I thing following "OWASP" principles would be a good baseline for secure software distribution and development. Updating already existing services to these standards might also solve already persisting security issues. These solutions I already used and can vouch for. On another note, I very much support the idea that the EU as a whole should prioritize open-source. It's a great path and offers a lot of freedom. Another way that I personally not support is the AI-path. It is an amazing technology but not on the right path currently. I'll just leave it at that, this shouldn't be the topic of this feedback. I thank you for the time and the possibility of making my opinion known.

FLOSS is the only way to further the official policy goals of the EU in fields like privacy, human rights, democracy protection, digital sovereignty. 1) The main strength of the FLOSS ecosystem in the EU is a strong foundation of passionate talent, supported by European education institutions and social welfare, united (by the Four Freedoms) in diversity. The main weakness is that the public sector, including the EU, does all it can to sabotage it and to promote foreign special interests like Microsoft and other big tech companies, or wannabe monopolists based in the EU. Pursuing gigantism is self-defeating; the EU is best served by a resilient multitude of small and mid sized entities. 2) The added value is self-evident. Every person, company or public sector office which uses LibreOffice or Thunderbird or a GNU/Linux distribution makes everyone in the EU a little safer by reducing dependencies on USA entities which are inevitably at odds with GDPR. The European Commission cannot do its job when the USA government can shut down its working tools at whim, as it did with the ICC. 3) Just keep doing what worked well. NLnet has funded hundreds of valuable projects with minimal administrative overhead and proven impact. I and my associations use Cryptpad, Codeberg, Thunderbird regularly, for example. This model can and should be be scaled by 10 or 100 times. NLnet alone has done more for the objectives of regulation like GDPR, DSA and DMA than dozens of regulatory agencies combined. The EC should figure out a way to channel billions of euros per year into similar funding mechanisms, extending them to the funding of maintenance projects and bigger ad hoc projects (such as rewrites in safer programming languages) as experimented by the Sovereign Tech Fund. Not only this will produce immediate benefits (the software projects themselves) but it will also produce thousands of developers and entities who may go on to develop viable business models, just like the Silicon Valley was created by Department of Defense funds channeled into permissive FLOSS projects by MIT and other universities. As NGI/NLnet grants can be assigned and spent quickly, they are an opportunity to spend funds left unused in other parts of the EU budget, such as NextGenEU/RRF funds currently stuck in unrealistic projects which are hard to deliver (like infrastructure projects), without having to switch such funds to the bottomless pit of the member states' operating expenses. Grants for FLOSS enrich the EU's and the global knowledge commons and should be thought of as a potential program of a size similar to Erasmus+, 10-50 G over 7 years. 5) No specific sector needs to be prioritised, but instead any project which is pure FLOSS, and which is demonstrably used by public sector bodies for any purpose or by EU citizens to handle their personal data, should be considered eligible. Projects with potential network effects, such as projects working on academic research, on interoperability and open standards, or on the migration of any sort of public sector process or entity from proprietary software to FLOSS (openly released and documented), can have further benefits. Special consideration needs to be given to migration projects, which are very expensive at the beginning and need to be supported for several years before displaying all their benefits. To support the migration of millions of public sector employees and tens of thousands of municipalities, schools etc. away from Microsoft, Google etc., instead of a plethora of small grants it would be more efficient to give a large grant to established EU pure-FLOSS competitors (say Nextcloud, Libreoffice, SUSE, Plausible, OVH, EMS) to be then disbursed to thousands of public sector entities in the form of a discount on migration costs and 5-10 years TCO.

The European Open Digital Ecosystem is central to strengthening the EUs technological sovereignty, security, and competitiveness. Open-source software and open digital assets enable transparency, interoperability, and innovation while reducing dependency on proprietary technologies. They are particularly important for SMEs, which often face resource constraints that limit access to advanced digital tools. By lowering entry barriers and fostering innovation diffusion, open digital ecosystems can drive economic growth and resilience across Europe. The Strategy should align closely with the forthcoming Cloud and AI Development Act (CAIDA) to ensure that cloud infrastructure, AI development, and open digital assets are governed coherently. Open-source AI tools enable auditability, transparency, and accountability, while interoperable cloud infrastructure allows institutions and businesses to access, deploy, and reuse digital assets efficiently. Open digital assets should be treated as strategic public goods that support both SMEs and public administrations. To translate strategy into measurable outcomes, the EU should adopt capability and agency-based assessment frameworks. Inspired by the TPDi AI Agency Framework, these could include: i) Capability mapping: Assessing open-source software, AI models, data assets, governance capacity, and infrastructure readiness. ii) Maturity assessment: Measuring adoption, reuse, interoperability, and accessibility across EU institutions and SMEs. iii) Agency metrics: Evaluating whether actors can control, leverage, and choose digital assets strategically. iv) Power and opportunity indicators: Identifying areas of comparative advantage and high-impact investment potential. These measurement tools enable benchmarking, identification of adoption barriers, and guidance for policy investment, particularly for SMEs. SME inclusion must be a core component of the Strategy. Open digital assets reduce compliance costs, simplify workflows, and foster participation in cross-border digital markets. The EU should support SMEs through capacity building, guidance, and targeted incentives, ensuring that open-source adoption translates into meaningful economic and societal impact. Recommendations: i) Embed capability, maturity, and agency metrics for open digital assets within EU institutions and across member states. ii) Align the Strategy with CAIDA, ensuring coherence across AI, cloud, and open-source policy frameworks. iii) Prioritise SME adoption with targeted guidance, training, and incentives. iv) Promote transparent and reusable digital infrastructure as public goods. v) Monitor outcomes using quantitative and qualitative measures, including economic impact, innovation adoption, and sectoral reach. By embedding capability, maturity, and agency metrics, the European Open Digital Ecosystem Strategy can move beyond symbolic adoption of open digital assets to a practical, measurable framework. This will strengthen EU technological sovereignty, reduce dependency on external providers, and empower SMEs, ensuring that open digital assets deliver real economic, societal, and policy impact across the Union.

Europe depends heavily on foreign technology especially US cloud and software services. This access to and control over our data is concerning, especially when considering that the Trump administration has demonstrated repeatedly that they are willing to exploit economic dependencies to force their policies on other nations. It will be difficult to replace US software services but the open source software model is very well suited for this transition. The need for technological sovereignty is shared by many nations within and outside Europe. Instead of wasting resources by independently developing solutions for the same problems open source allows for collaboration by reusing and extending existing solutions. Additionally private companies face many of the same technological challenges as public institutions and would also benefit from and contribute to the development of these solutions. While a lot of investment into the development of European alternatives is necessary this investment will benefit the domestic economy instead of going to large foreign tech corporations. The open source software development model has been proven extensively as a lot of the foundational software powering the internet and used by most companies and institutions is open source (e.g. Linux, OpenSSL, LLVM, GCC, chromium, etc.). The open source model is also beneficial for security. While being open source in itself does not make software secure, it allows anyone who used to software to audit and improve its security. With closed source software users have to trust the software vendor to ensure security with no way to perform independent audits. Having established open source standards and solutions also makes collaboration easier by reducing fragmentation between incompatible solutions. One of the biggest problems of open source is that the maintainers of widely used software are often overwhelmed and face burn out because they are maintaining these projects in their free time while working a full time job. Providing funding to allow them to make a living by working on open source projects would solve this issue. The EU should heavily invest into the development of open source solutions especially for public administration. Ensuring the independence of public administration is most important and would also serve as an example to other institutions that open source solutions are viable alternatives. Existing regulations for software development (e.g. in aerospace and automotive applications) also need to be adapted to accommodate open source software as in their current form it is often impractical or even impossible to achieve the compliance requirements when using open source solutions. These regulations were often written with the assumption that there exists a single software vendor that develops and sells the software which breaks down when using open source software. Other barriers for open source adoption should also be removed by requiring companies to provide open interfaces to their services. This is especially important companies providing essential services. For example most online banking applications rely on closed source solutions from Apple and Google which means they do not work on alternative open source operating systems. This means it is practically impossible to use these alternatives for most people as they are reliant on these services.

EU is one of the biggest hubs of open source software. And today, for EU to sustain its relevancy in the global market, it should invest in the projects and organizations that produce public domain software and services. This will easily resonate with the community, as we already have the root here. Namely, KDE project, ActivityPub servers (like Mastodon, Pleroma, PeerTube), software registries and git remotes (e.g. SourceHut), NextCloud, Lemmy, etc. The public money should be spent on public software, instead of funneling money into Microsoft, Google and other service providers. Funding FOSS projects is very important for preserving democracy and leveling the playing field for all participants. These programs keep the internet alive, prevents it from becoming an oligopoly market, and provides the means to a democratic environment. Most importantly, privacy and anonymity - which are the basis for free speech - can only achieved by publicly auditable code.

KDE ist in Deutschland ins Leben gerufen worden und hat sich in den letzten 20 Jahren enorm stark entwickelt. Windows sollte in der europäischen Verwaltung durch KDE ersetzt werden. Computer konnten auch damit vorinstalliert sein in den Geschäften. Wäre auch billiger für den Anwender und der Einstieg in Linux ist mit KDE mittlerweile wirklich einfach geworden. KDE finanziell unterstützen hilft uns allen!
feedbackTextUserLanguage: KdE was set up in Germany and has developed enormously over the last 20 years. Windows should be replaced by KdE in the European administration. Computers could therefore also be pre-installed in shops. Would also have been cheaper for the user and the entry into Linux has now become really easy with KdE. The CCC provides financial support to all of us!

feedback: Sehr geehrte Damen und Herren, ich möchte gerne meinen Beitrag leisten und meine Erfahrungen mit drei sinnvollen Open-Source-Programmen teilen: 1.) BigBlueButton BigBlueButton ist ein Tool für Webkonferenzen und wird speziell in der Lehre sowie für Schulungen eingesetzt. Bei meinem aktuellen Arbeitgeber wird es jedoch auch erfolgreich als Ersatz für Microsoft Teams verwendet. Es bietet unter anderem Audio- und Chatfunktionen. Für BigBlueButton ist keine separate App notwendig, da es direkt im Browser genutzt werden kann. 2.) Matrix-Client Matrix ist ein dezentrales Kommunikationstool mit Text-, Sprach- und Videoanrufen sowie Dateiaustausch. Es ist vergleichbar mit WhatsApp oder Slack, legt jedoch einen starken Fokus auf Datenschutz. Das Besondere ist, dass Endnutzer den Chat-Client selbst auswählen und an ihre individuellen Bedürfnisse anpassen können. Würde die EU künftig ein zentrales Protokoll vorschreiben, das auch von SMS und großen Messaging-Diensten genutzt werden muss (z. B. Matrix), könnte ein einzelner Matrix-Client sämtliche Kommunikation abdecken. 3.) Rocket.Chat Rocket.Chat ist ebenfalls eine vielseitige Open-Source-Kommunikationsplattform und kann als echte Alternative zu Slack oder Microsoft Teams angesehen werden. Zu den gängigen Funktionen zählen Gruppen- und Direktnachrichten, Audio- und Videoanrufe, Bildschirmfreigabe, Dateitransfer sowie anpassbare Kanäle. Zum Abschluss möchte ich noch eine Website teilen, die alternative Open-Source Software zu proprietärer Software vorschlägt: opensourcealternative.to Und das wichtigste zum Schluss: bitte keine KI (AI)
feedbackTextUserLanguage: Ladies and Gentlemen, I would like to contribute and share my experience with three useful open source programmes: 1.) BigBlueButton BigBlueButton is a webconference tool used specifically for teaching and training. However, it is also successfully used by my current employer to replace Microsoft Teams. It provides, inter alia, audio and chat functions. BigBlueButton does not require a separate app as it can be used directly in the browser. Matrix Client Matrix is a decentralised communication tool with text, voice and video calls and file exchange. It is similar to WhatsApp or Slack, but with a strong focus on data protection. The special feature is that end-users can choose the chat client themselves and adapt it to their individual needs. If the EU were to impose a central protocol in the future, which would also have to be used by SMS and large messaging services (e.g. matrix), a single matrix client could cover all communications. (3) Rocket.Chat Rocket.Chat is also a versatile open-source communication platform and can be seen as a real alternative to Slack or Microsoft Teams. Common features include group and direct messages, audio and video calls, screen release, file transfer and customisable channels. Finally, I would like to share a website proposing alternative open source software to proprietary software: opensourcealternative.to and the most important conclusion: please do not use AI

feedback: There are multiple reasons for why supporting open-source software has and will continue to be the best thing going forward: - Security, the software can be surveyed and peer-reviewed by anyone for full transparency. Obscuring implementations of security systems is not the same as obscured source code. - Adaptability, open-source software can be adapted for specific uses, either through in-house or outsourced programmers. Making solutions that adapt already recognized software saves both time and money. - Digital sovereignty, reduces the reliance of any one corporation and their nationality or allegiances. Open-source software has no borders when it comes to ownership. - Environmental impact, open-source projects are re-usable and powers nearly every piece of software and hardware made today. If something is doing most anything with video and audio files, it's highly likely that particular software or service uses the open-source software called 'ffmpeg' for instance. Having less open-source projects would make proprietary solutions more common meaning redundant solutions and less standardized implementations. Open-source initiatives also makes software and hardware last longer as they often combat the planned obsolescence of products. There are numerous projects who's goal to give the power back to the users have helped extend the use of electronics far past the creators intent, effectively reducing the e-waste of our age. Examples of this is everything from OpenWRT for unlocking the users networking gear to it's full potential and PostmarketOS which aims to give users a real option to the duopoly of Google and Apple in the phone market, not restricting the life of a smartphone to when the manufacturers want you to buy their next flagship device nor taking away the users agency in right of privacy. In a world that is feeling more isolated and hostile every day, open-source software has always been a collaborative effort held up on the backs of people who want to provide actual solutions and together make things that will help everyone, everywhere. Things that will persist as long as they are needed and then a bit more because they can. It is as much an investment into the future as funding medical and scientific research.

Funding open source infrastructure and communications software is among the cheapest, most cost effective ways Europe can support an open, equitable and competitive Internet for not just the EU citizens, but the world. Allocating more resources to these initiatives would be of great benefit to the Union.

In my opinion any fiscally paid software ought to be free software or at least open source. Instead of paying license costs, investment in free software will pay out in the long run. Not only in costs, but also in sovereignty.

I think the NGI program has been a great succes. Often I came across truly innovative projects and they were founded by NGI. I know quite some EU projects, but these seem to actually have an impact. It helps develop an actual alternative instead of a copy of bigtech solutions. And please, don't go the route of copying the US. DO NOT MAKE AN AI GRANT. Let's be smart, bold and solve actual problems.

Die Initiative verdient nachdrückliche Unterstützung. Doch die Herausforderung liegt nicht allein in der Finanzierung sie liegt z.T. in der Governance der Projekte selbst. Zentrale Schwächen des Open-Source-Sektors: 1. Governance-Defizite: Code-of-Conduct-Komitees in kritischen Projekten (z.B. LLVM) operieren ohne rechtsstaatliche Mindeststandards ohne Gesetzes-Kodifikationen, unabhängige Berufungsinstanzen, ohne transparente Begründungen, ohne Gleichbehandlung. Etablierte Entwickler genießen faktisch Sonderstellung und eine sehr hohe Machtstellung. Die Rule of Law endet nicht an der Grenze des Quellcodes. 2. Politische Fragmentierung: Projekte, die sich technologischen Fragen widmen sollten, werden immer öfter Schauplatz weltanschaulicher Auseinandersetzungen. Dies führt zur Exklusion von Beitragenden aufgrund politischer Präferenzen statt technischer Qualität. 3. Feindseligkeit gegenüber KI-gestützten Beiträgen: Als Nicht-Programmierer mit Domänenwissen habe ich KI-Werkzeuge eingesetzt, um reproduzierbare Leistungsverbesserungen zu identifizieren. Die Reaktion war keine Prüfung des messbaren Mehrwerts, sondern kulturelle Ablehnung. Die Forderung nach vollständiger Code-Ownership als Eintrittskarte statt als Ergebnis kollaborativer Prozesse ist ein technischer Anachronismus, der durch die fortschreitende Qualität von KI-Werkzeugen überholt wird. Hier sollten die Projekte zur Offenheit angehalten werden. 4. Individuelle Kontributoren werden übersehen: Diese Gruppe ist von Fördermechanismen strukturell ausgeschlossen, obwohl sie mit Fehlermeldungen, dem Testen und Code-Beisteuerung das Fundament des Ökosystems bildet. Konkrete Maßnahmen: - Governance-Standards als Fördervoraussetzung: Projekte mit EU-Förderung müssen die Einhaltung elementarer EU-Rechtsgrundsätze nachweisen, z.B. Trennung von Instanzen, begründete Entscheidungen, Recht auf Gehör. - Neutralitätsgebot: EU-Förderung sollte an die Verpflichtung geknüpft werden, Beitragende ausschließlich anhand technischer Qualität zu bewerten und politischen Pluralismus zuzulassen. - Offenheit für KI-Werkzeuge: Entscheidend muss der verifizierbare Mehrwert sein, nicht die Genealogie der Entdeckung. - Individuelle Förderprogramme: Stipendien für Beitragende ohne institutionelle Anbindung. Priorisierter Sektor Öffentliche Verwaltung: Open-Source-First-Prinzip in der Beschaffung: Die Entscheidung für proprietäre Lösungen muss begründungspflichtig werden. Öffentlich finanzierte Software muss unter freien Lizenzen veröffentlicht werden. Fazit: Die Stärkung des Open Source-Sektors ist sehr zu begrüßen, um technologische Souveränität zu gewinnen. Hierbei kann die EU auch neue Impulse setzen, die bislang eine untergeordnete Rolle spielten, etwa was die Rechtsstaatlichkeit der Governance-Strukturen betrifft, die Offenheit gegenüber neuen Beitragsformen und die Anerkennung individueller Beitragender fördern.
feedbackTextUserLanguage:
The initiative deserves strong support. However, the challenge does not lie solely in financing, but in part in the governance of the projects themselves. Key weaknesses of the open source sector: 1. Governance deficits: Code-of-Conduct Committees in critical projects (e.g. LLVM) operate without minimum rule-of-law standards, without legislative codifications, independent appeal bodies, without transparent justifications and without equal treatment. Established developers enjoy a de facto special position and a very high position of power. The rule of law does not end at the limit of the source code. 2. Political fragmentation: Projects that should address technological issues are increasingly becoming the scene of philosophical and non-confessional disputes. This leads to the exclusion of contributors based on political preferences rather than technical quality. 3. Hostility to AI-enab

feedback: When we talk to software there isn't better than open source. I'm long contributor to open source, paid or voluntary. So continue engaging to open source is crucial to the EU, no only that EU should endorse step away from closed source in public administration. Giving money to private company, it doesn't matter they are US or EU based, it's going to work for EU superstition. EU should start involve open and public companies and third parties to accomplished and maintain public administration, having full transparency of all public domains.

Considero fundamental que a União Europeia continue a investir de forma estratégica no financiamento de projetos europeus de software livre e de código aberto. Estes projetos não são apenas motores de inovação tecnológica, mas também pilares essenciais para a construção de uma verdadeira soberania digital europeia. Em particular, é crucial apoiar iniciativas que se afirmem como alternativas credíveis às plataformas dominantes das grandes empresas tecnológicas norte-americanas. O fortalecimento de ecossistemas digitais abertos, interoperáveis e desenvolvidos na Europa contribui para reduzir dependências externas, reforçar a autonomia tecnológica, proteger os dados dos cidadãos e alinhar as infraestruturas digitais com os valores europeus de transparência, concorrência justa e bem comum. O investimento continuado em software livre europeu é, por isso, um investimento estratégico no futuro digital da Europa, na sua resiliência económica e na sua capacidade de decidir de forma autónoma sobre as suas infraestruturas críticas.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: I believe it is crucial that the European Union continues to invest strategically in the financing of European Free and Open Source Software projects. These projects are not only drivers of technological innovation, but also essential pillars for building true European digital sovereignty. In particular, it is crucial to support initiatives that assert themselves as credible alternatives to the dominant platforms of large US tech companies. Strengthening open, interoperable and developed digital ecosystems in Europe contributes to reducing external dependencies, enhancing technological autonomy, protecting citizens’ data and aligning digital infrastructure with European values of transparency, fair competition and common good. Continued investment in European free software is therefore a strategic investment in Europe’s digital future, its economic resilience and its ability to decide autonomously on its critical infrastructure.

feedback: Mówiąc o otwartym oprogramowaniu należy pamiętać także o otwartych standardach struktur danych i interfejsach komunikacyjnych. W przypadku ochrony zdrowia jest to kluczowy aspekt umożliwiający przenoszenie danych medycznych nie tylko w obszarze systemów jednego kraju, interoperacyjność taka zapewniona by była na poziomie całej Unii Europejskiej. Dzięki otwartym standardom struktur danych medycznych, otworzył by się rynek systemów klasy HIS na wiele krajów i ograniczony zostałby efekt monopolu firm dostarczających rozwiązania HIS, pomiędzy którymi, migracja danych jest bardzo utrudniona. Konsekwencją takiego działania stałoby się podniesienie konkurencyjności, ponieważ z powstałyby firmy tworzące nowe oprogramowanie w oparciu nie o własne struktury danych medycznych, a o standardy, które obowiązują wszystkich producentów oprogramowania.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: When talking about open source, open standards for data structures and communication interfaces should also be kept in mind. In the case of health, this is a key aspect of allowing the portability of medical data not only in the area of one country’s systems, and such interoperability would be ensured at the level of the European Union as a whole. Open standards for medical data structures would open up the market for HIS-class systems to many countries and limit the monopoly effect of HIS-providing companies, between which data migration is very difficult. This would result in increased competitiveness, as companies would be created to develop new software based on their own medical data structures, but on standards that apply to all software manufacturers.

feedback: Europa nie może być zależna od obcych firm trzecich. Nie może być zależna od tego, by firma spoza UE mogła jednym przyciśnięciem klawisza zagrozić stabilności europejskiej gospodarki. Dlatego też należy stosować otwarte oprogramowanie, gdzie tylko można. Jego transparentność jest ściśle powiązana z jego bezpieczeństwem i szerokimi możliwościami stosowania. Pracuję na wolnym oprogramowaniu już wiele lat i zachęcam do stosowania innych. Życzyłbym sobie by było ono podstawowym narzędziem w pracy we wszelkiej maści urzędach. To pozwoliłoby na równy dostęp wszystkich podmiotów do możliwości współpracy z instytucjami europejskimi, samorządowymi i rządowymi.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: Europe cannot be dependent on foreign third-party companies. It must not be dependent on a non-EU company being able to threaten the stability of the European economy by pressing one key. Therefore, open source software should be used where it is possible. Its transparency is closely linked to its safety and wide applicability. I have been working on free-source software for many years and I encourage others to do so. I would like it to be an essential tool in all offices. This would allow equal access for all actors to opportunities for cooperation with European, local and regional authorities and governments.

feedback: There are various groups that are intensively engaged with the topic of digital sovereignty. One of these is the working group within the commendIT network. This working group of IT entrepreneurs has now compiled a list of over 90 non-US tools that can replace the IT-mainstream. Anyone who would like to see an overview should visit the following link and request the list: https://www.commendit.de/blog/digitale-souveraenitaet-in-europa-mehr-als-nur-ein-schlagwort/

Medical software systems contain vast amounts of privacy-sensitive data, such as personal details, medical histories, and other sensitive information. The main sources of this data are HIS/EPRs (Hospital Information Systems/Electronic Patient Records) for all personal data, medical notes, disease information, lab results, and other findings, andworking in conjunction or integrated with thesePACS (Picture Archiving and Communication Systems, https://www.postdicom.com/nl/blog/understanding-the-cricital-components-of-pacs) for all medical imaging and its reporting. There are only a few choices available. For HIS/EPRs, there are two major players: EPIC (USA, https://www.epic.com/software/) and Chipsoft HiX (NL, https://www.chipsoft.com/nl-nl/). The European variant HiX offers much less functionality, which is why more and more hospitals are switching to EPIC. EPIC, on the other hand, is a behemoth of a system. While searching online, I came across the following piece: https://zorgictzorgen.nl/de-patient-en-het-ziekenhuisinformatiesysteem-epic-ervaringen/ (Dutch), which may provide more insight. Doctors are not IT specialists and do not have the time (or mental bandwidth) to attend lengthy courses to learn all the software systems or to sit down and study them at their leisure. Older doctors, in particular, must be able to use these systems, but in practice, this is currently not the case. Then there are PACS. These are systems where images from radiology, among other sources, are stored in so-called DICOM files. In these software programmes, images are viewed and reported on by radiologists, nuclear medicine physicians, and other medical professionals. Since imaging is already widely used and increasingly so, these systems also contain large amounts of sensitive data. There are more players in this field, with Sectra (SE, https://medical.sectra.com/) being the largest: https://klasresearch.com/report/europe-pacs-2022-technology-and-partnership-crucial-in-evolving-market/1685. In addition, there are several American (GE, Change, IBM) and Asian (Fujifilm, INFINITT) competitors holding parts of the market. Finally, due to the fragmentation of systems, sharing data between different hospitals is extremely cumbersome. For sharing radiology images, several Dutch hospitals are connected to TWIIN (NL, https://www.twiin.nl/). For this, an IT staff member or radiology technician must manually click and upload each patients images, one by one, for each study (every single X-ray separately!). But if, for example, a German patient has an accident in the Netherlands and a CT scan is performed, and the patient is then transferred to a hospital in Germany, these images cannot be easily and securely shared digitally with the German hospital. A letter with the patients medical history and written results of imaging is printed on paper and given to the ambulance transporting the patient to Germany. But the radiology images? Well, the IT dept. does have a CD burner somewhere, but they wont be available again until Monday... In short, it is time for a European open-source HIS/EPR system and PACS, with a focus on security, functionality, speed, intuitive workflow, and the ability to communicate quickly and easily with other European medical centers.

Je propose ce chemin pour une indépendance informatique : 1) Assurer une conservation de l'information à très long terme, et sa protection, immédiatement (dans l'année) - N'autoriser l'usage dans la totalité des institutions publiques que de formats ouverts et libres avec une liste fermée de formats/protocoles, aussi bien pour les formats de documents (Le RGI français actuel est une très bonne base de départ) que les protocoles de communications (IMAP, SMTP pour les emails, HTML5 pour les formats web (strictement le standard et interdire toute extension Google Chrome), et les plateformes logicielles (visio-conférence). 2) Fermer l'extraction de donnée (dans les deux ans) - Taxer à 1% du chiffre d'affaires, toute entité qui opère un service Internet (y compris pour mobile, y compris juste en interne), pour financer l'effort de colmatage de la fuite des données de ses utilisateurs. Si une société demande à être certifiée pour être dispensée de cette taxe, la certification est gratuite, mais en cas d'échec, la taxe est doublée pour l'année. Exemple de fuite généralisée: les services mobiles bancaires qui imposent de télécharger l'application sur le Google ou App Store et qui ne fonctionnent que sur des téléphones laissant fuiter de nombreuses informations personnelles dont la localisation. 3) Assurer les services de bases (2 ans) - Fournir un email à vie garantie à chaque citoyen. Que ce soit purement gratuit (idéal) ou à très faible coût (1 ou 2 euros par mois, comme le fait posteo.de ?). Cet email personnel devra être maintenu par des institutions qui sont habilitées à vérifier l'identité d'une personne pour la maintenance (perte d'email, de mot de passe, ...). Pour la France, je pense typiquement à "La Poste" et aux mairies. - Interdire la vente de téléphones mobiles dont il n'est pas facile de remplacer le système d'exploitation par un système libre. Idéalement, financer le portage et la maintenance de plusieurs de ces systèmes sur l'ensemble des téléphones vendus en Europe, pour 10 ans (et pas uniquement une souche Android). Faire financer cet effort par une taxe de 10% sur chaque vente de téléphone. Cette taxe sera revue à la baisse si le coût de portage/maintenance diminue (les industriels devenant vertueux). - Déployer des services fédérés partout capables de remplacer les services centralisés connus (Mastodon, PeerTube, les multiples réseaux sociaux libres, XMPP, Matrix). Ces services fédérés ont le gros avantage de pouvoir être opérés simultanément par plusieurs entités locales, nationales ou européennes et donc déployé au fil de l'eau (bibliothèques, mairie, chaine de télévision, chaine de radio, régions, pays) 4) S'extraire de la dépendance dans les ordinateurs classiques (5 ans) Déployer des GNU/Linux partout sur les ordinateurs professionnels de l'UE (plus simple après les étapes 1 et 2). Favoriser le déploiement sur les ordinateurs personnels en fournissant un service de support de proximité (les mairies, La Poste, les Régions)

feedback: L'open source s'est fortement développé dans les environnements serveurs : Linux fait tourner +96% des serveurs de la planète. Ce mouvement doit s'appliquer maintenant sur les ordinateurs personnels, qui d'une part nous coûtent une fortune en obsolescence, licences privatives, dépendance, insécurité personnelle et technique, et d'autre part constituent un verrou au changement de mentalité. C'est une urgence. Avec les PC libérés, sans doute que les utilisaeurs y penseront aussi pour leurs téléphones. Il faut aussi bien entendu privilégier l'usage des logiciels libres dans l'administration, et en général partout pour le logiciel est financé par de l'argent public. C'est uniquement une question de volonté politique : une infime quantité d'utilisateurs a besoin d'outils bureautiques super-evolués. L'impact sur la productivité ne peut être que positif.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: Open source has developed strongly in server environments: Linux runs + 96 % of the world’s servers. This movement must now apply to personal computers, which, on the one hand, cost us a fortune in obsolescence, private licences, dependence, personal and technical insecurity and, on the other hand, are a barrier to a change in mentality. This is a matter of urgency. With the PCs released, users will probably also think about them for their phones. Of course, the use of open source software should also be favoured in the administration, and generally everywhere for the software is financed by public money. It is only a matter of political will: a tiny number of users need super-evoluted office tools. The impact on productivity can only be positive.

feedback: Molti feedback si stanno concentrando sulla potenza di Apple e Google a livello di smartphone. Questo è innegabile, ma credo ci sia un altro aspetto poco tenuto in considerazione e che voglio far presente. A livello di servizi pubblici (amministrazione, scuole, università, ospedali, servizi sanitari ecc) si utilizzano spesso servizi di outsourcing affidandosi a software privati e con sistemi chiusi. Faccio un esempio concreto per evidenziare l'importanza di adottare strumenti open source a livello pubblico. Lavoro in ambito di formazione e di istituzioni scolastiche e quindi porto la mia esperienza. Nelle scuole i servizi di Google Workspace for Education sono tra i più utilizzati al mondo. Perché a livello UE non decidiamo di sviluppare software open per la scuola che siano modulabili in base alle esigenze delle scuole stesse? Perché non si decide di risparmiare i soldi spesi in outsourcing per servizi di questo tipo, per finanziare dei team di sviluppo interni alle nazioni che fanno parte dell'UE e che possono personalizzare in base alle caratteristiche delle scuole nazionali i software open in uso nella comunità europea? Sicuramente non basteranno a coprire le spese, ma sarebbe già un modo per concepire in maniera innovativa la gestione dei servizi pubblici, partendo proprio dallo sviluppo software. Ho visto in alcuni comuni italiani che si decideva di utilizzare LibreOffice o OpenOffice, ma poi sottobanco si acquistavano licenze Microsoft 365 perché i programmi open non erano stabili e non performanti. Perché non investiamo nel miglioramento di tali software open al fine di renderli utilizzabili nella pubblica amministrazione in base ai feedback raccolti all'interno degli ambiti di lavoro della PA? Anche qui, risparmiamo dai costi di abbonamento degli SaaS di Microsoft per sostenere l'Open Source. Non ho le competenze per dire quanta differenza ci possa essere tra la cifra utilizzata in outsourcing in UE per sevizi della PA, rispetto al sostentamento di software open che vada a rimpiazzare quello privato, ma se si vuole fare un investimento in direzione differente rispetto a quanto vige ora sul mercato del digitale, questa può essere una direzione. Tra l'altro PA in Europa e software open source hanno una matrice comune e cioè che il bene pubblico rientra nelle responsabilità dei servizi che i cittadini pagano attraverso le proprie tasse e non da interessi privati.

Many feedback is focusing on the power of Apple and Google at smartphone level. This is undeniable, but I think there is another aspect that I do not take into account and that I want to point out. At the level of public services (administration, schools, universities, hospitals, health services, etc.), outsourcing services are often used using private software and closed systems. I take a concrete example to highlight the importance of adopting open-source tools at the public level. I work in training and educational institutions and therefore bring my experience. In schools, Google Workspace for Education services are among the most used in the world. Why do we not decide at EU level to develop open software for schools that can be modulated according to the needs of the schools themselves? Why is it not decided to save money spent on outsourcing for such services, to finance development teams within the nations that are part of the EU and that can customise the open software used in the European community according to the characteristics of national schools? They will certainly not be enough to cover expenditure, but it would already be a way of designing the management of public services in an innovative way, starting with software development. feedback: Ich bin hobbymäßig in der Open Source Community aktiv. Es gibt mehrere Herausforderungen, eine der größten ist die Pflege tausender sogenannter Abhängigkeiten (Bibliotheken, libraries), die von anderer Software verwendet werden können und die der Endanwender deshalb nie zu Gesicht bekommt. Oft werden sie von einer einzigen Person ehrenamtlich entwickelt, während sie tausendfach, ja millionenfach wiederverwendet werden. Software muss aber aktiv weiter entwickelt werden, um Bugs und Sicherheitslücken zu schließen, neue Funktionen hinzuzufügen und Leistungsoptimierungen hinzuzufügen, das schafft einer alleine oft nicht. Angreifer könne dies wie bei der gerade noch verhinderten xz utils Hintertür ausnutzen, womit Millionen Systeme plötzlich angreifbar werden, sogenannte supply chain Angriffe. Wie bei physischen Produkten gibt es eine Art "Software Lieferkette", kleine Projekte (Abhängigkeiten, libraries) die zum Endprodukt zusammen gesetzt werden, wobei die am Anfang der Kette oft zu kurz kommen. Hier bräuchte es verstärkte Förderung für alle weit verbreiteten und doch von wenigen unterhalten Projekte, etwa finanziell und/oder durch einen Entwickler. Darüber hinaus ist uns wichtig, dass man unsere Software nicht nur für Freiheit und Unabhängigkeit lobt, sondern sie auch nutzt. Was ich grundsätzlich empfehlen kann, ist die Loslösung von Microsoft Windows und deren Bürosoftware. Hauptgrund dafür ist volle Kontrolle über das System. Man ist nicht mehr in einer Bredouille wegen dem US Cloud Act, geheimdienstlicher, serverseitiger Spionage und Hintertüren. Konkret empfehlen kann ich Linux mit der Desktop-Umgebung KDE Plasma + LibreOffice als Bürosoftware. Ich habe sehr gute Erfahrungen damit gemacht. Sie laufen zuverlässig, effizient und datenschutzfreundlich. Ich persönlich mag zudem die Benutzeroberfläche und Bedingung deutlich lieber, sie sehen für meinen Geschmack schöner/moderner aus, reagieren schneller und machen insgesamt einfach mehr Spaß. Wenn man sich von Windows lösen will ist es sehr wichtig zunächst auf Anwendungsebene die Umstellung zu machen, da es gewisse Anwendungen nicht für Linux gibt und es eine Überforderung für die Anwender ist, Betriebssystem und alle Anwendungen auf einmal umgestellt zu bekommen. Das verursacht Frust und wird im Zweifel auf das neue System geschoben. Die Umstellung an sich ist das teure, aufwändige, danach hat man aber großes Einsparpotential + Souveränität. Nicht aufgeben, alle zusammen arbeiten anstatt jeder seine eigene Lösung zu entwickeln ist hier entscheidend. Man sollte einheitliche Standards setzen wie etwa das ODF Format für den Austausch von Dokumenten zwischen Behörden und möglichst einheitliche Standards für Server-Schnittstellen, damit etwa Behörden länderübergreifend besser kommunizieren können - falls man das möchte.
feedbackTextUserLanguage:
I am a hobbyist in the Open Source Community. There are several challenges, one of the biggest is the care of thousands of so-called dependencies (libraries, libraries) that can be used by other software and that the end-user therefore never sees. They are often developed by a single person on a voluntary basis, while being reused thousands or even millions of times. However, software needs to be actively further developed to close bugs and vulnerabilities, add new functionalities and add performance optimisations, which one alone often does not achieve. As with the xz utile backdoor, which has just been prevented, attackers can exploit this, making millions of systems suddenly vulnerable, so-called supply chain attacks. As with physical products, there is a kind of ‘software supply chain’, small projects (dependencies, libraries) that are brought together into the final product, with those at the beginning of the chain often falling short. In this context,

feedback: Thank you for letting me give you feedback on this important matter. The first thing i would like EU to do is to promote the usage of Open Standards that everywhere. Transport protocols: IMAP, SMTP, HTTP, ICAL, VCARD, etc. Document formats: Open Document Format (for text, presentations, spreadsheets, graphics) Also promote the usage of Linux, for example the Ubuntu distribution. EU could also maintain its own distribution. Linux is already the most used operating system when you install a server, but we in EU need to start using Linux also on the desktop. (stop using Windows or IOS) Nowadays it is as easy to learn (if not easier) then Windows or IOS. We also need to build a Linux-based EU phone (or promote one of the existing Linux phones). AND build a app ecosystem around that phone. The EU project DC4EU (that build a digital Wallet) should work with this phone. We should also build our own social network platforms (the same way Russia and China have done) So we can stop using: Facebook, X, instagram, whatsapp, tok-tok, ...

Utilisateur de lOpen Source depuis de nombreuses années, il est temps que lEurope se soucie de ce secteur. Mais essayer dacquérir notre souveraineté numérique au niveau logiciel sera un coup d'épée dans leau si lEurope na pas aussi son indépendance sur la conception et la fabrication des composants électroniques.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: A user of lopen Source for many years, it is time for Europe to care about this sector. But trying to acquire our digital sovereignty at software level will be a wake-up call if Europe does not also have its independence in the design and manufacture of electronic components.

feedback: Für den Großteil der alltäglichen Computertätigkeiten ist ein volles Open-Source-System (Linux mit Libreoffice, Firefox, Thunderbird mit eigenem Mailserver, Nextcloud usw.) wesentlich effizienter als kommerzielle Lösungen. Leider gibt es einen Lock-In, der mich in unerwünschte Abhängigkeiten zwingt. Erstens, dass bestimmte professionelle Software (etwa Adobe Creative Suite) nur für Windows oder Apple erhältlich ist und ich daher immer einen Windows-Rechner vorhalten muss. Zweitens (und das ist viel schlimmer), dass auch eine Universität, an der ich aktiv bin, erst vor wenigen Monaten von Open-Source-Lösungen auf MS365 umgestiegen ist und sich neu in eine gefährliche Abhängigkeit begeben hat. Es ist verheerend, wenn gerade Bildungseinrichtungen wie Universitäten oder Schulen in diese Abhängigkeit gezwungen werden. Zudem versagen sie dabei in ihrem Bildungsauftrag, wenn Schüler bzw. Studenten keine Kompetenzen im Umgang mit Open Source vermittelt werden. Es wäre dringend nötig, dass zumindest für öffentliche Einrichtungen oder Einrichtungen mit öffentlicher Föderung gilt: 1. Keinesfalls darf ein Wechsel von bestehenden Open-Source-Lösungen zu kommerziellen Produkten stattfinden. 2. Kommerzielle Produkte sollten baldmöglichst durch Open Source ersetzt werden 3. Bei kommerziellen Lösungen sind US-Produkte abzulehnen, wenn es europäische Alternativen gibt. Es braucht außerdem eine intensive staatliche Förderung europäischer Open-Source-Produkte.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: For most of the everyday computer activities, a full open source system (Linux with LibreOffice, Firefox, Thunderbird with its own mail server, Nextcloud, etc.) is much more efficient than commercial solutions. Unfortunately, there is a lock-in that forces me into unwanted dependencies. First, that certain professional software (such as Adobe Creative Suite) is only available for Windows or Apple and I must therefore always have a Windows calculator. Secondly (and this is much worse) that even a university where I am active only a few months ago moved from open-source solutions to MS365 and moved to a dangerous dependency. It is devastating to force educational institutions such as universities or schools into this dependence. They also fail in their educational mission if pupils or students are not given skills in using open source. There is an urgent need to apply at least to public bodies or bodies with a public federation: 1. Under no circumstances should there be a switch from existing open-source solutions to commercial products. 2. Commercial products should be replaced by open source as soon as possible 3. For commercial solutions, US products should be rejected if European alternatives exist. There is also a need for strong public support for European open-source products.

feedback: Ottima iniziativa, ma non credo il sistema per l'invio di feedback sia il massimo della praticità: di fatto, credo scoraggi buona parte delle persone interessate a contribuire. L'Europa deve affrancarsi dalla dipendenza tecnologica da partner ormai, inaffidabili: sistemi operativi, software, cloud, git, tutto dovrebbe essere gestito all'interno della Comunità, evitando di foraggiare anche economicamente attori esterni. Anche la partecipazione istituzionale nei social dovrebbe rifarsi a strutture gestibili autonomamente: penso a una qualche incarnazione del Fediverso, sottostare ancora ai capricci di miliardari e multinazionali è di un'assurdità evidente, eppure sembra che ai piani alti non ce ne si accorga.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: Very good initiative, but I do not think the feedback system is as practical as possible: in fact, I think it discourages a large proportion of those interested in contributing. Europe must move away from technological dependence on partners that are now unreliable: operating systems, software, cloud, GIT, everything should be managed within the Community, avoiding forging external actors also economically. Institutional participation in social media should also be based on autonomously manageable structures: I think of some sort of embodiment of the Fediverse, still falling under the umbrella of billionaires and multinationals is a clear absurdity, yet it seems that at high levels there is no such absurdity.

feedback: Great initiative!
Dear all please find my feedback in the attached document. Kind regards

Please see attached document. Below the executive summary. Executive Summary Europe has become a rule-maker in the digital domain, but much of the underlying infrastructure that executes those rules remains non-European and highly concentrated. This creates a practical sovereignty gap: policy ambition depends on systems Europe does not fully control. The Commissions initiative is timely because open source can increase auditability, reduce lock-in, and improve supply chain transparency, but openness alone does not guarantee sovereignty. Sovereignty becomes real when governance, operational control, and credible exit paths are designed into the infrastructure. The European Decentralisation Institute (EDI) recommends a compact set of measures that convert Europes open-source strength into scalable, secure, and deployable capabilities across cloud and edge, AI, cybersecurity, open hardware, and industrial platforms. The core idea is simple: use EU policy and funding to make open, interoperable, and verifiable building blocks cheaper to adopt than proprietary lock-in. Pair that with governance standards, long-term maintenance funding, and procurement practices that measure exit costs and systemic risk. Key recommendations (high impact, near-term) · Make interoperability and portability testable: fund open test suites and conformance labs for cloud, data, and AI stacks. · Shift procurement incentives: require an exit and auditability scorecard for public sector IT and EU-funded deployments. · Fund maintenance as infrastructure: create multi-year support for critical open-source dependencies, security audits, and incident response. · Strengthen governance by design: set minimum governance criteria for strategic open projects used in critical sectors. · Back European foundation infrastructure: repositories, package registries, CI/CD tooling, and sovereign hosting options under EU jurisdiction. · Use blended finance to scale EU open-source firms: crowd-in private capital while preserving open licensing and community stewardship.

feedback: I have always supported open-source! So this is a great initative.

Within the EU we have to reduce the dependency on non-eu made software. This can be done by supporting open source software. We should start on two main categories. The operating software and the so called office software. For the operating software I would suggest Linux Mint as the usage is quite similar to the well known software from Microsoft. For the office software I would suggest Softmaker Office or Libre Office. If we achieve a significant move within this two categories, a solide base for ongoing transmission will be possible.

Beware of introduction and maintenance costs. In practice, open source software is the only reliable path to achieve digital software sovereignty at the moment, but it has significant cost of maintenance. Currently, the easiest way to adopt open source software is to leverage most popular, accessible and supported GNU/Linux distributions such as Ubuntu, Debian, Fedora, SuSE. The fact that vital development is still carried out in United States is not problematic for open source software. The problem is that the most of the supported distributions adopted very specific solution for software distribution. Speaking with extreme simplification, it basically requires rebuilding entire catalog of supported software for each individual release. For the core software components this process is entirely automated. Given the example, each Ubuntu release (20.04, 22.04, 22.10 etc) has its very own unique version of e.g. PostrgreSQL database server and running it in later of older version may be impossible or unstable. This leads to quick adoption of new technologies and quick reduction of technological debt and security vulnerabilities, but is also creates a large maintenance requirement and additional costs for individual software developers (including companies or individual country institutions). Those developers would have to ensure that their software is supported on every major supported distribution version. Locking them on particular release will deprecate them quickly and create a security risks. Assumption that local companies providing software for local needs (e.g. country specific invoice software) will share their source and delegate maintenance is dystopian, unrealistic and will be considered as a business risk. GNU/Linux distributions now try to adopt new software distribution solutions called Flatpak/Snap, which technically, should remove the burden of maintaining per-variant per-version support matrix, but this solution haven't matured yet and have numerous other limitations, especially related to inability to ship with hardware drivers modules. On the contrary, Windows operating system (driven by Microsoft, USA) has been well known for its backward compatibility. Enormous amount of software developed and build 5, 10, 15 years ago will work properly on latest versions (10, 11 including not yet released) with zero to minimal effort which usually means installing specific version of core dependency (msvc runtime). Linux distributions may break that promise in a single year. The point is that I highly agree with leveraging open source solutions and software, but adopters who are non opensource software developers must be ready to face the significant costs of introduction and change in their software release and distribution practice. This aspect must be evaluated.

As a technology risk professional, as well as an open technology enthusiast, I would consider the accelerated adoption of open source solutions by the EU as potentially beneficial for three reasons: 1. De-risking Europe's technology supply chains (especially as they relate to critical infrastructure) by switching from "key vendors" to "key interoperable standards" that can be operated by many vendors (avoiding vendor lock-in). 2. Such vendors (acting primarily as operators - administration and support) could, of course, be EU-based. With broader adoption, more such vendors would be required, creating regional growth opportunities in the tech sector. 3. Maturing the open source ecosystem in a well-coordinated fashion, by sharing costs and reusing software across the EU. In alignment with the "Public Money, Public Code" principle, funds would be used to create a shared public resource, and potentially help each member state save on individual proprietary licensing costs. I am convinced that, with the EU's appropriate support and long-term commitment, embracing open source is the most sustainable, resilient, and transparent path forward for a more sovereign public digital ecosystem.

While the Commissions focus on open-source software (OSS) is vital, digital sovereignty is fundamentally limited by the hardware on which that software runs. Software is only as "open" and secure as the underlying silicon. Currently, European software excellence is often built upon proprietary "black-box" hardware, creating a critical vulnerability in our digital infrastructure. To achieve true technological sovereignty, the 2026 Strategy must treat Open-Source Hardware (OSH) as a primary pillar. ​1. The "Silicon Black Box" as a Barrier to Security Proprietary hardware architectures often contain closed microcode and undocumented features. No matter how transparent the open-source software stack is, it cannot verify the integrity of the execution environment if the hardware remains opaque. This creates "hidden" vendor lock-ins and security risks that undermine the Cyber Resilience Act's goals. ​Recommendation: Prioritize the development of transparent, verifiable European hardware based on open Instruction Set Architectures (ISAs) like RISC-V. ​2. Addressing the "Valley of Death" in Hardware Manufacturing As noted in the Call for Evidence, Europe struggles to move from research to market. In hardware, this "valley of death" is wider due to the extreme costs of physical implementation. ​PDK Accessibility: Most foundries require proprietary Process Design Kits (PDKs). Without open PDKs, European SMEs cannot design truly open chips without signing restrictive NDAs that contradict open-source principles. ​NRE Costs: The Non-Recurring Engineering (NRE) costs for mask sets and EDA (Electronic Design Automation) tools are prohibitive. ​Recommendation: The EU should fund "Open Foundries" and the development of open-source EDA toolchains to lower the entry barrier for European hardware startups. ​3. Strategic Priority Areas: RISC-V and the Edge To maximize impact, the EU should focus on areas where we have industrial strength: ​Automotive and Industrial IoT: These sectors require long-term stability and security. Open hardware ensures that European manufacturers are not dependent on the lifecycle or licensing whims of non-EU chip designers. ​Edge Computing: By controlling the hardware at the "edge," Europe can ensure data privacy and sovereignty at the point of origin. ​4. Concrete Measures for the 2026 Strategy ​Public Procurement: Mandate that publicly funded digital infrastructure prioritize hardware that uses open standards and provides verifiable, open-source firmware/microcode. ​Sustenance Funding: Shift from "one-off" research grants to supporting the long-term maintenance of open hardware IP (Intellectual Property) to ensure industrial-grade reliability. ​Certification: Create a "European Open Hardware" label that certifies a products transparency from the physical gate level up to the application layer. ​ If the foundation is proprietary, the ecosystem is not truly open. By incentivizing a robust European Open-Source Hardware ecosystem, the Commission can ensure that our digital sovereignty is built on solid, verifiable ground rather than rented infrastructure.

The vast majority of open source software currently resides on GitHub, which is owned and controlled by Microsoft. As such, it is subject to their whims. It currently offers a very generous free plan that allows for private repositories, and even something like 2000 minutes of free monthly compute for automated CI workflows. The trade is that Microsoft gets data. Microsoft can at any point change the service or shut it down. You could say some EULA prevents this but we've seen how far the law in US goes in the past year. If EU wishes to have an independent open source sector, it first needs its own GitHub rival. It needs to have the same or better features, be just as easy to use across operating systems, integrate well with Git UIs like GitKraken, Fork, SourceTree, Sublime Merge, as well as IDEs like VSCode, Visual Studio, Xcode, JetBrains, or at least as well as GitHub does. The added value of open source is undeniable. The entire web is built on open source technologies. They accelerate development of new products and enable the products built on it to profit from improvements other users submit. Just look at all the open source web frameworks which run all the websites being created nowadays. Look at all the open source codecs released by Xiph and how they power the media delivery of pretty much the entire internet and have been doing so for the past few decades. Look at how JUCE has transformed the music industry by enabling more people to create audio software, which has in turn enabled artists to create better-sounding music. It created massive competition, which ultimately resulted in the prices of audio software being so low the barrier to entry is basically $100 and owning a computer built in the last decade. Look at how France's GRAME is pushing the envelope with FAUST to absolutely trivialize writing DSP and shipping it on as many platforms as possible. When EU creates its own GitHub, called GitOutOfGreenland or however it ends up being called, there should be some sort program to stimulate EU developers (and wider) to move their repositories here. Whether it'll be compute, security and privacy guarantees, guarantees of service life, some recognition blog where you'll spotlight the most active developers which will further encourage them as it could have tremendous impact on their career, etc. The absolute focus of any EU-level initiative to then start working on open source software to deploy here should be some sort of country-level management software. The idea would be that in an ideal situation, all EU countries end up using this instead of their own in-house software. This is just a shell, they would need to populate it with their own data, but one improvement shipped could then be merged by individual countries and they could all benefit from it. I'm in Croatia and Croatia has e-Građani, which is pretty great. There's a lot of bugs still, and stupid design decisions, but it is working pretty well. If it were based on an EU-level framework for governments, I could go in and fix the bugs I encountered myself, verify the fix and submit a pull request which you could then choose to merge. Croatia could then choose to pull the new merge and have its software updated this way. As for the sectors that would benefit most from increased competitiveness due to increased use of open source, it would definitely be accounting and any business management software. There's an insane amount of churn in accounting companies, with dozens of different software companies providing the software. This way all laws for all countries could be tracked in a single place, updated for changes. It would allow accounting offices and accounting divisions to move much faster, share knowledge with each other across the country and across the EU, law divisions to speed up implementations of new directives where everyone is looking at the same data and same workflow

For the moment, Apple and Google, for example, have de facto to paralyse the power of virtually all smartphones or their services (including banking, etc.). Apple and Google often argue with ‘security’ that their ecosystem is closed. The big downside is the transfer of power from the consumer to the foreign group. We need to move away from this. IoT, desktops, servers and Co. are other candidates that we should not leave to the control of other powers. Otherwise, we can be extorted to the maximum extent possible. Transposition is not straightforward, but, in my view, there is no alternative.

feedback: I am Dries Buytaert, founder and project lead of Drupal, one of the largest open-source content management systems in the world. Drupal powers government websites across Europe, including sites for the European Commission itself and is at the core of initiatives such as Open Europa and the Europa Communities Platform. I have spent over twenty years building and studying open-source communities, including developing systems to measure and reward contribution. I welcome this initiative and want to highlight one concrete measure that could strengthen the EU open-source sector: making contribution back into the open-source ecosystem a criterion in public procurement. Currently, when governments purchase open-source services, contracts often go to vendors who resell open-source software but do not help maintain it. This undermines the sustainability of the projects governments depend on and means public money does not strengthen public digital infrastructure. A better approach would give procurement advantage to vendors who actively contribute to the open-source projects they sell through code, documentation, security work, and/or financial support. I have written in more detail about this proposal on my blog: https://dri.es/funding-open-source-for-digital-sovereignty Thank you for your consideration.

The entire discussion about "business models" which will allow future welfare is missing in the paper and with this not only competitiveness or reliable generation responsibilities are not given. Further more the EU should take a different role in sense of keeping open rules vs. trying to determine what the can not deliver.

feedback: 1.a. Strengths: 1.a.1 opportunity: Thanks to solid residential infrastructure, a well educated population, low technology restrictions and generous social welfare programs. Many people can contribute and develop it further. 1.a.2. Lawfull protection. Many of the laws the EU implements in the context technology enforce either things the open source sector was already doing and/or leave the weak open source projects out of it. This, while they often greatly limit other players. 1.b.Weaknesses 1.b.1. Capital access: open source never had great access to the capital markets, due to weak ip and vendor lockin. In the EU this doesn't really get much better. 1.b.2 Lawfull understanding: the EU's open source ecosystem is pretty aimed at USA and Indian law, while EU law is mostly skipped. Even english law is considered more. 1.b.3 Moderation: protection against online harassment can be very lacking leading to maintainer burnout(examples: xz attack and sloptracker.) 2. added value 2.a public sector 2.a.1 promotes accountability. If one publishes their source code its easy to check if one is following most laws involved(also why open source projects don't really suffer from most transparency laws). 2.a.2 High impact. Due to the reasons in point b open source projects tend to be when adopted to get adopted very widely. 2.a.3 promotes competition. Open standards flow naturally from having access to the entire api of popular applications available. Standards promote competition by lowering migration costs. 3.a.4 easy to steer. One can just make a fork if one wants something different and even the most powerfull open source projects can't dodge the law. 2.b. private sector 2.b.1 cheap, due to competition. 2.b.2 neutral, because one knows they can always fork if they disagree. 3.concrete actions 3.a sovereignty 3.a.1 Promote and enable open standards. If you want more compatibility simply publish your api expectations and the open source developers will follow suit. A great American example of this is POSIX, which really was just a shopping list from the DOD. 3.b security The open source security philosophy is completely different from the proprietary one. In open source trust and security flows from the code. In proprietary security it flows from the developer. 3.b.1 check the source. C 3.b.2 publish the source. Ask and/or demand clarity and auditability beyond what your open source projects are already offering you. Have them generate mock data from auditable code and data. Demand standardized explanation of relevance in commits. Have someone generate signed machine readable access manifests for code that matters to you. 4.Technology areas to be prioritized I will focus on technologies declared as strategic by the commission. 4.1. cybersecurity. This is a high information, high human capital and low venture capital product and as such a place where open source really shines. 4.2. chip development, because although building a full sovereign manufacturing chain can't be done alone, but it can be done together. We already make the machines, which don't benefit nearly as much from open source. The designs and the ecosystem can totally 4.3. AI. Going from CUDA to openCL would break, so much of the foreign hold on this sector. 5. Benefiting sectors. 5.1. Health care. Health care tech is notorious for its consumer hostile behavior and unused, but functional projects. 5.2. Education. Education is notorious for being the start of vendor lockins lasting a lifetime.

Es war höchste Zeit, dass auch die Gesetzgeber erkennen, dass der Anteil an Open-Source-Software erhöht werden muss. Eine solche Maßnahme lässt sich ohne Weiteres im Bereich der öffentlichen Verwaltung umsetzen. Gemeindeverwaltungen, Schulen, Internate, Krankenhäuser, Streitkräfte, karitative Organisationen und Kirchen sind alles Bereiche, in denen der Einsatz kommerzieller Software entbehrlich oder zumindest nur in eingeschränktem Umfang erforderlich wäre. Heute können die Software- und Netzwerkbedürfnisse dieser Bereiche vollständig durch freie Software abgedeckt werden, die kosteneffizientere, unabhängigere, schnellere und sicherere Lösungen bietet als proprietäre Produkte. Von der derzeitigen Situation profitieren ausschließlich große US-amerikanische Konzerne. Die Gewinne werden dort realisiert, und diese Unternehmen nutzen ihre Marktmacht häufig aus, um Entscheidungsprozesse zu ihren Gunsten zu beeinflussen. Darüber hinaus sind ihre Datenschutzstandards oftmals nicht so streng, wie man sie in Europa erwarten würde. Ich, persönlich nutze seit vielen Jahren ausschließlich das ungarische Betriebssystem und die Softwarelösungen von blackPantherOS, die eine stabile Arbeitsumgebung, eine sorgfältig kuratierte Auswahl an Anwendungen, hohe Sicherheit sowie umfassende Lösungen für sämtliche Herausforderungen bieten sei es im Bereich der Publikationsgestaltung, der Notensatzbearbeitung, der Dokumentenverwaltung oder der Cloud-Synchronisierung. Besonders besorgniserregend und meines Erachtens rechtswidrig ist jedoch, dass bestimmte Unternehmen oder gesetzliche Bestimmungen die Nutzer faktisch zum Einsatz von Microsoft-Produkten zwingen. Dies führt dazu, dass ich in einigen Fällen Kompromisse eingehen muss so ist es mir beispielsweise nicht möglich, Dienste wie TelekomTVGo oder SkyShowTime zu nutzen. Die betreffenden Anbieter zeigen keinerlei Interesse an dieser Problematik und behindern gezielt die Nutzung alternativer Lösungen. Gegen derartige Praktiken sollte die Europäische Union mit geeigneten gesetzlichen Maßnahmen entschieden vorgehen.
