However, it is particularly worrying and, in my view, unlawful that certain undertakings or statutory provisions de facto compel users to use Microsoft products. As a result, I have to compromise in some cases, for example, I am unable to use services such as TelekomTVGo or SkyShowTime. The providers concerned have shown no interest in this issue and are deliberately hindering the use of alternative solutions. feedback: 23 years ago, we began developing and using our own open-source operating system in order to break away from foreign companies and dependencies. As early as 2006, the Hungarian government's press office was already using our softwares for free. Also in several companies and schools, we replaced foreign commercial products that, in practice. This free environments never changed for many years, because provide more stability and serurity unless a government decree forced them to. It is an unfortunate fact that Hungarian public administration, Hungarian education, and certain public services are typically embeddedoften in a sophisticated wayinto multinational corporations from which oligarchies can be financed. Thus, corruption is deeply intertwined with this field, which is why we have sent multiple complaints to the EU Commission over the past years. The transition is NOT a technical issue, just a MARKET and corruption issue! We have been present for 23 years, fighting against goverment, corruption, and the deliberate dismantling of education. Even today, we have several thousand users, and this number is growing daily, yet despite this, it is impossible to sustain such development at a corporate level, because corruption pushes alternatives out of the market. At EUOS, I have outlined a longer guideline about the currently existing problems, which the EUOS team has also been encountering regularly ever since: https://gitlab.com/eu-os/eu-os.gitlab.io/-/issues/27 This reflects 23 years of experience and is not beginner-level fiction. One final thought: All member states should have started the separation 10 years ago. But despite the fact that we also wrote to the EU Commission, and despite our attempts to assert our case with our own government, we were ultimately met with indifference everywhere. Just take a look at Hungarian public procurementit is all a joke embedded in corruption. We would also have further proposals, as with a few short legislative resolutions it would be possible to create balance across this entire market, resolve cartel-related problems, and yet not hinder the success of current playersonly open up new markets. And all that is needed for this is political will

1. What are the strengths and weaknesses of the EU open-source sector? The EU has always had a strong standing in OS among IT professionals. There exist vibrant communities who actively promote Open Source culture (Linux, Python). Many members see OS as a prerequisite to civil rigths and a supporting factor in a healthy democracy. On the downside, many (non-IT) people are unaware of the benefits of Open Source and feel stuck in the systems created by large companies, because they do not know any alternatives or the change feels insurmountable. 2. What is the added value of open source for the public and private sectors? Open Source has been a main driver of innovation in IT for at least 35 years. Europe played a crucial role in it (Linux, scientific software, many others). The risks of using OS are much lower in the long term. Some examples: - Win11 update are forced on many organizations, generates cost at possibly bad moments and might render older hardware unusable. - with a non-OS opearting system you have to expect that the integrity of your system can be breached by a foreign government (in particular the US). With OS security holes are usually made transparent and therefore fixable. 3. Suggested measures: - make infrastructure available to communities (e.g. alternatives to social media, file storages, email, GitHub etc.) - fund development and maintenance of OS software (direct development work, conferences etc.) - provide infrastructural support to government agencies that want to switch to OS. There are quite a few successful examples where cities or counties have adopted OS for their own business. - promote education using OS software, starting from primary schools (teach LibreOffice, not MS Word, Inkscape, not Adobe etc.) 4. What technology areas should be prioritised and why? One of the key aspects is becoming able to run local Large Language Models. The moment I can use a language AI running in a box at my companies office, my government office, my hospital, my SME or even my home, the monopolies of the big tech corporations will break and develop into something more federal.

Die bestehende Abhängigkeit von einigen wenigen Cloud- und Softwareanbietern ist einfach bequem! Über Jahrzehnte sind daraus Monopole gewachsen, die nun nicht nur die bequemste und bekannteste Textverarbeitung oder Tabellenverarbeitung anbieten, sonder die Daten praktischerweise nun auch gleich speichern. Das Anmeldeverfahren und die Benutzerkennung sind ebenfalls integriert. Die meisten weniger IT-affinen Bürger nutzen verständlicherweise das Bekannte und vermeintlich am einfachsten zu bedienende Softwarewerkzeug für ihre Anforderung. Zudem ist die öffentliche Wahrnehmung der großen Anbieter enorm. Jeder kennt die Namen der entsprechenden Firmen. Es gibt wenig bis kein Bewusstsein über die Konsequenzen dieser Abhängigkeit. Das kann ich aus vielen Gesprächen sicher sagen. Das auch Staaten und die EU diesem unreflektierten Weg folgen, war für mich nie verständlich. Wenn bestimmte Deutsche Bundesländer gerade heute noch Milliardenverträge mit Softwareanbietern abschließen, frage ich mich, was wäre, wenn nur eine Zehntel des Geldes an gezielte und an Verwaltungszwecke gebundene europäische Open Source Entwicklung gehen würde. Die Kleinstsummen, die hier bisher investiert werden, führen dank des Enthusiasmus der Open Source Gemeinde dennoch zu großen Ergebnissen! Wertschöpfung innerhalb der EU müsste doch ein Ziel sein!? Es geht hier zudem um Verwaltungsunabhängigkeit. Da sollten sich EU-weite Standards schaffen lassen! Ich selber nutze Open Source privat, und ja, es ist manchmal noch nicht so bequem wie die Software der Marktbeherrscher, aber es ist schon ziemlich gut. Die einschlägigen IT-Magazine berichten regelmäßig von den Möglichkeiten der Umstellung. Ich vermisse fast nichts! Zugegeben, kann ich mir gut helfen, wenn etwas klemmt. Aber wenn die EU-Staaten in Open Source investieren, kann auch die "Usability" von Open Source schnell weiter aufschließen. Nichttechniker, die an "Standardsoftware" gewöhnt sind, werden sich immer über die Umgewöhnung beschweren. Das tun sie auch in großen Firmen bei einer Softwareumstellung. Ein Hinderungsgrund zu mehr Digitaler Souveränität Europas sollte das aber nicht sein. Unabhängig von den politischen und finanziellen Aspekten, die Open Source aus meiner Sicht absolut notwendig machen, ist eine Software-Monokultur wie die derzeit bestehende absolut kritisch für die Gesllschaft. Crowdstrike und einige weitere Ausfälle haben es gezeigt. Es gibt bei aller Beteuerung keine 100% Verfügbarkeit und die wird es nie geben. Wenn Wasserwerke oder andere kritische Infrastruktur einmal wegen eines Authentifizierungsproblems europaweit nicht mehr funktionieren, weil sie alle am selben Anbieter in der selben Infrastruktur/Zone oder sonstetwas hängen... Das mag weit hergeholt klingen, aber nicht nur meine Wenigkeit hat Zweifel: https://www.networkdefenseblog.com/post/biggest-single-point-of-failure

feedback: As an EU resident and professional with a focus on digital infrastructure and open-source systems, I submit this feedback to emphasize that the transition toward European open digital ecosystems must move beyond traditional cloud paradigms to achieve true technological sovereignty. The European Union currently faces a critical challenge regarding its dependency on centralized, non-European hyperscale providers, and addressing this requires a shift toward infrastructures that are auditable and decentralized by design. Within this context, the Internet Computer protocol (ICP) represents a pivotal technological advancement because it provides an entirely operational model where application hosting, execution, and data storage occur on an open and transparent infrastructure. By utilizing the Internet Computer, the EU can move toward an environment where software and data logic are inherently verifiable, effectively eliminating the risks associated with opaque and proprietary execution environments. This technology is particularly significant for the public sector because it enables the deployment of digital services that do not rely on a single point of central control, thereby ensuring long-term resilience and public trust. I strongly encourage the Commission to recognize that ICP and similar distributed architectures are not merely theoretical concepts but are ready to be integrated into research, evaluation, and pilot programs today. Furthermore, the integration of such decentralized execution environments aligns seamlessly with the objectives of the upcoming Cloud and AI Development Act by providing a secure and auditable foundation for AI-based services and cross-border public platforms. The strategic autonomy of the European Union will be greatly enhanced if future policy frameworks remain inclusive of these non-centralized architectures alongside established cloud solutions. Ultimately, prioritizing operational distributed systems like the Internet Computer will allow the EU to lead in digital innovation while fostering a diverse and competitive ecosystem that is truly independent.

column31: ioBroker) There are a few different perspectives and how each part of our society could help embrace those open source projects: a) How EU could help? Most of these projects are unknown to the masses. And also often times open source projects are small and lack the sales and marketing team of bigger companies and would need help with that. EU could set up something like prototypefund.de/en EU-wide or help promote projects in a different way. b) Companies mainly develop interfaces to proprietary solutions. Companies could help and offer compatibility with at least one open source interface or application e.g. smart home devices should work with home assistant or printers should work under Linux too. Or Apple should be forced to make it possible to get Linux running for all their devices. c) Schools often use commercial software. Schools could be guided to use LibreOffice
column32: Nextcloud and Signal as good alternatives. But not only for organization purposes commercial software is used. Often schools teach their students how to use certain commercial software. Schools could help and use open source software instead. d) Governments could be asked to open up e.g. road data into public data sets (like OpenStreetMap). Or make elevation data available as open data (partially already the case). There is one area which is severely underdeveloped: mobile operating system. There is Android of course but it is not an open source project and highly dependent on Google and its proprietary services and apps. And so mobile operating system like ubuntu touch or postmarketOS should get a lot more attention and investment. Because having open source software for our mobile phones is critical and fundamental for our digital sovereignty. But oftentimes part makers for mobile phones do not release drivers under open source making it nearly impossible to let open source projects adapt. Of course the world is not perfect and so one important step in this direction would be to force Apple and Google to allow 3rd party app stores like Fdroid
column33: without exceptions and fees (like currently planned). As Fdroid consists of just open source software it automatically promotes open source projects wherever possible and would make a huge impact if available on every Android and iOS device by default."

feedback: open source solutions have ALWAYS been a better choice than others. Compared to how much money is spent on licensing fees, you would have already been able to create your own fully working eco system, not relying on "global players" like AWS or Microsoft. Starting with support for open source operating systems, the whole administration could have custom WORKING systems based on their needs. We see NGOs, companies and individuals struggling on a daily basis, because all is done by public tenders which do NOT explicitly give the government proper intelectual property rights so no other company can fix the issues except the initial one. Private individuals on the other hand are somehow also struck with current decisions from Microsoft. Either switch to a totaly broken Windows 11, full of bloatware and AI crap which gives the users ZERO control over their data or being stuck on Windows 10 with a forced Microsoft account -> selling their personal data there. So, from our perspective the EU has either done nothing at all or punished these players with too low penalties. This approach encourages continuing as before. There should be MORE focus on stuff which is used daily than the nice project the EU has done so far. EU should be FOR THE PEOPLE. And if you focus on open source, you will create A HUGE AMOUNT of new jobs. open source is one thing, professional support the other. You will need both, and this can't be done by AI.

As a scientist specializing in bioimaging and computational biology, I strongly support the European Open Digital Ecosystems initiative and urge explicit prioritization of open-source software (OSS), open data, and open standards as foundational research infrastructure. OSS constitutes 70 to 90% of modern software, yet lacks sustainable funding, while proprietary alternatives fragment research efforts and hinder reproducibility. ​ In data-intensive fields like microscopy image analysis, critical OSS tools enable reproducible pipelines and cross-disciplinary reuse across academia and industry. However, these assets remain fragile, maintained by underfunded volunteers despite continent-wide dependency. The initiative correctly recognizes that research programs alone prove insufficient for scaling OSS solutions. EU research grants must mandate OSS and open data (FAIR principles: Findable, Accessible, Interoperable, Reusable) as requirements, with explicit evaluation in peer review. Successful models exist: Germany's Sovereign Tech Fund has deployed 24.6M since 2022 supporting critical open infrastructure; NumFOCUS awards ~200k annually for scientific software sustainability; and the European Open Science Cloud partnership mobilizes 500M EU funding plus 500M in-kind contributions. Funding must allocate dedicated budget lines (15 to 20% of project funds) for maintenance, documentation, security audits, and governance preventing "grant cliff" abandonment when projects end. Three Strategic Gaps Requiring Action: 1) Sustainability: Research tools serving Europe-wide communities need long-term funding beyond project cycles, supporting foundations, cooperatives, and small teams. 2) Interoperability: OSS and open data must integrate with European Open Science Cloud (EOSC) and sectoral data spaces via funded standards, enabling cumulative scientific progress. 3) Security and Resilience: Shared OSS dependencies underpinning institutional stacks require coordinated funding for supply-chain audits and incident response critical for digital sovereignty. To unlock science's potential for European competitiveness: Recognize research software and open data as strategic infrastructure, equivalent to physical laboratories. Require OSI-approved licensing and FAIR principles for all EU-funded digital R&I outputs. Launch dedicated funding streams within Horizon Europe successors or EDICs for long-term maintenance of research-origin OSS and data assets. Align public procurement to favour research-originating open-source, avoiding vendor lock-in. By embedding open-source and open-data as binding funding requirements with dedicated maintenance support, this strategy transforms open ecosystems from aspiration into enduring research infrastructure, strengthening Europe's technological sovereignty, scientific competitiveness, and innovation equity.

Stakeholder feedback on the initiative Towards European Open Digital Ecosystems I submit this feedback as an individual stakeholder and EU resident, with professional interest in digital infrastructure, cloud technologies, and open-source systems. The forthcoming initiative Towards European open digital ecosystems addresses several critical challenges currently facing the European Union, notably technological sovereignty, dependency on centralized cloud infrastructures, and the need for interoperable, open digital solutions across public and private sectors. In this context, it is important that the initiative remains technology-neutral, while also acknowledging already operational infrastructure models that align with its stated objectives and may be relevant for research, evaluation, or pilot purposes. Open-source and transparency The initiative correctly emphasizes open-source technologies as a foundation for resilience, security, and transparency. Execution environments based on open protocols allow software, data, and application logic to be auditable by design, reducing reliance on opaque and proprietary systems. Such characteristics are particularly relevant for public digital services and critical infrastructure. Technological sovereignty and infrastructure resilience A central concern highlighted in the initiative is the EUs dependency on non-European, centralized cloud providers. There already exist distributed execution platforms that allow applications to be hosted and executed without reliance on a single hyperscale cloud operator. These architectures distribute computation and storage across independently operated data centres, reducing single points of control and supporting sovereignty objectives. By way of non-exhaustive illustration, the Internet Computer protocol, initiated by the DFINITY Foundation, demonstrates an operational model in which application hosting, execution, and data storage are performed on open, auditable infrastructure rather than centralized cloud services. Such examples may be relevant for exploratory research, evaluation, or pilot programmes, without prejudice to the principle of technology neutrality. Interoperability and digital public services Distributed application architectures can support interoperability, verifiability, and long-term resilience characteristics increasingly important for digital government, open data platforms, and cross-border public services. Transparent execution environments may contribute to accountability and trust in public-sector digital systems. Complementarity with Cloud and AI policy The initiative notes its complementarity with the upcoming Cloud and AI Development Act. Distributed execution infrastructures may also contribute to this policy area by enabling auditable compute environments, clearer governance over execution logic, and controlled deployment of AI-based services. Policy suggestion I encourage the Commission to: consider decentralized and distributed execution infrastructures as part of the broader open digital ecosystem landscape; include such models in research, pilot, or experimental programmes where appropriate; ensure that future policy frameworks remain open to non-centralized cloud architectures alongside traditional approaches. Conclusion The objectives outlined in this initiative present an opportunity for the EU to strengthen digital sovereignty through openness, interoperability, and diversity of infrastructure models. Considering already-operational distributed systems alongside established cloud solutions could enhance resilience, innovation, and strategic autonomy.

Bonjour, Moi je pense l'Europe doit définir une politique pour favoriser l'open source surtout dans le milieu public, ce qui pourrait faire de belles économies et être souverain. Par exemple, toute les administrations publics devraient utiliser des environnements Linux et des outils libres ou Européen. Peut être que l'Europe devrait créé sa propre distribution Linux ou sponsorisé quelque unes européennes. Toutefois il faut les outils mais aussi les services efficaces pour adopter les solutions. Peu de gens ont envie de passer des heures à paramétrer leur logiciel et les solutions Cloud semble toujours meilleurs. Je pense aussi qu'il faudrait, au delà d'aider le développement des outils, former les européens au solutions open source. Trop peu connaisse les alternatives et reste sur des outils propriétaires sans vraiment de raison. Aussi, les organismes de formation propose souvent peu de formation/certification sur des outils open source. Par exemple, j'ai suivi une formation sur le dessin vectoriel où seul Adode Illustrator était proposé alors que le contenu aurait très bien pu être fait sur le logiciel libre Inkscape. De même, c'est difficile de trouver des formations Linux compatible compte de formation hormis dans les grandes villes. Il est aussi nécessaire je pense que l'Europe trouve des solutions pour remplacer les GAFAM dans les télécommunication importante aux entreprises. Ca peut être basé sur des solutions open source mais qui doivent être mise en place. Le pire étant le mobile qui est aujourd'hui monopoliser par Google et Apple. Il n'existe aucune alternative aussi puissante à leurs écosystèmes et c'est inquiétant. L'Europe devrait essayer de construire des solutions libres au monde entier pour tout les besoins technologiques essentiels pour le monde particulier et professionnel (téléphonie, messagerie, sécurité, cloud, ChatBot IA...), et permettre à chaque pays d'avoir des systèmes technologiques sans être dans la dépendance. Bien sûr tout ne pourra pas être open source, mais la base devrait pouvoir l'être. Il serait aussi bien d'avoir un système libre européen ou mondial pour l'authentification (SSO) non dépendant des service des GAFAM.

column40: A clear commitment to FOSS has long been needed. This concerns both operating systems and the software running on them. The benefits clearly outweigh the benefits. In this context, attention must also be paid to and penalties imposed on the ‘motivation’ by which decision-makers often decide in favour of proprietary solutions. In addition, there is also a need to look at hardware, which is equally critical in terms of capacity to act and independence. Finally, there is also a need for awareness within Europe not to create those tools which, in ‘false’ hands, can and will lead to massive problems (see, for example, Messenger Monitoring).

feedback: Using open source software is an excellent initiative. However, there are many pitfalls. The Linux family is very diverse. I believe that there should be a common standard and common rules applied so that software can be used and developed according to a single common standard. In addition, open source systems are often more expensive to maintain than other options. Here, too, it is important to ensure that prices do not become prohibitively high.

This is shortened due to the text box character limit. My full feedback is attached as PDF and on my blog at more-magic.net. With FOSS, one does not have to trust a single company to maintain high code quality and security. Independent security researchers and programmers look at this code with a fresh perspective. FOSS reduces vendor lock-in. For example when a vendor gets acquired by a foreign company. Therefore, FOSS brings sovereignty by not being at the mercy of a single vendor. The EU can set a good example in the public sector. Closed source software still reigns supreme there. Only "established" companies may apply to tenders. These often employ professionals certified in proprietary tech. The existing dependency ensures lock-in for future projects, as compatibility is often a key requirement. These same vendors are ruthless and have repeatedly sabotaged FOSS migrations. Microsoft was implicated in multiple bribery scandals. How the EU can help: * Fully commit to FOSS. Set a date by which all software used by the public sector must be FOSS and running on hardware within the EU, at fully EU-owned companies. No compromises, no excuses and no easy outs - those were the bane of previous efforts. * Map out missing requirements and pay EU consultancy firms to improve FOSS where it is lacking. This will also make said software also more attractive for large private organisations that provide essential services in the EU. Concrete examples: * Many EU and member state institutes rely on American services for hosting or securing their e-mail. E-mail software is a complete commodity, for which there are good European alternatives, based on FOSS. It should be easy to switch. * Workstations for public servants typically run on Windows and use Microsoft Office. Switch these to a proven open operating system like Linux and office suite like LibreOffice. In schools, informatics is typically taught using proprietary software. Network effects ensure deeper entrenchment. Big tech offers steep discounts for educational licenses for these exact reasons. Vocational schools focus on proprietary tech most used in industry. This goes beyond IT studies. A focus on the impact of tech choices in education could change the situation from the ground up. In high school, there could be a place (e.g. in civic education class) to focus on the impact of tech choices on society. This goes beyond domestic versus foreign "cloud" hosting and open versus proprietary code. For example, studies show that social media can have harmful effects on mental well-being, societal cohesion and even democracy. How the EU can help: * Provide funding for course material, and/or create a certification programme for suitable course material to wean schools off of big tech software. * Start an education campaign aimed at the broader public to to explain why closed software and the non-EU cloud are harmful. * For the existing work force, the EU can fund training in open alternatives. The EU has FOSS businesses already. These companies are small in the global market place. Competitors from the US benefit from economies of scale. How the EU can help: * Promote tech sovereignty across the world. * Help EU companies become more well-known by organising trade shows. * Provide funding to organisations like the FSF Europe to run awareness campaigns about FOSS alternatives. * Perhaps controversial: heavily tax proprietary, non-EU software or provide tax breaks for FOSS EU software to level the playing field. * Even more controversially, prevent foreign-owned companies from operating data centers in the EU. Make it as hard as possible for them to offer high-speed cloud software here. These data centers are already unpopular, as they use precious water and land, and they only make foreign companies more powerful. Conclusion: The reasons for dependency on foreign proprietary solutions are systemic. The solu

feedback: I have been a tinkerer and a web developer for a few years now. Enough time to see a shift in practices and tools, going from deploying websites on Linux, using open sources servers, databases, and tools, to a widespread use of vendor-locking proprietary software from massive non-europeans actors. This has led to the necessity for tech worker to learn platform-dependent knowledge as well as a difficulty to migrate a project to a different provider (for example, one that would reside in Europe). Regardless of the political context, I am absolutely in favor of promoting European open source projects, and the underlying infrastructure, in order to offer a healthy alternative for technology across Europe.

Credo vi sia necessità di un sistema operativo che sia open, credo sarebbe interessante creare una piattaforma di stampo ibrido dove istituzioni eu e imprese private collaborino. Probabilmente un os basato su kernel Linux sarebbe più facilmente implementabile, ma c'è bisogno che la distro venga controllata da un ente pubblico che possa controllarne la sicurezza e la conformità alle norme eu. Penso sia indispensabile creare dei protocolli di comunicazione tra i diversi os e i diversi programmi. (Es. Se uso un calendario google dovrei essere libero di spostare la mia utenza verso Microsoft o verso un nuovo sistema europeo. Credo che dovrebbe esistere un sistema di autenticazione statale che possa funzionare da accesso non solo alle applicazioni dello stato (come IO in Italia) ma dovrei essere libero di accedere ai vari siti utilizzando quell'account. (Un po' come si può fare con google e facebook). Penso che il cittadino europeo dovrebbe poter avere uno spazio di archiviazione statale in cui vengono conservati i documenti ufficiali che lo riguardano, dai documenti notarili alle semplice buste paga e dichiarazioni dei redditi. Questo renderebbe più pratica la conservazione dei documenti ufficiali, i quali verrebbero consegnati e gestiti direttamente dalla pubblica amministrazione e sarebbero pertanto facilmente consultabili anche da quest'ultima. Penso sia molto importante che un sistema operativo di stampo europeo debba guardare anche alla salute del cittadino evitando l'utilizzo di sistemi che creino dipendenza e che portino alla continua interruzione dell'attenzione. Il calo di attenzione , nonché la diminuzione nei risultati dei test di intelligenza sono un'evidente piaga che gli stati dovrebbero combattere e di cui questi sistemi operativi (assieme a molte applicazioni) sono una causa evidente. Dovremmo cercare di utilizzare l'ai per rendere il sistema più intelligente ma non invasivo, cercando di incentivare l'utilizzo di prodotti europei (come Mistral) che sicuramente potrebbe avere una accelerazione importante al netto di un utilizzo più diffuso. Penso sarebbe interessante l'implementazione di schermi e-ink per la produzione di supporti (con il sistema operativo eu) in grado di avvicinare i minori al mondo digitale in modo graduale e più controllato, risultando molto meno attraente ma ugualmente utile. Grazie per il vostro lavoro.

companySize: I see for example an open-source Java application server as a critical component in any enterprise. It can form the basis for any ICT system without inducing vendor lock-in. At the same time it allows for innovation of Java middleware into different strategies by cooperating with other open-source developers. To ensure the sustainability of open-source software I believe we need to change the fundamentals of how we treat open-source software. Instead of allowing the software to be used freely for commercial activities we should strive for a model in which open-source software developers are properly compensated for their efforts. I believe this starts with changing the underlying licensing terms. As for technological sovereignty
organization: it should be addressed by having a secured environment in which to build and test open-source software. This environment should be completely vendor independent to ensure continued operation by EU companies and individuals. Ideally the environment should be Digital Operational Resilience Act compliant and produce software which adheres to the Cyber Resilience Act. The technical focus should be on open-source software projects making use of Memory Safe Languages

feedback: Europe already has strong open-source communities and excellent technical talent, but too much value creation still happens outside the EU. The main bottleneck is not the lack of new inventions - it is the lack of scalable conditions for European start-ups and SMEs to build, maintain, secure, and commercialize open solutions that can be widely adopted in the public and private sector. A key point for the upcoming strategy is to shift from a novelty-based innovation mindset to a value-based impact mindset. In open source, the highest impact often comes from making existing components production-ready: usability, documentation, integration, security hardening, long-term maintenance, governance, and reliable support. Funding and evaluation should therefore prioritize measurable societal and economic value, not only how new a technology is. What the EU should do (practical, high-impact actions): 1. Targeted funding for open-source start-ups and SMEs with multi-year horizons (23 years), enabling teams to build sustainable products and ecosystems, not short-lived prototypes. 2. Adoption and scale programmes: support packaging, interoperability, migration paths, training, and integration into real environments (public administration and industry). 3. Maintenance and security as first-class funding items: LTS, security audits, SBOM/tooling, incident response capacity, documentation, and release engineering. 4. Public procurement as an anchor customer: simplify access for SMEs (smaller lots, faster pilots, vendor-neutral requirements, open standards, clear exit/portability criteria). 5. Market building and go-to-market support: certification pathways, cross-border references, partnerships, and visibility for high-quality EU open solutions. Priority technology areas: cybersecurity and software supply-chain, identity/IAM, cloud/platform building blocks, data/AI toolchains, and industrial/edge use cases. Sectors with highest impact: public services, critical infrastructure, healthcare, mobility/transport, and manufacturing. Suggested success metrics: adoption rates, number of public deployments, reduced dependency/lock-in, time-to-patch for critical vulnerabilities, availability of EU-based support providers, and growth of EU open-source SMEs/start-ups. Europe should treat open source as strategic digital infrastructure: funded for impact, built for adoption, and strengthened through start-up enablement and fair market access.

With Linux Europe has a powerful Alternative for the Desktop. There are however only rudimentary drafts for mobile environments. So for now nearly 100% of the population is stuck with iOS and Android. Those systems include Phones, TVs, Cars. Should they ever be turned against Europe everyone is instantly a spy. So Jolla/SailOs could be a starting point for an alternative mobile stack.

Open-Source is a critical part of getting away from Major Monopolies and providers. Open-Source is worth supporting and there are countless projects that already exist and make every day life better or even possible. Supporting these existing projects instead of starting new ones is vital for this to succeed, but starting new projects s when none fit the purpose is a valid approach. Avoiding fragmentation and building on existing work would be a core aspect of supporting Open Digital Ecosystems. One should always keep in mind tho: Public Money, Public Code

Microsoft verkauft Windows Lizenzen für wenige Cent und gibt so den Herstellern und Händlern einen "Anreiz" Microsoft Produkte zu bewerben und zu verkaufen. EK 50 Cent und VK dann 150 für Wwindows Professionel Selbsternannte Experten wie zuletzt Joe Käser erklärten, dass die deutsche Wirtschaft in große Probleme kommen wird, wenn Microsoft uns von der Cloud abklemmt. Niemand kann in die Glaskugel schauen, ich behaupte das Gegenteil: Wenn Europa von amerikanischen Clouds abgeschnitten würde, dann würde Deutschland und Europa endlich erkennen, dass kostenlosen, offene und freie Software nicht nur die billigere sondern auch die "bessere" Lösung ist. Der hohe Marktanteil vov Windows Betriebssystemen kann nicht mit technischen und finanziellen Vorteilen erklärt werden, da es keine vorteile gibt. Aktuell sind viele Institutionen und Unternehmen "locked in", bedeutet, dass Unternehmen wie Microsoft erkannt haben, dass 30000% Stückgewinn nicht genug Anreiz für Verkäufer und Pc Hersteller sind und deshalb versucht wird die "user" "einzuschließen", auf dass, falls Sie erkennen, dass Sie schlechte teuere Software nutzen, es nicht schaffen auf die bessere kostenlose Open Source Software zu wechseln. Frei nach Dr. Angela Merkel's "das Internet ist Neuland" hoffe ich das, die Entscheidungsträger endlich aufwachen und erkennen, dass Open Source die größte menschliche Errungenschaft ist. Entscheidungsträger haben Angst vor Opensource da Gegenmodell zum Patentrecht. Da über 50% der Patentverfahren vor Gericht von den Patentinhabern verloren werden, ist es jetzt Zeit sich gedanklich von Mein Mein - Klein Klein und dem Patentrecht zu verabschieden und open source zu gehen.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: Microsoft sells Windows licences for a few cents, giving manufacturers and distributors an ‘incentive’ to advertise and sell Microsoft products. EC 50 cents and UK 150 for Wwindows Professionel Self-appointed experts, most recently Joe Käser, said that the German economy will face major problems if Microsoft shuts us off the cloud. No one can look into the glass sphere, I say the opposite: If Europe were cut off from American clouds, Germany and Europe would finally realise that free, open and free software is not only the cheaper but also the “better” solution. The high market share of vov Windows operating systems cannot be explained by technical and financial advantages as there are no advantages. Currently, many institutions and companies are ‘locked in’, meaning that companies like Microsoft have realised that 30 000 % profit per unit is not a sufficient incentive for sellers and Pc manufacturers, and therefore the ‘user’ is being ‘included’, that if you realise that you are using badly expensive software, you will not be able to switch to the better free open source software. Free from Dr Angela Merkel’s ‘Internet is new land’, I hope that decision-makers will finally wake up and realise that open source is the greatest human achievement. Decision-makers are afraid of open source as a counter-model to patent law. As more than 50 % of patent litigation in court is lost by patent holders, it is now time to think of My My Small and Patent Law and open source.

feedback: I am an Austrian engineer working daily with the European Commission in a member-state-spanning project. I think it would be an important signal if the commission would officially start to use open source alternatives for meetings everywhere, and open formats for data exchange (not MS Word but ODF for Example). This might encourage member states to go into the same direction and eliminate the need to stay in the Microsoft/Adobe/Windows world. Also, providing a top level CA for Browser Certificates by the EC would be an important signal and help to become digitally independent from the US.

As a concerned citizen, I wish to provide feedback regarding the EU's reliance on "software infrastructure" that, while indispensable to daily life, remains almost exclusively owned by US-based corporations. The EU should formally define "critical software infrastructure" based on the essential needs of its citizens and public services. Following this identification, policies should be enacted requiring public services to utilize open-source software for these tools, thereby fostering a robust ecosystem that benefits both the public sector and private citizens. However, a significant hurdle for open source is its tendency toward constant forking and fragmentation; therefore, EU policy must incentivize development teams to remain focused on a single, high-quality product. For example, Microsoft Excels ubiquity creates a "vendor lock-in" effect for companies; the EU should counter this by mandating the use of open-source alternatives within its own institutions. To ensure success, the EU must consolidate development efforts to yield tangible improvements in one or two primary open-source competitors, rather than diluting resources across many subpar versions. Multiple inferior versions cannot replace a single, high-performing tool; establishing a "standard feature set" could serve as a roadmap for this focused development. Furthermore, encrypted messaging represents a vital component of modern infrastructure that should be treated as a public utility. Currently, EU citizens lack a viable means of digital communication that does not rely on US-owned messaging platforms. The EU should establish a privacy-first, end-to-end encrypted messaging standard to which various apps could connect, ensuring a secure and sovereign communication network.

Hello! Happpy to help! I am a professional developer with an Informatics Master (Dipl. Ing.) roughly 30 years into business. To untangle the entire mess we have with tghe USA regarding services Opensource can help! It is a huge mountain but we have the core infrastructure and knowledge and also supporting companies in place to take over the job. The project I am involved in for instance apache myfaces, stems from originally a viennese company (irian.at) my employeer and still has active participants here in Austria and Germany for maintenance. It is a subproject driving web interfaces! What needs to be done. The biggest stumbling block probably is the heavy reliance on Windows, while it is not as dominant on the desktop as it used to be many companies still use it. The alternative is Linux and we have companies being able to support and maintain Linux distributions the most prominent one being the german SuSE for instance! Office packages the same LibreOffice stems from a german office package! The backend infrastructure the same we have companies for various parts of the backend infrastructure like JEE who have the knowledge to be able to maintain those parts I do not know the exact names for those companies in this case (except for the one I am working for which can maintain a vital substack of the JEE spec (JSF, CDI under the Apache implementation)) Cloud and AI here we have smaller companies which never really could get up to US sizes due to the lack of venture capital funding! But they are here! Mobile phone operating systems. Android still is maintained on googles side, but in Asia some companies already have forked their variants, it is doable it just needs the money to do that! Also Nokia had alternatives in the pipeline also based on Linux which with the Microsoft takeover were terminated the code might be still lingering around, although an Android fork might be the better option for now! On the hardware side our biggest problem is the total reliance on Asia for production, it really bites us now that we have offshored literally everything (the same now goes on the software side with the off shoring to india on many levels for services which might bite us in the future) We need to inshore production which will take years and a general concensous that this is vital for the long term survival of the EU, but we have started with all those problems in the 90s when we still had technological parity on all fronts with the rest of the world. Now or own EU processor house (ARM which is UK based) belongs to a japanese bank and is for sale and has been for a while! Arduino a successful company in the makers business from Italy recently has been bought by Qualcom a US company known for its hard business practices and it seems their latest offering basically fuels the fears that they are closing up the maker ecosystem many smaller companies thrieve on and lots of opensource is based on, by changing the patent parts of their license! Feel free to contact me for further discussion, I am always willing to help in the effort when I can help! Opensource is vital to untangle our ties to the USA but also vital for a startup ecosystem and to be competitive internationally!

I strongly support this initiative and would like to represent my interests in the areas of education, public administration, digital sovereignty, IT security, and integrity. In the education sector, the focus should be on skills rather than product training from commercial providers: current certification products such as ECDL are de facto Microsoft training courses in which students learn Excel and Word, for example, instead of developing basic skills in using spreadsheets and word processing programs. It is crucial to establish European digital sovereignty, which is currently insufficient. We are currently too dependent on US and Chinese services. The EU must pursue the strategic goal of operating independently and sustainably with its own technical and digital infrastructures. Every citizen must have the opportunity to use services with digital sovereignty, always in full compliance with applicable data protection rights and obligations and all applicable regulations to ensure security and integrity. The first step should be to switch to open-source administrative and government software in the EU and its member states. This will consequently lead to the development of independent digital services that are not dependent on commercial cloud providers. The primary goal must be to specifically promote European open-source software products and offer them at a low threshold. Software solutions such as GrapheneOS, LibreOffice, Nextcloud, BigBlueButton, Moxis eSign, various Linux distributions and many more must be actively integrated into society in order to break the monopoly positions of large US technology corporations. Finally, I would like to quote Levy: "Access to computers and everything that can show you how this world works should be unlimited and complete." In my opinion, this best describes the approach.

Here is why European development policy fail, and the US development policy sometimes works. If you are working on some strategically important technology, at a university or in a shed somewhere in the US, some day a man you never seen will appear and ask some questions. With out saying who they are they will end the conversation with a "Keep working on this", and then a few weeks later a million dollar check will show up in the mail from some agency you have never heard of. Eventually the technology starts working and is adopted by others. Mean while, the EU has also recognized that this is an important technology, so they will not spend a measly million euros, they will spend 100 million euros! And they will do so by putting out a call for anyone who might be interested in this technology, pulling in every university that wants a grant, and none of the people in sheds who actually are working on it. Then the EU says "We must leverage all 500 million Europeans and all 28 countries" so its puts together a group of every possible stakeholder, and tells them to come up with a plan. 5 years later they have written a 3000 page plan, but have no implementation. Then to support this "important European endeavour" the EU will mandate that everyone uses the new European standard, in order to get EU support. But since the new standard is just a paper product, it doesn't solve anyone's problems, so European companies now have a choice: Adopt the EU standard, and eventually fail, or adopt the working standard coming from the US and lock them selves out of EU support. The wise ones choose the later. You want to help Open source? Great, It takes about ten minutes of googling to find the biggest opensource projects, and who the Europeans behind them are. Dont ask industry what they want, ask them what they are already using. Dont ask for people to apply for grants. The people you want to support, will never apply for them. You have to find them. They are busy people and if you are taking time away from what they are doing, you are not helping. The processing of the grant applications probably cost more than the grant size needs to be. 2 people in a tiny office could spend 10milion euro a year and make EU a haven for open source. That's 100k per year for the top 100 projects in Europe. That's the difference between doing a project on the side or full time. Saying you have money to give out attracts the wrong people. You have to find them yourself, and put your trust in them because you can see that they are willing to do the work without any support. Dont think you can create new projects, there are so many projects already, support the ones that are taking off. Dont pick winners, see who the winners are. Linux, Curl, Python, Blender. Dont write big checks, write small checks that lets people keep doing what they are doing. Europe is full of amazing projects by amazing people, but EU is a institution that only deals with institutions, so it never bothers to find us.

Software development can still be done globally (for example, I would fully support GrapheneOS being used on phones in public sector departments). However, storing the artifacts and running the build pipelines should take place in an EU-hosted environment. Update servers that distribute release artifacts to end users should also be hosted within the EU and be controlled by a dedicated EU authority that is capable of auditing what is being released and of testing those software releases. At the same time, everything that is released should be fully transparent so that the public can review it as well. There should be bug bounty programs. The EU should help fund the organizations and individuals who produce open-source software that the EU considers to be of strategic importance for its economy and society. It should also be in the EUs interest to reduce single-maintainer dependencies in certain projects (which also occur in the Linux ecosystem) by making these projects more heterogeneous. Organizations and individuals should be paid above average IT salaries to reflect the fact that independent IT and software infrastructure is and will remain crucial for our society.

I am a Polish EU citizen that profits substantially from open source. During my life I have lived in four EU countries and my experiences have shown me that open ecosystems (open data and open source) are critical to each of these countries and it's citizens faring well. One of my professors in Italy said in broken English: "software is like water -- it should be free". I think by that he meant not that it should be gratis, as people would have little respect for it. In my opinion he meant that realistically speaking one cannot live without software, as one cannot live with water. I cannot imagine a word where I can drink only what is sold and sharing is forbidden. Free and Open Source Software is the only way to guarantee this freedom for it's users. I would like to point out that copyleft licenses assure that this freedom is not taken away and the EUPL is a good license for me. The Open Database License is a good choice for Open Data, as OpenStreetMap proved me. I got into FOSS by starting using Linux over one summer break where I wanted to keep learning to stay in the rhythm -- in some way out of boredom. I have stayed there as I have discovered how much better FOSS is but what really cemented my position was the freedom. I think that Oneness is one of the purest ideas that we came up and implemented as humanity. An ISS astronaut can use the same software with the same data as an average Kowalski and even as a nearly-starving African child. I work in the ICT sector so I understand first-hand how important open digital ecosystems are. When software is interoperable companies cannot boast about integration in their walled garden because there are no walls. I would also like to note that as long as we have the Internet public digital ecosystems know no bounds. It does not matter if the ecosystem is Australian, Austrian or American if it grants it's users freedom -- if they want they can get involved. I would like the EU to recognize how critical FOSS and OpenData is and support it first-hand. I would love if the EU member states would adopt a common standard software (a digital ecosystem) and the best way to do it is with Open Source.
Please find our detailed response in the attached PDF.

feedback: Thank you for the opportunity to provide feedback on this crucial topic, as it is one of the keys to a sovereign EU community and its citizens. I utilize Linux desktop and laptop, manage my own Nextcloud home server, rely on Linux or FOSS Android smartphones, use TAN generator for banking, and navigate with OpenStreetMap. For years, I have faced many limitations and often feel like an outsider. Where to begin? Here are my suggestions: 1. Encourage Vendors to Offer FOSS OS Options: When purchasing desktops, laptops, or smartphones, require vendors and manufacturers to sell devices pre-installed with FOSS operating systems like Linux or Google-free Android. This would logically lower device prices, as there would be no licensing fees to Microsoft. The need to flash your own OS poses a significant barrier to adoption. 2. Eliminate Gatekeeping for Smartphone Apps: Currently, there are only Apple and Google app stores, which is critical since essential applications for banking, electric vehicle charging, and ticket purchasing are available only through these stores. Every company should be obligated to provide their apps as APK files on their websites for sideloading. Why is a Google account needed to use services like wero-wallet.eu? 3. Support Decentralized Internet Solutions: Promote the use of decentralized platforms such as Matrix Messenger and Mastodon. Why do official governments continue to post on Elon Musks platform, X? 4. Support Education Initiatives: If teachers are unaware of these tools, students will be as well. I have consistently heard negative remarks about Wikipedia in schools, often focusing on its potential inaccuracies. Schools should adopt a positive approach, engaging in collaborative efforts to identify and correct mistakes. 5. Engage Internet Service Providers: Encourage ISPs to support public IP addresses (IPv6, no NAT) to facilitate access to home networks. This would allow users to host their own Nextcloud servers as alternatives. 6. Consider Car Manufacturers Information Systems: Consumers pay significant amounts for vehicles, yet they often do not fully own the systems within them. There should be open-source alternatives available in the automotive sector as well. 7. Reevaluate Data Monetization Practices: Today, data is paramount. Individuals often provide personal data for free but receive inadequate services in return. There should be an equitable approach that allows consumers to use their data for purchases instead of euros, complete with transparent pricing rather than convoluted contracts. Alternatively, the companies' user data could also be stored in the users' home networks, as they actually belong to them. 8. Address Patent Troll Issues: Take proactive measures to stop patent trolls, as experienced by Mycroft AI, which severely hampered their development and growth. Protecting innovative companies from baseless patent claims is essential to fostering a thriving open-source ecosystem. Additionally, I would like to acknowledge and highlight several projects that exemplify the potential and functionality of open-source solutions: OSMand, Organic Maps, Tuta, LineageOS, GrapheneOS, Fdroid, Nextcloud, Wikipedia, Mastodon, Matrix, Signal, Bitwarden, Aegis, Dicio, Syncloud, Ubuntu, Debian, LibreOffice, Collabora, Volla, Pine64, Ubuntu Touch, PostmarketOS, Phosh, Gnome, Duckduckgo, Firefox, Droidian, Waydroid.

1. The biggest strength of the free and open source sector is control over the programs you run on your device. When you run a proprietary program, you have almost no way of knowing what instructions that program runs, which puts the user under the control of the program. A weakness of open source programs is that someone could modify the source code of that program and, if the license of that program does not say the modified code must also be open source, they could use it under a proprietary program (essentially getting the code and giving nothing back). The biggest obstacle to overcome for wide scale adoption is social inertia, because average citizens are not aware of these issues. 2. The biggest value is control of your own programs. This is where I think it's important to mention the free/libre software movement, because they are the ones who emphasize this fact first and foremost. The practical advantages of open source are very commonly heard, but not so much the moral advantage of controlling your computing, and that's why I think this aspect needs to be heard. 3. Encourage users to use free and open source over proprietary software, teach free software in schools, promote open standards, fund projects with the scope of making up the difference in functionality for a smoother transition, and to make sure users always have the choice over what programs run on their device. 4. I would say the most commonly used proprietary software's competitors. The software is up to par, with only a few minor differences of functionality and that is why I think it's the best place to start. I'd start by switching Windows with Linux, because that is the most commonly used proprietary software. 5. I think every sector could benefit because anyone can make the code better and the code can be patched as soon as vulnerabilities are discovered.

When it comes to data sovereignty, only an open-source solution is viable, as all other systems fail and cannot guarantee where the stored and generated data is transferred. It's striking how this trend begins with banks, where all European banks are obligated to send all customer information to the USA. It continues with servers that, in turn, send data to China or even the USA, unsolicited. This happens partly according to regulations and agreements, and partly covertly and intentionally. Amazon also deserves mention in this context. Their excellent cloud-based offering is practically indispensable in IT, yet even here, data is funneled to other EU countries. The question remains, however, whether this is truly so negative. But back to the topic of open source. It's essential that not only software but also hardware is open source to partially prevent the processes described above. Municipalities should be pioneers in this area, as this strengthens local service providers and simultaneously saves them money. Given their economic situation, it's incomprehensible that they haven't acted out of necessity. The European Union could support these municipalities with funding and, above all, demand open standards, which are particularly important for data exchange in the public sector. Only then would funding be available! Ministries should be encouraged to contract software for all sub-organizations only with providers that offer open-source software as an alternative to the usual suspects. Funding should then be available for any necessary adaptation and further development, which would ultimately benefit the entire EU. A brief note on alternatives: LibreOffice is a strong alternative to Microsoft Office and, integrated into Nextcloud with Nextcloud Talk, replaces many Microsoft packages with high licensing costs and insufficient GDPR compliance. There are countless other examples in academia, but these open-source software applications should also be taught. The first introduction should begin in school and continue at universities and colleges.

Il est intéressant de lire "indépendance" et "démocratie" en piliers de cette consultation car ce sont CES piliers qui sont les fondations de l'architecture SekNet (Sekurit Netswerk). Je vous joins ma réponse à l'appel à contribution, réponse qui, si elle commence par des points de vues pouvant sembler disruptifs, réponse qui est dans les faits complètement en accord avec ces deux piliers. Vous souhaitant bonne lecture et dans l'attente de vos commentaires, cordialement, W.Pfister ---
feedbackTextUserLanguage: It is interesting to read “independence” and “democracy” as pillars of this consultation because it is ESC pillars that are the foundations of the SekNet (Sekurit Netswerk) architecture. I enclose my response to the call for evidence, which, while beginning with views that may seem disruptive, is in fact fully in line with both pillars. I wish you a good reading and look forward to receiving your comments, w.Pfister —

feedback: Die Europäische Union sollte sich in der Welt als starker Vertreter der Rechtsstaatlichkeit und Unterschützer der Souveränität von sowohl Individuen und als auch Staaten stark machen. Open Source Software gibt Ihren Nutzern diesen Freiheiten. Außerdem wird durch offene und gut dokumentierte Schnittstellen der wechsel zwischen verschiedenen Anbietern erleichtert was zu einem freieren und faireren Markt führt, in dem Innovation und Sicherheit im Vordergrund steht. Hierfür sollte Europa als Standort der Entwicklung gestärkt werden. Förderung von Open Source Projekten die an den oben genannten zielen Arbeiten und ihren Sitz und Entwickler in der Europäischen Union haben. Dies fördert direkt die Europäische Wirtschaft als Standort der Entwicklung, kommt aber auch indirekt anderen Staaten zu gute, da diese ebenfalls von rechtsstaatlicher und souveräner Software profitieren. Außerdem könnte die Europäische Union gezielt Ihren Bürgern verschiedene Dienste anbieten, die Entwicklung voran treiben und dabei selbst Kompetenzen aufbauen. ENTWICKLUNG: Förderprogramme für Universitäten, Schulen und ihre Absolventen die zu Open Source beitragen. Das würde dazu führen, dass sich junge Entwickler schon früh mit diesen Technologien auseinandersetzen und somit dem Arbeitsmarkt zu Verfügung stehen und in Unternehmen entsprechende anreize setzen können. MATRIX: https://de.wikipedia.org/wiki/Matrix_(Kommunikationsprotokoll) Dabei könnte Matrix als sicherer, offener und dezentralisierter Messanger für Bürger der Europäischen Union angeboten werden. Damit hätte die EU eine unabhängige, robuste und souveräne Plattform für den Austausch ihrer Bürger. VERWALTUNG (z.B. Nextcloud und Libre Office): https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nextcloud https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/LibreOffice Unterstützung von Software die in der Open Source Software die in der Verwaltung zum Einsatz kommt, um Staatlichen Strukturen unabhängiger von einzelnen oft nicht Europäischen Akteuren zu machen. Dabei würde Fachwissen für diese kritische Infrastruktur in der EU gefördert und belastende Lizenzkosten für Verwaltungen verringert werden. Das Open Source Model unterstützt dabei auch das Motto der EU in "In Vielfalt geeint", da einzelne kleinere Verwaltungen ihre lokalen Ansprüche und Interessen leichter einfließen lassen können. Außerdem sollten offene Dateiformate und Schnittstellen eingeführt werden um des Austausch einzelner Institutionen untereinander und der Bürger zu vereinfachen. So könnte die Europäische Union stärker auf Formate der Open Document Faundation setzen https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Document_Foundation SCHULEN: Schule ist ein wichtiger Ort für die Prägung von Kindern. Vor der Digitalisierung gab es Stift und Papier, das unabhängig von jedem Benutzt werden konnte. Hat ein Kind gelernt mit Stift und Papier zu schreiben ist es egal von welchen Hersteller diese Stammen. Dies ist nicht der Fall bei Software im Schulumfeld. Schreibt eine Schule ein bestimmtes Digitales Lernmittel eines Herstellers vor, lernt es mit diesem und potenziell nur mit diesem umzugehen. Damit ist es ein leben lang von staatlicher Stelle von einem Hersteller geprägt. Hier sollte die EU eingreifen und Digitale Schreibmedien und Lernplattformen auf Open Source Basis Fördern. Dies fängt beim eventuellen Tablett zum schreiben an und hört beim Informatikunterricht auf. Dabei könnte die EU Plattformübergreifende Standards für Schreibapps auf Basis von Open Source fördern oder entwickeln um Schülern und auch Studenten beim lernen nicht abhängig von Herstellen zu machen.

feedback: As someone who works in a large organisation, I see a lot of vendor lock-in and opaque cloud solutions. The cost of buying proprietary software would be better suited in paying for open-source support, which generates highly skilled labour and allows for companies avoid vendor lock-in. Regarding the cloud solutions, it is irrelevant if the data is hosted in Europe when non-EU companies can have remote access to the data. Regulation compliance does not protect data from being funnelled out of Europe. The only solution is to have the data hosted within Europe by European companies that have no presence outside or Europe and therefore are not under the jurisdiction of foreign governments.

1. Beware of "general bureaucratic burden": in establishing high requirements (as originally e.g. under the GDPR), sometimes evidently aimed at "limiting the influence of multinational companies", often exactly the reverse effect is achieved - the multinational companies are the only ones who have the means to actually shoulder the burden. 2. Promote some form of binding "traditional" contractual relationships: software and services are not that "expensive" for most companies. Many companies will simply try to extend their business practices into the software sphere, because they "know how that works" in a business setting. Address that e.g. in the form of a "reliability pre-check", e.g. in a similar way as a CE-certification helps for physical products. 3. Insist on the use of "standards": the wild forest of macros and custom add-on-tools for various proprietary software makes independence very difficult. 4. Address "service dependency" rather than "software dependency": particularly with the advent of generative AI, but also before that with social networks, cloud services etc., the IT landscape is switching towards solutions from major providers. You cannot replace "services" easily with "programs", particularly if communication and interoperability are an issue. 5. Foster "executability" of free and open source licenses: e.g. create some public body that would pursue claims against third parties in case of license disputes, with proceeds e.g. going into some EU fonds. Think of the scandal around Linux and BSD in the 1990s / early 2000s. 6. Foster "customer competence": unfortunately, even large entities simply lack competent departments to deal with IT contracting and IT operations issues. Demand some form of specific qualifications for the procurement and employment of some types of software. 7. Adjust "education": stop teaching exclusively the products of any major particular vendors in schools and at universities. 8. Abstain from "soft law": that makes negotiations with vendors very difficult, see e.g. in the financial sector, as it is hard to establish what even the actual EU requirements "are". 9. Demand porting of certain commercial software to other platforms. There is really no reason why any modern office suite or image manipulation programs should not be able to run on e.g. GNU/Linux. You could do that e.g. via incentives of some sort. 10. Define obligatory minimum functionality, e.g. for some certifications or standards. The tactics of "embrace, extend and extinguish" only work because one market dominant party, in some sphere, can sway and shape functionality in any way it wishes. 11. Give measurable advantages. E.g. some default preference in a tender if an open source solution is employed, or if it is a proprietary solution, but by some entity that otherwise does support open source... basically, answer the question for providers, "Why should I care about open source?" Make it a clear and measurable business advantage for providers to propose open source solutions. 12. "Actually do execute" and "incentivise rather than regulate": the EU has a lot of laws that, however, are not really executed in practice - sometimes even simply because they are considered so cumbersome that authorities of Member States shun to heckle their own industries. Much could already be handled under competition rules. Beware of a situation where you create more and more regulations, thus an ever-larger legal burden on individual entities, and thus actually removing potential actors from a market on which they simply cannot participate any more as they are unable to muster the needed legal resources. Consider instead incentives - what e.g. worked well are the Binding Corporate Rules, which, though not obligatory, are a genuine business advantage for those who bothered implementing them.

I deleted my Google account last week after migrating most things to open source applications (a lot of them based in the EU). Next Ill switch operating systems. Seeing what is happening in the US I am very concerned about the Trump administration using our reliance on US-BigTech against us (as they have for the International Criminal Court). The only solution is open source software which no one can take away from you. By systematically supporting this we can Improve open software a lot. But an open approach to software also opens the doors for governments all around the world to first use the same software and possibly follow our example and fund more open software. This could benefit humanity greatly (except for the Bill Gates of this world). Please make this a reality. And keep up the good work regulating Big Tech.

QUESTION 1 : Forces et faiblesses du secteur libre de l'UE Forces : communautés de développeurs et développeuses parmi les plus actives au monde, cadre réglementaire favorable (RGPD, Data Act), initiatives réussies (DINUM, Barcelone). Selon la Commission européenne, le libre représente 65 à 95 milliards d'euros d'impact économique annuel dans l'UE [1]. Faiblesses : fragmentation des initiatives nationales, dépendance aux infrastructures étrangères (GitHub, AWS), sous-financement de la maintenance. Les rares difficultés (Munich 2017) résultent de facteurs organisationnels : structure décentralisée en 18 départements sans coordination, changement de majorité politique, absence d'interopérabilité avec les autres administrations utilisant des formats propriétaires [2]. Obstacles : formation insuffisante des décideurs et décideuses, contrats-cadres favorisant les éditeurs établis, garanties de vie privée insuffisantes. QUESTION 2 : Valeur ajoutée des solutions libres Secteur public : souveraineté, contrôle du code, respect de la vie privée. La Gendarmerie française documente 40% d'économies sur 72 000 postes migrés [3]. Transparence démocratique : le code auditable permet aux citoyens et citoyennes de vérifier le fonctionnement des services publics. Secteur privé : évitement du verrouillage fournisseur, conformité RGPD, résilience, respect de la vie privée des clients et clientes. Exemple : l'emploi de logiciels libres supprime les coûts de licences (Microsoft, Apple, ...) tout en améliorant stabilité et protection des données. QUESTION 3 : Mesures concrètes au niveau UE Infrastructure respectueuse de la vie privée : - Forge logicielle européenne, hébergée et gouvernée en Europe - Cloud souverain sur sol européen, garantissant la confidentialité - Services numériques accessibles d'abord aux agents et agentes des États, puis à l'ensemble des citoyens et citoyennes Réglementation : - Formats ouverts obligatoires - Clause « libre d'abord » dans les marchés publics - Évaluation d'impact sur la vie privée systématique Financement : - Fonds européen de maintenance des briques critiques (modèle Sovereign Tech Fund [4]) - Équipes de revue européennes pour validation des contributions des développeurs et développeuses Recherche : travaux financés sur fonds publics publiés en accès ouvert [5]. QUESTION 4 : Domaines prioritaires Court terme logiciel (compétences disponibles, déploiement immédiat) : 1. Services essentiels protégeant la vie privée 2. Cloud et virtualisation souverains 3. Cybersécurité : outils d'audit transparents 4. Systèmes d'exploitation européens Long terme matériel : la souveraineté logicielle reste fragile sans maîtrise du hardware. Reconstruction des filières industrielles en Europe QUESTION 5 : Secteurs à fort potentiel - Administration publique : effet d'entraînement économique, transparence démocratique - Santé : protection des données des patients et patientes - Éducation : former sur des outils libres respectueux de la vie privée - Défense : souveraineté totale indispensable - Automobile : audit des logiciels embarqués - Énergie et infrastructures critiques : cyber-résilience vérifiable par audit public CONCLUSION Une coordination européenne évitera l'isolement des initiatives. Priorité au logiciel (court terme), transition matérielle planifiée (long terme). Le libre garantit transparence démocratique et respect de la vie privée. feedback: Linux-Open-Source-Distributionen sind heute zumeist als ISO-Image zugänglich. Das Brennen eines solchen ISO-Images auf DVD oder das Übertragen auf einen startbaren USB-Stick stellt für viele Personen aber bereits eine unüberwindbare Hürde dar. Daher mein Vorschlag: Die EU sollte ausgewählte Linux-Distributionen als DVD oder USB-Stick kostenlos verteilen. Die EU sollte den Handel verpflichten, beim Kauf von Komplettsystemen bestimmten Personengruppen kostenlos eine Linux-Distribution als DVD oder USB-Stick zur Verfügung zu stellen oder zumindest aktiv anzubieten.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: Linux Open Source Distributions are now mostly accessible as an ISO image. However, burning such an ISO image on DVD or transferring it to a startable USB stick is already an insurmountable hurdle for many people. Therefore, my proposal: The EU should distribute selected Linux distributions free of charge as DVD or USB key. The EU should require traders to provide, or at least actively offer, a Linux distribution as DVD or USB key free of charge to specific groups of people when purchasing complete systems.

feedback: Proprietary software cannot be audited, or even verified that it does what it's supposed to do. By outsourcing crucial software like the operating system or all document editors / data analysis tools used in governments and institutions, we are giving up total control over all sensitive data. The only justification for letting a foreign corporation have total control over our critical software is that we hope they aren't doing anything malicious, and that we hope they won't start doing it in the future, whether for their own gain, or by being forced to by their government. There's no reason to depend on hope alone, especially since the current political climate has proved that cyber attacks or invasions of privacy on seemingly allied nations aren't off the table. Free software can be fully audited, and proven to not be malicious. It is as secure as proprietary software, but is guaranteed to be free of foreign interventions or control. Existing free and open source software can already match or nearly match the available proprietary choices. With additional funding and support, they could easily surpass them as well. On top of the freedom and security that open software provides, it's also obviously free, saving everyone from additional costs and bureaucracy of proprietary software licenses. Apart from the important security considerations, supporting the development of free software also has a positive impact on society as a whole. Improvements to free software can be used and benefited from by all.

Hello, I would like to share some feedback, particularly about France, but I think this is the case throughout Europe. I often travel to France and each time, I have to use apps specific to each city or department. It's a pain because these apps don't always work very well, and some use proprietary technologies like Google. We have some great apps in France, such as Cartes.app and Organic Maps, which do an incredible job, but they don't get any support. I think that instead of paying a lot of money for apps for their bus/underground/tram networks, cities should focus on open source apps.

I am employed by a big corporation as software developer and in my personal time I maintain and contribute to several OSS and personal projects. The main issue, visible with the Eclipse (foundation) projects is that there is no money to pay for someone to do security updates. It took several years for the log vulnerability to be updated in Eclipse IDE. This is an issue, preventing the adoption of OSS software: Eclipse vs IntelliJ or MS-VisualStudio. And myself, I have the issue that I cannot accept payments. Accepting a payment (even 1 Euro), I need a DUN number (incorporate a company, as required by Microsoft and Apple), I need an accountant to file a yearly tax report (Euro 3000 cost); and other costs related to a company (minimum contribution for accidents). As a result, I publish my software for free for iOS and macOS, and I am a reqistered Eclipse contributor (ECA). Thanks EU to close the app-store to individual developers.

The biggest part for people/users to receive the products, is by marketing. Getting lots of help and advertisements for Open Source products would help gradually. Especially because that's what the other side of corporate greed is doing. How else can you explain to me that many PC users praised their OS just because it was common and loud with marketing. Those people hated Linux for example, even though it had much more features even back then. Today we are lucky that this stigma is softly shifting. But lots of teaching and marketing might still be needed to push for Open Source alternatives. The biggest benefit in Open Source culture could be that everyone could help everyone. I myself seem to be able to tinker with lots of Open Source software and repair someone's hobby project that is open source. But this is not possible with closed source software or hardware. Especially in corporations, any repair taken on closed sourced software or hardware can become very expensive and unnecessary. How do we prove that the person isn't pretending that the fix did take 5h while in reality he finished in 5 minutes but wanted more money. I privately saw a person actually doing this on his own service with his customers by asking for a 5h payment just for waiting 5h after editing a single line. Open Source can deliver transparency, but its more important that we would be able to decide who to trust if we dislike or dis-believe a corporation or a person. We still shouldn't judge someone's coding skills, but still should have the option to decide whom to give the task. Its obvious that its easy to squeeze every penny out of its customers if any corporation would want to.
