I really like this European Open Digital Ecosystems proposal. I think it is important to think about the adoption of the open source software. If we have an abundance of amazing open source tools that could get us through most of the everyday tasks that we do both at work and at home, how do we get people and organisations to do the switch from proprietary licensing from non-EU tech giants to open source? One part of this complex task, I think, could be spreading knowledge to individuals in their personal lives as well, since that knowledge, experience from (and even preference of) using FOSS to solve tasks could be brought into their work, thus finding its way into organisations and businesses too. As more and more individuals get concerned with their data being used in unwanted ways, vendor lock-in and the risk of loosing important data (e.g. personal images, documents, etc. that get inserted into non-open formats) due to disturbances (both technical and potentially political) "somewhere in the cloud", we need to provide guiding examples and proof that there is an alternative way to do these things. If the average user had more knowledge about the modern open source alternatives that exist, and how they sometimes can be easier to use or more productive than their often bloated proprietary counterparts, would they be a lot more open to the idea then? An other aspect to address is that many users might also have a very outdated view of what open source software is, and might recall some very early and rough version of a Linux desktop environment, or that you would need to be a "hacker that spends 16 h per day infront of a terminal" just to use it. That representation just isn't true today, and there is more than enough variety of great and polished tools out there that can get a lot of computer users through the day. But if people are not willing to try from the get-go due to preconceptions, it is important to also address these preconceptions and show them what is possible. Could there be some free, open and short form online resources that can help users depending on what task they want to do? E.g. "I want to print PDF documents", "I want to respond to emails in a desktop client", "I want to make a video call", "I want to play video games", etc. It is also an opportunity to gradually bring back more computer knowledge (and thus power) to the people, which could potentially increase digital resilience in a population. Most people use some type of computer everyday and a lot of our contemporary lives are tied up with technology. A lot of people could therefore benefit from some average technical know-how about the tools they so heavily rely on. A lot of big tech companies simply remove this organic knowledge growth that occurs from using tools by stripping away choices and promoting complex features disguised in an intuitive format. "Hey User, we just launched this incredible cloud storage feature that takes all your local data and puts it on our servers instead so we control it for you! You will use this and you will like it, press this magical yes-button and we will set everything up for you". A lot of users just get steered into something rather complex without getting to think it through, and also are not presented with the potential risks and consequences, and sometimes not even an option to opt-out. One final additional aspect is the perspective of hardware lifespans and the ecological standpoint. Running Linux and open source software gives you a lot of more modular control over what software components you need to run on your system in order for it to work in your favour, and you don't (necessarily) get forced into resource hogging updates every 2 years or so that ultimately makes your device feel slow. It would be in our best interest to keep exploring ways of maintaining longer lifespans for our devices, asking ourselves the qu

feedback: Having recently started our own Association initiative and having worked about 10 years on a niche Operatingsystem project I see a couple of things where Europe can improve to keep talent and make good OpenSource Software In most cases the big FOSS projects have a bespoke Funding strategy and one can learn about those and adapt which ones work. But all that funding is not a Culture shift that directs money to Tech that actually works. The Culture that gets us todays problem is that Managers see Workers as replaceable cogs and not as knowledge keepers. Rather than to become knowledge keepers themselves and train their people it is assumed that a Labour Market allows buying of work. This does not work for Technology. The US recognized that in the lower management levels and made sure to retain the best people while pretending to their upper management that a completely different rule worked. The EU and many Organisations also fell for that lie and kept spreading it. But the truth is, Tech is knowledge work. It takes decades of on the Job training to really understand it. Thus we should stop pretending that Hire and Fire works at all. We need NGO's that ensure the Long term maintenance of code and ways to make Companies pay for all code used and not get away with simply not paying for the labor invested. Let's use the EU for what it does best Bureaucracy and Accounting. All use of each individual piece of software costs money that the EU collects and distributes to Associations registered with that codebase. With our modern infrastructure we can prove individuals and Organizations that work on codebases. We just have to enforce payment.

The core idea behind the European Open Digital Ecosystems is brilliant and holds great potential for fostering innovation and digital sovereignty within the EU. However, to fully unlock this potential, the EU should create more accessible pathways for EU citizens to actively contribute - be it through employment, collaboration, or entrepreneurship with companies that work for and with the EU. Encouraging direct participation would not only accelerate progress but also strengthen public trust and engagement in these vital digital infrastructures.

J'utilise les outils opensource pour mon usage personnel depuis 15 ans. Sur cette période, les solutions se sont considérablement simplifiées et il est désormais facile de faire avec exclusivement des logiciels libre tout ce qui est nécessaire pour la vie numérique de tout les jours pour les citoyens et les entreprises. On n'est pas vraiment propriétaire d'un appareil si son logiciel est fermé et immuable (voir s'accaparant discrètement des données). Tout appareil disposant d'un logiciel vendu en UE (du téléphone mobile au scanner IRM en passant par l'ordinateur) devrait laisser la possibilité aux utilisateurs d'installer (facilement) leur propre logiciel alternatif sans perte de fonctionnalité. Sinon une partie significative de la valeur de l'appareil reste au propriétaire du logiciel sans contrepartie.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: I have been using OpenSource tools for my personal use for 15 years. During this period, solutions have been considerably simplified and it is now easy to do everything necessary for the digital life of all days for citizens and businesses with exclusively open source software. A device is not really owned if its software is closed and immutable (see discreet data capture). Any device with software sold in the EU (from mobile phone to IRM scanner to computer) should allow users to (easily) install their own alternative software without loss of functionality. Otherwise, a significant part of the value of the device remains with the owner of the software for no consideration.

feedback: Support for developers and companies developing open source software would be great. Funding of open source projects is a big issue. If done correctly this could leverage an independent european IT market with a huge potential. For many things good software already exists. But switching from the Microsoft world to the Linux world is not an easy transition, espacially for smaller companies. Anyway, as we (as a small company with <10 employees) could do this (this january), it should also be possible for other companies in case they get support in form of guidance, best practices and so on. IMHO, to be successful we need better solutions for setting up domain controllers and terminal servers. Especially the latter is still quite complicated and has certain limitations. For mobile phones it would be necessary to ensure that alternative OSs get supported - first of all banking software as those do currently not run inside an android compatibility layer. And being unable to do online banking will be a blocker for a widespread usage of alternative phones.

It is a good thing you are asking for feedback. A lot of IT professionals would like to help build the systems that can make the EU truly independent. We already have good and tested Open Source Software for almost every use case imaginable and investments in those projects or EU-based companies that can support these solutions are much safer and more sustainable than any licensing agreements could ever be. Secondly, the large Social Networks, the american ones as well as chinese and all other ones need to be tightly regulated and the spread of "Fake News" needs to be prohibited. None of these "services" is providing a service to us, they are purely there to control and steer. Thirdly, hardware production needs to be encouraged in the eu. Especially The dutch company ASML needs to be protected from outside influence and the development of market-competitive european CPUs and GPUs should be subsidized. And, this should not have to be said, any critical Infrastructure should not contain any components from countries that aren't trustworthy like the us or russia.

Since big American corporations have monopolised the digital space, free press has come under pressure. Political institutions are coming under pressure as well. The corporations' push for AI is bad for the environment, pushing up prices of RAM memory (which is bad for the PC and mobile market) and making totally fine products redundant. Open source software can save a lot of otherwise discarded machines, can help bring back free speech and help combat monopolisation by too powerful tech corporations. A European open source solution for office work, cybersecurity, media, PC manufacturing can bring about sustainable and secure innovation for the internal (and maybe external) market.

As an IT consultant with more than ten years of experience working for the European Commission, this feedback reflects a professional and informed perspective. I strongly believe that open-source software is a strategic pillar for Europes digital future. While open-source solutions are widely used, I observe that we still rely heavily on non-European (particularly US-based) companies for many critical digital services. This dependency raises concerns in terms of technological sovereignty, long-term sustainability, and public value. I hope this initiative will encourage EU institutions and public administrations to adopt a more consistent and ambitious approach when selecting digital solutions, by prioritising open, transparent, and reusable technologies. Open-source should not be treated as an exception, but as a default choice where appropriate. I fully support this initiative and strongly endorse the principle: public money, public code.

Dear European Commission, I would like to submit the following feedback, drawing on the public talk by Cory Doctorow (A post-American, enshittification-resistant internet, 39C3, https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3C1Gnxhfok0), which I believe contains highly relevant insights for how the European Union can meaningfully support the open source community and the public interest digital ecosystem. Doctorows core argument is that todays internet is structurally shaped by extreme concentration of power in a small number of large, primarily US-based commercial platforms. Over time, these platforms undergo what he calls enshittification: they initially serve users well, then increasingly prioritize business customers, and eventually optimize almost exclusively for shareholder value. The result is declining quality, reduced openness, lock-in, and diminished user and developer autonomy. Open source communities are particularly harmed by this dynamic, as they depend on interoperability, modifiability, and the ability to compete on fair terms. A central takeaway is that digital resilience and technological sovereignty cannot be achieved through branding or funding alone, but through enforceable structural conditions. In particular, Doctorow highlights the importance of ensuring that users and developers can leave platforms without losing their data, social connections, or functionality. Strong requirements for interoperability, open standards, and real data portability are therefore essential. Without credible exit options, even well-intentioned platforms eventually degrade. Another key point concerns legal barriers that actively undermine open source and user freedom. Anti-circumvention rules and related copyright enforcement mechanisms often make it illegal to repair, modify, or improve hardware and software that people legally own. These rules suppress innovation, prevent community maintenance, and favor large vendors over independent developers. Reforming such laws is a powerful, low-cost way to strengthen open source ecosystems and long-term sustainability. Doctorow also stresses that public investment should prioritize shared digital infrastructure rather than reinforcing private monopolies. Funding federated, decentralized, and openly governed systemswhere multiple implementations can interoperatecreates durable value and competition. Open source should be treated not merely as a cost-saving measure, but as critical civic infrastructure that supports democracy, resilience, and innovation. Finally, the talk frames these issues not as opposition to any particular country or company, but as a practical recognition that excessive centralization creates systemic risk. By supporting openness, competition, repairability, and interoperability, the EU has a real opportunity to lead globally in building an internet that resists enshittification and genuinely serves the public interest. Thank you for considering this perspective, and for your continued work on supporting open source and digital commons in Europe.

The open source software produced in Europe by a strong determined and motivated comunity is the real backbone of many , if not every, big tech in Europe but also in America, China and the whole world. These software are the basis for any starting up company to .. start. Economies all around the world are using that software to grow and prosper, which is a quintessential achivement for humanity, humans developing and giving to the community helping bricks that make things grow as nice seeds for the common good. Beyond that beauty, to which I am a keen supporter since my earliest years of work, we, should acquire the conciousness of our value and reason on how that value could resonate more. There is not a single company using software that has not benefit from open source work. Startups are a driving force in the global economy, with over 150 million startups worldwide. The United States leads with 1.14 million startups, followed by India with 493K startups. No brand new start up will exist without the open source ecosystem, open results efforts. EU has a "rare material " that is in the brain and good will of the people around the open source ecosystem world, in the companies pushing for that, in the governements funding those efforts. The AI revolution with all LLMs has proved how an enormous advantage using that open source code to train thier models has been. To strengthen the open source ecosystem I think the best would be to enlarge the visibility of the comunity, open source conferences and business fairs should be in the spotlight, great existing open source European solutions should be helped to be adopted at a larger scale by more European actors, by governements and istitutions as well when possible. Tax reduction could help as well, as many have suggested, but the greatest help would come from establishing a more general consciouness and rewards on the value that this comunity is bringing to all economioc actors and to the progress towards digital autonomy of Europes own, independent digital approach that it can help to foster.

"free as a bird not like a beer" La contribution de l'Europe pour les logiciels & matériels libres doit se faire pour l'ensemble des acteurs du logiciel libre au niveau mondial car c'est les européens qui gagneront grâce à l'intérêt général. En soutenant financièrement les fondations et acteurs du monde libre, l'impact positive ne rayonnera pas que sur les européens mais sur l'ensemble du monde qui pourra utiliser librement aussi ces logiciels permettant un affranchissement mondial : ce qui me semble correspondre aux valeurs de l'Europe. Vouloir se limiter à l'écosystème européen n'apporterait qu'une limite et des réinventions de la roue totalement stériles et coûteuses. Si des logiciels existent en libres et qu'ils sont valables : il faut donner des moyens pour les renforcer, les améliorer, leur permettre de dépasser les solutions à code source fermé. Concernant les potentielles ingérences étrangères, elle sont insolvables sans exiger du code ouvert et publié. Un autre rôle de l'Europe me parait être autour du soutien de l'audit de sécurité de ces codes publiés afin de s'assurer qu'ils sont de qualités & sécurisés. Les accusations des uns sur les autres, sans visibilité sur le code/matériel, ne seront toujours que des allégations infondées, quais impossible à prouver, toujours à risque. Rien n'empêchera un système fermé d'un jour, pour une raison quelquonque de déclencher un code malveillant que ce soit sur des antennes 5G, des onduleurs, des firewalls, téléphones, voitures, ... Tout équipement fermé aura toujours un risque d'avoir une faille volontaire ou non. Cela inclus TOUTES les entreprises européennes & étrangères car faire cette distinction est de toute façon impossible sur le long terme (rachat / actionnaire / intérêts / ...) Pour des services très sensibles, elle pourrait exiger que le code soit compilé chez l'utilisateur et que ce code source ne soit pas publié mais qu'en aucun cas cela soit juste le binaire qui soit juste installé. A l'heure du cloud, elle pourrait aussi exiger le fonctionnement autonome de certains systèmes. Quand on voit des bateaux militaires sous Windows 95 et qu'on invoque le secret des affaires : c'est à pleurer ! Le noyau Linux et son design seraient moins sécurisés que ces systèmes fermés : soyons sérieux (et en plus on peut auditer le code pour vérifier) ! Les logiciels libres sont beaucoup plus adaptatifs dans un écosystème numérique car si un lien manque, il peut être développé puis publié pour être repris par d'autres. Avec un logiciel fermé, on reste dépendant du bon vouloir de l'éditeur. Un effet de bord intéressant du logiciel libre est qu'il participe également contre l'obsolescence programmée ou "non programmée" : combien d'appareils électroniques ne sont maintenus que 1-2-3 ans avant que leur constructeur ne disparaisse, passe à une nouvelle version. On Fait quoi de cet objet connecté sans support ? sans mise à jour de sécurité ? On le jette car il ne support pas SSL xx ? Quasiment tous les objets connectés (IOT) sont dans ce cas : cela représente un risque de sécurité majeur : des millions d'équipements qui s'ajoutent jour après jour, dans le monde entier et qui sont potentiellement vulnérables, probablement pas à leur sortie mais demain : c'est une véritable bombe à retardement permettant de paralyser un pays voir un continent. Concernant les domaines technologiques, il est incroyable que l'Europe a su se doter du RGPD pour le bien de nos données personnelles mais que tous systèmes qui les traitent n'aient pas un code libre et ouvert : on a identifié ce qui est sensible mais on le mets dans une boite en carton ! Le rôle de l'Europe est donc d'aider financièrement tous les contributeurs de logiciel libre sur base de la qualité/utilité du logiciel/framework, d'éviter un monopole d'un logiciel unique

feedbackTextUserLanguage: PUBLISHED
column30: Most people do not realise that the entire global IT infrastructure relies on open source. — 80 % of servers worldwide use Linux, an open source operating system. — 70 % of smartphones use Android, the core of which is open source. — MacOS and the iPhone are based on Unix nuclei, which are also open source. — The vast majority of AI systems use Python, which is open source. — Many IT development tools (code editor, compilers, ticket tracking, etc.), used in the creation of proprietary tools, are open source. Open source is not an anecdotal element. It is the basis of the global infrastructure. The strength of giants such as Microsoft, Apple or Google lies precisely in their ability to overlay proprietary and paid layers.

feedback: Bonjour, Je suis prestataire de service Déjà, l'important c'est la communication. Il faut que l'Europe, les états, les collectivités territoriales ... communiquent sur le fait qu'elles utilisent des outils Opensource, qu'elles choisissent des intégrateurs qui proposent de l'Opensource. Pour la souveraineté, la priorité des priorités c'est, il me semble, avoir une solution d'authentification européenne interopérable (comme un google ou un microsoft). Cela devrait être un mix de public/privé. Merci pour votre travail
feedbackTextUserLanguage: Hello, I am a Dejà service provider, the important thing is communication. Europe, states, local and regional authorities... need to communicate that they use OpenSource tools, that they choose integrators that offer OpenSource. For sovereignty, the priority is, it seems to me, to have an interoperable European authentication solution (such as a google or a microsoft). This should be a mix of public and private. Thank you for your work

feedback: Using and developing Open Source Software helps building trust and independence. In time it will lower overall costs as more and more use cases are covered and won't require license fees and duplicate development in the future. As it is a common good, it should also be funded as such by directly supporting Open Source Developers in as many ways as possible.

In my view, one of Europe's strengths over other global powers is innovation. I think that is starting to show in recent years in the tech and digital domain, but there is still a lot to be done. In particular, I think we should be bolder in setting the agenda, instead of just following it. There are plenty of technologies or initiatives that are being developed and nursed within Europe, but it feels that they only way for them to mature and be used more widely is if that starts happening first in the United States or China. I refer to topics like: - Open hardware (or open source hardware), for which there is a great opportunity now with the advent of 3D printing and the pressures generated in semiconductor manufacturing. - Decentralised/distributed/federated architectures (Mastodon for social media, but also LoRa and Meshtastic for radio communications, or similar ideas applied to the energy grid...). - Non-mainstream paradigms of artificial intelligence (such as neuromorphic computing), or non-standard applications for robotics. I think we should stop only trying to catch up, and start trying to overtake by pushing forward methods and technologies that have become standard somewhere else yetthat is what innovation means, after all.

L'opensource est une nécessité dans une séquence géopolitique changeante. En limitant les accès au logiciel propriétaire, nous sommes moins vulnérable aux coupures d'accès et aux coercitions. Nécessité fait loi dit-on. Et ce qui n'était pas le cas ces vingt dernières années le deviennent. Il va de soi qu'il faut soutenir ces initiatives telle que La Suite (r) par ex développé par l'état français mais aussi les intiatives privées telle que OnlyOffice. Toutes les briques ne sont pas encore développées. Par exemple, les navigatuers internet sont basés sur des logiciels open source basés aux US (Firefox ou Chromium) sans véritable équivalent européen. des efforts doivent donc être effectués. Tout comme d'autres domaines pour se passer de Visa ou Mastercard pour ne citer que cela.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: OpenSource is a necessity in a changing geopolitical sequence. By limiting access to proprietary software, we are less vulnerable to access cuts and coercion. Necessity is said to be the law. And what was not the case in the last 20 years is becoming so. It goes without saying that these initiatives, such as La Suite (r) by way of example developed by the French State, but also private initiatives such as OnlyOffice, should be supported. Not all bricks are yet developed. For example, internet browsers are based on open source software based on US (Firefox or Chromium) without a true European equivalent, so efforts need to be made. Just like other areas to do without Visa or Mastercard to name but a few.

feedback: Der ausschließliche Einsatz von offenen digitalen Ökosystemen bringt uns nur Vorteile: - wir lösen uns von der Abhängigkeit von anderen Staaten - Investitionssummen bleiben innerhalb der EU und damit innerhalb unserer gemeinsamen europäischen Werte - jede/r kann von diesen offenen Ökosystemen profitieren - jede/r kann dazu beitragen - wir brechen die Macht der Tech-Oligarchen - wir können mehr Inklusion leisten - alle EU-Bürger werden gleichberechtigter - es gibt mehr Teilhabe Und viele weitere Punkte, die mir gerade nicht einfallen. Meiner Meinung nach wäre es sehr wichtig, Open-Source-Stipendien zu vergeben. Viele OpenSource-Programmierer*innen haben eine hohe intrinische Motivation und möchten Gutes tun, und Produkte (Software) erstellen, die unser Leben erleichtern. Sie sehen ein Problem, dass durch den richtigen Einsatz von Software behoben werden kann. Leider ist ihnen das nur in ihrer Freizeit möglich und die Arbeit wird noch nicht einmal entlohnt. Häufig sind noch nicht einmal Spenden von Unternehmen vorhanden, und es gibt viele Anfragen zu neuen Features oder zum Beheben von Problemen. Dieses Problem wird zwar durch verschiedene kleinere Förderlösungen angegangen (z.B. Prototype Fund auf deutscher Ebene), aber die Maßnahmen sind immer noch für Programmierer*innen zu kompliziert, der Förderzeitraum zu kurz und die entstehenden Projekte sind außerhalb der jeweiligen Blasen nicht bekannt. Ein Beispiel unserer Zeit ist die schnelle Umsetzung der Verkehrswende. Es gibt hierfür nicht eine perfekte Lösung für alle Fälle und Gegenden. Die Mobilitätsxpert*innen wie Katja Diehl beschreiben sehr gute Lösungen. Das häufige Gegenargument ist, nichts zu ändern, weil der Optimalzustand nicht sofort erreichbar ist. Das ist Unsinn, denn es gibt einfache technische Lösungen, wie ein Weg zu dieser optimalen Lösung zu beschreiten ist. Derzeit gibt es schon viele offene Enden, die einfach nur miteinander verknüpft werden müssen. Folgende Projekte existieren schon: - ein motis-Server, auf dem alle belkannten öffentlich auslesbaren GTFS-Feeds eingebunden sind. Dadurch ist ein Routing von Haustür zu Haustür möglich. Der Server wird nebenbei auf einer Uni betrieben. (Transitous) - eine argentinische Mitfahrwebapp, die dort sehr häufig eingesetzt wird (carpoolear) - ein derzeit entstehendes Projekt basierend auf Typescript, das mit Hilfe des Fediverse-Protokolls verschiedene Instanzen von Taxiservern (und Mitfahrapps) miteinander verbinden möchte - das gleiche auf PHP-Basis - Smartphone-Apps, die ÖPNV besser und schneller können als die Apps der einzelnen Verkehrsverbünde Zusätzlich noch meine Ideen: - Wie wäre es, die Navi-Apps in den Autos mit den Mitfahrgelegenheiten-Servern/Apps zu verbinden und den Autofahrenden die Möglichkeit geben, ein paar Euro zu verdienen, wenn diese eine zusätzliche Person mitnehmen? - Wie wäre es, diese Verknüpfung in allen Mitfahrapps mitanzubieten? Falsch ist es, ein einzelnes Unternehmen mit der Umsetzung einer solchen Lösung zu beauftragen. Und noch schlimmer ist es, wenn dann nachher kein Quelltext verfügbar ist. (Beispiel Molly- die Mitfahrapp für Lennestadt, kostete 1Mio und wurde wieder eingestellt.) Die Lösung kann nur sein, wenn Personen (z.B. Programmierer*innen) eine dauerhafte öffentliche Förderung/ Stipendium bekommen für die Arbeit an solchen gemeinschaftlich notwendigen Lösungen. Ich würde sofort ein solches Stipendium annehmen- und ich bin mir sicher die an o.g. Projekten beteiligten Programmierer*innen ebenfalls. Es ist wichtig, dass solche Lösungen dauerhaft staatlich unterstützt werden, um sicherzustellen, dass diese Lösungen immer im Sinne der EU-Bürger*innen umgesetzt werden und nicht nur für den Profit eines einzelnen Unternehmens. Ich kann mir vorstellen, dass das ebenso für andere Beispiele für OpenSource-Produkte gilt.

At the Alexandra Institute in Denmark, we both use and produce open source as an essential part of our IT and AI innovation efforts and services. Open source is also a strong motivator for our colleagues, helping us attract, develop, and retain some of the best IT and AI specialists. The opensource agenda aligns very well with EU sovereignty. Without it, far too many resources are sent abroad, undermining the EUs potential for local excellence. Open source also enables consolidation of EU efforts by reducing fragmentation and avoiding the tendency to repeatedly start from scratch, for instance in relation to public tenders. Privately, I dedicate a significant amount of my free time to contributing to opensource projects, particularly within the broader ecosystem of important communities such as Framasoft in France.

Guten Tag, aus meiner Sicht ist es dringend notwendig, dass die öffentliche Verwaltung auf ein zentrales sicheres und transparentes System aufgebaut wird, das zuverlässig ist und auch das Vertrauen der Bevölkerung gewinnt. Dies ist als Grundlage für eine digitale Verwaltung unabdingbar. Die Software hierfür ist vorhanden, in der Politik fehlt jedoch die Akzeptanz, Kompetenz und auch die Neutralität, diese Möglichkeiten zu nutzen.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: Good afternoon, in my view, there is an urgent need for public administration to be built on a central secure and transparent system that is reliable and also builds public trust. This is essential as a basis for a digital administration. The software for this is in place, but there is a lack of acceptance, competence and neutrality in policy-makers to take advantage of these opportunities.

feedback:
Passionné des ordinateurs puis de la programmation informatique, j'ai commencé très tôt ma vie professionnelle, dès l'adolescence, en réalisant des logiciels libres. J'ai travaillé ensuite dans différents environnements, libres et non libres, pour de petites associations, des PME, des collectivités françaises ou de grands comptes, et des multinationales J'ai pu mesurer une chose simple : l'écosystème informatique d'une structure est toujours le reflet de deux valeurs : l'indépendance de celle-ci, et la chaîne de confiance qu'elle construit en son sein, et vis-à-vis des destinataires de son objet : clients, partenaires, administrés... Le problème concernant l'industrie l'Union européenne, c'est son rapport à ces deux notions d'indépendance, et de confiance. Du point de vue d'un citoyen lambda comme moi, il y a de l'hypocrisie sur les deux tableaux. 1) On nous dit : « l'UE doit servir de contrepoids continental aux autres blocs comme les USA ou l'Asie » mais dans les faits, on observe que toutes nos décisions sont suivistes ou clientélistes vis à vis de ces autres blocs. On nous dit "Europe indépendante", mais on observe "Europe ultra-dépendante", ficellée, intriquée dans un maillage mondialiste 2) On nous dit par ailleurs « l'UE est un rempart pour les libertés et la démocratie », mais on observe au contraire l'augmentation des mesures de surveillance des populations (les caméras, la sécurité aéroportuaire, la copie privée, l'ambition chat control), et de contrôle social (Les questions sanitaires, la taxe carbone, les restrictions appliqués aux logements et aux véhicules liées à la protection environnementales, etc.) Mais vous savez tout cela, je ne l'apprend à personne je le dis juste pour placer ma contribution dans le réel. Donc concernant l'écosystème informatique en Europe, les créateurs de libre ne manquent pas, les solutions non plus, et des dirigeants dotés de bon sens non plus. Mais le seul problème c'est l'hypocrisie sur la volonté d'indépendance et de confiance de l'UE dans son modèle de société, et dans ses peuples. Cette hypocrisie est fondée sur une ambition qui transcende la construction de l'UE elle-même : l'ambition de fabriquer une architecture mondialiste. Cette ambition ne va pas changer du jour au lendemain, et ce n'est pas avec les mêmes qu'on fait une soupe différente. Mais à l'aune de la divergence constatée actuellement entre les blocs, il n'est pas étonnant que certains veuillent utiliser les contributions populaires (qui évidemment vont réclamer plus de libre), pour obtenir un levier supplémentaire, afin de mieux négocier les positions de l'UE. Est-ce que cela changera à long terme les positions de l'UE sur le libre ? Permettez-moi d'en douter. Car véritablement promouvoir le libre, c'est à dire le déployer à toutes les échelles de nos collectivités, PME et grandes entreprises, développer un écosystème universitaire entièrement tourné vers le libre, et surtout modifier les lois sur les ayants-droits pour protéger davantage le faible contre le fort : tout cela contribuerait à rendre l'UE véritablement indépendante, et à valoriser l'autonomie et la confiance entre tous les citoyens, ce qui va à l'inverse de la démarche de surveillance et contrôle social constatée actuellement. Tout cela contribuerait à créer une économie de la croissance, d'abondance et d'entrepreunariat, ce qui inévitablement distribuerait cette croissance à de nouveaux acteurs, relancerait l'inflation, ce qui déstabilliseraient l'omnipotence et les oligopoles des grand acteurs, souvent internationalistes, qui oeuvrent pour toujours plus de concentration, au sein de l'UE, comme à l'échelle mondiale. Bref, à mon sens cette consultation a pour seule utilité de vernir le levier de l'UE dans un bras de fer vis-à-vis des GAFAMs. Mais ce bras de fer est perdu d'avan
33365688,https://ec.europa.eu/info/law/better-regulation/have-your-say/initiatives/16213-European-Open-Digital-Ecosystems/F33365688_en,Ares(2026)69111,2026/01/20 09:25:53,Quelques mesures simples pour faire de lEurope le centre dinnovation et dutilisation des solutions libres : Mettre fin à la vente forcée et liée de Windows en laissant le choix de ne pas payer la taxe Microsoft à lachat dun PC Nutiliser que des formats réellement libres et implementables facilement pour toutes les données publiées ou demandées par lUE

login: il est clair qu'un tel changement nécessite un accompagnement des utilisateurs (et probablement des administateurs) pour une transition en douceur."
feedbackTextUserLanguage: MALATERRE
column28: Some simple steps to make Europe the centre of innovation and the dutilisation of open solutions: Put an end to the forced and tied sale of Windows by leaving the choice of not paying Microsoft tax on the purchase of a PC to genuinely free and easily implementable formats for all data published or requested by the EU, (.odt instead of.docx) Publish all data on free forms on a website, Mastodon, etc. (and possibly also on closed platforms such as Facebook or Instagram) Comply with the European Patent Convention, which rightly provides that software is protected by copyright, and put an end to Loeb’s mafia practices, which gives patents for inventions implemented by computers in order to secure the development of software free of the legal threat of GAFAM and other trolls, make it known and attract foundations which develop free Promouvoir lutilisation exclusive de source software in teaching which at least does not qualify Migrer all servers of the European institutions under Linux, BSD or other free OS and cherry, on the cake, migrate the EU workstations under Linux and a free office suite, Libretic suite. After that, it is clear that such a change requires support from users (and probably administrators) for a smooth transition.

feedback: People often choose software they know. In order to support open source and digital souvereignty governmental organizations need to use open source office software and standards. By still using Microsoft Office, docx, and so on, people and companies will use US based proprietary software. Even companies who use Linux often prefer US RedHat Enterprise Linux instead an European enterprise Linux like SUSE. If the EU governments would invest in those European based software projects they could use this money to grow and improve their quality to match or even surpass the quality of US based software. One of the big strength of Open Source Software, the large diversity, in such large scale implementations can quickly become an issue. If cities like Munich start their own projects it will be cost intensive and most likely fail. There needs to be a decision on a few software projects that have potential, instead of giving every small community the freedom to do an own project with too much customization. Support 2-3 operating systems as base with some specific distributions for things like education, 2-3 Microsoft Exchange alternatives, 2-3 distributed messengers as a MS Teams alternative and so on. Also change the way on how public tenders work. Add a big malus for proprietary and none EU based software and cloud companies. If a company like Amazon or Microsoft is avoiding taxes in Europe they should not be a valid option to be paid by public money for their services.

Il est inacceptable que les systèmes que nous utilisons au quotidien soient opaques et appartiennent à des entreprises qui œuvrent contre nos intérêts et contre la liberté des utilisateurs, et qui rendent des comptes à des états qui nous menacent. Les logiciels open source, auditables par une large communauté ou par n'importe quel service de l'état, me semblent une alternative incontournable aux produits actuellement utilisés dans les administrations. Une participation de l'état au financement de tels logiciels est forcément possible. Je ne suis pas programmeur, je suis un simple utilisateur mais je m'intéresse de près à ce qui est fait de mes données. J'ai laissé tomber Microsoft depuis quelques années maintenant et je recherche activement une alternative à Android, à Gmail, aux pilotes graphiques propriétaires etc etc. Je suis pour payer pour soutenir les développeurs et évidemment les fabricants de hardware, mais je refuse, si c'est possible, de mettre de l'argent dans un système fermé, non libre. L'informatique doit être un bien commun et l'affaire d'une communauté d'utilisateurs, du boot (oui, même le boot) au jeu en passant par la bureautique et la navigation. Et quand on voit les performances de Windows 11, c'est juste du gaspillage de ressources, surtout pour se faire voler ses données et envahir par une IA à laquelle on n'a rien demandé.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: It is unacceptable that the systems we use on a daily basis are opaque and belong to companies that work against our interests and against the freedom of users, and that are accountable to states that threaten us. Open source software, which can be audited by a large community or by any government department, seems to me to be an essential alternative to the products currently used in administrations. It is necessarily possible for the State to contribute to the financing of such software. I am not a programmer, I am just a user, but I am very interested in what is being done with my data. I have let Microsoft fall down for some years now and I am actively looking for an alternative to Android, Gmail, proprietary graphic drivers, etc. I am paying to support developers and obviously hardware manufacturers, but I refuse, if possible, to put money into a closed, non-free system. It must be a common good and the business of a community of users, from boot (yes, even boot) to game, office automation and navigation. And when you look at the performance of Windows 11, it is just a waste of resources, especially to steal your data and invade it with AI that you have not asked for.

feedback: The primary goal of the European Open Digital Ecosystem Strategy to forster the development of open source within the EU is a good goal, as we need to get more self-dependent in technological matters. Also the scope of not only driving open-source as part of research projects but, at least in my understanding, funding also open-source projects/works is worth it. The main reason is that typical wide-spread and used open source software is not necessarily an outcome of a research project, but out of a practical need. Second, academics are not rewarded by publishing open-source software or hardware, but by publishing research papers. However, I fear that the EU will, like in the EU research frameworks, create artificial barriers in terms of too high-level goals to be fulfilled, so that we will have, like in many EU (and also national funded research projects) excellent results, but with no mid-term or long-term impacts on our society, economic or robustness in international proportions. A proposal would be to have low-hanging fruit funding: 100.000 k per person (including some materials, like a computer) acutally implementing open-source software for 12 months. After 8 months an evaluation, if a second step is good to go, e.g., progress up to then, outlook. If ok funding for another year. After this go for bigger, probably more complex fundings. And do not follow the hypes: so less or no AI, no block-chain, no whatever. About me: Professor and open-source contributor: - goSDN: https://code.fbi.h-da.de/danet/gosdn - Opensource Quantum Key Distribution Networks (QKDN) software: https://code.fbi.h-da.de/danet/quant In short: go for it but try to really reach out to the open-source community and not just the most visible people. Invite people to discuss and talk. Forget shining announcement about how great things are. Measure real progress.

Pour assurer la souveraineté technologique de l'Union européenne, il est impératif de mettre à disposition des entreprises des briques logicielles fondamentales performantes. Cela inclut des outils de messagerie aussi puissants que les leaders actuels du marché (type Gmail ou Outlook) et des suites bureautiques web, afin de réduire la dépendance critique envers des solutions propriétaires tierces et de renforcer la sécurité de la chaîne d'approvisionnement. Lefficacité de cette initiative repose sur une approche agile. La création d'une entité restreinte de 10 à 20 ingénieurs de haut niveau répondrait à l'objectif de soutenir le développement et le déploiement industriel rapide des solutions libres. Cette structure permettrait de produire des outils de grande qualité. Pour garantir une adoption massive par les secteurs public et privé, il est crucial de proposer une solution "clé en main". Cela exige une documentation d'excellence, facilitant tant le déploiement technique que l'utilisation quotidienne, afin de répondre aux impératifs de facilité d'usage et de maintenance du code. En fournissant ces infrastructures de base ouvertes et vérifiables, l'UE peut transformer ses capacités numériques en ressources partagées et souveraines.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: In order to ensure the technological sovereignty of the European Union, it is imperative to provide companies with high-performance basic software blocks. This includes messaging tools as powerful as current market leaders (such as Gmail or Outlook) and web office suites, to reduce critical reliance on third-party proprietary solutions and strengthen supply chain security. The effectiveness of this initiative is based on an agile approach. The creation of a restricted entity of 10 to 20 high-level engineers would meet the objective of supporting the development and rapid industrial deployment of open-source solutions. This structure would make it possible to produce high-quality tools. To ensure mass adoption by the public and private sectors, it is crucial to propose a ‘turnkey’ solution. This requires excellent documentation, facilitating both technical deployment and daily use, in order to meet the requirements of ease of use and maintenance of the code. By providing this open and verifiable basic infrastructure, the EU can transform its digital capacities into shared and sovereign resources.

feedback: Les écosystèmes ouverts trouvent leur fondement dans le partage de la connaissance, l'un des meilleurs outils de paix que nous ayons connu dans notre histoire. Ils participent directement du processus démocratique : les écosystèmes ouverts et leur fonctionnement peuvent faire l'objet d'un contrôle citoyen. Que l'Europe se dote et utilise de tels outils apparaît donc comme une évidence, à la fois pour contribuer à faire vivre les principes démocratiques qui l'ont fondée et pour la protéger de la dépendance, voire des ingérences hostiles.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: Open ecosystems are based on the sharing of knowledge, one of the best tools for peace that we have known in our history. They are directly involved in the democratic process: open ecosystems and their functioning can be subject to citizen control. It is therefore obvious that Europe should equip itself with and use such tools, both to help bring to life the democratic principles on which it is founded and to protect it from dependence and even hostile interference.

feedback: En tant qu'employé dans le domaine du développement informatique (et de l'open-source en très grande majorité), je trouve que cela est une excellente idée. Il y a plusieurs points qui pousseront les entreprises et les institutions à franchir le cap de l'open-source. Il y a l'aspect fonctionnel: est-ce que le programme en question correspond à mon besoin? Si ce n'est 100% pas le cas, ce n'est pas (toujours) un problème vu que tout est accessible et modifiable pour ses propres besoins (pour résumer très simplement). L'aspect purement technique: la communauté de l'open-source est composée de différents profils dont des développeurs expérimentés qui font de leur mieux afin que l'architecture des différents projets corresponde aux meilleurs standards (entre-autres) afin de garantir toutes les qualités d'un bon logiciel: maintenabilité, qualité, lisibilité, UX et j'en passe. Un autre avantage technique indéniable est que vu que le code est accessible par tout un chacun, il est plus facile de repérer des failles de sécurités et de trouver une solution rapide. C'est exactement le même avantage pour la partie fonctionnelle: si un utilisateur repère un bug, il le corrige pour tout le monde. Si un autre utilisateur a un autre cas d'usage (qui n'avait pas été pensé avant), il peut l'ajouter et toute la communauté en bénéficie. Le point qui me tient à cœur est d'inciter les européens à participer à l'open-source. Pourquoi ne pas créer un incitant financier pour les personnes qui contribuent à cette communauté? Cet avantage donnant-donnant permettrait de récompenser les personnes qui sont dans l'engrenage de ce système et de continuer à s'investir. Il ne faut pas oublier que l'informatique est un domaine en constante évolution, qui demande beaucoup d'auto-apprentissage afin de rester à jour. Un programme open-source qui n'utilise pas les technologies modernes n'est pas toujours fonctionnellement intéressant pour ses utilisateurs/entreprises. Pousser les entreprises et les institutions vers une voie, ce n'est possible que si l'offre (les programmes open-source) est suffisante, robuste, de qualité etc. Un des leviers pour cette possibilité est d'inciter les citoyens à y contribuer.

As an employee in the field of IT development (and open-source in the vast majority), I find this an excellent idea. There are several points that will push businesses and institutions to move beyond the open source. There is the functional aspect: does the programme in question meet my need? If this is not 100 %, it is not (always) a problem as everything is accessible and modifiable for its own needs (to summarise very simply). The purely technical aspect: the open-source community is made up of different profiles, including experienced developers who do their best to ensure that the architecture of the various projects meets the best standards (among others) in order to guarantee all the qualities of good software: maintainability, quality, readability, UX and I am in the process. Another undeniable technical advantage is that, as the Code is accessible to everyone, it is easier to identify security gaps and find a quick solution. This is exactly the same advantage for the functional part: if a user identifies a bug, he or she corrects it for everyone. If another user has another use case (which had not been conceived before), he can add it and the whole community benefits from it. I am keen to encourage Europeans to take part in open-source activities. Why not create a financial incentive for those who contribute to this community? This grant-giving advantage would reward those who are in the grip of this system and continue to engage. It should not be forgotten that IT is a constantly evolving field, which requires a lot of self-learning in order to stay up t

I am enclosing a short version here. The full and detailed opinion (including justifications and examples) is attached as a PDF annex. In addition, it is available (as a backup) here: https://drive.proton.me/urls/RZGZ4MJD80#xVaxj9T9T7UJ My mindset: FOSS is a critical infrastructure. The EU should not only use open source, but also strengthen it through procurement and funding logic in such a way that dependencies, lock-in and opacity are reduced in real terms. Key points: (1) Public funds public code: In the case of procurement and funding, source code should in principle be published and usable. Effective Copyleft as a backflow protection is important to ensure that improvements are not re-privatised through circumvention models (e.g. SaaS/Cloud). (2) Avoid open core: Core free, relevant functions paid for/closed lead to lock-in again in practice. Public authorities should favour solutions that are fully free to use, maintain and further develop. (3) Interoperability also in hardware/building technology: Open interfaces and free standards must be mandatory for systems to really wor

feedback: For us as a small independent IT company, open source systems allow us to provide services like adapting software which we cannot do for closed source software. When (public) clients request changes to the software, they are always restricted to the vendor in case of closed source software (e.g. Microsoft products) and therefore there is no business opportunity for European businesses, whereas for open source software (e.g. Nextcloud, Libreoffice, ...) European businesses could change the software according to the clients needs. That would keep business within the EU but also allow for competition and allow for better quality or lower prices because if just the vendor can make changes, there won't be any (real) competition. And if the vendor does not want to perform these changes while the client is happy with the product in general (so they don't want to switch to a completely new platform), they are left with software which is not optimal regarding their needs - leaving efficiency and (tax payers) money on the table. With open source products, other companies can perform the changes, even if the original vendor doesn't want to. Europe is the home of a lot of open source developers, companies and products which are often deliberately ignored for huge contracts because esp. public clients often buy from the same vendor ("Nobody ever got fired for buying IBM", the modern version would be "Microsoft" or "AWS"). Public clients will, mid- and longterm, save a lot of money, getting better products which can be adapted to their needs without being dependent on the decisions of big companies, often located in countries which tend to threaten or sanction institutions whenever they want - see the court in Den Haag or the current demands regarding Greenland.

I am a german citizen who profits immensely from open source. Data and Software have become way more than just a tool that individuals use to process their own things. It is critical infrastructure, and "not using something" is not an solution anymore, for a long time. In school I learned nothing about IT, but had a motivated teacher. Didnt understand the need for open source and free software, as anyone else. I started using Google-free Android because my phone was not supported anymore. Linux out of curiosity, as a hobby. No institution ever recommended me to use tools that respect me, and I wish that for the EU. We need to invest in code and infrastructure for our own good. I want an internet connection I can trust, with a router and a modem running open source software. I want to use open source operating systems on my phone and my Laptop, without needing to fear that I cannot access some services like train infrastructure, universities or important tools. The "buy european" initiatives are often unhealthy, as they ignore the fact that open source and good software is an international effort. I use Software from India, the USA, Russia, Africa, China and more, and all Software I can trust, because the code is open. I do not trust proprietary code for good reasons, and it is important to me and all people who know less about how they can protect themselves from data krakens than me. I wish for the new digital identity system to implement homomorphic encryption with plausible deniability. I wish for a digital Euro like GNU Taler, which grants individuals the privacy and freedom of cash, but stops money laundering and illegal businesses on a large scale, where the real harm to society occurs. I want a world where public surveillance is prohibited, as it is not effective for preventing crimes, and involves proprietary systems that are often trivial to get access to. I want less IOT and more sustainability. Devices and Software should be standardized, interoperanle and repairable. The EU should heavily invest in existing open source companies, NGOs and community projects, that show every year anew how effective they can be at converting money into work for the public good. I fear a Europe under surveillance, where freedom of speach and thought is impossible because of client-side-scanning. Where people are not free to go wherever they want. Where every transaction is transparent to those who own the money and offer banking services. Where the discrepancy between poor and rich has gotten so big, that most people can only dream of a free life. Where every movement and health-affecting practice is tracked by apps, involving publicly financed health insurances. Where secure operating systems like GrapheneOS are forbidden, because even stupid criminals have understood how far you need to go, to regain a glance of privacy in the already existing tech-dystopia. Please make sure that Europe does not become a surveillance hell on earth. Empower people who do good, be strict and clear, finance good software. Thank you.

Als EU-Bürger und deutscher Staatsbürger ist es mir ein großes persönliches Anliegen, dass die Europäische Union in den Bereichen Digitalisierung, technologische Entwicklung, Datenhoheit und digitale Souveränität deutlich unabhängiger wird. Ich arbeite selbst aktiv und täglich mit Software aus dem Open-Source-Umfeld, mit Linux-Systemen sowie mit Software von in der EU ansässigen Herstellern. Dabei geht es mir nicht ausschließlich um Open Source, aber insbesondere deutsche und europäische Software spielt für mich eine zentrale Rolle. Als Selbständiger in Deutschland unterstütze ich meine Kunden dabei, ihre bestehenden IT-Systeme auf offene und zukunftssichere Lösungen umzustellen, insbesondere auf Proxmox VE. Diese Umstellungen funktionieren in der Praxis zuverlässig und ohne nennenswerte Probleme. Proxmox ermöglicht es, sowohl kleine IT-Umgebungen als auch komplexe Infrastrukturen bis hin zu großen Rechenzentren und europaweiten oder weltweiten Clustern effizient zu betreiben. Als Open-Source-Plattform auf Basis von Debian kann Proxmox als tragende Grundlage für nahezu alle öffentlich verfügbaren Softwaretechnologien dienen und zeigt sehr deutlich, dass leistungsfähige, sichere und skalierbare Schlüsseltechnologien bereits heute aus Europa kommen können und einen echten Unterschied machen. Mit meinen zahlreichen Schulungsvideos auf YouTube erreiche ich viele Menschen, die sich gezielt über Debian, Linux, Proxmox und Themen rund um IT-Sicherheit informieren. Diese Community wächst kontinuierlich und zeigt sehr deutlich, wie groß der Bedarf an verständlichen, praxisnahen Informationen zu offenen und souveränen IT-Lösungen ist. Durch meine tägliche Arbeit im IT-Bereich in Berlin und den engen Austausch mit meinen Zuschauern habe ich einen sehr direkten Einblick in das wachsende Interesse daran, digitale Kontrolle und Datenhoheit zurückzugewinnen. Ich helfe jeden Tag Menschen dabei, sich von US-Diensten zu lösen und auf europäische Alternativen umzusteigen. Die Voraussetzungen dafür sind in Europa vorhanden. Die Technologie ist da. Das Wissen ist da. Die Mittel sind da. Gleichzeitig spüre ich aber auch, wie man als einzelner Mensch an Grenzen stößt. Nicht selten habe ich das Gefühl, mit diesem Engagement weitgehend allein zu sein, obwohl der Bedarf offensichtlich ist. Ich verlagere meine Softwareentwicklung zu Codeberg. Meine Videoinhalte ziehe ich zu Dailymotion um. Meine Server laufen vollständig auf Linux, Proxmox und Open-Source-Software. Ich arbeite mit Thunderbird und LibreOffice und betreibe KI-Systeme lokal. All das zeigt, dass dieser Weg realistisch und praktikabel ist. Aber es ist eine große Aufgabe, die langfristig nicht von Einzelpersonen getragen werden kann. Deshalb bitte ich ausdrücklich darum, Proxmox als europäische Virtualisierungsumgebung nicht zu übersehen. Mit dieser Plattform bewege ich täglich ganze IT-Welten, auch wenn sie im Einzelnen klein erscheinen mögen. In der Summe zeigen sie, was heute schon möglich ist, wenn man europäische Open-Source-Technologien konsequent einsetzt. Proxmox ist eine europäische Open-Source-Plattform zur Virtualisierung und zum Betrieb moderner IT-Infrastrukturen. Technisch basiert Proxmox auf Debian Linux und kombiniert klassische virtuelle Maschinen mit Containern in einer einheitlichen Oberfläche. Damit lassen sich komplette IT-Umgebungen zentral verwalten, absichern und automatisieren, ohne auf proprietäre Cloud- oder US-Anbieter angewiesen zu sein. Eingesetzt werden kann Proxmox überall dort, wo Server, Dienste oder Anwendungen zuverlässig betrieben werden müssen. Das beginnt bei kleinen Umgebungen, etwa einem einzelnen Server in einem Büro oder bei Selbständigen, und reicht bis hin zu großen Rechenzentren mit Hochverfügbarkeit, Clustern und verteilten Standorten. Mit Proxmox lassen sich Windows- und Linux-Systeme parallel betreiben, Backups

column34:
When an entity (public or private, physical or legal) wishes to use a service for storing and/or processing its data in the cloud, it de facto loses ownership and availability. The services of today’s big tech companies depend on US law, giving the government access to the data they host. It is also possible to imagine economic war measures being taken by this government to block access to certain customers of these companies, making their economic and strategic data inaccessible, without of course forgetting other services (communication, data processing, etc.), thus paralysing parts of the economy. However, without going so far as these extreme hypotheses, we have already reached a stage where it is difficult (if not impossible) to leave in order to change cloud service provider. The example of Airbus trying, unsuccessfully, to leave the Microsoft Azure cloud since 2017 is telling. By subscribing to the services of a Cloud provider, we walk the handcuffs ourselves to the wrists and give them the key. The promotion of Open Source could enable the emergence of services subject exclusively to European law capable of competing with BigTech, thereby preserving European sovereignty in terms of protecting the confidentiality and availability of the data of European entities. Businesses (European but not only) should also be encouraged to participate and contrib

feedback: Let's reduce our dependence on entities, whose interests might not be aligned with our interests. The EU should be a strong player in all areas (at least I as a citizen would like it to be that way), and open source software can help building the necessary IT infrastructure. Let's found this infrastructure on software unencumbered by arbitrary restrictions. When money is spent, it should be for the good of a broad population, not just for a few already too powerful corporations. Using and helping to further develop open source software should be a no-brainer, if independence is a real goal, not secret behind closed doors "deals". I think our political leaders owe us citizens honest, thoughtful and clean decisions, benefiting the public, not only a small elite group.

I welcome the idea of better supporting the use of open-source software. It's the only way companies and also public administrations can escape the vendor lock-in, because if the code is available, any company with employees having the right skills can support the software, add features, extract the data for further analysis etc. I have two main proposals: 1. Source code always available I would propose that it would become a binding requirement for any and all IT purchases of the public sector that the source code of all software parts is also given to the buying entity (not necessarily as open-source to the public, because of trade secrets etc.). Also for all updates and later changes, the source code has to be provided. The code has to include working instructions to generate the product from the given source code. This would prohibit any vendor lock-in because the product can be maintained by other companies as well. 2. Public open-source code when beneficial Oftentimes multiple public entities face the same tasks, e.g. accepting car registrations from citizens. For such types of IT purchases, the requirement should be that the source code is not only given to the buyer but additionally that the license allows the buyer to publish the source code so other public administrations can use and/or adapt the product for their use. A strong copyleft license like AGPLv3 would make sure that any variations would remain public so that everyone would benefit. This would lead to overall cost reduction because every work would only have to be done once (and not again for every public administration). Thanks for your initiative! It's really appreciated.

Damit OpenSource Softwareprodukte die selbe Chance auf eine Marktpartizipation haben müssen einige Kontexte legislativ einbezogen werden. Zur gleichberechtigten Teilnahme von beispielsweise Open-Source Betriebssystem müssen Betreiber monopolistisch oder kritischer IT-Systeme, sofern sie keine Open-Source Anwendersoftware anbieten, eine geeignete API bereitstellen um selbe Funktionen zu ermöglichen. Dies verhindert einen Lock-In auf die duopolistischen Hersteller von mobilen Betriebssystemen. Meist sogar mit dem Effekt, dass dort die Registrierung eines Benutzerkontos verpflichtend ist. Beispiele: Die Nutzung einer eID, elektronischer Führerscheine oder IKFZ/DFZ und anderen eGovernment-Anwendungen darf nicht nur mit den geschlossenen Betriebssystemen und der Bezug der Anwendung nicht nur aus App-Stores von Apple oder Google möglich sein. Die Nutzung von Banking-Apps darf nicht nur mit den geschlossenen Betriebssystemen und der Bezug der Anwendung nicht nur aus App-Stores von Apple oder Google möglich sein. Zur Abholung von Paketsendungen darf aus Pakstationen oder zur Nutzung einer eTickets in öffentlichen Transportmitteln nicht nur mit den geschlossenen Betriebssystemen und der Bezug der Anwendung nicht nur aus App-Stores von Apple oder Google möglich sein.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: In order for OpenSource software products to have the same opportunity to participate in the market, some contexts need to be included in legislation. To participate e.g. in open source operating systems on an equal footing, operators of monopolistic or critical IT systems, unless they offer open source application software, must provide an appropriate API to enable the same functionalities. This prevents the duopolistic manufacturers of mobile operating systems from locking in. Most often even with the effect that it is mandatory to register a user account there. Examples: The use of an eID, electronic driving licences or IKFZ/DFZ and other eGovernment applications must not only be possible with the closed operating systems and not only with app stores from Apple or Google. The use of banking apps must not only be possible with the closed operating systems, and the use of the app must not only be possible from app stores belonging to Apple or Google. For the pick-up of parcels, it must not only be possible to access the closed operating systems and the app from Apple’s or Google’s app stores from pick-up stations or to use an e-ticket on public means of transport.

feedback: For 25 years, Ive built software for small and global companies around the world. Ive never written a single line of code that didnt stand on the shoulders of open source. Linux is my OS, Java language is my workhorse, PostgreSQL my database, Kubernetes my orchestration, and the entire web stack is built on open source foundations. My career, my livelihood, *my ability to solve problems* it was all made possible by a global community of developers, sharing code freely, building trust through transparency. This isnt just a personal anecdote; its the bedrock of modern software engineering. Open source isnt a "nice-to-have" its the *only* viable model for rapid, secure, and innovative development at scale. Do not let you tell otherwise, it is factually wrong. Proprietary alternatives are expensive, lock you into vendor whims, and often lack the scrutiny and community-driven security that open source provides.

Digital sovereignty depends on multiple columns: * Host your own data on your own servers. ("the cloud" is just another name for "other people's computers). It is cheaper in the long run. At least have your cloud run by enterprises, that have their real HQ in the EU. No EU data should rest in AWS, Azure or Google clouds. * Know your software stack - i.e. use trusted, open source software. * Have skilled people to maintain the whole thing. * Use open, documented (standardized?!) interfaces between components if possible. * Support relevant open source projects via dependable, direct or indirect funding (see Apache Foundation, Linux Foundation - all US based). Open source needs funding and professional developers. Otherwise, a tiny but relevant part of the software stack might get hijacked (see xz-issue) or developers stop working on the project. * Open source needs independence from major software vendors. * Demand publication of public funded custom software on EU-hosted git servers. Leave git-hub. The public pays for ist, the public sees it (and the public can help improve it). * In the long term, try to establish compute hardware production in the EU for at least partial independence. * KISS-principle: do not build on vendor specific tools. The vendor will migrate his platform and everything has to be rebuilt (or kept running on outdated platforms). * Invest in real IT education. Not the consumer based "how to use [xy]" stuff. (Insert any proprietary brand like "MS-Word"). Let students play with Raspberry Pis instead of Windows-Computers. (Consider the Brits at least as friendly neighbors of the EU). * There is life without Microsoft or Apple or Oracle. * Try not to re-invent the wheel 1000 times (each hamlet developing their own traffic management system) but promote EU-wide standards. * Keep politics open and transparent and keep private communication private (and encrypted!). And - please, please! - forget about AI to solve all our problems. A stochastic parrot will provide convincing language but false "facts". Leave AI to the engineers. There we have some interesting applications.

Contribution to the Call for Evidence: European Open Digital Ecosystems I strongly support the objective of building European Open Digital Ecosystems as a foundation for digital sovereignty, resilience and long-term competitiveness. Reducing structural dependencies on non-European technology providers is essential. However, the success of this initiative will depend less on the promotion of openness as a principle and more on whether open ecosystems become operationally sustainable in real-world conditions. In many policy discussions, openness is primarily associated with open-source software. While open source is a crucial building block, openness should be understood more broadly as the ability to retain control over development, deployment, integration and long-term evolution. Code availability alone does not ensure sovereignty if operation, maintenance and critical dependencies remain concentrated elsewhere. From practical experience in developing modular, API-driven software solutions for small and medium-sized enterprises, a recurring structural challenge becomes visible: open and interoperable systems are technically feasible and often closer to real user needs, yet they struggle to scale beyond pilot use. The limiting factors are rarely technical. Instead, they are rooted in procurement frameworks, certification requirements, liability models and funding mechanisms that implicitly favour large, vertically integrated vendors. In practice, many innovative solutions are built around open standards, open interfaces and replaceable components. They are designed to integrate into heterogeneous digital environments rather than to lock users into a single ecosystem. This architectural openness aligns closely with the stated goals of the European Open Digital Ecosystem initiative. Yet such solutions frequently face barriers when transitioning from experimentation to long-term operation, particularly in regulated or publicly funded contexts. Funding often focuses on initial development, while maintenance, security updates, documentation and governance remain structurally underfunded. This creates a paradox: Europe encourages openness and innovation, but its digital frameworks often reward scale and consolidation over modularity and adaptability. As a result, smaller actors including SMEs, micro-enterprises and independent developers contribute innovation but are excluded from sustained participation in digital ecosystems. To address this gap, the European Open Digital Ecosystem strategy should explicitly recognise that openness must be supported across the entire lifecycle of digital systems. In particular, it should: Treat open digital ecosystems as long-term infrastructure, not as short-term innovation projects. Complement funding for open development with durable mechanisms for operation, maintenance, security auditing and governance. Enable procurement and compliance models that value interoperability, modularity and open interfaces, even when solutions are delivered by small providers. Reduce structural barriers that prevent SMEs and independent developers from participating in public digital ecosystems while maintaining high standards of security, reliability and trust. Digital sovereignty is ultimately about capacity and choice the ability to adapt, replace and evolve systems without structural lock-in. European Open Digital Ecosystems will only fulfil this promise if they are designed to be economically viable, operationally robust and accessible to Europes diverse innovation landscape, rather than optimised primarily for its largest players.

Defined Sotware Stacks a unified set of software for common use casese would be helpful to help users moving to Open Source Software. Linked on an EU website which does also provide manuals etc. Furthermode, a userfriendly EU Linux distribution would be nice. For example, preinstalled wine, winboat, bottles, steam. A unified UI for all those compatibility tools should be developed. The desktop manager theme should be created in a way that it is easy for people moving to Linux to orientate. Launching AppImages should allow the user to install them and create a link without using the terminal etc. Most Linux distributions are in some way userfriendly, but the features differe too much. China has got it's own Linux, Russia has got Astra Linux, even the north koreans do have their own Linux. Why don't we have one?

Social networks are full of poison and this is exactly what americans want: dumb people fed with fear, fake news, stupid influencers'opinion, etc Not only do we need to create european digital solutions, services, social networks and plateforms; but we also must EDUCATE our kids to use them and teach them why they must be careful using the US ones.
