LET S START BY HELPING THEM Thanks

As a software engineer and open source contributor working in the EU, consideration should be made to allow and protect contributions made to open source projects on personal time from employers who try to stifle personal contributions in employment contracts. I am a proponent of open source software (especially for interoperability purposes), and have published and contributed open source projects in the past. However my current employer does not allow open source contributions unless strictly approved. They do not approve personal contributions to open source even on private time, on private equipment, where it does not infringe on company time or performance, and even in areas that have no conflict of interest/competition with the company. As such, I no longer publish personal open source contributions publicly for fear of retaliation by my employer. This is a shame, as I cannot contribute back to the open source community and help it reach its potential. Other colleagues I have spoken to also are in the same boat. Legislation that builds upon EU directive (2019/1152) to specifically call out and allow open source contributions done on personal time would be welcome.

Auf dem 39C3 präsentierten Schüler der Gruppe Teckids ihr Anliegen für eine verstehbare (digitale) Welt, abseits der Produkte der IT-Monopolisten mit Hilfe von OPEN-Source und beklagten die Hindernisse die ihnen im Schulaltag auf dem Weg dorthin begegneten. Mein Appell: Die junge Generation braucht dringend mentale Unterstützung gerade aus der Politik, mit Digitalisierung alleine ist es nicht getan. Oft scheitern diese an den Vorgaben der Kultusbürokratie, nur Produkte und zentrale Social media kanäle nutzen zu müssen. Dabei gibt es genügend dezentrale und den datenschutz beachtende Alternativen wie das Fediverse bzw. Mastodon und Signal oder Threema, etc. Statt dem closed Source Windows von Microsoft ist das offene Linux die bessere Alternative, die gerade in der Wissenschaft genutzt wird. Wollen wir als Gesellschaft unsere Kinder zu eigenverantwortlichen Menschen erziehen oder zu Konsumsklaven? Danke für die Möglichkeit der Stelkungnahme MfG Michel Sauee
feedbackTextUserLanguage: At 39C3, students from the Teckids group presented their desire for a resilient (digital) world, away from the products of IT monopolists using OPEN-source, and deplored the obstacles they faced in everyday school life on their way there. My appeal: The young generation urgently needs mental support, especially from politics; digitalisation alone is not enough. These often fail because of the requirements of cultural bureaucracy to use only products and central social media channels. There are enough decentralised alternatives that respect data protection, such as the Fediverse or Mastodon and Signal or Threema, etc. Instead of Microsoft’s closed source windows, open linux is the better alternative used in science. As a society, do we want to educate our children to become responsible people or consumer slaves? Thank you for the possibility of taking the car by MfG Michel Sauee.

feedback: Software developed with public funds must be made available under a Free and Open Source Software license to ensure that taxpayers retain rights to the digital tools they finance. Adopting this framework fosters European digital sovereignty by reducing reliance on non-European proprietary vendors and eliminating expensive vendor lock-in. It promotes economic efficiency by allowing Member States and municipalities to share solutions, thereby avoiding redundant development costs and accelerating innovation. Furthermore, open code guarantees critical security and transparency, allowing independent auditing of the digital infrastructure that governs public life. Consequently, establishing "Public Money, Public Code" as a standard is essential for a democratic, collaborative, and fiscally responsible digital Europe.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: Software developed with public funds must be made available under a Free and Open Source Software license to ensure that taxpayers retain rights to the digital tools they finance. Adopting this framework fosters European digital sovereignty by reducing reliance on non-European proprietary vendors and eliminating expensive vendor lock-in. It promotes economic efficiency by allowing Member States and municipalities to share solutions, thereby avoiding redundant development costs and accelerating innovation. Furthermore, open code guarantees critical security and transparency, allowing independent auditing of the digital infrastructure that governs public life. Consequently, establishing ‘Public Money, Public Code’ as a standard is essential for a democratic, collaborative, and fiscally responsible digital Europe.

feedback: Offene Software ist die einzig tragfähige Grundlage für digitale Souveränität. Jede ernsthafte Strategie zur technologischen Unabhängigkeit Europas muss offene Software nicht als Option, sondern als verbindlichen Standard begreifen. Proprietäre Software steht diesem Ziel strukturell entgegen. Der zentrale Vorteil offener Software liegt in ihrer Transparenz. Nur wenn der Quellcode öffentlich einsehbar ist, können Nutzerinnen und Nutzer, Unternehmen, Wissenschaft und öffentliche Stellen nachvollziehen, wie Software tatsächlich funktioniert, wie Daten verarbeitet werden und ob Sicherheits- oder Datenschutzrisiken bestehen. Transparenz ist eine Voraussetzung für Vertrauen, Kontrolle und Rechtsstaatlichkeit. Proprietäre Software hingegen basiert auf bewusster Intransparenz. Der Code ist verborgen, Prüfungen sind ausgeschlossen oder nur unter restriktiven Bedingungen möglich. Damit wird Kontrolle systematisch vom Nutzer zum Anbieter verlagert. Offene Software schafft Unabhängigkeit und verhindert "Vendor Lock-in". Sie ermöglicht es, Systeme weiterzuentwickeln, zu warten oder zu ersetzen, ohne von einzelnen Herstellern, deren Geschäftsinteressen oder geopolitischen Abhängigkeiten abhängig zu sein. Proprietäre Software erzeugt dagegen langfristige Bindungen an einzelne Anbieter, proprietäre Schnittstellen und Dateiformate, die einen Wechsel erschweren oder wirtschaftlich unmöglich machen. Dies schwächt Wettbewerb, Innovationsfähigkeit und Handlungsfreiheit, insbesondere im öffentlichen Sektor. Auch aus Sicherheits- und Resilienzsicht ist offene Software überlegen. Offener Code kann von einer breiten Gemeinschaft geprüft, verbessert und abgesichert werden. Sicherheitslücken werden schneller erkannt und behoben. Bei proprietärer Software müssen Nutzer darauf vertrauen, dass der Anbieter korrekt, vollständig und zeitnah handelt, ohne eigene Kontrollmöglichkeiten. Darüber hinaus ist offene Software die Grundlage des heutigen Internets und nahezu aller modernen IT-Systeme. Betriebssysteme, Netzwerktechnologien, Kryptografie, Webserver, Programmiersprachen, Cloud-Infrastrukturen und eingebettete Systeme basieren überwiegend auf offener Software. Ohne offene Software wären das Internet, globale Kommunikation und moderne digitale Dienste weder technisch noch wirtschaftlich realistisch. Selbst proprietäre Produkte bauen in großem Umfang auf offenen Komponenten auf. Proprietäre Software dient in vielen Fällen primär dazu, Informationen zu verbergen, Abhängigkeiten zu schaffen und Kontrolle zu monopolisieren. Sie widerspricht damit den Zielen von Transparenz, Nachvollziehbarkeit, Wettbewerb und demokratischer Kontrolle. Für kritische Infrastrukturen, öffentliche Verwaltung, Bildung, Forschung und sicherheitsrelevante Systeme ist sie daher ungeeignet. Die EU sollte offene Software konsequent priorisieren durch offene Standards, bevorzugte Nutzung in öffentlichen Beschaffungen, nachhaltige Finanzierung zentraler Projekte und rechtliche Rahmenbedingungen, die Offenheit belohnen statt behindern. Digitale Souveränität ist ohne offene Software nicht erreichbar.

Open software is the only viable basis for digital sovereignty. Any serious strategy for Europe’s technological independence must consider open software not as an option but as a binding standard. Proprietary software is structurally at odds with this objective. The key advantage of open software is its transparency. Only if the source code is publicly available can users, businesses, academia and public authorities understand how software actually works, how data is processed, and whether there are security or privacy risks. Transparency is a prerequisite for trust, control and the rule of law. Proprietary software, on the other hand, is based on deliberate opacity. The code is hid

De plus, nous pourrions devenir une alternative mondiale et crédible, notamment en garantissant labsence de contrôle et stockage des données. feedbackTextUserLanguage: It is high time to work on mutualisation and digital lindependence of Europe. Our dependence on usa is unacceptable, especially as we have all the tools and infrastructure we need, so why wait? In addition, we could become a global and credible alternative, including by ensuring the lack of control and storage of data. feedback: Je suis très favorable au développement de solutions open source européennes en remplacement des solutions commerciales majoritairement américaines mais aussi de plus en plus chinoises. Outre le fait que celles-ci ne garantissent absolument pas les données personnelles des utilisateurs et les monayent sans leur accord, ces solutions sont aussi des outils d'influence et de pression culturelle et géopolitique, ainsi que d'espionnage économique et technologique. Les principaux freins utilisateurs à l'utilisation de nouveaux outils open source sont : -La simplicité d'installation et d'utilisation -Le support -La garantie de pérennité et de sécurité -Les coûts directs et indirects de migration -Les coûts éventuels d'utilisation à mettre en face de la fausse gratuité de certaines solutions commerciales, au moins dans leur version d'appel. Il faut également que ces outils s'appuient sur des solutions d'hébergement de données souveraines et à l'abri d'intervention étatiques injustifiées, ainsi que des solutions de cyber sécurité à la pointe, qui doivent être soutenues par l'UE conjointement. Pour que ces solutions émergent et se développent et pour éviter les écueils financiers à la wikipedia, elles devraient pouvoir être financées de manière pérenne par l'UE ou avec le soutien de l'UE. Une possibilité serait la création de fondations indépendantes, contrôlées par les citoyens européens, et dont le capital pourrait être apporté par l'UE, les états membres et les citoyens directement. Ces fondations devraient être aussi contrôlées democratiquement par les citoyens, et participeraient à la sélection et au soutien des projets et solutions européennes, de manière transparente. Pour finir, cet écosystème devraient faire l'objet de larges communications et publicité auprès du public et des citoyens européens pour les sensibiliser aux enjeux et faciliter son adoption.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: I am very much in favour of developing European open source solutions as an alternative to the predominantly American but also increasingly Chinese commercial solutions. Apart from the fact that they do not guarantee users’ personal data at all and monayers them without their consent, these solutions are also tools for cultural and geopolitical influence and pressure, as well as for economic and technological espionage. The main user barriers to the use of new open source tools are: — Simplicity of installation and use – Support – Guarantee of durability and security – Direct and indirect costs of migration – Possible costs of use to be faced with the false free nature of certain commercial solutions, at least in their call version. These tools also need to rely on sovereign data hosting solutions that are free from unjustified state intervention, as well as state-of-the-art cyber security solutions, which need to be jointly supported by the EU. For these solutions to emerge and develop and to avoid financial pitfalls to wikipedia, it should be possible for them to be financed sustainably by the EU or with EU support. One possibility would be the creation of independent foundations, controlled by European citizens, the capital of which could be provided by the EU, Member States and citizens directly. These foundations should also be democratically controlled by citizens, and would participate in the selection and support of European projects and solutions, in a transparent manner. Finally, this ecosystem should be widely communicated and publicised to the European public and citizens to raise awareness and facilitate its uptake.

feedback: Ich arbeite seit über 25 Jahren als Softwareentwickler und Softwarearchitekt zuerst im Finanzwesen und seit fünf Jahren in der Bergbau-Industrie in Nord-Schweden. Im Finanzwesen nutzt man das Tool, welches am effizientesten funktioniert, egal ob Open-Source oder kostenpflichtig. Aber bei meinem derzeitigen Arbeitgeber spielt Effizienz kaum eine Rolle. Open-Source Produkte kommen hier aus Bequemlichkeit kaum zum Einsatz. Es ist eine Schande, dass CTOs und Stakeholder mehr auf externe Berater hören, statt auf eigenes Personal, welches teilweise schon seit Jahrzehnten im Unternehmen tätig ist. Dies scheint primär aus Unwissenheit zu passieren. Die Verantwortlichen wissen einfach nicht, dass es einfacher und günstiger wäre, auf Open-Source Produkte zu setzen. Als Beispiel möchte ich hier das Beratungsunternehmen Gartner erwähnen, welches - als US-Unternehmen - den Tech-Stack von US-Unternehmen empfiehlt. Gleiches gilt aber auch für andere Beratungsunternehmen, egal ob EU oder nicht-EU. CTOs holen sich hier Rat und externe Berater untermauern ihre Vorschläge und Angebote eben mit den Dokumenten von Gartner etc. So wird IT-Infrastruktur in US-Clouds wie Azure und AWS ausgelagert. Diese ausgelagerten Teile der IT werden dann primär von externen Unternehmen betreut. Das interne Personal bereut quasi nur noch den verbleibenden "abgenagten Knochen" der ursprünglichen IT. Die Kosten für bestehende Cloud-Dienste steigen kontinuierlich, und es kommen weitere Kosten für neu hinzugekommene Dienste hinzu. US-Unternehmen wie "Workday" binden ihre Dienste ausschließlich an US-Clouds. Microsoft erzwingt für die Nutzung ihrer Cloud-Dienste einen Microsoft-Account, welcher eben über Microsoft Azure Entra (ehemals Azure Active Directory) an die Microsoft Cloud gebunden ist. Eine Abschaltung von Azure Entra ist gleichbedeutend mit einer Abschaltung aller verknüpften Dienste wie z.B. Office 365, Teams, etc. Der Wildwuchs bei Azure/AWS/Google, der eine Migration stark erschwert, ist kein Versehen von Microsoft, Amazon und Google, es ist ein gewünschtes Feature um einen Wechsel der Kunden möglichst zu erschweren. Geplante Obsoleszenz wird auch von US-Unternehmen genutzt, um ihre Kunden in neue Cloud-Dienste zu zwingen. Statt Bizztalk weiterzuentwickeln "empfiehlt" (zwingt) Microsoft seine Kunden zu Azure Logic apps etc. zu wechseln. Da Bizztalk kein Open Source ist, können andere Entwickler dieses Produkt nicht weiter pflegen. Gleiches gilt für andere proprietäre Produkte und Protokolle. Das "geschlossene" Ökosystem von Apple dient nicht dem Nutzer sondern der Gewinnmaximierung von Apple. Freie Versionen von Android (ohne Google) oder Linux als Betriebssysteme für Smartphones sollten per Gesetz verpflichtend für Unternehmen sein. Dabei gibt es bessere Alternativen. Proxmox statt VMWare oder HyperV, Samba AD DC als Ersatz für Microsoft Active Directory, FreeIPA als vergleichbare Software für Linux Server/Clients, Keycloak als Identitätsprovider (IDP) und zur Föderierung der Benutzer. Grommunio statt Exchange, NextCloud statt Sharepoint, Jitsi Meet statt Teams/Slack/Webex, TrueNAS statt Windows Server, ... Ich denke, dass ohne eine Digital-Market-Tax und gesetzliche Vorgaben zur Cloud-Nutzung von Unternehmen sich nichts ändern wird. Unternehmen welche innerhalb der EU tätig sind, sollten dazu verpflichtet werden, für den Betrieb innerhalb der EU und Dienste, welche sie innerhalb der EU anbieten wollen, ausschließlich freie Open-Source Produkte und Dienste anderer EU Unternehmen nutzen zu dürfen, welche ebenso dieser Regelung unterliegen. Um den Wildwuchs zu beenden, sollten verpflichtende Standards zur Kompatibilität geschaffen werden, wie z.B. durch die Cloud Native Computing Foundation, damit Dienste entsprechend dieser Standards auch außerhalb der EU angeboten/genutzt werden können.

I software Open Source permettono di avere sistemi aperti e ridurre le dipendenze da singole società commerciali, che tra l'altro sono sostanzialmente americane (quindi extra UE). Potenzialmente posso portare a costi bassi, a non dipendere da paesi oggi ostili e a ridurre le rendite. Al contempo, però, la natura non commerciale (o limitatamente commerciale) può portare a una mancanza di sviluppo adeguato per mancanza di risorse comparato con le grosse società americane, che posso contare su introiti enormi. Il rischio è quindi che certe soluzioni Open Source rimangano soluzioni di serie B, come sono stati per anni i software alternativi a MS Office (magari validi per uso personale, ma per uso professionale con macro ecc. rimane un divario sensibile). Per tale motivo le aziende preferiscono pagare una soluzione professionale che risparmiare per avere soluzioni mediocri. Le soluzioni Open Source e gli standard rimangono però essenziale nell'ambito delle reti, degli standard di sicurezza, dell'autenticazione avanzata, della firma elettronica, ecc. Sarebbe auspicabile avere soluzioni Open Source anche in ambito applicativo, ma è forse meno facile per quanto detto sopra. Detto questo, l'obiettivo prioritario della UE è rendersi indipendente dai paesi extra-UE, quindi deve essere favorito a tutti i costi lo sviluppo di soluzioni proprietarie per Cloud, AI, mail e, possibilmente, sistemi operativi/browser. Probabilmente ciò si può ottenere solo con un mix fra Open Source e software commerciale, in modo da creare l'interesse per le società europee ad investire nello sviluppo delle soluzioni.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: Open Source software makes it possible to have open systems and reduce dependencies on individual commercial companies, which, among other things, are essentially American (i.e. non-EU). I can potentially lead to low costs, no dependence on countries that are currently hostile and reduced rents. At the same time, however, the non-commercial (or limited commercial) nature may lead to a lack of adequate development due to a lack of resources compared to the big American companies, which can count on huge revenues. The risk is therefore that certain Open Source solutions will remain B series solutions, as have been the alternative software to MS Office for years (perhaps valid for personal use, but for professional use with macros, etc. a significant gap remains). This is why companies prefer to pay for a professional solution that they save for poor solutions. However, Open Source solutions and standards remain essential in the area of networks, security standards, advanced authentication, electronic signature, etc. It would be desirable to have Open Source solutions also in the field of application, but it is perhaps less easy for the reasons set out above. That said, the EU’s priority objective is to become independent from non-EU countries, so the development of proprietary solutions for Cloud, AI, email and, possibly, operating systems/browsers must be promoted at all costs. This can probably only be achieved through a mix of Open Source and commercial software, so as to create an interest for European companies to invest in the development of solutions.

feedback: This is an experience report from a psychology professor working at a state financed university in germany. My main aim is to show that a transition by an average user to open source software is possible in a typical academic/administrational context that is currently still strongly rooted in proprietary software. I switched almost completely to open source software (Linux MINT, Libre Office, etc) more than 1 year ago. I work in an environment that is Microsoft dominated, but none of the processes in my organization were interrupted in any significant way. The switch itself cost me half a day, the necessary transition in materials about 2 work days (e.g. adapting thousands of ppt slides for lectures for a whole year to libre office impress etc). Everything went very smooth. My whole working group is now switching and we save a lot of money every year. None of my co-workers is an OSS specialist, but the transition is going smooth again. This shows in a scientific/administrative context that OSS is now in a state that anyone can use it productively. The only exception is PDF editing software, which, however, is much cheaper when switching away from ADOBE to payed alternatives on Linux (though a complete open source pdf editor seems something still to be lacking). I know that many other colleagues also would like to switch (one did after talking to me and is happy now, too), but most are insecure and would like support from the institution. If our university would push this a bit, it could be a turning point. The amount of money saved for licenses would be enourmous without any significant loss of functionality.

Context and ambition As an entrepreneur and investor, I propose an ambitious roadmap to quadruple in four years the Linux user base in Europe (from 16 to 64 millions), increase awareness of Free Software and structure a sustainable European ecosystem around Open Source. Indeed, the EU has many assets in Open Source: o Collaborative innovation (e.g.: KDE, Nextcloud, Blender, Mastodon). o Cost reduction and sovereignty (e.g., migration of the National Gendarmerie to Linux). o Security and transparency (e.g.: Matrix). On the other hand, the EU also has many weaknesses in Open Source: o Lack of visibility and coordination of awareness campaigns. o Fragmentation of efforts and absence of a unified European leader (unlike Red Hat in the US). o Lack of mature support companies and sustainable contributions from European businesses. o Cultural (distrust of CIOs) and legal barriers (license uncertainties). Yet the added value of Open Source is proven: o Cost reduction (e.g. savings of 50 million/year for the region of Bolzano in Italy, 20 to 30% reduction in costs for SMEs) o Sustainability and environment (longer use of even old equipment) o Interoperability and locking brake (e.g.: EU OSOR portal, OVHcloud with OpenStack). o Security and privacy (e.g.: Kolab for sovereign emails in Germany). Proposed concrete measures 1. Quadruple the European Linux base in 4 years: o Campaigns for the general public (" Linux is simple ", "Linux is freedom "). o Mandatory pre-installation of Linux on PCs sold in the EU. o Training and European certifications (e.g.: " EU certified Linux administrator "). o Tax incentives for companies migrating to open source. 2. Increase awareness: o General public events (e.g.: "Free Month"). o Documentary series on the 'heroes' of European Open Source in European media o Label 'Open Source Friendly' for committed companies and administrations. 3. Develop user support companies: o European investment fund (500 million) to finance scale-ups. o Reserved calls for tenders (20% of IT public contracts for open source solutions). o Network of Centres of Excellence (e.g.: a "CERN of Free Software"). Flagship proposal Launch an "Open Source Plan for Europe" with a budget of 2 billion/year, combining grants, training and communication, led by a European Free Software Agency, to be created, in partnership with the Free Software Foundation Europe and APELL. For more information, please go to: http://linux4all.eu

I really welcome this initiative and hope it won't get captured by the usual suspects from BigTech an that there will be real steps on this track. In my personal and professional surrounding here in Germany I can't see any progress - it is rather the opposite, everywhere MS365, Google or Apple. Postings from Politicians and Officials on X and Meta. Come on, we can do better... What I totally miss in the discussion is the importance of transparency and open code not only in Software, but also in Hardware, Firmware and Drivers. For real trust in our digital devices this is crucial.

Sehr geehrte Damen und Herren, als engagierter Nutzer und Befürworter von Open-Source-Software möchte ich mich im Rahmen der aktuellen Konsultation zur digitalen Souveränität zu Wort melden. Besonders begrüße ich die Initiative der EU-Kommission, die Bedeutung von Open-Source-Software und offenen Standards in den Fokus zu rücken. Diese Technologien sind nicht nur essenziell für Innovation und Sicherheit, sondern auch für die Unabhängigkeit Europas im digitalen Raum. Open-Source-Software wie Linux bietet entscheidende Vorteile: - Transparenz und Sicherheit: Offener Quellcode ermöglicht unabhängige Prüfungen und reduziert Abhängigkeiten von einzelnen Anbietern. - Kosteneffizienz: Durch den Verzicht auf Lizenzgebühren können öffentliche Haushalte erhebliche Mittel einsparen Gelder, die stattdessen in Bildung, Infrastruktur oder digitale Innovation fließen könnten. - Flexibilität und Anpassbarkeit: Open-Source-Lösungen lassen sich bedarfsgerecht anpassen und fördern so digitale Souveränität. - Förderung lokaler Wirtschaft: Europäische Unternehmen und Entwickler:innen profitieren von einem wachsenden Ökosystem, das Arbeitsplätze schafft und Know-how im Kontinent hält. Herausforderungen in der öffentlichen Verwaltung Als Mitarbeiter einer Landesregierung erlebe ich täglich, wie stark öffentliche Institutionen von proprietären Lösungen insbesondere von Microsoft abhängig sind. Diese Abhängigkeit birgt Risiken: - Kostenexplosion: Regelmäßige Preiserhöhungen für Lizenzen belasten die Haushalte und treffen letztlich alle Steuerzahler:innen. - Lock-in-Effekte: Technologische Abhängigkeiten erschweren den Wechsel zu alternativen, kostengünstigeren oder sichereren Lösungen. - Datenhoheit: Geschlossene Systeme werfen Fragen nach Datenschutz und Kontrolle auf besonders kritisch in sensiblen Bereichen wie Verwaltung oder Bildung. Ich appelliere an die EU-Kommission, hier aktiv zu werden: Die EU sollte klare Richtlinien erlassen, die den Einsatz von Open-Source-Software und offenen Standards in der öffentlichen Verwaltung fördern etwa durch verbindliche Quoten oder Präferenzklauseln in Ausschreibungen. Förderprogramme für Behörden, die auf Open-Source-Lösungen umsteigen, könnten die Transformation beschleunigen. Investitionen in Schulungen für Mitarbeiter:innen und die Förderung von Open-Source-Communities stärken die langfristige Unabhängigkeit. Erfolgreiche Umstellungen (z.B. in München, Frankreich oder der spanischen Region Extremadura) sollten als Vorbild kommuniziert werden. Die digitale Souveränität Europas hängt maßgeblich davon ab, ob wir es schaffen, uns von monopolistischen Strukturen zu lösen. Die EU hat hier die Chance, eine Vorreiterrolle einzunehmen zum Wohl der Steuerzahler:innen, der Innovation und der demokratischen Kontrolle über unsere digitale Infrastruktur. Ich danke Ihnen für die Möglichkeit, mein Feedback einzubringen.

I particularly welcome the European Commission’s initiative to focus on the importance of open source software and open standards. Open source software such as Linux offers crucial advantages: Transparency and security: Open source allows for independent audits and reduces dependencies on individual suppliers. Flexibility and adaptability: Open-source solutions can be customised to promote digital sovereignty. Promoting

column38: I discovered the open-source tools 15 years ago and now I am 100 % open-source. In addition to being reliable and respectful of privacy, they are often much closer ‘to the ground’ than the big proprietary solutions that have only to do with users and the way they use them again. Many too many people are not even aware of these tools, where there are many prejudices when they are installed and used. In the same way as awareness-raising campaigns on tobacco, alcohol, road safety, etc., it is also vital to deploy means of communication to promote these tools. Creating them is one thing, but having them adopted is another. Cybercrime has become endemic in our societies and I do not even talk about deepfakes, which are a poison for our democraticians. Citizens continue to remain largely passive in their relationship with technology and only those who have convictions or a certain sensitivity are proactive in their use of digital tools. It is also necessary to spread propaganda for the free tools (in the right sense of the term), if they will remain confidential as they are still the case. Ehut does not.

feedback: I highly appreciate this initiative! Open Source can and shall be an important column of our infrastructure. What's important to me: - focus on single developers and small groups of developers who are not backed by big tech companies - priority to developers/teams residing inside EU territory - supported projects shall not be allowed to sell their project to any company. Forming a non-commercial organization like a foundation or association for better coordination and easier fundrausing would ve fine and shall be encouraged - transparency about what the funds are used for and how it is done Overall, I'm in high support of this initiative and would like to see that coming into realization sooner than later!

Bonjour, Il semble nécessaire de disposer doutils numériques souverains et en particulier dun système dexploitation. Peu importe quil soit payant ou gratuit, mais nous devons cesser de dépendre doutils ou de plateformes qui récupèrent et revendent nos données. En tant que technicien informatique indépendant, je propose souvent à mes clients dinstaller des solutions Linux, afin de conserver du matériel déclaré obsolète pour Windows 11, et cela repose souvent sur la conservation des outils américains (Gafam). il serait intéressant daller plus loin et de proposer un système dexploitation entièrement européen mais surtout des services souverains.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: Hello, there seems to be a need for sovereign digital solutions and in particular an operating system. No matter whether it is paid or free, but we need to stop relying on dubious platforms that retrieve and resell our data. As an independent IT technician, I often offer my customers to install Linux solutions, in order to keep equipment declared obsolete for Windows 11, and this is often based on the preservation of US tools (GAFAM). It would be interesting to go further and offer a fully European operating system but above all sovereign services.

feedback: Les données des Européens doivent être hébergées au sein de l'Union européenne. Les logiciels des États membres ne doivent plus dépendre d'un pays extérieur à l'Union européenne. Des serveurs européens devraient être disponibles pour la sauvegarde de nos données.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: Europeans’ data must be hosted within the European Union. Member States’ software must no longer be dependent on a country outside the European Union. European servers should be available to save our data.

feedback: Bonjour, Excellente initiative. Parler, c'est bien, agir c'est mieux. J'attends donc avec impatience que l'Europe agisse enfin. Cordialement.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: Hello, Excellent initiative. Talking is good, acting is better. So I look forward to Europe finally acting. Kind regards.

feedback: Un écosystème numérique consiste en une ou plusieurs plateformes numériques ainsi que d'autres services imbriqués ou connectés par des relations de complémentarité. La question que vous abordez est donc extrêmement vaste. Je pense être légitime dy répondre en tant que citoyen européen, dautant que je suis un utilisateur constant des logiciels et systèmes Open source et depuis très longtemps dans de très nombreux domaines. Docteur en droit spécialisé en droit de la fonction publique, ancien avocat, depuis huit ans responsable juridique, jutilise très souvent pour ne pas dire quotidiennement les outils source tant dans mon travail que dans ma vie personnelle. Dans mon cadre professionnel, jutilise très souvent les outils open source et notamment les logiciels Firefox et brave. Pour des raisons de travail coopératif, je dois néanmoins utiliser la suite bureautique Office Microsoft comme mes collègues, ce qui est normal. À titre personnel, jutilise presque exclusivement des systèmes et logiciels Open source Non seulement parce que je souhaite en tant que citoyen mextraire du carcan technique imposé par les États-Unis, mais pour des raisons plus globales de sécurité de préservation des données, etc. pour ne pas dire defficacité technique. Je suis en train de basculer tous mes ordinateurs personnels sur Linux. Ce système est désormais totalement opérationnel et totalement mature. Jutilise LibreOffice, OnlyOffice, Firefox, Thunderbird, évolution jutilise aussi à profit avec profit speechnote qui a remplacé chez moi Dragon pro. Il faut savoir que javais dicté ma thèse de droit sous dragon, il y a plus de 15 ans et que je retrouve les mêmes qualités, sous speech note En musique, jutilise Audacity VLC Ayant développé à titre personnel depuis longtemps une expertise dans le son (pyramix samplitude professionnel protools.), je nai néanmoins pas trouvé matière suffisamment satisfaisante dans ce domaine très particulier qui est une niche technique mais jutilise des versions Linux de softs propriétaires : reaper bitwig studio et presonus studio one 8 mais tous en version native linux. Avec des cartes son Merging et Neumann. Je ne rencontre strictement aucune difficulté technique, Linux répond à tous mes besoins, il est bien plus efficace et opérationnel que Windows 11 dont on connaît les problématiques non seulement sur le plan de lefficacité technique, mais également sur le plan de la préservation des données personnelles il nest pas question de poursuivre en ce sens. Jamais je nirai sur Windows 12. Je ne suis pas fermé à toutes hypothèses, puisque j'utilise aussi des logiciels propriétaires sous Linux, mais je fais la part des choses et il nest pas question de poursuivre sous système propriétaire Windows avec un Copilot qui est imposé à peu près partout. Aussi pour conclusion, je vais juste me permettre dêtre surpris par linterrogation européenne quelque peu nonchalante sur cette question quand on sait que de nombreuses collectivités publiques commencent à basculer, il était temps sur Linux, et que la gendarmerie nationale française est sur Linux depuis 20 ans. Or, la gendarmerie est un service public de grande qualité comme chacun sait. À mon sens, il est plus que temps de basculer sur le logiciel libre pour quantité de raisons : économies budgétaires, contrôle des données personnelles et des données professionnelles, maximisation de lapplication du RGPD, etc. Il serait temps à mon avis justement que lEurope propose quelques distributions Linux à destination des citoyens et des services. Les systèmes existent, ils sont matures et tres simples demploi. (jai véritablement débuté sous Linux avec Agnula DEMUDI qui était poussée par à lépoque et de mémoire, la communauté européenne et lIRCAM.) Cordialement

feedback: I work as a senior IT executive in a critical infrastructure in Bavaria. Our systems must remain operational precisely when others fail. Yet today, operators of critical infrastructure are structurally and strategically dependent on non-European vendors primarily U.S. corporations. With more than 14,000 employees, our organization relies heavily on on-premise solutions while at the same time being locked into products from Microsoft, VMware, Veeam, Citrix, Softcell, Zoom, and similar providers. This level of dependency is no longer acceptable from a sovereignty, security, or resilience perspective. The European Union urgently needs binding and enforceable regulations to significantly reduce dependence on U.S. technology providers in critical infrastructure. At the same time, the EU must actively foster and protect European alternatives that are capable, competitive, and suitable for large-scale, mission-critical environments. This transformation will not happen through market forces alone. It requires mandatory, well-funded EU transformation programs that explicitly support the transition to non-U.S. products and prioritize European solutions. Without such instruments, critical infrastructure operators will remain trapped in existing vendor dependencies. The economic argument is equally compelling: our annual software expenditure alone exceeds 20 million euros a figure that is rising sharply year over year. Redirecting even a portion of this spending toward European vendors would strengthen technological sovereignty, secure jobs, and retain value creation within the EU. Finally, it must be made unequivocally clear to all executive and political decision-makers: continued dependence on non-European technology in critical infrastructure is no longer tolerable. The transition will be uncomfortable at first, but abandoning it for the sake of short-term convenience would be a strategic failure with long-term consequences.

Un des aspects important souvent négligé est l'importance des algorithmes de recommandations qui servent à sélectionner le contenu qui nous est recommandé sur les différents médias sociaux et sites agrégateurs de journaux (ex: Google actualités). La proportion des personnes s'informant en grande partie ou exclusivement via ces moyens est maintenant très importante, pour le bon fonctionnement de nos démocraties, avoir un bon contrôle de leur fonctionnement est essentiel. Le problème est que la majorité de ces algorithmes sont connus pour maximiser la rétention (souvent à des fins de collecte de données et publicitaires), avec pour effet de bord connu d'amplifier le clivage politique, de renforcer les théories du complot, voire même dans certains cas extrêmes de causer des génocides (voire les accusations de génocide au Myanmar causé par l'algorithme de Facebook). Ces algorithmes dans de mauvaises mains peuvent également être utilisés volontairement dans des objectifs d'ingérence politique (scandale de Cambridge Analytica ou plus récemment élections annulées en Roumanie). Reprendre le contrôle sur la recommandation de l'information est à mon avis essentiel pour le bon fonctionnement de nos démocraties européennes. Agir sur ce sujet peut se faire de plusieurs manières : Tout d'abord obliger les réseaux sociaux à publier le code qui sert à recommander massivement du contenu en Europe, ensuite permettre aux chercheurs de pouvoir étudier à nouveaux le fonctionnement de ces algorithmes librement. Il faudrait également soutenir les projets de recherche qui visent à la réalisation d'algorithmes de recommandation alternatifs visant par exemple à de la création de communs et dont la robustesse à des manipulations extérieures est prouvée mathématiquement (voire par exemple le projet Polis développé par Taïwan dans le cadre d'ingérences Chinoises ou encore le projet d'algorithme de recommandation alternatif Tournesol). Idéalement, on pourrait imposer aux plateformes de contenu d'exposer une API publique permettant aux utilisateurs d'utiliser l'algorithme de recommandation de leur choix (de manière modulaire). Tout comme il est vital qu'un processus de vote soit simple et compréhensible par tous pour que les citoyens aient confiance dans la légitimité des élections, il est vital que les algorithmes de recommandations soient transparents (donc open source) et au maximum "explicables" à tous pour que les citoyens reprennent confiance dans l'information qui leur est recommandée. Si les plateformes ne sont pas tenues responsables du contenu qu'elles hébergent (tout comme un hébergeur web n'est pas responsable des sites créés par ses clients), elles sont en revanche tout à fait responsables du contenu qu'elles recommandent et amplifient massivement. À ce titre, l'Europe a une légitimité à exiger de ces plateformes une transparence de la recommandation et une intercompatibilité avec des algorithmes open source tiers.

An important aspect that is often overlooked is the importance of recommendation algorithms that serve to select the content that is recommended to us on the various social media and newspaper aggregators (e.g.: Google news). The proportion of people who learn to a large extent or exclusively through these means is now very important, for the proper functioning of our democracies, having proper control over their functioning is essential. The problem is that the majority of these algorithms are known to maximise detention (often for data collection and advertising purposes), with the known side effect of amplifying political polarisation, reinforcing conspiracy theories, and even in extreme cases causing genocide (or even accusations of genocide in Myanmar caused by Facebook’s algorithm). column38: The European Open Digital Ecosystem Strategy is an important step towards strengthening the EU’s technological sovereignty, security and competitiveness through open source. The clear strategic approach recognising the central role of open source for an independent and innovative digital Europe is particularly welcome. Building a strategic and operational framework to increase the use, development and re-use of open digital assets within the Commission is consistent and usefully builds on the achievements of the Open Source 20202023 strategy.

feedback: I completely support the initiative to strengthen the EUs open-source ecosystem, particularly its emphasis on promoting open-source adoption across all public sectors. Open-source solutions offer transparency, cost-efficiency, and greater control over digital infrastructure -- critical advantages for governments and public institutions. By mandating or incentivizing the use of open-source software in public administration, the EU can set an example, reduce dependency on proprietary vendors, and foster innovation that aligns with European values of openness and collaboration. A key opportunity lies in the education sector, where adopting open-source technologies as the standard for teaching and learning would have a transformative impact. Integrating open-source tools into curricula -- from primary schools to universities -- would not only equip students with practical skills but also normalize open-source as the default choice for digital solutions. This approach would create a generation of professionals and citizens who are familiar with, and advocates for, open technologies, further accelerating the EUs tech sovereignty and competitiveness. Finally, I strongly advocate for enforcing the use of open formats and protocols for data exchange and communication within public institutions and beyond. Relying on proprietary formats, such as those tied to specific office suites, creates unnecessary dependencies and barriers. By standardizing open formats, the EU can ensure interoperability, long-term accessibility of data, and fair competition. This would empower individuals and organizations to choose tools based on merit, not vendor lock-in, and reinforce the EUs commitment to digital autonomy and innovation.

Les logiciels open sources devraient particulièrement devenir la norme dans l'éducation. Car il est beaucoup plus difficile de développer l'usage des outils opensource lorsque l'éducation numérique s'est faite avec les outils des géants américain. Quand toute une génération a découvert et a appris à manier les outils numériques avec Windows, Google, Microsoft Office. Ils vont reproduire ces usages par la suite dans leur vie profesionnelle et privée. Si nous développons les apprentissages sur des outils opensource alors toute une génération aura acquis directement de bons réflèxes.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: Open source software should especially become the norm in education. This is because it is much more difficult to develop the use of OpenSource tools when digital education has taken place with the tools of American giants. When an entire generation discovered and learned how to handle digital tools with Windows, Google, Microsoft Office. They will then reproduce these uses in their professional and private lives. If we develop learning on OpenSource tools, then a whole generation will have achieved good results directly.

feedback: This submission addresses the Call for Evidence questions on the EU open-source ecosystem from the perspective of governance, operational resilience, and public sector accountability. The attached document focuses on structural dependency and exit capacity as conditions for legitimacy in public digital systems, and on the role of open source, open standards, and interoperability as enablers of auditability, substitutability, and long-term control. It is submitted as independent analytical input intended to support the development of the European Open Digital Ecosystem Strategy.

EU should embrace open digital ecosystems. They foster cultural growth, empower developers, reduce dependencies from single entities, and provide knowledge to all participants - easily accessible via the community. True, there could be set backs (why should a company invest if the result is free and not protected?), but the overall benefits outweigh - and business models are still possible.

Il est stratégique que lEurope soit indépendante pour ses outils numériques en promouvant et développant des solutions open source : Cloud Réseau, téléphonie Informatique décisionnelle Bureautique Messagerie type whatsapp IA Réseau sociaux Systèmes dexploitation Processeurs et semi-conducteurs Ordinateurs, smarphones
feedbackTextUserLanguage: It is strategic for Europe to be independent in its digital tools by promoting and developing open source solutions: Cloud Network, Decision-making computer telephony Bureautique Messagerie type whatsapp IA Social Network Operating systems Processors and semiconductors Computers, smarphones

feedback: I strongly support the initiative towards more digital sovereignty and open source. But there are 2 major things that need to be addressed. One is that the EU should have some amount of capacity for professional code reviewers, especially for some critical software that are used in military/government/critical business infrastructure. The other one is, that we need ruling round the software support for Linux. I am not an expert, so I am just saying things that I think are helpful but maybe I am overseeing something. My point is, if some Company sells for example a headset in the EU and the headset needs a proprietary software to work properly, then there should be a law around that software that the manufacturer has to offer support for Linux. I recently switched my home PC to Linux and mostly everything works smooth but some devices just don't work without software and that software is only available for Windows. So then there is a long and frustrating process trying to make this software work. At work I am an IT specialist and we are currently setting up a ruleset of how to offer Linux as an alternative for users while also staying complient with ISMS.

About question 4, and resilience in general, I suggest that it is better to include decentralization and federation of services, as it happens for messagging systems based on XMPP, as an example, and distributed social networks like Friendica, Mastodon, Diaspora.

As the founder of Agiledrop, a company that has built an international business serving clients like UNESCO, European Union institutions, Deutsche Telekom, T-Systems, and Capgemini entirely on open-source technologies, I welcome this initiative and offer the following feedback. /// STRENGTHS AND WEAKNESSES OF THE EU OPEN-SOURCE SECTOR /// Strengths: Europe has excellent developer communities, strong technical talent, and mature open-source projects that compete globally. Our ecosystem aligns well with EU values around transparency, privacy, and user rights. /// Weaknesses: European open-source companies struggle to access growth capital compared to US counterparts. The SaaS business model requires significant marketing investment that European companies cannot match. Additionally, many high-quality open-source projects lack the documentation and formal governance structures required to access EU funding, creating a barrier that favors established players over innovative emerging projects. /// BARRIERS TO ADOPTION AND SUSTAINABLE CONTRIBUTIONS /// For adoption: Large consulting firms are often incentivized to propose proprietary solutions due to partnership arrangements and licensing margins. Procurement processes frequently favor established vendors over open-source alternatives. /// For contributions: Open-source business models based on implementation services are labor-intensive and difficult to scale. Without access to venture capital, European companies build sustainable businesses but cannot achieve the growth rates of US SaaS competitors. /// ADDED VALUE OF OPEN SOURCE /// We are in an era where every organization is essentially a digital company. Software and data have become core intellectual property. This means organizations need to own their software, build it in-house, and control it fully. Open source makes this possible. /// Concrete examples from our experience: Content management - With Drupal, organizations self-host and own their data completely. No vendor lock-in, no per-seat licensing, no per-revenue fees. You can scale and adapt without worrying about who controls your content and customer data. Education - Licensed LMS platforms typically charge per student, making costs unpredictable as institutions grow. With Moodle, universities pay for implementation and maintenance, then scale without additional licensing costs. /// RECOMMENDED MEASURES /// Reform procurement to evaluate total cost of ownership and vendor lock-in risks, not just initial price. Create funding mechanisms accessible to promising open-source projects regardless of documentation maturity. Reduce regulatory burden on technology startups (current regulations disproportionately affect small European companies while US giants absorb compliance costs easily). Support scaling and market integration, not just research phases. Let private sector lead innovation while government creates enabling conditions. /// PRIORITY TECHNOLOGY AREAS /// AI should be prioritized. Europe lacks strong AI model builders, but can leverage open-source models (Llama, Mistral) to build competitive applications. Beyond foundation models, we should not forget the AI application layer, where US investors are pouring money at dot-com bubble levels into mostly American companies - a rare European success story is Lovable.dev, a platform enabling anyone to create applications without coding experience using AI. Speed is essential - regulatory processes must not delay our ability to compete. /// SECTORS FOR INCREASED OPEN-SOURCE ADOPTION /// Public administration, education, and healthcare would benefit significantly. These sectors handle sensitive citizen data and should not depend on foreign vendors whose terms and pricing they cannot control. /// The initiative's diagnosis is correct. Success requires addressing fundamental issues: investment access, market fragmentation, and regulatory burden.

status: the machine can be supported by community for a long time. There is no need for involvement of the original producer. This decrease electronic waste. The second benefit is for alternative systems. It is much easier for them to add support for such hardware. It helps with healthy competition. I would like to mention one aspects more. The Europe has many IT specialists and these people can perform work with high added value. Many of them had to go to the USA to find a suitable position. There is a cost in switching from one software to an other. However this cost can go to local specialists."

feedback: With our product Sequoia PGP we provide security critical infrastructure latest since Redhat and Debian both decided to base their package signatures on our software. I would never trust security relevant software where I cannot check the source code. As provider of Free Software under GNU licenses we understand that making business and providing Free Software does not contradict each other. China started to use own operating systems, based on Free Software. So do many other states, who lack the software industry of the Silicon Valley. It is a unique chance for the EU to support building a software industry based on Free Software making itself independent from other powers. As important as helping financing Free Software is helping financing independent professional code reviews. This should be part of the strategy from the beginning. It is not enough to make code readable, it must get read.

I strongly support the European Unions strategic initiative to embrace open source technologies and establish genuine digital sovereignty. This isnt merely a policy preferenceits an existential necessity in todays geopolitical landscape. American technology companies dont just dominate the digital sphere; they define it. From cloud infrastructure to operating systems, from social media to artificial intelligence frameworks, US corporations control the fundamental building blocks of our digital existence. This concentration creates profound vulnerabilities extending beyond economics into security, privacy, and democratic governance. Recent years have demonstrated that digital infrastructure is not politically neutral. Weve witnessed how rapidly access can be revoked, how data can be weaponized, and how technological dependencies become tools of geopolitical leverage. When American companies control the infrastructure upon which European businesses, governments, and citizens depend, were talking about sovereignty in its most fundamental sense. Open source represents Europes most viable path toward digital autonomy. Unlike proprietary systems that lock users into opaque ecosystems controlled by distant corporations, open source provides transparency, auditability, and genuine control. When code is open, European developers can verify security, adapt it to local needs, and ensure it serves European values rather than foreign corporate interests. The economic argument is equally compelling. Every euro spent on American cloud services or software licenses leaves the European economy permanently. Building open source alternatives means investing in European talent, creating European jobs, and developing expertise that compounds over time. Critics suggest Europe lacks technical capacity to compete with American tech giants. This is false and defeatist. Europe has world-class universities, exceptional engineering talent, and rich technological innovation history. What weve lacked isnt capability but political will and coordinated strategy. As artificial intelligence reshapes digital life, depending entirely on American AI platforms means ceding control over technologies that will determine economic competitiveness and social organization for generations. Europe must develop its own AI capabilities, built on open foundations reflecting European values around privacy, transparency, and human dignity. Digital sovereignty doesnt mean isolation. It means possessing genuine choices, maintaining strategic autonomy, and ensuring European citizens, businesses, and governments arent perpetually dependent on infrastructure they neither control nor understand. Open source enables this precisely because it facilitates collaboration while preventing lock-in. The path forward requires sustained commitment, significant investment, and willingness to prioritize long-term strategic interests over short-term convenience. Europe must recognize that every proprietary system adopted today is a dependency inherited tomorrow. We stand at a decisive moment. The digital infrastructure being built today will shape European society for decades. Either we build it ourselves, on open foundations we control, or we accept permanent subordination in the most critical domain of modern civilization. The EUs commitment to open source and digital sovereignty represents the only viable path forward for a continent aspiring to genuine autonomy in an increasingly multipolar world.​​​​​​​​​​​​​​​​

As an expert on digital infrastructure for GLAM (Galleries, Libraries, Archives, Museums) institutions, I work in the German public sector in IT project management. Open source server-focused software like Debian Linux, Docker, and Kubernetes, but also office-oriented tools like Nextcloud, Matrix Element, and OpenRefine are the indispensable basis of our daily work in planning, developing, providing, and maintaining digital infrastructure for GLAM institutions. The institution I work for is a contributor to the OSS community and provides its own OSS solutions for digital assets and object metadata based on international standards and with (at least) national impact. There is no shortage of technical competencies, high-quality software solutions, or innovative drive in my area of expertise. However, the ubiquitous project-based funding strategy in the GLAM sector and the need for resilient, sustainable digital infrastructure are, in my humble opinion, fundamentally incommensurable. While infrastructure is about stability, maintenance, and slow, well-considered steps, short-term project funding calls for fast, uneven developmental leaps speeding up towards the end of the project phase in the hope of securing another funding. My proposal is to couple the project phase and the operation phase in infrastructure development at the funding instrument level. Ten percent of the project funds should be provided annually for five years after the end of a project to secure maintenance and iterative development (+50% of the original budget in total). This would allow stakeholders to adapt to the new technology, test different use cases, and develop a strategy to make it part of their core software stack if it proves valuable.

I strongly support "public money, public code" It is to be extended to "public money, public data". Proprietary data, proprietary code, and proprietary platforms are to be avoided for the sake of European values, European wealth, and European people.

Wat zijn sterke en zwakke punten van de open source-sector? De sterke punten van Open Source zien wij terug in het duurzame karakter. Code wordt niet verbeterd door 'het wiel opnieuw uit te vinden', maar door te leren van elkaar. Daarnaast zorgt ditzelfde karakter voor herbruikbaarheid, samenwerking en betaalbaarheid van open source oplossingen. Deelnemers van het Pleio platform dragen gezamenlijk de kosten voor de doorontwikkeling. De uitdagingen zitten in het imago van Open Source. Er bestaat de misvatting dat open source onveilig is, omdat de code zichtbaar is. Daarnaast werken wij met een open source oplossing waarbij deelnemers de keuze hebben hun site open of besloten te maken. Wanneer we dan werken aan een verbetering voor een besloten site, dient het proces van open code schrijven te worden nagegaan. Wat levert open source concreet op voor overheid en bedrijfsleven? Open source stimuleert samenwerking, betaalbaarheid en hergebruik van data. Al met al zorgt dit voor efficiëntie die ervoor zorgt dat de gebruiker van een open source oplossing snel en betrouwbaar aan de slag kan. Bij Pleio zie je dit terug in de volgende onderdelen: (Europese) Samenwerking: Pleio bouwt niet alleen haar eigen open source oplossing, maar integreert ook andere open source oplossingen. Zo ontstaat er een all in one oplossing die ervoor zorgt dat de deelnemer snel aan de slag kan. Tevens zorgt dit voor (inter)nationale samenwerking. Vooral binnen Europa. Een aantal voorbeelden hiervan zijn de integratie van Jitsi en werkdocumenten van Collabora. Door samenwerkingen binnen Europa op te zetten, kunnen we loskomen van commerciële Big Tech die anders met data omgaan. We beschermen daarmee de privacy van onze gebruikers en blijven autonoom. Betaalbaarheid: Pleio is zo ingericht dat deelnemers mede-bepalen hoe de doorontwikkeling van het platform eruit ziet. Met een maandelijkse bijdrage en geen winstoogmerk zorgt de stichting ervoor dat de open source oplossing voor iedereen betaalbaar blijft, maar ook daadwerkelijk naar de wensen van deelnemers wordt geluisterd. Dit zorgt voor betrouwbare innovatie van het product. Pleio maakt daarbij geen gebruik van een verdor-lockin. Deelnemers kunnen altijd opzeggen en blijven eigenaar van hun data. Hergebruik: Hergebruik van code is niet alleen duurzaam maar ook een enorme kans. De kans om een hoge standaard neer te zetten op belangrijke gebieden zoals veiligheid, digitale toegankelijkheid en AI. Hoe kan de EU de open source-sector een boost geven? Stimuleer Europese samenwerking door overheden en publieke organisaties actief te verbinden rondom open source-oplossingen en gezamenlijke platforms. Maak open source de standaard bij publieke IT-investeringen (open source, tenzij) om vendor lock-in te voorkomen en digitale soevereiniteit te versterken. Investeer structureel in onderhoud en security van kritieke open source-componenten via initiatieven zoals het EU Sovereign Tech Fund. Vergroot bewustwording en vaardigheden rondom verantwoord data- en AI-gebruik, met nadruk op transparante en uitlegbare open source AI. Ondersteun veilige publieke digitale infrastructuur die voldoet aan de Wet inzake digitale markten (DMA/Digital Markets Act), Europese verordening voor kunstmatige intelligentie (AI Act) en de Wet inzake cyberweerbaarheid (CRA/Cyber Resilience Act), en waarin publieke waarden centraal staan. Conclusie: Door open source actief te faciliteren, verbinden en financieren, versterkt de EU haar technologische onafhankelijkheid, cybersecurity en publieke digitale infrastructuur. Kleinere, goed functionerende open source-initiatieven in Nederland, blijken vaak het onderspit te delven tegenover de grote techbedrijven. Terwijl deze projecten juist aantoonbaar waardevolle, bewezen tools leveren, ontbreekt het hen aan structurele steun. Het is daarom cruciaal dat de EU dergelijke initiatieven actief ondersteunt, zodat deze een volwaardi

feedback: Utilisateur depuis des décennies des logiciels libres et open source, tant en logiciels client, logiciels de poste de travail, système d'exploitation que de logiciels serveur (web, mail et applications), j'ai pu établir avec certitude la faisabilité d'une informatique ouverte et ne dépendant pas des principaux fournisseurs (les GAFAM). Pour autant, on ne pas nier l'absence de services européens dans divers domaines (positionnement géographique, cartographie et photos, équivalent à Google Maps/street view), des réseaux sociaux, de la messagerie instantanée, du "cloud" où Amazon, Microsoft ou Google sont très largement dominants (allant même jusqu'à rendre un protocole proche du standard (aws) et des équipements réseau. Sans parler du matériel (Intel et AMD dominent le marché). Une initiative européenne serait plus qu'utile, notamment en imposant au sein de l'UE l'interopérabilité des protocoles et l'ouverture des protocoles (qui devraient répondre à des RFC publiques comme pour le web (http) ou le mail (smtp). Par exemple en imposant xmpp ou un protocole ouvert du même type pour les communications instantanées. Le problème est qu'il est un peu tard pour agir efficacement dans le sens de l'ouverture dans la mesure où bon nombre de protocoles ou de logiciels non libres sont devenus des standards de fait.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: Having been a user of free and open-source software for decades, in terms of client software, workstation software, operating system and server software (web, mail and applications), I have been able to establish with certainty the feasibility of open-source computing that does not depend on the main suppliers (GAFAM). However, it cannot be denied that there are no European services in various areas (geographic positioning, mapping and photos, equivalent to Google Maps/street view), social networks, instant messaging, the cloud where Amazon, Microsoft or Google are overwhelmingly dominant (even making a protocol close to standard (aws) and network equipment. Not to mention hardware (Intel and AMD dominate the market). A European initiative would be more than useful, in particular by requiring within the EU the interoperability of protocols and the opening of protocols (which should respond to public FTRs such as for the web (http) or e-mail (smtp)). For example, by imposing XMPP or an open protocol of the same type for instant communications. The problem is that it is a bit late to act effectively in the direction of openness as many non-open source protocols or software have become de facto standards.

feedback:
From 2005-2019 I had a company specialized in giving control of the computer to the user. It was aimed at small businesses and home users. I wrote articles in the Dutch Linux magazines and gave presentations about the subject. I had businesses and families that used Linux on the desktop. I deployed web/svn/zarafa servers (zarafa = linux based exchange server) for local businesses. Nowadays I'm a senior webdeveloper and use various open source tools, I work with mac, windows and linux machines. The latter I prefer. I will give my take on becoming less dependant on foreign ICT technology. The way I see it is, that most of the software is already there. Linux is a mature OS, it runs supercomputers, desktop pc's, servers and phones. Yes the desktop experience is not as polished as a mac, but I think instead of spending money on Foreign companies, the EU can make a difference in that respect. On the hardware side, we are dependent on US/China technology. Perhaps we can adopt RISC-V. Which is an open specification. There are mostly Chinese companies who make motherboards with RISC-V. China is also adopting RISC-V (and Linux) to be less dependent. But this is only the processor, the chipset must also be open. We still have the technology to design and make chips, this should be given priority. Networking: There is a successful company (Mikrotik) that makes networking equipment in Europe. Perhaps it is willing to open source it's OS? Look at pfsense/opnsense for firewall software, there are companies that make hardware for it (for example Deciso). Look at snort for intrusion detection. Cloud/Servers: - Apache/Nginx, MariaDb/Postgres are all widely used. - Nextcloud and Collabra can be an alternative to Google docs/drive. - Immich for as an alternative to Google photos. - It could be possible to bring Zarafa back to life and make a Microsoft exchange server that is Linux based. Phones: - there are some options for instance ubuntu touch, pine phone, lineageOs, eos, volla os or sailfish os. But alot of work has to be done. Perhaps the issue is not technological, but more practical. - Lobbying; Big corporations, like Microsoft do lobby. Present products that are "open source" and "private AI", "private cloud", but that aren't. (see for instance open document specification vs. Microsoft docx/xlsx, the latter is not and is EU wide accepted as open). - Balance between the power of government and individuals; in general the open source community is much in favor of openness, transparancy, giving power to people (the computer is theirs to control; see free software foundation). Why do volunteers want to contribute if legislation is made that is to the contrary of openness/transparency? There is a trend that governments do not want to share information, but do want all kinds of information about their citizens. There is also a trend since 2001(ms palladium) to make computers more and more a "secure" by giving less control to the user and more to the businesses that made them. Now with AI (falling behind on AI as EU is not bad, see https://asahilinux.org/docs/project/policies/slop) and cloud tech more and more information is flowing from users to Big tech. What kind of future does the EU see in this regard? Does it want to present itself as a liberal? Does it want to encourage the freedom of owning your own computer and owning your own information? - Adoption: Linux on the desktop is very usable, but it will take time to learn it. It is not as polished as using a mac, but if I can learn home users in 2005 to use Linux, it should be doable. - Vendor lockin: transfering data from ms/google cloud will take a lot of time. There should be a good balance between using cloud services (with lockin problems) and using software on your own computer. - Money: Being independent will be more expensive than running in Microsoft/Google cloud. Please feel free to contact me whe

feedback: There can be no democracy if the media is not free. A large portion of the population receives information from SoMe, which is controlled by foreign nations and is filled with misinformation. EU does not have its own SoMe and switching requires mass adoption to work. Bring down the barrier to switch by storing my friends/contacts in my digital wallet (or some place neutral) and allow me to control which companies have access to it. This will make it easier for new EU SoMe companies to enter market and provide base for new products and innovation. Also require any SoMe service to allow export/import from this list. Its my data and my friends and I want it back! The only thing keeping me from not using FB is the loss of my contacts not the product itself.

EU member states and the EU as a whole, must have complete autonomy of their cloud stack (from IaaS to SaaS). While decoupling from hardware vendors is difficult at this stage, it does not mean we can't begin to implement a sovereign cloud stack. This effort should be split up in stages. We need to implement what is possible right away, the rest as we progress. There are foundational services that need to be implemented first: * Datacenters to host clouds and services. More than one will be needed. We don't need to have one mega cloud. Multiple smaller ones work just as well and with proper integration can actually limit the impact of outages/attacks. * A scalable, resilient IaaS. OpenStack is by far the best option. Investment by the EU in OpenStack would make it even more valuable as a technology. * Scalable, resilient PaaS. OpenStack has the ability to launch and scale Kubernetes clouds on demand. * SaaS for all services we depend on now. This one is a bit more tough, but given enough investment, not impossible. There are already *some* SaaS that can be augmented to replace existing big tech services. We have the technical expertise. We sorely lack political will and proper policy/regulation/legislation to supercharge investment, research and development in our tech stack. We're trying to compete in a Formula 1 race with our foot firmly on the breaks. Take the breaks off. Create a unified set of rules for all states that allows predictability when investing. Actively search for and encourage talent in STEM. Make a Silicone Valley in the EU.

Open Source Software in Kombination mit leistungsstarken Europäischen Hosting-Angeboten könnte ein sehr guter Weg hin zu Digitaler Souveränität und weg von Erpressbarkeiten durch Vendor-Lock-In sein. Es gibt bereits sehr gute Initiativen wie bspw. das ZenDiS mit OpenDesk. Verglichen mit der Höhe der Lizenzgebühren, die seitens öffentlicher Institutionen jährlich an Nicht-EU-Konzerne gezahlt werden ist die finanzielle Ausstattung des ZenDiS geradezu ein trauriger Witz. Hier sollte dringend umpriorisiert werden und es bräuchte es eine EU-weite Kooperation. Zudem sollten öffentliche Einrichtungen bei jeder Lizenzanschaffung/-verlängerung begründen müssen, warum keine OpenSource-Software zum Einsatz kommen kann. Entsprechend sollte der Einsatz von Nicht-EU-Hyperscalern begründet werden müssen.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: Open source software combined with high-performance European hosting services could be a very good way to move towards digital sovereignty and away from blackmail through Vendor lock-in. There are already very good initiatives such as the ZenDiS with openDesk. Compared to the level of licence fees paid annually by public institutions to non-EU groups, ZenDiS’s financial resources are a sad joke. This should be urgently re-prioritised and EU-wide cooperation needed. In addition, public bodies should be required to justify why open source software cannot be used each time a licence is obtained/renewed. Accordingly, the use of non-EU hyperscalers should be justified.

feedback: Je travaille dans l'informatique et uniquement sur des sujets open source pour des entreprises et des organisations publiques depuis 10 ans. Le principal frein a l'adoption de logiciels open source sûrs pour l'Europe provient de la très faible demande des services publics à utiliser un hébergement souverain. Il est beaucoup plus facile pour tous les prestataires informatiques de travailler avec AWS, GCP et Azure car il y a de très nombreuses personnes formées et compétentes. Les grandes structures informatiques ne peuvent pas se permettre de proposer des hébergements européens car trop peu de gens sont formés, et elles auraient à assumer le coû de la formation d'équipe entière, ainsi que le risque en cas de turn-over car aucune ressource humaine ne pourrait les remplacer rapidement.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: I have been working in IT and only on open source topics for companies and public organisations for 10 years. The main barrier to the uptake of safe open source software for Europe comes from the very low demand from public services to use sovereign hosting. It is much easier for all IT providers to work with AWS, GCP and Azure because there are very many trained and competent people. Large IT structures cannot afford to offer European accommodation because too few people are trained, and they would have to take on the co-responsibility of full team training, as well as the risk in the event of a turn-over, as no human resource could replace them quickly.

feedback: I'm long time open source active contributor with the Apache Wicket project. I'm happy EU has started to put opensource at the core of its sovereign strategy. For me it's important that public organizations (like EU ) start funding strategic projects in order to keep them alive and give theme enough resources to stay independent from private companies. Hope EU could create a council to decide which projects should be promoted, in a similar way like the European Research Council does with scientific projects.

Beaucoup de solutions libres sont développées en Europe, parfois l'appui direct ou indirect d'institutions publiques. L'UE dispose de plusieurs forces : - Des communautés associatives très présentes - Des entreprises mobilisées Beaucoup de solutions libres et développées (ou non) en UE sont de qualité. Elles souffrent de plusieurs handicaps à leur bon déploiement : - L'absence d'obligation d'interopérabilité imposée aux acteurs numériques déjà établis (GAFAM). Les solutions libres, bien qu'efficaces, ne peuvent pas s'interfacer correctement avec les autres solutions propriétaires et non documentées. - L'absence d'obligation d'usage de ces solutions aux états membres et à leurs différentes administration. Le recourt à des solutions essentiellement privatrices, non interopérables et américaines (Microsoft Windows, Microsoft Office, Google Docs, etc.) est très répandu et n'encourage pas (voir empêche) les administrés à faire de même. Valeur ajoutée des solutions libres : - Le coût : Une solution libre permet de répartir le coût entre les différents acteurs concernés par la solution et limite les positions monopolistiques. - La résilience : Même si une solution libre est développée par un acteur unique (exemple : une entreprise), il n'y a pas une dépendance forte des usagers de la solution vis-à-vis de celui-ci. Cela protège les usagers à plusieurs titres. Dans le cas où l'acteur unique devient malveillant (augmentation drastique et injustifiée des coûts, changement radical de la direction du projet, etc.) ou défaillant (faillite, acteur étranger sous embargo, etc.), les usagers peuvent s'organiser pour (faire) reprendre le développement de la solution. C'est impossible avec une solution propriétaire. Il est nécessaire d'intégrer des contraintes dans l'ensemble des législations touchant de près ou de loin au numérique au sujet des solutions libres. Un très bon exemple : les Directives européennes sur les services de paiement (DSP, DSP2 et bientôt DSP3). Ces directives imposent aux acteurs bancaires la mise en place de mesures de sécurité supplémentaires, notamment la double authentification pour les clients. Ce processus de double authentification se fait dans la quasi-totalité des cas via des applications mobiles. Ces applications mobiles ne sont disponibles que pour les smartphones sous Android avec Google et les iPhone. Il est donc quasiment impossible de gérer son compte bancaire en ligne avec un smartphone utilisant exclusivement des logiciels libres et sans systèmes américains. Il faut donc, pour chaque réglementation, imposer des solutions standardisées et exploitables sans dépendre de solutions propriétaires. Les domaines prioritaires : - Bureautique : Les administrations devraient utiliser uniquement des suites bureautiques libres avec des formats de fichiers libres et standardisés pour les échanges entre administrations et mais aussi avec l'extérieur (citoyens européens, entreprises, etc.). - Systèmes d'exploitation : C'est la clé de voute de nos ordinateurs et smartphone. Les systèmes d'exploitation propriétaires, pour la plupart américain, ont un accès total aux données stockées sur nos appareils. La fin du support de Windows 10 est une catastrophe écologique par pure décision unilatérale de Microsoft (https://endof10.org/fr/). Les systèmes d'exploitation des smartphones doivent aussi être considérés. Les secteurs prioritaires : - Éducation : Il est indispensable que l'éducation des jeunes et moins jeunes se fasse exclusivement avec des logiciels libres. Les GAFAM (en particulier Microsoft, Google et Apple) ont bien compris l'intérêt de proposer leurs services au plus tôt aux plus jeunes d'entre nous pour les habituer à leurs systèmes. Ils proposent réduction importantes ou gratuité de leurs services aux étudiants. - Militaire : Dépendre de so
