feedback: Il est important que nous, européens et nationaux des pays membres, puissions développer nos propres moyens numériques et informatiques indépendants de leurs homologues américains (windows, android, ios, apple,...). Il est inacceptable que nos données, au motif de sauvegarde, soient dupliqués sur des serveurs obéissant à un autre cadre juridique que le notre et pouvant servir à alimenter d'autres systèmes que les notres. Il me semble aussi primordial que chaque pays développe son propre système informatique indépendant ; bien sur des passerelles permettant des échanges d'informations doivent exister mais ne pas devenir la norme commune. Il est possible de créer une plateforme commune pouvant pleinement être personnalisable par les autorités étatiques des Etats membres.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: It is important for us, European and national, to be able to develop our own digital and IT resources that are independent of their American counterparts (windows, android, ios, apple, etc.). It is unacceptable that our data, for the purpose of backup, should be duplicated on servers which follow a different legal framework from our and which can be used to feed systems other than notres. I also consider it essential that each country develops its own independent IT system; good on gateways to exchange information must exist but not become the common standard. It is possible to create a common platform that can be fully customised by the state authorities of the Member States.

feedback: Ich finde Open Source wichtig und es sollte in so vielen Bereichen wie möglich implementiert werden.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: I find open source important and it should be implemented in as many areas as possible.

feedback:
In the geopolitical context of January 2026, it is essential for Europe as a continent to reduce its dependence on non-european software companies, and in particular American ones. There is much to be done, and leveraging open-source software (FOSS) is a good solution for many reasons. Among them: - so much is available today as FOSS that it massively reduces the cost of bootstrapping a sovereign infrastructure. - it speeds up innovation by avoiding the need for different organizations to reimplement the same things over and over. This frees up a lot of capacity for truly innovative work. - It is a great mechanism to leverage international cooperation while preserving everybody's sovereignty at all levels. This can even work between adverse parties because each one is able to assess for themselves the quality or security of the other party's contribution. - it is good for sovereignty because all tools based entirely on FOSS are fully auditable, contrary to proprietary software which requires complex legal mechanisms to achieve the same thing. FOSS can also be an effective policy tool by encouraging / funding the development of certain types of software to facilitate their use. For example, funding the development of tools that make it easy to safeguard privacy (end-to-end encryption libraries of tools to detect the presence of sensitive data, etc.) will make them more accessible, and if they're also made easy to use, their deployment would be facilitated. In terms of measures than can be taken at EU level to develop FOSS in Europe, I would suggest the following: - put regulation in place to prevent capture of EU innovation by foreign capital. For example, mandating FOSS in all software used in critical infrastructure, blocking mergers or acquisition of EU companies when deemed contrary to sovereignty objectives, or require that their code be published as FOSS first. - strongly enforce competition rules, in particular unfair practices. Example: when a startup tries to build a new type of tool, the company is very vulnerable and it's very easy for large companies to undercut them by building a similar feature and providing it for free (i.e. funded by profits from an unrelated products). - mandate or very strongly incentivize the publication of software deemed critical as FOSS. Similar to the original intent behind patents, sharing code will strengthen innovation by rewarding reuse instead of rent-seeking. - develop in-house skills inside the EU institutions themselves by having strong software teams, directly responsible for the institutions' software infrastructure, and offering support for member states through FOSS. (https://lasuite.numerique.gouv.fr from the French government could serve as a starting point). The goal would be to set an example for the rest of society, and bring technical expertise much closer to decision-makers, enabling them to make better policy decisions. In terms of digital sovereignty: - make an inventory of all the critical digital infrastructure, from chips to data centers, operating systems, security vulnerability databases, data storage, communication systems, etc. Then identify the most critical dependencies and provide tax incentives or directly fund companies, organizations or individuals to remove those dependencies using FOSS. This is meant to solve urgent questions like: is the power grid fully sovereign? how is our internal food production dependent on foreign approval? I believe these questions can't be solved efficiently by the market. In this case a strong government intervention is necessary if we want to make fast progress (similar to climate change). - review European and international treaties, including free-trade agreements, identify clauses limiting or threatening European digital sovereignty (for example anti-circumventing rules from the 2001/29/EC directive that give undue control over most of our infras

feedback: Europe needs to invest in bringing together fundamental software solutions that can bring intrinsic security, protection of data ownership, and tool and infrastructure independence. Crucial for reaching these goals is coordination and legislation to enforce generic compatibility and interchangeability and to ban tool and vendor lock-in. The solutions can be achieved through goal oriented software components that synthesize functionality to serve the need of the user. Most of the technology for these solutions already exists or is close to breakthrough development. Open source is a license model that is likely to contribute to this vision, as it takes away commercial stakes and allows for independent peer reviewing. Merging software parts from the academic knowledge to industry proven should be the key focus of EU software strategy to reach technological sovereignty, security and competitiveness. Development and reuse of digital assets can only be achieved by enforcing "open" standards.

Q: What are the strengths and weaknesses of the EU open-source sector? What are the main barriers that hamper adoption and maintenance of high-quality and secure open source; A: There is a saying that open source software (OSS) is free as in free kitten. The acquisition cost may be zero, but the ongoing "care and feeding" - cost to stay up to date and ensure the software continues to work as expected can be high. Many commercial OSS vendors profit from this dynamic, but if the goal is independence, enterprises and other users need to be mindful of swapping one form of dependence (namely on the maker of proprietary sw) for another (dependence on third parties for ongoing support and maintenance of an open source alternative). The real power of open source is attained when users become sufficiently knowledgeable on the open source software to be able to contribute to its maintenance. Barrier: The cost here is in training and in the enterprise committing the money to have people on staff that contribute upstream. It should be noted that this cost is not necessarily higher than paying an outside party for support, but there is often a mindset and operational change required from the typical way of consuming and using software. There are substantial benefits to doing this, such as increased control and independence, improved security posture,and greater utility since the software can be customized to meet the users precise needs. This session (https://youtu.be/h5C97dwIjM8?si=YdR4IhnxdSjhtXe8&t=108) provides a good overview of upstreaming in FreeBSD. Q: sustainable contributions to open-source communities? There are many ways to support the open source that businesses and governments use. They can provide financial support to the maintainers, and they can contribute their employees time to the project to write code, fix bugs, write documentation, etc. Q: What is the added value of open source for the public and private sectors? Please provide concrete examples, including the factors (such as cost, risk, lock-in, security, innovation, among others) that are most important to assess the added value. A: The biggest added value is control. But taking advantage of this benefit requires knowledge of the project(s) in use so that the public and private sector users can contribute to the project, customize it for their needs, and support it internally. Its important at this point to distinguish between different types of open source. Some open source projects are too complex for most users to contribute to, let alone to fork. This 2017 article goes into this point: https://www.infoworld.com/article/2260293/open-source-innovation-is-now-all-about-vendor-on-ramps-2.html The greatest digital sovereignty bang for the buck will, in my opinion, come from community-governed projects where involvement is flatter and more accessible. Q:What concrete measures and actions may be taken at EU level to support the development and growth of the EU open-source sector and contribute to the EUs technological sovereignty and cybersecurity agenda? A: It may be valuable to create an EU OSPO chartered with coordinating involvement in and advocating for strategic open source projects. If pursued, I believe its vital this organization be oriented towards code, community, and advocacy, and away from regulation. The goal should be to listen to stakeholders, identify strategic OSS projects where stakeholders can meaningfully participate to shape the projects direction, channel engagement into these projects, and champion these projects use across Europe and beyond. Q: What technology areas should be prioritised and why? A: 1. Operating systems, because they gatekeep systems and ecosystems. 2. The AI software stack. Openness here is vital to competitiveness. 3. Secure data transfer and sharing (X-Road) 4, Cloud native technologies, because they gatekeep the cloud ecosystem

Hello, Im a cybersecurity specialist, and previously worked for an IT services company focused on FOSS development. In todays (and future) world, supporting open-source software would help Europe achieve a higher level of independence from closed-source, foreign software and service providers. It is also significantly more sustainable in the long term, because it allows anyone to contribute to, improve, audit, and use the software (i.e. the software is not dependent on the survival of a single company). History has also shown that when monopolies were broken up and their technologies were made open, the result was a strong multiplier effect, enabling the creation of many more products and services. Europe urgently needs that kind of momentum and FOSS can support and enable it. Additionally: * By distributing and maintaining quality open-source software, the EU can expand its influence (soft-power) abroad * It sends a strong signal in favor of fundamental European values such as freedom, transparency, and democracy. * Open-source projects grow organically through collaboration, rather than relying on expensive large-scale government investments that have already streched budgets For me it is pretty clear: FOSS can become a cornerstone of a broader strategy for Europes future development and resilience. It can support economical growth in an inexpensive and sustainable way, support foreign-policy objectives as well as EU's fundamental values. EU should go all-in on FOSS <3.
Stop waiting and do something. Invest in Europe, invest in our technology, our future. It takes time, do it now.

My opinion is that it is mandatory to become independent from worldwide services such as MS, AWS, PayPal, etc. - make WERO mandatory for any shop that also offers PayPal and make it mandatory for all EU banks - stop using X for all political announcements, build something European - force digitalization efforts towards EU companies
This is something that was obvious since the 90s, but you did not listen.

As an avid open-source software user for many years now, this proposal is very nice to see! It is good to know that the EU recognizes the potential advantages of open-source software and development, and is planning to take concrete steps in supporting open-source development for use within the EU. One thing that I feel is missing from this proposal is a stronger emphasis on consumer technology. With this, I am talking about computer operating systems and applications for use on ordinary home computers. Currently, nearly all personal computing is done on proprietary operating systems using proprietary software. As an example: virtually every personal computer at home runs Microsoft Windows, and uses the likes of Microsoft Office, OneDrive, Google Chrome/Microsoft Edge for internet access etc. This creates a strong lock-in to these proprietary solutions and makes it very difficult for these people to adopt open-source software in a governmental or business setting, as they are not used to it and will therefore have greater difficulties adopting it. As I see it, the adoption of open-source software among private individuals should be prioritized more, as it opens people up more to using such software in commercial and governmental sectors as well. Open-source for private citizens could be incentivized by first investing in consumer facing open-source solutions for proprietary counterparts, e.g. desktop environments, web browsers, office-suites, and then incentivizing the use of this open-source software on private computing hardware.

Software innovation and digital infrastructure are critical for Europes autonomy, competitiveness, and long-term prosperity. Yet, current market dynamics increasingly favor large, vertically integrated monopolies that create closed, proprietary ecosystems. To ensure European digital sovereignty and maintain innovation capacity, the European Union must commit to systematically supporting open source software as a strategic asset. 1. All software systems, regardless of origin, possess inherent shortcomings and limitations. Open source software uniquely allows professionalsresearchers, businesses, public institutions, and technical expertsto address these shortcomings directly. By granting access to source code and permitting modification, open software transforms users into active participants in technological innovation, rather than dependents on external vendors. 2. It is unrealistic to expect individual European tech companies to challenge the scale and integration of U.S. technology conglomerates across entire software stacksoperating systems, productivity suites, security platforms, and especially artificial intelligence ecosystems. A European response based solely on proprietary development will not overcome these structural disadvantages. A coordinated, EU-level investment in open source ecosystems, however, can create reusable foundations upon which smaller actors can innovate competitively. 3. High initial investment requirements continue to stifle entry and slow innovation across software-dependent sectors. By contrast, open source availability reduces start-up and research costs, enabling new entrants to build upon existing, continuously improving infrastructures. This effect democratizes access to advanced technology and fosters sustainable, distributed innovation instead of concentration of power. 4. True data sovereignty and user autonomy require meaningful choice. In todays digital markets, dominant platforms amplify network effects that prevent competition; once a critical mass is reached, alternative products become unviable. This winner-takes-all dynamic contradicts European values of fairness and open markets. To counteract this, the EU should establish legal frameworks ensuring interoperability and open interfaces between digital products. Mandatory open APIsnot EU-defined technical standards, but adherence to widely accepted oneswould guarantee that new actors can integrate into existing ecosystems and present users with genuine alternatives.

A critical gap in the proposal is the absence of any explicit recognition of steward-owned business models as a governance and ownership solution for the open digital ecosystems the EU seeks to build. The document correctly identifies structural problemsvalue extraction by non-EU actors, fragile governance of open-source projects, difficulties in scaling without capture, and the need for sustainable, mission-aligned business modelsbut stops short of addressing ownership, which is the root determinant of long-term control and incentives. Without ownership structures that legally lock assets, decision-making power, and strategic direction into stewardship rather than shareholder value maximisation, it is inconceivable that the EU can sustainably retain value, ensure sovereignty, and prevent consolidation and lock-in as open technologies scale. Ignoring steward ownership risks repeating the very pattern the initiative aims to break: publicly supported open infrastructures ultimately being captured, monetised, or controlled by actors whose incentives are misaligned with Europes public-interest goals.

Pour une souveraineté numérique européenne, différents éléments doivent être pris en compte. Bien évidemment, on va parler de logiciel libre mais pas seulement, il faut aussi qu'il soit européen, sinon on rajoute une dépendance vers l'extérieur. Ensuite il faut comprendre qu'il ne faut pas se limiter à un logiciel par catégorie. Si on force l'utilisateur a une solution, il sera retissant de migrer car il se sent forcé. En revanche, si on propose par exemple 2-3 outils, il se sentira libre de choisir l'outil et d'entamer lui-même sa migration vers des outils européen. Ensuite, il y a la question du cloud. Actuellement, les leaders du marché sont américains. Si on veut entamer une transition vers de la souveraineté européen, il faut obligatoirement avoir l'ensemble de nos donnes hébergés en Europe, aucun sauvegarde ne doit sortir de l'europe. Cela apportera des contraintes en terme de latence si nous nous trouvons de l'autre côté du globe, mais cela garantira toutefois qu'un loi local ne forcera pas le prestataire à ouvrir les donnés au pays. Maintenant l'acteur qui se chargera de cela, à première vue, le plus proche d'y arriver est OVHCloud, c'est une entreprise qui est dans le secteur depuis plus d'une dizaine d'années. Mais à mon sens, elle n'a pas la capacité seule d'y arriver. Comparer à des géants américains, elle va principalement manquer de ressources financières pour accroître ces ressources RH et ces ressources physiques pour supporter la charge qui va arriver. C'est là que peuvent entrer en jeu les sociétés européennes. Je suis persuadé que si on leur garantis la fondation d'un cloud 100% européen, des acteurs seraient prêt à investir dedans. Cela leur permettrait d'avoir de nouvelles solutions cloud pour héberger leur propre donnée. Pour finir, un point qui commence à prendre de plus en plus de place dans notre société, l'IA. Comme pour le cloud, les plus gros acteurs du domaine sont américains. Pour continuer dans cette objectif de souveraineté européen, il est obligatoire de proposer des européens. Car même si dans la finalité nos donnés sont stockés en Europe, si nous devons passer par des partenaires externes pour utiliser de l'IA, c'est comme si on avait rien fait. À l'heure actuelle, Mistral est un des rares acteurs du domaine qui soit européen. C'est une entreprise prometteuse mais comme OVHCloud, elle va manquer de ressources pour arriver au niveau des leaders actuels. Donc ce serait intéressant de l'aider à grossir, mais attention le monde de l'IA et surtout du traitement des données est primordial. À mon sens, il faut aider Mistral mais en les laissant libre de leur choix, ne pas influencer leur vision de la chose. Et en parallèle, créer des solutions peut-être plus local pour aider dans différents domaines et proposer des outils qui soit adaptés aux besoins. À un moment donné, il faudra également se poser la question du matériel qui est utilisé pour toutes ces solutions, mais je pense que ce sera dans un autre chapitre. Déjà si on arrive à finaliser ce genre d'initiative dans les 10 prochaines années, ce sera bien. Seul chose à retenir à mon sens pour y arriver vite. Il ne faut pas se briser, il faut y aller vite et fort pour rattraper le retour accumulé avec les années et prendre de l'avance sur les prochaines années.

Je recommande que la Commission et les États membres : financent durablement les projets libres stratégiques ; adoptent euxmêmes ces solutions dans leurs administrations ; créent une gouvernance européenne dédiée aux communs numériques ; mesurent limpact de lopen source comme un actif industriel

column40: The European Union cannot simply dare itself at source: it must invest directly in it. Projects such as EU OS or openDesk show that credible alternatives already exist to reduce structural dependence on non-European technologies. But without long-term funding, inter-state coordination and direct involvement of the institutions, these initiatives will remain marginal. I recommend that the Commission and the Member States: provide sustainable funding for strategic open projects; adopt these solutions themselves in their administrations; create a European governance dedicated to digital commons; measure the clear impact of the source lopen as an industrial asset, and not as a mere technical tool. Lopen source is not a cost: this is a sovereignty infrastructure, already used in 7 090 % of Europe’s digital systems. Finally, Europe must act to meet this challenge.

feedback: As a researcher and professor in software development, I rely, at the maximum possible on Free Libre and Open Source software for my work and teaching. Students are then autonomous in building on top of the tools they studied, without strings attached. I'm also a former Debian project contributor. Such a Linux distribution represents a great infrastructure project I could help to improve, for all users to benefit. FLOSS deliverables were contributed in the R&D projects under the FP7 where I contributed as a researcher and evaluator, as a great way to balance cooperation vs varying agenda of companies/institutes, making it a common ground. The Commons made possible by Open Source are invaluable and must be sustained. I strongly rely on FLOSS and welcome institutional support from the Commission.

We represent the KiCad EDA open source project. Attached you will find a comprehensive statement on the impact of KiCad for the European market and how the EU as an entity can best leverage our investment to the benefit of member states.

feedback: Open Source Software, while no silver bullet, has significant benefits for Governmental and Social profit organisations that have to follow public tendering procedures: - Switch suppliers without having to switch software, bringing down costs for migration and training - Open licensing results in more straightforward IP clauses in contracts - Enables more transparent security auditing by independent third parties - No need for insolvency clauses that transfer IP rights in case of bankruptcy. - Less dependent on company's decisions regarding product life cycle and licensing Often, the migration cost is so great that changing suppliers becomes economically unfeasible when using closed source software. The supplier can then drive up the costs for licensing and support between contracts. This results in a higher total cost of ownership for closed source software, even when the initial pricing was reasonable. While there are always costs involved in switching suppliers, using Open source licenses puts the procuring party in a stronger negotiating position.
Excellente initiative, les logiciels libres sont bien plus répandus et utilisables qu'auparavant, et ça nous rendrait plus indépendants. Merci !
feedbackTextUserLanguage: Excellent initiative, open source software is much more widespread and usable than before, and it would make us more independent. Thank you!

feedback: I've been working on open source software since the last 30 years and I've never heard about European initiatives promoting open source development. Just about all open source projects are aware of Google Summer of Code program (see https://summerofcode.withgoogle.com/) allowing students to work on open source projects during summer recess, and, any misgivings about it being provided by a quasi-monopolistic US company notwithstanding, it has definitely been great for both students and projects that they participated in, including the ones I'm involved with. It would be great if the EU could provide something similar for European students!

A adoção de software opensource não só é uma excelente medida mas como também será crucial e fundamental para um ecossistema digital mais justo, colaborativo e sustentável. A Europa tem que adotar software opensource em todos os seus servidores e computadores, para sermos donos dos nossos próprios computadores, o software proprietário não permite isso, torna-nos reféns de empresas que de um dia para o outro podem passar a cobrar o que quiserem as nos ou deixar até de existir de um dia para o outro. Alem disso o software opensource hoje em dia é muitas vezes melhor que o software proprietário, Linux é muito melhor que Windows por exemplo e é grátis. Temos que largar os sistemas operativos e programas da Microsoft e trocamos por alternativas como Linux, LibreOffice, ONLYOFFICE, Collabora Office, Inkscape, Gimp, VLC, Firefox. Também temos que preferir as empresas de hardware que são as mais amigas de firmware e software opensource como a AMD tanto nos CPU's como nos GPU's, RISC-V, as portas Display-Port (Criar regras para obrigar as TVs a incluírem essa porta porque o standard HDMI é proprietário e é muito caro, alem disso devia ser aberta uma investigação ao consorcio do HDMI se estão a fazer pressão para essa porta não ser incluída pois é uma rival aberta). Finalmente os formatos opensource como ODF, SVG, Vulkan, opengl, VP9, AV1, AV2, OPUS, FLAC, MKV, JPEG-XL, PNG, glTF, HDR10+ etc..
feedbackTextUserLanguage: The adoption of OpenSource software is not only an excellent measure but will also be crucial and key for a fairer, collaborative and sustainable digital ecosystem. Europe has to adopt OpenSource software on all its servers and computers, so that we own our own computers, the proprietary software does not allow this, it makes us hostage from companies that can shift from one day to the next to charge for what they want, or it can stop there from one day to the next. Moreover, OpenSource software today is often better than proprietary software, Linux is much better than Windows for example and is free. We need to drop Microsoft’s operating systems and programs and switch to alternatives such as Linux, LibreOffice, ONLYOFFICE, Collabora Office, Inkscape, Gimp, VLC, Firefox. We must also prefer hardware companies that are the most friendly of firmware and OpenSource software, such as AMD in both CPUs and GPUs, RISC-V, Display-Port ports. Finally OpenSource formats such as ODF, SVG, Vulkan, opengl, VP9, AV1, AV2, OPUS, FLAC, MKV, JPEG-XL, PNG, glTF, HDR10 + etc.

feedback:
I strongly welcome the European Commissions clear recognition of the strategic importance of open-source software and open digital ecosystems. Open source is essential for transparency, security, privacy, user autonomy, and long-term resilience. The acknowledgement that excessive dependence on non-EU (in particular US-based) technology providers undermines control over critical digital infrastructure is both accurate and overdue. Open source, by its very nature, aligns well with European values such as privacy, interoperability, and democratic oversight. Supporting open-source development, maintenance, and adoptionespecially in foundational layers such as cloud, AI frameworks, cybersecurity, and hardwareis a positive and necessary objective. However, I have serious concerns about how this objective is pursued, particularly regarding the role of EU-level governance and coordination. While reducing dependence on non-EU actors is desirable, replacing it with increased dependence on EU-level institutions risks creating a different form of centralisation. Technological sovereignty should not mean shifting control away from private monopolies only to concentrate it within supranational political structures. For many citizens, national sovereignty and democratic accountability remain fundamental, and EU-led frameworks are often perceived as distant, opaque, and politically driven. To address this, I would urge the Commission to explicitly design this strategy around decentralisation and subsidiarity, rather than central coordination alone. Concrete suggestions: 1. Prioritise national and regional implementation - EU action should focus on enabling Member States, not directing them. - Funding, procurement guidance, and best practices should be modular and optional, allowing national governments to decide how open-source solutions are adopted, governed, and sustained. - National public administrations should be encouraged to develop their own open-source strategies, adapted to local needs, legal systems, and political cultures. 2. Avoid EU-controlled single platforms - The success of open source depends on diversity and federation. - The EU should avoid creating or implicitly favouring single EU-managed repositories, cloud platforms, or foundation structures that could become de facto monopolies. - Instead, support interoperability between existing national, regional, and community-run infrastructures. 3. Strengthen subsidiarity in procurement - Public procurement rules should explicitly allow and encourage national and local authorities to prefer open-source solutions without forcing uniform EU-wide standards or vendors. - Member States should retain control over procurement decisions, especially for sensitive or critical infrastructure. 4. Support independent governance models - Open-source projects and digital commons should be governed by independent foundations, cooperatives, or community-based modelsnot directly by EU institutions. - EU funding should come with strict safeguards to prevent political capture or agenda-setting through financial leverage. 5. Focus EU action on coordination, not control - The EUs most constructive role is facilitating knowledge sharing, cross-border interoperability, and research collaboration. - Strategic alignment should emerge organically from cooperation between Member States, not from top-down frameworks. In summary, I strongly support the goal of strengthening open source as a means to reduce technological dependence on external actors and to improve privacy, security, and resilience. However, this goal will only gain broad public legitimacy if it respects national sovereignty, avoids new forms of centralisation, and remains faithful to the decentralised ethos that made open source successful in the first place. Technological independence should empower citizens, communities, and Member Statesnot merely shift dependenc

feedback: With respect to the five questions asked under *Consultation strategy*: 1. Many developers are EU citizens. In general, free software quality is better than commercial software. Most importantly, it can be upgraded more frequently. Preferring commercial software is a psychological blemish that has to be addressed. For (ii), many developers have a /donate/ section where they accept money contributions; please give. 2. Free software respects privacy. Nowadays, most companies host their email and internal web in the cloud, notwithstanding the risk. Running your own server costs more, also because you need to hire competent system administrators. Could this be addressed by de-taxing or similar means? A network of many, well administered servers is way more resilient than a few giant data centers, especially if they are abroad. 3. Funding is the usual way to incentivize. I don't think having an European GitHub would solve any problem; rather, cooperating with them in order to get in touch with developers could bring more advantages. Various American employers pay their employees to develop free software. In Europe, managers view this as a disadvantage. Either convince them that free software is an advantage, or fund developers directly. 4. Medical systems are in poor conditions, also because EU states cut on that. In Italy, TAC images are still distributed on DVDs; private hospitals don't share data. And what about research? 5. As I mentioned in (2), many servers are more resilient than a few big ones. However, servers in colocation centers tend to be abandoned and "0wned". In my humble opinion, a server ought to stay in the company premises, or at home for personal servers, where its sys-admin can take care of it. Internet providers tend to not provide fixed IP addresses, reverse address delegations, RIPE registrations, including abuse contacts. I do send notices to abuse contacts on fake login attempts, which are a symptom of compromised devices; this kind of cooperation should be encouraged, because few do so. Thank you for your attention Best Ale

Summary Relying on foreign proprietary technology primarily optimizes for short-term efficiency. Adopting open source strategically optimizes for long-term optionality, resilience, and digital sovereignty. Open source should be treated as a preferred strategic path for public and critical systems, provided that organizations invest in competence, governance, and maintenance. While it requires more upfront effort, it reduces long-term dependency, systemic risk, and exposure to external jurisdictional control. Detailed input Open source should be considered a preferred strategic path, even though it requires more initial effort. Its long-term benefits materialize when organizations invest deliberately in technical competence and governance. Open source is not free: costs are shifted toward expertise, infrastructure, and maintenance rather than licensing. In return, it offers greater independence, resilience, and long-term control. Security in open source systems is based on transparency rather than blind trust. Vulnerabilities can be inspected and addressed by those with the appropriate expertise and incentives. This contrasts with opaque, proprietary systems where risk assessment depends on trusting external vendors whose incentives may not align with long-term sovereignty, public interest, or risk management requirements. Governments and organizations retain the ability to fork open source projects to introduce specific functionality, strengthen security, and comply with local requirements. Sensitive systems and data can be self-hosted, improving data sovereignty and reducing exposure to external jurisdictional or contractual constraints. In conflict or crisis scenarios, reliance on proprietary collaboration or infrastructure platforms introduces systemic risk. Such services can be remotely restricted or shut down, potentially disrupting large parts of the European public and private sectors. In addition, it is difficult to fully verify how data is processed or accessed when it resides within closed systems subject to non-EU legal frameworks. Open source platforms enable cooperation at the EU level while allowing individual member states to adapt implementations to local laws, operational needs, and cultural contexts. This supports shared infrastructure without enforcing uniform dependency.

CONTRIBUTION TO EU OPEN DIGITAL ECOSYSTEMS INITIATIVE THE FALSE CHOICE Europe faces a strategic choiceexcept it's not really a choice: **Option A**: Recreate entire US software stacks as proprietary European alternatives. Rebuild iOS, Android, cloud, AI, developer tools from scratch. Cost: hundreds of billions. Timeline: decades. Success probability: near zero. **Option B**: Leverage open-source to build sovereign capabilities on existing foundations. Cost: billions. Timeline: years. Probability: high if we act now. The answer is obvious. But here's what nobody discusses: **open-source licenses are weaponizable**. MIT, Apache 2.0, GPLall US-origin licenses. When geopolitical tensions escalate, US-controlled foundations can change terms, add restrictions, create compliance chaos. We've seen export controls weaponized. Software licenses are next. Europe needs its own open-source legal framework. Not because we distrust open-sourcebecause we can't build sovereignty on foundations controlled by adversaries. CONCRETE EXAMPLE: MOBILE STACK **Android** (Google/US) **Kotlin** (JetBrains/Czech, open-source) **Koin** (European maintainer, Apache 2.0) **Kotzilla** (French monitoring) This shows European capability: - Kotlin powers Android development globally - European frameworks serve 25% of Android appsMcDonald's, Emirates, Volkswagen, government services - European companies build commercial services on top But the entire stack sits on Apache 2.0 licenses controlled by US foundations. One executive orderEuropean companies face compliance chaos. WHAT EUROPE MUST DO **1. EU Open-Source License Framework** Interoperable license under EU jurisdiction, protected from US enforcement, guaranteed continuity for European entities. Default for EU-funded projects. **2. Strategic Fork Points** Map critical dependencies. Fund European alternatives with EU licensing: - Mobile frameworks: We maintain 25% of Android infrastructure - Cloud orchestration: European Kubernetes contributions lack license sovereignty - AI tooling: Research excellence, no commercial leverage **3. Infrastructure Fund** Real money for maintenance, security, toolingEU-funded projects use EU license. Creates operational support for maintainers, sovereignty guarantees, stable commercial foundation. **4. Public Procurement Priority** Prioritize EU-licensed over US-licensed, European-maintained over US-maintained, verifiable supply chains over black boxes. Coordinate France, Germany, Spain efforts EU-wide. **5. Talent Retention** Operational funding for EU-licensed projects. Pathway: community European startup growth capital. PRIORITY SECTORS **Mobile**: Every citizen uses apps daily. US controls stores, analytics, monitoring. We have technical leadership. Need license sovereignty. **Automotive**: Software-defined vehicles can't depend on US-controlled tooling. **Healthcare/Finance**: Patient data, banking on weaponizable licenses? Unacceptable. BOTTOM LINE Recreating US stacks as proprietary alternatives is fantasy. Leveraging open-source is the only sovereignty path. But open-source without license sovereignty builds on sand. We need EU legal framework protecting European entities from extraterritorial enforcement. We have technical talent, community adoption, commercial opportunities. We lack coordinated support and license sovereignty. Fix that, or watch sanctions shut down European tech overnight.

feedback: Per i sistemi embedded automotive (mio campo di lavoro) l'open source rappresenta una base comune che riduce la dipendenza dai singoli fornitori e accelera l'innovazione su funzioni non differenzianti. I principali punti di forza risiedono nella trasparenza del codice e nella flessibilità, mentre le debolezze riguardano la difficoltà di certificare software comunitario secondo gli standard di sicurezza funzionale ISO 26262. Gli ostacoli principali sono l'incertezza sulla responsabilità legale e i processi aziendali rigidi che impediscono contributi attivi. Il valore aggiunto si traduce in una riduzione del lock-in e dei costi di sviluppo, permettendo di investire su soluzioni proprietarie solo per le funzioni critiche. A livello UE servono finanziamenti per l'hardware aperto come RISC-V e la creazione di framework di certificazione pre-approvati per componenti open source. I settori prioritari devono essere i sistemi operativi in tempo reale e il middleware per la guida autonoma, essenziali per la ciberresilienza e la sovranità tecnologica nei semiconduttori. L'adozione di software open source negli uffici comunali e postali elimina l'onere economico delle licenze periodiche, che per suite come Microsoft Office o sistemi Windows possono incidere pesantemente sui bilanci pubblici con costi di centinaia di euro per singola postazione. Un vantaggio critico riguarda il ciclo di vita dell'hardware: mentre i sistemi Windows moderni impongono requisiti tecnici sempre più elevati, costringendo alla sostituzione di parchi macchine ancora funzionanti, le distribuzioni Linux sono estremamente efficienti e capaci di operare su computer datati. Questo permette di evitare investimenti massicci nel rinnovo dei dispositivi, riducendo i rifiuti elettronici e permettendo alle amministrazioni di reindirizzare i fondi dalle licenze estere verso l'assistenza tecnica e lo sviluppo di competenze locali. L'adozione di software open source negli uffici comunali e postali elimina l'onere economico delle licenze periodiche, che per suite come Microsoft Office o sistemi Windows possono incidere pesantemente sui bilanci pubblici con costi di centinaia di euro per singola postazione. Un vantaggio critico riguarda il ciclo di vita dell'hardware: mentre i sistemi Windows moderni impongono requisiti tecnici sempre più elevati, costringendo alla sostituzione di parchi macchine ancora funzionanti, le distribuzioni Linux sono estremamente efficienti e capaci di operare su computer datati. Questo permette di evitare investimenti massicci nel rinnovo dei dispositivi, riducendo i rifiuti elettronici e permettendo alle amministrazioni di reindirizzare i fondi dalle licenze estere verso l'assistenza tecnica e lo sviluppo di competenze locali.

The main strengths are in code transparency and flexibility, while weaknesses relate to the difficulty of certifying Community software to ISO 26262 functional safety standards. The main obstacles are uncertainty about legal liability and rigid business processes that prevent active contributions. The added value results in reduced lock-in and development costs, making it possible to invest in proprietary solutions only for critical functions. At EU level, funding is needed for open hardware such as RISC-V and the creation of pre-approved certification frameworks for open source components. Priority areas must be real-time operating systems and middleware for autonomous driving, which are essential for cyber resilience and technological sovereignty in semiconductors. feedback:
Pourquoi personne ne nous passe commande alors qu'on délivre des solutions 100% LIBRES ??? Free-Solutions Sàrl est la seule entreprise IT sans aucun logiciels propriétaire ni aucun service GAFAM utilisé depuis 20 ans On propose des systèmes de Chat et de Visioconférence 100% LIBRES depuis 2014 alternatives à Whatsapp et Teams et basées sur openfire igniterealtime.org On propose aussi des serveurs d'IA performants libres et sous contrôle sans aucune fuite de données possible https://aiborg.eu alternative à openai gemini grok Début d'année 2026 mon entreprise est en grande très grande difficulté et pourtant on propose les produits dont tout le monde rêve Comment se fait il que personne ne nous passe commande alors que tout le monde veux des solutions LIBRE des GAFAM sans techno US ? Pourquoi les acheteurs IT ne savent t'il que commander aux entreprises En tant que fondateur et gérant de Free-Solutions Sàrl, une entreprise suisse spécialisée dans les technologies disruptives de communications, je souhaite partager notre expérience concernant les défis de financement auxquels sont confrontées les entreprises travaillant dans l'open source, en particulier dans un contexte de concurrence avec des géants comme Microsoft Teams et WhatsApp. 1. Barrières à l'adoption et au financement L'un des principaux défis que nous rencontrons est la difficulté d'accès aux financements. Les investisseurs et les institutions de financement public ont souvent une préférence pour les solutions propriétaires, perçues comme plus rentables et plus stables. Les entreprises open source, comme Free-Solutions, doivent souvent se contenter de budgets limités, ce qui freine leur capacité à se développer et à innover. De plus, les politiques de financement public ne sont pas toujours alignées avec les besoins spécifiques des projets open source, qui nécessitent souvent des investissements à long terme dans la maintenance et l'amélioration continue des solutions. 2. Concurrence déloyale avec les géants du secteur Free-Solutions propose des solutions de visioconférence et de chat basées sur des technologies open source comme Jitsi et Cryptpad, qui sont en concurrence directe avec des solutions propriétaires comme Microsoft Teams et WhatsApp. Ces géants bénéficient de ressources financières colossales, leur permettant de proposer des services gratuits ou à faible coût, souvent subventionnés par la collecte de données. En revanche, les entreprises open source comme la nôtre doivent assumer les coûts de développement, de maintenance et de support sans pouvoir compter sur des modèles économiques similaires. Cette concurrence déloyale rend difficile la pérennité de nos activités et limite notre capacité à attirer des clients et des partenaires. 3. Propositions pour un écosystème plus équitable Pour renforcer le secteur de l'open source en Europe, nous suggérons les mesures suivantes : Financements ciblés : Créer des fonds spécifiques pour soutenir les entreprises open source, notamment pour des projets innovants dans des secteurs critiques comme la cybersécurité et la visioconférence. Soutien à l'innovation : Encourager les politiques de public procurement qui privilégient les solutions open source, garantissant ainsi une concurrence équitable et un marché plus diversifié. Partenariats public-privé : Faciliter la création de partenariats entre les institutions publiques et les entreprises open source pour co-développer des solutions adaptées aux besoins des citoyens et des entreprises européennes. Nous croyons fermement que l'open source est un pilier essentiel pour la souveraineté technologique de l'Europe. Cependant, pour qu'il puisse prospérer, il est crucial de créer un environnement plus favorable, où les entreprises open source peuvent se développer sans être écrasées par la concurrence des gé

column28: Last but not least! This is more than necessary; we have undeniable strengths in these open technologies, it can considerably reduce our systemic dependencies (technical debts, suppliers, etc.), our debts, and it can also be a source of – real and effective – cooperation in Europe. feedback: Der öffentliche Sektor muss Marktversagen korrigieren. Der Markt versagt automatisch, weil die Netzwerkeffekte so stark sind. Bereits existierende (möglicherweise illegal erreichte) Monopole werden in neue Märkte übertragen: zu sehen am Beispiel von Microsoft, denn Windows-> Word/Excel/Office-> Visual Basic->Access -> SQL Server->Exchange->Outlook->Visual Studio->Internet Explorer->IIS->Windows Server->SharePoint->OneDrive->Azure->Teams (die Reihenfolge und Kausalität ist nicht richtig, es geht um den Mechanismus). Zusätzlich werden beispielsweise Monopole gestärkt, weil die öffentlichen Schulen die Nutzung der Produkte der Quasi-Monopole fördern. Praktisch alle Bildungseinrichtungen nutzen und unterrichten Microsoft Office. Es gibt genug Anbieter von Alternativen, sie bekommen aber keine Chance. Beispielsweise gibt es den Hersteller von Büroanwendungen in Deutschland, die Fa. SoftMaker, kaum ein öffentlicher Auftraggeber kauft von ihr die Tabellenkalkulations- oder Textverarbeitungsprogramme. Ein anderes Beispiel sind die "sozialen Medien". Warum veröffentlichen EU-Institutionen ihre Beiträge auf Facebook, Youtube, TikTok etc., welche von ebendiesen Beiträgen profitieren? Diese Informationen gehören auf nicht gewinnorientierte Plattformen, z.B. Mastodon (oder andere Plattformen im Fediverse). VORSCHLAG: Sperre der marktbeherrschenden Anbieter für mehrere Jahre bis der Markt wieder funktioniert, d.h. in der Beschaffung der Öffentlichen Hand, die ja Steuergelder ausgibt, müssen alle Anbieter mit mehr als 25% Marktanteil ausgeschlossen werden. Von der Wettbewerbsbehörde muss die Marktverfassung jährlich überprüft und die Marktanteile neu bestimmt werden. Es gibt genug Ideen, aber die Umsetzung scheitert, möglicherweise am fehlenden politischen Willen.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: The public sector needs to correct market failures. The market fails automatically because the network effects are so strong. Existing (possibly illegal) monopolies are being transferred to new markets: see Microsoft’s example, because Windows-> Word/Excel/Office-> Visual Basic->Access -> SQL Server->Exchange->Outlook->Visual Studio->Internet Explorer->IIS->Windows Server->SharePoint->OneDrive->Azure->Teams (the order and causality are not correct, it’s the mechanism). In addition, for example, monopolies are strengthened because public schools promote the use of quasi-monopolies’ products. Virtually all educational institutions use and teach Microsoft Office. There are enough providers of alternatives, but they do not get a chance. For example, the manufacturer of office applications in Germany, SoftMaker, hardly any contracting authority buys spreadsheet or word-processing programs from SoftMaker. Another example is ‘social media’. Why are EU institutions publishing their posts on Facebook, Youtube, TikTok, etc., which benefit from these same posts? This information belongs to non-profit platforms, such as Mastodon (or other platforms in the Fediverse). PROPOSAL: Blocking dominant suppliers for several years until the market is functioning again, i.e. in public procurement, which spends taxpayers’ money, all suppliers with more than 25 % market share must be excluded. The competition authority must review the market structure on an annual basis and re-assess market shares. There are enough ideas, but implementation fails, possibly due to a lack of political will.

feedback: Dear Madam, Dear Sir, I am excited to learn that Europe is finally waking up to the digital reality and is trying to understand the advantages of open source software. Please let me congratulate you to the inquiry. As a private person who got upset with closed source software back in 2013 on a very personal level, when my first wife died in a tragic accident. At the time we were living in a very remote community in the Arctic. When I informed my family, I spoke to my brother over Skype (Microsoft owned). Apart from the police and emergency service, nobody knew about it yet, apart from my brother at that time. Five (5!) Minutes after the conversation I began to receive marketing messages from funeral directors, etc. I was so upset that I immediately cancelled all my subscriptions to closed source software and switched to the open source world, centered around Linux. Since then I am very privacy focused and use only software or products that warrant a certain degree of privacy and digital sovereignty. Over time I learned a lot about it and I also had the necessary technical skills as a former network safety guy. Since then I have been helping people to regain control over their data. Today I can showcase how easy a switch is, how far Linux has advanced. I own several PC, laptops, NAS and phones, but all are secured with the best protection there is: accountability by being open source. All closed source software is banned and removed from my house and life. My phones are all equipped with Graphene OS and all other data is on Linux. I have never had to look back, but every time I am fixing someones Windows PC or Mac, I can feel the restrictions and sense the distrust necessary in order to stay safe. On a higher level, thinking about the data safety within countries, armies and the EU, I am scared sharing any data whatsoever with the authorities, knowing how exposed my data will be. And this is not only from the «normally» expected candidates, like Russia or North Korea or China, but also on a massive scale the US. Did you know that the USA is in fact the largest Cyber attacker globally? On a regular basis the US is responsible for 60-70 % of all cyber attacks worldwide (source Radware.com)! Please protect the people of Europe by securing their digital safety, especially in the current political situation. Kind regards, Christoph Hupe

One of the weaknesses that affect the EU open source sector is lack of funding and weak community-building around the interest/field. Many smaller open source components struggle to make an impact without proper advertisement and funding. Advertising allows projects to find experts in their specific fields and funding allows them to focus their personal time using their expertise for development and to seek talent. Platforms like GitHub, which allows developers to publish their code and annotate it with tags for simplified discovery somewhat help reduce the fragmentation and helps with discovery of the project, but the projects are still required to find own ways to advertise beyond this. If projects can acquire funding, they can attract interest of other experts and join together to develop the software as a group, thus strengthening the support for the code and the developers behind it. Software developed as open source can be easily audited by 3rd parties. Any auditor can be hired or freely choose to go through the source code which is open to review it and find potential software bugs or other kinds of errors/mistakes. This allows critical code to be easily reviewed, which allows anyone to validate the safety of the software used in anything from vehicles to banking systems. Software in these fields is often well audited, but the actual audit reports are rarely public. This would increase the transparency and trust in the critical systems that power and assist our daily lives. Open source code outlives the counterparts that are developed by corporations and always outlives their initial developer's interest or development interest. When organizations behind the development fail, the development most often ceases without any plan to continue. Sometimes this development is passed on to a buyer/stakeholder. It is rare that the source of the code that is not developed anymore is published as open source. Open source can be redistributed, modified, integrated and as such even if the main "copy" of the software source is deleted, due to it's licensing the rest of the copies can continue to live under a different maintainer/organization and possibly name/trademark. To summarize, open source reduces dependency and increases the review count of the code produced, thus reducing the risk of using a component that will possibly not exist in a few years or decade. It also reduces development costs in the case that the developer of a component cannot maintain it anymore due to any reason, the development can be passed to another developer. It allows anyone to find mistakes and either report them and fix the issue themselves, allowing timely reaction to any security issues, no matter the developer/vendor. Now, EU can help in the following ways: - Providing funding to groups which organize to develop open source software together - This already happens and has a strong impact, yet there is room for improvement - Providing a platform to aggregate or advertise at EU-level the need of developers in specific fields - Creating platforms for professional exchange between groups and individuals - Providing development groups with assistance in creating a financial plan to become self-sustainable - Maintaining recommendations of financial strategies - Encouraging developers behind critical software which isn't open source to publish their work - Requiring organizations behind critical yet private code to publish their work before ceasing to exist or stopping development

I am an open source maintainer of a project with millions of weekly downloads on npmjs. Strengths of EU open-source: - big potential, at the EU as well as individual states level (everything that is digital has open source alternatives that can be used today). - regulation that prevents abuse of the large players to destroy competition Weaknesses: - have fallen behind non-eu players - locked in to non-eu players - very shy initiatives (until recently) to move away from closed-source and actually use open-source on a broad scale Barriers that hamper adoption: - lack of strategic, long-term vision barriers that hamper maintenance: - lack of funding - this is true at global level; open source maintainers are working long hours for less pay. Also lack of funding for supporting those projects inside the companies/public institutions where they are used. Just because it is open source, doesn't mean there's no maintainance or overhead in adopting it. Barriers that hamper sustainable contributions: - again, lack of funding. Usually open-source maintainers are overworked and low paid compared to regular employees. There is also the issue of online abuse from users, which keep demanding a lot from usually very small, underpaid individuals or teams. This can lead to burnout and abandonment of the project by the maintainers. Added value of open source for the public and private sectors: - lower lock-in effects; transparency; independence; not leaking data to external entities Concrete measures and actions may be taken at EU level to support the development and growth of the EU open-source sector and contribute to the EUs technological sovereignty and cybersecurity agenda? - most importantly: START USING IT YOURSELVES at all levels! For example, switch to Linux and open source alternatives at the EU institutions' levels but also at the individual countries levels. Start using open source Office suites! - support important open source with grants and money, with long term commitments! What technology areas should be prioritised and why? - I'm not an expert but I would go with the low-hanging fruits first: switch to Linux on all PC's and servers used in the EU. Same for Office suites, Email servers. - Another important one is digital payments, although I am unsure if this is necessarily related to open-source. It is clearly detrimental to the EU to depend on third-party countries for the payment (ie credit card) infrastructure.

I submit this contribution based on practical experience from senior roles in global technology companies (cloud infrastructure, AI and hardware ecosystems) as well as European digital service providers. I am currently preparing the foundation of a new company in the European digital ecosystem. From this perspective, Europe does not lack Open Source innovation or engineering capability. The core challenge lies in the missing industrialisation layer that turns Open Source into dependable, accountable and economically sustainable digital infrastructure. Open Source is widely used in production environments, yet operational control, default deployments and monetisation are often carried out by non-European platform providers. Europe contributes significantly to development, but less to long-term operation, security response and managed service delivery. A central barrier is the operational responsibility gap. While Open Source ensures transparency and reuse, it does not by itself provide long-term support, coordinated security patching, compliance readiness or contractual accountability (SLAs, liability, exit options). This limits adoption in public administration and regulated industries. In practice, many European Open Source projects also fail to follow the path from project to startup to monetised managed service. This is not primarily due to a lack of entrepreneurial intent, but to structural conditions. Early anchor customers are often missing, while the investment required to build production-grade managed services must be made before market acceptance, references or sufficient growth capital are available. This creates a systemic catch-22: without managed services adoption remains limited; without adoption capital and references remain inaccessible. Policy approaches that focus primarily on creating new Open Source projects or short-term development funding risk reinforcing this gap. Without complementary measures addressing operation, accountability and demand, such efforts may unintentionally increase Europes dependence on external platforms that industrialise Open Source elsewhere. To strengthen European open digital ecosystems, policy measures should therefore focus on concrete operational mechanisms: Support professional Open Source operators, not only projects, by enabling entities that assume responsibility for production operation, security response and long-term support. Link financial support to committed demand and deployment, for example through letters of intent or concrete implementation programmes. Use public procurement as an early risk absorber, including EU-level or multi-country framework contracts and reference deployments for Open Source-based infrastructure services. Encourage sustainable maintainer participation models, where maintainers benefit economically from the operational success of widely used Open Source components. Prioritise a small number of horizontal infrastructure domains (e.g. observability, security middleware, data and event pipelines, edge/IoT), where Open Source is already dominant but operationally fragile. Open Source can be a meaningful lever for European technological autonomy, but only if complemented by industrial-grade operation, accountability and aggregated demand. Shifting the focus from funding code to enabling responsibility would significantly strengthen Europes digital foundations.

Investing in open source projects is the correct way forward for the EU. It will enable the robust and sovereign EU institutional operation on the one hand, and will allow for a more distributed/decentralized, self-governed, and private digital future for the EU population in general. The increasing centralization of the modern Internet was not something desired or anticipated in its initial design, and the fact that the central point of multiple critical services is outside the EU is, to say the least, worrying. Decoupling from the tech giants is must at this point, as the digital infrastructure is no longer something that is good to have, but a mandatory piece integrated in our lives, both for public institutions and individuals. Investing in open source will benefit both.

An interesting domain where there is almost no open-source alternatives: legacy systems. Typical legacy systems are the COBOL infrastructures, that most big corporations in Europe have, they are critical to their business (usually, the financial part of the company), but they never talk about them publicly (maybe ashamed of using COBOL in 2025 ?). Anyway, COBOL is still in 2025 the most executed programming language, but is almost completely absent in the open-source world. As a result, most companies in Europe only rely on two american software providers (IBM and RocketSoftware, that owns the former Micro Focus company), with costs of licences increasing dramatically over the years. We (the OCamlPro/Titagone French company) are proposing an open-source alternative: SuperBOL/GnuCOBOL, a full industrial-ready open-source COBOL development and execution environment, that can be used to run any COBOL infrastructure. Another very important contributor to the GnuCOBOL open-source compiler is the ObjectWay company in Germany. Yet, when looking for help for funding our research and development efforts, we face the image the COBOL is old and does not deserve funding. This is true for R&D fundings, for research fundings in general, and for open-source fundings also (because open-source communities only focus on modern systems and not legacy ones). We think that the EU should focus some funding towards the development of European open-source bricks to replace existing proprietary software for legacy systems. Computer infrastructures are like pyramids: you cannot keep the top of the pyramid in the air without creating first the bottom part. American companies have well understood that: most customers will choose IA solutions from Google and Microsoft in the end, because they offer them on top of big integrated suites. For infrastructures in general, it's the same, companies will prefer to buy new software from the same vendors that provide their basic/legacy infrastructure. As long as American companies have the control of the market of legacy software, they will be able to flood the market with other additional products, without fearing the competition from European vendors.

Hello, I would like to draw your attention to a problem that we users in the EU becoming heavily dependent on Google and Apple operating systems for smartphones. Although various hardware and operating system providers have made some efforts to offer alternatives, they are mostly niche providers for geeks. This is mainly because there are no banking apps from banks operating in the EU for Linux, for example. One example is the Finnish company Jolla (jolla.com), which was founded by former Nokia employees. They developed a European, open Linux-based operating system (Sailfish OS) that offers an alternative to the American operating systems from Google and Apple. But without essential apps such as banking apps for Linux, users will never be able to break away from their American systems. Perhaps you and your teams could take a look at this and possibly initiate legal regulation requiring banks across the EU to provide a Linux-based app for users who do not want to use Google or Apple operating systems. It would also be welcome if other essential apps developed by the EU, such as digital driving licences or ID documents, were also available for Linux operating systems such as Sailfish OS. Thank you very much. Kind regards, Marek Schwarz

Open source software is not a marginal topic: it is a foundational pillar of Europes digital infrastructure, public services, and innovation capacity. Europe already depends on it at scale; treating open source as a strategic asset is no longer optional, it is essential. Today, many widely used open source components function as critical digital infrastructure while being maintained under fragile and underfunded conditions. This creates a structural risk for Europes digital resilience. The EU should explicitly recognise key open source projects as digital public goods and ensure long-term support for their maintenance, security, and continuity. The core issue is not a lack of innovation, but a lack of sustainability. Redirecting targeted EU support toward maintenance, documentation, governance, and security would deliver immediate, concrete, and lasting impact. Public procurement is a decisive lever and should actively reward openness, interoperability, and upstream contributions rather than reinforcing short-term, closed solutions. Failing to act will increase systemic risk, deepen external dependencies, and weaken Europes ability to control and maintain its own digital foundations. Acting now would allow the EU to strengthen digital sovereignty, secure long-term resilience, and sustain innovation aligned with European values.

This should in fact like for RGPD even enforce all companies in the world to adopts ours Open Solutions. - Create an European Non Profit Public Web Search Engine using Open Web Search. - Anticipate the enshitification of alternative Web Browsers whose company is run by FAANG and finance/contribute to a fork of Firefox like Librefox or work with companies like Vivaldi. - Enforce usage of Open Source Social network like Mastodon and stop using X for all European Institutions. - Create laws and service to have the possibility to migrate all of our accounts from one mail to another, update/delete multiple of our accounts data via one service only to help people degooglizing and update/delete their personal datas. - Finance Degooglization Campaign and solutions which help people to degooglize. - Force smartphone manufacturers to publish their source code and bootloader to facilitate Custom ROMs installation. - Finance and contribute to Android ROMs alternatives like Graphene, Lineage, CRDroid. - Finance and make all European countries contribute to development of Linux Operating System which should be the default installed on all new Desktops/Laptops and used by all of our institutions. - Finance and contribute to a Youtube alternative. - Finance and contribute to chat apps (Discord for ex) alternatives like Revolt. - Finance campaigns for kids AND adults about Social Networks Mental Health Risks. - Create law to enforce to prevent companies from using certain types of algorithms to capture users' attention and make them addicted of their apps. - Anticipate the AI Slop risk of Wikipedia. Finance and host the project for UE. - Create laws, finance and contribute to Open formats development and enforce their usage on all public institutions and on all private client interfaces asking for specific files formats.

Je soutiens lidée que lEurope doit maîtriser davantage ses infrastructures et réduire sa dépendance aux géants technologiques non européens. Cela me semble essentiel pour protéger nos données, nos entreprises et notre économie numérique. En tant que citoyen, je considère que lopen source offre plus de transparence, plus de contrôlabilité et plus dopportunités économiques pour les entreprises européennes, notamment les PME. Encourager louverture et la réutilisation des solutions me semble bénéfique pour linnovation et la confiance. Pour réduire la dépendance aux GAFAM, lEurope doit rendre les alternatives réellement utilisables, compatibles entre elles et faciles à adopter par les administrations, les entreprises et les citoyens. Linteropérabilité me semble un point essentiel. En tant que nondéveloppeur, jinsiste sur limportance de solutions faciles à utiliser et bien intégrées. Louverture ne suffira pas si les produits européens ne sont pas ergonomiques ou accessibles au grand public. Je considère essentiel dinvestir dans lécosystème numérique européen : logiciels, plateformes, cloud, IA. LEurope ne doit pas seulement se protéger, elle doit aussi devenir attractive et compétitive. Les technologies ouvertes améliorent la sécurité, car elles peuvent être vérifiées par tous. Comme citoyen, cela me donne plus confiance quun modèle fermé contrôlé par quelques grandes entreprises étrangères. Nos smartphones, qui sont aujourdhui loutil numérique central de nos vies, reposent presque entièrement sur des systèmes dexploitation contrôlés par des acteurs non européens : Google et Apple dun côté, Huawei de lautre. En Europe, Android et iOS représentent ensemble plus de 99% du marché, ce qui signifie que nous navons pratiquement aucun contrôle sur les choix techniques, les modèles économiques, la collecte de données ou les orientations stratégiques de ces plateformes. Cette dépendance massive pose un problème de souveraineté : nous utilisons tous quotidiennement un environnement logiciel que lEurope ne maîtrise pas ni dans son code, ni dans ses règles, ni dans ses priorités. Je considère essentiel que lUnion européenne soutienne lémergence de véritables alternatives ouvertes, auditables et interopérables pour les appareils mobiles, et pas seulement pour les infrastructures cloud. Cest un enjeu majeur pour la sécurité, la protection des données, la compétitivité et lindépendance numérique de long terme.

feedback: I am an open source advocate, Field CTO for HCS Company and founder of OpenCommit: a Dutch ANBI foundation that is currently fund raising for the development of a fully open source Git hosting platform that is EU hosted and fully transparent, and I very much welcome the initiative "Towards European open digital ecosystems" and would like to respond to the call for evidence. The EU already has a large, active and highly skilled open source community, with a healthy mix of individual contributors, SMEs, integrators, research institutions and public bodies, which is a solid foundation for robust digital commons. However, much EU open source development still relies on non-EU platforms and infrastructure (e.g. Git hosting) with significant legal, geopolitical and sovereignty risks, because funding is still highly fragmented, short-term and mainly focused on research projects with too little long term support for maintenance, security and governance. Moreover, public procurement and risk frameworks are still often tailored to large proprietary vendors, making it very difficult for open source consortia, foundations and SMEs to compete, since the awareness of mature, EU-rooted open source building blocks is still way too low with decision makers and many organisations still consider open source mainly as "free" or as a risk rather than as strategic infrastructure. In practice, open source does reduce vendor lock-in and increases strategic autonomy (since open standards plus open implementations make it easier to switch providers and retain control over critical systems and data), it does improve transparency and security (since code can be audited, tested and improved collaboratively, and security fixes can be coordinated directly with upstream communities) and open source does accelerate innovation (since organisations can reuse common building blocks and focus on their own domain needs). It is much more efficient for the public sector to co-develop and reuse open components across borders, and this aligns with EU goals on sovereignty, trustworthy digital services and interoperability, therefore, to fully realise this potential, the EU should explicitly recognise and fund critical open source as critical digital infrastructure, including stable, long-term support for maintenance, security and governance, and support EU-sovereign infrastructure for key services like Git hosting, CI/CD, package registries and security tooling. OpenCommit's goal of an EU-wide, EU-hosted, fully open Git platform is one concrete example of the kind of shared building block that would directly strengthen European digital sovereignty, and the EU should adapt its procurement frameworks and provide model clauses to allow public administrations to ask for open standards and to fairly evaluate open source solutions and consortia, and support open source-based business models, particularly the many European SMEs and start-ups that offer services around open technologies. While increased use of open source can boost competitiveness and cyber resilience in various sectors, those where it can have the most impact include public administration and digital government, healthcare, energy and other critical infrastructures, automotive and mobility, manufacturing and logistics, education and research. I warmly welcome this initiative and the recognition that open source is part of Europe's core digital infrastructure, and a coherent EU strategy that combines policy, funding, procurement reform and concrete EU-sovereign infrastructure (e.g. open EU-hosted code hosting and collaboration platforms) will be crucial for European technological sovereignty, competitiveness and cybersecurity. Consequently, as a Dutch-based ANBI foundation, OpenCommit would be more than happy to help with these efforts and is fully committed to support the EU's open source ambitions.

Cela fait longtemps que je milite pour lutilisation des logiciels libres. Cest à mon avis la seule solution dassurer la liberté de choix des utilisateurs par le refus des stratégies captatrices, le respect des standards, la préservation des données personnelles et bien dautres choses dont évidemment la souveraineté. Jai contribué à lessor la fondation dInkscape, contribué à Scribus, Gimp, Krita, Blender, Godot, des logiciels que nous utilisons tous les jours et qui ont tous faits leurs preuves dans leur domaine. Il est donc temps darrêter à lincitation doutils privateurs qui sont de plus souvent imposés par les institutions elles-mêmes dans leur stratégie numérique pseudo sécurisée. Je suis responsable du studio graphique et développement ActivStudio et du centre de formation Activdesign dans lequel nous nutilisons que des logiciels libres et franchement pourquoi utiliser un logiciel non libre qui utilise à notre insu des IA, stockent nos données sur le serveur sans que nous ayons les choix et nous dépossède des fichiers que nous créons si nous ne payons plus la mensualité, et qui créent volontairement des formats non interopérables pour nous empêcher daller ailleurs. Linformatique est assez compliquée pour ne pas rajouter les couches volontaires de complexité malvenues. Nous développons 3 logiciels, deux ont déjà des sources publiées sous licence GPL. Idem pour nos produits culturels. Je suis aussi responsable de lassociation AFGRAL qui fait la promotion des outils libres dans le domaine créatif, et de Floss Manuals qui, a sa grande époque, a publié des dizaines des livres numériques et papiers sur lutilisation des logiciels libres. Les logiciels libres existent depuis les années 80, cest bien que la question de leur utilisation se pose, mais en réalité, on a déjà 40 ans de retard, et on se pose la question à un moment où les opérateurs sont plutôt en train de tout renvoyer aux IA. Si lUE veut faire quelque chose, il faudra donc aller vite et fort, sinon ce sera encore un coup dépée dans leau comme il y en a eu de nombreux ces 2 dernières décennies avec beaucoup dannonce et jamais de résultats. En tout cas, moi -même et mes associations somment disponibles pour contribuer à cette réflexion, si notre aide est utile.
