feedback:
1. Adoption Barriers a) Pre-installation Monopolies: The bundling of proprietary OS (Windows) on consumer hardware creates a massive barrier to entry. Most users never change their default settings and are not even aware of open-source alternatives. b) Proprietary formats demand: In many places it is a stated requirement to upload .doc file or .xls file instead of the open-soure .odt and .ods; which additionally encourages use of proprietary software c) Hardware Compatibility: A lack of open-source drivers for specific components makes the transition risky for non-technical users, many linux forums cite Nvidia drivers as ones creating problems, similarly wifi card drivers do not always work out of the box. d) Lack of Software/Worse Software: open-source tools lack the polished User Experience (UX) of proprietary counterparts, LibreOffice is much bleaker experience, than MS Office, GIMP is a shadow of Adobe creative suite. They do not have same funding as these tech giants. 2. Added Value for Public/Private Sectors a) Economic Sovereignty: Transitioning to open source means stopping paying tech tithe to the US companies. No more Software as a service. b) Security & Transparency: Open source allows for independent auditing, ensuring no "backdoors" exist; right now Windows telemetry sends our data to the US. c) Right to repair: No more artificial obsolescence see Windows 10 end of support. In many cases Linux often seems like a less hardware demanding system. d) No more lock in: Since the widespread adoption of Snaps/Flatpaks most of the software can be installed on every Linux regardless of distribution. Even in case of enterprise Linux it is entirely possible to move to another distribution and still use same software as it is all interoperable. 3. Concrete EU-Level Measures a) Lead by Example: EU institutions and national governments should mandate the use of open-source desktops and tools for their own representatives to signal trust and dedication to the ecosystem. It would look disingenuous, if everyday people would be encouraged to work on a Linux computer, while the EU representatives still openly used Macbooks. b) Tax Breaks: If the company does not use any proprietary software and actively contributes to open-source projects/foundations. c) FOSS in Schools: Implement policy that school computers should run free and open-source software to de-normalize proprietary software. d) Interoperability Mandates: Require that dominant software providers (like Adobe or Microsoft) ensure their file formats and applications are fully compatible with open-source operating systems. e) Open Document Format Mandate: Use this open-source format as the default instead of proprietary ones. f) Public Money, Public Code: Implement a policy where software developed with public tax money must be released under an open-source license. 4. Priority Technology Areas a) Operating Systems: It would be quicker and cheaper to just stick with Linux and fork an existing distribution and customize it to the demands of the users. At first it would require iterative improvement and a lot of funding. It would be very important not to get discouraged like in case of LiMux. It would be great if there would be one main base European Linux, probably based on an already existing distribution like Debian, Fedora, Arch or maybe the European and German SUSE. b) Productivity Suites: High-quality, professional-grade alternatives to Office 365 and Creative Cloud are essential for business competitiveness. It would either require funding existing open-source projects like Libreoffice or GIMP or creating something completely new from scratch. c) Administrative Software: EU would need to run a questionnaire for clerks and officials and ask for what software they use and what functions do they perform and create and open source alternative d) Cloud Service: As part of decreasing reliance on Amer

feedback: Suggestions for EU Software Independence: * Recognize open software as a public good. Encourage knowledge transfer instead of patents. * Recognize that new technology is mostly based on tax-funded university research. Funding universities is more important that subsidizing big companies. * Tax US big-tech more than small EU companies. Use these taxes to fund EU solutions. If trade-agreements prohibit this (via so-called "intellectual property"), the EU should leave these trade agreements. * Do NOT blindly reduce taxes for companies - only for those EU-companies that INVEST into research and developing products (instead of paying large bonuses, dividends or doing share-buybacks). * Being a potential security threat, prohibit non-EU proprietary software in security-sensitive environments. In particular, software of anti-democratic origin (e.g. Palantir) should be illegal to use in the EU. * Governments should be prohibited from using those cloud-services, whose owners can be forced by non-EU governments to hand over data. * Prioritize open source / free software where readily available. * Replace proprietary systems where open alternatives are readily available. * The EU should host or support hosting a (git) repository for open source projects on a domestic platform. * Support coordination: if many EU cities develop their own, different software solutions, facilitate communication, knowledge transfer and cooperation to develop shared solutions. * If the lacking support of using free software should be a problem, consider to develop an EU owned support agency, that contributes to the open-source projects. * Don't fall for the "AI" hype: in most applications PREDICTABLE, RULE-BASED behavior is required - not a (possibly dangerous) black box. Therefore, do some AI research but don't prioritize it over the meaningful IT. * Foster and enforce interoperability to ease transition to free / open systems. Telephone and email works between different providers - other services should, too. Consider supporting projects such as wine (which allows to run windows applications on Linux). * People will switch only if good alternatives exist. If there was a "EU-Tube" and similar EU-alternatives to other platforms, reducing disinformation might get easier. * Offer Linux courses at schools. And consider supporting EU developers of goods games that run on Linux - as another incentive for people to switch platforms.

È indispensabile rimuovere prodotti con licenza dalla pubblica amministrazione Inoltre si deve vietare la vendita di PC,notebook e altro con sistemi operativi pre-installati, dando la possibilità all'acquirente di scegliere tra sistemi operativi a pagamento o open source
feedbackTextUserLanguage: It is essential to remove licensed products from government. In addition, the sale of PCs, notebooks and others with pre-installed operating systems should be prohibited, giving the buyer the choice between paid or open-source operating systems.

feedback: Ik ben een groot voorstander van open source software. Maar ik ben niet van mening dat iedereen geforceerd zou moeten worden om het te gebruiken, dat organisaties kiezen voor amerikaanse cloud bedrijven is logisch, het aanbod is meer gestroomlijnd en beter, zo is het simpelweg gewoon. Echter denk ik dat door als overheid wel gebruik te maken van open source er ook een cultuur ontstaat waarin bedrijven volgen. Als een grote institutionele speler op open source overstapt creeert dat ook zoveel vraag dat er wel een serieuze speler op dat vlak moet op staan om dat aan te bieden. Daarnaast ben ik van mening dat het wel goed zou zijn om universiteiten te verbieden om windows of apple te eisen. Bij mijn eigen universiteit, TU eindhoven moet ik elke tentamenweek door hoepels springen om weer een windows laptop te hebben omdat ik anders geen tentamens kan maken. Omdat ik weiger een closed source amerikaans besturingssyteem te gebruiken is onderwijs volgen actief moeilijker. Hier denk ik dat er wel een rol is voor de overheid. Verder, er zijn inmiddels wel linux distributies die makkelijk genoeg zijn, en goed genoeg werken om windows te vervangen voor het over grote gedeelte van de gebruikers. Echter wat de boer niet kent, dat eet ie niet. De meeste consumenten zullen nooit linux proberen als ze dat niet hoeven, windows werkt prima, over het algemeen. Open source is in de laatste jaren wel zo ver gekomen dat ik als individu een hele cluster van computers kan draaien met services, die ik openbaar op het internet bereikbaar kan maken, het is dus ook empowerment voor het individu. Het enige wat ik heb gekocht is hardware, alle software was "gratis" als je maar de tijd neemt om te leren hoe het werkt, en tijd is ook geld. Ik denk ook dat er serieus gekeken moet worden naar of je er al bent als je open source ondersteunt, digitaal onafhankelijk zijn van amerika gaat verder dan geen gebruik maken van de amerikaanse cloud diensten en besturingssytemen. Alle processors worden ontworpen in amerika, etc etc. Ook hier is een opensource alternatief, risc V. Wat nu al in een paar europese super computers zit, van het franse bedrijf SI pearl. Echter ook hier, er is geen serieuze europese speler. Ik woon bovendien in eindhoven, naast veldhoven, naast ASML en hier is niet eens een grote chip design speler. Waarom ik denk dat dit topic bij europa hoort is omdat wij het continent van echte vrijheid zijn (zodra de eu stopt met het proberen invoeren van chat control :) ) en een goed open source eco systeem waar overheden achter staan kan echt zoveel mogelijk maken en zoveel versnelling van onderzoek ook. Je kan naar china kijken en zien wat je kan bereiken als alle onderzoek openbaar is voor iedereen, nu doen de chinezen dit door octrooirecht te negeren, maar het punt blijft, cooperatie maakt onderzoek sneller.

Furthermore, Linux distributions are now sufficiently easy and working wel

feedback: A lot of open source software projects are maintained by developers that have spare time and like to contribute to the projects. I think if european governmental bodies want to utilize open source software within their organization they need a guarantee to some extend that these projects are properly maintained and have active options for support. Options for this can be but are not limited to: ensuring active maintainers from within an organization that is using the open source software or eu funding for developers or organizations maintaining the projects, with some kind of guarantee that the project is actively maintained. Active maintenance and proper support is one of the main reasons some open source projects are embraced by users in my view. A great example is vlc media player.

FOSS is important for the HOW. But Open Standards are more important for the WHAT. Many standards today are quasi-standards based on US business software such as MS Office, Adobe PDF etc. There is a huge need and opportunity to define new EU open standards for Information Objects. They can be exchanged between citizens, governments and businesses. Freeing us from US dependence. And putting Digital information in the hands of people. Where its all compatible and secure, not locked in US silos or file formats. Contact me for my research work.

In 2003 I established a consortium that worked with the EU's IDA (Interchange of Data between Administrations) and with EU member states developing Open Source Migration Guidelines. As stated in the introduction: The purpose of these guidelines is twofold: 1. To help Administrators decide whether a migration to OSS should be undertaken. 2. To describe in broad technical terms how such a migration could be carried out. The guidelines are intended to be of practical use to Administrators and so must be relevant and accurate whilst being accessible and understandable. They are not a detailed technical reference manual. The structure is intended to allow changes to be easily made in the future as experience is gained by Administrations and as changes are made to the products available. When published in November 2003 the guidelines were very well received by the Open Source community. The Project Director, Bernard Schnittger, informed me that there were over 75,000 downloads of the report in the first few days after publication. At that time it was, by far, the most popular report that had been produced by the European Commission. The introduction to the Guidelines went on to add: To meet these objectives it is imperative that the content is kept up to date and that any inaccuracies are removed. Unfortunately this did not happen. Though now out of date the Guidelines provide a template that could be used to develop an updated migration strategy that takes into consideration the latest developments in Open Source, both hardware and software together with the modern use of IT systems. These Guidelines are no longer published on the EU's web site. They can be found at: https://www.phcomp.co.uk/netproject/IDA-Open-Source-Migration-Guidelines.pdf If these guidelines could be of use to the European Open Digital Ecosystems project please feel free to use them. Wishing you every success with your work. Eddie Bleasdale

Having to click on a URL that is almost 500 characters long is not a friendly thing to do. Using something like sha512 will generate a string 128 bytes long that is good enough to be secure and is much easier to handle.

I start to say with the fact that this initiative is a valuable political position in the actual big tech oligarchies era. Anyway, I found the previous intervention by the Zig Software Foundation very centered: without a straight-forward way for EU citizens to setup non-profit, tax-exempt foundations to host big open source projects, it would be difficult to expand open digital platforms and to spread them significatively enough to become a common use. The issues just mentioned reminds us the importance of software and hardware interoperability needed in all the strategical economic sector, such as cars. So industrial support should be put in place so that European and ideally open-source computers can be manufactured. In general, many open-source software products exist by the sole will of the contributors. Once open-source will be a driving force in the EUs digital strategy, the stable survival of these products should be ensured by providing funding to pay teams to maintain these products. As a digital humanities Msc student, I find equally crucial to promote and push open-source in schools and universities, beside the principle of a digital common good, incentivating the teaching of what open-source is and how to contribute, together with the adoption of cheap or free access software in alternative to otherwise costly (such as Altium, Ansyns, Autodesk, Matlab). Dealing with the issue of having fully open-source infrastructure and services but accessible only via a personal device is another key point, because at the moment we are forced to use external products over which you have no real control (HP, Dell, Lenovo, Apple, Samsung, etc.) from which we have to create proficient alternatives in order to have a chance to reach effective digital sovereignity. And underlining other emerged considerations, I claim the Commission to evaluate the mandatory, with a procured software, to evaluate open-source solutions first. Non-free software should only be bought if there is no reasonable alternative. Another aim should be to disincentivize the use of closed file formats or cloud-services: design documents needs to be accessible, that includes the software to view and edit them. In the end, scalability and repairability are crucial aspects to implement. For the complexity of the challenge, strongly consider hiring more developers and designers with experience on these and continue to spread initiatives of awareness and citizenship involvement and debate all around Europe.

Le passage à l'adoption d'un écosystème libre, ouvert, plus sécurisé et respectant notre vie privée, est une étape nécessaire et doit être un enjeu prioritaire, afin de se défaire de la main-mise des États-Unis dans ce domaine. Nous leur offrons nos données depuis trop longtemps sans réagir. MERCI D'Y METTRE LES MOYENS NÉCESSAIRES ! Quelques pistes : - Mise en place d'un OS européen sous Linux (avec une vrai équipe...), avec un suivi, une maintenance et un développement soutenu. - Utilisation exclusive de format de document libre (odt, ods...) - NE PAS RÉINVENTER LA ROUE. Il existe de très nombreux logiciels Open Source de qualité, sur lesquels se baser pour démarrer les briques de cet écosystème - Interdiction d'utiliser des mails propriétaires pour tous les métiers du médical (une petite pensée pour les pharmacie et les docteurs avec une boîte Gmail) ainsi que pour toutes les institutions publiques et leurs équivalents privés (les écoles par exemple). - Ne pas proposer l'utilisation de messageries propriétaires pour les services qui le proposent (X, Instagram, Facebook, Whatsapp...) si une alternative existe (Mastodon, Signal...) - ÉCOUTER ET COMMUNIQUER avec la communauté libre/open source - EVITER à tout prix les entreprises FAUSSEMENT EXPERTES (coucou Atos, CapGemini, Orange...). On a en europe de vrais sociétés leader dans le domaine (OVH...). - Financer de la publicité dans les médias traditionnels afin de promouvoir ce nouveau écosystème (sur plusieurs mois) - ÉDUQUER ET FORMER !!! Il est impératif de mettre en place des formations GRATUITES sur ces nouveaux logiciels
feedbackTextUserLanguage: Moving towards the adoption of a free, open, more secure and privacy-friendly ecosystem is a necessary step and must be a priority in order to move away from the US in this area. We have been offering our data for too long without reacting. THANK YOU FOR PUTTING IN PLACE THE NECESSARY RESOURCES! Some avenues: Setting up a European AOS under Linux (with a real team, etc.), with monitoring, maintenance and sustained development. — Use only free document format (odt, ods...) – Do NOT reinvent the wheel. There is a wealth of high-quality Open Source software on which to start the bricks of this ecosystem – Prohibition on using proprietary mails for all medical professions (a small thought for pharmacies and doctors with a Gmail box) as well as for all public institutions and their private equivalents (e.g. schools). — Not to offer the use of proprietary mailboxes for the services that offer it (X, Instagram, Facebook, Whatsapp, etc.) if there is an alternative (Mastodon, Signal, etc.) – COVERY AND COMMUNITY with the free/open source community – EVITER at all costs the FAUSSEMENT expert companies (coucou Atos, CapGemini, Orange, etc.). In Europe, there are real leading companies in the field (OVH, etc.). — Fund advertising in traditional media to promote this new ecosystem (over several months) – educate AND FORMER! It is imperative to set up GRATUITES training courses on these new software

I work in the public sector (University) and maintain a large open-source project in my free time. Here are a few proposals that would make maintaining my and similar projects more sustainable: * Encourage open-source contributions during work-hours. Make it easier for both employers and employees of the public sector to dedicate time for this. * Devise a way how public entities (here a University) can sponsor open-source project that they use. Nearly all my colleagues use Thunderbird, but we can't even donate 1 to the project. * Make donations to open-source projects/maintainers tax deductible, even if that project does not have a legal entity that would otherwise qualify. * Create an incentive to teach more open-source tools instead of commercial ones. Universities quite often have cheap or free access to otherwise costly software and use that for teaching. Examples are Altium, Ansyns, Autodesk, Matlab, ... * Also teach what open-source is and how one starts to contribute. Most projects are looking for more help. * When Software is procured, make it mandatory to evaluate open-source solutions first. Non-free software should only be bought if there is no reasonable alternative. * Open-Hardware needs Open-Source Software and open file formats. Disincentivize the use of closed file formats or cloud-services. Design documents needs to be accessible, that includes the software to view and edit them.

Je suis membre de la fonction publique hospitalière et utilisateur de longue date de logiciels libres comme les OS Linux. Je pense que la souveraineté numérique est essentielle et salue cette initiative allant dans le sens de l'indépendance européenne. Je ressens dans mon quotidien les conséquences négatives de cette dépendance aux systèmes privés : les partenariats avec Microsoft nous obligent à nous contorsionner et être hypervigilants pour que des données sensibles ne partent pas sur des serveurs aux USA ; nous utilisons des systèmes lourds et lents, aspirant de nombreuses données et parfois pollués par des publicités, au lieu de systèmes véloces, sécurisés, compartimentés et allant à l'essentiel. Cela a également un impact sur la dimension écologique : ces logiciels sont si lourds qu'ils poussent à un renouvellement accélé du matériel, rajoutant des coûts inutiles. Pour mener à bien cette stratégie, je pense essentiel de sortir de logiques de marchés et d'acteurs privés : il faut une communauté de développeurs payés par l'état, sans objectifs contraints de rentabilité (la vigueur du monde libre montre qu'ils n'ont pas besoin de contraintes pour savoir ce dont les gens ont besoin ni comment le faire), proposant à l'ensemble de la population des services simples : suite bureautique, OS, service mail et cloud hébergé en france, service de visioconférence, des LLM et logiciels Speech-to-text 100% locaux ou connectés à des serveurs français, et éventuellement du hardware modulable et réparable. Les bénéfices indirects seront énormes, et il est urgent de répondre à ces enjeux.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: I am a member of the hospital civil service and a long-standing user of open source software such as OS Linux. I believe that digital sovereignty is essential and welcome this move towards European independence. I feel in my daily life the negative consequences of this dependence on private systems: the partnerships with Microsoft oblige us to configure ourselves and be hypervigilant so that sensitive data does not leave on servers in the USA; we use cumbersome and slow systems, extracting a lot of data and sometimes polluted by advertisements, instead of biased, secure, compartmentalised and essential systems. This also has an impact on the ecological dimension: such software is so cumbersome that it pushes for accelerated hardware renewal, adding unnecessary costs. In order to carry out this strategy, I think it is essential to move away from the logic of markets and private actors: we need a community of developers paid for by the state, without binding targets for profitability (the strength of the free world shows that they do not need constraints to know what people need or how to do it), offering simple services to the whole population: Office suite, OS, mail and cloud service hosted in france, videoconferencing service, local LLMs and Speech-to-Text software 100 % or connected to French servers, and possibly scalable and repairable hardware. The indirect benefits will be huge, and there is an urgent need to address these challenges.

feedback: Greetings, I am a videogames developer who graduated at my university in Portugal with a game developed entirely with open source tools, mainly Blender3D, Linux Manjaro and Godot. To keep it simple, open source software like Linux, for example, has proven to be a excellent alternative to closed source alternatives like Windows. It isnt attached to major corporations, has plenty of use cases and best of all: it is built for the communities by the community. I havent encountered an error or bug that I couldnt fix myself or with help from other users of said software. I strongly believe the EU should invest and adopt in tools that help mantain and improve open source OS and other types of software and maybe consider hiring more developers and designers with experience on these.

I'm 45 years old and I speak both as a user and as a Senior System Administrator of a company in the FinTech sector. If the wheel were a closed-source technology, inequality in the world would be far greater than what we observe today. The EU initiative fully embraces what I have voluntarily and quietly done in my life since 2005 and in my family since 2013. In 2005, I chose to completely abandon the use of technologies that create dependency on providers unable to guarantee me explicit, complete, and documented clarity about everything that is done with my data. The difficulties I had to face were mainly related to lack of knowledge, but this trained me and induced me to think constructively. What happens on all my family's devices every day is a source of analysis and debate, and as soon as an open-source alternative emerges, we try to introduce and embrace it by stepping out of our comfort zone. Unfortunately, however, the obstacles are many and often insurmountable, also and especially due to the laziness that has characterized the entire technology sector over the last 30 years. Today there are no smartphones that are not inextricably linked to the unilateral choices of very few actors. I don't rule out that a single button is enough to shut down all our communications, wherever we are. In schools, the PC is seen as a branded tool and not as a real instrument of emancipation and personal growth. The choice of technological solutions is presented as already made, inevitable; they simply tell you: "There are no valid alternatives." Free services, where the user is the product to be sold, have destroyed the very concept of freedom, creating new forms of slavery, more mental than real. In recent years, the EU has put the user at the center and services as its satellites, exactly as it should be in a free market. Nothing in the world where I work doesn't have its roots in open-source. Without open-source, there would be no infrastructure capable of delivering services. The problem should be addressed from two points of view, as in a pincer movement: 1.In schools, from an early age, technology should be introduced and explained for what it can do, for better or worse. As one moves toward higher education, all tools and related problems that arise in their use should be shown in a critical and in-depth manner. Having a critical and analytical spirit in the use of technology is a necessity, at this point in human history. Today I don't find this in most of my peers and often not even in my own IT colleagues. 2.Companies that invest in open-source tools should be helped with migration and staff training. Their experiences should be shared and made visible by public information. Those who instead do research and contribute directly to open-source should be given tax relief, because they will be the real new force for EU competitiveness. There is no shortage of projects, but visibility and culture still have a long way to go.

I'm VP of Community at Zig Software Foundation (ZSF from now on), an American non-profit foundation (501c3, EIN 84-5105214) dedicated to developing Zig, an open source programming language. ZSF lives entirely off donations (see 2025 financials https://ziglang.org/news/2025-financials/ ), has been operating for about 8 year now and we're starting to see mainstream adoption of the language by tech companies all over the world. In my experience the funding model we adopted is extremely effective for big-enough open source projects, but it doesn't seem it would be possible to replicate it in EU. More specifically, I'm an Italian citizen and I don't believe it would be possible for me to create a tax-exempt foundation comparable to an American 501c3. Likewise, US taxpayers can deduct donations to ZSF (and other 501c3 non-profits) while in EU, as far as I'm aware, tax deducibility of donations to non-profits can only happen within the same country (so I, an Italian citizen, can only deduct donations to Italian non-profits). The fact that ZSF can pay developers to work full-time on its open-source project shows that the tech industry is interested in this particular open-source solution, to the point of being willing to pay for its development. This is testament to the value that the public attributes to open source projects such as Zig. As stated above, unfortunately it doesn't seem possible for EU citizens to capture that interest in the same way that American companies can under tax code 501c3. In my opinion, first and foremost there must be a straight-forward way for EU citizens to setup non-profit, tax-exempt foundations to host big open source projects. Secondarily EU citizens should be able to donate to these foundations and get tax benefits. In terms of industries that would benetit the most from increased usage of open source software, I think that the automotive sector is the one that would benefit the most. I know of plenty of horror stories where car manufacturers are effectively held hostage by closed source software, sold to them by vendors that often go out of business, leaving them with unmaintainable software solutions.

Merci pour cette consultation. Même si elle y contribue, l'open-source ne suffit pas pour atteindre une souveraineté numérique. Cette dernière implique un contrôle et une maîtrise de l'outil pour lui faire adopter la trajectoire voulue. L'open-source permet (théoriquement) le contrôle, mais pas nécessairement la maîtrise de la trajectoire qui nécessite des ressources (humaines, matérielles,...) disponibles. Outre l'open-source, il faudrait donc promouvoir aussi les capacités opérationnelles. En réponses à vos questions: Q1. Le bât blesse fort en ce qui concerne le matériel. Un soutien industriel devrait être mis en place afin que puissent être fabriqués des ordinateurs européens et, idéalement, open-source. D'une manière générale, nombre de produits logiciels open-source existent par la seule volonté des contributeurs. A partir du moment où l'open-source est un élément moteur dans la stratégie numérique de l'UE, il faudrait assurer une survie stable de ces produits en apportant un financement destiné à payer des équipes pour maintenir ces produits. Q2. Le contrôle. On peut vérifier, corriger, adapter comment les choses fonctionnent, notamment en matière de sécurité. On n'est pas soumis au bon vouloir d'un tiers qui pourra décider de "débrancher la prise" quand bon lui semblera. L'open-source rend possible la liberté et la sécurité. Le partage. L'open-source est un peu le bien commun numérique de l'humanité. Cela favorise l'interopérabilité et les partenariats technologiques et commerciaux entre tous les pays du monde (pas uniquement l'UE). Q3. Inciter la création d'entreprises technologiques en Europe fabriquant des ordinateurs, serveurs, smartphones,... en s'appuyant sur l'open-source, que ce soit au niveau matériel ou logiciel. Pousser l'open-source dans les écoles et universités. Les jeunes s'habituent aux outils propriétaires car les entreprises sont promptes à proposer des offres gratuites ou très bon marché dans le milieu éducatif. Les habitudes sont vite acquises. Mettre en place des fonds qui viennent alimenter de manière structurelle des produits open source afin d'en garantir la pérennité. Typiquement, rétribuer les personnes qui développent les produits. Imposer l'usage des produits open source dans les administrations publiques. Les produits propriétaires pouvant être utilisés uniquement lorsqu'il n'y a pas d'équivalent fonctionnel dans le monde open-source. Q4. La fabrication de matériel. Il existe déjà beaucoup d'équivalents logiciels open-source par rapport aux propriétaires (dont certains surclassent ces derniers d'ailleurs). Par contre, au niveau matériel, on est totalement dépendant. Il n'y a pas de marques connues de produits (PC, serveur, smartphone, tablette,...) que l'on peut acheter "made in Europe" d'une part, et "open source" (quant aux plans de fabrications et composants matériels) d'autre part. Or tout part de là. On peut avoir une infrastructure et des services totalement open-source, on ne peut y accéder que via un périphérique "personnel" (que cela concerne le domaine privé ou professionnel, les individus ou les entreprises). A moins que l'on puisse accéder à Internet par télépathie... Q5. Le matériel... On est contraint d'utiliser des produits externes sur lesquels on n'a pas de véritable contrôle. De plus, si demain, on ne peut plus s'approvisionner en HP, Dell, Lenovo, Apple, Samsung,... on pourra peut-être retrouver quelques machines à écrire Olympia dans le grenier...
feedbackTextUserLanguage:
Thank you for this consultation. Even if it contributes to this, open-source is not enough to achieve digital sovereignty. This involves monitoring and mastering the tool to ensure that it follows the desired path. Open-source allows (theoretically) control, but not necessarily con
33365007,https://ec.europa.eu/info/law/better-regulation/have-your-say/initiatives/16213-European-Open-Digital-Ecosystems/F33365007_en,Ares(2026)69111,2026/01/15 16:32:25,As EU Citizen
companySize: I want to use EU Software with full GDPR compliance. As a senior developer and early adopter of open source software
organization: I encourage you to adopt open source software."

feedback: Open source software is and will always be important. Transparency on what is happening on our computers and devices as well as how the software is handling data and what data is being sent where is one of the most important things to have both digital sovereignty and security. How would you know what the software you're currently using is working in a safe manner? You can't. All you have are empty promises of someone else. It isn't and should never be enough. In our aviation a lot of our countries have some form of government body to study and make a detailed report of any aviation accident. This report is then used to make recommendations and implement new laws and procedures to make it one of the safest methods of transportation. You or your neighbour might not be a accident inspector but you know there are people who will work the case, read the reports and that the reports will be acted upon. These documents are available to be read through by anyone but we don't have to. We trust that the system of agencies and lawmakers will take care of that and a large majority of the time they do. I think open source software can be seen in the same way. For the same reason you or your neighbour might not be a aviation accident inspector or read through the reports to make sure they've been implemented for your next flight, there are software engineers and software security specialists that do go through open source software. Either through a company being hired to do so, or by their free time for the goodness of their heart. We then know, for certain, that the software is more secure. Because either you yourself have the possibility to go through the transparent code changes of what they've done to actually fix the problem or because you've been able to read a report that states what they've discovered and read patch notes on what has been changed the next time you download an update. Aviation is safe because of a clear and concise transparency and we can put trust in that transparency. For the same reason we can trust open source software. We shouldn't allow us to blindly trust closed source software on their word alone, especially not from regions and countries that might not agree with the European Unions goals and growth. It is and will always be empty words. We have an over-reliance software outside the EU today and if they would like, either for personal reasons or pressure from governments, make it difficult for us to use, make our services slow or even completely shut it down causing a continental wide crisis. This can't happen when we have transparency to audit and analyze changes to our critical software infrastructure.

Als langjähriger zivilgesellschaftlicher Open Data, Open Knowledge, Open Source & Open Government Aktivist und UX-Designer bei einer Open Source Software Firma begrüße ich diesen Vorstoß außerordentlich. Public Money = Public Code sollte ein zentrales Element öffentlicher Ausschreibungen sein. Offene Standards verhindern Vendor-Lock-In. Föderierte, offene Social-Media-Plattformen ermöglichen es Nutzer*innen frei zu wählen wo und wie sie partizipieren möchten. Die EU muss sich aktiv beteiligen und ein Teil eines fairen, nachhaltigen Open-Source-Ökosystems werden. Menschen, die offene, millionenfach verwendete Software programmieren, müssen dafür angemessen entlohnt werden und dürfen nicht von proprietären Anbietern zusätzlich noch unter Druck gesetzt werden. Open Source Software liefert zentrale Bausteine unserer digitalen Infrastruktur. Es ist Zeit ihr die Beachtung zu schenken, die sie verdient.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: As a long-standing civil society open data, open knowledge, open source & open government activist and UX designer at an open source software company, I warmly welcome this initiative. Public Money = Public Code should be a central element of public tenders. Open standards prevent vendor lock-in. Federated, open social media platforms allow users to freely choose where and how to participate. The EU must actively participate and become part of a fair, sustainable open-source ecosystem. People programming open, millions of times used software must be adequately remunerated for this and must not be put under additional pressure by proprietary providers. Open source software provides key building blocks of our digital infrastructure. It is time to give it the attention it deserves.

feedback: Penso che la prima cosa che l'UE dovrebbe fare è vietare l'uso di formati file proprietari, da parte di tutte le pubbliche amministrazioni, sia nella gestione di progetti europei, sia nell'interscambio documentale. In questo modo verrebbe meno il lock-in tecnologico indotto dall'uso di inutili macro o di particolari font. Bisogna sviluppare ed utilizzare sistemi informativi non prevedere rendicontazioni basate su tabelle ex...l. In parallelo è fondamentale portare a scuole e università iniziative e finanziamenti che permettano di renderle indipendenti dalle licenze "educational" gratuite delle software house che non sono altro che strumenti per far si che chi impara ad usare uno strumento resti poi fidelizzato allo stesso.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: I think the first thing the EU should do is to ban the use of proprietary file formats by all public administrations, both in the management of European projects and in document exchange. This would eliminate the technological lock-in induced by the use of unnecessary macros or particular fonts. It is necessary to develop and use information systems that do not provide for reporting based on tables under... l. At the same time, it is essential to provide schools and universities with initiatives and funding that make them independent of free educational licences for software houses, which are nothing more than tools to ensure that those who learn how to use a tool remain loyal to it.

feedback: Yes, we need to untie us from USA software and companies, first thing to do is untie our smartphones from Google and Apple control, force them to allow third party operating system and software to be installed (eg: mandatory option to unlock bootloader and documentation along with it)

En tant que professionnel, je constate que la dépendance au cloud US est souvent masquée par une simple localisation géographique des serveurs en Europe. Or, sans contrôle de l'infrastructure et du code, cette souveraineté n'est qu'une façade soumise aux lois extraterritoriales. Pour inverser cette tendance, l'UE doit agir sur trois leviers : - Marchés publics européens : Prioriser systématiquement les solutions issues du marché européen. L'UE doit également protéger ses pépites technologiques par des mécanismes de régulation contre les rachats agressifs visant à étouffer la concurrence locale. - Financement de la pérennité : Le soutien ne doit pas être que ponctuel. Il faut établir une base économique solide pour les contributeurs open source, garantissant la maintenance et la sécurité à long terme des solutions critiques dont dépendent nos entreprises. - Alternative souveraine : L'open source est le seul levier permettant de briser les effets de réseau des géants du tech et de reprendre le contrôle de notre infrastructure numérique. Une participation active de l'Europe au financement des écosystèmes ouverts est un investissement stratégique pour notre résilience et notre autonomie future.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: As a professional, I see that dependency on US cloud is often masked by a mere geographical location of servers in Europe. However, without control over the infrastructure and the code, this sovereignty is merely a facade subject to extraterritorial laws. To reverse this trend, the EU needs to act on three levers: — European public procurement: Systematically prioritise solutions from the European market. The EU also needs to protect its technological seeds through regulatory mechanisms against aggressive takeovers to stifle local competition. — Financing sustainability: Support should not only be ad hoc. A sound economic basis for open source contributors needs to be established, ensuring the long-term maintenance and security of the critical solutions on which our companies depend. — Sovereign alternative: Open source is the only lever to break the network effects of tech giants and regain control over our digital infrastructure. Europe’s active involvement in financing open ecosystems is a strategic investment for our resilience and future autonomy.

feedback: Yes please. I won't add anything more that is already been said by far more knowledgeable and competent people than me. All I will say is this: please do it and don't let this die if a more European-friendly administration comes after the Trump's one. Thank you.

Il est pour moi nécessaire de se libérer de notre dépendance envers de sociétés américaines qui outre le fait qu'elles on un respect limité des lois européennes, sont soumises aux lois Américaines. Encourageons des alternatives européennes de préférence libre de droits, par une législation unique et favorable aux entreprises européennes. Finançons ces alternatives pour permettre leurs développements. Encourageons par l'exemple (utilisation uniquement de ces solutions). Bannissement de tout logiciel américain... Developpons une alternative à Android viable installée sur des Smartphones grand public
feedbackTextUserLanguage: I need to free myself from our dependence on American societies, which, in addition to their limited compliance with European laws, are subject to American laws. Let us encourage European alternatives, preferably free of rights, by means of single legislation favourable to European businesses. Let’s finance these alternatives so that they can be developed. Encourage by example (use only of these solutions). Banning any US software... Let’s develop an alternative to viable Android installed on consumer smartphones

feedback: Je salue cette initiative de la Commission européenne qui identifie enfin le logiciel libre (open source) non plus comme une simple commodité technique, mais comme un pilier stratégique de notre souveraineté. En réponse à votre appel à contribution (Réf. Ares(2026)69111), je souhaite confirmer la pertinence du diagnostic posé et proposer des axes daction concrets pour transformer cette vision en réalité industrielle. 1. Validation du diagnostic : La dépendance est un risque systémique Lanalyse de la Commission est juste : la dépendance de lUE aux technologies non-européennes nest pas seulement un frein économique, cest une vulnérabilité sécuritaire majeure. En laissant les infrastructures critiques (Cloud, IA, cybersécurité) sous le contrôle dacteurs tiers, nous nous exposons à des risques despionnage industriel, de coupure de service unilatérale et de vendor lock-in (enfermement propriétaire) qui brident linnovation européenne. Le constat que la valeur générée par nos développeurs est souvent captée par des géants technologiques extra-européens est particulièrement alarmant et doit être le point central de la nouvelle stratégie. 2. Lopen source comme vecteur de souveraineté Le logiciel libre est la seule voie viable pour garantir la transparence des chaînes dapprovisionnement logicielles et la maîtrise de nos infrastructures. Cependant, il ne suffit pas que le code soit ouvert ; il faut que la gouvernance et la valeur économique restent ancrées en Europe.La souveraineté ne se décrète pas, elle se construit par le code et linfrastructure. Linitiative doit donc dépasser le stade de la recherche et innovation pour viser lindustrialisation et la pérennité commerciale des solutions européennes. 3. Propositions pour une stratégie offensive Pour que cette initiative Vers des écosystèmes numériques ouverts soit efficace, elle doit saccompagner de mesures radicales : La commande publique comme levier prioritaire : Il est impératif dinstaurer une préférence communautaire claire et un principe de L'open source dabord dans les marchés publics. Largent du contribuable européen doit financer des technologies que lEurope contrôle. Les barrières à lentrée mentionnées dans le document doivent être levées par des procédures simplifiées pour les PME et start-ups du libre. Financer la maintenance, pas juste linnovation : comme le souligne le document, le soutien via les programmes R&I est insuffisant pour le passage à léchelle. LUE doit créer des fonds dédiés à la maintenance long terme des communs numériques critiques, assurant ainsi aux entreprises la stabilité nécessaire pour bâtir leurs services sur ces briques. Protéger lécosystème des prédations : la stratégie doit inclure des mécanismes pour sassurer que les géants technologiques non européens qui profitent de lopen source européen contribuent en retour (financièrement ou techniquement) à lécosystème, rétablissant ainsi une équité concurrentielle. Conclusion LEurope dispose déjà des talents et des communautés de développeurs parmi les plus actives au monde. Ce qui nous manque, cest un marché intérieur unifié qui privilégie structurellement ses propres solutions. Cette initiative est loccasion historique de passer dune souveraineté de discours à une souveraineté de fait, en faisant de lopen source le standard industriel de lEurope de demain.

I welcome this initiative by the European Commission, which finally identifies open source software no longer as a mere technical convenience but as a strategic pillar of our sovereignty. In response to your call for evidence (Ref. Ares (2026) 69111), I would like to confirm the relevance of the diagnosis made and propose concrete lines of action to transform this vision into an industria
