column40: French and European, I am pleased to see that we finally have the right questions about Europe’s digital sovereignty. It would be time to no longer entrust the hosting, backup and access of our digital data to those who monetise, spy on and take us hostage with our own data. We are a world of talent, and the world of freedom offers all the tools we need for our digital sovereignty! So, yes to the free world and not to US digital companies! Finally, let’s make up for 10 years of delay...

feedback: A l'heure où les tensiosn géopolitique grandissent et que les services numériques sont utilisés à des fins numériques (services bloqués à la demande d'état pour certaines personnes). Il est essentiel que l'Europe augmente son autonomie numérique qui passe notamment par l'open-source. Cet écosystème doit être utilisé mais également financé pour qu'il puisse perdurer et s'améliorer.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: At a time when geopolitical surges are growing and digital services are being used for digital purposes (services blocked at the request of the state for some people). It is essential for Europe to increase its digital autonomy, including through open-source technology. This ecosystem needs to be used but also funded so that it can continue and improve.

feedback: Le logiciel libre, Linux, les licences GPL - GNU sont la plus grande force de l'Europe. Nous avons des développeurs de talent, du matériel tout à fait compatible dans toutes les administrations des pays européens et nous continuons à laisser notre argent partir aux USA. Soyons créatifs et ne soyons pas mesquins avec nos programmeurs. Enfin, cessons de faire semblant d'enseigner le codage avec Scratch. Les langages restent indispensables et l'iA ne remplace pas la créativité.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: Open source software, Linux, LPG – GNU licences are Europe’s greatest strength. We have talented developers, fully compatible materials in all administrations in European countries and we continue to let our money go to the USA. Let’s be creative and not mesquine with our programmers. Finally, let’s stop seeming to teach coding with Scratch. Languages remain indispensable and the iA does not replace creativity.

feedback: Bonjour, Que mon pays, ou l'Europe, sache tout de moi je n'y vois aucun problème. Mais l'usage de solutions américaines ou autre pour le traitement et le stockage des données alors ces firmes ont elles même déclaré qu'elles ne pouvaient pas imposer le secret à l'état dont elles dépendent pose un problème fondamental. Pour moi, citoyen, cela pose un problème sur mes données et pour nos forces, administrations et autres sur notre indépendance, notre survie économique, évidente, idéologique à l'heure de la désinformation et demain notre survie tout court à l'heure du vas t'en guerre latent. Le combat pour une réappropriation va même plus loin que les outils européens car nos entreprises, grandes ou petites, et administrations nationales ou locales devraient également être concernées. J'utilise déjà des solutions libres et les seuls freins identifiables à une adoption plus large tient en un mot : l'habitude. Et si on veut être plus large : la feignantise. Et si vous attendez qu'il soit trop tard pour réagir, rassurez vous : c'est probablement déjà le cas. Bien cordialement,
feedbackTextUserLanguage: Hello, Which my country, or Europe, knows all of me there are no problems. However, the use of US or other solutions for the processing and storage of data, when these firms even stated that they could not impose secrecy on the state on which they depend, is a fundamental problem. For me, as a citizen, this poses a problem for my data and for our strengths, administrations and others on our independence, our obvious economic survival, our ideological survival at the time of disinformation, and tomorrow our very survival at the time of your latent war. The fight for reappropriation goes even further than European tools because our companies, big or small, and national or local administrations should also be involved. I already use open solutions and the only identifiable obstacles to wider adoption are in a nutshell: the habit. And if we want to be broader: feignantise. And if you wait for it to be too late to react, reassure you: this is probably already the case. Kind regards,

feedback: Bonjour, En tant qu'enseignant je pense qu'il est grand temps de se passer des systèmes d'exploitations et logiciels fermés généralement états-uniens. Cela nous permettrait de renforcer notre sécurité et nous libérerait de possibles blocages par des entreprises, dépendant de pays hors d'Europe, notamment les États-Unis.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: Hello, As a teacher, I think it is high time to do away with closed operating systems and software that are usually US-owned. This would allow us to strengthen our security and free us from potential blockages by companies, depending on countries outside Europe, including the United States.

feedback: I fully support this initiative. A good way to act and declare digital sovereignty is also to address the same issue for all the software stack used by public institutions , using only open and free software without vendor lock-ins or "wall garden" by American's companies. Please act and stay put about this because we are not Americans and we should pursuit our interests (not theirs).

Il est nécessaire d'utiliser un écosystème open source en lieu et place des logiciels étrangers et notamment américain, tout comme ol est nécessaire de développer des alternatives européennes aux gafam.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: It is necessary to use an open source ecosystem instead of foreign and especially American software, just as it is necessary to develop European alternatives to GAFAM.

feedback: Il est temps... Aujourdhui, la souveraineté numérique n'est plus une option, c'est une nécessité. Le contexte actuel nous montre qu'on doit impérativement être indépendants, que ce soit pour nos logiciels ou nos serveurs. Cest avant tout une question de sécurité pour nous tous.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: It’s time... Today, digital sovereignty is no longer an option, it is a necessity. The current context shows us that it is imperative to be independent, whether for our software or servers. This is above all a question of security for all of us.

feedback: As an EU citizen, I believe open source is not just a technical choice, but a strategic imperative for Europes future. It offers a unique opportunity to reduce our dependency on non-EU tech giants, enhance our cybersecurity, and foster innovation that aligns with European values. The EU must act decisively to remove barriers to adoption, invest in skills and infrastructure, and create a regulatory environment that supports open-source growth. I urge the Commission to: Prioritize public procurement reform to ensure open-source solutions are given fair consideration. Invest in sustainable funding and business models to support the long-term maintenance and scaling of open-source projects. Strengthen governance and community support to ensure open-source projects are secure, reliable, and aligned with EU priorities. Focus on critical sectors like cloud, AI, cybersecurity, and public infrastructure to maximize the impact of open-source investments. Concrete Measures and Actions at EU Level To unlock the full potential of open source, the EU should focus on the following actions: Policy & Funding: EU Open-Source Strategy (Q1 2026): Develop and implement a comprehensive strategy that supports the entire open-source lifecycle, from development to market integration, with a strong emphasis on sustainable governance and scaling Public Procurement Reform: Update procurement rules to mandate open-source components (e.g., 70% by 2030) and establish clear cybersecurity certification pathways for open-source solutions Public-Private Partnerships: Encourage public sector adoption and contribution to open-source projects, ensuring financial sustainability through partnerships with industry and civil society Regulation & Standardization: Cyber Resilience Act (CRA): Enforce baseline cybersecurity standards for all digital products, including open-source software, to ensure security and reliability Open Source Programme Offices (OSPOs): Establish OSPOs in public administrations to drive institutional learning, collaboration, and governance Standardization: Support the creation of a Fourth European Standardisation Organisation (ESO) to promote open development and interoperability across the EU Investment & Skills: Targeted Funding: Direct EU funding (e.g., Digital Europe Programme, Horizon Europe) to open-source projects in critical sectors such as cloud computing, AI, cybersecurity, and automotive Skills Development: Invest in training and certification programs to address the skills gap and support digital transformation in both public and private sectors 4. Priority Technology Areas The EU should prioritize open-source development in the following areas to maximize impact: Cloud & Edge Computing: Reduce dependency on non-EU providers and enhance data sovereignty by supporting open-source alternatives Artificial Intelligence (AI): Foster ethical, transparent, and compliant AI development, in line with the EU AI Act, to ensure Europe leads in responsible AI innovation Cybersecurity: Develop open-source tools for secure software, identity management, and infrastructure resilience to protect critical digital infrastructure Open Hardware & Industrial Applications: Support open-source solutions in automotive, manufacturing, and energy sectors to strengthen competitiveness and digital sovereignty Public Digital Infrastructure: Invest in open-source solutions for government services, health, transport, and public administration to ensure secure, interoperable, and citizen-centric digital services By taking these steps, the EU can harness the full potential of open source to achieve technological sovereignty, competitiveness, and cyber resilienceensuring that Europe remains a leader in the global digital economy.

Enfin ! Merci de vous pencher sur ce sujet CAPITAL. Cette décision aurait selon moi du être prise il y a au moins 10 ans mais mieux vaut tard que jamais. Par contre, s'il vous plaît, ne vous focalisez pas sur l'IA uniquement. Il faut absolument sécuriser les domaines suivants : matériels réseaux, logiciels socles (concurrent a Microsoft), Système d'exploitation PC et mobile, etc... Beaucoup de talent sont présent en Europe. Avec une véritable volonté politique, on peut se mettre a l'abri des démocraties vacillantes.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: Last but not least! Please consider this topic CAPITAL. In my view, this decision should have been taken at least 10 years ago, but it is better than ever before. On the other hand, if you like, you are not focusing solely on AI. It is essential to secure the following areas: network hardware, socket software (competitor to Microsoft), PC and mobile operating system, etc. There is a lot of talent in Europe. With real political will, we can protect ourselves from looming democracies.

feedback: Il faut en effet travailler uniquement avec des solutions européennes avec un stockage souverain. Il faudrait même imposer ces solutions au niveau des etats membres pour les services publics.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: We need to work only with European solutions with sovereign storage. These solutions should even be imposed at Member State level for public services.

feedback: Merci de lire mon avis sur cette consultation. Je confirme qu'il est important à mon avis que l'argent public utilisé ou attribué pour générer du logiciel, implique obligatoirement que le code généré soit public. Et également je pense qu'il est nécessaire que toutes les structures gouvernementales à tout niveau dans l'UE utilisent exclusivement des services numériques ouverts, libres, et localisés dans l'UE.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: Please read my opinion on this consultation. I confirm that it is important in my view that the public money used or allocated to generate software necessarily implies that the code generated is public. And I also believe it is necessary that all government structures at all levels in the EU exclusively use open, free, and localised digital services in the EU.

feedback: 1. Paid SW outsources any risk for management buying it both in public and private companies. Small companies supporting open source frequently cannot participate in tenders due to requirements for financial stability and risks. On top cannot offer easily 24/7 support and onsite. 2. No lock in, security, possiblt cost. 3. Add a scope Tax to support pure open source and support aggregations to overcome point 1 issues. 4. Security areas because intrusions are real and currently we have no real defence vs backdoors. 5. Again security and all cloud related technologies to allow ownership and open migration.
See the attached file.
organization: UiT The Arctic University of Norway

feedback: I want to suport Open Source. I' m a Linux User since 2000. I' m writing from my Ubuntu Linux Workstation. I worked as as an Engeeneer and supported open source since the beginnings...Windows only as a VM to coexist with Linux as a Virtualbox VM:) Bye

Bonjour, Mon avis est forgé sur des années d'utilisation de logiciel Open Source que ce soit du système d'exploitation (en particulier Linux) jusqu'a des logiciels bureautiques. Le créateur de Linux (Linus Torvald) est Finlandais. C'est notre Bill Gates Européen. Je n'ai jamais compris pourquoi l'Europe n'a jamais soutenu le projet. Il est temps de mettre cela en place pour garantir notre indépendance numérique. Par expérience si vous voulez assoir linux comme système d'exploitation Européen, il faut obliger les fabricants de matériel à développer des drivers solides certifiés Linux pour que les joueurs puissent avoir la garantie de fonctionnement des jeux sur Linux. En effet, si vous garantissez aux joueurs Européens que Linux est garanti comme Windows (et même mieux) cela touchera l'ensemble de la population Européenne et facilitera l'utilisation de Linux pour la bureautique. Voila mon avis
feedbackTextUserLanguage: Hello, My opinion is forged over years of use of Open Source software, from the operating system (in particular Linux) to office software. The creator of Linux (Linus Torvald) is Finns. This is our European Bill Gates. I have never understood why Europe has never supported the project. It is time to put this in place to ensure our digital independence. On the basis of experience, if you want to assoir linux as a European operating system, hardware manufacturers must be obliged to develop solid drivers certified Linux so that players can be guaranteed the operation of games on Linux. If you guarantee to European players that Linux is guaranteed like Windows (and even better), this will affect the entire European population and facilitate the use of Linux for office automation. Voila mon avis

feedback: L'utilizzo di software libero nel settore pubblico nazionale ed europeo non è solo utile ma necessaria per rendere una democrazia tale. L'uso di OSS non è solo una scelta tecnica, con tutti i benefici che porta con sé, ma anche etica, morale e politica che minima dinamiche di potere monopolistiche e talvolta dittatoriali in senso ampio. Il software libero è per definizione libero da dinamiche di potere e di controllo, poiché esso è trasparente. Tutte le persone con le adeguate competenze potranno comprendere il funzionamento dei software usati dall'unione europea garantendo così una diffusione di conoscenza, nonché la possibilità di individuare velocemente problematiche correlate alla sicurezza stessa di tali software. I cittadini sono ben disposti ad aiutare laddove se ne sente la necessità. Inoltre, ciò rende anche trasparente i processi e le dinamiche interne, di come l'informazione viene gestita e processata, anche qui consentendo alla cittadinanza tutta di poter proporre metodologie più efficaci qualora fosse necessario.La promozione di software libero è allo stesso tempo promozione di un modello sostenibile di sviluppo e promozione di un modello trasparente di democrazia, lasciando dunque da parte gli interessi economici e politici di enti privati che hanno lo scopo di generare profitto.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: The use of free software in the national and European public sector is not only useful but necessary to make such a democracy. The use of SDGs is not only a technical choice, with all the benefits it brings, but also an ethical, moral and political one that minimises the dynamics of monopolistic power and sometimes dictatorial power in the broad sense. Free software is by definition free of power and control dynamics, as it is transparent. All people with the appropriate skills will be able to understand how the software used by the European Union works, thus ensuring that knowledge is disseminated and that problems relating to the safety of that software can be quickly identified. Citizens are well prepared to help where they feel the need. Moreover, this also makes the internal processes and dynamics transparent, of how information is managed and processed, also here allowing citizens to propose more effective methodologies if needed. The promotion of free software is at the same time promoting a sustainable model of development and promoting a transparent model of democracy, thus leaving aside the economic and political interests of private entities that aim to generate profit.

feedback: Penso che sia necessario rimuovere da tutta la pubblica amministrazione europea ogni traccia di software proprietario, le alternative esistono e sono attuabili. Io stesso utilizzo da piu' di 10 anni linux e nel mio piccolo homelab uso nextcloud senza rimpiangere i prodotti di massa. Se posso io rimuovere o per lo meno limitare di molto l'accesso alla mia vita da parte dei giganti esteri, perchè non farlo a livello europeo? Vista la triste situazione geopolitica, penso sia altamente auspicabile un generale e rapido passaggio a piattaforme opensource, senza contare che tutto ciò, se ben gestito, potrebbe innescare un circolo virtuoso anche per l'economia del settore. E' giunto il momento di un Europa unita.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: I think it is necessary to remove all traces of proprietary software from all parts of the European public administration, alternatives exist and are feasible. I have been using linux myself for more than 10 years and I use Nextcloud in my small homelab without replacing mass products. If I can remove or at least significantly restrict access to my life for foreign giants, why not do it at European level? In view of the sad geopolitical situation, I think a general and rapid shift to opensource platforms is highly desirable, not to mention that this, if well managed, could trigger a virtuous circle also for the sector’s economy. It is time for a united Europe.

feedback: Sono amministratore di una azienda SrlS che opera nel settore digitale e sono completamente favorevole a questa iniziativa, anzi, anche leggermente in ritardo giusto di qualche anno. Le big USA ci stanno strozzando e deve finire questo monopolio, non è possibile essere dipendenti da 4 o 5 aziende che hanno la possibilità di far fallire aziende europee nel giro di una notte per il cambio di un algoritmo che fa gli interessi solo ed unicamente dell'azienda che detiene l'algoritmo, in primis Google. Inoltre, non voglio i miei dati personali e aziendali in mano a una azienda americana. Personalmente ho già iniziato la migrazione per tutto quello che mi è possibili in realtà europee iniziando dall'account mail e cloud. Chiederei alla commissione anche di rimuovere tutti i loghi delle big tech USA dai siti web istituzionali che risulta essere una pubblicità.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: I am the manager of a Srls company operating in the digital sector and I am entirely in favour of this initiative, even slightly late in just a few years. The big US are choking us and must end this monopoly, it is not possible to be dependent on 4 or 5 companies that have the possibility of having European companies go bankrupt within one night to change an algorithm that only interests the company that owns the algorithm, primarily Google. Moreover, I do not want my personal and business data in the hands of an American company. Personally, I have already started migration for everything that is possible for me in Europe, starting with my email and cloud account. I would also ask the committee to remove all US big tech logos from institutional websites that appear to be advertising.

feedback: En tant que citoyen, je suis parfaitement favorable à cette initiative, permettant d'accroitre notre souveraineté et notre autonomie stratégique. Les logiciels libres sont en parfaites cohérences avec les valeurs européennes de partage, d'unité dans la diversité, et sont source d'une compétitivité (en brisant les monopoles) et d'une émulation collective.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: As a citizen, I am very much in favour of this initiative, making it possible to increase our sovereignty and our strategic autonomy. Open source software is perfectly consistent with European values of sharing, unity in diversity, and creates competitiveness (breaking monopolies) and collective emulation.

feedback: Depuis des années, et ce n'est pas une mince durée de temps, nous tournons sur des interfaces propriétaires qui n'appartiennent même pas à l'Europe. On a beau nous assurer de l'impénétrabilité de ce que l'on fait, le contrat de confiance est un contrat d'entreprise où l'entreprise contrat beaucoup plus que l'individu. Passer à l'open source n'est pas seulement une nécessité mais une obligation. Tout consommateur a le droit d'être assuré qu'aucune de ces informations ne se retrouvera vendue. Il est très drôle de savoir que l'éducation nationale française met en avant les rgpd et vous en démontre l'importance avec un formateur qui tourne sous Windows ou Apple. Il y a, dans toute l'Europe, un nombre incalculable d'informaticiens, de programmateurs, et nous préférons les laisser de côté, et nous tourner vers des services qui nous propose en permanence un chantage inadmissible. Si je reste dans la matière de l'éducation nationale, l'ensemble des logiciels, qu'ils soient des logiciels de tous les jours, ou des logiciels plus vastes, comme par exemple cloud interactif, où les plateformes d'hébergement des sites, doivent être open source. Cela assure à tous les acteurs de l'éducation nationale de travailler en toute sérénité et de pouvoir poser l'ensemble des pierres de l'édifice éducatif sans avoir à se soucier de ce que le travail fait nourrice d'autres entreprises qui ne regardent pas la qualité du travail, mais la valeur commerciale de ce qui est fait. Tout ne peut pas être commerce, surtout pas le savoir....
feedbackTextUserLanguage: For years, and not for so long, we have been working on proprietary interfaces that do not even belong to Europe. We should be assured of the impenetrability of what we do, the contract of trust is a contract for a business where the company contracts much more than the individual. Moving to open source is not just a necessity but an obligation. Every consumer has the right to be assured that none of this information will be sold. It is very dubious to know that French national education highlights rgpd and demonstrates the importance of rgpd with a trainer running on Windows or Apple. There are countless computer scientists and programmers across Europe, and we prefer to leave them behind, and turn to services that constantly offer us unacceptable blackmail. If I remain in the field of national education, all software, be it everyday software, or broader software, such as interactive cloud, where site hosting platforms must be open source. This ensures that all those involved in national education work in a serenity and can lay all the stones of the educational structure without having to worry about what work does for other companies that do not look at the quality of work, but at the commercial value of what is done. Not everything can be traded, especially not knowledge....

feedback: Europe's open-source sector is a strategic asset for digital sovereignty and cybersecurity, but it remains under-leveraged due to structural market failures and policy gaps. It combines strong communities and technical capabilities. Core strengths: - Vibrant ecosystem: Active, cross-border communities and SMEs create interoperable, adaptable solutions that align with EU values of transparency, collaboration, and openness.​ - Security and resilience: Transparency, shared ownership, and decentralization support faster vulnerability discovery, lower systemic risk, and better alignment with EU cybersecurity objectives.​ - Economic value in Europe: Open source keeps more valuejobs, skills, and tax revenuewithin the EU and underpins technological sovereignty by reducing strategic vendor lock-in.​ Structural weaknesses: - Limited commercialisation: Many projects lack mature business models, long-term funding, and professionalization, which undermines sustainability and visibility.​ - Perception and trust gaps: Open source is still perceived as niche or less user-friendly, while open-source SMEs face disproportionate scrutiny compared to US-based incumbents.​ - Regulatory and compliance burden: Certification, security assurance and regulatory compliance are harder to navigate for small open-source vendors than for established Big Tech players.​ Key barriers - Big Tech market power: Bundling, lock-in practices, and control over cloud and platform infrastructure reduce openness, despite the objectives of GDPR, DSA and DMA to curb such gatekeeper behavior.​ - Public procurement lock-in: Complex, bundle-oriented tenders mirror proprietary portfolios, systematically excluding modular open-source offers and SMEs from large public contracts.​ - Lack of strategic demand: Governments rarely use their purchasing power to build European alternatives, missing a major lever to structurally grow the EU open-source market.​ Public and private added value - Lower lock-in and better control: Open source enables data, identity, and infrastructure control in line with GDPR and EU cybersecurity goals, while improving auditability and long-term sovereignty.​ - Innovation and adaptability: Open collaboration and open standards accelerate innovation, enable local customization, and better reflect user needs than closed, global one-size-fits-all services.​ Priority EU actions - Enforce and sharpen regulation: Robust enforcement of DMA/DSA/GDPR and stricter control of anti-competitive acquisitions to curb gatekeeper abuses and support fair access for open-source providers.​ - Reform procurement: Introduce a Buy European/Open Source by default approach where feasible, unbundle tenders, simplify cross-border participation, and make public administrations visible lead users of Open Source.​ - Focus investments: Direct roughly 70% of effort to scaling existing open-source solutions (productivity, cloud, collaboration) and 30% to critical dependency areas (defence, health, core infrastructure).

And who can, if they wish, cut critical infrastructure as they see fit (e.g. CPI mailbox).

And who can, if they wish, cut critical infrastructure as they see fit (e.g. CPI mailbox).

feedback: Sono un sistemista e sviluppatore con oltre 30 anni di esperienza. I prodotti open source oltre a garantire sicurezza in quanto se ne può visionare il codice, garantiscono anche l'investimento sulle competenze professionali. Personalmente penso che un paese dovrebbe usare solo prodotti liberi ed aperti in tutte le sue infrastrutture critiche.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: I am a system-maker and developer with more than 30 years of experience. Open source products not only ensure safety by viewing their code, but also ensure investment in professional skills. I personally think that a country should only use free and open products in all its critical infrastructure.

feedback: Does the European gerontocracy truly care about providing young adults pathways of climbing the economic ladder through their labor? To me, it looks like software developers are seen as expensive plumbers who are now kindly asked to replace some pipes, because the EU had a disagreement with the utilities company (Trump). If individual EU states had paid attention to the plumbing from the beginning, they would not need to introduce a new sovereignty doctrine, because those pipes would already be there - that's magically what happens when people are allowed to build things - the infrastructure would already be there: European operating systems, phones, cloud services, social media, etc. I am avoiding discussing the usual solutions like a common European market - because those are already known (see Draghi report) - I consider it low hanging fruit. I am more worried about the tendency of the EU to educate young adults into becoming activists. You fund them. Meanwhile, enterprising people go to USA where they can build their dream company. Yes, I am in favor of funding open-source projects, every nation funds their best engineers, whether that's open-source or in the private sector, but embracing open-source is ultimately a band-aid. Will the EU make the mindset shift that is needed to become a continent where we build things? This requires dramatic change in how society is structured (labor law, taxes). Installing Nextcloud, or developing our own platforms is a start, but ultimately the issue is more fundamental. If the EU has innovation, it automatically gains sovereignty.

As an European tech entrepreneur, I strongly advise on supporting European open source software engineering. Basically all technology today is built on basis of open source components and we need to ensure this large ecosystem is well-maintained and flourishing in order to enable digital independence and eventually leadership.

Dear Team, We're highlighting some topics - attached report - related to the open source consultation. We believe we have to take into account that the Artificial Intelligence disruption accelerate the opportunity to Europe as most code will be partially or fully written by AI. We also consider that many software stacks will be used by AI (AI agents etc) Europe has to transform its historical issues like fragmentation in an opportunity in its open source strategy: all local, national and European institutions should use the same interface (APIs, protocols etc) for all filings (tax like VAT etc, social security filings, corporate registry filings): so that implementing one API allows a tech company to give its service across Europe for all 27 Member States without the need to develop 27 different connectors etc. Finally, we remind the European Commission -as I gave many insights to the EU Commission on the 28th regime - that we also need to be an attractive headquarters destination for open source software foundations, which right now - like most tech startups even for profit ones - set headquarters in the US. In conclusion open source should be used to accelerate Europe's growth and make more real its single market. It should be a tool of defragmentation, especially that nowadays most business and non-business actions involve a digital tool:let's make sure those tools work across Europe, let's a have a true digital single market. BV

feedback: The use of open-source software within a regulatory framework that prioritizes the individual over profit is not only commendable but absolutely worth promoting. Over the years, Europe has chosen to delegate hardware and software development to third parties, and today, in this field as in many others, we risk facing disastrous consequences. It is essential to become as independent as possible from the major players in the sector and to provide adequate alternatives for businesses and citizens. However, this must be accompanied by user training and awareness-raising activities; otherwise, we risk tilting at windmills: those who use Microsoft Office today not only are unaware of the alternatives but also have no desire to learn how to use them. The same applies to mainstream applications, both in domestic and corporate environments, on PCs and smartphones alike. In Europe, we already have the know-how to introduce something new. I simply think of Linux distributions like Mint or OpenSUSE, or smartphone operating systems like MurenaOS or SailfishOS. Without having to start from scratch, it would be necessary to bring together the main European open-source actors in a consortium to create an ecosystem no longer dominated by American and Chinese giants such as Microsoft, Google, Apple, ByteDance, and the like. At the same time, education, starting from primary schools, should include up-to-date computer science curricula taught by teachers whose expertise is not limited to the Windows ecosystem. There is so much more to sayfrom privacy issues to the superficial way both adults and teenagers use applications. No one reads the terms and conditions, few use strong passwords, and even fewer adjust the settings on accounts created across various platforms (and sometimes its pointless anyway, since the average citizen has no way of knowing whether opting out of a particular setting actually stops tracking or not). One thing is certain: regardless of everything else, these issues must be addressed in the most serious, yet also the swiftest, way possible. Technology now moves at a dizzying pace, and legislation struggles to keep up, failing to regulate its use effectively. In fact, sometimes regulation intervenes in such a heavy-handed way that it ends up stifling development. Yet, for all its limitations, we have the GDPRsomething the rest of the world should envy us for. Open source, education, investment in transparent and ethical technology, independencethese are all issues of fundamental importance that must be turned into reality as soon as possible. By the way, this message has been translated to english using Mistral AI. Not Chatgpt or Gemini. Every little action has its meaning.

Based on my experiences within IT community, I believe open source digital technology (including more specific licensing subgenres such as copyleft software) is a highly useful tool for establishing successful software enterprises, fostering resilient national and international communities, and reducing dependencies on possibly rogue international actors. However, to achieve success in these fields, some level of prior planning is unsurprisingly required. I would personally point to following possible problems: - Using externally managed open source projects without developing EU-internal workforce that understands their inner workings. - National and EU public institutions not supporting the open source efforts in actual action. For example, it's fairly common for public messaging channels and legally required software to be available exclusively on external state controlled proprietary ecosystems. For more specific example of that example, this very website recommends using a log-in app available through US-controlled Google Play Store without listing alternatives. - Allowing overzealous copyright and patent law to prevent certain previously proprietary technology from establishing a de facto open ecosystem. This may be partially encouraged by international law, but some exceptions can clearly be developed. For example, legality of compatibility with existing CPU instruction set. - Technically open source projects that are practically highly dependent on proprietary software, or worse, services. Dependence on on-premises proprietary hardware is also a possible issue, but it seems better understood. - Intentionally unstable ecosystems, particularly with said unstability being controlled by non-EU actors. - Not even technically open source projects masquerading as such. This is particularly common in machine learning community (marketed as "artificial intelligence", which I also find misleading), where it had become common to refer to models as "open source", while by all means they are analogous to what was commonly known as freeware - proprietary software with a gratis license. - Badly thought out copyleft borders. The most common copyleft license family, GNU GPL, forbids proprietary programs in on-premise devices from interacting with GPL modules in convenient ways, but de facto allows usage in proprietary off-premise services, which is a far worse situation for everyone but the service operator. A license trying to handle this problem, Affero GPL, exists, but has major legal problems, as I understand it. - General badly planned funding as possible with most types of projects. Thank you for taking feedback on open digital ecosystems.

Bonjour, Je pense qu'il est indispensable de développer l'Open Source en Europe car c'est le seul moyen de réussir à s'émanciper des GAFAM américains et des chinois Cela permettrait de développer des alternatives libres, sérieuses et ne dépendant pas de la politique d'un pays Sans cette initiative nous risquons d'être dépendant et de subir les fake news et autres influences culturelles et sociétales venant des États Unis qui prennent un tournant autoritaire inquiétant Je suis moi même dans la milieu de l'informatique et essaie de trouver ces alternatives aujourd'hui qui existent parfois mais qui nécessite des investissements et aides de notre part à tous Bien à vous Kevin DOYET Un citoyen concerné
feedbackTextUserLanguage: Hello, I think it is essential to develop Open Source in Europe because this is the only way to successfully emancipate ourselves from the US GAFAM and the Chinese. This would allow free, serious alternatives to be developed that do not depend on a country’s policy. Without this initiative, we risk being dependent on and suffering fake news and other cultural and societal influences from the United States, which are taking a worrying authoritarian turn. I am myself in the IT world and trying to find these alternatives today, which sometimes exist but which require investment and support from us all. You Kevin DOYET A citizen concerned

feedback: Nous avons en Europe les meilleurs ingénieurs au monde, qui sont à l'origine de 2 immenses révolutions techno-industrielle des 40 dernières années : le Web et l'Intelligence Artificielle Générative ! Or, la plupart de ces talentueux ingénieurs ne font pas leur carrière en Europe, car ils ne trouvent pas de structures à la hauteur de leur talent et de leurs ambitions. Il est grand temps, aujourd'hui, alors que la dépendance technique aux USA se révèle enfin aux yeux des décideurs, de prendre très vite les mesures adéquates pour retenir ces talents de demain, pour leur offrir le cadre nécessaire à l'expression de leurs compétences au sein de nos entreprises Européennes. Visitez le site www.goeuropean.org dans la partie IT pour voir que nous avons déjà à notre disposition un nombre incroyable d'entreprises capables de fournir la quasi-totalité des services états-uniens dont nous dépendons aujourd'hui. En tant que développeur indépendant, je privilégie toujours depuis des années ces solutions techniques à mes clients. Pour le développement de sites et applications web : Symfony, un framework ultra-populaire, créé il y a 20 ans par un français et toujours maintenu par cette même personne. Une solution de référence, sur laquelle se sont bâtis tout un tas de solutions, même américaines et chinoises ! Pour le e-commerce : Sylius, une plateforme évolutive, basée sur Symfony et créée en Pologne. Qui vient de racheter PrestaShop en 2025 (une autre solution e-commerce européenne), avec l'ambition de devenir un champion mondial du e-commerce ! Pour les emails : ProtonMail ou Tuta, pour enfin conserver nos échanges électroniques à l'abris des regards de Google ! Pour l'hébergement cloud : OVH, Scaleway, Clever Cloud. Ces derniers sont français, et Clever Cloud a une maîtrise parfaite de toute sa chaîne de valeur technique. Ils travaillent avec des fabricants européens de puce et de matériels pour les datacenter. Ils développent également toute leur chaîne logicielle (du noyau Linux de leur système d'exploitation, aux services de bases de données pour leurs clients). Les pièces du puzzle sont sur la table, devant vous, devant nous ! Il nous faut maintenant tous en prendre conscience et collaborer pour faciliter et encourager l'usage de ces solutions en lieu et place des grandes entreprises tech états-uniennes ! Trouvez les moyens et leviers politiques, économiques et civiques pour embarquer toute l'Europe dans cette voie qui est notre avenir !

As an independent developer, I have always favoured these technical solutions to my customers for years. column52: The European Commissions decision to launch a public consultation on an EU-wide open source digital ecosystems strategy is a highly valuable and timely initiative. Open source software forms the backbone of todays digital economy, yet Europe has long lacked a coordinated approach capable of fully capturing the value created by its vibrant communities, researchers, and companies. This consultation represents an important step towards strengthening Europes technological sovereignty and reducing structural dependence on nonEU technologies. The Commissions focus on critical domains such as cloud and edge computing, AI, cybersecurity, and open hardware is particularly welcome. These are areas where Europe must reinforce resilience, competitiveness, and Longterm security. By inviting contributions from developers, industry, public administrations, and research institutions, the Commission is fostering an inclusive and collaborative process that reflects the very principles of open source. It is also encouraging to see attention given to structural challenges such as sustainable funding for maintenance and security, the need for demonstrator projects, and the Modernisation of public procurement policies. Addressing these issues is essential to unlock scalable business models and ensuring that open source solutions can be reliably integrated into strategic infrastructures. Building on the achievements of the 20202023 internal open source strategy, this new initiative has the potential to deliver a comprehensive and forwardlooking framework for the entire open source lifecycle. It is a strong signal of Europes commitment to innovation, openness, and digital autonomy. I welcome this consultation and look forward to seeing a robust and ambitious strategy emerges in 2026.

feedback: Directeur informatique et informaticien depuis 30 ans; j'ai toujours privilegié l'Open-source. Actuellement j'utilise 80% des ressources en open source; ma sociéte est donc à 80% indépendante. J'ai du mal à intégrer un logiciel dit "gratuit" dans mon budget, pour une entreprise privée. Je propose donc pour développer l'Open Source 1. une contribution (impôt basé sur le chiffre d'affaire des entreprises) qui permettrait de le financer et donc de solidifier et pérenniser ce secteur. 2. Voter une loi obligeant les développeurs de grosses solutions (comptabilité par exemple) d'écrire leurs applications pour Windows ET Linux. Les surcoûts seront amortis grâce à une durée de vie plus importante et ne dépendant pas de l'obsolescence programmée et voulue par les Gafams !! Merci
feedbackTextUserLanguage: Director of IT and IT for 30 years; I have always privileged Open-source. I currently use 80 % of open source resources; my company is therefore 80 % independent. I find it difficult to integrate ‘free’ software into my budget, for a private company. I therefore propose a contribution (tax based on companies’ turnover) to develop Open Source 1, which would make it possible to finance it and thus solidify and perpetuate this sector. 2. Pass a law obliging developers of large solutions (e.g. accounting) to write their applications for Windows AND Linux. The additional costs will be recouped thanks to a longer lifespan that does not depend on planned obsolescence desired by the Gafams! Thank you

feedback: Bonjour. En tant qu'utilisateur, et formateur technique Linux/BSD, il me paraît clair, et sans équivoque, que l'Open Source (ou Logiciels libres, en français), ne présente que des avantages : Liberté d'utilisation, d'achat, de vente, de correction du code, de suppression, ... J'ajoute que, si on supprime la liste des qualités de l'Open Source, ci-dessus, on retourne vers les produits sous licences propriétaires, fermés, ... En conclusion : J'ai basculé en "full Open Source" il y a 25 ans et ... je n'ai jamais été déçu (bien au contraire !). Mes amitiés Open Source à toutes et à tous
feedbackTextUserLanguage: Hello. As a user and Linux/BSD technical trainer, it seems clear and unequivocal to me that Open Source offers only advantages: Freedom to use, buy, sell, correct the code, delete, etc. I would add that, if we remove the list of qualities from the Open Source above, we return to products under proprietary, closed licences, etc. In conclusion: I switched to “full open source” 25 years ago and... I was never disappointed (quite the contrary!). My friends Open Source to everyone

feedback: As an engineer deeply involved in the open source ecosystem for years, I firmly believe Europe must champion the adoption of open source within its large companies in a sustainable. This is done by ensuring that the open source developers, team or companies, can thrive and continue to maintain high-quality, open technologies. To achieve this, I propose the creation of an Open Source Charter (and potentially a certification scheme) that would commit large European companies and Gov to actively support a healthy, sustainable open source ecosystem. Large EU companies claiming that they are OSS champions should respect those principles. Here are examples of key principles this charter could promote: Direct Financial Support for Maintainers Prioritize paying for support contracts with the open source entities responsible for creating and maintaining projects. Open source is not free: financial contributions are essential to enable those orgs to invest in their technology and avoid shifting to closed-source models or being acquired. Transparency and Knowledge Sharing Encourage and reward companies to publicly disclose their use of open source, including architectures, best practices, and patterns. This transparency will drive broader adoption of Open Source technology and foster a culture of collaboration. Self-Hosting and Reversibility Disregarding their business model, promote open source technologies that can be self-hosted with reasonable effort. OSS Cloud vendors should demonstrate clear paths to reversibility between Cloud and self hosted. Promote full OSS licences and not open core. European Open Source Marketplace Establish a validated marketplace for open source technologies, making it easier for businesses and public institutions to discover and adopt trusted solutions. Neutrality and Global Collaboration Avoid political or regional restrictions on open source projects. As long as a project is open and usage is unrestricted, it should be eligible regardless of the country of origin of the entity / developers. Good developers are everywhere. Preventing Consultancy Cannibalization of OSS Discourage consulting firms from profiting from open source support without ensuring significant contribution to projects. Minimizing Bureaucracy Protect innovation by avoiding unnecessary administrative burdens on open source developers and product managers. Should be all focused on using more Open Source tech everywhere rather than complexifying things.
Bonne idée mais avec 20 ans de retard et le temps perdu ne se rattrape pas. A part cela, l'Open Source présenté un sérieux problème. Vous le découvrirez tardivement. J'en suis quasi certain.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: Good idea but 20 years behind schedule and time wasted doesn’t catch up. Apart from that, the Open Source presented a serious problem. You will discover it late. I am almost sure of that.

Où est l'Europe des peuples ? Ce n'est pas VDL qui s'en occupe. Elle doit ses fonctions à son rang, ses origines et sa nullité est bien connue. It is well known that 30 % of the equipment and funds provided to Ukraine are evaporating and nothing is done. Where is the People’s Europe? This is not dealt with by VDL. feedback: Bonjour, Je suis pour, l'Europe aurait du sy pencher il y a plus de 10 ans. Dautant plus que la philosophie de l'open source correspond aux valeurs profondes de l'Europe. On évitera ainsi d'enrichir inutilement un allié qui ne l'est plus vraiment et de donner nos données sensibles pour exploitation mercantile. Arrêter d'écouter les lobbies présents dans vos locaux et écouter votre bon sens et les Européens. L'Europe doit retrouver son indépendance numérique mais pas que. L'Europe est peut-être contraignante et décriée pour ses règles mais elle sont là pour le bien commun. Les autres sont libres de ne pas les suivre chez eux, mais l'Europe aura fait sa part et n'aura rien à se repprocher. Cordialement.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: Hello, I am in favour, Europe would have to think more than 10 years ago. This is all the more true given that the open source philosophy corresponds to the deep values of Europe. This will avoid unnecessarily enriching an ally who is no longer really enriching and giving our sensitive data for mercantile exploitation. Stop listening to lobbies on your premises and listen to your common sense and Europeans. Europe must regain its digital independence, but not only. Europe may be binding and criticised for its rules, but it is there for the common good. Others are free not to follow them at home, but Europe will have done its part and will have nothing to blame for. Kind regards.

feedback: Le développement structuré et planifié de systèmes numériques ouverts et souverains est indispensable pour que l'Europe continue à exister indépendamment des pressions économiques et géostratégiques émergentes. L'appel aux compétences européennes favorisera leur pérennité et accroitra le poids de notre Union dans le monde.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: The structured and planned development of open and sovereign digital systems is essential for Europe to continue to exist independently of emerging economic and geostrategic pressures. The call for European skills will promote their sustainability and increase the weight of our Union in the world.

feedback: Oui il est nécessaire d'enfin travailler notre souveraineté numérique et d'arrêter de dépendre des GAFAM et autres technologies américaines. Nous possédons des personnes capables de créer les outils numériques dont nous avons besoin en s'appuyant sur l'open source et en évitant les dépendances dangereuses
feedbackTextUserLanguage: Yes, we must finally work on our digital sovereignty and stop being dependent on GAFAM and other US technologies. We have people who can create the digital tools we need by relying on open source and avoiding dangerous dependencies

feedback: The support of the EU towards Open Source is critical to strengthen the union and allow Open Source developments in and outside of the union to flourish. I would like to see the following focus: - Make sure to lead by example: roll out open source projects by acting as the launching customer. - Pay for your open source: even when a project provides software for free, support the project by investing in it and the ecosystem of support organisations around it - Put leadership in place that values in-house knowledge in stead of outsourcing everything - Make sure digitalisation has a permanent spot at the table when discussing other union affairs - Development of software commissioned by the EU will always be open source. this is perfectly possible and has a positive impact on code quality
Bonjour, À mon avis, c'est un sujet essentiel qui doit être traité en priorité et avec des budgets conséquents. Merci pour votre initiative, Bien cordialement Matthieu Canto
feedbackTextUserLanguage: Hello, in my view, this is a key topic that must be dealt with as a matter of priority and with substantial budgets. Thank you for your initiative, Welly Matthieu Canto

feedback: I'm an EU citizen with masters degree in engineering. I'm not directly involved in public Open Source projects, but, since several years ago, I develop software for direct customers and release it with EUPL license. I respond to the call and express my opinion over the 5 points of the call itself. 1 - EU pioneered Open Source (I'm thinking about Linux, but not only), as we pioneered almost all the technology (from communications to electronics, including computing). This is, of course, the main point of strength. EU weakness lies on the inability to take advantage of what we invented. On the contrary, US and China, invented almost nothing, but take big advantages from what WE invented. In a famous speech, Steve Jobs talked about "connecting the dots". This was the key to his (and not only his) success. EU is the greatest in making "the dots", but don't connect them. It was not always so. I remember big European companies like Nokia, Siemens, Olivetti (and many others). They were ruling the world about technology. It's no longer so. We need to come to edge again. 2 - Open Source, if well used, has a lot of advantages. Cost is not really the main of these. Not having a "vendor lock-in" is one of the first. Security and data sovereign are other great advantages. At least, security depends on what the user is doing, and not on non-EU players. Also, the possibility of customizing and adapting to company's needs, even if almost not leveraged, is a great opportunity. 3 - So many European developers ara actively working on Open Source projects. EU can do something to make them feel European developers and not GAFAM employees. Direct funding to relevant projects may be good, but I think that the most important thing is to build an EU ecosystem for Open Source. For instance, 99% of Open Source projects need to rely on 3 non-EU services: GitHub (read Microsoft), SourceForce (big US finance) and GitLab (still independent, but US). Almost all the Open Source is there, out of European sovereign. There're already EU alternatives that need to be powered up and also advertised, incentivizing EU developers to use them. 4 - The priority has to be to the area where EU completely lacks technology: i) collaboration suites (like GSuite or 365). No real alternatives exist. ii) communication tools (like Meet, Teams, Zoom, Whatsapp, Telegram). Some EU alternatives, but almost not used. iii) operating systems (like Windows, MacOs, Android, iOs). EU has the kernel of almost all the OS (I mean Linux), but no complete OS with relevant market share in any kind of device. iv) office suites (like Office, GSuite, Open Office). EU has Libre Office, but very few adoptions. Needs a boost to come up with appealing features. v) cloud stacks. Great majority of the cloud is on the hands of GAFAM. There're EU players trying to gain market share, but they are all powered by OpenStack, that is an US project used to follow the big tech and, in my opinion, not to give them too many problems. An EU cloud stack aimed not to follow, but innovate, could be a great base to a lot of things (Open Source and not). 5 - If well used and implemented, Open Source can give competitive advantages and better cyber resilience to almost every sector. The key factor is not only how the Open Source is developed, but how is implemented and deployed. EU should encourage the grow of supporting companies, not directly involved in development (to prevent conflict of interests), but with great expertise in Open Source adoption for EU users. All that said, I think that the matter is not to replace non-EU software, but to guarantee a concrete and competitive EU-alternative to the most used software. Market needs to have a choice, but not be forced in a direction. Today, in many important software categories, there's no choice, no viable EU-alternatives.

Une part significative des logiciels et services utilisés en Europe repose sur des composants open source, mais leur valorisation économique, leur gouvernance et leur exploitation sont souvent captées par des acteurs non européens. Cette situation crée une dépendance structurelle vis-à-vis de fournisseurs soumis à des cadres juridiques et à des intérêts étrangers à ceux de lUE. Lopen source est un puissant moteur dinnovation, notamment pour les PME, les startups et la recherche. Pourtant, labsence de soutien structuré à léchelle européenne limite la capacité des acteurs européens à rivaliser avec les grandes plateformes mondiales. Un investissement européen ciblé dans lopen source permettrait : de renforcer la compétitivité des entreprises européennes, de favoriser lémergence de solutions industrielles durables, de retenir la valeur économique, les compétences et les talents au sein de lUE.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: A significant proportion of software and services used in Europe rely on open source components, but their economic valorisation, governance and exploitation are often captured by non-European actors. This situation creates a structural dependence on suppliers subject to legal frameworks and interests outside the EU. Lopen source is a powerful driver of innovation, especially for SMEs, start-ups and research. Yet, the lack of structured support at European level limits the ability of European players to compete with major global platforms. A targeted European investment in lopen source would: strengthen the competitiveness of European companies, foster the emergence of sustainable industrial solutions, retain economic value, skills and talent within the EU.

feedback: La géopolitique actuelle montre qu'il faut que l'Europe soit autonome, y compris dans le domaine du numérique. De plus le code de Windows est non ouvert ! Il faut,à minima, utiliser un OS Open source dans nos institutions et idéalement définir notre propre OS pour toutes les institutions soumises à NIS2.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: Current geopolitics show the need for Europe to be autonomous, including in the digital field. In addition, the Windows code is not open! As a minimum, use an OS Open Source in our institutions and ideally define our own OS for all institutions subject to NIS2.

feedback:
La législation européenne me semble aujourdhui très en retard sur la question de la souveraineté numérique. Quelques action que jaimerais voire discuter pour la future législation: # Une augmentation des moyens alloués à la CNIL qui na aujourdhui aucun moyen dagir lorsquune infraction est signalée. Certaines entreprises sont en infraction depuis 20 ans sans que rien nai changé depuis. # Un mécanisme dindemnisation des victimes Les fuites de données et les collectes illégales sont quotidiennes. Même lorsquil y a condamnation, ce qui est rare, les victimes ne sont jamais indemnisées. Tous les opérateurs téléphoniques y sont passés, le TAJ, carrefour, le site du SNU. # Linterdiction pour les administrations publics et les secteurs sensibles (défense, médical) davoir leur système dinformation soumis à des juridictions extra-nationales Toute administration publique devrait sassurer que ses données sont sous contrôle exclusif de létat qui les mandate. Il est inacceptable que des données de police, de tribunaux, de santé, etc, soient soumises au Patriot Act ou autre loi incompatible avec la législation européenne. De fait, larticle 31 du projet de loi de financement de la sécurité sociale française serait nul et non avenu. # Une interdiction pour les entreprises de stocker les données des ressortissant européens sous juridiction extra-européenne. Si une entreprise veux vendre un produit ou un service à un client européen, il me semble normal que ce dernier continue de bénéficier de la protection offerte par la législation européenne peu importe la localisation du siège social de lentreprise. Le problème est le même que pour lindustrie ou lagriculture :pourquoi les lois qui impose des standards de qualité élevé aux entreprises européennes ne sont jamais appliquées aux produits importés ? # Linterdiction pour les employeurs de stocker les données de ses salariés sous juridiction extra-européenne ou de le forcer à utiliser des services qui le fond Le rapport de force entre employé et employeur ne permet pas aujourdhui à un employé de refuser doffrir ses données personnelles via le compte Office365 de sa boite, de refuser une réunion zoom, ou tout autre service dont il nest pas prêt à accepter les conditions de confidentialité (qui sont par ailleurs généralement illégales). Il est nécessaire de créer un cadre juridique pour ce genre de situation. # Obligation dinteropérabilité de toutes les plateformes numériques centralisées. Normalisation dun protocole standard (par exemple activity pub) permettant dassurer les communication entre les différentes plateformes numériques et donc de supprimer les effets «marchés captifs» # Mise en domaine publique des logiciel privatif non maintenus Les entreprises qui ne sont plus en étant de maintenir un logiciel quelles ont développé (faillite, manque de rentabilité, produit dappel à vocation temporaire), doivent en publier le code source et le mettre à disposition de la communauté afin de garantir le fonctionnement des services qui en dépendent (et qui ont potentiellement payé pour le logiciel en question). # Expiration de tout les brevets inexploités depuis plus dun an Le système de brevet est largement détourné pour intimider les petits acteurs et empêcher lapparition dinnovation de la part de la concurrence. Afin déviter ces phénomènes de chantage et de guerre des brevets, les brevets non exploités doivent tomber dans le domaine public. # La création dune forge logicielle européenne pour les services publics des états membres Les services publics des états membre pourraient mettre les codes sources de leurs sites web, leurs applications et autres services sur une instance forgejo (celle qui fait tourner Codeberg). De cette manière ils pourraient recevoir directement les rapports de bugs et les contributions des citoyens qui

feedback: Afin de garder notre souveraineté numérique face aux autres grandes puissances, il est fondamental que l'UE se réveille enfin, les états unis n'ont jamais été nos alliés et encore moins depuis les récents événements, il existe pourtant une multitude d'équivalence open source à quasiment tout les services propriétaires. Il faut que nous soyons indépendant face au GAFAM qui la joue de plus en plus en mode 1984 avec nos données, le RGPD n'est quasiment jamais respecté. En tant que gérant d'une micro entreprise je me tourne de plus en plus vers des solutions open source et auto hébergé ayant de plus en plus de mal avec les GAFAM et les dérives récentes de ses dernières. L'union européenne aurait dû se réveiller depuis bien longtemps sur les questions de souveraineté mais je soutiens le projet.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: In order to maintain our digital sovereignty vis-à-vis the other major powers, it is essential that the EU finally wake up, the United States has never been our allies, and even less so since recent events, there is a multitude of open source equivalence for almost all proprietary services. We must be independent of the GAFAM, which is increasingly playing it in Mode 1984 with our data. The GDPR is hardly ever respected. As a manager of a micro enterprise, I am increasingly turning to open-source and self-hosted solutions that are having more and more problems with GAFAM and the recent abuses of GAFAM. The European Union should have been waking up on sovereignty issues for a long time, but I support the project.

feedback: Dans un paysage technologique mondial marqué par des tensions géopolitiques croissantes et une concentration extrême des pouvoirs numériques, la dépendance aux solutions propriétaires fermées n'est plus seulement un risque technique : cest une vulnérabilité stratégique. Pour une institution moderne, le passage à lOpen Source (logiciel et matériel) ne relève plus du simple choix informatique, mais dun impératif de souveraineté, de sécurité et de responsabilité sociale. 1. Garantir lIndépendance et la Souveraineté Digitale Ladoption de solutions propriétaires crée un « enfermement propriétaire » (vendor lock-in) où linstitution perd le contrôle de ses coûts, de ses données et de son calendrier dévolution. Maîtrise du cycle de vie : En optant pour l'Open Source, nous nous affranchissons des décisions unilatérales des éditeurs (fin de support, modification des tarifs, changements de licence). Souveraineté des données : Le code ouvert permet de vérifier l'absence de "backdoors" et garantit que les données restent sous notre juridiction exclusive, loin des législations extraterritoriales intrusives. 2. La Sécurité par la Transparence Contrairement à l'idée reçue, l'ouverture du code est un gage de sécurité supérieure. C'est le principe de la "Loi de Linus" : « avec assez de regards, tous les bugs sont superficiels ». Audit permanent : Une communauté mondiale dexperts et de chercheurs en cybersécurité analyse, teste et durcit les solutions en continu. Réactivité : La découverte et la correction des vulnérabilités sont souvent plus rapides que dans les cycles de développement fermés, car elles ne dépendent pas de la communication de crise d'un seul fournisseur. 3. LOpen Hardware : Vers une Résilience Matérielle La dépendance ne s'arrête pas au code. L'extension du modèle Open Source au matériel (Open Source Hardware) est cruciale pour garantir la pérennité de nos infrastructures. Réparabilité et durabilité : En accédant aux plans et schémas techniques, nous luttons contre l'obsolescence programmée et facilitons la maintenance locale. Innovation inclusive : Pour les secteurs critiques, comme lautonomie et le handicap, le matériel ouvert permet de co-concevoir des outils sur mesure, adaptés aux besoins réels des utilisateurs et non aux contraintes de rentabilité de masse. 4. Une Éthique de lInnovation au Service de lIntérêt Général LOpen Source transforme la dépense technologique en investissement pour le bien commun. Plutôt que de payer des rentes de licences exportatrices de capitaux, les ressources sont réinjectées dans lécosystème local. Mutualisation des coûts : Les développements financés par linstitution profitent à tous, tout en bénéficiant en retour des améliorations apportées par dautres partenaires. Impact Social et Inclusion : En rendant la technologie accessible et modifiable, nous favorisons une informatique éthique où la performance technique se double d'une utilité sociale concrète. 5. Conclusion : Un Engagement pour l'Avenir Choisir lOpen Source, cest refuser de subir la technologie pour redevenir acteur de son destin numérique. Cest bâtir une infrastructure robuste, transparente et résiliente, capable de soutenir les ambitions de notre institution tout en protégeant les libertés fondamentales et en stimulant l'innovation de proximité.
feedbackTextUserLanguage:
In a global technological landscape marked by increasing geopolitical tensions and an extreme concentration of digital powers, reliance on closed proprietary solutions is no longer just a technical risk: this is a strategic vulnerability. For a modern institution, switching to lopen Source (software and hardware) is no longer a simple IT choice, but an imperative of sovereignty, security and social responsibility. 1. E
