feedback: Bonjour, Nous possédons aujourdhui une quantité immense de données personnelles et professionnelles, souvent hébergées ou traitées aux ÉtatsUnis. Prenons lexemple de Windows : ce système connaît une grande partie des infrastructures des entreprises. Avec des outils comme Excel ou OneDrive, il devient très simple dobtenir des informations sur le fonctionnement et la gestion des organisations françaises, européennes, etc. Pourtant, il existe des alternatives. Il faut oser Linux : un système stable, pratique, et indépendant des réseaux Microsoft, Google, et autres géants du numérique. Lutilisation de solutions libres permettrait de réaliser des économies considérables sur les licences, que ce soit pour les administrations, les institutions, les écoles ou les entreprises. Cela contribuerait également à réduire la dépendance au monopole de Windows et dApple. Nous avons linfrastructure nécessaire pour aller dans cette direction. Une grande campagne de sensibilisation aux risques liés à lutilisation de Windows ou dApple, aussi bien pour les entreprises que pour les usages personnels, serait bénéfique pour notre communauté. En réalité, 80 % des utilisateurs trouveraient largement leur compte avec des alternatives libres. Mais pour cela, il faut les accompagner, les former, leur montrer et leur apprendre. Refusons que les GAFAM sachent tout de nos activités. Adoptons une attitude plus responsable et constructive quant à ce que nous voulons pour nos vies et celles des générations futures. Apprenons à nos enfants et à nos entreprises à sortir de ce cercle devenu trop visible.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: Hello, today we have a huge amount of personal and professional data, often hosted or processed in the United States. Let’s take a look at Windows: this system has a large part of the business infrastructure. With tools such as Excel or OneDrive, it becomes very simple to gather information on the functioning and management of French, European, etc. organisations. However, there are alternatives. You have to dare Linux: a stable, convenient system that is independent of Microsoft, Google and other digital giants. The use of open solutions would lead to considerable savings on licensing, be it for administrations, institutions, schools or businesses. This would also contribute to reducing the dependence on the Windows and Apple monopoly. We have the necessary infrastructure to move in this direction. A major campaign to raise awareness of the risks associated with the use of Windows or Apple, both for businesses and for personal use, would be beneficial for our community. In fact, 80 % of users would find their accounts largely with free alternatives. But to do so, they need to be accompanied, trained, shown and taught. Let us not let GAFAM know everything we do. Take a more responsible and constructive attitude towards what we want for our lives and those of future generations. Let’s teach our children and businesses how to get out of this overly visible circle.

feedback: The continent-wide adoption of Open-Source standards is an urgent priority that will profoundly influence the security, freedom, and future of the European Union. This shift is motivated by several critical factors. First and foremost is the "elephant in the room": the increasingly adversarial stance of the United States towards the EU. Recent geopolitical shifts have made it clear that the Union is often viewed as a competitor rather than a trusted partner in critical strategic sectors. Consequently, outsourcing IT infrastructure and data management to US-based corporations is no longer a viable long-term strategy from a security or sovereignty perspective. Furthermore, the economic implications are significant. As major tech firms transition toward Software-as-a-Service (SaaS) models, the EU risks falling into a trap of "vendor lock-in." Reliance on these subscriptions makes the Union susceptible to arbitrary price increases and service limitations dictated solely by shareholder interests. Therefore, it is essential to implement a robust regulatory framework that supports the following pillars: 1. Public Infrastructure Transition: All EU-based public administrations and research entities should migrate to open-source operating systems (e.g., Linux) as soon as possible. Modern Linux distributions have overcome the usability hurdles of the past and are now easily accessible to non-technical users; therefore, this transition should be mandatory. 2. FOSS Alternatives: These same entities should shift from proprietary subscription-based software, such as Office 365, to Free and Open-Source Software (FOSS) alternatives like LibreOffice. This ensures that EU institutions and citizens retain full ownership and control of their data and documents. 3. General Public Education and Engagement: While the shift toward open source should be encouraged rather than forced upon the general population, the EU should actively promote this transition through dedicated educational materials and public dissemination initiatives. 4. AI Sovereignty: The EU must invest in its own data centerscompliant with environmental standards and local community needsto host and develop domestic AI models. By fostering and providing open-source models (such as Minerva LLM) to the general public, as well as the research community, the EU can ensure its technological independence.

The USA have made very clear through their words and actions (and the US citizens through their inactivity gave quiet approval) that the EU is an enemy of the US. Therefore, European data is not safe in the hands of US institutions and by extension in the hands of US corporations, as it may be used against us at any point. We should take this risk seriously, since US Tech corporations could easily shut down our daily live (operating systems, mobile networks, payment services, ...). In many fields, there are Open Source alternatives to US products, starting with Linux, Open Source office suites and file formats, and Open Source cloud solutions. Using these should be standard in all public institutions in the EU and would hopefully encourage the private sector to follow their example for better interoperability. Currently the dependence on docx and other proprietary file formats practically forces us to use Microsoft Office products and therefore Microsoft Windows or MacOS from Apple. Furthermore European tax payers' money should primarily profit European citizens and economy. There is a gigantic potential for synergies and cost savings within the EU. The logical consequence regarding software (and data) should be - utilization and financing of the development of Open Source operating systems and software (especially office suites) - creation of a widely available and more attractive European alternative to VISA/Mastercard/paypal - financing of an alternative to Android (which Google keeps closing down), iOS and their app-stores - allowing and encouraging custom ROMs on mobile phones. Banking applications not working or potentially breaking on custom ROMs is a major problem for the growth of alternative mobile OSes - no data of EU citizens (not even criminal ones) should be passed to the US or other states, even if this means the end of ESTA. Our sovereignty should be worth more than some convenience while traveling

LUnion européenne se trouve à un moment décisif de son histoire technologique. Pour garantir sa souveraineté numérique, la protection des données de ses citoyens et sa sécurité stratégique, lEurope doit faire de lintelligence artificielle open-source un axe central de sa politique industrielle et scientifique. Dabord, lopen-source est un levier fondamental de souveraineté. En maîtrisant le code, les modèles et les infrastructures, lEurope réduit sa dépendance vis-à-vis dacteurs extra-européens et retrouve une capacité de décision autonome sur des technologies devenues critiques. Ensuite, lopen-source est un gage de confiance et de protection des données. La transparence du code permet des audits indépendants, facilite la conformité avec le RGPD et garantit que les données sensibles publiques, industrielles ou personnelles ne soient pas captives de systèmes opaques ou hébergés hors du cadre juridique européen. Sur le plan de la sécurité, des modèles ouverts et audités collectivement sont souvent plus robustes. Ils permettent une détection plus rapide des failles, une correction distribuée et une meilleure résilience face aux usages malveillants, contrairement aux systèmes fermés dont les vulnérabilités restent invisibles. Enfin, lopen-source est un moteur puissant pour la recherche et le développement. Il favorise la collaboration entre universités, centres de recherche, startups et industriels, accélère linnovation, réduit les barrières à lentrée et permet à lécosystème européen de rivaliser à léchelle mondiale. Investir massivement dans lIA open-source, cest donc investir dans une Europe plus indépendante, plus sûre, plus innovante et fidèle à ses valeurs démocratiques. Cest transformer lexcellence scientifique européenne en leadership technologique durable.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: The European Union is at a defining moment in its technological history. To guarantee its digital sovereignty, the protection of its citizens’ data and its strategic security, Europe must make open-source artificial intelligence a central pillar of its industrial and scientific policy. First of all, lopen-source is a fundamental lever of sovereignty. By mastering the code, models and infrastructure, Europe is reducing its dependence on non-European actors and regaining an autonomous decision-making capacity on technologies that have become critical. Secondly, lopen-source is a guarantee of trust and data protection. The transparency of the Code allows for independent audits, facilitates compliance with the GDPR and ensures that sensitive public, industrial or personal data are not captured from opaque systems or hosted outside the European legal framework. In terms of security, collectively open and audited models are often more robust. They allow for faster detection of vulnerabilities, distributed remediation and greater resilience against malicious use, unlike closed systems whose vulnerabilities remain invisible. Finally, lopen-source is a powerful engine for research and development. It fosters collaboration between universities, research centres, start-ups and industry, accelerates innovation, reduces barriers to entry and allows the European ecosystem to compete globally. Investing massively in open-source AI means investing in a Europe that is more independent, secure, innovative and true to its democratic values. This translates European science into sustainable technological leadership.

feedback: Depuis l'élection de Donal Trump, nous avons un besoin fort de renforcement de notre indépendance numérique, les Etats-Unis ayant un trop fort pouvoir de dissuasion envers nous. Il est donc primordial de nous renforcer numériquement. Nous avons déjà de bons outils, de bonnes bases sur lesquelles avancer. Nous pouvons nous démarquer des autres régions du monde en insistant sur les outils open source. Pourquoi cela ? Les outils open source peuvent être audités. Quand un outil est propriétaire, nous ne savons pas ce qu'elle fait en fond. Par exemple, Apple se targue d'être un protecteur de la vie privée, mais il est impossible de réellement le savoir. Un outil open source lui le permet. De plus, les outils les plus réputés en matière de protection de la confidentialité des utilisateurs sont open source. Cela permet aussi de créer des communautés, qui peuvent à tout moment remonter des erreurs, et faire améliorer les produits, les sécuriser, et d'avoir des outils toujours plus compétitifs. Cela nous permettrait aussi d'avoir des talents nous permettant d'être plus forts. Ayons des outils européens, dont chacun pourra s'assurer de la fiabilité, de la sécurité, et du respect de la vie privée des utilisateurs.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: Since the election of Donal Trump, we have a strong need to strengthen our digital independence, as the United States has too strong a deterrent power towards us. It is therefore crucial to strengthen us digitally. We already have good tools, good foundations on which to move forward. We can stand out from other parts of the world by focusing on open source tools. Why this? Open source tools can be audited. When a tool is owned, we do not know what it does in substance. For example, Apple boasts to be a privacy protector, but it is impossible to really know it. An open source tool allows it to do so. In addition, the most reputable tools for protecting users’ confidentiality are open source. It also makes it possible to create communities, which can at any time make mistakes, improve products, secure them, and have ever more competitive tools. It would also allow us to have the talent to be stronger. Let’s have European tools, each of which will be able to ensure the reliability, security and privacy of users.

feedback: Il est indispensable que l'Europe insufle un tournant vers l'Open Source. Au niveau des OS. Interdire le pré-équipement d'un ordinateur avec un OS mais que ce soit une option chiffrée. Au niveau des documents : utilisation de la recommandation T.413 de l'union internationale des télécommunications (ITU), «Architecture ouverte des documents (ODA) et format ouvert d'échange des documents (ODIF)» et sa déclinaison dans Libre Office. Au niveau des applications : renforcer l'utilisation des alternatives libres pour les applications usuelles. Au niveau de l'enseignement : proscrire, sauf formation technique, les logiciels propriétaires.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: It is essential for Europe to make a turning point towards Open Source. At AOS level. Prohibit the pre-fitting of a computer with an OS, but this is a numerical option. At document level: use of Recommendation T.413 of the International Telecommunication Union (ITU), ‘Open Document Architecture (ODA) and Open Document Exchange Format (ODIF)’ and its implementation in the Free Office. At application level: strengthen the use of free alternatives for standard applications. At the educational level: ban proprietary software, except for technical training.

feedbackTextUserLanguage: It is essential to oblige European and Member State administrations to use free logics to 1/s ensure better control of our 2/susciter data an ecosystem and virtuous dynamic driven by European 3/se actors to protect against foreign interference in our European and national affairs.

feedback: European Research and Innovation funding should step away from funding based on competitive projects and, instead, fund sustainable research networks (see attached proposal). This would support open source software development that (partly) relies on Horizon Europe funding. Now, often, this funding supports projects that lead to unsustainable results and open source initiatives that have no follow-up, attached to precarious careers. Continuity funding, the funding of sustainable research networks, would counter this. In a nutshell, continuity funding would be funding for R&I networks that does not expire in principle but that can still be policy-driven (e.g., renewal of networks could be halted while not affecting the careers of its participants, to make room for new thematic networks). Network renewal happens primarily through career progression of the participants: once a participant progresses to a permanent contract, room is freed up for a new participant. This career progression is incentivized by means of a reserve fund, which is part of the grant, which can only be accessed by institutions once participants progress in their career towards permanent contracts. The major advantage of this type of funding for European Open Digital Ecosystems is that it would support the R&I ecosystem such that open source innovation streams become much more sustainable. A continuity funding funded network could sustain an open source project for as long as needed. Apart from this, there are additional benefits for European funding as this scheme would combat precarious labour (even acting as an incentive to reform national R&I funding), and have much lower costs for proposal writing and review because all networks are funded through one-off competitions without needing to re-apply for funding.

The public image of open source used to be "geeky", even rebellious. A bunch of IT "Robin Hood" who competed with the big tech companies by releasing free software. It clearly wasn't aiming at the common consumer but at power users that enjoyed combatting bugs and limited feature sets. That image changed into a consumer trap. You can get a free basic software version without any quality guarantees or support, and once you are hooked the hidden costs surface for service, or for buying slightly advanced features, until support for the software stops for one reason or another. When a consumer buys into Microsoft (as one example), everything is included for a very reasonable price: Operating System, office suite, cloud storage, and there is a whole eco-system of reputable companies that bring well functioning products/services to the market from media players to photo/ video editing software that fairly seamlessly integrate on the platform. When a consumer tries to go towards open source (the European "solution"?) he/she has to choose between 11 (?) distributions of Linux, 8 (?) office suites(some very poor), a bunch of other open source products that may or may not function on a given linux distribution, or are not interoperable with other packages, all without any long term guarantees. In addition, expensive peripherals (printer, scanner, ...) can remain unsupported (no drivers) in a given linux set-up. This is the kind of jungle the common consumer, for whom the computer is nothing but a tool, has no interest in. Besides, also large organisations that turn towards open source seem to struggle. Europe needs at least one (but not more than 3) for profit entities. I emphasise "for profit" to ensure that the entities remain largely independent from EU public funding and must keep an eye on innovation and competitiveness. Those should build a new software eco-system: - A selection of the best possible combination of linux based tools (OS, office, ). It all exists, but has to be brought together. - One "installer (by lack of a better name) that automates the process of installing a European Linux distribution, office suite, whatever needed that meet European legal and quality criteria. -- The user selects the modules he/she needs and the installer downloads and installs -- The installer warns the user of new developments, bug fixes, features and lets the user decide whether to upgrade - A feedback system that creates priorities for further development/ bug fixing of those tools - Builds a roadmap to - better integrate/ ensure interoperability between the various parts of the distribution - Selects or if needed, develops standards for further developments. - provide documentation to software developers on how to integrate their software - This entity could act as an intermediate between the home end user and the various linux/ open source communities. It has to go on the market, make publicity (one problem with open source is that people ate not aware it exists, and what it can do) - It should use the linux/ open source communities/companies to develop additions/modules for integration in the distribution (paid or at least supported by the profits it generated) - It should operate from a clear vision and ensure that applicable EU law is at its core and work with e.g; eID for user identification , SOLID for private data storage and if it is an unthinkable success: bring EU Linux phones, tablets, PC, servers, cloud to the market The entity should also reach out to banks (an app in the distribution that logs into a bank), on-line retailers (bol.com) for managing sales, governments (fill in your taxes), social security For the end user, using such EU eco-system should be as hassle free as using one of the current corporate slutions, with the benefits of respecting EU user protection.

EU's reliance on non-European technology suppliers should stop. Stop using GAFAM services, stop using Windows/Android and use Linux/LineageOS for e.g instead and fund European FOSS. USA has windows, macos, android, ios... the chinese have HarmonyOS and are building their own computer operating system while we do nothing and rely on both. The result is that european companies cannot compete with US ones. For example, Sennheiser an old audio manufacturer from Germany is slowing dying because it cannot compete with Apple/Airpods simply because Apple is preventing any competitor to do fast pair and therefore degrading a lot the user experience for non apple headphone consumer, capturing more than 70% of the market on earbuds. Another example is that app dev needs to pay a annual fee to distribute iOS/macos apps and on top of that Apple is taking a cut on any purchase made in-app, despite EU effort to change that, it's still not possible to put a simple donation button in open source app. There are a ton of anti-competitive and greedy examples in the software industry and EU should act on it before it's too late.

dans les temps troublés qui nous attendent , il est tout simplement suicidaire de laisser la gestion de nos données, vies, finances, et applications à des entités extérieures à l'Europe. Il est devient urgent que le concept de souvaineté deviennent une réalité
feedbackTextUserLanguage: in the turbulent times ahead of us, it is simply suicidal to leave the management of our data, lives, finances, and applications to entities outside Europe. There is an urgent need for the concept of souvaineté to become a reality

feedback: Je suis un professionnel du numérique qui utilise et déploie de l'open source à titre personnel et professionnel. Pour moi nous devrions raisonner "open source first" : système d'exploitation, logiciel de bureautique, infrastructure réseau. Plusieurs bénéfices : - limitation de la dépendance aux éditeurs - soutien des développeur open source et de la communauté - liberté de changement - liberté de développer des fonctionnalités supplémentaires - facilité d'audit du code : meilleure sécurisation Cela facilitera également lémergence de nouveaux logiciels. On a un besoin d'investissements massifs dans l'open source qui est fondamentale pour notre liberté numérique
feedbackTextUserLanguage: I am a digital professional who uses and deploys open source in a personal and professional capacity. For me, we should think “open source first”: operating system, office software, network infrastructure. Several benefits: — limitation of dependency on publishers – support from open source developers and the community – freedom of change – freedom to develop additional functionalities – ease of auditing the code: better security This will also facilitate the emergence of new software. We need massive investment in open source, which is fundamental to our digital freedom

feedback: La population ne devait pas avoir à utiliser les services d'un gafam ou d'une méga entreprise. Les services devraient être décentralisés, et on peut choisir son prestataire. L'Europe devrait reposé sur un écosystème ouvert et compatible même aux petits acteurs qui peuvent avoir des capacités de développement bien plus intéressantes que les grosses entreprises.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: People should not have to use the services of a GAFAM or a mega company. The services should be decentralised and its provider can be chosen. Europe should be based on an open and compatible ecosystem even for smaller players who can have much better development capabilities than larger companies.

feedback: I am the author of The Ethical Resolution Method (ERM): A Procedural Framework for Evaluating and Stabilizing Moral Norms in Sociotechnical and AI Systems I know the EU is looking for open source, soverign systems that solve the problem of AI alignment and I just happen to have authored one. My CV is in your system EX2026D1335528 if anyone would like to reach out.

Je pense que l'UE doit garder ses données sur son territoire sans les donner aux États-Unis. Cela permet aussi avec des logiciels libres de limiter les dépenses inutiles vers des services étrangers. Il est toutefois nécessaire de continuer à encourager les développements open-source avec des dons vers ces bénévoles.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: I think the EU should keep its data on its territory without giving it to the US. This also makes it possible, with open source software, to limit unnecessary expenditure on foreign services. However, it is necessary to continue to encourage open-source developments with donations to these volunteers.

feedback: Hi, As an EU citizen, I would like to express my strong support for any initiative aimed at reducing, and where possible eliminating, the European Unions dependency on proprietary software provided by large non-European technology corporations. Repeatedly, companies such as Microsoft and other GAFAM actors have demonstrated practices that raise serious concerns, including opaque data handling, transfers of European data outside the EU, forced upgrade cycles, recurring subscription price increases, and artificial hardware obsolescence. These practices persist despite existing regulations and directly undermine user autonomy, public budget sustainability, and European digital sovereignty. At a time when data confidentiality is critical for the protection of European citizens, public administrations, and critical infrastructure, and when several EU member states are facing severe budgetary constraints, continued reliance on costly proprietary solutions is neither economically nor strategically justifiable. Proprietary software from foreign vendors should, at a minimum, be excluded from critical infrastructure and public sector use. Given the repeated disregard for European legal frameworks and sanctions, as well as recent hostile economic measures taken by the United States against European interests, the European Union would be justified in considering proportionate economic countermeasures, similar in scope to those previously applied in other strategic technology sectors, such as telecommunications. Open-source software now provides viable, user-friendly, transparent, and resilient alternatives. It allows public institutions and citizens alike to verify what is done with their data and, more importantly, what is not. Beyond transparency, open-source solutions strengthen local ecosystems, reduce long-term costs, and reinforce European technological independence. For these reasons, it is clear to me that any reduction in our dependency on proprietary software is a strategic investment in Europes security, economy, and democratic values. It is necessary, and it is sound. Kind regards,

Bonjour, Je ne suis ni juriste, ni lobbyiste, mais un professionnel du numérique qui utilise et déploie de lopen source à titre personnel dans mon infrastructure domestique ( à défaut de pouvoir le faire au bureau). Je ne me sens pas qualifié pour répondre aux questions purement politiques ou macro-économiques de cette consultation, mais je tenais à déposer ce message pour une raison simple : votre initiative va dans le bon sens et nous en avons cruellement besoin. À mon échelle, en tant quutilisateur engagé (et non dans un cadre professionnel), je constate chaque jour la difficulté de saffranchir des GAFAM et des acteurs extra-européens, faute dalternatives réellement crédibles, maintenues et documentées. Pousser des alternatives européennes open source ou non face aux géants américains et proposer de vrais outils en face : je suis infiniment pour. Mais soyons clairs : cela ne se fera pas avec des demi-mesures. Il faudra investir massivement, sur le long terme, et pas uniquement dans la R&D : maintenance, sécurité, UX, documentation, interopérabilité, et adoption terrain. Mon message est donc pragmatique : si lEurope propose des solutions solides, souveraines et viables, je suis prêt à suivre.Je mengage, à mon niveau, à : 1. Tester et adopter les solutions open source européennes mises en avant ou soutenues par cette stratégie dans mon infrastructure personnelle. 2. Contribuer techniquement (rapports de bugs, documentation, retours dexpérience) sur les briques logicielles qui émergent. 3. Privilégier systématiquement ces alternatives dans mes choix personnels lorsque la maturité technique est au rendez-vous. Ne lâchez rien sur lexigence de qualité et de sécurité. Si lécosystème est robuste, la communauté technique suivra naturellement. Mais noubliez pas : les bonnes intentions ne suffisent pas, il faut des moyens à la hauteur. Cordialement, Un citoyen numérique engagé.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: Hello, I am not a lawyer or lobbyist, but a digital professional who uses and deploys source lopen personally in my home infrastructure (if not able to do so in the office). I do not feel qualified to answer the purely political or macroeconomic questions of this consultation, but I wanted to deliver this message for a simple reason: your initiative is a step in the right direction and we badly need it. At my level, as a committed user (and not in a professional context), I see every day the difficulty of cutting off GAFAM and non-European actors, in the absence of genuinely credible alternatives that are maintained and documented. Pushing open source or non-open source European alternatives to American giants and offering real tools in front of them: I am infinitely in favour. But let’s be clear: this will not be done with half measurements. Massive long-term investment is needed, not just in R & D: maintenance, security, UX, documentation, interoperability, and field adoption. My message is therefore pragmatic: if Europe offers robust, sovereign and viable solutions, I am ready to follow. I commit, at my level, to: 1. Test and adopt the European open source solutions promoted or supported by this strategy in my personal infrastructure. 2. Contribute technically (bug reports, documentation, feedback) to emerging software bricks. 3. Systematically prioritise these alternatives in my personal choices when technical maturity is up to date. Do not release anything about quality and safety. If the ecosystem is robust, the technical community will naturally follow. But don't forge: good intentions are not enough, resources are needed. Kind regards, A committed digital citizen.

feedback: Bonjour, Il est absolument indispensable que l'Europe assure sa Souveraineté numérique en utilisant les ressources à sa disposition dans l'Union Européenne, car c'est un enjeu stratégique majeur. Il n'est pas acceptable que la plus grande part de notre infrastructure numérique soit détenue par des sociétés hébergées hors de L'Union et qui, de ce fait, ne dépendent pas ou peu des Lois qui régissent l'Europe ou qui sont soumises à leur propre législation, incompatible avec celle de l'Union Européenne (Ex : "Patriot Act" des USA). Nous avons les ressources nécessaire, tant humaines que techniques, à notre disposition et il est urgent de mettre en place des structures fiables et sécurisées pour garantir notre indépendance. La seule et unique solution doit s'appuyer sur les ressources logicielles Libre, afin que chaque partie puisse être auditée, vérifiée et garantie par nos instances compétentes et s'assurer ainsi qu'aucun élément malveillant ne soit introduit à notre insu dans nos infrastructures souveraines. Cordialement,
feedbackTextUserLanguage: Hello, it is absolutely essential for Europe to ensure its digital sovereignty by using the resources at its disposal in the European Union, as this is a major strategic issue. It is not acceptable for the largest share of our digital infrastructure to be owned by companies hosted outside the Union and which, as a result, do not depend, or only to a limited extent, on the laws governing Europe or which are subject to their own legislation, which is incompatible with that of the European Union (e.g. US Patriot Act). We have the necessary resources, both human and technical, at our disposal and there is an urgent need for reliable and secure structures to ensure our independence. The only solution must be based on Free software resources, so that each party can be audited, verified and guaranteed by our competent bodies and thus ensure that no malicious element is unknowingly introduced into our sovereign infrastructure. Kind regards,

feedback: Je salue très positivement linitiative de la Commission européenne visant à définir une stratégie pour des écosystèmes numériques ouverts européens et à renforcer le rôle des logiciels libres et des ressources numériques ouvertes. Cette démarche va clairement dans le bon sens et répond à des enjeux devenus critiques pour lUnion européenne. Il est aujourdhui largement établi que limmense majorité de léconomie numérique repose sur des briques logicielles open source. Pourtant, la valeur stratégique, économique et industrielle créée à partir de ces briques est encore trop souvent captée par des acteurs extra-européens. Cette situation crée une dépendance structurelle, expose lUE à des risques sur la chaîne dapprovisionnement logicielle et affaiblit sa souveraineté technologique. À ce titre, reconnaître explicitement les logiciels libres comme une composante essentielle de la souveraineté, de la sécurité et de la compétitivité européennes est une étape indispensable même si beaucoup dacteurs du numérique auraient souhaité voir cette prise de conscience émerger plus tôt. Mieux vaut cependant agir maintenant que jamais. LUnion européenne dispose dun vivier exceptionnel de développeurs, dingénieurs, de chercheurs et dentreprises capables de concevoir, maintenir et sécuriser des solutions open source de premier plan. Le défi nest donc pas technique, mais stratégique et organisationnel : il sagit de créer les conditions pour que ces compétences puissent sinscrire dans des écosystèmes durables, visibles et soutenus à léchelle européenne. Enfin, cette stratégie représente une opportunité majeure pour renforcer la résilience numérique de lUE, réduire les effets de verrouillage propriétaire et garantir que les données, les infrastructures et les logiciels critiques restent sous un contrôle conforme aux valeurs européennes. Je soutiens pleinement cette initiative et encourage la Commission à en faire un pilier structurant et durable de la politique numérique européenne, avec des objectifs concrets, des moyens dédiés et une vision de long terme.
feedbackTextUserLanguage:
I very much welcome the European Commission’s initiative to define a strategy for European open digital ecosystems and to strengthen the role of open source software and open digital resources. This is clearly a step in the right direction and responds to challenges that have become critical for the European Union. It is now widely established that the majority of the digital economy is based on open-source software bricks. Yet the strategic, economic and industrial value created from these bricks is still too often captured by non-European actors. This situation creates structural dependence, exposes the EU to risks in the software supply chain and weakens its technological sovereignty. As such, explicitly recognising open source software as an essential component of European sovereignty, security and competitiveness is an indispensable step, although many digital players would have liked to see this awareness emerge earlier. But it is better to act now than ever. The European Union has an exceptional pool of developers, engineers, researchers and businesses able to design, maintain and secure leading open source solutions. The challenge is therefore not technical, but strategic and organisational: the aim is to create the conditions for these skills to be embedded in sustainable, visible and supported ecosystems at European level. Finally, this strategy represents a major opportunity to strengthen the EU’s digital resilience, reduce proprietary lock-in effects and ensure that critical data, infrastructure and software remain under control in line with European values. I fully support this initiative and encourage the Commission to make it a structuring and sustainable pi

feedback:
I give my feedback as a software engineer with 25+ years of experience who works on developing open source software for CERN. The main barriers that hamper widespread open source adoption are monopolistic practices of Big Tech companies, including: 1. Lack of interoperability A prime example is Facebook Messenger which, when it launched in 2010, was made interoperable with XMPP, the most popular messaging protocol at the time. This allowed Facebook to capture the messaging market. Having succeeded in this, Facebook removed its interoperability features in 2015 (the same year that it acquired WhatsApp). This move locked in users already on Messenger and forced remaining users to migrate to a Facebook platform or be cut off from all their contacts. Now that Meta has been designated a gatekeeper under DMA, the company is required to make both Messenger and WhatsApp interoperable. But the company has dragged its heels, complaining that compliance with the law is technically difficult, despite showing in the past its ability to achieve interoperability when it suited its goal of capturing the market. The argument is particularly specious given that WhatsApp is based on XMPP at its core. WhatsApp remains a closed ecosystem only because Meta wants it that way. Enforcing the DMA interoperability requirement would put an end to Meta's role as gatekeeper, allowing users to migrate away from WhatsApp and permitting an ecosystem of alternative messaging software to flourish. I refer the Commission to the XMPP technical briefing on this subject which contains detailed recommendations: https://xmpp.org/announcements/open-letter-meta-dma/technical-briefing/ 2. Anti-circumvention laws The USA introduced anti-circumvention laws in Section 1201 of the Digital Millennium Copyright Act 1998. Similar provisions were foisted on Europe in Article 6 of the European Copyright Directive 2001/29/EC. These laws make it a crime to reverse engineer software designed to protect "copyrighted works". The intention was probably to protect music and videos, but in practice "copyrighted works" includes software designed to restrict or remove user choice. For example, a printer manufacturer adds an anti-feature to its printers so you can only use their ink. It is not a crime to sell a 3rd party ink cartridge, but it is a crime to reverse engineer the software lock so the 3rd party cartridge works with the printer. The same mechanism is used by coffee machine companies to restrict which coffee pods you can use up to parts for cars, tractors, trains or aeroplanes. In every case the only purpose of the software is to reduce consumer choice and create a monopoly. Today, Apple is using Article 6 in Europe's courts to shut down European companies that defend European merchants, performers, makers, news outlets, game devs and creative workers, from Apple's app store monopoly by jailbreaking phones. The EU should immediately repeal Article 6. This would create a vibrant economy of open source software that gets around monopolistic anti-features in all devices that contain them (which today means almost everything). 3. Alternative app stores for Android and Apple devices In Europe, there is a flourishing market of alternate app stores for Android, including F-Droid and the /e/OS app store for Murena phones. Apple does not currently allow third party app stores on its phones. Google and Apple have both taken measures to restrict which software can be installed on their phones. Right now, Google is taking measures to shut down the third party app stores available for Android. This monopolistic behaviour is justified as "user security" while in reality it is purely to maintain Apple and Google's positions as gatekeepers. The EU must robustly enforce the requirement that all phone operating systems must allow third-party app stores. This more than any other measure will ensure a large market of

feedback: You state that EU-funded projects are "exploited outside the EU, often benefiting tech giants". AVOIDING permissive licenses (MIT, BSD etc.) in favor of copyleft ones (GPL, AGPL), and prosecuting companies who knowingly violate the licenses, is the only way to prevent this. This goes beyond what's publicly funded: A lot of vital infrastructure is developed by volunteers, without money or resources to enforce their own licenses. Ideally, the EU should assist European developers with this.

Wir brauchen für alle öffentlichen Einrichtungen Software, die nicht einfach abgeschaltet werden kann, open source ist, und die Daten zuverlässig innerhalb der EU speichert und verwaltet. Wir sind zu sehr abhängig von Microsoft, Palantir, Apple, Google. Auch wenn versichert wird, dass diese Abhängigkeit nicht missbraucht werden wird: keine der US-amerikanischen oder internationalen Firmen kann garantieren, dass sie nicht gezwungen werden abzuschalten oder die Daten zu missbrauchen oder für einen nicht vereinbarten Zweck zu nutzen. Wir müssen digital unabhängig werden. Es ist ein langer Weg dorthin. Aber irgendwie müssen wir uns auf diesen Weg machen. Keine neuen Verträge mit den Tech-Giganten der USA ist ein Anfang. Alle laufenden Verträge unter detailorientierten Prüfung. Gleichzeitig recherchieren, was schon heute ersetzt werden kann. Und bitte ein allererster Schritt heraus aus der aktuellen Misere mit Grok: Endlich X abschalten. Alles dort dient nur der Profitgenerierung und Beeinflussung durch Hass und Hetze. Vielen Dank für die Möglichkeit, dass wir EU-Bürger*innen unsere Meinung hier abgeben können. Liebe Grüße aus München
feedbackTextUserLanguage: We need software for all public institutions that cannot be easily switched off, that is open source, and that stores and manages the data reliably within the EU. We are too dependent on Microsoft, Palantir, Apple, Google. While reassuring that this dependency will not be abused: none of the US or international companies can guarantee that they will not be forced to shut down or abuse the data or use it for an unagreed purpose. We need to become digitally independent. It is a long way to go. But somehow we need to embark on this path. No new contracts with the US tech giants is a start. All ongoing contracts under detailed examination. At the same time, research what can already be replaced today. And please take a first step out of the current misery with coarseness: Finally turn off X. All of this is only for the purpose of generating profit and being influenced by hate speech and hate speech. Thank you for the opportunity to give our opinion here to EU citizens. Best wishes from Munich

feedback: EU Leaders, I wish to resonate just how important Open Source works are in general, but to us, the citizens of the EU especially in times like these. Having our infrastructure be Open Sourced *AND* on a legally permissive license, would foster innovation beyond belief. There's millions of hobbyist programmers, coders, and tinkerers who could change the face of consumer devices permanently if our things were openly accessible. The openness of computing is effectively the democratisation of technology, and i can hardly think of anything that is more central to our countries. In addition, if Our software ran on Open Source software licensed under permissive licenses, we could literally cut ourselves free of american computing in thousands of ways we most likely cant even imagine until we give individual citizens the power to build our systems piece by piece, over time. My views are that of someone who may not be able to code himself but i am very active in these hobbyist spheres of Electrical/IT related tinkering, and repairing broken devices, and there's a lot of people chomping at the bit to just get some legislative push! I beseech you to push this through!

El uso del codigo abierto es algo muy importante hoy dia, en mi opinion los diferentes gobiernos deberian apoyar mas al codigo abierto y en lo posible, tratar de reemplazar los servicios cerrados de las grandes empresas. El codigo abierto es algo muy seguro, transparente y mejorable. Llevo usando software libre desde hace mucho y realmente estoy mas que satisfecho. En mis dispositivos de hecho ya no cuento con sistemas operaticos cerrados, ni aplicaciones de codigo cerrado, seria muy bueno ver que Europa impulse sistemas operativos basados en el kernel Linux.

In my de facto devices I no longer have closed operating systems, or closed code applications, it would be very good to see Europe pushing for operating systems based on Linux kernel.

feedback:
It is imperative that Windows is banned across public administration and education systems within the EU and Linux is used instead. The fact that America is now antagonistic towards the EU yet also holds the largest monopoly on operating systems used across the planet, both inside and outside the EU, is a major security risk that needs to be rectified as soon as possible. Linux has come a long way over the years and is now a perfectly viable alternative for all purposes. In many cases, it's an even better alternative as many distros have the same or similar ease of use as Windows products but with all the garbage, bloat, AI slop, and spyware mixed in. Take inspiration from GendBuntu. There should also be EU-provided incentives for businesses to switch over as well. This next part is not feedback I wrote myself, it was taken from another user but I echo the sentiment of it: This is important! Get the EU back on reverse engineering, right to repair - the US muscled the EU into adopting Article 6 of the EU Copyright Directive, preventing reverse engineering in return for free trade. By implementing tariffs, the US broke that agreement. Theres no reason not to delete Article 6 of the EUCD, and all the other laws that prevent European companies from jailbreaking iPhones and making their own App Stores (minus Apples 30% commission), as well as ad-blockers for Facebook and Instagrams apps (which would zero out EU revenue for Meta), and, of course, jailbreaking tools for Xboxes, Teslas, and every make and model of every American car, so European companies could offer service, parts, apps, and add-ons for them. Regarding social media, there needs to be an initiative by the EU to properly promote official EU accounts on open source alternatives such as Mastodon and the Fediverse. We live in the modern world where information is power, and the EU needs to start taking this seriously. Toxic foreign social media such as X (formerly Twitter), Facebook, and Tiktok have allowed people to construct for themselves alternate realities where they get to decide what is and isn't true and what events did or didn't happen. They have weaponized information to promote and assert these alternative realities in order to radicalize, sensationalize, and propagandize the world population. They force bots and paid shills pushing disinformation and aggressive narratives all over people's feeds while forcing them to have to go out of their way to find the truth or even just normal mundane discussions that aren't constantly political. People are tired and frustrated, but they don't even know about the alternatives available for them. They don't know that there's an entire open world ecosystem of social media that properly moderates disinformation. If EU official accounts and politicians are still willing to deliver messages on these platforms that now also represent a real security risk, then they should be willing to show people the way to proper open-source alternatives. I know its weird to see an American of all people comment on this initiative, but as far as I know, the EU has been helping me my whole life, even if indirectly. The EU has stuck up for proper consumer rights and regulations where no other governmental body would. Would my data be as secure as it is if the EU didn't fight for GDPR? Would the food in my country have even lower standards (lower than they already are) if they didn't also have to do trade with the EU and be forced to meet their much higher standards? Would Apple products still have USB-C without the EU? Stop Killing Games isn't law yet, but would there even be a chance with it to exist without the EU? The answer to all these questions is no. To me the EU is a body which has fought for the average consumer and well and truly represented freedom and democracy. I'm ashamed of what my country has been doing, of how they've been threatening our allies and tr

feedback: A full stack of EU support and coordination is needed, starting from silicon companies (e.g., by encouraging or mandating the use of the RISC-V architecture) and extending to product manufacturers, such as smartphone makers, as well as cloud and email providers. This level of coordination is essential to create a smartphone that functions without Google services while offering the same features. To make this ecosystem viable, it is mandatory to require companies like Google and Meta to make their services interoperable with others via APIs. This would allow for genuine competition in areas like cloud storage, providing consumers with a real choice and breaking current monopolies (for example, Google Photos, which currently dominates photo backup without significant competition).

Ci serve in primis un'alternativa a GitHub dove poter tenere in modo sicuro il codice. Ci vogliono poi forme di finanziamento per gli sviluppatori. Ad oggi se uno sviluppatore volesse creare un framewoek, una libreria o qualsiasi pezzo di codice open source il problema sarebbe il finanziamento di esso. Il modello più comune sarebbe ricevere micro donazioni ma una gran parte andrebbe via in tasse il resto mangiato dai circuiti come paypal. Altro modello sarebbe avere pubblicità sulla pagina di documentazione o la vendita del corso per usare il framework ma anche qui si configurerebbe un'azienda con tutti i suoi oneri e non compatibile con il lavoro dipendente specialmente in italia.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: We need first and foremost an alternative to GitHub where we can safely keep the code. There is also a need for funding for developers. To date, if a developer wanted to create a framewoek, bookshop or any piece of open source code, the problem would be its funding. The most common model would be to receive micro-donations, but a large part would go through taxes the rest eaten by the circuits as paypal. Another model would be to advertise on the documentation page or to sell the course to use the framework, but here too there would be a company with all its costs and not compatible with employment, especially in Italy.

feedback: We have to become really independent and make sure 100% of all public data and critical infrastruture as well as most of media (including social media) is open sourced. We do not know how american corporation's alorithms work - we need to have clarity why some people see one info while others see something totally different. Only way is to use fediverse (open source social media).

Open-source is of paramount importance for managing costs, freedom from major foreign companies and countries, freedom from being spied or having one's data collected. For country/european structures, it ensures to stay sovereign and free from american influence.

Etre souverain, en matière de systèmes d'information, à mon sens implique la maîtrise des briques de ces systèmes, pour un population de professionnels standards et pas seulement des experts. C'est pourquoi je pense qu'il ne faut pas chercher à atteindre la souveraineté sur des systèmes aussi complexes que les clouds (d'OpenStack à Kubernetes), mais sur des systèmes d'information basés sur des technologies moins complexes (virtualisation, stockage logiciel). Pour donner un exemple concret soutenir des initiatives comme Proxmox qui peuvent être mises en oeuvre par de très nombreuses entités, plutôt que de pousser à l'utilisation d'opérateurs clouds. Ce type d'infrastructure est suffisante pour de très nombreux cas d'usage.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: Being sovereign, in terms of information systems, means, in my view, mastering the bricks of those systems, for a population of standard professionals and not just experts. That is why I think we should not seek to achieve sovereignty over systems as complex as clouds (from OpenStack to Kubernetes), but over information systems based on less complex technologies (virtualisation, software storage). To give a concrete example of supporting initiatives such as Proxmox that can be implemented by a very large number of entities, rather than pushing for the use of cloud operators. This type of infrastructure is sufficient for a very large number of use cases.

feedback: To build European open digital ecosystems EU must repeal Article 6 of the Copyright Directive and allow for reverse-engineering and adversarial interoperability. And then EU must help to build European open mobile ecosystem - European mobile operating systems and applications for it. I of course mean - promote SailfishOS!

We view the work of NLnet Foundation as absolutely critical for the EU digital sovereignty. Without the Foundation support, we would not have been in the position to form a technology startup in Sarajevo, Bosnia-Herzegovina, through which the young and talented engineers get to work on the top-notch FPGA projects, developing applications for Cryptography, DSP, AI, RISC-V Embedded, using High Level Synthesis and open-source tools ecosystem. The EU is in a dire need of robust and flexible startup incubator programs. The NLnet role in that regard is indispensable. Can it be enlarged, strengthened and driven to the higher level?!
Its very important to begin to become more indipendent in the IT sector, we are giving away our independence to possible future enemies or bad states.

The European Union already hosts a large open-source talent pool with many public GitHub commits coming from EU accounts. Our companies and universities support well-known projects such as KDE Plasma, KVM, OpenNebula, Nextcloud, OnlyOffice, Collabora, ProtonMail, OpenStack and the reference RISC-V emulator. This ecosystem is healthy, innovative and a proven source of technological sovereignty.

Yet the money does not follow the code. EU institutions and national governments still spend billions per year on proprietary licences, even when open-source alternatives exist. The Dutch tax offices recent 250M Microsoft-cloud deal is only the latest example. Procurement officers cite the convenience of a single SLA, the fear of hidden security flaws and the absence of one throat to choke as reasons for staying locked into U.S. stacks. The result is an unhealthy external dependency that jeopardises the EUs cyber-resilience and stalls the emergence of a fully-fledged Eurostack: a cloud and software supply-chain that can run, be audited and be improved inside European jurisdiction.

To correct this market failure the EU should set hard targets, finance the missing pieces and create predictable demand for European open-source products.

I therefore propose the following EU Open-Source Sovereignty Policy:

[1] A Directive requiring that, by 2027, at least 75% of new IT spending by EU institutions goes to solutions whose core software is released under an OSI-approved licence and is primarily maintained inside the Union.

[2] A Directive requiring that, by 2030, at least 50% of member-state government software-licence spending is for open-source products.

[3] An annual Open-Source Scoreboard published by DG CONNECT that tracks open source adoption across the EU.

[4] A 500M EU Sovereign Tech Fund that buys maintainer time, security audits and productisation services for strategic projects (cloud control planes, AI models for European languages, end-to-end encrypted collaboration, identity wallets and tooling). All code delivered must remain under an OSI licence.

[5] A European Seal of Security that finances independent fuzzing, bug-bounties and long-term-support contracts for the 200 most critical EU-maintained packages, removing the last rational excuse for buying closed source.

[6] The creation of a publicly-funded EU CodeHub (a European GitHub-like forge) operated under an EU legal entity, hosted exclusively on EU soil and fully compliant with GDPR, Cyber-Resilience Act and NIS-2. All repositories are mirrored to national data centres and can be self-hosted by member states to guarantee full data sovereignty.

[7] A procurement rule that any IT project receiving more than 10M in EU money must publish a machine-readable Software Bill Of Materials (SBOM) and justify in writing why no mature open-source component was used (comply-or-explain).

These measures give public buyers the confidence, the legal cover and the financial incentive to choose European open-source solutions. The resulting steady demand will accelerate the growth of local support vendors, shorten innovation cycles and deliver a resilient, sovereign digital infrastructure for the EU.

Since 2000 I have been using opensource software, mainly dev tools, as coder. I started to switch completely to opensource software in 2010 researching and trying stuff, with pain. Actually, since 2015, I own my flagship website with almost 150 web properties deployed on Linux as cloud solution, worked at my site under Unix, OpenBSD exactly, with XFCE as desktop environment, LiberOffice and Gimp, with my inhouse contributed IDE to develop my software. This doesnt give justice to my adopted env if I do not mention that I'm allowed by OpenBSD to deploy in any kind of modern hardware, many minipc and laptops (including Mac), and I'm allowed to exchange my env between stations, doing machine cloning by my drive support in half an hour, adopt ups and backup solutions scripted by myself to copy data on external and very old hot swapped sata drive. That said I invite you to clarify why we need proprietary software if not to support the commercial org behind it. We are already in our future, it is time to realize it.

Open Source as a basis for public and governmental IT systems is a necessary goal for the EU and its member-countries to work towards. As recent events have shown we cannot always count on the impartiality of the current chosen providers nor/or expect the benevolence of their host countries. This puts us at a major disadvantage cybersecurity-wise, where various providers either voluntarily or under pressure will disable various critical accounts and/or services in order to influence EU decision-making or cause harm to particular member-states/entities within the EU. It is therefore in the EU's best interest to fully adopt Open Source OS'es such as Linux and productivity-software solutions such as LibreOffice or OnlyOffice (as well as other auxiliary software) sooner rather than later, as the nature of Open Source software development prevents any one foreign national interest to control the software and what goes into it; and as such it becomes in everyone's best interest to keep such software free of security vulnerabilities, backdoors and kill-switches, while at the same time giving everyone free access to scrutinize the sourcecode for malicious activity. Time has run out for Microsoft Windows. It is clear that the trajectory of their OS is pointing towards the cloud, more centralization in data-centers, more AI, and more SaaS; all of these proving a tremendous security-concern when it comes subjects such as data-protection and GDPR as we can do nothing but blindly trust Microsoft's word that they will not harvest data, train their AI on it, or leak it to thirdparties on request. I propose we begin a push for a gradual rollout of Open Source software wherever possible inside the EU, with the guiding-arrow being "if an open source alternative can be found and replace the current solution adequately, use it; if not, use the existing proprietary solution, but commit to working towards a usable alternative that will eventually replace the proprietary solution". This is not just a win security-wise; economically an Open Source solution for public and governmental institutions would be an equally big win, as expenditures on expensive proprietary software-licenses and subscriptions would plummet, while the per-country expenses on development would be spread out across the EU, as the demand for features between countries would be similar/identical at the core. Such a move would also free us from the addition of resource-demanding bloat in our software, superfluous telemetry and outright spying on user-behavior under the guise of product-feedback; unnecessary features and additions whose sole purpose is to upsell a service, addon or subscription, or in other ways provide unnecessary behavior the end-user didn't ask for. At the end of it this the result is slowdowns, sluggish behavior, pc-hardware being deemed "too old", "too slow", obsolete, and requiring new expensive hardware-purchases, all resulting in a heightened CO2-footprint that could have been avoided, and an unnecessary mountain of e-waste made of otherwise perfectly functional pc's. This is one of those times where the right choice is staring us in the face (and has been for quite some time I might add). So far, paid advertising for proprietary software, a desire to wield massive budgets to pad the resume, ignorance of open source solutions and, most of all, a debilitating all-consuming reluctance/fear of having to adapt to a new OS/software has put a stop to Open Source adoption; but a lot has changed in the last decade. Open Source software is mature, proprietary software is at odds with our needs, and the geopolitical situation beckons us to control our own IT-destiny without reliance on external vendors who can morph into a security-threat from one day to the next. Thank you for your time Res publica non dominatur

There are many reasons why we should switch to free software. I won't rank them in order of importance, but I believe that the first three are equally fundamental. 1) We cannot depend on other countries for our security. Proprietary software is sometimes distributed with significant differences depending on the geographical region in which it is distributed. There are missing features and different behaviors. Why should we depend on the whims of people who have no interest in defending ours? 2) We will save money. Proprietary software costs an exorbitant amount of money, and very often manufacturers send updates that are only cosmetic changes, presenting them as important changes just to make money; 3) Security. Microsoft Windows has never been a stable or secure operating system. It has always been a very attractive software, but lacking in real customization and stability. Very often Windows updates have caused problems such as computer crashes or instability. With Windows 11, a silent BIOS update caused BIOS degradation with irreparably damaged computers. What should be a very useful feature, OneDrive, has turned into a nightmare. Many users have reported that the program has unknowilgly transfered all files to the cloud, deleting the files on the computer and acting as the main drive, so deleting from the cloud deletes the files from all locations. This happens without the user's knowledge. It's like piracy. A Linux system is not immune to viruses or hacker attacks, but it is much more secure than a Windows system, not only because it is used by few people but because of an intrinsic robust structure. (90% of Internet servers, stock markets, and space probes run on free software, not proprietary software); 4) Consistency of use. I have been using Linux since 1999, and I have used various distributions and free software such as OpenOffice and, later, LibreOffice. I have never had any problem opening files created with a specific distribution or program, and I have always been able to work without losing compatibility with older files. 5) Stability. Since 1999, I have never lost any files, and my distributions have never crashed. Only in the first year did I have to format a disk and reinstall everything, but that was a serious mistake on my part. Stability also means non-invasive system updates. Updates can be performed when necessary and in 99% of cases do not require a system reboot. Unless the operator wishes to do so, the system will never reboot a computer without the owner's intervention. A warship will never get stuck in the middle of the ocean because the computer has started an update (based on a true story); 6) Customization. A Linux distribution allows for complete customization to make the system work and look exactly the way you want it to, making the workflow smooth and simple. 7) Full control. A distro can be developed according to our specific needs, it will be compatible with all other distros, will use the same software but It can be tailored to our needs and specific characteristics without having to adapt to other people's models. Furthermore, free software has little to envy proprietary software. These are just some of the reasons why we should switch to free software. Europe as a whole should do everything to follow its own path; this is just one of the aspects to consider.

EU bør lovgive, udbyde, kræve og etablere åbne digitale økosystemer på følgende områder: (1) Identitet og ressource-adgangstyring (eID, MitID.dk) på fælles EU plan, så enhver borger i EU entydigt kan identificeres. (2) Enhver borger skal kunne tilgå tildelte ressourcer og tilladelser digitalt. Det kan være kørekort, social- og sundheds-id, adgang til egne sundhedsoplysninger (sundhed.dk). (3) En digital myndighed og virksomhed til borger kommunikation som Borger.dk (https://lifeindenmark.borger.dk/). (4) Borger til borger fora hvor EU borgere kan dele, kommunikere og debattere frit under overholdelse af landenes love og ansvar (læs: erstat Facebook og kommuniker ordenligt). Disse fora skal være fri for bagvedliggende kommercielle interesser, dog bør der ikke være udelukket, at virksomheder kan reklamere. Borgernes opmærksomhed og tid i fora er alene kontrolleret af dem selv og ikke af profilerende og manipulerende AI-algoritmer eller andre fastholdelsesmekanismer. (5) Obligatoriske åbne standarder for virksomhed til virksomhed kommunikation som PEPPOL og lignende indenfor alle brancher. (6) Åbne IT-standarder i offentlig administration. Det kan blandt andet være: (i) Sundhed, omsorg og telemedicin, (ii) Borgeradministration fra fødsel, immigration, emigration, død etc., (iii) Social- og beskæftigelse, (iv) Geologiske data og oplysninger til alle formål, (v) Bolig-, bygnings- og ejendomsregistrering, (vi) Tinglysning, (vii) Politi, fængsel samt håndhævelse af lov og ret, (viii) Orkestrerings- og datahubs med betydende interesser fra myndigheder og offentligheden som energiforbrug (eloverblik.dk), infrastruktur-forbrug som affald, dataudvekslinger mellem myndigheder og offentlig administration. (7) Alt software leveret til offentlig administration eller myndighed bør i udgangspunktet være åben source (FOSS). Militært software kan være undtaget, da det ikke overholder åben software (FOSS) krav om at være til almen nytte. Hensigten er at muliggøre genanvendelse eller udvidelse af en eksisterende applikationer og systemer på tværs. (8) EU markedsplads for godkendte og støttede åben software (FOSS) løsninger. Løsningerne kan være til enkelt borgeren, store virksomheder. Det kan være operativ systemer f.eks. Linux, e/OS og andre, kontorpakker og løsninger som f.eks. LibreOffice, CRM, elektroniske betalingssystemer, ejendomsadministration, intranet og meget andet. (9) Videns- og dokumentationshub for åben software (FOSS) for godkendte og støttede løsninger, (10) Repository som erstatter GitHub til at opbevarer og tilgængeligøre åben software (FOSS). (11) Krav og standarder så handikappede kan anvende digitale systemer og løsninger. (12) Love og krav og standarder for ikke digitale alternativer til digitale borgervendte systemer og løsninger, så borgeren kan anvende disse i stedet for de digitale løsninger på grund af handikap eller andre personlige forhold.
