As a PhD student, the entirety of my work is focused on open source systems, specifically the Linux Kernel. The EU should expand their contributions in this sector as currently there are areas of the technology stack that are fully closed. Examples of these are within the hardware/firmware of devices, the BIOS software, the actual design of the hardware. For the main barriers on the adoption of the open source software there are missing feature parity, a different workflow for many programs, and a missing support service. Software that is provided "as is" has no guarantees, that are sometimes needed in specific fields. The added value for open source is that it avoids a lot of repetition and rewriting of the same code over different competing products. Having the code also be open, and with a copyleft license, means all possible upgrades are always available to the public. A security flaw being fixed would not be able to reappear in competing products, as the single product can provide for everyone. This also allows a very open stance, as lock-in can be virtually non existent. Proprietary formats cannot exist within an open source program, and therefore a program that can translate data from one program to the other can always exist, giving a guarantee of interoperability. The EU should both financially and legally support these open source projects, defending them from possible company takeovers, or namesquatting, an example being OBS being "Open Broadcasting Software" being almost taken over by a company using the same name for their own fork of the project "Streamlabs OBS", which ended up replacing a lot of the traffic towards the original, due to SEO optimization tricks, fundamentally removing support from the original, especially as this version was closed source. The areas to focus first are on the mainstream software, programs that reduce the dependency on US based companies, for example Office and Windows. Continuning to support projects like Linux and LibreOffice/OnlyOffice means widening the support for the average citizen to have freedom of computation, in order to actually being able to own their machine and the software running on it. Open Source software needs extra guardrails over the security, as every single bit of code needs peer review and various guarantees, but on the opposite side, the fact that the code is open, means it's open to public scrutiny, and more likely to be more secure than closed counterparts, even if a lot of projects do not have the means to hire security consultants and audits, this could be another area in which the EU could support these projects.

As an entrepreneur of an european opensource solution competing with Microsoft on large accounts I would like to see the European Commission must less dependant to Microsoft and AWS. Recent study (Astères 2025) shows that for 15% of digital products/services bought in the US it is more than 400.000 jobs lost in Europe. Added to this, the European institutions have now a huge operational risk using those US technologies with the degradation of the transatlantic relations. The European Commission should lead by example and buy European tech

Open-source and digital commons are incredibly valuable. They also severely limit possible business models and thus the people that can work on them. It is quite common for widely used libraries to be maintained by a single person in their free time, without monetary compensation or any kind of recognition, but very close to burn out. It is more useful to define requirements for support and use not from the perspective of general property rights (freely accessible for anyone to use, modify and share), but problem-specific as rights. By those I mean *development direction guided by user needs only (vs. commercial needs of the producer, which in the worst case leads to 'enshittification'), which include strong privacy, user data ownership, focus (i.e. no advertising), security *source-auditable *automatic open-sourcing, if unmaintained *free for non-commercial and non-governmental use *producer independent use (i.e. locally installable in a way that cannot be shut down or forced to update remotely) *(likely additional) Projects / products, like open-source and digital commons, that basically forgo property rights by allowing anyone to use, modify and share (with attribution), are a limiting case. They automatically fulfill the problem-specific rights. There are models other than open source / digital commons, that also fulfill the problem-specific rights without giving up property rights. These enable business models that beyond those of open source (mostly selling support and consultancy or in the open-core model additional features). Specifically selling to for-profit and governmental organizations (while being free for use with non-profit, non-governmental users). Companies with such business models would still need to innovate, to be competitive with closed-source providers, but could be self-sustaining in the long run, while bound to honor the problem-specific rights. In their infancy they could be supported like open source projects.

This initiative is of crucial importance but, as the EU Commision and Parliament have acostumed us to, unfortunately rather late. The great majority of the EU's law enforcement has shown its fragility by intertwining itself with private corporations that offer little guarantees, and whose arbitration takes place outside the EU scope of court jurisdiction. Companies like Palantir are now a ruler of the rulers thanks to the lazyness of European Union police forces. They had, long time before, been using the Red Wolf and Blue Wolf systems that seriously endangered the Union's Sovereignty. Former German Chancellor Dr. Angela Merkel was proven to be spied upon by the then Obama-led US Government, to no serious consequence. Google, Apple, Microsoft and Amazon, to name a few American tech giants, pay virtually no taxes in Europe, and get penalized with laughable fines: another sign that the EU is always too late in reacting and too lenient towards what are now our suserains. For decades now, the technologically gifted brains of the European Union have found no place and no stimulus from within its governance, and are mostly all working for the American companies that destroy our "Digital Sovereignty". There are fortunately some European resistance small companies, and it would be fundamental that the European Union finally come to aid their development and implement their fully working systems. Finland has created the Sailfish OS for mobile telephones, the French e/os and Iodé have adapted a de-Googled operating system as a replacement for the Google Android OS. Also in France, a group of enthusiasts have developed Asteroid OS for smartwatches, as a substitute for the very security and privacy liability called Wear OS. OpenSuSe, in Germany, provides a Linux distribution capable of being run up to the enterprise or governmental levels. Tuta, also in Germany, runs a calendar, email service and cloud focused on privacy. Mistral AI, also focused on privacy, and from France, has to run its servers from the US for lack of governmental support. There are many others, the list is too long to detail. The point being: if the European Union politicians, military and other security and law enforcement organisms have been and are still seriously compromised, as are the industrial and educational innovation producers, it a matter of first priority to block exo-European eavesdropping and assure absolute confidentiality in the Eurozone's communications, security-led decision making and idea-creation processes, rather than focusing on the American model of mass-surveilling its citizens. The implementation of the EU's Chat Control is a stunning example of how not to do things: the computer manufacturers start producing a "security chip" five years ago and ship their products with it pre-installed. Kutcher, an American citizen, manages to lobby a Swedish MEP, and every individual European Union device is leaking information across the Atlantic. This is exactly why Open Source software and a thorough analysis of the hardware that is being sold in Europe are so vital. Europe can have allies and "friends", but it should stop inviting them into its bedroom.

There is a momentum where Microsoft and Google can be replaced easily: -There is a fatigue of Microsoft among IT departments and they are looking for alternatives. Could be open source ones. -Mobile-Only can be a great replacement for Windows with Open Source Android or Ubuntu Touch. We can see euro people and organizations working with a single device by adopting this disruptive vision of IT, but EU needs to lead. -Linux is rising in gaming with Open Source project like FEX or Proton and this is also a tremendous opportunitiy to replace Microsoft hegemony. The only missing piece is action. Europeans are talking but not leading. If there is a big leap in promoting and using these open source solutions, then we might reach a sustainable european open source IT. #UbuntuTouch #Mobile-Only #OpenSource

1. Analisi della dipendenza tecnologica Come professionista nel campo dell'ingegneria del software, confermo che la dipendenza dagli stack tecnologici extra-UE è attualmente totale e attraversa ogni livello: dall'hardware (dispositivi mobili e PC) alle infrastrutture cloud (AWS, Oracle), fino ai servizi di consumo e agli strumenti di intelligenza artificiale. Sebbene l'autonomia strategica sia auspicabile, occorre riconoscere che il divario competitivo è estremamente ampio. Una strategia efficace non dovrebbe solo puntare a "sostituire", ma a creare ecosistemi dove l'open source europeo possa integrarsi e, gradualmente, offrire alternative di pari affidabilità. 2. Barriere all'adozione e affidabilità Il principale ostacolo all'adozione di soluzioni open source europee da parte delle imprese è la percezione di una minore affidabilità e continuità rispetto ai prodotti commerciali consolidati. Le aziende necessitano di garanzie sul lungo periodo, supporto tecnico certo e roadmap di sviluppo stabili, elementi che i grandi player americani garantiscono grazie a risorse finanziarie massicce. 3. Proposte di misure concrete Per incentivare un cambio di rotta, si suggeriscono due direttrici principali: Incentivi fiscali: Prevedere sgravi per le aziende che contribuiscono attivamente (con codice o finanziamenti) a progetti open source critici basati in UE. Questo trasformerebbe lo sviluppo open source in un asset economico tangibile per le imprese. Ruolo della Pubblica Amministrazione: Introdurre una preferenza o un obbligo normativo per l'adozione di software a codice aperto nella PA. Sebbene rappresenti una sfida operativa notevole nel breve termine, è l'unico modo per creare una domanda di mercato interna sufficiente a sostenere lo sviluppo di alternative europee.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: 1. Analysis of technological dependence As a software engineering professional, I confirm that dependence on non-EU technology stacks is currently total and crosses every level: from hardware (mobile devices and PCs) to cloud infrastructure (AWS, Oracle), consumer services and artificial intelligence tools. While strategic autonomy is desirable, it must be recognised that the competitive gap is extremely wide. An effective strategy should not only aim to “replace”, but to create ecosystems where European open source can integrate and gradually offer equally reliable alternatives. 2. Barriers to adoption and reliability The main obstacle to the uptake of European open source solutions by businesses is the perception of lower reliability and continuity compared to established commercial products. Companies need long-term guarantees, firm technical support and stable development roadmaps, which are guaranteed by the major American players thanks to massive financial resources. 3. Proposals for concrete measures to incentivise a change of course, two main directions are suggested: Tax incentives: Provide relief for companies that actively contribute (with code or funding) to critical open source projects based in the EU. This would turn open source development into a tangible economic asset for companies. Role of the public administration: Introduce a regulatory preference or obligation for the adoption of open code software in the PA. Although it represents a significant operational challenge in the short term, it is the only way to create sufficient internal market demand to support the development of European alternatives.

feedback: By its very nature, FOSS is a community project and, as such, is not restricted or restrictable to the EU. However, it aligns perfectly with the EU's values, geopolitical needs and social requirements. Therefore, supporting it through funding or creating favourable legal conditions has a positive global impact on several levels: 1) For society as a whole, FOSS helps to respond to the growing and dangerous dependency of the EU's infrastructure on uncontrollable external forces. 2) For science and education, FOSS provides an excellent and unparalleled opportunity to communicate and learn from existing projects. 3) For businesses, FOSS helps them to share resources on projects that are not company-specific. Infrastructure is a good example of this. This strengthens Europes industry against monopolies. 4) Finally, for individuals, FOSS provides unrestricted, democratic access to knowledge and working tools. This is particularly true in less developed countries.

I firmly believe that any software used in the public sector and/or created by taxpayer' money should be open source so the entire European Union can benefit. I use open source software nearly exclusively for my office work for at least 15 years and it has proven its maturity and usefulness to me during that time. Furthermore, the use of such software would virtually guard public interest from the private vendors of the proprietary closed-source software. Commercial software vendors owned by companies outside of EU have no place in the public sector of EU.

To protect the economic interests of society as a whole while also contributing to the most rapid technical innovation the EU should require open source tech development for all EU funded research and demand purchasing preferences for open source software and hardware products. This will save money and result in an enormous return on investment. The literature showing that open source software development is superior is well developed and explains why it underpins the internet, all major internet companies and the vast majoirty of the Fortune 500. Open source hardware is younger technically so I will add some evidence: * UN publication on Open Hardware supporting open science https://unesdoc.unesco.org/ark:/48223/pf0000386890 * Review article summarizing open hardware's economic impacts. The results of the review find overwhelming evidence for a wide range of scientific tools, that open source technologies provide economic savings of 87% compared to equivalent or lesser proprietary tools. These economic savings increased slightly to 89% for those that used Arduino technology and even more to 92% for those that used RepRap-class 3-D printing. Combining both Arduino and 3-D printing the savings averaged 94% for free and open source tools over commercial equivalents. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.ohx.2020.e00139 * A study on the use of open hardware in Finland. The results of an example analysis for a single nation indicate Finland's science funders could save between 2.8427.7 million Euro/year directly on scientific equipment purchases if research hardware is converted to FOSH and the nation would likely garner the well-established concomitant benefits of increased research innovation within their economy. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.techfore.2020.119986 * Open hardware builds equitable capacity. Article offers science funders three policy recommendations to promote open science hardware for research capacity strengthening: a) incorporating open hardware into existing open science mandates, b) incentivizing demand through technology transfer and procurement mechanisms, c) promoting the adoption of open hardware in national and regional service centers. This agenda fosters capacity building towards enabling the more equitable and efficient science needed to achieve the SDGs. https://doi.org/10.38126/JSPG210202 * How to determine the downloaded substitution value of open hardware that can then be made locally using distributed manufacturing. https://dx.doi.org/10.4236/me.2015.61001 * Digital fabrication tools (that can also be open hardware) have advanced to the point that it enables even in-home manufacturing of open source products - this is good for the environment but also a way to democratize manufacturing and enable greater socio-economic equity - The simple payback time for the high-cost comparison was less than 6 months, and produced a 986% return. https://doi.org/10.3390/technologies5010007 * An article on how to overcome the limitations of proprietary hardware funding. The results of using the proprietary model of hardware development are a series of challenges including the following: (1) slow innovation and limited novelty, (2) black box syndrome, (3) reduced technology transfer, (4) vendor lock in, (5) no lateral scaling, and (6) high economic costs. This work evaluates the potential for the free and open-source hardware development model to overcome these challenges and finds the open hardware approach contributes to (1) faster innovation, (2) increased transparency, (3) rapid and widespread technology transfer, 4) enhanced competition, (5) peer production and scalability, and (6) lower economic costs. https://doi.org/10.1007/s13132-025-02783-w

Please, consider the work that you can find in the Publication Office of the European Union (2021): Levi, Simona et al. - Proposal for a Sovereign and Democratic Digitalisation of Europe https://op.europa.eu/en/publication-detail/-/publication/dae77969-7812-11ec-9136-01aa75ed71a1 In particular chapter 7: 7. Sustainability of sovereign and democratic digitalisation. Anti-monopolistic and investment policies that reach SMEs. Bonjour, Je me place sur le point de vue cybersécurité pour aborder le sujet du numérique ouvert et on ne part pas de trop loin, le groupe Thales ayant migré sous linux l'ensemble de son parc informatique en 48h en juin 2025. Des avantages de souveraineté, maîtrise et confidentialité des données et connexions. Sans parler de coût, qui au demeurant sont moindre qu'une migration vers Windows 11 nécessitant le renouvellement de tout ou partie du parc informatique, la souveraineté engendrée par la maîtrise du code et la confidentialité des données permettent de sortir d'une dépendance qui peut être mortelle pour la démocratie. Beaucoup disent que c'est impossible car l'usage des produits Microsoft implique une trop forte dépendance. Thales et d'autres comme la Gendarmerie Nationale en France, mais ailleurs aussi, le prouvent régulièrement en choisissant de basculer vers l'open source. L'avantage est d'accéder au code, de pouvoir le modifier pour x raisons, et de le redistribuer. Alors que tous les autres fournisseurs ont un code propriétaire dépendant de leur bon vouloir pour corriger les failles de sécurité. De plus, la communauté open source est la plus réactive pour corriger les failles signalées. N'attendons pas octobre 2026 pour migrer vers linux et sa suite de logiciels tous gratuits et interopérables répondant à 95% des besoins d'un utilisateur. Les 5% à faire sont soit superflus soit peuvent être développés à la demande ou par une association ou par des développeurs internes à l'entreprises. Les applicatifs métiers développés en interne sont transpilables aisément pour s'adapter à linux. Il est nettement plus simple d'auditer un code source ouvert qu'un code source propriétaire et fermé pour des raisons de sécurité, et donc de le corriger. Voilà, en moins de 2000 caractères mon avis sur le numérique ouvert pour plus de sécurité, souveraineté et maîtrise.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: Hello, I put myself on the cybersecurity front to address the topic of open digital and we do not go too far, as the Thales group migrated the whole of its IT park under pressure in 48 hours in June 2025. Advantages of sovereignty, control and confidentiality of data and connections. Not to mention the cost, which, moreover, is lower than a migration to Windows 11 requiring the renewal of all or part of the computer park, the sovereignty created by the control of the code and the confidentiality of the data make it possible to overcome a dependence which may be fatal for democracy. Many say that this is impossible because the use of Microsoft products implies too much dependence. Thales and others such as the Gendarmerie Nationale in France, but also elsewhere, regularly prove this by choosing to switch to the open source. The advantage is that you can access the code, edit it for x reasons, and redistribute it. All other suppliers have a proprietary code that depends on their willingness to correct security breaches. Moreover, the open source community is the most reactive to correct reported flaws. Let us not wait for October 2026 to migrate to the linux and its suite of software that is all free and interoperable and meets 95 % of a user’s needs. The 5 % to be done is either superfluous or can be developed upon request or by an association or by in-house developers. In-house business applications can be easily transferred to adapt to linux. It is much simpler to audit an open source code than a proprietary and closed source code for security reasons, and therefore to correct it. This is, in less than 2000 characters, my opinion on open digital for more security, sovereignty and control.

feedback: Il semble qu'au vu des budgets immenses qui sont engagés dans des solutions logicielles propriétaires (et américaines) de bureautique dans tous les services publics européens, et au vu des problèmes de souveraineté que cela engendre, le développement d'une solution open source basée sur les solution existantes, avec un investissement fort de la Commission, peut devenir une référence mondiale et utilisable à moindre coût dans nos administrations, et pour les citoyens de l'UE. Pour un investissement dont la Commission a les moyens, les retours sur investissements sont colossaux, à tous niveaux.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: It seems that, given the huge budgets involved in proprietary (and American) office automation software solutions in all European public services, and the problems of sovereignty that this creates, the development of an open source solution based on existing solutions, with strong investment by the Commission, can become a global benchmark that can be used at lower cost in our administrations, and for EU citizens. For an investment that the Commission has the means to make, returns on investment are huge at all levels.

feedback: Europe has a deep reservoir of opensource talent, anchored in worldclass universities, research centres and an industry base that already contributes actively to open-source projects. This ecosystem is aligned with European values, prioritising openness, security and digital rights. However, despite the strong foundations, the sector struggles to scale. Promising projects often begin with good intentions but quickly become acquisition targets for large US companies, weakening Europes capacity to retain its own innovation. Barriers to adoption of highquality, secure open-source solutions frequently stem from limited funding and an insufficient strategy to keep successful teams and companies in Europe. Longterm sustainability is also at risk, particularly as emerging agentic AI systems reduce incentives for developers to maintain codebases, creating uncertainty about the future role of human contributors. Sustainable contributions are further limited by two factors: the pressure from users and businesses for rapid feature delivery at the expense of security and sovereignty, and insufficient funding to support longterm, communitydriven development. For the public sector, open source provides the strategic advantage of reducing dependence on US technology vendors, strengthening autonomy, and enabling public services to operate on platforms aligned with European values and legal frameworks. For the private sector, it reinforces Europes local technology base and supports the longterm viability of a highly skilled European workforce. Key application areas include collaboration platforms, cloud infrastructure and hardware solutions. The main criteria for assessing the value of open source should include availability, interoperability, portability, usability and security all critical for reducing lockin and increasing resilience. To support growth of the EU open-source sector, the most important step is for the EU to lead by example: EU institutions, agencies and bodies should adopt EUbased solutions first, and only revert to nonEU providers if no viable European option exists. This single procurement principle would drive demand, create early reference customers and lay the foundation for scale. EU action should focus on reforming procurement rules, increasing funding for scaling (not just research), establishing EUlevel securitybydesign frameworks, and providing reliable infrastructure and governance support for communities. Europes technological sovereignty requires precisely this shift toward strategic, longterm investment in cloud, hardware and AI areas where open source can both accelerate innovation and secure supply chains. Cybersecurity can be strengthened by enforcing securitybydesign practices across opensource projects and by investing in audits, certifications and longterm maintenance support. Existing initiatives such as EUtech, the European Tech Champions Initiative, NextGenerationEU, RISCV efforts and middleware programmes like Simpl should be expanded to focus more on scaling and industrial adoption. Europe has all the ingredients talent, values, and active communities but must now create the economic and policy environment that allows its open-source ecosystem not only to innovate, but to grow and remain European.

Standardize regulatory enforcement actions. The EU and its member countries has all kinds of laws. This is not what I'm critisizing that's their job. Yet, the agencies that enforce those don't have a standardized way of making demands, which really adds to the burden of hosting and adopation. This is also part of the reason development is, so much further than adoption, hosting and bussinesses in this sphere. Development is by its very nature slow(by IT standards) allowing one to manually and thus slowly handle differences in law enforcement demands. In other words provide the public with the tools and/or data to comply. Official identifier of EU registered businesses: amazing. Official enforcement ips: good. Public cryptographic hashes of restricted content: usefull. An open standard for DSA content removal demands: top. An open standard for law enforcement subpoena api access: great. Publicised public keys to proof that something actually came from law enforcement: great. Signed warrants: great. Machine readable policy manifests for compliance: amazing, but probably unachievable. Anything would be an improvement. Right now it works with barely verifiable email contact, long trials and C-level negotiations for automated access. For non-hyperscalers this is massive burden. An understandable one, but maybe you could simplify some of it standardizing some of the process. Don't forget violating subpoenas comes with the price of imprisonment, but providing that kind of access to anybody else is a great breach of trust and often just as illegal. Also, since open source development is mostly done from residential homes. Residential utility improvements could also help.

- systèmes ouverts: indispensables - qui dit systèmes ouverts doit aussi dire auditabilité, donc audits documentés, et pas pa des cabinets de conseils qui se vendent au plus offrant - implique l'éducation des citoyens au contrôle numérique, et à la responsabilisation - impique uassi des plates-formes souveraines d'échange libres, cfr github racheté par Microsoft pour ne prendre que cet exemple - ces systèmes ouverts doivent aussi être souverains, et indem intégration dans la paysage civil et militaire
feedbackTextUserLanguage: — open systems: essential – which means open systems must also mean auditability, i.e. documented audits, and not just consultancies selling to the highest bidder – involves educating citizens about digital control, and accountability – the uassi impact of sovereign free exchange platforms, cfr github bought by Microsoft to take just this example – these open systems must also be sovereign, and they must be integrated into the civil and military landscape.

feedback: As long as possible, I would strongly suggest to limit the dependency from 3. party software and move to open source one. This would support its development and, consequently, would raise the integration between different softwares (open source). Actually a lot of organization heavily depend of software that is not under the direct control of the EU, exposing the EU itself to blackmail and forced actions. What if tomorrow the "next Trump" (if not even the actual one) will say that every user of US software must pay an extra tax? And what if a private EU company is sold to an US one with this rules? While there are a lot of laws to protect us from 'unfair' actions, there's no way to protect from bullies if we depend from software that is not open.

As a Senior Software Engineer with years of experience in cloud infrastructure and software architecture, I strongly urge the EU to pivot toward a sovereign digital ecosystem that prioritizes European interests over US-based monopolies. 1. Ending Dependency & Economic Fairness Currently, we are funneled into a massive capital drain toward US tech giants (Hyperscalers). This is not just a technical risk but an economic one. While European providers like Hetzner or OVH Cloud offer highly competitive pricing, many organizations remain trapped in expensive AWS/Azure ecosystems. Sovereignty Levy: I propose a digital service tax (sovereignty levy) on non-EU cloud and software providers. These funds should be directly reinvested into the European tech sector to level the playing field against companies that benefit from unfair market dominance. Geopolitical Risk: Relying on US infrastructure makes us vulnerable to volatile political shifts and potential trade wars. We must stop subsidizing foreign economies that threaten us with tariffs. 2. Investing in Usable Open Source Open Source is the backbone of digital freedom, but it lacks the "polish" of US SaaS products. Financial Support: The EU must provide direct financial backing for critical Open Source projects to ensure modern, performant tech stacks (moving beyond legacy architectures like PHP toward more robust, scalable solutions). UX is Key: To replace Microsoft 365 or Google Workspace, we need European managed-service providers that offer a seamless "one-click" experience. Solutions like Nextcloud are a start, but they require a professionalized, integrated approach for mail, calendar, and collaboration that matches the ease of use of US competitors. 3. Visibility and Adoption European alternatives remain largely unknown to the broader public. The EU must actively promote domestic providers and mandate Open Source First for public administrations. We need to stop "shoving money down the throats" of US corporations and instead build a resilient, user-friendly, and self-sufficient European digital landscape.

Iniziativa importante. Non tanto per il costo diretto ma per una opportunità di ROI anche nell'evoluzione tecnologica che un driver come l'opensource può attuare. Recuperare il divario tecnologico rispetto Stati Uniti e Cina e India è molto complesso visto che questi paesi hanno testimoniato muovendo enormi risorse per aumentare il divario rispetto i concorrenti e quindi anche nei confronti dell'Europa che tradizionalmente non ha una Industria particolarmente "Tecnologica" e ha abdicato di fatto in quanto i maggiori investimenti economici avvengono sempre dall'altra parte dell'oceano. Per quanto riguarda la Cina, la loro economia dipende dall'enorme disponibilità di denaro che viene dalla loro bilancia commerciale. L'Europa deve velocemente recuperare la strada persa e, l'opensource sposa in pieno la filosofia rappresentata dalla Commissione europea di mantenere comunque una certa eticità (vedi regolamenti relativi alla Privacy e all'IA) volta a garantire un progresso per la razza umana prima che per le aziende.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: Important initiative. This is not so much because of the direct cost but also because of an opportunity for ROI in the technological evolution that a driver such as opensource can implement. Closing the technology gap with the United States and with China and India is very complex, as these countries have demonstrated that they have moved huge resources to increase the gap with their competitors, and therefore also with Europe, which traditionally does not have a particularly “technology” industry and has in fact abdicated because the greatest economic investment always takes place on the other side of the ocean. As far as China is concerned, their economy depends on the huge availability of money from their trade balance. Europe must quickly catch up and the opensource fully embodies the philosophy of the European Commission to maintain a certain eticity (see regulations on privacy and AI) aimed at ensuring progress for the human race rather than for companies.

feedback: Its great that the EU is finally looking seriously at open digital ecosystems instead of just talking about sovereignty while everyone is stuck in vendor lockin. ​ If this Strategy is going to work, it has to put real money and attention into the basics: maintaining core opensource projects, security fixes, documentation, and longterm support, not just flashy new pilots. ​ Public procurement also needs to stop treating big proprietary vendor as the safe default and make it easy for administrations to choose opensource solutions with proper paid support and clear rules. ​ Right now, a lot of the value is created by opensource communities, and then some companies throw a proprietary wrapper around it and fight against truly open alternatives because lockin pays better. ​ Success for this initiative should mean less lockin, more upstream contributions from public bodies, and stable multiyear support for the opensource projects Europe already depends on every day.
firstName: Mitchell Damian Gunnar Dennis Hennie Louie

feedback: The main reason for me to support this is so we have more EU based products and to limit how dependent we are of America or China. We already import alot of products from those country's so i think its good to limit our digital dependency of those country's and build a digitally stronger and more independent Europe.

The EU luckily already has a vibrant and innovative Open Source community. But support is needed to capitalize on our strength, and remain competitive. Too often, I feel that politicians are looking for the "Next Google/Microsoft/Facebook/..., but now from the EU and Open Source". We will not be successful if we define our goals in the terms of what other players achieved. It would be good, instead, to change the perspective from the apparent dichtomy "Open Source vs. Proprietary" to understanding Open Source Software as the necessary infrastructure on which innovation and business models can be built. Maintaining this infrastructure, as one would maintain a road network, is crucial to remain competitive. An open infrastructure lowers the entry barrier to innovation for everyone, enables easier teaching on current IT technologies, and gives the public sector more fine-granular options to incentivize/disincentivize behaviour. An important part of such an open infrastructure are open and freely accessible standards. Some concrete ideas: - The focus of public investment in IT solutions should not only be on "Open Source vs. Proprietary", but also ask, whether (part of) the invest strengthens the underlying Open Source infrastructure (e.g., via support contracts). - Open Source must not be seen primarily as a measure to cut costs, but rather as a chance to strategically spend budget to strengthen both local business *and* the underlying infrastructure. - Supporting the development and insisting on the use of open data interchange standards is not cost-intensive and strengthens Open Source Software indirectly, as proprietary software often depends on lock-in effects to remain competitive.

Vi ringrazio per questa consultazione.Potreste aiutarmi a stimare, anche in modo approssimativo, quanto lEuropa ha speso negli ultimi ventanni in licenze per software proprietario? E, ipotizzando che il 50% di quella somma fosse stato investito nelle università e nei centri di ricerca per sviluppare alternative libere e open source ai software proprietari più diffusi, quale impatto avrebbe potuto avere sulla sovranità tecnologica, sull innovazione e sulla riduzione della dipendenza da pochi attori dominanti? Questa domanda si inserisce nel solco della campagna Denaro pubblico, codice pubblico (publiccode.eu), che promuove l adozione di software aperto nella pubblica amministrazione. Tuttavia, il problema va affrontato in modo sistemico: non basta solo il software libero. Servono anche hardware aperti, riparabili e migliorabili dagli utenti finali. Solo così si può garantire una reale indipendenza tecnologica e promuovere uneconomia circolare, in cui la tecnologia non diventi rapidamente obsoleta, ma possa essere adattata, aggiornata e riutilizzata nel tempo.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: Thank you for this consultation.Can you help me to estimate, even approximately, how much Europe has spent in the last twenty years on proprietary software licences? And, assuming that 50 % of that sum had been invested in universities and research centres to develop free and open-source alternatives to the most popular proprietary software, what impact could it have had on technological sovereignty, innovation and reducing dependence on a few dominant players? This question follows on from the public money campaign (publiccode.eu), which promotes the adoption of open software in public administration. However, the problem needs to be addressed in a systemic way: free software alone is not enough. There is also a need for hardware that is open, repairable and upgradable by end users. This is the only way to ensure real technological independence and promote a circular economy, in which technology does not quickly become obsolete, but can be adapted, updated and reused over time.

feedback: EU must sever the dependencies on software and hardware made and controlled by foreign countries, as they pose critical security and sovereignty risks to our strategic autonomy. The financial and defence industries should be at the forefront of this independence movement: unfortunately, the reliance on closed source solutions (Windows OSs) or privately-held clouds (GCP, AWS, Azure) in this key sectors is a liability. Foreign actors that control consumer hardware (e.g. US with Apple), might use this advantage by snooping on former allies. Open-source software is one key tool to reclaim independence: EU should mandate strict guidelines for using OSS software in institutions (e.g. oss browsers and operating systems) instead of closed source counterparts. For example, a stronger push on OSS browsers in EU will likely guarantee EU has a way to shape the future of the internet, influencing web standards: something it currently has little way to do.
Great initiative, and long overdue - we need digital sovereignty in the EU! However, look at the existing open source communities. There's no need to start from scratch.

1. Points forts et points faibles du secteur européen des logiciels libres : À titre privé, j'utilise plusieurs logiciels libres qui démontrent la force et la diversité de l'écosystème open source. Par exemple, ArchLinux comme système d'exploitation, LibreOffice pour la suite bureautique, SilverBullet pour la prise de notes, Mastodon pour les réseaux sociaux, Immich pour le stockage de photos, Pixelfed pour le partage d'images, DuckDuckGo comme moteur de recherche, et Mistral.ai pour l'intelligence artificielle. Ces outils montrent que des alternatives open source de haute qualité existent et peuvent remplacer des solutions propriétaires. Cependant, il existe des points faibles, notamment un manque de visibilité et de soutien financier pour certains projets. Les principaux obstacles à l'adoption et à la maintenance de logiciels open source incluent la résistance au changement, le manque de soutien technique et de documentation accessible, ainsi que la dépendance aux solutions propriétaires. 2. Valeur ajoutée de l'open source pour les secteurs public et privé : L'open source apporte une valeur ajoutée significative en termes de réduction des coûts, de meilleure sécurité et transparence, d'indépendance technologique, et d'innovation accrue. Par exemple, l'utilisation de distribution GNU/Linux à la place de Windows et de LibreOffice à la place de Office 365 montre que des alternatives open source peuvent être tout aussi performantes, sinon plus, que leurs équivalents propriétaires. À titre professionnel, j'utilise Ubuntu comme système d'exploitation, Jenkins pour l'intégration continue, Forgejo pour la gestion de code source, Clever Cloud pour le déploiement, OpenJDK pour le développement Java, Apache Tomcat comme serveur d'applications, Gradle pour la gestion de projets, Nexus OSS pour la gestion des artefacts, Ollama et Open-WebUI pour l'IA, et Bitwarden pour la gestion des mots de passe. Ces outils permettent une meilleure maîtrise des coûts, une plus grande flexibilité et une meilleure sécurité. Les facteurs les plus importants pour évaluer la valeur ajoutée de l'open source incluent le coût, la sécurité, l'innovation, et l'indépendance technologique. 3. Mesures et actions concrètes pour soutenir le développement et la croissance du secteur open source de l'UE : Pour soutenir le développement et la croissance du secteur open source de l'UE, il est essentiel d'augmenter le financement des projets open source, de promouvoir l'utilisation de l'open source dans les administrations publiques et dans les écoles et d'améliorer la documentation et le soutien technique, et de créer des partenariats public-privé pour soutenir les projets open source. 4. Domaines technologiques prioritaires : Les domaines technologiques qui devraient être priorisés incluent les systèmes d'exploitation, les suites bureautiques, les outils de développement et de déploiement, ainsi que les solutions de stockage et de gestion de données. Ces domaines sont cruciaux pour assurer une indépendance technologique et une compétitivité accrue. 5. Secteurs où une utilisation accrue de l'open source pourrait conduire à une compétitivité et une cyber-résilience accrues : Les secteurs où une utilisation accrue de l'open source pourrait être bénéfique incluent l'éducation, l'administration publique, la santé, et la finance. Dans ces secteurs, l'open source peut apporter une meilleure sécurité, une plus grande transparence, et une réduction des coûts.
feedbackTextUserLanguage:
1. Strengths and Weaknesses of the European Open Source Software Industry: Privately, I use several open source software that demonstrate the strength and diversity of the open source ecosystem. For example, ArchLinux as an operating system, LibreOffice for the office suite, SilverBulle
33364438,https://ec.europa.eu/info/law/better-regulation/have-your-say/initiatives/16213-European-Open-Digital-Ecosystems/F33364438_en,Ares(2026)69111,2026/01/13 10:25:30,For true digital sovereignty and security the EU needs to massively invest and contribute to open source solutions for software. Be that as contributing to current open source solutions
organization: provided they share a non-restrictive license or start new projects for crucial sectors. This will help public institutions as a plethora of developers employed both by the EU and private companies would be able to contribute and verify/test the code

Take for example Linux. Why would a company try to maintain a Windows server for which they have to pay the license to use when they can use a free open source solution that has thousands of active maintainers and a huge community for support. As a software engineer having open source alternatives to use both in my work and my personal projects is a great thing

feedback: This submission provides experience-based input from an open-source software company active in development, maintenance, and deployment across EU/EMEA and US contexts. It focuses on structural barriers affecting the sustainability of the EU open-source ecosystem, including incentive misalignment for long-term maintenance, supply-chain security, and dependency on non-EU collaboration infrastructure. The submission also outlines concrete, non-legislative actions the EU could take to strengthen open-source sustainability, resilience, and adoption. A detailed response addressing all consultation questions is provided in the attached document.

feedback: While I welcome the EU's decision to pursue this, I simply want to encourage the Commission to avoid reinventing the wheel. There are so many wonderful open-source communities around the EU focusing on everything from technical development to policy, from small groups of hackers to larger commercial entities (i.e., Nextcloud). This includes national Internet communities, technical and standards development bodies, groups like the Chaos Computer Club, and countless other developers, engineers, techies, and everything in-between. So, I encourage you to proactively seek them out, request best practices, and create an alternative Big Tech movement together. As an example of some of these communities and alternatives, see the following websites: 1. https://european-alternatives.eu/ 2. https://www.goeuropean.org/ 3. https://www.opensourcealternative.to/ I also encourage close collaboration with Eurostack and other similar initiatives. Do not mistake the obvious: American Big Tech is NOT your friend! This is a great opportunity for the EU to unite all kinds of different groups and stakeholders, ranging the full spectrum of political and ideological beliefs, to collaborate on building and enabling a different path for European technology going forward.

Il software è ormai diventato di fatto un bene di prima necessità quasi al pari di energia elettrica e connettività. È necessario che l'UE svolga il proprio ruolo di ente pubblico al servizio dei cittadini europei promuovendo lo sviluppo di software open source libero dai vincoli di segretezza e dai pericoli di sicurezza e privacy dei software proprietari, soprattuto non europei. I software proprietari inoltre, elevando per natura il profitto al di sopra di tutto, anche di morale, etica e giustizia sociale, sono spesso incompatibili con le esigenze di "bene di prima necessità". Si potrebbe anche aggiungere che qualunque software è il risultato non solo del lavoro del programmatore ma della conoscenza delle passate generazioni, che è patrimonio culturale universale; in questo senso il software open source "restituisce" alla società quello che il software ha "prelevato" dal patrimonio culturale comune (un tema importante soprattutto in relazione ai software di intelligenza artificiale).
feedbackTextUserLanguage: Software has become a de facto basic necessity almost as much as electricity and connectivity. The EU must play its role as a public body serving European citizens by promoting the development of open-source software free from secrecy and the dangers of security and privacy of proprietary software, especially non-European software. Furthermore, proprietary software, by nature raising profit above everything, including moral, ethical and social justice, is often incompatible with the requirements of ‘basic necessities’. It could also be added that any software is the result not only of the programmer’s work but of knowledge of past generations, which is a universal cultural heritage; in this sense, open source software ‘returns’ to society what the software has ‘taken’ from the common cultural heritage (an important topic especially in relation to artificial intelligence software).

feedback: The European Union should establish a unified portfolio of sovereign, opensource digital products to strengthen Europes technological independence and resilience. This initiative should focus on strategic alternatives to dominant nonEU technology providers, with a clear priority roadmap. Key focus areas could include: Developing a European alternative to Cloudflaretype network and security infrastructure. Creating scalable, EUbased cloud platforms to reduce reliance on hyperscalers such as Google Cloud, AWS, and Microsoft Azure. Microsoft 365 and Google Workspace replacements Windows commands 73% of EU desktop OS, while Android (Google) and iOS (Apple) near 100% of mobile; Google Search exceeds 89%. Browsers, social media (Meta platforms), and marketplaces like Amazon further entrench US control over consumer and data flows. Identifying and replacing other critical U.S.based tools currently monopolizing EU markets (e.g., communication platforms, productivity suites, analytics services). To reduce fragmentation, this effort should be coordinated by a central body or visionary leader from the opensource community, ensuring coherence and momentum,perhaps under the mentorship of figures such as Linus Torvalds or equivalent European innovators. The EU should maintain a dedicated and transparent online repository showcasing these sovereign products, encouraging both public and private sector adoption. Awareness campaigns, including targeted digital advertising, should promote these projects to build recognition and trust among EU citizens and enterprises. Moreover, the EU should ensure that these solutions are costcompetitive with U.S. alternatives, offering financial and regulatory incentives for EU governments and companies to adopt and contribute to them.

Whatever past wall we had to not be able to abandon the microsoft ecosystem does not exist anymore. Nowdays we can browse without internet explorer, we can work in offices without microsoft office (by using libreoffice or other cloud services), and we can live without microsoft. There is a long path from this moment (13-jan-2026) to complete independence, but the time to start is now! As a tax contributor I prefer that the money are invested in open source technologies, in freedom!

Start building European counterparts to American big tech immediately, especially cloud, content delivery etc, preferably open source. Do it as soon as possible! It's a critical continental security risk

In aggiunta tutte gli ottimi suggerimenti che ho letto fin qui, vorrei che consideraste l'idea di finanziare la creazione di un sistema operativo mobile partendo dall' Open source Android che eviti il flusso continuo di informazioni personali di utenti europei che vanno all'estero. Nelle tasche di ogni cittadino europeo c'è oggi almeno un dispositivo mobile. Andrebbe creato un ecosistema più rispettoso dei dati utente che consenta di sostituire sui dispositivi Android in uso in modo semplice ed user friendly l'attuale paradigma Google, a partire dall'indirizzo mail che dovrà essere europeo. A cascata tutto l'insieme di backup della configurazione , dei contatti , uno spazio Cloud. Inoltre dalla commissione dovrebbe partire l'invito alle aziende, in special modo quelle pubbliche, affinché inizino ad utilizzare alternative Open source europee. È più facile per un'azienda creare un account su un social americano, ma è molto più produttivo e rispettoso dei cittadini creare una istanza mastodon in ambito europeo ed evitare che i dati finiscano impasto a qualche multinazionale.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: In addition to all the very good suggestions I have read so far, I would like you to consider the idea of financing the creation of a mobile operating system starting from the Open Source Android that avoids the continuous flow of personal information of European users going abroad. Every European citizen now has at least one mobile device in his or her pockets. A more user friendly ecosystem should be created to replace the current Google paradigm on existing Android devices in a simple and user friendly way, starting with the email address that must be European. Cascade all the backup set of configuration, contacts, a Cloud space. In addition, the committee should start by inviting companies, especially public ones, to start using European open source alternatives. It is easier for a company to create an account on an American social media account, but it is much more productive and respectful for citizens to create a Mastodon instance at European level and to prevent data from becoming blurred to some multinationals.

feedback: Es gibt in Europa schon gute OpenSource-Firmen (zum Beispiel OpenSuse Linux). Solche Firmen sollten gefördert werden bzw. diese Software in der Regel flächendeckend genutzt werden. Dann benötigen wir in Europa einen strategischen Gegenentwurf: nicht Software-Firmen, die mit den persönlichen Daten ihrer "Kunden" Geld verdienen. Das bedeutet aber auch, dass sie anderweitig ihre finanziellen Mittel erhalten. (Erhebliche) Staatliche Unterstützung muss möglich sein. Wir haben in Europa genug Ideen und genug intelligente Menschen, die das auch umsetzen können. Es fehlt "nur" die finanzielle Sicherheit dazu. Das muss anders werden.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: There are already good open source companies in Europe (e.g. OpenSuse Linux). Such companies should be encouraged or, as a rule, this software should be widely used. Then we need a strategic counter-approach in Europe: not software companies that earn money from their ‘customers’ personal data. However, this also means that they receive their financial resources from other sources. (Significant) state support must be possible. We have enough ideas in Europe and enough smart people to make it happen. There is ‘only’ a lack of financial security for this. This needs to change.

feedback: We should identify the highest dependece or crucial systems and push for alternatives. It will not be enough to just build alternatives, but they will need to rival existing US solution AND crucially be promoted, potentially even starting in schools. Something like di.day is already a great initiative to reduce the load. Strategically Investing in open source alternatives and helping people switch to them is important.

Uno dei padri dei sistemi open source, Linus Torvalds, è un europeo. Tenerne conto coinvolgendolo sarebbe un indubbio vantaggio. Inoltre il problema dei sistemi open source è la frammentazione che rende difficile per le aziende scegliere su quali sistemi investire in quanto manda la certezza della durata di sistemi che potrebbero perdere supporto e adesione della comunità nel tempo. L'UE dovrebbe fare delle scelte su architetture su cui far concentrare lo studio e sviluppo e l'aggiornamento dei sistemi open source da parte delle università europee per dare garanzie di durabilità dei sistemi alle aziende, creando anche le competenze necessarie per uno sviluppo duraturo nel tempo e creando così un mercato del lavoro attrattivo.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: One of the fathers of open source systems, Linus Torvalds, is a European. Taking this into account by involving them would be an undoubted advantage. Moreover, the problem of open source systems is the fragmentation that makes it difficult for companies to choose which systems to invest in as it lacks certainty about the duration of systems that may lose community support and buy-in over time. The EU should make choices on architectures on which to focus the study and development and updating of open source systems by European universities in order to guarantee the durability of systems for companies, also creating the skills needed for sustainable development over time and thus creating an attractive labour market.

feedback: L'utilisation de logiciels opensource et de services européens gérés en Europe doit être promue. Or, l'omniprésence des plateformes et logiciels américains en fait les options par défaut. Il nous faudrait : - des services faciles, efficaces, abordables et même gratuits pour les usages essentiels. Basés et gérés en europe ; - de la publicité massive (comme pour les automobiles et autres gaspillages) ; - utilisation obligatoire par les administrations ; - utilisation obligatoire (et possible) par les citoyens dans leurs rapports avec les administrations ; - l'enseignement basé sur les logiciels open source ; - une aide d'état à la population pour le passage vers ces technologies. Actuellement, tant la promotion que l'aide repose sur le bénévolat ! Ça fonctionne bien mais, en terme de puissance, les bénévoles ne remplacent pas les état. Linux permet l'utilisation de matériel obsolète pour Windows. Cela donne accès à l'informatique à des gens qui n'ont pas le moyens d'utiliser l'informatique mainstream. Ce sont aussi des bénévole qui s'en occupent. Et ils n'ont même pas le droit de récupérer les ordinateurs jetés dans les déchetteries. Il est temps d'officialiser et organiser l'économie circulaire dans ce domaine.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: The use of OpenSource software and European services managed in Europe should be promoted. However, the ubiquity of US platforms and software makes them the default options. We should: — easy, efficient, affordable and even free services for essential uses. Based and managed in Europe; — massive advertising (as for cars and other waste); mandatory use by administrations; — mandatory (and possible) use by citizens in their dealings with administrations; — education based on open source software; — State aid to the population for the transition to these technologies. Currently, both promotion and support are based on volunteering! It works well, but in terms of power, volunteers do not replace the state. Linux allows the use of obsolete hardware for Windows. This gives access to IT to people who do not have the means to use mainstream IT. Volunteers are also involved. And they do not even have the right to retrieve the computers thrown away at the civic amenity sites. It is time to formalise and organise the circular economy in this area.

feedback: Of course it is important to be as flexible and indipendent as possible. Up to now, most effort and responses here are focussing on software and the software ecosystem. That is good. Next to that, more attention should be given to hardware and a hardware ecosystem. The chain is as weak as the weakest point will be. EU built hardware and hardware ecosystem might be even more important since control, sovereingty and indepence can be exercised best at the lowest level in the digital stack. Who owns the systems, owns the data and communication.

I believe public sectors in the EU should only use open source software, if there is no open source software that covers the use case, they should put double of the cost for the closed source software into open source development, so that there can be a open source alternative that covers the use case. Since the public sector's software use is not much different of that of a large companies, this would also help companies reduce their dependencies towards non european tech giants.

he US muscled the EU into adopting Article 6 of the EU Copyright Directive, preventing reverse engineering in return for free trade. By implementing tariffs, the US broke that agreement. Theres no reason not to delete Article 6 of the EUCD, and all the other laws that prevent European companies from jailbreaking iPhones and making their own App Stores (minus Apples 30% commission), as well as ad-blockers for Facebook and Instagrams apps (which would zero out EU revenue for Meta), and, of course, jailbreaking tools for Xboxes, Teslas, and every make and model of every American car, so European companies could offer service, parts, apps, and add-ons for them. Video games need to be able to be run after official support shuts down and servers close down. We need to get out from under the high tech lock-in scams, we need to get rid of e-waste. We need to get back to ownership of the products we buy. This is an important part of digital sovereignity and in an uncertain world with unreliable partners, the importance of being able to follow EU values needs to be underscored. FOSS and allowing FOSS to develop is an important lynchpin of this.

Europe needs to develop its own OS and largely separate itself from American closed software. We could create our own OS based on Linux, our own mobile based on Android. SOHO routers could use OpenWRT. HDMI 2.1 is a closed standard, so DisplayPort should be used on TVs instead.

Is important for the EU to foster more towards open sourc software in order to diminish our dependance from the US. Microsoft products are a burden on bureocracy cost, for examples in schools, offices suite products are a cost that often chip the disponibility of funds for educational projects, an open source eu- developed solutions could be more cheaper and more scalable to each environment where it's used.

As a part European Open Digital Ecosystem Strategy, a pathway to remove antitampering legislation, specifically repeal Article 6 of the Copyright Directive, to enhance adversarial interoperability and sovereign EU open tech stack.
Dobbiamo essere totalmente Europa ed Europei, basta dipendenze da USA o Cina o Russia. È giusto dotarsi di strumenti informatici all'avanguardia per un futuro migliore. Grazie per questa iniziativa.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: We need to be totally Europe and Europeans, just dependent on the US or China or Russia. It is right to equip ourselves with state-of-the-art IT tools for a better future. Thank you for this initiative.

feedback: Apologies for writing in a less formal language that Id like to, but I am tired and English is not my native language. In my opinion consumer protection laws need to be updated in order for people owning their devices again. Let me give you an example: Lets say for the sake of an argument, you bought a fancy new washing machine which you can control with an equally fancy app from your smartphone Whats that? After a few weeks the manufacturer pushes an update to your phone and now you can no longer control your washing machine? Since the app is the only way to control your washing machine, you are now either in an hostage situation or the proud owner of a pile of metal that does nothing, basically a sculpture. How can such an hostage situation between company and customer be legal??? If you buy an electrical device (washing machine, laptop, phone, tv, toaster, fridge) you should actually own it and have the right to repair these devices. The only way to ensure consumer rights in the future is to have more devices which are build on an open ecosystem. The bootloader should not be proprietary. The operating system should not be proprietary. This would also avoid Megatons of e-waste, so the environment would profit, too. To name at least one concrete measure: the EU should support coreboot, an open-source EFI system for pc hardware. Another subject is long-term preservation of software where open-source emulation is very valuable. The EU should investigate this japanese company named Nintendo which seeks to make any sort of long-term preservation illegal. Why not allow them to burn down all our libraries while theyre at it??? If all knowledge and innovation ends up being proprietary it is doomed to vanish into the void, which makes me question how a society should make actual progress. The very progress the institutions of the EU are profiting from, as if we only need to defend the status quo, the European citizens will no longer need any European institution. So, in my eyes, the European Union as an entity should start to be a little selfish and strive to guarantee progress and innovation which strengthen the rights of its citizens, if only for self-preserving motives. Oh and before I forget: taking away the European citizens right to encrypt their communications? Hello? Why not fire every single European Commissioner and let Palantir run the place? Palantir being the US-based mass-surveillance company, which prides itself on camera that their product is used to kill people. Such a noble goal! Instead of stripping away rights from your citizens you should empower them a little more against such companies. Especially if these companies operate out of countries which are not our allies The European institutions could also set an example and stop supporting Microsoft by paying millions of licensing fees every year. Having pretty much every single pc in the European institutions run an operating system from a company that, again, is operating out of a foreign country that is not an ally of the EU very independent. <- this is sarcasm The EU should have created their own open-source operating system years ago. Look at valve, if a private company with 350 employees can pull it off, I am confident Europe with its half-a-billion citizens can do it, too! Apologies for the strong remarks

The role of open source is absolutely crucial if you want to have any sort of control over technology. What politicians need to understand is that tech companies, especially tech giants, don't care about laws or contracts, simply because in the vast majority of cases, you have no way to know they're actually following it, especially when their software is not open source, because there's no way to know what it's actually doing. This is bad for both the citizens and the government, because they're the ones who are actually in charge, at most they'll do you a favor by giving you *some* control over their products, but generally speaking, they work above the law and you probably don't even know it. Without open source, free software, open formats, and unlocked bootloaders, what you have is techno-fascism by corporations. Don't let that happen.

Adopting Open Source in EU is a critical matter especially when the proprietary alternatives are subject to non-EU laws. Open Source projects should be funded when they enable locals to compete internationally, and EU legislation must allow EU entities to be on-par with the rest of the world with a fair - but not suffocating - regulation and incentives, to attract talents and investors.

In short, it could be said that it's the design and development of open source. I know this is just feedback, and I thank you for giving us the opportunity to express our opinion. This is called direct democracy, and democracy exists in the EU. I know what I'm writing might seem "nationalistic," but I assure you it isn't. I'm just aware, like millions of other European citizens, that our long history isn't just about monuments. Yes, our monuments are wonderful, but what's even more wonderful is our awareness, through the history of every single country on this continent, that we have achieved democracy. Of course, sometimes democracy isn't perfect, but that's also its beauty. Many will wonder what European history has to do with open source. Apparently, it has absolutely nothing to do with it, but being tied to the clouds of other countries, even if they are allied with the EU, is not a positive thing. Nowadays, a citizen who decides to buy a PC can no longer be the administrator of his own PC as he was in the past. And if a simple citizen can't be the administrator and owner of his own PC, perhaps it doesn't matter much, but if it involves companies, sensitive state or institutional data, then it is. Serious. And this is where democracy comes in. It's true that the EU is heavily dependent on non-EU service providers, both in the private sector and in the public sectors of the member states. I wonder where the European institutions themselves store their sensitive datathe member states' ministries, such as Defense, Foreign Affairs, and Home Affairs, among others. The lack of such providers in Europe cannot be accepted as an excuse. The EU is far behind in this field, and not only that. But when Europe wants, it can, as in the case of the Airbus foundation, which is a rebuke to the fact that European states, when they want, not only can but are also capable of carrying out major projects. Europe has young people with the best IT backgrounds, eager to create projects. Being tied to companies doesn't help the productivity of European companies, but also the security of the companies themselves, the states, and the European institutions. Use and leverage open source The sector is not only possible, but Europe's duty. It must not only be funded but also supervised. I would suggest that institutional leaders not retire officials who are still very productive (at 66, a person who has spent their life not only developing programs but also managing projects is too young). I have several people to recommend, people with extensive experience both in the private sector and who have spent over twenty years in institutions... but I am a simple European citizen with no decision-making power except in my own home. So, in conclusion, yes to projects that strengthen freedom, sovereignty, and technology, because democracy must be preserved in this field too.

At the moment, some specific companies profit for the situations we are in right now. Like Microsoft being pushed onto students in all kind of places and recently caused a lot of harm to the environment with making perfectly working devices obsolete, with the end of life of Windows 10. Those devices still run perfectly fine, but people don't know or have no other option, because of the push to use one software from one company on every device. Furthermore, should money from the public be used for causes that help everyone and not one company in specific. This includes operating system, office suit and many more. While there are already are open source projects that do those things, Libreoffice, OnlyOffice or for operating system OpenSUSE and CachyOS with KDE when you look at Germany alone. But those can often not compete with bigger scale corporations because of their limited funding. While as example I have a PC from 2011 in my house, which wouldn't be supported under windows, but I was able to install Linux on it and still use it Then there is the problem with locked ecosystems like iOS from apple or soon to be android from Google. There are barely any options and they try to limit the options of usage you have in those devices even more. Google plans on only allowing to run Google approved programs, which would kill a lot of open source projects Then there is the problem of monopolies, that aren't able to be taken down, like WhatsApp, which ignore all senses of privacy, but you can't really get rid of it, because there is no open standard that everything has to use, which is also secure and end to end encrypted and if you use another messaging app it means you won't be able to write with people that don't have those. Which can mean you are excluded of updates for something like Work, Uni or other things Open source also gives options. As an example, if something like instagram introduces that they will use all posts to train AI you are still locked in. There is no option to leave, while with open source you can have something like mastodon, which is decentralized and if they go in a direction you don't like there will probably be a fork in the near future to go back to how it was before Or let's go to hardware. CMF Watch 2 Pro can't be used without an account. Means you spend money on hardware that you can't use on your own terms. At least not without an open source alternative, like Gadgetbridge (probably also at risk with the new Android rules) Which means you are either being spied on, limited by choice, locked in to an ecosystem, with only a theoretical option being available, as if you use that you are basically out of society Open source also means more local work. A lot of open source projects are at home in the eu, like CachyOS, OpenSUSE, KDE, Tuta, Filen, Tuxedo and so many more. And honestly maybe if we are lucky also fewer Monopolies, which would be better for everyone After all open source isn't just about freedom, it is about community, transparency, ownership and not for corporate greed And after all that, I have a request. Please put all the EU apps open source alternatives to the app stores of the devices, and if possible make them open source as well. That is how you show support

Hello, I am a Software Engineer with more than 10 years of experience, with a fair history of Open Source contributions. I'm answering the Call for Evidence, as requested. Without further ado, here's my feedback to the questions at hand: ## Adoption Proprietary software has benefited for years of large marketing budgets and other tactics to force increased adoption: Be it offering free/cheap licenses to universities, partnering with consulting companies to provide free/cheap certifications to consultants or simply paying influential users to use their platforms. A large organization like the EU can balance this: Using FOSS in schools, public projects and for external communications, but this doesn't seem to be happening right now, at least at a large scale. ## Sustainable contributions Those need either public funding or corporate sponsorship. Some EU countries have a good track record of funding such projects, but it would probably help to unify those initiatives in a EU-wide program with larger budgets. ## Added value It's quite rare to see large private software companies using Windows server (as opposed to Linux distributions) or Oracle DB/Microsoft SQL (as opposed to Postgres). FOSS or Open Core software is usually preferred due to cost an lock-in reasons. Consider the latest influx of FOSS/Open Core technologies being forked recently, after a licensing change. This was only possible because they picked an FOSS/Open Core solution in the first place. ## Concrete measures As mentioned above, the EU has to start using FOSS projects instead of promoting proprietary alternatives. There's a large history of high quality and high impact FOSS started in the EU. But they don't seem to be promoted by the EU itself. For example: ### Social Networks In 2022 the EDPS launched the EU Voice (based on Mastodon) and EU Video (based on PeerTube) platforms, which were discontinued 2 years later (The EU Voice project somewhat lives on as a Mastodon instance). I find two things here particularly egregious: One is the lack of usage of these services by official EU bodies, the other is the lack of visible ActivityPub social buttons on websites when compared to competitors. ### Mobile Devices The Mobile ecosystem is dominated by proprietary non-EU based Operative Systems, namely iOS and Android, controlled by Apple and Google. There are quite some Linux based alternatives (some of them with proprietary components) that all face one particular issue: Lack of apps. They usually are able to mitigate this by supporting Android Apps, this support is a bit limited, specifically due to dependencies on Google private libraries, like Google Play Services. As such, one way that the EU could foster the development of alternative mobile operative systems is by enforcing that apps that are considered essential (e.g. anything related to EUDI) can be executed in systems without proprietary components. ### Open Hardware This call for evidence mentions RISC-V. I was a bit disappointed that the "Call for expression of interest in AI Gigafactories" from April 2025 does not have a single mention of RISC-V, while it does mention "Reference here is NVIDIAs H100 GPUs or equivalent". As far as I am aware, there's no RISC-V AI coprocessor equivalent to H100, so this is effectively a grant to buy NVIDIA and AMD hardware, reinforcing their leading position. The EU already has the DARE project to develop RISC-V AI chips, but if those chips are not generally available, the software ecosystem around them will not grow, and they will never be competitive. One way to tackle this is to give incentives to European cloud providers to make RISC-V CPUs available, in the same way that they receive incentives to create AI Gigafactories with GPUs. Most EU Cloud providers don't even have RISC-V offerings (with Scaleway's RISC-V offerings as an exception). I would elaborate more, but the character limit sto
