feedback: As a senior ecommerce manager with 15 years of experience, it is evident to me that we need to explore open source solutions for productivity, coworking and file sharing, OS, online-payments etc. Large parts of our european ecommerce infrastructure are built on proprietary software with massive single-points-of-failure. Only through an initiative spearheaded by the EU can we create proper alternatives that will lead more economic growth and security.

We need open source software in place of all critical infrastructure. It is the only way to ensure proper and independent governance for all EU citizens. If we continue to rely on foreign companies to provide the software, we risk to remain open to blackmail by them and their government! Only if we cultivate a strong and independent IT sector ourselves, can we ensure that our data is save and secure. We cannot risk Palantir and/or other private co-operations with exclusive deals and access to personal data and government internals. To ensure a stable democracy; FOSS is the only way forward.

As a developer and user of open source applications I think the most urgent and important thing EU can do to promote open source communities is to secure platforms our software runs on. Currently Linux offers great, open platform to for out computers but two other very important platforms, Mobile and Web, are controlled by American corporations. On Mobile the only available options are iOS and Android. iOS was always hard to access for open source developers but now Google is actively trying to lock down Android as well. New requirements for Android developers (Developer Verification program) and progressive locking on the Android Open Source Project mean that many open source developers will no longer be able to distribute their apps to majority of Android users using certified versions of Android and alternative version are in danger if not being able to continue development. Quick and decisive action to ensure the mobile platform stays open is needed. To achieve this alternative version of Android need to be supported and the ability to install then on phones guaranteed. Ideally, full functionality of all apps should be ensured on phones that do not use any of Google's proprietary services. Today we use open apps for everything: communications, banking, accessing public services and so on. Ensuring that mobile platform is accessible to open source community is crucial. At the same time Web platform is also dominated by Google. To guarantee free, secure and private access to the web alternative browsers must be supported and promoted. Firefox, Servo and Ladybird are crucial project for the open source community.

Opensource software and operating system are really better overally. In my opinion schools, public institutions MUST use ONLY opensource software, with enormous advantages in financial saving, distributed cognition, technological upgrade. It's time to detach Italy and Europe from proprietary sofware.

Alternative operative system to microsoft windows and tech giants services. I been a gamer and used computer since 1990. And honestly i think its great. The major reason why i dident use linux more in the past is that my games did not work BUT now 90% of them do work on linux. This is fantastic and i have been using linux for gaming for about 5 month and 90% of all my games work perfect and many even better on linux vs windows that they where designed to run on. My suggestion for the future. Everytime you buy a new computer it comes with windows preinstalled and that is how windows become so dominent for ordinary consumers since they never get a choice. THis is not good for independence or open source since the tech industry is so powerfull they just design the systems so you have no real choise but to use their service. Even if this data is encrypted they can get info about who talk to who and when and from what IP / phone number. Peoples passwords are terrible and we need new standards and default encryption and so on. And we also need a right to be forgotten in the healthcare system. Today its impossible to have our data deleted or corrected if there are mistakes. ( example in Denmark ) we can only have attached a yellow note that we do not agree so the falce info follow you around for a life time. In general we need human digital rights that protect us against state survaliance and registration what goes on in secrety is a c

feedback: Sono favorevole all'adozione di software open source e con dati gestiti e conservati in server europei. Non solo aziende ma anche entità statali oramai sono esempi che dimostrano che è una soluzione possibile. L'open source da libertà di scelta, favorisce il miglioramento tecnologico, consente un pieno controllo dei dati, consente alle aziende di adottare soluzioni più consistenti alle proprie necessità.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: I am in favour of the adoption of open-source software with data managed and stored on European servers. Not only companies but also state entities are now examples that show that this is a possible solution. Open source, with freedom of choice, fosters technological improvement, allows full control of data, allows companies to adopt more robust solutions to their needs.

feedback: I will go through each proposed question. Im not affiliated with any project/company mentioned. Strengths/weaknesses; barriers to adoption/maintenance; sustainable contributions? ---- Open source is inherently global; I interpret EU open-source sector as EU-based contributors/companies/public administrations and EU policy levers within a global ecosystem. Adoption barriers are usually not license cost but practical factors: - "As is" supply: organizations may need an accountable counterparty (contract, support/SLA, liability). - Certification/audit constraints: costly and hard for underfunded projects. - Integration/migration costs - Documentation that lags development. Maintenance: many critical components are run by tiny teams/volunteers; funding is often far below the value created. Security reports/CVEs/coordinated disclosure timelines can overwhelm maintainers. Security: C/C++ are powerful but prone to memory-safety bugs with severe consequences; multiple government bodies recommend moving to memory-safe languages where feasible (e.g., Rust, Go). Examples: https://media.defense.gov/2022/Nov/10/2003112742/-1/-1/1/CSI_SOFTWARE_MEMORY_SAFETY.PDF https://bidenwhitehouse.archives.gov/wp-content/uploads/2024/02/Final-ONCD-Technical-Report.pdf This doesnt mean existing C/C++ projects are "bad"; for new publicly funded, security-sensitive software, a reasonable default is "memory-safe unless justified otherwise." Added value for public/private sectors? ---- - Transparency/auditability: independent review; easier to detect defects or malicious changes (especially when well-resourced/actively reviewed). - Reduced lock-in: easier to switch vendors, self-host, or keep a project alive via forks if a vendor disappears. - Talent identification/development: public portfolios; peer feedback via pull/merge requests or patches. - Innovation/diffusion: learn from prior projects; experiment faster. - Institutional legitimacy: when public services handle citizen data, open sourcing components (where feasible) reduces the need for blind trust. Supply-chain risks exist in all models; closed source lacks many of these benefits while still having vulnerabilities. Concrete EU-level measures for sovereignty/cybersecurity? ---- 1. Transparent funding for critical OSS: citizen/stakeholder-directed allocations of tax funds, with eligibility focused on widely used critical infrastructure (networking, crypto, toolchains/compilers, OS components, cloud/container stack), plus governance/auditability. 2. Promote memory-safe languages and safer-by-default practices for new, security-critical software (exceptions via justification). 3. Support reproducible builds/verifiable supply chains: https://reproducible-builds.org/ (users install binaries; reproducibility helps ensure binaries match source). 4. Encourage EU-hosted and/or self-hostable dev infrastructure (code hosting, CI/CD, registries) to reduce dependence on a single non-EU platform; e.g., Codeberg (Germany), self-hosted GitLab. 5. Require adequate documentation for publicly funded projects. 6. Support creation/legal structuring of foundations or companies around OSS projects; e.g., Red Hat-style open source with paid support. 7. Make it easier to contract maintainers to adapt almost there OSS (features/certifications) when funding is attached. Finally, when software is delivered as a service, users cant verify what code actually runs server-side. Where feasible, encourage local-first designs, data minimisation, and self-hostable options to align transparency with real-world verifiability and improve resilience (fewer central points of failure). Im available to discuss further and can be reached via LinkedIn.

I am a software engineer with many years of professional experience who lives and works in the EU. The single most impactful thing the EU could do in order to preserve and expand its digital sovereignty is to repeal its anti-circumvention laws (specifically, the Copyright and Information Society Directive 2001, article 6, which obigates member states to pass and enforce laws criminalising the reverse-engineering of certain technologies). These laws were written at the behest of the US, under pressure, in order to maintain access to preferential tariffs and trading agreements. As the US has proven itself to be an unreliable trading partner, it no longer makes sense to keep these laws on the books. They hinder European innovation. Without them, European technologists and companies would be empowered and incentivised to find ways to mitigate against the monopolitistic practices of American tech giants. This could even become a massive growth industry, in a trading and political bloc that sorely needs it. Another likely benefit would be a massive cost reduction in IT and infrastructure spending, as these solutions could be open-sourced and made freely available for all to use; governments, small companies, non-profits and private individuals would almost overnight have access to many solutions, tools and products whose creation was previously needlessly and counter-productively criminalised. These laws benefit no-one other than the U.S. tech sector.

Ritengo che lUnione Europea debba adottare una strategia chiara e coerente sulluso del software open source, per garantire autonomia, sicurezza e interoperabilità delle proprie infrastrutture digitali. In particolare, propongo quanto segue: Indipendenza da fornitori privati: Le entità pubbliche europee non dovrebbero dipendere da aziende private come Microsoft, Amazon, Google o Oracle, che oltretutto non sono sotto il diretto controllo dellUnione. Questa dipendenza comporta rischi strategici, di sicurezza e di interoperabilità, oltre a costi legati a licenze proprietarie. Ladozione di soluzioni open source europee può ridurre significativamente tali rischi, garantendo trasparenza del codice e controllo completo sulle proprie infrastrutture. Definizione di linee guida comuni: LUE dovrebbe definire linee guida ufficiali relative a: * Infrastruttura cloud pubblica e privata * Sistema operativo per le postazioni di lavoro e server * Suite per lufficio e la produttività (word processor, fogli di calcolo, strumenti di collaborazione) Sviluppo e finanziamento di implementazioni ufficiali: LUE dovrebbe finanziare lo sviluppo di una implementazione ufficiale delle linee guida, che sia pronta alluso e accessibile gratuitamente a tutte le istituzioni europee e ai cittadini. Lobiettivo non è imporre soluzioni uniche, ma fornire una base stabile, affidabile e conforme agli standard definiti. Esempi concreti esistono già: SUSE rappresenta un esempio di sistema operativo europeo open source, e OnlyOffice mostra come una suite office open source possa essere pienamente compatibile con Microsoft Office, anche nella semplicità di utilizzo, offrendo al contempo indipendenza tecnologica. Supporto allinnovazione e soluzioni alternative: Chiunque desideri sviluppare nuovi sistemi operativi o suite office può farlo liberamente, purché rispetti le linee guida di interoperabilità e sicurezza definite dallUE. Questo approccio consente di avere unalternativa ufficiale già pronta, senza ostacolare linnovazione e lo sviluppo di soluzioni terze. Obiettivo finale: Garantire che lUnione Europea disponga di strumenti digitali ufficiali, sicuri, interoperabili e gratuiti, riducendo la dipendenza da aziende esterne e promuovendo al contempo lecosistema open source europeo. In questo modo, lUE può rafforzare la propria sovranità digitale, fornire soluzioni immediate e standardizzate per le istituzioni e incentivare lo sviluppo tecnologico competitivo allinterno dellEuropa.
feedbackTextUserLanguage:
I believe that the European Union should adopt a clear and consistent strategy on the use of open source software to ensure the autonomy, security and interoperability of its digital infrastructure. In particular, I propose that the Court should: Independence from private suppliers: European public entities should not be dependent on private companies such as Microsoft, Amazon, Google or Oracle, which are also not under the direct control of the Union. This dependency entails strategic, security and interoperability risks, as well as costs related to proprietary licensing. The deployment of European open source solutions can significantly reduce these risks by ensuring code transparency and comprehensive control over its infrastructure. Definition of common guidelines: The EU should establish official guidelines on: * Public and private cloud infrastructure * Operating system for workstations and servers * Word processor, spreadsheets, collaboration tools Development and financing of official implementations: The EU should finance the development of an official implementation of the guidelines, which should be ready for use and accessible free of charge to all European institutions and citizens. The aim is not to impose one-size-fits-all solutions, but to provide a stable, reliable basis that meets the defined standards. Concret

feedback: Although the initiative is good, the question leans too heavily on which Open Source Software (OSS) should be supported and how. In essence, it does not matter which OSS package is used, as long as any given OSS package can be deployed competitively. To create market conditions that make the deployment of OSS feasible, it is essential to embrace open standards. Much of our dependency on proprietary software is locked into the (semi) closed file formats and communication protocols used. Microsoft Office formats lock us into MS Office and, by extension, Windows or the MS cloud. WhatsApp binds us to Metas silo. X (formerly Twitter) binds us to Elon Musks X companies, and so on. For many of these closed formats and services, open alternatives exist. However, these do not gain traction because network effects keep people bound to the closed formats and services. The government can provide a positive impulse by adopting open standards. Do not use Microsoft document formats for government communication, but mandate the truly open ODF (Open Document Format). With this adoption, it becomes possible to use various alternative office software suites without sacrificing interoperability. As a government, do not communicate via X or BlueSky, but via Mastodon. Mastodon can be self-hosted and has multiple clients for communication. For direct messaging, do not use WhatsApp or Teams. Use Matrix, Signal, or Nextcloud Talk. The goal is to solve the 'chicken and egg' problem. If open document formats, open coding formats for image and sound, and open protocols for communication are deployed, the lock-in of the tech giants is broken. Europeans generally do not use OSS because the services used are closed, and the protocols and formats bind us to American companies. By switching to open alternatives for documents, media, and communication, the government can provide the incentive to deploy more OSS software. If the proprietary barrier to collaboration falls, it removes the obstacles for OSS to offer competitive software. An additional advantage is that embracing open standards does not exclude the proprietary software industry; however, because of the open standards, these software providers cannot establish a lock-in. This creates an open playing field. N.B.! Be careful that no closed extensions are created on top of the open standards. That would nullify the benefit.

I've been working as a Linux system engineer for over 25 years and one thing is clear: open-source software is a game changer, not just for private households and businesses, from small startups to large enterprises, but also for governments and the EU! When governments move to open-source, theyre not just cutting out the high costs of proprietary software, theyre freeing up resources to invest in public services and infrastructure. But the real power? Control. Open-source means full ownership and control over both your software and data. No more relying on Microsoft, Google, or Amazon, whose cloud services often store data overseas, placing it under foreign jurisdiction. Lets be real, they dont always follow GDPR to the letter. Your data can get shared internally or, worse, handed off without proper oversight (believe me, this happens more than you think). Then theres security. With open-source, governments arent stuck waiting on a corporation to fix flaws or patch vulnerabilities. They can look at the code (since its public), see what's going on and fix issues themselves. Its about moving faster, not being tied to slow-moving proprietary systems. Plus, it reduces reliance on a handful of companies controlling everything from software to cloud to AI development. And guess whose data they use to train their AI models? In addition, Linux isnt just a powerful operating system for servers, but its also a robust, reliable and user-friendly (free of charge) option for desktops. I work with Linux on both servers and desktop every day, and its more than capable of handling all tasks efficiently. Tools like LibreOffice and open-source communication platforms (Jitsi, Matrix aso.) not only eliminate costly software licenses, but they also offer security and transparency that proprietary systems cant match. Plus, they empower users to modify and adapt the software to meet their unique needs. Even better? You can host these tools yourself, giving you full control over your communications and data, without relying on external services. In a world where geopolitical tensions are rising, especially with political shifts in the USA, relying on a few global tech giants for critical infrastructure is risky. Open-source empowers governments to stay secure, keep data in-house and reduce dependence on corporations that may not have their best interests at heart. It also drives competition and innovation, enabling governments to lead in technology rather than be at the mercy of external players. Plus, embracing open-source creates jobs, stimulates local economies and strengthens a self-sustaining tech ecosystem. You have my contact information, if youre interested in discussing how open-source can strengthen the EU governments infrastructure, feel free to reach out. I'd be more than happy to share my insights and experience. Thank you for considering the significant advantages that open-source software can offer in building a more resilient, secure and sustainable digital future for all of us.

feedback: The strategy is clear, timely, and highly impactful. It strongly underscores the need for the EU to achieve technological autonomy independent of other global superpowers, positioning open source as a key driver of sovereignty, security, and long-term competitiveness.

Open software has been a huge help for me in both professional and personal aspects. The principles of free and open source software safeguard against changes made by unaccountable corportations and allow the users to take software in a more desirable and inclusive direction. In an age of American tech behemoths and and increasingly unaccountable American regime I think the virtues of open source are heighten even more. Further more the nature of open software makes public auditing of possible mistakes in code transparent and easier to spot. Open source is more secure not less. Finally, I believe large scale adoption and investment by a block as large as the EU is would drive up interest in volunteer development and investment into said software, which would make it influential world wide and put the EU digital sector in a powerful position as one of if not the main driver of innovation and development in a field that impacts our lives more and more.

EU is an important contributor to open source, with contributions such as Linux, Drupal, Odoo, etc. However, most economic revenues from these contributions are harvested abroad. Even the hosting of open source is owned abroad (e.g. GitHub owned by Microsoft). It is important to coordinate and repatriate these vital assets. Public procurement can play an important role. Important contributions should also be rewarded through e.g. prizes. Open source supply chains should be hardened against malevolent contributors. A first step in this direction is a strong european authentification framework, expected for very long.

First, opensource gives us real control over the software we run. When the code is public, we can inspect it, modify it, and host it wherever we choose on our own servers, on a trusted cloud, or even on a local machine. That means were not forced to rely on a foreign vendor whose business model might clash with EU dataprivacy rules or who could ban us overnight. Being able to run the same software inside a government agency, a university lab, or a small startup without paying licence fees is a huge advantage for budgetconscious organisations across the bloc. Security is another strong point. With closedsource binaries you have to trust the vendors word that there are no hidden backdoors. In the opensource world anyone can look at the source, spot a flaw, and propose a fix. Vulnerabilities tend to get patched faster because the whole community, researchers, security firms, hobbyists can contribute. That collective scrutiny is far harder to achieve with proprietary stacks. From an economic perspective, opensource lowers the barrier to entry for new ideas. A developer can take an existing library, adapt it to a niche problem, and ship a product without paying royalties. That speeds up innovation and creates jobs in the EU tech sector. Companies can also avoid vendor lockin, which keeps competition healthy and prices reasonable for customers. Interoperability is baked into many open standards. When software follows a public specification, data can move between tools without getting stuck in a proprietary format. This fits nicely with the EUs goal of a seamless digital market where a service built in Berlin can talk to one in Madrid without extra adapters. Why social presence of EU need to focus on Mastodon? Mastodon is a social platform built on the ActivityPub protocol, which is an open, federated standard. Each instance is just a regular server running the same opensource code. Anyone can spin up an instance under local jurisdiction, enforce regional dataprotection rules, and still communicate with users on other instances worldwide (like Email server in a more modern way). That gives us sovereignty our data stays where we decide, but it doesnt isolate us. The network remains a single, interconnected space, unlike a closed platform that decides who gets to see what. The federated model also adds resilience. If one server crashes or is taken down, the rest of the network keeps working. No single point of failure, no single entity that can censor everything. For public bodies or NGOs that need reliable communication channels, that redundancy is valuable. To make the most of this, the EU should keep funding core opensource projects and the standards they rely on, like ActivityPub. Public institutions could start by migrating official communication tools to your selfhosted Mastodon instances, showing that a sovereign yet open network works in practice. Providing clear guidelines for secure deployment and regular audits would help organisations feel safe adopting these tools. In short, opensource lets us keep control, improve security, foster innovation, and stay interoperable, all while keeping costs low. Decentralised platforms such as Mastodon prove that we can protect our digital sovereignty without cutting ourselves off from the rest of the internet. By backing these technologies, we preserve the freedom to shape our own digital future while staying connected to the global community.

Verso una piena Sovranità Digitale Federale attraverso l'Open Source e l'Indipendenza Industriale. In quanto cittadino europeo, accolgo con favore questa iniziativa, ritenendola un pilastro fondamentale per la maturazione dell'Unione. Il mio contributo si focalizza su tre direttrici essenziali. 1. Indipendenza Infrastrutturale e Software (Full-Stack): L'Europa deve perseguire una sovranità digitale assoluta che superi le attuali sfere d'influenza geopolitiche. Questo richiede un impegno concreto per lo sviluppo e l'adozione di ecosistemi basati su Linux e standard aperti a ogni livello: dal cloud computing ai sistemi operativi desktop e mobile, garantendo che l'infrastruttura critica dell'Unione sia trasparente, verificabile e autonoma. 2. Accessibilità e UX (User Experience): L'Open Source non deve rimanere uno strumento per soli addetti ai lavori. Per una vera transizione digitale, è necessario investire nella "fruibilità" del software libero. I sistemi aperti devono diventare intuitivi, moderni e meno macchinosi, affinché cittadini e imprese possano adottarli senza barriere tecniche, rendendo la scelta open la scelta più naturale e semplice. 3. Produzione Industriale in Scala: La sovranità software è incompleta senza quella hardware. È urgente un progetto industriale serio per la produzione europea di hardware, sia per il settore Cloud/Data Center che per il mercato consumer. La capacità di produrre i propri dispositivi e server è propedeutica e coadiuvante alla sicurezza e alla crescita economica di un'Europa che aspiri a una configurazione federale forte e matura. In sintesi, l'Open Source deve essere il motore di un'Europa capace di costruire il proprio futuro digitale senza dipendenze esterne, unendo l'eccellenza tecnica alla facilità d'uso per tutti i suoi cittadini. Cordiali Saluti, Ferdinando Mongillo
feedbackTextUserLanguage: Towards full Federal Digital Sovereignty through Open Source and Industrial Independence. As a European citizen, I welcome this initiative, considering it a fundamental pillar for the maturing of the Union. My contribution focuses on three key strands. 1. Independence of Infrastructure and Software (Full-Stack): Europe must pursue absolute digital sovereignty that goes beyond the current geopolitical spheres of influence. This requires a concrete commitment to the development and adoption of ecosystems based on Linux and open standards at all levels: from cloud computing to desktop and mobile operating systems, ensuring that the Union’s critical infrastructure is transparent, verifiable and autonomous. 2. Accessibility and UX (User Experience): The Open Source must not remain a tool for practitioners alone. For a true digital transition, it is necessary to invest in the “usability” of free software. Open systems need to become intuitive, modern and less cumbersome, so that citizens and businesses can adopt them without technical barriers, making choice more natural and simple. 3. Industrial production in Scala: Software sovereignty is incomplete without hardware sovereignty. There is an urgent need for a serious industrial project for European hardware production, both for the Cloud/Data Center sector and for the consumer market. The ability to produce its own devices and servers is a prerequisite for, and an adjuvant to, the security and economic growth of a Europe that aspires to a strong and mature federal configuration. In short, Open Source must be the engine of a Europe capable of building its own digital future without external dependencies, combining technical excellence with user-friendliness for all its citizens. Best regards, Ferdinando Mongillo

feedback: Verplicht softwareleveranciers om hun broncode open te publiceren van elke versie die ze niet meer actief ondersteunen (bijv. Windows7, Word95, Oracle9). Dat dwingt hen ofwel verlengd te ondersteunen ofwel om open te worden. Maak een project voor een EU open source operating system (gebaseerd op Linux of gebruik en support Linux), een project voor een open source office-suite (incl. tekstverwerking, spreadsheet, presentatie en e-mail of liever gebruik en support LibreOffice). Subsidieer overheden en bedrijven die willen overstappen en subsidieer bedrijven die opleidingen aanbieden voor open tools. Borg de overgang in wetgeving. De Nederlandse overheid heeft dit al jarem verzuimd, waardoor nieuwe bestuurders steds opnieuw de discussie kunnen starten.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: Requires software providers to publish their source code of any version that they no longer actively support (e.g. Windows 7, Word95, Oracle9). This forces them to either support them for a longer period or to be open. Create an EU open source operating system project (based on Linux or use and support Linux), an open source office suite project (incl. word processing, spreadsheet, presentation and email or prefer use and support LibreOffice). Subsidise public authorities and companies that want to switch and subsidise companies that offer training for open tools. Ensure the transition into legislation. The Dutch authorities have already omitted to do so, which means that new drivers can systematically restart the discussion.

feedback: As a long-term user of free and open-source software and a programmer who often uses FOSS in my daily work I would love to see public institutions of all the EU states to support and use free and open source solutions instead of relying on, mostly American, proprietary ones. I would like to see increased funding and state-level protection of open-source software, specifically I imagine solutions similar to these ideas to be beneficial both to FOSS ecosystem and to the EU (as its sponsor and user) and its citizens: 1. Formal requirement of all software whose creation was publicly commissioned (and thus paid for by the EU citizens) to be released on open-source licenses so that it is available to the citizens to audit and modify (eg. porting public software to platforms not officially supported by the state). The exceptions could be made for software involving classified intellectual property in carefully considered military and security sectors. This would allow the state to easily switch providers and maintainers of the software publicly commissioned and used (any company hired to maintain it could have previously familiarize themselves with it), and it would give the citizens better control over the software paid for from their money. 2. Public fund to support open source and an open source tax. Since most (all?) big tech companies these days rely on free and open source components, they should help fund them just like users of public infrastructure and services contribute to funding those through taxes. So it would make sense to require any company using open source components in their products or the IT infrastructure they maintain as part of their operations (ie. any company directly benefiting from FOSS), above certain minimal annual income threshold, to pay small tax from their income. The threshold would need to be such as to not be a burden to small businesses and start-ups which should not be afraid of joining the FOSS community and benefit from it. Any company, if such exist, able to prove they do not directly depend on any open source components would be free from the tax. Any company releasing their software as open source would also be free from paying. The tax money would go to the fund which then would be used to financially support organizations maintaining open source projects. Such tax should depend only on the fact of using open source components not on the types or amount of open source projects used, as to not discourage anyone from using FOSS if they use any. The aim is not to encourage existing users of FOSS to start relying only on closed solutions moving forward. Scheme of this type would ensure big commercial users of open source projects contribute at least a little back and EU structures would also have control over significant funding of FOSS projects. Implementing such fund and tax would require, though, establishing a body overseeing the fund, deciding on who benefits from it and what the process of using the fund is.

feedback: 1. Technological Sovereignty & Strategic Autonomy. Open source software (OSS) reduces dependency on proprietary technologies controlled by non-EU entities. By fostering homegrown open digital assets, the EU can: - Control critical infrastructure: Avoid vendor lock-in and ensure resilience in key sectors (e.g., healthcare, energy, defense). - Set global standards: Lead in defining open, interoperable frameworks that reflect EU values (privacy, transparency, ethics). - Future-proof innovation: Open source enables rapid adaptation to emerging technologies (AI, quantum computing, IoT) without reliance on external actors. 2. Security & Trust: - Transparency as a safeguard: Open source code allows for continuous peer review, reducing vulnerabilities and enabling faster patching (e.g., Linux, OpenSSL). - EU-led security standards: Collaborative development within the EU can embed robust security-by-design principles, aligning with GDPR and the Cybersecurity Act. - Resilience against supply chain risks: Diversified, community-driven development mitigates risks from single points of failure or geopolitical tensions. 3. Economic Competitiveness & Innovation: - Cost efficiency: Open source reduces licensing fees, freeing resources for R&D and SME growth. - Level playing field: SMEs and startups can compete with tech giants by building on shared open assets, fostering a vibrant EU digital economy. - Job creation: Open source ecosystems create high-skilled jobs in software development, maintenance, and cybersecurity 4. Public Sector Leadership & Citizen Trust - Digital public goods: Open source aligns with the EUs commitment to digital commons (e.g., FIWARE, NextCloud), ensuring public services are accessible, auditable, and citizen-centric. - Interoperability: Open standards enable seamless cross-border services (e.g., eHealth, digital identity), supporting the Single Market. - Democratic values: Open source reflects EU principles of openness, collaboration, and inclusivity, strengthening public trust in digital transformation. 5. Operational Framework for the Commission - Reuse and scalability: The Commission can leverage existing open assets (e.g., EUPL-licensed software) to avoid duplication and accelerate digitalization. - Collaborative governance: Partner with member states, academia, and industry to co-develop solutions (e.g., OSOR.eu, GAIA-X). - Skills development: Invest in open source training programs to upskill the EU workforce and bridge the digital divide. 6. Global Leadership & Soft Power - Diplomatic leverage: The EU can promote open source as a tool for digital diplomacy, partnering with like-minded regions (e.g., US, India, Africa) on shared challenges. - Ethical tech exports: EU-open source solutions can become global benchmarks for ethical, sustainable technology. Why this matters now: The global digital landscape is fragmented by proprietary silos and geopolitical rivalries. By championing open source, the EU can assert its sovereignty, drive innovation, and model a collaborative, values-based approach to technology, setting a precedent for the 21st century.

Der bør sikres åbne standarder for data og dataudveksling. Dette sker som regelkrav, som leverandører skal leve op til for at kunne bruges af offentlige organisationer. Derudover incitamenter til at andre virksomheder og organisationer anvender disse åbne standarder. Derudover bør EU anbefale en software-pakke, der implementerer de ovennævnte standarder, men der skal ikke stilles krav til at det netop er disse der anvendes, de skal udelukkende demonstrere, at det kan lade sig gøre, og være "det lette valg" for almindelige brugere.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: Open standards for data and data exchange should be ensured. This takes the form of regulatory requirements that suppliers must comply with in order to be used by public organisations. In addition, incentives for other companies and organisations to use these open standards. In addition, the EU should recommend a software package implementing the above standards, but there should be no requirement for these to be used, to demonstrate only that this is feasible and to be the “easy choice” for ordinary users.

feedback: 1. Strengths of the Open-Source(Free Software)-Sector include the auditability and adaptivity of software. In effect, a Free Software offering can be independently audited for security flaws, and adapted (forked) to suit the needs of the end user with zero organizational red tape. The Weakness of this is, unfortunately, the fact that it is free. Maintainers and developers of Free Software (with a few exceptions) do not get paid for their work, and therefore have to relegate maintenance of their software offerings to their free time, reducing oversight, quality and therefore security of the software. 2. An Open-Source election software can be audited for security flaws that might jeopardize operations. Accounting Software can be adapted for the specific transactions that take place in that organization. 3. Anti-circumvention laws (i.e. Article 6 of the 2001 European Copyright Directive) grant (US-)companies a monoply over their hard- and software offerings, and technologies therein. Repealing, or at least softening, these would ease the lives of European developers creating competitive alternative offerings for the domestic market. The Sovereign Technology Fund should be expanded to more Software projects and be given more resources. 4. - Critical, low-level libraries (e.g. libxml). These are generally maintained by one person and lack funding while having a gigantic userbase. - Hardware, particularly in the networking space. Currently, the Internet is run entirely on US technology, containing state-mandated backdoors beholdent to an unpredictable administration. It is not unthinkable that this could be weaponized against Europe in a potential conflict. 5. Given that just about every aspect of modern life is defined by software, any critical infrastructure (Utility Companies, Manufacturing, Farming Equipment, ...) would benefit from auditable, resilient software offerings. In my professional opinion any generative AI ventures can be safely ignored. If there was a market for the technology we would have seen profitable companies in the field by 2024 at the latest.

I fully support this initiative. The use of Open Source Software helps in reducing electronic waste by allowing the repurposing of hardware that is otherwise unsupported by proprietary software. This is extremely important in an age where we need to implement better strategies for the handling of older electronic devices as they are, more often than not, subject to software-based obsolescence. Funding developers to work on Open Source implementations for critical software also lets that software (and thus the hardware it's installed on) be supported for far longer (and for a wider hardware base), as its modification and thus support is not tied to the whims of a select group of people. We cannot maintain a cycle of consuming hardware products only for them to get essentially "locked down" by the software proprietor after a few years, generally through the unwillingness for them to maintain software optimized for the performance and specifications of such hardware. This has major ties to the ecology as supporting hardware with properly optimized software greatly delays the need for recycling such hardware. Technological infrastructure in critical spaces like hospitals and government buildings, as well as education spaces and other data-sensitive institutions would be able to easily get access to the latest security updates if they were encouraged and funded to transition towards using Open Source software, including Open Source Operating Systems, as those tend to function in a continuous release update cycle that is not limited to get stopped by a limited group of proprietors. If an Open Source program loses support from its original developers, any other group of developers can start working on that code without any licensing fees or delays, and security research can be done on that software for quick patching and pushing of security updates. The COVID-19 pandemic has shown that it is of utmost importance for critical infrastructure to always be up to date with current digital safety standards, and that is best achieved by letting the wider developer community look into the source code of software and patch it as needed. Obfuscation by closing access to the source code is not efficient as proprietary software too is victim of a significant number of malicious attacks. Thank you for taking this issue seriously.

I am posting this as a private EU citizen, but I own an IT shop since many years here in Italy. We, as in the EU population, NEED to get rid of anything that isn't open source or directly tied to us europeans. We need social and financial independence from the other powers of the world that are closing in, we need to stand as the last place where freedom truly exist, and all of this cannot happen as long as we are dependant on USA's, China's etc and their technology. I work with PC and fix them everyday, for a living; I can tell you that the average person will not see any difference between Windows and Linux Mint, between Office and Open Office. The transitional period could last a month at most, since as of now Linux and Open Source alternatives are pretty much the same as paid for private apps. This is what I would expect if no EU state (or an EU private company) steps in and decides to create or modify an existing linux OS or an existing open source office alternative. Please, for our future, let the EU be as indipendent as possible, only this way we can fight the rise of extremists in the other parts of the world that keep threatening our ways of life.

We need to encourage companies to make Open-Source software, as transparency is one key value of a good working democracy. It would make sure constituents know where their software is from, what it contains and how their data is stored and managed. Likewise, code for public services, official apps, websites, and others should also be Open-Source as our tax money pays for it. Additionally, it would mean that talents across the EU could even participate in the improvement of EU platforms and tools. More funding for independent projects would be welcome, lots of Open-Source components are often maintained by a single developer who has been on the task for years, for instance, citing cURL which has been under the direction of Daniel Stenberg since its inception. Some are breaking the boundaries of the digital realm, such as Overte, which is maintained by a small team, but lacks proper funding to realise its full vision. I believe that anti-circumvention laws are to be revoked to stay competitive, and so European developers can make the tools to escape large United-Statesian silos. For instance, an Apple jailbreak made in the EU would mean that the Apple platform could finally comply with DMA, in addition to giving users more freedom of use over their device. Same with social media, if a European social media platform were to appear, legally having the legal right to make a tool to ease the migration of European users from United-Statesian silos to said platform would mean a great boost for the social network itself, the company making it, and the economy. Another case would be with sensitive equipment, such as medical equipment: if a company decides to remotely disable the equipment, with anti-circumvention laws blocking any path of self-repair, our sensitive infrastructure is at risk of being remotely locked without being able to do anything about it. Additionally, software that reaches end-of-life should also have its source code released for several reasons: 1. This software is not generating any kind of revenue for the company any more. 2. Companies and citizens might be still relying on that software for various reasons and might want to patch bugs and improve it. 3. It would allow companies and developers to know how the software works, to ensure a better interoperability in the ecosystem. Open-Source in general is also a tremendous resource for educational means. An open software is one you can learn from, not only from its function, but also from its inner workings. This could in term encourage more young Europeans to pursue a path in computer engineering and related fields, thus making Europe more educated, and more competitive. To sum up, an open Europe would be a safer one with more oversights, more checks and more trust. It would make us stronger by the fact of being independent on the software side while assuring citizen's rights are being respected via transparency. While Open-Source isn't a magical solution to all issues, it does offer considerable benefits, especially in this time in which our allies are keen to backstab us with sanctions and tariffs. To work, Open-Source needs to be encouraged, if not mandated in some cases, but also funded properly so European talents, new and old alike can make everybody else benefit from it.

I am completely in favor of open source technology. Office suites, operating systems, mobile and desktop, etc. Counting on EU commission for boosting this tech because many of these alternatives to American infrastructures do not have accessibility in mind. I am a blind accessibility consultant, and only if EU with its European accessibility acts pushes forwards with this open source matter, developers and organizers will feel motivated to invest and work on accessibility, because us, blind people, are the most vulnerable in american tech surveillance.

Free and Open Source Software (FOSS) alternatives to proprietary software have allowed me to flee from anti-consumer and monopolizing measures put in place by tech giants like Microsoft, Google, and other conglomerates. Because its code is open to view, my private data is safely handled by software I can truly trust. Open-source code is more reviewed, can be verified, and is discloses what it does on your machine, making it the gold standard for crucial security components for encryption and malware resilience. On the other hand, proprietary code applies security through obscurity, which means less reviews of the code, non-disclosure of what is done by the code, and it is impossible for the community to contribute, which prevents the software from being extended for and by individuals in need of certain things, like accessibility for the blind, language translations, security enhancements, and a plethora of other small changes that make FOSS much more consumer-friendly. Proprietary software can also be changed for the worse, or even discontinued, with no way to roll back, while FOSS can be forked, continued independently of the original developers, and handled democratically by the community. FOSS is almost never developped for profit, but to solve a problem, making it exceptionally ethical in its approaches. I truly hope the EU will continue to increase support of FOSS, because it can solve problems in a democratic, sovereign, secure, and ethical manner.

feedback: Totally favorable. But EU is late - please, fast-forward!

Europe has contributed to the Free and Open Source software movement greatly. I don't think it's even worth mentioning, that the operating system kernel used by most mobile operating systems, servers and all fastest supercomputers on earth was developed by a Finnish man, Linus Torvalds. Beyond that, we have had numerous innovative projects, like the Nix package manager and even Mistral AI, a European alternative to ChatGPT and its ilk. However, adoption is greatly hindered by Microsoft's lobbying with "favourable" contracts for Office 365 and Windows in the public sector. Work still has to be done for a unified Linux or even FreeBSD or any other FOSS operating system compatible e-mail, productivity and office suite, though LibreOffice is great for most administrative tasks. As proven by belle France's GendBuntu, Schleswig-Holstein's move to LibreOffice and more recently Denmark's pledges to follow in their footsteps, Free and Open Source software is certainly perfectly good for the public sector. What this would buy Europe is European data on the continent of Europe - no need to trust Microsoft, or even the US government for that matter, to not expedite our data overseas. The cost is also worth mentioning - licenses for LibreOffice or Linux distributions are not required - that means saved Euros. Security is an another pro: Linux (and especially BSD's like OpenBSD) feature a much higher standard of security as opposed to the easily compromised software of Microsoft. In short, FOSS offers Europe cheaper, more malleable, secure and most importantly European software. The biggest thing the European Union can do for open source is simply increase adoption. When people use the software, the impetus to improve it comes naturally. A good example is the amount of contributions to the Linux kernel by employees of Google, Microsoft, Amazon and so on. Using OSS in universities and for more administrative purposes is a great start. For smooth adoption, the most important thing, as mentioned earlier, are great office, productivity and e-mail environments. If something comparable to Office 365 is realised, then any reason to use it is moot. Things like a universal European operating system (ideally based on Linux) or Windows translation-layers are important too, as some professions and disciplines utilise specialised tools, sometimes only available on Windows. As for security, I believe no European citizen's personal data should end up or go through any proprietary tool. That means census, taxation data shouldn't go through any US or otherwise foreign cloud service. This would require EU-wide governmental adoption of OSS tools.

Open Source Software is the often unacknowledged foundation upon which most of our computing capability is built. EU citizens unknowingly interact with OSS through almost every electronic action they partake in, because almost all commercial software involves the usage of OSS. These commercial companies sometimes directly support development through hiring employees to work on critical projects such as the Linux kernel, or donating to individual developers. The latter is often a challenge, even though an employee may wish to donate to a software library being used in a project, this can be incredibly difficult within an organisational structure due to the optional and low-value nature of such spending. The EU could provide incentives to companies for funding OSS developers and projects in order to improve OSS development for all. A pillar of OSS is that the software itself often uses or defines open standards for data. The EU has already made great strides in data portability through the GDPR and this should continue by making it easier for users to transport their data in open, documented, formats to other services and interoperate with them. ActivityPub is a successful open standard for decentralised social media currently used by Mastodon and other services. As part of a public campaign and for less reliance on foreign technical services, EU and governmental departments should be directed to have an equivalent standing on social media on such open services as they currently do on Instagram or Facebook. Using decentralised services for publishing would take control back from USA companies and serve as a demonstrative example to the public and companies that it is possible. OSS is often credited as being more secure because anyone can examine the source code and thus "many eyes makes all bugs shallow". In reality, a project may have a thousand-fold more users than contributors who understand it and can find such bugs. Also, many projects in certain languages consist of a huge library dependency graph. Meaning the project is trusting potentially hundreds of external developers not to cause harm. Such supply chain attacks are likely to increase as state actors have the resources to cause such sabotage. The EU should prioritise supporting public package registries as a common good and helping them to become more resilient against attacks. Lastly, following the current corporate mantra of adding so-called "AI" to everything is against the long-term interests of the EU community. Actual Machine Learning is revolutionising many scientific and industrial fields but large language models are a distraction from solving real technical problems such as making software accessible, data portable, and application development secure.

Question: What is the added value of open source for the public and private sectors in EU? Answer: I propose to also consider the open-source strategy as a geopolitical vehicle to find like-minded partners in Africa, Latin America and Asia to jointly strengthen digital sovereignty. Specifically, the key technology of Artificial Intelligence should be open-source in order to unlock the potential of EU in this space and find likeminded partners and achieve shared digital Sovereignty instead of dependencies. In AI and taking a global view, the concrete added-value of open source for public and private sector is as follows: 1) Markets instead of monopolies: Open-source AI will create open local markets and structures and thereby provide economic opportunities for a multitude of local builders of AI instead of contributing to AI-monopolies, both in EU and worldwide in Asia, Africa and Latin America. 2) Shared digital Sovereignty instead of dependencies: EU will have more control of AI and will rely less on outside closed technologies at the same time EU will retain access to shared global public goods and will not have to reinvent the full AI wheel - but can work together with likemindes partners in Asia, Africa and Latin America. 3) EU will be able to foster more tech alliances one eye level with other countries instead of more isolation or dependencies: Boost international technological cooperation and tech exchange with other countries (fair exchange) 4) Fairness instead of rising inequality: EU and other world regions will be able to directly tackle inequalities and make sure no part of population is left behind. 5) Equal opportunities instead of wealth for a few: Open source allows for equal access of all of EU and other companies and communities in a marketplace 6) More rapid technology education: Makes it easier to spread technical know-how on AI 7) AI innovation for public interest instead of AI for private interest only: EU will be able to steer priorities and ensure, that some AI innovation will benefit the public interest fully. 8) Better use of public money: EU will be able to make sure that public money funds openly accessible AI, which remains available even if the original companies building it goe out of business. 9) More secure AI in EU and worldwide, leading to less cyberthreats in the EU.

feedback: Most people are addicted to American based, closed source cloud services which are designed to suck personal data of said users to sell to advertisers. We need to ditch the current mobile phone ecosystem which is based either on Google's Android and Apple's iOS. Both are under total control of the above American mega corporations. Take a look at Furilabs.com's Furiphone. It's running Linux giving the user all control instead of Google or Apple. No office365, instead use NextCloud for document storage and use LibreOffice and the open document format instead of propiertary corporate solutions. No Windows. It's not an operating system anymore. It's designed soly for the extraction of user data. Recall being the latest 'innovation' which will take a screenshot of the entire desktop and have AI analyze it. The photos stay on the machine, the extracted meta data goes to Microsoft. Thankfully, more and more people seem to be switching. Government systems should not be running closed source, and American systems. I don't care how much lobbying is done. And I don't care if users find it hard to switch. Just switch.

It's no secret that the US projects geopolitical soft power through its proprietary, particularly SaaS, software solutions. In the event of (for example) an international incident over Greenland, it is conceivable that the US President could issue a national security directive ordering all American tech companies to immediately cease serving customers based in the EU. Even if this was confined to SaaS platforms, it would be absolutely apocalyptic, with Google, Gmail, Github, Amazon / AWS, Outlook, Office365 and most social media platforms all becoming inaccessible to Europeans on the same day. If it was extended to operating systems with remote update functionality, one could even imagine every Windows, Apple, and Android device simply going dark. This should not be considered an unrealistic scenario, the US does have robust rule of law for matters within the country, but international affairs are generally left at the discretion of the president. Furthermore, even if the decision was later reversed by a court, it would not happen before the damage was already done. Fortunately the EU can improve its situation at a very marginal cost because open source alternatives exist already, and they have no such kill-switch. However, there are three main obstacles to broader adoption: 1. Because open source software is able to be copied and used without paying, open source business models are rarely successful. People who would be creating immense strategic value are often walled out by the reality of needing a modest salary to feed their family. 2. Open source developers who are not so constrained face another challenge in resources and awareness. American tech companies spend exorbitantly on user experience, testing, and marketing - establishing their products as a global leader in excellence. So even when open source alternatives exist, they often lack the UX and testing/debugging polish of American products, leading to a stereotype of "2nd rate" which drives potential adopters away. And even those products which are impressively well polished are often simply unknown to the European citizenry because they are unable to spend on marketing. 3. Startups who may consider offering EU-hosted SaaS solutions are often scared of regulations such as the GDPR and DSA. The headlines about these regulations speak of tremendous fines for non-compliance, and there is rarely any word about the treatment of good-faith small operators. So people are lead to believe that running a SaaS service in Europe is impossible without a large compliance team - which only American SaaS companies can afford. This poses a serious impediment to the adoption of open source web-app software because even when it exists, European companies are fearful to host it for the public.
Support open source HW & SW & formats when possibile
feedbackTextUserLanguage: Support open source HW & SW & formats when possible

feedback:
A strong European Open Source (OS) needs a network of companies that can provide consultancy services (e.g.: installation, training, bug fixing). In Europe, many of these companies are Small and Medium Enterprises (SME). These companies may be negatively impacted by the CRA, since they may not have the resources to comply with all the requirements imposed by this directive. One of the barriers to the adoption of open source in the public sector is the lack of adoption of Standards in procurement. Standards enable a healthy competition between OS companies and proprietary companies for the best solutions. However, if we do not see standards enforced, there is a risk of vendor lock-in, putting the organisations in the hands of a solution that often can be maintained by only one company. Open Source is overall a cost efficient solution, since it makes sure that every cent spent by a customer towards bug fixing or the implementation of new features, benefits every single user of the project. However, to facilitate this approach we need a strong ecosystem of OS companies that can take commercial projects and streamline the results back to the upstream OS project. Open source leads to greater code quality, due to the peer reviewed process harnessed by the Pull Request mechanism. Moreover, the perception that the code will be public and will be scrutinised pushes developers to self enforce a higher degree of quality. Open Source projects are often made by a diverse community of contributors; this often includes a mix of backgrounds. From my experience, it also includes a diversity of ages and geographical regions. It has been consistently shown that diversity and multi-disciplinarity often lead to innovation. Open Source is the path to achieve digital sovereignty; i.e., enabling an organisation to take ownership of their software infrastructure and avoid vendor lock-in. Finally, open source software is really a sustainable solution in the long term. A project backed up by a vibrant community, will never die out, and even if it does, one always has the option of taking the software and continuing using it and even keep developing it ourselves. The EU may support the OS projects, by supporting the SME ecosystem around those projects. This support should include legal advice, but also financial resources to tackle things such as the CRA. The EU can help the public service sector to transition towards open source, by providing them with the financial resources to transition to do so. This will also strengthen the open source SME ecosystem, and ultimately the OS projects. However, in order to make sure that the solutions really percolate to the upstream projects, this must be clear in the requirements. The EU may provide financial resources to umbrella organisations such as OSGeo, which can channel those resources to the projects in a sustainable way. In general, the EU can support a more competitive and efficient software sector, by establishing and enforcing a legal framework that mandates the use of Standards. To support this, the EU should also make available financial resources for organisations to transition to a software stack based on Standards, and to software projects that want to embrace compliance certification. Code repositories (such as Codeberg) should be prioritised, since the open source projects need these environments to operate, and right now there is a huge reliance/dependency on a single tool, which is run by a non European proprietary company. With the increase of AI slop in software contributions to open source, we need tools that enable us to detect Pull Requests created by AI; these unsupervised contributions create a burden for the maintainers of the projects and can lead to inclusion of copyrighted or even malicious code in the code base. Standards are crucial for enabling interoperability between open source and proprietary products,
