column30: Independence from American and foreign companies will allow for a smoother European Union, attracting new nostrane minds to important projects, fostering development and growth. Open source, as also demonstrated abroad by China, for example, allows almost simultaneous and spontaneous work without the time and money restrictions that would bind each and every one of us. Driven by the idea of doing good and seeking a common and healthy independence, I think it is very important that we Europeans come together to increase our identity, working on our image, and making us respect as a global power. Being European is a pride, and this can only be confirmed by one’s own quest for solidarity between our nations, abandoning dependence on those who might leave us if time goes wrong.

feedback: Open source software is less prone to cyber security threats by design. Since anyone (given the expertize) can look up at the source code you can prevent some bugs to be exploited and you can contribute to make the software better for eveyone. Proprietary software and proprietary platforms make sure that you get locked in in the ecosystem making it hard to switch back for one, for two it's also harder to interop with other standards. Licesing cost is also a big issue, since theese kind of software tent to not be cheap. This is also a big opportunity to make people tech aware in a world were tech is in our life, it can create new jobs through training, it will make public infrastructure reliable and predictable (you don't have to pay another license for another windows server version to be up to date and secure). Open source software also enables smaller companies to get started since the upfront cost of licensing gets significally reduced

It should be mandatory for all EU countries, due to sovereignty concerns, to either use local (European-made and owned) proprietary Operating Systems, or, ideally, Free and Open-Source ones. You cannot start thinking about sovereignty and freedom without the base software being something you can inspect and/or control. There's obviously more that can be done in terms of hardware, but that's considerably harder to accomplish, even if not less important. There's also the need for making cloud software alternatives to the huge US and Chinese companies who virtually own and control all of them. You can attract europeans to build these alternatives with grants (or actual jobs) distributed to individuals and software companies (not big agencies who will subcontract other smaller agencies and freelancers) who can be vetted as capable of doing so.

I think when Europe looks into open source to take back our digital sovereignty, we need to look to all layers of what it means to use software, and not specific products. Many times, only replacing Office and similar productivity suites are the focus of the conversation. However we should look to the complete computing stack, meaning Europe should adopt hardware designs, operating systems available under open source licenses, like RISC-V, FreeBSD, Linux, Haiku, among others. Programming languages that are either available under open source licenses, or international standards like ISO. International standards for graphics programming, compute and AI, like those from Khronos. As matter of principle steer away from products developed by foreign nation companies that can harm the economy of any European nation by withdrawing their software, or introduce backdoors in commercial products not easily availble for security validation.

As a citizen, one feels obliged to offer these succinct reflections upon your commendable initiative "Towards European open digital ecosystems". One applauds the emphasis on transparency for critical infrastructure. Proprietary software of non-Union origin is, regrettably, opaque; FOSS permits independent scrutiny and improvement a course more aligned with our European principles. Our digital security, alas, exhibits certain regrettable porosities one might say Swiss cheese owing to over-reliance upon foreign proprietary technologies, with the inevitable risks of lock-in, supply chains, and geopolitical exposure. Proprietary models hasten premature obsolescence and electronic waste; FOSS sustains hardware of considerable vintage, reducing consumption and supporting the Green Deal. That said and one strives always for balance the open-source domain is not without its own delicate vulnerabilities. Far too many projects of vital strategic importance depend upon the labours of a single individual or a diminutive band of volunteers. Should human frailty, exhaustion, or unforeseen circumstance intervene, the repercussions for security, continuity, and the public weal could be disproportionate in the extreme. In these circumstances, therefore, one ventures with the utmost deference and in a purely advisory capacity to propose certain prudent and proportionate measures: - The establishment of a well-resourced European Sovereign Tech Fund (inspired by successful national precedents, but Union-scale) to deliver stable, multi-year funding for maintenance, security audits, and sustainability of critical open-source projects. Particular attention might be given to exemplary European efforts such as KDE, SUSE Linux, RISC-V, Servo, SailfishOS, and Nextcloud (the sovereign German collaboration platform positioning itself as a GDPR-compliant alternative to Microsoft 365 and Google Workspace). - A clear and binding policy to the effect that software developed with public funds shall be released under open licences, with appropriate contributions returned to upstream communities thus giving practical expression to the equitable maxim that what is financed by the taxpayer should, in justice, redound to the taxpayer's benefit. - A modest but thoughtfully calibrated regime of tax incentives for those enterprises which contribute financial resources, developer time, or other support to the nourishment of significant open-source endeavours. Should these suggestions be embraced they would materially advance the Union's technological sovereignty, fortify its digital resilience, mitigate external dependencies, and ensure that our shared digital future remains both trustworthy and indubitably European.

Since the new war on tariffs, incredible opportunities have emerged for the EU. It must be turned into a chance. 1. To paraphrase Cory Doctorow in "The Post-American Internet" (https://pluralistic.net/2026/01/01/39c3/), the Article 6 of the 2001 EU Copyright Directive is about anticircumvention, which enables technology lock-in, in a large part used at the benefit of US tech companies. Surely, the US had something to do with this law adoption. Now that the trading rules are broken with the US, should we keep the restrictions? This law could be amended to fight technology lock-in. Of course, a few EU companies also take advantage of that law - essentially against the EU people. So, the EU must be clear about that: are we against lock-in or not? 2. There are European tech companies that compete with US cloud big techs. OVH, Hetzner, Scaleway, NextCloud, Suse... They get just the scraps of the market shares. Why are they left behind? It's hard to create a space in a market so outrageously dominated by US techs. Nobody ever got fired for buying Microsoft, Amazon or Google, the vicious circle is hard to break. So, how comes it that China was able to break it? They have Alibaba, Tencent, Baidu... Bigger players than the European ones. Surely, regulation is part of how they achieved it, in addition to $$. Isn't there something to learn? I am convinced that the bulk of the efforts should be done on R&D. Tax credits like French CIR or American R&D Tax Credit can help: designed at the EU scale, restricted to European companies, with a special focus on a few techs (not necessarily oriented towards innovation, but rather, towards strategic goals such as catching up on cloud technologies). Do not restrict to a handful of selected companies like the EU has done before: open it to everyone in the EU, and allocate based on progress & results (probably with a mix of controls and declarative). But for this to work, we need more than just high-level goals with a top-down approach. My feeling is that the success is intrinsically related to the management workflows, and I believe there is a cultural difference between US and EU tech companies in that regard, which often allows US companies to build things faster, and to retain talents. A EU-scale financial incentive that is clearly targeting engineering-led initiatives would be interesting to see. 3. Protect the education from Microsoft. Ministries of education conclude good deals for Windows and Office, well below the market prices, in an attempt for Microsoft to familiarize whole populations with their products. This is where lock-in begins, they are buying future buyers. The law should draw a line somewhere, either because this is a form of dumping, or because children digital education should not be built around one single product/vendor, or find another angle to attack this monopolistic situation. 4. Invest in open-source. Governments, regions, city councils have started to use open-source. That's great, but fragile, it can end up in a bad way. First, it's mostly uncoordinated, with probably a lot of redundant efforts, so it can surely be done better. Most importantly, switching to open-source is not a one-time decision, it's something to invest in, in the long run. There must be a capacity to operate, upgrade, maintain, and even fork. Without this capacity, open-source is not a solution to lock-in - you can still be locked in an open-source software, which is still better than being lock-in Microsoft, but not *that* better. So the EU could help, though not sure exactly how; perhaps with a kind of "open-source engineering task force"? Paid by the EU, with a good expertise in open-source, used to interacting with open-source communities, able to contribute, and even maintaining their own projects and forks whenever it's necessary?

Ritengo che l'Europa debba prendere la decisione strategica di promuovere tecnologie libere, open source e interoperabili, favorendone l'adozione a livello istituzionale, aziendale e dei singoli cittadini. - I bandi di gara dovrebbero includere dei punteggi bonus per l'utilizzo di tecnologie aperte e interoperabili. - Dovrebbero essere allocati fondi economici per supportare lo sviluppo e la manutenzione di software e servizi aperti e interoperabili. - Bisognerebbe iniziare, già nelle scuole, ad insegnare ai ragazzi l'uso di software e servizi open source, in contrapposizione a quanto avviene ora, ove molto spesso si utilizzano strumenti closed-source come Microsoft Office, Google Classroom/Workspace, Autocad, ecc. facendo spesso uso di licenze gratuite emesse dalle stesse aziende che, in questo modo, creano futura domanda degli stessi software e servizi in un circolo vizioso difficile da spezzare. L'uso di software e servizi aperti e interoperabili avrebbe di conseguenza due vantaggi importanti: - La creazione di un tessuto produttivo europeo composto da tante aziende europee, in contrapposizione alle mega-corporation (spesso straniere) che monopolizzano il mercato. - L'emancipazione europea da tecnologie e servizi extra-UE che oggi costituiscono una grossa criticità in termini di sicurezza, privacy e indipendenza dai voleri di governi stranieri.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: I believe that Europe must take the strategic decision to promote free, open source and interoperable technologies, fostering their adoption at institutional, business and individual citizen level. — Calls for tender should include bonus scores for the use of open and interoperable technologies. — Economic funds should be allocated to support the development and maintenance of open and interoperable software and services. Schools should start teaching children about the use of open-source software and services, as opposed to what is currently happening, where very often closed-source tools such as Microsoft Office, Google Classroom/Workspace, Autocad, etc. are used, often using free licences issued by the same companies which, in this way, create future demand for the same software and services in a vicious circle that is difficult to break. The use of open and interoperable software and services would therefore have two important advantages: — The creation of a European productive fabric made up of many European companies, as opposed to the (often foreign) mega-corporations that monopolise the market. — Europe’s emancipation from non-EU technologies and services, which are currently a major challenge in terms of security, privacy and independence from the will of foreign governments.

feedback: Open Source is vital for a culture of freedom of choice. European citizens are confronted daily with US Big Tech products by Google, Microsoft, Facebook/Meta, Amazon etc and the policies they employ. The biggest Belgian internet company (Telenet) sold their hardware infrastructure to an American company, to then lease the infrastructure. For Open Digital Ecosystems, Europe needs to be able to run their own servers within the EU, to host their own services, which they can develop/improve themselves (for at least the majority). Europe needs to support Open Source software such as -The Linux operating system to get away from Microsoft, including alternatives to Microsoft Office (such as LibreOffice). -Mailing services such a Protonmail and Tuta to get away from Google. -Internet browser alternatives such as Waterfox to get away from both Google and Microsoft. Not only must Europe support Open Source development of software as a way of investing into its own future and people, Europe has to secure its indepence by producing its own hardware. It's incredibly worrying ALL computer hardware comes from Taiwan and China. I realize we're talking about many years of work and huge amounts of money, but software means nothing without being able to run it without restrictions. I realize I don't have much technical feedback to share but I simply wanted to share my views as a EU citizen that is concerned about current state of tech.

[ Barriers that hamper adoption ] Throughout our educational system, it is taught that there is basically one kind of computer, and that computer runs Windows. Unless youth is particularly curious, or happen to go into IT, they will never know about open source software in general, and Linux specifically. This knowledge barrier is maintained by lucrative contracts that Microsoft and others have with the public sector. If we want adoption, we need to start with awareness. And that starts with education. [ Added value of open source in public sector ] The added value of open source in the public sector overlaps a lot with the added value in industrial or even private use: - The guarantee that software will not disappear or have unforeseen license costs - The freedom and ability to change software as needs come up In addition, using open source in the public sector aligns nicely with the mission of most public sectors: to be of benefit to the public, not to one closed corporation. [ Concrete measures that may be taken at the EU level ] - Recommend that all government-developed or sponsored software needs to have an OSI-approved license - Education: Re-introduce computers away from being "magic boxes that Microsoft or Apple control" to "sophisticated machines that we can control ourselves". This can totally be done from day 1 in school, see for example the Raspberry Pi (yes, a US initiative, but the concept can easily be repeated on e.g. RISC-V). - Education: Create a software awareness of the "state of the art" of open source. Things that have been accepted as a "solved problem", exist as open source software that is slowly taking over their respective industry. Examples of solved problems are operating system (Linux), document writing (multiple alternatives), 3D editing (Blender), Audio editing (Ardour), and many more. [ Prioritization of technology areas ] Prioritization shouldn't be based on industry or technology areas, but rather on maturity of available open source solutions. See the list above, operating systems, document writing tools, etc. [ Open source for increased competitiveness and resilience ] This question is somewhat conflicting in its premise. Quality open source emerges, because multiple parties find that competition is undesirable on a certain product area: everybody needs an operating system, everybody needs a standard way to exchange documents, etc. So these are no longer areas one can compete on. Quite the opposite: By embracing open source in ANY industry to solve problems that make a certain company NOT unique, resources can be spent on the actual unique selling points of a company.

There is a lot of great open source projects. For some time now i have been either switching to open source alternatives or helping with development of them in some ways. And with projects being open source anyone can help with them in any way they want.

À mon avis une structure aussi complexe et lourde que EU narrivera pas à mettre sur pied une solution facile, flexible répondant aux besoins du marché. La manière de fonctionner, de faire participer tout le monde, la législation des marchés publiques . Cela coûtera une fortune pour aboutir à une solution dont personne ne voudra et quon imposera peut-être comme solution pour les services publics . Un exemple concret: la manière de devoir sidentifier pour pouvoir remettre un avis et itsmee. A la place de mettre ridas en place il aurait été mieux détendre lutilisation ditsmee a tous les pays dEurope et de sassurer que la firme reste européenne et ne passe pas sous contrôle américain ou chinois.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: In my view, such a complex and cumbersome structure that EU will not be able to develop an easy, flexible solution that meets the needs of the market. How to work, how to involve everyone, public procurement legislation. This will cost a fortune to achieve a solution that nobody will want and which may be imposed as a solution for public services. A concrete example: the way in which people must be confident in order to be able to deliver an opinion and itsmee. Instead of putting in place ridas, it would have been better to relax the use said to all the countries of Europe and to ensure that the firm remained European and did not come under US or Chinese control.

feedback: EU wide free email for citizens of the EU. Something like foo@europe.de or foo@de.europe.eu... This will reduce greatly the dependence on US Big-Tech accounts. EU firewall protecting all major internet hubs. Redundant hub connections. Monetary support for all major Linux forks. Google free Android for the EU market. Google/Apple free Apps/App-Market. There are a lot of FOSS projects out there. Create a fund for FOSS projects and once a year award top projects. Send representatives to the next CCC in Germany and talk to people and listen to what they have to say. EU technology fair only for companies operating and manufacturing in the EU. Need a program or technology? Put out a bounty... Offer awards for certain things. Support and promote Federated social media.

From what I've learned about opensource and US Big Tech replacements it's this: - Replace Microsoft Office with Libreoffice or Onlyoffice - Replace Google Search by DuckDuckGo or Ecosia - Use the Proton Suite instead of Microsoft's/Google's - Use Nextcloud for Cloud Drive if not Proton - For AI use Proton Lumo or Mistral's Le Chat as they're both European and store their data in Europe and Le Chat is also opensource - Replace Windows with Linux. I'd go with RHEL, something Debian-based or Fedora for an actual stable and simple to use OS - Try to phase out Android for /e/OS or better yet, fork Android and make a new phone OS (EUOS idea but for smartphones) - Use Signal or host a Matrix/Element instance instead of using Whatsapp for direct messaging Thanks for asking for help!

Q1: Historically, people with European roots have been at the forefront of open source software (OSS) development and computer science, with well-known heroes like Linus Torvald, Guido van Rossum, Andrew Tannenbaum and Edsger Dijkstra to name a few. This heritage remains strong, particularly in research institutions like CWI Amsterdam and the Swiss CERN-cluster. In the area of data science, we see that people like Hannes Muhleisen (DuckDB), Ritchie Vink (polars) and Marco Gorelli (narwhals) presently have a major influence in shaping the data science ecosystem, developing OSS libraries and specifications which are de facto standards. At the same time, I feel that corporate support for OSS in Europe is lagging compared to the US. Looking at the largest OSS projects in the data science domain, I see there are more corporate-sponsored core contributors from the US compared to Europe. I think this is partly due to the lack of recognition at European companies to foster and support these types of technical unicorns (in the truest sense of the word). Also, I feel there are less European companies who are willing and able to adopt some form of OSS-based company strategy, for example using an OSS core with paid services on top of that. These factors stand in the way of more large-scale adoption of OSS in Europe. Q2: There are many benefits to OSS, which I will not re-iterate here. Instead, I defer to the work of the Open Future Foundation (https://openfuture.eu/) which I find to be the most relevant and thorough policy analysis on this topic. Q3: My main point of feedback is not to just focus on the sustainability of individual OSS projects, but consider taking non-legistative action to stimulate the integration of existing OSS components into a coherent system/platform. In practice, many companies lack the expertise and resources to integrate and deploy different OSS components into a production environment. To address this issue, OSS initiatives that take systems integration as their key focus could be stimulated. As an example, consider the Instant OpenHIE project (https://openhie.github.io/instant/) that aims to reduce the costs and skills required for software developers to deploy an OpenHIE architecture for quicker initial solution testing and as a starting point for faster production implementation and customization. This project does so by integrating around a dozen OSS projects into a health information exchange system. The development of Instant OpenHIE was funded by the McGovern Foundation (https://www.mcgovern.org/). A similar approach could be taken for what is known as the modern, composable data stack (https://voltrondata.com/codex). New initiatives (although still very much in their infancy) include https://github.com/dkapitan/srdp and https://github.com/l-mds/local-data-stack. These developments are closely related to creating interoperability and standards for the basic cloud infrastructure, such as the ECOFED initiative. From experience, an OSS based data platform is significantly more cost-effective than data platforms based on enterprise software and commercial databases. I have direct experience in deploying OSS-based platforms for mid-sized healthcare organizations (thousands of FTEs, EUR 100 m revenue) where cost could be reduced from hundredsto tens of thousands per year. Q4: OSS developments related to data platforms should be prioritised to support the European data economy. This opportunity is supported by research by de Reuver et al. (2022, https://dl.acm.org/doi/10.1145/3565011.3569056) that data platforms inherently have less of a winner-takes-all dynamic compared to other digital/software platforms. Hence, any action undertaken in this area may in fact have a higher chance of success compared to challenging the current market power and transgression of spheres from large tech companies. Q5: the same sectors that have been prior

feedback: Please DO NOT SCREW UP another working niche. Just ignore any open source, let it live on its own. Forget that anything like open source exists. We do not need your attention, we do not need any legislation or money. All you touch is doomed.

Open-source, in my eyes, is critical for governments, the industry and citizens alike for sovereignity in these uncertain times and also for educating others on software and hardware as well as encouraging new developments and further research and improvements upon existing things. It's what drives society forward instead of stagnating or even pushing back, it's protecting us from something like the influence of the US government already use against people from the International criminal court and cutting us off from vital services and tools.

Bonjour, Quels que soient les softwares ou OS opensource choisis, les gens n'y adhèrent tout simplement pas car leurs débuts informatiques ont été inondés de Microsoft, de Google ou de Meta. Ne faudrait-il pas commencer par orienter les écoles vers le monde du libre : Suite LibreOffice, Thunderbird, Gimp, OS Linux, Octave et plus encore. De plus, quelques initiatives européennes apparaissent tel que Vivaldi, Qwant/Ecosia, Nextcloud/Owncloud. Ne serait-ce pas le rôle de la Communauté Européenne de les aider a se développer ? Un point également essentiel est lesprit de fatalité qui règne dans lIT : cest plus facile dinstaller des produits Microsoft, ou utiliser des surfaces type Google. Cependant, en tant quinformaticien, je préférerais installer du Linux et produits opensource au moins jaurais la satisfaction que chaque heure prestée lest à bon escient. Je plaide pour l'usage de ces produits opensource depuis plus de 20 ans. Pour ma part, j'ai atteint la souveraineté digital depuis environ 5 ans.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: Hello, whatever the softwares or OS OpenSource chosen, people simply do not subscribe to them because their computer beginnings have been flooded by Microsoft, Google or Meta. Should we not start by directing schools towards the free world: LibreOffice suite, Thunderbird, Gimp, OS Linux, Octave and more. In addition, a few European initiatives appear, such as Vivaldi, Qwant/Ecosia, Nextcloud/OwnCloud. Would it not be the role of the European Community to help them develop? A crucial point is also the inevitability of littering: this makes it easier to install Microsoft products, or to use Google like surfaces. However, as a computer scientist, I would prefer to install Linux and OpenSource products at least to be satisfied that every hour worked is good. I have been advocating the use of these OpenSource products for more than 20 years. For my part, I have achieved digital sovereignty for about 5 years.

feedback: One of the strongest data sovereignty solutions that should be adopted across the EU is, without a doubt, Mautic - the open-source alternative to US-based email marketing and automation platforms such as Mailchimp, HubSpot and many others. Mautic offers a fundamentally different security model. Because it is self-hosted, public institutions maintain full ownership and physical control of their data on EU-based servers. No customer information, behavioural data or personal identifiers are processed by external companies or transferred outside European jurisdiction. This architecture significantly reduces exposure to 3rd party risks, including data leakage, vendor access, opaque data processing, and non-compliant data transfers. All data storage, backups, access policies and security layers are defined by the institution itself, according to its internal governance and national or EU regulations. In addition, Mautic's open-source nature provides full transparency: the codebase can be audited, security practices can be independently verified, and no hidden data collection or proprietary processing takes place. This ensures not only technical security, but also legal and ethical compliance with GDPR(!), data minimisation principles and public sector accountability requirements. By adopting Mautic, public institutions gain a secure, sovereign and future-proof platform, one that guarantees data ownership, operational independence and complete alignment with European data protection standards!

The EU should mandate free+open standards for all government procurements. This allows everyone to compete at the same level and to benefit from integrations that otherwise would not be possible. It will also reduce the walled-garden push that big-tech is performing. It is essential to approach IT systems as essential infrastructure similarly to water, sewage, and electricity.

This comment is from a full service open source solution provider. We see three major pillars to boost digital sovereignty in the EU: 1. Tenders should give additional points for open source solutions. 2. Organizations or companies that use open source solutions should have a simple way to pay the maintainers or contributors or a partner offering a service level agreement. 3. Open Source procurement should become part of sustainability reports of companies. For 1 see the criteria published by OSBA https://osb-alliance.de/publikationen/veroeffentlichungen/vergabekriterien-fuer-eine-nachhaltige-beschaffung-von-open-source-software . In addition, to motivate OS companies to participate in tenders, the turnover limits should be set low, administrative and compliance requirements reduced and ideally a (small) installment paid to participants of a tender or a pitch (as suggested by a brochure of the Austrian Chamber of Commerce's sub-organisation Kreativwirtschaft in the "Die Kunden der Kreativen" (in German https://www.kreativwirtschaft.at/KundenderKreativen.pdf page 70). For 2 often donations are no option and classical licenses do not comply with the open source culture. At the BigBlueButton Developer Summit in November 2025 in Vienna we have worked out a commercial payment and partner template that supports self-assigned invoicing (see https://hedgedoc.uni-osnabrueck.de/s/fairpay#). For 3, as digital sovereignty is also an ethical issue, companies using and buying OS solutions should be motivated to devote a chapter in their annual Corporate Social Responsibility reports. We are well connected and support several OS communities and run our own high availability cloud infrastructure. We offer a broad portfolio of online services with low entry barriers to showcase what OS solutions can do today for your daily life or work. We've learned that a key factor for a successful implementation of open source solutions at customers are: a. Assign a person who coordinates the tech teams. b. Create a nice user experience with a concise branding (see my talk at LinuxDay 2025 https://www.linuxday.at/branding-bei-freier-software-ein-widerspruch ) c. Offer Service Level Agreements, so that IT decision makers, who are finally responsible for the tech stack, sleep well. d. Open source professionals or solution providers should cooperate not only when writing code, but also when building or maintaining businesses. This allows us to handle also larger or international projects. Open Source service providers or consultants have founded co-operatives or similar member based governance models (fairkom, HostSharing, Mastodon, LaSuite, ...). As these companies lack traditional exit strategies, they are not a target in investment rounds and can only grow organically. e. Integrate, do not separate. Replacing services with an OS stack has to be done usually gradually, which often requires interfacing with existing infrastructure (e.g. AD, Entra, Outlook). This is do-able, but requires blingual minds that also understand the language of the proprietary world.

(1) github, google colab, huggingface, youtube, gmail, yahoomail is infrastructure offered for free by private companies. Public infrastructure would be a nice addition! (2) Open Source projects (eg opendesk/zendis) which would be very usefull for administrations/public often fail because microsoft/.... offers incompatible formats which frustrates users. Maybe the EU could be usefull in defining (open) standards (eg the german DIN) (3) Microfunding. Example : youtube. There should be a system to compensate individuals (not companies) for their effort. (be it euros or credits for the use of infrastructure) (4) maintenance, often forgotten but very important. Howto encourage companies/inidividuals to take on the maintenance? Suppose you run into a (severe) bug, how to get it solved quickly? A unique call handling system (for all open source related problems) would be a first step. To avoid cherry picking, a system should be in place to compensate companies/individuals for their effort in fixing bugs. Here you even could introduce a competition element; first solved, first paid, increasing the renumeration the longer the call remains open (taken into account severity)

Please go talk in person to the open source experts at FOSDEM, the open source conference that takes places at the Université Libre de Bruxelles every year. FOSDEM gathers thousands of experts from all around the world, and most of the open source software that people use have probably been written by some of the conference attendees. We will be happy to contribute with ideas and more. This year FOSDEM is on January 31st and Februy1st, https://fosdem.org

The EU in the past initiated multiple instruments (cf. Gaia-X, IPCEI-CIS, ...), many EU countries invest into local digital sovereignty initiatives, somewhat not coordinated EU-wide yet (cf. numerique.gouv.fr, zendis.de and many more). There is not a SINGLE above initiative that does not highly rely upon neutrally governed open-source software (OSS), predominantly the ecosystem around the Linux Foundation, CNCF, etc. but of course also Eclipse and Apache. Hereby, the most relevant consideration is that open-source ownership must be held by a neutral foundation, a digital commons, where funding is jointly governed by interested parties using that open source in commercial products/services. Beware: there are many single vendor owned oss projects, often marketed under the OSS-Flag and thereby benefitting from public funding and developer trust. Such open source should be explicitly flagged, and special scrutiny must be applied by the EU for consideration, as myriad negative examples (license rug-pulls, acquisitions by hyperscaler, etc.) prove that with increasing adoption, companies ditch the digital commons in favor of monetarization. We have a positive, forward-looking example in the EU: While IPCEI-CIS, for example, "welcomed" participants to contribute their efforts into open-source, no obligations were contractually required. Nonetheless, a number of participants (some of the largest European enterprises, together with many smaller partners with highly specialized expertise) recognized the failure and created the necessary "open-source foundation infrastructure" to jointly and freely share core efforts: see https://NeoNephos.org/introduction . NeoNephos' mission statement is highly relevant for the 8RA multi-provider cloud-edge continuum goal (https://youtu.be/8_GUj1tLdPo). A recent landmark study by The Harvard Business School (https://papers.ssrn.com/sol3/papers.cfm?abstract_id=4693148) quantified the massive financial impact of OSS: * Demand-Side Value: Estimated at $8.8 trillion. This represents the replacement cost if every firm using OSS had to develop that software internally from scratch. * Supply-Side Value: Estimated at $4.15 billion, which is the direct cost required to recreate the most widely used OSS packages once. For the EU it would be FUTILE not to consider OSS as the most important tool for its digital sovereignty ambitions. The EU could employ a pattern in technology business & economics commonly known as commoditize your complement, only on an EU-wide scale, by contractually obliging all beneficiaries of EU-funding towards contributing towards foundation-led OSS. (Also, in lieu of technology disruption with AI, most commercial and dominating players double down on OSS, cf. Linux Foundation led AAIF.io).

First what do I think the EU could do to improve their efforts to achieve their goals with the European open source community. A. Simplify enforcement of user rights granted under copyleft licenses. Copyleft licenses provide users of a product that integrates the licensed codes with certain rights in theory. In practice these rights are hard to enforce, due to legal uncertainty and power/budget/awareness differences between the user and their vendor. A common example of this would be a vendor refusing to provide the complete and corresponding source code to someone they distributed code based on GPL licensed code. B. How to handle export controls. The EU and its member states need export controls on critical technology, I understand. Open source is build on freely sharing information. These things can clash, but don't have to, as the Nintendo version of Godot demonstrates. What it does require though is thought and preparation. Based on the example I just named the following things are required. Strong industry incentives, iron clad NDA's and sovereign controlled servers. C. Publishing cryptographic hashes of CSAM and other restricted material should enable, those without the access to (rightly) restricted pneumatic hashing to build their own automated illegal content filtering systems. This would allow small scale server owners to take a little bit of extra regulatory risk, while hosting. Don't publish other indicators of these materials like pneumatic hashes. These may have shown to work in closed context, but there is pretty solid proof that this can become very problematic in open context. Second I somewhat think the commission sells itself short in the call for evidence. I think that the Eu hasn't worked just through research funding in their support for open source. The Eu's competition, standardization and transparency laws an actions have served many open source projects very well. The Eu's view of software patents is similarly quite beneficial for a it's local open source development community(A clear champion of this one is the VLC project, those guys would've been sued into oblivion long ago if it wasn't for this.).

Spend money into a healthy diverse ecosystem and put open standards front and center for the user (not apps) in your policies (for inspiration see https://communities.surf.nl/en/regie-op-data/article/fair-data-too-little-too-late-unless). Also strongly enforce the policies you already have and practice what you preach; for example no .docx files, no X/Twitter, etc.

Bonjour, Téléphonie mobile ################# Je suis un simple citoyen mais néanmoins très sensible au respect de la vie privée, à la maîtreise des technologies et à la souveraineté numérique européenne. En tant qu'utilisateur de systèmes libres et ouverts depuis plusieurs décénies, je me permets de faire part de mon point de vue averti. J'utiliser SFOS depuis 3 ans tous les jours. Le système d'exploitation pour téléphones Sailfish OS est l'alternative la plus aboutie sur laquelle l'Europe pourrait se baser. Créé en Finlande par la société Jolla, cet OS est aujourd'hui une réelle aux géants du numérique qui fournissent IOS et Android. Je l'utilise sur mon téléphone depuis 4 ans. Sailfish OS est lun des rares systèmes mobiles conçus en Europe, avec un noyau Linux ouvert et une architecture sécurisée. Il nest pas encore 100 % open source certaines parties sont encore propriétaires mais l'ouverture est en cours. Sailfish OS n'a pas de dépendance à Google ou Apple et ne repose pas sur des services cloud non-européens. Sailfish OS présente une architecture par défaut sécurisée (sandbox, permissions fines). Écosystème matériel : Compatible avec des appareils européens tels que Jolla, Fairphone mais aussi avec d'autres grandes marques comme Sony, Gigaset, Oneplus... Sailfish OS bénéficie dune communauté très active, enthousiaste et internationale, qui contribue au développement, à la documentation, et au support. Au niveau environnemental, Sailfish OS est également intéressant car il est peu gourmand. Il permet donc de continuer à utiliser des appareils anciens. Mon téléphone a, par exemple, 8 ans et il est toujours maintenu, notemment en regard des mises à jour de sécurité. Le Jolla 2, son deuxième téléphone, a connu en ce début d'année un succès au-delà des attentes, avec une campagne de financement remplie en un week-end. La quantité minimum de commandes a atteint 350% à ce jour. Références: Le J2, téléphone européen de Jolla: https://commerce.jolla.com/products/jolla-phone-preorder Dossier de presse: https://jolla.com/content/uploads/2025/12/Jolla-pre-order-campaign-sold-organically-5000-phones-in-a-week.pdf?x26973 (https://jolla.com/content/uploads/2025/12/Jolla_Phone_Press_Release_8-12-2025_FINAL_EN.pdf?x26973) Liste d'articles, vidéos et blogs parlant du nouveau téléphone J2: https://forum.sailfishos.org/t/j2-articles-videos-and-discussions-summary/26232

As a user of free and open systems for several decades, I have the opportunity to share my informed views. I have been using SFOS for 3 years every day. It is not yet 100 % open source, some parts are still proprietary, but the opening is ongoing. Sailfish OS is not dependent on Google or Apple and is not based on non-European cloud services. Sailfish OS has a secure default architecture (sandbox, fine permissions). Material ecosystem: Compatible with European devices such as Jolla, Fairphone, but also with other major brands such as Sony, Gigaset, OnePlus, etc. Sailfish OS benefits from a very active, enthusiastic and international community, which contributes to development, documentation and support. feedback: As the Commission has noted, merely funding research is not sufficient to reach scale. One front, the Mobile Phone market, seems to not have been of much concern. That though the Finnish company, Jolla, has been surviving with a largely FOSS alternative OS for Mobiles for almost 20 years. It is notable that Jolla was founded by engineers previously employed by Nokia, once a world leader. If the Commission and Parliament seriously want to challenge the dominant players, they would be advised to fund companies like Jolla that actually produce a product which can compete with Android and IOs. Thanks and regards.

Pracuji jako programátor dvanáctým rokem. Plně podporuji rozvoj OpenSource, kterému jsem se dříve věnoval profesionálně a dnes ve svém volném čase. Zde jsou mé osobní názory: Evropa se musí zbavit závislosti na uzavřených dodavatelích software (Microsoft, Oracle, ..). Jen tak je možné získat nezávislost na dodavatelích z cizích zemí, ale i větší bezpečnost (auditovatelnost, crowdsourced hledání chyb, ale i supply chain dependency). V neposlední řadě tím také vzniká významná možnost ušetřit finanční prostředky. Za tímto účelem je dle mého názoru důležité podporovat finančně vývojáře vytvářející otevřený software. Z investic do opensource vývojářů a jejich publikační činnosti benefituje celá společnost, podobně jako například z investic do akademického prostředí. V neposlední řadě je třeba dbát na to aby všechen státem veřejně používaný software v EU byl publikován jako otevřený software.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: I work as a programmer for the twelfth year. I fully support the development of Opensource, to which I have previously devoted myself professionally and today in my free time. Here are my personal views: Europe must break its dependency on closed software suppliers (Microsoft, Oracle,..). This is the only way to gain independence from foreign suppliers, but also more security (auditability, crowdsourced error-finding, as well as supply chain dependency). Last but not least, it also provides an important opportunity to save money. To that end, it is important, in my view, to support financially developers producing open source software. Investments in Opensource developers and their publications benefit society as a whole, similar to investments in academia, for example. Finally, care should be taken to ensure that all state-owned software in the EU is published as open source software.

feedback: Within the EU, there already exists a highly active open source developer community with many practically important projects like KDE, Debian, Nextcloud, etc. being developed to a significant extent by EU citizens. I have personally contributed to a number of open source projects and have been using open source on my own as well as organizational server and desktop systems almost exclusively since 1999. It is already very practical - if one has the expertise and willingness to rely on it. One of the issues for enterprise usage remains in - often more perceived than real - liability risks. Security and compliance decisions are regularly treated as checkbox exercises with the intention of transferring risk to the "vendor" of some software component through legal agreements. While this has been demonstrated to be ineffective in actually preventing harm, buying software components from another organization implies the hope of transferring liability post-hoc. For open source components, there is no vendor to regress to on a legal basis (CSA concerns aside). Clarifying legal options for handling this liability concern would therefore help in making open source more attractive to some organizational decision makers. One possibility could be service providers taking on the legal responsibility of vetting, integrating, and maintaining the use of open source components for another organization. Another could be insurance against risks incurred through the use of such open source components that cannot be transferred onto a vendor. Such legal options need a proper framework and must be equal across the EU to strengthen the practical use within organizations - especially in regulated sectors such as finance, medical, energy, or other critical infrastructure.

feedback: Europe must regain control over its software supply chain to safeguard freedom, security, and innovation. Achieving this goal requires deliberate support of a healthy, resilient open-source ecosystem. In this context, I strongly encourage consideration of Nix and NixOS technologies with European origin that offer a powerful foundation for reproducible, secure, and transparent software systems, and that can meaningfully contribute to these strategic objectives. Additionally, I suggest working with well-established organizations such as NLnet, which have many years of experience in supporting and strengthening the open-source ecosystem.

# Stellungnahme zur EU Open-Source-Strategie **Zur Person:** Als Freelancer mit über 25 Jahren Erfahrung in Software-Architektur und aktiver Contributor bei Apache Maven, Eclipse Adoptium, Jenkins und weiteren OSS-Projekten bringe ich praktische Perspektiven zur EU-Konsultation ein. ## Zu Frage 1: Stärken, Schwächen und Barrieren **Stärken:** Die EU verfügt über exzellente OSS-Communities mit hoher technischer Qualität. Projekte wie Apache Maven (Build-Infrastruktur für Millionen Java-Projekte), Eclipse Adoptium (OpenJDK-Distribution) oder docToolchain (Documentation-as-Code) werden maßgeblich von EU-Entwicklern getragen. Die EU-Werte von Transparenz, Datenschutz und Interoperabilität spiegeln sich natürlich in OSS-Prinzipien wider. **Schwächen:** Die Wertschöpfung erfolgt oft außerhalb der EU. Meine Erfahrung bei Apache Maven zeigt: EU-Entwickler leisten substanzielle Beiträge, während kommerzielle Verwertung (z.B. durch Cloud-Anbieter oder Tool-Hersteller) überwiegend in den USA stattfindet. EU-Foundations fehlen Ressourcen für professionelle Governance und Marketing. **Barrieren für Maintenance:** Aus meiner Arbeit an Maven 4.x und Jenkins-X kenne ich die chronische Unterfinanzierung der Wartung kritischer Infrastruktur. Unternehmen nutzen OSS intensiv, tragen aber selten zur Pflege bei. Die "Maven Support & Care"-Initiative zeigt, wie schwierig es ist, nachhaltige Finanzierung für Core-Infrastruktur zu organisieren. ## Zu Frage 2: Mehrwert von Open Source **Öffentlicher Sektor:** Bei meinem Projekt für FITKO (FIT-Connect) ermöglichte OSS volle Kontrolle über die Behördenkommunikations-Middleware. Keine Vendor-Lock-ins, transparente Sicherheitsaudits, Anpassbarkeit an deutsche Verwaltungsanforderungen. **Privater Sektor:** Bei Cloud-Accounting-Projekten auf OpenStack-Basis und Kubernetes reduzierte OSS die Abhängigkeit von Hyperscalern erheblich. Die Kombination aus Cluster-API, CrossPlane und GitOps ermöglicht souveräne Multi-Cloud-Strategien. **Kostenfaktoren:** OSS reduziert Lizenzkosten, aber der eigentliche Wert liegt in Unabhängigkeit, Anpassbarkeit und Security-Transparenz. Die Möglichkeit, Code zu auditieren (wie bei jQAssistant für Architektur-Analyse), ist für kritische Infrastruktur unverzichtbar. ## Zu Frage 3: Konkrete EU-Maßnahmen - **Maintenance-Fonds:** Etablierung eines EU-Fonds für die Wartung kritischer OSS-Infrastruktur (Build-Tools, Compiler, Frameworks). Die NLnet-Foundation oder Sovereign Tech Agency zeigen, dass dies funktioniert, aber mehr Skalierung ist nötig. - **Contribution-Anreize:** Steuerliche Vorteile für Unternehmen, die Entwickler für OSS-Arbeit freistellen. - **Public-Code-First:** Verpflichtung öffentlicher Auftraggeber, geförderte Software unter Open-Source-Lizenzen zu veröffentlichen. - **EU-Hosting-Infrastruktur:** Alternative zu GitHub/GitLab.com unter EU-Kontrolle für souveräne Code-Repositories. ## Zu Frage 4: Priorisierte Technologiebereiche - **Build- und Entwickler-Infrastruktur:** Maven, Gradle, CI/CD-Systeme fundamental für alle Software-Entwicklung. - **Cloud-Native-Technologien:** Kubernetes, OpenStack, Cluster-API Basis für souveräne Cloud-Infrastruktur. - **AI/ML-Tooling:** Integration von LLMs in Entwicklungsprozesse (MCP-Server, wie ich sie für Maven entwickle) muss auf offenen Standards basieren. - **Observability:** OpenTelemetry, Prometheus unverzichtbar für sichere Betriebsführung. ## Zu Frage 5: Sektoren mit Potenzial **Automotive:** Meine Erfahrung bei TollCollect (Mautsystem) und Audi-Projekten zeigt: OSS-Microservices und Container-Technologien können proprietäre Stacks ersetzen. **Öffentliche Verwaltung:** FIT-Connect demonstriert, wie OSS Interoperabilität zwischen Behörden ermöglicht. **Finanzsektor:** Bei Banken-Projekten ermöglichte OSS-basierte Middleware (Kafka, KeyCloak) sichere, auditierbare Systeme. --- Die EU sollte OSS

column29: Hello EU, I find Europe’s digital independence a hugely important issue. I would mainly rely on open source. No absolute ‘everything’, but just as useful and perhaps a bit more. I myself use Nextcloud for my private hosting and have also connected an association to it. That works super. I would like to see all of us together financing the further development like Office Tools in order to get out of Microsoft Office. As a software developer and architect, I learned that it is most sustainable to develop software that can be further developed independently of individuals and businesses. So specific to myself: I develop software in such a way that my company does not depend on me. And this is precisely why I am valued by the company. This is a sustainability that lasts for a very long time. And so it should also be with administrative software: it shall not be tied to undertakings. You should be able to change business at any time! I encourage you to: continue! Europe and its values are the best and most sustainable in the world. They must not be undermined by powerful individuals with personal interests! Marco Stroppel

feedback: This is a great initiative and would have wide ranging benefits (including to big tech). Having worked in the FOSS community for many years, I believe it's still very poorly understood by most (including the tech community). As articulated much better than I could in the book by Jim Whitehurst, The Open Organization. Book Isbn : 9781625275271 The true value of FOSS is not in the "free", but in "open developments" ability to "predicting the future", "without guessing". This (as he explains) is achieved by supporting communities across a wide gambit of "strategic initiatives" and then allowing the community to cement around the best solution (simply based on git stats). This enables specific and targeted grants "and" expertise into the chosen FOSS communities. This was his secret source to the success of Red Hat and is very easily emulated by nation states. The EU could target research and education grants, using a proven model to target funds to popular FOSS communities, that align to the strategic initiatives, in the same way RH succeeded. My experience would tell me that this is best done by extending where commercial entities would stop short (e.g. documentation, packaging and delivery of FOSS alternatives). I've witnessed that FOSS projects are as capable as commercial alternatives. However they tend to fail in the delivery and operation. This is intentional, as it is not in the interest of commercial FOSS to make this easy. A very worthy initiative. Thank you.

I believe that everyone has a lot to benefit from open-source software and hardware as well. From lower to no cost of operation, to better security, to less of a reliance on a company or forum that can dictate one direction or another. Free software can easily be forked and changed to something different, so resilience is also assured. Derived side-projects can freely research new ideas and these can be later reintegrated in bigger applications, benefiting a larger amount of users. I also feel that an OSS initiative would be great for Europe as everyone can chime in at their time and leisure, as we are fragmented and different in many ways, but can unite under one goal. At this point of time, for a EU FOSS initiative to thrive, I think the following steps should be ensured: 1) create an EU-based code repository that can host all the code required for these projects to exist. This platform should allow users to host all their public and private code and should allow for good cooperation between code contributors. Basically, an alternative to github that is not privately owned. 2) most important for open-source software is it's license as this justifies the scope in which the code can be used, if it can be used in private or profit areas or if it can be altered / modified without giving credit to it's creators. I think there should be a highlight on a few standardized code licenses that everyone can use and some public information on what you are allowed to do and what not. Legal enforcement is also required. 3) create a transparent mechanism that states, companies and individuals can donate to finance FOSS projects. There should be an way for entities to finance the research and development of key features that are needed in the day-to-day software that everyone is using. This creates job opportunities for professionals or financing opportunities hobbyists or freelancers and will speed up software development. The end results will benefit all users. 4) a list of endorsed projects should be published. This list should be open and show statistics of their adoption by various institutions and what other alternatives are being worked on. The role is to highlight what projects are the most important at the moment, so people can contribute to these or to have an idea of what to choose. 5) use only open standards. Many people say that the main issue to adapting OSS software is that their specific documents and workflow is not supported and as such OSS software is bad. On the contrary, major tech companies no not want to support open standards or use closed-source standards within open standards just to have a captive audience. For example, Microsoft with their proprietary document and email standards and Adobe that uses proprietary standards within an open standard (for PDF files). Public institutions should only use open standards or have a web-based applications that allows documents to be filled in such a way that the input is platform-agnostic, without any vendor lock-in. 6) private EU institutions should provide payed hosting for clients based on these software solutions. The contract should state that these institutions should also contribute back some of their earnings to these projects or for public training. 7) public courses should be available both for system administrators, maintenance workers and final users, so that everyone has some idea on how the software works and what are it's limitations at the moment. Public tech schools should also prioritize these software solutions in their curricula. This will create a lot of job opportunities and will solidify an open ecosystem. Open-source hardware should also be taken into consideration. A collaborative effort between board and component designers and EU institutions that could print and assemble these designs could speed up tech advances and research in the EU. This would also help out if propriet

In 2009 we already advanced the problems EU is facing now, writing proposals to mitigate them, which are still totally valid. The report was mandated by Spanish Ministry of Industry. I am sorry but its language is Spanish. It is publicly available at https://digital.csic.es/handle/10261/38114 (CSIC - Spanish National Research Council)

Im submitting input to the European Commissions Call for Evidence for the upcoming Communication Towards European open digital ecosystems (Q1 2026). Given the 4,000-character limit, Im sharing here a concise summary and attaching a full PDF with detailed evidence, examples, and proposed EU-level measures. In short: Europes key strength is high-quality open technologies and strong institutional trust. The core weakness is the maintenance and security stewardship gap (funding, governance, succession, LTS support). The biggest adoption barriers are procurement/compliance built for proprietary vendors, plus operational friction (deployment, documentation, integration) and uneven software supply-chain practices (SBOM, signing, coordinated vulnerability handling). Open source delivers concrete lifecycle benefits: reduced lock-in, improved auditability and resilience, stronger competition and SME participation, and better sovereignty outcomes. Priority areas where EU action can move the needle: EU-funded stewardship (maintenance + security + governance operations) EU-centered foundation infrastructure (trusted repos, secure CI/CD, signing/attestation, SBOM pipelines, vulnerability intake/triage) Procurement reform with lifecycle-ready support contracts and audit-based accountability Focus domains: cloud, AI infrastructure, cybersecurity, edge/IoT, internet technologies, open hardware, and industrial stacks (automotive/manufacturing) Full submission is provided in the attached PDF. #OpenSource #DigitalSovereignty #Cybersecurity #FOSS #OpenStandards #OSPO #EUDigital

Myself: I am an expert in offensive cybersecurity with 8 years of experiences. Answer (ii): Founding. Private money: Companies need to be able to sell their works in open source software. Some companies sell services around their open-source software (IT support, in selling hardware with preinstalled open source software, ). Some companies create a private non-open source product, based on their open source product where they add features that companies like/need and individuals hobbyists dont. Some companies sell services/hosting, cloud access to a service provided by open source software). If thoses companies growth, gain more clients, earn more money, they will contribute more to their open-source project. (Note: Licensing is important. GPL-3/AGPL are interesting.) So the question for me is how to help those companies to growth and earn more money. Public money and associations: NlNet foundation, NGI, Framasoft, Those associations, organizations and funding are important and successfully create a lot of high-quality software with minimal cost. Need to keep funding them, and increase funding for them. 3. What concrete measures and actions may be taken at EU level to support the development and growth of the EU open-source sector and contribute to the EUs technological sovereignty and cybersecurity agenda? The biggest issue is money. Not public money to develop open source software and research, but commercial contract money. The best thing that can happen is companies and public organization deciding to switch from their current technological solution to an open source European solution. The ones deciding which product they buy or services they use are DSI, RSSI and company owners. DSI and RSSI, before working once where students, children. Also people, when choosing what technologies to use in their professional environment, have opinions and known products based on what their use in their personal life. Long term: In schools, open source European software/system/cloud must be used and taught instead of non-European systems. Education, about the risks of using non-open source system, non-European system. And about the interest of open source systems. What is happening right now should and will be taught for future generations. Short term: DSI, RSSI and company owners must be sensibilized to the risks of using foreign systems. Most of them dont understand or refuse to accept that there are many risks in using foreign systems, which can be fatal for their company. Some incorrectly thinks that if the data are hosted in a European company they mitigated the risks. This is completely wrong, for example, with the USA law cloud act, just hosting the data in Europe is worse than useless: It is useless and provides a we did something (useless) stamps. People speaking about this subject and risks at events attended by DSI, RSSI, or company owners. With European opensource companies present so they can after show their solutions/products / Also, it is the responsibility of the DSI and RSSI to protect their company against those risks. Most DSI and RSSI believe that this is not their duty, and that it is the duty of the government/European law and regulation. Labels: To help DSI and RSSI, labels should exist that certify that This product is made by a European company, the investor of this company are European, the team is European, the servers/data are in Europe, the technology is European. Regulations and financial incentive: Add criteria to various funds. Some years ago in France, after many cyberattacks against hospital, the government decided that if a hospital doesnt spend at least 10% of their IT budget in cybersecurity, the hospital wont receive any money from the government. Something similar could be implemented for various industries: If you dont spend at least X% of your IT budget in European company products/services, you lose the subvention/fund

There are three key things I believe will rapidly improves European posture and resilience. 1) A universal switch to Linux operating systems and collaboration suites such as Libre Office - with Next Cloud for a more enterprise level approach; 2) An approach to hyperscale and black box vendor systems grounded in Responsibility by Design (see the framework at https://responsibility-by-design.anvil.app)
