feedbackTextUserLanguage: Patrick

feedback: The European Open Digital Ecosystem strategy should support the development of open-source software through the following European initiatives: - Obligatory education on open-source resources, European AI and IT security at all levels of the obligatory education and continuously for the most updated knowledge for any young EU citizen. The education of and onto open-source resources would help at several levels: - Understanding the relevance of open-source software and how to contribute to it. - Future Human Resources for a world-relevant efficiency of the European software workforce. - Understanding of IT infrastructures of business and public entities. - Learning the IT security basics as a future EU citizen and workforce, avoiding human-induced security exploits such as phishing and social engineering mechanisms. - Understanding of AI, its uses and golden standards for personal and professional needs. - The creation of the European Open-Source Software Authority (EU-O2SA): this authority, composed of selected European senior IT engineers in all critical software and infrastructures, would: - Maintain the critical open-source resources, technically and security-wise. - Maintain a CVE-like reference website with its recommendations for long-term support for businesses. - Produce an annual report on the newest security standards in the most critical open-source resources. - Evaluate on an annual basis different open-source resources, based on their relevance, accessibility, security and maintenance requirements. - Produce recommendations on an annual basis for easier and better recruitment for both public and private entities in the domain of IT infrastructure and software development. - The Open-Source Software Authority would amount to teams of 5 - 15 engineers dedicated to each critical open-source software for a renewable contract of 1 year. Should the criticality of an open-source resource lose in relevance, quality and security relevance, the aforementioned engineers contract would stop and a reconversion offer would be provided. - Additionally, to jumpstart the EU-O2SA, the first open-source teams would be specialised in the migration from critical paid non-EU software and infrastructures to EU open-source software and infrastructures. - Enforcement of Open-Source Software adoption for critical institutions and infrastructures with a proportional budget allocation (or re-allocation in case of present contracts with non-EU-based companies). - Recruitment of open-source developers would follow the EU-O2SA standards. - In budget reallocation cases, the EU-O2SA would narrowly accompany the public or private entity. - The EU-O2SA subsidies for public and private institutions in the adoption of open-source software and infrastructures in place of foreign non-EU software. - Promotion of open-core business models in European-based software and infrastructures to improve the competitiveness and security of EU digital resources.

Je suis architecte (bâtiment), et je travaille dans une agence d'architecture. Tous nos ordinateurs sont sous windows. Nous utilisons quotidiennement la suite office pour la bureautique et Outlook pour les courriels. J'ai tenté de faire passer mon agence sur Thunderbird mais ça n'a pas été maintenu pour la raison que pour l'archivage de nos mails, nous utilisons des fichiers d'archive spécifiques à Outlook, qui sont faciles à ouvrir, consulter et modifier depuis un poste sur un réseau, contrairement à ceux de Thunderbird. Concernant les logiciels de conception et dessin architectural : nous sommes passés de la suite Adobe à la suite Affinity. Scribus, GIMP et Inkskape pourraient répondre à nos besoins mais ont été jugés inadaptés. Par contre nous faisons un usage croissant de QGIS pour nos cartes. Nous dépendons également de Sketchup pour nos modélisations, ainsi que d'un clone d'Autocad. Il n'existe actuellement pas d'équivalent open source pour les activités suivantes à performance équivalente : - modélisation de type sketchup - dessin technique 2d de grande echelle avec gestion de grands fichiers topographiques - modélisation BIM Je crois qu'il est possible au niveau européen, de financer une solution logicielle open-source pour la modélisation BIM, tournant sur Linux, Mac, et Windows. Ce serait en tout cas une grande avancée dans l'autonomie européenne.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: I am an architect (building), working in an architectural agency. All our computers are in windows. We use the Office suite for office automation and Outlook for emails on a daily basis. I tried to pass my agency over Thunderbird, but this was not maintained because for the archiving of our emails, we use archive files specific to Outlook, which are easy to open, consult and edit from a post on a network, unlike those of Thunderbird. With regard to architectural design and design software: we moved from the Adobe suite to Affinity. Scribus, GIMP and Inkskape could meet our needs but were considered unsuitable. On the other hand, we are making increasing use of QGIS for our cards. We also depend on Sketchup for our modelling, as well as on a clone from Autocad. There is currently no open source equivalent for the following activities with equivalent performance: — sketchup modelling – Large scale 2d technical drawing with management of large topographic files – BIM modelling I believe that it is possible at European level to finance an open-source software solution for BIM modelling, turning on Linux, Mac, and Windows. This would in any case be a major step forward in European autonomy.

feedback: I am an academic AI researcher in Ireland. Being in this field makes me keenly aware of how much digital sovereignty the EU is giving up by relying on privatised technology infrastructure. Especially infrastructure from outside the EU. The decisions made by EU citizens and organisations are being shaped by tech giants using data they collect from all levels of our increasingly digital infrastructure. AI especially is a technology where it is critical to have transparency in training, in injected automatic prompts, and in potential bias. As EU citizens and institutions become more dependent on AI, the ability for companies which control the AI to subtly influence people and organisations will grow massively. This can be used to swing elections and for these private AI companies to silently usurp power and control our understanding of the world to their benefit. Requiring AI be open source and transparent with open training is critical to ensuring the AI revolution works for the EU instead of creating private institutions (inside or outside the EU) which begin to control it.

One of the factors that hinders the adoption of Open Source software is the difficulty of ensuring compliance in regulated or partially regulated environments. In this context, compliance refers to the adoption of processes aimed at meeting security, regulatory, and legal requirements, as defined by recognised frameworks and standards such as NIST, ISO/IEC 27001, ISO/IEC 27017, ISO/IEC 27018, SOC 2, PCI DSS, and the GDPR. In the proprietary software ecosystem, major vendors typically provide compliance-oriented solutions that are tightly integrated with their own products and platforms. This approach, while effective within those ecosystems, effectively creates barriers to the adoption of Open Source solutions, particularly in sectors subject to strict regulatory and security requirements. This challenge does not arise from intrinsic limitations of Open Source software in terms of security or quality, but rather from the lack of shared and recognised governance frameworks explicitly addressing compliance in Open Source contexts. In this respect, the European Commission, including through targeted funding, should promote the development of governance frameworks aligned with existing regulatory and security standards. Such frameworks should focus on processes, roles, documentation, and auditability, and should be designed to support the development and adoption of Open Source solutions in regulated environments. This would contribute to reducing vendor lock-in, improving interoperability, and lowering the overall cost and complexity of compliance, in line with European digital sovereignty objectives.

Europe should be actively encouraging any entity over which it has the slightest influence at all - governments, emergency services &c - to transition to Free and Open Source Software (FOSS). If the EU could get its memeber states to get state-funded education to transition to FOSS - the use of the proprietary alternatives would decline dramatically. The smallest, easiest, no-cost change in behaviour would be the adoption of the objectively superior Open Document Format (or ,html) for all "Office" documents. Obviously governments can lead by example in this. No one need be trapped in an ecosystem by their legacy documents. Much nonsense is spouted about how difficult GNU/Linux operating systems are to learn - there are a number of desktop user-interfaces that are perfectly straightforward, and would seem familiar to anyone who has used either Windows or MacOS. Linux operating systems tend to require fewer resources than their proprietary counterparts, and some still offer 32bit images, long after most of the world moved to using 64bit systems. Linux opreating systems also tend to enjoy greater longevity, with seme providers offering Long Term Support versions - with security updates - of their software. Both these factors mean that hardware that is functioning perfectly well does not need to be replaced - saving literally tonnes of unnecessary e-waste (a political headache and an environmental catastrophe). And so to applications. As a consequence of "planned obsolescence", I have used Linux exclusively for a decade and a half, and have never had a problem finding an application to do a job I needed to do (including self-hosting a cloud). Many of the more fundamental applications are now in fairly carefully set-up Foundations, which seem, on the whole, to be well-run. Liaising with the Free Software Foundation (www.fsf.org) might be good advice. Obviously, the unique point about Open Source Software is its transparency - anyone with sufficient skill can inspect and probe the code for vulnerabilities, and this makes FOSS stronger than the proprietary alternatives. Also FOSS tends to be local. Since 2007 we have been encouraged to store our data remotely. It wasn't long afterwards that the industry realised the value of data-mining. This trend needs to be reversed, for numerous reasons, including security, accessability and reliability, but also so that individuals gain an understanding of the implications surrounding the amount of data that they are retaining. At which point mobile offerings need to be addressed. In the same way that every click, every keystroke, every application and document opened and saved is known on the internet-linked proprietary desktop, so the same is true on the smartphone. The UN declares that humanity has a right to privacy, and the EU's members of the UN need to make that a reality. The EU needs to advocate the use of completely open source mobile operating systems - such as postmarketOS or Ubuntu Touch - for use on touch-screen devices. Operating systems based on AOSP or even Halium are not guaranteed to be available in the long-term. However, these initiatives are staggeringly under-resourced, and would benefit from some help from the EU, or EU entities. Finally a word about open source hardware. It is encouraging to see the European Union putting some funding towards the development of open-source RISC-V processer designs. The EU needs to pursue an independent chip future. The EU would also do well to support one of a number of manufacturers of (Linux) hardware,

I'd like to provide two pieces of feedback, besides my general support for open-source software and hardware (such as 3d printers): * First, I've heard people from various background, including someone in charge of a hospital, say that they could not afford open-source. Not because it is difficult to use, not because it is failing often, the reasoning could never reach that point: the problem is, when there is an issue, they need to be able to call someone and have it fixed soon. This creates a dependency on closed-source technologies, and often, when the company fails, hospitals end up with an unsupported mess and without the funds to replace it. This is true at small scale for specialised software and at larger scale for general software (unsupported and insecure windows XP systems in critical environments, for example). But when they are big enough, these software become infrastructure, and could be managed as such. Instead of every public service paying for windows licenses, these millions (billions?) of euros could be used to provide support for open source technologies, through organisations similar to the ones responsible for electricity infrastructure. This would naturally help improve the open-source software public services use, keep competent devs happy and in the eu, enable widespread adoption by companies as the projects become more common and standard, reduce dependency on closed-source, and decrease costs through scale and federation of efforts. Companies could probably also pay for that support. * Existing funding solutions for open source are mostly for mature projects, but which opportunities help new projects launch? Which hackathon follows up with a way to fund a bunch of new open source projects sustainably, long enough for them to become big enough? Startups need capital investment before launching. Open source software, which enables everyone to be productive, requires passionate people sacrificing their free time. How much more would we have if some people could pay rent for moonshot projects? Could we get an open-source secure sms system for example (an open source implementation of Rich Communication Services, which should also probably be infrastructure) ? Linux and a lot of key projects started very small and were already useful. Significant projects nowadays require much more investment to be truly independent (see the ladybird browser), because there is simply much more existing hardware and standards to support. We need to think of how the next generation of open source software will be funded, not just how current software can survive.

Was mir wichtig ist: - Unterstützt die Entwickler finanziell angemessen und regelmäßig, weil sie eigentlich ein Ersatz für eigene Entwickler sind und selbst manchmal nicht arbeiten gehen können - Erarbeitet ein Konzept und Konkrete Gesetze, um Menschen in diesem Umfeld vor Burnout und psychischen Problemen zu schützen Viele Entwickler*innen arbeiten an solchen Projekten in ihrer Freizeit, ehrenamtlich. Sie müssen nebenbei auch Arbeiten. Vorallem bei kritischen Open Source Projekten ist das manchmal schwierig, zum Beispiel wenn schnell gehandelt werden muss (Sicherheitslücke offengelegt, Angriff auf System). Diese Menschen, die manchmal die Einzigen sind, die sich wirklich damit auskennen, können dann nicht wie gewohnt zur Arbeit gehen. Bei Projekten, die in Programme auf der ganzen Welt eingebaut sind, arbeiten sie tagelang durch, um schnellstmöglich das Problem zu lösen. Sie sehen sich als die Verantwortlichen, falls etwas schlimmes passiert. Nicht nur ist das extrem psychisch belastend ("Was, wenn jemand stirbt oder sein Geld verliert, weil wir den Fehler nicht schnell genug beheben konnten"). Auch bekommen sie dadurch Probleme mit ihrem Arbeitgeber und dadurch finanzielle Schwierigkeiten. Ich bitte sie, diese Punkte bei der Verwendung von Open Source Projekten zu beachten. Generell finde ich Open Source Projekte super und plädiere dafür, sie breit einzusetzten. Die Gründe dafür haben andere Kommentator*innen sicher ausfühlich dargestellt.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: What matters to me: Developers provide adequate and regular financial support because they are actually a substitute for their own developers and sometimes cannot work themselves – develop a concept and concrete laws to protect people in this environment from burnout and mental health problems. Many developers work on such projects in their free time, on a voluntary basis. You will also have to carry out work incidentally. This is sometimes difficult, especially for critical open-source projects, for example where rapid action is needed (vulnerability revealed, system attack). These people, who are sometimes the only ones who really know about it, will then not be able to go to work as usual. For projects embedded in programmes around the world, they work for days to solve the problem as soon as possible. You see yourself as the controller if something goes wrong. Not only is it extremely psychologically stressful (“what if someone dies or loses their money because we could not fix the mistake quickly enough”). They also experience problems with their employer and thus financial difficulties. I would ask you to take these points into account when using open source projects. In general, I find Open Source projects super and call for them to be widely deployed. The reasons for this have been shown to other commentators with certainty.

feedback: Ich setze seit über 20 Jahren, erfolgreich freie Software und Betriebssysteme auf Computern und Smartphones ein. Dadurch kann ich die Geräte weit über die Zeit hinaus, mit sicherer, aktueller und guter Software ausstatten. Bei Geräten, auf welchen Software von Microsoft, Apple oder Google wurde, ist ein sicherer Betrieb, nach wenigen Jahren nicht mehr möglich. Daher finde ich es unabdingbar, dass freie und quelloffene Software gefördert wird.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: I have been successfully using free software and operating systems on computers and smartphones for over 20 years. This will allow me to equip the devices with safe, up-to-date and good software well beyond the time. Devices on which Microsoft, Apple or Google software has become available will not be able to operate securely after a few years. I therefore consider it essential to promote free and open-source software.

feedback: One key idea that might not be clear to decision makers: open source is not free of charge! Just because nobody forces us to pay for it, doesn't mean the developers, hardware, electricity, events, etc. don't require money. I think we should orient the budget needs on what we used to or expect to pay for proprietary software and then think about how this money is split up reasonably between the different needs that create open source software. A second point is that open standards for file formats are just as important as open source software. The open format actually enables you to choose another software. Thanks all readers for working on this crucial topic!

I wish for the EU to rely on open source technologies, by which I explicitly mean technologies that are resilient from having their license changed by a company to their own benefit. The EU should be able to do their computing without being reliant on the US. Linux and BSDs are the only operating systems that currently allow such. Besides general Laptop/Desktop software (Desktop Environments such as Gnome/KDE, Kernels such as the Linux Kernel), which is already fairly decently supported, there are various pain points. - We need support for an office suite that can be used across the EU based on open source technologies to the benefit of everyone. Microsofts monopoly here is an everlasting blackmail opportunity by the US - We need to support the creation of competing mobile operating systems such as SailfishOS such as it is provided by for example the jolla phone. Only this way can be have a chance to not be spied upon by the US through google, have trade secrets stolen and Privacy infringed - We need to support the open source technologies we already rely upon and that often are operating on shoestring budgets. - We need to improve accessibility across the open source software stack. A lot of work has already been done here on Linux and Wayland, but more remains to be done by the various Desktop Environments. The german sovereign tech fund is already a great idea in that regard and has done fantastic work. I believe using this model and scaling this up to be EU wide with appropriate funds could be something to look into.

At a time when many feel at the mercy of rapid technological and economic shifts, it is reassuring to see decisive and unambiguous action being taken. The swift and clear commitment to achieving greater digital sovereignty and competitiveness not only restores agency but also builds confidence. Europe is demonstrating that by expanding open technologies, strengthening its own expertise, and fostering independent infrastructure, we can overcome dependencies and shape our future on our own terms. Every step toward open standards, transparent systems, and collaborative innovation is a step toward a future where we not only keep pace but leadsovereign, secure, and competitive. Please see my answers in the attached odt-file

Good day, these are concrete actions I believe the EU should take to enable opensource to flourish and make the EU competitive and a technology powerhouse. **Funding** It is imperative that the EU aggressively fund opensource projects they use, from top to bottom. Every library, every application, every protocol, everything. It must be possible to write opensource software and when its used to make money, the project should see revenue. How this is done will properly will have to be discussed and debated, but the outcome should be an easy procedure for projects to be reimbursed. A central registry for opensource projects (and the registry should be opensource too, not Microsofts Github) like a business registry, a new opensource license to legally enshrine the obligation of payment once financial gains are achieved, something like that. Another point: opensource shouldnt mean oh, its free. The developers of the Matrix protocol and Element are having a tough time staying afloat **despite** multiple governments using the protocol to build secure messengers. **Public Money, Public Code** Opensource should be the default for software, for contracts, for research, for anything the government touches. Our money shouldnt be shovelled into IP that we need to pay to access via a subscription. Money used to fund the development, procurement, installation, maintenance, of software must be tied to an obligation to reveal the source code. **End of Life = Opensource** Private companies have a lot of closed source products. Unfortunately, when these products reach their end of life and are no longer supported by the company, they are often abandonned or become insecure. This can have digital effects like the Stop Killing Games European Citizens Initiative showed (games being lost, sometimes forever), but also physical, real world effects like e-waste. Many products end up on the trash heap and pose a tangible problem for governments and communities worldwide. Therefore, products that reach EOL must be opensourced. The opportunity must be given to entities to carry the torch and prevent those products from turning into waste. It can open new markets, provide employment, lower our carbon footprint, and also lead to innovation. **Ownership of services** We are scrambling now to become digitally sovereign and owners of our own destiny. That shouldnt mean jumping from one frying pan of foreign ownership into the frying pan of domestic ownership without real ownership. Governments must own their services, software, and when possible also hardwre. The Eurostack is good way forward, but it must not lead to a single contractor owning all infrastructure. Where services are concerned, they should all be self-hosted. When users or others access social.government.eu it also helps the user identify genuine services that governments provide as well approved and public identities. President Von Der Leyen having an account @vonderleyen@social.europa.eu is much easier to verify than @vonderleyen, @leyen, @vdleyen, or even @eupresident on some platform, regardless of what icon put around the name to confuse the user into believing the account is genuine. Thank you for your time and please see the attached document for a more in-depth response

Open Source solutions should not only be supported, but actively used, and Open Source solutions made by EU companies should be actively procured to validate this support. The use and procurement of Open Source solutions, and support solutions by the EU gives more legitimacy and sets an example for governments of member states to use Open Source solutions. It will also promote and spur innovation by companies to create tools and services, which might now only be available for commercial products (for example Windows, or Outlook) to become available for Open Source alternatives (like Linux and Thunderbird). This in turn creates options for private businesses who are now locked-in to use Windows for example, because they are required to use an Outlook add-in. Furthermore, the active use, procurement, support, and promotion of Open Source software and solutions will create more demand for programmers and developers of open source code. Hence the adoption of open source software and solution should also be promoted within Education, as there is significant lock-in there too through often cheap or even free offers by commercial offerings (Google and Microsoft) to achieve said lock-ins. Something else the EU could do it support the organizing of IT and security expo's specifically for EU made products and services, and open source solutions from the EU. I name both open source and non-open source here as EU made solutions have a hard time being seen over the foreign solutions (which have "unlimited" VC funded marketing budgets). Help EU companies by championing them as OUR companies. The EU should provide funding as an investor, to make it more attractive for other investors to join. It should do so widely, and not only for products it uses itself. It ought to come with the stipulation that a company cannot be bought by, or having a controlling stake by a company or organization outside of the EU. This in order to prevent foreign companies just buying everything to starve out the EU. The EU could also pursue it as investment, rather than 'funding' companies through grants, investing in companies by buying a share of the company. There will be failures, but also big successes. Perhaps it could even help kick-start an EU sovereign wealth fund. I think we first ought to invest in Open Source solutions from EU companies that work on Data/ Cloud-based storage including building the infrastructure. This to ensure data sovereignty. We ought to invest in open source mobile OS's like Jolla's SailfishOS or the Spanish Liberux project as that has the biggest risk of lock-in by Apple and Google. Then we ought to invest in more user-friendly alternatives to Microsoft M365 ecosystem (exchange, entra, intune) that can support Open Source OS's (ea. Linux). (Relution is an example, though not open source I believe). As noted this should not just be supported, but bought, used, and promoted by the EU. To give a concrete example; China actively supported HuaWei by ensuring all government employees got HuaWei phones. Now the EU is not China, but it speaks to the need for the EU to use EU made products including open source in order to make it successful. Don't be shy to think big, out of the box, be greatly ambitious, and especially think long term, please!

Les citoyens européens doivent comprendre l'enjeu sur les logiciels libres et ouverts. La liberté est une composante primordiale de notre communauté européenne. La culture du logiciel libre et les enjeux de souveraineté, d'autonomie devraient être enseignés et les européens sensibilisés.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: European citizens need to understand the issue of free and open source software. Freedom is an essential component of our European community. The culture of open source software and the issues of sovereignty and autonomy should be taught and Europeans made aware of them.

feedback: Why this matters for Europe specifically US open source comes from corporations serving corporate interests. Google releases Kubernetes to commoditize infrastructure and drive cloud adoption. Meta releases React to attract developers to their ecosystem. The EU has a different opportunity: open source as public infrastructure for cross-border collaboration. No other mechanism lets 27 member states build shared digital infrastructure without corporate capture. When the EU funds open source, it creates genuinely public goodssoftware that serves citizens, not shareholders. This aligns with European values in a way the US model never will. What's needed 1. Treat open source as infrastructure, not research Roads get maintained. Open source should too. Current EU funding produces projects that die when grants end. Fund ongoing maintenance of critical shared infrastructure. 2. Use public procurement as a tool When governments pay for open-source development and support, they build European capacity. When they just use free software, they don't. Make it easy for public bodies to fund open-source work directly. 3. Invest in the operational layer Building software is solved. Running software sustainably isn't. The tools needed to operate systemsobservability, deployment safety, incident responseare US-dominated. Fund European alternatives. 4. Build sovereign infrastructure Code hosting, package registries, CI/CDstill US-controlled. This is fixable. Bottom line The EU shouldn't try to copy the US model. It should build something better: open source as public digital infrastructure, funded democratically, serving European collaboration. That's a model only the EU can do.

I consider FLOSS crucial for the EU sovereignty and security. FLOSS software projects, software and platforms should be considered critical strategic infrastructure for the UE, since larger and larger shares of our life and politics switches towards the digital.

We rely on foreign software for almost all our digital infrastructure but foreign countries could and often do have malicious intentions and introduce backdoors or kill switches in their hardware and software. Often they have different interests and values than european citizens. The software we use on critical and strategic sectors of society should be in the hands of european developers and companies only, moreover in this age of political uncertainty. The USA Cloud Act forces US tech corporations to submit data of european citizens when required, even if that data is stored on foreign soil. Microsoft itself, when asked last year before a Senate inquiry in France, admitted it cannot guarantee data sovereignty to customers should the Trump administration demand access to their information held on its servers. Digital services from the identification of citizens to payment systems cant rely on the will of other countries as theyre critical infrastractures. Its not only a matter of hostility and submission: free and open source software could be the basis for equal relations and strengthen cooperation between states. Sharing open source software and helping developing countries build a free digital infrastracture they can rely on could also help us spread democratic values in a peaceful and disinterested way, in a period where democracy is not a popular form of government around the world. We also are a developing country in terms of the digital infrastrctures. We do not own the production chain of the hardware we use, we cannot analyze its closed firmware and drivers, and we must submit to its planned obsolescence that is an additional cost and security threat for us as drivers and firmwares are only supported for a few years by manufacturers whom closed source code we have to blindly trust. While we need to invest in our autonomy, we also need to produce code that is more efficient and consumes fewer resources in order to cope with periodic hardware supply crises weve already seen in the last few years, and make ourselves more resilient. Theres no competition for european developers and companies when all european citizens have to use every day SaaS distributed by tech monopolies, who rely on lock-in techniques to prevent the possibility to choose alternatives. Foreign tech monopolies have access to funds european companies could never obtain - as antitrust laws are more permissive in other countries - so cooperation between our companies is essential to remain competitive both on our and on the global market. Proprietary softwares already rely a lot on open source libraries we need to maintain. As Public money, public code - a Free Software Foundation Europe campaign on the importance of Free and Open Source Software in the public sector - highlighted, there are a lot of reasons the software paid by the citizen should be released as free and open source and not be treated as a business secret. Free and open source public software can be checked in search of security issues, repaired when it presents some problems and upgraded by the contribution of different members of society from university researchers to indipendent developers which could have specific needs a company might not want to bother with (e.g. accessibility). A license that limits the use of the public good for economic interests is no different than building a city around hostile architecture, treating only the needs of people as consumers and not as citizens. Weve seen this in Italy with the privatization of the sanitary sector during the Covid pandemic. Preparedness for pandemic diseases in the Lombardia region was seen as an additional cost by the private sector, hence there was no investment in it. We must be prepared and spend for future possible crises, not only for the present. Transparency shouldnt be optional when our safety and rights are at stake.

The use of Free and Open Source Software enables digital sovereignty as it cuts reliance on third party uncontrollable solutions. Encouraging collaboration, as well as transparency, FOSS puts the power back into the hands of users and developers. Users get to know that they have full control of the software they use. And developers can focus on the technical quality of the software, instead of appeasing higher management in a traditional corporate setting.

Open source is no longer a niche, it is the foundation of modern software development, powering even the worlds largest tech companies. When major technology companies build new platforms, they start by leveraging open-source solutions. The real value lies in adding a service layer: refining the software, tailoring it to their brand, and delivering robust support. This service layer isn't just about branding, its about usability. Historically, open-source software was powerful but rarely polished. To drive adoption, we need solutions that are intuitive, visually appealing, and supported. This is where Europe can excel: combining technical excellence with design and customer experience. And this layer isn't exclusive to Big Tech. European players can and should build it too. Europe has the talent and expertise to lead this transformation. By combining open-source foundations with strong service capabilities, we can compete globally and create sustainable, high-value software ecosystems. In short: open source is at the heart of modern software engineering. The only exceptions are legacy products from an earlier era, like Microsoft Windows or Office, which were built under a very different approach. Open Engineering: The Four Pillars To truly achieve digital sovereignty and foster innovation, we need to think beyond open-source software. The future lies in Open Engineering, built on four interconnected pillars: 1. Open Infrastructure Transparent, interoperable data centers and cloud platforms, reducing dependency on proprietary systems. 2. Open-Source Software The foundation for collaboration, reuse, and rapid innovation. 3. Open Data Accessible, standardized datasets powering AI, analytics, and new services while respecting privacy and security. 4. Open Standards Common protocols and specifications that ensure interoperability and prevent vendor lock-in. Together, these pillars create a sustainable, competitive environment where Europe can lead - not just by consuming open technologies, but by shaping and governing them. The service layer on top of these pillars is where European players can add value through integration, customization, and support. Open AI Models: A Strategic Imperative AI is transforming every industry, and open-source AI models are already widely available. It is crucial that the EU supports the development of truly open AI models and encourages European companies to adopt and contribute to them. Models learn and improve through user feedback - the more we use open models, the better they become. By prioritizing open AI, Europe can ensure transparency, trust, and technological sovereignty in this critical domain. Collaboration and Usability To make this vision a reality, Europe must unite companies, universities, and research centers. Collaboration will allow us to learn from past experiences, share best practices, and accelerate innovation. By embracing Open Engineering and investing in usability, collaboration, and open AI, Europe can build a digital ecosystem that is innovative, sovereign, and globally competitive.

J'espère ne pas être hors-sujet en osant parler du fond plutot que de la forme : 1) le matériel (hardware) : fonderies, p.c européens. 2) les fonds des citoyens disposés à investir dans les projets de l'E.U concernant l'adoption, la formation, la création des logiciels libres. 1) L'avenir est dans la capacité à créer ses propres puces et autres matériels non pas uniquement pour être indépendant mais parce que cela fait partie de la chaine de compétence, d'autonomie, de savoir-faire soutenant le logiciel libre qu'il nous faut acquérir. 2) Comme de nombreux utilisateurs et participants, créateurs et fournisseurs de plus-value (bénévolement ou pas) , je souhaite léguer ou donner une somme substentielle pour devellopper et affermir la position du logiciel libre - libre ne veut pas dire gratuit, cela a un cout non négligeable et permet à de nombreuses personnes mondialement mobilisées / mobilisables d'en vivre correctement. Pour ce faire, il faut que l'E.U accepte d'une part de créer une *fondation pour les grandes ambitions dont elle aura la charge de gérer les fonds , d'autre part de permettre aux citoyens de l'union de **léguer sans frais ni pour le donateur, ni pour le receveur des sommes pour tel ou tel projet, tel ou tel association ou tel ou tel étude (dont les certifications/tests/audits) et ce, à travers l'europe pour les pays européens exclusivement. ***Rien n'interdit d'ailleurs a-priori d'attirer des ames sensibles non-européennes. nota bene : *fondation est le terme le plus souvent rencontré ou qui vient à l'esprit, rien ne vous empêche de le nommer comme vous voulez , dès le moment où cela correspond à l'esprit et à la lettre ... **léguer est le terme générique pour dire faire un don d'argent / en nature sur testament ou durant sa vie. *** Accepter une aide venant hors-europe et en définir les limites et modalités est un sujet ardu.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: I hope not to be out of scope by daring to talk about substance rather than form: (1) hardware: European foundries. (2) funds from citizens willing to invest in EU projects related to adoption, training, creation of open source software. (1) the future is in the capacity to create its own chips and other materials not just to be independent but because it is part of the chain of competence, autonomy, know-how supporting the open-source software we need to acquire. 2) like many users and participants, creators and providers of added value (whether or not on a voluntary basis), I would like to bequeath or give a substantial sum of money to develop and strengthen the position of free software – free does not mean free, it has a significant cost and enables many people who are mobilised/able to work around the world to live well. To this end, the Member State must agree to set up a * foundation for the major ambitions for which it will be responsible for managing the funds, and to allow the citizens of the Union to bequeath * * at no cost either to the donor or to the recipient sums for a particular project, association or study (including certifications/tests/audits), through Europe exclusively for European countries. * * * there is nothing to prevent, a priori, the attraction of sensitive non-European Ames. * Foundation is the term most often encountered or coming to mind, there is nothing to prevent you from naming it as you want, from the moment it corresponds to the spirit and the letter... * * bequeath is the generic term for making a gift of money/in kind on will or during life. * * * accepting aid from outside Europe and defining its limits and modalities is a difficult topic.

feedback: Since a long time I have used open source software and done so preferentially. The open source software world has consistently made high quality software that is in use nearly everywhere, as evident by how many companies will include the open source software licenses with hardware and software they distribute. When working as a technician in the industry I have often run into problems with non open source software. The same machine still has to run 20 years later, but the software to configure it is only available on this 20 year old machine. And might require a license key no longer found. Not every industry can afford to update their machine park regularly and thus will run into these issues. Once the original software can no longer be used, they run the risk of falling even further behind with no possible solution. The machine has to keep running but a very important portion can no longer be modified. The PLC software no longer exists or can no longer run on any newer machine, the configuration utility of a converter module can no longer be found. Most of the companies I worked at have a stack of older and older laptops still hanging around. These insecure machines are what allows us to avoid large issues and keep things running until actual updates can happen. By having more open source software, some of these issues of incompatibility could still be fixed afterwards. If the source code was available for programs no longer supported, the industry could run better. For non industrial usage, these days it is clear that much of the software is licensed from American companies. Companies that are legally bound to enforce their governments law. And thus will do things like shutting down access to judges in European courts. The US is also showing themselves as more and more hostile towards Europe and specifically the EU. There is basically no risk of huge impact to Europe for open source software usage if the US grows even more adversarial to the EU. The exact opposite is the case for all closed source software, especially those with licenses that have to be checked online upon each program usage. What happens if all microsoft PCs suddenly no longer work or even no longer get updates? The disruption to European society would be enormous and would coordination of military action if necessary close to impossible. Open source software should nearly always be preferable to closed source software. If EU governments invested in open source software, an investment done by one government would directly help all other EU governments. Capitalism breaks down when there is no competition possible. As is almost always the case for closed source software, because they will more often than not avoid implementing standards correctly. Hoping to make rivals harder to work with for no benefit for the end user. It is not unlikely that if all software was forced to be open source, a better software economy would exist, with healthier competition where you could contract companies for specific features and companies would have an incentive to be better, not just attempt to capture the market and extract profit from that. Also important for Europe, money spend on digital infrastructure could be spent in Europe more frequently. When the government wants to construct a road, it would also not accept that for the entire future usage of that road, it would be bound by one company servicing that road and if they no longer wish to do so, the road becomes unusable. We can ask other companies to fix the road if they have shown to be better. And we should be able to do so with software. Software is also somewhere where EU governments can benefit a lot from each others investment, waste could be reduced and interoperability increased.

The EU's priority should be to support the maintenance of existing projects without imposing excessive constraints. Experience shows that bureaucratic barriers and reporting requirements can discourage independent developers, while direct and targeted funding, based on the actual use of projects, would ensure greater stability and continuity. The EU should focus on creating support infrastructure and visibility for free software, while providing a sustainable economic framework that incentivizes the participation of developers and SMEs. The idea should be to nurture the bees that produce the software, providing them with resources and support, without trying to control every line of code produced. Only by guaranteeing continuity, recognition, and fair compensation to maintainers can Europe build an independent digital infrastructure that is ready to compete globally and protect strategic sectors from external dependencies. Furthermore, let's not hide behind a finger: the term open source is dangerous and misleading. Misleading: because it transforms a highly POLITICAL issue (European independence and sovereignty in the face of a former ally now turn openly authoritarian, sinking into practices typical of the Nazi period in Germany or the Stalinist period in the former USSR) into a dull TECHNICAL issue. Software freedom is a political issue: it is the PREREQUISITE for the exercise of any FUNDAMENTAL RIGHT in a society that, even today, depends dramatically on technical infrastructure for their exercise. Open Source does not need any incentives, it is already mainstream: Microsoft Cloud runs on Linux, as does AWS. Everything that is not client-based (which is becoming less important with every passing second) is based on open source software. But all this open source is under permissive licenses (such as MIT, Apache, etc), that allow appropriation from Big Tech. First they let the public finance development at the taxpayer's expense, and then charge the public again for products such as the spyware known as Android, a graphical interface called MacOSX, etc. Using a BSD, MIT, Apache, or any other non-viral open source license is like taking a mountain of 500 euro bills and burning them in the public square. Please do not promote this nonsense. Free software, on the other hand, allows maximum market freedom, but DISINCENTIVES monopolies and the accumulation of money and power. According to Lewis Mumford's definition, it is a democratic technology, the very opposite of the authoritarian technologies with which GAFAM has stuffed the internet.

Question 1: Strengths, Weaknesses & Barriers Strengths: The EU has a vibrant open-source community delivering mature, production-ready solutions across critical sectors (networking, storage, security, AI). Weaknesses & Barriers: Fragmented documentation and lack of standardized deployment guides hinder enterprise adoption Public procurement optimized for proprietary vendors creates artificial barriers Hardware compatibility issues, particularly for AI accelerators and specialized processors Critical projects often rely on volunteer maintainers without guaranteed funding Absence of EU-hosted infrastructure (repositories, CI/CD platforms) creates non-EU dependencies Unclear business models for open-source companies Question 2: Added Value of Open Source Public Sector: Sovereignty: Full control without vendor lock-in Transparency: Auditable code enables security verification Cost efficiency: 40-60% cost reduction versus proprietary alternatives Interoperability: Open standards facilitate cross-border collaboration Private Sector: Supply chain security: Verifiable components reduce cybersecurity risks Flexibility: Customization without vendor permission Competitive advantage: SMEs compete equally with established players Market access: Build differentiated solutions on shared foundations Question 3: Concrete EU Measures Development & Sustainability: Dedicated funding for maintenance and security updates beyond R&D grants EU-hosted infrastructure services (code repositories, container registries, CI/CD) Support for open-source foundations providing professional governance Adoption & Integration: Reform procurement to mandate open-source consideration with interoperability requirements Certification programs for open-source solutions in critical sectors Standardized migration toolkits for transitioning from proprietary systems Ecosystem Growth: Accelerator programs for open-source startups and SMEs Professional support networks around key open technologies Educational programs integrating open-source development into curricula Open-source driver development and hardware certification programs Question 4: Priority Technology Areas AI/ML infrastructure: Open models, training frameworks, inference engines Cloud & edge computing: Alternatives to hyperscaler dominance Cybersecurity: Open security tools, intrusion detection, identity management Network infrastructure: Open networking stacks, DNS systems IoT & industrial control: Open protocols for Industry 4.0 Data management: Open databases, data space infrastructure Question 5: Sectors for Increased Competitiveness High-priority sectors: Public administration: Digital government, cross-border interoperability Healthcare: Electronic health records, medical imaging Manufacturing: Industrial IoT, supply chain management Automotive: Software-defined vehicles, autonomous systems Finance: Payment systems, compliance tools Energy: Smart grid, renewable energy management Open-source adoption simultaneously improves cybersecurity (transparency, auditability), reduces costs (eliminating vendor lock-in), and enhances competitiveness (rapid innovation, customization). Critical infrastructure sectors particularly benefit from verified security and long-term control over essential systems.

Quoting Poul-Henning Kamp: At the most fundamental level, the EU has three options: 1. Pick and bless a set of winners, consisting of: a) Operating system, portable to any reasonable computer architecture. b) Text-processing, suitable for tasks up to a book. c) Spreadsheet d) Email client. e) Web Browser f) Accounting software, suitable for small organizations. and fund organizations to maintain, develop and support the software for the future as open source, turning that software into infrastructure like water, power and electricity, free for all, individuals, startups and established companies alike, to use and benefit from. 2. Continuously develop/pick, bless and meticulously enforce open standards of interoperability, and then "let the competition loose". 3. Both. By providing a free baseline and de-facto reference implementations for the open standards, "the market" will be free to innovate, improve and compete, but cannot (re)create walled gardens. To everybody, me included, option two seems the ideologically "pure" choice, because we have all been brought to believe that "governments should not pick winners". But governments have always picked winners. Today all of EU has 230VAC electrical grids, because EU picked that as a winner, thereby leveling the market to everybody's benefit. Therefore I will argue, that the wise choice for EU is option three. First, it will be incredibly cheap, as in just tens of millions of Euro per year, to provide all EU citizens with a free and trustworthy software platform to run on their computers. Second, it can be done incredibly fast: From EU makes the decision, the first version can be release in a matter of months, if not weeks. Third, it will guarantee interoperability of data.

I have been developing OpenSource software for 20 years. Used by major players like Red Hat, Source forge, NVIDIA, Meta etc as a foundation of their products. OSS is a serious viable solution, it proves it every day, but it needs the will to invest time and effort into building a good and simple user experience around it. And marketing investment in building momentum so that there are enough users to interest other users. Those are all opportunities to help internal market and EU companies grow as they could be the ones building those experiences. But it needs to be done seriously. Not just with incentives and funds that are wasted to big companies that are better at filling papers and forms instead of innovating and building products for users.

I fully support this initiative and strongly believe it's necessary for the future of Europe. People aren't as aware of EU software products as big tech ones, I believe this is a symptom of vendor lock-in, e.g. using Microsoft OneDrive because it's built into windows, or the entire Apple Software ecosystem. As someone who is trying to integrate more open source software into my daily life (e.g. using Linux over windows), I found that many Microsoft based tools that I need for my average school work aren't available on Linux. I believe this to be the main cause of slow adoption, some open source tools don't work well with many people's work flow. This can be aided by using cross platform standards (such as PDF or DOC files) over proprietary ones (Microsoft Word Files) in governments and schools. There are smaller parts of day to day digital tasks such as using Microsoft Forms for surveys, which should also be addressed. One of the benefits of using open source software is the lack of planned obsolescence (specifically with Linux). I have successfully run Linux on decade old laptops with no problems, and have since incorporated them into my daily life, this will save me a lot of money because I don't need to upgrade to newer laptops, on a larger scale this can heavily reduce E-Waste (especially in schools, hospitals, governments and households). As part of the initiative, old hardware (e.g. not supported by windows 11) could be collected, open source alternatives installed and resold at low prices. The first step to make as many day to day digital tasks as platform independent as possible, which will make long term adoption easier, this switch alone will encourage many people already interested in FOSS to make the transition.

Hi, I want pre-phrase this by saying that I think that this topic as a very crucial topic for the following years and we as EU need to use open source software essentially everywhere where it's possible. Especially public entities using public money should use open source first. Public money, public code. However, regarding the questions... Barriers that hamper... 1. Adoption and maintenance - Defaults. Schools and universities (at least in Germany) mainly use Windows and Microsoft Office. At home, if young people are not gaming many don't have computers anymore and those (for now) primarily use Windows. This is difficult to change (although Valve is pushing with SteamOS, Proton and FEX), but the EU could help foster the use of Linux in schools in order to reach young people and change the default. If people learn e.g. Linux and Libre Office in school instead of Windows and Microsoft Office, the subsequent change in companies might be easier. - Reduce bureaucracy for the funding of open source projects - Reduce hurdles for the creation of non-profits. Maybe in the 28th regime? 2. Sustainable contributions - Create a EU open source fund. Companies can donate to this fund and decide towards which category of open source 50% of this money goes to. The rest of the money will be split equally over all projects. There can also be a public leaderborad or a kind of "badge" for sponsoring open source and promoting EU technology. I think initiatives such as "buy eu" clearly showed that this carries some weight. Additionally, companies could use this donation for a tax write-off. What is the added value of open source for the public and private sectors? - A customizable degree of freedom. Freedom to choose alternatives, freedom to keep using software even, if transatlantic relations become tricky. - Off course, open source software is also financially "free", but that's not the point. For companies, the "cost" simply shifts from software that can be gone in an instant to enterprise support agreements or investment in people that contribute to and maintain open source projects within the own company (better option). This builds in-house know-how while not having to "re-invent the wheel" for everything. It's essentially the best of both worlds. Open Source is also much more customizable and closer to user demands as the users can participate in the development. - Except for specialized applications and default habits there is no real reason to not use open source software wherever available. - The public sector should definitely try to avoid using Microsoft or other proprietary US software wherever possible. What concrete measures and actions may be taken at EU level to support the development and growth of the EU open-source sector etc. etc. - Don't mandate it or disallow proprietary US software as this might lead to aversions. - Instead make it more desirable financially to use open source as a company. Maybe in the form of tax write-offs for investments in local EU "open source companies" and contractors. What technologies should be prioritized and why? Ideally the fully stack from top to bottom, but IT infrastructure is already on it's way towards open source (thanks Broadcom) and for collaboration suites different countries like France and Germany already have solutions in progress (la suite and opensdesk). Therefore, I'm unsure if there is one concrete technology that must be prioritized, I'd rather put emphasis on platforms and tech close to the citizens of the EU. There especially the ones that purposefully hurt our democracies and spread hate. There are open source alternatives that can be supported: Instagram -> Pixelfed Twitter (X) -> Mastodon Youtube -> PeerTube Maybe even Linux-based smartphones? In what sectors could an increased use of open source lead to increased competitiveness and cyber resilience? If cyber resilience as a term is st

feedback: If you want to improve users' choice, stimulate competitiveness and reduce supply chain security issues, then I think the focus should be on decentralized software solutions. Take for example Matrix (embraced by the French government), which is an open network for secure, decentralized communication. It's comprised of several entities hosting the software, all being interconnected with each other. Such an entity could be a government, a corporation or a private individual. End users get the choice between hosting Matrix themselves or choosing a provider, so more users' choice. To get a bigger user-base, the commercial Matrix providers providers will need to compete more, so there is an inherent competitiveness stimulance. And since there is no single point of failure, taking down such a network becomes much harder.

We are depending on foreign countries to make our computer infrastructure work. Both the USA and China have already advanced hardware that we depend on. On top of that we depend on them to use that hardware with proprietary sofware. I think that, in order to gain more independance on foreign country, bringing the sofware in EU is aa firsr solid step. To do that step, I think EU should promote free and open source sofwaee. To do so, I think EU institution should rule bu exemple, and plan the use of such sofware internaly, and use that experience to promote the FOSS ecosystem. Promoting FOSS sofware at school will also allow new generarion of workers trained with those, reducing the friction needed to transition in the private sectore. With these two points, I think the investisment made to transition and promote FOSS will payoff and encourage private companies to do the same.

There is no time like today for boosting the EU's open source ecosystem. The guiding document highlights the need for a) EU digital/technological sovereignty; b) solutions and products for critical sectors. It also asks for evidence of added value, and calls for concrete measures. In this context, the following regulatory and practical points seem relevant: #1: Don't weaken the EU's state-of-the-art digital legislation (e.g. GDPR) in the context of 'simplification' (read: deregulation). Such work runs fully counter to our technological, economic, and geopolitical interests in 2026. The EU should stick to its existing legislation and use this to drive competitiveness. Everything else will make us look wishy-washy in terms of our own take on digital legislation. As illustrated by Cory Doctorow (link: https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2026/jan/10/trump-beginning-of-end-enshittification-make-tech-good-again), until now decision-makers had to somewhat placate Big Tech's interests lest we be subjected to broader economic responses by those protective of the sector. At this point the Trump administration is unashamedly pursuing an anti-EU agenda anyway, so why bother with being remotely helpful to Big Tech's interests? #2: Use open source solutions in your own offices to speed up mass-market adoption: If public institutions and agencies - be it EU, national, regional or local - start using open source solutions, people will become accustomed to them. This makes the jump to their use in private life much smaller. It would also undercut profits to actors who are actively trying to undermine our economy, political system, and long-term interests. The EU should coordinate this, so we avoid half of Europe reinventing the wheel. Perhaps the existing experiences of the International Criminal Court and the German state of Schleswig-Holstein can provide inspiration on project managing such a shift. #3: Break the overall 'lock-in effect': this builds on the previous point. For example, Belgium's government ID app (ItsMe) currently only appears to be compatible with Android and iOS software. While I am not against either of these software, this means residents of the country face a huge barrier to, for example, choose a phone if it were to run on an open-source operating system. #4: Recognise that this is not just about open source. For example: A) EU institutions should be wary of using digital products and services that profit actors who seek to undermine the EU (case in point: why are you still on X? Many civil society and other actors have already left, with their 'reach' being a small price to pay). B) The more broadly prioritising of EU(ropean) companies in EU procurement, i.e. to "become its own best customer" as the Canadian government recently phrased it in its "Buy Canadian" communication (https://www.canada.ca/en/treasury-board-secretariat/services/policy-notice/2025-7.html). Of course such procurement policies can be flexible in terms of close EU partners (like Canada, but also Norway, Iceland, Switzerland, the UK, accession countries, and countries such as Mercosur, Japan, Taiwan (ROC), or Singapore).

Free and open-source software developed in Europe reduces dependence on non-EU vendors (e.g. Microsoft) and strengthens Europes digital sovereignty. Open source software enables faster security fixes and more transparent vulnerability management, both of which are critical for protecting essential and critical infrastructure, where trust, auditability, and long-term resilience are paramount. Embracing FOSS is therefore not only technically sound, but also strategically beneficial for European citizens and Europes infrastructure.

Avoimen lähdekoodin ratkaisut ovat kannatettava ja mielestäni ainoa realistinen polku kohti riippumattomuutta amerikkalaisista ja kiinalaisista alustoista ja teknologiasta. Euroopassa on paljon alan osaamista ja avoimen luonteensa vuoksi avoimen lähdekoodin ratkaisut tuovat yhteen saman avoimen arvomaailman omaavia toimijoita myös muilta mantereilta. Näin kartutamme myös yhteistä osaamistamme ja vahvistamme yhteistä arvopohjaamme. Julkisen hallinnon, palveluiden ja esimerkiksi koulujen pitäisi ehdottomasti olla ensimmäisten joukossa ottamassa käyttöön Linux-pohjaisia, avoimia käyttöjärjestelmiä ja ohjelmistoja. Kansalaisten valistaminen on tärkeää, useimmat ovat tottuneet käyttämään suljettuja, kaupallisia alustoja eivätkä tiedosta riskejä. Tästäkin syystä koulut ovat erityisen tärkeässä asemassa tukemassa avointen digitaalisten ekosysteemien käyttöönottoa ja kasvua. Avoimuus on linjassa myös EU:n vihreän siirtymän tavoitteiden ja Right To Repair -aloitteen kanssa; laitteiden korjattavuus ja käyttöikä lisääntyy, koska Linux-pohjaisina ne ovat aidosti omistajansa hallinoitavissa.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: Open source solutions are a laudable and, in my view, the only realistic path towards independence from US and Chinese platforms and technologies. Europe has a great deal of know-how in this field and, due to its open nature, open source solutions bring together actors from other continents with the same open values. By doing so, we will also build up our common knowledge and strengthen our common values. Public administrations, services and schools, for example, should definitely be at the forefront of the roll-out of Linux-based, open-access operating systems and software. Educating citizens is important, most are used to using closed, commercial platforms and are not aware of the risks. This is also why schools play a particularly important role in supporting the uptake and growth of open digital ecosystems. Transparency is also in line with the EU’s green transition objectives and the Right To Repair initiative; the reparability and lifetime of the devices will increase as they are genuinely manageable by their owner on a Linux basis.

feedback: Ritengo che la sovranità digitale sia indispensabile per un Europa forte soprattutto in seguito ai cambiamenti nella politica Americana, in conseguenza delle elezioni di D. Trump. L'adozione di standard Open e la consolidazione di una struttura Cloud, insieme a massicci investimenti per un AI allineata sono improrogabili. Allo stesso tempo ritengo indispensabile un sostanziale miglioramento in ambito di cyber security per fare fronte alle minacce ibride russe..
feedbackTextUserLanguage: I believe that digital sovereignty is indispensable for a strong Europe, especially as a result of the changes in American politics following the elections of D. Trump. The adoption of Open Standards and the consolidation of a Cloud structure, together with massive investment in an aligned AI, are unavoidable. At the same time, I see a substantial improvement in cyber security as indispensable to address Russian hybrid threats.

feedback: Please, please, please get out of American tech. Host everything locally in Europe. Get rid of all Microsoft and Apple products, or force them into an opensource ecosystem where their powers are severely limited. What used to be reliable technology has become a vector for the largest ransomware attack in history. We cannot have war with America as it stands, as they can simply delete our economy and governance. It is that dire. Volkswagen made vehicles for Nazi Germany using slave labor, a company cannot be treated in isolation of its country. Apple can use our devices against us just as well. Moreover, there is a huge value proposition for EU: specializing in open source digital services. Embrace Linux, and invest heavily in companies and public institutions that can build world-class accessible experiences on them. Open source projects have created exceptional things with less funding than Christine Lagarde salary. Other countries also don't want to be so America reliant. If we can offer them support with a federated tech stack that they can own, this solves a real problem for them. Expertise that we can export.

The European Union must not only provide financial support but also lead by example. The Commission should mandate Open Source as the preferred standard for public procurement. Only by consistently implementing Open Source in public administration and education can we achieve the critical mass necessary for an independent, resilient European digital ecosystem that secures both our technological sovereignty and future jobs within the EU. You can find the details of my feedback in the PDF attachment!!!

feedback: I agree that the EU depends far too much on largely US-based technology. Free and open source software could solve many issues caused by this dependency, and instead of spending millions and millions of euros on subscription-based, closed, and potentially insecure software, the European Commission ought to invest that money in the development of FOSS to allow it to compete with its big tech competitors. FOSS should not feel like an afterthought, like a cheaper and less functional compromise, but it should be actively and enthusiastically adopted.

I believe that this is a great initiative. The lack of European software is evident, bur something less evident is how powerless the end user really is with proprietary software powered products. Especially outside the EU many people are ripped from core functionalities of what they bought and paid for because the manufacturer shut down the servers that were powering the product or because they pushed out a non-optional update locking functionalities behind paywalls and digital locks. With open-source all of these problems are non-existent as they are just simply impossible to pull of with an open-source structure as users can patch the code for themselves in the worse case scenario. Open-source also makes innovation thrive, since with open-source projects it is much easier and faster to get a desirable product. As a final thought: an open-source producing EU would be very powerful and would hopefully set the precedent for other countries to follow as open-source is good for the consumer and new players in the software world.

For a while now we have given most of our sovereignty away by destroying our industry due to incoherent EU legislation and forced ourselves into a service economy. These services, if they are all controlled my Microsoft, apple, etc , will not be ours, any other opponent will take over, and our economy will crumble. We will also lose all privacy, and give away everything to countries that openly hate us, such as the US or China. We cannot under any circumstance enrich the countries that openly hate us. If governments, schools, government services, etc, make use of open source software, this software will then become the standard in most industries as well - schools set the standard for what people learn, and use later on. Government services set the standards for preferred administration tools, which in turn become used by private business. Open source software becomes better when used by large quantities of people, and the recent years have seen a large switch to Linux due to the unacceptability of the state of things on Windows - most people reject surveillance (something the EU itself has not figured out) and, as it stands, most alternatives appear to be better than whatever is available on solutions given by Microsoft, apple, amazon, etc. People who were previously very unwilling to get out of their comfort zone have been pushed past the point where they feel forced to give up said comfort, signaling that the world is ready for this change. Even the dystopian attempt by the EU at spying on its citizen under the pretense of protecting the children is set up to use google services - ensuring that the Americans will have access to all private information on all citizens in the hypothetical police state some member states want the EU to be. Azure, AWS, etc have proven to be solutions as weak as they are invasive, showing the world that only a few errors from a few American companies can take down most of the internet for a while. The office 365 administrative suite, used by a large quantity of companies, is attempting copilot integration - something also being done with GitHub, which will now steal sources from developers for usage by a company in a country hostile to us, and known to help their intelligence to spy on its users. I cannot give an exhaustive list of companies and solutions, but any company within China is forced to hand over data to the CCP, and any large company in the US openly supports a government that is corrupt, hostile to us, and threatens to invade one of our member states. It is inconceivable to buy anything from them that has industrial, informational, or military importance. Although I am a developer, and make extensive use of FOSS on a daily basis, it is not necessarily as important in my opinion, for the EU to adopt FOSS as it is to get rid of private foreign solutions. It is of strategical importance - we are essentially handing them the keys to all information, and we know that they thrive on espionage. Otherwise, FOSS is responsible for most of what is good in the IT world of today, if not everything. - IoT would simply not exist aside from a few large manufacturers as everything changed when open source compilers, linkers, build systems replaced completely locked and extremely expensive platforms, IDEs, compilers etc for MCUs. - The computing world (internet, mobile, etc) would simply not exist, in general, if it wasn't for Unix, Linux, the C standard library, and so on - collapsing development costs to near zero, eliminating vendor lock in, enabling global collaboration. - Your router runs Linux. Your car probably does, your phone probably does. So do most of the servers you connect to, and nearly all super calculators in use today. - etc. It is nausea inducing to imagine all that we have missed by forcing ourselves to use these solutions, OSes, and so on for decades. Some of it would have been non foss - you'd only hav
