feedback: Todas las instituciones europeas deberían crear instancias de servicios de redes sociales libres (Mastodon, Lemmy, Piefed, Pixelfed, ...), las cuales deberían dar servicio exclusivo a las personas que trabajan en dichas instituciones, no admitiendo registro externo de cuentas. De esa manera se reduciría la dependencia de empresas de redes sociales foráneas a la Unión, ya que los ciudadanos europeos dejarían de necesitar esas redes foráneas para comunicarse con los ayuntamientos, gobiernos nacionales e instituciones europeas.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: All the European institutions should set up bodies for free social media services (Mastodon, Lemmy, Piefed, Pixelfed, etc.), which should only serve people working in these institutions and not accept external registers of accounts. This would reduce reliance on social media companies from outside the Union, as European citizens would no longer need such foreign networks to communicate with municipalities, national governments and European institutions.

feedback: I am writing as a concerned EU citizen to express my strong support for the European Open Digital Ecosystems initiative and to urge bold, decisive action to reduce our dependence on non-EU technologiesparticularly those from the US that have unfettered access to our data. 1. Digital Sovereignty Must Be a Priority Europe cannot afford to remain dependent on foreign tech giants for our critical digital infrastructure. The risks to privacy, security, and autonomy are too great. The recent push for digital sovereignty is a step in the right direction, but it must be accelerated. Public money should be invested in European contractors, open-source projects, and homegrown digital solutions that benefit all citizensnot just a handful of corporations. 2. Move the EUs Software Stack Away from Microsoft and Other US Providers The EU must lead by example. All European Union institutions and public administrations should transition away from proprietary software like Microsoft Office, Windows, and Azure to open-source alternatives. This shift should be immediate and comprehensive, covering: Operating systems: Replace Windows with European-supported Linux distributions. Office suites: Migrate to open-source alternatives like LibreOffice or OnlyOffice. Email and collaboration tools: Replace Microsoft Exchange and Teams with European email providers (e.g., Mailfence, Tutanota, ProtonMail) and open-source collaboration platforms like Nextcloud or Matrix. 3. Invest in European Cloud and Hosting Infrastructure The EU must stop relying on US cloud providers (AWS, Microsoft Azure, Google Cloud) and instead invest in European alternatives such as: Gaia-X (a federated data infrastructure for Europe) Sovereign cloud providers like OVHcloud, Stackit, and others that comply with GDPR and EU data protection laws. Decentralized, open-source cloud solutions that allow smaller European companies to compete and innovate. Public procurement rules should mandate the use of European cloud providers for all EU-funded projects, ensuring data stays within Europe and supports local innovation. 4. Open Source as a Catalyst for Innovation and Citizen Engagement Open-source software is not just about cost savingsits about transparency, participation, and faster innovation. When the EU invests in open-source projects, it: Empowers citizens to contribute, audit, and improve the tools they use. Lowers barriers for SMEs and startups to build on top of public digital infrastructure. Creates a level playing field where European companies can compete globally without being locked into proprietary ecosystems. Example: The Indian governments open-source payment system (UPI) achieved near-universal bank account penetration by making the infrastructure open and accessible. Europe should replicate this approachopen APIs, open standards, and open-source codeto accelerate digital inclusion and service innovation. 5. Concrete Steps for the European Commission I urge the Commission to: Mandate the transition of all EU institutions and public administrations to open-source software within 24 months. Allocate public funding exclusively to European contractors and open-source projects that align with digital sovereignty goals. Create a European Open-Source Fund to support the development and maintenance of critical digital infrastructure. Enforce strict procurement rules that prioritize European cloud providers and open-source solutions. Launch a public awareness campaign to educate citizens and businesses about the benefits of open-source and European digital alternatives. Integrate open-source education into school curricula to ensure that new that new generations grow up with open-source as the default culture, not Microsoft or Google. This will foster a mindset of collaboration, innovation, and digital autonomy from an early age.

The European Union has long championed digital sovereignty, innovation, and the protection of citizens data. However, the persistent reliance on US-made softwaredespite the availability of robust, privacy-respecting, and often free European alternativesundermines these goals. European Open Digital Ecosystems should prioritize homegrown solutions, not only to foster local innovation but also to protect citizens and businesses from unnecessary data exploitation and vendor lock-in. 1. The Case for European Software Europe is home to a thriving ecosystem of open-source and free software (FOSS) projects that match, or even surpass, the functionality of their US counterparts. From operating systems (e.g., openSUSE, KDE Neon) to productivity tools (e.g., Nextcloud, OnlyOffice), communication platforms (e.g., Matrix/Element, Jitsi), and creative software (e.g., Krita, Blender), European developers have built alternatives that are secure, customizable, and respectful of user privacy. Yet, many EU institutions, businesses, and citizens default to US-made softwareoften out of habit, marketing influence, or misconceptions about the quality of European alternatives. This reliance is not just a missed economic opportunity; its a strategic risk. US-based software frequently comes with invasive data collection, proprietary restrictions, and dependencies that conflict with European values of transparency and user control. 2. Data Sovereignty and Privacy The EUs General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) sets a global standard for privacy, yet the use of US software often contradicts its principles. Many US companies operate under legal frameworks (e.g., the CLOUD Act) that allow government access to user data, regardless of where it is stored. European software, especially FOSS projects, typically offers greater transparency, local hosting options, and stronger protections against surveillance and data misuse. For example, Nextclouda German-developed, self-hostable alternative to Google Drive or Dropboxgives users full control over their data, with no hidden tracking or third-party access. Similarly, Matrix/Element provides decentralized, end-to-end encrypted communication without relying on US-based servers. These tools align with GDPR and empower users, yet they remain underutilized in favor of convenience or brand recognition. 3. Economic and Strategic Benefits Supporting European software isnt just about privacy; its about economic resilience. Every euro spent on US software licenses is a euro that could be reinvested in local developers, startups, and digital infrastructure. Open-source projects, in particular, create jobs, foster innovation, and reduce dependency on foreign tech giants. Consider the success of projects like Blender (3D modeling), which rivals US tools like Autodesk Maya but remains free and community-driven. Or the rise of European Linux distributions, which power everything from personal computers to supercomputers without the bloat or surveillance of proprietary systems. These examples prove that European software is not just viableits world-class. 4. Barriers to Adoption Despite these advantages, several challenges hinder wider adoption: Awareness: Many users and decision-makers are unaware of European alternatives or assume they are inferior. Ecosystem Fragmentation: While the EU has strong individual projects, they often lack the integrated, user-friendly ecosystems that US companies provide. Procurement Policies: Public and private sector procurement processes frequently favor established US brands, even when European solutions meet the requirements. The EUs digital future should not be outsourced to US corporations. By embracing European Open Digital Ecosystemsbuilt on transparency, privacy, and local innovationwe can create a digital landscape that serves citizens, protects data, and strengthens our economy. The tools are already here; wh

feedbackTextUserLanguage: European companies from start-ups to established enterprises gain real technological choice. They can build on reliable open components without fear of vendor lock-in or restrictive licensing. Innovation is then driven by the quality of services and adaptations instead of dependence on monopolistic infrastructures. The long-term resilience of this ecosystem depends on the health of the underlying open technologies. The strategy should clearly recognize that many critical OSS components function as public goods and therefore require structural and sustainable support. Financial mechanisms are needed to maintain widely used libraries and infrastructure code relied upon by both the public sector and the economy. Additional support should be directed to open-source foundations and non-profit organizations that provide governance and legal certainty."

feedback:
I think promoting EU-grown FOSS is necessary for many reasons. While the starting costs of such migrations are high (training and IT), this will save billions of EU money in a few years and give us back our digital sovereignty. I don't think there's even a question as to whether we should do those migrations, I think we should fight for quicker adoption of FOSS. I think the EU should first focus on University students by building programs to reward those that create FOSS to change the culture regarding proprietary software for future generations. Then, we should ideally make students from their youngest age use FOSS in school instead of training them on foreign closed-source software (like Microsoft Windows and Word). All computers given to / accessible by students should only run OSS ideally by default. if no such open-source alternatives exist, the EU should contract companies to build such alternatives, and making them open-source. The only way this could fail would be (a) because of the EU trying to reinvent the wheel in too many scenarios or (b) fail to prevent fragmentation of open-source work. I believe the EU should start by defining in law European FOSS software independently of the Open Source Initiative (which is an American public benefit corporation) by asking for essentially the same licenses as what the OSI considers Free and Open Source and on top of that whether we have in the knowledge and resources necessary in the EU to maintain such software. For example, the Linux kernel project currently lead by Linus Torvalds should still be considered EU FOSS because of companies such as Tuxedo Computers (Germany) which have an advanced understanding of the Linux kernel. This definition should be easy to check for anybody independently. The easiest way to do so would be by simply asking project owners to list an arbitrary amount of European contributors in the AUTHORS file to be automatically eligible for European grants (I thought through this and I think 2 persons on projects with 10 or less contributors and 20% (round up) of contributors when above 10 contributors is enough). This way, most FOSS should already pass this check and there won't have to be any government body required to label projects as EU FOSS (meaning no waiting time for public and private institutions to adopt those pieces of software). I think only EU FOSS should eventually be accepted in public institutions (10 or 15 years down the road). But in the mean time, I recommend imposing FOSS priority to public institutions (EU FOSS then non-EU FOSS) is one of the first steps to make then only allow EU FOSS. Exceptions should also be made for firmware which most of the time cannot be open-sourced (security through obscurity) as well as legacy hardware-controlling software (actual word in law for this should really careful as this could create loopholes) for which the developer is not existent anymore. As to (b), it is important for the EU to carefully make its grants for OSS collaboration-friendly. Reducing grants when software categories are fragmented will automatically make development teams want to be as united as possible, which overall reduces development times, increases software quality and stability and in the long run is less costly as supporting two or more distinct projects which achieves the same functionality. It would also be great to make every student learn about what FOSS software is and its many benefits over closed-source software. In France, I believe this should be done in Education Morale et Civique lessons. My last idea would be to find ways for the EU to promote to EU AND non-EU companies EU FOSS. By investing heavily in FOSS, the EU would become the #1 most trusted software developer area. Influencing future EU tech workers towards FOSS and making them the face of the next most well-known pieces of free software will enable them to sell their services

feedback: "Open Source" software (a better term would be "free/libre software" as defined by e.g. https://www.gnu.org/philosophy/free-sw.html) is necessary to achieve truly independent and/or sovereign computing. Without it, e.g. when only using proprietary software where the source code is hidden and only one company or country can change it, you are subjecting your IT infrastructure to the whims of that one company or country. You are vulnerable to malicious updates being distributed only to you by that one company or country. You are vulnerable to hacking because you can't independently study the security of the source code. Among other negative things. With proprietary software that's locked behind an online account for access (e.g. Microsoft 365, Azure, AWS, Adobe Cloud), it's even worse: not only do you still have zero control or insight over what the software actually does and how it's being changed over time, but you're now even vulnerable to a single point of failure attack: if that company or country decides to lock or delete your account, you lose everything that's associated with that account. For example if you have all your servers running in an Azure or AWS cloud (doesn't matter which geographical region/datacenter it's running in), and the US decides to force Microsoft to block access for certain companies or instituitions within the EU, then you will completely lose access to your own infrastructure. Simply because you gave away control over it. By heavily using for example US-based software and services locked behind US-based online accounts, the EU (respectively many institutions and companies within the EU) is automatically heavily vulnerable to being blackmailed or bullied into submission. Because they've outsourced all control over many important parts of their own IT infrastructure to a company from a different country. Once that company or country is no longer friendly, you have a huge self-imposed problem. Open source or free/libre software, on the other hand, allows for a much more independent and sovereign IT infrastructure with 100% control over the data and 100% insight into what the programs are actually doing (thanks to availability of its source code, and the freedom to change it (or hire someone to do it) to adjust it for your own purposes). Unfortunately, in the past decades many popular mistakes have been made in the IT sector and so today, the EU is heavily dependent on proprietary foreign-controlled software and services, including but not at all limited to: Microsoft 365, Azure, AWS, Github, Palantir, Anduril, Youtube, Tiktok, Amazon, OpenAI, Gemini, Google Search, Dropbox, OneDrive, X, Apple AppStore/Google Play, Visa and Mastercard, Paypal. This makes the EU easily blackmailable by a rogue US administration forcing US companies to lock out or otherwise harm customers in the EU. As a result, the EU is currently the equivalent to a digital colony of the US. The best time to switch to 100% sovereign and independent open source technologies was already decades ago, the next best time is NOW. The EU MUST switch to self-hosted and self-controlled independent software, and do it fast. Many technical experts have been tirelessly repeating this general recommendation over the last decades, but many refused to listen. Now it is high time to listen to what independent technical experts have been saying the whole time and to do what actually matters, to do things that actually improve the situation.

Moving to FOSS is not only a good idea - it is now absolutely critical to the safety and security of the European Union. Current geopolitical events have underscored the EU's vulnerability to proprietary software systems which are controlled by companies residing within hostile government states. Failure to immediately move to FOSS would constitute an abrogation of the EU's responsibility to protect the safety and security of its citizens and represent an existential threat to the European Union itself.

Les avantages des logiciels libres sont multiple: économique, écologique, éthique. -Économique: Pas de license, pas d'abonnement, pas de souscription. Pas de renouvellement de matériel qui fonctionne pour s'adapter à une nouvelle version du système d'exploitation. -Écologique: La même machine, éxecutant les mêmes tâches consommera beaucoup moins de ressources sous Linux que sous Windows. Il y a des versions de Linux compatibles avec tous types de matériel, même ancien. La fin du support de Windows 10 va créer d'énorme quantité de dêchets électroniques. -Éthique: La plupart des logiciels propriétaires collectent des données personnelles et surveillent leurs utilisateurs. Les établissements scolaires devraient être les premiers à adpoter massivement les logiciels libres.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: The benefits of open source software are manifold: economic, ecological, ethical. Economic: No license, no subscription, no subscription. No renewal of equipment that works to adapt to a new version of the operating system. —Ecology: The same machine, performing the same tasks, will consume much less resources on Linux than on Windows. There are versions of Linux compatible with all types of equipment, even old ones. The end of Windows 10 support will create a huge amount of electronic dêchets. —Ethics: Most proprietary software collects personal data and monitors its users. Schools should be the first to massively embrace open source software.

Cak i ja, srednjoskolac, pronalazim vrijednost u FOS software-u kao jednakom, kad-tad cak i boljoj alternativi nego "popularnim" odabirima. Ne samo da takav tip organiziranja programa omogucuje ljude da kolaboriraju diljem svijeta, nebitno o tvom zanimanju, rasi, vjeri ili zemlji jer svako moze pomoci makar da pruzi ideju za novu funkciju. Druga tocka kojoj bih se htio posvetiti je pitanje javnog novca za financiranje sustava zatvorenog koda. Biti cu jasan na ovome kada kazem da nema situacije gdje javno financirani kod ne moze biti otvorenog koda. Reci da je zbog "sigurnosnih razloga" je samo izlika jer se zna kako je kod napravljen na brzinu, nije testiran, nije ga napravila osoba s pravom strukom. Takav kod nesmije biti vidljiv javnosti jer ce ljudi s malicioznim namjerama odmah uociti ruoe u sigurnosti, pa je jednostavnije samo ga zatvoriti i praviti se da ni nisu tamo. To je apsolutno absurdno misljenje koje ce samo kupiti vremena dok isti ljudi ne otkriju arhitekturu sustava sto je lakse nego sto zvuci jer su sve tehnologije s kojima su ti sustavi napravljeni javno dostupni. Bolja opcija je da se ti sustavi otvore, ali ne i stave u pogon. Mogu se reklamirat pozivajuvi programere (i ljude sire) da zajedno razviju taj sustav. Kada se vidi da je sve spremno sustav se moze staviti u akciju. Tu je jako bitna reklamacija jer inace rijetko ce tko cuti za taj projekt. Takoder ne garantira kao i sve da nece biti i dalje rupa u sigurnosti, ali ako gledamo primjer Linux i FreeBSD sustava naspram Microsoft Windows sustava odmah je vidljivo kako sustavi otvorenog koda imaju vise puta manje sigutnpsnih rupa pronadenih nego zatvorenog koda. Takoder ne davati opciju kompanijama da stavljaju telemetriju i analitiku skrivenu od korisnika u svoje produkte je isto plus, jer bih kod bio javno dostupan, no naravno to nike realno, ali uz edukativne programe i reklamacije FOS software-a moze se dogoditi da FOSS bude 'default'-na opcija za ljude. (npr. Whatsapp je od Mete, i iako Meta koristi privatne chatove za treniranje AI modela sa 'per-chat' opvijom da izades iz tog programa, svi koriste Whatsapp jer svi drugi koriste Whatsapp. Ako bi naprimjer Matrix mreza koristeci klient poput FluffyChat-a bila populatna tolikl da bi je ljudi koristili jer je njegov prijatelj koristi bila realnost, moralo bk se tesko investirati u edukaciju i reklamaciju takvih programa.) Dakle da zakljucim sigurnost, privatnost, zajednistvo i fleksibilnost su sve stvari oko kojih se FOSS vodi. (Zalim zbog lose konstruitanog teksta i vjerovatno tonu gramatickih i pravopisnih gresaka, ali knjizevnost mi nije jaca strana. Svejedno htio sam izraziti svoje misljenje.) Ima zajednica posvecenim FOSS-u ihttps://fosdem.org/ je edna od njih, koja operatira u Belgiji.

column26: I would recommend introducing a 15 incentive for every computer that is migrated to Linux instead of being discarded. Actively promoting open-source desktop environments to SMBs and consumers will accelerate broader open-source adoption and reduce the persistent fear many individuals and organizations have of relying on non-paid software (yes
column27: that hesitation still exists). This approach could prevent thousands of tons of e-wastethere are an estimated 1.2 million computers in the Netherlands alone running obsolete Windows versionswhile also saving substantial costs. A second key focus should be rethinking how we approach ICT infrastructure altogether. We are currently developing an SMB-focused Nextcloud setup based on compact mini-computers using Intel N150 chipsets. These systems can be self-hosted by companies and consume as little as 6 watts per 10 users. This not only significantly reduces operational costs but also drastically lowers power consumption compared to mainstream cloud solutions
column28: such as those offered by Google."

feedback: Open source is great and should become the digital foundation for the european society. But what I am painfully missing in the OSS landscape is accessibility (A11Y), and usability to a certain degree. Sorry, but many OSS applications are developed by enthusiasts for enthusiasts. Teams implement A11Y only if they're motivated and the resources are available. But I as a blind dev and user cannot rely on it. So if I enter a new workplace, I have to be afraid about missing A11Y of used applications. This is discrimination and exclusion from social participation. I know many blind people who are very reluctant about OSS due to bad experience. American software companies were forced to implement A11Y by legal pressure about 10 years ago. The quality difference between these commercial products and OSS is still remarkable, but the quality rapidly degrades and will further degrade. For example, GitHub's CEO Thomas Dohmke left Github. He strongly cared about A11Y. Since he left, their web interface becomes more and more inaccessible, even within these few months. If nobody actively cares about A11Y and if quality insurance is missing, it degrades. A11Y doesn't happen by accident and needs active maintenance. Efforts to implement A11Y for infrastructure (operating systems, UI toolkits, APIs ) needs financial support and incentives. This approach scales, because this infrastructure is the foundation for OSS applications. I already applied for programmes like Prototype Fund or NLnet with projects from this category. A11Y is key for any application or software project that produces content, from website templates, page builders to PDF creating apps. A positive example is the OSS project Typst, which can generate accessible (tagged) PDF out of the box. No expensive proprietary software, just generate and there you go. Creators can deploy accessible content instead of having to fix A11Y afterwards. That scales and saves money. There is no official A11Y qualification, just some dubios commercial certificates and courses. An officially recognized definition like mine above, education and qualification means: It can be a requirement in job offers. Expectations are clear and standardized. Due to the lack of common standards, anyone can pretend being the greatest and best of all, given they have enough contacts on Linkedin. It's a similar situation like with coaching, a job title which is not legally protected in Germany. Practical frontend development and A11Y should be more prevalent in education. Meanwhile, in software development, the paradigm of experimentation has fundamentally changed and we build complex architectures and infrastructure with an enormous social impact. This infrastructure, e.g., in the medical sector, needs to be reliable, sustainable, secure, and user-friendly (help users to use id correctly). Practical software development is about decision-making, weighting cost factors, reflecting questions like Should we adopt this new cool technology that will become a vendor lock-in?, or Will taking this shortcut hit us later?, How can we avoid damage from incorrect usage or even abuse? We know much about these topics. Positive examples like Typst (OSS and commercial) deserve more attention and recognition for quality, e.g., as public awards. If smaller achievements would be honored more frequently, this could motivate OSS contributors, and it could show the public a more positive future perspective. There should be many categories next to A11Y to cover OSS landscape.

As an aside (but an important one), I believe you mean "free software" in place of "open-source software". You are clearly concerned with users' freedom and control over their own computing when you say "[...] increases user agency, helps regain control [...]". "Open-source software" is only a development methodology and the term is often used to eschew moral issues, by the very same tech giants you are trying to break free from. When deeper ideas are involved, such as who owns our computing, please join me in using the term "free software". To address some of your questions (from the "Consultation strategy" section): 1. At least in Romania, there are two major barriers to wider-scale adoption of free software. First, the childhood indoctrination in non-free software forced upon students in schools. They only use and study proprietary programs such as Microsoft Office or Adobe Acrobat Reader. They are required to memorize all the menus and functions of those programs and they are never taught the basic principles that would enable them to switch to freedom-respecting alternatives (e.g. "any word processor should have a Print function, usually under the File menu"). And second, the authorities explicitly require use of such non-free programs and offer no alternatives. One example is digital signatures, which only work using proprietary modifications to the PDF format by Adobe Acrobat Reader. I strongly advise you to pass legislation (1) forbidding schools from using and teaching non-free software, and (2) requiring authorities to accept documents that citizens can produce using free software. 2. One major benefit is breaking the lock-in factor. With proprietary software, including SaaS, users are often locked in because no other program can read and use the same data. Furthermore, the author can decide to change the way the program works at any time, including dropping some functionality that users depend on (see "Adobe steals your color" by Cory Doctorow for a good example). With free software, formats and protocols are open, because interoperability is a core principle. So when users become dissatisfied with a program they can modify it, switch to a different program or develop an entirely new one. This would go a long way towards chipping away at the walled gardens of tech giants that your document explicitly mentions. 3. Again, one concrete step is for the EU to require all its agencies, authorities and schools to promote free software at least in equal proportion to proprietary software. One example: The International Certification of Digital Literacy (also known as The European Computer Driving Licence or ECDL) certifies students in basic computer operation. It always specifies free software alternatives such as "Microsoft Office OR LibreOffice". But, at least in Romania, nobody even glances at the OR part. Another general mechanism is interoperability. Whenever non-free software is used, the EU must require it to interoperate with equivalent programs or systems. For example, much of EU's political debate happens on Facebook and X. When our politicians and all their followers (hundreds of millions of them) use Facebook, we are all collectively feeding a very dangerous beast, one that has demonstrably been used to manipulate us and to interfere with our democracies. If Facebook wants to step in as middleman between politicians and their electorate, the least we should do is ask it to publish clear protocols so that users can see the feed in their system of choice (such as Mastodon, a free and tracking-free social network). This would protect us all from the manipulative, paid-for content injected by suggestion algorithms.

Background: These are my thoughts on what are some blocking factors for adoption of OSS in PAs and more broadly blocking innovation and killing efficiency. 1. Leadership: leadership in PAs completely lacks engineering skills, completely. They simply do not understand technology, innovation, software and the engineering mindset. PAs should hire from the private sector, there are many Europeans working in bigtech, hire more engineers. Shining examples are the Italian experience with Diego Piacentini and the GDS in UK. Draw from those, there is nothing new. 2. Outsourcing: Outsourcing of IT projects is a big waste of time and money. Service providers work under fixed-price contracts with no incentive on driving better outcomes for the PAs, they optimise for gains hiring unskilled engineers with poor outcomes, rework, waste of time in contracting, negotiations and escalations. Also, founding is per project, enabling infrastructural projects face challenges to find funding as these are not understood by leadership (lack of engineering skills) and not backed by business. To support this model, PAs hire employees which have to deal with contracts and have never delivered IT projects, detached from industry standard delivery and focus on paper-work. Leadership wants outsourcing to not own outcomes, it's easier to blame someone else! This blocks innovation and increase dependency on external providers reducing speed of execution and control over the project as the PA voluntarily gives up control and lacks the engineering skills to drive and control outcomes. PAs should own outcomes and the delivery end-to-end and optimise for outcomes not contracts! 3. Hiring procedures: PAs hiring procedures are a daunting experience for candidates. Good engineers tend to not waste time on this. Look at the website of PAs to get a sense of what it means to apply. Procedures are a waste of time, engineering skills are not assessed if not through mnemonic and useless questions that tend to hire whomever has a better memory. Look at how startups and other companies hire, the hiring process is subpar and it's not fit for engineers. Panels are not effective as whomever is in the panel normally lacks engineering skills to make a sound assessment. Concrete actions: - Draw from the industry, hire from American bigtech companies, attract engineering talent using special tax regimes for European Companies and talents especially European expatriates. Bring them back and drain resources from US! - Change hiring procedures to fit engineers and create environments in PAs which are fit for engineers and reward good engineering outcomes - Change leadership, introduce rotation schemes where leadership has to go after some years (3-5 maximum) - Have concrete goals for OSS adoption for PAs with clear goals to replace solution where alternatives are available (Linux vs Windows, Mysql/Postgres vs Oracle) - Hire engineers and pay them to develop and contribute to OSS starting with those Europeans already in the OSS communities. Forget about current hiring processes! These won't be able to engage with these engineers. - Force development of all PA software in the public and hire community managers to manage PA software as OSS. - PAs should hire engineers and pay them to contribute to OSS.

Europe critically need to widely move away from Android and IOS. Peoples most valuable data is inside their phones these days and when using either one you are vulnerable to constant data mining. Especially with Android. There is completely independent European mobile operating system called SailfishOS. Sailfish is developed by Jolla since 2011. Sailfish is mostly open source and they are constantly opening it even more. SailfishOS is currently mature enough to be daily drivable. And there is option to use android apps in special container which keeps your core data safe. This is good for transition period, but I would like to see European comission to mandate by law that all bank/goverment/eID etc. apps shouldn't rely on Google services which would allow them to work in alternative operating systems. Of course even better if all apps operating inside EU need to make sure their compatibility without Google services. Jolla has been able to keep developing SailfishOS over a decade but I would like to directs some serious funding towards them and declaring them as important company for European security. It would be great if people in important positions inside EU comission switch their work phones to ones running SailfishOS etc. Thank you for having this questionary!
Just Use Postgres. Jokes aside, it's pretty straightforward to utilize, support and contribute to existing iconic FOSS movement like Linux, PostgreSQL etc.

Practical experience with open source in an SME context I make extensive use of open-source software in a commercial setting, primarily for running an online webshop and related data analysis. My experience is that open source is not an ideological alternative, but a key economic enabler that allows small and medium-sized enterprises to remain competitive. 1. Cost reduction and market access For my infrastructure and webshop, I rely on: Linux (server and hosting environment) WordPress and WooCommerce as the e-commerce platform A combination of open-source plugins and paid commercial extensions This stack: structurally lowers fixed operational costs avoids dependency on closed SaaS platforms enables scalability without high upfront investment Without open-source software, many SMEs would simply not have a viable digital business model. 2. Hybrid ecosystems work in practice My use case demonstrates that open source works best in hybrid ecosystems: an open core complemented by commercial plugins, extensions and paid support combined with custom development where needed This hybrid model supports both innovation and sustainability. EU policy should enable and strengthen this model, rather than framing open source and commercial software as opposites. 3. Community contribution is valuable but fragile In addition to using open source, I contribute back where possible: reporting bugs developing my own code and tooling, mainly focused on data analysis and SQL processing of large datasets These contributions are typically made alongside regular work and without structural support. As a result, many core projects remain vulnerable, particularly in areas such as: long-term maintenance security documentation This highlights a clear role for the EU in supporting sustainable maintenance, not only innovation projects. 4. Open source as infrastructure, not a niche Open source is often discussed as a niche or ideological choice, while in reality it functions as: foundational digital infrastructure a critical layer for web services, cloud, data and cybersecurity a prerequisite for digital autonomy EU policy should therefore treat open source as strategic digital infrastructure, comparable to energy or telecommunications. 5. Where EU action can make a difference Based on practical experience, EU-level impact would be strongest through: public procurement rules that require open standards measures to prevent vendor lock-in structural support for maintenance and security of core open-source components explicit recognition of open source as a valid and scalable foundation for SME digitalisation Conclusion Open source is not an end in itself, but a strategic and economic instrument. In practice, it directly contributes to competitiveness, innovation and cost efficiency within the European internal market.

The bare minimum is that the public sector should not actively _hinder_ development and adoption of open and sovereign alternatives, which it often does. Let me start with the starkest example: mobile devices. Currently, most mobile devices in EU are sold with either Google's locked-down version of Android (not the original open source Android) or iOS. Google/Apple has complete control over that device, unlike its owner. If they wished, they could use it to eavesdrop, they could put a whole nation's phones out of service by pushing a simple update. There is nothing conspiratiorial about that, I am not saying these companies are abusing their powers, I am only stating, that purely technically, they _could_. Say if compelled by an autocrat currently ruling their country. Presumably many of Europe's top decisionmakers, military personel, critical sector workers, etc. carry Android/iOS smartphones controlled by a potentially hostile country, or even rely on them for their work. This could get very nasty in case of an open conflict, say, over Greenland? Now there are great communities developing alternatives, including European ones -- communities around mobile Linux distributions, Ubuntu Touch, PostmarketOS, companies like Murena (FR) that sell phones open-source user-controlled versions of Android (now in partnership with Fairphone(NL)). However, these alternatives will never get off the ground if people are forced in numerous ways into the Apple/Google ecosystem in order to fully participate in society. Many banks, digital ID systems, digital payments systems, e-Government systems, transit ticketing systems, require you to use an Android/iOS device to be able to use them at all. Many of these are publicly funded and yet only deepen our strategic and economical dependency of the US tech ecosystem. Now we can't ask public institutions to develop apps for 0.5% users. But we are not asking that! The community is more than glad to develop alternatives themselves, if they are not actively prevented from doing that. The answer is simple: open standards, open APIs, open communication protocols. The government should not care what software the user uses if it can talk the agreed-upon protocol. This opens up a space for innovation and for developing better alternatives and allows alternative ecosystems off the ground. Another example: until recently, it was very easy to install alternative software (that gave sovereign control over the device to the user and not to a US company). Apparently they stopped that and one of the official reasons was compliance with EU regulations. They were arguments about wheter their interpretation of the regulation was correct or not. But the EU should definitely prevent the users (or even government organizations!) from having a CHOICE of what software they run on a device they bought and own. I even think that the EU should legally mandate allowing the installation of alternative operating systems. But at the very least it should not actively hinder that. Developing hardware is hard and expensive. Developing new and independent software for existing hardware is much easier. If only we are allowed to do that. The open source community changed the world once already, with Linux, which now powers pretty much everything. It could do the same for the mobile ecosystem, for the cloud ecosystem, etc., if only it is allowed to. Our dependence on the US is pretty much self-imposed.

Sovereign and GDPR compliant operating system (OS) for destops and mobile phones urgently needed. Sovereign and GDPR compliant cloud services urgently needed. Sovereign payment systems, independent of VISA and Mastercard, urgently needed. Electronic identification (eID) and banking services NOT locked in via Apple Store or Google Play Store, urgently needed.

Sfogo. Creare con un URGENZA una certificazione sovranità digitale e sovranità digitale open-source. Vincolare finanziamenti nel settore IT alla certificazione. Definire aree di intervento tecniche basilari e non astratte (es: Gaia-X) Dobbiamo ricostruire lecosistema Internet dalle fondamenta: - e-mail - sistemi di comunicazione aziendale - sistemi operativi - hardware e processori STOP con meglio in cloud. Aggiungere tra i requisiti delle certificazioni di sicurezza informatica la gestione on-premises di tutti gli assetti strategici. Capita troppo spesso che gli IT adottino soluzioni cloud per ridurre il proprio carico di responsabilità ed essere compliant. Grandi aziende utilizzano soluzioni delicatissime PAM in cloud (ACN italiana le certifica anche!). Abbiamo una normativa privacy stringente ma sotto il cappello sicurezza accettiamo di dare le chiavi del regno ad aziende non europee. Soprattutto FINANZIARE DIRETTAMENTE le principali comunità open-source (Debian, Codeberg, ecc) da individuare attraverso consultazione pubblica. Il prima possibile e senza usare Teams.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: Browse. Create open-source digital sovereignty and digital sovereignty with URGENCE. Link IT funding to certification. Define basic and non-abstract technical areas of intervention (e.g.: Gaia-X) We need to rebuild the internet ecosystem from its foundations: — e-mail – corporate communication systems – operating systems – hardware and STOP processors better in the cloud. Add on-premises management of all strategic set-ups to the requirements of IT security certifications. It is all too often the case that IT adopts cloud solutions to reduce its burden of responsibility and be compliant. Large companies use very sensitive PAM solutions in the cloud (Italian ACN also certifies them!). We have strict privacy rules, but under the hallmark of security we agree to give the keys to the kingdom to non-European companies. Mainly FINANCIAL DIRECTORATEMENT the main open-source communities (Debian, Codeberg, etc.) to be identified through public consultation. As soon as possible and without using Teams.

feedback: "1.What are the strengths and weaknesses of the EU open-source sector? What are the main barriers that hamper (i) adoption and maintenance of high-quality and secure open source; and (ii) sustainable contributions to open-source communities?" Public procurement is a key that should be used to leverage the best of both worlds. In other words, public sector has the responsibility to lead. A good start would be EU institutions themselves. However, as it stands, even they have gone to the exact opposite direction, adopting even Office 366 despite well-known data protection risks. Why open source is not even mentioned in Directive 2014/24/EU and related jurisprudence? "2. What is the added value of open source for the public and private sectors? Please provide concrete examples, including the factors (such as cost, risk, lock-in, security, innovation, among others) that are most important to assess the added value." The adoption of open source software should not be marketed a cost-saving solution. Even though such marketing may work in the public sector, given the previous reasons mentioned, also marketing should be aligned with the digital sovereignty agenda. For the EU, including EU institutions, reducing dependencies and vendor lock-in already provide much value added, regardless whether an open source software solution is cheaper or more expensive than a commercial solution from a non-EU company. "3. What concrete measures and actions may be taken at EU level to support the development and growth of the EU open-source sector and contribute to the EUs technological sovereignty and cybersecurity agenda?" See the answer to (1). "4. What technology areas should be prioritised and why?" The question is poorly formulated; instead, the question should be: what are the needs particularly in the public sector? Please run a pilot survey among a selected group of EU institutions, for instance. "5. In what sectors could an increased use of open source lead to increased competitiveness and cyber resilience?" Public sectors, throughout Europe and regardless of a level in an administrative hierarchy.

Open source software is fundamental to a healthy democracy. Any piece of code that is used in a public setting, funded by tax money, should be public. The European Union at the moment suffers from fragmented ecosystems that do their best to lock in users in their own platforms, all for the benefit of foreign companies. I have studied in the Netherlands, where one university used Google's environment, and another used Microsoft's. Both platforms did their best to make interactions between the two institutions as difficult as possible. If you wished to set up a meeting, you would be required to use their apps or a Chromium-based browser, which are terrible in terms of privacy. Given the diversity we harbor across all the member countries, the EU should facilitate the development of interoperable platforms. An example of this is the Fediverse for social media, where each platform can communicate with all the others that use the ActivityPub protocol. Similarly, we should streamline the deployment of open source software in the sectors that are in need of this the most: banking (avoiding Visa and Mastercard), tax systems, communication (EU citizens depend too much on WhatsApp), healthcare, and public administration. By mandating open standards and funding the development of open source alternatives, the EU can ensure that public institutions are not held hostage by a few tech giants.

Open Source should be the only thing that the public institutions use. Why would we use our tax money to pay for software developed most of the times outside of Europe and not have sovereignty over our own data? If anything, that budget should be spent on paying developers for said open source software to improve or innovate. These improvements would then benefit all citizens. Please make the right decisions...

Open source helps mitigate lock-in and security risks that lead to reduced sovereignty. Operating systems and user-facing software that we can build, run, and maintain ourselves allows retaining control over our devices without having to build a European OS from scratch. Examples could include Android and Ubuntu, both with a vibrant ecosystem of freely available and open source apps that provide most functions needed in modern daily life, except for mostly (semi-)government software such as national transport providers (Deutsche Bahn) or national authentication methods (DigiD). National software typically requires some amount of lock-in to Google or Apple, not just in ecosystem and convenience but also in cryptographic signatures. In 2025, Samsung, among the most popular mobile device vendors in Europe, stopped allowing installing software on smartphones except when it is cryptographically signed by themselves. There are only a few remaining options and even fewer European ones. Positive examples would be Fairphone, Shiftphone, and Murena, but their market share is such that we would basically have to restart society with pre-smartphone technology if Apple and Google get an order from their elected leader to disable devices and disallow future unlocking via an update. If users could, instead, choose to always unlock their devices, install a Google- or Apple-free operating system, and software would not actively thwart these open systems, daily life could recover expediently. GrapheneOS provides an example of how simple the installation procedure can be using WebUSB: I would trust an average citizen to do it in an hour so long as (a copy of) website remains available in their language. Beyond sovereignty: requiring openability of general computation hardware also strengthens article 8 ECHR (the right to private and family life) by not being subject to Google's, Microsoft's, or Apple's policies and algorithms as a fact of modern life.

The EU should sponsor politically, economically and negotiation power to build a fully open source, indipendently running social platform for teens and young adults, similar to tik-tok and instagram. All internal "moderating" rules, fact checking and "algorithm" to select reels or similar should be clearly listed and agreed upon by the community. Should then heavily publicize the initiative in schools and on TV and youtube, paying influencers to spread the word, while warning of progressively stricter rules on established socials, like age verification, per-use timers, to total bans for teens. Students should be able to partecipate to development. The platform will be stay indipendent by statute and mantained by a Foundation with open processes. The UE should negatiate infrastructure resources with mayor UE cloud providers while still remaining platform agnostic, while allowing minimum presence of ads to make it economically less costly. I believe that mental health of our children and of society in general will improve steadily.

Article 6 of the 2001 EU Copyright Directive grants big US tech companies undue power in the EU. Without reverse engineering the US software products that power so many EU companies and even governments, migrating from such closed source US based software to open source software (OSS) developed in the EU is a very painful process. At the same time, US tech companies are free to make this migration as hard as they like, while article 6 makes it so that OSS developers trying to circumvent such anti-migration measures make themselves liable to prosecution. Without OSS that seamlessly connects to the existing US-based closed source software, many people and companies in the EU are forced to continue relying on the goodwill of US tech companies. At the same time, the recent actions of the US government have shown that they anything but a reliable partner. By repealing article 6, the EU would give a huge boost to their digital sovereignty and the OSS sector.

Find below my responses to the posed questions: 1. What are the strengths and weaknesses of the EU open-source sector? Strengths: Size, communities, experience Weaknesses: Funding, Legal uncertainties, Weak lobby regarding new laws What are the main barriers that hamper (i) adoption and maintenance of high-quality and secure open source? -> Funding, Infrastructure (both technical and legal/organizational, i.e. lack of umbrella organizations willing to host Open Source communities) and (ii) sustainable contributions to opensource communities? -> Funding: Few Open Source communities can afford even one full-time employee, and many contributors are forced to seek employment in private companies, thereby again contributing to proprietary code. 2. What is the added value of open source for the public and private sectors? -> Sovereignty, severely reduced risk of foreign interference or denial of service -> Cost (although a sustainable use of Open Source does require to fund the projects which are used) -> No vendor lock-in, and thereby increased competition, actual free markets and lower costs, more innovation as past innovations are free for all to build upon 3. What concrete measures and actions may be taken at EU level to support the development and growth of the EU open-source sector and contribute to the EUs technological sovereignty and cybersecurity agenda? Provide stable sources of: A) Funding B) Technical infrastructure (European Versioning and CI / CD platform, like Codeberg) C) Organizational / Legal infrastructure (Umbrella organizations that handle donations, taxes, paying/hiring contributors EU-wide, ...) 4. The focus should be on Open Standards above all. The Internet and tech world in general was a better place when everybody came together and agreed to use the same protocol, thereby making compatibility, interoperability and switching from one vendor to another easy. There are many examples, ranging from TCP to USB-C (a recent accomplishment of the EU, making that standard truly universal). To achieve these open standards, it is imperative to support and work with established open source projects, which should be chosen carefully. 5. The mobile OS sector has desperate need for more Openness, with Android (despite being Open Source) becoming more dependent on Google with every day. This issue further highlights that Open Source alone is good, but not enough: The personnel and expertise to maintain the Open Source software needs to be European as well.

Hi, as a computer science graduate and PhD student, I will share my thought on Open source in the following paragraphs (# separated): # Actions that should be taken for governments: - Governments should exclusively use open source software and open file format and reduce as much a possible vendor lock-in with Microsoft and the like. I would like an "Public money, Public Code" approach moving forward at the EU and the individual country level. - Government should make any code they contract 3rd party for or external software they use, either open-source (for anything public facing) or government owned (for military/confidential matters). This will help remove vendor lock-in, and reduce long term cost, improve transparency to citizens, and help with data security (from foreign access) # Why does it matter: - Data security: the US cloud act (https://www.congress.gov/bill/115th-congress/house-bill/4943) allow the US government to retrieve any data they want if it use American infrastructure/software (even when the data is stored on European land), this much as been confirmed by Microsoft themself in French court. - Transparency: As citizen currently we have no transparency on to the system that run our lives, or even on the cost of contracts made with Big Techs while it's being financed by public money. I think as citizen we would like a lot more transparency into government software, when systems like "parcoursup" can have impact on our whole carriers. - Pricing: if consumer/enterprise pricing are anything to go by, the cost will continue to go up, as it will become harder and harder to move out. What is being paid today to big tech is not the operating cost of the product but the cost of being granted privileged to access our OWN data i.e. we are paying always increasing rates due to vendor lock-in and open source technologies can ensure a future where this lock in does not exist. # Education: Currently schools across the EU put children directly in the hands of American monopolies with school computer running windows, chromeOS or MacOS and using Office 365 suite to learn basic computer usage, this translate years later into adults and entire industries always only using those same technology whereas especially in lower education open-source OS (linux, bsd, etc...) and office suite (open office, nextcloud, etc...) are very capable of completing all the schoolwork required while often being better at spreading technological literacy (due to open source system not having to protect their inner workings). We should have a open-source learning platform. I think education is the best way to get open source software naturally enter the industries and private live of citizens and might be the most important matter in the long term. # Open hardware: Spreading of open hardware systems like DisplayPort (competitor to HDMI), RISC-V (processor instruction set, compete with Intel/AMD x86 and ARM), could also allow Europeans companies to compete in sector inaccessible before. For example, currently no EU companies can currently compete on desktop/server CPU market space due to x86 being proprietary and locked to a handful of companies. # PS: As a short aside, on to the problems sticking to open source as a citizen, as a full time Linux user with no direct access to Windows/MacOS computer: in some important paperwork I had to complete, there was a PDF (semi-open format) containing a XFA form (adobe proprietary extension to PDF) that only worked with adobe acrobat. This software not only have very restrictive user license, but also only work on Windows/macOS (which both comes with very restrictive user license, as well as cost, windows being 145euros and macOS requiring Apple hardware) making it very hard to complete PDF form this without borrowing someone else computer. # PPS: I also want to congratulate Germany for the sovereign tech fund: https://en.wikipedia.or
33363601,https://ec.europa.eu/info/law/better-regulation/have-your-say/initiatives/16213-European-Open-Digital-Ecosystems/F33363601_en,Ares(2026)69111,2026/01/09 19:55:49,As founder of OS Informatica (Open Source Informatics) in Italy
language: I've been looking forward to this moment for almost two decades. I have been developing for years solutions to help people transition to European solutions and even created a website (osinformatica.eu) to explain to people how to do it. We need to use the open source stack as a launch pad to create a full sovereign ecosystem. Please finance R&D as well as companies and organizations like Murena
login: SoftMaker
feedbackTextUserLanguage: Matrix
trNumber: Lemmy and the Fediverse in general. It is also important to create steps to gradually ban Intrusive US services like Meta
scope: Google and Microsoft. Forcing companies like adobe to support Linux or prohibit sales in Europe is also mandatory. I offer my expertise to help the EU transition to EU digital sovereignty."

feedback: I have been using Linux Mint (French developer) as my only client os for 5 years now and found that it can do all I need so I don't see why governments don't run pilots converting client-systems to Linux. And perhaps converting both client and server to a European Linux-version will give extra costs but as one Europe we can share a lot (also with the rest of the world). And as we develop European platforms and tools we will build an open source base for governments, companies and citizens. Lots of systems that are in use now have a lot of functions we don't really need but miss functions that are essential. Lets try to take the initiative of Sleeswijk-Holstein in Germany and make it into a good base for the rest of Europe!

Because of AI, the role of Open Source software and open source communities are in flux. One of the economic purposes Open Source serves is as a software project accelerant. By creating a forum to share toil to create common functionality that is not business differentiating, Open Source makes it possible for tech companies to bring valuable new innovation to market faster. And by creating shared paradigms open source also makes training in the resulting shared components more valuable for employees and their employers. But AI can do some of the same things by making it possible for people with much lower expertise to stand up common functionality. And it's far easier to customize the result, making project forks easier and more likely. AI also impacts communities directly as contributors seeking a way to differentiate themselves on the job market bombard expert or core maintainers with an unreliable mixture of useful contributions and "workslop". The central effort to maintain Open Source components has shifted from coding to reviewing. Expert maintainers can also leverage AI to improve the quality of their code reviews. When the creation of IP itself becomes commoditised, the license models and IP protection that define the boundaries and interactions with Open Source projects become less meaningful. While that is happening AI data centers are currently mostly American and Chinese and these two countries are also dominant in AI research. AI tools are already extremely powerful, and their power is only increasing. If Europe wishes to maintain open digital ecosystems and digital sovereignty, Europe's top priorities need to be building its own data centers, innovating in the AI space, and educating students entering the job force on how to successfully and ethically leverage AI tools to increase their own effectiveness and how to defend themselves against the downsides of unethical AI use by others. About me: I've served in numerous operational and governance roles within the non-profit Apache Software Foundation, and I am a Senior Director for the for-profit open source company, Grafana Labs. I've been volunteering and working in open source since 2015, and did my master's thesis in Cologne/Rotterdam on vendor neutrality in open source in 2020. I lived in Germany for 23 years.

Cory Doctorow has eloquently outlined what the digital strategy of the EU should be, most european software professionals do agree with his plan. Just apply it! https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7wE8G-d7SnY

I have become increasingly concerned about our business's dependency on American digital infrastructure. Recent geopolitical developments have shown that the United States can no longer be assumed to be a reliable partner. This matters to my business because core servicesemail, collaboration tools, paymentsare essential. These services being subject to foreign jurisdiction, dragnet surveillance and political pressure, our data, continuity, and intellectual property are at risk. The idea that Europe cannot do the internet is simply wrong. Europe has built globally relevant companies and foundational technologies, from SAP and Spotify to the World Wide Web and Linux. What we lack is not capability, but a strategic framework that treats digital infrastructure as infrastructure, rather than as a purely commercial convenience. Today, using hyperscale cloud providers often means deep vendor lock-in, high costs, and fragile complexity. Much engineering effort is spent adapting systems to a single provider, making it difficult or impossible to switch. This is not resilience. Luckily, the majority of business applications don't need hyperscalers. Some businesses do, but most use these aspirationally, or because their software engineers have no incentive to do something else. Bureaucratic businesses risk aversion doing exactly the opposite. We need a cultural shift from hyperscalers to efficient, close to home, simple, but high-tech solutions. I want European cloud services that are hosted in the EU, governed by European law, built on locally produced hardware and open standards, and designed for sustainability and decentralization. Open standards and decentralization are key, as these allow for (many) small businesses to compete with AWS, Google and Azure. A cloud doesn't have to be provided by a single provider! Such infrastructure would reduce risk, improve reliability, and strengthen Europes competitiveness, as customers in the rest of the world face the same issues.

I am going to address questions 2 and 3, as outlined in the "C. - Consultation strategy" section. 2. Open-source software provides many benefits over proprietary software, especially in the public sector. Given the open nature of the software, it is often interoperable with other competing products, reducing lock-in. This goes hand-in-hand with another important pillar open-source software brings to the table: digital sovereignty. In proprietary software, the customers (governments, companies, individuals) often do not have a choice about where their data is stored, and even if they have, the data is usually still handled by whoever is providing the software. If they handle your data incorrectly (e.g., sharing it with a foreign government), you have a choice. By contrast, in open-source software, customers are usually free to decide where and how software is hosted, ensuring their data is safe from external actors. Additionally, given that anyone can inspect and analyse the source code of open-source software, security researchers from all over Europe and the world can discover, report and fix security vulnerabilities that could otherwise go unnoticed in proprietary software. While this is not a silver bullet, and there have certainly been cases of open-source software being vulnerable (see OpenSSL Heartbleed, XZ compromise, and the recent React2Shell vulnerability), it can be argued that security vulnerabilities are handled in a much more transparent way in open-source projects, and those that have been found could have remained undetected if it were not for independent security researchers. Finally, while cost savings are also a factor to consider, it is far from the most important. Given one of the main struggles of open-source software is funding, the savings from switching to open-source software should be invested back into funding and donations to the projects being used. 3. As mentioned, the main problem with open-source is the lack of funding, which means there are not many developers that can focus on those projects outside of their free time. If those developers could work on open-source as part of their job, the open-source software offerings would substantially improve quality, the lack of which has in some cases been a major barrier to adoption. As a concrete measure, the EU should fund open-source projects that are important to its sovereignty and create incentives for the private sector to do the same.

Europe relies far too heavily on a few non-European tech companies. This dependence concentrates power outside our borders and exposes our societies to structural vulnerabilities. As a matter of strategic urgency, we must realize that we need our own GitHub, our own YouTube, and our own Twitter. We should have introduced them 15 years ago, but it is better to be late than to never embrace it to begin with. Social media and digital platforms have fundamentally changed our behaviors, political discourse, and culture, much like Gutenbergs printing press. As Marshall McLuhan wrote, technologies are extensions of man that reshape society. Alfred North Whitehead noted that civilization advances by increasing the number of important operations which we can perform without thinking about them. Today, many of these operations are outsourced to foreign digital monopolies. Git is a distributed version control system that allows developers to track and collaborate on code. GitHub is the largest platform for hosting and sharing Git repositories. If Europeans were denied access to these repositories, innovation could slow and technological stagnation would threaten critical infrastructure. Tools like curl and protocols for secure communication depend on open-source contributions. Much of the internet, from cloud services to industrial systems, relies on these shared technologies. Microsoft and Apple have repeatedly violated user privacy, enforced proprietary lock-in, and weakened digital autonomy. Europe must stay friendly but also actively support logical, secure, and free alternatives. Linux and the broader free software ecosystem provide privacy, control, and adaptability. Supporting these alternatives is essential for Europes security, competitiveness, and technological sovereignty. The European Commissions initiative to strengthen open-source ecosystems is urgent. By ensuring access, support, and scaling of free technologies, Europe can regain control over its digital infrastructure, protect citizens rights, and maintain long-term innovation without depending on external actors. Jonatan Jansson

I'm a maintainer of the open source Arch Linux distribution. We have struggled with the required time and effort for applying to various grants. Even with some successful applications, we still do not have a predictable or stable way to fund development of core components of the project. Obtaining funding is even more difficult for the majority of popular open source projects which is maintained by single individuals, leading to critical projects becoming unmaintained due to developer burnout. Public funding programs need to become more predictable: It's impossible for many to plan their finances if a grant takes more than half a year to evaluate applications, then another few months before the first payment. The application process itself needs to rely less on keywords and form, and the effort required to write an application should be lowered. The barriers to entry are too high, and many developers I know gave up before even trying.

Open-Source is a great benefit for the world and I applaud the EU looking at the Open-Source community as a solution for digital sovereignty. However, I invite the commissioners to visit FOSDEM in Brussels to see and understand what the open-source community looks like. Open-source tools have low adoption because while often made by brilliant technical people, they rarely pay attention to the end-user experience. Creating useable and intuitive products is very hard and requires constant feedback and iterations on shallow interfaces. Something most highly technical people hate. As somebody who has done tech startups and managed engineers I can tell you that the biggest hurdle open-source has is that open-source is created mostly for other highly technical people. As such, open-source is deeply successful as a half-fabricate. A solution used by other technical people to create an end-solution. It is successful as a platform, saving engineering time but rarely as a standalone solution. Tech startups are much more successful in creating digital sovereignty, it suffices to solve the capital market (more equity investments) and to ensure high demand (protectionism/european preference). I would not look at the open-source community as a solution to digital sovereignty. Mandating public institutions to have european preference would enable a suite of startups delivering this for them. Once that is done it can be extended to sensitive companies and ultimately expanded to the entire economy. Protectionism has downsides but actually those can be circumvented by funding 100s of competitors which ensures high internal competition but also very cutthroat competition that would enable those companies to survive once protectionism is lifted. This answers 1-3 of your questions. There are areas where Open-Source could yield tremendous value if you consider that it is very successful in platforms (linux, android) The US and Chinese car companies have managed to transition to software-based cars while European ones are still stuck integrating different vendor components which are often written in different languages. An Open Car initiative could create the Android of cars, a global platform to speed up innovation. Similar for boats, planes, trucks and trains. Converting the software-stack of those large systems to open-source ecosystems could lead to wild, unexpected innovation. (E.g. applying the technology of self-driving cars to trains is perfectly possible) EU action on this level can unlock innovation by allowing very small teams to create improvements independent of the major car manufacturers.

Je pense qu'il est important de se séparer de toute entreprise pour les services publiques, je ne pense pas qu'il soit sain de donner de l'argent à Microsoft (par exemple) pour effectuer une tâche que n'importe quel logiciel libre peut remplacer aisément. Et tout peut être remplacer, du système d'exploitation au logiciel spécifique, il faut juste trouver la bonne alternative. Personnellement, j'utilise Linux depuis un peu plus d'un an, et je n'ai rencontré aucun problème critique, et les quelques rares problème que j'ai eu concerne des cas isolés, comme certains jeux qui refuse de démarrer car leur logiciel anti triche est spécifiquement développer pour Windows et que les développeurs ne supportent pas Linux, cependant, ce genre de cas isolés n'arriverais pas pour les outils dont ont besoin les agents du services publique, qui se limiterait à LibreWolf (Ou autre navigateur open source), LibreOffice (Ou autre logiciel de bureautique open source), etc. De plus, certaines démarches sont déjà en cours pour passer du côté libre des logiciels, comme pour GendBuntu, un OS basé sur Ubuntu développé pour les gendarme Français. Le transfert vers un OS développé par eux est un choix évident qui permet d'accélérer la gestion des bugs, de gagner en liberté d'utilisation, de perdre en logiciel espion installé, bref, énormément de positif. Et le choix de logiciel ouvert apporte le même lot de bienfait. N'oubliez pas que le principale frein à l'abandon d'entreprise du GAFAM, est le fait que le support est universelle et par défaut partout, si on commence à abandonner de manière universelle leurs support, les entreprises développant des logiciels n'auront d'autre choix que de supporter d'autre services que ceux issues des GAFAM. Autrement dit, si les PC viennent préinstallé avec de l'open source, que ce qu'on utilise au quotidien est issu de l'open source, que on apprends à l'école a utilisé des logiciels open source, alors l'influence des GAFAM sera réduit, et ce sera idéal pour le bien commun. C'est hélas eux qui sont la source de bien des pannes, que si nous utilisons de l'open source, pourrais être éviter. La panne AWS, la panne mondial de Windows, etc. Ce genre de panne n'existerais plus si nous étions indépendant de ces méga entreprises.
