feedback: My feedback is summarized in this presentation: https://youtu.be/39jsstmmUUs?si=FCCthQGRZfo9jaI2

Open Source software is fundamental to guarantee Europe's digital infrastructure is safe from foreign interference. Even locally made closed source software doesn't provide the same guarantees, as the software maker may at any time be acquired by a foreign company that would move control of the software outside of the EU's purview, whereas FOSS projects built on Copyleft licenses provide the option for EU-based actors to fork them should the original project leads give the EU cause to worry. There needs to be wide reaching initiatives to move to FOSS at various levels of our digital infrastucture, be it operating systems, communication platforms, office suites and many others. But there also needs to be support provided to FOSS projects to ensure they are able to continue to be capable of meeting our needs in a fast moving digital world. This support needs to be financial but also needs to be backed at the legislative level: Germany's Sovereign Tech Fund and the EU-STF proposal from OpenForum Europe of how it could be scaled up to an EU wide initiative is a good blueprint of how to properly implement EU funding for FOSS projects, and the German STF has already proven to be invaluable for important projects, helping the GNOME project improve accessibility in its software suite for example. It is also important and, in my view, in line with the EU's existing Digital Markets Act that we ensure large tech conglomerate aren't allowed to use their gatekeeper status to hinder FOSS adoption. An example of how they do this is by pushing proprietary standards which FOSS projects can't properly interoperate with, for example Microsoft docx/xlsx/... which can be a pain point of migrating to FOSS office suites which cannot properly support them. The EU should examine those sorts of behavior under the DMA and where appropriate should compel gatekeepers to either open up their proprietary formats or adopt open standards themselves, in this case that would be the OpenDocument Format. Lastly, the EU should consider mandating that computers and smartphones sold in Europe provide interoperability with third party Operating Systems such as Linux, as improper hardware support is another hindrance to FOSS adoption and gatekeepers like Apple, Microsoft or Google leverage their position to keep users within their own walled gardens.

The EU has an enormous human capital in the field of computer science and software engineering. Many of the most important FOSS (free and open source software) initiatives originated in the EU, Linux being one notable example. We must understand, however, that the word "free" in "free software" means free as in "free speech", not "free beer". In other words, there should be incentives (financial but not only) for FOSS developers to make good, solid software which could then be used by enterprises, public institutions, and individuals in the EU. Grants for FOSS developers (without too much red tape!!) would be one solution; another idea might be to support European companies writing FOSS open source products are not necessarily a steady source of income, which can bring down small enterprises building them. I think the biggest and most important challenge is achieving "feature parity" with equivalent non-EU products used in strategic areas, so: software powering cloud platforms (load balancers, firewalls, orchestration tools, etc.), secure communications tools, collaborative office suites, and so on. Definitely *NOT* chasing the latest fads "not to be left behind".

The core strengths of the EU open-source sector are rooted in our underlying digital laws in terms of data collection, requiring consent and enforcing integrity and transparency. European citizens are overall well educated when it comes to digital integrity, user rights and transparency, which translates very well to the open-source mindset. It's a lot easier to adapt to and build open-source technology when you live in a society that mirrors the collaborative and transparent nature of open-source development. The main barrier for wider adoption of open-source technology is that it's usually maintained and developed by single individuals (or smaller groups of individuals) as side projects, and as time permits. Open-source maintainers usually have to solve the impossible equation of balancing their paid job, family life and their open-source project. This imbalance increases as projects gain traction and perhaps become an integral part of other, even more popular software. The expectations of upholding and maintaining open-source projects are usually set way too high - it's a difficult and time consuming job, and often leads to projects becoming unmaintained. Europe has a lot of skilled developers and tech people that want to be part of open-source but are tied up in their daily jobs. More creative initiatives, from both national and EU levels, are required, that give EU tech companies tools and regulations to allow their employees to dedicate part of their time to contribute to select open-source projects, ideally during work hours, without financial loss, or through some other creative compensation. To many, contributing to open-source projects fulfills a need to help others and the society, which is important for personal growth. Contributing to open-source projects is also a great way of improving your skills and/or learning about new technologies and platforms and should be more endorsed by EU tech company leaders. Overall we need more incentives and alternatives for leaders and employers to allow their employees to spend more time on open-source. When it comes to focus areas, instead of focusing on complete, end-to-end products ("leaves of the tree" if you will), focus on smaller, isolated modules like data transfer protocols, authentication and authorization, adapters and interfaces between various data models, to use as building blocks for existing and future products ("branches of the tree"). This has many benefits compared to complete products: * It naturally shrinks the scope of the project, making it easier to maintain, understand and contribute to. * It can be more easily adapted and used in a wider variety of projects. * It's easier to replace. Building through modularity like this is considered good practice in modern software development, as it prevents building up a "tech debt" and generally allows for easier maintenance and feature updates. Finally, addressing the value of open-source, I'd say it's primarily in the transparency and collaboration. Allowing anyone to see all the insides of how something works is the easiest way to guarantee secure, efficient and future-proof software. With the increase of AI it becomes even more important for developers, researchers, law enforcers and technically skilled people to review, question and examine how the software we use daily work.

Subject: Feedback on the Call for Evidence Towards European open digital ecosystems (Initiative Q1-2026) 1. Strengths and weaknesses of the EU open-source sector: The EUs primary strength is its highly skilled and active developer community that is well-aligned with EU digital rights and principles. However, a major weakness is the "high entry barriers" and "network effects of dominant players" from outside the EU, which make it difficult for local open-source projects to achieve commercial viability or scale. Additionally, there is a lack of sustainable funding and governance frameworks for upscaling smaller community projects. 2. Added value of open source for the public and private sectors: Open source provides critical added value by reducing "vendor lock-in" and increasing transparency and security through public code audits. For the public sector, it ensures that digital infrastructure remains a "public good" that can be freely reused and modified, which is essential for sovereign government processes. 3. Concrete measures and actions at the EU level: I recommend that the EU implement a "European Preference" or similar incentivization for open-source solutions in public procurement. Furthermore, the Commission should provide dedicated funding for the maintenance and "software supply chain security" of existing critical open-source libraries to prevent vulnerabilities in the digital economy. 4. Technology areas that should be prioritized: Priority should be given to Artificial Intelligence (AI), Cloud, Edge computing, and Cybersecurity. Specifically, supporting open AI models is vital to ensure that the "exponential growth" of this technology does not create new dependencies on non-EU proprietary stacks. 5. Sectors where open source can lead to increased competitiveness: The Automotive and Industrial manufacturing sectors would benefit most from increased use of open-source software-defined stacks. By sharing the development costs of non-competitive core infrastructure, EU companies can focus their resources on high-value innovation and cyber resilience. Vittorio Quattrone

When talking about Open Source, we should not only look at user-facing apps (e.g. compare LibreOffice to MS Office) but look at fundamentals: Operating systems, programming languages, databases, web frameworks, libraries etc. This is an area where open source is incredibly successful and Europeans are quite involved. However, it would be wrong to speak of european projects because these projects are usually global collaborations. The main issue is that many gatekeepers are strongly tied to the US (e.g. IETF, ICANN, GitHub, NPM, PyPI, Docker Hub, Apple Store, ). Providing alternatives to these gate keepers would just fracture the community. So if we strive for digital sovereignty, the goal must be to decentralize these gate keepers as much as possible so that no single nation can use them against other nations. Following these observations, I would recommend: - Fund work on open source, especially on fundamentals, to provide a reliable and secure base that businesses can build on - Continue regulating the IT industry to incentivize security, transparency and data protection (which inherently favors Open Source) - Work to decentralize organizations that act as gate keepers and which currently are dominated by the US

2. Value: Only open source software *can* be considered secure. Wherever source code is not public, the vendor is able to introduce vulnerabilities (with or without intent) and has very few incentives to be rigorous. Open source software is subject to audit by citizens - where bugs or vulnerabilities can be discovered, issues raised, solutions proposed and there's public pressure to get things fixed. Open source is the only way to keep data mostly/ asymptotically secure, with an adequate level of institutional integrity - is most important reason for using open source even in the best of times. It should be the right of all European citizens, that any public institution or business using their data must only use open source software on machines that handle their data. Certainly for all services or systems where people have no reasonable alternative but to submit their data. There is also a whole different sense of "security" to keep in mind. Given militarist expansionism and state economic extortion are state policy in both the US and China, European institutions, businesses and individuals cannot trust software or cloud vendors based in the US or China. We also cannot trust software or cloud vendors with enough involvement in those markets to be subject to effective sanctions. To ensure non-vulnerability in general, open source is not quite enough. We should also require that vendors for European services use open standards so far as possible. That is, standards freely adopted and supported by many vendors, often though not always with open source implementations. This ensures portability across multiple competing vendors, which is the best way to avoid having to trust the integrity of any individual vendor. 5. There is no subset of sectors where this matters. In every context, software is open source and built on open standards with multiple competing vendors and low entry barriers, or it is insecure and it will suffer data compromise or be used to extort European businesses and undermine EU and nation state sovereignty. 3. Structural problems: - for custom software projects, open source software will always be more expensive. Partly because it must be of higher quality and largely free from discoverable vulnerabilities. But mainly because vendors will fear more competition in future and less lucrative maintenance spending. So open source must be a hard legal requirement. - well financed private vendors (software and cloud) have aggressive marketing, subsidized on-ramps and procurement outreach (corruption?). They spend to get users & deals, with the goal of vendor lock-in and extortion. - Microsoft has been aggressively pushing Windows across all PCs for 3 decades now, cooperating and dealing with hardware manufacturers to prevent them from shipping PCs or laptops with other operating systems. Schools tend to use Windows. Most consumers and workers are more familiar with Windows. All of this needs to be changed through legislation and competent institutional leadership. Schools and universities should not be allowed to use Windows, Microsoft Office or Google Docs. - public procurement is broken today. All software systems paid for with public money should be open source - that is a minimum requirement for taxpayers and citizens to have any confidence that public funds are well spent or that data is safe. - there is a deep supply chain across open source: many projects freely distribute their code and packaged binaries. This has immense social value, but the people working on this are often underpaid. There is an immense amount of public good that could be achieved with more open source development, where the development just isn't happening because there isn't a market to pay for it. Where an open source project becomes a dependency (at any level) in a public system, there should be some level of public subisdy paid to the maintainers of that pro

feedback: I am a Computational Physics scholar, and in the field of science the value of open source software is invaluable. Everybody can study a topic and learn from the implementation of computational methods, and when working on new research it is easier to get the most performance out of programs, and easily adapt them to the task thanks to the full access to the source code. This is crucial to further our knowledge in strategical sectors such as medical treatments, energy and material science. In an epoch where technologies are increasingly weaponised by foreign governments and companies, supporting FOSS is the right choice for the world and for EU, morally and practically. A big problem for EU's open source space is the total dependency of european governments and companies on technology provided by US monopolist companies, which makes it hard to sell a service even if it is clearly better and cheaper. However most people don't know alternatives exists and identifies some techonologies by the associated US monopolist. Another problem is the dirigiste and surveillance approach from EU and some countries which is forcing surveillance (eg Chat Control) and unfavorable and convoluted burden of verificatoin of security for open source projects. We need to understand that closed source = security threat and that cloud = other people's computers. Adoption of FOSS should be encouraged for the whole of public administration: 1. EU should provide financial support and incentive to institutions willing to switch to open source solutions : municipalities, regions, universities and hospitals. 2. EU should move to prohibit proprietary formats where not necessary, in documents released from the government 3. EU should provide financial and tecnical support to project of informatization of education which involve open source technologies and promote education and awareness about digital sovereignty and freedom. While the best technologies are built from the bottom up, their adoption is a consequence of involvement from the government.

Supernova Labs and The Open Spaceplane Project exemplify how open design, FabLab/Hackspace culture, and publicly shared knowledge accelerate innovation, lower barriers to entry, and strengthen European technological sovereignty. Supernova Labs grew within makerspace environments, developing rapid prototyping and systems integration in 3D printing, drones, and aerospace workflows. The Open Spaceplane Project maintains an open repository of spaceplane designs, enabling broader participation in space vehicle development beyond elite industrial actors. These initiatives show how open knowledge commons underpin rapid, low-cost innovation, allowing vertical integration across the EU for fast deployment in aerospace, energy, mobility, and research. Defending Open Licenses and Knowledge Commons is essential. Open software and hardware require licensing protections to preserve shared value. Without safeguards, contributions can be used without attribution or reinvestment in the community. Strong open licenses including GPL, CERN OHL, and Creative Commons ensure transparency, accountability, and reusable outputs. Embedding licensing requirements in EU-funded projects, procurement, and partnerships strengthens trust and encourages cross-border innovation. FabLabs, Hackspaces and Distributed Infrastructure enable rapid prototyping and local production. Supernova Labs experience shows how FabLabs support the transition from prototypes to industrial-grade deployments, reduce supply chain dependency, and foster regional innovation. EU support for Hackspace/FabLab networks and open manufacturing hubs could accelerate low-cost solutions in energy, aerospace, healthcare, and mobility, linking digital and physical infrastructure via open standards and tools. Open Source AI Operating Systems and Public Data Archival form a transparent, trustworthy digital layer. They allow EU institutions, SMEs, and research centers to deploy local AI without vendor lock-in, tailor solutions to local contexts, and integrate with FAIR-compliant public datasets. Open OSes and open datasets accelerate cross-institutional collaboration and reproducible science, as demonstrated in aerospace and systems engineering workflows. Tools and Projects Illustrating Open Innovation include: Linux foundational OS underpinning EU infrastructure and AI frameworks; OpenVSP parametric aircraft design; Libre Space Foundation/PHASMA open hardware in space systems; ESA open-source FPGA toolchains; MakerPlane open aircraft designs; OpenFOAM CFD platform used in aerospace, energy, and climate; Blender evolved from 3D modeling to full animation and simulation platform. These examples show that open platforms broaden participation, reduce costs, and enable innovation in software, hardware, research, mission design, and public infrastructure. Policy Recommendations: Embed mandatory open licensing for publicly funded software, hardware, and data. Support FabLabs, hackspaces and distributed open hardware infrastructure for rapid deployment and capacity building. Remove dependency on Big Tech in favour of home-grown solutions with open architecture. Promote open-source AI OSes and FAIR-compliant data archives as core European digital goods. Include simple open ecosystem criteria in procurement, funding, and partnerships. Enable governance frameworks for long-term community stewardship and knowledge reuse through a common repository and data archive framework. Europe can achieve digital sovereignty, economic resilience, and rapid innovation by leveraging open-source software, open knowledge, and shared infrastructure across EU member states and ESA signatories, including the UK. Supernova Labs and The Open Spaceplane Project demonstrate the real-world impact of low-cost, replicable innovation anchored in open collaboration. We must define a new model for the future.

I'm a software engineer working on a large open source project (80k stars on GitHub). Our customers use our software as part of their own software engineering efforts, leveraging our tool to improve efficiency and quality. The team is funded by a large american corporation. Within the EU, a lot of software engineers are already avid fans of the open source development model. Supporting open source is a force multiplier for trustworthy, sovereign systems. To enable this, the following actions would help: - a publicly-hosted, high quality code platform like GitLab, including cheap CI infrastructure - public grants for open source work that's traditionally hard to fund (like the Sovereign Tech Fund) - help offerings for companies and institutions to migrate from proprietary to open systems, for example via special grants Funding open source has historically been hard, there's a couple of models that emerged: - corporate sponsorship. large profits from proprietary products fund small efforts that improve engineering efficiency. This model also exists with intermediary foundations, e.g. via the Linux Foundation. This model *only* works for efforts that improve engineering efficiency, it does not work for products. - open core model, where there's an open core and a proprietary extended offering; GitLab is an example. Can work, but not ideal. - Fully open product funded by a professional services branch. openDesk and Element are examples. Ideal for products, this model should be the preferred.

As a software developer and user of open source software, having previously opted into the Microsoft ecosystem and having used Google products, I see that the current digital infrastructure is centralised in the United States by the few large tech corporations there. It is no wonder that opting into an external, subscription-based, closed-source solution has its downsides: not allowing for digital sovereignity is the biggest - your payment provider, email provider, all your documents can be taken away at any point in time, should the corporation (or in some cases, its government) wish so. The example where ICC prosecutor Karim Khan was locked out of her email by the USA was a wake-up call (https://www.heise.de/en/news/Criminal-Court-Microsoft-s-email-block-a-wake-up-call-for-digital-sovereignty-10387383.html). I believe that open source office suites and productivity software is the start of digital souvereignity: how can a government be truly independent if it depends on other governments, institutions, or companies for the storage or processing of its data? Luckily, there are already some initiatives that aim to combine open source projects into comprehensive office suites, such as Germany's "Open Desk" (https://www.opendesk.eu/en) and the Dutch "Mijn Bureau" (https://minbzk.github.io/mijn-bureau-infra/). By combining these projects with open source accounting software, and of course, an open source operating system, we guarantee that we remain sovereign in the modern, technology-filled world. Integrating open-source intiatives and projects like mentioned before into a centralised EU strategy and framework would in my opinion be a good stepping stone to at least let people, companies, institutions, governments, etc. know that these options exist, and help them adopt the strategy of open source.

Feedback on the European Open Digital Ecosystem Strategy (from practical experience with justbsocial.eu) As the developer and administrator of justbsocial.eu, a European, privacy-friendly and open social community platform, I strongly welcome this initiative. It addresses real challenges we encounter when building digital services aligned with European values and regulatory frameworks. 1. Open Digital Ecosystems Strengthen European Sovereignty Open source is not just a development model; it is a strategic pillar for technological sovereignty, security, and competitiveness. Through justbsocial.eu we demonstrate that it is possible to provide alternatives to dominant commercial platforms that: are hosted in Europe do not sell or broker user data respect GDPR rights (data portability & right to be forgotten) are interoperable through open standards This clearly benefits the EUs strategic autonomy and digital resilience. 2. Reuse of Open Digital Assets Must Be Accelerated In practice, we observe that open digital components (modules, privacy tools, federation protocols, etc.) remain fragmented and inaccessible. A structured EU framework encouraging reusesupported by certification, documentation, and shared standardswould greatly reduce development cost and stimulate innovation. An EU Open Digital Asset Library would be a major enabler, especially if it ensures: interoperability security validation compliance with EU privacy and accessibility rules 3. Digital Rights by Design One major benefit of EU-led digital ecosystems is the ability to embed fundamental rights by design rather than as afterthoughts. On justbsocial.eu, for example: GDPR data export right to erasure no behavioural profiling no advertising no external trackers are implemented by default, not as optional settings. The Strategy should consider such rights as a minimum baseline for EU public interest digital services. 4. Support for European Alternatives Is Necessary Today, citizens, schools, NGOs and local communities remain locked into non-European platforms because: alternatives lack visibility there is insufficient structural funding federation standards are not mandated there are no public adoption programmes This Strategy could gain real impact by: encouraging public sector institutions to adopt open platforms supporting open federation protocols (e.g., ActivityPub) establishing EU digital sandboxing & funding streams raising public awareness through trusted communication campaigns 5. Strategic Value for Education & Society Digital literacy, data autonomy and civic engagement are key elements of Europes knowledge economy. Platforms like justbsocial.eu already serve education, neighbourhood communities and cross-border collaboration because: there is no commercial tracking no algorithmic content manipulation users retain ownership of their data This aligns strongly with the European vision of an open, democratic and human-centric digital space. Conclusion The European Open Digital Ecosystem Strategy is timely and important. Based on our experience, we recommend: Treat open source as a strategic asset for digital sovereignty Invest in reusable, interoperable open digital assets Enforce privacy-by-design and user rights as a baseline Support European alternatives through funding and adoption programmes Promote open digital ecosystems in education and the public sector Europe has the talent and vision to build a secure, resilient and democratic digital ecosystem. This initiative is a major step toward that future.

In unserem Unternehmen setzen wir seit vielen Jahren Open Source Software ein. Privat ebenso. Dazu zählen unter anderem Linux, FreeBSD, LibreOffice, Kolab, Apache sowie zahlreiche andere Programme. Dies hat uns über all die Jahre sehr viele Kosten erspart. Ein nicht zu unterschätzender Aspekt ist auch die Unabhängigkeit und der Datenschutz. Für bestimmte Programme müssen wir leider auch Windows einsetzen. Die Richtung, in die Microsoft Windows entwickelt, bereitet uns zunehmend Bauchschmerzen. Insbesondere der Datenschutz ist hier zu nennen. Wer personenbezogene Daten verarbeitet, darf Windows eigentlich nicht mehr einsetzen. Gerade in der aktuellen Zeit, Stichworte USA, Trump, ist es wichtiger denn je, dass wir uns unabhängig machen können. Mit Open Source Software lässt sich dies leisten. Mit Closed Source Software nicht. Big Tech verfolgt andere Ziele als unser Wohl und unsere Unabhängigkeit. Die Sperre des E-Mail-Kontos, des Chefanklägers des Internationalen Gerichtshof durch Microsoft, sollte Warnung genug sein, was passieren kann, wenn wir uns nicht von bisherigen Abhängigkeiten lösen. Statt weiterhin viel Geld an die großen IT-Unternehmen zu zahlen und einzelne Personen noch reicher zu machen, als sie eh schon sind, siehe Jeff Bezos, Elon Musk, die nichts Gutes im Schilde führen und unsere Gesellschaft eher spalten und zerstören, Investieren wir unser Geld viel besser in Open Source Software, die allen nützt. Bestes Beispiel ist das Open Source Software Paket Kolab, das vor einigen Jahren vom Deutschen Bundesamt für Sicherheit in der Informationstechnik beauftragt wurde. Es kann von jedermann heruntergeladen und eingesetzt werden und kann einen Microsoft Exchange Server ersetzen. Hier ist sicherlich noch weitere Entwicklungsarbeit notwendig, um das Programmpaket komfortabler und universeller einsetzbar zu machen. Generell sollte bei Investitionen in die IT das Motto "public money, public code" lauten. Kolab baut auf anderen Open Source-Software-Paketen auf. Hier wurde im Prinzip nur die notwendige Software entwickelt, die dazu notwendig ist, diese einzelnen Softwarepakete zu einem Gesamtpaket zu verbinden und zu ergänzen. Die Entwicklung von Kolab halte ich für ein Paradebeispiel dafür, wie es laufen kann, wie man Software für die Verwaltung entwickeln lässt, aber gleichzeitig auch der Allgemeinheit zur Verfügung stellt. Gleichzeitig schaffen wir somit Unabhängigkeit und einen Mehrwert für sehr viele. Zusätzlich ist zu erwähnen, dass es viele Open Source Software Pakete gibt auf die viele andere Pakete aufbauen und die letztendlich ein Grundpfeiler unserer modernen Informationsgesellschaft sind. Nichtsdestotrotz werden diese Projekte von einigen wenigen teils als Hobby betrieben. Hier wäre sicherlich eine Forderung durch Geld oder durch steuerliche Vergünstigungen angebracht, um eine Weiterentwicklung zu gewährleisten. Aufgrund der aktuellen Weltlage stehen wir vor großen Herausforderungen, haben aber meiner Meinung nach definitiv die Chance, jetzt den Grundstein für eine bessere Zukunft der EU zu legen. Bitte verzeihen Sie meine drastischen Worte. Aber es ist einfach notwendig, dass wir endlich richtig handeln und den Lobbyisten großer Unternehmen kein Gehör mehr schenken. Wir müssen endlich europäische Lösungen schaffen, ohne immer nur den großen Buzzwords blind hinterher zu laufen. Wir brauchen praktische Lösungen für den Alltag, egal ob für den privaten Gebrauch oder den Einsatz im Unternehmen.

feedback:
1. What are the strengths and weaknesses of the EU open-source sector? What are the main barriers that hamper (i) adoption and maintenance of high-quality and secure open source; and (ii) sustainable contributions to opensource communities? The greatest weakness is general lack of knowledge about how open-source world works in both public and private sectors. That is easily the greatest barrier I can see for both (i) and (ii). For private industry and (ii), a common problem has been that due to heavy hierarchies, it is often impossible for developers to contribute their patches to the upstream. I have personally witnessed more than one occasion where the local branch of the company would be completely willing to upstream their fixes, but they need to get approval from elsewhere, where approval is needed from yet elsewhere, etc. This means a lot of fixes never get upstreamed, and have to be reinvented multiple times in different companies. It is hard to untangle these problems even from inside the companies themselves. 2. What is the added value of open source for the public and private sectors? Please provide concrete examples, including the factors (such as cost, risk, lock-in, security, innovation, among others) that are most important to assess the added value. Avoiding vendor lock-in and in many cases access to vetted, possibly audited, code, which requires a lot more trust in the service provider in proprietary environments. In much of open-source development, priority is given to different concerns than in for-product development. This allows much greater care in development as "sellable" functionality is not the main concern. As such, libraries and programs offering core functionality, such as cURL (http), OpenCV (computer vision) or ffmpeg (video) can focus their efforts on being really good at what they do, without profit motive hindering them. A lot of open-source projects are created because a skilled enough person is annoyed by how something works, and sees a possibility to create something better. This often leads to more novel, if fragmented, solutions. Most obviously seen in different user interfaces for *nix computers. KDE, GNOME, Enlightenment, i3, etc. all come from different viewpoints. Open-source software also places higher value on interoperability and standard-compatibility (if not conformance). Open-source developers are often scattered, and they need standards to be interoperable with each other. They do not have either manpower or time to invent everything themselves. 3. What concrete measures and actions may be taken at EU level to support the development and growth of the EU open-source sector and contribute to the EUs technological sovereignty and cybersecurity agenda? Open source is critically underfunded. While foundations such as NLNet offer grants, they cannot help everyone. Two concrete suggestions: - Pass a directive to make it legal everywhere to ask for donations for open source. Currently this is illegal e.g. in Finland. - Open source tends to be localised, provide insentives for EU companies to contribute part of their earnings back to Open source-related foundations that can distribute the money. This can be done e.g. via tax benefits to companies that donate to foundations such as NLnet, effectively insentivising redirecting the money back to the developers. 4. What technology areas should be prioritised and why? Anything used by public services and government. Common tools used by people working in these institutions. Maybe even cloud tech (though I think private cloud was a mistake for public sector in the first place). France and Germany are showing signs of doing this right. That is where Europe is almost completely dependant on non-EU services, and it really shouldn't be. 5. In what sectors could an increased use of open source lead to increased competitiveness and cyber resilience? Open source is a way

feedback: 1. What are the strengths and weaknesses of the EU open-source sector? What are the main barriers that hamper (i) adoption and maintenance of high-quality and secure open source; and (ii) sustainable contributions to opensource communities? Main strength is plenty of active communities. The wo main barriers to sustainable contribution is A) the hostile EU politics, like "Chat Control", which is a serious, active and fundamental threat to democracy as a whole, but also particularly to people knowledgeable in the digital space. B) the "free meal" attitude of both businesses and political actors in Europe, which stems from a lack of understanding of just how large the value gained already is and how much infrastructure and business depend on it. 2. What is the added value of open source for the public and private sectors? Please provide concrete examples, including the factors (such as cost, risk, lock-in, security, innovation, among others) that are most important to assess the added value. Shared, secure and verifiable software libraries are foundational to the European economy. It is literally impossible to imagine a functioning banking or ordering and delivery system, without reliable encryption technology. Basic communication and self presentation: websites, pictures, video, sound, messaging, web browsers all require equally reliable standards on a wide range of devices. They are other good examples of open source software that is taken for granted, but still foundational and generally underfunded. 3. What concrete measures and actions may be taken at EU level to support the development and growth of the EU open-source sector and contribute to the EUs technological sovereignty and cybersecurity agenda? Companies should be forced to take stock of the software they actually use and actually depend upon. Ideally, a sincere "make or buy" analysis that explores how much it would cost companies to replicate bits and pieces they are currently unaware of, would probably highlight the value they are receiving and should make the self-interest they have in supporting it more obvious. There should be an incentive (or law) for companies in similar market segments to cooperate and identify areas of redundant structures: system for login, user administration, website structure and presentation are common problems shared by a wide variety of companies, with equally common and unremarkable solutions. Yet these solutions are treated as important "business secrets" and "assets", when they mostly represent a sunk cost. Adopting a sharing friendly mindest that distinguishes between actually critical business secrets and mundane software, could create new areas of cooperation. 4. What technology areas should be prioritised and why? Foundational pieces of business. Standards for bills, receipts, payments, dates, time, generalized tasks and other every day relevant things. There are two steps in creating an "industry 4.0": first, one has to recognizes the benefits and adopt it locally, second, it is important to make one's own system inter-operable with other public systems. This is only feasible when shared standards are used. Imagine manufacturing even a simple product from only a few components made by different suppliers: different document formats for data sheets, delivery documents, business correspondence, which all have to be reformatted into the manufacturers system. Also, increased codification of common terms of service. 5. In what sectors could an increased use of open source lead to increased competitiveness and cyber resilience? All of them: building and infrastructure, manufacturing, services, agriculture and resources. There are no sectors anymore. that are not using hardware with a software component or software directly.

Germany and the European Union demonstrate substantial strength in open-source ecosystems through large-scale community knowledge projects and public-sector Linux adoption, showing that open digital ecosystems are built on sustained, mostly voluntary contributions that merit formal recognition as Ehrenamt (civic volunteer work). Germany hosts one of the largest and most active Wikipedia communities worldwide, with the German-language edition ranking among the top language versions by number of articles and active editors. Wikimedia Deutschland, a non-profit with over 111,000 members, develops free software, maintains the open data project Wikidata, and supports volunteer editors who provide a critical pillar of Europe's digital public knowledge infrastructure. German public institutions have a long track record of adopting Linux and open-source software to strengthen digital sovereignty. Examples include Linux use by the German Bundestag's server infrastructure, large-scale deployments in federal agencies such as the Federal Employment Office (Bundesagentur für Arbeit), and municipal migrations including Munich's LiMux project and Schleswig-Holstein's ongoing transition to Linux and LibreOffice. A significant share of this infrastructureWikipedia, Wikidata, and core open-source software used in public administrationis built and maintained by unpaid volunteers acting in the public interest. However, Germany's legal framework does not generally recognize open-source development and maintenance as Ehrenamt under tax and funding law, prompting recent petitions calling for such recognition. For the European Open Digital Ecosystems initiative, these German examples illustrate that Europe already hosts mature, high-impact open-source and open-knowledge communities delivering public goods at continental scale. Recognizing contributions to Wikipedia, Wikidata, Linux distributions, and strategic open-source components as Ehrenamt (voluntary work with accepted tax or similar benefits) would align legal and financial support with the EU's objectives of digital sovereignty, resilience, and trustworthy digital infrastructure. References: - European Commission Better Regulation Portal - European Open Digital Ecosystems Initiative: https://ec.europa.eu/info/law/better-regulation/have-your-say/initiatives/16213-European-Open-Digital-Ecosystems/ - Wikimedia Deutschland: https://www.wikimedia.de/ - Wikipedia - German Wikipedia: https://de.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deutschsprachige_Wikipedia - Wikipedia - Open-Source-Software in öffentlichen Einrichtungen (German): https://de.wikipedia.org/wiki/Open-Source-Software_in_%C3%B6ffentlichen_Einrichtungen - Wikipedia - LiMux: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/LiMux - Linux Foundation - Open Source as Europe's Strategic Advantage (2025): https://www.linuxfoundation.org/research/world-of-open-source-eu-2025 - Recognition of open source work as voluntary work in Germany: https://www.web-vision.de/en/petition-anerkennung-von-open-source-arbeit-als-ehrenamt-in-deutschland.html

Opensource could be the successstory for overarching contributions across a lot of different entities in the EU. Let me tell you this with examples: In german we have probably 40k schools and every single school struggles with the same issue: They need software for the teachers like class preparation, worksheets, software to manage the schedules but every school has to do it themselves. Now depending on the federal level, schools might have something available to them and might not. How would opensource solve this? It would solve this because instead of buying software on every level (federal, local etc.) you have one overarching EU project were everyone can invest into in an open and transparent manner. This would even allow parents and experts to support these endevours. You probably also need software for building streets, managing a city and plenty of others. If you on any level, get budget, and you could invest into the core open source strategy of germany or the eu, we could build up something owned by all of us and freely available. The investment into opensource is very similiar to investment into renewable energy: You invest and you get the full control over it instead of being dependend on one company forever. I don't think anyone needs Microsoft Words millions of features but imagine how much software you can build with the maintenance costs to Microsoft alone. What does the EU need to do to make this a success? It needs to generate the Open Source EU Gov org. Very similiar to something like the Eclipse Foundation. Providing basic infrastructure like Githosting, Basic Governance, Webhosting and Community support (like providing an Open Source EU Matrix server). This can be extend by so much like a small platform for freelancers from the EU, a process of certification for single contributors or companies from the EU to keep it in the EU. Guidance and Governance and aligned default technology stack to make all of it saver, better and with better quality. Lighthouse projects like Catena-X could then run under this program. Software like Matrix (opensource, french, end to end encryption communication) could benefit from this by having more funds. Big projects like pushing an EU wide cloud software stack could make us less dependend from the USA. Open Source doesn't mean free though that has to be understood but it allows for transparency which motivates more people to trust it especially if you have to work across borders (countries, states, federal) and it makes it a lot easier to be used. Known validated opensource software with security updates should be allowed to be used by any gov entity out of the box. Basically a greenlist of software you are allowed to run without complicated approval processes. It would also fit very well of what the EU represents.

Linux and other open-source software should be able to provide for all of the EU's software needs, and what little truly doesn't exist can be adapted from existing open-source software, especially if the EU as a whole or individual member states are willing to fund development of features and software they need. It's mostly the transition away from American mainstream software that will likely be somewhat painful. Even if the alternatives are good and do everything that's needed, the transition will require conscious effort to pull the EU away from the inertia that is present today. Office, Exchange, Azure, AWS, Windows, et cetera, are all very obvious and simple choices, and while there are alternatives, you have to go looking for them. If the EU can settle on a few baseline replacements for these, such that those can then become as or more obvious than the American standards we have today, and maybe fund development of whatever features are missing in the alternatives if needed, I'd imagine we'd be golden.

ad 1.i: A major barrier for adoption is the lack of access to mobile platforms (on Apple because the DMA ruling had loopholes they exploit to frustrate the ruling's intention; upcoming on Google because they see Apple get away with it). Customer projects have shown that beyond successful proof-of-concept projects that showed the FLOSS ecosystem's capabilities (in creating reliable local-first solutions inexpensively by building on existing blocks), adoption into production is hindered by platforms' tools being forced by platform operators. (src: customer project debriefs) ad 2: Working on FLOSS allows developers to collaborate between service providers and thus produce more real-world value from the same working hours (src: own experience). In addition, it fosters SMEs: It enables them offer services because customers can trust that even if the SME becomes unavailable, there are others whom they can contract (src: customer statements). ad 3: Continue and expand NGI initiative and/or its successors; include maintenance and not just innovation. Mandate FLOSS publication in public contracting ("public money, public code"; https://publiccode.eu/ ). ad 4: Four fields: - Collaborate with EFF to replicate the LetsEncrypt setup domestically, or incentivize certificate providers to offer public ACME interfaces equivalent to LetsEncrypt. - Digital payment. The Digital Euro initiative solves real-world issues, but runs the risk of requiring non-FLOSS components if unchecked, and thus hinders fully-FLOSS business deployments. The NGI Taler initiative already provides good templates. - Browser technology. The EU has already once helped keep the web a diverse space, it can do this again, and needs to. Relying on Google's Blink engine source code being open is insufficient, as it exerts control over the technology when unchecked. Collaborating with Mozilla to establish domestic expertise through European funding is a viable option. - (also applies to 5): Promote domestic identity management. Passwordless logins through identity providers are technically beneficial compared to passwords, but practical options are often "Sign in with Apple", "with Google" and "using GitHub". The eIDAS framework is a start, but is unsuitable for the bulk of accounts that are not real-name for privacy concerns. Research into how European identity providers can hit a balance between trustworthiness to relying parties while not being linked to government issued identities.

1) Funding is hard. EU-based open source projects regularly appear underfunded, so many projects have to turn into business first, open source second, just to stay alive. This often times leads to a focus on features that provide very little actual value, but create paths for monetization. Murena / e/OS/ is a great example of this, where a promising idea (a more privacy-friendly Android variant) is now mostly stuck, because they need to stay viable as a for-profit company, rather than continuing to innovate their core product. 2) I'm using CAD software on a regular basis, occasionally in a commercial context. There are a few CAD software tools that don't cost money, but require constant connection to US-based licensing servers. Due to proprietary file formats, I'd be in constant danger of losing my entire library of designs, should the company behind the tool decide to disable free licenses, discontinue their product, etc. This danger is a cost I can't accept, so even functionally inferior, but open source alternatives are the only real option for me. 3) We need fostering of open standards, ideally created in dialogue with experts in the open source space, not just private companies that are trying to extract as much money as possible from the EU. 4) The two greatest areas by far are browsers and mobile operating systems. These are two pieces of software that exert direct control over the digital life of EU citizens. And both of them are stuck in a quasi-monopoly state controlled by Google/Alphabet. Even though Android (Google's mobile OS) is technically open source, device owners are regularly prevented from installing a modified OS on their own devices, thereby effectively nullifying the open source aspect. 5) Literally everywhere. The vast majority of our citizens, including the uppermost ranks of government and economy, are constantly walking around with devices that monitor their every step and can be turned into wiretaps at the drop of a hat, both with the will of Google/Alphabet or against it, following something like a National Security Letter. If you must choose a single sentence to remember from all of this, let it be this one: We NEED a European mobile OS, or we'll have a Europe controlled by Google, not Europeans.

I have 30 years of experience with FLOSS (Free, Libre, Open Source Software) 1. Strengths: - Strong talent and academia - Multi-language operating environment - Interoperability experience - Privacy focus - Public sector market that can demand FLOSS Weaknesses: - Fragmentation - Procurement - Maintenance 2. - Sovereignty - Auditing - No dependence on vendor - Focus on added value instead of reinventing the wheel 3. - Public money should result in public code (FLOSS) - Require open standards and interfaces - Require data portability - Anti-lock-in measures - EU model for FLOSS-friendly procurement - Fund work (NLnet NGI, Sovereign tech fund, procure FLOSS solutions), maintenance and dependencies - Provide mirrors and alternatives to key dependencies (code forge, package registries, vulnerability tracking) - Have national CERT teams engage with FLOSS projects on vulnerabilities 4. - Everything, from start to finish, required for essentials in order to improve resilience - Identity & trust - Security - Federated cloud (like Matrix/Element, email) 5. - Healthcare - Public Services - Government - Infrastructure - Education - Research - Operating systems - Mobile operating systems - Cloud services. Every cloud service procurement that isn't won by an european company with european tech stack needs to be evaluated to identify gaps that need to be filled. And then those gaps must be filled.

From my experience in academia, public sector and IT services, I see tenders with the foregone conclusion of buying Microsoft products as the biggest problem. If this practice cannot be prevented directly through legal, executive or legislative action, I do propose adding the following requirement to all public sector tenders within the EU: Either a tender requires all software offered to be open source. Or, if this is not feasible, the tender must include an item over at least 30% of the total amount that furthers the development and maintenance of open source software in the field of this tender. So e.g. if the tender intends to find the cheapest reseller of Microsoft Windows, a 30% subitem would need to be included that finances improving desktop Linux software in such a way that it might one day a viable alternative in a similar tender. This suggestion has precedents: Comparable provisions exist in member states requiring a percentage of public building expenses to go towards art. Similarly, environmental impact of public and private building projects needs to be compensated by improving habitats elsewhere. The advantages of this suggestion are numerous: Public institutions can, through this tender process, come into contact with companies, projects or individuals developing and maintaining open source projects that might fulfill their needs, or at least can be extended that they could do so in the future. Funding such a requirement would not require a large amount if EU funds since expenses would be paid by the institutions issuing the tender. This funding would also automatically be proportional to the spending on proprietary foreign software, thus compensating for increases or decreases. And since the 30% open source subitem is part of a tender, not a subsidy, a local European open source economy can be grown, steadily and through competitive market mechanisms.
Migrating to Open Source is essential to avoid US Big Tech, promote security, and to minimize costs for software licenses.

After the recent development with the US it is imperative that the EU detaches itself from the American ecosystem of technologies as much as possible. The damage of the propaganda machine that are American social networks and technologies cannot be underestimated. They are actively using it to undermine and to destroy the EU from within. The EU should and must implement its own ecosystem; regulated, democratic, and EU-only.

1) Sterktes/zwaktes EU open-source sector + barrières Open source is voor de EU een strategisch middel om transparantie, auditbaarheid en gezamenlijke kennisopbouw te versterken. Door te kunnen inspecteren én bijdragen, groeit Europese technische expertise structureel, wat direct economisch voordeel oplevert. Tegelijk is in vrijwel alle sectoren (overheid, energie, zorg, telecom, finance, industrie) zichtbaar dat kosten en afhankelijkheid toenemen door concentratie rond een beperkt aantal niet-EU leveranciers. Incidenten en uitval bij dominante platformen en leveranciers (bijv. werkplek-/remote-access stacks en grote internet/CDN-dienstverleners) hebben laten zien hoe snel verstoringen sector-overstijgend kunnen doorwerken, waaronder in de telecommunicatiesector. De grootste barrières die ik zie: aanbestedingen die feitelijk lock-in versterken (functioneel of contractueel), netwerkeffecten/monopolieposities die overstappen duur maken, te weinig structurele investering in onderhoud, security en professionalisering van open-source alternatieven, gebrek aan Europese default basisvoorzieningen (hosting, identity, collaboration, CI/CD, registries) met passende governance. 2) Meerwaarde voor publiek en privaat Open source levert de EU: Transparantie en controle: betere auditbaarheid en sneller herstel/mitigatie bij kwetsbaarheden. Expertisegroei door bijdragen: organisaties bouwen interne capaciteit op in plaats van uitsluitend consument te zijn van gesloten technologie. Kostenbeheersing en minder verspilling: hergebruik en gezamenlijke verbetering voorkomt dubbel werk en kennisverlies. Strategische autonomie: minder afhankelijkheid van niet-EU diensten verhoogt stabiliteit en veiligheid op de lange termijn. 3) Welke EU-maatregelen zijn nodig? De EU kan afhankelijkheid niet in één dag afbouwen, maar kan wél een realistische route uitstippelen om die afhankelijkheid op termijn sterk te verminderen: Procurement: open by default where possible Eis open standaarden, interoperabiliteit, dataportabiliteit en exit-plannen. Voorkom contractvormen die lock-in normaliseren. Structurele investering in Europese open-source capaciteit Niet alleen innovatieprojecten, maar vooral maintenance, security-audits, SBOM/secure-by-design, release engineering en lange-termijn support. Europese digitale basisinfrastructuur versterken Stimuleren van EU-gebaseerde/Europees bestuurde alternatieven voor cruciale bouwstenen (cloud stack componenten, identity, collaboration, CI/CD, repositories, registries). Beleid dat monopolievorming en gedwongen afhankelijkheid afremt Waar marktdominantie overstappen praktisch onmogelijk maakt, zijn pro-competitieve maatregelen nodig zodat open oplossingen een eerlijke kans krijgen. 4) Prioritaire technologiegebieden Cloud-infrastructuur en platformdiensten Cybersecurity en supply-chain security Identity & access management Internet-infrastructuur (CDN/DNS/edge) en telecom-kritische ketens Werkplek/endpoint-ecosystemen en collaboration tooling 5) Sectoren met grootste impact In alle genoemde sectoren geldt: afhankelijkheid van een klein aantal dominante leveranciers vergroot zowel continuïteitsrisico als strategisch risico. Open source en open standaarden zijn essentieel voor overheid, energie, zorg, telecom, finance en industrie om weerbaar en concurrerend te blijven. Tot slot: Een aanzienlijk deel van de Europese digitale uitgaven stroomt vandaag naar niet-EU big tech (o.a. grote cloud- en platformproviders). Door doelgericht te investeren in open source en open standaarden kan de EU die geldstroom geleidelijk ombuigen naar Europese kennis, Europese diensten en Europese innovatie, met minder lock-in en meer stabiliteit en veiligheid.

feedback:
To remain competitive in the global technology landscape, the European Union must address a structural issue: talent and good ideas are widely available, but the support, continuity and conditions needed to turn them into solutions adopted at scale are often missing. Many promising projects do not fail due to lack of vision or quality, but because of insufficient resources, visibility, infrastructure and long-term support. The EU should therefore create a structured initiative to support the development, adoption and growth of European software, inspired by models such as the Cloud Native Computing Foundation (CNCF) or, on a smaller scale, initiatives like GNOME Circle. These should not be limited to one-off financial contributions, but consist of projects that the European Union actively adopts and supports over time. The goal should not only be funding, but the creation of an ecosystem where developers, companies, public administrations and end users can collaborate and converge on shared solutions. Joining a European circle or incubator should provide access to technical and architectural support, open-source governance frameworks, institutional visibility, promotion of adoption across public administrations and businesses, and long-term accompaniment. For many projects, being incubated within a recognised European framework could represent a decisive boost. This approach could also be applied to sectors currently dominated by large global platforms. Tourism and booking platforms, for example, often have a significant negative impact on European cities, as seen with services such as Airbnb. A European alternative could better respect local communities, reduce excessive fees and avoid forcing every operator to independently develop complex technological solutions. Existing local initiatives already demonstrate that more balanced models are possible. Alongside the software ecosystem, physical innovation spaces are equally important. Models such as the NOI Techpark in South Tyrol show how research, industry and technological development can coexist in shared environments. Universities, research centres and public infrastructures across Europe could become digital innovation campuses, providing connectivity, computing capacity and basic services to promising projects that cannot afford the high costs of commercial cloud platforms. Having an idea should not require taking unsustainable financial risks at the earliest stages. The European Union should also identify a set of key digital services where dependence on non-EU providers is currently very high. A clear example is Google Workspace, covering email, calendars, collaboration tools and cloud storage, with very few credible alternatives. Functional replacements are not enough: European platforms must be usable, reliable and attractive. Without a compelling user experience, adoption will remain limited. In this context, a European digital identity system interoperable with existing national digital identities could play a central role. Such an identity could become the entry point to a modular ecosystem of services, allowing users to compose their own workspace by selecting different providers for email, storage, calendars or collaboration, much like an operating system. Multiple workspace providers could exist, focusing mainly on integration and user experience rather than ownership of data. Projects such as SOLID could represent a useful starting point for this approach. I envision the European Union as a platform similar to LEGO, where each incubated project is a smart brick: interoperable, reusable and able to grow without constantly reinventing the entire system. A modular ecosystem of this kind would reduce fragmentation and accelerate innovation. Many of todays global technology leaders emerged from academic or public environments, leveraging shared infrastructure before becoming mature compani

column32: As an academic, it seems to me that the support mechanisms for initiatives in the field of free or open-source software are not sufficient and that this creates difficulties in bringing about innovative and promising projects. For example, in my University of Technology, we are developing two open-source software packages. The first is a software to help with problem solving and feedback. This software is used by several companies (ETI-type), particularly in the aeronautics sector. It therefore corresponds to a real need and could be disseminated on a larger scale if we had the means to do so, which is not the case today. The second is software resulting from a pedagogical innovation that consists of developing scenarios in which students play the role of characters in an adventure punctuated by puzzles that need to be resolved in order to progress. We have developed a collaborative platform to easily create, play and share such scenarios. But here too, we are struggling to find funding to accompany and promote this initiative. I therefore suggest that calls for projects be put in place very quickly to enable the emergence and consolidation of initiatives in the field of open source software (at all stages of maturity). Finally, a more personal reflection: as a daily user of open source software, I believe that the European Commission should provide more resources for open source environments, which often run after relatively low funding despite being very useful. The laudable political ambition to develop open-source software must be accompanied by means to make it a reality.

feedback: Even as a non-expert, its clear to me that the EU is vulnerable due to its dependence on US technologies and services. We need a different approach, and the EU has a real opportunity to lead the shift towards open-source software. Over the past few years, open-source solutions have proven to be reliable, secure (often more so than proprietary alternatives), transparent, andcruciallyfinally accessible not just to tech-savvy users but to everyone. A large-scale communication campaign is also essential to help EU citizens understand the importance of adopting EU-made FOSS to safeguard their digital freedom. Some countries have already begun transitioning their systems to open-source solutions. The education sector, in particular, needs urgent and radical change. Our children are currently using mediocre, distracting, and often misleading software and operating systems from US companiessolutions that, aside from their many drawbacks, come at an exorbitant cost. Linux could serve as a viable replacement, breathing new life into old laptops that could be donated to schools. Finally, a decentralised approach must be the foundation of our digital systems. The EU, inherently decentralised, should embrace this principle in its technological infrastructure, creating a natural alignment that strengthens strategic coherence, reinforces core values like transparency and resilience, and, above all, restores public trust in technology.

First of all, thank you for thinking about European pen Source ecosystem and for wanting to help that ecosystem. Among other things, whatever "US based" we're currently "locked into", contains under to heeod lots of Open Source component. And many of those are developed by people in Europe. (Which is noted in the your document.) Hence getting out of (not just) US vendor-lock is quite possible. Few remarks regarding "Towards European open digital ecosystems" initiative: 1) Open Source developers themselves won't do "marketing" and "business", since the code it "development". This is IMHO the main barrier. Hence the need for supporting them on time+material basis. They'll do same work as now for free, but with support they can do more of it and better, without the need to twelve into stuff they are not expert in or do not like. 2) Governments supporting directly developers would be thus hard, hence the need for some intermediaries: tech funds, non-profits and also actual businesses. They can do also "marketing" and "business". (As mentioned by for example Bert Hubert, companies sell mostly guarantees/insurance, when it comes so something built on top of Open Source and that's OK, that is "added value" complementing the Open Source software from developers.) All of those can get some support but in a way to make sure that they pass relevant portion of the funds to actual Open Source developers. 3) To avoid changing US-based vendor-lock for some EU based vendor-lock, governments needs to promote truly open standards. Typically (but not only) getting rid of "proprietary office formats" in government-citizen interaction. Plus, Open Source works best with open standards (but beware: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reasonable_and_non-discriminatory_licensing#Excluding_costless_distribution_schemes ). 4) Enforcement: Troubles with GDPR & co .already demonstrated, that we can have very nice and important regulations, but if our own institutions not only do not enforce them, but break them, it is causing more damage than good. Meaning, talk is cheap and if, for example, EU Commission still relies heavily on Office365 with no reasonable plan to abandon it soon, then good luck with all the strategies and initiatives, nobody will take them seriously. Meaning: Make sure whatever will EU ecosystem come up with, some EU gov. organizations will be buying and using it as early adopters, thus driving adoption and also making sure it works. 5) Transition will hurt. Current vendor-lock work precisely because easy switching (from say US to EU solution) is NOT possible. (And current suppliers did and are still doing a lot to make sure it stays that way. Typically by lobbying, buy-outs of competition and abuse of monopoly or dominant position.) The Commission, and we all, need to count with that. But without transition, we are and will be exploited and extorted. TL;DR: EU can do some funding/support via tech funds, NGO and companies. And EU (and government of EU countries) needs to also drive adoption by buying and using those existing and new Open Source-based solutions.

We are a hosting, datacenter and IT solutions provider, based in Germany. We're using a LOT of open source software; our security -- and that of our customers! -- depends on that software being maintained and enhanced in a timely, reliable and sustainable manner. While we do fund some projects that are particular relevant to our core business directly, we expect the EU to coordinate and pool efforts to finance, sustain, and grow the free software ecosystem on which much of our collective infrastructure depends. This includes documentation, security audits, standards compliance, certifications, and related tasks which historically tended to be neglected, esp. when nobody is paying for the result. In particular, we urge the EU to ensure that the standards and specifications which interoperable software must adhere to are available free of charge. Requirements to pay membership fees or to buy documentation, at price levels that are prohibitive for part-time or hobbyist developers, are detrimental to the open source ecosystem.
Technology areas regarding free software should be prioritized, strong copyleft to be exact. Open source is a too loose and vague term to be used by the EU. Instead of open source, say free software.

L'Open Source et le principal levier de la souveraineté numérique en Europe. Partons déjà d'un constat : L'Europe est numériquement très vulnérable. Elle fait face à une dépendance systémique envers des fournisseurs technologiques extra-européens, principalement américains. Cette hégémonie crée un "mille-feuille technologique" où chaque couche (matérielle ou logicielle) comporte des racines propriétaires souvent impossibles à tracer intégralement. Cette situation expose le continent à trois risques majeurs : - Le Blackout Numérique : L'arrêt brutal du support (comme Microsoft ou Oracle en Russie en 2022) montre qu'un fournisseur peut paralyser des administrations entières pour des raisons géopolitiques. En Allemagne, 96 % des agences fédérales dépendent encore de Windows et Office. - L'enfermement propriétaire (Vendor Lock-in) : Les clients captifs subissent des hausses de prix unilatérales et perdent leur maîtrise technologique. - Un déficit stratégique : Si 90 % des organisations tirent de la valeur du libre, seules 34 % disposent d'une stratégie formelle et l'engagement des dirigeants reste faible (62 % contre 86 % pour les employés). Les logiciels libres offrent la transparence et le contrôle nécessaires pour reprendre en main les piles technologiques européennes. Des initiatives existent déjà en Europe : - L'initiative "EU OS" propose un concept d'OS libre basé sur Linux Fedora et destiné au secteur public qui privilégie une architecture modulaire permettant d'ajouter des couches spécifiques selon les besoins nationaux ou régionaux tout en restant performant sur des équipements anciens. - OS Smartphone : Face au duopole Android/iOS, des alternatives comme GrapheneOS, LineageOS ou postmarketOS émergent. Le projet Librephone de la FSF vise à créer un OS 100 % libre, comblant l'espace entre Android et la vraie liberté. Problème, ces OS ne sont compatibles qu'avec un très petit nombre de smartphones. - Virtualisation : Suite au rachat de VMware, les entreprises se tournent vers des solutions comme Proxmox VE ou XCP-NG. Ces alternatives sont souvent 2 à 3 fois moins chères et s'intègrent parfaitement aux technologies modernes comme Kubernetes. Voici maintenant mes propositions concrètes pour contribuer à développer une souveraineté numérique européenne basée sur l'Open Source : - Création d'un OS Desktop Européen : Il est impératif de transformer le concept "EU OS" en un projet institutionnel officiel. Ce système doit devenir le standard par défaut des administrations européennes pour mutualiser les coûts de maintenance et garantir une base souveraine. Par effet d'entrainement, il pourra toucher l'ensemble des citoyens européens. - Levier des marchés publics et pilotes (Drivers) : L'accès aux marchés publics doit être conditionné à l'obligation pour les fabricants de fournir des drivers open source aussi fonctionnels que les versions propriétaires. C'est la condition sine qua non pour permettre le développement d'un OS européen souverain pour smartphone, aujourd'hui entravé par le verrouillage matériel. - Inciter règlementairement et financièrement la Tech européenne à contribuer activement : Les entreprises européennes doivent cesser d'être de simples consommatrices. Elles doivent généraliser les bureaux de l'open source (OSPO) et financer des mainteneurs à temps plein (seulement 28 % le font actuellement). - L'Europe doit se doter d'outils de pilotage et de financement de de ces projets numériques fondés sur l'Open Source. Ces mécanismes doivent être simples, agiles et efficaces, inspirés de la Sovereign Tech Agency allemande par exemple. L'Europe a déjà été épinglée pour la complexité excessive de certaines aides, perçues comme un "parcours d'obstacles" par leurs destinataires. Il faut donc privilégier une logique de performance plutôt q
