column91: I am a professional user of Linux and OpenSource. Indeed, the software is mature for this. The problem is adoption, training and retention of skills. This is where we fish: it is not enough to make it available for walking. There is a need for documentation and training support. We can find help easily under Windows, but nothing under Linux and we have to deal with it alone. Technological updates are very difficult because we cannot find the skills. Both current and future technology must be managed. This is where we need to catch up: OpenSource is no less expensive than the owner. This saves on licences, so you have to pay for training skills.

feedback: The initiative rightly frames open digital ecosystems as a pillar for EU tech sovereignty and resilience, and it explicitly calls for foundations that are open, interoperable and verifiable. However, the current outline remains largely strategic and does not yet specify the interoperability deliverables needed to make interoperability-by-design operational. I recommend that the Communication commits to a small, concrete set of EU-level deliverables that make interoperability testable, repeatable and scalable: Open standards and implementation profiles Define and maintain API and data profiles (implementation guidance on top of open standards) for priority capabilities and use cases. This reduces divergent interpretations and ensures consistent, reusable interfaces. Conformance testing Publish conformance test suites for each profile so that implementations can be validated consistently. Reference implementations (open source) and reusable patterns Provide reference implementations that demonstrate correct application of profiles, including CI/CD and automated chain testing. With testable profiles and reference implementations, open ecosystem becomes an executable roadmap that accelerates standardisation, adoption and reuse. Annex (technical evidence): I attach a short technical factsheet as practical evidence of how an open-standards-based approach can be implemented with reusable integration patterns, strong test/debug support, integrated testing and CI/CD-enabled deployment (including automated chain testing for assurance). This annex is provided as technical evidence, not as a commercial proposal.

What are the strengths and weaknesses of the EU open-source sector? - strengths: projects such as LibreOffice, KDE, Open Street Map, Nextcloud, VLC, a.s.o.. They are located within EU (they have contributions from outside of EU as well) - weaknesses: industry not using / migrate / contribute to these projects What are the main barriers that hamper adoption and maintenance of high-quality and secure open source? - hardware lock-in (no information to properly build drivers) by manufacturers -> sometimes subpar experience than other OSes (Win, MacOS) - high / additional cost of creating apps for another OS with lower market share (software makers are creating versions for Windows, possibly MacOS) What are the main barriers that hamper sustainable contributions to opensource communities? - companies not focused on this / no such culture - R&D invested in creating value on top of the OS, not the OS itself What is the added value of open source for the public and private sectors? - cost: lower CAPEX and OPEX (no licensing) - innovation: increased capacity for inovation, since you can see and learn - lock-in: higher interoperability - security: auditable OS, more eyes, more chances to fix it / improve it / share it - risk: gatekeeping the contributions - someone might atempt to contribute malware code What concrete measures and actions may be taken at EU level to support the development and growth of the EU open-source sector and contribute to the EUs technological sovereignty and cybersecurity agenda? - declare open source as EU priority - create organization which is responsible to provide / sponsor turn-key hardware/software solutions for various industrial sectors - generic, consumer, automotive, aerospace, academic, ... - fund this organization centrally, fund the open source developers in EU - fund the reasearch of a real time Linux kernel and its certification - provide financiar incentives to the companies contributing to this open source ecosistem - provide financiar incentive for creating applications for OS - use existing know how from companies which are already doing this such as Tuxedo Computers GMBH, Fairphone B.V., ... What technology areas should be prioritised and why? - automotive and transportation (speeding up time to market / quality) - academics and AI (new frontiers for new human centric products) In what sectors could an increased use of open source lead to increased competitiveness and cyber resilience? - all of them. Interoperability and common contributions is the key of a new type of economy

1. Strengths, Weaknesses, and Barriers * Strengths: the EU possesses a strong talent pool, active maintainer communities, and credible projects in cybersecurity and data infrastructure. Open source is foundational to the digital economy, offering leverage if policy aligns with demand. * Weakness (Economic Leakage): the sector suffers from a "free rider" problem. Reliance on purely permissive licenses (MIT/Apache) allows non-EU hyperscalers to productise European innovation without financial return to the creators. Licensing, market power, and capital access remain critical bottlenecks. * Barrier to Sustainability: the primary barrier is lack of revenue protection. Small EU developers cannot compete with US-based cloud providers who resell open-source code as a managed service, outspending original authors on support and bundling. * Barrier to Adoption: a major misconception is that "Open Source" equals "Free of Cost," leading to under-funded maintenance. Buyers often procure "delivery" (deployment) rather than "stewardship" (long-term maintenance/security). Without business models that incentivize *selling* software (e.g., dual-licensing), high-quality maintenance is unsustainable. 2. Added Value for Public and Private Sectors * True vs. "Paper" Sovereignty: the theoretical value of "digital sovereignty" is nullified if the software runs exclusively on non-EU proprietary cloud infrastructure. Open source improves portability and auditability, but true sovereignty requires control over the entire stack (hardware + software). * Risk & Security: while open source offers "security by transparency," public administrations face a greater risk of operational dependency. * Concrete Example: a European municipality running open-source software but relying entirely on AWS or Azure for compute and storage has not achieved sovereignty; they have merely achieved *software portability* on captured infrastructure. 3. Concrete Measures and Actions * Reform Procurement: the EU must shift from "encouraging" open source to purchasing it. Tenders should prioritize solutions where the IP and core development team reside in the EU, turning tax revenue into ecosystem investment. * Legitimize "Source Available": the Commission must formally recognize "Source Available" or "Fair-Code" licenses (e.g., BUSL) in funding/procurement. These models allow open inspection while protecting EU SMEs from predatory resale by foreign tech giants. * Capital vs. Code: shift funding from "middleware" research to CAPEX support for physical infrastructure. Subsidize the building of European data centers (power, cooling, bare metal) rather than redundant orchestration software. 4. Priority Technology Areas * Avoid Redundancy: do not duplicate mature standards (e.g., Kubernetes) unless there is a specific security gap. EU funding must target differentiated needs. * Prioritise Bare Metal (IaaS): the absolute priority is competitive, European-owned hardware infrastructure to rival AWS/GCP/Azure. * Prioritise Sovereign Compute for AI: funding "Open Weights" is insufficient if training data and compute remain proprietary. The EU must prioritize Public Compute availability (Sovereign GPU clusters) to allow EU developers to train models, not just fine-tune foreign ones. 5. Sectors for Competitiveness * Public Administration & Utilities: these sectors currently funnel massive public funds into foreign proprietary licenses and cloud fees. Migrating them to EU-developed software hosted on EU-owned bare metal would immediately improve the trade balance and cyber resilience. * Industrial Edge (IoT): as edge computing grows, the EU has a window to own the hardware/software stack before it is centralized by hyperscalers, provided the hardware ecosystem remains diverse.

Dear Politicians, it's incredibly important to make the jump to FOSS Software. For too long have we used centralized and US-based software, that cost a lot of money and we can't even tell what happens to the data that we store in them. I don't believe it makes sense to develop alternative software ourselfs, when there is already a Open-Source alternative for everything out there! The EU should contribute Code and Money to these projects and use them themselves. Also, I believe that all social media communication of public institutions should migrate to the Fediverse. It's inheritely democratic, since everyone can host a server, you have no vendor lock-in and everyone could view the contents without an account. Using platforms of trch monopolies is a terrible thing, because these platforms dictate what is allowed to be said and especially X with their far-right CEO is a terrible platform to have public institutions on Please choose free, open and democratic software

I think the uptake of open source soft- and hardware is often hampered by a mixture of issues. Until recently I worked for a large Austrian NPO/NGO. The organisation is regularly dealing with a lot of sensitive data. The whole organisations IT structure is deeply cemented in the use of propitiatory products. In several years no change towards OSS was possible. In this specific case the uptake of OSS was hampered by the believe that OSS is inferior to proprietary products, that management generally lacks digital literacy and that the IT department is generally understaffed and fixed in closed source eco-systems. In my private environment, the picture is quite similar, family and friends do not think that OSS is as good as customary closed-source software, are not digitally literate and think that because they have nothing to hide, it does not matter if their data is scraped. Thus the main barriers are a lack of digital literacy and the negative image of OSS. I think that more/mandatory use of OSS in the public and NGO/NPO sector will increase data security, increase product ownership and ensure that the basic ideas of the protection of sensitive data is up kept. While no longer payed staff, I still work as a volunteer in the same NGO/NPO in the area of disaster response. Using more OSS and especially locally hosted services will increase the resilience of the organization and the whole civil society. On a private level, I think the increase use of OSS will return data sovereignty and reduce the dependency on non-European big tech/data companies. I think the EU should increase funding in open source developments and for example make open source mandatory in Horizon and ECHO programs. Further, the use of OSS should be made mandatory in the whole public sector within the EU (the use of any propitiatory software should require a detailed argumentation and need to be approved). If the EU could replicate the effects of the REACH chemical labeling system in the IT world, I think OSS could have a good chance to become the standard approach.

# In response to Question 1 (barriers to adoption and contribution): ## Using Open Source A major practical barrier: we cannot buy infrastructure "just in case", so there is nowhere to run FOSS without lengthy procurement. A lot of open source registered in government OSPOs (when they exist at all) is actually packaged in commercial products, which solves the practical problems but defeats the purpose. ## Creating Open Source In-house open source development is usually part of innovation projects, not regular production. This creates problems when scaling up: experimental projects that succeed still face all the same questions about liability, maintenance and hosting when moving to production. Research confirms this pattern: a 2025 empirical study found that 80% of public sector OSS development involves small groups using formalized processes, rather than broader collaborative models. This supports what I observe in practice: the innovation/production divide means successful experiments struggle to transition to full production environments where practical questions remain unresolved. ## Contributing to Open Source Contributing to existing projects is seen as endorsing those projects, which requires vetting. This makes routine technical contribution impractical and treats it like a political statement instead of normal collaboration. # In response to Question 3 (concrete measures): * Allow government organisations to have pre-approved capacity (servers, workflows) for trying out new FOSS, without procurement each time * Make it more normal to contribute to existing projects as standard technical work. Though I don't know exactly how to address the vetting problem - perhaps the EU could make clear that technical contribution is different than institutional endorsement?

We need our own European Open Source AI definition (China and US already have one) In Europe, everyone developing and deploying open-source generative AI systems must navigate two challenges: some of the strictest personal data protection laws (in the form of the GDPR or its derivatives in the UK and Switzerland) and unclear regulation regarding open-source AI systems (e.g., underspecified use of the term 'open-source' in the EU AI Act and the Cybersecurity Act). To make matters worse, Europeunlike the US and Chinadoes not have a definition of open-source AI that is aligned with its own laws. This confusing regulatory landscape stands in sharp contrast to the significant contributions that organizations in Europe make to the open-source AI ecosystem. A recent example of this is the Swiss AI Initiative's "Apertus" model series, which achieved an outstanding degree of openness. It is high time to simplify our regulation of open-source AI and come up with a future-proof definition that underpins existing law and propose a European Open Source AI definition that is GDPR-aligned and uniquely European. Full proposal published on the European Open Source AI Index website.

feedback: J'aimerais beaucoup qu'on sorte de notre dépendance aux logiciels américains. L'Open source est une solution qui peut être très intéressante et donner un élan positif à ce chantier. Nous avons des ressources et des entreprises européennes compétentes. Il ne manque que le courage politique. La première chose à faire serait peut être d'arrêter de communiquer sur X, dont il est plus qu'évident qu'un des objectifs est de déstabiliser les démocraties européennes. On ne gagnera jamais rien à être sur ces plateformes.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: I would very much like us to move away from our dependence on US software. The Open Source is a solution that can be very interesting and give a positive boost to this work. We have competent European resources and businesses. Only political courage is missing. The first thing to do could be to stop communicating about X, of which it is more than obvious that one of the objectives is to destabilise European democracies. We will never win anything from being on these platforms.

feedback: Open Source ist ein wichtiger Weg, um aus der Abhängigkeit der vor allem US-amerikanischen Monopolisten herauszukommen. Vor allem Microsoft. In einer Zeit, in der KI in alle Produkte Einzug hält und der Nutzer damit zur "Datenquelle" wird und in der eine Regierung (unter Trump) anordnen kann, dass unliebsamen Personen der Zugang zu über Microsoft gehosteten E-Mails und anderen Funktionen entzogen wird, ist genau das bitter nötig. Die Abkehr von diesen Monopolisten muss in einer digitalen Souveränität jedes Einzelnen münden. Das gleiche gilt für die immer unvermeidbaren Cloud-Speicherung und -Anwendungen. Nehmen wir wieder Microsoft als Beispiel. Die Nutzung der Produkte von Microsoft ohne deren Cloud ist heute quasi unmöglich. Und schon wieder verliert man damit die Hoheit über die eigenen Daten. Entsprechende Gesetze in den USA verschaffen US-Behörden Zugang zu diesen Daten, selbst dann, wenn diese in einer Microsoft-Cloud liegen, die in Europa gehostet wird. Erst Recht im Bereich der rapide wachsenden KI-Branche und deren Anwendungen muss eine stringente Regulierung und Verpflichtung auf das Wohl der Menschen erfolgen. Denn bislang sind diese Systeme vor allem auf die Maximierung von Umsatz und Profit ihrer Betreiber ausgelegt.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: Open source is an important way to break the dependence of the monopolies, especially the US monopolies. In particular Microsoft. At a time when AI is embedding in all products, making the user a ‘data source’, and when a government (under Trump) can order unpopular people to be deprived of access to emails and other functionalities hosted via Microsoft, this is all the more necessary. Moving away from these monopolists must result in digital sovereignty for every individual. The same applies to cloud storage and applications, which are always unavoidable. Let’s take Microsoft as an example. Using Microsoft’s products without its cloud is now almost impossible. And once again, this means losing sovereignty over one’s own data. US law gives US authorities access to this data, even if it is located in a Microsoft cloud hosted in Europe. Even more so in the field of the rapidly growing AI industry and its applications, strict regulation and an obligation to protect people’s well-being must be put in place. To date, these systems have been designed primarily to maximise the turnover and profit of their operators.

feedback: La communauté du logiciel libre a prouvé à maintes reprises que l'open-source était la clé de la souveraineté et de la sécurité. Souveraineté parce que nous ne pouvons pas nous appuyer sur une entreprise pour gérer nos données : cela nous rend dépendant de l'état de santé de ladite entreprise ainsi que de l'évolution des juridictions dont elle dépend. De plus, l'entreprise peut appliquer toute modification souhaitée à l'échéance du contrat qui la lie à son client. L'open-source étant un gage d'interopérabilité, il permet de changer de prestataire lorsque nécessaire. Voire de se passer de prestataire puisque n'importe quelle entité peut se donner les moyens d'héberger elle-même ses propres services (pour son compte, pour le compte de ses usagers ou pour un usage plus largement défini). Sécurité parce que des programmes dont la robustesse est mise à l'épreuve à chaque instant a toutes les chances d'être attestée ou renforcée après chaque attaque. Les entreprises et les organismes publics gagneraient à investir dans des tests de robustesse et de développement de solutions de sécurité bénéfiques pour tous, qu'en des solutions qui tentent de réparer les fuites non encore révélées par une entreprise qui se garde bien de communiquer sur les failles du système qu'il vend. L'Europe n'a pas besoin d'un géant comme Google ou Microsoft qui grignote les libertés individuelles. L'Europe a besoin des meilleurs développeurs et des meilleurs hackers pour donner à l'humanité toute entière des solutions qui fassent honneur à des principes universels tels que l'entraide, le partage, l'égalité, la vie privée et l'accès non discriminant à la culture. C'est une bataille politique et même idéologique, face à des pays comme les États Unis qui privatisent et exploitent tout ce qui peut rapporter de l'argent, ou la Chine qui opère un usage trompeur de ses services dans le but de priver certains humains de leurs droits élémentaires. L'Europe doit représenter une autre voie, un autre rêve, comme elle l'a fait en créant le web, Linux, Nextcloud, Mastodon et bien d'autres. Et pour cela, elle doit être pionnière et exemplaire. Pionnière en prouvant qu'il est possible de travailler uniquement avec de l'open-source, et exemplaire en prouvant qu'il est possible de rémunérer correctement les développeurs qui s'impliquent dans cette technologie, ainsi que les techniciens et les formateurs qui assurent son déploiement. L'Europe est la seule entité politique au monde à pouvoir tenir ce rôle et à fédérer autour d'un idéal de liberté. Et l'Europe ne peut pas rivaliser sur les autres terrains où elle n'a jamais voulu se frotter à des entreprises trop puissantes pour être domptées. L'Europe, ou plus précisément l'Union Européenne doit prendre sa place de rempart contre tous les comportements belliqueux. C'est pour cela qu'elle a été créée.

feedback: 1. Strengths, weaknesses, and barriers The foundation of the EU open-source sector is strong. Europe benefits from a well-educated population, strong technical universities, and long-standing community traditions that encourage collaboration and contribution to open-source projects. Compared to my own experience studying in the United States, where high education costs forced me to priorities paid work over open-source contribution, Europes education systems appear to better enable students and early-career technologists to participate in open source. This creates a positive feedback loop: an educated society contributes to shared digital infrastructure, which in turn generates long-term societal and economic return on investment. The main barriers are not technical but structural: procurement practices that favor proprietary vendors, under investment in long-term maintenance, and limited pathways for community projects to scale sustainably without becoming dependent on short-term funding cycles. 2. Added value of open source for public and private sectors Reducing vendor lock-in is one of the most critical benefits of open source. Open-source solutions give public and private organizations greater control over their digital infrastructure, improve transparency and security, and reduce long-term costs. The greatest value comes when policymakers trust developers and technologists to build the best solutions, rather than optimizing for short-term commercial interests. Supporting strong, tech-driven ideas ultimately benefits society, innovation, and economic resilience. 3. Concrete EU-level measures EU-level actions should focus on identifying and strengthening the open-source economy itself. A technologist-led focus group could help identify areas where increased investment would generate the highest collective benefit. However, such structures must be designed carefully to avoid becoming mechanisms for wealth transfer from taxpayers to specific companies or projects. Decision-making should remain technology-driven and evidence-based, not politically driven, to reduce the risk of misallocation of funds or corruption. Sustainable investment should priorities shared infrastructure, maintenance, and long-term viability. 4. Priority technology areas Artificial intelligence and open hardware should be prioritized. Open-source AI frameworks and open hardware platforms can significantly reduce dependency on proprietary ecosystems, lower barriers to innovation, and it can reduce electronic waste by extending hardware lifecycles. These areas offer strong opportunities to build collective, reusable solutions that benefit the entire EU digital ecosystem rather than isolated actors. 5. Sectors where open source increases competitiveness and resilience All sectors listed like public administration, industry, healthcare, education, and SMEs stand to benefit from increased use of open source. Widespread adoption reduces duplication, lowers taxpayer spending through shared solutions, and improves cyber resilience by increasing transparency and auditability. A strong open-source ecosystem enables mutual benefit across sectors while strengthening Europes technological sovereignty. Conclusion Establishing and recognizing the open-source economy as a strategic asset will help direct investment toward solutions that deliver long-term societal value. Education, open collaboration, and trust in technologists are essential to sustaining this ecosystem and ensuring a strong return on investment for European society as a whole.

Address the Indoctrination occurring in Education. From the earliest stages of schooling, children are subtly indoctrinated into proprietary digital ecosystems. My own son navigated primary school immersed in Google Cloud Services, only to switch to Microsoft in higher education. The result? A generation that views these giants as the defaults, unaware of the broader landscape of alternatives. This pattern is widespread across Europe, perpetuating a digital divide where innovation is funneled through U.S.-based corporations rather than homegrown or open-source options. Non-sovereign/proprietary US solutions should be exceptions, not the default go-to option, it is time to prioritize inclusive, high-performing ecosystems that include open-source alternatives. (this goes for government bodies too by the way!) Let's make the next generation truly tech-savvy and tech-independent! It may be too late for the current one, but future generations will reap the rewards of a diverse, sovereign digital toolkit.

### Towards European open digital ecosystems I submit this contribution from the perspective of an independent expert focusing on governance, deployment and operational integration of digital and AI-based systems. My input does not advocate for specific technologies or business models. Instead, it addresses how open digital ecosystems can be designed in a way that is sustainable, trustworthy and deployable at scale across diverse public and private contexts. A key observation from deployment practice is that *openness alone is not sufficient*. While open source and open standards play an essential role in reducing lock-in and increasing transparency, openness without appropriate governance often leads to fragmentation, unclear accountability and operational risk. This challenge becomes particularly visible in complex ecosystems where AI systems are integrated, adapted and reused across organisational and sectoral boundaries. In such environments, the main difficulties do not arise from the availability of code or interfaces, but from the absence of a clear governance layer. Questions around responsibility allocation, lifecycle management, and change control frequently remain unresolved. As a result, actors may become reluctant to adopt or reuse open components, not because they oppose openness in principle, but because legal and operational uncertainty increases deployment risk. From this perspective, governance should not be understood as a restrictive element, but as an enabling condition for open digital ecosystems. Predictability, accountability and clarity of roles are prerequisites for trust. Without them, open systems risk becoming effectively closed in practice, as organisations resort to proprietary solutions to manage risk. A further challenge relates to the dynamic nature of digital and AI-based systems. In open ecosystems, systems are rarely static. Configuration changes, updates, retraining, contextual reuse and functional extensions are common and often necessary. These changes should not automatically be treated as exceptional events. Instead, governance frameworks should be designed to accommodate continuous evolution while providing clear criteria for when responsibilities, safeguards or oversight mechanisms need to be reassessed. This is closely linked to the notion of lifecycle governance. Traditional approaches that focus primarily on initial compliance or market entry are insufficient in environments where systems evolve after deployment. Open digital ecosystems therefore require governance mechanisms that operate throughout the lifecycle of a system, including post-deployment monitoring, documented change management and proportional reassessment of risks. Interoperability is another core objective of open digital ecosystems. However, experience shows that technical interoperability alone does not guarantee effective integration. Legal, organisational and institutional interoperability are equally important. Without clarity on roles, obligations and escalation pathways, interoperability remains superficial and fragile. This is particularly relevant in cross-border and multi-actor settings, where divergent interpretations can quickly undermine intended openness. Looking ahead, EU-level action should focus less on prescribing specific technologies and more on supporting governance-by-design approaches. This includes promoting shared frameworks for responsibility allocation, lifecycle accountability and structured flexibility. Such approaches can help ensure that openness translates into real-world deployability rather than remaining an abstract principle. The attached document provides more detailed analysis and practical considerations, structured around governance functions and lifecycle stages rather than individual technologies. It aims to complement this submission by offering concrete insights into how open digital ecosystems

feedback: As an open source maintainer of several projects, I believe strongly in the advantages that open source can bring to EU citizens, companies and the Union as a whole. During my time in the open source community I have seen people build phenomenal projects and solutions, almost all of which are released to the wider community without monetary cost. It unites people in the one thing they love to do most: building things to make the world a little nicer for everyone. The sheer creativity and willingness of people to work on open source projects cannot be overstated. Unfortunately, not everyone is able to work on these projects as much as they please. Open source project management takes a lot of time; time that most people simply do not have. The problem is, as usual, funding: providing maintainers with the financial means to work on their project part- or even fulltime will bring a massive boost to the open source community and provide benefit for us all. When talking about open-source, people often tend to jump to end-user software. However, I would like to shift your attention towards the lesser-known projects: libraries and tooling that build the foundation of practically any piece of software we use today, including proprietary ones. Many pieces of open source software exist that are directly or indirectly used by private companies in their end-user products. While this illustrates how the effects of open source can reach far beyond its direct sphere of influence, it also presents a risk in the form of security vulnerabilities or supply chain attacks. Aside from increased public spending on open source initiatives, I believe it would be good to incentivize private companies to give back to the projects they rely on, both to strengthen the community and to increase the security of not only their software, but others as well. Finally, and this one is of a more personal note, we need stronger legal protections for organizations and individuals who reverse engineer products or services to release open-source products and tooling. Currently, those who release projects that interact with proprietary products can face legal risks, even though their efforts directly contribute towards the sustainability and digital sovereignty goals of the EU. I call upon the Commission to provide for stronger legal protections for those who wish to contribute towards these goals. I hope you will consider these points. Open source is a phenomenal thing, and I believe that investing in this area could do much good to the EU as a whole.

The most action the EU can do is not only focusing on open source software, but acquiring independence from abroad technology companies. In this context, talking on operating systems for consumer devices, especially smartphones, there could be a change to retake an old operating system used by an EU company, Nokia: it is called Symbian OS, used not only from Nokia, but even by Ericsson, in the first decade of 2000's, it was an advanced piece of software, always focused to maintain low battery consumption, thus having at the same time a great behavior, like using a PC. It was a truly effort to start the smartphone era. Then it was abandoned in favor to use abroad companies operating systems. It was open source for a year, and it's repositories are publicly visible on https://github.com/symbiansource. My advice could be the EU have to do: 1) involve all the persons that have worked on this OS; 2) give an opportunity to EU people to create new European smartphone manufacturers, to make the reborn of symbian, and spread a new culture of open source software, that abroad companies wants to cancel; 3) create an EU platform to hosting the entire symbian source code, so that anyone can see it eventually, helping to improve; 4) create the dedicated courses to learn the programming language to develop the Symbian OS and the relative apps, in order to make more rich the Full stack developer professional work; 5) make more independent the EU people from abroad social network companies, staying only in Europe. I know it exists some EU options, but it is needed more efforts, from all EU people, elder and younger, obviously correctly educated by EU.

As a university we try to use open source whenever possible. It enables us to save on licensing fees, prevent vendor lock-in, collaborate, extend functionality and give back to the community. A lot of our business-critical systems (both on the infrastructure side and business-related systems) are open source based and they have served us well for the most part. But we also use a lot of SaaS and then it becomes more difficult. We would like to use more open source there as well but also exclude big tech from the infrastructure underpinning the SaaS solutions to enable our digital sovereignty. The first thing that the EU needs to fix are the tender rules. We need to be able to exclusively ask for open-source solutions and to exclude non-EU entities from the supply chain in the tender in order to exclude the big tech. Otherwise we might get open source hosted on Azure/GCK/AWS. You need to enable and maybe even stimulate the use of open source at governments and related entities using an open source first strategy. If there are no viable alternatives, then commercial solutions are fine (but preferably exclude big tech whenever possible, at least for critical systems). This would increase demand for open source / sovereign solutions that now automatically goes to big tech. They are very hard to beat currently because of lobbying power, pricing power and risk avoidance at the executive level. All systems should have open API's to be able to communicate and integrate. Interoperability, also for the big tech platforms, is key. With the PaaS components you are automatically locked to a specific vendor and the only viable exit strategy is a complete rebuild in most cases. This is where open-source solutions can help a lot. If you want to further sovereignty, we need a couple alternatives for: - Office365: obviously, the elephant in the room. We need a user-friendly open alternative that we can host ourselves. It needs to have proper online collaboration, communication and interoperability with the Microsoft ecosystem to enable the transition. Investing in something like Nextcloud and furthering adopting could help a lot. - EntraID: something like keycloak is a viable alternative but it misses the intelligence for detecting attacks that Entra does have. This is the basis for the identity infrastructure for an organisation and essential. - Endpoint management: we need an open alternative to Intune to manage our assets (Windows, Linux, Mac, Android, Ios). Open-source alternatives should have the same level of access as Intune does. - Sentinel: we need an open-source solution that provides similar functionality that integrates with all the big ecosystems out of the box. We use opensearch with a lot of customisations and it works well. But especially smaller organizations don't have the means to deploy an alternative, way too complex and expensive. - Endpoint detection & response: there are European alternatives like ESET but no viable open-source alternatives to Defender. This would enable a lot of organisations to become much less dependent on Microsoft. These systems are the basis for a lot the regular IT infrastructure and this is where open source is currently lacking massively. For a lot of other stuff there are alternatives, this is where it hurts the most. I'm posting this under a pseudonym to prevent legal consequences in future tenders. My apologies. I work at a university in the IT department. Im reachable with the provided email address and would like to participate in future discussions if needed.

I want to impress upon you, the absolute necessary of using open source software, if (not just) digital sovereignty of Europe, is what you strive for. Closed source suites, might be presented as "all you ever wanted", like Microsoft's 365 or Azure cloud, but please consider the following: Closed source companies offer you complete solutions, with lots of applications, that all integrate flawlessly (at least they say so). That might seem ideal, but it immediately brings you into a subordinate position. There is an undeniable dependency on this company, when it comes to customization, and there is literally no way to check, if they honor your requests. Especially seen the current geopolitical situation, Europe has to reconsider, what foreign nations we trust with our data. What this implies, is that we must, under any circumstances(!), take control of our own data. Even if that means, we have to sacrifice on usability. That is initially! Open source software might seem less integrated, at first sight, but also consider the Unix philosophy, that each program, should do one thing flawlessly, rather than adding complexity to a program, to do everything (hello Microsoft). Realize, that this will take a culture change. This will generate a lot of resistance among users and will cost a lot of money (initially). But also realize that the alternative (closed source) will cost even more on the long term. Probably even lives and sovereignty for all European countries. Again, please bite the bullet now. Open source is our only way to true sovereignty. It is the long and hard road, but there really is no other option. I would almost beg you to take my advice in consideration. Please contact me if you have any questions.

I believe in a stronger, more cohesive Europe. I firmly believe that we cannot create that if we are forced to use technology develeped and controlled by foreign oligarchs. We cannot be sure of the security, whether our systems are compromised, or who has access to them. I believe that locally developed, opensource solutions are the best alternative. We can create systems and crucially retain sole control over them. I would love to see the EU champion this way of thinking, and show leadership in the fast development of new tech solutions, away from digital colonialism. Opensource allows us build variations, giving us a solid foundation. We own our data. We control it. We can tailor the systems themselves for various use cases. Opensource is adaptable. I also acknowledge the greatest challenge to a campaign to create our own European tech solutions might be complacency; why spend money making a version of something that already exists. I think many people even the highest level users, are unaware of the liability that is produced by placing huge interlinked networks and their dependencies under control of companies that may not always be allied to European values. This high level risk has never been greater. A campaign to develop European tech strength needs to be twinned with an effective information campaign as to why it's necessary. In short, we stand at a point now where we could have the carpet pulled from under us. We should choose independent security before it's too late.

Depuis plusieurs années, je remplace un maximum d'applications et de logiciels par des alternatives libres et open source. J'ai commencé à réaliser que l'intérêt de l'utilisateur n'était en général pas la priorité des entreprises, mais bien un intérêt marchand pour monétiser la moindre information. Si je ne peux pas vérifier ce qu'un logiciel fait sur ma machine, je n'ai tout simplement pas envie de le faire tourner car je ne peux pas lui faire confiance. De plus, beaucoup de services commerciaux sont américains et cela fait des décennies que nous savons que l'état américain a la main mise sur les données récoltées par des entreprises américaines. Je pense que c'est une erreur stratégique pour les entreprises et les institutions européennes d'être dépendantes à un tel point d'une puissance étrangère. Il n'y a aucune souveraineté dans cela. Malheureusement, des alternatives commerciales européennes ont du mal à concurrencer les servies déjà en place pour diverses raisons (étouffement de la compétition, effet de réseau, grosse différence de moyens). Il serait sain au niveau souveraineté de décentraliset l'internet et le monde du logiciel. Cela passe par l'utilisation de logiciels qui ne sont pas clôturés, c'est-à-dire libres. Finalement, le système de logiciels fermés et propriétaires est une faille de cybersécurité. Certes, j'ai parlé des entreprises elles-mêmes malveillantes, des états qui auraient un certain contrôle, mais sans une communauté pour évaluer un code source, les failles peuvent passer inaperçue et dépendent du bon vouloir des entreprises qui les possèdent. Si ces dernières ne sont pas rigoureuses ou cherchent à minimiser les dépenses, elles ignoreront les failles qui pourront être exploitées par quiconque les découvre. Les logiciels libres sont transparents, ce qui met les hackers et la communauté sur un pied d'égalité et favorise la détection de failles.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: For several years, I have replaced as many applications and software as possible with free and open-source alternatives. I started to realise that the interest of the user is in general not the priority of companies, but rather a commercial interest to monetise any information. If I cannot check what software does on my machine, I simply do not want to rotate it because I cannot trust it. Moreover, many commercial services are American and for decades we know that the US state has control over data collected by US companies. I think it is a strategic mistake for European companies and institutions to be so dependent on a foreign power. There is no sovereignty in this. Unfortunately, European commercial alternatives find it difficult to compete with the services already in place for various reasons (stifling of competition, network effect, big difference in resources). It would be healthy at the level of decentralisation sovereignty and the internet and software world. This involves the use of software that is not closed, i.e. free. Finally, the system of closed and proprietary software is a cybersecurity loophole. Of course, I talked about malicious companies themselves, states that would have some control, but without a community to assess a source code, loopholes can go unnoticed and depend on the goodwill of the companies that own them. If the latter are not rigorous or seek to minimise expenditure, they will ignore the loopholes that can be exploited by anyone who discovers them. Open source software is transparent, which puts hackers and the community on an equal footing and promotes the detection of loopholes.

feedback: I am a long-term open source practitioner with over 15 years of experience building and operating fully open-source infrastructures. My work spans Linux systems, automation (Terraform, Ansible), containers and Kubernetes, identity & access management, private CAs, finance management (Firefly III), document management (Paperless-NGX), backup, monitoring, SIEM (Wazuh, MISP), and other community-driven software. I have built secure, privacy-preserving systems entirely independent of US hyperscalers. Open source should be treated as strategic European digital infrastructure, not just a licensing model. Currently, European public funding, research, universities, startups, and government IT disproportionately benefits non-European hyperscalers. The EU must move from passive openness to active stewardship of its digital commons, ensuring long-term sovereignty, security, and control over critical software. I strongly support creating European Cloud Modules: modular, interoperable building blocks that cover IAM, DNS, networking, Kubernetes, infrastructure, private networks, logging, SIEM, backup, and monitoring. These modules should be standards-based, provider-agnostic, and composable, allowing governments, SMEs, and citizens to assemble secure cloud environments without vendor lock-in. The goal is a click-together experience comparable to hyperscalers, built entirely on open-source and European control. A major barrier to open-source adoption is security and quality assurance. Many community projects cannot afford audits or compliance. The EU should fund continuous security audits, shared quality pipelines, and automated feedback loops, providing actionable guidance to thousands of projects. This reduces duplication, raises baseline quality, and ensures secure, trustworthy software at scale. European projects must be protected from extractive acquisitions. Publicly funded projects, research, and engineering talent should remain under European governance. Funding should include mechanisms to safeguard European control, prevent strategic exploitation, and ensure open-source projects like Postfix, Dovecot, Nextcloud, OpenDesk, Keycloak, and Authentik can scale and integrate across public and private sectors. Open source should also empower citizens directly. A European home & SME cloud stack would allow individuals and small organizations to deploy trusted infrastructures that protect privacy and sovereignty. Personal data pods, as proposed by Tim Berners-Lee, could enable selective sharing of personal data, including medical or administrative records, without centralised exploitation. Europe has the talent, software, and vision; what is missing is strategic coordination, sustainable funding, protection of the digital commons, and alternatives to hyperscaler dependency. With EU support, open-source projects can scale, interoperate, and serve governments, businesses, and citizens efficiently, securely, and in full European control. This strategy should treat open source as infrastructure, public good, and strategic asset, not just code.

I really support the idea of Europe building its own open digital ecosystem. Its super important that we reduce dependence on big non-EU tech companies and keep our data safe and under EU law. I think all European citizens data should be stored securely within the EU, so our privacy and security are guaranteed. Open source is a great way to do this because its transparent, adaptable, and helps Europe stay innovative while being independent. Overall, I just want Europe to have control over its digital future secure, open, and independent. I hope this project prioritizes safety, transparency, and European sovereignty.

As a government organisation we have run opensource for over 15 years. Most difficult part is a lot of overhead isn't needed for running open source solutions or delivering opensource solutions. The decision makers are generally out of work when free open source is being used. A directive to prohibit the use of closed source or licensed (closed/open source) software solutions by governments can make a big difference. To allow for support: that's also possible on an hourly fee. Opensource also allows for more standardization towards open apis/ open protocols / open implementations.

The main strength of the European open source sector is, I think, its extensive collaborative nature that leads to important innovations and creative thinking. The main weakness of EU open source is that it isn't talked about much, at least in my experience, compared to the closed-source programs and solutions from overseas. Another point is that most people want to stay in closed-sourced environment more known by the general public and easier to use, for example social media and operating systems. Open source for me brings significant added value in both public and private sector. Firstly, it saves costs compared to closed sourced counterparts. Secondly, there isn't any vendor lock-in, because open source protocols prioritize interoperability, so different applications can work together without problems: this in important particularly in the communication sector, where people can choose the communication app that they prefer and stay in contact with all their friends without worrying about the applications they might use. Let's not forget about decentralization, so there isn't a single person or corporation that controls the thing and that can decide to restrict or stop the service as they please. This also link to transparency, because everyone can inspect, verify and also contribute to the open source code. The first thing to do for me would be to let people know about the benefits and advantages of open source. Another interesting idea would be to provide economic incentives to open source workers, I think for example of the Germany petition to recognize pen source work as volunteering. The technology to prioritize for me is the infrastructural one. With the uncertainty of the current international political climate, we cannot risks that our most important services, even the vital ones, can stop at any moment because one entity wants it. Also relying too much on closed source critical infrastructure can lead to important incidents, we had several of these in recent years. If we prioritize this technology we can also increase cyber resilience for the reasons explained above.
Upgrade to Linux !

Let me be direct: - We need more European-hosted alternatives to USA cloud services and APIs, such as those provided by AWS. This will make the transition much smoother and easier for developers, and companies of all kinds who integrate 'the cloud' in their products, projects, and services. - To this end, many opensource projects exist that can fill this gap, from e.g MinIO which can provide AWS S3-like file APIs, to simply hosting our own Kubernetes (or derivative) stacks, feel free to ask around. - The EU and EC have the opportunity here to fund these OpenSource projects, and fund independent European parties that host these services. - I would strongly consider the possibility of a directly EU/EC-backed Cloud service to set an example and standard for the EU industries. All the necessary feedback to improve this will come directly to you as a result. - I would also advise for the European Board of Digital Services to be more involved in the areas where the actual geeks and hobbyists live, rather than just as an isolated board and within companies, as this will create an echo chamber that's hard to breach. I have for example not seen them actively participate on https://ec.social-network.europa.eu/ (which is a great and underrated and under-advertised platform), even though the fediverse/activitypub decentralized social media is a great way to get in touch with a lot of experts without the corporate control of other platforms. - I would also advise for more politicians to move to these decentralized and officially (W3Org) standardized social media platforms, rather than just the closed controlled ecosystems of american big tech providers. - This does not have to be mutually exclusive either if you want reach; There are plenty ways to write a message and then broadcast it across multiple such platforms. Staying on these limited platforms limits the reach of our own politicians, and increases the control over the USA and big tech over our politicians, which I think is an important and undervalued consideration for sovereignty. - Consider setting up a system where industry experts can be a regular part of considerations put up by the European Board of Digital Services without them having to leave the companies they work at. This will also help breach the echo chamber and pull in knowledge from across the various industry subsections that exist out there. - As someone who is very passionate about the european opensource and technology scene, I find it very hard to truly voice my thoughts, concerns, and other such things. The EU Board of Digital Services is a great start of a concept, but they need to work on being more accessible for people to actually voice their opinions, without having to travel abroad to attend to meetings or necessarily becoming part of a working group. - This current open feedback initiative is *great*, we need more of these, and perhaps some open forums or alike based on the EU eID systems, so that actual citizens and domain experts that live within the EU can easily talk and interact with the EU/EC for ideas and reaching consensus on important topics, without going through too much bureaucracy and physical meeting requirements. Just to give my considerations some background without tooting my own horn too much: I consider myself an expert on the scene with decades worth experience, regularly contributing to FOSS projects, writing articles, and creating tools for people to use, and I'd ironically consider myself a domain expert in big tech as being employed by Google (but I *do NOT* speak for them), after they scouted me due to my other experience in setting up my own cloud platforms for myself and various organizations. I would be happy to be a more regular part of these feedback mechanisms and other working groups, and pull in fellow experts from different areas, or even work on independent (preferably opensource) softwares and
