feedbackTextUserLanguage: DEU

feedback: I applaud the initiative to openly request feedback from the EU in this regard. Personally I'm an avid Home Assistant, ESPHome, EVCC and TrueNAS user and an active home automation / smart home community member. I would like to convey my support to the EU to foster open source standards throughout the Union. This to make it possible for these projects to continue to flourish. In my opinion there are no comparable commercial products that live up to these products in feature-set, tweakability and reliability. Many of these products rely on open specification standards such as bluetooth/zigbee/matter/thread/..., supporting these open standards will help integration and interoperability of products using these standards in the long run. Professionally, I've administered OpenBSD firewalls (a prime example of ingenuity on the forefront in secure versatile firewalls) and a variety of linux hosts for over more than a decade. Aside to the open source software initiative I would also like to point out the (in part) open hardware initiatives. e.g. ESPHome, Raspberry Pi, ... which should also receive the EU's support in my opinion. I'm also a big proponent of the USB-C power standard on all electronic devices, thank you for that. Where I can I try to support the open source initiatives by donating to their cause (If I use them extensively), but that is just a small drop on a hot plate for most of these initiatives.

As an active contributor to various open source projects, I think there are two ways the EU could ensure a healthy Open Source ecosystem. First, and the most obvious, is to help open source projects become more sustainable. This doesnt just mean throwing money at them, but identifying critical projects and offering to help set up governance structures if they dont have any would also go a long way. The second way to help would be to guide educational institutions to include Open Source in the IT curriculum. Many students are familiar with the concept, and yet I often get asked how do you start with open source because education very often focuses on business development and not open source development.

To start off, let me say that open source technology is an excellent fit for what the EU needs at this point in time where we want to substitute non-EU technologies with solutions to support our development. We should also understand that the cost factor, while important is really the least strategic argument for the shift from non-EU proprietary to open source. The main argument for open source must be the ability to implement solutions that can easily be customised for the different environments in the 27 member states. This is largely impossible with any proprietary technology as the interest of the owner is to maintain as little divergence as possible and also to encourage the purchase of add on software and services. This locks EU users into an endless cycle of high complexity with low functionality. Our current situation requires us to implement efficient solutions that enable emerging technologies such as EU AI solutions, EU Blockchain solutions and EU Cloud solutions. All proprietary solutions will by nature make this more difficult to achieve. The transition will be neither inexpensive nor very quick. It requires building teams of excellence for each tech being used and acquiring a critical mass across the entire EU. Turning this into national projects is a recipe for disaster, resulting in high costs and low penetration essentially repeating the same discoveries 27 times separately. I believe the main focus of the EC needs to be support a transition of government computing from non-EU platforms to EU-based open source solutions. We are talking of government at EU level, national level, regional level and local level. Due to common legal frameworks, we are all implementing very similar solutions in 130,000 local authorities, 400 regions and 27 states. There are differences in details, but they all implement essentially similar processes, often using half-baked tools implemented as primitive spreadsheets and shared data storage. These solutions need to be built as bullet-proof, AI-ready, internet-ready applications fit for 21st century deployments instead of forms translated from paper to PDF or spreadsheets. The solutions need to be such that they can easily be tailored for use in any local environment. Achieving this requires building and financing development communities and the exchange of information, specifications and code between member states and other stakeholders. Reference solutions need to be built together with teams in member states working on localisation and tailoring to the needs of their users. To make this work, there also has to be a readiness to improve processes and even the legal base for these systems. Member states need to commit to the idea that regulations need to follow available technology, which is a paradigm shift for many. A central role has to be played by an EU agency tasked with maintaining architecture, cooperation and exchange along with seed projects financed by the EU and/or member states. There should likewise be bodies in the member states that coordinate cooperation. It is important that this system not become a closed government-only system in which companies and individuals are not allowed to participation or contribute. It has to be an open system as the results will be open sourced. In the end, we need to create a set of solutions which are capable of using AI in a responsible way to enhance the capacity of government computing at all levels. This will create very capable teams that will also implement such solutions in companies and be suitably financed by those users. The public sector needs to the proving ground and financier of this transformation or creation of a common EU IT community.

Ich habe persönlich durch meine Arbeit bzw. mein Studium große Vorteile in offen Standards bzw. Quelloffenen Programmen erleben können. Da diese für alle zugänglich sind, unabhängig von Betriebssystemen, und so eine mögliche Transition von Windows und den damit angebunden Lizenzgebüren erlauben. Dies würde einen möglichen "Vendor-lock-in" verhindern und die damit einhergehende Bindung, quasi monopol Stellung, zu entsprechenden Firmen verhindern und damit vorallem Kontrolle zurück in die Hand der Nutzer bringen. Während wir momentan davon abhängig das Firmen in solchen Situationen ihre Position nicht zu stark ausnutzen. Auch die Abhängigkeit zu closed source Software könnte zum Beispiel in der Verwaltung zu einem großen Problem werden, wenn die USA entsprechende Gruppen als unlieb einstufen und so Microsoft oder Google ihre services dieser Gruppe nicht mehr zu Verfügung stellen und so möglicherweise die Arbeit dieser Gruppen unmöglich machen. Dies sollte bei der momentan politischen Instabilität in der USA durch aus ein Punkt sein, da ihre Ideale von unseren anscheinend sich trennen.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: I have personally been able to experience great advantages in open standards or open source programmes through my work or studies. As these are accessible to all, regardless of operating systems, allowing for a possible transition of Windows and the licence guarantees linked to it. This would prevent a possible ‘vendor-lock-in’ and prevent the associated connection, quasi-monopolistic position, to corresponding companies, thus bringing control back into the hands of users. While at the moment we depend on this, the firm does not exploit its position too much in such situations. Reliance on closed source software could also become a major administrative issue, for example, if the US classifies such groups as unpopular and thus ceases to provide Microsoft or Google with their services to that group, potentially making the work of those groups impossible. This should be a point in the current political instability in the US, as its ideals seem to be separate from ours.

feedback: I have been working with open source since the mid 1990's, both privately as in commercial and corporate environments. I have seen and heard all the pro's and cons come by. And in the end every company is using open source whether they know it or not. If open source software is a viable option therefore is a non-discussion since the mid 2010's. Open source has proven itself and is already the most used software worldwide. Every Apple device runs because of FreeBSD. Every Android device is basically a Linux distribution. Most TV's, routers, firewalls, robot cleaners, etc. run some sort of open source firmware. And most websites or AI platforms are either 100% open source code or they highly depend on it. Therefore open source is already part of our daily life in almost everything we do. All major social media platforms exists because of open source software and/or hardware. Therefore the only question that is relevant, is why are our national and European public services are using not open source software. For me the two most important elements for any software implementation in a public environment are being able to change running software to meet new demands or insights. This because in real life, the political landscape constantly changes. And so must the software tools that support the people working in those areas (instead of the other way around). This demands software that can be changed with ease and without any, expensive, technical consultants or programmers. In this, it does not matter whether it is open- or closed software. But based on experience, open source software allows this without restrictions. Closed source software is built around business models accompanied with expensive licences and restrictive, enforced with legal actions, rules. Therefore the MOST important reason to use open source software is preventing vendor lock-in and vendor restrictions. Where closed software has restriction on changing software code without consent of the supplier, open source on the other hand can almost always be changed without restrictions from a supplier. The second element is costs. It is often said that open source costs more then closed source. This used to be true in the golden days of IT management where organisations like Microsoft, Oracle and IBM ruled the waves. In todays world there are more people with extensive programming experience outside IT organisations then within. Meaning that the chance that someone in an organisation is able to read and change open source code is more often a rule than an exception. This makes the costs for support of open source software more than competitive with big IT companies as many low skilled people now are able to code and fulfil the jobs where a few years ago university degrees were needed. IT is no longer a niche area, and the people within no longer need to be overpaid. One final remark is in place. And that is costs in general. This because most costs, and not only IT related, are related to reactive event management. This means that we act when an event or issue happens. Several large studies in the past 40 or so years have proven that switching to a pro-active organisation can reduce organisational costs up to 60%. But it needs a cultural and management change as it demands us to think about preventing events from happening instead of (re)fixing them when they occur. Most cost savings can be made in this approach regardless being open- or closed software. It even applies on politics....

We desperately need an open-source operating system for mobile devices. Currently the average EU citizen uses Android or iOS and by this heavily relies on closed operating systems controlled by the US duopoly. Many EU services rely on these platforms: banking apps, messangers, etc. Even the EU login App relys on the Google or Apple authentication and infrastructure. This is in the of some crazy Agent Orange president who can pull tge plug to these services anytime. Much worse, since the operating systems are driven by US closed source code, it is possible that the Android and iOS devices will not boot anymore when crazy president pulls the plug. Since also the bootloader of each and every handset with US operating system is locked, device cannot be reaminmated by reflashing. We need desperately an EU open-source operating system for mobile devices such as smartphones, wearables and future devices to come. The seeds are already there: Murenas /e/OS, Vollas VollaOS, postmarked OS, droidian, etc. I currently use SailfishOS, a Linux OS from Finland, nearly 100% open. The manufacturer majes the remaining parts currently open source one by one. All services I use can in principle be done by Webapps and the browser, making me independent from Google or Apple app stores. When some crazy Agent Orange president over the ocean decides to pull the plug, I would probably get to know when reading the news, but from a unreachable app store or unbootable device. I believe in the EU idea and I think that an open source operating system on mobile devices from EU independent from US closed source slavery contributes and is an essential element for a brighter European future. We need that so desperately...

Ich arbeite seit >20 Jahren als Systemadministrator (Infrastruktur, Schulen, Verwaltung), leider wird erst jetzt, da es fast zu spät ist, nach unserer Meinung gefragt. Und genau das muss sich wirklich ändern: hört endlich auf die Menschen, die wissen um was es geht. Das sind sicher nicht die überbezahlten "Berater" aus irgendwelchen Großkanzleien und schon gar nicht Vertreter der Tech-Konzerne. Sicher, das hat euch das Leben und die Entscheidung einfacher gemacht, jedoch Menschen mit Sachverstand in den Burnout getrieben. Denn wir müssen die Suppe auslöffeln. Darum mein Feedback für den dringend erforderlichen Umschwung: 1.) Politischen Einfluss auf IT-Infrastruktur so gering wie möglich halten (Beispiel LiMux München oder jetzt schon wieder die millionenschwere Entscheidung für M365 aus der Münchner Staatskanzlei, MITTEN IN DER KRISE!!!), 2.) Aus-und Weiterbildung in allen IT Bereichen fördern;wir brauchen Leute für die Infrastruktur und Backbones, nicht nur Software-Entwickler (es gibt keinen einzigen Studiengang oder Meisterbrief für Systemintegratoren/-admins, dafür 1 Mio. Software-Studiengänge, gerne mit Wirtschaftsschwerpunkt...), 3.) Vertretern der Großkonzerne und -kanzleien den Zugang zu IT-Entscheidern in Verwaltung und Politik erschweren (Beispiel: Palantir im Herzen des LKA BaWü). Alle Tools sind bereits vorhanden, es geht nicht darum das Rad neu zu erfinden. Für jedes Produkt eines Tech-Konzerns gibt es bereits eine OpenSource Lösung, jedoch nicht das benötigte Personal. Hört bitte endlich auch mal auf die Menschen die damit arbeiten, nicht nur auf Akademiker, Vertreter von Aktienunternehmen und Karriere-Verwaltungsleute.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: I have been working as a system administrator (infrastructure, schools, administration) for more than 20 years, but unfortunately we are only asked for our opinion now that it is almost too late. And that is exactly what needs to change: finally listens to the people who know what is at stake. These are certainly not the overpaid ‘consultants’ from any large firms, let alone representatives of the tech groups. Sure, this has made life and decision easier for you, but has pushed people with expertise into burnout. Because we have to spoon the soup. This is why I am giving my feedback for the much-needed change: (I) minimise political influence on IT infrastructure (e.g. LiMux Munich, or now again the million-strong decision for M365 from the Munich State Chancellery, in the middle of the KRISE!), (ii) promote education and training in all IT areas; we need people for infrastructure and backbones, not only software developers (there is no single course or master’s certificate for system integrators/admins, for which there are 1 million software courses, with a focus on the economy...), (iii) make it difficult for representatives of large groups and law firms to access IT decision-makers in administration and politics (e.g.: Palantir at the heart of the BaWü LKA). All tools already exist, it is not a question of reinventing the wheel. There is already an open source solution for each product of a tech group, but not the staff needed. Finally, please listen to the people who are working with it, not just academics, company representatives and career managers.

feedback: I welcome the initiative for European Open Digital Ecosystems. However, as a citizen concerned with public safety, infrastructure resilience, and the rule of law in an era of hybrid warfare and shifting geopolitical alliances, I urge the Commission to anchor this ecosystem in strict reciprocity and pragmatism. True digital sovereignty cannot exist if governments act as 'Free Riders' on the work of open-source communities, nor if we remain dependent on volatile external powers for our digital foundations. Therefore, I strongly suggest the following pillars for a robust strategy: 1. Mandatory Reciprocity & Upstream Obligation The usage of Open Source Software by public institutions must come with a mandatory 'upstream obligation.' If public funds rely on existing open libraries, kernels, or frameworks, there must be a facilitating contribution in returnbe it financial support, developer hours for maintenance, or infrastructure. 'Public Money, Public Code' should not just be about transparency, but about the active maintenance of the digital foundation that guarantees our collective security. This directly supports the EUs goal of Strategic Autonomy by securing the supply chain against neglect and external sabotage. 2. A Decentralised, Scalable 'EuroStack' The Commission should facilitate the creation of a decentralised 'EuroStack': a software and infrastructure standard that is scalable from supranational institutions down to SMEs and the individual self-hosting citizen, prioritising 'local-first' principles and edge processing. This stack must ensure individual data sovereignty independent of hyperscalers, European or not. Furthermore, given the reality of fluctuating Atlantic policies, the EU should not act in isolation but form a 'Coalition of the Willing' with stable, like-minded OECD partnerssuch as Japan, South Korea, Switzerland, Ukraine, and Canadato create a global standard for democratic, open technology. 3. Extended Right to Repair & Legalised Reverse Engineering In alignment with the objectives of the Cyber Resilience Act (CRA), reverse engineering must be explicitly legalised in cases where manufacturers fail to provide a proper End-of-Life exit strategy for IoT or networking devices. Abandoned hardware is not just e-waste; it is a potential beachhead for hostile botnets and state-sponsored cyberattacks. If a vendor abandons the security of a device, the community must have the legal right to inspect the firmware and maintain the 'maintenance contract' themselves. Additionally, manufacturers who commercially free-ride on open-source software without honoring the license terms (e.g., GPL violations) must face active penalties. 4. A European Legal Structure for Open Source To support this, the EU needs a dedicated legal vehicle tailored for open-source foundations, akin to the Societas Europaea, serving as an EU-wide alternative to the Belgian AIBSL or U.S. 501(c)(3). This will streamline cross-border collaboration and funding, essential for retaining talent and innovation within the Single Market. These steps are vital to maintain the open-source ecosystem as a high-trust community through a zero-trust approach to source code auditability. This strategy provides Europe with the opportunity to develop a healthy, sovereign tech culture that upholds the international rule of law and European values.

Open source is the most effective tool to counter dependence on external suppliers and the centralization of capital. Its key strengths are security and trust, as public code allows for universal verification, ethics, where large entities can support development that everyone benefits, and the elimination of vendor lock-in, ensuring that any skilled entity can provide support rather than a single provider. However, the current industry approach is unsustainable. A major barrier is the "take without giving" mentality, especially when organizations treat open source merely as a cost-saving shortcut rather than a strategic asset. This creates an existential risk for valid projects-often used in critical government infrastructure-which currently lack the necessary budgets for maintenance and updates. To achieve true technological sovereignty, the EU must enforce a shift toward a "give-and-take" dynamic. We need a two-way support network where usage implies contribution. A concrete measure to achieve this would be to introduce strict verification in public tenders: providers of open-source solutions must demonstrate that they reinvest a portion of their resources back into the projects they utilize, in proportion to the investment they receive. This ensures that public spending directly supports the sustainability of the digital infrastructure it relies upon.

De EU zou via een fonds OSS projecten moeten ondersteunen voor meerdere jaren. Ondersteunde projecten zouden kunnen zijn: - Inbouw goede debugomgeving voor scripting in LibreOffice als alternatief voor MS Office. - Open source ondersteunde Remote Desktop software - Video conferencing software ipv Teams - Ook het porteren van veelgebruikte OSS Windows only applicaties naar Linux zou wenselijk zijn. Maar ondersteuning is ook daadwerkelijk de software in gebruik nemen en samen met (betaalde) ontwikkelaars de problemen opsporen en verhelpen en natuurlijk de software verbeteren. Regelgeving: - De overheden verplichten om zoveel mogelijk open standaarden te gebruiken die ook met OSS gebruikt kunnen worden. Dat hier wel xls/xlsx bestanden toegestaan zijn maar niet het open ods bestandstype is al veelzeggend treurig bij deze omvraag. - Overheidssoftware moet Open Source ontwikkeld worden zodat er nooit een vendor lock-in ontstaat.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: The EU should support multi-year projects through an OSS fund. Supported projects could include: — Install good debug environment for scripting in LibreOffice as an alternative to MS Office. — Open source supported Remote Desktop software – Video conferencing software instead of Teams – Porting widely used OSS Windows only applications to Linux would also be desirable. But support is also actually putting the software into use and, together with (paid) developers, detecting and remedying the problems and, of course, improving the software. Regulatory: — Require public authorities to use as many open standards as possible that can also be used with OSS. The fact that xls/xlsx files are allowed here, but not the open ods file type, is already striking in this question. — Public sector software should be developed Open Source to avoid vendor lock-in.

feedback: Germany is switching over to Matrix for secure digital communication. https://element.io/en/matrix-in-germany As far as I know the French police has been using their own adaptation of Linux (GendBuntu) for a while now. Both of those examples allow for member states to develop their own tools and host it locally when required, while at the same time allowing for interoperability because the foundation is the same, solid, developed and maintained by a relatively small group of people. Imagine the possibilities if the EU started to use and contribute to already existing projects on an even larger scale than it already is. TL;DR: Do not reinvent the wheel (No EUbuntu, there are enough distros already). Using and contributing to what is already there is the smarter play. France and Germany should be the textbook examples for other member states. It just needs to work.

It is crucial that there is a stronger initiative for interoperable an open source digital infrastructures in Europe. This should encompass: * Identify strategic open source infrastructure in organisations and private households in Europe (e.g. which open source is used there) and document them publicly - we need good and recent data and statistics to align (maybe Eurostat can coordinate this) * Create strategic alternative blueprints where we people may have not yet a good idea forward (e.g. secure Linux Desktop for private use or private home cloud), make sure it is not a paper tiger, work with the companies, such as Tuxedo Computers and IONOS Nextcoud, so it is light weight and makes sense. Think how it scales to neglected organisations (e.g. how can schools exchange data with parents, with pupils/students etc.) * Strengthen education with "sellable" skills in open source (e.g. certificates etc.) * Review existing regulation and standards to provide also an overview of open source software and configurations that can be used to meet the standards. We will see gaps, use funding to close the gaps. Make it possible that cloud provider can selectively be certified according to standards depending on their target groups (e.g. webhosting for small customers vs enterprise cloud for large customers) * Centrally coordinate and align open source tech funding (e.g. DE Sovereign Tech fund, NGI etc.). Allow the European countries to top-up but avoid double spending they should be able to align. Think how companies can contribute and pay to this. * Have lean and lightweight standards. Nothing complex that cannot be implemented by one skilled person. * The digital Euro must be integrated in the open source strategy - otherwise it is doomed to fail * Games, books, etc. also belong to the digital commons and should be founded

3. Un levier d'action important pour faciliter l'usage des écosystèmes open-source est d'imposer via les contrats de marchés publics l'usage de logiciel open-source ou bien la publication des logiciels fournis sous des licenses open-source. Ceci est également vrai pour les plateformes et logiciels utilisées dans le secteur public européen ou des différents Etat-membres : penser le développement de plateforme et outils public publiquement, et encourager les administration a utiliser et contribuer directement aux logiciels open-source pertinent pour leur mission.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: 3. An important lever for facilitating the use of open-source ecosystems is to impose, through public procurement contracts, the use of open-source software or the publication of software supplied under open-source licenses. This is also true for platforms and software used in the European public sector or in the various Member States: think about the development of public platforms and tools, and encourage administrations to use and contribute directly to open-source software relevant to their mission.

feedback: Why using micrsoft windows when there are perfectly alrigh linix distributions available. Same goed for the use of microsoft office, since there is a very nice alternative called libre office. both linux distributions and libre office are mostly open source and free to use. so please tep away from everything microsoft becouse its realy not needed to use those paid american products when there are good european alternatives available

W Europie istnieje szereg kluczowych dla niezależności naszych obywateli usług, które powinny być adoptowane przez organizacje sektora publicznego, działając jako koło zamachowe dla tych usług. Istnieje kilka obszarów, które są zdominowane przez rozwiązania zza oceanu: - komunikacja tekstowa - alternatywą jest Matrix protocol, który mógłby zostać zaadoptowany przez sektor publiczny - obsługa dokumentów - Libre Office (otwarty), ale też np OnlyOffice - poczta - tutanota, mailbox Widzę sporą szansę na zmianę systemową, zaczynając od szkół. W szkołach mocno promowane są rozwiązania Microsoftu, które później owocują znajomością jedynie tych narzędzi przez uczniów, co napędza rynek Microsoftu. Ucząc w szkole na rozwiązaniach otwartych, możemy wspierać te rozwiązania bezpośrednio jak i pośrednio (lepsza ich znajomość zwiększy ich użycie). Inny aspekt to open source w świecie SAAS. Opensource przy usługach typu SASS, jest mniej problematyczny, gdyż większość dochodów wynika z utrzymania usługi, a nie samej sprzedaży kodu. Korzystanie z rozwiązań SAAS, od firm, które należą do UE i dodatkowo wspierają OpenSource, może naturalnie wspierać biznes. Ostatni aspekt to promocja samego podejścia. Obywatele muszą zrozumieć w czym leży problem, więc trzeba zainwestować w promocję nurtu open source oraz niezależności technologicznej, docierając do osób nietechnicznych. Wtedy można uzyskać spory napływ nowych klientów.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: In Europe, there are a number of essential services for the independence of our citizens, which should be adopted by public sector organisations, acting as a breeding ground for these services. There are several areas that are dominated by solutions from behind the ocean: text-based communication – an alternative is the Matrix protocol, which could be adopted by the public sector – document handling – Libre Office (open), but also, for example, OnlyOffice – post – tutanota, mailbox I see a great opportunity for systemic change, starting with schools. Microsoft solutions are strongly promoted in schools, which later produce students’ knowledge only of these tools, driving the Microsoft market. By teaching open-source solutions at school, we can support these solutions directly as well as indirectly (better knowledge will increase their use). Another aspect is open source in the SAAS world. OpenSource for SASS services is less problematic, as most of the revenue comes from maintaining the service rather than simply selling the code. Using SAAS solutions, from EU-owned companies that additionally support OpenSource, can naturally support business. The last aspect is the promotion of the approach itself. Citizens need to understand what the problem is, so we need to invest in promoting open-source and technological independence, reaching out to non-technical people. You can then get a lot of new customers.

feedback: The concept of European Open Source seems unsustainable if we focus on which countries provided the authors of the code. An EU only open source project would not be able to gain the community by excluding/limiting input outside of the EU. Linux, Kubernetes etc. are not worth duplicating. Focus the efforts on wide scale deployment of open source and building EU based consultancies rather than restricting contributions.
I think that a European independant ecosystem is paramount. There should be less influence of Big Data companies like Microsoft, Meta and all.

Alles wat in Europa en Europa aanbeland moet in Europa blijven. Ik vermoed dat er al opensource alternatieven bestaan die mits een kleine aanpassing voldoen of kunnen voldoen aan de Europese eisen. Werk samen en maak een Europees ding voor alle landen. Zodat er geen versplintering ontstaat en alle diensten vlot kunnen samenwerken. Maak het bruikbaar voor zowel de diensten die instaan voor de burger, als voor de burger zelf. Maak dat het qua veiligheid een gesloten omgeving is, maar toegankelijk is voor de gewone burger zodat hij of zij vlot kan overstappen van Windows en Office. Zo denk ik aan een linux variant en libre Office met Thunderbird voor de mail en Firefox voor het browsen. Geef alles een Europees tintje voor mijn part, maar zorg dat de ondersteuning voor alle landen er is. Gemakkelijk te installeren voor de burgers en maak voor de beginperiode een site aan die duidelijk de stappen van installatie en werking weergeeft. Eventueel een usb key uitbrengen met de installatiebestanden erop in de taal van het land. Veel succes!
feedbackTextUserLanguage: Everything that ends up in Europe and Europe must remain in Europe. I suspect that there are already open source alternatives that meet or can meet European requirements subject to minor adaptation. Work together and make a European thing for all countries. This avoids fragmentation and allows all services to work together smoothly. Make it useful both for the services that provide for citizens and for the citizens themselves. Make sure that it is a closed environment in terms of security, but is accessible to ordinary citizens so that they can easily switch from Windows and Office. I am thinking, for example, of a Linux variant and libre Office with Thunderbird for the mail and Firefox for the browsing. Give everything a European tone for my part, but make sure that support is available for all countries. Easy to install for citizens and create a site for the initial period that clearly shows the steps of installation and operation. If necessary, issue a USB key with the installation files on it in the language of the country. Good luck!

feedback: Hi, I'm a Systems Administrator and run Promxox / Ceph Clusters. Great alternative to VMware/Proprietary SAN storage solutions which are 100% Free, Open Source and largely software agnostic. Meaning that both Proxmox nor Ceph care on which hardware they run.

The projected European Opensource should not restrain the free-software, those that exists and those that may be invented. And on the other side, the opensource initiative should respect the patents. The equilibrium that need to be found must at least respect the author rights, which is already the case in the free-software and by definition in patents. I hope, as a EU-citizen and also as a business owner, that all the initiatives will tend to use KISS methods (Keep It Stupid Simple). And I wait from the Europe administration that more simple standards are used. The electronic invoicing system which will be in use from this year in many countries should be simplified, in order that SME and associations can invoice their work easier. More simple software is hard to produce but it should be prioritized over complex software. Less digitization is suitable to avoid the mandatory use of computers and portable appliances (phones, tablets, etc). About the storage of information at the Europe scale, the duration of data retention should me minimized at the shortest possible, RGPD is part of it but it should be improved on the definition of retention duration. i.e., there exists such duration for administrative documents in France for example. It should be harmonized in Europe. There should be a European directory of open-source software, free-software and proprietary software, like the well-known site "alternativeto" or like the French ANSSI lists. If there are subsidiaries from Europe for software companies, that should involve a complete liberation of source code of such software for European users : one may provide an eID to access such code, but the idea behind is to maintain access to what Europeans pay for in taxes. About identification, one may not force the use of smartphones. As it can easily be stolen or lost, it should only be used as a two-factor authentication system. The eID card should be the main authentication system instead, but not in a electronic-only way. I hope that the future of digitization will be a lot easier and respectful than now : it is actually a real mess that just tends to use lesser and lesser digital things. And stop winter/summer time also : that's a reminder.

I own a business and it's very frustrating that it is nearly impossible to stay away from US or Asian IT infrastructure or software solutions. I find privacy and security very important but for a business it's nearly impossible to circumvent US tech or clouds. https://european-alternatives.eu/ is a good initiative but nearly invisible. And projects like LibreOffice and Nextcloud should be adopted much much more by governments, lead by example.

1. Open Source competence, activity and use in the EU is strong. Many of the world's finest, oldest and most critical infrastructure Open Source projects have European citizens in leading roles. Europeans have been involved and have been driving Open Source since long before even the name Open Source was established. Europe has a long established and well developed tradition in education, cooperation, communication and learning English. All helpful skills when developing Open Source or even just participating in an Open Source project. Open Source sees no borders. Open Source made by Europeans helps companies in the US or Asia equally well as it benefits European enterprises, and vice versa. Europeans are used to working in that spirit and when working with Open Source we rarely care about countries or citizenship. We make open products and services as good as we can for the entire world to benefit. Including the EU of course. Sometimes what hampers adoption is companies not adopting Open Source enough, and often the problem is that (European) companies don't fully understand the value of this infrastructure or how they can help themselves make better products faster by helping out and sustaining the Open Source projects they themselves benefit from. Writing quality Open Source and maintaining the project over time is hard and time consuming work. It is hard to convince companies to contribute and help projects survive. It might be apt to mention that "companies" here also include governments, non-profits and other communal organizations. They are rarely better at helping sustainability, even when they are major users and consumers of Open Source. 2. Open Source is a better way to develop software. It allows and enables more parties to get quality output at a lower cost. This enables companies to accelerate innovation and reduce time for their next product to reach the market. Open Source *survives*. It doesn't die or go away when companies go bankrupt or otherwise go under. Many fundamental Open Source projects have existed for thirty years or more and are still striving and remain the preferred option in their fields. Of course this happens a lot because there is no vendor lock-in or hidden secrets only a secret cabal knows. Open Source also allows for better security since everything is there in the open for everyone to analyze, scrutinize and try to poke holes at, and detected problems are then subsequently quickly fixed. Proprietary solutions cannot compete with this. 3. The EU could take measures and work on making sure that critical infrastructure Open Source projects are sustainable and secure - which could include funding. It would serve the EU and all its member countries to make sure that the current digital society stands on solid ground. That foundation is to a large degree made up from Open Source components today. Like the CRA is going to make sure all the products and services sold in the EU are secure, the next step could be to widen that net and make sure that whatever our entire society leans on, also in terms of Open Source, is good and solid. And that it remains good and solid for years to come. 4. The most important open source is the open source that is used widely or that powers and enables infrastructure. That sustains and upholds the fabrics of our modern society. Those open source projects exist in a wide variety of different technologies and sectors. Open Source exists and is the superior choice everywhere where software exists. Open Source is key to real and actual digital sovereignty. 5. Every sector that looks for efficiency, cost effectiveness and quality will select open source solutions. / Daniel Stenberg, president of the European Open Source Academy

When taxpayers pay for software, the code should be public. Backed by mandatory open source standards and a clear security framework. Unless there's a national security reason not to. This would prevent duplicated work across agencies and make long-term maintenance more sustainable. It's not necessarily about "free software" but about control and transparency. Vulnerabilities are easier to find and trust increases. Vendor lock-in is expensive and closed source has not proven to be secure either. More open source with good governance might be the way for Europe to pull itself away from the current (software / license / dependence) situation.

Bonjour. Nous sommes très nombreux à travailler et produire des solutions open-sources. Des gros projets, ou des bien plus petits. Parfois des librairies, qui permettent de construire de plus solides solutions. Aujourd'hui ce travail est surtout réalisé bénévolement, et structurer un projet autour pour tenter d'en vivre dans cette société capitaliste est extrêmement difficile, et précaire. L'europe a une source de main d'oeuvre immense dans la communauté du libre, qui ne souhaite que de se structurer autour d'un modèle adéquat, pour s'y investir pleinement. Seule certaines organisation permettent de financer des projets. On peux citer la fondation NL.net. Mais la quantité de demande de financement est très forte, et il est impensable de faire reposer ces travaux exclusivement sur cela. C'est pourtant une vrais alternative aux grosses companies américaine de la Silicon. Selon moi, il faudrait créer un model suffisamment ouvert pour permettre de rémunérer les développeur et développeuse open-source, dés lors que les licences utilisés garantissent le caractère libre de leurs créations. Nous pouvons nous inspirer sur le model économique du cinéma Francais. Affranchissons nous des dictas de la rentabilités, pour garantir notre souveraineté logicielle.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: Hello. Many of us are working and producing open-source solutions. Big projects, or much smaller ones. Sometimes bookshops, which make it possible to build stronger solutions. Today, this work is mainly carried out on a voluntary basis, and structuring a project around it to try to live in this capitalist society is extremely difficult and precarious. Europe has a huge source of labour in the free community, which only wants to structure itself around an appropriate model, in order to become fully involved. Only some organisations can fund projects. The foundation NL.net. But the demand for funding is very high, and it is unthinkable to base this work exclusively on this. Yet it is a real alternative to the big American companies in Silicon. In my view, a model should be created that is sufficiently open to allow developers and open-source developers to be remunerated, provided that the licences used guarantee the free nature of their creations. We can draw inspiration from the economic model of French cinema. We are relieving ourselves of the dictas of profitability, to ensure our software sovereignty.

feedback: Je soutiens pleinement linitiative pour des écosystèmes numériques européens ouverts et souhaite insister sur trois points essentiels La protection juridique des licences open source doit être renforcée de toute urgence car trop de projets voient leur code réutilisé illégalement par des acteurs commerciaux sans respect des obligations de redistribution ou de paiement cela décourage les contributeurs et menace la pérennité de lopen source en Europe il faut créer un mécanisme de défense juridique accessible et imposer des sanctions claires en cas de violation Les administrations et entreprises européennes doivent adopter massivement des solutions open source pour réduire la dépendance aux géants américains cela passe par des obligations dans les marchés publics une formation des décideurs et un soutien technique pour faciliter les migrations Enfin il est crucial de financer des infrastructures européennes indépendantes pour héberger développer et déployer des projets open source sans dépendre de plateformes étrangères cela inclut des forges logicielles des services cloud et des outils DNS souverains LEurope a les compétences et les communautés pour réussir mais sans action forte et coordonnée elle restera dépendante technologiquement
feedbackTextUserLanguage: I fully support the initiative for open European digital ecosystems and would like to stress three key points. The legal protection of open source licences must be strengthened as a matter of urgency, as too many projects have their code reused illegally by commercial actors without complying with redistribution or payment obligations. This discourages contributors and threatens the sustainability of source lopen in Europe. An accessible legal defence mechanism must be created and clear sanctions imposed in the event of infringements. European administrations and businesses must massively adopt open source solutions to reduce dependence on American giants. This requires obligations in public procurement, training for decision-makers and technical support to facilitate migration. Finally, it is crucial to finance independent European infrastructure to host and deploy open source projects without depending on foreign platforms. This includes software forges for cloud services and sovereign DNS tools. LEurope has the skills and communities to succeed, but without strong and coordinated action it will remain technologically dependent.

feedback:
Icecat is a listed SME (ISIN: NL0012291266) headquartered in Amsterdam and operates at the intersection of open product data, global e-commerce integrations, and deep-tech investments. Icecats experience is grounded in the practical use of open source and open data as drivers of European digital sovereignty and wealth. Icecat pioneered an open source model for product information that directly addresses the Commission's concerns about digital dependencies and market concentration. Our Open Icecat taxonomy and basic product datasheets are freely accessible, creating a level playing field for European retailers while maintaining commercial sustainability through premium services. Strengths. The EU has a robust ecosystem of specialized OSS providers. In eCommerce, Europe leads with platforms such as PrestaShop and PIM solutions such as Akeneo and Pimcore, emphasizing modularity and data privacy. Open Icecat is presented as a single global source of product content for the eCommerce industry, particularly in tech and consumer electronics. Weaknesses. A key weakness is the EU scale-up gap: world-class OSS often struggles to transition to global market leadership due to limited late-stage venture capital compared to the US. The internal market remains fragmented by varying national interpretations of digital procurement, including continued reliance on non-EU providers for government solutions. Research programs insufficiently foster OSS initiatives and tend to be input- rather than output-oriented. These weaknesses reduce Europes ability to develop world-class cloud solutions with OSS as a key ingredient and contribute to deficits in specialized open AI models for critical verticals (eCommerce, healthcare, manufacturing). Barriers. Icecat highlights: (1) the free fallacyopen source perceived as zero cost, leading to underfunded maintenance and security, reducing stimulus for related cloud initiatives; (2) limited fiscal incentives to contribute back to upstream projects, creating a tragedy of the commons; (3) the absence of legal requirements for manufacturers to donate public product information as open data, making it harder for EU eCommerce to develop local champions in verticals such as fashion and automotive; and (4) a compute infrastructure gap, as training competitive AI models requires massive GPU resources largely controlled by US hyperscalers. Added value and case study. Icecat views open source as risk mitigation, global branding, and innovation acceleration: reducing lock-in (e.g., via open-source eCommerce integrations), improving security through transparency, and strengthening data sovereignty. Icecat cites its investment in Orange Quantum Systems, where the Orange Juice open-source operating system supports community auditing and ecosystem development for quantum chip testing software. Open Icecat provides standardized open product data, preventing data monopolies, enabling interoperability across 77 locales, and supporting EU regulatory needs (Digital Product Passport, GPSR safety labels, packaging waste data). Icecat states that participation in Open Icecat can also reduce manufacturers ability to harass eCommerce startups with cease-and-desist actions. Recommended EU actions. Icecat recommends: (1) R&D tax credits to incentivize upstream contributions to critical OSS; (2) expansion of sovereign funding for ecosystem stewards to enable compliance with the Cyber Resilience Act without stifling innovation; and (3) an Open Source First procurement policy with a Comply or Explain requirement for proprietary purchases. Priority areas and sectors. Priority areas include open quantum stacks, open-weight AI models hostable locally to meet EU AI Act requirements (including for eCommerce), and enterprise middleware strengthening open-source PIM/ERP integrations for SMEs. Key sectors for competitiveness and resilience include retail/eCommerce, quant

feedback: Escribo como ciudadano, pero también como investigador y docente en ingeniería informática. El software libre proporciona libertad a todo el mundo, tanto a personas individuales como administraciones. No depender de programas escritos en códigos opacos o con licencias basadas en suscripciones ayudará enormemente a reducir la dependencia a las grandes tecnológicas que funcionan casi como pequeños países debido a la gran cantidad de influencia que tienen. Considero que el efecto práctico de esta propuesta debe materializarse al menos de 2 formas. Por un lado apoyar económicamente proyectos de software libre relevantes tanto para la administración como para la ciudadanía, como suites ofimáticas, navegadores, o sistemas operativos. Por otro, fomentar la proliferación de equipos de desarrollo de software dentro de las propias administraciones de los distintos países miembros ya sea para hacer desarrollos propios o para contribuir con nuevas características o arreglos de errores a proyectos ya existentes. Por supuesto, hacia qué proyectos específicos se dirijan estas acciones deberá seguir una línea estratégica que se alineé con los objetivos de la UE, pero fomentando sobre todo reducir la dependencia con el software privativo. A parte del foco sobre el desarrollo, es fundamental trabajar en fomentar la adopción. Por un lado, sustituir herramientas de software privativo en instituciones y administraciones públicas es complicado, pero con una planificación y formación para el personal adecuadas puede acabar consiguiéndose. Lo complicado es conseguir que la mayoría de la ciudadanía las adopte en su día a día. A parte de una campaña fomentando su adopción, me parece fundamental que algunos de los esfuerzos de desarrollo se centren en hacer más usables y cómodas las herramientas de software libre a la ciudadanía general. Hay muchas que funcionan ya de manera equivalente a herramientas privativas, pero un "click" más o un "click" menos muchas veces supone la diferencia de que una persona elija una herramienta u otra. Por último, quería hablar de que hay que llevar a cabo campañas para enseñar a la gente lo importante que es la soberanía digital, es decir, que sea dueña de sus propios datos y herramientas para evitar ceder su vida virtual a grandes empresas que trafiquen con sus datos. En esta línea me parece también fundamental impulsar el uso de redes descentralizadas, como las del fediverso (Mastodón, Pixelfed, Bookwyrm...), que, entre otras cosas, huyen de algoritmos de recomendación que han sido utilizados en numerosas ocasiones para guiar la opinión pública de la ciudadanía hacia temas concretos, lo cual puede verse claramente como una injerencia en la política de los países miembros por parte de entidades ajenas.

I am writing as a citizen, but also as a researcher and teacher in IT engineering. Free software provides freedom for everyone, both individuals and administrations. Not relying on programmes written in opaque codes or with subscription-based licences will greatly help reduce dependency on big tech that operate almost as small countries due to the large amount of influence they have. I consider that the practical effect of this proposal should materialise in at least 2 ways. On the one hand, to financially support free software projects that are relevant to both the administration and the public, such as office suites, browsers or operating systems. Secondly, to encourage the proliferation of software development teams within the various Member States’ own administrations, either to develop their own software or to contribute with new features or error arrangements to existing projects. Of course, the specific projects targeted by these actions should follow a strategic line that was aligned with

feedback: Une façon de faire progresser le logiciel libre durablement dans l'Union consiste à conduire les institutions chargées de former (à tout, littéralement, depuis les écoles, les instituts de formation, les universités) à utiliser du logiciel libre. Je suis chercheur au CNRS et je vois encore aujourd'hui de jeunes étudiants (master, thèse, post-doctorat) arriver dans les laboratoires de recherche expérimentaux (biologie, chimie, physique) avec des ordinateurs Apple! Quand je leur fais remarquer qu'il est contre-intuitif de vouloir faire de la recherche et d'utiliser des systèmes d'exploitation fermés/verrouillés comme le leur, ils me répondent: "c'est que je j'ai appris à utiliser au cours de ma formation". Si les jeunes gens qui sortent de ces formations avaient utilisé GNU/Linux au lieu de MS Windows ou Apple macOS, nous n'en serions pas là. Voilà une proposition simple. Je lis souvent "ah oui, mais il faut le financer !". Combien de milliards ont été dépensés depuis trente ans (tous pays UE confondus) en licences propriétaires? Si cet argent avait été investi dans le logiciel libre, pour notre bien commun, où en serions-nous aujourd'hui? Il faut que la Commission européenne se libère *effectivement* des lobbies du logiciel propriétaire (en 2000, à l'époque de notre lutte contre les brevets logiciels, je crois me souvenir que la responsable de l'interopérabilité des logiciels était une ancienne employée de Microsoft). Si cette libération politique est réelle, alors je ne doute pas qu'elle réussira à améliorer la situation actuelle de dépendance toxique de l'UE aux éditeurs de logiciels propriétaires. Sincèrement, un utilisateur/créateur de logiciels libres depuis 1999/2005.

Mooi om te zien dat de EC een consultatie heeft uitgezet met als doel de standpunten te verzamelen van alle geïnteresseerde belanghebbenden, in het bijzonder de Europese open-sourcegemeenschap (inclusief individuele bijdragers, open-sourcebedrijven en stichtingen), overheidsinstanties, gespecialiseerde bedrijfstakken, de ICT-sector, academische instellingen en onderzoeksinstituten. Ik zie veel raakvlak met onze whitepaper "Samen de NDS realiseren / Marktperspectief op NDS: samen van ideeën naar maatschappelijke impact" waaraan ik heb meegeschreven als reactie van Dawn Technology en marktexperts op het gebied van digitalisering, wet- en regelgeving op de Nederlandse Digitaliseringsstrategie (NDS) van de overheid. Het opensource onderdeel komt hier o.a. terug bij de thema's digitale soevereiniteit, data en AI. In ons paper beschrijven wij onze positieve bevindingen, visie, standpunten en concrete adviezen die direct kunnen worden opgepakt om bij te dragen aan de NDS-doelstellingen en opensource-oplossingen. Zie link voor onze whitepaper: https://dawn.tech/publicatie/samen-de-nds-realiseren#contact of in bijlage.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: It is good to see that the EC has launched a consultation with the aim of gathering the views of all interested stakeholders, in particular the European open-source community (including individual contributors, open-source companies and foundations), public authorities, specialised industries, the ICT sector, academic institutions and research institutes. I see a lot of interface with our whitepaper "Delivering together the NDS/market perspective on NDS: together from ideas to societal impact ", to which I contributed as a response from Dawn Technology and market experts in the field of digitalisation, legislation and regulation to the Dutch Government’s Digitalisation Strategy (NDS). The open source component comes back here, among other things, to the topics of digital sovereignty, data and AI. In our paper, we describe our positive findings, vision, views and concrete opinions that can be directly addressed to contribute to the NDS objectives and open source solutions. See link for our whitepaper: https://dawn.tech/publicatie/samen-de-nds-realiseren#contact or attached.

feedback: I strongly support the development of a European Open Digital Ecosystem, provided the strategy is grounded in technological sovereignty, interoperability, and institutional resilience, rather than a purely ideological commitment to open source. Open source should be treated as a strategic instrument, not an end in itself. Its primary value lies in enabling open standards, reducing vendor lock-in, fostering interoperability, and preserving the EUs long-term capacity to govern, audit, and evolve its digital infrastructure independently. These properties are essential for competitiveness, innovation, and democratic legitimacy. The strategy should therefore explicitly prioritize open standards and interoperability over source code openness alone. Open, royalty-free standards enable multiple independent implementations, substitutability, and real competition. Open source implementations are often the most practical way to operationalize such standards, but they are not the only mechanism, nor always sufficient. For public administrations, maintaining exit rights from vendors through interoperable architectures should be a first-class objective. Security must be addressed explicitly and separately. Open source does not automatically result in secure systems. Security is a distinct engineering, governance, and funding problem that depends on sustained maintenance, adversarial review, clear accountability, and, where appropriate, formal or automated verification. The strategy should avoid assuming that transparency alone provides security, and instead support long-term stewardship of critical digital assets, including funding for maintenance, security audits, and reproducible builds. Beyond infrastructure, the strategy should recognize the importance of digital commons (including software, data, documentation, and creative works) as enabling infrastructure for innovation. European innovation depends less on isolated breakthroughs than on reuse, composability, and recombination across institutional and national boundaries. Low-friction reuse and shared assets strengthen Europes creative and technological capacity. Public administrations should act not only as users, but as long-term stewards of open digital assets. This requires investment in governance, maintenance, and institutional responsibility, rather than short-term or pilot-driven approaches for systems that underpin public services. I submit this feedback based on experience in public administration, current graduate-level studies in computer science with a focus on secure software and privacy, and long-standing engagement with European technical and digital civil-society communities. This background informs a pragmatic view: openness is most valuable where it preserves institutional autonomy, enables interoperability and innovation, and supports verifiable trustwhile security must always be engineered and governed deliberately. To inform the development and implementation of the strategy, the Commission should actively engage with European civil-society and technical NGOs that combine practical experience with policy expertise. Relevant interlocutors include Chaos Computer Club, Free Software Foundation Europe, European Digital Rights, OpenForum Europe, and Open Knowledge Foundation Europe. These organizations can provide grounded input on open standards, interoperability, digital commons, and the gap between formal openness and operational security in public-sector systems.
