feedbackTextUserLanguage: My opinion on the subject is as follows: Appendix to the Act on the Openness of Government Activities: The public authority’s statutory information and public communications shall be organised primarily through a channel of communication accessible to the public without registration, where the public authority is responsible for publishing, updating and removing content. Other communication channels may be used in a complementary manner. This would take into account the possibility for commercial platforms to limit the visibility of content and would keep the information material under the control of public authorities.

feedback: Open source software drives innovation in academia but faces sustainability challenges. Fragmentation and lack of long-term maintenance incentives create risks that discourage adoption, particularly in fields like medical practice where trust is critical. Objective criteria for assessing these risks could help both researchers and practitioners make informed decisions. Such analysis might reveal high-risk dependencies (e.g., critical libraries maintained by single volunteers), which the EU could subsidize to strengthen Europe's software ecosystem. More broadly, the EU should build trust in open source through guarantees and strategic support.

I am a user of open source software both in private as well as professional settings. In my role as researcher in an advanced technology field a lot of my data analysis would be harder, more resource expensive and slower without the wealth of open source software available e. g. in the python environment. As a private citizen I am happy to be able to use open source software and community built and maintained tools for my communication, navigation and other everyday tasks. As a person interested in the technological landscape in general I am painfully aware of how deeply a lot of our software ecosystem relies on open source tools often maintained thanklessly by a few determined individuals. I think the EU would be well advised to set up a robust system that ensures relevant funding for continued open source development. Many of these projects, especially the larger ones, have supporting organizations such as foundations etc. that fund some of the continuing development. Supporting these and making it possible for smaller projects to receive funding without a large bureaucratic overhead. Such an agenda would benefit all EU citizens that rely on digital tools and also foster an ecosystem that reduces the reliance on tech monopolies which are more easily exploited in the face of current geopolitical instabilities.

Digital sovereignty should be an essential goal of the EU now more than ever. Both because of the current geopolitical context but also because private companies outside of the EU are gathering large training data from European citizens for AI models without proper consent as EU citizens don't have much knowledge about open source alternatives. The current open source infrastructure seems at an ideal stage to transition most of the EU's digital infrastructure to open source alternatives. As a personal example, I mainly use free and open-source softwares without being an expert in informatics. I also helped quite a lot of relatives to adopt these tools (e.g. Ubuntu, libreoffice, nextcloud...). The only time I needed a proprietary software recently is to fill a form from the EU about a grant I received. I believe this shows both that the transition is possible and that for now the EU is mostly acting against open source solutions at least in it's administration

1. strengths/weaknesses The EU OSS sector is innovative and has access to a large pool of knowledgeable and motivated workers thanks to a strong value alignment with the principles of open source. What is lacking is the commercial strength. Most in the sector are technical and/or idealistically driven, with far fewer commercially minded folks compared to the USA, while the startup environment in the EU is already severely lacking. 1(i/ii) barriers to adoption and contribution The two main barriers are the anti-competitive behavior of big tech which goes nearly unchallenged by the EU and the total lack of any kind of strategic thinking in procurement policy in the EU. All open source gets is encouraging words and token subsidies. 2. added value Open Source is the only solution if Europe wants to have any kind of serious, value-adding IT industry and any degree of technological independence from US Big Tech. How important the EU economy and its political decision making is I leave to the reader. 3. Concrete measures The EU needs to get serious about cracking down on anti-competitive behavior of big tech - stop the continuous buying of competitors, progressive pricing, self-preferencing and bundling. Second, the EU needs to get strategic in its purchasing/tender policies. Buy European when suitable. The definition of suitable should include 'when the vendor is willing to fix the remaining feature gap under a conditional sale', as often EU solutions are excluded on extremely thin grounds; moreover, when 80% of workloads can be ran by sovereign, EU providers, and 20% require specialized technology only available at foreign solutions, split the tender up that way. Often, it is really a tiny percentage of workloads that really require non-EU tech, but the public sector tries to consolidate everything at Microsoft or Amazon. Yes, that simplifies IT, but also increases dependency and massively helps these firms kill their competition. And third, the EU should improve its internal market. It is usually easier to buy and sell to US firms than to other countries in the EU. Equally, it is insanely hard to hire across borders within Europe. This is an ongoing effort, but the self-harm this internal barriers create are worth mentioning. 4. priorities We should prioritize 70/30 between two things: * 70% effort should go into the easiest to migrate solutions, that is, those, which already have (nearly) complete European solutions available. This will support Europe's IT sector as massive spending currently going to foreign firms gets redirected to EU, enabling our innovators to start building the capabilities currently lacking. Depending on the space, between 30 and 80% of workloads can already be migrated, so success should be counted in the percentage of EU public sector spending on IT going from big tech to EU tech. * 30% of the effort should go into fixing the most critical strategic dependency challenges Europe face - critical services around self defense, health care and core infrastructure. 5. what sectors would benefit I struggle to think of a sector that would not benefit from lower costs, increased flexibility, improved usability and increased resilience that would result from a stronger European IT sector built upon healthy Open Source businesses.

𝗧𝗵𝗶𝘀 𝘀𝘂𝗯𝗺𝗶𝘀𝘀𝗶𝗼𝗻 𝗮𝗰𝗰𝗼𝗺𝗽𝗮𝗻𝗶𝗲𝘀 𝗮𝗻 𝗮𝘁𝘁𝗮𝗰𝗵𝗲𝗱 𝗘𝘅𝗲𝗰𝘂𝘁𝗶𝘃𝗲 𝗦𝘂𝗺𝗺𝗮𝗿𝘆 (𝗣𝗗𝗙) 𝗮𝗱𝗱𝗿𝗲𝘀𝘀𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗮𝗿𝗰𝗵𝗶𝘁𝗲𝗰𝘁𝘂𝗿𝗮𝗹 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗴𝗼𝘃𝗲𝗿𝗻𝗮𝗻𝗰𝗲 𝗽𝗿𝗲𝗰𝗼𝗻𝗱𝗶𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻𝘀 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝗘𝘂𝗿𝗼𝗽𝗲𝗮𝗻 𝗢𝗽𝗲𝗻 𝗗𝗶𝗴𝗶𝘁𝗮𝗹 𝗘𝗰𝗼𝘀𝘆𝘀𝘁𝗲𝗺𝘀. While most contributions understandably focus on open-source licensing, funding, or vendor lock-in, this submission highlights a missing layer: operational authority, accountability, and enforceable governance within open digital ecosystems. The Executive Summary argues that open digital assets alone do not produce sovereignty or resilience unless embedded in a system that clearly defines: decision authority and override rights, responsibility allocation across lifecycle stages, and institutional mechanisms for accountability under real-world pressure. These considerations are particularly relevant for public sector adoption, cross-border interoperability, and long-term sustainability of open digital infrastructures within the Union. The attached document is intended as a concise policy-level input to support the Commissions strategic and operational framework.

I would also recommend that you take a look at the "Business Source License". that way you can invest in European companies, they can make money on the software, and then in 4 years it goes fully open source. It is a balance between the needs of the users, the companies, and investors.

Free and Open Source Software helps consumers reclaim ownership of technology. An easy example is how using an operating system alternative to Windows (Linux for example) allowed countless users to keep using their computers after the end of life of Windows 10, saving money and reducing e-waste. Similarly, when Microsoft abandoned support for their Windows Mixed Reality (Virtual Reality) platform, many of those headsets remained and still remain usable with an Open Source third party driver called Monado, again reducing e-waste. Open Source Software also democratizes access to technology: professional grade applications like for example Microsoft Office, Mathworks MATLAB, Autodesk Autocad, Autodesk Maya, Adobe Photoshop, Adobe Illustrator, Adobe Premiere have proibitively expensive licensing costs that are often unsustainable by a vast majority of the population, particularly younger people still in their education with little to no personal income. Open Source alternatives to these applications allow everyone to access these professional industries without expensive licensing costs. Some of the alternatives to the applications mentioned are respectively: LibreOffice, GNU Octave, FreeCad, Blender, Krita, Inkscape, Kdenlive. By its nature Open Source Software is also inherently more transparent in terms of privacy and user tracking, as any code path leading to information leaving the user's device where the software is running is clearly visible in human legible source code, and in case a user doesn't want to send any tracking or private information at all, with a little bit of technical knowledge, they can just remove any tracking code from the application by themselves. To conclude, investing in Free and Open Source technology allows everyone to democratically access technology, without political or economical barriers, and ensures that no single point of failure exists in the production and maintainance of said software.

Dear EC, I am one of the leaders for a large and venerable open source project called Inkscape and I wish to share with you the experience of running an organisation that has contributors from the EU and the rest of the world. The Inkscape project founded in 2003 is a vector image editor useful for making designs, logos, pdfs, prints and other useful made materials. It was founded by a group of USA citizens as volunteers with no company or employees. Despite not having many resources the project has millions of users and is well known in various industries and academic settings. Over time, I have notice that the contributions from volunteers in the USA have waned, while those from the EU have increased dramatically. This change in who is willing to spend time building such a project feels like it is due to the change in culture within the Free Software and Open Source communities themselves, moving from a libertarian culture to a more social democratic one and I believe these slow shifts have changed us and who does this work. The EU is in a partially strong alignment with this new open source spirit and I believe you will be best placed to build many great things if you do it right. The main concern is, as it always was, resources. Our project is run on a shoe string and while we are able to pay people through our 501c3 parent organisation to provide technical labour, we do not have the stability or sustainability of some of our sister projects. What marks our project out differently is that we are still joined to a US organisation which is misaligned to industrious objectives so are limited in what we can do. While our fellow projects in the EU such as Blender, Krita and Godot have found better success through grants, industry partnerships and direct user funding. Although they have struggled to find consistency in various EU country legal frameworks for the types of organisation that they are, something I think you should think about making a consistent type of organisation EU wide. Improving the economic and labour cultural values within the Free and Open Source community has always been one of my objectives and I'm keen to see the EU recognise this deficit in the open source model and what can be done to keep projects healthy, independent and capable. Thank you for your time.
The only way to avoid vendor lock-in is to use open source software. That way you are always free to fork the software on your own developer team if the vendor does not suit your requirementy.

Open Source, Open Standards og interoperabilitet mellem tjenester er et absolut *must*, hvis EU-borgere, virksomheder og organisationer skal opleve et bedre IT-landskab i fremtiden. Som tingene er i dag, så har ingen EU-borgere tilstrækkeligt med frit valg, når det kommer til teknisk udstyr: Computere sælges med bestemte, forudvalgte operativsystemer, og købere af mobiltelefoner er låst til at bruge de samme to operativsystemer, der ikke nemt kan skiftes ud. Manglen på valgfrihed for forbrugerne betyder, at meget få etablerede, ressourcestærke producenter kan diktere, hvordan markedet skal se ud, og det påvirker givetvis EU-virksomheders muligheder for nogensinde at vinde fodfæste i markedet for alvor. Der findes allerede velfungerende Open Source-alternativer, såsom Linux, hvor idérige, sprudlende fællesskaber har været i gang med at udvikle kvalitetssoftware i årevis.. Dette kører allerede på udvalgte mobiltelefoner, men det store "push" kunne komme, hvis man indenfor EU iværksatte initiativer, der kunne sikre, at forbrugerne kunne installere operativsystemer efter eget ønske på mobiltelefoner og tablets På internettet er der ej heller fri bevægelighed. Brugere på en platform kan typisk ikke kontakte andre brugere på andre platforme. Forestil jer, det samme scenarie gjorde sig gældende for telefonkunder - at de kun kunne ringe til kunder fra samme teleselskab... Det ville ingen acceptere, så hvorfor er det tilladt for kommercielle sociale medier? Åbenhedsorienterede Open Source-udviklere har allerede lavet alternative gennem oprettelsen af federerende åbne sociale medier i det globale græsrodsfænomen The Fediverse. Her kan brugerne af social media software såsom Mastodon og Friendica, skrive sammen på tværs af tjenesterne, fordi W3Cs åbne ActivityPub-protokol agerer kommunikationsbindeled. Det, selvom tjenesterne fungerer forskelligt nede i "maskinrummet". Det er internettet, som det burde være.
feedbackTextUserLanguage: Open Source, Open Standards and interoperability of services are an absolute * must * if EU citizens, businesses and organisations are to experience a better IT landscape in the future. As things are today, no EU citizen has enough freedom of choice when it comes to technical equipment: Computers are sold with specific, pre-selected operating systems, and buyers of mobile phones are locked to use the same two operating systems that cannot be easily replaced. The lack of freedom of choice for consumers means that very few established, well-resourced producers can dictate what the market should look like, and it certainly affects the ability of EU companies ever to gain a significant foothold in the market. Well-functioning Open Source alternatives already exist, such as Linux, where ideal, evocative communities have been developing quality software for years. This already runs on selected mobile phones, but the big push could come if initiatives were taken within the EU to ensure that consumers could install operating systems as they wish on mobile phones and tablets. Users on a platform typically cannot contact other users on other platforms. Imagine that the same scenario applied to telephone customers – that they could only call customers from the same telecommunications company... Nobody would accept, so why is it allowed for commercial social media? Open-source open source developers have already made alternatives through the creation of bold open social media in the global grassroots phenomenon The Fediverse. Here, users of social media software, such as Mastodon and Friendica, can join forces across services because the W3C’s open ActivityPub protocol acts as a communication link. This is despite the fact that the services operate differently in the “engine room”. It is the internet as it should be.

feedback: Payment systems such as Mastercard that operate globally. Applications such as Google Pay or Samsung Pay. Open source search engines that respect privacy. Do not miss out on Mistral and severely restrict the purchase of shares by foreign companies in strategic European companies. Device security certifications not monopolised by Google or a few companies with conflicts of interest on operating systems, thus involving European and non-European entities such as GraphenOS. Create new open source operating systems for augmented reality glasses and smartphones. Adaptive drivers for operating systems such as Linux or impose open source drivers for new hardware. However, licences should be linked to a minimum set of rules of use that do not go against European interests. Also promote open hardware and 3D printing of components. Encourage innovative start-ups in the sector without creating zombie companies that live off welfare and squandered public funds. A browser that truly respects privacy. Limit the data that applications such as TikTok etc. can read and send. Provide more funding to the Matrix Foundation and DeltaChat by bringing in experts to have a greater impact on the market. WhatsApp should be truly obliged to be interoperable with Matrix, Signal and DeltaChat etc. without applying its own privacy conditions in hybrid chats, but rather predefined European rules. Google is taking over everything, which is not good at all.

Hi, I speak as a contributor of opensource projects such as rust, gcc, llvm or linux kernel. The whole IT economy uses these projects but rarely give back in any way. The problem here is that these opensource projects are mostly done and maintained by volunteers on their free time and they're not paid for any of that. So now if a major security breach is found in such a project, it could be fixed quickly... or not at all since the maintainers may or may not have time and/or motivation to fix it, leaving their users (can be anyone, including military companies) with a big breach in the tools they use/provide.

One way to encourage and promote open-source is to ask (or demand) from software providers that their software be supported on a GNU/Linux and/or BSD operating system. Why? If a stakeholder needs a piece of software that is only supported on Windows, said stakeholder will remain reliant on Windows. If the same software is also supported on GNU/Linux/BSD, then a stakeholder has the freedom to choose which operating system they want to use. For example: if a school requires that students run software that is only supported on Windows, students will be required to run Windows on their devices. The software requirements of the school demand that students run a proprietary operating system. Many software vendors offer a SaaS version of their software in todays market, but this is not guaranteed for all software that is available. Students in this example do not have the freedom to choose. A second reason to consider this is that if public sector stakeholders start increasing their demand that the software they need be supported on non-Windows operating systems, software vendors would have an incentive to increase investments in open-source development work. If a software vendor has always exclusively supported Windows as the operating system of choice, they will not have an incentive to change if there is no market demand.

Q1. Inertia, vendor lock-in and network effects. Proprietary formats that do not work seamlessly with alternative products (e.g. MS Office formats, ESRI formats, AutoCAD formats). Procurement - maybe introduce a system like the utilities procurement directive (2014/25/EU) to set a standards based level playing field for medium to large organisations across the NACE sectors. 2. Free and Open Source options are generally very powerful and are easier to set up (unless relying on locked-in features). They tend to be very stable and are based on open standards as there is no incentive not to do so. For example postgresql database is fast stable and runs on most platforms. The FOSS spatial stack is fast and powerful. R now dominates statistics. Web frameworks such as django enable high quality modular data management and publication. The list goes on an on - curl, geos, gdal, proj - nobody uses anything else anymore. It is worth noting that startups rarely use non-free software and the dominant technology companies and systems integrators rely heavily on FOSS for their own operations and integrations. 3. Utilities Directive (2014/25/EU) equivalent to require open procurement of software based on open standards to ensure a level playing field for medium and large organisations across all NACE sectors. Something like 1% art scheme (Ireland) for publicly funded software to be directed into FOSS maintenance (priority) and development (important but lower priority). 5% would seem to be a fair level for a tax to ensure sustainability. Something like the Single resolution mechanism for banks for failing / dangerous companies under the Digital Services Act - use of a temporary escrow to allow them to be taken over under a temporary board to address egregious breaches of the DSA. 4. Communications (email, telephony, video calling), document and cloud storage, operating systems, office software. For security of people in the EU. 5. All sectors would benefit. It is worth noting that startups rarely use non-free software and the dominant technology companies and systems integrators rely heavily on FOSS for their own operations and integrations.

The longer version (with more focus on strategy) is in the attached PDF. Highlight recommendations can be found here: Recommendations 1. Strengthen the open-source technology stack that already exists, thanks to the NGI initiative. There are 1500 projects sponsored by NGI so far, many of them are existing modules in open-source ecosystems. The networks are already there, and started thriving. 2. Legal entity legislation for open-source Legislate the ability to establish legal entities which match the long-term safeguarding needs of open-source licenses. Examples are Post Growth Entrepreneurship and strict Stewardship models, see work by Dr. Melanie Rieback 3. Lead by example. Be the change. By adopting open-source infrastructures within the EU, nations and municipalities see what is possible. Self-host or hire self-hosting organizations. Replace Big Tech solutions with open-source solutions: video-calls, knowledge bases, communication channels and more. 4. Support local connections & physical spaces Local communication happens in physical spaces. Local problems require local solutions. Real collaboration and weaving of networks occurs in person: in libraries, hackerspaces, conferences, makerspaces & communal centers. 5. Distinctions of Licenses copyleft vs BSD-licenses There are two main types of open-source licenses, BSD-licenses and copyleft (9). Each type serves its purposes, copyleft licensing (such as AGPL) is ideal for the purpose of safeguarding core infrastructure from becoming co-opted by proprietary incentives. Copyleft licenses are ideal for infrastructure developed by public funding or for the digital commons. BSD-licensing (such as MIT) is suitable when the developing source want to be able to build a proprietary company on top of the code, usually at a later point, and to put it bluntly, quite awful for public infrastructure. 6. Enable the Many and Small A common issue in the IT space of Europe is that once a project becomes big and successful enough, it gets bought up by Big Tech. The european strategy for IT is through open-source which enables many small initiatives collaborating rather than having to grow into large companies. Supporting the many and small leads to thriving ecosystems of interoperability. This also applies for technical solutions. Modularity and compostability of software enables ecosystems to thrive, with low entrance cost and low-maintenance cost for developers. 7. Communication Structures The communication infrastructure permeates all of society and all sectors. Emphasizing a shift towards federated, interoperable P4P communication infrastructures(10) enable technical communication ecosystems which are robust, adaptable and resilient. 8. Document, documen, document The Digital Commons European Digital Infrastructure Consortium (DC-EDIC) is a great potential for this. All digital public infrastructure should be well documented and information about it should be accessible. Interoperability is a social issue as well as technical and knowledge exchange is imperative. I learnt this from a professor at MIT, Niel Gershenfeld, as it is essential for open-source in general. Cautions Open-source development by proprietary companies. Handing over large funds to companies to build open-source when they themselves aren't open-source is a tragedy. It leads to diluted values and poor-results, commonly through license changes which impact entire open-source ecosystems. An industry led path of open-source is one of more of the same, yet we need change. Risk of top-down approach Applying a top-down approach of frameworks to "professionalize" or apply a pre-constructed idea of how open-source projects should organize or present leads not only to a loss of legitimacy in open-source contexts but also lacking engagement from open source communities.

column37: I think open digital systems are very important and especially today with all corporations trying to control public opinion, our data and our lives. Platforms such as Linux, Mastodon, Pixelfed, Peertube, Open Office, Organic Maps, Tutamail, Protonmail are what Europeans need and it is just to give an example. We need open digital systems that are not controlled by magnets that seek to enrich themselves, but that users have free and unadvertised access to these services. It is also important for Europe to have digital sovereignty in all this and to no longer rely on or use services and products from other countries such as the US or China. We need our own digital services more than ever.

feedback: EU institutions must invest in and accelerate mandatory business and individual identity systems, secure European payment rails and a communications network which is as independent of US and hostile powers as possible. Software should be registered in order to access the API's of this infrastructure and low cost access should only be granted to open source components, or those in the process of being open sourced.

Open-source software is a great solution for breaking lock-in and insecure supply chains. The EU should support the development of open-source software by directly funding the established maintainers of crucial software such as the most popular Python and Rust libraries.

"1. () What are the main barriers that hamper (i) adoption and maintenance of high-quality and secure open source; and (ii) sustainable contributions to opensource communities?" Many open-source projects start as passion projects. Taking a huge risk, taking up a loan, and founding a company the traditional is a big leap to make, since most developers who start their passion project can continue to work on it on the side without taking such risks. Funding them through easily accessible grants allows them to start with a smaller step in that direction. At the same time, knowing that the EU Commission actively supports open-source, encourages citizens and public procurement to give open-source adoption a try. "3. What concrete measures and actions may be taken at EU level to support the development and growth of the EU open-source sector and contribute to the EUs technological sovereignty and cybersecurity agenda?" Keep funding the NGI initiative. A very effective way of supporting the open-source ecosystem are easily accessible grants, such as the ones offered by NLnet and the Next Generation Internet programs. Most projects already exist, but are done on the side by their developers. With easily accessible grants, such developers can work on their projects without needing a separate full-time job to pay the bills and their projects can grow into something larger. Provide financial incentives for public procurement to take a look at open solutions. Government offices are often struck for money and have little to no wiggle room to try something new. There are plenty of small and large companies who can install and maintain all kinds of open tools and infrastructure, it frequently just seems less risky to many procurement officers to go with huge overseas companies like Microsoft because everyone else does and nobody will blame the procurement officers if something goes wrong. "4. What technology areas should be prioritised and why?" The health sector. It is very hard for open-source to gain foothold in the health sector, because of extremely high upfront cost of developing and certifying many health sector related products. On the other side, proprietary health sector products are often extremely expensive, unsecure, and restrictive; A common example would be CT machines which need a completely outdated and insecure Windows XP computer because they stopped receiving support from the manufacturer decades ago. Open-source technology would allow third parties to support such machines even when the original manufacturer stopped doing so. "2. What is the added value of open source for the public and private sectors?" Open-source solutions are typically superior to proprietary ones, as they are cheaper, put more power into the hands of the consumer, and are resilient to monopoly, price hikes, and companies going under. As a consumer, I can use the smart home sector as an example: My Panasonic air conditioning unit offers the ability to control it via Wi-Fi adaptors which cost 180 total for both my units. At the same time, they can only be controlled by Google Assistant, Amazon Alexa or Panasonic's smartphone app; all of which require an internet connection to Panasonic's servers. This system is relatively expensive, is fully dependent on Panasonic providing updates and not shutting their servers down, and doesn't even integrate with most smart home systems (including Home Assistant, which I am using). Alternatively, there is an open-hardware and open-software solution available, which costs less than 50 for both units, doesn't require an internet connection, receives permanent security and feature updates through the open-source ecosystem it is based on, and integrates perfectly into my smart home system. Disclaimer: I am an open-source developer, and my passion project (an open-source social-VR platform) grew into employment for me, with a jump-start

feedback: As someone who has used Free/libre software for over 27 years: this is welcome. The EU *really* needs to step up on document formats (ODF) and operating systems that are not dependent on one country. There are a lot of European developers of Debian Linux :) which is available worldwide at no cost and transparently. EU sovereign infrastructure is also vital Andy (from England - now outside the EU and having lost my EU citizenship)

Key to Europe's digital sovereignty is having good opensource operating systems available for consumers and businesses. The desktop ecosystem is the closest to maturity. There are several European opensource Linux distributions offering roughly the same functionality found on prominent non-European operating systems. The technology is there, we just need to start using it in government institutions and schools. This will also help drive cultural awareness and market demand for desktop Linux. In the mobile operating system space, we're doing quite badly. One very important barrier is the availability of bank apps, payment applications (Payconiq/Wero in Belgium) and eIDAS-compatible identity providers (Itsme/MyGov in Belgium). They only support iOS and Android, which are controlled by two non-European companies. In Android's case, there is some amount of openness of the source code, but the aforementioned apps often require the user to run a closed source version of Android, run Google Play Services and/or download their app via the Google Play Store. There are several interesting opensource operating system projects such as PostmarketOS, currently lacking maturity and funding. While they have achieved a lot by building on the progress desktop Linux made, they are not readily available to consumers and businesses. Furthermore, since the aforementioned essential apps are unavailable on their OS, these projects are unable to build momentum. This is why I would advocate for requiring financial institutions and identity providers to support opensource mobile operating systems in some way. Since Linux has been more or less been the standard in open source for decades, requiring them to support Linux could be a means of achieving that. Alternatively, requiring them to provide an open API/SDK that opensource projects could integrate with is also an option. That way, the opensource community can help pave the way for new operating systems without mandating one specific technology. In conclusion, mobile Linux can be a key driver for increasing our digital independence. In addition to funding for opensource mobile OS projects, it is crucial that essential services like banking and identity providers support opensource operating systems.

1. El punto fuerte son iniciativas como NLnet, que permite la financiación de proyectos de código abierto europeos. El punto débil es que la administración realmente no apuesta por ello, ya que no se trata solo de ayudar a financiar esos proyectos para su desarrollo, sino de usarlos e implementarlos en detrimento de la tecnología exterior. Hemos visto como en el aspecto de red social, la Comisión Europea ha abierto su propia instancia de Mastodon https://ec.social-network.europa.eu (aunque se le debería dar mas uso) lo cual es un ejemplo de lo que hablo y que debería de extenderse a mas aspectos 2. Para el sector público son muchos como mayor transparencia, que el dinero público sea invertido en proyectos comunitarios con licencia de software libre, mejor auditoría de vulnerabilidades y rapidez de detección y corrección al ser el código público y que cualquiera pueda contribuir y parchear errores. Para el sector privado no me pronuncio, a ese sector solo le interesa el beneficio económico y por ello son alérgicos al software libre 3. Hay dos bases importantes, invertir en hardware libre y en sistemas operativos libres. Para lo primero se podría potenciar Risc-V como ya se está haciendo, para lo segundo, se podrían potenciar sistemas operativos europeos libres como SailfishOS https://sailfishos.org/ de la empresa finlandesa Jolla. Tras esos pilares, apoyar ya a diferentes tipos de software, en especial a suites como Nextcloud que ofrecen diferentes servicios (organizaciones como Disroot https://disroot.org/ son ejemplo de servir varios servicios con software libre), sistemas de mensajería como XMPP, redes sociales como Mastodon, suites de salud como GnuHealth, sistemas de pagos como GnuTaler... 4 y 5. Debe darse la máxima prioridad a la transición hacia soluciones de código abierto en infraestructuras críticas como la electricidad, la logística, los hospitales, las instituciones. Los proveedores comerciales (y especialmente los de los Estados Unidos) tienen demasiada influencia y lo que es peor, acceso con sus spywares a todos esos datos (todos sabemos que no cumplen RGPD). Considero que sistemas como Windows o el Android privativo de Google por una parte, y las suites cloud de Google, Microsoft, Amazon entre otros por otra parte, son inadecuados y por lo tanto, la transición a GNU/Linux, tanto en ordenadores como en moviles (potenciando SailfishOS por ejemplo en este último caso) como a proveedores cloud europeos como OVH, Internxt y muchos otros debe llevarse a cabo con tanta rapidez como sea razonable en todas partes. Eso y a nivel monetario fomentar la implantación de sistemas como GNU Taler https://www.taler.net/es/index.html y a nivel sanitario sistemas como GNU Health https://www.gnuhealth.org/

column42: The use of open source must be an absolute priority: as far as possible, the use of public money should not be given to large companies with unresolved procedures, but the “Open Money – Open Code” principle should be implemented. This allows civil society to participate in the development of relevant tools and apps to help assess open standards and adherence to common security practices, and prevents the focus on (quasi-)monopolies. Important here, for example, are the strengthening of Linux and, for example, in the mobile environment, the strengths of Google Android alternatives such as/e/OS and iodeOS, both European initiatives. The EUid Wallet, as well as privacy-preserving applications such as age verification (if it cannot be prevented in this way), must not depend on Google Play services, for example.

feedback:
There is a lot to say about this topic. As a professional in IT and a member of various open source software organisations, I see multiple obstacles for widespread FOSS adoption (Free and Open Source Software). 1. Context and Finances : A lot of FOSS is currently managed by non-profits (not businesses) running on donations (example: VideoLan.org). As has been seen with the Odoo success story, one can't just make money on FOSS. For that, you need to bill support and maybe add proprietary add-ons. While a developer is building/maintaining FOSS, someone else gets the time to profit off of it. Often times, patches (as in fixes for code) are written by unpaid developers that still need to sustain themself at the end of the day (and if it's done in the context of a company, said company may see the contribution as wasted time because non-billable). Releasing the financial burden in some way could already be a big push in the back of FOSS. 2. Tooling and sovereignty : One of the big problems we have in EU is that, even though we have a lot of foundations writing free software, the tooling they use to do so (to develop,collaborate, host and sometimes run) is still foreign due to a lack of local alternatives. By pushing for local resources at European cloud providers (Email, collaborative software, hosting) and funding projects like Codeberg for code hosting, then pushing organizations to actually use them seriously, we can have a better sovereignty for those FOSS projects in Europe. This works to for our Internet Service Providers that may have operational dependencies on external entities (brands, clouds...). We can have all the FOSS we want, if the internet is still controlled by external entities, that doesn't help. 3. Business cases and support : For a lot of companies, the problem with FOSS is that it requires staff to be able to maintain it. Who do you call when something goes wrong? In the case of a Small-Business, it is impossible to have developers and system administrators on staff. Bigger companies may also choose to have their machines externally managed for operational reasons. Integrator need to be pushed towards a more local way of working. End Customers needs to be shown the difference between using a big foreign SaaS and using locally hosted software. Companies need to be pushed towards supporting those solutions (They take a risk by doing so. So often times, it's easier to offset the risk by sacrificing costs and externalizing it and that's how we end up in the current situation). We need to train and hire locally. 4. Education : A lot of universities are entirely reliant on closed source software and hosted into foreign clouds. Some of them are also forcing students to install proprietary software to do their assignments (the Microsoft office suite, Zoom...). This keeps FOSS in a niche as the students aren't trained to use them. It even actively pushes against the idea of doing so. Some schools give windows/chromebook machines to children under 10. They will grow with that software and get accustomed to it. It then becomes significantly harder for them to break out of the walled garden. Maybe a procurement program may help. Many of those establishments could use FOSS hosted by themself or their NREN operators (for email, collaboration, office suites...) instead. Conclusion : Europe has a great FOSS ecosystem. It is partly because a lot of us want to get our digital sovereignty back, but it is also because a lot of us believe in software for a greater good. We share with our neighbors and we work together. Responding to the problems above may push for an even stronger ecosystem where anyone can be independent in the future and where public money goes towards public code. Everyone, users as well as businesses will benefit from FOSS. Because it frees us from the predatory and monopolistic practices of some companies and allows us to build our

feedback: A big part of what's driving organisations to adopt proprietary American solutions like Teams or Slack instead of open source European ones like Element is cultural inertia. A lot of people aren't aware of these alternatives or the role their supply chain decisions play in Europe's digital sovereignty. The EU should consider the possibility of acting to raise the profile of the sovereignty problem and its solutions. As a software engineer working in public service broadcasting within the EU I'd like to see communications tooling prioritised. Even in organisations where robustness and sovereignty are prioritised at great expense it's commonplace for groupware to be the weak link in the chain. So even where great pain is already taken to build a public software service using open source software components, and then deliver it using the organisations own data centres within national borders, the collaboration necessary to maintain that service will typically be dependent on proprietary software services sourced from America.

NLNET does a great job. They just need to require people to actually sell the open source hardware which they pay for the design of. In particular these boards were designed, but I cannot buy them, I have to make them myself. Useless. https://colognechip.com/news/new-extensions-for-the-olimex-gatemate-fpga-board/ Same for this board. https://github.com/intergalaktik/ulx5m-gs I do not fault NLNET. Overall their money is in the right place. They just have to make a small change. And you are on the right track having an open source strategy. I would also recommend that you take a look at the business source license. that way you can invest in European companies, they can make money on the software, and then in 4 years it goes fully open source. It is a balance between the needs of the users and the needs of the companies.

On software: The initiative has the correct conclusion, that network effects of US tech giants are one of the greatest challenges. Strong vertical integration with API's and services that fit together keep companies on them effectively. This is something that might need to be addressed on a systemic level, as these types of systems typically form under an instinct to dominate, which is not the desired outcome, but we should still strive for the same end-user result. Open-source projects typically concentrate on small but necessary problem spaces, and thus vertical integration does not typically come first. Vertical integration is critical in applications of scale, and requires leadership and commitment that will undoubtedly provide difficult by ample funding alone. However, it is also the case that US open-source projects have on occasion become led by industry-aligned people and become shoehorned to fit a certain company's priorities (Google particularly being very good at this). Investing in governance structures and support for open-source projects in managing this could provide the solution for both the problems listed above. Both achieving vertical integration and avoiding capture by a single private company can be combatted by healthy governance structures. These should not be imposed of course, as many projects are capable of governing themselves, but funds, support and most importantly staffing should be available easily by grant / application for those that need it. Continuity is the last building-block that I will address, and again it is something that does not inherently come from the open-source community, but is critical for commercial success if building on it. And option of deploying public staffing in the case of emergency for absolutely critical projects of infrastructural nature should be considered to establish a guarantee of continuity for business. On networks: The initiative is missing emphasis on another aspect of open source: open protocol networks. Services that build on open protocols are more resilient and resistant to industry or political capture through billionaire private interests. It should be absolutely central for Europe to build it's media and social ecosystems on distributed platforms like ActivityPub or similar to avoid the single points of failure where ownership of a global platform becomes politically captured. The EU and the institutions of it's member states should treat open protocol networks as first-class citizens, instead of preferring closed-source US platforms. This would also guarantee distribution to everyone, preventing politically captured billionaires from deciding who gets to hear what we have to say. On hardware: Open source is not limited to software. The EU should encourage bringing microelectronic design & fabrication to the public domain. Older-generation fabrication plants are perfectly viable for small runs of custom hardware, sometimes needed by specialist businesses. A good example of this is photonic computing that accelerates AI inference far beyond traditional computing, but can be built on older-generation fabrication technologies. Encouraging open hardware designs also enables companies to tweak parts in ways that offer better vertical integration. On public access: Finally, public access to computing resources should be considered the basis of maintaining a renewed and self-refreshing open-source community decades into the future. People won't experiment with open-source computing to come up with new solutions unless they have access to the necessary computing. I therefore propose public cloud-based resourcing with IP connection to be available by birthright to any EU citizen. These need not be expensive, mere time-slices and basic storage on virtual machines. But universal access to computing is the best guarantee of attracting even the most peculiar and never-before-seen talent i

column26: The use of free software is not only vital to avoid technological lock-in but is also an important source of innovation. Access to previous developments to learn and build on them has a multiplier effect similar to that seen in the world of science, also based on building on prior knowledge and the ability to challenge and improve it. Nowadays, scientific or supercomputing infrastructure is in fact already based on free or open software. However, the benefits of these developments are not always shared with those who bear the costs of them (development of functionality, maintenance, correction of faults, etc.) and this is why the European Union should articulate mechanisms to promote more equitable development. Technological foundations in Germany or the Netherlands, financially supporting improvements in strategic free software, can be interesting models. Open software-based procurement should also be favoured.

It is important that this initiative takes into account the Spanish Supreme Court ruling for the "BOSCO" case. Information about this case is available at https://www.poderjudicial.es/cgpj/es/Poder-Judicial/Tribunal-Supremo/Oficina-de-Comunicacion/Notas-de-prensa/El-Tribunal-Supremo-condena-a-la-Administracion-a-facilitar-a-una-Fundacion-Ciudadana-el-codigo-fuente-de-la-aplicacion-informatica-que-acredita-a-los-beneficiarios-del-bono-social-electrico , and a 80-page PDF of the ruling is available at https://www.poderjudicial.es/portal/site/cgpj/viewDocument?ECLI=ECLI:ES:TS:2025:3826 . This ruling does not address "Open Source" *per se*, but rather gubernamental transparency. In a nutshell, the plaintiffs (investigative journalists) argued that knowing the source code of software used by public administrations is needed to know how society works, while the defendants (a Spanish ministry) argued intellectual property rights and national security prevented them from showing the code. The ruling states that the right to transparency (the right of citizens to know) takes precedence over intellectual property (see pages 57-64 of the BOSCO ruling) and that publishing the code can improve (instead of deteriorate) national security (pages 68-69). "Open Source" can be seen as a relaxation of intellectual property rights which makes software development faster and better. But I do not agree with this simplistic view: the root of the issue is the consequences of the over-reach of intellectual property rights. These consequences are not only innefficiencies, oligopolies and dependency on foreign actors: one consequence obvious from the BOSCO ruling is that we've became used to public administrations being opaque with the excuse of intellectual property. As the ruling argues, this is not compatible with the principles of a democratic society. I will not make a full argument here, so let me be pragmatic and answer one of the questions posed by the call to evidence: > What concrete measures and actions may be taken [to] contribute to the EUs technological sovereignty and cybersecurity agenda? The short answer is "Intellectual Property Law Reform". Lower non-moral IP rights down to 2 years, abolish anti-circumvention provisions, renegotiate WIPO agreements. As Cory Doctorow explained in length in his keynote at the 39C3 conference held in Hamburg a few days ago (see https://media.ccc.de/v/39c3-a-post-american-enshittification-resistant-internet ), this has not been done over fear of tariff retaliation byt the USA. Given that the current political landscape already comes standard with USA tariffs, the EU needs to rethink why are we refraining from something if we're already suffering the consequences by unrelated reasons. I **implore** you to study the BOSCO resolution, and to meet in person with Cory Doctorow, and to meet in person with Javier de la Cueva (the lawyer behind the BOSCO case).

feedback: You (EU institutions) are the public example to lead and implement open-source solution so we (citizens) can see the advantages once it is up and running. There is a lot of fear surrounding open source because it is different from paid solutions, and users need to overcome that fear by seeing that the public sector has already taken that step. The transition starts with you. My first question is, why do public institutions continue to use Twitter/X? Then don't be surprised that users continue to use closed networks and apps instead of being the ones who control what we see and read. Promoting open source means sharing, advertising, giving seminars, and informing people as much as possible about its short and long-term advantages. It doesn't cost that much to take the step; you just have to invest more in information campaigns and make it attractive. And, of course, starting with you (EU institutions) using open-source tools and software as much as possible; only by example can you preach.

I have worked 20+ years in the Swedish IT sector building enterprise-grade services using open source software, for companies and organisations across both private and public sectors, as well as alongside enterprise solutions from established vendors. The main difference when implementing enterprise services with open source is the significantly larger need for a strong and competent IT department to maintain the solution. Unlike commercial enterprise vendors who provide dedicated support, most open source projects offer limited or no direct support. This means all support must come from within your own organisation, or from external consultants you've hired to create and maintain the solution. There is no single certification or training course that will adequately prepare staff for open source enterprise deployments. The technology landscape is constantly evolving, requiring IT personnel who can continuously adapt to emerging changes and new approaches. I strongly recommend that the EU prioritizes establishing a robust, centralized authentication service as a foundational component. This service should provide single sign-on (SSO) capabilities via OAuth/OpenID Connect to all other EU government services, acting as an authentication umbrella across the ecosystem. This approach is particularly crucial when working with open source solutions, which should be considered significantly more ephemeral than proprietary services. A strong authentication layer decouples user identity from individual backend services, enabling organizations to easily replace or upgrade specific services with better alternatives as they emerge, without disrupting user access or requiring credential migration. This architectural pattern provides the flexibility needed to take full advantage of the open source ecosystem's rapid evolution.
All electronic devices sold must provide the purchaser with any and all keys necessary to inspect and modify all internal software. Without this basic right, no other changes can be effective.

In response to question 1, from my perspective there is no clearly visible or coherent EU open-source ecosystem. What I observe instead is a loosely connected community of developers who happen to be based in the EU but work within largely global structures, or without any specific target at all. If an EU-level ecosystem exists beyond funding programmes and strategy papers, it is not apparent to me personally. While I do see strong open-source projects developed or maintained in Europe, this does not translate into a clearly recognisable structure that supports discoverability, trust, or long-term sustainability. I think privacy, interoperability, and transparency are the core strengths of open source, and I see these values reflected in several European projects. In my opinion, these principles must remain non-negotiable at almost any cost. Any attempt to introduce government access or backdoors into privacy-focused open-source projects would undermine trust and contradict the purpose of such software. A major obstacle to the success of open source in the EU, in my view, is limited trust and accessibility for non-technical users. Many people are not able to compile, host, or meaningfully assess software themselves and therefore hesitate to rely on open source, especially when projects are maintained by small teams. I mean, big software companies do everything for them, and they just have to double-click an icon to make it run. Discoverability of reliable projects is poor if someone does not know where to look, and even motivated users face barriers such as lack of technical knowledge and high hardware costs, which are currently amplified by AI-driven demand. Sustainable contribution is also difficult, as most projects rely on volunteers with limited time while expectations grow as projects become more widely used. With regard to question 2, the added value of open source for both public and private sectors is very clear to me. Open-source solutions reduce licensing costs and avoid vendor lock-in, providing greater long-term control over digital infrastructure. I have observed this when proprietary office software, whole operating systems, CAD tools, and commercial firewall solutions are replaced with open alternatives (in these cases, for example, LibreOffice, Linux, FreeCAD, and nftables, respectively). From a security perspective, transparency and auditability are key advantages. When decisions are made, I observe that cost and sovereignty are usually the most important factors, followed by speed and security, while ecosystem maturity, supportability, and compliance tend to play a secondary role, as these can be added when the software is open source. As an answer to question 3, I believe EU action should go beyond research and maintenance funding alone. One concrete measure would be to identify and support a baseline set of strategically important open-source software across key domains, including operating systems, desktop environments, office software, communication tools, engineering software, mobile platforms, and open hardware, based on clear and adaptable criteria. Responsibility for maintenance should be more fairly balanced: when companies with sufficient resources benefit from open source and identify critical issues, they should share responsibility for fixing them rather than shifting the burden entirely to volunteer maintainers. Clearer legal frameworks are needed for reverse engineering for learning, interoperability, and security research, while respecting patent protections. As a side note, enforceable rules around open-source licensingparticularly in the context of AI training and useare essential, as licenses are currently often ignored without consequences. This is also a significant demotivator for some talented open-source developers.

In my work on digital services for government I have seen open source work effectively save costs (because reuse is enabled, both by the license and by the fact that source code is openly available), save time (because departments can suddenly work together better when they do it in an open space), work against vendor lockin (more vendors can apply) and improve security (because researchers can easily verify).

To secure independent open source development the EU should introduce open source charitable non-profit organisations that -require simplified book-keeping -are tax-exempt -can accept donations -apply for grants -are protected from government intervention. Moreover every MEP should watch or read Cory Doctorows remarks on a post-american internet and why anti-circumvention laws only benefit US big tech: https://pluralistic.net/2026/01/01/39c3/#the-new-coalition Defend the GDPR at all costs.

medienhaus/ is a digital infrastructure collective at the Berlin University of the Arts (UdK Berlin) that develops and operates selfhosted, free and opensource services for teaching, collaboration and public engagement. Our project tried to understand prototypical systems as institutional digital commons rather than outsourced products, aligning with EU goals on technological sovereignty, cybersecurity and open digital ecosystems. 1. **Strengths, weaknesses, barriers** The EU opensource sector benefits from highly skilled communities, strong alignment with European rights and values, and decades of public investment in education and research that already rely on open technologies. Yet several structural weaknesses and barriers limit impact: - Underfunding of longterm maintenance and operations compared to shortterm innovation projects, which makes it difficult to sustainably run opensource infrastructures in public institutions. - Legal and administrative uncertainty in procurement, liability and compliance, which discourages universities and public bodies from adopting and contributing to open source at scale. - Strong lockin effects from large proprietary cloud and platform providers, including free offers to the education sector, which make open alternatives appear risky despite their strategic advantages. From our institutional practice, a key barrier is the lack of recognized hybrid roles (developer-researcher-administrator) and governance frameworks that embed open-source stewardship into the core mission of universities and public administrations. 2. **Added value and examples** Open source brings decisive value for both public and private sectors by increasing control over infrastructure, reducing dependency on nonEU vendors and enabling experimentation with alternative sociotechnical arrangements. At UdK Berlin, medienhaus/ operates opensourcebased services such as collaboration spaces and digital exhibition infrastructures that support everyday teaching and public events, while keeping data, identities and workflows under institutional control. The most important factors are: - Reduced longterm lockin and better risk management, as institutions can migrate, adapt and audit systems. - Improved security and transparency through open code, open standards and local expertise. - Greater flexibility and innovation capacity, since infrastructures can be tailored to specific pedagogical, artistic and organisational needs. - Alignment with the idea of digital commons, where infrastructures are cocreated and governed in the public interest by institutions, communities and civil society. 3. **Measures and actions at EU level** To fully realise this potential, the EU should: - Support longterm operation and maintenance of opensource infrastructures in public institutions (universities, schools, cultural institutions, administrations) through dedicated, multiyear funding and recognition of infrastructure work as a public task, not only research. - Adapt procurement and compliance frameworks so that public bodies can adopt opensource solutions and contribute back (e.g. model clauses, guidance, opensource first where secure solutions exist). - Develop shared European hosting, security and governance support for critical opensource projects, building on digital commons initiatives and enabling universities and research institutions to act as operational and governance nodes. - Fund pilots in which opensource, selfhosted alternatives replace or complement dominant proprietary platforms in education and culture, including evaluation and documentation so that patterns can be reused in other sectors. - Strengthen intermediary structures (foundations, cooperatives) that ensure sustainable governance and business models for opensource components crucial to EU sovereignty (identity, cloud, AI, middleware). More can be found at https://medienhaus.dev/ and the websi

feedback: 1. Strengths, weaknesses and barriers of the EU open-source sector The EU open-source sector benefits from a diverse community of developers, SMEs, research organisations and public administrations, aligned with European values such as openness, interoperability and digital rights. Open source underpins Europes digital infrastructure. However, adoption, maintenance and sustainable contributions remain hindered by structural weaknesses. A key barrier is the lack of long-term, operational commitment to open-source communities beyond initial project funding. Sustainable projects require not only code development, but also continuous community governance, roadmap steering, infrastructure provision (repositories, CI/CD, hosting), promotion, and stable financing of key contributors. Another major challenge is discoverability and transparency. There is no comprehensive, EU-level catalogue of open-source solutions comparable to mature ecosystems such as those developed by major open-source foundations (e.g Apache, Linux or Eclipse foundations). A curated and actively maintained catalogue should describe what problems projects solve, their maturity and adoption level, governance models and sustainability outlook. This requires an online service and dedicated human resources to monitor community health and project evolution, following proven governance and stewardship practices. 2. Added value of open source for public and private sectors Open source delivers clear added value by reducing vendor lock-in, improving supply-chain transparency and strengthening technological sovereignty. It enhances security and accelerates innovation through reuse and interoperability. In the public sector, open source enables fairer and more competitive public procurement, allowing SMEs and specialised providers to contribute and compete on services rather than proprietary control. In the private sector, it lowers entry barriers, supports interoperability and allows companies to focus investment on value-adding innovation. 3. Concrete EU-level measures and actions At EU level, concrete actions could include enabling SMEs and larger companies to submit open-source projects for structured support covering maintenance, governance and scaling, not only initial development. Project maturity should be assessed systematically, with targeted support to increase Technology Readiness Levels and address security and technical debt. These actions should be framed as EU-level stewardship of shared digital assets. The EU should establish and actively maintain a European catalogue of open-source solutions, inspired by the operating models of established foundations such as the Apache, the Linux or the Eclipse Foundation, and combined with continuous monitoring of project health and adoption. In addition, tracking open-source software developed and used across the European Commission and EU bodies would reduce duplication, promote reuse and strengthen interoperability. 4. Priority technology areas Priority should be given to technologies enabling data sovereignty and interoperability, including data management, governance, lineage and quality; semantic technologies such as ontologies and knowledge graphs; FAIR data management and linked data; decentralised and data-centric digital architectures; AI-ready data sources; and open standards with reference implementations. These technologies are essential to operationalise data spaces and enable the free movement of data across borders and sectors. 5. Sectors with high potential impact Open source could significantly increase competitiveness and cyber resilience in sectors such as energy, mobility (air, maritime, rail and public transport), public procurement, health and biomedical research, public infrastructure, civil engineering and academia, where long-term data assets and interoperability are critical.

I have written extensively about the extractive status quo of open source development and what to do about it here: https://blog.muni.town/open-source-power/ https://blog.muni.town/company-as-commons/ Happy to engage in further conversations about this.

Open source software can lower costs, encourage european tech sovereignty and support a collaborative internet and a faster development of technology. However, the EU open source sector could benefit from more promotion and exposure, as not all citizens know about it. Initiatives and organisations supporting open source exist (e.g. Ulyssis in KU Leuven), but don't have the same outreach. Supporting such tech organisations or open source symposia can help give exposure in the tech world. In my job, lots of people wish to use open source alternatives that they have used in the past. However, cybersecurity concerns exist for software that is not backed by a company and a full-time security team. This disappoints me as I wish we could support these, often European companies, but we do not have a high enough level of security to do so. Perhaps the encouragement of enterprise licenses, with some support in return for clear security guarantees such as those of the CRA could be encouraged. I think what works best is to offer different types of support and legal requirements depending on the scale of the open source project (e.g. different requirements for Linux compared to a small GIMP plugin). Moreover, some open-source projects like FFMPEG are used extensively by large multimedia companies but not adequately supported. Measures to encourage more equitable relations between open source companies and their users, whether that is new requirements for contracts, financial support of open source companies or tax exemptions for companies who work with them and fund these organisations are some possibilities.

Tengo muchos motivos personales para apoyar el uso de herramientas de código abierto y/o soberanas en todas las instituciones públicas de la Unión Europea, de sus organismos vinculados o dependientes, y de sus estados miembros. Pero, en lugar de exponerlos, enumeraré algunos hechos recientes, y no tan recientes: 1. «Microsoft bloqueó supuestamente el correo electrónico del Fiscal Jefe de la Corte Penal Internacional.» Es decir, una empresa, alojada en Estados Unidos pero que opera a nivel global, decide unilateralmente bloquear el acceso de una persona, en otro país del mundo, a su correo electrónico, bien sea por orden ejecutiva de un gobierno, o bien sea por otras razones. Algo que no pasaría si se usaran servicios de código abierto y con sede en la Unión Europea. 2. «Nicolas Guillou, el juez francés en la lista negra de EE.UU. por investigar crímenes de guerra en Gaza Las sanciones prohíben a cualquier persona u organización estadounidense, incluidas empresas y sus filiales en el extranjero, ofrecer servicios al magistrado. Las consecuencias han sido inmediatas. Guillou ha perdido sus cuentas en plataformas como Amazon, Airbnb y PayPal, no puede realizar transacciones en dólares ni recibir paquetes de compañías estadounidenses, y sus tarjetas bancarias American Express, Visa y Mastercard han quedado anuladas incluso en Francia». Nada más que decir sobre este punto. 3. «Escándalo con Windows Recall: todavía hace capturas de tarjetas de crédito y contraseñas a veces». Ahora imaginemos una administración pública, que maneja datos personales, como la Agencia Tributaria, o la Agencia de Protección de Datos, o un centro sanitario... Y seguro que habrá muchos más ejemplos. Aparte que el dinero que se le paga a Microsoft y a otras empresas por usar sus productos se podría invertir, en su lugar, en mejorar las administraciones públicas, en becas, en pensiones, etc., solo cambiando a productos europeos y de código abierto, como Tuta, OpenSUSE, Internxt, Mastodon...

I have many personal reasons to support the use of open source or sovereign tools in all public institutions of the European Union, its linked or dependent bodies, and its Member States. Instead of setting out them, however, I shall list a number of recent, rather than recent, facts: 1. “Microsoft allegedly blocked the email of the Chief Prosecutor of the International Criminal Court.” In other words, a company, hosted in the United States but operating globally, unilaterally decides to block an individual’s access, in another country of the world, to his email, either by executive order of a government or for other reasons. This would not happen if open source services based in the European Union were used. 2. “Nicolas Guillou, the French judge on the US blacklist for investigating war crimes in Gaza Sanctions prohibit any US person or organisation, including companies and their subsidiaries abroad, from offering services to the magistrate. The consequences have been immediate. Guillou has lost his accounts on platforms such as Amazon, Airbnb and PayPal, he cannot trade in dollars or receive parcels from US companies, and his American Express, Visa and Mastercard bank cards have been cancelled even in France.” There is nothing more to say on this point. 3. “Windows Recall scandal – still makes credit card captures and passwords sometimes”. Now let’s imagine a public administration, handling personal data, such as the Tax Agency, the Data Protection Agency, or a health centre... And there will certainly be many more examples. Apart from the fact that the money paid to Microsoft and other companies for using their products could instead be invested in improving public administrations, scholarships, pensions, etc., only by switching to European an

feedback: 1. Strengths, Weaknesses, and Barriers Strengths: Growing political support for digital sovereignty, vibrant startup ecosystem, "Public Money, Public Code" initiatives, and recognition of open source as strategic asset. Weaknesses: Uneven adoption maturity, lack of corporate investment in open-source projects, deficit of qualified professionals, and governance of key projects outside the EU. Barriers to Adoption & Contribution: The dual compliance burden of the AI Act and Medical Device Regulation (MDR) for healthcare AI is the primary barrier. Additional challenges include liability ambiguity for open-source components in medical devices, security vulnerabilities, and lack of sustainable monetization models. The Cyber Resilience Act (CRA), while offering exemptions for non-commercial activities, introduces regulatory uncertainty. 2. Added Value of Open Source Open source delivers critical advantages: reduced development costs, accelerated innovation through global collaboration, enhanced security via community scrutiny, elimination of vendor lock-in, customization flexibility, and digital sovereignty. 3. Recommended EU Measures 1. Dedicated Healthcare Open-Source Fund: Extend the proposed EU Sovereign Tech Fund with targeted support for healthcare projects navigating regulatory compliance and certification. 2. Regulatory Clarity: Provide clear guidance on MDR-AI Act-CRA interplay, establishing liability frameworks and safe harbor provisions for open-source medical software contributors. 3. Promote Open-Source Software Stewards: The CRA's steward model offers a sustainable path. The EU should provide financial and legal support to organizations stewarding critical healthcare projects. 4. Strategic Public Procurement: Enforce "Public Money, Public Code" with European preference, creating market demand for companies like Isaree. 5. Create Research Incentives for Mass Collaboration (Impact Factor) eg BigScience or Human Genome Project 4. Priority Technology Areas AI & Machine Learning: Support open-source healthcare AI models, frameworks, and privacy-preserving techniques. Cybersecurity: Invest in open-source security solutions. Edge Computing: Fund on-device AI platforms for privacy and real-time performance. Interoperability: Promote FHIR and open health data standards. 5. Sectors for Increased Competitiveness Healthcare: Drive innovation in diagnostics and personalized medicine while enhancing IT security. Public Administration: Reduce costs and vendor lock-in. Energy: Support renewable energy and smart grid solutions. Manufacturing: Democratize access to AI-powered robotics and predictive maintenance. Conclusion The EU is positioned to lead a digital transformation anchored in open source. For Isaree, a supportive regulatory environment combined with targeted funding creates the opportunity to build certified, open-source medical AI agents that improve patient outcomes across Europe.

There are several aspects to consider here: * First, to me it is obvious that any public service should use open source software to provide the aforesaid service. A common service shouldn't be dependent on a single private entity, within EU or not. * When private actors are unavoidable, interoperability should always be enforced. EU services and EU citizens should always be in control of the data, and be able to switch provider if needed. * It is important to understand that open source software does have a cost and a lifecycle. Developers should be paid, contributions/modifications should be proposed to the main project. Without this, even a wildly used opensource software can become unmaintained and die. * If the data is stored outside of EU, using opensource won't solve anything: we still won't be in control of our data. Facebook and Microsoft use tons of opensource softwares, nevertheless they own the data, and that data is under US legislation rule, not EU. Opensource and interoperability are the way to go (and should have been since day one), but it also must be done properly.

Nesúhlasím. EÚ bola založená za účelom mieru a pomoci a nie za účelom riadenia a vmiešavania sa do politík a ekonomík jednotlivých členských štátov. Tri hlavné piliere EÚ - slobodný pohyb ľudí, tovaru a služieb - nie centrálna digitálna kontrola a ovládania ľudí, tovaru a služieb! POZOR: EÚ uskutočňuje opačné kroky - smerom k diktatúre, smerom ku kontrole a k ovládaniu ľudí, k znižovaniu životnej úrovne ľudí,... Každý členský štát sám vie najlepšie rozhodovať a prijímať opatrenia vo všetkých oblastiach existencie štátu, vrátane ochrany životného prostredia, recyklácie, digitalizácie, či čohokoľvek. EÚ škodí a plytvá finančnými zdrojmi jednotlivých členských štátov. EÚ ohrozuje bezpečnosť a životnú úroveň občanov v Európe! EÚ je zbytočná organizácia, nefunkčná, drahá (EÚ sama netvorí žiadne príjmy - členské štáty hradia jej veľmi nákladnú a zbytočnú činnosť). EÚ je diktátorská, pompézna, jej činnosť ohrozuje zdravie a bezpečnosť občanov (Covid opatrenia, Ukrajina,...) a škodí životnému prostrediu (letecká preprava, Green Deal, nezmyselné a nepotrebné veterné turbíny,...). EÚ ničí kultúru a svojbytnosť jednotlivých štátov a priamo zasahuje do ich politiky, kultúry a aj do ekonomiky, navyše zasahuje bezdôvodne aj do politiky nečlenských štátov - no a toto nie je rozhodne v poriadku! EÚ si sama vymýšľa a prijíma rozhodovacie právomoci - no a na toto nemá právo a je to v rozpore s účelom, pre ktorý bola zriadená!!!
feedbackTextUserLanguage: I disagree. The EU was established for the purpose of peace and aid, and not for the purpose of steering and embracing the policies and economies of individual Member States. The three main pillars of the EU – the free movement of people, goods and services – not central digital control and control of people, goods and services! NOTE: The EU is taking the opposite steps – towards dictatorship, towards control and control of people, towards lowering people’s standard of living,... Each Member State is best placed to decide and take action in all areas of national existence, including environmental protection, recycling, digitalisation or anything. The EU harms and wastes the financial resources of individual Member States. The EU threatens the security and well-being of citizens in Europe! The EU is an unnecessary organisation, dysfunctional, expensive (the EU does not generate any revenue on its own – Member States pay for its very costly and unnecessary work). The EU is dictatorial, pomemorial, its actions threaten the health and safety of citizens (Covid Action, Ukraine,...) and harm the environment (air transport, Green Deal, senseless and unnecessary wind turbines,...). The EU is destroying national cultures and personalities and directly interfering with their policies, cultures and economies, as well as unjustifiably interfering with the policies of non-member countries – but this is certainly not right! The EU invents itself and takes decision-making powers – but it does not have the right to do so and this is contrary to the purpose for which it was established!

feedback: Open source can play a key role as a foundational and interoperability layer, provided it is complemented by clear governance, sustainable maintenance models, and accountable industrial actors. For critical and long-lived infrastructures, openness should enhance resilience and choice, not replace responsibility, liability, and lifecycle guarantees.
